31. WAR AND PEACE
32. 
33. By Leo Tolstoy/Tolstoi
34. 
35. 
36. 
37. 
38. 
39. BOOK ONE: 1805
40. 
41. 
42. 
43. 
44. 
45. CHAPTER I
46. 
47. 
48. "Well, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates of the
49. Buonapartes. But I warn you, if you don't tell me that this means war,
50. if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that
51. Antichrist--I really believe he is Antichrist--I will have nothing more
52. to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer my 'faithful
53. slave,' as you call yourself! But how do you do? I see I have frightened
54. you--sit down and tell me all the news."
55. 
56. It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pavlovna
57. Scherer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress Marya Fedorovna. With
58. these words she greeted Prince Vasili Kuragin, a man of high rank and
59. importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception. Anna Pavlovna
60. had had a cough for some days. She was, as she said, suffering from la
61. grippe; grippe being then a new word in St. Petersburg, used only by the
62. elite.
63. 
64. All her invitations without exception, written in French, and delivered
65. by a scarlet-liveried footman that morning, ran as follows:
66. 
67. "If you have nothing better to do, Count (or Prince), and if the
68. prospect of spending an evening with a poor invalid is not too terrible,
69. I shall be very charmed to see you tonight between 7 and 10--Annette
70. Scherer."
71. 
72. "Heavens! what a virulent attack!" replied the prince, not in the
73. least disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearing an
74. embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on
75. his breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke in that
76. refined French in which our grandfathers not only spoke but thought, and
77. with the gentle, patronizing intonation natural to a man of importance
78. who had grown old in society and at court. He went up to Anna Pavlovna,
79. kissed her hand, presenting to her his bald, scented, and shining head,
80. and complacently seated himself on the sofa.
81. 
82. "First of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friend's mind
83. at rest," said he without altering his tone, beneath the politeness
84. and affected sympathy of which indifference and even irony could be
85. discerned.
86. 
87. "Can one be well while suffering morally? Can one be calm in times like
88. these if one has any feeling?" said Anna Pavlovna. "You are staying the
89. whole evening, I hope?"
90. 
91. "And the fete at the English ambassador's? Today is Wednesday. I must
92. put in an appearance there," said the prince. "My daughter is coming for
93. me to take me there."
94. 
95. "I thought today's fete had been canceled. I confess all these
96. festivities and fireworks are becoming wearisome."
97. 
98. "If they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would have been
99. put off," said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by force of habit
100. said things he did not even wish to be believed.
101. 
102. "Don't tease! Well, and what has been decided about Novosiltsev's
103. dispatch? You know everything."
104. 
105. "What can one say about it?" replied the prince in a cold, listless
106. tone. "What has been decided? They have decided that Buonaparte has
107. burnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to burn ours."
108. 
109. Prince Vasili always spoke languidly, like an actor repeating a stale
110. part. Anna Pavlovna Scherer on the contrary, despite her forty years,
111. overflowed with animation and impulsiveness. To be an enthusiast had
112. become her social vocation and, sometimes even when she did not
113. feel like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to disappoint the
114. expectations of those who knew her. The subdued smile which, though it
115. did not suit her faded features, always played round her lips expressed,
116. as in a spoiled child, a continual consciousness of her charming defect,
117. which she neither wished, nor could, nor considered it necessary, to
118. correct.
119. 
120. In the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna Pavlovna burst
121. out:
122. 
123. "Oh, don't speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I don't understand things,
124. but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. She is
125. betraying us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our gracious sovereign
126. recognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That is the one
127. thing I have faith in! Our good and wonderful sovereign has to perform
128. the noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble that God will
129. not forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and crush the hydra of
130. revolution, which has become more terrible than ever in the person of
131. this murderer and villain! We alone must avenge the blood of the just
132. one.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely on?... England with her commercial
133. spirit will not and cannot understand the Emperor Alexander's loftiness
134. of soul. She has refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to find,
135. and still seeks, some secret motive in our actions. What answer did
136. Novosiltsev get? None. The English have not understood and cannot
137. understand the self-abnegation of our Emperor who wants nothing for
138. himself, but only desires the good of mankind. And what have they
139. promised? Nothing! And what little they have promised they will not
140. perform! Prussia has always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and
141. that all Europe is powerless before him.... And I don't believe a
142. word that Hardenburg says, or Haugwitz either. This famous Prussian
143. neutrality is just a trap. I have faith only in God and the lofty
144. destiny of our adored monarch. He will save Europe!"
145. 
146. She suddenly paused, smiling at her own impetuosity.
147. 
148. "I think," said the prince with a smile, "that if you had been sent
149. instead of our dear Wintzingerode you would have captured the King of
150. Prussia's consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you give me a
151. cup of tea?"
152. 
153. "In a moment. A propos," she added, becoming calm again, "I am expecting
154. two very interesting men tonight, le Vicomte de Mortemart, who is
155. connected with the Montmorencys through the Rohans, one of the best
156. French families. He is one of the genuine emigres, the good ones. And
157. also the Abbe Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He has been
158. received by the Emperor. Had you heard?"
159. 
160. "I shall be delighted to meet them," said the prince. "But tell me," he
161. added with studied carelessness as if it had only just occurred to him,
162. though the question he was about to ask was the chief motive of his
163. visit, "is it true that the Dowager Empress wants Baron Funke to be
164. appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all accounts is a poor
165. creature."
166. 
167. Prince Vasili wished to obtain this post for his son, but others were
168. trying through the Dowager Empress Marya Fedorovna to secure it for the
169. baron.
170. 
171. Anna Pavlovna almost closed her eyes to indicate that neither she nor
172. anyone else had a right to criticize what the Empress desired or was
173. pleased with.
174. 
175. "Baron Funke has been recommended to the Dowager Empress by her sister,"
176. was all she said, in a dry and mournful tone.
177. 
178. As she named the Empress, Anna Pavlovna's face suddenly assumed an
179. expression of profound and sincere devotion and respect mingled with
180. sadness, and this occurred every time she mentioned her illustrious
181. patroness. She added that Her Majesty had deigned to show Baron Funke
182. beaucoup d'estime, and again her face clouded over with sadness.
183. 
184. The prince was silent and looked indifferent. But, with the womanly and
185. courtierlike quickness and tact habitual to her, Anna Pavlovna wished
186. both to rebuke him (for daring to speak he had done of a man recommended
187. to the Empress) and at the same time to console him, so she said:
188. 
189. "Now about your family. Do you know that since your daughter came
190. out everyone has been enraptured by her? They say she is amazingly
191. beautiful."
192. 
193. The prince bowed to signify his respect and gratitude.
194. 
195. "I often think," she continued after a short pause, drawing nearer to
196. the prince and smiling amiably at him as if to show that political
197. and social topics were ended and the time had come for intimate
198. conversation--"I often think how unfairly sometimes the joys of life are
199. distributed. Why has fate given you two such splendid children? I don't
200. speak of Anatole, your youngest. I don't like him," she added in a tone
201. admitting of no rejoinder and raising her eyebrows. "Two such charming
202. children. And really you appreciate them less than anyone, and so you
203. don't deserve to have them."
204. 
205. And she smiled her ecstatic smile.
206. 
207. "I can't help it," said the prince. "Lavater would have said I lack the
208. bump of paternity."
209. 
210. "Don't joke; I mean to have a serious talk with you. Do you know I am
211. dissatisfied with your younger son? Between ourselves" (and her face
212. assumed its melancholy expression), "he was mentioned at Her Majesty's
213. and you were pitied...."
214. 
215. The prince answered nothing, but she looked at him significantly,
216. awaiting a reply. He frowned.
217. 
218. "What would you have me do?" he said at last. "You know I did all a
219. father could for their education, and they have both turned out fools.
220. Hippolyte is at least a quiet fool, but Anatole is an active one. That
221. is the only difference between them." He said this smiling in a way more
222. natural and animated than usual, so that the wrinkles round his mouth
223. very clearly revealed something unexpectedly coarse and unpleasant.
224. 
225. "And why are children born to such men as you? If you were not a father
226. there would be nothing I could reproach you with," said Anna Pavlovna,
227. looking up pensively.
228. 
229. "I am your faithful slave and to you alone I can confess that my
230. children are the bane of my life. It is the cross I have to bear. That
231. is how I explain it to myself. It can't be helped!"
232. 
233. He said no more, but expressed his resignation to cruel fate by a
234. gesture. Anna Pavlovna meditated.
235. 
236. "Have you never thought of marrying your prodigal son Anatole?" she
237. asked. "They say old maids have a mania for matchmaking, and though I
238. don't feel that weakness in myself as yet, I know a little person who is
239. very unhappy with her father. She is a relation of yours, Princess Mary
240. Bolkonskaya."
241. 
242. Prince Vasili did not reply, though, with the quickness of memory and
243. perception befitting a man of the world, he indicated by a movement of
244. the head that he was considering this information.
245. 
246. "Do you know," he said at last, evidently unable to check the sad
247. current of his thoughts, "that Anatole is costing me forty thousand
248. rubles a year? And," he went on after a pause, "what will it be in five
249. years, if he goes on like this?" Presently he added: "That's what we
250. fathers have to put up with.... Is this princess of yours rich?"
251. 
252. "Her father is very rich and stingy. He lives in the country. He is the
253. well-known Prince Bolkonski who had to retire from the army under the
254. late Emperor, and was nicknamed 'the King of Prussia.' He is very clever
255. but eccentric, and a bore. The poor girl is very unhappy. She has a
256. brother; I think you know him, he married Lise Meinen lately. He is an
257. aide-de-camp of Kutuzov's and will be here tonight."
258. 
259. "Listen, dear Annette," said the prince, suddenly taking Anna Pavlovna's
260. hand and for some reason drawing it downwards. "Arrange that affair for
261. me and I shall always be your most devoted slave-slafe with an f, as
262. a village elder of mine writes in his reports. She is rich and of good
263. family and that's all I want."
264. 
265. And with the familiarity and easy grace peculiar to him, he raised the
266. maid of honor's hand to his lips, kissed it, and swung it to and fro as
267. he lay back in his armchair, looking in another direction.
268. 
269. "Attendez," said Anna Pavlovna, reflecting, "I'll speak to Lise, young
270. Bolkonski's wife, this very evening, and perhaps the thing can be
271. arranged. It shall be on your family's behalf that I'll start my
272. apprenticeship as old maid."
273. 
274. 
275. 
276. 
277. 
278. CHAPTER II
279. 
280. 
281. Anna Pavlovna's drawing room was gradually filling. The highest
282. Petersburg society was assembled there: people differing widely in age
283. and character but alike in the social circle to which they belonged.
284. Prince Vasili's daughter, the beautiful Helene, came to take her father
285. to the ambassador's entertainment; she wore a ball dress and her badge
286. as maid of honor. The youthful little Princess Bolkonskaya, known as la
287. femme la plus seduisante de Petersbourg, * was also there. She had been
288. married during the previous winter, and being pregnant did not go to
289. any large gatherings, but only to small receptions. Prince Vasili's son,
290. Hippolyte, had come with Mortemart, whom he introduced. The Abbe Morio
291. and many others had also come.
292. 
293. 
294.      * The most fascinating woman in Petersburg.
295. 
296. 
297. To each new arrival Anna Pavlovna said, "You have not yet seen my aunt,"
298. or "You do not know my aunt?" and very gravely conducted him or her to
299. a little old lady, wearing large bows of ribbon in her cap, who had come
300. sailing in from another room as soon as the guests began to arrive;
301. and slowly turning her eyes from the visitor to her aunt, Anna Pavlovna
302. mentioned each one's name and then left them.
303. 
304. Each visitor performed the ceremony of greeting this old aunt whom not
305. one of them knew, not one of them wanted to know, and not one of them
306. cared about; Anna Pavlovna observed these greetings with mournful and
307. solemn interest and silent approval. The aunt spoke to each of them in
308. the same words, about their health and her own, and the health of Her
309. Majesty, "who, thank God, was better today." And each visitor, though
310. politeness prevented his showing impatience, left the old woman with a
311. sense of relief at having performed a vexatious duty and did not return
312. to her the whole evening.
313. 
314. The young Princess Bolkonskaya had brought some work in a
315. gold-embroidered velvet bag. Her pretty little upper lip, on which a
316. delicate dark down was just perceptible, was too short for her teeth,
317. but it lifted all the more sweetly, and was especially charming when she
318. occasionally drew it down to meet the lower lip. As is always the case
319. with a thoroughly attractive woman, her defect--the shortness of her
320. upper lip and her half-open mouth--seemed to be her own special and
321. peculiar form of beauty. Everyone brightened at the sight of this pretty
322. young woman, so soon to become a mother, so full of life and health, and
323. carrying her burden so lightly. Old men and dull dispirited young ones
324. who looked at her, after being in her company and talking to her a
325. little while, felt as if they too were becoming, like her, full of life
326. and health. All who talked to her, and at each word saw her bright smile
327. and the constant gleam of her white teeth, thought that they were in a
328. specially amiable mood that day.
329. 
330. The little princess went round the table with quick, short, swaying
331. steps, her workbag on her arm, and gaily spreading out her dress sat
332. down on a sofa near the silver samovar, as if all she was doing was a
333. pleasure to herself and to all around her. "I have brought my work,"
334. said she in French, displaying her bag and addressing all present.
335. "Mind, Annette, I hope you have not played a wicked trick on me," she
336. added, turning to her hostess. "You wrote that it was to be quite a
337. small reception, and just see how badly I am dressed." And she spread
338. out her arms to show her short-waisted, lace-trimmed, dainty gray dress,
339. girdled with a broad ribbon just below the breast.
340. 
341. "Soyez tranquille, Lise, you will always be prettier than anyone else,"
342. replied Anna Pavlovna.
343. 
344. "You know," said the princess in the same tone of voice and still in
345. French, turning to a general, "my husband is deserting me? He is going
346. to get himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?" she
347. added, addressing Prince Vasili, and without waiting for an answer she
348. turned to speak to his daughter, the beautiful Helene.
349. 
350. "What a delightful woman this little princess is!" said Prince Vasili to
351. Anna Pavlovna.
352. 
353. One of the next arrivals was a stout, heavily built young man with
354. close-cropped hair, spectacles, the light-colored breeches fashionable
355. at that time, a very high ruffle, and a brown dress coat. This stout
356. young man was an illegitimate son of Count Bezukhov, a well-known
357. grandee of Catherine's time who now lay dying in Moscow. The young man
358. had not yet entered either the military or civil service, as he had only
359. just returned from abroad where he had been educated, and this was his
360. first appearance in society. Anna Pavlovna greeted him with the nod she
361. accorded to the lowest hierarchy in her drawing room. But in spite of
362. this lowest-grade greeting, a look of anxiety and fear, as at the sight
363. of something too large and unsuited to the place, came over her face
364. when she saw Pierre enter. Though he was certainly rather bigger than
365. the other men in the room, her anxiety could only have reference to
366. the clever though shy, but observant and natural, expression which
367. distinguished him from everyone else in that drawing room.
368. 
369. "It is very good of you, Monsieur Pierre, to come and visit a poor
370. invalid," said Anna Pavlovna, exchanging an alarmed glance with her aunt
371. as she conducted him to her.
372. 
373. Pierre murmured something unintelligible, and continued to look round as
374. if in search of something. On his way to the aunt he bowed to the little
375. princess with a pleased smile, as to an intimate acquaintance.
376. 
377. Anna Pavlovna's alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the
378. aunt without waiting to hear her speech about Her Majesty's health. Anna
379. Pavlovna in dismay detained him with the words: "Do you know the Abbe
380. Morio? He is a most interesting man."
381. 
382. "Yes, I have heard of his scheme for perpetual peace, and it is very
383. interesting but hardly feasible."
384. 
385. "You think so?" rejoined Anna Pavlovna in order to say something and
386. get away to attend to her duties as hostess. But Pierre now committed
387. a reverse act of impoliteness. First he had left a lady before she had
388. finished speaking to him, and now he continued to speak to another who
389. wished to get away. With his head bent, and his big feet spread apart,
390. he began explaining his reasons for thinking the abbe's plan chimerical.
391. 
392. "We will talk of it later," said Anna Pavlovna with a smile.
393. 
394. And having got rid of this young man who did not know how to behave, she
395. resumed her duties as hostess and continued to listen and watch, ready
396. to help at any point where the conversation might happen to flag. As
397. the foreman of a spinning mill, when he has set the hands to work, goes
398. round and notices here a spindle that has stopped or there one that
399. creaks or makes more noise than it should, and hastens to check the
400. machine or set it in proper motion, so Anna Pavlovna moved about her
401. drawing room, approaching now a silent, now a too-noisy group, and by a
402. word or slight rearrangement kept the conversational machine in steady,
403. proper, and regular motion. But amid these cares her anxiety about
404. Pierre was evident. She kept an anxious watch on him when he approached
405. the group round Mortemart to listen to what was being said there, and
406. again when he passed to another group whose center was the abbe.
407. 
408. Pierre had been educated abroad, and this reception at Anna Pavlovna's
409. was the first he had attended in Russia. He knew that all the
410. intellectual lights of Petersburg were gathered there and, like a child
411. in a toyshop, did not know which way to look, afraid of missing any
412. clever conversation that was to be heard. Seeing the self-confident and
413. refined expression on the faces of those present he was always expecting
414. to hear something very profound. At last he came up to Morio. Here the
415. conversation seemed interesting and he stood waiting for an opportunity
416. to express his own views, as young people are fond of doing.
417. 
418. 
419. 
420. 
421. 
422. CHAPTER III
423. 
424. 
425. Anna Pavlovna's reception was in full swing. The spindles hummed
426. steadily and ceaselessly on all sides. With the exception of the aunt,
427. beside whom sat only one elderly lady, who with her thin careworn face
428. was rather out of place in this brilliant society, the whole company had
429. settled into three groups. One, chiefly masculine, had formed round the
430. abbe. Another, of young people, was grouped round the beautiful Princess
431. Helene, Prince Vasili's daughter, and the little Princess Bolkonskaya,
432. very pretty and rosy, though rather too plump for her age. The third
433. group was gathered round Mortemart and Anna Pavlovna.
434. 
435. The vicomte was a nice-looking young man with soft features and polished
436. manners, who evidently considered himself a celebrity but out of
437. politeness modestly placed himself at the disposal of the circle in
438. which he found himself. Anna Pavlovna was obviously serving him up as a
439. treat to her guests. As a clever maitre d'hotel serves up as a specially
440. choice delicacy a piece of meat that no one who had seen it in the
441. kitchen would have cared to eat, so Anna Pavlovna served up to her
442. guests, first the vicomte and then the abbe, as peculiarly choice
443. morsels. The group about Mortemart immediately began discussing the
444. murder of the Duc d'Enghien. The vicomte said that the Duc d'Enghien had
445. perished by his own magnanimity, and that there were particular reasons
446. for Buonaparte's hatred of him.
447. 
448. "Ah, yes! Do tell us all about it, Vicomte," said Anna Pavlovna, with a
449. pleasant feeling that there was something a la Louis XV in the sound of
450. that sentence: "Contez nous cela, Vicomte."
451. 
452. The vicomte bowed and smiled courteously in token of his willingness to
453. comply. Anna Pavlovna arranged a group round him, inviting everyone to
454. listen to his tale.
455. 
456. "The vicomte knew the duc personally," whispered Anna Pavlovna to of
457. the guests. "The vicomte is a wonderful raconteur," said she to another.
458. "How evidently he belongs to the best society," said she to a third;
459. and the vicomte was served up to the company in the choicest and most
460. advantageous style, like a well-garnished joint of roast beef on a hot
461. dish.
462. 
463. The vicomte wished to begin his story and gave a subtle smile.
464. 
465. "Come over here, Helene, dear," said Anna Pavlovna to the beautiful
466. young princess who was sitting some way off, the center of another
467. group.
468. 
469. The princess smiled. She rose with the same unchanging smile with which
470. she had first entered the room--the smile of a perfectly beautiful
471. woman. With a slight rustle of her white dress trimmed with moss
472. and ivy, with a gleam of white shoulders, glossy hair, and sparkling
473. diamonds, she passed between the men who made way for her, not looking
474. at any of them but smiling on all, as if graciously allowing each the
475. privilege of admiring her beautiful figure and shapely shoulders,
476. back, and bosom--which in the fashion of those days were very much
477. exposed--and she seemed to bring the glamour of a ballroom with her as
478. she moved toward Anna Pavlovna. Helene was so lovely that not only
479. did she not show any trace of coquetry, but on the contrary she even
480. appeared shy of her unquestionable and all too victorious beauty. She
481. seemed to wish, but to be unable, to diminish its effect.
482. 
483. "How lovely!" said everyone who saw her; and the vicomte lifted his
484. shoulders and dropped his eyes as if startled by something extraordinary
485. when she took her seat opposite and beamed upon him also with her
486. unchanging smile.
487. 
488. "Madame, I doubt my ability before such an audience," said he, smilingly
489. inclining his head.
490. 
491. The princess rested her bare round arm on a little table and considered
492. a reply unnecessary. She smilingly waited. All the time the story was
493. being told she sat upright, glancing now at her beautiful round arm,
494. altered in shape by its pressure on the table, now at her still more
495. beautiful bosom, on which she readjusted a diamond necklace. From time
496. to time she smoothed the folds of her dress, and whenever the story
497. produced an effect she glanced at Anna Pavlovna, at once adopted just
498. the expression she saw on the maid of honor's face, and again relapsed
499. into her radiant smile.
500. 
501. The little princess had also left the tea table and followed Helene.
502. 
503. "Wait a moment, I'll get my work.... Now then, what are you thinking
504. of?" she went on, turning to Prince Hippolyte. "Fetch me my workbag."
505. 
506. There was a general movement as the princess, smiling and talking
507. merrily to everyone at once, sat down and gaily arranged herself in her
508. seat.
509. 
510. "Now I am all right," she said, and asking the vicomte to begin, she
511. took up her work.
512. 
513. Prince Hippolyte, having brought the workbag, joined the circle and
514. moving a chair close to hers seated himself beside her.
515. 
516. Le charmant Hippolyte was surprising by his extraordinary resemblance
517. to his beautiful sister, but yet more by the fact that in spite of
518. this resemblance he was exceedingly ugly. His features were like his
519. sister's, but while in her case everything was lit up by a joyous,
520. self-satisfied, youthful, and constant smile of animation, and by the
521. wonderful classic beauty of her figure, his face on the contrary
522. was dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen
523. self-confidence, while his body was thin and weak. His eyes, nose, and
524. mouth all seemed puckered into a vacant, wearied grimace, and his arms
525. and legs always fell into unnatural positions.
526. 
527. "It's not going to be a ghost story?" said he, sitting down beside
528. the princess and hastily adjusting his lorgnette, as if without this
529. instrument he could not begin to speak.
530. 
531. "Why no, my dear fellow," said the astonished narrator, shrugging his
532. shoulders.
533. 
534. "Because I hate ghost stories," said Prince Hippolyte in a tone which
535. showed that he only understood the meaning of his words after he had
536. uttered them.
537. 
538. He spoke with such self-confidence that his hearers could not be sure
539. whether what he said was very witty or very stupid. He was dressed in
540. a dark-green dress coat, knee breeches of the color of cuisse de nymphe
541. effrayee, as he called it, shoes, and silk stockings.
542. 
543. The vicomte told his tale very neatly. It was an anecdote, then current,
544. to the effect that the Duc d'Enghien had gone secretly to Paris to visit
545. Mademoiselle George; that at her house he came upon Bonaparte, who also
546. enjoyed the famous actress' favors, and that in his presence Napoleon
547. happened to fall into one of the fainting fits to which he was subject,
548. and was thus at the duc's mercy. The latter spared him, and this
549. magnanimity Bonaparte subsequently repaid by death.
550. 
551. The story was very pretty and interesting, especially at the point
552. where the rivals suddenly recognized one another; and the ladies looked
553. agitated.
554. 
555. "Charming!" said Anna Pavlovna with an inquiring glance at the little
556. princess.
557. 
558. "Charming!" whispered the little princess, sticking the needle into her
559. work as if to testify that the interest and fascination of the story
560. prevented her from going on with it.
561. 
562. The vicomte appreciated this silent praise and smiling gratefully
563. prepared to continue, but just then Anna Pavlovna, who had kept a
564. watchful eye on the young man who so alarmed her, noticed that he was
565. talking too loudly and vehemently with the abbe, so she hurried to the
566. rescue. Pierre had managed to start a conversation with the abbe about
567. the balance of power, and the latter, evidently interested by the young
568. man's simple-minded eagerness, was explaining his pet theory. Both were
569. talking and listening too eagerly and too naturally, which was why Anna
570. Pavlovna disapproved.
571. 
572. "The means are... the balance of power in Europe and the rights of the
573. people," the abbe was saying. "It is only necessary for one powerful
574. nation like Russia--barbaric as she is said to be--to place herself
575. disinterestedly at the head of an alliance having for its object the
576. maintenance of the balance of power of Europe, and it would save the
577. world!"
578. 
579. "But how are you to get that balance?" Pierre was beginning.
580. 
581. At that moment Anna Pavlovna came up and, looking severely at Pierre,
582. asked the Italian how he stood Russian climate. The Italian's
583. face instantly changed and assumed an offensively affected, sugary
584. expression, evidently habitual to him when conversing with women.
585. 
586. "I am so enchanted by the brilliancy of the wit and culture of the
587. society, more especially of the feminine society, in which I have had
588. the honor of being received, that I have not yet had time to think of
589. the climate," said he.
590. 
591. Not letting the abbe and Pierre escape, Anna Pavlovna, the more
592. conveniently to keep them under observation, brought them into the
593. larger circle.
594. 
595. 
596. 
597. 
598. 
599. CHAPTER IV
600. 
601. 
602. Just then another visitor entered the drawing room: Prince Andrew
603. Bolkonski, the little princess' husband. He was a very handsome young
604. man, of medium height, with firm, clearcut features. Everything about
605. him, from his weary, bored expression to his quiet, measured step,
606. offered a most striking contrast to his quiet, little wife. It was
607. evident that he not only knew everyone in the drawing room, but had
608. found them to be so tiresome that it wearied him to look at or listen to
609. them. And among all these faces that he found so tedious, none seemed
610. to bore him so much as that of his pretty wife. He turned away from her
611. with a grimace that distorted his handsome face, kissed Anna Pavlovna's
612. hand, and screwing up his eyes scanned the whole company.
613. 
614. "You are off to the war, Prince?" said Anna Pavlovna.
615. 
616. "General Kutuzov," said Bolkonski, speaking French and stressing the
617. last syllable of the general's name like a Frenchman, "has been pleased
618. to take me as an aide-de-camp...."
619. 
620. "And Lise, your wife?"
621. 
622. "She will go to the country."
623. 
624. "Are you not ashamed to deprive us of your charming wife?"
625. 
626. "Andre," said his wife, addressing her husband in the same coquettish
627. manner in which she spoke to other men, "the vicomte has been telling us
628. such a tale about Mademoiselle George and Buonaparte!"
629. 
630. Prince Andrew screwed up his eyes and turned away. Pierre, who from
631. the moment Prince Andrew entered the room had watched him with glad,
632. affectionate eyes, now came up and took his arm. Before he looked round
633. Prince Andrew frowned again, expressing his annoyance with whoever was
634. touching his arm, but when he saw Pierre's beaming face he gave him an
635. unexpectedly kind and pleasant smile.
636. 
637. "There now!... So you, too, are in the great world?" said he to Pierre.
638. 
639. "I knew you would be here," replied Pierre. "I will come to supper with
640. you. May I?" he added in a low voice so as not to disturb the vicomte
641. who was continuing his story.
642. 
643. "No, impossible!" said Prince Andrew, laughing and pressing Pierre's
644. hand to show that there was no need to ask the question. He wished to
645. say something more, but at that moment Prince Vasili and his daughter
646. got up to go and the two young men rose to let them pass.
647. 
648. "You must excuse me, dear Vicomte," said Prince Vasili to the Frenchman,
649. holding him down by the sleeve in a friendly way to prevent his rising.
650. "This unfortunate fete at the ambassador's deprives me of a pleasure,
651. and obliges me to interrupt you. I am very sorry to leave your
652. enchanting party," said he, turning to Anna Pavlovna.
653. 
654. His daughter, Princess Helene, passed between the chairs, lightly
655. holding up the folds of her dress, and the smile shone still more
656. radiantly on her beautiful face. Pierre gazed at her with rapturous,
657. almost frightened, eyes as she passed him.
658. 
659. "Very lovely," said Prince Andrew.
660. 
661. "Very," said Pierre.
662. 
663. In passing Prince Vasili seized Pierre's hand and said to Anna Pavlovna:
664. "Educate this bear for me! He has been staying with me a whole month
665. and this is the first time I have seen him in society. Nothing is so
666. necessary for a young man as the society of clever women."
667. 
668. Anna Pavlovna smiled and promised to take Pierre in hand. She knew his
669. father to be a connection of Prince Vasili's. The elderly lady who had
670. been sitting with the old aunt rose hurriedly and overtook Prince Vasili
671. in the anteroom. All the affectation of interest she had assumed had
672. left her kindly and tear-worn face and it now expressed only anxiety and
673. fear.
674. 
675. "How about my son Boris, Prince?" said she, hurrying after him into the
676. anteroom. "I can't remain any longer in Petersburg. Tell me what news I
677. may take back to my poor boy."
678. 
679. Although Prince Vasili listened reluctantly and not very politely to
680. the elderly lady, even betraying some impatience, she gave him an
681. ingratiating and appealing smile, and took his hand that he might not go
682. away.
683. 
684. "What would it cost you to say a word to the Emperor, and then he would
685. be transferred to the Guards at once?" said she.
686. 
687. "Believe me, Princess, I am ready to do all I can," answered Prince
688. Vasili, "but it is difficult for me to ask the Emperor. I should advise
689. you to appeal to Rumyantsev through Prince Golitsyn. That would be the
690. best way."
691. 
692. The elderly lady was a Princess Drubetskaya, belonging to one of the
693. best families in Russia, but she was poor, and having long been out of
694. society had lost her former influential connections. She had now come to
695. Petersburg to procure an appointment in the Guards for her only son.
696. It was, in fact, solely to meet Prince Vasili that she had obtained an
697. invitation to Anna Pavlovna's reception and had sat listening to the
698. vicomte's story. Prince Vasili's words frightened her, an embittered
699. look clouded her once handsome face, but only for a moment; then she
700. smiled again and clutched Prince Vasili's arm more tightly.
701. 
702. "Listen to me, Prince," said she. "I have never yet asked you for
703. anything and I never will again, nor have I ever reminded you of my
704. father's friendship for you; but now I entreat you for God's sake to
705. do this for my son--and I shall always regard you as a benefactor," she
706. added hurriedly. "No, don't be angry, but promise! I have asked Golitsyn
707. and he has refused. Be the kindhearted man you always were," she said,
708. trying to smile though tears were in her eyes.
709. 
710. "Papa, we shall be late," said Princess Helene, turning her beautiful
711. head and looking over her classically molded shoulder as she stood
712. waiting by the door.
713. 
714. Influence in society, however, is a capital which has to be economized
715. if it is to last. Prince Vasili knew this, and having once realized that
716. if he asked on behalf of all who begged of him, he would soon be unable
717. to ask for himself, he became chary of using his influence. But in
718. Princess Drubetskaya's case he felt, after her second appeal, something
719. like qualms of conscience. She had reminded him of what was quite true;
720. he had been indebted to her father for the first steps in his career.
721. Moreover, he could see by her manners that she was one of those
722. women--mostly mothers--who, having once made up their minds, will not
723. rest until they have gained their end, and are prepared if necessary
724. to go on insisting day after day and hour after hour, and even to make
725. scenes. This last consideration moved him.
726. 
727. "My dear Anna Mikhaylovna," said he with his usual familiarity and
728. weariness of tone, "it is almost impossible for me to do what you ask;
729. but to prove my devotion to you and how I respect your father's memory,
730. I will do the impossible--your son shall be transferred to the Guards.
731. Here is my hand on it. Are you satisfied?"
732. 
733. "My dear benefactor! This is what I expected from you--I knew your
734. kindness!" He turned to go.
735. 
736. "Wait--just a word! When he has been transferred to the Guards..." she
737. faltered. "You are on good terms with Michael Ilarionovich Kutuzov...
738. recommend Boris to him as adjutant! Then I shall be at rest, and
739. then..."
740. 
741. Prince Vasili smiled.
742. 
743. "No, I won't promise that. You don't know how Kutuzov is pestered since
744. his appointment as Commander in Chief. He told me himself that all the
745. Moscow ladies have conspired to give him all their sons as adjutants."
746. 
747. "No, but do promise! I won't let you go! My dear benefactor..."
748. 
749. "Papa," said his beautiful daughter in the same tone as before, "we
750. shall be late."
751. 
752. "Well, au revoir! Good-by! You hear her?"
753. 
754. "Then tomorrow you will speak to the Emperor?"
755. 
756. "Certainly; but about Kutuzov, I don't promise."
757. 
758. "Do promise, do promise, Vasili!" cried Anna Mikhaylovna as he went,
759. with the smile of a coquettish girl, which at one time probably came
760. naturally to her, but was now very ill-suited to her careworn face.
761. 
762. Apparently she had forgotten her age and by force of habit employed
763. all the old feminine arts. But as soon as the prince had gone her face
764. resumed its former cold, artificial expression. She returned to the
765. group where the vicomte was still talking, and again pretended to
766. listen, while waiting till it would be time to leave. Her task was
767. accomplished.
768. 
769. 
770. 
771. 
772. 
773. CHAPTER V
774. 
775. 
776. "And what do you think of this latest comedy, the coronation at Milan?"
777. asked Anna Pavlovna, "and of the comedy of the people of Genoa and
778. Lucca laying their petitions before Monsieur Buonaparte, and Monsieur
779. Buonaparte sitting on a throne and granting the petitions of the
780. nations? Adorable! It is enough to make one's head whirl! It is as if
781. the whole world had gone crazy."
782. 
783. Prince Andrew looked Anna Pavlovna straight in the face with a sarcastic
784. smile.
785. 
786. "'Dieu me la donne, gare a qui la touche!' * They say he was very fine
787. when he said that," he remarked, repeating the words in Italian: "'Dio
788. mi l'ha dato. Guai a chi la tocchi!'"
789. 
790. 
791.      * God has given it to me, let him who touches it beware!
792. 
793. 
794. "I hope this will prove the last drop that will make the glass run
795. over," Anna Pavlovna continued. "The sovereigns will not be able to
796. endure this man who is a menace to everything."
797. 
798. "The sovereigns? I do not speak of Russia," said the vicomte, polite but
799. hopeless: "The sovereigns, madame... What have they done for Louis XVII,
800. for the Queen, or for Madame Elizabeth? Nothing!" and he became more
801. animated. "And believe me, they are reaping the reward of their betrayal
802. of the Bourbon cause. The sovereigns! Why, they are sending ambassadors
803. to compliment the usurper."
804. 
805. And sighing disdainfully, he again changed his position.
806. 
807. Prince Hippolyte, who had been gazing at the vicomte for some time
808. through his lorgnette, suddenly turned completely round toward the
809. little princess, and having asked for a needle began tracing the Conde
810. coat of arms on the table. He explained this to her with as much gravity
811. as if she had asked him to do it.
812. 
813. "Baton de gueules, engrele de gueules d'azur--maison Conde," said he.
814. 
815. The princess listened, smiling.
816. 
817. "If Buonaparte remains on the throne of France a year longer," the
818. vicomte continued, with the air of a man who, in a matter with which
819. he is better acquainted than anyone else, does not listen to others but
820. follows the current of his own thoughts, "things will have gone too far.
821. By intrigues, violence, exile, and executions, French society--I mean
822. good French society--will have been forever destroyed, and then..."
823. 
824. He shrugged his shoulders and spread out his hands. Pierre wished to
825. make a remark, for the conversation interested him, but Anna Pavlovna,
826. who had him under observation, interrupted:
827. 
828. "The Emperor Alexander," said she, with the melancholy which always
829. accompanied any reference of hers to the Imperial family, "has declared
830. that he will leave it to the French people themselves to choose their
831. own form of government; and I believe that once free from the usurper,
832. the whole nation will certainly throw itself into the arms of its
833. rightful king," she concluded, trying to be amiable to the royalist
834. emigrant.
835. 
836. "That is doubtful," said Prince Andrew. "Monsieur le Vicomte quite
837. rightly supposes that matters have already gone too far. I think it will
838. be difficult to return to the old regime."
839. 
840. "From what I have heard," said Pierre, blushing and breaking into the
841. conversation, "almost all the aristocracy has already gone over to
842. Bonaparte's side."
843. 
844. "It is the Buonapartists who say that," replied the vicomte without
845. looking at Pierre. "At the present time it is difficult to know the real
846. state of French public opinion."
847. 
848. "Bonaparte has said so," remarked Prince Andrew with a sarcastic smile.
849. 
850. It was evident that he did not like the vicomte and was aiming his
851. remarks at him, though without looking at him.
852. 
853. "'I showed them the path to glory, but they did not follow it,'" Prince
854. Andrew continued after a short silence, again quoting Napoleon's words.
855. "'I opened my antechambers and they crowded in.' I do not know how far
856. he was justified in saying so."
857. 
858. "Not in the least," replied the vicomte. "After the murder of the
859. duc even the most partial ceased to regard him as a hero. If to some
860. people," he went on, turning to Anna Pavlovna, "he ever was a hero,
861. after the murder of the duc there was one martyr more in heaven and one
862. hero less on earth."
863. 
864. Before Anna Pavlovna and the others had time to smile their appreciation
865. of the vicomte's epigram, Pierre again broke into the conversation, and
866. though Anna Pavlovna felt sure he would say something inappropriate, she
867. was unable to stop him.
868. 
869. "The execution of the Duc d'Enghien," declared Monsieur Pierre, "was a
870. political necessity, and it seems to me that Napoleon showed greatness
871. of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole responsibility of
872. that deed."
873. 
874. "Dieu! Mon Dieu!" muttered Anna Pavlovna in a terrified whisper.
875. 
876. "What, Monsieur Pierre... Do you consider that assassination shows
877. greatness of soul?" said the little princess, smiling and drawing her
878. work nearer to her.
879. 
880. "Oh! Oh!" exclaimed several voices.
881. 
882. "Capital!" said Prince Hippolyte in English, and began slapping his knee
883. with the palm of his hand.
884. 
885. The vicomte merely shrugged his shoulders. Pierre looked solemnly at his
886. audience over his spectacles and continued.
887. 
888. "I say so," he continued desperately, "because the Bourbons fled
889. from the Revolution leaving the people to anarchy, and Napoleon alone
890. understood the Revolution and quelled it, and so for the general good,
891. he could not stop short for the sake of one man's life."
892. 
893. "Won't you come over to the other table?" suggested Anna Pavlovna.
894. 
895. But Pierre continued his speech without heeding her.
896. 
897. "No," cried he, becoming more and more eager, "Napoleon is great because
898. he rose superior to the Revolution, suppressed its abuses, preserved all
899. that was good in it--equality of citizenship and freedom of speech and
900. of the press--and only for that reason did he obtain power."
901. 
902. "Yes, if having obtained power, without availing himself of it to commit
903. murder he had restored it to the rightful king, I should have called him
904. a great man," remarked the vicomte.
905. 
906. "He could not do that. The people only gave him power that he might rid
907. them of the Bourbons and because they saw that he was a great man. The
908. Revolution was a grand thing!" continued Monsieur Pierre, betraying by
909. this desperate and provocative proposition his extreme youth and his
910. wish to express all that was in his mind.
911. 
912. "What? Revolution and regicide a grand thing?... Well, after that... But
913. won't you come to this other table?" repeated Anna Pavlovna.
914. 
915. "Rousseau's Contrat social," said the vicomte with a tolerant smile.
916. 
917. "I am not speaking of regicide, I am speaking about ideas."
918. 
919. "Yes: ideas of robbery, murder, and regicide," again interjected an
920. ironical voice.
921. 
922. "Those were extremes, no doubt, but they are not what is most important.
923. What is important are the rights of man, emancipation from prejudices,
924. and equality of citizenship, and all these ideas Napoleon has retained
925. in full force."
926. 
927. "Liberty and equality," said the vicomte contemptuously, as if at last
928. deciding seriously to prove to this youth how foolish his words were,
929. "high-sounding words which have long been discredited. Who does not love
930. liberty and equality? Even our Saviour preached liberty and equality.
931. Have people since the Revolution become happier? On the contrary. We
932. wanted liberty, but Buonaparte has destroyed it."
933. 
934. Prince Andrew kept looking with an amused smile from Pierre to the
935. vicomte and from the vicomte to their hostess. In the first moment of
936. Pierre's outburst Anna Pavlovna, despite her social experience, was
937. horror-struck. But when she saw that Pierre's sacrilegious words had
938. not exasperated the vicomte, and had convinced herself that it was
939. impossible to stop him, she rallied her forces and joined the vicomte in
940. a vigorous attack on the orator.
941. 
942. "But, my dear Monsieur Pierre," said she, "how do you explain the fact
943. of a great man executing a duc--or even an ordinary man who--is innocent
944. and untried?"
945. 
946. "I should like," said the vicomte, "to ask how monsieur explains the
947. 18th Brumaire; was not that an imposture? It was a swindle, and not at
948. all like the conduct of a great man!"
949. 
950. "And the prisoners he killed in Africa? That was horrible!" said the
951. little princess, shrugging her shoulders.
952. 
953. "He's a low fellow, say what you will," remarked Prince Hippolyte.
954. 
955. Pierre, not knowing whom to answer, looked at them all and smiled. His
956. smile was unlike the half-smile of other people. When he smiled,
957. his grave, even rather gloomy, look was instantaneously replaced by
958. another--a childlike, kindly, even rather silly look, which seemed to
959. ask forgiveness.
960. 
961. The vicomte who was meeting him for the first time saw clearly that
962. this young Jacobin was not so terrible as his words suggested. All were
963. silent.
964. 
965. "How do you expect him to answer you all at once?" said Prince Andrew.
966. "Besides, in the actions of a statesman one has to distinguish between
967. his acts as a private person, as a general, and as an emperor. So it
968. seems to me."
969. 
970. "Yes, yes, of course!" Pierre chimed in, pleased at the arrival of this
971. reinforcement.
972. 
973. "One must admit," continued Prince Andrew, "that Napoleon as a man was
974. great on the bridge of Arcola, and in the hospital at Jaffa where he
975. gave his hand to the plague-stricken; but... but there are other acts
976. which it is difficult to justify."
977. 
978. Prince Andrew, who had evidently wished to tone down the awkwardness of
979. Pierre's remarks, rose and made a sign to his wife that it was time to
980. go.
981. 
982. Suddenly Prince Hippolyte started up making signs to everyone to attend,
983. and asking them all to be seated began:
984. 
985. "I was told a charming Moscow story today and must treat you to it.
986. Excuse me, Vicomte--I must tell it in Russian or the point will be
987. lost...." And Prince Hippolyte began to tell his story in such Russian
988. as a Frenchman would speak after spending about a year in Russia.
989. Everyone waited, so emphatically and eagerly did he demand their
990. attention to his story.
991. 
992. "There is in Moscow a lady, une dame, and she is very stingy. She must
993. have two footmen behind her carriage, and very big ones. That was her
994. taste. And she had a lady's maid, also big. She said..."
995. 
996. Here Prince Hippolyte paused, evidently collecting his ideas with
997. difficulty.
998. 
999. "She said... Oh yes! She said, 'Girl,' to the maid, 'put on a livery,
1000. get up behind the carriage, and come with me while I make some calls.'"
1001. 
1002. Here Prince Hippolyte spluttered and burst out laughing long before his
1003. audience, which produced an effect unfavorable to the narrator. Several
1004. persons, among them the elderly lady and Anna Pavlovna, did however
1005. smile.
1006. 
1007. "She went. Suddenly there was a great wind. The girl lost her hat and
1008. her long hair came down...." Here he could contain himself no longer and
1009. went on, between gasps of laughter: "And the whole world knew...."
1010. 
1011. And so the anecdote ended. Though it was unintelligible why he had told
1012. it, or why it had to be told in Russian, still Anna Pavlovna and the
1013. others appreciated Prince Hippolyte's social tact in so agreeably ending
1014. Pierre's unpleasant and unamiable outburst. After the anecdote the
1015. conversation broke up into insignificant small talk about the last and
1016. next balls, about theatricals, and who would meet whom, and when and
1017. where.
1018. 
1019. 
1020. 
1021. 
1022. 
1023. CHAPTER VI
1024. 
1025. 
1026. Having thanked Anna Pavlovna for her charming soiree, the guests began
1027. to take their leave.
1028. 
1029. Pierre was ungainly. Stout, about the average height, broad, with huge
1030. red hands; he did not know, as the saying is, how to enter a drawing
1031. room and still less how to leave one; that is, how to say something
1032. particularly agreeable before going away. Besides this he was
1033. absent-minded. When he rose to go, he took up instead of his own, the
1034. general's three-cornered hat, and held it, pulling at the plume, till
1035. the general asked him to restore it. All his absent-mindedness and
1036. inability to enter a room and converse in it was, however, redeemed by
1037. his kindly, simple, and modest expression. Anna Pavlovna turned toward
1038. him and, with a Christian mildness that expressed forgiveness of his
1039. indiscretion, nodded and said: "I hope to see you again, but I also hope
1040. you will change your opinions, my dear Monsieur Pierre."
1041. 
1042. When she said this, he did not reply and only bowed, but again everybody
1043. saw his smile, which said nothing, unless perhaps, "Opinions are
1044. opinions, but you see what a capital, good-natured fellow I am." And
1045. everyone, including Anna Pavlovna, felt this.
1046. 
1047. Prince Andrew had gone out into the hall, and, turning his shoulders
1048. to the footman who was helping him on with his cloak, listened
1049. indifferently to his wife's chatter with Prince Hippolyte who had also
1050. come into the hall. Prince Hippolyte stood close to the pretty, pregnant
1051. princess, and stared fixedly at her through his eyeglass.
1052. 
1053. "Go in, Annette, or you will catch cold," said the little princess,
1054. taking leave of Anna Pavlovna. "It is settled," she added in a low
1055. voice.
1056. 
1057. Anna Pavlovna had already managed to speak to Lise about the match she
1058. contemplated between Anatole and the little princess' sister-in-law.
1059. 
1060. "I rely on you, my dear," said Anna Pavlovna, also in a low tone.
1061. "Write to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter. Au
1062. revoir!"--and she left the hall.
1063. 
1064. Prince Hippolyte approached the little princess and, bending his face
1065. close to her, began to whisper something.
1066. 
1067. Two footmen, the princess' and his own, stood holding a shawl and a
1068. cloak, waiting for the conversation to finish. They listened to
1069. the French sentences which to them were meaningless, with an air of
1070. understanding but not wishing to appear to do so. The princess as usual
1071. spoke smilingly and listened with a laugh.
1072. 
1073. "I am very glad I did not go to the ambassador's," said Prince Hippolyte
1074. "-so dull-. It has been a delightful evening, has it not? Delightful!"
1075. 
1076. "They say the ball will be very good," replied the princess, drawing up
1077. her downy little lip. "All the pretty women in society will be there."
1078. 
1079. "Not all, for you will not be there; not all," said Prince Hippolyte
1080. smiling joyfully; and snatching the shawl from the footman, whom he
1081. even pushed aside, he began wrapping it round the princess. Either from
1082. awkwardness or intentionally (no one could have said which) after the
1083. shawl had been adjusted he kept his arm around her for a long time, as
1084. though embracing her.
1085. 
1086. Still smiling, she gracefully moved away, turning and glancing at her
1087. husband. Prince Andrew's eyes were closed, so weary and sleepy did he
1088. seem.
1089. 
1090. "Are you ready?" he asked his wife, looking past her.
1091. 
1092. Prince Hippolyte hurriedly put on his cloak, which in the latest fashion
1093. reached to his very heels, and, stumbling in it, ran out into the porch
1094. following the princess, whom a footman was helping into the carriage.
1095. 
1096. "Princesse, au revoir," cried he, stumbling with his tongue as well as
1097. with his feet.
1098. 
1099. The princess, picking up her dress, was taking her seat in the dark
1100. carriage, her husband was adjusting his saber; Prince Hippolyte, under
1101. pretense of helping, was in everyone's way.
1102. 
1103. "Allow me, sir," said Prince Andrew in Russian in a cold, disagreeable
1104. tone to Prince Hippolyte who was blocking his path.
1105. 
1106. "I am expecting you, Pierre," said the same voice, but gently and
1107. affectionately.
1108. 
1109. The postilion started, the carriage wheels rattled. Prince Hippolyte
1110. laughed spasmodically as he stood in the porch waiting for the vicomte
1111. whom he had promised to take home.
1112. 
1113. "Well, mon cher," said the vicomte, having seated himself beside
1114. Hippolyte in the carriage, "your little princess is very nice, very nice
1115. indeed, quite French," and he kissed the tips of his fingers. Hippolyte
1116. burst out laughing.
1117. 
1118. "Do you know, you are a terrible chap for all your innocent airs,"
1119. continued the vicomte. "I pity the poor husband, that little officer who
1120. gives himself the airs of a monarch."
1121. 
1122. Hippolyte spluttered again, and amid his laughter said, "And you were
1123. saying that the Russian ladies are not equal to the French? One has to
1124. know how to deal with them."
1125. 
1126. 
1127. Pierre reaching the house first went into Prince Andrew's study like
1128. one quite at home, and from habit immediately lay down on the sofa, took
1129. from the shelf the first book that came to his hand (it was Caesar's
1130. Commentaries), and resting on his elbow, began reading it in the middle.
1131. 
1132. "What have you done to Mlle Scherer? She will be quite ill now," said
1133. Prince Andrew, as he entered the study, rubbing his small white hands.
1134. 
1135. Pierre turned his whole body, making the sofa creak. He lifted his eager
1136. face to Prince Andrew, smiled, and waved his hand.
1137. 
1138. "That abbe is very interesting but he does not see the thing in the
1139. right light.... In my opinion perpetual peace is possible but--I do not
1140. know how to express it... not by a balance of political power...."
1141. 
1142. It was evident that Prince Andrew was not interested in such abstract
1143. conversation.
1144. 
1145. "One can't everywhere say all one thinks, mon cher. Well, have you
1146. at last decided on anything? Are you going to be a guardsman or a
1147. diplomatist?" asked Prince Andrew after a momentary silence.
1148. 
1149. Pierre sat up on the sofa, with his legs tucked under him.
1150. 
1151. "Really, I don't yet know. I don't like either the one or the other."
1152. 
1153. "But you must decide on something! Your father expects it."
1154. 
1155. Pierre at the age of ten had been sent abroad with an abbe as tutor,
1156. and had remained away till he was twenty. When he returned to Moscow
1157. his father dismissed the abbe and said to the young man, "Now go to
1158. Petersburg, look round, and choose your profession. I will agree to
1159. anything. Here is a letter to Prince Vasili, and here is money. Write to
1160. me all about it, and I will help you in everything." Pierre had
1161. already been choosing a career for three months, and had not decided
1162. on anything. It was about this choice that Prince Andrew was speaking.
1163. Pierre rubbed his forehead.
1164. 
1165. "But he must be a Freemason," said he, referring to the abbe whom he had
1166. met that evening.
1167. 
1168. "That is all nonsense." Prince Andrew again interrupted him, "let us
1169. talk business. Have you been to the Horse Guards?"
1170. 
1171. "No, I have not; but this is what I have been thinking and wanted to
1172. tell you. There is a war now against Napoleon. If it were a war for
1173. freedom I could understand it and should be the first to enter the army;
1174. but to help England and Austria against the greatest man in the world is
1175. not right."
1176. 
1177. Prince Andrew only shrugged his shoulders at Pierre's childish words. He
1178. put on the air of one who finds it impossible to reply to such nonsense,
1179. but it would in fact have been difficult to give any other answer than
1180. the one Prince Andrew gave to this naive question.
1181. 
1182. "If no one fought except on his own conviction, there would be no wars,"
1183. he said.
1184. 
1185. "And that would be splendid," said Pierre.
1186. 
1187. Prince Andrew smiled ironically.
1188. 
1189. "Very likely it would be splendid, but it will never come about..."
1190. 
1191. "Well, why are you going to the war?" asked Pierre.
1192. 
1193. "What for? I don't know. I must. Besides that I am going..." He paused.
1194. "I am going because the life I am leading here does not suit me!"
1195. 
1196. 
1197. 
1198. 
1199. 
1200. CHAPTER VII
1201. 
1202. 
1203. The rustle of a woman's dress was heard in the next room. Prince Andrew
1204. shook himself as if waking up, and his face assumed the look it had had
1205. in Anna Pavlovna's drawing room. Pierre removed his feet from the sofa.
1206. The princess came in. She had changed her gown for a house dress as
1207. fresh and elegant as the other. Prince Andrew rose and politely placed a
1208. chair for her.
1209. 
1210. "How is it," she began, as usual in French, settling down briskly and
1211. fussily in the easy chair, "how is it Annette never got married? How
1212. stupid you men all are not to have married her! Excuse me for saying so,
1213. but you have no sense about women. What an argumentative fellow you are,
1214. Monsieur Pierre!"
1215. 
1216. "And I am still arguing with your husband. I can't understand why he
1217. wants to go to the war," replied Pierre, addressing the princess with
1218. none of the embarrassment so commonly shown by young men in their
1219. intercourse with young women.
1220. 
1221. The princess started. Evidently Pierre's words touched her to the quick.
1222. 
1223. "Ah, that is just what I tell him!" said she. "I don't understand it; I
1224. don't in the least understand why men can't live without wars. How is
1225. it that we women don't want anything of the kind, don't need it? Now
1226. you shall judge between us. I always tell him: Here he is Uncle's
1227. aide-de-camp, a most brilliant position. He is so well known, so much
1228. appreciated by everyone. The other day at the Apraksins' I heard a lady
1229. asking, 'Is that the famous Prince Andrew?' I did indeed." She laughed.
1230. "He is so well received everywhere. He might easily become aide-de-camp
1231. to the Emperor. You know the Emperor spoke to him most graciously.
1232. Annette and I were speaking of how to arrange it. What do you think?"
1233. 
1234. Pierre looked at his friend and, noticing that he did not like the
1235. conversation, gave no reply.
1236. 
1237. "When are you starting?" he asked.
1238. 
1239. "Oh, don't speak of his going, don't! I won't hear it spoken of," said
1240. the princess in the same petulantly playful tone in which she had spoken
1241. to Hippolyte in the drawing room and which was so plainly ill-suited
1242. to the family circle of which Pierre was almost a member. "Today when I
1243. remembered that all these delightful associations must be broken off...
1244. and then you know, Andre..." (she looked significantly at her husband)
1245. "I'm afraid, I'm afraid!" she whispered, and a shudder ran down her
1246. back.
1247. 
1248. Her husband looked at her as if surprised to notice that someone besides
1249. Pierre and himself was in the room, and addressed her in a tone of
1250. frigid politeness.
1251. 
1252. "What is it you are afraid of, Lise? I don't understand," said he.
1253. 
1254. "There, what egotists men all are: all, all egotists! Just for a whim of
1255. his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone in
1256. the country."
1257. 
1258. "With my father and sister, remember," said Prince Andrew gently.
1259. 
1260. "Alone all the same, without my friends.... And he expects me not to be
1261. afraid."
1262. 
1263. Her tone was now querulous and her lip drawn up, giving her not a
1264. joyful, but an animal, squirrel-like expression. She paused as if she
1265. felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the
1266. gist of the matter lay in that.
1267. 
1268. "I still can't understand what you are afraid of," said Prince Andrew
1269. slowly, not taking his eyes off his wife.
1270. 
1271. The princess blushed, and raised her arms with a gesture of despair.
1272. 
1273. "No, Andrew, I must say you have changed. Oh, how you have..."
1274. 
1275. "Your doctor tells you to go to bed earlier," said Prince Andrew. "You
1276. had better go."
1277. 
1278. The princess said nothing, but suddenly her short downy lip quivered.
1279. Prince Andrew rose, shrugged his shoulders, and walked about the room.
1280. 
1281. Pierre looked over his spectacles with naive surprise, now at him and
1282. now at her, moved as if about to rise too, but changed his mind.
1283. 
1284. "Why should I mind Monsieur Pierre being here?" exclaimed the little
1285. princess suddenly, her pretty face all at once distorted by a tearful
1286. grimace. "I have long wanted to ask you, Andrew, why you have changed
1287. so to me? What have I done to you? You are going to the war and have no
1288. pity for me. Why is it?"
1289. 
1290. "Lise!" was all Prince Andrew said. But that one word expressed an
1291. entreaty, a threat, and above all conviction that she would herself
1292. regret her words. But she went on hurriedly:
1293. 
1294. "You treat me like an invalid or a child. I see it all! Did you behave
1295. like that six months ago?"
1296. 
1297. "Lise, I beg you to desist," said Prince Andrew still more emphatically.
1298. 
1299. Pierre, who had been growing more and more agitated as he listened to
1300. all this, rose and approached the princess. He seemed unable to bear the
1301. sight of tears and was ready to cry himself.
1302. 
1303. "Calm yourself, Princess! It seems so to you because... I assure you
1304. I myself have experienced... and so... because... No, excuse me!
1305. An outsider is out of place here... No, don't distress yourself...
1306. Good-by!"
1307. 
1308. Prince Andrew caught him by the hand.
1309. 
1310. "No, wait, Pierre! The princess is too kind to wish to deprive me of the
1311. pleasure of spending the evening with you."
1312. 
1313. "No, he thinks only of himself," muttered the princess without
1314. restraining her angry tears.
1315. 
1316. "Lise!" said Prince Andrew dryly, raising his voice to the pitch which
1317. indicates that patience is exhausted.
1318. 
1319. Suddenly the angry, squirrel-like expression of the princess' pretty
1320. face changed into a winning and piteous look of fear. Her beautiful eyes
1321. glanced askance at her husband's face, and her own assumed the timid,
1322. deprecating expression of a dog when it rapidly but feebly wags its
1323. drooping tail.
1324. 
1325. "Mon Dieu, mon Dieu!" she muttered, and lifting her dress with one hand
1326. she went up to her husband and kissed him on the forehead.
1327. 
1328. "Good night, Lise," said he, rising and courteously kissing her hand as
1329. he would have done to a stranger.
1330. 
1331. 
1332. 
1333. 
1334. 
1335. CHAPTER VIII
1336. 
1337. 
1338. The friends were silent. Neither cared to begin talking. Pierre
1339. continually glanced at Prince Andrew; Prince Andrew rubbed his forehead
1340. with his small hand.
1341. 
1342. "Let us go and have supper," he said with a sigh, going to the door.
1343. 
1344. They entered the elegant, newly decorated, and luxurious dining room.
1345. Everything from the table napkins to the silver, china, and glass bore
1346. that imprint of newness found in the households of the newly married.
1347. Halfway through supper Prince Andrew leaned his elbows on the table and,
1348. with a look of nervous agitation such as Pierre had never before seen on
1349. his face, began to talk--as one who has long had something on his mind
1350. and suddenly determines to speak out.
1351. 
1352. "Never, never marry, my dear fellow! That's my advice: never marry till
1353. you can say to yourself that you have done all you are capable of, and
1354. until you have ceased to love the woman of your choice and have seen
1355. her plainly as she is, or else you will make a cruel and irrevocable
1356. mistake. Marry when you are old and good for nothing--or all that is
1357. good and noble in you will be lost. It will all be wasted on trifles.
1358. Yes! Yes! Yes! Don't look at me with such surprise. If you marry
1359. expecting anything from yourself in the future, you will feel at every
1360. step that for you all is ended, all is closed except the drawing
1361. room, where you will be ranged side by side with a court lackey and an
1362. idiot!... But what's the good?..." and he waved his arm.
1363. 
1364. Pierre took off his spectacles, which made his face seem different and
1365. the good-natured expression still more apparent, and gazed at his friend
1366. in amazement.
1367. 
1368. "My wife," continued Prince Andrew, "is an excellent woman, one of those
1369. rare women with whom a man's honor is safe; but, O God, what would I
1370. not give now to be unmarried! You are the first and only one to whom I
1371. mention this, because I like you."
1372. 
1373. As he said this Prince Andrew was less than ever like that Bolkonski who
1374. had lolled in Anna Pavlovna's easy chairs and with half-closed eyes had
1375. uttered French phrases between his teeth. Every muscle of his thin face
1376. was now quivering with nervous excitement; his eyes, in which the fire
1377. of life had seemed extinguished, now flashed with brilliant light. It
1378. was evident that the more lifeless he seemed at ordinary times, the more
1379. impassioned he became in these moments of almost morbid irritation.
1380. 
1381. "You don't understand why I say this," he continued, "but it is the
1382. whole story of life. You talk of Bonaparte and his career," said he
1383. (though Pierre had not mentioned Bonaparte), "but Bonaparte when he
1384. worked went step by step toward his goal. He was free, he had nothing
1385. but his aim to consider, and he reached it. But tie yourself up with
1386. a woman and, like a chained convict, you lose all freedom! And all you
1387. have of hope and strength merely weighs you down and torments you with
1388. regret. Drawing rooms, gossip, balls, vanity, and triviality--these are
1389. the enchanted circle I cannot escape from. I am now going to the war,
1390. the greatest war there ever was, and I know nothing and am fit for
1391. nothing. I am very amiable and have a caustic wit," continued Prince
1392. Andrew, "and at Anna Pavlovna's they listen to me. And that stupid set
1393. without whom my wife cannot exist, and those women... If you only knew
1394. what those society women are, and women in general! My father is right.
1395. Selfish, vain, stupid, trivial in everything--that's what women are
1396. when you see them in their true colors! When you meet them in society it
1397. seems as if there were something in them, but there's nothing, nothing,
1398. nothing! No, don't marry, my dear fellow; don't marry!" concluded Prince
1399. Andrew.
1400. 
1401. "It seems funny to me," said Pierre, "that you, you should consider
1402. yourself incapable and your life a spoiled life. You have everything
1403. before you, everything. And you..."
1404. 
1405. He did not finish his sentence, but his tone showed how highly he
1406. thought of his friend and how much he expected of him in the future.
1407. 
1408. "How can he talk like that?" thought Pierre. He considered his friend
1409. a model of perfection because Prince Andrew possessed in the highest
1410. degree just the very qualities Pierre lacked, and which might be best
1411. described as strength of will. Pierre was always astonished at Prince
1412. Andrew's calm manner of treating everybody, his extraordinary memory,
1413. his extensive reading (he had read everything, knew everything, and had
1414. an opinion about everything), but above all at his capacity for work and
1415. study. And if Pierre was often struck by Andrew's lack of capacity
1416. for philosophical meditation (to which he himself was particularly
1417. addicted), he regarded even this not as a defect but as a sign of
1418. strength.
1419. 
1420. Even in the best, most friendly and simplest relations of life, praise
1421. and commendation are essential, just as grease is necessary to wheels
1422. that they may run smoothly.
1423. 
1424. "My part is played out," said Prince Andrew. "What's the use of talking
1425. about me? Let us talk about you," he added after a silence, smiling at
1426. his reassuring thoughts.
1427. 
1428. That smile was immediately reflected on Pierre's face.
1429. 
1430. "But what is there to say about me?" said Pierre, his face relaxing into
1431. a careless, merry smile. "What am I? An illegitimate son!" He suddenly
1432. blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a great effort to say
1433. this. "Without a name and without means... And it really..." But he
1434. did not say what "it really" was. "For the present I am free and am
1435. all right. Only I haven't the least idea what I am to do; I wanted to
1436. consult you seriously."
1437. 
1438. Prince Andrew looked kindly at him, yet his glance--friendly and
1439. affectionate as it was--expressed a sense of his own superiority.
1440. 
1441. "I am fond of you, especially as you are the one live man among our
1442. whole set. Yes, you're all right! Choose what you will; it's all the
1443. same. You'll be all right anywhere. But look here: give up visiting
1444. those Kuragins and leading that sort of life. It suits you so badly--all
1445. this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!"
1446. 
1447. "What would you have, my dear fellow?" answered Pierre, shrugging his
1448. shoulders. "Women, my dear fellow; women!"
1449. 
1450. "I don't understand it," replied Prince Andrew. "Women who are comme il
1451. faut, that's a different matter; but the Kuragins' set of women, 'women
1452. and wine' I don't understand!"
1453. 
1454. Pierre was staying at Prince Vasili Kuragin's and sharing the dissipated
1455. life of his son Anatole, the son whom they were planning to reform by
1456. marrying him to Prince Andrew's sister.
1457. 
1458. "Do you know?" said Pierre, as if suddenly struck by a happy thought,
1459. "seriously, I have long been thinking of it.... Leading such a life I
1460. can't decide or think properly about anything. One's head aches, and one
1461. spends all one's money. He asked me for tonight, but I won't go."
1462. 
1463. "You give me your word of honor not to go?"
1464. 
1465. "On my honor!"
1466. 
1467. 
1468. 
1469. 
1470. 
1471. CHAPTER IX
1472. 
1473. 
1474. It was past one o'clock when Pierre left his friend. It was a cloudless,
1475. northern, summer night. Pierre took an open cab intending to drive
1476. straight home. But the nearer he drew to the house the more he felt the
1477. impossibility of going to sleep on such a night. It was light enough to
1478. see a long way in the deserted street and it seemed more like morning
1479. or evening than night. On the way Pierre remembered that Anatole Kuragin
1480. was expecting the usual set for cards that evening, after which there
1481. was generally a drinking bout, finishing with visits of a kind Pierre
1482. was very fond of.
1483. 
1484. "I should like to go to Kuragin's," thought he.
1485. 
1486. But he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go
1487. there. Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so
1488. passionately once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to
1489. that he decided to go. The thought immediately occurred to him that his
1490. promise to Prince Andrew was of no account, because before he gave it he
1491. had already promised Prince Anatole to come to his gathering; "besides,"
1492. thought he, "all such 'words of honor' are conventional things with no
1493. definite meaning, especially if one considers that by tomorrow one may
1494. be dead, or something so extraordinary may happen to one that honor and
1495. dishonor will be all the same!" Pierre often indulged in reflections
1496. of this sort, nullifying all his decisions and intentions. He went to
1497. Kuragin's.
1498. 
1499. Reaching the large house near the Horse Guards' barracks, in which
1500. Anatole lived, Pierre entered the lighted porch, ascended the stairs,
1501. and went in at the open door. There was no one in the anteroom; empty
1502. bottles, cloaks, and overshoes were lying about; there was a smell of
1503. alcohol, and sounds of voices and shouting in the distance.
1504. 
1505. Cards and supper were over, but the visitors had not yet dispersed.
1506. Pierre threw off his cloak and entered the first room, in which were the
1507. remains of supper. A footman, thinking no one saw him, was drinking on
1508. the sly what was left in the glasses. From the third room came sounds of
1509. laughter, the shouting of familiar voices, the growling of a bear, and
1510. general commotion. Some eight or nine young men were crowding anxiously
1511. round an open window. Three others were romping with a young bear, one
1512. pulling him by the chain and trying to set him at the others.
1513. 
1514. "I bet a hundred on Stevens!" shouted one.
1515. 
1516. "Mind, no holding on!" cried another.
1517. 
1518. "I bet on Dolokhov!" cried a third. "Kuragin, you part our hands."
1519. 
1520. "There, leave Bruin alone; here's a bet on."
1521. 
1522. "At one draught, or he loses!" shouted a fourth.
1523. 
1524. "Jacob, bring a bottle!" shouted the host, a tall, handsome fellow who
1525. stood in the midst of the group, without a coat, and with his fine linen
1526. shirt unfastened in front. "Wait a bit, you fellows.... Here is Petya!
1527. Good man!" cried he, addressing Pierre.
1528. 
1529. Another voice, from a man of medium height with clear blue eyes,
1530. particularly striking among all these drunken voices by its sober ring,
1531. cried from the window: "Come here; part the bets!" This was Dolokhov,
1532. an officer of the Semenov regiment, a notorious gambler and duelist, who
1533. was living with Anatole. Pierre smiled, looking about him merrily.
1534. 
1535. "I don't understand. What's it all about?"
1536. 
1537. "Wait a bit, he is not drunk yet! A bottle here," said Anatole, taking a
1538. glass from the table he went up to Pierre.
1539. 
1540. "First of all you must drink!"
1541. 
1542. Pierre drank one glass after another, looking from under his brows at
1543. the tipsy guests who were again crowding round the window, and listening
1544. to their chatter. Anatole kept on refilling Pierre's glass while
1545. explaining that Dolokhov was betting with Stevens, an English naval
1546. officer, that he would drink a bottle of rum sitting on the outer ledge
1547. of the third floor window with his legs hanging out.
1548. 
1549. "Go on, you must drink it all," said Anatole, giving Pierre the last
1550. glass, "or I won't let you go!"
1551. 
1552. "No, I won't," said Pierre, pushing Anatole aside, and he went up to the
1553. window.
1554. 
1555. Dolokhov was holding the Englishman's hand and clearly and distinctly
1556. repeating the terms of the bet, addressing himself particularly to
1557. Anatole and Pierre.
1558. 
1559. Dolokhov was of medium height, with curly hair and light-blue eyes. He
1560. was about twenty-five. Like all infantry officers he wore no mustache,
1561. so that his mouth, the most striking feature of his face, was clearly
1562. seen. The lines of that mouth were remarkably finely curved. The middle
1563. of the upper lip formed a sharp wedge and closed firmly on the firm
1564. lower one, and something like two distinct smiles played continually
1565. round the two corners of the mouth; this, together with the resolute,
