1566. insolent intelligence of his eyes, produced an effect which made it
1567. impossible not to notice his face. Dolokhov was a man of small means and
1568. no connections. Yet, though Anatole spent tens of thousands of rubles,
1569. Dolokhov lived with him and had placed himself on such a footing that
1570. all who knew them, including Anatole himself, respected him more than
1571. they did Anatole. Dolokhov could play all games and nearly always won.
1572. However much he drank, he never lost his clearheadedness. Both Kuragin
1573. and Dolokhov were at that time notorious among the rakes and scapegraces
1574. of Petersburg.
1575. 
1576. The bottle of rum was brought. The window frame which prevented anyone
1577. from sitting on the outer sill was being forced out by two footmen, who
1578. were evidently flurried and intimidated by the directions and shouts of
1579. the gentlemen around.
1580. 
1581. Anatole with his swaggering air strode up to the window. He wanted to
1582. smash something. Pushing away the footmen he tugged at the frame, but
1583. could not move it. He smashed a pane.
1584. 
1585. "You have a try, Hercules," said he, turning to Pierre.
1586. 
1587. Pierre seized the crossbeam, tugged, and wrenched the oak frame out with
1588. a crash.
1589. 
1590. "Take it right out, or they'll think I'm holding on," said Dolokhov.
1591. 
1592. "Is the Englishman bragging?... Eh? Is it all right?" said Anatole.
1593. 
1594. "First-rate," said Pierre, looking at Dolokhov, who with a bottle of rum
1595. in his hand was approaching the window, from which the light of the sky,
1596. the dawn merging with the afterglow of sunset, was visible.
1597. 
1598. Dolokhov, the bottle of rum still in his hand, jumped onto the window
1599. sill. "Listen!" cried he, standing there and addressing those in the
1600. room. All were silent.
1601. 
1602. "I bet fifty imperials"--he spoke French that the Englishman might
1603. understand him, but he did, not speak it very well--"I bet fifty
1604. imperials... or do you wish to make it a hundred?" added he, addressing
1605. the Englishman.
1606. 
1607. "No, fifty," replied the latter.
1608. 
1609. "All right. Fifty imperials... that I will drink a whole bottle of rum
1610. without taking it from my mouth, sitting outside the window on this
1611. spot" (he stooped and pointed to the sloping ledge outside the window)
1612. "and without holding on to anything. Is that right?"
1613. 
1614. "Quite right," said the Englishman.
1615. 
1616. Anatole turned to the Englishman and taking him by one of the buttons
1617. of his coat and looking down at him--the Englishman was short--began
1618. repeating the terms of the wager to him in English.
1619. 
1620. "Wait!" cried Dolokhov, hammering with the bottle on the window sill to
1621. attract attention. "Wait a bit, Kuragin. Listen! If anyone else does the
1622. same, I will pay him a hundred imperials. Do you understand?"
1623. 
1624. The Englishman nodded, but gave no indication whether he intended to
1625. accept this challenge or not. Anatole did not release him, and though
1626. he kept nodding to show that he understood, Anatole went on translating
1627. Dolokhov's words into English. A thin young lad, an hussar of the Life
1628. Guards, who had been losing that evening, climbed on the window sill,
1629. leaned over, and looked down.
1630. 
1631. "Oh! Oh! Oh!" he muttered, looking down from the window at the stones of
1632. the pavement.
1633. 
1634. "Shut up!" cried Dolokhov, pushing him away from the window. The lad
1635. jumped awkwardly back into the room, tripping over his spurs.
1636. 
1637. Placing the bottle on the window sill where he could reach it easily,
1638. Dolokhov climbed carefully and slowly through the window and lowered his
1639. legs. Pressing against both sides of the window, he adjusted himself on
1640. his seat, lowered his hands, moved a little to the right and then to
1641. the left, and took up the bottle. Anatole brought two candles and placed
1642. them on the window sill, though it was already quite light. Dolokhov's
1643. back in his white shirt, and his curly head, were lit up from both
1644. sides. Everyone crowded to the window, the Englishman in front. Pierre
1645. stood smiling but silent. One man, older than the others present,
1646. suddenly pushed forward with a scared and angry look and wanted to seize
1647. hold of Dolokhov's shirt.
1648. 
1649. "I say, this is folly! He'll be killed," said this more sensible man.
1650. 
1651. Anatole stopped him.
1652. 
1653. "Don't touch him! You'll startle him and then he'll be killed. Eh?...
1654. What then?... Eh?"
1655. 
1656. Dolokhov turned round and, again holding on with both hands, arranged
1657. himself on his seat.
1658. 
1659. "If anyone comes meddling again," said he, emitting the words separately
1660. through his thin compressed lips, "I will throw him down there. Now
1661. then!"
1662. 
1663. Saying this he again turned round, dropped his hands, took the bottle
1664. and lifted it to his lips, threw back his head, and raised his free hand
1665. to balance himself. One of the footmen who had stooped to pick up some
1666. broken glass remained in that position without taking his eyes from the
1667. window and from Dolokhov's back. Anatole stood erect with staring eyes.
1668. The Englishman looked on sideways, pursing up his lips. The man who had
1669. wished to stop the affair ran to a corner of the room and threw himself
1670. on a sofa with his face to the wall. Pierre hid his face, from which a
1671. faint smile forgot to fade though his features now expressed horror
1672. and fear. All were still. Pierre took his hands from his eyes. Dolokhov
1673. still sat in the same position, only his head was thrown further back
1674. till his curly hair touched his shirt collar, and the hand holding the
1675. bottle was lifted higher and higher and trembled with the effort. The
1676. bottle was emptying perceptibly and rising still higher and his head
1677. tilting yet further back. "Why is it so long?" thought Pierre. It seemed
1678. to him that more than half an hour had elapsed. Suddenly Dolokhov made
1679. a backward movement with his spine, and his arm trembled nervously; this
1680. was sufficient to cause his whole body to slip as he sat on the sloping
1681. ledge. As he began slipping down, his head and arm wavered still more
1682. with the strain. One hand moved as if to clutch the window sill, but
1683. refrained from touching it. Pierre again covered his eyes and thought he
1684. would never open them again. Suddenly he was aware of a stir all around.
1685. He looked up: Dolokhov was standing on the window sill, with a pale but
1686. radiant face.
1687. 
1688. "It's empty."
1689. 
1690. He threw the bottle to the Englishman, who caught it neatly. Dolokhov
1691. jumped down. He smelt strongly of rum.
1692. 
1693. "Well done!... Fine fellow!... There's a bet for you!... Devil take
1694. you!" came from different sides.
1695. 
1696. The Englishman took out his purse and began counting out the money.
1697. Dolokhov stood frowning and did not speak. Pierre jumped upon the window
1698. sill.
1699. 
1700. "Gentlemen, who wishes to bet with me? I'll do the same thing!" he
1701. suddenly cried. "Even without a bet, there! Tell them to bring me a
1702. bottle. I'll do it.... Bring a bottle!"
1703. 
1704. "Let him do it, let him do it," said Dolokhov, smiling.
1705. 
1706. "What next? Have you gone mad?... No one would let you!... Why, you go
1707. giddy even on a staircase," exclaimed several voices.
1708. 
1709. "I'll drink it! Let's have a bottle of rum!" shouted Pierre, banging the
1710. table with a determined and drunken gesture and preparing to climb out
1711. of the window.
1712. 
1713. They seized him by his arms; but he was so strong that everyone who
1714. touched him was sent flying.
1715. 
1716. "No, you'll never manage him that way," said Anatole. "Wait a bit and
1717. I'll get round him.... Listen! I'll take your bet tomorrow, but now we
1718. are all going to ----'s."
1719. 
1720. "Come on then," cried Pierre. "Come on!... And we'll take Bruin with
1721. us."
1722. 
1723. And he caught the bear, took it in his arms, lifted it from the ground,
1724. and began dancing round the room with it.

1732. 
1733. Prince Vasili kept the promise he had given to Princess Drubetskaya who
1734. had spoken to him on behalf of her only son Boris on the evening of Anna
1735. Pavlovna's soiree. The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an exception
1736. made, and Boris transferred into the regiment of Semenov Guards with the
1737. rank of cornet. He received, however, no appointment to Kutuzov's staff
1738. despite all Anna Mikhaylovna's endeavors and entreaties. Soon after
1739. Anna Pavlovna's reception Anna Mikhaylovna returned to Moscow and went
1740. straight to her rich relations, the Rostovs, with whom she stayed when
1741. in the town and where her darling Bory, who had only just entered a
1742. regiment of the line and was being at once transferred to the Guards
1743. as a cornet, had been educated from childhood and lived for years at a
1744. time. The Guards had already left Petersburg on the tenth of August, and
1745. her son, who had remained in Moscow for his equipment, was to join them
1746. on the march to Radzivilov.
1747. 
1748. It was St. Natalia's day and the name day of two of the Rostovs--the
1749. mother and the youngest daughter--both named Nataly. Ever since
1750. the morning, carriages with six horses had been coming and going
1751. continually, bringing visitors to the Countess Rostova's big house on
1752. the Povarskaya, so well known to all Moscow. The countess herself and
1753. her handsome eldest daughter were in the drawing-room with the visitors
1754. who came to congratulate, and who constantly succeeded one another in
1755. relays.
1756. 
1757. The countess was a woman of about forty-five, with a thin Oriental type
1758. of face, evidently worn out with childbearing--she had had twelve.
1759. A languor of motion and speech, resulting from weakness, gave her a
1760. distinguished air which inspired respect. Princess Anna Mikhaylovna
1761. Drubetskaya, who as a member of the household was also seated in the
1762. drawing room, helped to receive and entertain the visitors. The young
1763. people were in one of the inner rooms, not considering it necessary to
1764. take part in receiving the visitors. The count met the guests and saw
1765. them off, inviting them all to dinner.
1766. 
1767. "I am very, very grateful to you, mon cher," or "ma chere"--he called
1768. everyone without exception and without the slightest variation in his
1769. tone, "my dear," whether they were above or below him in rank--"I thank
1770. you for myself and for our two dear ones whose name day we are keeping.
1771. But mind you come to dinner or I shall be offended, ma chere! On
1772. behalf of the whole family I beg you to come, mon cher!" These words he
1773. repeated to everyone without exception or variation, and with the same
1774. expression on his full, cheerful, clean-shaven face, the same firm
1775. pressure of the hand and the same quick, repeated bows. As soon as he
1776. had seen a visitor off he returned to one of those who were still in the
1777. drawing room, drew a chair toward him or her, and jauntily spreading out
1778. his legs and putting his hands on his knees with the air of a man who
1779. enjoys life and knows how to live, he swayed to and fro with dignity,
1780. offered surmises about the weather, or touched on questions of health,
1781. sometimes in Russian and sometimes in very bad but self-confident
1782. French; then again, like a man weary but unflinching in the fulfillment
1783. of duty, he rose to see some visitors off and, stroking his scanty gray
1784. hairs over his bald patch, also asked them to dinner. Sometimes on his
1785. way back from the anteroom he would pass through the conservatory and
1786. pantry into the large marble dining hall, where tables were being set
1787. out for eighty people; and looking at the footmen, who were bringing in
1788. silver and china, moving tables, and unfolding damask table linen, he
1789. would call Dmitri Vasilevich, a man of good family and the manager of
1790. all his affairs, and while looking with pleasure at the enormous table
1791. would say: "Well, Dmitri, you'll see that things are all as they should
1792. be? That's right! The great thing is the serving, that's it." And with a
1793. complacent sigh he would return to the drawing room.
1794. 
1795. "Marya Lvovna Karagina and her daughter!" announced the countess'
1796. gigantic footman in his bass voice, entering the drawing room. The
1797. countess reflected a moment and took a pinch from a gold snuffbox with
1798. her husband's portrait on it.
1799. 
1800. "I'm quite worn out by these callers. However, I'll see her and no more.
1801. She is so affected. Ask her in," she said to the footman in a sad voice,
1802. as if saying: "Very well, finish me off."
1803. 
1804. A tall, stout, and proud-looking woman, with a round-faced smiling
1805. daughter, entered the drawing room, their dresses rustling.
1806. 
1807. "Dear Countess, what an age... She has been laid up, poor child...
1808. at the Razumovski's ball... and Countess Apraksina... I was so
1809. delighted..." came the sounds of animated feminine voices, interrupting
1810. one another and mingling with the rustling of dresses and the scraping
1811. of chairs. Then one of those conversations began which last out until,
1812. at the first pause, the guests rise with a rustle of dresses and say,
1813. "I am so delighted... Mamma's health... and Countess Apraksina..." and
1814. then, again rustling, pass into the anteroom, put on cloaks or mantles,
1815. and drive away. The conversation was on the chief topic of the day: the
1816. illness of the wealthy and celebrated beau of Catherine's day, Count
1817. Bezukhov, and about his illegitimate son Pierre, the one who had behaved
1818. so improperly at Anna Pavlovna's reception.
1819. 
1820. "I am so sorry for the poor count," said the visitor. "He is in such bad
1821. health, and now this vexation about his son is enough to kill him!"
1822. 
1823. "What is that?" asked the countess as if she did not know what the
1824. visitor alluded to, though she had already heard about the cause of
1825. Count Bezukhov's distress some fifteen times.
1826. 
1827. "That's what comes of a modern education," exclaimed the visitor. "It
1828. seems that while he was abroad this young man was allowed to do as he
1829. liked, now in Petersburg I hear he has been doing such terrible things
1830. that he has been expelled by the police."
1831. 
1832. "You don't say so!" replied the countess.
1833. 
1834. "He chose his friends badly," interposed Anna Mikhaylovna. "Prince
1835. Vasili's son, he, and a certain Dolokhov have, it is said, been up to
1836. heaven only knows what! And they have had to suffer for it. Dolokhov
1837. has been degraded to the ranks and Bezukhov's son sent back to Moscow.
1838. Anatole Kuragin's father managed somehow to get his son's affair hushed
1839. up, but even he was ordered out of Petersburg."
1840. 
1841. "But what have they been up to?" asked the countess.
1842. 
1843. "They are regular brigands, especially Dolokhov," replied the visitor.
1844. "He is a son of Marya Ivanovna Dolokhova, such a worthy woman, but
1845. there, just fancy! Those three got hold of a bear somewhere, put it in a
1846. carriage, and set off with it to visit some actresses! The police tried
1847. to interfere, and what did the young men do? They tied a policeman and
1848. the bear back to back and put the bear into the Moyka Canal. And there
1849. was the bear swimming about with the policeman on his back!"
1850. 
1851. "What a nice figure the policeman must have cut, my dear!" shouted the
1852. count, dying with laughter.
1853. 
1854. "Oh, how dreadful! How can you laugh at it, Count?"
1855. 
1856. Yet the ladies themselves could not help laughing.
1857. 
1858. "It was all they could do to rescue the poor man," continued the
1859. visitor. "And to think it is Cyril Vladimirovich Bezukhov's son who
1860. amuses himself in this sensible manner! And he was said to be so well
1861. educated and clever. This is all that his foreign education has done for
1862. him! I hope that here in Moscow no one will receive him, in spite of his
1863. money. They wanted to introduce him to me, but I quite declined: I have
1864. my daughters to consider."
1865. 
1866. "Why do you say this young man is so rich?" asked the countess, turning
1867. away from the girls, who at once assumed an air of inattention. "His
1868. children are all illegitimate. I think Pierre also is illegitimate."
1869. 
1870. The visitor made a gesture with her hand.
1871. 
1872. "I should think he has a score of them."
1873. 
1874. Princess Anna Mikhaylovna intervened in the conversation, evidently
1875. wishing to show her connections and knowledge of what went on in
1876. society.
1877. 
1878. "The fact of the matter is," said she significantly, and also in a half
1879. whisper, "everyone knows Count Cyril's reputation.... He has lost count
1880. of his children, but this Pierre was his favorite."
1881. 
1882. "How handsome the old man still was only a year ago!" remarked the
1883. countess. "I have never seen a handsomer man."
1884. 
1885. "He is very much altered now," said Anna Mikhaylovna. "Well, as I was
1886. saying, Prince Vasili is the next heir through his wife, but the count
1887. is very fond of Pierre, looked after his education, and wrote to the
1888. Emperor about him; so that in the case of his death--and he is so
1889. ill that he may die at any moment, and Dr. Lorrain has come from
1890. Petersburg--no one knows who will inherit his immense fortune, Pierre
1891. or Prince Vasili. Forty thousand serfs and millions of rubles! I know
1892. it all very well for Prince Vasili told me himself. Besides, Cyril
1893. Vladimirovich is my mother's second cousin. He's also my Bory's
1894. godfather," she added, as if she attached no importance at all to the
1895. fact.
1896. 
1897. "Prince Vasili arrived in Moscow yesterday. I hear he has come on some
1898. inspection business," remarked the visitor.
1899. 
1900. "Yes, but between ourselves," said the princess, "that is a pretext. The
1901. fact is he has come to see Count Cyril Vladimirovich, hearing how ill he
1902. is."
1903. 
1904. "But do you know, my dear, that was a capital joke," said the count; and
1905. seeing that the elder visitor was not listening, he turned to the young
1906. ladies. "I can just imagine what a funny figure that policeman cut!"
1907. 
1908. And as he waved his arms to impersonate the policeman, his portly form
1909. again shook with a deep ringing laugh, the laugh of one who always eats
1910. well and, in particular, drinks well. "So do come and dine with us!" he
1911. said.

1918. 
1919. 
1920. Silence ensued. The countess looked at her callers, smiling affably,
1921. but not concealing the fact that she would not be distressed if they now
1922. rose and took their leave. The visitor's daughter was already smoothing
1923. down her dress with an inquiring look at her mother, when suddenly from
1924. the next room were heard the footsteps of boys and girls running to
1925. the door and the noise of a chair falling over, and a girl of thirteen,
1926. hiding something in the folds of her short muslin frock, darted in and
1927. stopped short in the middle of the room. It was evident that she had
1928. not intended her flight to bring her so far. Behind her in the doorway
1929. appeared a student with a crimson coat collar, an officer of the Guards,
1930. a girl of fifteen, and a plump rosy-faced boy in a short jacket.
1931. 
1932. The count jumped up and, swaying from side to side, spread his arms wide
1933. and threw them round the little girl who had run in.
1934. 
1935. "Ah, here she is!" he exclaimed laughing. "My pet, whose name day it is.
1936. My dear pet!"
1937. 
1938. "Ma chere, there is a time for everything," said the countess with
1939. feigned severity. "You spoil her, Ilya," she added, turning to her
1940. husband.
1941. 
1942. "How do you do, my dear? I wish you many happy returns of your name
1943. day," said the visitor. "What a charming child," she added, addressing
1944. the mother.
1945. 
1946. This black-eyed, wide-mouthed girl, not pretty but full of life--with
1947. childish bare shoulders which after her run heaved and shook her
1948. bodice, with black curls tossed backward, thin bare arms, little legs
1949. in lace-frilled drawers, and feet in low slippers--was just at that
1950. charming age when a girl is no longer a child, though the child is not
1951. yet a young woman. Escaping from her father she ran to hide her
1952. flushed face in the lace of her mother's mantilla--not paying the least
1953. attention to her severe remark--and began to laugh. She laughed, and in
1954. fragmentary sentences tried to explain about a doll which she produced
1955. from the folds of her frock.
1956. 
1957. "Do you see?... My doll... Mimi... You see..." was all Natasha managed
1958. to utter (to her everything seemed funny). She leaned against her mother
1959. and burst into such a loud, ringing fit of laughter that even the prim
1960. visitor could not help joining in.
1961. 
1962. "Now then, go away and take your monstrosity with you," said the mother,
1963. pushing away her daughter with pretended sternness, and turning to the
1964. visitor she added: "She is my youngest girl."
1965. 
1966. Natasha, raising her face for a moment from her mother's mantilla,
1967. glanced up at her through tears of laughter, and again hid her face.
1968. 
1969. The visitor, compelled to look on at this family scene, thought it
1970. necessary to take some part in it.
1971. 
1972. "Tell me, my dear," said she to Natasha, "is Mimi a relation of yours? A
1973. daughter, I suppose?"
1974. 
1975. Natasha did not like the visitor's tone of condescension to childish
1976. things. She did not reply, but looked at her seriously.
1977. 
1978. Meanwhile the younger generation: Boris, the officer, Anna Mikhaylovna's
1979. son; Nicholas, the undergraduate, the count's eldest son; Sonya, the
1980. count's fifteen-year-old niece, and little Petya, his youngest boy,
1981. had all settled down in the drawing room and were obviously trying to
1982. restrain within the bounds of decorum the excitement and mirth that
1983. shone in all their faces. Evidently in the back rooms, from which they
1984. had dashed out so impetuously, the conversation had been more amusing
1985. than the drawing-room talk of society scandals, the weather, and
1986. Countess Apraksina. Now and then they glanced at one another, hardly
1987. able to suppress their laughter.
1988. 
1989. The two young men, the student and the officer, friends from childhood,
1990. were of the same age and both handsome fellows, though not alike. Boris
1991. was tall and fair, and his calm and handsome face had regular, delicate
1992. features. Nicholas was short with curly hair and an open expression.
1993. Dark hairs were already showing on his upper lip, and his whole face
1994. expressed impetuosity and enthusiasm. Nicholas blushed when he entered
1995. the drawing room. He evidently tried to find something to say, but
1996. failed. Boris on the contrary at once found his footing, and related
1997. quietly and humorously how he had known that doll Mimi when she was
1998. still quite a young lady, before her nose was broken; how she had aged
1999. during the five years he had known her, and how her head had cracked
2000. right across the skull. Having said this he glanced at Natasha. She
2001. turned away from him and glanced at her younger brother, who was
2002. screwing up his eyes and shaking with suppressed laughter, and unable
2003. to control herself any longer, she jumped up and rushed from the room as
2004. fast as her nimble little feet would carry her. Boris did not laugh.
2005. 
2006. "You were meaning to go out, weren't you, Mamma? Do you want the
2007. carriage?" he asked his mother with a smile.
2008. 
2009. "Yes, yes, go and tell them to get it ready," she answered, returning
2010. his smile.
2011. 
2012. Boris quietly left the room and went in search of Natasha. The plump
2013. boy ran after them angrily, as if vexed that their program had been
2014. disturbed.
2015.

2020. CHAPTER XII
2021. 
2022. 
2023. The only young people remaining in the drawing room, not counting the
2024. young lady visitor and the countess' eldest daughter (who was four years
2025. older than her sister and behaved already like a grown-up person), were
2026. Nicholas and Sonya, the niece. Sonya was a slender little brunette with
2027. a tender look in her eyes which were veiled by long lashes, thick black
2028. plaits coiling twice round her head, and a tawny tint in her complexion
2029. and especially in the color of her slender but graceful and muscular
2030. arms and neck. By the grace of her movements, by the softness and
2031. flexibility of her small limbs, and by a certain coyness and reserve of
2032. manner, she reminded one of a pretty, half-grown kitten which promises
2033. to become a beautiful little cat. She evidently considered it proper to
2034. show an interest in the general conversation by smiling, but in spite
2035. of herself her eyes under their thick long lashes watched her cousin who
2036. was going to join the army, with such passionate girlish adoration that
2037. her smile could not for a single instant impose upon anyone, and it
2038. was clear that the kitten had settled down only to spring up with more
2039. energy and again play with her cousin as soon as they too could, like
2040. Natasha and Boris, escape from the drawing room.
2041. 
2042. "Ah yes, my dear," said the count, addressing the visitor and pointing
2043. to Nicholas, "his friend Boris has become an officer, and so for
2044. friendship's sake he is leaving the university and me, his old father,
2045. and entering the military service, my dear. And there was a place
2046. and everything waiting for him in the Archives Department! Isn't that
2047. friendship?" remarked the count in an inquiring tone.
2048. 
2049. "But they say that war has been declared," replied the visitor.
2050. 
2051. "They've been saying so a long while," said the count, "and they'll say
2052. so again and again, and that will be the end of it. My dear, there's
2053. friendship for you," he repeated. "He's joining the hussars."
2054. 
2055. The visitor, not knowing what to say, shook her head.
2056. 
2057. "It's not at all from friendship," declared Nicholas, flaring up and
2058. turning away as if from a shameful aspersion. "It is not from friendship
2059. at all; I simply feel that the army is my vocation."
2060. 
2061. He glanced at his cousin and the young lady visitor; and they were both
2062. regarding him with a smile of approbation.
2063. 
2064. "Schubert, the colonel of the Pavlograd Hussars, is dining with us
2065. today. He has been here on leave and is taking Nicholas back with
2066. him. It can't be helped!" said the count, shrugging his shoulders and
2067. speaking playfully of a matter that evidently distressed him.
2068. 
2069. "I have already told you, Papa," said his son, "that if you don't wish
2070. to let me go, I'll stay. But I know I am no use anywhere except in the
2071. army; I am not a diplomat or a government clerk.--I don't know how to
2072. hide what I feel." As he spoke he kept glancing with the flirtatiousness
2073. of a handsome youth at Sonya and the young lady visitor.
2074. 
2075. The little kitten, feasting her eyes on him, seemed ready at any moment
2076. to start her gambols again and display her kittenish nature.
2077. 
2078. "All right, all right!" said the old count. "He always flares up! This
2079. Buonaparte has turned all their heads; they all think of how he rose
2080. from an ensign and became Emperor. Well, well, God grant it," he added,
2081. not noticing his visitor's sarcastic smile.
2082. 
2083. The elders began talking about Bonaparte. Julie Karagina turned to young
2084. Rostov.
2085. 
2086. "What a pity you weren't at the Arkharovs' on Thursday. It was so dull
2087. without you," said she, giving him a tender smile.
2088. 
2089. The young man, flattered, sat down nearer to her with a coquettish
2090. smile, and engaged the smiling Julie in a confidential conversation
2091. without at all noticing that his involuntary smile had stabbed the heart
2092. of Sonya, who blushed and smiled unnaturally. In the midst of his talk
2093. he glanced round at her. She gave him a passionately angry glance, and
2094. hardly able to restrain her tears and maintain the artificial smile
2095. on her lips, she got up and left the room. All Nicholas' animation
2096. vanished. He waited for the first pause in the conversation, and then
2097. with a distressed face left the room to find Sonya.
2098. 
2099. "How plainly all these young people wear their hearts on their
2100. sleeves!" said Anna Mikhaylovna, pointing to Nicholas as he went out.
2101. "Cousinage--dangereux voisinage;" * she added.
2102. 
2103. 
2104.      * Cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood.
2105. 
2106. 
2107. "Yes," said the countess when the brightness these young people had
2108. brought into the room had vanished; and as if answering a question no
2109. one had put but which was always in her mind, "and how much suffering,
2110. how much anxiety one has had to go through that we might rejoice in
2111. them now! And yet really the anxiety is greater now than the joy. One is
2112. always, always anxious! Especially just at this age, so dangerous both
2113. for girls and boys."
2114. 
2115. "It all depends on the bringing up," remarked the visitor.
2116. 
2117. "Yes, you're quite right," continued the countess. "Till now I have
2118. always, thank God, been my children's friend and had their full
2119. confidence," said she, repeating the mistake of so many parents who
2120. imagine that their children have no secrets from them. "I know I shall
2121. always be my daughters' first confidante, and that if Nicholas, with his
2122. impulsive nature, does get into mischief (a boy can't help it), he will
2123. all the same never be like those Petersburg young men."
2124. 
2125. "Yes, they are splendid, splendid youngsters," chimed in the count, who
2126. always solved questions that seemed to him perplexing by deciding that
2127. everything was splendid. "Just fancy: wants to be an hussar. What's one
2128. to do, my dear?"
2129. 
2130. "What a charming creature your younger girl is," said the visitor; "a
2131. little volcano!"
2132. 
2133. "Yes, a regular volcano," said the count. "Takes after me! And what a
2134. voice she has; though she's my daughter, I tell the truth when I say
2135. she'll be a singer, a second Salomoni! We have engaged an Italian to
2136. give her lessons."
2137. 
2138. "Isn't she too young? I have heard that it harms the voice to train it
2139. at that age."
2140. 
2141. "Oh no, not at all too young!" replied the count. "Why, our mothers used
2142. to be married at twelve or thirteen."
2143. 
2144. "And she's in love with Boris already. Just fancy!" said the countess
2145. with a gentle smile, looking at Boris' and went on, evidently concerned
2146. with a thought that always occupied her: "Now you see if I were to be
2147. severe with her and to forbid it... goodness knows what they might be up
2148. to on the sly" (she meant that they would be kissing), "but as it is,
2149. I know every word she utters. She will come running to me of her own
2150. accord in the evening and tell me everything. Perhaps I spoil her, but
2151. really that seems the best plan. With her elder sister I was stricter."
2152. 
2153. "Yes, I was brought up quite differently," remarked the handsome elder
2154. daughter, Countess Vera, with a smile.
2155. 
2156. But the smile did not enhance Vera's beauty as smiles generally do;
2157. on the contrary it gave her an unnatural, and therefore unpleasant,
2158. expression. Vera was good-looking, not at all stupid, quick at learning,
2159. was well brought up, and had a pleasant voice; what she said was
2160. true and appropriate, yet, strange to say, everyone--the visitors and
2161. countess alike--turned to look at her as if wondering why she had said
2162. it, and they all felt awkward.
2163. 
2164. "People are always too clever with their eldest children and try to make
2165. something exceptional of them," said the visitor.
2166. 
2167. "What's the good of denying it, my dear? Our dear countess was too
2168. clever with Vera," said the count. "Well, what of that? She's turned out
2169. splendidly all the same," he added, winking at Vera.
2170. 
2171. The guests got up and took their leave, promising to return to dinner.
2172. 
2173. "What manners! I thought they would never go," said the countess, when
2174. she had seen her guests out.
2175. 
2176. 
2177. 
2178. 
2179. 
2180. CHAPTER XIII
2181. 
2182. 
2183. When Natasha ran out of the drawing room she only went as far as the
2184. conservatory. There she paused and stood listening to the conversation
2185. in the drawing room, waiting for Boris to come out. She was already
2186. growing impatient, and stamped her foot, ready to cry at his not coming
2187. at once, when she heard the young man's discreet steps approaching
2188. neither quickly nor slowly. At this Natasha dashed swiftly among the
2189. flower tubs and hid there.
2190. 
2191. Boris paused in the middle of the room, looked round, brushed a little
2192. dust from the sleeve of his uniform, and going up to a mirror examined
2193. his handsome face. Natasha, very still, peered out from her ambush,
2194. waiting to see what he would do. He stood a little while before the
2195. glass, smiled, and walked toward the other door. Natasha was about
2196. to call him but changed her mind. "Let him look for me," thought she.
2197. Hardly had Boris gone than Sonya, flushed, in tears, and muttering
2198. angrily, came in at the other door. Natasha checked her first impulse to
2199. run out to her, and remained in her hiding place, watching--as under an
2200. invisible cap--to see what went on in the world. She was experiencing
2201. a new and peculiar pleasure. Sonya, muttering to herself, kept looking
2202. round toward the drawing-room door. It opened and Nicholas came in.
2203. 
2204. "Sonya, what is the matter with you? How can you?" said he, running up
2205. to her.
2206. 
2207. "It's nothing, nothing; leave me alone!" sobbed Sonya.
2208. 
2209. "Ah, I know what it is."
2210. 
2211. "Well, if you do, so much the better, and you can go back to her!"
2212. 
2213. "So-o-onya! Look here! How can you torture me and yourself like that,
2214. for a mere fancy?" said Nicholas taking her hand.
2215. 
2216. Sonya did not pull it away, and left off crying. Natasha, not stirring
2217. and scarcely breathing, watched from her ambush with sparkling eyes.
2218. "What will happen now?" thought she.
2219. 
2220. "Sonya! What is anyone in the world to me? You alone are everything!"
2221. said Nicholas. "And I will prove it to you."
2222. 
2223. "I don't like you to talk like that."
2224. 
2225. "Well, then, I won't; only forgive me, Sonya!" He drew her to him and
2226. kissed her.
2227. 
2228. "Oh, how nice," thought Natasha; and when Sonya and Nicholas had gone
2229. out of the conservatory she followed and called Boris to her.
2230. 
2231. "Boris, come here," said she with a sly and significant look. "I
2232. have something to tell you. Here, here!" and she led him into the
2233. conservatory to the place among the tubs where she had been hiding.
2234. 
2235. Boris followed her, smiling.
2236. 
2237. "What is the something?" asked he.
2238. 
2239. She grew confused, glanced round, and, seeing the doll she had thrown
2240. down on one of the tubs, picked it up.
2241. 
2242. "Kiss the doll," said she.
2243. 
2244. Boris looked attentively and kindly at her eager face, but did not
2245. reply.
2246. 
2247. "Don't you want to? Well, then, come here," said she, and went further
2248. in among the plants and threw down the doll. "Closer, closer!" she
2249. whispered.
2250. 
2251. She caught the young officer by his cuffs, and a look of solemnity and
2252. fear appeared on her flushed face.
2253. 
2254. "And me? Would you like to kiss me?" she whispered almost inaudibly,
2255. glancing up at him from under her brows, smiling, and almost crying from
2256. excitement.
2257. 
2258. Boris blushed.
2259. 
2260. "How funny you are!" he said, bending down to her and blushing still
2261. more, but he waited and did nothing.
2262. 
2263. Suddenly she jumped up onto a tub to be higher than he, embraced him so
2264. that both her slender bare arms clasped him above his neck, and, tossing
2265. back her hair, kissed him full on the lips.
2266. 
2267. Then she slipped down among the flowerpots on the other side of the tubs
2268. and stood, hanging her head.
2269. 
2270. "Natasha," he said, "you know that I love you, but..."
2271. 
2272. "You are in love with me?" Natasha broke in.
2273. 
2274. "Yes, I am, but please don't let us do like that.... In another four
2275. years... then I will ask for your hand."
2276. 
2277. Natasha considered.
2278. 
2279. "Thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen," she counted on her slender
2280. little fingers. "All right! Then it's settled?"
2281. 
2282. A smile of joy and satisfaction lit up her eager face.
2283. 
2284. "Settled!" replied Boris.
2285. 
2286. "Forever?" said the little girl. "Till death itself?"
2287. 
2288. She took his arm and with a happy face went with him into the adjoining
2289. sitting room.
2290. 
2291. 
2292. 
2293. 
2294. 
2295. CHAPTER XIV
2296. 
2297. 
2298. After receiving her visitors, the countess was so tired that she gave
2299. orders to admit no more, but the porter was told to be sure to invite
2300. to dinner all who came "to congratulate." The countess wished to have
2301. a tete-a-tete talk with the friend of her childhood, Princess Anna
2302. Mikhaylovna, whom she had not seen properly since she returned from
2303. Petersburg. Anna Mikhaylovna, with her tear-worn but pleasant face, drew
2304. her chair nearer to that of the countess.
2305. 
2306. "With you I will be quite frank," said Anna Mikhaylovna. "There are not
2307. many left of us old friends! That's why I so value your friendship."
2308. 
2309. Anna Mikhaylovna looked at Vera and paused. The countess pressed her
2310. friend's hand.
2311. 
2312. "Vera," she said to her eldest daughter who was evidently not a
2313. favorite, "how is it you have so little tact? Don't you see you are not
2314. wanted here? Go to the other girls, or..."
2315. 
2316. The handsome Vera smiled contemptuously but did not seem at all hurt.
2317. 
2318. "If you had told me sooner, Mamma, I would have gone," she replied as
2319. she rose to go to her own room.
2320. 
2321. But as she passed the sitting room she noticed two couples sitting,
2322. one pair at each window. She stopped and smiled scornfully. Sonya was
2323. sitting close to Nicholas who was copying out some verses for her, the
2324. first he had ever written. Boris and Natasha were at the other window
2325. and ceased talking when Vera entered. Sonya and Natasha looked at Vera
2326. with guilty, happy faces.
2327. 
2328. It was pleasant and touching to see these little girls in love; but
2329. apparently the sight of them roused no pleasant feeling in Vera.
2330. 
2331. "How often have I asked you not to take my things?" she said. "You have
2332. a room of your own," and she took the inkstand from Nicholas.
2333. 
2334. "In a minute, in a minute," he said, dipping his pen.
2335. 
2336. "You always manage to do things at the wrong time," continued Vera.
2337. "You came rushing into the drawing room so that everyone felt ashamed of
2338. you."
2339. 
2340. Though what she said was quite just, perhaps for that very reason no one
2341. replied, and the four simply looked at one another. She lingered in the
2342. room with the inkstand in her hand.
2343. 
2344. "And at your age what secrets can there be between Natasha and Boris, or
2345. between you two? It's all nonsense!"
2346. 
2347. "Now, Vera, what does it matter to you?" said Natasha in defense,
2348. speaking very gently.
2349. 
2350. She seemed that day to be more than ever kind and affectionate to
2351. everyone.
2352. 
2353. "Very silly," said Vera. "I am ashamed of you. Secrets indeed!"
2354. 
2355. "All have secrets of their own," answered Natasha, getting warmer. "We
2356. don't interfere with you and Berg."
2357. 
2358. "I should think not," said Vera, "because there can never be anything
2359. wrong in my behavior. But I'll just tell Mamma how you are behaving with
2360. Boris."
2361. 
2362. "Natalya Ilynichna behaves very well to me," remarked Boris. "I have
2363. nothing to complain of."
2364. 
2365. "Don't, Boris! You are such a diplomat that it is really tiresome," said
2366. Natasha in a mortified voice that trembled slightly. (She used the word
2367. "diplomat," which was just then much in vogue among the children, in the
2368. special sense they attached to it.) "Why does she bother me?" And she
2369. added, turning to Vera, "You'll never understand it, because you've
2370. never loved anyone. You have no heart! You are a Madame de Genlis
2371. and nothing more" (this nickname, bestowed on Vera by Nicholas,
2372. was considered very stinging), "and your greatest pleasure is to be
2373. unpleasant to people! Go and flirt with Berg as much as you please," she
2374. finished quickly.
2375. 
2376. "I shall at any rate not run after a young man before visitors..."
2377. 
2378. "Well, now you've done what you wanted," put in Nicholas--"said
2379. unpleasant things to everyone and upset them. Let's go to the nursery."
2380. 
2381. All four, like a flock of scared birds, got up and left the room.
2382. 
2383. "The unpleasant things were said to me," remarked Vera, "I said none to
2384. anyone."
2385. 
2386. "Madame de Genlis! Madame de Genlis!" shouted laughing voices through
2387. the door.
2388. 
2389. The handsome Vera, who produced such an irritating and unpleasant effect
2390. on everyone, smiled and, evidently unmoved by what had been said to her,
2391. went to the looking glass and arranged her hair and scarf. Looking at
2392. her own handsome face she seemed to become still colder and calmer.
2393. 
2394. 
2395. In the drawing room the conversation was still going on.
2396. 
2397. "Ah, my dear," said the countess, "my life is not all roses either.
2398. Don't I know that at the rate we are living our means won't last long?
2399. It's all the Club and his easygoing nature. Even in the country do we
2400. get any rest? Theatricals, hunting, and heaven knows what besides! But
2401. don't let's talk about me; tell me how you managed everything. I often
2402. wonder at you, Annette--how at your age you can rush off alone in a
2403. carriage to Moscow, to Petersburg, to those ministers and great people,
2404. and know how to deal with them all! It's quite astonishing. How did you
2405. get things settled? I couldn't possibly do it."
2406. 
2407. "Ah, my love," answered Anna Mikhaylovna, "God grant you never know
2408. what it is to be left a widow without means and with a son you love
2409. to distraction! One learns many things then," she added with a certain
2410. pride. "That lawsuit taught me much. When I want to see one of those big
2411. people I write a note: 'Princess So-and-So desires an interview with
2412. So and-So,' and then I take a cab and go myself two, three, or four
2413. times--till I get what I want. I don't mind what they think of me."
2414. 
2415. "Well, and to whom did you apply about Bory?" asked the countess. "You
2416. see yours is already an officer in the Guards, while my Nicholas is
2417. going as a cadet. There's no one to interest himself for him. To whom
2418. did you apply?"
2419. 
2420. "To Prince Vasili. He was so kind. He at once agreed to everything,
2421. and put the matter before the Emperor," said Princess Anna Mikhaylovna
2422. enthusiastically, quite forgetting all the humiliation she had endured
2423. to gain her end.
2424. 
2425. "Has Prince Vasili aged much?" asked the countess. "I have not seen him
2426. since we acted together at the Rumyantsovs' theatricals. I expect he has
2427. forgotten me. He paid me attentions in those days," said the countess,
2428. with a smile.
2429. 
2430. "He is just the same as ever," replied Anna Mikhaylovna, "overflowing
2431. with amiability. His position has not turned his head at all. He said to
2432. me, 'I am sorry I can do so little for you, dear Princess. I am at
2433. your command.' Yes, he is a fine fellow and a very kind relation.
2434. But, Nataly, you know my love for my son: I would do anything for his
2435. happiness! And my affairs are in such a bad way that my position is now
2436. a terrible one," continued Anna Mikhaylovna, sadly, dropping her voice.
2437. "My wretched lawsuit takes all I have and makes no progress. Would you
2438. believe it, I have literally not a penny and don't know how to equip
2439. Boris." She took out her handkerchief and began to cry. "I need five
2440. hundred rubles, and have only one twenty-five-ruble note. I am in such a
2441. state.... My only hope now is in Count Cyril Vladimirovich Bezukhov.
2442. If he will not assist his godson--you know he is Bory's godfather--and
2443. allow him something for his maintenance, all my trouble will have been
2444. thrown away.... I shall not be able to equip him."
2445. 
2446. The countess' eyes filled with tears and she pondered in silence.
2447. 
2448. "I often think, though, perhaps it's a sin," said the princess, "that
2449. here lives Count Cyril Vladimirovich Bezukhov so rich, all alone... that
2450. tremendous fortune... and what is his life worth? It's a burden to him,
2451. and Bory's life is only just beginning...."
2452. 
2453. "Surely he will leave something to Boris," said the countess.
2454. 
2455. "Heaven only knows, my dear! These rich grandees are so selfish. Still,
2456. I will take Boris and go to see him at once, and I shall speak to him
2457. straight out. Let people think what they will of me, it's really all the
2458. same to me when my son's fate is at stake." The princess rose. "It's now
2459. two o'clock and you dine at four. There will just be time."
2460. 
2461. And like a practical Petersburg lady who knows how to make the most of
2462. time, Anna Mikhaylovna sent someone to call her son, and went into the
2463. anteroom with him.
2464. 
2465. "Good-by, my dear," said she to the countess who saw her to the door,
2466. and added in a whisper so that her son should not hear, "Wish me good
2467. luck."
2468. 
2469. "Are you going to Count Cyril Vladimirovich, my dear?" said the count
2470. coming out from the dining hall into the anteroom, and he added: "If
2471. he is better, ask Pierre to dine with us. He has been to the house, you
2472. know, and danced with the children. Be sure to invite him, my dear.
2473. We will see how Taras distinguishes himself today. He says Count Orlov
2474. never gave such a dinner as ours will be!"
2475. 
2476. 
2477. 
2478. 
2479. 
2480. CHAPTER XV
2481. 
2482. 
2483. "My dear Boris," said Princess Anna Mikhaylovna to her son as Countess

2489. Cyril Vladimirovich is your godfather after all, your future depends on

2491. to be."
2492. 
2493. "If only I knew that anything besides humiliation would come of it..."
2494. answered her son coldly. "But I have promised and will do it for your
2495. sake."
2496. 
2497. Although the hall porter saw someone's carriage standing at the
2498. entrance, after scrutinizing the mother and son (who without asking to
2499. be announced had passed straight through the glass porch between the
2500. rows of statues in niches) and looking significantly at the lady's old
2501. cloak, he asked whether they wanted the count or the princesses, and,
2502. hearing that they wished to see the count, said his excellency was worse
2503. today, and that his excellency was not receiving anyone.
2504. 
2505. "We may as well go back," said the son in French.
2506. 
2507. "My dear!" exclaimed his mother imploringly, again laying her hand on
2508. his arm as if that touch might soothe or rouse him.
2509. 
2510. Boris said no more, but looked inquiringly at his mother without taking

2512. 
2513. "My friend," said Anna Mikhaylovna in gentle tones, addressing the hall

2515. have come... I am a relation. I shall not disturb him, my friend... I

2517. Please announce me."
2518. 
2519. The hall porter sullenly pulled a bell that rang upstairs, and turned

2521. 
2522. "Princess Drubetskaya to see Prince Vasili Sergeevich," he called to a
2523. footman dressed in knee breeches, shoes, and a swallow-tail coat, who

2525. 
2526. The mother smoothed the folds of her dyed silk dress before a large

2529. 
2530. "My dear," she said to her son, once more stimulating him by a touch,
2531. "you promised me!"
2532. 
2533. The son, lowering his eyes, followed her quietly.
2534. 
2535. They entered the large hall, from which one of the doors led to the
2536. apartments assigned to Prince Vasili.
2537. 
2538. Just as the mother and son, having reached the middle of the hall, were
2539. about to ask their way of an elderly footman who had sprung up as they

2544. 
2545. "Then it is certain?" said the prince.
2546. 
2547. "Prince, humanum est errare, * but..." replied the doctor, swallowing
2548. his r's, and pronouncing the Latin words with a French accent.
2549. 
2550. 
2551.      * To err is human.
2552. 
2553. 
2554. "Very well, very well..."
2555. 
2556. Seeing Anna Mikhaylovna and her son, Prince Vasili dismissed the doctor

2559. mother's face, and he smiled slightly.
2560. 
2561. "Ah, Prince! In what sad circumstances we meet again! And how is our
2562. dear invalid?" said she, as though unaware of the cold offensive look
2563. fixed on her.
2564. 
2565. Prince Vasili stared at her and at Boris questioningly and perplexed.

2569. 
2570. "Is it possible?" exclaimed Anna Mikhaylovna. "Oh, how awful! It is
2571. terrible to think.... This is my son," she added, indicating Boris. "He
2572. wanted to thank you himself."
2573. 
2574. Boris bowed again politely.
2575. 
2576. "Believe me, Prince, a mother's heart will never forget what you have
2577. done for us."
2578. 
2579. "I am glad I was able to do you a service, my dear Anna Mikhaylovna,"
2580. said Prince Vasili, arranging his lace frill, and in tone and manner,
2581. here in Moscow to Anna Mikhaylovna whom he had placed under an
2582. obligation, assuming an air of much greater importance than he had done
2583. in Petersburg at Anna Scherer's reception.
2584. 
2585. "Try to serve well and show yourself worthy," added he, addressing Boris
