2587. usual tone of indifference.
2588. 
2589. "I am awaiting orders to join my new regiment, your excellency," replied
2590. Boris, betraying neither annoyance at the prince's brusque manner nor
2591. a desire to enter into conversation, but speaking so quietly and
2592. respectfully that the prince gave him a searching glance.
2593. 
2594. "Are you living with your mother?"
2595. 
2596. "I am living at Countess Rostova's," replied Boris, again adding, "your
2597. excellency."
2598. 
2599. "That is, with Ilya Rostov who married Nataly Shinshina," said Anna
2600. Mikhaylovna.
2601. 
2602. "I know, I know," answered Prince Vasili in his monotonous voice.
2603. "I never could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that
2604. unlicked bear! A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a gambler too,
2605. I am told."
2606. 
2607. "But a very kind man, Prince," said Anna Mikhaylovna with a pathetic
2608. smile, as though she too knew that Count Rostov deserved this censure,
2609. but asked him not to be too hard on the poor old man. "What do the
2610. doctors say?" asked the princess after a pause, her worn face again
2611. expressing deep sorrow.
2612. 
2613. "They give little hope," replied the prince.
2614. 
2615. "And I should so like to thank Uncle once for all his kindness to me and
2616. Boris. He is his godson," she added, her tone suggesting that this fact
2617. ought to give Prince Vasili much satisfaction.
2618. 
2619. Prince Vasili became thoughtful and frowned. Anna Mikhaylovna saw that
2620. he was afraid of finding in her a rival for Count Bezukhov's fortune,
2621. and hastened to reassure him.
2622. 
2623. "If it were not for my sincere affection and devotion to Uncle," said
2624. she, uttering the word with peculiar assurance and unconcern, "I know
2625. his character: noble, upright... but you see he has no one with him
2626. except the young princesses.... They are still young...." She bent
2627. her head and continued in a whisper: "Has he performed his final duty,
2628. Prince? How priceless are those last moments! It can make things no
2629. worse, and it is absolutely necessary to prepare him if he is so ill. We
2630. women, Prince," and she smiled tenderly, "always know how to say these
2631. things. I absolutely must see him, however painful it may be for me. I
2632. am used to suffering."
2633. 
2634. Evidently the prince understood her, and also understood, as he had
2635. done at Anna Pavlovna's, that it would be difficult to get rid of Anna
2636. Mikhaylovna.
2637. 
2638. "Would not such a meeting be too trying for him, dear Anna Mikhaylovna?"
2639. said he. "Let us wait until evening. The doctors are expecting a
2640. crisis."
2641. 
2642. "But one cannot delay, Prince, at such a moment! Consider that the
2643. welfare of his soul is at stake. Ah, it is awful: the duties of a
2644. Christian..."
2645. 
2646. A door of one of the inner rooms opened and one of the princesses, the
2647. count's niece, entered with a cold, stern face. The length of her body
2648. was strikingly out of proportion to her short legs. Prince Vasili turned
2649. to her.
2650. 
2651. "Well, how is he?"
2652. 
2653. "Still the same; but what can you expect, this noise..." said the
2654. princess, looking at Anna Mikhaylovna as at a stranger.
2655. 
2656. "Ah, my dear, I hardly knew you," said Anna Mikhaylovna with a happy
2657. smile, ambling lightly up to the count's niece. "I have come, and am at
2658. your service to help you nurse my uncle. I imagine what you have gone
2659. through," and she sympathetically turned up her eyes.
2660. 
2661. The princess gave no reply and did not even smile, but left the room as
2662. Anna Mikhaylovna took off her gloves and, occupying the position she had
2663. conquered, settled down in an armchair, inviting Prince Vasili to take a
2664. seat beside her.
2665. 
2666. "Boris," she said to her son with a smile, "I shall go in to see the
2667. count, my uncle; but you, my dear, had better go to Pierre meanwhile
2668. and don't forget to give him the Rostovs' invitation. They ask him to
2669. dinner. I suppose he won't go?" she continued, turning to the prince.
2670. 
2671. "On the contrary," replied the prince, who had plainly become depressed,
2672. "I shall be only too glad if you relieve me of that young man.... Here
2673. he is, and the count has not once asked for him."
2674. 
2675. He shrugged his shoulders. A footman conducted Boris down one flight of
2676. stairs and up another, to Pierre's rooms.
2677. 
2678. 
2679. 
2680. 
2681. 
2682. CHAPTER XVI
2683. 
2684. 
2685. Pierre, after all, had not managed to choose a career for himself in
2686. Petersburg, and had been expelled from there for riotous conduct and
2687. sent to Moscow. The story told about him at Count Rostov's was true.
2688. Pierre had taken part in tying a policeman to a bear. He had now been
2689. for some days in Moscow and was staying as usual at his father's house.
2690. Though he expected that the story of his escapade would be already known
2691. in Moscow and that the ladies about his father--who were never favorably
2692. disposed toward him--would have used it to turn the count against him,
2693. he nevertheless on the day of his arrival went to his father's part of
2694. the house. Entering the drawing room, where the princesses spent most
2695. of their time, he greeted the ladies, two of whom were sitting at
2696. embroidery frames while a third read aloud. It was the eldest who was
2697. reading--the one who had met Anna Mikhaylovna. The two younger ones were
2698. embroidering: both were rosy and pretty and they differed only in that
2699. one had a little mole on her lip which made her much prettier. Pierre
2700. was received as if he were a corpse or a leper. The eldest princess
2701. paused in her reading and silently stared at him with frightened eyes;
2702. the second assumed precisely the same expression; while the youngest,
2703. the one with the mole, who was of a cheerful and lively disposition,
2704. bent over her frame to hide a smile probably evoked by the amusing scene
2705. she foresaw. She drew her wool down through the canvas and, scarcely
2706. able to refrain from laughing, stooped as if trying to make out the
2707. pattern.
2708. 
2709. "How do you do, cousin?" said Pierre. "You don't recognize me?"
2710. 
2711. "I recognize you only too well, too well."
2712. 
2713. "How is the count? Can I see him?" asked Pierre, awkwardly as usual, but
2714. unabashed.
2715. 
2716. "The count is suffering physically and mentally, and apparently you have
2717. done your best to increase his mental sufferings."
2718. 
2719. "Can I see the count?" Pierre again asked.
2720. 
2721. "Hm.... If you wish to kill him, to kill him outright, you can see
2722. him... Olga, go and see whether Uncle's beef tea is ready--it is almost
2723. time," she added, giving Pierre to understand that they were busy, and
2724. busy making his father comfortable, while evidently he, Pierre, was only
2725. busy causing him annoyance.
2726. 
2727. Olga went out. Pierre stood looking at the sisters; then he bowed and
2728. said: "Then I will go to my rooms. You will let me know when I can see
2729. him."
2730. 
2731. And he left the room, followed by the low but ringing laughter of the
2732. sister with the mole.
2733. 
2734. Next day Prince Vasili had arrived and settled in the count's house. He
2735. sent for Pierre and said to him: "My dear fellow, if you are going to
2736. behave here as you did in Petersburg, you will end very badly; that is
2737. all I have to say to you. The count is very, very ill, and you must not
2738. see him at all."
2739. 
2740. Since then Pierre had not been disturbed and had spent the whole time in
2741. his rooms upstairs.
2742. 
2743. When Boris appeared at his door Pierre was pacing up and down his room,
2744. stopping occasionally at a corner to make menacing gestures at the wall,
2745. as if running a sword through an invisible foe, and glaring savagely
2746. over his spectacles, and then again resuming his walk, muttering
2747. indistinct words, shrugging his shoulders and gesticulating.
2748. 
2749. "England is done for," said he, scowling and pointing his finger at
2750. someone unseen. "Mr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the rights
2751. of man, is sentenced to..." But before Pierre--who at that moment
2752. imagined himself to be Napoleon in person and to have just effected the
2753. dangerous crossing of the Straits of Dover and captured London--could
2754. pronounce Pitt's sentence, he saw a well-built and handsome young
2755. officer entering his room. Pierre paused. He had left Moscow when Boris
2756. was a boy of fourteen, and had quite forgotten him, but in his usual
2757. impulsive and hearty way he took Boris by the hand with a friendly
2758. smile.
2759. 
2760. "Do you remember me?" asked Boris quietly with a pleasant smile. "I have
2761. come with my mother to see the count, but it seems he is not well."
2762. 
2763. "Yes, it seems he is ill. People are always disturbing him," answered
2764. Pierre, trying to remember who this young man was.
2765. 
2766. Boris felt that Pierre did not recognize him but did not consider it
2767. necessary to introduce himself, and without experiencing the least
2768. embarrassment looked Pierre straight in the face.
2769. 
2770. "Count Rostov asks you to come to dinner today," said he, after a
2771. considerable pause which made Pierre feel uncomfortable.
2772. 
2773. "Ah, Count Rostov!" exclaimed Pierre joyfully. "Then you are his son,
2774. Ilya? Only fancy, I didn't know you at first. Do you remember how we
2775. went to the Sparrow Hills with Madame Jacquot?... It's such an age..."
2776. 
2777. "You are mistaken," said Boris deliberately, with a bold and slightly
2778. sarcastic smile. "I am Boris, son of Princess Anna Mikhaylovna
2779. Drubetskaya. Rostov, the father, is Ilya, and his son is Nicholas. I
2780. never knew any Madame Jacquot."
2781. 
2782. Pierre shook his head and arms as if attacked by mosquitoes or bees.
2783. 
2784. "Oh dear, what am I thinking about? I've mixed everything up. One has so
2785. many relatives in Moscow! So you are Boris? Of course. Well, now we
2786. know where we are. And what do you think of the Boulogne expedition?
2787. The English will come off badly, you know, if Napoleon gets across the
2788. Channel. I think the expedition is quite feasible. If only Villeneuve
2789. doesn't make a mess of things!"
2790. 
2791. Boris knew nothing about the Boulogne expedition; he did not read the
2792. papers and it was the first time he had heard Villeneuve's name.
2793. 
2794. "We here in Moscow are more occupied with dinner parties and scandal
2795. than with politics," said he in his quiet ironical tone. "I know nothing
2796. about it and have not thought about it. Moscow is chiefly busy with
2797. gossip," he continued. "Just now they are talking about you and your
2798. father."
2799. 
2800. Pierre smiled in his good-natured way as if afraid for his companion's
2801. sake that the latter might say something he would afterwards regret.
2802. But Boris spoke distinctly, clearly, and dryly, looking straight into
2803. Pierre's eyes.
2804. 
2805. "Moscow has nothing else to do but gossip," Boris went on. "Everybody
2806. is wondering to whom the count will leave his fortune, though he may
2807. perhaps outlive us all, as I sincerely hope he will..."
2808. 
2809. "Yes, it is all very horrid," interrupted Pierre, "very horrid."
2810. 
2811. Pierre was still afraid that this officer might inadvertently say
2812. something disconcerting to himself.
2813. 
2814. "And it must seem to you," said Boris flushing slightly, but not
2815. changing his tone or attitude, "it must seem to you that everyone is
2816. trying to get something out of the rich man?"
2817. 
2818. "So it does," thought Pierre.
2819. 
2820. "But I just wish to say, to avoid misunderstandings, that you are quite
2821. mistaken if you reckon me or my mother among such people. We are very
2822. poor, but for my own part at any rate, for the very reason that your
2823. father is rich, I don't regard myself as a relation of his, and neither
2824. I nor my mother would ever ask or take anything from him."
2825. 
2826. For a long time Pierre could not understand, but when he did, he jumped
2827. up from the sofa, seized Boris under the elbow in his quick, clumsy
2828. way, and, blushing far more than Boris, began to speak with a feeling of
2829. mingled shame and vexation.
2830. 
2831. "Well, this is strange! Do you suppose I... who could think?... I know
2832. very well..."
2833. 
2834. But Boris again interrupted him.
2835. 
2836. "I am glad I have spoken out fully. Perhaps you did not like it? You
2837. must excuse me," said he, putting Pierre at ease instead of being put
2838. at ease by him, "but I hope I have not offended you. I always make it
2839. a rule to speak out... Well, what answer am I to take? Will you come to
2840. dinner at the Rostovs'?"
2841. 
2842. And Boris, having apparently relieved himself of an onerous duty and
2843. extricated himself from an awkward situation and placed another in it,
2844. became quite pleasant again.
2845. 
2846. "No, but I say," said Pierre, calming down, "you are a wonderful fellow!
2847. What you have just said is good, very good. Of course you don't know me.
2848. We have not met for such a long time... not since we were children. You
2849. might think that I... I understand, quite understand. I could not have
2850. done it myself, I should not have had the courage, but it's splendid. I
2851. am very glad to have made your acquaintance. It's queer," he added after
2852. a pause, "that you should have suspected me!" He began to laugh. "Well,
2853. what of it! I hope we'll get better acquainted," and he pressed Boris'
2854. hand. "Do you know, I have not once been in to see the count. He has not
2855. sent for me.... I am sorry for him as a man, but what can one do?"
2856. 
2857. "And so you think Napoleon will manage to get an army across?" asked
2858. Boris with a smile.
2859. 
2860. Pierre saw that Boris wished to change the subject, and being of the
2861. same mind he began explaining the advantages and disadvantages of the
2862. Boulogne expedition.
2863. 
2864. A footman came in to summon Boris--the princess was going. Pierre, in
2865. order to make Boris' better acquaintance, promised to come to dinner,
2866. and warmly pressing his hand looked affectionately over his spectacles
2867. into Boris' eyes. After he had gone Pierre continued pacing up and down
2868. the room for a long time, no longer piercing an imaginary foe with
2869. his imaginary sword, but smiling at the remembrance of that pleasant,
2870. intelligent, and resolute young man.
2871. 
2872. As often happens in early youth, especially to one who leads a lonely
2873. life, he felt an unaccountable tenderness for this young man and made up
2874. his mind that they would be friends.
2875. 
2876. Prince Vasili saw the princess off. She held a handkerchief to her eyes
2877. and her face was tearful.
2878. 
2879. "It is dreadful, dreadful!" she was saying, "but cost me what it may I
2880. shall do my duty. I will come and spend the night. He must not be left
2881. like this. Every moment is precious. I can't think why his nieces put
2882. it off. Perhaps God will help me to find a way to prepare him!... Adieu,
2883. Prince! May God support you..."
2884. 
2885. "Adieu, ma bonne," answered Prince Vasili turning away from her.
2886. 
2887. "Oh, he is in a dreadful state," said the mother to her son when they
2888. were in the carriage. "He hardly recognizes anybody."
2889. 
2890. "I don't understand, Mamma--what is his attitude to Pierre?" asked the
2891. son.
2892. 
2893. "The will will show that, my dear; our fate also depends on it."
2894. 
2895. "But why do you expect that he will leave us anything?"
2896. 
2897. "Ah, my dear! He is so rich, and we are so poor!"
2898. 
2899. "Well, that is hardly a sufficient reason, Mamma..."
2900. 
2901. "Oh, Heaven! How ill he is!" exclaimed the mother.
2902. 
2903. 
2904. 
2905. 
2906. 
2907. CHAPTER XVII
2908. 
2909. 
2910. After Anna Mikhaylovna had driven off with her son to visit Count Cyril
2911. Vladimirovich Bezukhov, Countess Rostova sat for a long time all alone
2912. applying her handkerchief to her eyes. At last she rang.
2913. 
2914. "What is the matter with you, my dear?" she said crossly to the maid who
2915. kept her waiting some minutes. "Don't you wish to serve me? Then I'll
2916. find you another place."
2917. 
2918. The countess was upset by her friend's sorrow and humiliating poverty,
2919. and was therefore out of sorts, a state of mind which with her always
2920. found expression in calling her maid "my dear" and speaking to her with
2921. exaggerated politeness.
2922. 
2923. "I am very sorry, ma'am," answered the maid.
2924. 
2925. "Ask the count to come to me."
2926. 
2927. The count came waddling in to see his wife with a rather guilty look as
2928. usual.
2929. 
2930. "Well, little countess? What a saute of game au madere we are to have,
2931. my dear! I tasted it. The thousand rubles I paid for Taras were not
2932. ill-spent. He is worth it!"
2933. 
2934. He sat down by his wife, his elbows on his knees and his hands ruffling
2935. his gray hair.
2936. 
2937. "What are your commands, little countess?"
2938. 
2939. "You see, my dear... What's that mess?" she said, pointing to his
2940. waistcoat. "It's the saute, most likely," she added with a smile. "Well,
2941. you see, Count, I want some money."
2942. 
2943. Her face became sad.
2944. 
2945. "Oh, little countess!"... and the count began bustling to get out his
2946. pocketbook.
2947. 
2948. "I want a great deal, Count! I want five hundred rubles," and taking out
2949. her cambric handkerchief she began wiping her husband's waistcoat.
2950. 
2951. "Yes, immediately, immediately! Hey, who's there?" he called out in a
2952. tone only used by persons who are certain that those they call will rush
2953. to obey the summons. "Send Dmitri to me!"
2954. 
2955. Dmitri, a man of good family who had been brought up in the count's
2956. house and now managed all his affairs, stepped softly into the room.
2957. 
2958. "This is what I want, my dear fellow," said the count to the deferential
2959. young man who had entered. "Bring me..." he reflected a moment, "yes,
2960. bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don't bring me such
2961. tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones for the
2962. countess."
2963. 
2964. "Yes, Dmitri, clean ones, please," said the countess, sighing deeply.
2965. 
2966. "When would you like them, your excellency?" asked Dmitri. "Allow me to
2967. inform you... But, don't be uneasy," he added, noticing that the count
2968. was beginning to breathe heavily and quickly which was always a sign of
2969. approaching anger. "I was forgetting... Do you wish it brought at once?"
2970. 
2971. "Yes, yes; just so! Bring it. Give it to the countess."
2972. 
2973. "What a treasure that Dmitri is," added the count with a smile when
2974. the young man had departed. "There is never any 'impossible' with him.
2975. That's a thing I hate! Everything is possible."
2976. 
2977. "Ah, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world," said
2978. the countess. "But I am in great need of this sum."
2979. 
2980. "You, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift," said the count,
2981. and having kissed his wife's hand he went back to his study.
2982. 
2983. When Anna Mikhaylovna returned from Count Bezukhov's the money, all
2984. in clean notes, was lying ready under a handkerchief on the countess'
2985. little table, and Anna Mikhaylovna noticed that something was agitating
2986. her.
2987. 
2988. "Well, my dear?" asked the countess.
2989. 
2990. "Oh, what a terrible state he is in! One would not know him, he is so
2991. ill! I was only there a few moments and hardly said a word..."
2992. 
2993. "Annette, for heaven's sake don't refuse me," the countess began, with a
2994. blush that looked very strange on her thin, dignified, elderly face, and
2995. she took the money from under the handkerchief.
2996. 
2997. Anna Mikhaylovna instantly guessed her intention and stooped to be ready
2998. to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.
2999. 
3000. "This is for Boris from me, for his outfit."
3001. 
3002. Anna Mikhaylovna was already embracing her and weeping. The countess
3003. wept too. They wept because they were friends, and because they were
3004. kindhearted, and because they--friends from childhood--had to think
3005. about such a base thing as money, and because their youth was over....
3006. But those tears were pleasant to them both.
3007. 
3008. 
3009. 
3010. 
3011. 
3012. CHAPTER XVIII
3013. 
3014. 
3015. Countess Rostova, with her daughters and a large number of guests, was
3016. already seated in the drawing room. The count took the gentlemen into
3017. his study and showed them his choice collection of Turkish pipes.
3018. From time to time he went out to ask: "Hasn't she come yet?" They were
3019. expecting Marya Dmitrievna Akhrosimova, known in society as le terrible
3020. dragon, a lady distinguished not for wealth or rank, but for common
3021. sense and frank plainness of speech. Marya Dmitrievna was known to the
3022. Imperial family as well as to all Moscow and Petersburg, and both cities
3023. wondered at her, laughed privately at her rudenesses, and told good
3024. stories about her, while none the less all without exception respected
3025. and feared her.
3026. 
3027. In the count's room, which was full of tobacco smoke, they talked of war
3028. that had been announced in a manifesto, and about the recruiting. None
3029. of them had yet seen the manifesto, but they all knew it had appeared.
3030. The count sat on the sofa between two guests who were smoking and
3031. talking. He neither smoked nor talked, but bending his head first to one
3032. side and then to the other watched the smokers with evident pleasure
3033. and listened to the conversation of his two neighbors, whom he egged on
3034. against each other.
3035. 
3036. One of them was a sallow, clean-shaven civilian with a thin and wrinkled
3037. face, already growing old, though he was dressed like a most fashionable
3038. young man. He sat with his legs up on the sofa as if quite at home and,
3039. having stuck an amber mouthpiece far into his mouth, was inhaling the
3040. smoke spasmodically and screwing up his eyes. This was an old bachelor,
3041. Shinshin, a cousin of the countess', a man with "a sharp tongue" as they
3042. said in Moscow society. He seemed to be condescending to his companion.
3043. The latter, a fresh, rosy officer of the Guards, irreproachably washed,
3044. brushed, and buttoned, held his pipe in the middle of his mouth and with
3045. red lips gently inhaled the smoke, letting it escape from his handsome
3046. mouth in rings. This was Lieutenant Berg, an officer in the Semenov
3047. regiment with whom Boris was to travel to join the army, and about
3048. whom Natasha had, teased her elder sister Vera, speaking of Berg as her
3049. "intended." The count sat between them and listened attentively. His
3050. favorite occupation when not playing boston, a card game he was very
3051. fond of, was that of listener, especially when he succeeded in setting
3052. two loquacious talkers at one another.
3053. 
3054. "Well, then, old chap, mon tres honorable Alphonse Karlovich," said
3055. Shinshin, laughing ironically and mixing the most ordinary Russian
3056. expressions with the choicest French phrases--which was a peculiarity of
3057. his speech. "Vous comptez vous faire des rentes sur l'etat; * you want
3058. to make something out of your company?"
3059. 
3060. 
3061.      * You expect to make an income out of the government.
3062. 
3063. 
3064. "No, Peter Nikolaevich; I only want to show that in the cavalry the
3065. advantages are far less than in the infantry. Just consider my own
3066. position now, Peter Nikolaevich..."
3067. 
3068. Berg always spoke quietly, politely, and with great precision. His
3069. conversation always related entirely to himself; he would remain calm
3070. and silent when the talk related to any topic that had no direct bearing
3071. on himself. He could remain silent for hours without being at all put
3072. out of countenance himself or making others uncomfortable, but as
3073. soon as the conversation concerned himself he would begin to talk
3074. circumstantially and with evident satisfaction.
3075. 
3076. "Consider my position, Peter Nikolaevich. Were I in the cavalry I should
3077. get not more than two hundred rubles every four months, even with the
3078. rank of lieutenant; but as it is I receive two hundred and thirty," said
3079. he, looking at Shinshin and the count with a joyful, pleasant smile,
3080. as if it were obvious to him that his success must always be the chief
3081. desire of everyone else.
3082. 
3083. "Besides that, Peter Nikolaevich, by exchanging into the Guards I shall
3084. be in a more prominent position," continued Berg, "and vacancies occur
3085. much more frequently in the Foot Guards. Then just think what can be
3086. done with two hundred and thirty rubles! I even manage to put a little
3087. aside and to send something to my father," he went on, emitting a smoke
3088. ring.
3089. 
3090. "La balance y est... * A German knows how to skin a flint, as the
3091. proverb says," remarked Shinshin, moving his pipe to the other side of
3092. his mouth and winking at the count.
3093. 
3094. 
3095.       * So that squares matters.
3096. 
3097. 
3098. The count burst out laughing. The other guests seeing that Shinshin was
3099. talking came up to listen. Berg, oblivious of irony or indifference,
3100. continued to explain how by exchanging into the Guards he had already
3101. gained a step on his old comrades of the Cadet Corps; how in wartime
3102. the company commander might get killed and he, as senior in the company,
3103. might easily succeed to the post; how popular he was with everyone in
3104. the regiment, and how satisfied his father was with him. Berg evidently
3105. enjoyed narrating all this, and did not seem to suspect that others,
3106. too, might have their own interests. But all he said was so prettily
3107. sedate, and the naivete of his youthful egotism was so obvious, that he
3108. disarmed his hearers.
3109. 
3110. "Well, my boy, you'll get along wherever you go--foot or horse--that
3111. I'll warrant," said Shinshin, patting him on the shoulder and taking his
3112. feet off the sofa.
3113. 
3114. Berg smiled joyously. The count, by his guests, went into the drawing
3115. room.
3116. 
3117. It was just the moment before a big dinner when the assembled guests,
3118. expecting the summons to zakuska, * avoid engaging in any long
3119. conversation but think it necessary to move about and talk, in order
3120. to show that they are not at all impatient for their food. The host and
3121. hostess look toward the door, and now and then glance at one another,
3122. and the visitors try to guess from these glances who, or what, they are
3123. waiting for--some important relation who has not yet arrived, or a dish
3124. that is not yet ready.
3125. 
3126. 
3127.      * Hors d'oeuvres.
3128. 
3129. 
3130. Pierre had come just at dinnertime and was sitting awkwardly in the
3131. middle of the drawing room on the first chair he had come across,
3132. blocking the way for everyone. The countess tried to make him talk, but
3133. he went on naively looking around through his spectacles as if in search
3134. of somebody and answered all her questions in monosyllables. He was in
3135. the way and was the only one who did not notice the fact. Most of the
3136. guests, knowing of the affair with the bear, looked with curiosity at
3137. this big, stout, quiet man, wondering how such a clumsy, modest fellow
3138. could have played such a prank on a policeman.
3139. 
3140. "You have only lately arrived?" the countess asked him.
3141. 
3142. "Oui, madame," replied he, looking around him.
3143. 
3144. "You have not yet seen my husband?"
3145. 
3146. "Non, madame." He smiled quite inappropriately.
3147. 
3148. "You have been in Paris recently, I believe? I suppose it's very
3149. interesting."
3150. 
3151. "Very interesting."
3152. 
3153. The countess exchanged glances with Anna Mikhaylovna. The latter
3154. understood that she was being asked to entertain this young man, and
3155. sitting down beside him she began to speak about his father; but he
3156. answered her, as he had the countess, only in monosyllables. The other
3157. guests were all conversing with one another. "The Razumovskis... It was
3158. charming... You are very kind... Countess Apraksina..." was heard on all
3159. sides. The countess rose and went into the ballroom.
3160. 
3161. "Marya Dmitrievna?" came her voice from there.
3162. 
3163. "Herself," came the answer in a rough voice, and Marya Dmitrievna
3164. entered the room.
3165. 
3166. All the unmarried ladies and even the married ones except the very
3167. oldest rose. Marya Dmitrievna paused at the door. Tall and stout,
3168. holding high her fifty-year-old head with its gray curls, she stood
3169. surveying the guests, and leisurely arranged her wide sleeves as if
3170. rolling them up. Marya Dmitrievna always spoke in Russian.
3171. 
3172. "Health and happiness to her whose name day we are keeping and to her
3173. children," she said, in her loud, full-toned voice which drowned all
3174. others. "Well, you old sinner," she went on, turning to the count who
3175. was kissing her hand, "you're feeling dull in Moscow, I daresay? Nowhere
3176. to hunt with your dogs? But what is to be done, old man? Just see how
3177. these nestlings are growing up," and she pointed to the girls. "You must
3178. look for husbands for them whether you like it or not...."
3179. 
3180. "Well," said she, "how's my Cossack?" (Marya Dmitrievna always called
3181. Natasha a Cossack) and she stroked the child's arm as she came up
3182. fearless and gay to kiss her hand. "I know she's a scamp of a girl, but
3183. I like her."
3184. 
3185. She took a pair of pear-shaped ruby earrings from her huge reticule and,
3186. having given them to the rosy Natasha, who beamed with the pleasure
3187. of her saint's-day fete, turned away at once and addressed herself to
3188. Pierre.
3189. 
3190. "Eh, eh, friend! Come here a bit," said she, assuming a soft high tone
3191. of voice. "Come here, my friend..." and she ominously tucked up her
3192. sleeves still higher. Pierre approached, looking at her in a childlike
3193. way through his spectacles.
3194. 
3195. "Come nearer, come nearer, friend! I used to be the only one to tell
3196. your father the truth when he was in favor, and in your case it's my
3197. evident duty." She paused. All were silent, expectant of what was to
3198. follow, for this was dearly only a prelude.
3199. 
3200. "A fine lad! My word! A fine lad!... His father lies on his deathbed and
3201. he amuses himself setting a policeman astride a bear! For shame, sir,
3202. for shame! It would be better if you went to the war."
3203. 
3204. She turned away and gave her hand to the count, who could hardly keep
3205. from laughing.
3206. 
3207. "Well, I suppose it is time we were at table?" said Marya Dmitrievna.
3208. 
3209. The count went in first with Marya Dmitrievna, the countess followed
3210. on the arm of a colonel of hussars, a man of importance to them because
3211. Nicholas was to go with him to the regiment; then came Anna Mikhaylovna
3212. with Shinshin. Berg gave his arm to Vera. The smiling Julie Karagina
3213. went in with Nicholas. After them other couples followed, filling the
3214. whole dining hall, and last of all the children, tutors, and governesses
3215. followed singly. The footmen began moving about, chairs scraped, the
3216. band struck up in the gallery, and the guests settled down in their
3217. places. Then the strains of the count's household band were replaced by
3218. the clatter of knives and forks, the voices of visitors, and the soft
3219. steps of the footmen. At one end of the table sat the countess with
3220. Marya Dmitrievna on her right and Anna Mikhaylovna on her left, the
3221. other lady visitors were farther down. At the other end sat the count,
3222. with the hussar colonel on his left and Shinshin and the other male
3223. visitors on his right. Midway down the long table on one side sat the
3224. grownup young people: Vera beside Berg, and Pierre beside Boris; and on
3225. the other side, the children, tutors, and governesses. From behind the
3226. crystal decanters and fruit vases the count kept glancing at his wife
3227. and her tall cap with its light-blue ribbons, and busily filled his
3228. neighbors' glasses, not neglecting his own. The countess in turn,
3229. without omitting her duties as hostess, threw significant glances from
3230. behind the pineapples at her husband whose face and bald head seemed
3231. by their redness to contrast more than usual with his gray hair. At the
3232. ladies' end an even chatter of voices was heard all the time, at the
3233. men's end the voices sounded louder and louder, especially that of the
3234. colonel of hussars who, growing more and more flushed, ate and drank so
3235. much that the count held him up as a pattern to the other guests. Berg
3236. with tender smiles was saying to Vera that love is not an earthly but a
3237. heavenly feeling. Boris was telling his new friend Pierre who the guests
3238. were and exchanging glances with Natasha, who was sitting opposite.
3239. Pierre spoke little but examined the new faces, and ate a great deal.
3240. Of the two soups he chose turtle with savory patties and went on to the
3241. game without omitting a single dish or one of the wines. These latter
3242. the butler thrust mysteriously forward, wrapped in a napkin, from behind
3243. the next man's shoulders and whispered: "Dry Madeira"... "Hungarian"...
3244. or "Rhine wine" as the case might be. Of the four crystal glasses
3245. engraved with the count's monogram that stood before his plate,
3246. Pierre held out one at random and drank with enjoyment, gazing with
3247. ever-increasing amiability at the other guests. Natasha, who sat
3248. opposite, was looking at Boris as girls of thirteen look at the boy they
3249. are in love with and have just kissed for the first time. Sometimes that
3250. same look fell on Pierre, and that funny lively little girl's look made
3251. him inclined to laugh without knowing why.
3252. 
3253. Nicholas sat at some distance from Sonya, beside Julie Karagina, to
3254. whom he was again talking with the same involuntary smile. Sonya wore
3255. a company smile but was evidently tormented by jealousy; now she turned
3256. pale, now blushed and strained every nerve to overhear what Nicholas
3257. and Julie were saying to one another. The governess kept looking round
3258. uneasily as if preparing to resent any slight that might be put upon the
3259. children. The German tutor was trying to remember all the dishes, wines,
3260. and kinds of dessert, in order to send a full description of the dinner
3261. to his people in Germany; and he felt greatly offended when the butler
3262. with a bottle wrapped in a napkin passed him by. He frowned, trying to
3263. appear as if he did not want any of that wine, but was mortified because
3264. no one would understand that it was not to quench his thirst or from
3265. greediness that he wanted it, but simply from a conscientious desire for
3266. knowledge.
3267.

3272. CHAPTER XIX
3273. 
3274. 
3275. At the men's end of the table the talk grew more and more animated. The
3276. colonel told them that the declaration of war had already appeared in
3277. Petersburg and that a copy, which he had himself seen, had that day been
3278. forwarded by courier to the commander in chief.
3279. 
3280. "And why the deuce are we going to fight Bonaparte?" remarked Shinshin.
3281. "He has stopped Austria's cackle and I fear it will be our turn next."
3282. 
3283. The colonel was a stout, tall, plethoric German, evidently devoted to
3284. the service and patriotically Russian. He resented Shinshin's remark.
3285. 
3286. "It is for the reasson, my goot sir," said he, speaking with a German
3287. accent, "for the reasson zat ze Emperor knows zat. He declares in ze
3288. manifessto zat he cannot fiew wiz indifference ze danger vreatening
3289. Russia and zat ze safety and dignity of ze Empire as vell as ze sanctity
3290. of its alliances..." he spoke this last word with particular emphasis as
3291. if in it lay the gist of the matter.
3292. 
3293. Then with the unerring official memory that characterized him he
3294. repeated from the opening words of the manifesto:
3295. 
3296. ... and the wish, which constitutes the Emperor's sole and absolute
3297. aim--to establish peace in Europe on firm foundations--has now decided
3298. him to despatch part of the army abroad and to create a new condition
3299. for the attainment of that purpose.
3300. 
3301. "Zat, my dear sir, is vy..." he concluded, drinking a tumbler of wine
3302. with dignity and looking to the count for approval.
3303. 
3304. "Connaissez-vous le Proverbe: * 'Jerome, Jerome, do not roam, but turn
3305. spindles at home!'?" said Shinshin, puckering his brows and smiling.
3306. "Cela nous convient a merveille.*(2) Suvorov now--he knew what he was
3307. about; yet they beat him a plate couture,*(3) and where are we to find
3308. Suvorovs now? Je vous demande un peu,"*(4) said he, continually changing
3309. from French to Russian.
3310. 
3311. 
3312.      *Do you know the proverb?
3313. 
3314.      *(2) That suits us down to the ground.
3315. 
3316.      *(3) Hollow.
3317. 
3318.      *(4) I just ask you that.
3319. 
3320. 
3321. "Ve must vight to the last tr-r-op of our plood!" said the colonel,

3324. particularly on the word possible... "as po-o-ossible," he ended, again
3325. turning to the count. "Zat is how ve old hussars look at it, and zere's
3326. an end of it! And how do you, a young man and a young hussar, how do you
3327. judge of it?" he added, addressing Nicholas, who when he heard that the
3328. war was being discussed had turned from his partner with eyes and ears
3329. intent on the colonel.
3330. 
3331. "I am quite of your opinion," replied Nicholas, flaming up, turning his

3333. desperation as though he were at that moment facing some great danger.
3334. "I am convinced that we Russians must die or conquer," he concluded,
3335. conscious--as were others--after the words were uttered that his remarks
3336. were too enthusiastic and emphatic for the occasion and were therefore
3337. awkward.
3338. 
3339. "What you said just now was splendid!" said his partner Julie.
3340. 
3341. Sonya trembled all over and blushed to her ears and behind them and down

3343. 
3344. Pierre listened to the colonel's speech and nodded approvingly.
3345. 
3346. "That's fine," said he.
3347. 
3348. "The young man's a real hussar!" shouted the colonel, again thumping the

3350.

3353. you thumping the table for?" she demanded of the hussar, "and why are
3354. you exciting yourself? Do you think the French are here?"
3355. 
3356. "I am speaking ze truce," replied the hussar with a smile.
3357. 
3358. "It's all about the war," the count shouted down the table. "You know my
3359. son's going, Marya Dmitrievna? My son is going."
3360. 
3361. "I have four sons in the army but still I don't fret. It is all in
3362. God's hands. You may die in your bed or God may spare you in a battle,"
3363. replied Marya Dmitrievna's deep voice, which easily carried the whole
3364. length of the table.
3365. 
3366. "That's true!"
3367. 
3368. Once more the conversations concentrated, the ladies' at the one end and
3369. the men's at the other.
3370. 
3371. "You won't ask," Natasha's little brother was saying; "I know you won't
3372. ask!"

3376. Her face suddenly flushed with reckless and joyous resolution. She half

3382.

3388.

3391.

3393. fat finger.
3394.

3396. 
3397. Most of the guests, uncertain how to regard this sally, looked at the

3400. "You had better take care!" said the countess.
3401. 
3402. "Mamma! What sweets are we going to have?" Natasha again cried boldly,

3404. 
3405. Sonya and fat little Petya doubled up with laughter.
3406.

3428. pineapple ice. Before the ices, champagne was served round. The band

3441. 
3442. 
3443. The card tables were drawn out, sets made up for boston, and the count's
3444. visitors settled themselves, some in the two drawing rooms, some in the
3445. sitting room, some in the library.
3446. 
3447. The count, holding his cards fanwise, kept himself with difficulty from
3448. dropping into his usual after-dinner nap, and laughed at everything.
3449. The young people, at the countess' instigation, gathered round the
3450. clavichord and harp. Julie by general request played first. After she
3451. had played a little air with variations on the harp, she joined the
3452. other young ladies in begging Natasha and Nicholas, who were noted for
3453. their musical talent, to sing something. Natasha, who was treated as
3454. though she were grown up, was evidently very proud of this but at the
3455. same time felt shy.
3456. 
3457. "What shall we sing?" she said.
3458. 
3459. "'The Brook,'" suggested Nicholas.
3460. 
3461. "Well, then, let's be quick. Boris, come here," said Natasha. "But where
3462. is Sonya?"
3463. 
3464. She looked round and seeing that her friend was not in the room ran to
3465. look for her.
3466. 
3467. Running into Sonya's room and not finding her there, Natasha ran to the
3468. nursery, but Sonya was not there either. Natasha concluded that she must
3469. be on the chest in the passage. The chest in the passage was the place
3470. of mourning for the younger female generation in the Rostov household.
3471. And there in fact was Sonya lying face downward on Nurse's dirty feather
3472. bed on the top of the chest, crumpling her gauzy pink dress under her,
3473. hiding her face with her slender fingers, and sobbing so convulsively
3474. that her bare little shoulders shook. Natasha's face, which had been so
3475. radiantly happy all that saint's day, suddenly changed: her eyes became
3476. fixed, and then a shiver passed down her broad neck and the corners of
3477. her mouth drooped.
3478. 
3479. "Sonya! What is it? What is the matter?... Oo... Oo... Oo...!" And
3480. Natasha's large mouth widened, making her look quite ugly, and she began
3481. to wail like a baby without knowing why, except that Sonya was crying.
3482. Sonya tried to lift her head to answer but could not, and hid her face
3483. still deeper in the bed. Natasha wept, sitting on the blue-striped
3484. feather bed and hugging her friend. With an effort Sonya sat up and
3485. began wiping her eyes and explaining.
3486. 
3487. "Nicholas is going away in a week's time, his... papers... have come...
3488. he told me himself... but still I should not cry," and she showed
3489. a paper she held in her hand--with the verses Nicholas had written,
3490. "still, I should not cry, but you can't... no one can understand... what
3491. a soul he has!"
3492. 
3493. And she began to cry again because he had such a noble soul.
3494. 
3495. "It's all very well for you... I am not envious... I love you and Boris
3496. also," she went on, gaining a little strength; "he is nice... there are
3497. no difficulties in your way.... But Nicholas is my cousin... one would
3498. have to... the Metropolitan himself... and even then it can't be done.
3499. And besides, if she tells Mamma" (Sonya looked upon the countess as her
3500. mother and called her so) "that I am spoiling Nicholas' career and am
3501. heartless and ungrateful, while truly... God is my witness," and she
3502. made the sign of the cross, "I love her so much, and all of you, only
3503. Vera... And what for? What have I done to her? I am so grateful to you
3504. that I would willingly sacrifice everything, only I have nothing...."
3505. 
3506. Sonya could not continue, and again hid her face in her hands and in the
3507. feather bed. Natasha began consoling her, but her face showed that she
3508. understood all the gravity of her friend's trouble.
3509. 
3510. "Sonya," she suddenly exclaimed, as if she had guessed the true reason
3511. of her friend's sorrow, "I'm sure Vera has said something to you since
3512. dinner? Hasn't she?"
3513. 
3514. "Yes, these verses Nicholas wrote himself and I copied some others, and
3515. she found them on my table and said she'd show them to Mamma, and that
3516. I was ungrateful, and that Mamma would never allow him to marry me,
3517. but that he'll marry Julie. You see how he's been with her all day...
3518. Natasha, what have I done to deserve it?..."
3519. 
3520. And again she began to sob, more bitterly than before. Natasha lifted
3521. her up, hugged her, and, smiling through her tears, began comforting
3522. her.
3523. 
3524. "Sonya, don't believe her, darling! Don't believe her! Do you remember
3525. how we and Nicholas, all three of us, talked in the sitting room after
3526. supper? Why, we settled how everything was to be. I don't quite remember
3527. how, but don't you remember that it could all be arranged and how nice
3528. it all was? There's Uncle Shinshin's brother has married his first
3529. cousin. And we are only second cousins, you know. And Boris says it
3530. is quite possible. You know I have told him all about it. And he is so
3531. clever and so good!" said Natasha. "Don't you cry, Sonya, dear love,
3532. darling Sonya!" and she kissed her and laughed. "Vera's spiteful; never
3533. mind her! And all will come right and she won't say anything to Mamma.
3534. Nicholas will tell her himself, and he doesn't care at all for Julie."
3535. 
3536. Natasha kissed her on the hair.
3537. 
3538. Sonya sat up. The little kitten brightened, its eyes shone, and it
3539. seemed ready to lift its tail, jump down on its soft paws, and begin
3540. playing with the ball of worsted as a kitten should.
3541.

3543. frock and hair.
3544.

3546. strayed from under her friend's plaits.
3547. 
3548. Both laughed.
3549. 
3550. "Well, let's go and sing 'The Brook.'"
3551. 
3552. "Come along!"
3553.

3555. Natasha, stopping suddenly. "I feel so happy!"
3556.

3558. 
3559. Sonya, shaking off some down which clung to her and tucking away the

3565. 
3566. 
3567.    At nighttime in the moon's fair glow
3568.      How sweet, as fancies wander free,
3569.    To feel that in this world there's one
3570.      Who still is thinking but of thee!
3571.

3573.      Wafting sweet music o'er the lea,

3585. 
3586. Pierre was sitting in the drawing-room where Shinshin had engaged him,

3598. While the couples were arranging themselves and the musicians tuning up,
3599. Pierre sat down with his little partner. Natasha was perfectly happy;
3600. she was dancing with a grown-up man, who had been abroad. She was
3601. sitting in a conspicuous place and talking to him like a grown-up lady.
3602. She had a fan in her hand that one of the ladies had given her to hold.
3603. Assuming quite the pose of a society woman (heaven knows when and where
3604. she had learned it) she talked with her partner, fanning herself and
3605. smiling over the fan.
3606. 
3607. "Dear, dear! Just look at her!" exclaimed the countess as she crossed
3608. the ballroom, pointing to Natasha.
3609. 
3610. Natasha blushed and laughed.
3611. 
3612. "Well, really, Mamma! Why should you? What is there to be surprised at?"
3613. 
3614. 
3615. In the midst of the third ecossaise there was a clatter of chairs being
3616. pushed back in the sitting room where the count and Marya Dmitrievna had
3617. been playing cards with the majority of the more distinguished and older
3618. visitors. They now, stretching themselves after sitting so long, and
3619. replacing their purses and pocketbooks, entered the ballroom. First came
3620. Marya Dmitrievna and the count, both with merry countenances. The count,
3621. with playful ceremony somewhat in ballet style, offered his bent arm to
3622. Marya Dmitrievna. He drew himself up, a smile of debonair gallantry lit
3623. up his face and as soon as the last figure of the ecossaise was ended,
3624. he clapped his hands to the musicians and shouted up to their gallery,
3625. addressing the first violin:
3626. 
3627. "Semen! Do you know the Daniel Cooper?"
3628. 
3629. This was the count's favorite dance, which he had danced in his youth.
3630. (Strictly speaking, Daniel Cooper was one figure of the anglaise.)
3631. 
3632. "Look at Papa!" shouted Natasha to the whole company, and quite
3633. forgetting that she was dancing with a grown-up partner she bent her
3634. curly head to her knees and made the whole room ring with her laughter.
3635. 
3636. And indeed everybody in the room looked with a smile of pleasure at the
3637. jovial old gentleman, who standing beside his tall and stout partner,
3638. Marya Dmitrievna, curved his arms, beat time, straightened his
3639. shoulders, turned out his toes, tapped gently with his foot, and, by
3640. a smile that broadened his round face more and more, prepared the
3641. onlookers for what was to follow. As soon as the provocatively gay
3642. strains of Daniel Cooper (somewhat resembling those of a merry peasant
3643. dance) began to sound, all the doorways of the ballroom were suddenly
3644. filled by the domestic serfs--the men on one side and the women on the
3645. other--who with beaming faces had come to see their master making merry.
3646. 
3647. "Just look at the master! A regular eagle he is!" loudly remarked the
3648. nurse, as she stood in one of the doorways.
3649. 
3650. The count danced well and knew it. But his partner could not and did not
3651. want to dance well. Her enormous figure stood erect, her powerful arms
3652. hanging down (she had handed her reticule to the countess), and only her
3653. stern but handsome face really joined in the dance. What was expressed
3654. by the whole of the count's plump figure, in Marya Dmitrievna found
3655. expression only in her more and more beaming face and quivering nose.
3656. But if the count, getting more and more into the swing of it, charmed
3657. the spectators by the unexpectedness of his adroit maneuvers and the
3658. agility with which he capered about on his light feet, Marya Dmitrievna
3659. produced no less impression by slight exertions--the least effort
3660. to move her shoulders or bend her arms when turning, or stamp her
3661. foot--which everyone appreciated in view of her size and habitual
3662. severity. The dance grew livelier and livelier. The other couples could
3663. not attract a moment's attention to their own evolutions and did not
3664. even try to do so. All were watching the count and Marya Dmitrievna.
3665. Natasha kept pulling everyone by sleeve or dress, urging them to "look
3666. at Papa!" though as it was they never took their eyes off the couple.
3667. In the intervals of the dance the count, breathing deeply, waved and
3668. shouted to the musicians to play faster. Faster, faster, and faster;
3669. lightly, more lightly, and yet more lightly whirled the count, flying
3670. round Marya Dmitrievna, now on his toes, now on his heels; until,
3671. turning his partner round to her seat, he executed the final pas,
3672. raising his soft foot backwards, bowing his perspiring head, smiling
3673. and making a wide sweep with his arm, amid a thunder of applause and
3674. laughter led by Natasha. Both partners stood still, breathing heavily
3675. and wiping their faces with their cambric handkerchiefs.
3676. 
3677. "That's how we used to dance in our time, ma chere," said the count.
3678. 
3679. "That was a Daniel Cooper!" exclaimed Marya Dmitrievna, tucking up her
3680. sleeves and puffing heavily.

3686. CHAPTER XXI
3687. 
3688. 
3689. While in the Rostovs' ballroom the sixth anglaise was being danced, to a
3690. tune in which the weary musicians blundered, and while tired footmen and
3691. cooks were getting the supper, Count Bezukhov had a sixth stroke.
3692. The doctors pronounced recovery impossible. After a mute confession,
3693. communion was administered to the dying man, preparations made for the
3694. sacrament of unction, and in his house there was the bustle and thrill
3695. of suspense usual at such moments. Outside the house, beyond the gates,
3696. a group of undertakers, who hid whenever a carriage drove up, waited in
3697. expectation of an important order for an expensive funeral. The Military
3698. Governor of Moscow, who had been assiduous in sending aides-de-camp to
3699. inquire after the count's health, came himself that evening to bid a
3700. last farewell to the celebrated grandee of Catherine's court, Count
3701. Bezukhov.
3702. 
3703. The magnificent reception room was crowded. Everyone stood up
3704. respectfully when the Military Governor, having stayed about half an
3705. hour alone with the dying man, passed out, slightly acknowledging their
3706. bows and trying to escape as quickly as possible from the glances fixed
3707. on him by the doctors, clergy, and relatives of the family. Prince
3708. Vasili, who had grown thinner and paler during the last few days,
3709. escorted him to the door, repeating something to him several times in
3710. low tones.
3711. 
3712. When the Military Governor had gone, Prince Vasili sat down all alone on
3713. a chair in the ballroom, crossing one leg high over the other, leaning
3714. his elbow on his knee and covering his face with his hand. After sitting
3715. so for a while he rose, and, looking about him with frightened eyes,
3716. went with unusually hurried steps down the long corridor leading to the
3717. back of the house, to the room of the eldest princess.
3718. 
3719. Those who were in the dimly lit reception room spoke in nervous
3720. whispers, and, whenever anyone went into or came from the dying man's
3721. room, grew silent and gazed with eyes full of curiosity or expectancy at
3722. his door, which creaked slightly when opened.
3723. 
3724. "The limits of human life... are fixed and may not be o'erpassed,"

3726. listening naively to his words.
3727.

3731.

3741. 
3742. "I knew someone who received that sacrament seven times."
3743. 
3744. The second princess had just come from the sickroom with her eyes red

3748. 
3749. "Beautiful," said the doctor in answer to a remark about the weather.

3751. if one were in the country."
3752.

3754. something to drink?"
3755. 
3756. Lorrain considered.
3757. 
3758. "Has he taken his medicine?"
3759. 
3760. "Yes."
3761. 
3762. The doctor glanced at his watch.
3763.

3789. 
3790. Meanwhile Prince Vasili had opened the door into the princess' room.
3791. 
3792. In this room it was almost dark; only two tiny lamps were burning before

3794. The room was crowded with small pieces of furniture, whatnots,
3795. cupboards, and little tables. The quilt of a high, white feather bed was

3797. 
3798. "Ah, is it you, cousin?"
3799. 
3800. She rose and smoothed her hair, which was as usual so extremely smooth
3801. that it seemed to be made of one piece with her head and covered with
3802. varnish.
3803. 
3804. "Has anything happened?" she asked. "I am so terrified."
3805. 
3806. "No, there is no change. I only came to have a talk about business,

3808. she had just vacated. "You have made the place warm, I must say," he

3811. 
3812.      *Catherine.
3813. 
3814. 
3815. "I thought perhaps something had happened," she said with her unchanging
3816. stonily severe expression; and, sitting down opposite the prince, she
3817. prepared to listen.
3818. 
3819. "I wished to get a nap, mon cousin, but I can't."
3820.

3827. The princess, who had a straight, rigid body, abnormally long for her

3833.

3836. serious talk."
3837. 
3838. Prince Vasili said no more and his cheeks began to twitch nervously, now

3840. which was never to be seen on it in a drawing room. His eyes too seemed
3841. strange; at one moment they looked impudently sly and at the next

3843. 
3844. The princess, holding her little dog on her lap with her thin bony

3853.

3865.

3950.

3953.

3962. 
3963. But the princess did not listen to him.
3964.

3973. sacrificed myself. But only the base, the vile succeed! I know who has

3979.

3992.

4001. You must know. We will take it at once and show it to the count. He has,
4002. no doubt, forgotten it and will wish to destroy it. You understand that

4020. would not see us for a whole fortnight. I know it was then he wrote this
