4035. CHAPTER XXII
4036. 
4037. 
4038. While these conversations were going on in the reception room and the
4039. princess' room, a carriage containing Pierre (who had been sent for) and
4040. Anna Mikhaylovna (who found it necessary to accompany him) was driving
4041. into the court of Count Bezukhov's house. As the wheels rolled softly
4042. over the straw beneath the windows, Anna Mikhaylovna, having turned with
4043. words of comfort to her companion, realized that he was asleep in
4044. his corner and woke him up. Rousing himself, Pierre followed Anna
4045. Mikhaylovna out of the carriage, and only then began to think of the
4046. interview with his dying father which awaited him. He noticed that they
4047. had not come to the front entrance but to the back door. While he
4048. was getting down from the carriage steps two men, who looked like
4049. tradespeople, ran hurriedly from the entrance and hid in the shadow of
4050. the wall. Pausing for a moment, Pierre noticed several other men of the
4051. same kind hiding in the shadow of the house on both sides. But neither
4052. Anna Mikhaylovna nor the footman nor the coachman, who could not help
4053. seeing these people, took any notice of them. "It seems to be all
4054. right," Pierre concluded, and followed Anna Mikhaylovna. She hurriedly
4055. ascended the narrow dimly lit stone staircase, calling to Pierre,
4056. who was lagging behind, to follow. Though he did not see why it was
4057. necessary for him to go to the count at all, still less why he had to go
4058. by the back stairs, yet judging by Anna Mikhaylovna's air of assurance
4059. and haste, Pierre concluded that it was all absolutely necessary.
4060. Halfway up the stairs they were almost knocked over by some men who,
4061. carrying pails, came running downstairs, their boots clattering. These
4062. men pressed close to the wall to let Pierre and Anna Mikhaylovna pass
4063. and did not evince the least surprise at seeing them there.
4064. 
4065. "Is this the way to the princesses' apartments?" asked Anna Mikhaylovna
4066. of one of them.
4067. 
4068. "Yes," replied a footman in a bold loud voice, as if anything were now
4069. permissible; "the door to the left, ma'am."
4070. 
4071. "Perhaps the count did not ask for me," said Pierre when he reached the
4072. landing. "I'd better go to my own room."
4073. 
4074. Anna Mikhaylovna paused and waited for him to come up.
4075. 
4076. "Ah, my friend!" she said, touching his arm as she had done her son's
4077. when speaking to him that afternoon, "believe me I suffer no less than
4078. you do, but be a man!"
4079. 
4080. "But really, hadn't I better go away?" he asked, looking kindly at her
4081. over his spectacles.
4082. 
4083. "Ah, my dear friend! Forget the wrongs that may have been done you.
4084. Think that he is your father... perhaps in the agony of death." She
4085. sighed. "I have loved you like a son from the first. Trust yourself to
4086. me, Pierre. I shall not forget your interests."
4087. 
4088. Pierre did not understand a word, but the conviction that all this had
4089. to be grew stronger, and he meekly followed Anna Mikhaylovna who was
4090. already opening a door.
4091. 
4092. This door led into a back anteroom. An old man, a servant of the
4093. princesses, sat in a corner knitting a stocking. Pierre had never been
4094. in this part of the house and did not even know of the existence of
4095. these rooms. Anna Mikhaylovna, addressing a maid who was hurrying past
4096. with a decanter on a tray as "my dear" and "my sweet," asked about the
4097. princess' health and then led Pierre along a stone passage. The first
4098. door on the left led into the princesses' apartments. The maid with the
4099. decanter in her haste had not closed the door (everything in the house
4100. was done in haste at that time), and Pierre and Anna Mikhaylovna in
4101. passing instinctively glanced into the room, where Prince Vasili and the
4102. eldest princess were sitting close together talking. Seeing them pass,
4103. Prince Vasili drew back with obvious impatience, while the princess
4104. jumped up and with a gesture of desperation slammed the door with all
4105. her might.
4106. 
4107. This action was so unlike her usual composure and the fear depicted
4108. on Prince Vasili's face so out of keeping with his dignity that Pierre
4109. stopped and glanced inquiringly over his spectacles at his guide. Anna
4110. Mikhaylovna evinced no surprise, she only smiled faintly and sighed, as
4111. if to say that this was no more than she had expected.
4112. 
4113. "Be a man, my friend. I will look after your interests," said she in
4114. reply to his look, and went still faster along the passage.
4115. 
4116. Pierre could not make out what it was all about, and still less what
4117. "watching over his interests" meant, but he decided that all these
4118. things had to be. From the passage they went into a large, dimly lit
4119. room adjoining the count's reception room. It was one of those sumptuous
4120. but cold apartments known to Pierre only from the front approach, but
4121. even in this room there now stood an empty bath, and water had been
4122. spilled on the carpet. They were met by a deacon with a censer and by
4123. a servant who passed out on tiptoe without heeding them. They went into
4124. the reception room familiar to Pierre, with two Italian windows opening
4125. into the conservatory, with its large bust and full length portrait of
4126. Catherine the Great. The same people were still sitting here in almost
4127. the same positions as before, whispering to one another. All became
4128. silent and turned to look at the pale tear-worn Anna Mikhaylovna as she
4129. entered, and at the big stout figure of Pierre who, hanging his head,
4130. meekly followed her.
4131. 
4132. Anna Mikhaylovna's face expressed a consciousness that the decisive
4133. moment had arrived. With the air of a practical Petersburg lady she now,
4134. keeping Pierre close beside her, entered the room even more boldly than
4135. that afternoon. She felt that as she brought with her the person the
4136. dying man wished to see, her own admission was assured. Casting a rapid
4137. glance at all those in the room and noticing the count's confessor
4138. there, she glided up to him with a sort of amble, not exactly bowing yet
4139. seeming to grow suddenly smaller, and respectfully received the blessing
4140. first of one and then of another priest.
4141. 
4142. "God be thanked that you are in time," said she to one of the priests;
4143. "all we relatives have been in such anxiety. This young man is the
4144. count's son," she added more softly. "What a terrible moment!"
4145. 
4146. Having said this she went up to the doctor.
4147. 
4148. "Dear doctor," said she, "this young man is the count's son. Is there
4149. any hope?"
4150. 
4151. The doctor cast a rapid glance upwards and silently shrugged his
4152. shoulders. Anna Mikhaylovna with just the same movement raised her
4153. shoulders and eyes, almost closing the latter, sighed, and moved away
4154. from the doctor to Pierre. To him, in a particularly respectful and
4155. tenderly sad voice, she said:
4156. 
4157. "Trust in His mercy!" and pointing out a small sofa for him to sit
4158. and wait for her, she went silently toward the door that everyone was
4159. watching and it creaked very slightly as she disappeared behind it.
4160. 
4161. Pierre, having made up his mind to obey his monitress implicitly, moved
4162. toward the sofa she had indicated. As soon as Anna Mikhaylovna had
4163. disappeared he noticed that the eyes of all in the room turned to him
4164. with something more than curiosity and sympathy. He noticed that they
4165. whispered to one another, casting significant looks at him with a kind
4166. of awe and even servility. A deference such as he had never before
4167. received was shown him. A strange lady, the one who had been talking to
4168. the priests, rose and offered him her seat; an aide-de-camp picked up
4169. and returned a glove Pierre had dropped; the doctors became respectfully
4170. silent as he passed by, and moved to make way for him. At first Pierre
4171. wished to take another seat so as not to trouble the lady, and also to
4172. pick up the glove himself and to pass round the doctors who were not
4173. even in his way; but all at once he felt that this would not do, and
4174. that tonight he was a person obliged to perform some sort of awful
4175. rite which everyone expected of him, and that he was therefore bound
4176. to accept their services. He took the glove in silence from the
4177. aide-de-camp, and sat down in the lady's chair, placing his huge hands
4178. symmetrically on his knees in the naive attitude of an Egyptian statue,
4179. and decided in his own mind that all was as it should be, and that in
4180. order not to lose his head and do foolish things he must not act on his
4181. own ideas tonight, but must yield himself up entirely to the will of
4182. those who were guiding him.
4183. 
4184. Not two minutes had passed before Prince Vasili with head erect
4185. majestically entered the room. He was wearing his long coat with three
4186. stars on his breast. He seemed to have grown thinner since the morning;
4187. his eyes seemed larger than usual when he glanced round and noticed
4188. Pierre. He went up to him, took his hand (a thing he never used to do),
4189. and drew it downwards as if wishing to ascertain whether it was firmly
4190. fixed on.
4191. 
4192. "Courage, courage, my friend! He has asked to see you. That is well!"
4193. and he turned to go.
4194. 
4195. But Pierre thought it necessary to ask: "How is..." and hesitated, not
4196. knowing whether it would be proper to call the dying man "the count,"
4197. yet ashamed to call him "father."
4198. 
4199. "He had another stroke about half an hour ago. Courage, my friend..."
4200. 
4201. Pierre's mind was in such a confused state that the word "stroke"
4202. suggested to him a blow from something. He looked at Prince Vasili
4203. in perplexity, and only later grasped that a stroke was an attack of
4204. illness. Prince Vasili said something to Lorrain in passing and went
4205. through the door on tiptoe. He could not walk well on tiptoe and his
4206. whole body jerked at each step. The eldest princess followed him, and
4207. the priests and deacons and some servants also went in at the door.
4208. Through that door was heard a noise of things being moved about, and at
4209. last Anna Mikhaylovna, still with the same expression, pale but resolute
4210. in the discharge of duty, ran out and touching Pierre lightly on the arm
4211. said:
4212. 
4213. "The divine mercy is inexhaustible! Unction is about to be administered.
4214. Come."
4215. 
4216. Pierre went in at the door, stepping on the soft carpet, and noticed
4217. that the strange lady, the aide-de-camp, and some of the servants, all
4218. followed him in, as if there were now no further need for permission to
4219. enter that room.
4220. 
4221. 
4222. 
4223. 
4224. 
4225. CHAPTER XXIII
4226. 
4227. 
4228. Pierre well knew this large room divided by columns and an arch, its
4229. walls hung round with Persian carpets. The part of the room behind the
4230. columns, with a high silk-curtained mahogany bedstead on one side and
4231. on the other an immense case containing icons, was brightly illuminated
4232. with red light like a Russian church during evening service. Under
4233. the gleaming icons stood a long invalid chair, and in that chair
4234. on snowy-white smooth pillows, evidently freshly changed, Pierre
4235. saw--covered to the waist by a bright green quilt--the familiar,
4236. majestic figure of his father, Count Bezukhov, with that gray mane of
4237. hair above his broad forehead which reminded one of a lion, and the deep
4238. characteristically noble wrinkles of his handsome, ruddy face. He lay
4239. just under the icons; his large thick hands outside the quilt. Into the
4240. right hand, which was lying palm downwards, a wax taper had been thrust
4241. between forefinger and thumb, and an old servant, bending over from
4242. behind the chair, held it in position. By the chair stood the priests,
4243. their long hair falling over their magnificent glittering vestments,
4244. with lighted tapers in their hands, slowly and solemnly conducting the
4245. service. A little behind them stood the two younger princesses holding
4246. handkerchiefs to their eyes, and just in front of them their eldest
4247. sister, Catiche, with a vicious and determined look steadily fixed on
4248. the icons, as though declaring to all that she could not answer
4249. for herself should she glance round. Anna Mikhaylovna, with a meek,
4250. sorrowful, and all-forgiving expression on her face, stood by the door
4251. near the strange lady. Prince Vasili in front of the door, near the
4252. invalid chair, a wax taper in his left hand, was leaning his left arm on
4253. the carved back of a velvet chair he had turned round for the purpose,
4254. and was crossing himself with his right hand, turning his eyes upward
4255. each time he touched his forehead. His face wore a calm look of piety
4256. and resignation to the will of God. "If you do not understand these
4257. sentiments," he seemed to be saying, "so much the worse for you!"
4258. 
4259. Behind him stood the aide-de-camp, the doctors, and the menservants;
4260. the men and women had separated as in church. All were silently crossing
4261. themselves, and the reading of the church service, the subdued chanting
4262. of deep bass voices, and in the intervals sighs and the shuffling of
4263. feet were the only sounds that could be heard. Anna Mikhaylovna, with an
4264. air of importance that showed that she felt she quite knew what she was
4265. about, went across the room to where Pierre was standing and gave him
4266. a taper. He lit it and, distracted by observing those around him, began
4267. crossing himself with the hand that held the taper.
4268. 
4269. Sophie, the rosy, laughter-loving, youngest princess with the mole,
4270. watched him. She smiled, hid her face in her handkerchief, and remained
4271. with it hidden for awhile; then looking up and seeing Pierre she
4272. again began to laugh. She evidently felt unable to look at him
4273. without laughing, but could not resist looking at him: so to be out of
4274. temptation she slipped quietly behind one of the columns. In the midst
4275. of the service the voices of the priests suddenly ceased, they whispered
4276. to one another, and the old servant who was holding the count's hand got
4277. up and said something to the ladies. Anna Mikhaylovna stepped forward
4278. and, stooping over the dying man, beckoned to Lorrain from behind her
4279. back. The French doctor held no taper; he was leaning against one of the
4280. columns in a respectful attitude implying that he, a foreigner, in spite
4281. of all differences of faith, understood the full importance of the rite
4282. now being performed and even approved of it. He now approached the
4283. sick man with the noiseless step of one in full vigor of life, with his
4284. delicate white fingers raised from the green quilt the hand that was
4285. free, and turning sideways felt the pulse and reflected a moment. The
4286. sick man was given something to drink, there was a stir around him, then
4287. the people resumed their places and the service continued. During this
4288. interval Pierre noticed that Prince Vasili left the chair on which he
4289. had been leaning, and--with an air which intimated that he knew what he
4290. was about and if others did not understand him it was so much the worse
4291. for them--did not go up to the dying man, but passed by him, joined the
4292. eldest princess, and moved with her to the side of the room where stood
4293. the high bedstead with its silken hangings. On leaving the bed both
4294. Prince Vasili and the princess passed out by a back door, but returned
4295. to their places one after the other before the service was concluded.
4296. Pierre paid no more attention to this occurrence than to the rest of
4297. what went on, having made up his mind once for all that what he saw
4298. happening around him that evening was in some way essential.
4299. 
4300. The chanting of the service ceased, and the voice of the priest was
4301. heard respectfully congratulating the dying man on having received the
4302. sacrament. The dying man lay as lifeless and immovable as before. Around
4303. him everyone began to stir: steps were audible and whispers, among which
4304. Anna Mikhaylovna's was the most distinct.
4305. 
4306. Pierre heard her say:
4307. 
4308. "Certainly he must be moved onto the bed; here it will be impossible..."
4309. 
4310. The sick man was so surrounded by doctors, princesses, and servants
4311. that Pierre could no longer see the reddish-yellow face with its gray
4312. mane--which, though he saw other faces as well, he had not lost sight of
4313. for a single moment during the whole service. He judged by the cautious
4314. movements of those who crowded round the invalid chair that they had
4315. lifted the dying man and were moving him.
4316. 
4317. "Catch hold of my arm or you'll drop him!" he heard one of the servants
4318. say in a frightened whisper. "Catch hold from underneath. Here!"
4319. exclaimed different voices; and the heavy breathing of the bearers and
4320. the shuffling of their feet grew more hurried, as if the weight they
4321. were carrying were too much for them.
4322. 
4323. As the bearers, among whom was Anna Mikhaylovna, passed the young man
4324. he caught a momentary glimpse between their heads and backs of the dying
4325. man's high, stout, uncovered chest and powerful shoulders, raised by
4326. those who were holding him under the armpits, and of his gray, curly,
4327. leonine head. This head, with its remarkably broad brow and cheekbones,
4328. its handsome, sensual mouth, and its cold, majestic expression, was
4329. not disfigured by the approach of death. It was the same as Pierre
4330. remembered it three months before, when the count had sent him to
4331. Petersburg. But now this head was swaying helplessly with the uneven
4332. movements of the bearers, and the cold listless gaze fixed itself upon
4333. nothing.
4334. 
4335. After a few minutes' bustle beside the high bedstead, those who had
4336. carried the sick man dispersed. Anna Mikhaylovna touched Pierre's hand
4337. and said, "Come." Pierre went with her to the bed on which the sick
4338. man had been laid in a stately pose in keeping with the ceremony just
4339. completed. He lay with his head propped high on the pillows. His hands
4340. were symmetrically placed on the green silk quilt, the palms downward.
4341. When Pierre came up the count was gazing straight at him, but with a
4342. look the significance of which could not be understood by mortal man.
4343. Either this look meant nothing but that as long as one has eyes they
4344. must look somewhere, or it meant too much. Pierre hesitated, not knowing
4345. what to do, and glanced inquiringly at his guide. Anna Mikhaylovna made
4346. a hurried sign with her eyes, glancing at the sick man's hand and moving
4347. her lips as if to send it a kiss. Pierre, carefully stretching his neck
4348. so as not to touch the quilt, followed her suggestion and pressed his
4349. lips to the large boned, fleshy hand. Neither the hand nor a
4350. single muscle of the count's face stirred. Once more Pierre looked
4351. questioningly at Anna Mikhaylovna to see what he was to do next. Anna
4352. Mikhaylovna with her eyes indicated a chair that stood beside the bed.
4353. Pierre obediently sat down, his eyes asking if he were doing right.
4354. Anna Mikhaylovna nodded approvingly. Again Pierre fell into the naively
4355. symmetrical pose of an Egyptian statue, evidently distressed that his
4356. stout and clumsy body took up so much room and doing his utmost to look
4357. as small as possible. He looked at the count, who still gazed at the
4358. spot where Pierre's face had been before he sat down. Anna Mikhaylovna
4359. indicated by her attitude her consciousness of the pathetic importance
4360. of these last moments of meeting between the father and son. This lasted
4361. about two minutes, which to Pierre seemed an hour. Suddenly the broad
4362. muscles and lines of the count's face began to twitch. The twitching
4363. increased, the handsome mouth was drawn to one side (only now did Pierre
4364. realize how near death his father was), and from that distorted mouth
4365. issued an indistinct, hoarse sound. Anna Mikhaylovna looked attentively
4366. at the sick man's eyes, trying to guess what he wanted; she pointed
4367. first to Pierre, then to some drink, then named Prince Vasili in an
4368. inquiring whisper, then pointed to the quilt. The eyes and face of the
4369. sick man showed impatience. He made an effort to look at the servant who
4370. stood constantly at the head of the bed.
4371. 
4372. "Wants to turn on the other side," whispered the servant, and got up to
4373. turn the count's heavy body toward the wall.
4374. 
4375. Pierre rose to help him.
4376. 
4377. While the count was being turned over, one of his arms fell back
4378. helplessly and he made a fruitless effort to pull it forward. Whether he
4379. noticed the look of terror with which Pierre regarded that lifeless arm,
4380. or whether some other thought flitted across his dying brain, at any
4381. rate he glanced at the refractory arm, at Pierre's terror-stricken face,
4382. and again at the arm, and on his face a feeble, piteous smile appeared,
4383. quite out of keeping with his features, that seemed to deride his own
4384. helplessness. At sight of this smile Pierre felt an unexpected quivering
4385. in his breast and a tickling in his nose, and tears dimmed his eyes. The
4386. sick man was turned on to his side with his face to the wall. He sighed.
4387. 
4388. "He is dozing," said Anna Mikhaylovna, observing that one of the
4389. princesses was coming to take her turn at watching. "Let us go."
4390. 
4391. Pierre went out.
4392. 
4393. 
4394. 
4395. 
4396. 
4397. CHAPTER XXIV
4398. 
4399. 
4400. There was now no one in the reception room except Prince Vasili and the
4401. eldest princess, who were sitting under the portrait of Catherine the
4402. Great and talking eagerly. As soon as they saw Pierre and his companion
4403. they became silent, and Pierre thought he saw the princess hide
4404. something as she whispered:
4405. 
4406. "I can't bear the sight of that woman."
4407. 
4408. "Catiche has had tea served in the small drawing room," said Prince
4409. Vasili to Anna Mikhaylovna. "Go and take something, my poor Anna
4410. Mikhaylovna, or you will not hold out."
4411. 
4412. To Pierre he said nothing, merely giving his arm a sympathetic squeeze
4413. below the shoulder. Pierre went with Anna Mikhaylovna into the small
4414. drawing room.
4415. 
4416. "There is nothing so refreshing after a sleepless night as a cup of this
4417. delicious Russian tea," Lorrain was saying with an air of restrained
4418. animation as he stood sipping tea from a delicate Chinese handleless
4419. cup before a table on which tea and a cold supper were laid in the small
4420. circular room. Around the table all who were at Count Bezukhov's house
4421. that night had gathered to fortify themselves. Pierre well remembered
4422. this small circular drawing room with its mirrors and little tables.
4423. During balls given at the house Pierre, who did not know how to dance,
4424. had liked sitting in this room to watch the ladies who, as they passed
4425. through in their ball dresses with diamonds and pearls on their bare
4426. shoulders, looked at themselves in the brilliantly lighted mirrors which
4427. repeated their reflections several times. Now this same room was dimly
4428. lighted by two candles. On one small table tea things and supper dishes
4429. stood in disorder, and in the middle of the night a motley throng
4430. of people sat there, not merrymaking, but somberly whispering, and
4431. betraying by every word and movement that they none of them forgot what
4432. was happening and what was about to happen in the bedroom. Pierre did
4433. not eat anything though he would very much have liked to. He looked
4434. inquiringly at his monitress and saw that she was again going on tiptoe
4435. to the reception room where they had left Prince Vasili and the eldest
4436. princess. Pierre concluded that this also was essential, and after a
4437. short interval followed her. Anna Mikhaylovna was standing beside the
4438. princess, and they were both speaking in excited whispers.
4439. 
4440. "Permit me, Princess, to know what is necessary and what is not
4441. necessary," said the younger of the two speakers, evidently in the same
4442. state of excitement as when she had slammed the door of her room.
4443. 
4444. "But, my dear princess," answered Anna Mikhaylovna blandly but
4445. impressively, blocking the way to the bedroom and preventing the other
4446. from passing, "won't this be too much for poor Uncle at a moment when he
4447. needs repose? Worldly conversation at a moment when his soul is already
4448. prepared..."
4449. 
4450. Prince Vasili was seated in an easy chair in his familiar attitude, with
4451. one leg crossed high above the other. His cheeks, which were so flabby
4452. that they looked heavier below, were twitching violently; but he wore
4453. the air of a man little concerned in what the two ladies were saying.
4454. 
4455. "Come, my dear Anna Mikhaylovna, let Catiche do as she pleases. You know
4456. how fond the count is of her."
4457. 
4458. "I don't even know what is in this paper," said the younger of the two
4459. ladies, addressing Prince Vasili and pointing to an inlaid portfolio she
4460. held in her hand. "All I know is that his real will is in his writing
4461. table, and this is a paper he has forgotten...."
4462. 
4463. She tried to pass Anna Mikhaylovna, but the latter sprang so as to bar
4464. her path.
4465. 
4466. "I know, my dear, kind princess," said Anna Mikhaylovna, seizing the
4467. portfolio so firmly that it was plain she would not let go easily.
4468. "Dear princess, I beg and implore you, have some pity on him! Je vous en
4469. conjure..."
4470. 
4471. The princess did not reply. Their efforts in the struggle for the
4472. portfolio were the only sounds audible, but it was evident that if
4473. the princess did speak, her words would not be flattering to Anna
4474. Mikhaylovna. Though the latter held on tenaciously, her voice lost none
4475. of its honeyed firmness and softness.
4476. 
4477. "Pierre, my dear, come here. I think he will not be out of place in a
4478. family consultation; is it not so, Prince?"
4479. 
4480. "Why don't you speak, cousin?" suddenly shrieked the princess so loud
4481. that those in the drawing room heard her and were startled. "Why do you
4482. remain silent when heaven knows who permits herself to interfere, making
4483. a scene on the very threshold of a dying man's room? Intriguer!" she
4484. hissed viciously, and tugged with all her might at the portfolio.
4485. 
4486. But Anna Mikhaylovna went forward a step or two to keep her hold on the
4487. portfolio, and changed her grip.
4488. 
4489. Prince Vasili rose. "Oh!" said he with reproach and surprise, "this is
4490. absurd! Come, let go I tell you."
4491. 
4492. The princess let go.
4493. 
4494. "And you too!"
4495. 
4496. But Anna Mikhaylovna did not obey him.
4497. 
4498. "Let go, I tell you! I will take the responsibility. I myself will go
4499. and ask him, I!... does that satisfy you?"
4500. 
4501. "But, Prince," said Anna Mikhaylovna, "after such a solemn sacrament,
4502. allow him a moment's peace! Here, Pierre, tell them your opinion," said
4503. she, turning to the young man who, having come quite close, was gazing
4504. with astonishment at the angry face of the princess which had lost all
4505. dignity, and at the twitching cheeks of Prince Vasili.
4506. 
4507. "Remember that you will answer for the consequences," said Prince Vasili
4508. severely. "You don't know what you are doing."
4509. 
4510. "Vile woman!" shouted the princess, darting unexpectedly at Anna
4511. Mikhaylovna and snatching the portfolio from her.
4512. 
4513. Prince Vasili bent his head and spread out his hands.
4514. 
4515. At this moment that terrible door, which Pierre had watched so long
4516. and which had always opened so quietly, burst noisily open and banged
4517. against the wall, and the second of the three sisters rushed out
4518. wringing her hands.
4519. 
4520. "What are you doing!" she cried vehemently. "He is dying and you leave
4521. me alone with him!"
4522. 
4523. Her sister dropped the portfolio. Anna Mikhaylovna, stooping, quickly
4524. caught up the object of contention and ran into the bedroom. The eldest
4525. princess and Prince Vasili, recovering themselves, followed her. A few
4526. minutes later the eldest sister came out with a pale hard face, again
4527. biting her underlip. At sight of Pierre her expression showed an
4528. irrepressible hatred.
4529. 
4530. "Yes, now you may be glad!" said she; "this is what you have been
4531. waiting for." And bursting into tears she hid her face in her
4532. handkerchief and rushed from the room.
4533. 
4534. Prince Vasili came next. He staggered to the sofa on which Pierre was
4535. sitting and dropped onto it, covering his face with his hand. Pierre
4536. noticed that he was pale and that his jaw quivered and shook as if in an
4537. ague.
4538. 
4539. "Ah, my friend!" said he, taking Pierre by the elbow; and there was
4540. in his voice a sincerity and weakness Pierre had never observed in it
4541. before. "How often we sin, how much we deceive, and all for what? I am
4542. near sixty, dear friend... I too... All will end in death, all! Death is
4543. awful..." and he burst into tears.
4544. 
4545. Anna Mikhaylovna came out last. She approached Pierre with slow, quiet
4546. steps.
4547. 
4548. "Pierre!" she said.
4549. 
4550. Pierre gave her an inquiring look. She kissed the young man on his
4551. forehead, wetting him with her tears. Then after a pause she said:
4552. 
4553. "He is no more...."
4554. 
4555. Pierre looked at her over his spectacles.
4556. 
4557. "Come, I will go with you. Try to weep, nothing gives such relief as
4558. tears."
4559. 
4560. She led him into the dark drawing room and Pierre was glad no one could
4561. see his face. Anna Mikhaylovna left him, and when she returned he was
4562. fast asleep with his head on his arm.
4563. 
4564. In the morning Anna Mikhaylovna said to Pierre:
4565. 
4566. "Yes, my dear, this is a great loss for us all, not to speak of you. But
4567. God will support you: you are young, and are now, I hope, in command of
4568. an immense fortune. The will has not yet been opened. I know you well
4569. enough to be sure that this will not turn your head, but it imposes
4570. duties on you, and you must be a man."
4571. 
4572. Pierre was silent.
4573. 
4574. "Perhaps later on I may tell you, my dear boy, that if I had not been
4575. there, God only knows what would have happened! You know, Uncle promised
4576. me only the day before yesterday not to forget Boris. But he had no
4577. time. I hope, my dear friend, you will carry out your father's wish?"
4578. 
4579. Pierre understood nothing of all this and coloring shyly looked in
4580. silence at Princess Anna Mikhaylovna. After her talk with Pierre, Anna
4581. Mikhaylovna returned to the Rostovs' and went to bed. On waking in the
4582. morning she told the Rostovs and all her acquaintances the details of
4583. Count Bezukhov's death. She said the count had died as she would herself
4584. wish to die, that his end was not only touching but edifying. As to the
4585. last meeting between father and son, it was so touching that she could
4586. not think of it without tears, and did not know which had behaved better
4587. during those awful moments--the father who so remembered everything
4588. and everybody at last and had spoken such pathetic words to the son, or
4589. Pierre, whom it had been pitiful to see, so stricken was he with grief,
4590. though he tried hard to hide it in order not to sadden his dying father.
4591. "It is painful, but it does one good. It uplifts the soul to see such
4592. men as the old count and his worthy son," said she. Of the behavior of
4593. the eldest princess and Prince Vasili she spoke disapprovingly, but in
4594. whispers and as a great secret.
4595. 
4596. 
4597. 
4598. 
4599. 
4600. CHAPTER XXV
4601. 
4602. 
4603. At Bald Hills, Prince Nicholas Andreevich Bolkonski's estate, the
4604. arrival of young Prince Andrew and his wife was daily expected, but
4605. this expectation did not upset the regular routine of life in the
4606. old prince's household. General in Chief Prince Nicholas Andreevich
4607. (nicknamed in society, "the King of Prussia") ever since the Emperor
4608. Paul had exiled him to his country estate had lived there continuously
4609. with his daughter, Princess Mary, and her companion, Mademoiselle
4610. Bourienne. Though in the new reign he was free to return to the
4611. capitals, he still continued to live in the country, remarking that
4612. anyone who wanted to see him could come the hundred miles from Moscow to
4613. Bald Hills, while he himself needed no one and nothing. He used to
4614. say that there are only two sources of human vice--idleness and
4615. superstition, and only two virtues--activity and intelligence. He
4616. himself undertook his daughter's education, and to develop these two
4617. cardinal virtues in her gave her lessons in algebra and geometry
4618. till she was twenty, and arranged her life so that her whole time was
4619. occupied. He was himself always occupied: writing his memoirs, solving
4620. problems in higher mathematics, turning snuffboxes on a lathe, working
4621. in the garden, or superintending the building that was always going on
4622. at his estate. As regularity is a prime condition facilitating activity,
4623. regularity in his household was carried to the highest point of
4624. exactitude. He always came to table under precisely the same conditions,
4625. and not only at the same hour but at the same minute. With those about
4626. him, from his daughter to his serfs, the prince was sharp and invariably
4627. exacting, so that without being a hardhearted man he inspired such fear
4628. and respect as few hardhearted men would have aroused. Although he was
4629. in retirement and had now no influence in political affairs, every high
4630. official appointed to the province in which the prince's estate lay
4631. considered it his duty to visit him and waited in the lofty antechamber
4632. just as the architect, gardener, or Princess Mary did, till the prince
4633. appeared punctually to the appointed hour. Everyone sitting in this
4634. antechamber experienced the same feeling of respect and even fear when
4635. the enormously high study door opened and showed the figure of a rather
4636. small old man, with powdered wig, small withered hands, and bushy gray
4637. eyebrows which, when he frowned, sometimes hid the gleam of his shrewd,
4638. youthfully glittering eyes.
4639. 
4640. On the morning of the day that the young couple were to arrive, Princess
4641. Mary entered the antechamber as usual at the time appointed for the
4642. morning greeting, crossing herself with trepidation and repeating a
4643. silent prayer. Every morning she came in like that, and every morning
4644. prayed that the daily interview might pass off well.
4645. 
4646. An old powdered manservant who was sitting in the antechamber rose
4647. quietly and said in a whisper: "Please walk in."
4648. 
4649. Through the door came the regular hum of a lathe. The princess timidly
4650. opened the door which moved noiselessly and easily. She paused at the
4651. entrance. The prince was working at the lathe and after glancing round
4652. continued his work.
4653. 
4654. The enormous study was full of things evidently in constant use.
4655. The large table covered with books and plans, the tall glass-fronted
4656. bookcases with keys in the locks, the high desk for writing while
4657. standing up, on which lay an open exercise book, and the lathe with
4658. tools laid ready to hand and shavings scattered around--all indicated
4659. continuous, varied, and orderly activity. The motion of the small foot
4660. shod in a Tartar boot embroidered with silver, and the firm pressure
4661. of the lean sinewy hand, showed that the prince still possessed the
4662. tenacious endurance and vigor of hardy old age. After a few more turns
4663. of the lathe he removed his foot from the pedal, wiped his chisel,
4664. dropped it into a leather pouch attached to the lathe, and, approaching
4665. the table, summoned his daughter. He never gave his children a blessing,
4666. so he simply held out his bristly cheek (as yet unshaven) and, regarding
4667. her tenderly and attentively, said severely:
4668. 
4669. "Quite well? All right then, sit down." He took the exercise book
4670. containing lessons in geometry written by himself and drew up a chair
4671. with his foot.
4672. 
4673. "For tomorrow!" said he, quickly finding the page and making a scratch
4674. from one paragraph to another with his hard nail.
4675. 
4676. The princess bent over the exercise book on the table.
4677. 
4678. "Wait a bit, here's a letter for you," said the old man suddenly, taking
4679. a letter addressed in a woman's hand from a bag hanging above the table,
4680. onto which he threw it.
4681. 
4682. At the sight of the letter red patches showed themselves on the
4683. princess' face. She took it quickly and bent her head over it.
4684. 
4685. "From Heloise?" asked the prince with a cold smile that showed his still
4686. sound, yellowish teeth.
4687. 
4688. "Yes, it's from Julie," replied the princess with a timid glance and a
4689. timid smile.
4690. 
4691. "I'll let two more letters pass, but the third I'll read," said the
4692. prince sternly; "I'm afraid you write much nonsense. I'll read the
4693. third!"
4694. 
4695. "Read this if you like, Father," said the princess, blushing still more
4696. and holding out the letter.
4697. 
4698. "The third, I said the third!" cried the prince abruptly, pushing the
4699. letter away, and leaning his elbows on the table he drew toward him the
4700. exercise book containing geometrical figures.
4701. 
4702. "Well, madam," he began, stooping over the book close to his daughter
4703. and placing an arm on the back of the chair on which she sat, so that
4704. she felt herself surrounded on all sides by the acrid scent of old age
4705. and tobacco, which she had known so long. "Now, madam, these triangles
4706. are equal; please note that the angle ABC..."
4707. 
4708. The princess looked in a scared way at her father's eyes glittering
4709. close to her; the red patches on her face came and went, and it was
4710. plain that she understood nothing and was so frightened that her
4711. fear would prevent her understanding any of her father's further
4712. explanations, however clear they might be. Whether it was the teacher's
4713. fault or the pupil's, this same thing happened every day: the princess'
4714. eyes grew dim, she could not see and could not hear anything, but was
4715. only conscious of her stern father's withered face close to her, of his
4716. breath and the smell of him, and could think only of how to get away
4717. quickly to her own room to make out the problem in peace. The old man
4718. was beside himself: moved the chair on which he was sitting noisily
4719. backward and forward, made efforts to control himself and not become
4720. vehement, but almost always did become vehement, scolded, and sometimes
4721. flung the exercise book away.
4722. 
4723. The princess gave a wrong answer.
4724. 
4725. "Well now, isn't she a fool!" shouted the prince, pushing the book aside
4726. and turning sharply away; but rising immediately, he paced up and down,
4727. lightly touched his daughter's hair and sat down again.
4728. 
4729. He drew up his chair, and continued to explain.
4730. 
4731. "This won't do, Princess; it won't do," said he, when Princess Mary,
4732. having taken and closed the exercise book with the next day's lesson,
4733. was about to leave: "Mathematics are most important, madam! I don't want
4734. to have you like our silly ladies. Get used to it and you'll like it,"
4735. and he patted her cheek. "It will drive all the nonsense out of your
4736. head."
4737. 
4738. She turned to go, but he stopped her with a gesture and took an uncut
4739. book from the high desk.
4740. 
4741. "Here is some sort of Key to the Mysteries that your Heloise has sent
4742. you. Religious! I don't interfere with anyone's belief... I have looked
4743. at it. Take it. Well, now go. Go."
4744. 
4745. He patted her on the shoulder and himself closed the door after her.
4746. 
4747. Princess Mary went back to her room with the sad, scared expression that
4748. rarely left her and which made her plain, sickly face yet plainer. She
4749. sat down at her writing table, on which stood miniature portraits and
4750. which was littered with books and papers. The princess was as untidy as
4751. her father was tidy. She put down the geometry book and eagerly broke
4752. the seal of her letter. It was from her most intimate friend from
4753. childhood; that same Julie Karagina who had been at the Rostovs'
4754. name-day party.
4755. 
4756. Julie wrote in French:
4757. 
4758. 
4759. Dear and precious Friend, How terrible and frightful a thing is
4760. separation! Though I tell myself that half my life and half my happiness
4761. are wrapped up in you, and that in spite of the distance separating us
4762. our hearts are united by indissoluble bonds, my heart rebels against
4763. fate and in spite of the pleasures and distractions around me I cannot
4764. overcome a certain secret sorrow that has been in my heart ever since
4765. we parted. Why are we not together as we were last summer, in your big
4766. study, on the blue sofa, the confidential sofa? Why cannot I now, as
4767. three months ago, draw fresh moral strength from your look, so gentle,
4768. calm, and penetrating, a look I loved so well and seem to see before me
4769. as I write?
4770. 
4771. 
4772. Having read thus far, Princess Mary sighed and glanced into the mirror
4773. which stood on her right. It reflected a weak, ungraceful figure and
4774. thin face. Her eyes, always sad, now looked with particular hopelessness
4775. at her reflection in the glass. "She flatters me," thought the princess,
4776. turning away and continuing to read. But Julie did not flatter her
4777. friend, the princess' eyes--large, deep and luminous (it seemed as if at
4778. times there radiated from them shafts of warm light)--were so beautiful
4779. that very often in spite of the plainness of her face they gave her an
4780. attraction more powerful than that of beauty. But the princess never saw
4781. the beautiful expression of her own eyes--the look they had when she
4782. was not thinking of herself. As with everyone, her face assumed a forced
4783. unnatural expression as soon as she looked in a glass. She went on
4784. reading:
4785. 
4786. 
4787. All Moscow talks of nothing but war. One of my two brothers is already
4788. abroad, the other is with the Guards, who are starting on their march
4789. to the frontier. Our dear Emperor has left Petersburg and it is thought
4790. intends to expose his precious person to the chances of war. God grant
4791. that the Corsican monster who is destroying the peace of Europe may
4792. be overthrown by the angel whom it has pleased the Almighty, in His
4793. goodness, to give us as sovereign! To say nothing of my brothers, this
4794. war has deprived me of one of the associations nearest my heart. I mean
4795. young Nicholas Rostov, who with his enthusiasm could not bear to remain
4796. inactive and has left the university to join the army. I will confess to
4797. you, dear Mary, that in spite of his extreme youth his departure for
4798. the army was a great grief to me. This young man, of whom I spoke to you
4799. last summer, is so noble-minded and full of that real youthfulness which
4800. one seldom finds nowadays among our old men of twenty and, particularly,
4801. he is so frank and has so much heart. He is so pure and poetic that
4802. my relations with him, transient as they were, have been one of the
4803. sweetest comforts to my poor heart, which has already suffered so much.
4804. Someday I will tell you about our parting and all that was said then.
4805. That is still too fresh. Ah, dear friend, you are happy not to know
4806. these poignant joys and sorrows. You are fortunate, for the latter are
4807. generally the stronger! I know very well that Count Nicholas is too
4808. young ever to be more to me than a friend, but this sweet friendship,
4809. this poetic and pure intimacy, were what my heart needed. But enough of
4810. this! The chief news, about which all Moscow gossips, is the death of
4811. old Count Bezukhov, and his inheritance. Fancy! The three princesses
4812. have received very little, Prince Vasili nothing, and it is Monsieur
4813. Pierre who has inherited all the property and has besides been
4814. recognized as legitimate; so that he is now Count Bezukhov and possessor
4815. of the finest fortune in Russia. It is rumored that Prince Vasili played
4816. a very despicable part in this affair and that he returned to Petersburg
4817. quite crestfallen.
4818. 
4819. I confess I understand very little about all these matters of wills and
4820. inheritance; but I do know that since this young man, whom we all used
4821. to know as plain Monsieur Pierre, has become Count Bezukhov and the
4822. owner of one of the largest fortunes in Russia, I am much amused to
4823. watch the change in the tone and manners of the mammas burdened by
4824. marriageable daughters, and of the young ladies themselves, toward
4825. him, though, between you and me, he always seemed to me a poor sort
4826. of fellow. As for the past two years people have amused themselves
4827. by finding husbands for me (most of whom I don't even know), the
4828. matchmaking chronicles of Moscow now speak of me as the future Countess
4829. Bezukhova. But you will understand that I have no desire for the post. A
4830. propos of marriages: do you know that a while ago that universal auntie
4831. Anna Mikhaylovna told me, under the seal of strict secrecy, of a plan of
4832. marriage for you. It is neither more nor less than with Prince Vasili's
4833. son Anatole, whom they wish to reform by marrying him to someone rich
4834. and distinguee, and it is on you that his relations' choice has fallen.
4835. I don't know what you will think of it, but I consider it my duty to
4836. let you know of it. He is said to be very handsome and a terrible
4837. scapegrace. That is all I have been able to find out about him.
4838. 
4839. But enough of gossip. I am at the end of my second sheet of paper,
4840. and Mamma has sent for me to go and dine at the Apraksins'. Read the
4841. mystical book I am sending you; it has an enormous success here. Though
4842. there are things in it difficult for the feeble human mind to grasp, it
4843. is an admirable book which calms and elevates the soul. Adieu! Give
4844. my respects to monsieur your father and my compliments to Mademoiselle
4845. Bourienne. I embrace you as I love you.
4846. 
4847. JULIE
4848. 
4849. P.S. Let me have news of your brother and his charming little wife.
4850. 
4851. 
4852. The princess pondered awhile with a thoughtful smile and her luminous
4853. eyes lit up so that her face was entirely transformed. Then she suddenly
4854. rose and with her heavy tread went up to the table. She took a sheet of
4855. paper and her hand moved rapidly over it. This is the reply she wrote,
4856. also in French:
4857. 
4858. 
4859. Dear and precious Friend, Your letter of the 13th has given me great
4860. delight. So you still love me, my romantic Julie? Separation, of which
4861. you say so much that is bad, does not seem to have had its usual effect
4862. on you. You complain of our separation. What then should I say, if I
4863. dared complain, I who am deprived of all who are dear to me? Ah, if
4864. we had not religion to console us life would be very sad. Why do you
4865. suppose that I should look severely on your affection for that young
4866. man? On such matters I am only severe with myself. I understand such
4867. feelings in others, and if never having felt them I cannot approve of
4868. them, neither do I condemn them. Only it seems to me that Christian
4869. love, love of one's neighbor, love of one's enemy, is worthier, sweeter,
4870. and better than the feelings which the beautiful eyes of a young man can
4871. inspire in a romantic and loving young girl like yourself.
4872. 
4873. The news of Count Bezukhov's death reached us before your letter and
4874. my father was much affected by it. He says the count was the last
4875. representative but one of the great century, and that it is his own
4876. turn now, but that he will do all he can to let his turn come as late as
4877. possible. God preserve us from that terrible misfortune!
4878. 
4879. I cannot agree with you about Pierre, whom I knew as a child. He always
4880. seemed to me to have an excellent heart, and that is the quality I value
4881. most in people. As to his inheritance and the part played by Prince
4882. Vasili, it is very sad for both. Ah, my dear friend, our divine
4883. Saviour's words, that it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of
4884. a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God, are terribly
4885. true. I pity Prince Vasili but am still more sorry for Pierre. So young,
4886. and burdened with such riches--to what temptations he will be exposed!
4887. If I were asked what I desire most on earth, it would be to be poorer
4888. than the poorest beggar. A thousand thanks, dear friend, for the volume
4889. you have sent me and which has such success in Moscow. Yet since you
4890. tell me that among some good things it contains others which our weak
4891. human understanding cannot grasp, it seems to me rather useless to spend
4892. time in reading what is unintelligible and can therefore bear no fruit.
4893. I never could understand the fondness some people have for confusing
4894. their minds by dwelling on mystical books that merely awaken their
4895. doubts and excite their imagination, giving them a bent for exaggeration
4896. quite contrary to Christian simplicity. Let us rather read the Epistles
4897. and Gospels. Let us not seek to penetrate what mysteries they contain;
4898. for how can we, miserable sinners that we are, know the terrible and
4899. holy secrets of Providence while we remain in this flesh which forms
4900. an impenetrable veil between us and the Eternal? Let us rather confine
4901. ourselves to studying those sublime rules which our divine Saviour has
4902. left for our guidance here below. Let us try to conform to them and
4903. follow them, and let us be persuaded that the less we let our feeble
4904. human minds roam, the better we shall please God, who rejects all
4905. knowledge that does not come from Him; and the less we seek to fathom
4906. what He has been pleased to conceal from us, the sooner will He
4907. vouchsafe its revelation to us through His divine Spirit.
4908. 
4909. My father has not spoken to me of a suitor, but has only told me that
4910. he has received a letter and is expecting a visit from Prince Vasili. In
4911. regard to this project of marriage for me, I will tell you, dear sweet
4912. friend, that I look on marriage as a divine institution to which we must
4913. conform. However painful it may be to me, should the Almighty lay
4914. the duties of wife and mother upon me I shall try to perform them as
4915. faithfully as I can, without disquieting myself by examining my feelings
4916. toward him whom He may give me for husband.
4917. 
4918. I have had a letter from my brother, who announces his speedy arrival
4919. at Bald Hills with his wife. This pleasure will be but a brief one,
4920. however, for he will leave, us again to take part in this unhappy war
4921. into which we have been drawn, God knows how or why. Not only where you
4922. are--at the heart of affairs and of the world--is the talk all of
4923. war, even here amid fieldwork and the calm of nature--which townsfolk
4924. consider characteristic of the country--rumors of war are heard
4925. and painfully felt. My father talks of nothing but marches and
4926. countermarches, things of which I understand nothing; and the day
4927. before yesterday during my daily walk through the village I witnessed a
4928. heartrending scene.... It was a convoy of conscripts enrolled from our
4929. people and starting to join the army. You should have seen the state of
4930. the mothers, wives, and children of the men who were going and should
4931. have heard the sobs. It seems as though mankind has forgotten the
4932. laws of its divine Saviour, Who preached love and forgiveness of
4933. injuries--and that men attribute the greatest merit to skill in killing
4934. one another.
4935. 
4936. Adieu, dear and kind friend; may our divine Saviour and His most Holy
4937. Mother keep you in their holy and all-powerful care!
4938. 
4939. MARY
4940. 
4941. 
4942. "Ah, you are sending off a letter, Princess? I have already dispatched
4943. mine. I have written to my poor mother," said the smiling Mademoiselle
4944. Bourienne rapidly, in her pleasant mellow tones and with guttural r's.
4945. She brought into Princess Mary's strenuous, mournful, and gloomy world a
4946. quite different atmosphere, careless, lighthearted, and self-satisfied.
4947. 
4948. "Princess, I must warn you," she added, lowering her voice and evidently
4949. listening to herself with pleasure, and speaking with exaggerated
4950. grasseyement, "the prince has been scolding Michael Ivanovich. He is in
4951. a very bad humor, very morose. Be prepared."
4952. 
4953. "Ah, dear friend," replied Princess Mary, "I have asked you never to
4954. warn me of the humor my father is in. I do not allow myself to judge him
4955. and would not have others do so."
4956. 
4957. The princess glanced at her watch and, seeing that she was five minutes
4958. late in starting her practice on the clavichord, went into the sitting
4959. room with a look of alarm. Between twelve and two o'clock, as the
4960. day was mapped out, the prince rested and the princess played the
4961. clavichord.
4962. 
4963. 
4964. 
4965.

4967. CHAPTER XXVI
4968. 
4969. 
4970. The gray-haired valet was sitting drowsily listening to the snoring of
4971. the prince, who was in his large study. From the far side of the house
4972. through the closed doors came the sound of difficult passages--twenty
4973. times repeated--of a sonata by Dussek.
4974. 
4975. Just then a closed carriage and another with a hood drove up to the
4976. porch. Prince Andrew got out of the carriage, helped his little wife to
4977. alight, and let her pass into the house before him. Old Tikhon, wearing
4978. a wig, put his head out of the door of the antechamber, reported in
4979. a whisper that the prince was sleeping, and hastily closed the door.
4980. Tikhon knew that neither the son's arrival nor any other unusual event
4981. must be allowed to disturb the appointed order of the day. Prince Andrew
4982. apparently knew this as well as Tikhon; he looked at his watch as if to
4983. ascertain whether his father's habits had changed since he was at home
4984. last, and, having assured himself that they had not, he turned to his
4985. wife.
4986. 
4987. "He will get up in twenty minutes. Let us go across to Mary's room," he
4988. said.
4989. 
4990. The little princess had grown stouter during this time, but her eyes
4991. and her short, downy, smiling lip lifted when she began to speak just as
4992. merrily and prettily as ever.
4993. 
4994. "Why, this is a palace!" she said to her husband, looking around with
4995. the expression with which people compliment their host at a ball. "Let's
4996. come, quick, quick!" And with a glance round, she smiled at Tikhon, at
4997. her husband, and at the footman who accompanied them.
4998. 
4999. "Is that Mary practicing? Let's go quietly and take her by surprise."
5000. 
5001. Prince Andrew followed her with a courteous but sad expression.
5002. 
5003. "You've grown older, Tikhon," he said in passing to the old man, who
5004. kissed his hand.
5005. 
5006. Before they reached the room from which the sounds of the clavichord
5007. came, the pretty, fair haired Frenchwoman, Mademoiselle Bourienne,
5008. rushed out apparently beside herself with delight.
5009. 
5010. "Ah! what joy for the princess!" exclaimed she: "At last! I must let her
5011. know."
5012. 
5013. "No, no, please not... You are Mademoiselle Bourienne," said the little
5014. princess, kissing her. "I know you already through my sister-in-law's
5015. friendship for you. She was not expecting us?"
5016. 
5017. They went up to the door of the sitting room from which came the sound
5018. of the oft-repeated passage of the sonata. Prince Andrew stopped and
5019. made a grimace, as if expecting something unpleasant.
5020. 
5021. The little princess entered the room. The passage broke off in the
5022. middle, a cry was heard, then Princess Mary's heavy tread and the sound
5023. of kissing. When Prince Andrew went in the two princesses, who had only
5024. met once before for a short time at his wedding, were in each other's
5025. arms warmly pressing their lips to whatever place they happened to
5026. touch. Mademoiselle Bourienne stood near them pressing her hand to her
5027. heart, with a beatific smile and obviously equally ready to cry or to
5028. laugh. Prince Andrew shrugged his shoulders and frowned, as lovers
5029. of music do when they hear a false note. The two women let go of one
5030. another, and then, as if afraid of being too late, seized each other's
5031. hands, kissing them and pulling them away, and again began kissing each
5032. other on the face, and then to Prince Andrew's surprise both began to
5033. cry and kissed again. Mademoiselle Bourienne also began to cry. Prince
5034. Andrew evidently felt ill at ease, but to the two women it seemed quite
5035. natural that they should cry, and apparently it never entered their
5036. heads that it could have been otherwise at this meeting.
5037. 
5038. "Ah! my dear!... Ah! Mary!" they suddenly exclaimed, and then laughed.
5039. "I dreamed last night..."--"You were not expecting us?..." "Ah! Mary,
5040. you have got thinner?..." "And you have grown stouter!..."
5041. 
5042. "I knew the princess at once," put in Mademoiselle Bourienne.
5043. 
5044. "And I had no idea!..." exclaimed Princess Mary. "Ah, Andrew, I did not
5045. see you."
5046. 
5047. Prince Andrew and his sister, hand in hand, kissed one another, and
5048. he told her she was still the same crybaby as ever. Princess Mary had
5049. turned toward her brother, and through her tears the loving, warm,
5050. gentle look of her large luminous eyes, very beautiful at that moment,
5051. rested on Prince Andrew's face.
5052. 
5053. The little princess talked incessantly, her short, downy upper lip
5054. continually and rapidly touching her rosy nether lip when necessary
5055. and drawing up again next moment when her face broke into a smile of
5056. glittering teeth and sparkling eyes. She told of an accident they had
5057. had on the Spasski Hill which might have been serious for her in her
5058. condition, and immediately after that informed them that she had left
5059. all her clothes in Petersburg and that heaven knew what she would have
5060. to dress in here; and that Andrew had quite changed, and that Kitty
5061. Odyntsova had married an old man, and that there was a suitor for Mary,
5062. a real one, but that they would talk of that later. Princess Mary was
5063. still looking silently at her brother and her beautiful eyes were full
5064. of love and sadness. It was plain that she was following a train of
5065. thought independent of her sister-in-law's words. In the midst of a
5066. description of the last Petersburg fete she addressed her brother:
5067. 
5068. "So you are really going to the war, Andrew?" she said sighing.
5069. 
5070. Lise sighed too.
5071. 
5072. "Yes, and even tomorrow," replied her brother.
5073. 
5074. "He is leaving me here, God knows why, when he might have had
5075. promotion..."
5076. 
5077. Princess Mary did not listen to the end, but continuing her train of
5078. thought turned to her sister-in-law with a tender glance at her figure.
5079. 
5080. "Is it certain?" she said.
5081. 
5082. The face of the little princess changed. She sighed and said: "Yes,
5083. quite certain. Ah! it is very dreadful..."
5084. 
5085. Her lip descended. She brought her face close to her sister-in-law's and
5086. unexpectedly again began to cry.
5087. 
5088. "She needs rest," said Prince Andrew with a frown. "Don't you, Lise?
5089. Take her to your room and I'll go to Father. How is he? Just the same?"
5090. 
5091. "Yes, just the same. Though I don't know what your opinion will be,"
5092. answered the princess joyfully.
5093. 
5094. "And are the hours the same? And the walks in the avenues? And the
5095. lathe?" asked Prince Andrew with a scarcely perceptible smile which
5096. showed that, in spite of all his love and respect for his father, he was
5097. aware of his weaknesses.
5098. 
5099. "The hours are the same, and the lathe, and also the mathematics and my
5100. geometry lessons," said Princess Mary gleefully, as if her lessons in
5101. geometry were among the greatest delights of her life.
5102. 
5103. When the twenty minutes had elapsed and the time had come for the old
5104. prince to get up, Tikhon came to call the young prince to his father.
5105. The old man made a departure from his usual routine in honor of his
5106. son's arrival: he gave orders to admit him to his apartments while
5107. he dressed for dinner. The old prince always dressed in old-fashioned
5108. style, wearing an antique coat and powdered hair; and when Prince Andrew
5109. entered his father's dressing room (not with the contemptuous look and
5110. manner he wore in drawing rooms, but with the animated face with which
5111. he talked to Pierre), the old man was sitting on a large leather-covered
5112. chair, wrapped in a powdering mantle, entrusting his head to Tikhon.
5113. 
5114. "Ah! here's the warrior! Wants to vanquish Buonaparte?" said the old
5115. man, shaking his powdered head as much as the tail, which Tikhon was
5116. holding fast to plait, would allow.
5117. 
5118. "You at least must tackle him properly, or else if he goes on like this
5119. he'll soon have us, too, for his subjects! How are you?" And he held out
5120. his cheek.
5121. 
5122. The old man was in a good temper after his nap before dinner. (He used
5123. to say that a nap "after dinner was silver--before dinner, golden.")
5124. He cast happy, sidelong glances at his son from under his thick, bushy
5125. eyebrows. Prince Andrew went up and kissed his father on the
5126. spot indicated to him. He made no reply on his father's favorite
5127. topic--making fun of the military men of the day, and more particularly
5128. of Bonaparte.
5129. 
5130. "Yes, Father, I have come to you and brought my wife who is pregnant,"
5131. said Prince Andrew, following every movement of his father's face with
5132. an eager and respectful look. "How is your health?"
5133. 
5134. "Only fools and rakes fall ill, my boy. You know me: I am busy from
5135. morning till night and abstemious, so of course I am well."
5136. 
5137. "Thank God," said his son smiling.
5138. 
5139. "God has nothing to do with it! Well, go on," he continued, returning to
5140. his hobby; "tell me how the Germans have taught you to fight Bonaparte
5141. by this new science you call 'strategy.'"
5142. 
5143. Prince Andrew smiled.
5144. 
5145. "Give me time to collect my wits, Father," said he, with a smile that
5146. showed that his father's foibles did not prevent his son from loving and
5147. honoring him. "Why, I have not yet had time to settle down!"
5148. 
5149. "Nonsense, nonsense!" cried the old man, shaking his pigtail to see
5150. whether it was firmly plaited, and grasping his by the hand. "The house
5151. for your wife is ready. Princess Mary will take her there and show her
5152. over, and they'll talk nineteen to the dozen. That's their woman's
5153. way! I am glad to have her. Sit down and talk. About Mikhelson's army
5154. I understand--Tolstoy's too... a simultaneous expedition.... But what's
5155. the southern army to do? Prussia is neutral... I know that. What about
5156. Austria?" said he, rising from his chair and pacing up and down the room
5157. followed by Tikhon, who ran after him, handing him different articles of
5158. clothing. "What of Sweden? How will they cross Pomerania?"
5159. 
5160. Prince Andrew, seeing that his father insisted, began--at first
5161. reluctantly, but gradually with more and more animation, and from habit
5162. changing unconsciously from Russian to French as he went on--to explain
5163. the plan of operation for the coming campaign. He explained how an army,
5164. ninety thousand strong, was to threaten Prussia so as to bring her out
5165. of her neutrality and draw her into the war; how part of that army was
5166. to join some Swedish forces at Stralsund; how two hundred and twenty
5167. thousand Austrians, with a hundred thousand Russians, were to operate in
5168. Italy and on the Rhine; how fifty thousand Russians and as many English
5169. were to land at Naples, and how a total force of five hundred thousand
5170. men was to attack the French from different sides. The old prince did
5171. not evince the least interest during this explanation, but as if he were
5172. not listening to it continued to dress while walking about, and three
5173. times unexpectedly interrupted. Once he stopped it by shouting: "The
5174. white one, the white one!"
5175. 
5176. This meant that Tikhon was not handing him the waistcoat he wanted.
5177. Another time he interrupted, saying:
5178. 
5179. "And will she soon be confined?" and shaking his head reproachfully
5180. said: "That's bad! Go on, go on."
5181. 
5182. The third interruption came when Prince Andrew was finishing his
5183. description. The old man began to sing, in the cracked voice of old age:
5184. "Malbrook s'en va-t-en guerre. Dieu sait quand reviendra." *
5185. 
5186. 
5187.      * "Marlborough is going to the wars; God knows when he'll
5188.      return."
5189. 
5190. 
5191. His son only smiled.
5192. 
5193. "I don't say it's a plan I approve of," said the son; "I am only telling
5194. you what it is. Napoleon has also formed his plan by now, not worse than
5195. this one."
5196. 
5197. "Well, you've told me nothing new," and the old man repeated,
5198. meditatively and rapidly:
5199. 
5200. "Dieu sait quand reviendra. Go to the dining room."
5201. 
5202. 
5203. 
5204.
