5206. CHAPTER XXVII
5207. 
5208. 
5209. At the appointed hour the prince, powdered and shaven, entered the
5210. dining room where his daughter-in-law, Princess Mary, and Mademoiselle
5211. Bourienne were already awaiting him together with his architect, who
5212. by a strange caprice of his employer's was admitted to table though the
5213. position of that insignificant individual was such as could certainly
5214. not have caused him to expect that honor. The prince, who generally kept
5215. very strictly to social distinctions and rarely admitted even important
5216. government officials to his table, had unexpectedly selected Michael
5217. Ivanovich (who always went into a corner to blow his nose on his checked
5218. handkerchief) to illustrate the theory that all men are equals, and had
5219. more than once impressed on his daughter that Michael Ivanovich was "not
5220. a whit worse than you or I." At dinner the prince usually spoke to the
5221. taciturn Michael Ivanovich more often than to anyone else.
5222. 
5223. In the dining room, which like all the rooms in the house was
5224. exceedingly lofty, the members of the household and the footmen--one
5225. behind each chair--stood waiting for the prince to enter. The head
5226. butler, napkin on arm, was scanning the setting of the table, making
5227. signs to the footmen, and anxiously glancing from the clock to the door
5228. by which the prince was to enter. Prince Andrew was looking at a large
5229. gilt frame, new to him, containing the genealogical tree of the Princes
5230. Bolkonski, opposite which hung another such frame with a badly painted
5231. portrait (evidently by the hand of the artist belonging to the estate)
5232. of a ruling prince, in a crown--an alleged descendant of Rurik and
5233. ancestor of the Bolkonskis. Prince Andrew, looking again at that
5234. genealogical tree, shook his head, laughing as a man laughs who looks at
5235. a portrait so characteristic of the original as to be amusing.
5236. 
5237. "How thoroughly like him that is!" he said to Princess Mary, who had
5238. come up to him.
5239. 
5240. Princess Mary looked at her brother in surprise. She did not understand
5241. what he was laughing at. Everything her father did inspired her with
5242. reverence and was beyond question.
5243. 
5244. "Everyone has his Achilles' heel," continued Prince Andrew. "Fancy, with
5245. his powerful mind, indulging in such nonsense!"
5246. 
5247. Princess Mary could not understand the boldness of her brother's
5248. criticism and was about to reply, when the expected footsteps were heard
5249. coming from the study. The prince walked in quickly and jauntily as was
5250. his wont, as if intentionally contrasting the briskness of his manners
5251. with the strict formality of his house. At that moment the great clock
5252. struck two and another with a shrill tone joined in from the drawing
5253. room. The prince stood still; his lively glittering eyes from under
5254. their thick, bushy eyebrows sternly scanned all present and rested on
5255. the little princess. She felt, as courtiers do when the Tsar enters, the
5256. sensation of fear and respect which the old man inspired in all around
5257. him. He stroked her hair and then patted her awkwardly on the back of
5258. her neck.
5259. 
5260. "I'm glad, glad, to see you," he said, looking attentively into her
5261. eyes, and then quickly went to his place and sat down. "Sit down, sit
5262. down! Sit down, Michael Ianovich!"
5263. 
5264. He indicated a place beside him to his daughter-in-law. A footman moved
5265. the chair for her.
5266. 
5267. "Ho, ho!" said the old man, casting his eyes on her rounded figure.
5268. "You've been in a hurry. That's bad!"
5269. 
5270. He laughed in his usual dry, cold, unpleasant way, with his lips only
5271. and not with his eyes.
5272. 
5273. "You must walk, walk as much as possible, as much as possible," he said.
5274. 
5275. The little princess did not, or did not wish to, hear his words. She was
5276. silent and seemed confused. The prince asked her about her father, and
5277. she began to smile and talk. He asked about mutual acquaintances, and
5278. she became still more animated and chattered away giving him greetings
5279. from various people and retailing the town gossip.
5280. 
5281. "Countess Apraksina, poor thing, has lost her husband and she has cried
5282. her eyes out," she said, growing more and more lively.
5283. 
5284. As she became animated the prince looked at her more and more sternly,
5285. and suddenly, as if he had studied her sufficiently and had formed a
5286. definite idea of her, he turned away and addressed Michael Ivanovich.
5287. 
5288. "Well, Michael Ivanovich, our Bonaparte will be having a bad time of it.
5289. Prince Andrew" (he always spoke thus of his son) "has been telling
5290. me what forces are being collected against him! While you and I never
5291. thought much of him."
5292. 
5293. Michael Ivanovich did not at all know when "you and I" had said such
5294. things about Bonaparte, but understanding that he was wanted as a peg on
5295. which to hang the prince's favorite topic, he looked inquiringly at the
5296. young prince, wondering what would follow.
5297. 
5298. "He is a great tactician!" said the prince to his son, pointing to the
5299. architect.
5300. 
5301. And the conversation again turned on the war, on Bonaparte, and the
5302. generals and statesmen of the day. The old prince seemed convinced not
5303. only that all the men of the day were mere babies who did not know the
5304. A B C of war or of politics, and that Bonaparte was an insignificant
5305. little Frenchy, successful only because there were no longer any
5306. Potemkins or Suvorovs left to oppose him; but he was also convinced that
5307. there were no political difficulties in Europe and no real war, but
5308. only a sort of puppet show at which the men of the day were playing,
5309. pretending to do something real. Prince Andrew gaily bore with his
5310. father's ridicule of the new men, and drew him on and listened to him
5311. with evident pleasure.
5312. 
5313. "The past always seems good," said he, "but did not Suvorov himself
5314. fall into a trap Moreau set him, and from which he did not know how to
5315. escape?"
5316. 
5317. "Who told you that? Who?" cried the prince. "Suvorov!" And he jerked
5318. away his plate, which Tikhon briskly caught. "Suvorov!... Consider,
5319. Prince Andrew. Two... Frederick and Suvorov; Moreau!... Moreau would
5320. have been a prisoner if Suvorov had had a free hand; but he had the
5321. Hofs-kriegs-wurst-schnapps-Rath on his hands. It would have puzzled
5322. the devil himself! When you get there you'll find out what those
5323. Hofs-kriegs-wurst-Raths are! Suvorov couldn't manage them so what chance
5324. has Michael Kutuzov? No, my dear boy," he continued, "you and your
5325. generals won't get on against Buonaparte; you'll have to call in the
5326. French, so that birds of a feather may fight together. The German,
5327. Pahlen, has been sent to New York in America, to fetch the Frenchman,
5328. Moreau," he said, alluding to the invitation made that year to Moreau
5329. to enter the Russian service.... "Wonderful!... Were the Potemkins,
5330. Suvorovs, and Orlovs Germans? No, lad, either you fellows have all lost
5331. your wits, or I have outlived mine. May God help you, but we'll see what
5332. will happen. Buonaparte has become a great commander among them! Hm!..."
5333. 
5334. "I don't at all say that all the plans are good," said Prince Andrew, "I
5335. am only surprised at your opinion of Bonaparte. You may laugh as much as
5336. you like, but all the same Bonaparte is a great general!"
5337. 
5338. "Michael Ivanovich!" cried the old prince to the architect who, busy
5339. with his roast meat, hoped he had been forgotten: "Didn't I tell you
5340. Buonaparte was a great tactician? Here, he says the same thing."
5341. 
5342. "To be sure, your excellency," replied the architect.
5343. 
5344. The prince again laughed his frigid laugh.
5345. 
5346. "Buonaparte was born with a silver spoon in his mouth. He has got
5347. splendid soldiers. Besides he began by attacking Germans. And only
5348. idlers have failed to beat the Germans. Since the world began everybody
5349. has beaten the Germans. They beat no one--except one another. He made
5350. his reputation fighting them."
5351. 
5352. And the prince began explaining all the blunders which, according to
5353. him, Bonaparte had made in his campaigns and even in politics. His
5354. son made no rejoinder, but it was evident that whatever arguments were
5355. presented he was as little able as his father to change his opinion. He
5356. listened, refraining from a reply, and involuntarily wondered how this
5357. old man, living alone in the country for so many years, could know and
5358. discuss so minutely and acutely all the recent European military and
5359. political events.
5360. 
5361. "You think I'm an old man and don't understand the present state of
5362. affairs?" concluded his father. "But it troubles me. I don't sleep
5363. at night. Come now, where has this great commander of yours shown his
5364. skill?" he concluded.
5365. 
5366. "That would take too long to tell," answered the son.
5367. 
5368. "Well, then go to your Buonaparte! Mademoiselle Bourienne, here's
5369. another admirer of that powder-monkey emperor of yours," he exclaimed in
5370. excellent French.
5371. 
5372. "You know, Prince, I am not a Bonapartist!"
5373. 
5374. "Dieu sait quand reviendra..." hummed the prince out of tune and, with a
5375. laugh still more so, he quitted the table.
5376. 
5377. The little princess during the whole discussion and the rest of
5378. the dinner sat silent, glancing with a frightened look now at her
5379. father-in-law and now at Princess Mary. When they left the table she
5380. took her sister-in-law's arm and drew her into another room.
5381. 
5382. "What a clever man your father is," said she; "perhaps that is why I am
5383. afraid of him."
5384. 
5385. "Oh, he is so kind!" answered Princess Mary.
5386. 
5387. 
5388. 
5389. 
5390. 
5391. CHAPTER XXVIII
5392. 
5393. 
5394. Prince Andrew was to leave next evening. The old prince, not altering
5395. his routine, retired as usual after dinner. The little princess was
5396. in her sister-in-law's room. Prince Andrew in a traveling coat without
5397. epaulettes had been packing with his valet in the rooms assigned to him.
5398. After inspecting the carriage himself and seeing the trunks put in, he
5399. ordered the horses to be harnessed. Only those things he always kept
5400. with him remained in his room; a small box, a large canteen fitted with
5401. silver plate, two Turkish pistols and a saber--a present from his
5402. father who had brought it from the siege of Ochakov. All these traveling
5403. effects of Prince Andrew's were in very good order: new, clean, and in
5404. cloth covers carefully tied with tapes.
5405. 
5406. When starting on a journey or changing their mode of life, men capable
5407. of reflection are generally in a serious frame of mind. At such moments
5408. one reviews the past and plans for the future. Prince Andrew's face
5409. looked very thoughtful and tender. With his hands behind him he paced
5410. briskly from corner to corner of the room, looking straight before him
5411. and thoughtfully shaking his head. Did he fear going to the war, or was
5412. he sad at leaving his wife?--perhaps both, but evidently he did not
5413. wish to be seen in that mood, for hearing footsteps in the passage he
5414. hurriedly unclasped his hands, stopped at a table as if tying the
5415. cover of the small box, and assumed his usual tranquil and impenetrable
5416. expression. It was the heavy tread of Princess Mary that he heard.
5417. 
5418. "I hear you have given orders to harness," she cried, panting (she had
5419. apparently been running), "and I did so wish to have another talk with
5420. you alone! God knows how long we may again be parted. You are not angry
5421. with me for coming? You have changed so, Andrusha," she added, as if to
5422. explain such a question.
5423. 
5424. She smiled as she uttered his pet name, "Andrusha." It was obviously
5425. strange to her to think that this stern handsome man should be
5426. Andrusha--the slender mischievous boy who had been her playfellow in
5427. childhood.
5428. 
5429. "And where is Lise?" he asked, answering her question only by a smile.
5430. 
5431. "She was so tired that she has fallen asleep on the sofa in my room. Oh,
5432. Andrew! What a treasure of a wife you have," said she, sitting down on
5433. the sofa, facing her brother. "She is quite a child: such a dear, merry
5434. child. I have grown so fond of her."
5435. 
5436. Prince Andrew was silent, but the princess noticed the ironical and
5437. contemptuous look that showed itself on his face.
5438. 
5439. "One must be indulgent to little weaknesses; who is free from them,
5440. Andrew? Don't forget that she has grown up and been educated in
5441. society, and so her position now is not a rosy one. We should enter into
5442. everyone's situation. Tout comprendre, c'est tout pardonner. * Think
5443. what it must be for her, poor thing, after what she has been used to,
5444. to be parted from her husband and be left alone in the country, in her
5445. condition! It's very hard."
5446. 
5447. 
5448.      * To understand all is to forgive all.
5449. 
5450. 
5451. Prince Andrew smiled as he looked at his sister, as we smile at those we
5452. think we thoroughly understand.
5453. 
5454. "You live in the country and don't think the life terrible," he replied.
5455. 
5456. "I... that's different. Why speak of me? I don't want any other life,
5457. and can't, for I know no other. But think, Andrew: for a young society
5458. woman to be buried in the country during the best years of her life,
5459. all alone--for Papa is always busy, and I... well, you know what poor
5460. resources I have for entertaining a woman used to the best society.
5461. There is only Mademoiselle Bourienne...."
5462. 
5463. "I don't like your Mademoiselle Bourienne at all," said Prince Andrew.
5464. 
5465. "No? She is very nice and kind and, above all, she's much to be pitied.
5466. She has no one, no one. To tell the truth, I don't need her, and she's
5467. even in my way. You know I always was a savage, and now am even more
5468. so. I like being alone.... Father likes her very much. She and Michael
5469. Ivanovich are the two people to whom he is always gentle and kind,
5470. because he has been a benefactor to them both. As Sterne says: 'We don't
5471. love people so much for the good they have done us, as for the good we
5472. have done them.' Father took her when she was homeless after losing her
5473. own father. She is very good-natured, and my father likes her way of
5474. reading. She reads to him in the evenings and reads splendidly."
5475. 
5476. "To be quite frank, Mary, I expect Father's character sometimes makes
5477. things trying for you, doesn't it?" Prince Andrew asked suddenly.
5478. 
5479. Princess Mary was first surprised and then aghast at this question.
5480. 
5481. "For me? For me?... Trying for me!..." said she.
5482. 
5483. "He always was rather harsh; and now I should think he's getting very
5484. trying," said Prince Andrew, apparently speaking lightly of their father
5485. in order to puzzle or test his sister.
5486. 
5487. "You are good in every way, Andrew, but you have a kind of intellectual
5488. pride," said the princess, following the train of her own thoughts
5489. rather than the trend of the conversation--"and that's a great sin.
5490. How can one judge Father? But even if one might, what feeling except
5491. veneration could such a man as my father evoke? And I am so contented
5492. and happy with him. I only wish you were all as happy as I am."
5493. 
5494. Her brother shook his head incredulously.
5495. 
5496. "The only thing that is hard for me... I will tell you the truth,
5497. Andrew... is Father's way of treating religious subjects. I don't
5498. understand how a man of his immense intellect can fail to see what is
5499. as clear as day, and can go so far astray. That is the only thing
5500. that makes me unhappy. But even in this I can see lately a shade of
5501. improvement. His satire has been less bitter of late, and there was a
5502. monk he received and had a long talk with."
5503. 
5504. "Ah! my dear, I am afraid you and your monk are wasting your powder,"
5505. said Prince Andrew banteringly yet tenderly.
5506. 
5507. "Ah! mon ami, I only pray, and hope that God will hear me. Andrew..."
5508. she said timidly after a moment's silence, "I have a great favor to ask
5509. of you."
5510. 
5511. "What is it, dear?"
5512. 
5513. "No--promise that you will not refuse! It will give you no trouble
5514. and is nothing unworthy of you, but it will comfort me. Promise,
5515. Andrusha!..." said she, putting her hand in her reticule but not yet
5516. taking out what she was holding inside it, as if what she held were
5517. the subject of her request and must not be shown before the request was
5518. granted.
5519. 
5520. She looked timidly at her brother.
5521. 
5522. "Even if it were a great deal of trouble..." answered Prince Andrew, as
5523. if guessing what it was about.
5524. 
5525. "Think what you please! I know you are just like Father. Think as
5526. you please, but do this for my sake! Please do! Father's father, our
5527. grandfather, wore it in all his wars." (She still did not take out what
5528. she was holding in her reticule.) "So you promise?"
5529. 
5530. "Of course. What is it?"
5531. 
5532. "Andrew, I bless you with this icon and you must promise me you will
5533. never take it off. Do you promise?"
5534. 
5535. "If it does not weigh a hundredweight and won't break my neck... To
5536. please you..." said Prince Andrew. But immediately, noticing the pained
5537. expression his joke had brought to his sister's face, he repented and
5538. added: "I am glad; really, dear, I am very glad."
5539. 
5540. "Against your will He will save and have mercy on you and bring you
5541. to Himself, for in Him alone is truth and peace," said she in a voice
5542. trembling with emotion, solemnly holding up in both hands before her
5543. brother a small, oval, antique, dark-faced icon of the Saviour in a gold
5544. setting, on a finely wrought silver chain.
5545. 
5546. She crossed herself, kissed the icon, and handed it to Andrew.
5547. 
5548. "Please, Andrew, for my sake!..."
5549. 
5550. Rays of gentle light shone from her large, timid eyes. Those eyes lit
5551. up the whole of her thin, sickly face and made it beautiful. Her brother
5552. would have taken the icon, but she stopped him. Andrew understood,
5553. crossed himself and kissed the icon. There was a look of tenderness, for
5554. he was touched, but also a gleam of irony on his face.
5555. 
5556. "Thank you, my dear." She kissed him on the forehead and sat down again
5557. on the sofa. They were silent for a while.
5558. 
5559. "As I was saying to you, Andrew, be kind and generous as you always
5560. used to be. Don't judge Lise harshly," she began. "She is so sweet, so
5561. good-natured, and her position now is a very hard one."
5562. 
5563. "I do not think I have complained of my wife to you, Masha, or blamed
5564. her. Why do you say all this to me?"
5565. 
5566. Red patches appeared on Princess Mary's face and she was silent as if
5567. she felt guilty.
5568. 
5569. "I have said nothing to you, but you have already been talked to. And I
5570. am sorry for that," he went on.
5571. 
5572. The patches grew deeper on her forehead, neck, and cheeks. She tried to
5573. say something but could not. Her brother had guessed right: the little
5574. princess had been crying after dinner and had spoken of her forebodings
5575. about her confinement, and how she dreaded it, and had complained of her
5576. fate, her father-in-law, and her husband. After crying she had fallen
5577. asleep. Prince Andrew felt sorry for his sister.
5578. 
5579. "Know this, Masha: I can't reproach, have not reproached, and never
5580. shall reproach my wife with anything, and I cannot reproach myself
5581. with anything in regard to her; and that always will be so in whatever
5582. circumstances I may be placed. But if you want to know the truth... if
5583. you want to know whether I am happy? No! Is she happy? No! But why this
5584. is so I don't know..."
5585. 
5586. As he said this he rose, went to his sister, and, stooping, kissed
5587. her forehead. His fine eyes lit up with a thoughtful, kindly, and
5588. unaccustomed brightness, but he was looking not at his sister but over
5589. her head toward the darkness of the open doorway.
5590. 
5591. "Let us go to her, I must say good-by. Or--go and wake and I'll come
5592. in a moment. Petrushka!" he called to his valet: "Come here, take these
5593. away. Put this on the seat and this to the right."
5594. 
5595. Princess Mary rose and moved to the door, then stopped and said:
5596. "Andrew, if you had faith you would have turned to God and asked Him
5597. to give you the love you do not feel, and your prayer would have been
5598. answered."
5599. 
5600. "Well, may be!" said Prince Andrew. "Go, Masha; I'll come immediately."
5601. 
5602. On the way to his sister's room, in the passage which connected one
5603. wing with the other, Prince Andrew met Mademoiselle Bourienne smiling
5604. sweetly. It was the third time that day that, with an ecstatic and
5605. artless smile, she had met him in secluded passages.
5606. 
5607. "Oh! I thought you were in your room," she said, for some reason
5608. blushing and dropping her eyes.
5609. 
5610. Prince Andrew looked sternly at her and an expression of anger suddenly
5611. came over his face. He said nothing to her but looked at her forehead
5612. and hair, without looking at her eyes, with such contempt that the
5613. Frenchwoman blushed and went away without a word. When he reached his
5614. sister's room his wife was already awake and her merry voice, hurrying
5615. one word after another, came through the open door. She was speaking as
5616. usual in French, and as if after long self-restraint she wished to make
5617. up for lost time.
5618. 
5619. "No, but imagine the old Countess Zubova, with false curls and her mouth
5620. full of false teeth, as if she were trying to cheat old age.... Ha, ha,
5621. ha! Mary!"
5622. 
5623. This very sentence about Countess Zubova and this same laugh Prince
5624. Andrew had already heard from his wife in the presence of others some
5625. five times. He entered the room softly. The little princess, plump and
5626. rosy, was sitting in an easy chair with her work in her hands, talking
5627. incessantly, repeating Petersburg reminiscences and even phrases. Prince
5628. Andrew came up, stroked her hair, and asked if she felt rested after
5629. their journey. She answered him and continued her chatter.
5630. 
5631. The coach with six horses was waiting at the porch. It was an autumn
5632. night, so dark that the coachman could not see the carriage pole.
5633. Servants with lanterns were bustling about in the porch. The immense
5634. house was brilliant with lights shining through its lofty windows. The
5635. domestic serfs were crowding in the hall, waiting to bid good-by to
5636. the young prince. The members of the household were all gathered in
5637. the reception hall: Michael Ivanovich, Mademoiselle Bourienne, Princess
5638. Mary, and the little princess. Prince Andrew had been called to his
5639. father's study as the latter wished to say good-by to him alone. All
5640. were waiting for them to come out.
5641. 
5642. When Prince Andrew entered the study the old man in his old-age
5643. spectacles and white dressing gown, in which he received no one but his
5644. son, sat at the table writing. He glanced round.
5645. 
5646. "Going?" And he went on writing.
5647. 
5648. "I've come to say good-by."
5649. 
5650. "Kiss me here," and he touched his cheek: "Thanks, thanks!"
5651. 
5652. "What do you thank me for?"
5653. 
5654. "For not dilly-dallying and not hanging to a woman's apron strings. The
5655. Service before everything. Thanks, thanks!" And he went on writing, so
5656. that his quill spluttered and squeaked. "If you have anything to say,
5657. say it. These two things can be done together," he added.
5658. 
5659. "About my wife... I am ashamed as it is to leave her on your hands..."
5660. 
5661. "Why talk nonsense? Say what you want."
5662. 
5663. "When her confinement is due, send to Moscow for an accoucheur.... Let
5664. him be here...."
5665. 
5666. The old prince stopped writing and, as if not understanding, fixed his
5667. stern eyes on his son.
5668. 
5669. "I know that no one can help if nature does not do her work," said
5670. Prince Andrew, evidently confused. "I know that out of a million cases
5671. only one goes wrong, but it is her fancy and mine. They have been
5672. telling her things. She has had a dream and is frightened."
5673. 
5674. "Hm... Hm..." muttered the old prince to himself, finishing what he was
5675. writing. "I'll do it."
5676. 
5677. He signed with a flourish and suddenly turning to his son began to
5678. laugh.
5679. 
5680. "It's a bad business, eh?"
5681. 
5682. "What is bad, Father?"
5683. 
5684. "The wife!" said the old prince, briefly and significantly.
5685. 
5686. "I don't understand!" said Prince Andrew.
5687. 
5688. "No, it can't be helped, lad," said the prince. "They're all like that;
5689. one can't unmarry. Don't be afraid; I won't tell anyone, but you know it
5690. yourself."
5691. 
5692. He seized his son by the hand with small bony fingers, shook it, looked
5693. straight into his son's face with keen eyes which seemed to see through
5694. him, and again laughed his frigid laugh.
5695. 
5696. The son sighed, thus admitting that his father had understood him. The
5697. old man continued to fold and seal his letter, snatching up and throwing
5698. down the wax, the seal, and the paper, with his accustomed rapidity.
5699. 
5700. "What's to be done? She's pretty! I will do everything. Make your mind
5701. easy," said he in abrupt sentences while sealing his letter.
5702. 
5703. Andrew did not speak; he was both pleased and displeased that his father
5704. understood him. The old man got up and gave the letter to his son.
5705. 
5706. "Listen!" said he; "don't worry about your wife: what can be done shall
5707. be. Now listen! Give this letter to Michael Ilarionovich. * I have
5708. written that he should make use of you in proper places and not keep you
5709. long as an adjutant: a bad position! Tell him I remember and like him.
5710. Write and tell me how he receives you. If he is all right--serve
5711. him. Nicholas Bolkonski's son need not serve under anyone if he is in
5712. disfavor. Now come here."
5713. 
5714. 
5715.      *Kutuzov.
5716. 
5717. 
5718. He spoke so rapidly that he did not finish half his words, but his son
5719. was accustomed to understand him. He led him to the desk, raised the
5720. lid, drew out a drawer, and took out an exercise book filled with his

5722. 
5723. "I shall probably die before you. So remember, these are my memoirs;
5724. hand them to the Emperor after my death. Now here is a Lombard bond and
5725. a letter; it is a premium for the man who writes a history of Suvorov's
5726. wars. Send it to the Academy. Here are some jottings for you to read
5727. when I am gone. You will find them useful."
5728. 
5729. Andrew did not tell his father that he would no doubt live a long time
5730. yet. He felt that he must not say it.
5731. 
5732. "I will do it all, Father," he said.
5733. 
5734. "Well, now, good-by!" He gave his son his hand to kiss, and embraced
5735. him. "Remember this, Prince Andrew, if they kill you it will hurt me,
5736. your old father..." he paused unexpectedly, and then in a querulous
5737. voice suddenly shrieked: "but if I hear that you have not behaved like a
5738. son of Nicholas Bolkonski, I shall be ashamed!"
5739. 
5740. "You need not have said that to me, Father," said the son with a smile.
5741. 
5742. The old man was silent.
5743. 
5744. "I also wanted to ask you," continued Prince Andrew, "if I'm killed
5745. and if I have a son, do not let him be taken away from you--as I said
5746. yesterday... let him grow up with you.... Please."
5747. 
5748. "Not let the wife have him?" said the old man, and laughed.
5749. 
5750. They stood silent, facing one another. The old man's sharp eyes were
5751. fixed straight on his son's. Something twitched in the lower part of the
5752. old prince's face.
5753. 
5754. "We've said good-by. Go!" he suddenly shouted in a loud, angry voice,
5755. opening his door.
5756. 
5757. "What is it? What?" asked both princesses when they saw for a moment at
5758. the door Prince Andrew and the figure of the old man in a white dressing
5759. gown, spectacled and wigless, shouting in an angry voice.
5760. 
5761. Prince Andrew sighed and made no reply.
5762. 
5763. "Well!" he said, turning to his wife.
5764. 
5765. And this "Well!" sounded coldly ironic, as if he were saying,: "Now go
5766. through your performance."
5767. 
5768. "Andrew, already!" said the little princess, turning pale and looking
5769. with dismay at her husband.
5770. 
5771. He embraced her. She screamed and fell unconscious on his shoulder.
5772. 
5773. He cautiously released the shoulder she leaned on, looked into her face,
5774. and carefully placed her in an easy chair.
5775. 
5776. "Adieu, Mary," said he gently to his sister, taking her by the hand and
5777. kissing her, and then he left the room with rapid steps.
5778. 
5779. The little princess lay in the armchair, Mademoiselle Bourienne chafing
5780. her temples. Princess Mary, supporting her sister-in-law, still looked
5781. with her beautiful eyes full of tears at the door through which Prince
5782. Andrew had gone and made the sign of the cross in his direction. From
5783. the study, like pistol shots, came the frequent sound of the old man
5784. angrily blowing his nose. Hardly had Prince Andrew gone when the study
5785. door opened quickly and the stern figure of the old man in the white
5786. dressing gown looked out.
5787. 
5788. "Gone? That's all right!" said he; and looking angrily at the
5789. unconscious little princess, he shook his head reprovingly and slammed
5790. the door.
5791. 
5792. 
5793. 
5794. 
5795. 
5796. BOOK TWO: 1805
5797. 
5798. 
5799. 
5800. 
5801. 
5802. CHAPTER I
5803. 
5804. 
5805. In October, 1805, a Russian army was occupying the villages and towns of
5806. the Archduchy of Austria, and yet other regiments freshly arriving from
5807. Russia were settling near the fortress of Braunau and burdening the
5808. inhabitants on whom they were quartered. Braunau was the headquarters of
5809. the commander-in-chief, Kutuzov.
5810. 
5811. On October 11, 1805, one of the infantry regiments that had just reached
5812. Braunau had halted half a mile from the town, waiting to be inspected
5813. by the commander in chief. Despite the un-Russian appearance of the
5814. locality and surroundings--fruit gardens, stone fences, tiled roofs, and
5815. hills in the distance--and despite the fact that the inhabitants (who
5816. gazed with curiosity at the soldiers) were not Russians, the regiment
5817. had just the appearance of any Russian regiment preparing for an
5818. inspection anywhere in the heart of Russia.
5819. 
5820. On the evening of the last day's march an order had been received that
5821. the commander in chief would inspect the regiment on the march. Though
5822. the words of the order were not clear to the regimental commander, and
5823. the question arose whether the troops were to be in marching order or
5824. not, it was decided at a consultation between the battalion commanders
5825. to present the regiment in parade order, on the principle that it is
5826. always better to "bow too low than not bow low enough." So the soldiers,
5827. after a twenty-mile march, were kept mending and cleaning all night long
5828. without closing their eyes, while the adjutants and company commanders
5829. calculated and reckoned, and by morning the regiment--instead of the
5830. straggling, disorderly crowd it had been on its last march the day
5831. before--presented a well-ordered array of two thousand men each of whom
5832. knew his place and his duty, had every button and every strap in place,
5833. and shone with cleanliness. And not only externally was all in order,
5834. but had it pleased the commander in chief to look under the uniforms he
5835. would have found on every man a clean shirt, and in every knapsack the
5836. appointed number of articles, "awl, soap, and all," as the soldiers
5837. say. There was only one circumstance concerning which no one could be at
5838. ease. It was the state of the soldiers' boots. More than half the men's
5839. boots were in holes. But this defect was not due to any fault of the
5840. regimental commander, for in spite of repeated demands boots had not
5841. been issued by the Austrian commissariat, and the regiment had marched
5842. some seven hundred miles.
5843. 
5844. The commander of the regiment was an elderly, choleric, stout, and
5845. thick-set general with grizzled eyebrows and whiskers, and wider from
5846. chest to back than across the shoulders. He had on a brand-new uniform
5847. showing the creases where it had been folded and thick gold epaulettes
5848. which seemed to stand rather than lie down on his massive shoulders. He
5849. had the air of a man happily performing one of the most solemn duties of
5850. his life. He walked about in front of the line and at every step pulled
5851. himself up, slightly arching his back. It was plain that the commander
5852. admired his regiment, rejoiced in it, and that his whole mind was
5853. engrossed by it, yet his strut seemed to indicate that, besides military
5854. matters, social interests and the fair sex occupied no small part of his
5855. thoughts.
5856. 
5857. "Well, Michael Mitrich, sir?" he said, addressing one of the battalion
5858. commanders who smilingly pressed forward (it was plain that they both
5859. felt happy). "We had our hands full last night. However, I think the
5860. regiment is not a bad one, eh?"
5861. 
5862. The battalion commander perceived the jovial irony and laughed.
5863. 
5864. "It would not be turned off the field even on the Tsaritsin Meadow."
5865. 
5866. "What?" asked the commander.
5867. 
5868. At that moment, on the road from the town on which signalers had been
5869. posted, two men appeared on horse back. They were an aide-de-camp
5870. followed by a Cossack.
5871. 
5872. The aide-de-camp was sent to confirm the order which had not been
5873. clearly worded the day before, namely, that the commander in chief
5874. wished to see the regiment just in the state in which it had been on
5875. the march: in their greatcoats, and packs, and without any preparation
5876. whatever.
5877. 
5878. A member of the Hofkriegsrath from Vienna had come to Kutuzov the day
5879. before with proposals and demands for him to join up with the army
5880. of the Archduke Ferdinand and Mack, and Kutuzov, not considering this
5881. junction advisable, meant, among other arguments in support of his view,
5882. to show the Austrian general the wretched state in which the troops
5883. arrived from Russia. With this object he intended to meet the regiment;
5884. so the worse the condition it was in, the better pleased the commander
5885. in chief would be. Though the aide-de-camp did not know these
5886. circumstances, he nevertheless delivered the definite order that the
5887. men should be in their greatcoats and in marching order, and that the
5888. commander in chief would otherwise be dissatisfied. On hearing this the
5889. regimental commander hung his head, silently shrugged his shoulders, and
5890. spread out his arms with a choleric gesture.
5891. 
5892. "A fine mess we've made of it!" he remarked.
5893. 
5894. "There now! Didn't I tell you, Michael Mitrich, that if it was said
5895. 'on the march' it meant in greatcoats?" said he reproachfully to
5896. the battalion commander. "Oh, my God!" he added, stepping resolutely
5897. forward. "Company commanders!" he shouted in a voice accustomed to
5898. command. "Sergeants major!... How soon will he be here?" he asked the
5899. aide-de-camp with a respectful politeness evidently relating to the
5900. personage he was referring to.
5901. 
5902. "In an hour's time, I should say."
5903. 
5904. "Shall we have time to change clothes?"
5905. 
5906. "I don't know, General...."
5907. 
5908. The regimental commander, going up to the line himself, ordered the
5909. soldiers to change into their greatcoats. The company commanders ran off
5910. to their companies, the sergeants major began bustling (the greatcoats
5911. were not in very good condition), and instantly the squares that had up
5912. to then been in regular order and silent began to sway and stretch and
5913. hum with voices. On all sides soldiers were running to and fro, throwing
5914. up their knapsacks with a jerk of their shoulders and pulling the straps
5915. over their heads, unstrapping their overcoats and drawing the sleeves on
5916. with upraised arms.
5917. 
5918. In half an hour all was again in order, only the squares had become gray
5919. instead of black. The regimental commander walked with his jerky steps
5920. to the front of the regiment and examined it from a distance.
5921. 
5922. "Whatever is this? This!" he shouted and stood still. "Commander of the
5923. third company!"
5924. 
5925. "Commander of the third company wanted by the general!... commander to
5926. the general... third company to the commander." The words passed along
5927. the lines and an adjutant ran to look for the missing officer.
5928. 
5929. When the eager but misrepeated words had reached their destination in a
5930. cry of: "The general to the third company," the missing officer appeared
5931. from behind his company and, though he was a middle-aged man and not in
5932. the habit of running, trotted awkwardly stumbling on his toes toward the
5933. general. The captain's face showed the uneasiness of a schoolboy who is
5934. told to repeat a lesson he has not learned. Spots appeared on his nose,
5935. the redness of which was evidently due to intemperance, and his mouth
5936. twitched nervously. The general looked the captain up and down as he
5937. came up panting, slackening his pace as he approached.
5938. 
5939. "You will soon be dressing your men in petticoats! What is this?"
5940. shouted the regimental commander, thrusting forward his jaw and pointing
5941. at a soldier in the ranks of the third company in a greatcoat of bluish
5942. cloth, which contrasted with the others. "What have you been after? The
5943. commander in chief is expected and you leave your place? Eh? I'll teach
5944. you to dress the men in fancy coats for a parade.... Eh...?"
5945. 
5946. The commander of the company, with his eyes fixed on his superior,
5947. pressed two fingers more and more rigidly to his cap, as if in this
5948. pressure lay his only hope of salvation.
5949. 
5950. "Well, why don't you speak? Whom have you got there dressed up as a
5951. Hungarian?" said the commander with an austere gibe.
5952. 
5953. "Your excellency..."
5954. 
5955. "Well, your excellency, what? Your excellency! But what about your
5956. excellency?... nobody knows."
5957. 
5958. "Your excellency, it's the officer Dolokhov, who has been reduced to the
5959. ranks," said the captain softly.
5960. 
5961. "Well? Has he been degraded into a field marshal, or into a soldier? If
5962. a soldier, he should be dressed in regulation uniform like the others."
5963. 
5964. "Your excellency, you gave him leave yourself, on the march."
5965. 
5966. "Gave him leave? Leave? That's just like you young men," said the
5967. regimental commander cooling down a little. "Leave indeed.... One says
5968. a word to you and you... What?" he added with renewed irritation, "I beg
5969. you to dress your men decently."
5970. 
5971. And the commander, turning to look at the adjutant, directed his jerky
5972. steps down the line. He was evidently pleased at his own display of
5973. anger and walking up to the regiment wished to find a further excuse for
5974. wrath. Having snapped at an officer for an unpolished badge, at another
5975. because his line was not straight, he reached the third company.
5976. 
5977. "H-o-o-w are you standing? Where's your leg? Your leg?" shouted the
5978. commander with a tone of suffering in his voice, while there were still
5979. five men between him and Dolokhov with his bluish-gray uniform.
5980. 
5981. Dolokhov slowly straightened his bent knee, looking straight with his
5982. clear, insolent eyes in the general's face.
5983. 
5984. "Why a blue coat? Off with it... Sergeant major! Change his coat... the
5985. ras..." he did not finish.
5986. 
5987. "General, I must obey orders, but I am not bound to endure..." Dolokhov
5988. hurriedly interrupted.
5989. 
5990. "No talking in the ranks!... No talking, no talking!"
5991. 
5992. "Not bound to endure insults," Dolokhov concluded in loud, ringing
5993. tones.
5994. 
5995. The eyes of the general and the soldier met. The general became silent,
5996. angrily pulling down his tight scarf.
5997. 
5998. "I request you to have the goodness to change your coat," he said as he
5999. turned away.
6000. 
6001. 
6002. 
6003. 
6004. 
6005. CHAPTER II
6006. 
6007. 
6008. "He's coming!" shouted the signaler at that moment.
6009. 
6010. The regimental commander, flushing, ran to his horse, seized the stirrup
6011. with trembling hands, threw his body across the saddle, righted himself,
6012. drew his saber, and with a happy and resolute countenance, opening
6013. his mouth awry, prepared to shout. The regiment fluttered like a bird
6014. preening its plumage and became motionless.
6015. 
6016. "Att-ention!" shouted the regimental commander in a soul-shaking voice
6017. which expressed joy for himself, severity for the regiment, and welcome
6018. for the approaching chief.
6019. 
6020. Along the broad country road, edged on both sides by trees, came a high,
6021. light blue Viennese caleche, slightly creaking on its springs and drawn
6022. by six horses at a smart trot. Behind the caleche galloped the suite and
6023. a convoy of Croats. Beside Kutuzov sat an Austrian general, in a white
6024. uniform that looked strange among the Russian black ones. The caleche
6025. stopped in front of the regiment. Kutuzov and the Austrian general were
6026. talking in low voices and Kutuzov smiled slightly as treading heavily
6027. he stepped down from the carriage just as if those two thousand men
6028. breathlessly gazing at him and the regimental commander did not exist.
6029. 
6030. The word of command rang out, and again the regiment quivered, as with a
6031. jingling sound it presented arms. Then amidst a dead silence the feeble
6032. voice of the commander in chief was heard. The regiment roared, "Health
6033. to your ex... len... len... lency!" and again all became silent. At
6034. first Kutuzov stood still while the regiment moved; then he and the
6035. general in white, accompanied by the suite, walked between the ranks.
6036. 
6037. From the way the regimental commander saluted the commander in chief and
6038. devoured him with his eyes, drawing himself up obsequiously, and from
6039. the way he walked through the ranks behind the generals, bending forward
6040. and hardly able to restrain his jerky movements, and from the way he
6041. darted forward at every word or gesture of the commander in chief,
6042. it was evident that he performed his duty as a subordinate with even
6043. greater zeal than his duty as a commander. Thanks to the strictness and
6044. assiduity of its commander the regiment, in comparison with others that
6045. had reached Braunau at the same time, was in splendid condition. There
6046. were only 217 sick and stragglers. Everything was in good order except
6047. the boots.
6048. 
6049. Kutuzov walked through the ranks, sometimes stopping to say a few
6050. friendly words to officers he had known in the Turkish war, sometimes
6051. also to the soldiers. Looking at their boots he several times shook his
6052. head sadly, pointing them out to the Austrian general with an expression
6053. which seemed to say that he was not blaming anyone, but could not help
6054. noticing what a bad state of things it was. The regimental commander
6055. ran forward on each such occasion, fearing to miss a single word of
6056. the commander in chief's regarding the regiment. Behind Kutuzov, at a
6057. distance that allowed every softly spoken word to be heard, followed
6058. some twenty men of his suite. These gentlemen talked among themselves
6059. and sometimes laughed. Nearest of all to the commander in chief walked a
6060. handsome adjutant. This was Prince Bolkonski. Beside him was his
6061. comrade Nesvitski, a tall staff officer, extremely stout, with a kindly,
6062. smiling, handsome face and moist eyes. Nesvitski could hardly keep from
6063. laughter provoked by a swarthy hussar officer who walked beside him.
6064. This hussar, with a grave face and without a smile or a change in the
6065. expression of his fixed eyes, watched the regimental commander's back
6066. and mimicked his every movement. Each time the commander started and
6067. bent forward, the hussar started and bent forward in exactly the same
6068. manner. Nesvitski laughed and nudged the others to make them look at the
6069. wag.
6070. 
6071. Kutuzov walked slowly and languidly past thousands of eyes which were
6072. starting from their sockets to watch their chief. On reaching the
6073. third company he suddenly stopped. His suite, not having expected this,
6074. involuntarily came closer to him.
6075. 
6076. "Ah, Timokhin!" said he, recognizing the red-nosed captain who had been
6077. reprimanded on account of the blue greatcoat.
6078. 
6079. One would have thought it impossible for a man to stretch himself
6080. more than Timokhin had done when he was reprimanded by the regimental
6081. commander, but now that the commander in chief addressed him he drew
6082. himself up to such an extent that it seemed he could not have sustained
6083. it had the commander in chief continued to look at him, and so Kutuzov,
6084. who evidently understood his case and wished him nothing but good,
6085. quickly turned away, a scarcely perceptible smile flitting over his
6086. scarred and puffy face.
6087. 
6088. "Another Ismail comrade," said he. "A brave officer! Are you satisfied
6089. with him?" he asked the regimental commander.
6090. 
6091. And the latter--unconscious that he was being reflected in the hussar
6092. officer as in a looking glass--started, moved forward, and answered:
6093. "Highly satisfied, your excellency!"
6094. 
6095. "We all have our weaknesses," said Kutuzov smiling and walking away from
6096. him. "He used to have a predilection for Bacchus."
6097. 
6098. The regimental commander was afraid he might be blamed for this and did
6099. not answer. The hussar at that moment noticed the face of the red-nosed
6100. captain and his drawn-in stomach, and mimicked his expression and pose
6101. with such exactitude that Nesvitski could not help laughing. Kutuzov
6102. turned round. The officer evidently had complete control of his face,
6103. and while Kutuzov was turning managed to make a grimace and then assume
6104. a most serious, deferential, and innocent expression.
6105. 
6106. The third company was the last, and Kutuzov pondered, apparently trying
6107. to recollect something. Prince Andrew stepped forward from among the
6108. suite and said in French:
6109. 
6110. "You told me to remind you of the officer Dolokhov, reduced to the ranks
6111. in this regiment."
6112. 
6113. "Where is Dolokhov?" asked Kutuzov.
6114. 
6115. Dolokhov, who had already changed into a soldier's gray greatcoat, did
6116. not wait to be called. The shapely figure of the fair-haired soldier,
6117. with his clear blue eyes, stepped forward from the ranks, went up to the
6118. commander in chief, and presented arms.
6119. 
6120. "Have you a complaint to make?" Kutuzov asked with a slight frown.
6121. 
6122. "This is Dolokhov," said Prince Andrew.
6123. 
6124. "Ah!" said Kutuzov. "I hope this will be a lesson to you. Do your duty.
6125. The Emperor is gracious, and I shan't forget you if you deserve well."
6126. 
6127. The clear blue eyes looked at the commander in chief just as boldly as
6128. they had looked at the regimental commander, seeming by their expression
6129. to tear open the veil of convention that separates a commander in chief
6130. so widely from a private.
6131. 
6132. "One thing I ask of your excellency," Dolokhov said in his firm,
6133. ringing, deliberate voice. "I ask an opportunity to atone for my fault
6134. and prove my devotion to His Majesty the Emperor and to Russia!"
6135. 
6136. Kutuzov turned away. The same smile of the eyes with which he had turned
6137. from Captain Timokhin again flitted over his face. He turned away with
6138. a grimace as if to say that everything Dolokhov had said to him and
6139. everything he could say had long been known to him, that he was weary of
6140. it and it was not at all what he wanted. He turned away and went to the
6141. carriage.
6142. 
6143. The regiment broke up into companies, which went to their appointed
6144. quarters near Braunau, where they hoped to receive boots and clothes and
6145. to rest after their hard marches.
6146. 
6147. "You won't bear me a grudge, Prokhor Ignatych?" said the regimental
6148. commander, overtaking the third company on its way to its quarters and
6149. riding up to Captain Timokhin who was walking in front. (The regimental
6150. commander's face now that the inspection was happily over beamed with
6151. irrepressible delight.) "It's in the Emperor's service... it can't be
6152. helped... one is sometimes a bit hasty on parade... I am the first to
6153. apologize, you know me!... He was very pleased!" And he held out his
6154. hand to the captain.
6155. 
6156. "Don't mention it, General, as if I'd be so bold!" replied the captain,
6157. his nose growing redder as he gave a smile which showed where two front
6158. teeth were missing that had been knocked out by the butt end of a gun at
6159. Ismail.
6160. 
6161. "And tell Mr. Dolokhov that I won't forget him--he may be quite easy.
6162. And tell me, please--I've been meaning to ask--how is he behaving
6163. himself, and in general..."
6164. 
6165. "As far as the service goes he is quite punctilious, your excellency;
6166. but his character..." said Timokhin.
6167. 
6168. "And what about his character?" asked the regimental commander.
6169. 
6170. "It's different on different days," answered the captain. "One day he
6171. is sensible, well educated, and good-natured, and the next he's a wild
6172. beast.... In Poland, if you please, he nearly killed a Jew."
6173. 
6174. "Oh, well, well!" remarked the regimental commander. "Still, one must
6175. have pity on a young man in misfortune. You know he has important
6176. connections... Well, then, you just..."
6177. 
6178. "I will, your excellency," said Timokhin, showing by his smile that he
6179. understood his commander's wish.
6180. 
6181. "Well, of course, of course!"
6182. 
6183. The regimental commander sought out Dolokhov in the ranks and, reining
6184. in his horse, said to him:
6185. 
6186. "After the next affair... epaulettes."
6187. 
6188. Dolokhov looked round but did not say anything, nor did the mocking
6189. smile on his lips change.
6190. 
6191. "Well, that's all right," continued the regimental commander. "A cup of
6192. vodka for the men from me," he added so that the soldiers could hear.
6193. "I thank you all! God be praised!" and he rode past that company and
6194. overtook the next one.
6195. 
6196. "Well, he's really a good fellow, one can serve under him," said
6197. Timokhin to the subaltern beside him.
6198. 
6199. "In a word, a hearty one..." said the subaltern, laughing (the
6200. regimental commander was nicknamed King of Hearts).
6201. 
6202. The cheerful mood of their officers after the inspection infected the
6203. soldiers. The company marched on gaily. The soldiers' voices could be
6204. heard on every side.
6205. 
6206. "And they said Kutuzov was blind of one eye?"
6207. 
6208. "And so he is! Quite blind!"
6209. 
6210. "No, friend, he is sharper-eyed than you are. Boots and leg bands... he
6211. noticed everything..."
6212. 
6213. "When he looked at my feet, friend... well, thinks I..."
6214. 
6215. "And that other one with him, the Austrian, looked as if he were smeared
6216. with chalk--as white as flour! I suppose they polish him up as they do
6217. the guns."
6218. 
6219. "I say, Fedeshon!... Did he say when the battles are to begin? You were
6220. near him. Everybody said that Buonaparte himself was at Braunau."
6221. 
6222. "Buonaparte himself!... Just listen to the fool, what he doesn't know!
6223. The Prussians are up in arms now. The Austrians, you see, are putting
6224. them down. When they've been put down, the war with Buonaparte will
6225. begin. And he says Buonaparte is in Braunau! Shows you're a fool. You'd
6226. better listen more carefully!"
6227. 
6228. "What devils these quartermasters are! See, the fifth company is turning
6229. into the village already... they will have their buckwheat cooked before
6230. we reach our quarters."
6231. 
6232. "Give me a biscuit, you devil!"
6233. 
6234. "And did you give me tobacco yesterday? That's just it, friend! Ah,
6235. well, never mind, here you are."
6236. 
6237. "They might call a halt here or we'll have to do another four miles
6238. without eating."
6239. 
6240. "Wasn't it fine when those Germans gave us lifts! You just sit still and
6241. are drawn along."
6242. 
6243. "And here, friend, the people are quite beggarly. There they all seemed
6244. to be Poles--all under the Russian crown--but here they're all regular
6245. Germans."
6246. 
6247. "Singers to the front" came the captain's order.
6248. 
6249. And from the different ranks some twenty men ran to the front. A
6250. drummer, their leader, turned round facing the singers, and flourishing
6251. his arm, began a long-drawn-out soldiers' song, commencing with the
6252. words: "Morning dawned, the sun was rising," and concluding: "On then,
6253. brothers, on to glory, led by Father Kamenski." This song had been
6254. composed in the Turkish campaign and now being sung in Austria, the only
6255. change being that the words "Father Kamenski" were replaced by "Father
6256. Kutuzov."
6257. 
6258. Having jerked out these last words as soldiers do and waved his arms
6259. as if flinging something to the ground, the drummer--a lean, handsome
6260. soldier of forty--looked sternly at the singers and screwed up his eyes.
6261. Then having satisfied himself that all eyes were fixed on him, he raised
6262. both arms as if carefully lifting some invisible but precious object
6263. above his head and, holding it there for some seconds, suddenly flung it
6264. down and began:
6265. 
6266. "Oh, my bower, oh, my bower...!"
6267. 
6268. "Oh, my bower new...!" chimed in twenty voices, and the castanet player,
6269. in spite of the burden of his equipment, rushed out to the front
6270. and, walking backwards before the company, jerked his shoulders and
6271. flourished his castanets as if threatening someone. The soldiers,
6272. swinging their arms and keeping time spontaneously, marched with long
6273. steps. Behind the company the sound of wheels, the creaking of springs,
6274. and the tramp of horses' hoofs were heard. Kutuzov and his suite were
6275. returning to the town. The commander in chief made a sign that the
6276. men should continue to march at ease, and he and all his suite showed
6277. pleasure at the sound of the singing and the sight of the dancing
6278. soldier and the gay and smartly marching men. In the second file
6279. from the right flank, beside which the carriage passed the company,
6280. a blue-eyed soldier involuntarily attracted notice. It was Dolokhov
6281. marching with particular grace and boldness in time to the song and
6282. looking at those driving past as if he pitied all who were not at that
6283. moment marching with the company. The hussar cornet of Kutuzov's suite
6284. who had mimicked the regimental commander, fell back from the carriage
6285. and rode up to Dolokhov.
6286. 
6287. Hussar cornet Zherkov had at one time, in Petersburg, belonged to the
6288. wild set led by Dolokhov. Zherkov had met Dolokhov abroad as a private
6289. and had not seen fit to recognize him. But now that Kutuzov had spoken
6290. to the gentleman ranker, he addressed him with the cordiality of an old
6291. friend.
6292. 
6293. "My dear fellow, how are you?" said he through the singing, making his
6294. horse keep pace with the company.
6295. 
6296. "How am I?" Dolokhov answered coldly. "I am as you see."
6297. 
6298. The lively song gave a special flavor to the tone of free and easy
6299. gaiety with which Zherkov spoke, and to the intentional coldness of
6300. Dolokhov's reply.
6301. 
6302. "And how do you get on with the officers?" inquired Zherkov.
6303. 
6304. "All right. They are good fellows. And how have you wriggled onto the
6305. staff?"
6306. 
6307. "I was attached; I'm on duty."
6308. 
6309. Both were silent.
6310. 
6311. "She let the hawk fly upward from her wide right sleeve," went the song,
6312. arousing an involuntary sensation of courage and cheerfulness. Their
6313. conversation would probably have been different but for the effect of
6314. that song.
6315. 
6316. "Is it true that Austrians have been beaten?" asked Dolokhov.
6317. 
6318. "The devil only knows! They say so."
6319. 
6320. "I'm glad," answered Dolokhov briefly and clearly, as the song demanded.
6321. 
6322. "I say, come round some evening and we'll have a game of faro!" said
6323. Zherkov.
6324. 
6325. "Why, have you too much money?"
6326. 
6327. "Do come."
6328. 
6329. "I can't. I've sworn not to. I won't drink and won't play till I get
6330. reinstated."
6331. 
6332. "Well, that's only till the first engagement."
6333. 
6334. "We shall see."
6335. 
6336. They were again silent.
6337. 
6338. "Come if you need anything. One can at least be of use on the staff..."
6339. 
6340. Dolokhov smiled. "Don't trouble. If I want anything, I won't beg--I'll
6341. take it!"
6342. 
6343. "Well, never mind; I only..."
6344. 
6345. "And I only..."
6346. 
6347. "Good-by."
6348. 
6349. "Good health..."
6350. 
6351.         "It's a long, long way.
6352.         To my native land..."
6353. 
6354. 
6355. Zherkov touched his horse with the spurs; it pranced excitedly from foot
6356. to foot uncertain with which to start, then settled down, galloped past
6357. the company, and overtook the carriage, still keeping time to the song.
6358. 
6359. 
6360. 
6361. 
6362. 
6363. CHAPTER III
6364. 
6365. 
6366. On returning from the review, Kutuzov took the Austrian general into his
6367. private room and, calling his adjutant, asked for some papers relating
6368. to the condition of the troops on their arrival, and the letters that
6369. had come from the Archduke Ferdinand, who was in command of the advanced
6370. army. Prince Andrew Bolkonski came into the room with the required
6371. papers. Kutuzov and the Austrian member of the Hofkriegsrath were
6372. sitting at the table on which a plan was spread out.
6373. 
6374. "Ah!..." said Kutuzov glancing at Bolkonski as if by this exclamation he
6375. was asking the adjutant to wait, and he went on with the conversation in
6376. French.
6377. 
6378. "All I can say, General," said he with a pleasant elegance of expression
6379. and intonation that obliged one to listen to each deliberately spoken
6380. word. It was evident that Kutuzov himself listened with pleasure to his
6381. own voice. "All I can say, General, is that if the matter depended on my
6382. personal wishes, the will of His Majesty the Emperor Francis would have
6383. been fulfilled long ago. I should long ago have joined the archduke. And
6384. believe me on my honour that to me personally it would be a pleasure
6385. to hand over the supreme command of the army into the hands of a better
6386. informed and more skillful general--of whom Austria has so many--and to
6387. lay down all this heavy responsibility. But circumstances are sometimes
6388. too strong for us, General."
6389. 
6390. And Kutuzov smiled in a way that seemed to say, "You are quite at
6391. liberty not to believe me and I don't even care whether you do or not,
6392. but you have no grounds for telling me so. And that is the whole point."
6393. 
6394. The Austrian general looked dissatisfied, but had no option but to reply
6395. in the same tone.
6396. 
6397. "On the contrary," he said, in a querulous and angry tone that
6398. contrasted with his flattering words, "on the contrary, your
6399. excellency's participation in the common action is highly valued by
6400. His Majesty; but we think the present delay is depriving the splendid
6401. Russian troops and their commander of the laurels they have been
6402. accustomed to win in their battles," he concluded his evidently
6403. prearranged sentence.
6404. 
6405. Kutuzov bowed with the same smile.
6406. 
6407. "But that is my conviction, and judging by the last letter with which
6408. His Highness the Archduke Ferdinand has honored me, I imagine that the
6409. Austrian troops, under the direction of so skillful a leader as General
6410. Mack, have by now already gained a decisive victory and no longer need
6411. our aid," said Kutuzov.
6412. 
6413. The general frowned. Though there was no definite news of an Austrian
6414. defeat, there were many circumstances confirming the unfavorable rumors
6415. that were afloat, and so Kutuzov's suggestion of an Austrian victory
6416. sounded much like irony. But Kutuzov went on blandly smiling with the
6417. same expression, which seemed to say that he had a right to suppose so.
6418. And, in fact, the last letter he had received from Mack's army informed
6419. him of a victory and stated strategically the position of the army was
6420. very favorable.
6421. 
6422. "Give me that letter," said Kutuzov turning to Prince Andrew. "Please
6423. have a look at it"--and Kutuzov with an ironical smile about the corners
6424. of his mouth read to the Austrian general the following passage, in
6425. German, from the Archduke Ferdinand's letter:
6426. 
6427. 
6428. We have fully concentrated forces of nearly seventy thousand men with
6429. which to attack and defeat the enemy should he cross the Lech. Also,
6430. as we are masters of Ulm, we cannot be deprived of the advantage of
6431. commanding both sides of the Danube, so that should the enemy not
6432. cross the Lech, we can cross the Danube, throw ourselves on his line
6433. of communications, recross the river lower down, and frustrate his
6434. intention should he try to direct his whole force against our faithful
6435. ally. We shall therefore confidently await the moment when the Imperial
6436. Russian army will be fully equipped, and shall then, in conjunction with
6437. it, easily find a way to prepare for the enemy the fate he deserves.
6438. 
6439. 
6440. Kutuzov sighed deeply on finishing this paragraph and looked at the
6441. member of the Hofkriegsrath mildly and attentively.
6442. 
6443. "But you know the wise maxim your excellency, advising one to expect the
6444. worst," said the Austrian general, evidently wishing to have done with
6445. jests and to come to business. He involuntarily looked round at the
6446. aide-de-camp.
6447. 
6448. "Excuse me, General," interrupted Kutuzov, also turning to Prince
6449. Andrew. "Look here, my dear fellow, get from Kozlovski all the reports
6450. from our scouts. Here are two letters from Count Nostitz and here is one
6451. from His Highness the Archduke Ferdinand and here are these," he said,
6452. handing him several papers, "make a neat memorandum in French out of all
6453. this, showing all the news we have had of the movements of the Austrian
6454. army, and then give it to his excellency."
6455. 
6456. Prince Andrew bowed his head in token of having understood from the
6457. first not only what had been said but also what Kutuzov would have liked
6458. to tell him. He gathered up the papers and with a bow to both, stepped
6459. softly over the carpet and went out into the waiting room.
6460. 
6461. Though not much time had passed since Prince Andrew had left Russia, he
6462. had changed greatly during that period. In the expression of his face,
6463. in his movements, in his walk, scarcely a trace was left of his former
6464. affected languor and indolence. He now looked like a man who has time
6465. to think of the impression he makes on others, but is occupied with
6466. agreeable and interesting work. His face expressed more satisfaction
6467. with himself and those around him, his smile and glance were brighter
6468. and more attractive.
6469. 
6470. Kutuzov, whom he had overtaken in Poland, had received him very kindly,
6471. promised not to forget him, distinguished him above the other adjutants,
6472. and had taken him to Vienna and given him the more serious commissions.
6473. From Vienna Kutuzov wrote to his old comrade, Prince Andrew's father.
6474. 
6475. 
6476. Your son bids fair to become an officer distinguished by his industry,
6477. firmness, and expedition. I consider myself fortunate to have such a
6478. subordinate by me.
6479. 
6480. 
6481. On Kutuzov's staff, among his fellow officers and in the army generally,
6482. Prince Andrew had, as he had had in Petersburg society, two quite
6483. opposite reputations. Some, a minority, acknowledged him to be different
6484. from themselves and from everyone else, expected great things of him,
6485. listened to him, admired, and imitated him, and with them Prince
6486. Andrew was natural and pleasant. Others, the majority, disliked him and
6487. considered him conceited, cold, and disagreeable. But among these people
6488. Prince Andrew knew how to take his stand so that they respected and even
6489. feared him.
6490. 
6491. Coming out of Kutuzov's room into the waiting room with the papers in
6492. his hand Prince Andrew came up to his comrade, the aide-de-camp on duty,
6493. Kozlovski, who was sitting at the window with a book.
6494. 
6495. "Well, Prince?" asked Kozlovski.
6496. 
6497. "I am ordered to write a memorandum explaining why we are not
6498. advancing."
6499. 
6500. "And why is it?"
6501. 
6502. Prince Andrew shrugged his shoulders.
6503. 
6504. "Any news from Mack?"
6505. 
6506. "No."
6507. 
6508. "If it were true that he has been beaten, news would have come."
6509. 
6510. "Probably," said Prince Andrew moving toward the outer door.
6511. 
6512. But at that instant a tall Austrian general in a greatcoat, with the
6513. order of Maria Theresa on his neck and a black bandage round his head,
6514. who had evidently just arrived, entered quickly, slamming the door.
6515. Prince Andrew stopped short.
6516. 
6517. "Commander in Chief Kutuzov?" said the newly arrived general speaking
6518. quickly with a harsh German accent, looking to both sides and advancing
6519. straight toward the inner door.
6520. 
6521. "The commander in chief is engaged," said Kozlovski, going hurriedly up
6522. to the unknown general and blocking his way to the door. "Whom shall I
6523. announce?"
6524. 
6525. The unknown general looked disdainfully down at Kozlovski, who was
6526. rather short, as if surprised that anyone should not know him.
6527. 
6528. "The commander in chief is engaged," repeated Kozlovski calmly.
6529. 
6530. The general's face clouded, his lips quivered and trembled. He took out
6531. a notebook, hurriedly scribbled something in pencil, tore out the leaf,
6532. gave it to Kozlovski, stepped quickly to the window, and threw himself
6533. into a chair, gazing at those in the room as if asking, "Why do they
6534. look at me?" Then he lifted his head, stretched his neck as if he
6535. intended to say something, but immediately, with affected indifference,
6536. began to hum to himself, producing a queer sound which immediately broke
6537. off. The door of the private room opened and Kutuzov appeared in the
6538. doorway. The general with the bandaged head bent forward as though
6539. running away from some danger, and, making long, quick strides with his
6540. thin legs, went up to Kutuzov.
6541. 
6542. "Vous voyez le malheureux Mack," he uttered in a broken voice.
6543. 
6544. Kutuzov's face as he stood in the open doorway remained perfectly
6545. immobile for a few moments. Then wrinkles ran over his face like a wave
6546. and his forehead became smooth again, he bowed his head respectfully,
6547. closed his eyes, silently let Mack enter his room before him, and closed
6548. the door himself behind him.
6549. 
6550. The report which had been circulated that the Austrians had been beaten
6551. and that the whole army had surrendered at Ulm proved to be correct.
6552. Within half an hour adjutants had been sent in various directions with
6553. orders which showed that the Russian troops, who had hitherto been
6554. inactive, would also soon have to meet the enemy.
6555. 
6556. Prince Andrew was one of those rare staff officers whose chief interest
6557. lay in the general progress of the war. When he saw Mack and heard the
6558. details of his disaster he understood that half the campaign was lost,
6559. understood all the difficulties of the Russian army's position, and
6560. vividly imagined what awaited it and the part he would have to
6561. play. Involuntarily he felt a joyful agitation at the thought of the
6562. humiliation of arrogant Austria and that in a week's time he might,
6563. perhaps, see and take part in the first Russian encounter with the
6564. French since Suvorov met them. He feared that Bonaparte's genius might
6565. outweigh all the courage of the Russian troops, and at the same time
6566. could not admit the idea of his hero being disgraced.
6567. 
6568. Excited and irritated by these thoughts Prince Andrew went toward his
6569. room to write to his father, to whom he wrote every day. In the corridor
6570. he met Nesvitski, with whom he shared a room, and the wag Zherkov; they
6571. were as usual laughing.
6572. 
6573. "Why are you so glum?" asked Nesvitski noticing Prince Andrew's pale
6574. face and glittering eyes.
6575. 
6576. "There's nothing to be gay about," answered Bolkonski.
6577. 
6578. Just as Prince Andrew met Nesvitski and Zherkov, there came toward them
6579. from the other end of the corridor, Strauch, an Austrian general who on
6580. Kutuzov's staff in charge of the provisioning of the Russian army, and
6581. the member of the Hofkriegsrath who had arrived the previous evening.
6582. There was room enough in the wide corridor for the generals to pass the
6583. three officers quite easily, but Zherkov, pushing Nesvitski aside with
6584. his arm, said in a breathless voice,
6585. 
6586. "They're coming!... they're coming!... Stand aside, make way, please
6587. make way!"
6588. 
6589. The generals were passing by, looking as if they wished to avoid
6590. embarrassing attentions. On the face of the wag Zherkov there suddenly
6591. appeared a stupid smile of glee which he seemed unable to suppress.
6592. 
6593. "Your excellency," said he in German, stepping forward and addressing
6594. the Austrian general, "I have the honor to congratulate you."
6595. 
6596. He bowed his head and scraped first with one foot and then with the
6597. other, awkwardly, like a child at a dancing lesson.
6598. 
6599. The member of the Hofkriegsrath looked at him severely but, seeing
6600. the seriousness of his stupid smile, could not but give him a moment's
6601. attention. He screwed up his eyes showing that he was listening.
6602. 
6603. "I have the honor to congratulate you. General Mack has arrived, quite
6604. well, only a little bruised just here," he added, pointing with a
6605. beaming smile to his head.
6606. 
6607. The general frowned, turned away, and went on.
6608. 
6609. "Gott, wie naiv!" * said he angrily, after he had gone a few steps.
6610. 
6611. 
6612.      * "Good God, what simplicity!"
6613. 
6614. 
6615. Nesvitski with a laugh threw his arms round Prince Andrew, but
6616. Bolkonski, turning still paler, pushed him away with an angry look and
6617. turned to Zherkov. The nervous irritation aroused by the appearance of
6618. Mack, the news of his defeat, and the thought of what lay before the
6619. Russian army found vent in anger at Zherkov's untimely jest.
6620. 
6621. "If you, sir, choose to make a buffoon of yourself," he said sharply,
6622. with a slight trembling of the lower jaw, "I can't prevent your doing
6623. so; but I warn you that if you dare to play the fool in my presence, I
6624. will teach you to behave yourself."
6625. 
6626. Nesvitski and Zherkov were so surprised by this outburst that they gazed
6627. at Bolkonski silently with wide-open eyes.
6628. 
6629. "What's the matter? I only congratulated them," said Zherkov.
6630. 
6631. "I am not jesting with you; please be silent!" cried Bolkonski, and
6632. taking Nesvitski's arm he left Zherkov, who did not know what to say.
6633. 
6634. "Come, what's the matter, old fellow?" said Nesvitski trying to soothe
6635. him.
6636. 
6637. "What's the matter?" exclaimed Prince Andrew standing still in his
6638. excitement. "Don't you understand that either we are officers serving
6639. our Tsar and our country, rejoicing in the successes and grieving at
6640. the misfortunes of our common cause, or we are merely lackeys who care
6641. nothing for their master's business. Quarante mille hommes massacres et
6642. l'armee de nos allies detruite, et vous trouvez la le mot pour rire," *
6643. he said, as if strengthening his views by this French sentence. "C'est
6644. bien pour un garcon de rien comme cet individu dont vous avez fait un
6645. ami, mais pas pour vous, pas pour vous. *(2) Only a hobbledehoy could
6646. amuse himself in this way," he added in Russian--but pronouncing the
6647. word with a French accent--having noticed that Zherkov could still hear
6648. him.
6649. 
6650. 
6651.      * "Forty thousand men massacred and the army of our allies
6652.      destroyed, and you find that a cause for jesting!"
6653. 
6654.      * (2) "It is all very well for that good-for-nothing fellow
6655.      of whom you have made a friend, but not for you, not for
6656.      you."
6657. 
6658. 
6659. He waited a moment to see whether the cornet would answer, but he turned
6660. and went out of the corridor.
6661. 
6662. 
6663. 
6664. 
6665. 
6666. CHAPTER IV
6667. 
6668. 
6669. The Pavlograd Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau. The
6670. squadron in which Nicholas Rostov served as a cadet was quartered in
6671. the German village of Salzeneck. The best quarters in the village were
6672. assigned to cavalry-captain Denisov, the squadron commander, known
6673. throughout the whole cavalry division as Vaska Denisov. Cadet Rostov,
6674. ever since he had overtaken the regiment in Poland, had lived with the
6675. squadron commander.
6676. 
6677. On October 11, the day when all was astir at headquarters over the news
6678. of Mack's defeat, the camp life of the officers of this squadron was
6679. proceeding as usual. Denisov, who had been losing at cards all night,
6680. had not yet come home when Rostov rode back early in the morning from
6681. a foraging expedition. Rostov in his cadet uniform, with a jerk to his
6682. horse, rode up to the porch, swung his leg over the saddle with a supple
6683. youthful movement, stood for a moment in the stirrup as if loathe to
6684. part from his horse, and at last sprang down and called to his orderly.
6685. 
6686. "Ah, Bondarenko, dear friend!" said he to the hussar who rushed up
6687. headlong to the horse. "Walk him up and down, my dear fellow," he
6688. continued, with that gay brotherly cordiality which goodhearted young
6689. people show to everyone when they are happy.
6690. 
6691. "Yes, your excellency," answered the Ukrainian gaily, tossing his head.
6692. 
6693. "Mind, walk him up and down well!"
6694. 
6695. Another hussar also rushed toward the horse, but Bondarenko had already
6696. thrown the reins of the snaffle bridle over the horse's head. It was
6697. evident that the cadet was liberal with his tips and that it paid
6698. to serve him. Rostov patted the horse's neck and then his flank, and
6699. lingered for a moment.
6700. 
6701. "Splendid! What a horse he will be!" he thought with a smile, and
6702. holding up his saber, his spurs jingling, he ran up the steps of the
6703. porch. His landlord, who in a waistcoat and a pointed cap, pitchfork in
6704. hand, was clearing manure from the cowhouse, looked out, and his face
6705. immediately brightened on seeing Rostov. "Schon gut Morgen! Schon gut
6706. Morgen!" * he said winking with a merry smile, evidently pleased to
6707. greet the young man.
6708. 
6709. 
6710.     * "A very good morning! A very good morning!"
6711. 
6712. 
6713. "Schon fleissig?" * said Rostov with the same gay brotherly smile which
6714. did not leave his eager face. "Hoch Oestreicher! Hoch Russen! Kaiser
6715. Alexander hoch!" *(2) said he, quoting words often repeated by the
6716. German landlord.
6717. 
6718. 
6719.     * "Busy already?"
6720. 
6721.     * (2) "Hurrah for the Austrians! Hurrah for the Russians!
6722.      Hurrah for Emperor Alexander!"
6723. 
6724. 
6725. The German laughed, came out of the cowshed, pulled off his cap, and
6726. waving it above his head cried:
6727. 
6728. "Und die ganze Welt hoch!" *
6729. 
6730. 
6731.     * "And hurrah for the whole world!"
6732. 
6733. 
6734. Rostov waved his cap above his head like the German and cried laughing,
6735. "Und vivat die ganze Welt!" Though neither the German cleaning his
6736. cowshed nor Rostov back with his platoon from foraging for hay had any
6737. reason for rejoicing, they looked at each other with joyful delight and
6738. brotherly love, wagged their heads in token of their mutual affection,
6739. and parted smiling, the German returning to his cowshed and Rostov going
6740. to the cottage he occupied with Denisov.
6741. 
6742. "What about your master?" he asked Lavrushka, Denisov's orderly, whom
6743. all the regiment knew for a rogue.
6744. 
6745. "Hasn't been in since the evening. Must have been losing," answered
6746. Lavrushka. "I know by now, if he wins he comes back early to brag about
6747. it, but if he stays out till morning it means he's lost and will come
6748. back in a rage. Will you have coffee?"
6749. 
6750. "Yes, bring some."
6751. 
6752. Ten minutes later Lavrushka brought the coffee. "He's coming!" said
6753. he. "Now for trouble!" Rostov looked out of the window and saw Denisov
6754. coming home. Denisov was a small man with a red face, sparkling black
6755. eyes, and black tousled mustache and hair. He wore an unfastened cloak,
6756. wide breeches hanging down in creases, and a crumpled shako on the back
6757. of his head. He came up to the porch gloomily, hanging his head.
6758. 
6759. "Lavwuska!" he shouted loudly and angrily, "take it off, blockhead!"
6760. 
6761. "Well, I am taking it off," replied Lavrushka's voice.
6762.
