6763. "Ah, you're up already," said Denisov, entering the room.
6764. 
6765. "Long ago," answered Rostov, "I have already been for the hay, and have
6766. seen Fraulein Mathilde."
6767. 
6768. "Weally! And I've been losing, bwother. I lost yesterday like a damned
6769. fool!" cried Denisov, not pronouncing his r's. "Such ill luck! Such ill
6770. luck. As soon as you left, it began and went on. Hullo there! Tea!"
6771. 
6772. Puckering up his face though smiling, and showing his short strong
6773. teeth, he began with stubby fingers of both hands to ruffle up his thick
6774. tangled black hair.
6775. 
6776. "And what devil made me go to that wat?" (an officer nicknamed "the
6777. rat") he said, rubbing his forehead and whole face with both hands.
6778. "Just fancy, he didn't let me win a single cahd, not one cahd."
6779. 
6780. He took the lighted pipe that was offered to him, gripped it in his
6781. fist, and tapped it on the floor, making the sparks fly, while he
6782. continued to shout.
6783. 
6784. "He lets one win the singles and collahs it as soon as one doubles it;
6785. gives the singles and snatches the doubles!"
6786. 
6787. He scattered the burning tobacco, smashed the pipe, and threw it away.
6788. Then he remained silent for a while, and all at once looked cheerfully
6789. with his glittering, black eyes at Rostov.
6790. 
6791. "If at least we had some women here; but there's nothing foh one to do
6792. but dwink. If we could only get to fighting soon. Hullo, who's there?"
6793. he said, turning to the door as he heard a tread of heavy boots and the
6794. clinking of spurs that came to a stop, and a respectful cough.
6795. 
6796. "The squadron quartermaster!" said Lavrushka.
6797. 
6798. Denisov's face puckered still more.
6799. 
6800. "Wetched!" he muttered, throwing down a purse with some gold in it.
6801. "Wostov, deah fellow, just see how much there is left and shove the
6802. purse undah the pillow," he said, and went out to the quartermaster.
6803. 
6804. Rostov took the money and, mechanically arranging the old and new coins
6805. in separate piles, began counting them.
6806. 
6807. "Ah! Telyanin! How d'ye do? They plucked me last night," came Denisov's
6808. voice from the next room.
6809. 
6810. "Where? At Bykov's, at the rat's... I knew it," replied a piping voice,
6811. and Lieutenant Telyanin, a small officer of the same squadron, entered
6812. the room.
6813. 
6814. Rostov thrust the purse under the pillow and shook the damp little hand
6815. which was offered him. Telyanin for some reason had been transferred
6816. from the Guards just before this campaign. He behaved very well in
6817. the regiment but was not liked; Rostov especially detested him and was
6818. unable to overcome or conceal his groundless antipathy to the man.
6819. 
6820. "Well, young cavalryman, how is my Rook behaving?" he asked. (Rook was a
6821. young horse Telyanin had sold to Rostov.)
6822. 
6823. The lieutenant never looked the man he was speaking to straight in the
6824. face; his eyes continually wandered from one object to another.
6825. 
6826. "I saw you riding this morning..." he added.
6827. 
6828. "Oh, he's all right, a good horse," answered Rostov, though the horse
6829. for which he had paid seven hundred rubbles was not worth half that sum.
6830. "He's begun to go a little lame on the left foreleg," he added.
6831. 
6832. "The hoof's cracked! That's nothing. I'll teach you what to do and show
6833. you what kind of rivet to use."
6834. 
6835. "Yes, please do," said Rostov.
6836. 
6837. "I'll show you, I'll show you! It's not a secret. And it's a horse
6838. you'll thank me for."
6839. 
6840. "Then I'll have it brought round," said Rostov wishing to avoid
6841. Telyanin, and he went out to give the order.
6842. 
6843. In the passage Denisov, with a pipe, was squatting on the threshold
6844. facing the quartermaster who was reporting to him. On seeing Rostov,
6845. Denisov screwed up his face and pointing over his shoulder with his
6846. thumb to the room where Telyanin was sitting, he frowned and gave a
6847. shudder of disgust.
6848. 
6849. "Ugh! I don't like that fellow," he said, regardless of the
6850. quartermaster's presence.
6851. 
6852. Rostov shrugged his shoulders as much as to say: "Nor do I, but what's
6853. one to do?" and, having given his order, he returned to Telyanin.
6854. 
6855. Telyanin was sitting in the same indolent pose in which Rostov had left
6856. him, rubbing his small white hands.
6857. 
6858. "Well there certainly are disgusting people," thought Rostov as he
6859. entered.
6860. 
6861. "Have you told them to bring the horse?" asked Telyanin, getting up and
6862. looking carelessly about him.
6863. 
6864. "I have."
6865. 
6866. "Let us go ourselves. I only came round to ask Denisov about yesterday's
6867. order. Have you got it, Denisov?"
6868. 
6869. "Not yet. But where are you off to?"
6870. 
6871. "I want to teach this young man how to shoe a horse," said Telyanin.
6872. 
6873. They went through the porch and into the stable. The lieutenant
6874. explained how to rivet the hoof and went away to his own quarters.
6875. 
6876. When Rostov went back there was a bottle of vodka and a sausage on the
6877. table. Denisov was sitting there scratching with his pen on a sheet of
6878. paper. He looked gloomily in Rostov's face and said: "I am witing to
6879. her."
6880. 
6881. He leaned his elbows on the table with his pen in his hand and,
6882. evidently glad of a chance to say quicker in words what he wanted to
6883. write, told Rostov the contents of his letter.
6884. 
6885. "You see, my fwiend," he said, "we sleep when we don't love. We are
6886. childwen of the dust... but one falls in love and one is a God, one is
6887. pua' as on the first day of cweation... Who's that now? Send him to the
6888. devil, I'm busy!" he shouted to Lavrushka, who went up to him not in the
6889. least abashed.
6890. 
6891. "Who should it be? You yourself told him to come. It's the quartermaster
6892. for the money."
6893. 
6894. Denisov frowned and was about to shout some reply but stopped.
6895. 
6896. "Wetched business," he muttered to himself. "How much is left in the
6897. puhse?" he asked, turning to Rostov.
6898. 
6899. "Seven new and three old imperials."
6900. 
6901. "Oh, it's wetched! Well, what are you standing there for, you sca'cwow?
6902. Call the quahtehmasteh," he shouted to Lavrushka.
6903. 
6904. "Please, Denisov, let me lend you some: I have some, you know," said
6905. Rostov, blushing.
6906. 
6907. "Don't like bowwowing from my own fellows, I don't," growled Denisov.
6908. 
6909. "But if you won't accept money from me like a comrade, you will offend
6910. me. Really I have some," Rostov repeated.
6911. 
6912. "No, I tell you."
6913. 
6914. And Denisov went to the bed to get the purse from under the pillow.
6915. 
6916. "Where have you put it, Wostov?"
6917. 
6918. "Under the lower pillow."
6919. 
6920. "It's not there."
6921. 
6922. Denisov threw both pillows on the floor. The purse was not there.
6923. 
6924. "That's a miwacle."
6925. 
6926. "Wait, haven't you dropped it?" said Rostov, picking up the pillows one
6927. at a time and shaking them.
6928. 
6929. He pulled off the quilt and shook it. The purse was not there.
6930. 
6931. "Dear me, can I have forgotten? No, I remember thinking that you kept
6932. it under your head like a treasure," said Rostov. "I put it just here.
6933. Where is it?" he asked, turning to Lavrushka.
6934. 
6935. "I haven't been in the room. It must be where you put it."
6936. 
6937. "But it isn't?..."
6938. 
6939. "You're always like that; you thwow a thing down anywhere and forget it.
6940. Feel in your pockets."
6941. 
6942. "No, if I hadn't thought of it being a treasure," said Rostov, "but I
6943. remember putting it there."
6944. 
6945. Lavrushka turned all the bedding over, looked under the bed and under
6946. the table, searched everywhere, and stood still in the middle of the
6947. room. Denisov silently watched Lavrushka's movements, and when the
6948. latter threw up his arms in surprise saying it was nowhere to be found
6949. Denisov glanced at Rostov.
6950. 
6951. "Wostov, you've not been playing schoolboy twicks..."
6952. 
6953. Rostov felt Denisov's gaze fixed on him, raised his eyes, and instantly
6954. dropped them again. All the blood which had seemed congested somewhere
6955. below his throat rushed to his face and eyes. He could not draw breath.
6956. 
6957. "And there hasn't been anyone in the room except the lieutenant and
6958. yourselves. It must be here somewhere," said Lavrushka.
6959. 
6960. "Now then, you devil's puppet, look alive and hunt for it!" shouted
6961. Denisov, suddenly, turning purple and rushing at the man with a
6962. threatening gesture. "If the purse isn't found I'll flog you, I'll flog
6963. you all."
6964. 
6965. Rostov, his eyes avoiding Denisov, began buttoning his coat, buckled on
6966. his saber, and put on his cap.
6967. 
6968. "I must have that purse, I tell you," shouted Denisov, shaking his
6969. orderly by the shoulders and knocking him against the wall.
6970. 
6971. "Denisov, let him alone, I know who has taken it," said Rostov, going
6972. toward the door without raising his eyes. Denisov paused, thought a
6973. moment, and, evidently understanding what Rostov hinted at, seized his
6974. arm.
6975. 
6976. "Nonsense!" he cried, and the veins on his forehead and neck stood out
6977. like cords. "You are mad, I tell you. I won't allow it. The purse is
6978. here! I'll flay this scoundwel alive, and it will be found."
6979. 
6980. "I know who has taken it," repeated Rostov in an unsteady voice, and
6981. went to the door.
6982. 
6983. "And I tell you, don't you dahe to do it!" shouted Denisov, rushing at
6984. the cadet to restrain him.
6985. 
6986. But Rostov pulled away his arm and, with as much anger as though Denisov
6987. were his worst enemy, firmly fixed his eyes directly on his face.
6988. 
6989. "Do you understand what you're saying?" he said in a trembling voice.
6990. "There was no one else in the room except myself. So that if it is not
6991. so, then..."
6992. 
6993. He could not finish, and ran out of the room.
6994. 
6995. "Ah, may the devil take you and evewybody," were the last words Rostov
6996. heard.
6997. 
6998. Rostov went to Telyanin's quarters.
6999. 
7000. "The master is not in, he's gone to headquarters," said Telyanin's
7001. orderly. "Has something happened?" he added, surprised at the cadet's
7002. troubled face.
7003. 
7004. "No, nothing."
7005. 
7006. "You've only just missed him," said the orderly.
7007. 
7008. The headquarters were situated two miles away from Salzeneck, and
7009. Rostov, without returning home, took a horse and rode there. There was
7010. an inn in the village which the officers frequented. Rostov rode up to
7011. it and saw Telyanin's horse at the porch.
7012. 
7013. In the second room of the inn the lieutenant was sitting over a dish of
7014. sausages and a bottle of wine.
7015. 
7016. "Ah, you've come here too, young man!" he said, smiling and raising his
7017. eyebrows.
7018. 
7019. "Yes," said Rostov as if it cost him a great deal to utter the word; and
7020. he sat down at the nearest table.
7021. 
7022. Both were silent. There were two Germans and a Russian officer in the
7023. room. No one spoke and the only sounds heard were the clatter of knives
7024. and the munching of the lieutenant.
7025. 
7026. When Telyanin had finished his lunch he took out of his pocket a double
7027. purse and, drawing its rings aside with his small, white, turned-up
7028. fingers, drew out a gold imperial, and lifting his eyebrows gave it to
7029. the waiter.
7030. 
7031. "Please be quick," he said.
7032. 
7033. The coin was a new one. Rostov rose and went up to Telyanin.
7034. 
7035. "Allow me to look at your purse," he said in a low, almost inaudible,
7036. voice.
7037. 
7038. With shifting eyes but eyebrows still raised, Telyanin handed him the
7039. purse.
7040. 
7041. "Yes, it's a nice purse. Yes, yes," he said, growing suddenly pale, and
7042. added, "Look at it, young man."
7043. 
7044. Rostov took the purse in his hand, examined it and the money in it, and
7045. looked at Telyanin. The lieutenant was looking about in his usual way
7046. and suddenly seemed to grow very merry.
7047. 
7048. "If we get to Vienna I'll get rid of it there but in these wretched
7049. little towns there's nowhere to spend it," said he. "Well, let me have
7050. it, young man, I'm going."
7051. 
7052. Rostov did not speak.
7053. 
7054. "And you? Are you going to have lunch too? They feed you quite decently
7055. here," continued Telyanin. "Now then, let me have it."
7056. 
7057. He stretched out his hand to take hold of the purse. Rostov let go of
7058. it. Telyanin took the purse and began carelessly slipping it into the
7059. pocket of his riding breeches, with his eyebrows lifted and his mouth
7060. slightly open, as if to say, "Yes, yes, I am putting my purse in my
7061. pocket and that's quite simple and is no one else's business."
7062. 
7063. "Well, young man?" he said with a sigh, and from under his lifted brows
7064. he glanced into Rostov's eyes.
7065. 
7066. Some flash as of an electric spark shot from Telyanin's eyes to Rostov's
7067. and back, and back again and again in an instant.
7068. 
7069. "Come here," said Rostov, catching hold of Telyanin's arm and almost
7070. dragging him to the window. "That money is Denisov's; you took it..." he
7071. whispered just above Telyanin's ear.
7072. 
7073. "What? What? How dare you? What?" said Telyanin.
7074. 
7075. But these words came like a piteous, despairing cry and an entreaty for
7076. pardon. As soon as Rostov heard them, an enormous load of doubt fell
7077. from him. He was glad, and at the same instant began to pity the
7078. miserable man who stood before him, but the task he had begun had to be
7079. completed.
7080. 
7081. "Heaven only knows what the people here may imagine," muttered Telyanin,
7082. taking up his cap and moving toward a small empty room. "We must have an
7083. explanation..."
7084. 
7085. "I know it and shall prove it," said Rostov.
7086. 
7087. "I..."
7088. 
7089. Every muscle of Telyanin's pale, terrified face began to quiver, his
7090. eyes still shifted from side to side but with a downward look not rising
7091. to Rostov's face, and his sobs were audible.
7092. 
7093. "Count!... Don't ruin a young fellow... here is this wretched money,
7094. take it..." He threw it on the table. "I have an old father and
7095. mother!..."
7096. 
7097. Rostov took the money, avoiding Telyanin's eyes, and went out of the
7098. room without a word. But at the door he stopped and then retraced his
7099. steps. "O God," he said with tears in his eyes, "how could you do it?"
7100. 
7101. "Count..." said Telyanin drawing nearer to him.
7102. 
7103. "Don't touch me," said Rostov, drawing back. "If you need it, take the
7104. money," and he threw the purse to him and ran out of the inn.
7105. 
7106. 
7107. 
7108. 
7109. 
7110. CHAPTER V
7111. 
7112. 
7113. That same evening there was an animated discussion among the squadron's
7114. officers in Denisov's quarters.
7115. 
7116. "And I tell you, Rostov, that you must apologize to the colonel!" said
7117. a tall, grizzly-haired staff captain, with enormous mustaches and
7118. many wrinkles on his large features, to Rostov who was crimson with
7119. excitement.
7120. 
7121. The staff captain, Kirsten, had twice been reduced to the ranks for
7122. affairs of honor and had twice regained his commission.
7123. 
7124. "I will allow no one to call me a liar!" cried Rostov. "He told me I
7125. lied, and I told him he lied. And there it rests. He may keep me on
7126. duty every day, or may place me under arrest, but no one can make me
7127. apologize, because if he, as commander of this regiment, thinks it
7128. beneath his dignity to give me satisfaction, then..."
7129. 
7130. "You just wait a moment, my dear fellow, and listen," interrupted the
7131. staff captain in his deep bass, calmly stroking his long mustache. "You
7132. tell the colonel in the presence of other officers that an officer has
7133. stolen..."
7134. 
7135. "I'm not to blame that the conversation began in the presence of other
7136. officers. Perhaps I ought not to have spoken before them, but I am not
7137. a diplomatist. That's why I joined the hussars, thinking that here one
7138. would not need finesse; and he tells me that I am lying--so let him give
7139. me satisfaction..."
7140. 
7141. "That's all right. No one thinks you a coward, but that's not the point.
7142. Ask Denisov whether it is not out of the question for a cadet to demand
7143. satisfaction of his regimental commander?"
7144. 
7145. Denisov sat gloomily biting his mustache and listening to the
7146. conversation, evidently with no wish to take part in it. He answered the
7147. staff captain's question by a disapproving shake of his head.
7148. 
7149. "You speak to the colonel about this nasty business before other
7150. officers," continued the staff captain, "and Bogdanich" (the colonel was
7151. called Bogdanich) "shuts you up."
7152. 
7153. "He did not shut me up, he said I was telling an untruth."
7154. 
7155. "Well, have it so, and you talked a lot of nonsense to him and must
7156. apologize."
7157. 
7158. "Not on any account!" exclaimed Rostov.
7159. 
7160. "I did not expect this of you," said the staff captain seriously and
7161. severely. "You don't wish to apologize, but, man, it's not only to him
7162. but to the whole regiment--all of us--you're to blame all round. The
7163. case is this: you ought to have thought the matter over and taken
7164. advice; but no, you go and blurt it all straight out before the
7165. officers. Now what was the colonel to do? Have the officer tried and
7166. disgrace the whole regiment? Disgrace the whole regiment because of one
7167. scoundrel? Is that how you look at it? We don't see it like that. And
7168. Bogdanich was a brick: he told you you were saying what was not true.
7169. It's not pleasant, but what's to be done, my dear fellow? You landed
7170. yourself in it. And now, when one wants to smooth the thing over, some
7171. conceit prevents your apologizing, and you wish to make the whole
7172. affair public. You are offended at being put on duty a bit, but why not
7173. apologize to an old and honorable officer? Whatever Bogdanich may be,
7174. anyway he is an honorable and brave old colonel! You're quick at taking
7175. offense, but you don't mind disgracing the whole regiment!" The staff
7176. captain's voice began to tremble. "You have been in the regiment next
7177. to no time, my lad, you're here today and tomorrow you'll be appointed
7178. adjutant somewhere and can snap your fingers when it is said 'There are
7179. thieves among the Pavlograd officers!' But it's not all the same to us!
7180. Am I not right, Denisov? It's not the same!"
7181. 
7182. Denisov remained silent and did not move, but occasionally looked with
7183. his glittering black eyes at Rostov.
7184. 
7185. "You value your own pride and don't wish to apologize," continued
7186. the staff captain, "but we old fellows, who have grown up in and, God
7187. willing, are going to die in the regiment, we prize the honor of the
7188. regiment, and Bogdanich knows it. Oh, we do prize it, old fellow! And
7189. all this is not right, it's not right! You may take offense or not but I
7190. always stick to mother truth. It's not right!"
7191. 
7192. And the staff captain rose and turned away from Rostov.
7193. 
7194. "That's twue, devil take it!" shouted Denisov, jumping up. "Now then,
7195. Wostov, now then!"
7196. 
7197.  Rostov, growing red and pale alternately, looked first at one
7198. officer and then at the other.
7199. 
7200. "No, gentlemen, no... you mustn't think... I quite understand. You're
7201. wrong to think that of me... I... for me... for the honor of the
7202. regiment I'd... Ah well, I'll show that in action, and for me the honor
7203. of the flag... Well, never mind, it's true I'm to blame, to blame all
7204. round. Well, what else do you want?..."
7205. 
7206. "Come, that's right, Count!" cried the staff captain, turning round and
7207. clapping Rostov on the shoulder with his big hand.
7208. 
7209. "I tell you," shouted Denisov, "he's a fine fellow."
7210. 
7211. "That's better, Count," said the staff captain, beginning to address
7212. Rostov by his title, as if in recognition of his confession. "Go and
7213. apologize, your excellency. Yes, go!"
7214. 
7215. "Gentlemen, I'll do anything. No one shall hear a word from me," said
7216. Rostov in an imploring voice, "but I can't apologize, by God I can't,
7217. do what you will! How can I go and apologize like a little boy asking
7218. forgiveness?"
7219. 
7220. Denisov began to laugh.
7221. 
7222. "It'll be worse for you. Bogdanich is vindictive and you'll pay for your
7223. obstinacy," said Kirsten.
7224. 
7225. "No, on my word it's not obstinacy! I can't describe the feeling. I
7226. can't..."
7227. 
7228. "Well, it's as you like," said the staff captain. "And what has become
7229. of that scoundrel?" he asked Denisov.
7230. 
7231. "He has weported himself sick, he's to be stwuck off the list tomowwow,"
7232. muttered Denisov.
7233. 
7234. "It is an illness, there's no other way of explaining it," said the
7235. staff captain.
7236. 
7237. "Illness or not, he'd better not cwoss my path. I'd kill him!" shouted
7238. Denisov in a bloodthirsty tone.
7239. 
7240. Just then Zherkov entered the room.
7241. 
7242. "What brings you here?" cried the officers turning to the newcomer.
7243. 
7244. "We're to go into action, gentlemen! Mack has surrendered with his whole
7245. army."
7246. 
7247. "It's not true!"
7248. 
7249. "I've seen him myself!"
7250. 
7251. "What? Saw the real Mack? With hands and feet?"
7252. 
7253. "Into action! Into action! Bring him a bottle for such news! But how did
7254. you come here?"
7255. 
7256. "I've been sent back to the regiment all on account of that devil, Mack.
7257. An Austrian general complained of me. I congratulated him on Mack's
7258. arrival... What's the matter, Rostov? You look as if you'd just come out
7259. of a hot bath."
7260. 
7261. "Oh, my dear fellow, we're in such a stew here these last two days."
7262. 
7263. The regimental adjutant came in and confirmed the news brought by
7264. Zherkov. They were under orders to advance next day.
7265. 
7266. "We're going into action, gentlemen!"
7267. 
7268. "Well, thank God! We've been sitting here too long!"
7269. 
7270. 
7271. 
7272. 
7273. 
7274. CHAPTER VI
7275. 
7276. 
7277. Kutuzov fell back toward Vienna, destroying behind him the bridges over
7278. the rivers Inn (at Braunau) and Traun (near Linz). On October 23 the
7279. Russian troops were crossing the river Enns. At midday the Russian
7280. baggage train, the artillery, and columns of troops were defiling
7281. through the town of Enns on both sides of the bridge.
7282. 
7283. It was a warm, rainy, autumnal day. The wide expanse that opened out
7284. before the heights on which the Russian batteries stood guarding the
7285. bridge was at times veiled by a diaphanous curtain of slanting rain, and
7286. then, suddenly spread out in the sunlight, far-distant objects could
7287. be clearly seen glittering as though freshly varnished. Down below,
7288. the little town could be seen with its white, red-roofed houses, its
7289. cathedral, and its bridge, on both sides of which streamed jostling
7290. masses of Russian troops. At the bend of the Danube, vessels, an island,
7291. and a castle with a park surrounded by the waters of the confluence of
7292. the Enns and the Danube became visible, and the rocky left bank of the
7293. Danube covered with pine forests, with a mystic background of green
7294. treetops and bluish gorges. The turrets of a convent stood out beyond a
7295. wild virgin pine forest, and far away on the other side of the Enns the
7296. enemy's horse patrols could be discerned.
7297. 
7298. Among the field guns on the brow of the hill the general in command of
7299. the rearguard stood with a staff officer, scanning the country through
7300. his fieldglass. A little behind them Nesvitski, who had been sent to the
7301. rearguard by the commander in chief, was sitting on the trail of a gun
7302. carriage. A Cossack who accompanied him had handed him a knapsack and
7303. a flask, and Nesvitski was treating some officers to pies and real
7304. doppelkummel. The officers gladly gathered round him, some on their
7305. knees, some squatting Turkish fashion on the wet grass.
7306. 
7307. "Yes, the Austrian prince who built that castle was no fool. It's a
7308. fine place! Why are you not eating anything, gentlemen?" Nesvitski was
7309. saying.
7310. 
7311. "Thank you very much, Prince," answered one of the officers, pleased to
7312. be talking to a staff officer of such importance. "It's a lovely place!
7313. We passed close to the park and saw two deer... and what a splendid
7314. house!"
7315. 
7316. "Look, Prince," said another, who would have dearly liked to take
7317. another pie but felt shy, and therefore pretended to be examining the
7318. countryside--"See, our infantrymen have already got there. Look there
7319. in the meadow behind the village, three of them are dragging something.
7320. They'll ransack that castle," he remarked with evident approval.
7321. 
7322. "So they will," said Nesvitski. "No, but what I should like," added he,
7323. munching a pie in his moist-lipped handsome mouth, "would be to slip in
7324. over there."
7325. 
7326. He pointed with a smile to a turreted nunnery, and his eyes narrowed and
7327. gleamed.
7328. 
7329. "That would be fine, gentlemen!"
7330. 
7331. The officers laughed.
7332. 
7333. "Just to flutter the nuns a bit. They say there are Italian girls among
7334. them. On my word I'd give five years of my life for it!"
7335. 
7336. "They must be feeling dull, too," said one of the bolder officers,
7337. laughing.
7338. 
7339. Meanwhile the staff officer standing in front pointed out something to
7340. the general, who looked through his field glass.
7341. 
7342. "Yes, so it is, so it is," said the general angrily, lowering the field
7343. glass and shrugging his shoulders, "so it is! They'll be fired on at the
7344. crossing. And why are they dawdling there?"
7345. 
7346. On the opposite side the enemy could be seen by the naked eye, and from
7347. their battery a milk-white cloud arose. Then came the distant report of
7348. a shot, and our troops could be seen hurrying to the crossing.
7349. 
7350. Nesvitski rose, puffing, and went up to the general, smiling.
7351. 
7352. "Would not your excellency like a little refreshment?" he said.
7353. 
7354. "It's a bad business," said the general without answering him, "our men
7355. have been wasting time."
7356. 
7357. "Hadn't I better ride over, your excellency?" asked Nesvitski.
7358. 
7359. "Yes, please do," answered the general, and he repeated the order that
7360. had already once been given in detail: "and tell the hussars that
7361. they are to cross last and to fire the bridge as I ordered; and the
7362. inflammable material on the bridge must be reinspected."
7363. 
7364. "Very good," answered Nesvitski.
7365. 
7366. He called the Cossack with his horse, told him to put away the knapsack
7367. and flask, and swung his heavy person easily into the saddle.
7368. 
7369. "I'll really call in on the nuns," he said to the officers who watched
7370. him smilingly, and he rode off by the winding path down the hill.
7371. 
7372. "Now then, let's see how far it will carry, Captain. Just try!" said the
7373. general, turning to an artillery officer. "Have a little fun to pass the
7374. time."
7375. 
7376. "Crew, to your guns!" commanded the officer.
7377. 
7378. In a moment the men came running gaily from their campfires and began
7379. loading.
7380. 
7381. "One!" came the command.
7382. 
7383. Number one jumped briskly aside. The gun rang out with a deafening
7384. metallic roar, and a whistling grenade flew above the heads of our
7385. troops below the hill and fell far short of the enemy, a little smoke
7386. showing the spot where it burst.
7387. 
7388. The faces of officers and men brightened up at the sound. Everyone got
7389. up and began watching the movements of our troops below, as plainly
7390. visible as if but a stone's throw away, and the movements of the
7391. approaching enemy farther off. At the same instant the sun came fully
7392. out from behind the clouds, and the clear sound of the solitary shot
7393. and the brilliance of the bright sunshine merged in a single joyous and
7394. spirited impression.
7395. 
7396. 
7397. 
7398. 
7399. 
7400. CHAPTER VII
7401. 
7402. 
7403. Two of the enemy's shots had already flown across the bridge, where
7404. there was a crush. Halfway across stood Prince Nesvitski, who had
7405. alighted from his horse and whose big body was jammed against the
7406. railings. He looked back laughing to the Cossack who stood a few
7407. steps behind him holding two horses by their bridles. Each time Prince
7408. Nesvitski tried to move on, soldiers and carts pushed him back again and
7409. pressed him against the railings, and all he could do was to smile.
7410. 
7411. "What a fine fellow you are, friend!" said the Cossack to a convoy
7412. soldier with a wagon, who was pressing onto the infantrymen who were
7413. crowded together close to his wheels and his horses. "What a fellow! You
7414. can't wait a moment! Don't you see the general wants to pass?"
7415. 
7416. But the convoyman took no notice of the word "general" and shouted at
7417. the soldiers who were blocking his way. "Hi there, boys! Keep to the
7418. left! Wait a bit." But the soldiers, crowded together shoulder to
7419. shoulder, their bayonets interlocking, moved over the bridge in a dense
7420. mass. Looking down over the rails Prince Nesvitski saw the rapid, noisy
7421. little waves of the Enns, which rippling and eddying round the piles of
7422. the bridge chased each other along. Looking on the bridge he saw equally
7423. uniform living waves of soldiers, shoulder straps, covered shakos,
7424. knapsacks, bayonets, long muskets, and, under the shakos, faces with
7425. broad cheekbones, sunken cheeks, and listless tired expressions, and
7426. feet that moved through the sticky mud that covered the planks of the
7427. bridge. Sometimes through the monotonous waves of men, like a fleck of
7428. white foam on the waves of the Enns, an officer, in a cloak and with
7429. a type of face different from that of the men, squeezed his way along;
7430. sometimes like a chip of wood whirling in the river, an hussar on foot,
7431. an orderly, or a townsman was carried through the waves of infantry; and
7432. sometimes like a log floating down the river, an officers' or company's
7433. baggage wagon, piled high, leather covered, and hemmed in on all sides,
7434. moved across the bridge.
7435. 
7436. "It's as if a dam had burst," said the Cossack hopelessly. "Are there
7437. many more of you to come?"
7438. 
7439. "A million all but one!" replied a waggish soldier in a torn coat, with
7440. a wink, and passed on followed by another, an old man.
7441. 
7442. "If he" (he meant the enemy) "begins popping at the bridge now,"
7443. said the old soldier dismally to a comrade, "you'll forget to scratch
7444. yourself."
7445. 
7446. That soldier passed on, and after him came another sitting on a cart.
7447. 
7448. "Where the devil have the leg bands been shoved to?" said an orderly,
7449. running behind the cart and fumbling in the back of it.
7450. 
7451. And he also passed on with the wagon. Then came some merry soldiers who
7452. had evidently been drinking.
7453. 
7454. "And then, old fellow, he gives him one in the teeth with the butt end
7455. of his gun..." a soldier whose greatcoat was well tucked up said gaily,
7456. with a wide swing of his arm.
7457. 
7458. "Yes, the ham was just delicious..." answered another with a loud laugh.
7459. And they, too, passed on, so that Nesvitski did not learn who had been
7460. struck on the teeth, or what the ham had to do with it.
7461. 
7462. "Bah! How they scurry. He just sends a ball and they think they'll all
7463. be killed," a sergeant was saying angrily and reproachfully.
7464. 
7465. "As it flies past me, Daddy, the ball I mean," said a young soldier with
7466. an enormous mouth, hardly refraining from laughing, "I felt like dying
7467. of fright. I did, 'pon my word, I got that frightened!" said he, as if
7468. bragging of having been frightened.
7469. 
7470. That one also passed. Then followed a cart unlike any that had gone
7471. before. It was a German cart with a pair of horses led by a German, and
7472. seemed loaded with a whole houseful of effects. A fine brindled cow with
7473. a large udder was attached to the cart behind. A woman with an unweaned
7474. baby, an old woman, and a healthy German girl with bright red cheeks
7475. were sitting on some feather beds. Evidently these fugitives were
7476. allowed to pass by special permission. The eyes of all the soldiers
7477. turned toward the women, and while the vehicle was passing at foot pace
7478. all the soldiers' remarks related to the two young ones. Every face bore
7479. almost the same smile, expressing unseemly thoughts about the women.
7480. 
7481. "Just see, the German sausage is making tracks, too!"
7482. 
7483. "Sell me the missis," said another soldier, addressing the German, who,
7484. angry and frightened, strode energetically along with downcast eyes.
7485. 
7486. "See how smart she's made herself! Oh, the devils!"
7487. 
7488. "There, Fedotov, you should be quartered on them!"
7489. 
7490. "I have seen as much before now, mate!"
7491. 
7492. "Where are you going?" asked an infantry officer who was eating an
7493. apple, also half smiling as he looked at the handsome girl.
7494. 
7495. The German closed his eyes, signifying that he did not understand.
7496. 
7497. "Take it if you like," said the officer, giving the girl an apple.
7498. 
7499. The girl smiled and took it. Nesvitski like the rest of the men on the
7500. bridge did not take his eyes off the women till they had passed. When
7501. they had gone by, the same stream of soldiers followed, with the same
7502. kind of talk, and at last all stopped. As often happens, the horses of
7503. a convoy wagon became restive at the end of the bridge, and the whole
7504. crowd had to wait.
7505. 
7506. "And why are they stopping? There's no proper order!" said the soldiers.
7507. "Where are you shoving to? Devil take you! Can't you wait? It'll
7508. be worse if he fires the bridge. See, here's an officer jammed in
7509. too"--different voices were saying in the crowd, as the men looked at
7510. one another, and all pressed toward the exit from the bridge.
7511. 
7512. Looking down at the waters of the Enns under the bridge, Nesvitski
7513. suddenly heard a sound new to him, of something swiftly approaching...
7514. something big, that splashed into the water.
7515. 
7516. "Just see where it carries to!" a soldier near by said sternly, looking
7517. round at the sound.
7518. 
7519. "Encouraging us to get along quicker," said another uneasily.
7520. 
7521. The crowd moved on again. Nesvitski realized that it was a cannon ball.
7522. 
7523. "Hey, Cossack, my horse!" he said. "Now, then, you there! get out of the
7524. way! Make way!"
7525. 
7526. With great difficulty he managed to get to his horse, and shouting
7527. continually he moved on. The soldiers squeezed themselves to make way
7528. for him, but again pressed on him so that they jammed his leg, and those
7529. nearest him were not to blame for they were themselves pressed still
7530. harder from behind.
7531. 
7532. "Nesvitski, Nesvitski! you numskull!" came a hoarse voice from behind
7533. him.
7534. 
7535. Nesvitski looked round and saw, some fifteen paces away but separated by
7536. the living mass of moving infantry, Vaska Denisov, red and shaggy, with
7537. his cap on the back of his black head and a cloak hanging jauntily over
7538. his shoulder.
7539. 
7540. "Tell these devils, these fiends, to let me pass!" shouted Denisov
7541. evidently in a fit of rage, his coal-black eyes with their bloodshot
7542. whites glittering and rolling as he waved his sheathed saber in a small
7543. bare hand as red as his face.
7544. 
7545. "Ah, Vaska!" joyfully replied Nesvitski. "What's up with you?"
7546. 
7547. "The squadwon can't pass," shouted Vaska Denisov, showing his white
7548. teeth fiercely and spurring his black thoroughbred Arab, which twitched
7549. its ears as the bayonets touched it, and snorted, spurting white foam
7550. from his bit, tramping the planks of the bridge with his hoofs, and
7551. apparently ready to jump over the railings had his rider let him. "What
7552. is this? They're like sheep! Just like sheep! Out of the way!... Let
7553. us pass!... Stop there, you devil with the cart! I'll hack you with my
7554. saber!" he shouted, actually drawing his saber from its scabbard and
7555. flourishing it.
7556. 
7557. The soldiers crowded against one another with terrified faces, and
7558. Denisov joined Nesvitski.
7559. 
7560. "How's it you're not drunk today?" said Nesvitski when the other had
7561. ridden up to him.
7562. 
7563. "They don't even give one time to dwink!" answered Vaska Denisov. "They
7564. keep dwagging the wegiment to and fwo all day. If they mean to fight,
7565. let's fight. But the devil knows what this is."
7566. 
7567. "What a dandy you are today!" said Nesvitski, looking at Denisov's new
7568. cloak and saddlecloth.
7569. 
7570. Denisov smiled, took out of his sabretache a handkerchief that diffused
7571. a smell of perfume, and put it to Nesvitski's nose.
7572. 
7573. "Of course. I'm going into action! I've shaved, bwushed my teeth, and
7574. scented myself."
7575. 
7576. The imposing figure of Nesvitski followed by his Cossack, and
7577. the determination of Denisov who flourished his sword and shouted
7578. frantically, had such an effect that they managed to squeeze through
7579. to the farther side of the bridge and stopped the infantry. Beside the
7580. bridge Nesvitski found the colonel to whom he had to deliver the order,
7581. and having done this he rode back.
7582. 
7583. Having cleared the way Denisov stopped at the end of the bridge.
7584. Carelessly holding in his stallion that was neighing and pawing the
7585. ground, eager to rejoin its fellows, he watched his squadron draw
7586. nearer. Then the clang of hoofs, as of several horses galloping,
7587. resounded on the planks of the bridge, and the squadron, officers in
7588. front and men four abreast, spread across the bridge and began to emerge
7589. on his side of it.
7590. 
7591. The infantry who had been stopped crowded near the bridge in the
7592. trampled mud and gazed with that particular feeling of ill-will,
7593. estrangement, and ridicule with which troops of different arms usually
7594. encounter one another at the clean, smart hussars who moved past them in
7595. regular order.
7596. 
7597. "Smart lads! Only fit for a fair!" said one.
7598. 
7599. "What good are they? They're led about just for show!" remarked another.
7600. 
7601. "Don't kick up the dust, you infantry!" jested an hussar whose prancing
7602. horse had splashed mud over some foot soldiers.
7603. 
7604. "I'd like to put you on a two days' march with a knapsack! Your fine
7605. cords would soon get a bit rubbed," said an infantryman, wiping the mud
7606. off his face with his sleeve. "Perched up there, you're more like a bird
7607. than a man."
7608. 
7609. "There now, Zikin, they ought to put you on a horse. You'd look fine,"
7610. said a corporal, chaffing a thin little soldier who bent under the
7611. weight of his knapsack.
7612. 
7613. "Take a stick between your legs, that'll suit you for a horse!" the
7614. hussar shouted back.
7615. 
7616. 
7617. 
7618. 
7619. 
7620. CHAPTER VIII
7621. 
7622. 
7623. The last of the infantry hurriedly crossed the bridge, squeezing
7624. together as they approached it as if passing through a funnel. At last
7625. the baggage wagons had all crossed, the crush was less, and the last
7626. battalion came onto the bridge. Only Denisov's squadron of hussars
7627. remained on the farther side of the bridge facing the enemy, who could
7628. be seen from the hill on the opposite bank but was not yet visible from
7629. the bridge, for the horizon as seen from the valley through which the
7630. river flowed was formed by the rising ground only half a mile away.
7631. At the foot of the hill lay wasteland over which a few groups of our
7632. Cossack scouts were moving. Suddenly on the road at the top of the high
7633. ground, artillery and troops in blue uniform were seen. These were the
7634. French. A group of Cossack scouts retired down the hill at a trot. All
7635. the officers and men of Denisov's squadron, though they tried to talk of
7636. other things and to look in other directions, thought only of what
7637. was there on the hilltop, and kept constantly looking at the patches
7638. appearing on the skyline, which they knew to be the enemy's troops. The
7639. weather had cleared again since noon and the sun was descending brightly
7640. upon the Danube and the dark hills around it. It was calm, and at
7641. intervals the bugle calls and the shouts of the enemy could be heard
7642. from the hill. There was no one now between the squadron and the enemy
7643. except a few scattered skirmishers. An empty space of some seven hundred
7644. yards was all that separated them. The enemy ceased firing, and that
7645. stern, threatening, inaccessible, and intangible line which separates
7646. two hostile armies was all the more clearly felt.
7647. 
7648. "One step beyond that boundary line which resembles the line dividing
7649. the living from the dead lies uncertainty, suffering, and death. And
7650. what is there? Who is there?--there beyond that field, that tree, that
7651. roof lit up by the sun? No one knows, but one wants to know. You fear
7652. and yet long to cross that line, and know that sooner or later it must
7653. be crossed and you will have to find out what is there, just as you will
7654. inevitably have to learn what lies the other side of death. But you are
7655. strong, healthy, cheerful, and excited, and are surrounded by other such
7656. excitedly animated and healthy men." So thinks, or at any rate feels,
7657. anyone who comes in sight of the enemy, and that feeling gives a
7658. particular glamour and glad keenness of impression to everything that
7659. takes place at such moments.
7660. 
7661. On the high ground where the enemy was, the smoke of a cannon rose,
7662. and a ball flew whistling over the heads of the hussar squadron. The
7663. officers who had been standing together rode off to their places. The
7664. hussars began carefully aligning their horses. Silence fell on the whole
7665. squadron. All were looking at the enemy in front and at the squadron
7666. commander, awaiting the word of command. A second and a third cannon
7667. ball flew past. Evidently they were firing at the hussars, but the balls
7668. with rapid rhythmic whistle flew over the heads of the horsemen and fell
7669. somewhere beyond them. The hussars did not look round, but at the sound
7670. of each shot, as at the word of command, the whole squadron with its
7671. rows of faces so alike yet so different, holding its breath while the
7672. ball flew past, rose in the stirrups and sank back again. The soldiers
7673. without turning their heads glanced at one another, curious to see their
7674. comrades' impression. Every face, from Denisov's to that of the bugler,
7675. showed one common expression of conflict, irritation, and excitement,
7676. around chin and mouth. The quartermaster frowned, looking at the
7677. soldiers as if threatening to punish them. Cadet Mironov ducked every
7678. time a ball flew past. Rostov on the left flank, mounted on his Rook--a
7679. handsome horse despite its game leg--had the happy air of a schoolboy
7680. called up before a large audience for an examination in which he feels
7681. sure he will distinguish himself. He was glancing at everyone with a
7682. clear, bright expression, as if asking them to notice how calmly he sat
7683. under fire. But despite himself, on his face too that same indication of
7684. something new and stern showed round the mouth.
7685. 
7686. "Who's that curtseying there? Cadet Miwonov! That's not wight! Look at
7687. me," cried Denisov who, unable to keep still on one spot, kept turning
7688. his horse in front of the squadron.
7689. 
7690. The black, hairy, snub-nosed face of Vaska Denisov, and his whole short
7691. sturdy figure with the sinewy hairy hand and stumpy fingers in which
7692. he held the hilt of his naked saber, looked just as it usually did,
7693. especially toward evening when he had emptied his second bottle; he was
7694. only redder than usual. With his shaggy head thrown back like birds when
7695. they drink, pressing his spurs mercilessly into the sides of his good
7696. horse, Bedouin, and sitting as though falling backwards in the saddle,
7697. he galloped to the other flank of the squadron and shouted in a hoarse
7698. voice to the men to look to their pistols. He rode up to Kirsten. The
7699. staff captain on his broad-backed, steady mare came at a walk to meet
7700. him. His face with its long mustache was serious as always, only his
7701. eyes were brighter than usual.
7702. 
7703. "Well, what about it?" said he to Denisov. "It won't come to a fight.
7704. You'll see--we shall retire."
7705. 
7706. "The devil only knows what they're about!" muttered Denisov. "Ah,
7707. Wostov," he cried noticing the cadet's bright face, "you've got it at
7708. last."
7709. 
7710. And he smiled approvingly, evidently pleased with the cadet. Rostov felt
7711. perfectly happy. Just then the commander appeared on the bridge. Denisov
7712. galloped up to him.
7713. 
7714. "Your excellency! Let us attack them! I'll dwive them off."
7715. 
7716. "Attack indeed!" said the colonel in a bored voice, puckering up his
7717. face as if driving off a troublesome fly. "And why are you stopping
7718. here? Don't you see the skirmishers are retreating? Lead the squadron
7719. back."
7720. 
7721. The squadron crossed the bridge and drew out of range of fire without
7722. having lost a single man. The second squadron that had been in the front
7723. line followed them across and the last Cossacks quitted the farther side
7724. of the river.
7725. 
7726. The two Pavlograd squadrons, having crossed the bridge, retired up the
7727. hill one after the other. Their colonel, Karl Bogdanich Schubert, came
7728. up to Denisov's squadron and rode at a footpace not far from Rostov,
7729. without taking any notice of him although they were now meeting for the
7730. first time since their encounter concerning Telyanin. Rostov, feeling
7731. that he was at the front and in the power of a man toward whom he now
7732. admitted that he had been to blame, did not lift his eyes from the
7733. colonel's athletic back, his nape covered with light hair, and his red
7734. neck. It seemed to Rostov that Bogdanich was only pretending not to
7735. notice him, and that his whole aim now was to test the cadet's courage,
7736. so he drew himself up and looked around him merrily; then it seemed to
7737. him that Bogdanich rode so near in order to show him his courage. Next
7738. he thought that his enemy would send the squadron on a desperate attack
7739. just to punish him--Rostov. Then he imagined how, after the attack,
7740. Bogdanich would come up to him as he lay wounded and would magnanimously
7741. extend the hand of reconciliation.
7742. 
7743. The high-shouldered figure of Zherkov, familiar to the Pavlograds as he
7744. had but recently left their regiment, rode up to the colonel. After his
7745. dismissal from headquarters Zherkov had not remained in the regiment,
7746. saying he was not such a fool as to slave at the front when he could
7747. get more rewards by doing nothing on the staff, and had succeeded in
7748. attaching himself as an orderly officer to Prince Bagration. He now came
7749. to his former chief with an order from the commander of the rear guard.
7750. 
7751. "Colonel," he said, addressing Rostov's enemy with an air of gloomy
7752. gravity and glancing round at his comrades, "there is an order to stop
7753. and fire the bridge."
7754. 
7755. "An order to who?" asked the colonel morosely.
7756. 
7757. "I don't myself know 'to who,'" replied the cornet in a serious tone,
7758. "but the prince told me to 'go and tell the colonel that the hussars
7759. must return quickly and fire the bridge.'"
7760. 
7761. Zherkov was followed by an officer of the suite who rode up to the
7762. colonel of hussars with the same order. After him the stout Nesvitski
7763. came galloping up on a Cossack horse that could scarcely carry his
7764. weight.
7765. 
7766. "How's this, Colonel?" he shouted as he approached. "I told you to fire
7767. the bridge, and now someone has gone and blundered; they are all beside
7768. themselves over there and one can't make anything out."
7769. 
7770. The colonel deliberately stopped the regiment and turned to Nesvitski.
7771. 
7772. "You spoke to me of inflammable material," said he, "but you said
7773. nothing about firing it."
7774. 
7775. "But, my dear sir," said Nesvitski as he drew up, taking off his cap and
7776. smoothing his hair wet with perspiration with his plump hand, "wasn't I
7777. telling you to fire the bridge, when inflammable material had been put
7778. in position?"
7779. 
7780. "I am not your 'dear sir,' Mr. Staff Officer, and you did not tell me to
7781. burn the bridge! I know the service, and it is my habit orders strictly
7782. to obey. You said the bridge would be burned, but who would it burn, I
7783. could not know by the holy spirit!"
7784. 
7785. "Ah, that's always the way!" said Nesvitski with a wave of the hand.
7786. "How did you get here?" said he, turning to Zherkov.
7787. 
7788. "On the same business. But you are damp! Let me wring you out!"
7789. 
7790. "You were saying, Mr. Staff Officer..." continued the colonel in an
7791. offended tone.
7792. 
7793. "Colonel," interrupted the officer of the suite, "You must be quick or
7794. the enemy will bring up his guns to use grapeshot."
7795. 
7796. The colonel looked silently at the officer of the suite, at the stout
7797. staff officer, and at Zherkov, and he frowned.
7798. 
7799. "I will the bridge fire," he said in a solemn tone as if to announce
7800. that in spite of all the unpleasantness he had to endure he would still
7801. do the right thing.
7802. 
7803. Striking his horse with his long muscular legs as if it were to blame
7804. for everything, the colonel moved forward and ordered the second
7805. squadron, that in which Rostov was serving under Denisov, to return to
7806. the bridge.
7807. 
7808. "There, it's just as I thought," said Rostov to himself. "He wishes to
7809. test me!" His heart contracted and the blood rushed to his face. "Let
7810. him see whether I am a coward!" he thought.
7811. 
7812. Again on all the bright faces of the squadron the serious expression
7813. appeared that they had worn when under fire. Rostov watched his enemy,
7814. the colonel, closely--to find in his face confirmation of his own
7815. conjecture, but the colonel did not once glance at Rostov, and looked as
7816. he always did when at the front, solemn and stern. Then came the word of
7817. command.
7818. 
7819. "Look sharp! Look sharp!" several voices repeated around him.
7820. 
7821. Their sabers catching in the bridles and their spurs jingling, the
7822. hussars hastily dismounted, not knowing what they were to do. The men
7823. were crossing themselves. Rostov no longer looked at the colonel, he
7824. had no time. He was afraid of falling behind the hussars, so much afraid
7825. that his heart stood still. His hand trembled as he gave his horse into
7826. an orderly's charge, and he felt the blood rush to his heart with a
7827. thud. Denisov rode past him, leaning back and shouting something. Rostov
7828. saw nothing but the hussars running all around him, their spurs catching
7829. and their sabers clattering.
7830. 
7831. "Stretchers!" shouted someone behind him.
7832. 
7833. Rostov did not think what this call for stretchers meant; he ran on,
7834. trying only to be ahead of the others; but just at the bridge, not
7835. looking at the ground, he came on some sticky, trodden mud, stumbled,
7836. and fell on his hands. The others outstripped him.
7837. 
7838. "At boss zides, Captain," he heard the voice of the colonel, who,
7839. having ridden ahead, had pulled up his horse near the bridge, with a
7840. triumphant, cheerful face.
7841. 
7842. Rostov wiping his muddy hands on his breeches looked at his enemy and
7843. was about to run on, thinking that the farther he went to the front the
7844. better. But Bogdanich, without looking at or recognizing Rostov, shouted
7845. to him:
7846. 
7847. "Who's that running on the middle of the bridge? To the right! Come
7848. back, Cadet!" he cried angrily; and turning to Denisov, who, showing off
7849. his courage, had ridden on to the planks of the bridge:
7850. 
7851. "Why run risks, Captain? You should dismount," he said.
7852. 
7853. "Oh, every bullet has its billet," answered Vaska Denisov, turning in
7854. his saddle.
7855. 
7856. 
7857. Meanwhile Nesvitski, Zherkov, and the officer of the suite were standing
7858. together out of range of the shots, watching, now the small group of
7859. men with yellow shakos, dark-green jackets braided with cord, and blue
7860. riding breeches, who were swarming near the bridge, and then at what was
7861. approaching in the distance from the opposite side--the blue uniforms
7862. and groups with horses, easily recognizable as artillery.
7863. 
7864. "Will they burn the bridge or not? Who'll get there first? Will they get
7865. there and fire the bridge or will the French get within grapeshot range
7866. and wipe them out?" These were the questions each man of the troops
7867. on the high ground above the bridge involuntarily asked himself with a
7868. sinking heart--watching the bridge and the hussars in the bright evening
7869. light and the blue tunics advancing from the other side with their
7870. bayonets and guns.
7871. 
7872. "Ugh. The hussars will get it hot!" said Nesvitski; "they are within
7873. grapeshot range now."
7874. 
7875. "He shouldn't have taken so many men," said the officer of the suite.
7876. 
7877. "True enough," answered Nesvitski; "two smart fellows could have done
7878. the job just as well."
7879. 
7880. "Ah, your excellency," put in Zherkov, his eyes fixed on the hussars,
7881. but still with that naive air that made it impossible to know whether he
7882. was speaking in jest or in earnest. "Ah, your excellency! How you look
7883. at things! Send two men? And who then would give us the Vladimir medal
7884. and ribbon? But now, even if they do get peppered, the squadron may be
7885. recommended for honors and he may get a ribbon. Our Bogdanich knows how
7886. things are done."
7887. 
7888. "There now!" said the officer of the suite, "that's grapeshot."
7889. 
7890. He pointed to the French guns, the limbers of which were being detached
7891. and hurriedly removed.
7892. 
7893. On the French side, amid the groups with cannon, a cloud of smoke
7894. appeared, then a second and a third almost simultaneously, and at the
7895. moment when the first report was heard a fourth was seen. Then two
7896. reports one after another, and a third.
7897. 
7898. "Oh! Oh!" groaned Nesvitski as if in fierce pain, seizing the officer of
7899. the suite by the arm. "Look! A man has fallen! Fallen, fallen!"
7900. 
7901. "Two, I think."
7902. 
7903. "If I were Tsar I would never go to war," said Nesvitski, turning away.
7904. 
7905. The French guns were hastily reloaded. The infantry in their blue
7906. uniforms advanced toward the bridge at a run. Smoke appeared again
7907. but at irregular intervals, and grapeshot cracked and rattled onto the
7908. bridge. But this time Nesvitski could not see what was happening there,
7909. as a dense cloud of smoke arose from it. The hussars had succeeded in
7910. setting it on fire and the French batteries were now firing at them, no
7911. longer to hinder them but because the guns were trained and there was
7912. someone to fire at.
7913. 
7914. The French had time to fire three rounds of grapeshot before the hussars
7915. got back to their horses. Two were misdirected and the shot went too
7916. high, but the last round fell in the midst of a group of hussars and
7917. knocked three of them over.
7918. 
7919. Rostov, absorbed by his relations with Bogdanich, had paused on the
7920. bridge not knowing what to do. There was no one to hew down (as he
7921. had always imagined battles to himself), nor could he help to fire the
7922. bridge because he had not brought any burning straw with him like the
7923. other soldiers. He stood looking about him, when suddenly he heard a
7924. rattle on the bridge as if nuts were being spilt, and the hussar nearest
7925. to him fell against the rails with a groan. Rostov ran up to him with
7926. the others. Again someone shouted, "Stretchers!" Four men seized the
7927. hussar and began lifting him.
7928. 
7929. "Oooh! For Christ's sake let me alone!" cried the wounded man, but still
7930. he was lifted and laid on the stretcher.
7931. 
7932. Nicholas Rostov turned away and, as if searching for something, gazed
7933. into the distance, at the waters of the Danube, at the sky, and at the
7934. sun. How beautiful the sky looked; how blue, how calm, and how deep!
7935. How bright and glorious was the setting sun! With what soft glitter the
7936. waters of the distant Danube shone. And fairer still were the faraway
7937. blue mountains beyond the river, the nunnery, the mysterious gorges, and
7938. the pine forests veiled in the mist of their summits... There was peace
7939. and happiness... "I should wish for nothing else, nothing, if only I
7940. were there," thought Rostov. "In myself alone and in that sunshine there
7941. is so much happiness; but here... groans, suffering, fear, and this
7942. uncertainty and hurry... There--they are shouting again, and again are
7943. all running back somewhere, and I shall run with them, and it, death, is
7944. here above me and around... Another instant and I shall never again see
7945. the sun, this water, that gorge!..."
7946. 
7947. At that instant the sun began to hide behind the clouds, and other
7948. stretchers came into view before Rostov. And the fear of death and of
7949. the stretchers, and love of the sun and of life, all merged into one
7950. feeling of sickening agitation.
7951. 
7952. "O Lord God! Thou who art in that heaven, save, forgive, and protect
7953. me!" Rostov whispered.
7954. 
7955. The hussars ran back to the men who held their horses; their voices
7956. sounded louder and calmer, the stretchers disappeared from sight.
7957. 
7958. "Well, fwiend? So you've smelt powdah!" shouted Vaska Denisov just above
7959. his ear.
7960. 
7961. "It's all over; but I am a coward--yes, a coward!" thought Rostov, and
7962. sighing deeply he took Rook, his horse, which stood resting one foot,
7963. from the orderly and began to mount.
7964. 
7965. "Was that grapeshot?" he asked Denisov.
7966. 
7967. "Yes and no mistake!" cried Denisov. "You worked like wegular bwicks and
7968. it's nasty work! An attack's pleasant work! Hacking away at the dogs!
7969. But this sort of thing is the very devil, with them shooting at you like
7970. a target."
7971. 
7972. And Denisov rode up to a group that had stopped near Rostov, composed of
7973. the colonel, Nesvitski, Zherkov, and the officer from the suite.
7974. 
7975. "Well, it seems that no one has noticed," thought Rostov. And this was
7976. true. No one had taken any notice, for everyone knew the sensation which
7977. the cadet under fire for the first time had experienced.
7978. 
7979. "Here's something for you to report," said Zherkov. "See if I don't get
7980. promoted to a sublieutenancy."
7981. 
7982. "Inform the prince that I the bridge fired!" said the colonel
7983. triumphantly and gaily.
7984. 
7985. "And if he asks about the losses?"
7986. 
7987. "A trifle," said the colonel in his bass voice: "two hussars wounded,
7988. and one knocked out," he added, unable to restrain a happy smile, and
7989. pronouncing the phrase "knocked out" with ringing distinctness.
7990. 
7991. 
7992. 
7993. 
7994. 
7995. CHAPTER IX
7996. 
7997. 
7998. Pursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under the command
7999. of Bonaparte, encountering a population that was unfriendly to it,
8000. losing confidence in its allies, suffering from shortness of supplies,
8001. and compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anything that had
8002. been foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand men commanded
8003. by Kutuzov was hurriedly retreating along the Danube, stopping where
8004. overtaken by the enemy and fighting rearguard actions only as far as
8005. necessary to enable it to retreat without losing its heavy equipment.
8006. There had been actions at Lambach, Amstetten, and Melk; but despite the
8007. courage and endurance--acknowledged even by the enemy--with which the
8008. Russians fought, the only consequence of these actions was a yet more
8009. rapid retreat. Austrian troops that had escaped capture at Ulm and
8010. had joined Kutuzov at Braunau now separated from the Russian army,
8011. and Kutuzov was left with only his own weak and exhausted forces.
8012. The defense of Vienna was no longer to be thought of. Instead of an
8013. offensive, the plan of which, carefully prepared in accord with the
8014. modern science of strategics, had been handed to Kutuzov when he was in
8015. Vienna by the Austrian Hofkriegsrath, the sole and almost unattainable
8016. aim remaining for him was to effect a junction with the forces that were
8017. advancing from Russia, without losing his army as Mack had done at Ulm.
8018. 
8019. On the twenty-eighth of October Kutuzov with his army crossed to the
8020. left bank of the Danube and took up a position for the first time
8021. with the river between himself and the main body of the French. On the
8022. thirtieth he attacked Mortier's division, which was on the left bank,
8023. and broke it up. In this action for the first time trophies were taken:
8024. banners, cannon, and two enemy generals. For the first time, after a
8025. fortnight's retreat, the Russian troops had halted and after a fight had
8026. not only held the field but had repulsed the French. Though the troops
8027. were ill-clad, exhausted, and had lost a third of their number in
8028. killed, wounded, sick, and stragglers; though a number of sick and
8029. wounded had been abandoned on the other side of the Danube with a letter
8030. in which Kutuzov entrusted them to the humanity of the enemy; and
8031. though the big hospitals and the houses in Krems converted into military
8032. hospitals could no longer accommodate all the sick and wounded, yet the
8033. stand made at Krems and the victory over Mortier raised the spirits of
8034. the army considerably. Throughout the whole army and at headquarters
8035. most joyful though erroneous rumors were rife of the imaginary approach
8036. of columns from Russia, of some victory gained by the Austrians, and of
8037. the retreat of the frightened Bonaparte.
8038. 
8039. Prince Andrew during the battle had been in attendance on the Austrian
8040. General Schmidt, who was killed in the action. His horse had been
8041. wounded under him and his own arm slightly grazed by a bullet. As a mark
8042. of the commander in chief's special favor he was sent with the news of
8043. this victory to the Austrian court, now no longer at Vienna (which was
8044. threatened by the French) but at Brunn. Despite his apparently delicate
8045. build Prince Andrew could endure physical fatigue far better than many
8046. very muscular men, and on the night of the battle, having arrived at
8047. Krems excited but not weary, with dispatches from Dokhturov to Kutuzov,
8048. he was sent immediately with a special dispatch to Brunn. To be so sent
8049. meant not only a reward but an important step toward promotion.
8050. 
8051. The night was dark but starry, the road showed black in the snow that
8052. had fallen the previous day--the day of the battle. Reviewing his
8053. impressions of the recent battle, picturing pleasantly to himself the
8054. impression his news of a victory would create, or recalling the send-off
8055. given him by the commander in chief and his fellow officers, Prince
8056. Andrew was galloping along in a post chaise enjoying the feelings of a
8057. man who has at length begun to attain a long-desired happiness. As soon
8058. as he closed his eyes his ears seemed filled with the rattle of the
8059. wheels and the sensation of victory. Then he began to imagine that
8060. the Russians were running away and that he himself was killed, but he
8061. quickly roused himself with a feeling of joy, as if learning afresh that
8062. this was not so but that on the contrary the French had run away. He
8063. again recalled all the details of the victory and his own calm courage
8064. during the battle, and feeling reassured he dozed off.... The dark
8065. starry night was followed by a bright cheerful morning. The snow was
8066. thawing in the sunshine, the horses galloped quickly, and on both sides
8067. of the road were forests of different kinds, fields, and villages.
8068. 
8069. At one of the post stations he overtook a convoy of Russian wounded.
8070. The Russian officer in charge of the transport lolled back in the front
8071. cart, shouting and scolding a soldier with coarse abuse. In each of
8072. the long German carts six or more pale, dirty, bandaged men were being
8073. jolted over the stony road. Some of them were talking (he heard Russian
8074. words), others were eating bread; the more severely wounded looked
8075. silently, with the languid interest of sick children, at the envoy
8076. hurrying past them.
8077. 
8078. Prince Andrew told his driver to stop, and asked a soldier in what
8079. action they had been wounded. "Day before yesterday, on the Danube,"
8080. answered the soldier. Prince Andrew took out his purse and gave the
8081. soldier three gold pieces.
8082. 
8083. "That's for them all," he said to the officer who came up.
8084. 
8085. "Get well soon, lads!" he continued, turning to the soldiers. "There's
8086. plenty to do still."
8087. 
8088. "What news, sir?" asked the officer, evidently anxious to start a
8089. conversation.
8090. 
8091. "Good news!... Go on!" he shouted to the driver, and they galloped on.
8092. 
8093. It was already quite dark when Prince Andrew rattled over the paved
8094. streets of Brunn and found himself surrounded by high buildings, the
8095. lights of shops, houses, and street lamps, fine carriages, and all that
8096. atmosphere of a large and active town which is always so attractive to a
8097. soldier after camp life. Despite his rapid journey and sleepless night,
8098. Prince Andrew when he drove up to the palace felt even more vigorous and
8099. alert than he had done the day before. Only his eyes gleamed feverishly
8100. and his thoughts followed one another with extraordinary clearness and
8101. rapidity. He again vividly recalled the details of the battle, no longer
8102. dim, but definite and in the concise form in which he imagined himself
8103. stating them to the Emperor Francis. He vividly imagined the casual
8104. questions that might be put to him and the answers he would give. He
8105. expected to be at once presented to the Emperor. At the chief entrance
8106. to the palace, however, an official came running out to meet him, and
8107. learning that he was a special messenger led him to another entrance.
8108. 
8109. "To the right from the corridor, Euer Hochgeboren! There you will find
8110. the adjutant on duty," said the official. "He will conduct you to the
8111. Minister of War."
8112. 
8113. The adjutant on duty, meeting Prince Andrew, asked him to wait, and went
8114. in to the Minister of War. Five minutes later he returned and bowing
8115. with particular courtesy ushered Prince Andrew before him along a
8116. corridor to the cabinet where the Minister of War was at work. The
8117. adjutant by his elaborate courtesy appeared to wish to ward off any
8118. attempt at familiarity on the part of the Russian messenger.
8119. 
8120. Prince Andrew's joyous feeling was considerably weakened as he
8121. approached the door of the minister's room. He felt offended, and
8122. without his noticing it the feeling of offense immediately turned into
8123. one of disdain which was quite uncalled for. His fertile mind instantly
8124. suggested to him a point of view which gave him a right to despise the
8125. adjutant and the minister. "Away from the smell of powder, they
8126. probably think it easy to gain victories!" he thought. His eyes narrowed
8127. disdainfully, he entered the room of the Minister of War with peculiarly
8128. deliberate steps. This feeling of disdain was heightened when he saw the
8129. minister seated at a large table reading some papers and making pencil
8130. notes on them, and for the first two or three minutes taking no notice
8131. of his arrival. A wax candle stood at each side of the minister's bent
8132. bald head with its gray temples. He went on reading to the end, without
8133. raising his eyes at the opening of the door and the sound of footsteps.
8134. 
8135. "Take this and deliver it," said he to his adjutant, handing him the
8136. papers and still taking no notice of the special messenger.
8137. 
8138. Prince Andrew felt that either the actions of Kutuzov's army interested
8139. the Minister of War less than any of the other matters he was
8140. concerned with, or he wanted to give the Russian special messenger that
8141. impression. "But that is a matter of perfect indifference to me," he
8142. thought. The minister drew the remaining papers together, arranged them
8143. evenly, and then raised his head. He had an intellectual and distinctive
8144. head, but the instant he turned to Prince Andrew the firm, intelligent
8145. expression on his face changed in a way evidently deliberate and
8146. habitual to him. His face took on the stupid artificial smile (which
8147. does not even attempt to hide its artificiality) of a man who is
8148. continually receiving many petitioners one after another.
8149. 
8150. "From General Field Marshal Kutuzov?" he asked. "I hope it is good news?
8151. There has been an encounter with Mortier? A victory? It was high time!"
8152. 
8153. He took the dispatch which was addressed to him and began to read it
8154. with a mournful expression.
8155. 
8156. "Oh, my God! My God! Schmidt!" he exclaimed in German. "What a calamity!
8157. What a calamity!"
8158. 
8159. Having glanced through the dispatch he laid it on the table and looked
8160. at Prince Andrew, evidently considering something.
8161. 
8162. "Ah what a calamity! You say the affair was decisive? But Mortier is
8163. not captured." Again he pondered. "I am very glad you have brought good
8164. news, though Schmidt's death is a heavy price to pay for the victory.
8165. His Majesty will no doubt wish to see you, but not today. I thank
8166. you! You must have a rest. Be at the levee tomorrow after the parade.
8167. However, I will let you know."
8168. 
8169. The stupid smile, which had left his face while he was speaking,
8170. reappeared.
8171. 
8172. "Au revoir! Thank you very much. His Majesty will probably desire to see
8173. you," he added, bowing his head.
8174. 
8175. When Prince Andrew left the palace he felt that all the interest
8176. and happiness the victory had afforded him had been now left in the
8177. indifferent hands of the Minister of War and the polite adjutant. The
8178. whole tenor of his thoughts instantaneously changed; the battle seemed
8179. the memory of a remote event long past.
8180. 
8181. 
8182. 
8183. 
8184. 
8185. CHAPTER X
8186. 
8187. 
8188. Prince Andrew stayed at Brunn with Bilibin, a Russian acquaintance of
8189. his in the diplomatic service.
8190. 
8191. "Ah, my dear prince! I could not have a more welcome visitor," said
8192. Bilibin as he came out to meet Prince Andrew. "Franz, put the prince's
8193. things in my bedroom," said he to the servant who was ushering Bolkonski
8194. in. "So you're a messenger of victory, eh? Splendid! And I am sitting
8195. here ill, as you see."
8196. 
8197. After washing and dressing, Prince Andrew came into the diplomat's
8198. luxurious study and sat down to the dinner prepared for him. Bilibin
8199. settled down comfortably beside the fire.
8200. 
8201. After his journey and the campaign during which he had been deprived of
8202. all the comforts of cleanliness and all the refinements of life, Prince
8203. Andrew felt a pleasant sense of repose among luxurious surroundings such
8204. as he had been accustomed to from childhood. Besides it was pleasant,
8205. after his reception by the Austrians, to speak if not in Russian
8206. (for they were speaking French) at least with a Russian who would, he
8207. supposed, share the general Russian antipathy to the Austrians which was
8208. then particularly strong.
8209. 
8210. Bilibin was a man of thirty-five, a bachelor, and of the same circle as
8211. Prince Andrew. They had known each other previously in Petersburg, but
8212. had become more intimate when Prince Andrew was in Vienna with Kutuzov.
8213. Just as Prince Andrew was a young man who gave promise of rising high
8214. in the military profession, so to an even greater extent Bilibin gave
8215. promise of rising in his diplomatic career. He still a young man but
8216. no longer a young diplomat, as he had entered the service at the age
8217. of sixteen, had been in Paris and Copenhagen, and now held a rather
8218. important post in Vienna. Both the foreign minister and our ambassador
8219. in Vienna knew him and valued him. He was not one of those many
8220. diplomats who are esteemed because they have certain negative qualities,
8221. avoid doing certain things, and speak French. He was one of those,
8222. who, liking work, knew how to do it, and despite his indolence would
8223. sometimes spend a whole night at his writing table. He worked well
8224. whatever the import of his work. It was not the question "What for?"
8225. but the question "How?" that interested him. What the diplomatic matter
8226. might be he did not care, but it gave him great pleasure to prepare a
8227. circular, memorandum, or report, skillfully, pointedly, and elegantly.
8228. Bilibin's services were valued not only for what he wrote, but also for
8229. his skill in dealing and conversing with those in the highest spheres.
8230. 
8231. Bilibin liked conversation as he liked work, only when it could be made
8232. elegantly witty. In society he always awaited an opportunity to say
8233. something striking and took part in a conversation only when that was
8234. possible. His conversation was always sprinkled with wittily original,
8235. finished phrases of general interest. These sayings were prepared in the
8236. inner laboratory of his mind in a portable form as if intentionally, so
8237. that insignificant society people might carry them from drawing room to
8238. drawing room. And, in fact, Bilibin's witticisms were hawked about
8239. in the Viennese drawing rooms and often had an influence on matters
8240. considered important.
8241. 
8242. His thin, worn, sallow face was covered with deep wrinkles, which always
8243. looked as clean and well washed as the tips of one's fingers after a
8244. Russian bath. The movement of these wrinkles formed the principal play
8245. of expression on his face. Now his forehead would pucker into deep folds
8246. and his eyebrows were lifted, then his eyebrows would descend and
8247. deep wrinkles would crease his cheeks. His small, deep-set eyes always
8248. twinkled and looked out straight.
8249. 
8250. "Well, now tell me about your exploits," said he.
8251. 
8252. Bolkonski, very modestly without once mentioning himself, described the
8253. engagement and his reception by the Minister of War.
8254. 
8255. "They received me and my news as one receives a dog in a game of
8256. skittles," said he in conclusion.
8257. 
8258. Bilibin smiled and the wrinkles on his face disappeared.
8259. 
8260. "Cependant, mon cher," he remarked, examining his nails from a distance
8261. and puckering the skin above his left eye, "malgre la haute estime que
8262. je professe pour the Orthodox Russian army, j'avoue que votre victoire
8263. n'est pas des plus victorieuses." *
8264. 
8265. 
8266.      * "But my dear fellow, with all my respect for the Orthodox
8267.      Russian army, I must say that your victory was not
8268.      particularly victorious."
8269. 
8270. 
8271. He went on talking in this way in French, uttering only those words in
8272. Russian on which he wished to put a contemptuous emphasis.
8273. 
8274. "Come now! You with all your forces fall on the unfortunate Mortier
8275. and his one division, and even then Mortier slips through your fingers!
8276. Where's the victory?"
8277. 
8278. "But seriously," said Prince Andrew, "we can at any rate say without
8279. boasting that it was a little better than at Ulm..."
8280. 
8281. "Why didn't you capture one, just one, marshal for us?"
8282. 
8283. "Because not everything happens as one expects or with the smoothness of
8284. a parade. We had expected, as I told you, to get at their rear by seven
8285. in the morning but had not reached it by five in the afternoon."
8286. 
8287. "And why didn't you do it at seven in the morning? You ought to have
8288. been there at seven in the morning," returned Bilibin with a smile. "You
8289. ought to have been there at seven in the morning."
8290. 
8291. "Why did you not succeed in impressing on Bonaparte by diplomatic
8292. methods that he had better leave Genoa alone?" retorted Prince Andrew in
8293. the same tone.
8294. 
8295. "I know," interrupted Bilibin, "you're thinking it's very easy to take
8296. marshals, sitting on a sofa by the fire! That is true, but still why
8297. didn't you capture him? So don't be surprised if not only the Minister
8298. of War but also his Most August Majesty the Emperor and King Francis
8299. is not much delighted by your victory. Even I, a poor secretary of the
8300. Russian Embassy, do not feel any need in token of my joy to give my
8301. Franz a thaler, or let him go with his Liebchen to the Prater... True,
8302. we have no Prater here..."
8303. 
8304. He looked straight at Prince Andrew and suddenly unwrinkled his
8305. forehead.
8306. 
8307. "It is now my turn to ask you 'why?' mon cher," said Bolkonski. "I
8308. confess I do not understand: perhaps there are diplomatic subtleties
8309. here beyond my feeble intelligence, but I can't make it out. Mack loses
8310. a whole army, the Archduke Ferdinand and the Archduke Karl give no signs
8311. of life and make blunder after blunder. Kutuzov alone at last gains a
8312. real victory, destroying the spell of the invincibility of the French,
