8313. and the Minister of War does not even care to hear the details."
8314. 
8315. "That's just it, my dear fellow. You see it's hurrah for the Tsar, for
8316. Russia, for the Orthodox Greek faith! All that is beautiful, but what
8317. do we, I mean the Austrian court, care for your victories? Bring us nice
8318. news of a victory by the Archduke Karl or Ferdinand (one archduke's as
8319. good as another, as you know) and even if it is only over a fire brigade
8320. of Bonaparte's, that will be another story and we'll fire off some
8321. cannon! But this sort of thing seems done on purpose to vex us. The
8322. Archduke Karl does nothing, the Archduke Ferdinand disgraces himself.
8323. You abandon Vienna, give up its defense--as much as to say: 'Heaven is
8324. with us, but heaven help you and your capital!' The one general whom we
8325. all loved, Schmidt, you expose to a bullet, and then you congratulate
8326. us on the victory! Admit that more irritating news than yours could not
8327. have been conceived. It's as if it had been done on purpose, on purpose.
8328. Besides, suppose you did gain a brilliant victory, if even the Archduke
8329. Karl gained a victory, what effect would that have on the general course
8330. of events? It's too late now when Vienna is occupied by the French
8331. army!"
8332. 
8333. "What? Occupied? Vienna occupied?"
8334. 
8335. "Not only occupied, but Bonaparte is at Schonbrunn, and the count, our
8336. dear Count Vrbna, goes to him for orders."
8337. 
8338. After the fatigues and impressions of the journey, his reception, and
8339. especially after having dined, Bolkonski felt that he could not take in
8340. the full significance of the words he heard.
8341. 
8342. "Count Lichtenfels was here this morning," Bilibin continued, "and
8343. showed me a letter in which the parade of the French in Vienna was fully
8344. described: Prince Murat et tout le tremblement... You see that your
8345. victory is not a matter for great rejoicing and that you can't be
8346. received as a savior."
8347. 
8348. "Really I don't care about that, I don't care at all," said Prince
8349. Andrew, beginning to understand that his news of the battle before Krems
8350. was really of small importance in view of such events as the fall of
8351. Austria's capital. "How is it Vienna was taken? What of the bridge and
8352. its celebrated bridgehead and Prince Auersperg? We heard reports that
8353. Prince Auersperg was defending Vienna?" he said.
8354. 
8355. "Prince Auersperg is on this, on our side of the river, and is defending
8356. us--doing it very badly, I think, but still he is defending us. But
8357. Vienna is on the other side. No, the bridge has not yet been taken and I
8358. hope it will not be, for it is mined and orders have been given to
8359. blow it up. Otherwise we should long ago have been in the mountains of
8360. Bohemia, and you and your army would have spent a bad quarter of an hour
8361. between two fires."
8362. 
8363. "But still this does not mean that the campaign is over," said Prince
8364. Andrew.
8365. 
8366. "Well, I think it is. The bigwigs here think so too, but they daren't
8367. say so. It will be as I said at the beginning of the campaign, it won't
8368. be your skirmishing at Durrenstein, or gunpowder at all, that will
8369. decide the matter, but those who devised it," said Bilibin quoting one
8370. of his own mots, releasing the wrinkles on his forehead, and pausing.
8371. "The only question is what will come of the meeting between the Emperor
8372. Alexander and the King of Prussia in Berlin? If Prussia joins the
8373. Allies, Austria's hand will be forced and there will be war. If not
8374. it is merely a question of settling where the preliminaries of the new
8375. Campo Formio are to be drawn up."
8376. 
8377. "What an extraordinary genius!" Prince Andrew suddenly exclaimed,
8378. clenching his small hand and striking the table with it, "and what luck
8379. the man has!"
8380. 
8381. "Buonaparte?" said Bilibin inquiringly, puckering up his forehead to
8382. indicate that he was about to say something witty. "Buonaparte?" he
8383. repeated, accentuating the u: "I think, however, now that he lays down
8384. laws for Austria at Schonbrunn, il faut lui faire grace de l'u! * I
8385. shall certainly adopt an innovation and call him simply Bonaparte!"
8386. 
8387. 
8388.     * "We must let him off the u!"
8389. 
8390. 
8391. "But joking apart," said Prince Andrew, "do you really think the
8392. campaign is over?"
8393. 
8394. "This is what I think. Austria has been made a fool of, and she is not
8395. used to it. She will retaliate. And she has been fooled in the first
8396. place because her provinces have been pillaged--they say the Holy
8397. Russian army loots terribly--her army is destroyed, her capital
8398. taken, and all this for the beaux yeux * of His Sardinian Majesty. And
8399. therefore--this is between ourselves--I instinctively feel that we are
8400. being deceived, my instinct tells me of negotiations with France and
8401. projects for peace, a secret peace concluded separately."
8402. 
8403. 
8404.     * Fine eyes.
8405. 
8406. 
8407. "Impossible!" cried Prince Andrew. "That would be too base."
8408. 
8409. "If we live we shall see," replied Bilibin, his face again becoming
8410. smooth as a sign that the conversation was at an end.
8411. 
8412. When Prince Andrew reached the room prepared for him and lay down in a
8413. clean shirt on the feather bed with its warmed and fragrant pillows, he
8414. felt that the battle of which he had brought tidings was far, far away
8415. from him. The alliance with Prussia, Austria's treachery, Bonaparte's
8416. new triumph, tomorrow's levee and parade, and the audience with the
8417. Emperor Francis occupied his thoughts.
8418. 
8419. He closed his eyes, and immediately a sound of cannonading, of musketry
8420. and the rattling of carriage wheels seemed to fill his ears, and now
8421. again drawn out in a thin line the musketeers were descending the hill,
8422. the French were firing, and he felt his heart palpitating as he rode
8423. forward beside Schmidt with the bullets merrily whistling all around,
8424. and he experienced tenfold the joy of living, as he had not done since
8425. childhood.
8426. 
8427. He woke up...
8428. 
8429. "Yes, that all happened!" he said, and, smiling happily to himself like
8430. a child, he fell into a deep, youthful slumber.
8431. 
8432. 
8433. 
8434. 
8435. 
8436. CHAPTER XI
8437. 
8438. 
8439. Next day he woke late. Recalling his recent impressions, the first
8440. thought that came into his mind was that today he had to be presented
8441. to the Emperor Francis; he remembered the Minister of War, the polite
8442. Austrian adjutant, Bilibin, and last night's conversation. Having
8443. dressed for his attendance at court in full parade uniform, which he had
8444. not worn for a long time, he went into Bilibin's study fresh, animated,
8445. and handsome, with his hand bandaged. In the study were four gentlemen
8446. of the diplomatic corps. With Prince Hippolyte Kuragin, who was a
8447. secretary to the embassy, Bolkonski was already acquainted. Bilibin
8448. introduced him to the others.
8449. 
8450. The gentlemen assembled at Bilibin's were young, wealthy, gay society
8451. men, who here, as in Vienna, formed a special set which Bilibin, their
8452. leader, called les notres. * This set, consisting almost exclusively of
8453. diplomats, evidently had its own interests which had nothing to do with
8454. war or politics but related to high society, to certain women, and to
8455. the official side of the service. These gentlemen received Prince
8456. Andrew as one of themselves, an honor they did not extend to many. From
8457. politeness and to start conversation, they asked him a few questions
8458. about the army and the battle, and then the talk went off into merry
8459. jests and gossip.
8460. 
8461. 
8462.     * Ours.
8463. 
8464. 
8465. "But the best of it was," said one, telling of the misfortune of
8466. a fellow diplomat, "that the Chancellor told him flatly that his
8467. appointment to London was a promotion and that he was so to regard it.
8468. Can you fancy the figure he cut?..."
8469. 
8470. "But the worst of it, gentlemen--I am giving Kuragin away to you--is
8471. that that man suffers, and this Don Juan, wicked fellow, is taking
8472. advantage of it!"
8473. 
8474. Prince Hippolyte was lolling in a lounge chair with his legs over its
8475. arm. He began to laugh.
8476. 
8477. "Tell me about that!" he said.
8478. 
8479. "Oh, you Don Juan! You serpent!" cried several voices.
8480. 
8481. "You, Bolkonski, don't know," said Bilibin turning to Prince Andrew,
8482. "that all the atrocities of the French army (I nearly said of the
8483. Russian army) are nothing compared to what this man has been doing among
8484. the women!"
8485. 
8486. "La femme est la compagne de l'homme," * announced Prince Hippolyte, and
8487. began looking through a lorgnette at his elevated legs.
8488. 
8489. 
8490.     * "Woman is man's companion."
8491. 
8492. 
8493. Bilibin and the rest of "ours" burst out laughing in Hippolyte's face,
8494. and Prince Andrew saw that Hippolyte, of whom--he had to admit--he had
8495. almost been jealous on his wife's account, was the butt of this set.
8496. 
8497. "Oh, I must give you a treat," Bilibin whispered to Bolkonski. "Kuragin
8498. is exquisite when he discusses politics--you should see his gravity!"
8499. 
8500. He sat down beside Hippolyte and wrinkling his forehead began talking
8501. to him about politics. Prince Andrew and the others gathered round these
8502. two.
8503. 
8504. "The Berlin cabinet cannot express a feeling of alliance," began
8505. Hippolyte gazing round with importance at the others, "without
8506. expressing... as in its last note... you understand... Besides, unless
8507. His Majesty the Emperor derogates from the principle of our alliance...
8508. 
8509. "Wait, I have not finished..." he said to Prince Andrew, seizing him
8510. by the arm, "I believe that intervention will be stronger than
8511. nonintervention. And..." he paused. "Finally one cannot impute the
8512. nonreceipt of our dispatch of November 18. That is how it will end." And
8513. he released Bolkonski's arm to indicate that he had now quite finished.
8514. 
8515. "Demosthenes, I know thee by the pebble thou secretest in thy golden
8516. mouth!" said Bilibin, and the mop of hair on his head moved with
8517. satisfaction.
8518. 
8519. Everybody laughed, and Hippolyte louder than anyone. He was evidently
8520. distressed, and breathed painfully, but could not restrain the wild
8521. laughter that convulsed his usually impassive features.
8522. 
8523. "Well now, gentlemen," said Bilibin, "Bolkonski is my guest in this
8524. house and in Brunn itself. I want to entertain him as far as I can, with
8525. all the pleasures of life here. If we were in Vienna it would be easy,
8526. but here, in this wretched Moravian hole, it is more difficult, and I
8527. beg you all to help me. Brunn's attractions must be shown him. You can
8528. undertake the theater, I society, and you, Hippolyte, of course the
8529. women."
8530. 
8531. "We must let him see Amelie, she's exquisite!" said one of "ours,"
8532. kissing his finger tips.
8533. 
8534. "In general we must turn this bloodthirsty soldier to more humane
8535. interests," said Bilibin.
8536. 
8537. "I shall scarcely be able to avail myself of your hospitality,
8538. gentlemen, it is already time for me to go," replied Prince Andrew
8539. looking at his watch.
8540. 
8541. "Where to?"
8542. 
8543. "To the Emperor."
8544. 
8545. "Oh! Oh! Oh! Well, au revoir, Bolkonski! Au revoir, Prince! Come back
8546. early to dinner," cried several voices. "We'll take you in hand."
8547. 
8548. "When speaking to the Emperor, try as far as you can to praise the way
8549. that provisions are supplied and the routes indicated," said Bilibin,
8550. accompanying him to the hall.
8551. 
8552. "I should like to speak well of them, but as far as I know the facts, I
8553. can't," replied Bolkonski, smiling.
8554. 
8555. "Well, talk as much as you can, anyway. He has a passion for giving
8556. audiences, but he does not like talking himself and can't do it, as you
8557. will see."
8558. 
8559. 
8560. 
8561. 
8562. 
8563. CHAPTER XII
8564. 
8565. 
8566. At the levee Prince Andrew stood among the Austrian officers as he had
8567. been told to, and the Emperor Francis merely looked fixedly into his
8568. face and just nodded to him with his long head. But after it was
8569. over, the adjutant he had seen the previous day ceremoniously informed
8570. Bolkonski that the Emperor desired to give him an audience. The Emperor
8571. Francis received him standing in the middle of the room. Before the
8572. conversation began Prince Andrew was struck by the fact that the Emperor
8573. seemed confused and blushed as if not knowing what to say.
8574. 
8575. "Tell me, when did the battle begin?" he asked hurriedly.
8576. 
8577. Prince Andrew replied. Then followed other questions just as simple:
8578. "Was Kutuzov well? When had he left Krems?" and so on. The Emperor spoke
8579. as if his sole aim were to put a given number of questions--the answers
8580. to these questions, as was only too evident, did not interest him.
8581. 
8582. "At what o'clock did the battle begin?" asked the Emperor.
8583. 
8584. "I cannot inform Your Majesty at what o'clock the battle began at the
8585. front, but at Durrenstein, where I was, our attack began after five in
8586. the afternoon," replied Bolkonski growing more animated and expecting
8587. that he would have a chance to give a reliable account, which he had
8588. ready in his mind, of all he knew and had seen. But the Emperor smiled
8589. and interrupted him.
8590. 
8591. "How many miles?"
8592. 
8593. "From where to where, Your Majesty?"
8594. 
8595. "From Durrenstein to Krems."
8596. 
8597. "Three and a half miles, Your Majesty."
8598. 
8599. "The French have abandoned the left bank?"
8600. 
8601. "According to the scouts the last of them crossed on rafts during the
8602. night."
8603. 
8604. "Is there sufficient forage in Krems?"
8605. 
8606. "Forage has not been supplied to the extent..."
8607. 
8608. The Emperor interrupted him.
8609. 
8610. "At what o'clock was General Schmidt killed?"
8611. 
8612. "At seven o'clock, I believe."
8613. 
8614. "At seven o'clock? It's very sad, very sad!"
8615. 
8616. The Emperor thanked Prince Andrew and bowed. Prince Andrew withdrew and
8617. was immediately surrounded by courtiers on all sides. Everywhere he saw
8618. friendly looks and heard friendly words. Yesterday's adjutant reproached
8619. him for not having stayed at the palace, and offered him his own house.
8620. The Minister of War came up and congratulated him on the Maria Theresa
8621. Order of the third grade, which the Emperor was conferring on him. The
8622. Empress' chamberlain invited him to see Her Majesty. The archduchess
8623. also wished to see him. He did not know whom to answer, and for a few
8624. seconds collected his thoughts. Then the Russian ambassador took him by
8625. the shoulder, led him to the window, and began to talk to him.
8626. 
8627. Contrary to Bilibin's forecast the news he had brought was joyfully
8628. received. A thanksgiving service was arranged, Kutuzov was awarded
8629. the Grand Cross of Maria Theresa, and the whole army received rewards.
8630. Bolkonski was invited everywhere, and had to spend the whole morning
8631. calling on the principal Austrian dignitaries. Between four and five in
8632. the afternoon, having made all his calls, he was returning to Bilibin's
8633. house thinking out a letter to his father about the battle and his visit
8634. to Brunn. At the door he found a vehicle half full of luggage. Franz,
8635. Bilibin's man, was dragging a portmanteau with some difficulty out of
8636. the front door.
8637. 
8638. Before returning to Bilibin's Prince Andrew had gone to a bookshop to
8639. provide himself with some books for the campaign, and had spent some
8640. time in the shop.
8641. 
8642. "What is it?" he asked.
8643. 
8644. "Oh, your excellency!" said Franz, with difficulty rolling the
8645. portmanteau into the vehicle, "we are to move on still farther. The
8646. scoundrel is again at our heels!"
8647. 
8648. "Eh? What?" asked Prince Andrew.
8649. 
8650. Bilibin came out to meet him. His usually calm face showed excitement.
8651. 
8652. "There now! Confess that this is delightful," said he. "This affair of
8653. the Thabor Bridge, at Vienna.... They have crossed without striking a
8654. blow!"
8655. 
8656. Prince Andrew could not understand.
8657. 
8658. "But where do you come from not to know what every coachman in the town
8659. knows?"
8660. 
8661. "I come from the archduchess'. I heard nothing there."
8662. 
8663. "And you didn't see that everybody is packing up?"
8664. 
8665. "I did not... What is it all about?" inquired Prince Andrew impatiently.
8666. 
8667. "What's it all about? Why, the French have crossed the bridge that
8668. Auersperg was defending, and the bridge was not blown up: so Murat is
8669. now rushing along the road to Brunn and will be here in a day or two."
8670. 
8671. "What? Here? But why did they not blow up the bridge, if it was mined?"
8672. 
8673. "That is what I ask you. No one, not even Bonaparte, knows why."
8674. 
8675. Bolkonski shrugged his shoulders.
8676. 
8677. "But if the bridge is crossed it means that the army too is lost? It
8678. will be cut off," said he.
8679. 
8680. "That's just it," answered Bilibin. "Listen! The French entered
8681. Vienna as I told you. Very well. Next day, which was yesterday, those
8682. gentlemen, messieurs les marechaux, * Murat, Lannes, and Belliard,
8683. mount and ride to the bridge. (Observe that all three are Gascons.)
8684. 'Gentlemen,' says one of them, 'you know the Thabor Bridge is mined and
8685. doubly mined and that there are menacing fortifications at its head and
8686. an army of fifteen thousand men has been ordered to blow up the bridge
8687. and not let us cross? But it will please our sovereign the Emperor
8688. Napoleon if we take this bridge, so let us three go and take it!' 'Yes,
8689. let's!' say the others. And off they go and take the bridge, cross it,
8690. and now with their whole army are on this side of the Danube, marching
8691. on us, you, and your lines of communication."
8692. 
8693. 
8694.     * The marshalls.
8695. 
8696. 
8697. "Stop jesting," said Prince Andrew sadly and seriously. This news
8698. grieved him and yet he was pleased.
8699. 
8700. As soon as he learned that the Russian army was in such a hopeless
8701. situation it occurred to him that it was he who was destined to lead it
8702. out of this position; that here was the Toulon that would lift him from
8703. the ranks of obscure officers and offer him the first step to fame!
8704. Listening to Bilibin he was already imagining how on reaching the army
8705. he would give an opinion at the war council which would be the only one
8706. that could save the army, and how he alone would be entrusted with the
8707. executing of the plan.
8708. 
8709. "Stop this jesting," he said
8710. 
8711. "I am not jesting," Bilibin went on. "Nothing is truer or sadder. These
8712. gentlemen ride onto the bridge alone and wave white handkerchiefs; they
8713. assure the officer on duty that they, the marshals, are on their way to
8714. negotiate with Prince Auersperg. He lets them enter the tete-de-pont. *
8715. They spin him a thousand gasconades, saying that the war is over, that
8716. the Emperor Francis is arranging a meeting with Bonaparte, that they
8717. desire to see Prince Auersperg, and so on. The officer sends for
8718. Auersperg; these gentlemen embrace the officers, crack jokes, sit on the
8719. cannon, and meanwhile a French battalion gets to the bridge unobserved,
8720. flings the bags of incendiary material into the water, and approaches
8721. the tete-de-pont. At length appears the lieutenant general, our dear
8722. Prince Auersperg von Mautern himself. 'Dearest foe! Flower of the
8723. Austrian army, hero of the Turkish wars Hostilities are ended, we can
8724. shake one another's hand.... The Emperor Napoleon burns with impatience
8725. to make Prince Auersperg's acquaintance.' In a word, those gentlemen,
8726. Gascons indeed, so bewildered him with fine words, and he is so
8727. flattered by his rapidly established intimacy with the French marshals,
8728. and so dazzled by the sight of Murat's mantle and ostrich plumes,
8729. qu'il n'y voit que du feu, et oublie celui qu'il devait faire faire sur
8730. l'ennemi!" *(2) In spite of the animation of his speech, Bilibin did not
8731. forget to pause after this mot to give time for its due appreciation.
8732. "The French battalion rushes to the bridgehead, spikes the guns, and the
8733. bridge is taken! But what is best of all," he went on, his excitement
8734. subsiding under the delightful interest of his own story, "is that the
8735. sergeant in charge of the cannon which was to give the signal to fire
8736. the mines and blow up the bridge, this sergeant, seeing that the French
8737. troops were running onto the bridge, was about to fire, but Lannes
8738. stayed his hand. The sergeant, who was evidently wiser than his general,
8739. goes up to Auersperg and says: 'Prince, you are being deceived, here are
8740. the French!' Murat, seeing that all is lost if the sergeant is allowed
8741. to speak, turns to Auersperg with feigned astonishment (he is a
8742. true Gascon) and says: 'I don't recognize the world-famous Austrian
8743. discipline, if you allow a subordinate to address you like that!' It
8744. was a stroke of genius. Prince Auersperg feels his dignity at stake and
8745. orders the sergeant to be arrested. Come, you must own that this affair
8746. of the Thabor Bridge is delightful! It is not exactly stupidity, nor
8747. rascality...."
8748. 
8749. 
8750.      * Bridgehead.
8751. 
8752.      * (2) That their fire gets into his eyes and he forgets that
8753.      he ought to be firing at the enemy.
8754. 
8755. 
8756. "It may be treachery," said Prince Andrew, vividly imagining the gray
8757. overcoats, wounds, the smoke of gunpowder, the sounds of firing, and the
8758. glory that awaited him.
8759. 
8760. "Not that either. That puts the court in too bad a light," replied
8761. Bilibin. "It's not treachery nor rascality nor stupidity: it is just
8762. as at Ulm... it is..."--he seemed to be trying to find the right
8763. expression. "C'est... c'est du Mack. Nous sommes mackes (It is... it
8764. is a bit of Mack. We are Macked)," he concluded, feeling that he
8765. had produced a good epigram, a fresh one that would be repeated. His
8766. hitherto puckered brow became smooth as a sign of pleasure, and with a
8767. slight smile he began to examine his nails.
8768. 
8769. "Where are you off to?" he said suddenly to Prince Andrew who had risen
8770. and was going toward his room.
8771. 
8772. "I am going away."
8773. 
8774. "Where to?"
8775. 
8776. "To the army."
8777. 
8778. "But you meant to stay another two days?"
8779. 
8780. "But now I am off at once."
8781. 
8782. And Prince Andrew after giving directions about his departure went to
8783. his room.
8784. 
8785. "Do you know, mon cher," said Bilibin following him, "I have been
8786. thinking about you. Why are you going?"
8787. 
8788. And in proof of the conclusiveness of his opinion all the wrinkles
8789. vanished from his face.
8790. 
8791. Prince Andrew looked inquiringly at him and gave no reply.
8792. 
8793. "Why are you going? I know you think it your duty to gallop back to
8794. the army now that it is in danger. I understand that. Mon cher, it is
8795. heroism!"
8796. 
8797. "Not at all," said Prince Andrew.
8798. 
8799. "But as you are a philosopher, be a consistent one, look at the other
8800. side of the question and you will see that your duty, on the contrary,
8801. is to take care of yourself. Leave it to those who are no longer fit for
8802. anything else.... You have not been ordered to return and have not been
8803. dismissed from here; therefore, you can stay and go with us wherever our
8804. ill luck takes us. They say we are going to Olmutz, and Olmutz is a very
8805. decent town. You and I will travel comfortably in my caleche."
8806. 
8807. "Do stop joking, Bilibin," cried Bolkonski.
8808. 
8809. "I am speaking sincerely as a friend! Consider! Where and why are you
8810. going, when you might remain here? You are faced by one of two things,"
8811. and the skin over his left temple puckered, "either you will not reach
8812. your regiment before peace is concluded, or you will share defeat and
8813. disgrace with Kutuzov's whole army."
8814. 
8815. And Bilibin unwrinkled his temple, feeling that the dilemma was
8816. insoluble.
8817. 
8818. "I cannot argue about it," replied Prince Andrew coldly, but he thought:
8819. "I am going to save the army."
8820. 
8821. "My dear fellow, you are a hero!" said Bilibin.
8822. 
8823. 
8824. 
8825. 
8826. 
8827. CHAPTER XIII
8828. 
8829. 
8830. That same night, having taken leave of the Minister of War, Bolkonski
8831. set off to rejoin the army, not knowing where he would find it and
8832. fearing to be captured by the French on the way to Krems.
8833. 
8834. In Brunn everybody attached to the court was packing up, and the heavy
8835. baggage was already being dispatched to Olmutz. Near Hetzelsdorf Prince
8836. Andrew struck the high road along which the Russian army was moving with
8837. great haste and in the greatest disorder. The road was so obstructed
8838. with carts that it was impossible to get by in a carriage. Prince Andrew
8839. took a horse and a Cossack from a Cossack commander, and hungry and
8840. weary, making his way past the baggage wagons, rode in search of the
8841. commander in chief and of his own luggage. Very sinister reports of the
8842. position of the army reached him as he went along, and the appearance of
8843. the troops in their disorderly flight confirmed these rumors.
8844. 
8845. "Cette armee russe que l'or de l'Angleterre a transportee des extremites
8846. de l'univers, nous allons lui faire eprouver le meme sort--(le sort de
8847. l'armee d'Ulm)." * He remembered these words in Bonaparte's address
8848. to his army at the beginning of the campaign, and they awoke in him
8849. astonishment at the genius of his hero, a feeling of wounded pride,
8850. and a hope of glory. "And should there be nothing left but to die?" he
8851. thought. "Well, if need be, I shall do it no worse than others."
8852. 
8853. 
8854.      * "That Russian army which has been brought from the ends of
8855.      the earth by English gold, we shall cause to share the same
8856.      fate--(the fate of the army at Ulm)."
8857. 
8858. 
8859. He looked with disdain at the endless confused mass of detachments,
8860. carts, guns, artillery, and again baggage wagons and vehicles of all
8861. kinds overtaking one another and blocking the muddy road, three and
8862. sometimes four abreast. From all sides, behind and before, as far as ear
8863. could reach, there were the rattle of wheels, the creaking of carts
8864. and gun carriages, the tramp of horses, the crack of whips, shouts, the
8865. urging of horses, and the swearing of soldiers, orderlies, and officers.
8866. All along the sides of the road fallen horses were to be seen, some
8867. flayed, some not, and broken-down carts beside which solitary soldiers
8868. sat waiting for something, and again soldiers straggling from their
8869. companies, crowds of whom set off to the neighboring villages, or
8870. returned from them dragging sheep, fowls, hay, and bulging sacks. At
8871. each ascent or descent of the road the crowds were yet denser and the
8872. din of shouting more incessant. Soldiers floundering knee-deep in mud
8873. pushed the guns and wagons themselves. Whips cracked, hoofs slipped,
8874. traces broke, and lungs were strained with shouting. The officers
8875. directing the march rode backward and forward between the carts. Their
8876. voices were but feebly heard amid the uproar and one saw by their faces
8877. that they despaired of the possibility of checking this disorder.
8878. 
8879. "Here is our dear Orthodox Russian army," thought Bolkonski, recalling
8880. Bilibin's words.
8881. 
8882. Wishing to find out where the commander in chief was, he rode up to
8883. a convoy. Directly opposite to him came a strange one-horse vehicle,
8884. evidently rigged up by soldiers out of any available materials and
8885. looking like something between a cart, a cabriolet, and a caleche. A
8886. soldier was driving, and a woman enveloped in shawls sat behind the
8887. apron under the leather hood of the vehicle. Prince Andrew rode up
8888. and was just putting his question to a soldier when his attention
8889. was diverted by the desperate shrieks of the woman in the vehicle. An
8890. officer in charge of transport was beating the soldier who was driving
8891. the woman's vehicle for trying to get ahead of others, and the strokes
8892. of his whip fell on the apron of the equipage. The woman screamed
8893. piercingly. Seeing Prince Andrew she leaned out from behind the apron
8894. and, waving her thin arms from under the woolen shawl, cried:
8895. 
8896. "Mr. Aide-de-camp! Mr. Aide-de-camp!... For heaven's sake... Protect
8897. me! What will become of us? I am the wife of the doctor of the Seventh
8898. Chasseurs.... They won't let us pass, we are left behind and have lost
8899. our people..."
8900. 
8901. "I'll flatten you into a pancake!" shouted the angry officer to the
8902. soldier. "Turn back with your slut!"
8903. 
8904. "Mr. Aide-de-camp! Help me!... What does it all mean?" screamed the
8905. doctor's wife.
8906. 
8907. "Kindly let this cart pass. Don't you see it's a woman?" said Prince
8908. Andrew riding up to the officer.
8909. 
8910. The officer glanced at him, and without replying turned again to the
8911. soldier. "I'll teach you to push on!... Back!"
8912. 
8913. "Let them pass, I tell you!" repeated Prince Andrew, compressing his
8914. lips.
8915. 
8916. "And who are you?" cried the officer, turning on him with tipsy rage,
8917. "who are you? Are you in command here? Eh? I am commander here, not
8918. you! Go back or I'll flatten you into a pancake," repeated he. This
8919. expression evidently pleased him.
8920. 
8921. "That was a nice snub for the little aide-de-camp," came a voice from
8922. behind.
8923. 
8924. Prince Andrew saw that the officer was in that state of senseless,
8925. tipsy rage when a man does not know what he is saying. He saw that his
8926. championship of the doctor's wife in her queer trap might expose him to
8927. what he dreaded more than anything in the world--to ridicule; but his
8928. instinct urged him on. Before the officer finished his sentence Prince
8929. Andrew, his face distorted with fury, rode up to him and raised his
8930. riding whip.
8931. 
8932. "Kind...ly let--them--pass!"
8933. 
8934. The officer flourished his arm and hastily rode away.
8935. 
8936. "It's all the fault of these fellows on the staff that there's this
8937. disorder," he muttered. "Do as you like."
8938. 
8939. Prince Andrew without lifting his eyes rode hastily away from the
8940. doctor's wife, who was calling him her deliverer, and recalling with
8941. a sense of disgust the minutest details of this humiliating scene he
8942. galloped on to the village where he was told that the commander in chief
8943. was.
8944. 
8945. On reaching the village he dismounted and went to the nearest house,
8946. intending to rest if but for a moment, eat something, and try to sort
8947. out the stinging and tormenting thoughts that confused his mind. "This
8948. is a mob of scoundrels and not an army," he was thinking as he went up
8949. to the window of the first house, when a familiar voice called him by
8950. name.
8951. 
8952. He turned round. Nesvitski's handsome face looked out of the little
8953. window. Nesvitski, moving his moist lips as he chewed something, and
8954. flourishing his arm, called him to enter.
8955. 
8956. "Bolkonski! Bolkonski!... Don't you hear? Eh? Come quick..." he shouted.
8957. 
8958. Entering the house, Prince Andrew saw Nesvitski and another adjutant
8959. having something to eat. They hastily turned round to him asking if he
8960. had any news. On their familiar faces he read agitation and alarm. This
8961. was particularly noticeable on Nesvitski's usually laughing countenance.
8962. 
8963. "Where is the commander in chief?" asked Bolkonski.
8964. 
8965. "Here, in that house," answered the adjutant.
8966. 
8967. "Well, is it true that it's peace and capitulation?" asked Nesvitski.
8968. 
8969. "I was going to ask you. I know nothing except that it was all I could
8970. do to get here."
8971. 
8972. "And we, my dear boy! It's terrible! I was wrong to laugh at Mack,
8973. we're getting it still worse," said Nesvitski. "But sit down and have
8974. something to eat."
8975. 
8976. "You won't be able to find either your baggage or anything else now,
8977. Prince. And God only knows where your man Peter is," said the other
8978. adjutant.
8979. 
8980. "Where are headquarters?"
8981. 
8982. "We are to spend the night in Znaim."
8983. 
8984. "Well, I have got all I need into packs for two horses," said Nesvitski.
8985. "They've made up splendid packs for me--fit to cross the Bohemian
8986. mountains with. It's a bad lookout, old fellow! But what's the matter
8987. with you? You must be ill to shiver like that," he added, noticing that
8988. Prince Andrew winced as at an electric shock.
8989. 
8990. "It's nothing," replied Prince Andrew.
8991. 
8992. He had just remembered his recent encounter with the doctor's wife and
8993. the convoy officer.
8994. 
8995. "What is the commander in chief doing here?" he asked.
8996. 
8997. "I can't make out at all," said Nesvitski.
8998. 
8999. "Well, all I can make out is that everything is abominable, abominable,
9000. quite abominable!" said Prince Andrew, and he went off to the house
9001. where the commander in chief was.
9002. 
9003. Passing by Kutuzov's carriage and the exhausted saddle horses of his
9004. suite, with their Cossacks who were talking loudly together, Prince
9005. Andrew entered the passage. Kutuzov himself, he was told, was in the
9006. house with Prince Bagration and Weyrother. Weyrother was the Austrian
9007. general who had succeeded Schmidt. In the passage little Kozlovski was
9008. squatting on his heels in front of a clerk. The clerk, with cuffs turned
9009. up, was hastily writing at a tub turned bottom upwards. Kozlovski's face
9010. looked worn--he too had evidently not slept all night. He glanced at
9011. Prince Andrew and did not even nod to him.
9012. 
9013. "Second line... have you written it?" he continued dictating to the
9014. clerk. "The Kiev Grenadiers, Podolian..."
9015. 
9016. "One can't write so fast, your honor," said the clerk, glancing angrily
9017. and disrespectfully at Kozlovski.
9018. 
9019. Through the door came the sounds of Kutuzov's voice, excited and
9020. dissatisfied, interrupted by another, an unfamiliar voice. From the
9021. sound of these voices, the inattentive way Kozlovski looked at him, the
9022. disrespectful manner of the exhausted clerk, the fact that the clerk and
9023. Kozlovski were squatting on the floor by a tub so near to the commander
9024. in chief, and from the noisy laughter of the Cossacks holding the
9025. horses near the window, Prince Andrew felt that something important and
9026. disastrous was about to happen.
9027. 
9028. He turned to Kozlovski with urgent questions.
9029. 
9030. "Immediately, Prince," said Kozlovski. "Dispositions for Bagration."
9031. 
9032. "What about capitulation?"
9033. 
9034. "Nothing of the sort. Orders are issued for a battle."
9035. 
9036. Prince Andrew moved toward the door from whence voices were heard.
9037. Just as he was going to open it the sounds ceased, the door opened,
9038. and Kutuzov with his eagle nose and puffy face appeared in the doorway.
9039. Prince Andrew stood right in front of Kutuzov but the expression of the
9040. commander in chief's one sound eye showed him to be so preoccupied with
9041. thoughts and anxieties as to be oblivious of his presence. He looked
9042. straight at his adjutant's face without recognizing him.
9043. 
9044. "Well, have you finished?" said he to Kozlovski.
9045. 
9046. "One moment, your excellency."
9047. 
9048. Bagration, a gaunt middle-aged man of medium height with a firm,
9049. impassive face of Oriental type, came out after the commander in chief.
9050. 
9051. "I have the honor to present myself," repeated Prince Andrew rather
9052. loudly, handing Kutuzov an envelope.
9053. 
9054. "Ah, from Vienna? Very good. Later, later!"
9055. 
9056. Kutuzov went out into the porch with Bagration.
9057. 
9058. "Well, good-by, Prince," said he to Bagration. "My blessing, and may
9059. Christ be with you in your great endeavor!"
9060. 
9061. His face suddenly softened and tears came into his eyes. With his left
9062. hand he drew Bagration toward him, and with his right, on which he wore
9063. a ring, he made the sign of the cross over him with a gesture evidently
9064. habitual, offering his puffy cheek, but Bagration kissed him on the neck
9065. instead.
9066. 
9067. "Christ be with you!" Kutuzov repeated and went toward his carriage.
9068. "Get in with me," said he to Bolkonski.
9069. 
9070. "Your excellency, I should like to be of use here. Allow me to remain
9071. with Prince Bagration's detachment."
9072. 
9073. "Get in," said Kutuzov, and noticing that Bolkonski still delayed, he
9074. added: "I need good officers myself, need them myself!"
9075. 
9076. They got into the carriage and drove for a few minutes in silence.
9077. 
9078. "There is still much, much before us," he said, as if with an old man's
9079. penetration he understood all that was passing in Bolkonski's mind. "If
9080. a tenth part of his detachment returns I shall thank God," he added as
9081. if speaking to himself.
9082. 
9083. Prince Andrew glanced at Kutuzov's face only a foot distant from him and
9084. involuntarily noticed the carefully washed seams of the scar near his
9085. temple, where an Ismail bullet had pierced his skull, and the empty eye
9086. socket. "Yes, he has a right to speak so calmly of those men's death,"
9087. thought Bolkonski.
9088. 
9089. "That is why I beg to be sent to that detachment," he said.
9090. 
9091. Kutuzov did not reply. He seemed to have forgotten what he had been
9092. saying, and sat plunged in thought. Five minutes later, gently swaying
9093. on the soft springs of the carriage, he turned to Prince Andrew.
9094. There was not a trace of agitation on his face. With delicate irony he
9095. questioned Prince Andrew about the details of his interview with the
9096. Emperor, about the remarks he had heard at court concerning the Krems
9097. affair, and about some ladies they both knew.
9098. 
9099. 
9100. 
9101. 
9102. 
9103. CHAPTER XIV
9104. 
9105. 
9106. On November 1 Kutuzov had received, through a spy, news that the army he
9107. commanded was in an almost hopeless position. The spy reported that the
9108. French, after crossing the bridge at Vienna, were advancing in immense
9109. force upon Kutuzov's line of communication with the troops that were
9110. arriving from Russia. If Kutuzov decided to remain at Krems, Napoleon's
9111. army of one hundred and fifty thousand men would cut him off completely
9112. and surround his exhausted army of forty thousand, and he would find
9113. himself in the position of Mack at Ulm. If Kutuzov decided to abandon
9114. the road connecting him with the troops arriving from Russia, he would
9115. have to march with no road into unknown parts of the Bohemian mountains,
9116. defending himself against superior forces of the enemy and abandoning
9117. all hope of a junction with Buxhowden. If Kutuzov decided to retreat
9118. along the road from Krems to Olmutz, to unite with the troops arriving
9119. from Russia, he risked being forestalled on that road by the French
9120. who had crossed the Vienna bridge, and encumbered by his baggage and
9121. transport, having to accept battle on the march against an enemy three
9122. times as strong, who would hem him in from two sides.
9123. 
9124. Kutuzov chose this latter course.
9125. 
9126. The French, the spy reported, having crossed the Vienna bridge, were
9127. advancing by forced marches toward Znaim, which lay sixty-six miles off
9128. on the line of Kutuzov's retreat. If he reached Znaim before the
9129. French, there would be great hope of saving the army; to let the
9130. French forestall him at Znaim meant the exposure of his whole army to a
9131. disgrace such as that of Ulm, or to utter destruction. But to forestall
9132. the French with his whole army was impossible. The road for the French
9133. from Vienna to Znaim was shorter and better than the road for the
9134. Russians from Krems to Znaim.
9135. 
9136. The night he received the news, Kutuzov sent Bagration's vanguard, four
9137. thousand strong, to the right across the hills from the Krems-Znaim to
9138. the Vienna-Znaim road. Bagration was to make this march without resting,
9139. and to halt facing Vienna with Znaim to his rear, and if he succeeded
9140. in forestalling the French he was to delay them as long as possible.
9141. Kutuzov himself with all his transport took the road to Znaim.
9142. 
9143. Marching thirty miles that stormy night across roadless hills, with his
9144. hungry, ill-shod soldiers, and losing a third of his men as stragglers
9145. by the way, Bagration came out on the Vienna-Znaim road at Hollabrunn
9146. a few hours ahead of the French who were approaching Hollabrunn from
9147. Vienna. Kutuzov with his transport had still to march for some days
9148. before he could reach Znaim. Hence Bagration with his four thousand
9149. hungry, exhausted men would have to detain for days the whole enemy army
9150. that came upon him at Hollabrunn, which was clearly impossible. But a
9151. freak of fate made the impossible possible. The success of the trick
9152. that had placed the Vienna bridge in the hands of the French without
9153. a fight led Murat to try to deceive Kutuzov in a similar way. Meeting
9154. Bagration's weak detachment on the Znaim road he supposed it to be
9155. Kutuzov's whole army. To be able to crush it absolutely he awaited the
9156. arrival of the rest of the troops who were on their way from Vienna,
9157. and with this object offered a three days' truce on condition that both
9158. armies should remain in position without moving. Murat declared that
9159. negotiations for peace were already proceeding, and that he therefore
9160. offered this truce to avoid unnecessary bloodshed. Count Nostitz, the
9161. Austrian general occupying the advanced posts, believed Murat's emissary
9162. and retired, leaving Bagration's division exposed. Another emissary rode
9163. to the Russian line to announce the peace negotiations and to offer the
9164. Russian army the three days' truce. Bagration replied that he was not
9165. authorized either to accept or refuse a truce and sent his adjutant to
9166. Kutuzov to report the offer he had received.
9167. 
9168. A truce was Kutuzov's sole chance of gaining time, giving Bagration's
9169. exhausted troops some rest, and letting the transport and heavy convoys
9170. (whose movements were concealed from the French) advance if but one
9171. stage nearer Znaim. The offer of a truce gave the only, and a quite
9172. unexpected, chance of saving the army. On receiving the news he
9173. immediately dispatched Adjutant General Wintzingerode, who was in
9174. attendance on him, to the enemy camp. Wintzingerode was not merely
9175. to agree to the truce but also to offer terms of capitulation, and
9176. meanwhile Kutuzov sent his adjutants back to hasten to the utmost the
9177. movements of the baggage trains of the entire army along the Krems-Znaim
9178. road. Bagration's exhausted and hungry detachment, which alone covered
9179. this movement of the transport and of the whole army, had to remain
9180. stationary in face of an enemy eight times as strong as itself.
9181. 
9182. Kutuzov's expectations that the proposals of capitulation (which were in
9183. no way binding) might give time for part of the transport to pass, and
9184. also that Murat's mistake would very soon be discovered, proved
9185. correct. As soon as Bonaparte (who was at Schonbrunn, sixteen miles from
9186. Hollabrunn) received Murat's dispatch with the proposal of a truce and
9187. a capitulation, he detected a ruse and wrote the following letter to
9188. Murat:
9189. 
9190. 
9191. Schonbrunn, 25th Brumaire, 1805,
9192. 
9193. at eight o'clock in the morning
9194. 
9195. To PRINCE MURAT,
9196. 
9197. I cannot find words to express to you my displeasure. You command only
9198. my advance guard, and have no right to arrange an armistice without my
9199. order. You are causing me to lose the fruits of a campaign. Break
9200. the armistice immediately and march on the enemy. Inform him that the
9201. general who signed that capitulation had no right to do so, and that no
9202. one but the Emperor of Russia has that right.
9203. 
9204. If, however, the Emperor of Russia ratifies that convention, I will
9205. ratify it; but it is only a trick. March on, destroy the Russian
9206. army.... You are in a position to seize its baggage and artillery.
9207. 
9208. The Russian Emperor's aide-de-camp is an impostor. Officers are nothing
9209. when they have no powers; this one had none.... The Austrians let
9210. themselves be tricked at the crossing of the Vienna bridge, you are
9211. letting yourself be tricked by an aide-de-camp of the Emperor.
9212. 
9213. NAPOLEON
9214. 
9215. 
9216. Bonaparte's adjutant rode full gallop with this menacing letter to
9217. Murat. Bonaparte himself, not trusting to his generals, moved with all
9218. the Guards to the field of battle, afraid of letting a ready victim
9219. escape, and Bagration's four thousand men merrily lighted campfires,
9220. dried and warmed themselves, cooked their porridge for the first time
9221. for three days, and not one of them knew or imagined what was in store
9222. for him.
9223. 
9224. 
9225. 
9226. 
9227. 
9228. CHAPTER XV
9229. 
9230. 
9231. Between three and four o'clock in the afternoon Prince Andrew, who had
9232. persisted in his request to Kutuzov, arrived at Grunth and reported
9233. himself to Bagration. Bonaparte's adjutant had not yet reached Murat's
9234. detachment and the battle had not yet begun. In Bagration's detachment
9235. no one knew anything of the general position of affairs. They talked of
9236. peace but did not believe in its possibility; others talked of a battle
9237. but also disbelieved in the nearness of an engagement. Bagration,
9238. knowing Bolkonski to be a favorite and trusted adjutant, received him
9239. with distinction and special marks of favor, explaining to him that
9240. there would probably be an engagement that day or the next, and giving
9241. him full liberty to remain with him during the battle or to join the
9242. rearguard and have an eye on the order of retreat, "which is also very
9243. important."
9244. 
9245. "However, there will hardly be an engagement today," said Bagration as
9246. if to reassure Prince Andrew.
9247. 
9248. "If he is one of the ordinary little staff dandies sent to earn a medal
9249. he can get his reward just as well in the rearguard, but if he wishes to
9250. stay with me, let him... he'll be of use here if he's a brave officer,"
9251. thought Bagration. Prince Andrew, without replying, asked the prince's
9252. permission to ride round the position to see the disposition of the
9253. forces, so as to know his bearings should he be sent to execute an
9254. order. The officer on duty, a handsome, elegantly dressed man with a
9255. diamond ring on his forefinger, who was fond of speaking French though
9256. he spoke it badly, offered to conduct Prince Andrew.
9257. 
9258. On all sides they saw rain-soaked officers with dejected faces who
9259. seemed to be seeking something, and soldiers dragging doors, benches,
9260. and fencing from the village.
9261. 
9262. "There now, Prince! We can't stop those fellows," said the staff officer
9263. pointing to the soldiers. "The officers don't keep them in hand. And
9264. there," he pointed to a sutler's tent, "they crowd in and sit. This
9265. morning I turned them all out and now look, it's full again. I must go
9266. there, Prince, and scare them a bit. It won't take a moment."
9267. 
9268. "Yes, let's go in and I will get myself a roll and some cheese," said
9269. Prince Andrew who had not yet had time to eat anything.
9270. 
9271. "Why didn't you mention it, Prince? I would have offered you something."
9272. 
9273. They dismounted and entered the tent. Several officers, with flushed and
9274. weary faces, were sitting at the table eating and drinking.
9275. 
9276. "Now what does this mean, gentlemen?" said the staff officer, in the
9277. reproachful tone of a man who has repeated the same thing more than
9278. once. "You know it won't do to leave your posts like this. The prince
9279. gave orders that no one should leave his post. Now you, Captain," and he
9280. turned to a thin, dirty little artillery officer who without his boots
9281. (he had given them to the canteen keeper to dry), in only his stockings,
9282. rose when they entered, smiling not altogether comfortably.
9283. 
9284. "Well, aren't you ashamed of yourself, Captain Tushin?" he continued.
9285. "One would think that as an artillery officer you would set a good
9286. example, yet here you are without your boots! The alarm will be sounded
9287. and you'll be in a pretty position without your boots!" (The staff
9288. officer smiled.) "Kindly return to your posts, gentlemen, all of you,
9289. all!" he added in a tone of command.
9290. 
9291. Prince Andrew smiled involuntarily as he looked at the artillery officer
9292. Tushin, who silent and smiling, shifting from one stockinged foot to the
9293. other, glanced inquiringly with his large, intelligent, kindly eyes from
9294. Prince Andrew to the staff officer.
9295. 
9296. "The soldiers say it feels easier without boots," said Captain Tushin
9297. smiling shyly in his uncomfortable position, evidently wishing to adopt
9298. a jocular tone. But before he had finished he felt that his jest was
9299. unacceptable and had not come off. He grew confused.
9300. 
9301. "Kindly return to your posts," said the staff officer trying to preserve
9302. his gravity.
9303. 
9304. Prince Andrew glanced again at the artillery officer's small figure.
9305. There was something peculiar about it, quite unsoldierly, rather comic,
9306. but extremely attractive.
9307. 
9308. The staff officer and Prince Andrew mounted their horses and rode on.
9309. 
9310. Having ridden beyond the village, continually meeting and overtaking
9311. soldiers and officers of various regiments, they saw on their left some
9312. entrenchments being thrown up, the freshly dug clay of which showed up
9313. red. Several battalions of soldiers, in their shirt sleeves despite
9314. the cold wind, swarmed in these earthworks like a host of white ants;
9315. spadefuls of red clay were continually being thrown up from behind the
9316. bank by unseen hands. Prince Andrew and the officer rode up, looked at
9317. the entrenchment, and went on again. Just behind it they came upon some
9318. dozens of soldiers, continually replaced by others, who ran from the
9319. entrenchment. They had to hold their noses and put their horses to a
9320. trot to escape from the poisoned atmosphere of these latrines.
9321. 
9322. "Voila l'agrement des camps, monsieur le Prince," * said the staff
9323. officer.
9324. 
9325. 
9326.     * "This is a pleasure one gets in camp, Prince."
9327. 
9328. 
9329. They rode up the opposite hill. From there the French could already be
9330. seen. Prince Andrew stopped and began examining the position.
9331. 
9332. "That's our battery," said the staff officer indicating the highest
9333. point. "It's in charge of the queer fellow we saw without his boots. You
9334. can see everything from there; let's go there, Prince."
9335. 
9336. "Thank you very much, I will go on alone," said Prince Andrew, wishing
9337. to rid himself of this staff officer's company, "please don't trouble
9338. yourself further."
9339. 
9340. The staff officer remained behind and Prince Andrew rode on alone.
9341. 
9342. The farther forward and nearer the enemy he went, the more orderly and
9343. cheerful were the troops. The greatest disorder and depression had been
9344. in the baggage train he had passed that morning on the Znaim road seven
9345. miles away from the French. At Grunth also some apprehension and alarm
9346. could be felt, but the nearer Prince Andrew came to the French lines the
9347. more confident was the appearance of our troops. The soldiers in
9348. their greatcoats were ranged in lines, the sergeants major and company
9349. officers were counting the men, poking the last man in each section in
9350. the ribs and telling him to hold his hand up. Soldiers scattered over
9351. the whole place were dragging logs and brushwood and were building
9352. shelters with merry chatter and laughter; around the fires sat others,
9353. dressed and undressed, drying their shirts and leg bands or mending
9354. boots or overcoats and crowding round the boilers and porridge cookers.
9355. In one company dinner was ready, and the soldiers were gazing eagerly
9356. at the steaming boiler, waiting till the sample, which a quartermaster
9357. sergeant was carrying in a wooden bowl to an officer who sat on a log
9358. before his shelter, had been tasted.
9359. 
9360. Another company, a lucky one for not all the companies had vodka,
9361. crowded round a pockmarked, broad-shouldered sergeant major who, tilting
9362. a keg, filled one after another the canteen lids held out to him. The
9363. soldiers lifted the canteen lids to their lips with reverential faces,
9364. emptied them, rolling the vodka in their mouths, and walked away from
9365. the sergeant major with brightened expressions, licking their lips and
9366. wiping them on the sleeves of their greatcoats. All their faces were
9367. as serene as if all this were happening at home awaiting peaceful
9368. encampment, and not within sight of the enemy before an action in
9369. which at least half of them would be left on the field. After passing a
9370. chasseur regiment and in the lines of the Kiev grenadiers--fine fellows
9371. busy with similar peaceful affairs--near the shelter of the regimental
9372. commander, higher than and different from the others, Prince Andrew came
9373. out in front of a platoon of grenadiers before whom lay a naked man. Two
9374. soldiers held him while two others were flourishing their switches and
9375. striking him regularly on his bare back. The man shrieked unnaturally.
9376. A stout major was pacing up and down the line, and regardless of the
9377. screams kept repeating:
9378. 
9379. "It's a shame for a soldier to steal; a soldier must be honest,
9380. honorable, and brave, but if he robs his fellows there is no honor in
9381. him, he's a scoundrel. Go on! Go on!"
9382. 
9383. So the swishing sound of the strokes, and the desperate but unnatural
9384. screams, continued.
9385. 
9386. "Go on, go on!" said the major.
9387. 
9388. A young officer with a bewildered and pained expression on his face
9389. stepped away from the man and looked round inquiringly at the adjutant
9390. as he rode by.
9391. 
9392. Prince Andrew, having reached the front line, rode along it. Our front
9393. line and that of the enemy were far apart on the right and left flanks,
9394. but in the center where the men with a flag of truce had passed that
9395. morning, the lines were so near together that the men could see one
9396. another's faces and speak to one another. Besides the soldiers who
9397. formed the picket line on either side, there were many curious onlookers
9398. who, jesting and laughing, stared at their strange foreign enemies.
9399. 
9400. Since early morning--despite an injunction not to approach the picket
9401. line--the officers had been unable to keep sight-seers away. The
9402. soldiers forming the picket line, like showmen exhibiting a curiosity,
9403. no longer looked at the French but paid attention to the sight-seers and
9404. grew weary waiting to be relieved. Prince Andrew halted to have a look
9405. at the French.
9406. 
9407. "Look! Look there!" one soldier was saying to another, pointing to a
9408. Russian musketeer who had gone up to the picket line with an officer and
9409. was rapidly and excitedly talking to a French grenadier. "Hark to him
9410. jabbering! Fine, isn't it? It's all the Frenchy can do to keep up with
9411. him. There now, Sidorov!"
9412. 
9413. "Wait a bit and listen. It's fine!" answered Sidorov, who was considered
9414. an adept at French.
9415. 
9416. The soldier to whom the laughers referred was Dolokhov. Prince Andrew
9417. recognized him and stopped to listen to what he was saying. Dolokhov had
9418. come from the left flank where their regiment was stationed, with his
9419. captain.
9420. 
9421. "Now then, go on, go on!" incited the officer, bending forward and
9422. trying not to lose a word of the speech which was incomprehensible to
9423. him. "More, please: more! What's he saying?"
9424. 
9425. Dolokhov did not answer the captain; he had been drawn into a hot
9426. dispute with the French grenadier. They were naturally talking about the
9427. campaign. The Frenchman, confusing the Austrians with the Russians, was
9428. trying to prove that the Russians had surrendered and had fled all
9429. the way from Ulm, while Dolokhov maintained that the Russians had not
9430. surrendered but had beaten the French.
9431. 
9432. "We have orders to drive you off here, and we shall drive you off," said
9433. Dolokhov.
9434. 
9435. "Only take care you and your Cossacks are not all captured!" said the
9436. French grenadier.
9437. 
9438. The French onlookers and listeners laughed.
9439. 
9440. "We'll make you dance as we did under Suvorov...," * said Dolokhov.
9441. 
9442. 
9443.     * "On vous fera danser."
9444. 
9445. 
9446. "Qu' est-ce qu'il chante?" * asked a Frenchman.
9447. 
9448. 
9449.     * "What's he singing about?"
9450. 
9451. 
9452. "It's ancient history," said another, guessing that it referred to a
9453. former war. "The Emperor will teach your Suvara as he has taught the
9454. others..."
9455. 
9456. "Bonaparte..." began Dolokhov, but the Frenchman interrupted him.
9457. 
9458. "Not Bonaparte. He is the Emperor! Sacre nom...!" cried he angrily.
9459. 
9460. "The devil skin your Emperor."
9461. 
9462. And Dolokhov swore at him in coarse soldier's Russian and shouldering
9463. his musket walked away.
9464. 
9465. "Let us go, Ivan Lukich," he said to the captain.
9466. 
9467. "Ah, that's the way to talk French," said the picket soldiers. "Now,
9468. Sidorov, you have a try!"
9469. 
9470. Sidorov, turning to the French, winked, and began to jabber meaningless
9471. sounds very fast: "Kari, mala, tafa, safi, muter, Kaska," he said,
9472. trying to give an expressive intonation to his voice.
9473. 
9474. "Ho! ho! ho! Ha! ha! ha! ha! Ouh! ouh!" came peals of such healthy and
9475. good-humored laughter from the soldiers that it infected the French
9476. involuntarily, so much so that the only thing left to do seemed to be
9477. to unload the muskets, explode the ammunition, and all return home as
9478. quickly as possible.
9479. 
9480. But the guns remained loaded, the loopholes in blockhouses and
9481. entrenchments looked out just as menacingly, and the unlimbered cannon
9482. confronted one another as before.
9483. 
9484. 
9485. 
9486. 
9487. 
9488. CHAPTER XVI
9489. 
9490. 
9491. Having ridden round the whole line from right flank to left, Prince
9492. Andrew made his way up to the battery from which the staff officer had
9493. told him the whole field could be seen. Here he dismounted, and stopped
9494. beside the farthest of the four unlimbered cannon. Before the guns an
9495. artillery sentry was pacing up and down; he stood at attention when the
9496. officer arrived, but at a sign resumed his measured, monotonous pacing.
9497. Behind the guns were their limbers and still farther back picket ropes
9498. and artillerymen's bonfires. To the left, not far from the farthest
9499. cannon, was a small, newly constructed wattle shed from which came the
9500. sound of officers' voices in eager conversation.
9501. 
9502. It was true that a view over nearly the whole Russian position and the
9503. greater part of the enemy's opened out from this battery. Just facing
9504. it, on the crest of the opposite hill, the village of Schon Grabern
9505. could be seen, and in three places to left and right the French troops
9506. amid the smoke of their campfires, the greater part of whom were
9507. evidently in the village itself and behind the hill. To the left from
9508. that village, amid the smoke, was something resembling a battery, but it
9509. was impossible to see it clearly with the naked eye. Our right flank was
9510. posted on a rather steep incline which dominated the French position.
9511. Our infantry were stationed there, and at the farthest point the
9512. dragoons. In the center, where Tushin's battery stood and from which
9513. Prince Andrew was surveying the position, was the easiest and most
9514. direct descent and ascent to the brook separating us from Schon Grabern.
9515. On the left our troops were close to a copse, in which smoked the
9516. bonfires of our infantry who were felling wood. The French line was
9517. wider than ours, and it was plain that they could easily outflank us
9518. on both sides. Behind our position was a steep and deep dip, making it
9519. difficult for artillery and cavalry to retire. Prince Andrew took
9520. out his notebook and, leaning on the cannon, sketched a plan of the
9521. position. He made some notes on two points, intending to mention them to
9522. Bagration. His idea was, first, to concentrate all the artillery in the
9523. center, and secondly, to withdraw the cavalry to the other side of the
9524. dip. Prince Andrew, being always near the commander in chief, closely
9525. following the mass movements and general orders, and constantly studying
9526. historical accounts of battles, involuntarily pictured to himself the
9527. course of events in the forthcoming action in broad outline. He imagined
9528. only important possibilities: "If the enemy attacks the right flank,"
9529. he said to himself, "the Kiev grenadiers and the Podolsk chasseurs must
9530. hold their position till reserves from the center come up. In that case
9531. the dragoons could successfully make a flank counterattack. If they
9532. attack our center we, having the center battery on this high ground,
9533. shall withdraw the left flank under its cover, and retreat to the dip by
9534. echelons." So he reasoned.... All the time he had been beside the gun,
9535. he had heard the voices of the officers distinctly, but as often happens
9536. had not understood a word of what they were saying. Suddenly, however,
9537. he was struck by a voice coming from the shed, and its tone was so
9538. sincere that he could not but listen.
9539. 
9540. "No, friend," said a pleasant and, as it seemed to Prince Andrew, a
9541. familiar voice, "what I say is that if it were possible to know what is
9542. beyond death, none of us would be afraid of it. That's so, friend."
9543. 
9544. Another, a younger voice, interrupted him: "Afraid or not, you can't
9545. escape it anyhow."
9546. 
9547. "All the same, one is afraid! Oh, you clever people," said a third manly
9548. voice interrupting them both. "Of course you artillery men are very
9549. wise, because you can take everything along with you--vodka and snacks."
9550. 
9551. And the owner of the manly voice, evidently an infantry officer,
9552. laughed.
9553. 
9554. "Yes, one is afraid," continued the first speaker, he of the familiar
9555. voice. "One is afraid of the unknown, that's what it is. Whatever we may
9556. say about the soul going to the sky... we know there is no sky but only
9557. an atmosphere."
9558. 
9559. The manly voice again interrupted the artillery officer.
9560. 
9561. "Well, stand us some of your herb vodka, Tushin," it said.
9562. 
9563. "Why," thought Prince Andrew, "that's the captain who stood up in
9564. the sutler's hut without his boots." He recognized the agreeable,
9565. philosophizing voice with pleasure.
9566. 
9567. "Some herb vodka? Certainly!" said Tushin. "But still, to conceive a
9568. future life..."
9569. 
9570. He did not finish. Just then there was a whistle in the air; nearer and
9571. nearer, faster and louder, louder and faster, a cannon ball, as if it
9572. had not finished saying what was necessary, thudded into the ground near
9573. the shed with super human force, throwing up a mass of earth. The ground
9574. seemed to groan at the terrible impact.
9575. 
9576. And immediately Tushin, with a short pipe in the corner of his mouth and
9577. his kind, intelligent face rather pale, rushed out of the shed followed
9578. by the owner of the manly voice, a dashing infantry officer who hurried
9579. off to his company, buttoning up his coat as he ran.
9580. 
9581. 
9582. 
9583. 
9584. 
9585. CHAPTER XVII
9586. 
9587. 
9588. Mounting his horse again Prince Andrew lingered with the battery,
9589. looking at the puff from the gun that had sent the ball. His eyes
9590. ran rapidly over the wide space, but he only saw that the hitherto
9591. motionless masses of the French now swayed and that there really was
9592. a battery to their left. The smoke above it had not yet dispersed. Two
9593. mounted Frenchmen, probably adjutants, were galloping up the hill. A
9594. small but distinctly visible enemy column was moving down the hill,
9595. probably to strengthen the front line. The smoke of the first shot had
9596. not yet dispersed before another puff appeared, followed by a report.
9597. The battle had begun! Prince Andrew turned his horse and galloped back
9598. to Grunth to find Prince Bagration. He heard the cannonade behind him
9599. growing louder and more frequent. Evidently our guns had begun to reply.
9600. From the bottom of the slope, where the parleys had taken place, came
9601. the report of musketry.
9602. 
9603. Lemarrois had just arrived at a gallop with Bonaparte's stern letter,
9604. and Murat, humiliated and anxious to expiate his fault, had at once
9605. moved his forces to attack the center and outflank both the Russian
9606. wings, hoping before evening and before the arrival of the Emperor to
9607. crush the contemptible detachment that stood before him.
9608. 
9609. "It has begun. Here it is!" thought Prince Andrew, feeling the blood
9610. rush to his heart. "But where and how will my Toulon present itself?"
9611. 
9612. Passing between the companies that had been eating porridge and drinking
9613. vodka a quarter of an hour before, he saw everywhere the same rapid
9614. movement of soldiers forming ranks and getting their muskets ready,
9615. and on all their faces he recognized the same eagerness that filled his
9616. heart. "It has begun! Here it is, dreadful but enjoyable!" was what the
9617. face of each soldier and each officer seemed to say.
9618. 
9619. Before he had reached the embankments that were being thrown up, he saw,
9620. in the light of the dull autumn evening, mounted men coming toward him.
9621. The foremost, wearing a Cossack cloak and lambskin cap and riding a
9622. white horse, was Prince Bagration. Prince Andrew stopped, waiting for
9623. him to come up; Prince Bagration reined in his horse and recognizing
9624. Prince Andrew nodded to him. He still looked ahead while Prince Andrew
9625. told him what he had seen.
9626. 
9627. The feeling, "It has begun! Here it is!" was seen even on Prince
9628. Bagration's hard brown face with its half-closed, dull, sleepy eyes.
9629. Prince Andrew gazed with anxious curiosity at that impassive face
9630. and wished he could tell what, if anything, this man was thinking and
9631. feeling at that moment. "Is there anything at all behind that impassive
9632. face?" Prince Andrew asked himself as he looked. Prince Bagration bent
9633. his head in sign of agreement with what Prince Andrew told him, and
9634. said, "Very good!" in a tone that seemed to imply that everything that
9635. took place and was reported to him was exactly what he had foreseen.
9636. Prince Andrew, out of breath with his rapid ride, spoke quickly.
9637. Prince Bagration, uttering his words with an Oriental accent, spoke
9638. particularly slowly, as if to impress the fact that there was no need to
9639. hurry. However, he put his horse to a trot in the direction of Tushin's
9640. battery. Prince Andrew followed with the suite. Behind Prince Bagration
9641. rode an officer of the suite, the prince's personal adjutant, Zherkov,
9642. an orderly officer, the staff officer on duty, riding a fine bobtailed
9643. horse, and a civilian--an accountant who had asked permission to
9644. be present at the battle out of curiosity. The accountant, a stout,
9645. full-faced man, looked around him with a naive smile of satisfaction
9646. and presented a strange appearance among the hussars, Cossacks, and
9647. adjutants, in his camlet coat, as he jolted on his horse with a convoy
9648. officer's saddle.
9649. 
9650. "He wants to see a battle," said Zherkov to Bolkonski, pointing to the
9651. accountant, "but he feels a pain in the pit of his stomach already."
9652. 
9653. "Oh, leave off!" said the accountant with a beaming but rather cunning
9654. smile, as if flattered at being made the subject of Zherkov's joke, and
9655. purposely trying to appear stupider than he really was.
9656. 
9657. "It is very strange, mon Monsieur Prince," said the staff officer. (He
9658. remembered that in French there is some peculiar way of addressing a
9659. prince, but could not get it quite right.)
9660. 
9661. By this time they were all approaching Tushin's battery, and a ball
9662. struck the ground in front of them.
9663. 
9664. "What's that that has fallen?" asked the accountant with a naive smile.
9665. 
9666. "A French pancake," answered Zherkov.
9667. 
9668. "So that's what they hit with?" asked the accountant. "How awful!"
9669. 
9670. He seemed to swell with satisfaction. He had hardly finished speaking
9671. when they again heard an unexpectedly violent whistling which suddenly
9672. ended with a thud into something soft... f-f-flop! and a Cossack, riding
9673. a little to their right and behind the accountant, crashed to earth with
9674. his horse. Zherkov and the staff officer bent over their saddles and
9675. turned their horses away. The accountant stopped, facing the Cossack,
9676. and examined him with attentive curiosity. The Cossack was dead, but the
9677. horse still struggled.
9678. 
9679. Prince Bagration screwed up his eyes, looked round, and, seeing the
9680. cause of the confusion, turned away with indifference, as if to say, "Is
9681. it worth while noticing trifles?" He reined in his horse with the case
9682. of a skillful rider and, slightly bending over, disengaged his saber
9683. which had caught in his cloak. It was an old-fashioned saber of a kind
9684. no longer in general use. Prince Andrew remembered the story of Suvorov
9685. giving his saber to Bagration in Italy, and the recollection was
9686. particularly pleasant at that moment. They had reached the battery at
9687. which Prince Andrew had been when he examined the battlefield.
9688. 
9689. "Whose company?" asked Prince Bagration of an artilleryman standing by
9690. the ammunition wagon.
9691. 
9692. He asked, "Whose company?" but he really meant, "Are you frightened
9693. here?" and the artilleryman understood him.
9694. 
9695. "Captain Tushin's, your excellency!" shouted the red-haired, freckled
9696. gunner in a merry voice, standing to attention.
9697. 
9698. "Yes, yes," muttered Bagration as if considering something, and he rode
9699. past the limbers to the farthest cannon.
9700. 
9701. As he approached, a ringing shot issued from it deafening him and his
9702. suite, and in the smoke that suddenly surrounded the gun they could see
9703. the gunners who had seized it straining to roll it quickly back to its
9704. former position. A huge, broad-shouldered gunner, Number One, holding
9705. a mop, his legs far apart, sprang to the wheel; while Number Two with
9706. a trembling hand placed a charge in the cannon's mouth. The short,
9707. round-shouldered Captain Tushin, stumbling over the tail of the gun
9708. carriage, moved forward and, not noticing the general, looked out
9709. shading his eyes with his small hand.
9710. 
9711. "Lift it two lines more and it will be just right," cried he in a feeble
9712. voice to which he tried to impart a dashing note, ill suited to his weak
9713. figure. "Number Two!" he squeaked. "Fire, Medvedev!"
9714. 
9715. Bagration called to him, and Tushin, raising three fingers to his cap
9716. with a bashful and awkward gesture not at all like a military salute
9717. but like a priest's benediction, approached the general. Though Tushin's
9718. guns had been intended to cannonade the valley, he was firing incendiary
9719. balls at the village of Schon Grabern visible just opposite, in front of
9720. which large masses of French were advancing.
9721. 
9722. No one had given Tushin orders where and at what to fire, but after
9723. consulting his sergeant major, Zakharchenko, for whom he had great
9724. respect, he had decided that it would be a good thing to set fire to the
9725. village. "Very good!" said Bagration in reply to the officer's report,
9726. and began deliberately to examine the whole battlefield extended before
9727. him. The French had advanced nearest on our right. Below the height on
9728. which the Kiev regiment was stationed, in the hollow where the rivulet
9729. flowed, the soul-stirring rolling and crackling of musketry was heard,
9730. and much farther to the right beyond the dragoons, the officer of the
9731. suite pointed out to Bagration a French column that was outflanking us.
9732. To the left the horizon bounded by the adjacent wood. Prince Bagration
9733. ordered two battalions from the center to be sent to reinforce the right
9734. flank. The officer of the suite ventured to remark to the prince that
9735. if these battalions went away, the guns would remain without support.
9736. Prince Bagration turned to the officer and with his dull eyes looked at
9737. him in silence. It seemed to Prince Andrew that the officer's remark was
9738. just and that really no answer could be made to it. But at that moment
9739. an adjutant galloped up with a message from the commander of the
9740. regiment in the hollow and news that immense masses of the French were
9741. coming down upon them and that his regiment was in disorder and was
9742. retreating upon the Kiev grenadiers. Prince Bagration bowed his head in
9743. sign of assent and approval. He rode off at a walk to the right and sent
9744. an adjutant to the dragoons with orders to attack the French. But this
9745. adjutant returned half an hour later with the news that the commander
9746. of the dragoons had already retreated beyond the dip in the ground, as
9747. a heavy fire had been opened on him and he was losing men uselessly, and
9748. so had hastened to throw some sharpshooters into the wood.
9749. 
9750. "Very good!" said Bagration.
9751. 
9752. As he was leaving the battery, firing was heard on the left also, and
9753. as it was too far to the left flank for him to have time to go there
9754. himself, Prince Bagration sent Zherkov to tell the general in command
9755. (the one who had paraded his regiment before Kutuzov at Braunau) that
9756. he must retreat as quickly as possible behind the hollow in the rear,
9757. as the right flank would probably not be able to withstand the enemy's
9758. attack very long. About Tushin and the battalion that had been in
9759. support of his battery all was forgotten. Prince Andrew listened
9760. attentively to Bagration's colloquies with the commanding officers and
9761. the orders he gave them and, to his surprise, found that no orders were
9762. really given, but that Prince Bagration tried to make it appear that
9763. everything done by necessity, by accident, or by the will of subordinate
9764. commanders was done, if not by his direct command, at least in accord
9765. with his intentions. Prince Andrew noticed, however, that though what
9766. happened was due to chance and was independent of the commander's will,
9767. owing to the tact Bagration showed, his presence was very valuable.
9768. Officers who approached him with disturbed countenances became calm;
9769. soldiers and officers greeted him gaily, grew more cheerful in his
9770. presence, and were evidently anxious to display their courage before
9771. him.
9772. 
9773. 
9774. 
9775. 
9776. 
9777. CHAPTER XVIII
9778. 
9779. 
9780. Prince Bagration, having reached the highest point of our right flank,
9781. began riding downhill to where the roll of musketry was heard but where
9782. on account of the smoke nothing could be seen. The nearer they got to
9783. the hollow the less they could see but the more they felt the nearness
9784. of the actual battlefield. They began to meet wounded men. One with a
9785. bleeding head and no cap was being dragged along by two soldiers who
9786. supported him under the arms. There was a gurgle in his throat and he
9787. was spitting blood. A bullet had evidently hit him in the throat or
9788. mouth. Another was walking sturdily by himself but without his musket,
9789. groaning aloud and swinging his arm which had just been hurt, while
9790. blood from it was streaming over his greatcoat as from a bottle. He had
9791. that moment been wounded and his face showed fear rather than suffering.
9792. Crossing a road they descended a steep incline and saw several men
9793. lying on the ground; they also met a crowd of soldiers some of whom were
9794. unwounded. The soldiers were ascending the hill breathing heavily, and
9795. despite the general's presence were talking loudly and gesticulating.
9796. In front of them rows of gray cloaks were already visible through the
9797. smoke, and an officer catching sight of Bagration rushed shouting after
9798. the crowd of retreating soldiers, ordering them back. Bagration rode up
9799. to the ranks along which shots crackled now here and now there, drowning
9800. the sound of voices and the shouts of command. The whole air reeked with
9801. smoke. The excited faces of the soldiers were blackened with it. Some
9802. were using their ramrods, others putting powder on the touchpans or
9803. taking charges from their pouches, while others were firing, though who
9804. they were firing at could not be seen for the smoke which there was no
9805. wind to carry away. A pleasant humming and whistling of bullets were
9806. often heard. "What is this?" thought Prince Andrew approaching the crowd
9807. of soldiers. "It can't be an attack, for they are not moving; it can't
9808. be a square--for they are not drawn up for that."
