9809. 
9810. The commander of the regiment, a thin, feeble-looking old man with a
9811. pleasant smile--his eyelids drooping more than half over his old eyes,
9812. giving him a mild expression, rode up to Bagration and welcomed him as
9813. a host welcomes an honored guest. He reported that his regiment had
9814. been attacked by French cavalry and that, though the attack had been
9815. repulsed, he had lost more than half his men. He said the attack
9816. had been repulsed, employing this military term to describe what had
9817. occurred to his regiment, but in reality he did not himself know what
9818. had happened during that half-hour to the troops entrusted to him, and
9819. could not say with certainty whether the attack had been repulsed or his
9820. regiment had been broken up. All he knew was that at the commencement
9821. of the action balls and shells began flying all over his regiment and
9822. hitting men and that afterwards someone had shouted "Cavalry!" and our
9823. men had begun firing. They were still firing, not at the cavalry which
9824. had disappeared, but at French infantry who had come into the hollow and
9825. were firing at our men. Prince Bagration bowed his head as a sign
9826. that this was exactly what he had desired and expected. Turning to his
9827. adjutant he ordered him to bring down the two battalions of the Sixth
9828. Chasseurs whom they had just passed. Prince Andrew was struck by
9829. the changed expression on Prince Bagration's face at this moment. It
9830. expressed the concentrated and happy resolution you see on the face of
9831. a man who on a hot day takes a final run before plunging into the water.
9832. The dull, sleepy expression was no longer there, nor the affectation
9833. of profound thought. The round, steady, hawk's eyes looked before him
9834. eagerly and rather disdainfully, not resting on anything although his
9835. movements were still slow and measured.
9836. 
9837. The commander of the regiment turned to Prince Bagration, entreating him
9838. to go back as it was too dangerous to remain where they were. "Please,
9839. your excellency, for God's sake!" he kept saying, glancing for support
9840. at an officer of the suite who turned away from him. "There, you see!"
9841. and he drew attention to the bullets whistling, singing, and hissing
9842. continually around them. He spoke in the tone of entreaty and reproach
9843. that a carpenter uses to a gentleman who has picked up an ax: "We are
9844. used to it, but you, sir, will blister your hands." He spoke as if those
9845. bullets could not kill him, and his half-closed eyes gave still more
9846. persuasiveness to his words. The staff officer joined in the colonel's
9847. appeals, but Bagration did not reply; he only gave an order to
9848. cease firing and re-form, so as to give room for the two approaching
9849. battalions. While he was speaking, the curtain of smoke that had
9850. concealed the hollow, driven by a rising wind, began to move from right
9851. to left as if drawn by an invisible hand, and the hill opposite, with
9852. the French moving about on it, opened out before them. All eyes fastened
9853. involuntarily on this French column advancing against them and winding
9854. down over the uneven ground. One could already see the soldiers' shaggy
9855. caps, distinguish the officers from the men, and see the standard
9856. flapping against its staff.
9857. 
9858. "They march splendidly," remarked someone in Bagration's suite.
9859. 
9860. The head of the column had already descended into the hollow. The clash
9861. would take place on this side of it...
9862. 
9863. The remains of our regiment which had been in action rapidly formed up
9864. and moved to the right; from behind it, dispersing the laggards, came
9865. two battalions of the Sixth Chasseurs in fine order. Before they had
9866. reached Bagration, the weighty tread of the mass of men marching in step
9867. could be heard. On their left flank, nearest to Bagration, marched
9868. a company commander, a fine round-faced man, with a stupid and happy
9869. expression--the same man who had rushed out of the wattle shed. At that
9870. moment he was clearly thinking of nothing but how dashing a fellow he
9871. would appear as he passed the commander.
9872. 
9873. With the self-satisfaction of a man on parade, he stepped lightly with
9874. his muscular legs as if sailing along, stretching himself to his full
9875. height without the smallest effort, his ease contrasting with the heavy
9876. tread of the soldiers who were keeping step with him. He carried close
9877. to his leg a narrow unsheathed sword (small, curved, and not like a real
9878. weapon) and looked now at the superior officers and now back at the men
9879. without losing step, his whole powerful body turning flexibly. It was as
9880. if all the powers of his soul were concentrated on passing the commander
9881. in the best possible manner, and feeling that he was doing it well he
9882. was happy. "Left... left... left..." he seemed to repeat to himself at
9883. each alternate step; and in time to this, with stern but varied faces,
9884. the wall of soldiers burdened with knapsacks and muskets marched in
9885. step, and each one of these hundreds of soldiers seemed to be repeating
9886. to himself at each alternate step, "Left... left... left..." A fat
9887. major skirted a bush, puffing and falling out of step; a soldier who had
9888. fallen behind, his face showing alarm at his defection, ran at a trot,
9889. panting to catch up with his company. A cannon ball, cleaving the air,
9890. flew over the heads of Bagration and his suite, and fell into the
9891. column to the measure of "Left... left!" "Close up!" came the company
9892. commander's voice in jaunty tones. The soldiers passed in a semicircle
9893. round something where the ball had fallen, and an old trooper on the
9894. flank, a noncommissioned officer who had stopped beside the dead men,
9895. ran to catch up his line and, falling into step with a hop, looked back
9896. angrily, and through the ominous silence and the regular tramp of feet
9897. beating the ground in unison, one seemed to hear left... left... left.
9898. 
9899. "Well done, lads!" said Prince Bagration.
9900. 
9901. "Glad to do our best, your ex'len-lency!" came a confused shout from
9902. the ranks. A morose soldier marching on the left turned his eyes on
9903. Bagration as he shouted, with an expression that seemed to say: "We know
9904. that ourselves!" Another, without looking round, as though fearing to
9905. relax, shouted with his mouth wide open and passed on.
9906. 
9907. The order was given to halt and down knapsacks.
9908. 
9909. Bagration rode round the ranks that had marched past him and dismounted.
9910. He gave the reins to a Cossack, took off and handed over his felt coat,
9911. stretched his legs, and set his cap straight. The head of the French
9912. column, with its officers leading, appeared from below the hill.
9913. 
9914. "Forward, with God!" said Bagration, in a resolute, sonorous voice,
9915. turning for a moment to the front line, and slightly swinging his arms,
9916. he went forward uneasily over the rough field with the awkward gait of
9917. a cavalryman. Prince Andrew felt that an invisible power was leading him
9918. forward, and experienced great happiness.
9919. 
9920. The French were already near. Prince Andrew, walking beside Bagration,
9921. could clearly distinguish their bandoliers, red epaulets, and even their
9922. faces. (He distinctly saw an old French officer who, with gaitered legs
9923. and turned-out toes, climbed the hill with difficulty.) Prince Bagration
9924. gave no further orders and silently continued to walk on in front of the
9925. ranks. Suddenly one shot after another rang out from the French, smoke
9926. appeared all along their uneven ranks, and musket shots sounded. Several
9927. of our men fell, among them the round-faced officer who had marched so
9928. gaily and complacently. But at the moment the first report was heard,
9929. Bagration looked round and shouted, "Hurrah!"
9930. 
9931. "Hurrah--ah!--ah!" rang a long-drawn shout from our ranks, and passing
9932. Bagration and racing one another they rushed in an irregular but joyous
9933. and eager crowd down the hill at their disordered foe.
9934. 
9935. 
9936. 
9937. 
9938. 
9939. CHAPTER XIX
9940. 
9941. 
9942. The attack of the Sixth Chasseurs secured the retreat of our right
9943. flank. In the center Tushin's forgotten battery, which had managed to
9944. set fire to the Schon Grabern village, delayed the French advance. The
9945. French were putting out the fire which the wind was spreading, and thus
9946. gave us time to retreat. The retirement of the center to the other side
9947. of the dip in the ground at the rear was hurried and noisy, but the
9948. different companies did not get mixed. But our left--which consisted
9949. of the Azov and Podolsk infantry and the Pavlograd hussars--was
9950. simultaneously attacked and outflanked by superior French forces under
9951. Lannes and was thrown into confusion. Bagration had sent Zherkov to the
9952. general commanding that left flank with orders to retreat immediately.
9953. 
9954. Zherkov, not removing his hand from his cap, turned his horse about
9955. and galloped off. But no sooner had he left Bagration than his courage
9956. failed him. He was seized by panic and could not go where it was
9957. dangerous.
9958. 
9959. Having reached the left flank, instead of going to the front where the
9960. firing was, he began to look for the general and his staff where they
9961. could not possibly be, and so did not deliver the order.
9962. 
9963. The command of the left flank belonged by seniority to the commander of
9964. the regiment Kutuzov had reviewed at Braunau and in which Dolokhov was
9965. serving as a private. But the command of the extreme left flank had been
9966. assigned to the commander of the Pavlograd regiment in which Rostov
9967. was serving, and a misunderstanding arose. The two commanders were much
9968. exasperated with one another and, long after the action had begun on
9969. the right flank and the French were already advancing, were engaged
9970. in discussion with the sole object of offending one another. But the
9971. regiments, both cavalry and infantry, were by no means ready for the
9972. impending action. From privates to general they were not expecting a
9973. battle and were engaged in peaceful occupations, the cavalry feeding the
9974. horses and the infantry collecting wood.
9975. 
9976. "He higher iss dan I in rank," said the German colonel of the hussars,
9977. flushing and addressing an adjutant who had ridden up, "so let him do
9978. what he vill, but I cannot sacrifice my hussars... Bugler, sount ze
9979. retreat!"
9980. 
9981. But haste was becoming imperative. Cannon and musketry, mingling
9982. together, thundered on the right and in the center, while the capotes of
9983. Lannes' sharpshooters were already seen crossing the milldam and forming
9984. up within twice the range of a musket shot. The general in command of
9985. the infantry went toward his horse with jerky steps, and having mounted
9986. drew himself up very straight and tall and rode to the Pavlograd
9987. commander. The commanders met with polite bows but with secret
9988. malevolence in their hearts.
9989. 
9990. "Once again, Colonel," said the general, "I can't leave half my men
9991. in the wood. I beg of you, I beg of you," he repeated, "to occupy the
9992. position and prepare for an attack."
9993. 
9994. "I peg of you yourself not to mix in vot is not your business!" suddenly
9995. replied the irate colonel. "If you vere in the cavalry..."
9996. 
9997. "I am not in the cavalry, Colonel, but I am a Russian general and if you
9998. are not aware of the fact..."
9999. 
10000. "Quite avare, your excellency," suddenly shouted the colonel, touching
10001. his horse and turning purple in the face. "Vill you be so goot to
10002. come to ze front and see dat zis position iss no goot? I don't vish to
10003. destroy my men for your pleasure!"
10004. 
10005. "You forget yourself, Colonel. I am not considering my own pleasure and
10006. I won't allow it to be said!"
10007. 
10008. Taking the colonel's outburst as a challenge to his courage, the general
10009. expanded his chest and rode, frowning, beside him to the front line, as
10010. if their differences would be settled there amongst the bullets. They
10011. reached the front, several bullets sped over them, and they halted in
10012. silence. There was nothing fresh to be seen from the line, for from
10013. where they had been before it had been evident that it was impossible
10014. for cavalry to act among the bushes and broken ground, as well as that
10015. the French were outflanking our left. The general and colonel looked
10016. sternly and significantly at one another like two fighting cocks
10017. preparing for battle, each vainly trying to detect signs of cowardice
10018. in the other. Both passed the examination successfully. As there was
10019. nothing to be said, and neither wished to give occasion for it to be
10020. alleged that he had been the first to leave the range of fire, they
10021. would have remained there for a long time testing each other's courage
10022. had it not been that just then they heard the rattle of musketry and a
10023. muffled shout almost behind them in the wood. The French had attacked
10024. the men collecting wood in the copse. It was no longer possible for the
10025. hussars to retreat with the infantry. They were cut off from the line of
10026. retreat on the left by the French. However inconvenient the position, it
10027. was now necessary to attack in order to cut away through for themselves.
10028. 
10029. The squadron in which Rostov was serving had scarcely time to mount
10030. before it was halted facing the enemy. Again, as at the Enns bridge,
10031. there was nothing between the squadron and the enemy, and again that
10032. terrible dividing line of uncertainty and fear--resembling the line
10033. separating the living from the dead--lay between them. All were
10034. conscious of this unseen line, and the question whether they would cross
10035. it or not, and how they would cross it, agitated them all.
10036. 
10037. The colonel rode to the front, angrily gave some reply to questions put
10038. to him by the officers, and, like a man desperately insisting on having
10039. his own way, gave an order. No one said anything definite, but the rumor
10040. of an attack spread through the squadron. The command to form up rang
10041. out and the sabers whizzed as they were drawn from their scabbards.
10042. Still no one moved. The troops of the left flank, infantry and hussars
10043. alike, felt that the commander did not himself know what to do, and this
10044. irresolution communicated itself to the men.
10045. 
10046. "If only they would be quick!" thought Rostov, feeling that at last
10047. the time had come to experience the joy of an attack of which he had so
10048. often heard from his fellow hussars.
10049. 
10050. "Fo'ward, with God, lads!" rang out Denisov's voice. "At a twot
10051. fo'ward!"
10052. 
10053. The horses' croups began to sway in the front line. Rook pulled at the
10054. reins and started of his own accord.
10055. 
10056. Before him, on the right, Rostov saw the front lines of his hussars and
10057. still farther ahead a dark line which he could not see distinctly but
10058. took to be the enemy. Shots could be heard, but some way off.
10059. 
10060. "Faster!" came the word of command, and Rostov felt Rook's flanks
10061. drooping as he broke into a gallop.
10062. 
10063. Rostov anticipated his horse's movements and became more and more
10064. elated. He had noticed a solitary tree ahead of him. This tree had been
10065. in the middle of the line that had seemed so terrible--and now he
10066. had crossed that line and not only was there nothing terrible, but
10067. everything was becoming more and more happy and animated. "Oh, how I
10068. will slash at him!" thought Rostov, gripping the hilt of his saber.
10069. 
10070. "Hur-a-a-a-ah!" came a roar of voices. "Let anyone come my way now,"
10071. thought Rostov driving his spurs into Rook and letting him go at a full
10072. gallop so that he outstripped the others. Ahead, the enemy was already
10073. visible. Suddenly something like a birch broom seemed to sweep over the
10074. squadron. Rostov raised his saber, ready to strike, but at that instant
10075. the trooper Nikitenko, who was galloping ahead, shot away from him, and
10076. Rostov felt as in a dream that he continued to be carried forward
10077. with unnatural speed but yet stayed on the same spot. From behind him
10078. Bondarchuk, an hussar he knew, jolted against him and looked angrily at
10079. him. Bondarchuk's horse swerved and galloped past.
10080. 
10081. "How is it I am not moving? I have fallen, I am killed!" Rostov asked
10082. and answered at the same instant. He was alone in the middle of a field.
10083. Instead of the moving horses and hussars' backs, he saw nothing before
10084. him but the motionless earth and the stubble around him. There was warm
10085. blood under his arm. "No, I am wounded and the horse is killed." Rook
10086. tried to rise on his forelegs but fell back, pinning his rider's leg.
10087. Blood was flowing from his head; he struggled but could not rise. Rostov
10088. also tried to rise but fell back, his sabretache having become entangled
10089. in the saddle. Where our men were, and where the French, he did not
10090. know. There was no one near.
10091. 
10092. Having disentangled his leg, he rose. "Where, on which side, was now the
10093. line that had so sharply divided the two armies?" he asked himself and
10094. could not answer. "Can something bad have happened to me?" he wondered
10095. as he got up: and at that moment he felt that something superfluous was
10096. hanging on his benumbed left arm. The wrist felt as if it were not his.
10097. He examined his hand carefully, vainly trying to find blood on it. "Ah,
10098. here are people coming," he thought joyfully, seeing some men running
10099. toward him. "They will help me!" In front came a man wearing a strange
10100. shako and a blue cloak, swarthy, sunburned, and with a hooked nose. Then
10101. came two more, and many more running behind. One of them said something
10102. strange, not in Russian. In among the hindmost of these men wearing
10103. similar shakos was a Russian hussar. He was being held by the arms and
10104. his horse was being led behind him.
10105. 
10106. "It must be one of ours, a prisoner. Yes. Can it be that they will take
10107. me too? Who are these men?" thought Rostov, scarcely believing his eyes.
10108. "Can they be French?" He looked at the approaching Frenchmen, and though
10109. but a moment before he had been galloping to get at them and hack them
10110. to pieces, their proximity now seemed so awful that he could not believe
10111. his eyes. "Who are they? Why are they running? Can they be coming at me?
10112. And why? To kill me? Me whom everyone is so fond of?" He remembered
10113. his mother's love for him, and his family's, and his friends', and the
10114. enemy's intention to kill him seemed impossible. "But perhaps they may
10115. do it!" For more than ten seconds he stood not moving from the spot or
10116. realizing the situation. The foremost Frenchman, the one with the hooked
10117. nose, was already so close that the expression of his face could be
10118. seen. And the excited, alien face of that man, his bayonet hanging down,
10119. holding his breath, and running so lightly, frightened Rostov. He seized
10120. his pistol and, instead of firing it, flung it at the Frenchman and
10121. ran with all his might toward the bushes. He did not now run with the
10122. feeling of doubt and conflict with which he had trodden the Enns bridge,
10123. but with the feeling of a hare fleeing from the hounds. One single
10124. sentiment, that of fear for his young and happy life, possessed his
10125. whole being. Rapidly leaping the furrows, he fled across the field with
10126. the impetuosity he used to show at catchplay, now and then turning his
10127. good-natured, pale, young face to look back. A shudder of terror went
10128. through him: "No, better not look," he thought, but having reached the
10129. bushes he glanced round once more. The French had fallen behind, and
10130. just as he looked round the first man changed his run to a walk and,
10131. turning, shouted something loudly to a comrade farther back. Rostov
10132. paused. "No, there's some mistake," thought he. "They can't have wanted
10133. to kill me." But at the same time, his left arm felt as heavy as if
10134. a seventy-pound weight were tied to it. He could run no more. The
10135. Frenchman also stopped and took aim. Rostov closed his eyes and stooped
10136. down. One bullet and then another whistled past him. He mustered his
10137. last remaining strength, took hold of his left hand with his right, and
10138. reached the bushes. Behind these were some Russian sharpshooters.
10139. 
10140. 
10141. 
10142. 
10143. 
10144. CHAPTER XX
10145. 
10146. 
10147. The infantry regiments that had been caught unawares in the outskirts
10148. of the wood ran out of it, the different companies getting mixed, and
10149. retreated as a disorderly crowd. One soldier, in his fear, uttered the
10150. senseless cry, "Cut off!" that is so terrible in battle, and that word
10151. infected the whole crowd with a feeling of panic.
10152. 
10153. "Surrounded! Cut off? We're lost!" shouted the fugitives.
10154. 
10155. The moment he heard the firing and the cry from behind, the general
10156. realized that something dreadful had happened to his regiment, and the
10157. thought that he, an exemplary officer of many years' service who had
10158. never been to blame, might be held responsible at headquarters for
10159. negligence or inefficiency so staggered him that, forgetting the
10160. recalcitrant cavalry colonel, his own dignity as a general, and above
10161. all quite forgetting the danger and all regard for self-preservation, he
10162. clutched the crupper of his saddle and, spurring his horse, galloped to
10163. the regiment under a hail of bullets which fell around, but fortunately
10164. missed him. His one desire was to know what was happening and at any
10165. cost correct, or remedy, the mistake if he had made one, so that he,
10166. an exemplary officer of twenty-two years' service, who had never been
10167. censured, should not be held to blame.
10168. 
10169. Having galloped safely through the French, he reached a field behind
10170. the copse across which our men, regardless of orders, were running and
10171. descending the valley. That moment of moral hesitation which decides
10172. the fate of battles had arrived. Would this disorderly crowd of soldiers
10173. attend to the voice of their commander, or would they, disregarding him,
10174. continue their flight? Despite his desperate shouts that used to seem
10175. so terrible to the soldiers, despite his furious purple countenance
10176. distorted out of all likeness to his former self, and the flourishing of
10177. his saber, the soldiers all continued to run, talking, firing into the
10178. air, and disobeying orders. The moral hesitation which decided the fate
10179. of battles was evidently culminating in a panic.
10180. 
10181. The general had a fit of coughing as a result of shouting and of the
10182. powder smoke and stopped in despair. Everything seemed lost. But at that
10183. moment the French who were attacking, suddenly and without any apparent
10184. reason, ran back and disappeared from the outskirts, and Russian
10185. sharpshooters showed themselves in the copse. It was Timokhin's company,
10186. which alone had maintained its order in the wood and, having lain in
10187. ambush in a ditch, now attacked the French unexpectedly. Timokhin, armed
10188. only with a sword, had rushed at the enemy with such a desperate cry and
10189. such mad, drunken determination that, taken by surprise, the French had
10190. thrown down their muskets and run. Dolokhov, running beside Timokhin,
10191. killed a Frenchman at close quarters and was the first to seize the
10192. surrendering French officer by his collar. Our fugitives returned, the
10193. battalions re-formed, and the French who had nearly cut our left flank
10194. in half were for the moment repulsed. Our reserve units were able to
10195. join up, and the fight was at an end. The regimental commander and Major
10196. Ekonomov had stopped beside a bridge, letting the retreating companies
10197. pass by them, when a soldier came up and took hold of the commander's
10198. stirrup, almost leaning against him. The man was wearing a bluish coat
10199. of broadcloth, he had no knapsack or cap, his head was bandaged, and
10200. over his shoulder a French munition pouch was slung. He had an officer's
10201. sword in his hand. The soldier was pale, his blue eyes looked impudently
10202. into the commander's face, and his lips were smiling. Though the
10203. commander was occupied in giving instructions to Major Ekonomov, he
10204. could not help taking notice of the soldier.
10205. 
10206. "Your excellency, here are two trophies," said Dolokhov, pointing to the
10207. French sword and pouch. "I have taken an officer prisoner. I stopped the
10208. company." Dolokhov breathed heavily from weariness and spoke in abrupt
10209. sentences. "The whole company can bear witness. I beg you will remember
10210. this, your excellency!"
10211. 
10212. "All right, all right," replied the commander, and turned to Major
10213. Ekonomov.
10214. 
10215. But Dolokhov did not go away; he untied the handkerchief around his
10216. head, pulled it off, and showed the blood congealed on his hair.
10217. 
10218. "A bayonet wound. I remained at the front. Remember, your excellency!"
10219. 
10220. 
10221. Tushin's battery had been forgotten and only at the very end of the
10222. action did Prince Bagration, still hearing the cannonade in the center,
10223. send his orderly staff officer, and later Prince Andrew also, to order
10224. the battery to retire as quickly as possible. When the supports attached
10225. to Tushin's battery had been moved away in the middle of the action
10226. by someone's order, the battery had continued firing and was only not
10227. captured by the French because the enemy could not surmise that anyone
10228. could have the effrontery to continue firing from four quite undefended
10229. guns. On the contrary, the energetic action of that battery led the
10230. French to suppose that here--in the center--the main Russian forces were
10231. concentrated. Twice they had attempted to attack this point, but on each
10232. occasion had been driven back by grapeshot from the four isolated guns
10233. on the hillock.
10234. 
10235. Soon after Prince Bagration had left him, Tushin had succeeded in
10236. setting fire to Schon Grabern.
10237. 
10238. "Look at them scurrying! It's burning! Just see the smoke! Fine! Grand!
10239. Look at the smoke, the smoke!" exclaimed the artillerymen, brightening
10240. up.
10241. 
10242. All the guns, without waiting for orders, were being fired in the
10243. direction of the conflagration. As if urging each other on, the soldiers
10244. cried at each shot: "Fine! That's good! Look at it... Grand!" The fire,
10245. fanned by the breeze, was rapidly spreading. The French columns that had
10246. advanced beyond the village went back; but as though in revenge for this
10247. failure, the enemy placed ten guns to the right of the village and began
10248. firing them at Tushin's battery.
10249. 
10250. In their childlike glee, aroused by the fire and their luck in
10251. successfully cannonading the French, our artillerymen only noticed this
10252. battery when two balls, and then four more, fell among our guns, one
10253. knocking over two horses and another tearing off a munition-wagon
10254. driver's leg. Their spirits once roused were, however, not diminished,
10255. but only changed character. The horses were replaced by others from a
10256. reserve gun carriage, the wounded were carried away, and the four guns
10257. were turned against the ten-gun battery. Tushin's companion officer
10258. had been killed at the beginning of the engagement and within an hour
10259. seventeen of the forty men of the guns' crews had been disabled, but the
10260. artillerymen were still as merry and lively as ever. Twice they noticed
10261. the French appearing below them, and then they fired grapeshot at them.
10262. 
10263. Little Tushin, moving feebly and awkwardly, kept telling his orderly to
10264. "refill my pipe for that one!" and then, scattering sparks from it, ran
10265. forward shading his eyes with his small hand to look at the French.
10266. 
10267. "Smack at 'em, lads!" he kept saying, seizing the guns by the wheels and
10268. working the screws himself.
10269. 
10270. Amid the smoke, deafened by the incessant reports which always made him
10271. jump, Tushin not taking his pipe from his mouth ran from gun to gun, now
10272. aiming, now counting the charges, now giving orders about replacing dead
10273. or wounded horses and harnessing fresh ones, and shouting in his feeble
10274. voice, so high pitched and irresolute. His face grew more and more
10275. animated. Only when a man was killed or wounded did he frown and turn
10276. away from the sight, shouting angrily at the men who, as is always the
10277. case, hesitated about lifting the injured or dead. The soldiers, for the
10278. most part handsome fellows and, as is always the case in an artillery
10279. company, a head and shoulders taller and twice as broad as their
10280. officer--all looked at their commander like children in an embarrassing
10281. situation, and the expression on his face was invariably reflected on
10282. theirs.
10283. 
10284. Owing to the terrible uproar and the necessity for concentration and
10285. activity, Tushin did not experience the slightest unpleasant sense of
10286. fear, and the thought that he might be killed or badly wounded never
10287. occurred to him. On the contrary, he became more and more elated. It
10288. seemed to him that it was a very long time ago, almost a day, since he
10289. had first seen the enemy and fired the first shot, and that the corner
10290. of the field he stood on was well-known and familiar ground. Though he
10291. thought of everything, considered everything, and did everything the
10292. best of officers could do in his position, he was in a state akin to
10293. feverish delirium or drunkenness.
10294. 
10295. From the deafening sounds of his own guns around him, the whistle and
10296. thud of the enemy's cannon balls, from the flushed and perspiring faces
10297. of the crew bustling round the guns, from the sight of the blood of men
10298. and horses, from the little puffs of smoke on the enemy's side (always
10299. followed by a ball flying past and striking the earth, a man, a gun, a
10300. horse), from the sight of all these things a fantastic world of his
10301. own had taken possession of his brain and at that moment afforded him
10302. pleasure. The enemy's guns were in his fancy not guns but pipes from
10303. which occasional puffs were blown by an invisible smoker.
10304. 
10305. "There... he's puffing again," muttered Tushin to himself, as a small
10306. cloud rose from the hill and was borne in a streak to the left by the
10307. wind.
10308. 
10309. "Now look out for the ball... we'll throw it back."
10310. 
10311. "What do you want, your honor?" asked an artilleryman, standing close
10312. by, who heard him muttering.
10313. 
10314. "Nothing... only a shell..." he answered.
10315. 
10316. "Come along, our Matvevna!" he said to himself. "Matvevna" * was the
10317. name his fancy gave to the farthest gun of the battery, which was large
10318. and of an old pattern. The French swarming round their guns seemed to
10319. him like ants. In that world, the handsome drunkard Number One of the
10320. second gun's crew was "uncle"; Tushin looked at him more often than
10321. at anyone else and took delight in his every movement. The sound of
10322. musketry at the foot of the hill, now diminishing, now increasing,
10323. seemed like someone's breathing. He listened intently to the ebb and
10324. flow of these sounds.
10325. 
10326. 
10327.     * Daughter of Matthew.
10328. 
10329. 
10330. "Ah! Breathing again, breathing!" he muttered to himself.
10331. 
10332. He imagined himself as an enormously tall, powerful man who was throwing
10333. cannon balls at the French with both hands.
10334. 
10335. "Now then, Matvevna, dear old lady, don't let me down!" he was saying as
10336. he moved from the gun, when a strange, unfamiliar voice called above his
10337. head: "Captain Tushin! Captain!"
10338. 
10339. Tushin turned round in dismay. It was the staff officer who had turned
10340. him out of the booth at Grunth. He was shouting in a gasping voice:
10341. 
10342. "Are you mad? You have twice been ordered to retreat, and you..."
10343. 
10344. "Why are they down on me?" thought Tushin, looking in alarm at his
10345. superior.
10346. 
10347. "I... don't..." he muttered, holding up two fingers to his cap. "I..."
10348. 
10349. But the staff officer did not finish what he wanted to say. A cannon
10350. ball, flying close to him, caused him to duck and bend over his horse.
10351. He paused, and just as he was about to say something more, another ball
10352. stopped him. He turned his horse and galloped off.
10353. 
10354. "Retire! All to retire!" he shouted from a distance.
10355. 
10356. The soldiers laughed. A moment later, an adjutant arrived with the same
10357. order.
10358. 
10359. It was Prince Andrew. The first thing he saw on riding up to the space
10360. where Tushin's guns were stationed was an unharnessed horse with a
10361. broken leg, that lay screaming piteously beside the harnessed horses.
10362. Blood was gushing from its leg as from a spring. Among the limbers lay
10363. several dead men. One ball after another passed over as he approached
10364. and he felt a nervous shudder run down his spine. But the mere thought
10365. of being afraid roused him again. "I cannot be afraid," thought he, and
10366. dismounted slowly among the guns. He delivered the order and did not
10367. leave the battery. He decided to have the guns removed from their
10368. positions and withdrawn in his presence. Together with Tushin, stepping
10369. across the bodies and under a terrible fire from the French, he attended
10370. to the removal of the guns.
10371. 
10372. "A staff officer was here a minute ago, but skipped off," said an
10373. artilleryman to Prince Andrew. "Not like your honor!"
10374. 
10375. Prince Andrew said nothing to Tushin. They were both so busy as to seem
10376. not to notice one another. When having limbered up the only two cannon
10377. that remained uninjured out of the four, they began moving down the hill
10378. (one shattered gun and one unicorn were left behind), Prince Andrew rode
10379. up to Tushin.
10380. 
10381. "Well, till we meet again..." he said, holding out his hand to Tushin.
10382. 
10383. "Good-by, my dear fellow," said Tushin. "Dear soul! Good-by, my dear
10384. fellow!" and for some unknown reason tears suddenly filled his eyes.
10385. 
10386. 
10387. 
10388. 
10389. 
10390. CHAPTER XXI
10391. 
10392. 
10393. The wind had fallen and black clouds, merging with the powder smoke,
10394. hung low over the field of battle on the horizon. It was growing
10395. dark and the glow of two conflagrations was the more conspicuous. The
10396. cannonade was dying down, but the rattle of musketry behind and on
10397. the right sounded oftener and nearer. As soon as Tushin with his guns,
10398. continually driving round or coming upon wounded men, was out of range
10399. of fire and had descended into the dip, he was met by some of the staff,
10400. among them the staff officer and Zherkov, who had been twice sent to
10401. Tushin's battery but had never reached it. Interrupting one another,
10402. they all gave, and transmitted, orders as to how to proceed,
10403. reprimanding and reproaching him. Tushin gave no orders, and,
10404. silently--fearing to speak because at every word he felt ready to weep
10405. without knowing why--rode behind on his artillery nag. Though the orders
10406. were to abandon the wounded, many of them dragged themselves after
10407. troops and begged for seats on the gun carriages. The jaunty infantry
10408. officer who just before the battle had rushed out of Tushin's wattle
10409. shed was laid, with a bullet in his stomach, on "Matvevna's" carriage.
10410. At the foot of the hill, a pale hussar cadet, supporting one hand with
10411. the other, came up to Tushin and asked for a seat.
10412. 
10413. "Captain, for God's sake! I've hurt my arm," he said timidly. "For God's
10414. sake... I can't walk. For God's sake!"
10415. 
10416. It was plain that this cadet had already repeatedly asked for a lift and
10417. been refused. He asked in a hesitating, piteous voice.
10418. 
10419. "Tell them to give me a seat, for God's sake!"
10420. 
10421. "Give him a seat," said Tushin. "Lay a cloak for him to sit on, lad,"
10422. he said, addressing his favorite soldier. "And where is the wounded
10423. officer?"
10424. 
10425. "He has been set down. He died," replied someone.
10426. 
10427. "Help him up. Sit down, dear fellow, sit down! Spread out the cloak,
10428. Antonov."
10429. 
10430. The cadet was Rostov. With one hand he supported the other; he was pale
10431. and his jaw trembled, shivering feverishly. He was placed on "Matvevna,"
10432. the gun from which they had removed the dead officer. The cloak they
10433. spread under him was wet with blood which stained his breeches and arm.
10434. 
10435. "What, are you wounded, my lad?" said Tushin, approaching the gun on
10436. which Rostov sat.
10437. 
10438. "No, it's a sprain."
10439. 
10440. "Then what is this blood on the gun carriage?" inquired Tushin.
10441. 
10442. "It was the officer, your honor, stained it," answered the artilleryman,
10443. wiping away the blood with his coat sleeve, as if apologizing for the
10444. state of his gun.
10445. 
10446. It was all that they could do to get the guns up the rise aided by the
10447. infantry, and having reached the village of Gruntersdorf they halted. It
10448. had grown so dark that one could not distinguish the uniforms ten paces
10449. off, and the firing had begun to subside. Suddenly, near by on the
10450. right, shouting and firing were again heard. Flashes of shot gleamed in
10451. the darkness. This was the last French attack and was met by soldiers
10452. who had sheltered in the village houses. They all rushed out of the
10453. village again, but Tushin's guns could not move, and the artillerymen,
10454. Tushin, and the cadet exchanged silent glances as they awaited their
10455. fate. The firing died down and soldiers, talking eagerly, streamed out
10456. of a side street.
10457. 
10458. "Not hurt, Petrov?" asked one.
10459. 
10460. "We've given it 'em hot, mate! They won't make another push now," said
10461. another.
10462. 
10463. "You couldn't see a thing. How they shot at their own fellows! Nothing
10464. could be seen. Pitch-dark, brother! Isn't there something to drink?"
10465. 
10466. The French had been repulsed for the last time. And again and again in
10467. the complete darkness Tushin's guns moved forward, surrounded by the
10468. humming infantry as by a frame.
10469. 
10470. In the darkness, it seemed as though a gloomy unseen river was flowing
10471. always in one direction, humming with whispers and talk and the sound of
10472. hoofs and wheels. Amid the general rumble, the groans and voices of the
10473. wounded were more distinctly heard than any other sound in the darkness
10474. of the night. The gloom that enveloped the army was filled with their
10475. groans, which seemed to melt into one with the darkness of the night.
10476. After a while the moving mass became agitated, someone rode past on a
10477. white horse followed by his suite, and said something in passing: "What
10478. did he say? Where to, now? Halt, is it? Did he thank us?" came eager
10479. questions from all sides. The whole moving mass began pressing closer
10480. together and a report spread that they were ordered to halt: evidently
10481. those in front had halted. All remained where they were in the middle of
10482. the muddy road.
10483. 
10484. Fires were lighted and the talk became more audible. Captain Tushin,
10485. having given orders to his company, sent a soldier to find a dressing
10486. station or a doctor for the cadet, and sat down by a bonfire the
10487. soldiers had kindled on the road. Rostov, too, dragged himself to the
10488. fire. From pain, cold, and damp, a feverish shivering shook his whole
10489. body. Drowsiness was irresistibly mastering him, but he kept awake by
10490. an excruciating pain in his arm, for which he could find no satisfactory
10491. position. He kept closing his eyes and then again looking at the fire,
10492. which seemed to him dazzlingly red, and at the feeble, round-shouldered
10493. figure of Tushin who was sitting cross-legged like a Turk beside him.
10494. Tushin's large, kind, intelligent eyes were fixed with sympathy and
10495. commiseration on Rostov, who saw that Tushin with his whole heart wished
10496. to help him but could not.
10497. 
10498. From all sides were heard the footsteps and talk of the infantry, who
10499. were walking, driving past, and settling down all around. The sound
10500. of voices, the tramping feet, the horses' hoofs moving in mud, the
10501. crackling of wood fires near and afar, merged into one tremulous rumble.
10502. 
10503. It was no longer, as before, a dark, unseen river flowing through the
10504. gloom, but a dark sea swelling and gradually subsiding after a storm.
10505. Rostov looked at and listened listlessly to what passed before and
10506. around him. An infantryman came to the fire, squatted on his heels, held
10507. his hands to the blaze, and turned away his face.
10508. 
10509. "You don't mind your honor?" he asked Tushin. "I've lost my company,
10510. your honor. I don't know where... such bad luck!"
10511. 
10512. With the soldier, an infantry officer with a bandaged cheek came up to
10513. the bonfire, and addressing Tushin asked him to have the guns moved a
10514. trifle to let a wagon go past. After he had gone, two soldiers rushed to
10515. the campfire. They were quarreling and fighting desperately, each trying
10516. to snatch from the other a boot they were both holding on to.
10517. 
10518. "You picked it up?... I dare say! You're very smart!" one of them
10519. shouted hoarsely.
10520. 
10521. Then a thin, pale soldier, his neck bandaged with a bloodstained leg
10522. band, came up and in angry tones asked the artillerymen for water.
10523. 
10524. "Must one die like a dog?" said he.
10525. 
10526. Tushin told them to give the man some water. Then a cheerful soldier ran
10527. up, begging a little fire for the infantry.
10528. 
10529. "A nice little hot torch for the infantry! Good luck to you, fellow
10530. countrymen. Thanks for the fire--we'll return it with interest," said
10531. he, carrying away into the darkness a glowing stick.
10532. 
10533. Next came four soldiers, carrying something heavy on a cloak, and passed
10534. by the fire. One of them stumbled.
10535. 
10536. "Who the devil has put the logs on the road?" snarled he.
10537. 
10538. "He's dead--why carry him?" said another.
10539. 
10540. "Shut up!"
10541. 
10542. And they disappeared into the darkness with their load.
10543. 
10544. "Still aching?" Tushin asked Rostov in a whisper.
10545. 
10546. "Yes."
10547. 
10548. "Your honor, you're wanted by the general. He is in the hut here," said
10549. a gunner, coming up to Tushin.
10550. 
10551. "Coming, friend."
10552. 
10553. Tushin rose and, buttoning his greatcoat and pulling it straight, walked
10554. away from the fire.
10555. 
10556. Not far from the artillery campfire, in a hut that had been prepared
10557. for him, Prince Bagration sat at dinner, talking with some commanding
10558. officers who had gathered at his quarters. The little old man with
10559. the half-closed eyes was there greedily gnawing a mutton bone, and the
10560. general who had served blamelessly for twenty-two years, flushed by a
10561. glass of vodka and the dinner; and the staff officer with the signet
10562. ring, and Zherkov, uneasily glancing at them all, and Prince Andrew,
10563. pale, with compressed lips and feverishly glittering eyes.
10564. 
10565. In a corner of the hut stood a standard captured from the French, and
10566. the accountant with the naive face was feeling its texture, shaking his
10567. head in perplexity--perhaps because the banner really interested him,
10568. perhaps because it was hard for him, hungry as he was, to look on at
10569. a dinner where there was no place for him. In the next hut there was a
10570. French colonel who had been taken prisoner by our dragoons. Our officers
10571. were flocking in to look at him. Prince Bagration was thanking the
10572. individual commanders and inquiring into details of the action and our
10573. losses. The general whose regiment had been inspected at Braunau was
10574. informing the prince that as soon as the action began he had withdrawn
10575. from the wood, mustered the men who were woodcutting, and, allowing the
10576. French to pass him, had made a bayonet charge with two battalions and
10577. had broken up the French troops.
10578. 
10579. "When I saw, your excellency, that their first battalion was
10580. disorganized, I stopped in the road and thought: 'I'll let them come
10581. on and will meet them with the fire of the whole battalion'--and that's
10582. what I did."
10583. 
10584. The general had so wished to do this and was so sorry he had not managed
10585. to do it that it seemed to him as if it had really happened. Perhaps
10586. it might really have been so? Could one possibly make out amid all that
10587. confusion what did or did not happen?
10588. 
10589. "By the way, your excellency, I should inform you," he
10590. continued--remembering Dolokhov's conversation with Kutuzov and his last
10591. interview with the gentleman-ranker--"that Private Dolokhov, who was
10592. reduced to the ranks, took a French officer prisoner in my presence and
10593. particularly distinguished himself."
10594. 
10595. "I saw the Pavlograd hussars attack there, your excellency," chimed in
10596. Zherkov, looking uneasily around. He had not seen the hussars all that
10597. day, but had heard about them from an infantry officer. "They broke up
10598. two squares, your excellency."
10599. 
10600. Several of those present smiled at Zherkov's words, expecting one of his
10601. usual jokes, but noticing that what he was saying redounded to the glory
10602. of our arms and of the day's work, they assumed a serious expression,
10603. though many of them knew that what he was saying was a lie devoid of any
10604. foundation. Prince Bagration turned to the old colonel:
10605. 
10606. "Gentlemen, I thank you all; all arms have behaved heroically: infantry,
10607. cavalry, and artillery. How was it that two guns were abandoned in
10608. the center?" he inquired, searching with his eyes for someone. (Prince
10609. Bagration did not ask about the guns on the left flank; he knew that all
10610. the guns there had been abandoned at the very beginning of the action.)
10611. "I think I sent you?" he added, turning to the staff officer on duty.
10612. 
10613. "One was damaged," answered the staff officer, "and the other I can't
10614. understand. I was there all the time giving orders and had only just
10615. left.... It is true that it was hot there," he added, modestly.
10616. 
10617. Someone mentioned that Captain Tushin was bivouacking close to the
10618. village and had already been sent for.
10619. 
10620. "Oh, but you were there?" said Prince Bagration, addressing Prince
10621. Andrew.
10622. 
10623. "Of course, we only just missed one another," said the staff officer,
10624. with a smile to Bolkonski.
10625. 
10626. "I had not the pleasure of seeing you," said Prince Andrew, coldly and
10627. abruptly.
10628. 
10629. All were silent. Tushin appeared at the threshold and made his way
10630. timidly from behind the backs of the generals. As he stepped past the
10631. generals in the crowded hut, feeling embarrassed as he always was by the
10632. sight of his superiors, he did not notice the staff of the banner and
10633. stumbled over it. Several of those present laughed.
10634. 
10635. "How was it a gun was abandoned?" asked Bagration, frowning, not so much
10636. at the captain as at those who were laughing, among whom Zherkov laughed
10637. loudest.
10638. 
10639. Only now, when he was confronted by the stern authorities, did his guilt
10640. and the disgrace of having lost two guns and yet remaining alive present
10641. themselves to Tushin in all their horror. He had been so excited that
10642. he had not thought about it until that moment. The officers' laughter
10643. confused him still more. He stood before Bagration with his lower
10644. jaw trembling and was hardly able to mutter: "I don't know... your
10645. excellency... I had no men... your excellency."
10646. 
10647. "You might have taken some from the covering troops."
10648. 
10649. Tushin did not say that there were no covering troops, though that
10650. was perfectly true. He was afraid of getting some other officer into
10651. trouble, and silently fixed his eyes on Bagration as a schoolboy who has
10652. blundered looks at an examiner.
10653. 
10654. The silence lasted some time. Prince Bagration, apparently not wishing
10655. to be severe, found nothing to say; the others did not venture to
10656. intervene. Prince Andrew looked at Tushin from under his brows and his
10657. fingers twitched nervously.
10658. 
10659. "Your excellency!" Prince Andrew broke the silence with his abrupt
10660. voice, "you were pleased to send me to Captain Tushin's battery. I went
10661. there and found two thirds of the men and horses knocked out, two guns
10662. smashed, and no supports at all."
10663. 
10664. Prince Bagration and Tushin looked with equal intentness at Bolkonski,
10665. who spoke with suppressed agitation.
10666. 
10667. "And, if your excellency will allow me to express my opinion," he
10668. continued, "we owe today's success chiefly to the action of that battery
10669. and the heroic endurance of Captain Tushin and his company," and without
10670. awaiting a reply, Prince Andrew rose and left the table.
10671. 
10672. Prince Bagration looked at Tushin, evidently reluctant to show distrust
10673. in Bolkonski's emphatic opinion yet not feeling able fully to credit it,
10674. bent his head, and told Tushin that he could go. Prince Andrew went out
10675. with him.
10676. 
10677. "Thank you; you saved me, my dear fellow!" said Tushin.
10678. 
10679. Prince Andrew gave him a look, but said nothing and went away. He felt
10680. sad and depressed. It was all so strange, so unlike what he had hoped.
10681. 
10682. 
10683. "Who are they? Why are they here? What do they want? And when will all
10684. this end?" thought Rostov, looking at the changing shadows before
10685. him. The pain in his arm became more and more intense. Irresistible
10686. drowsiness overpowered him, red rings danced before his eyes, and the
10687. impression of those voices and faces and a sense of loneliness merged
10688. with the physical pain. It was they, these soldiers--wounded and
10689. unwounded--it was they who were crushing, weighing down, and twisting
10690. the sinews and scorching the flesh of his sprained arm and shoulder. To
10691. rid himself of them he closed his eyes.
10692. 
10693. For a moment he dozed, but in that short interval innumerable things
10694. appeared to him in a dream: his mother and her large white hand, Sonya's
10695. thin little shoulders, Natasha's eyes and laughter, Denisov with his
10696. voice and mustache, and Telyanin and all that affair with Telyanin and
10697. Bogdanich. That affair was the same thing as this soldier with the harsh
10698. voice, and it was that affair and this soldier that were so agonizingly,
10699. incessantly pulling and pressing his arm and always dragging it in one
10700. direction. He tried to get away from them, but they would not for an
10701. instant let his shoulder move a hair's breadth. It would not ache--it
10702. would be well--if only they did not pull it, but it was impossible to
10703. get rid of them.
10704. 
10705. He opened his eyes and looked up. The black canopy of night hung less
10706. than a yard above the glow of the charcoal. Flakes of falling snow were
10707. fluttering in that light. Tushin had not returned, the doctor had not
10708. come. He was alone now, except for a soldier who was sitting naked at
10709. the other side of the fire, warming his thin yellow body.
10710. 
10711. "Nobody wants me!" thought Rostov. "There is no one to help me or pity
10712. me. Yet I was once at home, strong, happy, and loved." He sighed and,
10713. doing so, groaned involuntarily.
10714. 
10715. "Eh, is anything hurting you?" asked the soldier, shaking his shirt out
10716. over the fire, and not waiting for an answer he gave a grunt and added:
10717. "What a lot of men have been crippled today--frightful!"
10718. 
10719. Rostov did not listen to the soldier. He looked at the snowflakes
10720. fluttering above the fire and remembered a Russian winter at his warm,
10721. bright home, his fluffy fur coat, his quickly gliding sleigh, his
10722. healthy body, and all the affection and care of his family. "And why did
10723. I come here?" he wondered.
10724. 
10725. Next day the French army did not renew their attack, and the remnant of
10726. Bagration's detachment was reunited to Kutuzov's army.
10727. 
10728. 
10729. 
10730. 
10731. 
10732. BOOK THREE: 1805
10733. 
10734. 
10735. 
10736. 
10737. 
10738. CHAPTER I
10739. 
10740. 
10741. Prince Vasili was not a man who deliberately thought out his plans.
10742. Still less did he think of injuring anyone for his own advantage. He
10743. was merely a man of the world who had got on and to whom getting on had
10744. become a habit. Schemes and devices for which he never rightly accounted
10745. to himself, but which formed the whole interest of his life,
10746. were constantly shaping themselves in his mind, arising from the
10747. circumstances and persons he met. Of these plans he had not merely one
10748. or two in his head but dozens, some only beginning to form themselves,
10749. some approaching achievement, and some in course of disintegration. He
10750. did not, for instance, say to himself: "This man now has influence, I
10751. must gain his confidence and friendship and through him obtain a special
10752. grant." Nor did he say to himself: "Pierre is a rich man, I must entice
10753. him to marry my daughter and lend me the forty thousand rubles I need."
10754. But when he came across a man of position his instinct immediately told
10755. him that this man could be useful, and without any premeditation Prince
10756. Vasili took the first opportunity to gain his confidence, flatter him,
10757. become intimate with him, and finally make his request.
10758. 
10759. He had Pierre at hand in Moscow and procured for him an appointment as
10760. Gentleman of the Bedchamber, which at that time conferred the status of
10761. Councilor of State, and insisted on the young man accompanying him to
10762. Petersburg and staying at his house. With apparent absent-mindedness,
10763. yet with unhesitating assurance that he was doing the right thing,
10764. Prince Vasili did everything to get Pierre to marry his daughter. Had he
10765. thought out his plans beforehand he could not have been so natural and
10766. shown such unaffected familiarity in intercourse with everybody both
10767. above and below him in social standing. Something always drew him toward
10768. those richer and more powerful than himself and he had rare skill in
10769. seizing the most opportune moment for making use of people.
10770. 
10771. Pierre, on unexpectedly becoming Count Bezukhov and a rich man, felt
10772. himself after his recent loneliness and freedom from cares so beset and
10773. preoccupied that only in bed was he able to be by himself. He had to
10774. sign papers, to present himself at government offices, the purpose of
10775. which was not clear to him, to question his chief steward, to visit his
10776. estate near Moscow, and to receive many people who formerly did not
10777. even wish to know of his existence but would now have been offended
10778. and grieved had he chosen not to see them. These different
10779. people--businessmen, relations, and acquaintances alike--were all
10780. disposed to treat the young heir in the most friendly and flattering
10781. manner: they were all evidently firmly convinced of Pierre's noble
10782. qualities. He was always hearing such words as: "With your remarkable
10783. kindness," or, "With your excellent heart," "You are yourself so
10784. honorable Count," or, "Were he as clever as you," and so on, till
10785. he began sincerely to believe in his own exceptional kindness and
10786. extraordinary intelligence, the more so as in the depth of his heart it
10787. had always seemed to him that he really was very kind and intelligent.
10788. Even people who had formerly been spiteful toward him and evidently
10789. unfriendly now became gentle and affectionate. The angry eldest
10790. princess, with the long waist and hair plastered down like a doll's,
10791. had come into Pierre's room after the funeral. With drooping eyes
10792. and frequent blushes she told him she was very sorry about their past
10793. misunderstandings and did not now feel she had a right to ask him for
10794. anything, except only for permission, after the blow she had received,
10795. to remain for a few weeks longer in the house she so loved and where
10796. she had sacrificed so much. She could not refrain from weeping at these
10797. words. Touched that this statuesque princess could so change, Pierre
10798. took her hand and begged her forgiveness, without knowing what for.
10799. From that day the eldest princess quite changed toward Pierre and began
10800. knitting a striped scarf for him.
10801. 
10802. "Do this for my sake, mon cher; after all, she had to put up with a
10803. great deal from the deceased," said Prince Vasili to him, handing him a
10804. deed to sign for the princess' benefit.
10805. 
10806. Prince Vasili had come to the conclusion that it was necessary to throw
10807. this bone--a bill for thirty thousand rubles--to the poor princess that
10808. it might not occur to her to speak of his share in the affair of the
10809. inlaid portfolio. Pierre signed the deed and after that the princess
10810. grew still kinder. The younger sisters also became affectionate to him,
10811. especially the youngest, the pretty one with the mole, who often made
10812. him feel confused by her smiles and her own confusion when meeting him.
10813. 
10814. It seemed so natural to Pierre that everyone should like him, and it
10815. would have seemed so unnatural had anyone disliked him, that he could
10816. not but believe in the sincerity of those around him. Besides, he had
10817. no time to ask himself whether these people were sincere or not. He
10818. was always busy and always felt in a state of mild and cheerful
10819. intoxication. He felt as though he were the center of some important and
10820. general movement; that something was constantly expected of him, that if
10821. he did not do it he would grieve and disappoint many people, but if he
10822. did this and that, all would be well; and he did what was demanded of
10823. him, but still that happy result always remained in the future.
10824. 
10825. More than anyone else, Prince Vasili took possession of Pierre's affairs
10826. and of Pierre himself in those early days. From the death of Count
10827. Bezukhov he did not let go his hold of the lad. He had the air of a
10828. man oppressed by business, weary and suffering, who yet would not, for
10829. pity's sake, leave this helpless youth who, after all, was the son of
10830. his old friend and the possessor of such enormous wealth, to the caprice
10831. of fate and the designs of rogues. During the few days he spent in
10832. Moscow after the death of Count Bezukhov, he would call Pierre, or go to
10833. him himself, and tell him what ought to be done in a tone of weariness
10834. and assurance, as if he were adding every time: "You know I am
10835. overwhelmed with business and it is purely out of charity that I trouble
10836. myself about you, and you also know quite well that what I propose is
10837. the only thing possible."
10838. 
10839. "Well, my dear fellow, tomorrow we are off at last," said Prince Vasili
10840. one day, closing his eyes and fingering Pierre's elbow, speaking as if
10841. he were saying something which had long since been agreed upon and could
10842. not now be altered. "We start tomorrow and I'm giving you a place in
10843. my carriage. I am very glad. All our important business here is now
10844. settled, and I ought to have been off long ago. Here is something I have
10845. received from the chancellor. I asked him for you, and you have been
10846. entered in the diplomatic corps and made a Gentleman of the Bedchamber.
10847. The diplomatic career now lies open before you."
10848. 
10849. Notwithstanding the tone of wearied assurance with which these words
10850. were pronounced, Pierre, who had so long been considering his career,
10851. wished to make some suggestion. But Prince Vasili interrupted him in the
10852. special deep cooing tone, precluding the possibility of interrupting
10853. his speech, which he used in extreme cases when special persuasion was
10854. needed.
10855. 
10856. "Mais, mon cher, I did this for my own sake, to satisfy my conscience,
10857. and there is nothing to thank me for. No one has ever complained yet of
10858. being too much loved; and besides, you are free, you could throw it
10859. up tomorrow. But you will see everything for yourself when you get to
10860. Petersburg. It is high time for you to get away from these terrible
10861. recollections." Prince Vasili sighed. "Yes, yes, my boy. And my valet
10862. can go in your carriage. Ah! I was nearly forgetting," he added. "You
10863. know, mon cher, your father and I had some accounts to settle, so I have
10864. received what was due from the Ryazan estate and will keep it; you won't
10865. require it. We'll go into the accounts later."
10866. 
10867. By "what was due from the Ryazan estate" Prince Vasili meant several
10868. thousand rubles quitrent received from Pierre's peasants, which the
10869. prince had retained for himself.
10870. 
10871. In Petersburg, as in Moscow, Pierre found the same atmosphere of
10872. gentleness and affection. He could not refuse the post, or rather the
10873. rank (for he did nothing), that Prince Vasili had procured for him,
10874. and acquaintances, invitations, and social occupations were so numerous
10875. that, even more than in Moscow, he felt a sense of bewilderment, bustle,
10876. and continual expectation of some good, always in front of him but never
10877. attained.
10878. 
10879. Of his former bachelor acquaintances many were no longer in Petersburg.
10880. The Guards had gone to the front; Dolokhov had been reduced to the
10881. ranks; Anatole was in the army somewhere in the provinces; Prince Andrew
10882. was abroad; so Pierre had not the opportunity to spend his nights as he
10883. used to like to spend them, or to open his mind by intimate talks with
10884. a friend older than himself and whom he respected. His whole time was
10885. taken up with dinners and balls and was spent chiefly at Prince Vasili's
10886. house in the company of the stout princess, his wife, and his beautiful
10887. daughter Helene.
10888. 
10889. Like the others, Anna Pavlovna Scherer showed Pierre the change of
10890. attitude toward him that had taken place in society.
10891. 
10892. Formerly in Anna Pavlovna's presence, Pierre had always felt that what
10893. he was saying was out of place, tactless and unsuitable, that remarks
10894. which seemed to him clever while they formed in his mind became foolish
10895. as soon as he uttered them, while on the contrary Hippolyte's stupidest
10896. remarks came out clever and apt. Now everything Pierre said was
10897. charmant. Even if Anna Pavlovna did not say so, he could see that she
10898. wished to and only refrained out of regard for his modesty.
10899. 
10900. In the beginning of the winter of 1805-6 Pierre received one of Anna
10901. Pavlovna's usual pink notes with an invitation to which was added: "You
10902. will find the beautiful Helene here, whom it is always delightful to
10903. see."
10904. 
10905. When he read that sentence, Pierre felt for the first time that some
10906. link which other people recognized had grown up between himself and
10907. Helene, and that thought both alarmed him, as if some obligation were
10908. being imposed on him which he could not fulfill, and pleased him as an
10909. entertaining supposition.
10910. 
10911. Anna Pavlovna's "At Home" was like the former one, only the novelty she
10912. offered her guests this time was not Mortemart, but a diplomatist fresh
10913. from Berlin with the very latest details of the Emperor Alexander's
10914. visit to Potsdam, and of how the two august friends had pledged
10915. themselves in an indissoluble alliance to uphold the cause of justice
10916. against the enemy of the human race. Anna Pavlovna received Pierre with
10917. a shade of melancholy, evidently relating to the young man's recent loss
10918. by the death of Count Bezukhov (everyone constantly considered it a
10919. duty to assure Pierre that he was greatly afflicted by the death of the
10920. father he had hardly known), and her melancholy was just like the august
10921. melancholy she showed at the mention of her most august Majesty the
10922. Empress Marya Fedorovna. Pierre felt flattered by this. Anna Pavlovna
10923. arranged the different groups in her drawing room with her habitual
10924. skill. The large group, in which were Prince Vasili and the generals,
10925. had the benefit of the diplomat. Another group was at the tea table.
10926. Pierre wished to join the former, but Anna Pavlovna--who was in the
10927. excited condition of a commander on a battlefield to whom thousands
10928. of new and brilliant ideas occur which there is hardly time to put in
10929. action--seeing Pierre, touched his sleeve with her finger, saying:
10930. 
10931. "Wait a bit, I have something in view for you this evening." (She
10932. glanced at Helene and smiled at her.) "My dear Helene, be charitable to
10933. my poor aunt who adores you. Go and keep her company for ten minutes.
10934. And that it will not be too dull, here is the dear count who will not
10935. refuse to accompany you."
10936. 
10937. The beauty went to the aunt, but Anna Pavlovna detained Pierre, looking
10938. as if she had to give some final necessary instructions.
10939. 
10940. "Isn't she exquisite?" she said to Pierre, pointing to the stately
10941. beauty as she glided away. "And how she carries herself! For so young a
10942. girl, such tact, such masterly perfection of manner! It comes from her
10943. heart. Happy the man who wins her! With her the least worldly of men
10944. would occupy a most brilliant position in society. Don't you think so? I
10945. only wanted to know your opinion," and Anna Pavlovna let Pierre go.
10946. 
10947. Pierre, in reply, sincerely agreed with her as to Helene's perfection of
10948. manner. If he ever thought of Helene, it was just of her beauty and her
10949. remarkable skill in appearing silently dignified in society.
10950. 
10951. The old aunt received the two young people in her corner, but seemed
10952. desirous of hiding her adoration for Helene and inclined rather to show
10953. her fear of Anna Pavlovna. She looked at her niece, as if inquiring what
10954. she was to do with these people. On leaving them, Anna Pavlovna again
10955. touched Pierre's sleeve, saying: "I hope you won't say that it is dull
10956. in my house again," and she glanced at Helene.
10957. 
10958. Helene smiled, with a look implying that she did not admit the
10959. possibility of anyone seeing her without being enchanted. The aunt
10960. coughed, swallowed, and said in French that she was very pleased to see
10961. Helene, then she turned to Pierre with the same words of welcome and
10962. the same look. In the middle of a dull and halting conversation, Helene
10963. turned to Pierre with the beautiful bright smile that she gave to
10964. everyone. Pierre was so used to that smile, and it had so little meaning
10965. for him, that he paid no attention to it. The aunt was just speaking of
10966. a collection of snuffboxes that had belonged to Pierre's father, Count
10967. Bezukhov, and showed them her own box. Princess Helene asked to see the
10968. portrait of the aunt's husband on the box lid.
10969. 
10970. "That is probably the work of Vinesse," said Pierre, mentioning a
10971. celebrated miniaturist, and he leaned over the table to take the
10972. snuffbox while trying to hear what was being said at the other table.
10973. 
10974. He half rose, meaning to go round, but the aunt handed him the snuffbox,
10975. passing it across Helene's back. Helene stooped forward to make room,
10976. and looked round with a smile. She was, as always at evening parties,
10977. wearing a dress such as was then fashionable, cut very low at front and
10978. back. Her bust, which had always seemed like marble to Pierre, was
10979. so close to him that his shortsighted eyes could not but perceive the
10980. living charm of her neck and shoulders, so near to his lips that he need
10981. only have bent his head a little to have touched them. He was conscious
10982. of the warmth of her body, the scent of perfume, and the creaking of her
10983. corset as she moved. He did not see her marble beauty forming a complete
10984. whole with her dress, but all the charm of her body only covered by her
10985. garments. And having once seen this he could not help being aware of it,
10986. just as we cannot renew an illusion we have once seen through.
10987. 
10988. "So you have never noticed before how beautiful I am?" Helene seemed to
10989. say. "You had not noticed that I am a woman? Yes, I am a woman who
10990. may belong to anyone--to you too," said her glance. And at that moment
10991. Pierre felt that Helene not only could, but must, be his wife, and that
10992. it could not be otherwise.
10993. 
10994. He knew this at that moment as surely as if he had been standing at the
10995. altar with her. How and when this would be he did not know, he did not
10996. even know if it would be a good thing (he even felt, he knew not why,
10997. that it would be a bad thing), but he knew it would happen.
10998. 
10999. Pierre dropped his eyes, lifted them again, and wished once more to see
11000. her as a distant beauty far removed from him, as he had seen her every
11001. day until then, but he could no longer do it. He could not, any more
11002. than a man who has been looking at a tuft of steppe grass through the
11003. mist and taking it for a tree can again take it for a tree after he has
11004. once recognized it to be a tuft of grass. She was terribly close to him.
11005. She already had power over him, and between them there was no longer any
11006. barrier except the barrier of his own will.
11007. 
11008. "Well, I will leave you in your little corner," came Anna Pavlovna's
11009. voice, "I see you are all right there."
11010. 
11011. And Pierre, anxiously trying to remember whether he had done anything
11012. reprehensible, looked round with a blush. It seemed to him that everyone
11013. knew what had happened to him as he knew it himself.
11014. 
11015. A little later when he went up to the large circle, Anna Pavlovna said
11016. to him: "I hear you are refitting your Petersburg house?"
11017. 
11018. This was true. The architect had told him that it was necessary, and
11019. Pierre, without knowing why, was having his enormous Petersburg house
11020. done up.
11021. 
11022. "That's a good thing, but don't move from Prince Vasili's. It is good to
11023. have a friend like the prince," she said, smiling at Prince Vasili. "I
11024. know something about that. Don't I? And you are still so young. You need
11025. advice. Don't be angry with me for exercising an old woman's privilege."
11026. 
11027. She paused, as women always do, expecting something after they have
11028. mentioned their age. "If you marry it will be a different thing," she
11029. continued, uniting them both in one glance. Pierre did not look at
11030. Helene nor she at him. But she was just as terribly close to him. He
11031. muttered something and colored.
11032. 
11033. When he got home he could not sleep for a long time for thinking of what
11034. had happened. What had happened? Nothing. He had merely understood that
11035. the woman he had known as a child, of whom when her beauty was
11036. mentioned he had said absent-mindedly: "Yes, she's good looking," he had
11037. understood that this woman might belong to him.
11038. 
11039. "But she's stupid. I have myself said she is stupid," he thought. "There
11040. is something nasty, something wrong, in the feeling she excites in me.
11041. I have been told that her brother Anatole was in love with her and she
11042. with him, that there was quite a scandal and that that's why he was sent
11043. away. Hippolyte is her brother... Prince Vasili is her father... It's
11044. bad...." he reflected, but while he was thinking this (the reflection
11045. was still incomplete), he caught himself smiling and was conscious
11046. that another line of thought had sprung up, and while thinking of her
11047. worthlessness he was also dreaming of how she would be his wife, how she
11048. would love him become quite different, and how all he had thought and
11049. heard of her might be false. And he again saw her not as the daughter
11050. of Prince Vasili, but visualized her whole body only veiled by its gray
11051. dress. "But no! Why did this thought never occur to me before?" and
11052. again he told himself that it was impossible, that there would be
11053. something unnatural, and as it seemed to him dishonorable, in this
11054. marriage. He recalled her former words and looks and the words and looks
11055. of those who had seen them together. He recalled Anna Pavlovna's words
11056. and looks when she spoke to him about his house, recalled thousands of
11057. such hints from Prince Vasili and others, and was seized by terror lest
11058. he had already, in some way, bound himself to do something that was
11059. evidently wrong and that he ought not to do. But at the very time he was
11060. expressing this conviction to himself, in another part of his mind her
11061. image rose in all its womanly beauty.
11062. 
11063. 
11064. 
11065. 
11066. 
11067. CHAPTER II
11068. 
11069. 
11070. In November, 1805, Prince Vasili had to go on a tour of inspection in
11071. four different provinces. He had arranged this for himself so as to
11072. visit his neglected estates at the same time and pick up his son Anatole
11073. where his regiment was stationed, and take him to visit Prince Nicholas
11074. Bolkonski in order to arrange a match for him with the daughter of that
11075. rich old man. But before leaving home and undertaking these new affairs,
11076. Prince Vasili had to settle matters with Pierre, who, it is true, had
11077. latterly spent whole days at home, that is, in Prince Vasili's house
11078. where he was staying, and had been absurd, excited, and foolish in
11079. Helene's presence (as a lover should be), but had not yet proposed to
11080. her.
11081. 
11082. "This is all very fine, but things must be settled," said Prince Vasili
11083. to himself, with a sorrowful sigh, one morning, feeling that Pierre
11084. who was under such obligations to him ("But never mind that") was not
11085. behaving very well in this matter. "Youth, frivolity... well, God be
11086. with him," thought he, relishing his own goodness of heart, "but it must
11087. be brought to a head. The day after tomorrow will be Lelya's name day.
11088. I will invite two or three people, and if he does not understand what he
11089. ought to do then it will be my affair--yes, my affair. I am her father."
11090. 
11091. Six weeks after Anna Pavlovna's "At Home" and after the sleepless night
11092. when he had decided that to marry Helene would be a calamity and that he
11093. ought to avoid her and go away, Pierre, despite that decision, had not
11094. left Prince Vasili's and felt with terror that in people's eyes he was
11095. every day more and more connected with her, that it was impossible for
11096. him to return to his former conception of her, that he could not break
11097. away from her, and that though it would be a terrible thing he would
11098. have to unite his fate with hers. He might perhaps have been able
11099. to free himself but that Prince Vasili (who had rarely before given
11100. receptions) now hardly let a day go by without having an evening party
11101. at which Pierre had to be present unless he wished to spoil the general
11102. pleasure and disappoint everyone's expectation. Prince Vasili, in the
11103. rare moments when he was at home, would take Pierre's hand in passing
11104. and draw it downwards, or absent-mindedly hold out his wrinkled,
11105. clean-shaven cheek for Pierre to kiss and would say: "Till tomorrow,"
11106. or, "Be in to dinner or I shall not see you," or, "I am staying in for
11107. your sake," and so on. And though Prince Vasili, when he stayed in (as
11108. he said) for Pierre's sake, hardly exchanged a couple of words with him,
11109. Pierre felt unable to disappoint him. Every day he said to himself one
11110. and the same thing: "It is time I understood her and made up my mind
11111. what she really is. Was I mistaken before, or am I mistaken now? No, she
11112. is not stupid, she is an excellent girl," he sometimes said to himself
11113. "she never makes a mistake, never says anything stupid. She says little,
11114. but what she does say is always clear and simple, so she is not stupid.
11115. She never was abashed and is not abashed now, so she cannot be a bad
11116. woman!" He had often begun to make reflections or think aloud in
11117. her company, and she had always answered him either by a brief but
11118. appropriate remark--showing that it did not interest her--or by a silent
11119. look and smile which more palpably than anything else showed Pierre her
11120. superiority. She was right in regarding all arguments as nonsense in
11121. comparison with that smile.
11122. 
11123. She always addressed him with a radiantly confiding smile meant for him
11124. alone, in which there was something more significant than in the general
