11125. smile that usually brightened her face. Pierre knew that everyone was
11126. waiting for him to say a word and cross a certain line, and he knew that
11127. sooner or later he would step across it, but an incomprehensible terror
11128. seized him at the thought of that dreadful step. A thousand times during
11129. that month and a half while he felt himself drawn nearer and nearer to
11130. that dreadful abyss, Pierre said to himself: "What am I doing? I need
11131. resolution. Can it be that I have none?"
11132. 
11133. He wished to take a decision, but felt with dismay that in this matter
11134. he lacked that strength of will which he had known in himself and really
11135. possessed. Pierre was one of those who are only strong when they feel
11136. themselves quite innocent, and since that day when he was overpowered by
11137. a feeling of desire while stooping over the snuffbox at Anna Pavlovna's,
11138. an unacknowledged sense of the guilt of that desire paralyzed his will.
11139. 
11140. On Helene's name day, a small party of just their own people--as his
11141. wife said--met for supper at Prince Vasili's. All these friends and
11142. relations had been given to understand that the fate of the young girl
11143. would be decided that evening. The visitors were seated at supper.
11144. Princess Kuragina, a portly imposing woman who had once been handsome,
11145. was sitting at the head of the table. On either side of her sat the
11146. more important guests--an old general and his wife, and Anna Pavlovna
11147. Scherer. At the other end sat the younger and less important guests, and
11148. there too sat the members of the family, and Pierre and Helene, side by
11149. side. Prince Vasili was not having any supper: he went round the table
11150. in a merry mood, sitting down now by one, now by another, of the guests.
11151. To each of them he made some careless and agreeable remark except to
11152. Pierre and Helene, whose presence he seemed not to notice. He enlivened
11153. the whole party. The wax candles burned brightly, the silver and crystal
11154. gleamed, so did the ladies' toilets and the gold and silver of the
11155. men's epaulets; servants in scarlet liveries moved round the table, the
11156. clatter of plates, knives, and glasses mingled with the animated hum of
11157. several conversations. At one end of the table, the old chamberlain was
11158. heard assuring an old baroness that he loved her passionately, at which
11159. she laughed; at the other could be heard the story of the misfortunes of
11160. some Mary Viktorovna or other. At the center of the table, Prince Vasili
11161. attracted everybody's attention. With a facetious smile on his face, he
11162. was telling the ladies about last Wednesday's meeting of the Imperial
11163. Council, at which Sergey Kuzmich Vyazmitinov, the new military governor
11164. general of Petersburg, had received and read the then famous rescript
11165. of the Emperor Alexander from the army to Sergey Kuzmich, in which the
11166. Emperor said that he was receiving from all sides declarations of
11167. the people's loyalty, that the declaration from Petersburg gave him
11168. particular pleasure, and that he was proud to be at the head of such a
11169. nation and would endeavor to be worthy of it. This rescript began with
11170. the words: "Sergey Kuzmich, From all sides reports reach me," etc.
11171. 
11172. "Well, and so he never got farther than: 'Sergey Kuzmich'?" asked one of
11173. the ladies.
11174. 
11175. "Exactly, not a hair's breadth farther," answered Prince Vasili,
11176. laughing, "'Sergey Kuzmich... From all sides... From all sides... Sergey
11177. Kuzmich...' Poor Vyazmitinov could not get any farther! He began the
11178. rescript again and again, but as soon as he uttered 'Sergey' he sobbed,
11179. 'Kuz-mi-ch,' tears, and 'From all sides' was smothered in sobs and he
11180. could get no farther. And again his handkerchief, and again: 'Sergey
11181. Kuzmich, From all sides,'... and tears, till at last somebody else was
11182. asked to read it."
11183. 
11184. "Kuzmich... From all sides... and then tears," someone repeated
11185. laughing.
11186. 
11187. "Don't be unkind," cried Anna Pavlovna from her end of the table holding
11188. up a threatening finger. "He is such a worthy and excellent man, our
11189. dear Vyazmitinov...."
11190. 
11191. Everybody laughed a great deal. At the head of the table, where the
11192. honored guests sat, everyone seemed to be in high spirits and under the
11193. influence of a variety of exciting sensations. Only Pierre and
11194. Helene sat silently side by side almost at the bottom of the table, a
11195. suppressed smile brightening both their faces, a smile that had nothing
11196. to do with Sergey Kuzmich--a smile of bashfulness at their own feelings.
11197. But much as all the rest laughed, talked, and joked, much as they
11198. enjoyed their Rhine wine, saute, and ices, and however they avoided
11199. looking at the young couple, and heedless and unobservant as they seemed
11200. of them, one could feel by the occasional glances they gave that the
11201. story about Sergey Kuzmich, the laughter, and the food were all a
11202. pretense, and that the whole attention of that company was directed
11203. to--Pierre and Helene. Prince Vasili mimicked the sobbing of Sergey
11204. Kuzmich and at the same time his eyes glanced toward his daughter, and
11205. while he laughed the expression on his face clearly said: "Yes... it's
11206. getting on, it will all be settled today." Anna Pavlovna threatened
11207. him on behalf of "our dear Vyazmitinov," and in her eyes, which, for an
11208. instant, glanced at Pierre, Prince Vasili read a congratulation on his
11209. future son-in-law and on his daughter's happiness. The old princess
11210. sighed sadly as she offered some wine to the old lady next to her and
11211. glanced angrily at her daughter, and her sigh seemed to say: "Yes,
11212. there's nothing left for you and me but to sip sweet wine, my dear,
11213. now that the time has come for these young ones to be thus boldly,
11214. provocatively happy." "And what nonsense all this is that I am saying!"
11215. thought a diplomatist, glancing at the happy faces of the lovers.
11216. "That's happiness!"
11217. 
11218. Into the insignificant, trifling, and artificial interests uniting that
11219. society had entered the simple feeling of the attraction of a healthy
11220. and handsome young man and woman for one another. And this human feeling
11221. dominated everything else and soared above all their affected chatter.
11222. Jests fell flat, news was not interesting, and the animation was
11223. evidently forced. Not only the guests but even the footmen waiting at
11224. table seemed to feel this, and they forgot their duties as they looked
11225. at the beautiful Helene with her radiant face and at the red, broad, and
11226. happy though uneasy face of Pierre. It seemed as if the very light of
11227. the candles was focused on those two happy faces alone.
11228. 
11229. Pierre felt that he was the center of it all, and this both pleased and
11230. embarrassed him. He was like a man entirely absorbed in some occupation.
11231. He did not see, hear, or understand anything clearly. Only now and
11232. then detached ideas and impressions from the world of reality shot
11233. unexpectedly through his mind.
11234. 
11235. "So it is all finished!" he thought. "And how has it all happened? How
11236. quickly! Now I know that not because of her alone, nor of myself alone,
11237. but because of everyone, it must inevitably come about. They are all
11238. expecting it, they are so sure that it will happen that I cannot, I
11239. cannot, disappoint them. But how will it be? I do not know, but it will
11240. certainly happen!" thought Pierre, glancing at those dazzling shoulders
11241. close to his eyes.
11242. 
11243. Or he would suddenly feel ashamed of he knew not what. He felt it
11244. awkward to attract everyone's attention and to be considered a lucky man
11245. and, with his plain face, to be looked on as a sort of Paris possessed
11246. of a Helen. "But no doubt it always is and must be so!" he consoled
11247. himself. "And besides, what have I done to bring it about? How did
11248. it begin? I traveled from Moscow with Prince Vasili. Then there was
11249. nothing. So why should I not stay at his house? Then I played cards with
11250. her and picked up her reticule and drove out with her. How did it begin,
11251. when did it all come about?" And here he was sitting by her side as her
11252. betrothed, seeing, hearing, feeling her nearness, her breathing, her
11253. movements, her beauty. Then it would suddenly seem to him that it was
11254. not she but he was so unusually beautiful, and that that was why they
11255. all looked so at him, and flattered by this general admiration he would
11256. expand his chest, raise his head, and rejoice at his good fortune.
11257. Suddenly he heard a familiar voice repeating something to him a second
11258. time. But Pierre was so absorbed that he did not understand what was
11259. said.
11260. 
11261. "I am asking you when you last heard from Bolkonski," repeated Prince
11262. Vasili a third time. "How absent-minded you are, my dear fellow."
11263. 
11264. Prince Vasili smiled, and Pierre noticed that everyone was smiling at
11265. him and Helene. "Well, what of it, if you all know it?" thought Pierre.
11266. "What of it? It's the truth!" and he himself smiled his gentle childlike
11267. smile, and Helene smiled too.
11268. 
11269. "When did you get the letter? Was it from Olmutz?" repeated Prince
11270. Vasili, who pretended to want to know this in order to settle a dispute.
11271. 
11272. "How can one talk or think of such trifles?" thought Pierre.
11273. 
11274. "Yes, from Olmutz," he answered, with a sigh.
11275. 
11276. After supper Pierre with his partner followed the others into the
11277. drawing room. The guests began to disperse, some without taking leave
11278. of Helene. Some, as if unwilling to distract her from an important
11279. occupation, came up to her for a moment and made haste to go away,
11280. refusing to let her see them off. The diplomatist preserved a mournful
11281. silence as he left the drawing room. He pictured the vanity of his
11282. diplomatic career in comparison with Pierre's happiness. The old general
11283. grumbled at his wife when she asked how his leg was. "Oh, the old fool,"
11284. he thought. "That Princess Helene will be beautiful still when she's
11285. fifty."
11286. 
11287. "I think I may congratulate you," whispered Anna Pavlovna to the old
11288. princess, kissing her soundly. "If I hadn't this headache I'd have
11289. stayed longer."
11290. 
11291. The old princess did not reply, she was tormented by jealousy of her
11292. daughter's happiness.
11293. 
11294. While the guests were taking their leave Pierre remained for a long time
11295. alone with Helene in the little drawing room where they were sitting.
11296. He had often before, during the last six weeks, remained alone with her,
11297. but had never spoken to her of love. Now he felt that it was inevitable,
11298. but he could not make up his mind to take the final step. He felt
11299. ashamed; he felt that he was occupying someone else's place here beside
11300. Helene. "This happiness is not for you," some inner voice whispered to
11301. him. "This happiness is for those who have not in them what there is in
11302. you."
11303. 
11304. But, as he had to say something, he began by asking her whether she was
11305. satisfied with the party. She replied in her usual simple manner that
11306. this name day of hers had been one of the pleasantest she had ever had.
11307. 
11308. Some of the nearest relatives had not yet left. They were sitting in
11309. the large drawing room. Prince Vasili came up to Pierre with languid
11310. footsteps. Pierre rose and said it was getting late. Prince Vasili gave
11311. him a look of stern inquiry, as though what Pierre had just said was
11312. so strange that one could not take it in. But then the expression of
11313. severity changed, and he drew Pierre's hand downwards, made him sit
11314. down, and smiled affectionately.
11315. 
11316. "Well, Lelya?" he asked, turning instantly to his daughter and
11317. addressing her with the careless tone of habitual tenderness natural to
11318. parents who have petted their children from babyhood, but which Prince
11319. Vasili had only acquired by imitating other parents.
11320. 
11321. And he again turned to Pierre.
11322. 
11323. "Sergey Kuzmich--From all sides-" he said, unbuttoning the top button of
11324. his waistcoat.
11325. 
11326. Pierre smiled, but his smile showed that he knew it was not the story
11327. about Sergey Kuzmich that interested Prince Vasili just then, and Prince
11328. Vasili saw that Pierre knew this. He suddenly muttered something and
11329. went away. It seemed to Pierre that even the prince was disconcerted.
11330. The sight of the discomposure of that old man of the world touched
11331. Pierre: he looked at Helene and she too seemed disconcerted, and her
11332. look seemed to say: "Well, it is your own fault."
11333. 
11334. "The step must be taken but I cannot, I cannot!" thought Pierre, and he
11335. again began speaking about indifferent matters, about Sergey Kuzmich,
11336. asking what the point of the story was as he had not heard it properly.
11337. Helene answered with a smile that she too had missed it.
11338. 
11339. When Prince Vasili returned to the drawing room, the princess, his wife,
11340. was talking in low tones to the elderly lady about Pierre.
11341. 
11342. "Of course, it is a very brilliant match, but happiness, my dear..."
11343. 
11344. "Marriages are made in heaven," replied the elderly lady.
11345. 
11346. Prince Vasili passed by, seeming not to hear the ladies, and sat down on
11347. a sofa in a far corner of the room. He closed his eyes and seemed to be
11348. dozing. His head sank forward and then he roused himself.
11349. 
11350. "Aline," he said to his wife, "go and see what they are about."
11351. 
11352. The princess went up to the door, passed by it with a dignified and
11353. indifferent air, and glanced into the little drawing room. Pierre and
11354. Helene still sat talking just as before.
11355. 
11356. "Still the same," she said to her husband.
11357. 
11358. Prince Vasili frowned, twisting his mouth, his cheeks quivered and his
11359. face assumed the coarse, unpleasant expression peculiar to him. Shaking
11360. himself, he rose, threw back his head, and with resolute steps went
11361. past the ladies into the little drawing room. With quick steps he went
11362. joyfully up to Pierre. His face was so unusually triumphant that Pierre
11363. rose in alarm on seeing it.
11364. 
11365. "Thank God!" said Prince Vasili. "My wife has told me everything!" (He
11366. put one arm around Pierre and the other around his daughter.)--"My dear
11367. boy... Lelya... I am very pleased." (His voice trembled.) "I loved your
11368. father... and she will make you a good wife... God bless you!..."
11369. 
11370. He embraced his daughter, and then again Pierre, and kissed him with his
11371. malodorous mouth. Tears actually moistened his cheeks.
11372. 
11373. "Princess, come here!" he shouted.
11374. 
11375. The old princess came in and also wept. The elderly lady was using
11376. her handkerchief too. Pierre was kissed, and he kissed the beautiful
11377. Helene's hand several times. After a while they were left alone again.
11378. 
11379. "All this had to be and could not be otherwise," thought Pierre, "so
11380. it is useless to ask whether it is good or bad. It is good because it's
11381. definite and one is rid of the old tormenting doubt." Pierre held the
11382. hand of his betrothed in silence, looking at her beautiful bosom as it
11383. rose and fell.
11384. 
11385. "Helene!" he said aloud and paused.
11386. 
11387. "Something special is always said in such cases," he thought, but could
11388. not remember what it was that people say. He looked at her face. She
11389. drew nearer to him. Her face flushed.
11390. 
11391. "Oh, take those off... those..." she said, pointing to his spectacles.
11392. 
11393. Pierre took them off, and his eyes, besides the strange look eyes have
11394. from which spectacles have just been removed, had also a frightened and
11395. inquiring look. He was about to stoop over her hand and kiss it, but
11396. with a rapid, almost brutal movement of her head, she intercepted his
11397. lips and met them with her own. Her face struck Pierre, by its altered,
11398. unpleasantly excited expression.
11399. 
11400. "It is too late now, it's done; besides I love her," thought Pierre.
11401. 
11402. "Je vous aime!" * he said, remembering what has to be said at such
11403. moments: but his words sounded so weak that he felt ashamed of himself.
11404. 
11405. 
11406.     * "I love you."
11407. 
11408. 
11409. Six weeks later he was married, and settled in Count Bezukhov's large,
11410. newly furnished Petersburg house, the happy possessor, as people said,
11411. of a wife who was a celebrated beauty and of millions of money.
11412. 
11413. 
11414. 
11415. 
11416. 
11417. CHAPTER III
11418. 
11419. 
11420. Old Prince Nicholas Bolkonski received a letter from Prince Vasili in
11421. November, 1805, announcing that he and his son would be paying him a
11422. visit. "I am starting on a journey of inspection, and of course I shall
11423. think nothing of an extra seventy miles to come and see you at the same
11424. time, my honored benefactor," wrote Prince Vasili. "My son Anatole is
11425. accompanying me on his way to the army, so I hope you will allow him
11426. personally to express the deep respect that, emulating his father, he
11427. feels for you."
11428. 
11429. "It seems that there will be no need to bring Mary out, suitors are
11430. coming to us of their own accord," incautiously remarked the little
11431. princess on hearing the news.
11432. 
11433. Prince Nicholas frowned, but said nothing.
11434. 
11435. A fortnight after the letter Prince Vasili's servants came one evening
11436. in advance of him, and he and his son arrived next day.
11437. 
11438. Old Bolkonski had always had a poor opinion of Prince Vasili's
11439. character, but more so recently, since in the new reigns of Paul and
11440. Alexander Prince Vasili had risen to high position and honors. And now,
11441. from the hints contained in his letter and given by the little princess,
11442. he saw which way the wind was blowing, and his low opinion changed into
11443. a feeling of contemptuous ill will. He snorted whenever he mentioned
11444. him. On the day of Prince Vasili's arrival, Prince Bolkonski was
11445. particularly discontented and out of temper. Whether he was in a bad
11446. temper because Prince Vasili was coming, or whether his being in a bad
11447. temper made him specially annoyed at Prince Vasili's visit, he was in a
11448. bad temper, and in the morning Tikhon had already advised the architect
11449. not to go to the prince with his report.
11450. 
11451. "Do you hear how he's walking?" said Tikhon, drawing the architect's
11452. attention to the sound of the prince's footsteps. "Stepping flat on his
11453. heels--we know what that means...."
11454. 
11455. However, at nine o'clock the prince, in his velvet coat with a sable
11456. collar and cap, went out for his usual walk. It had snowed the day
11457. before and the path to the hothouse, along which the prince was in the
11458. habit of walking, had been swept: the marks of the broom were still
11459. visible in the snow and a shovel had been left sticking in one of the
11460. soft snowbanks that bordered both sides of the path. The prince went
11461. through the conservatories, the serfs' quarters, and the outbuildings,
11462. frowning and silent.
11463. 
11464. "Can a sleigh pass?" he asked his overseer, a venerable man, resembling
11465. his master in manners and looks, who was accompanying him back to the
11466. house.
11467. 
11468. "The snow is deep. I am having the avenue swept, your honor."
11469. 
11470. The prince bowed his head and went up to the porch. "God be thanked,"
11471. thought the overseer, "the storm has blown over!"
11472. 
11473. "It would have been hard to drive up, your honor," he added. "I heard,
11474. your honor, that a minister is coming to visit your honor."
11475. 
11476. The prince turned round to the overseer and fixed his eyes on him,
11477. frowning.
11478. 
11479. "What? A minister? What minister? Who gave orders?" he said in his
11480. shrill, harsh voice. "The road is not swept for the princess my
11481. daughter, but for a minister! For me, there are no ministers!"
11482. 
11483. "Your honor, I thought..."
11484. 
11485. "You thought!" shouted the prince, his words coming more and more
11486. rapidly and indistinctly. "You thought!... Rascals! Blackguards!... I'll
11487. teach you to think!" and lifting his stick he swung it and would have
11488. hit Alpatych, the overseer, had not the latter instinctively avoided the
11489. blow. "Thought... Blackguards..." shouted the prince rapidly.
11490. 
11491. But although Alpatych, frightened at his own temerity in avoiding the
11492. stroke, came up to the prince, bowing his bald head resignedly before
11493. him, or perhaps for that very reason, the prince, though he continued to
11494. shout: "Blackguards!... Throw the snow back on the road!" did not lift
11495. his stick again but hurried into the house.
11496. 
11497. Before dinner, Princess Mary and Mademoiselle Bourienne, who knew
11498. that the prince was in a bad humor, stood awaiting him; Mademoiselle
11499. Bourienne with a radiant face that said: "I know nothing, I am the same
11500. as usual," and Princess Mary pale, frightened, and with downcast eyes.
11501. What she found hardest to bear was to know that on such occasions she
11502. ought to behave like Mademoiselle Bourienne, but could not. She thought:
11503. "If I seem not to notice he will think that I do not sympathize with
11504. him; if I seem sad and out of spirits myself, he will say (as he has
11505. done before) that I'm in the dumps."
11506. 
11507. The prince looked at his daughter's frightened face and snorted.
11508. 
11509. "Fool... or dummy!" he muttered.
11510. 
11511. "And the other one is not here. They've been telling tales," he
11512. thought--referring to the little princess who was not in the dining
11513. room.
11514. 
11515. "Where is the princess?" he asked. "Hiding?"
11516. 
11517. "She is not very well," answered Mademoiselle Bourienne with a bright
11518. smile, "so she won't come down. It is natural in her state."
11519. 
11520. "Hm! Hm!" muttered the prince, sitting down.
11521. 
11522. His plate seemed to him not quite clean, and pointing to a spot he
11523. flung it away. Tikhon caught it and handed it to a footman. The little
11524. princess was not unwell, but had such an overpowering fear of the prince
11525. that, hearing he was in a bad humor, she had decided not to appear.
11526. 
11527. "I am afraid for the baby," she said to Mademoiselle Bourienne: "Heaven
11528. knows what a fright might do."
11529. 
11530. In general at Bald Hills the little princess lived in constant fear, and
11531. with a sense of antipathy to the old prince which she did not
11532. realize because the fear was so much the stronger feeling. The prince
11533. reciprocated this antipathy, but it was overpowered by his contempt
11534. for her. When the little princess had grown accustomed to life at Bald
11535. Hills, she took a special fancy to Mademoiselle Bourienne, spent whole
11536. days with her, asked her to sleep in her room, and often talked with her
11537. about the old prince and criticized him.
11538. 
11539. "So we are to have visitors, mon prince?" remarked Mademoiselle
11540. Bourienne, unfolding her white napkin with her rosy fingers. "His
11541. Excellency Prince Vasili Kuragin and his son, I understand?" she said
11542. inquiringly.
11543. 
11544. "Hm!--his excellency is a puppy.... I got him his appointment in the
11545. service," said the prince disdainfully. "Why his son is coming I don't
11546. understand. Perhaps Princess Elizabeth and Princess Mary know. I don't
11547. want him." (He looked at his blushing daughter.) "Are you unwell today?
11548. Eh? Afraid of the 'minister' as that idiot Alpatych called him this
11549. morning?"
11550. 
11551. "No, mon pere."
11552. 
11553. Though Mademoiselle Bourienne had been so unsuccessful in her choice
11554. of a subject, she did not stop talking, but chattered about the
11555. conservatories and the beauty of a flower that had just opened, and
11556. after the soup the prince became more genial.
11557. 
11558. After dinner, he went to see his daughter-in-law. The little princess
11559. was sitting at a small table, chattering with Masha, her maid. She grew
11560. pale on seeing her father-in-law.
11561. 
11562. She was much altered. She was now plain rather than pretty. Her cheeks
11563. had sunk, her lip was drawn up, and her eyes drawn down.
11564. 
11565. "Yes, I feel a kind of oppression," she said in reply to the prince's
11566. question as to how she felt.
11567. 
11568. "Do you want anything?"
11569. 
11570. "No, merci, mon pere."
11571. 
11572. "Well, all right, all right."
11573. 
11574. He left the room and went to the waiting room where Alpatych stood with
11575. bowed head.
11576. 
11577. "Has the snow been shoveled back?"
11578. 
11579. "Yes, your excellency. Forgive me for heaven's sake... It was only my
11580. stupidity."
11581. 
11582. "All right, all right," interrupted the prince, and laughing his
11583. unnatural way, he stretched out his hand for Alpatych to kiss, and then
11584. proceeded to his study.
11585. 
11586. Prince Vasili arrived that evening. He was met in the avenue by coachmen
11587. and footmen, who, with loud shouts, dragged his sleighs up to one of the
11588. lodges over the road purposely laden with snow.
11589. 
11590. Prince Vasili and Anatole had separate rooms assigned to them.
11591. 
11592. Anatole, having taken off his overcoat, sat with arms akimbo before a
11593. table on a corner of which he smilingly and absent-mindedly fixed his
11594. large and handsome eyes. He regarded his whole life as a continual round
11595. of amusement which someone for some reason had to provide for him.
11596. And he looked on this visit to a churlish old man and a rich and ugly
11597. heiress in the same way. All this might, he thought, turn out very well
11598. and amusingly. "And why not marry her if she really has so much money?
11599. That never does any harm," thought Anatole.
11600. 
11601. He shaved and scented himself with the care and elegance which had
11602. become habitual to him and, his handsome head held high, entered his
11603. father's room with the good-humored and victorious air natural to him.
11604. Prince Vasili's two valets were busy dressing him, and he looked round
11605. with much animation and cheerfully nodded to his son as the latter
11606. entered, as if to say: "Yes, that's how I want you to look."
11607. 
11608. "I say, Father, joking apart, is she very hideous?" Anatole asked, as if
11609. continuing a conversation the subject of which had often been mentioned
11610. during the journey.
11611. 
11612. "Enough! What nonsense! Above all, try to be respectful and cautious
11613. with the old prince."
11614. 
11615. "If he starts a row I'll go away," said Prince Anatole. "I can't bear
11616. those old men! Eh?"
11617. 
11618. "Remember, for you everything depends on this."
11619. 
11620. In the meantime, not only was it known in the maidservants' rooms that
11621. the minister and his son had arrived, but the appearance of both had
11622. been minutely described. Princess Mary was sitting alone in her room,
11623. vainly trying to master her agitation.
11624. 
11625. "Why did they write, why did Lise tell me about it? It can never
11626. happen!" she said, looking at herself in the glass. "How shall I enter
11627. the drawing room? Even if I like him I can't now be myself with him."
11628. The mere thought of her father's look filled her with terror. The little
11629. princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne had already received from Masha,
11630. the lady's maid, the necessary report of how handsome the minister's son
11631. was, with his rosy cheeks and dark eyebrows, and with what difficulty
11632. the father had dragged his legs upstairs while the son had followed him
11633. like an eagle, three steps at a time. Having received this information,
11634. the little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne, whose chattering voices
11635. had reached her from the corridor, went into Princess Mary's room.
11636. 
11637. "You know they've come, Marie?" said the little princess, waddling in,
11638. and sinking heavily into an armchair.
11639. 
11640. She was no longer in the loose gown she generally wore in the morning,
11641. but had on one of her best dresses. Her hair was carefully done and her
11642. face was animated, which, however, did not conceal its sunken and faded
11643. outlines. Dressed as she used to be in Petersburg society, it was still
11644. more noticeable how much plainer she had become. Some unobtrusive touch
11645. had been added to Mademoiselle Bourienne's toilet which rendered her
11646. fresh and pretty face yet more attractive.
11647. 
11648. "What! Are you going to remain as you are, dear princess?" she began.
11649. "They'll be announcing that the gentlemen are in the drawing room and we
11650. shall have to go down, and you have not smartened yourself up at all!"
11651. 
11652. The little princess got up, rang for the maid, and hurriedly and merrily
11653. began to devise and carry out a plan of how Princess Mary should be
11654. dressed. Princess Mary's self-esteem was wounded by the fact that
11655. the arrival of a suitor agitated her, and still more so by both her
11656. companions' not having the least conception that it could be otherwise.
11657. To tell them that she felt ashamed for herself and for them would be to
11658. betray her agitation, while to decline their offers to dress her would
11659. prolong their banter and insistence. She flushed, her beautiful eyes
11660. grew dim, red blotches came on her face, and it took on the unattractive
11661. martyrlike expression it so often wore, as she submitted herself to
11662. Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise. Both these women quite sincerely tried
11663. to make her look pretty. She was so plain that neither of them could
11664. think of her as a rival, so they began dressing her with perfect
11665. sincerity, and with the naive and firm conviction women have that dress
11666. can make a face pretty.
11667. 
11668. "No really, my dear, this dress is not pretty," said Lise, looking
11669. sideways at Princess Mary from a little distance. "You have a maroon
11670. dress, have it fetched. Really! You know the fate of your whole life may
11671. be at stake. But this one is too light, it's not becoming!"
11672. 
11673. It was not the dress, but the face and whole figure of Princess Mary
11674. that was not pretty, but neither Mademoiselle Bourienne nor the little
11675. princess felt this; they still thought that if a blue ribbon were placed
11676. in the hair, the hair combed up, and the blue scarf arranged lower on
11677. the best maroon dress, and so on, all would be well. They forgot that
11678. the frightened face and the figure could not be altered, and that
11679. however they might change the setting and adornment of that face, it
11680. would still remain piteous and plain. After two or three changes to
11681. which Princess Mary meekly submitted, just as her hair had been arranged
11682. on the top of her head (a style that quite altered and spoiled her
11683. looks) and she had put on a maroon dress with a pale-blue scarf, the
11684. little princess walked twice round her, now adjusting a fold of the
11685. dress with her little hand, now arranging the scarf and looking at her
11686. with her head bent first on one side and then on the other.
11687. 
11688. "No, it will not do," she said decidedly, clasping her hands. "No, Mary,
11689. really this dress does not suit you. I prefer you in your little gray
11690. everyday dress. Now please, do it for my sake. Katie," she said to the
11691. maid, "bring the princess her gray dress, and you'll see, Mademoiselle
11692. Bourienne, how I shall arrange it," she added, smiling with a foretaste
11693. of artistic pleasure.
11694. 
11695. But when Katie brought the required dress, Princess Mary remained
11696. sitting motionless before the glass, looking at her face, and saw in the
11697. mirror her eyes full of tears and her mouth quivering, ready to burst
11698. into sobs.
11699. 
11700. "Come, dear princess," said Mademoiselle Bourienne, "just one more
11701. little effort."
11702. 
11703. The little princess, taking the dress from the maid, came up to Princess
11704. Mary.
11705. 
11706. "Well, now we'll arrange something quite simple and becoming," she said.
11707. 
11708. The three voices, hers, Mademoiselle Bourienne's, and Katie's, who was
11709. laughing at something, mingled in a merry sound, like the chirping of
11710. birds.
11711. 
11712. "No, leave me alone," said Princess Mary.
11713. 
11714. Her voice sounded so serious and so sad that the chirping of the birds
11715. was silenced at once. They looked at the beautiful, large, thoughtful
11716. eyes full of tears and of thoughts, gazing shiningly and imploringly at
11717. them, and understood that it was useless and even cruel to insist.
11718. 
11719. "At least, change your coiffure," said the little princess. "Didn't I
11720. tell you," she went on, turning reproachfully to Mademoiselle Bourienne,
11721. "Mary's is a face which such a coiffure does not suit in the least. Not
11722. in the least! Please change it."
11723. 
11724. "Leave me alone, please leave me alone! It is all quite the same to me,"
11725. answered a voice struggling with tears.
11726. 
11727. Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess had to own to themselves
11728. that Princess Mary in this guise looked very plain, worse than usual,
11729. but it was too late. She was looking at them with an expression they
11730. both knew, an expression thoughtful and sad. This expression in Princess
11731. Mary did not frighten them (she never inspired fear in anyone), but they
11732. knew that when it appeared on her face, she became mute and was not to
11733. be shaken in her determination.
11734. 
11735. "You will change it, won't you?" said Lise. And as Princess Mary gave no
11736. answer, she left the room.
11737. 
11738. Princess Mary was left alone. She did not comply with Lise's request,
11739. she not only left her hair as it was, but did not even look in her
11740. glass. Letting her arms fall helplessly, she sat with downcast eyes and
11741. pondered. A husband, a man, a strong dominant and strangely attractive
11742. being rose in her imagination, and carried her into a totally different
11743. happy world of his own. She fancied a child, her own--such as she had
11744. seen the day before in the arms of her nurse's daughter--at her own
11745. breast, the husband standing by and gazing tenderly at her and the
11746. child. "But no, it is impossible, I am too ugly," she thought.
11747. 
11748. "Please come to tea. The prince will be out in a moment," came the
11749. maid's voice at the door.
11750. 
11751. She roused herself, and felt appalled at what she had been thinking, and
11752. before going down she went into the room where the icons hung and, her
11753. eyes fixed on the dark face of a large icon of the Saviour lit by a
11754. lamp, she stood before it with folded hands for a few moments. A painful
11755. doubt filled her soul. Could the joy of love, of earthly love for a
11756. man, be for her? In her thoughts of marriage Princess Mary dreamed of
11757. happiness and of children, but her strongest, most deeply hidden longing
11758. was for earthly love. The more she tried to hide this feeling from
11759. others and even from herself, the stronger it grew. "O God," she said,
11760. "how am I to stifle in my heart these temptations of the devil? How am I
11761. to renounce forever these vile fancies, so as peacefully to fulfill
11762. Thy will?" And scarcely had she put that question than God gave her the
11763. answer in her own heart. "Desire nothing for thyself, seek nothing, be
11764. not anxious or envious. Man's future and thy own fate must remain hidden
11765. from thee, but live so that thou mayest be ready for anything. If it be
11766. God's will to prove thee in the duties of marriage, be ready to fulfill
11767. His will." With this consoling thought (but yet with a hope for the
11768. fulfillment of her forbidden earthly longing) Princess Mary sighed,
11769. and having crossed herself went down, thinking neither of her gown and
11770. coiffure nor of how she would go in nor of what she would say. What
11771. could all that matter in comparison with the will of God, without Whose
11772. care not a hair of man's head can fall?
11773. 
11774. 
11775. 
11776. 
11777. 
11778. CHAPTER IV
11779. 
11780. 
11781. When Princess Mary came down, Prince Vasili and his son were already
11782. in the drawing room, talking to the little princess and Mademoiselle
11783. Bourienne. When she entered with her heavy step, treading on her heels,
11784. the gentlemen and Mademoiselle Bourienne rose and the little princess,
11785. indicating her to the gentlemen, said: "Voila Marie!" Princess Mary saw
11786. them all and saw them in detail. She saw Prince Vasili's face, serious
11787. for an instant at the sight of her, but immediately smiling again, and
11788. the little princess curiously noting the impression "Marie" produced on
11789. the visitors. And she saw Mademoiselle Bourienne, with her ribbon and
11790. pretty face, and her unusually animated look which was fixed on him,
11791. but him she could not see, she only saw something large, brilliant,
11792. and handsome moving toward her as she entered the room. Prince Vasili
11793. approached first, and she kissed the bold forehead that bent over her
11794. hand and answered his question by saying that, on the contrary, she
11795. remembered him quite well. Then Anatole came up to her. She still could
11796. not see him. She only felt a soft hand taking hers firmly, and she
11797. touched with her lips a white forehead, over which was beautiful
11798. light-brown hair smelling of pomade. When she looked up at him she was
11799. struck by his beauty. Anatole stood with his right thumb under a button
11800. of his uniform, his chest expanded and his back drawn in, slightly
11801. swinging one foot, and, with his head a little bent, looked with beaming
11802. face at the princess without speaking and evidently not thinking about
11803. her at all. Anatole was not quick-witted, nor ready or eloquent in
11804. conversation, but he had the faculty, so invaluable in society, of
11805. composure and imperturbable self-possession. If a man lacking in
11806. self-confidence remains dumb on a first introduction and betrays a
11807. consciousness of the impropriety of such silence and an anxiety to find
11808. something to say, the effect is bad. But Anatole was dumb, swung his
11809. foot, and smilingly examined the princess' hair. It was evident that he
11810. could be silent in this way for a very long time. "If anyone finds this
11811. silence inconvenient, let him talk, but I don't want to," he seemed to
11812. say. Besides this, in his behavior to women Anatole had a manner
11813. which particularly inspires in them curiosity, awe, and even love--a
11814. supercilious consciousness of his own superiority. It was as if he said
11815. to them: "I know you, I know you, but why should I bother about you?
11816. You'd be only too glad, of course." Perhaps he did not really think this
11817. when he met women--even probably he did not, for in general he thought
11818. very little--but his looks and manner gave that impression. The princess
11819. felt this, and as if wishing to show him that she did not even dare
11820. expect to interest him, she turned to his father. The conversation was
11821. general and animated, thanks to Princess Lise's voice and little downy
11822. lip that lifted over her white teeth. She met Prince Vasili with that
11823. playful manner often employed by lively chatty people, and consisting
11824. in the assumption that between the person they so address and themselves
11825. there are some semi-private, long-established jokes and amusing
11826. reminiscences, though no such reminiscences really exist--just as none
11827. existed in this case. Prince Vasili readily adopted her tone and the
11828. little princess also drew Anatole, whom she hardly knew, into these
11829. amusing recollections of things that had never occurred. Mademoiselle
11830. Bourienne also shared them and even Princess Mary felt herself
11831. pleasantly made to share in these merry reminiscences.

11875. The old prince dressed leisurely in his study, frowning and considering
11876. what he was to do. The coming of these visitors annoyed him. "What are
11877. Prince Vasili and that son of his to me? Prince Vasili is a shallow
11878. braggart and his son, no doubt, is a fine specimen," he grumbled to
11879. himself. What angered him was that the coming of these visitors revived
11880. in his mind an unsettled question he always tried to stifle, one about
11881. which he always deceived himself. The question was whether he could ever
11882. bring himself to part from his daughter and give her to a husband. The
11883. prince never directly asked himself that question, knowing beforehand
11884. that he would have to answer it justly, and justice clashed not only
11885. with his feelings but with the very possibility of life. Life without
11886. Princess Mary, little as he seemed to value her, was unthinkable to
11887. him. "And why should she marry?" he thought. "To be unhappy for certain.
11888. There's Lise, married to Andrew--a better husband one would think could
11889. hardly be found nowadays--but is she contented with her lot? And who

11895. proposing, and today or tomorrow he would probably ask for an answer.
11896. His birth and position in society were not bad. "Well, I've nothing

11991. "Yes, everything is different nowadays, everything is changed. The lad's

12013. As always happens when women lead lonely lives for any length of time
12014. without male society, on Anatole's appearance all the three women of
12015. Prince Bolkonski's household felt that their life had not been real
12016. till then. Their powers of reasoning, feeling, and observing immediately
12017. increased tenfold, and their life, which seemed to have been passed in
12018. darkness, was suddenly lit up by a new brightness, full of significance.
12019. 
12020. Princess Mary grew quite unconscious of her face and coiffure. The
12021. handsome open face of the man who might perhaps be her husband absorbed
12022. all her attention. He seemed to her kind, brave, determined, manly, and
12023. magnanimous. She felt convinced of that. Thousands of dreams of a future
12024. family life continually rose in her imagination. She drove them away and
12025. tried to conceal them.
12026. 
12027. "But am I not too cold with him?" thought the princess. "I try to be
12028. reserved because in the depth of my soul I feel too near to him already,
12029. but then he cannot know what I think of him and may imagine that I do
12030. not like him."
12031. 
12032. And Princess Mary tried, but could not manage, to be cordial to her new
12033. guest. "Poor girl, she's devilish ugly!" thought Anatole.
12034. 
12035. Mademoiselle Bourienne, also roused to great excitement by Anatole's
12036. arrival, thought in another way. Of course, she, a handsome young woman
12037. without any definite position, without relations or even a country, did
12038. not intend to devote her life to serving Prince Bolkonski, to reading
12039. aloud to him and being friends with Princess Mary. Mademoiselle
12040. Bourienne had long been waiting for a Russian prince who, able to
12041. appreciate at a glance her superiority to the plain, badly dressed,
12042. ungainly Russian princesses, would fall in love with her and carry her
12043. off; and here at last was a Russian prince. Mademoiselle Bourienne knew
12044. a story, heard from her aunt but finished in her own way, which she
12045. liked to repeat to herself. It was the story of a girl who had been
12046. seduced, and to whom her poor mother (sa pauvre mere) appeared, and
12047. reproached her for yielding to a man without being married. Mademoiselle
12048. Bourienne was often touched to tears as in imagination she told this
12049. story to him, her seducer. And now he, a real Russian prince, had
12050. appeared. He would carry her away and then sa pauvre mere would appear
12051. and he would marry her. So her future shaped itself in Mademoiselle
12052. Bourienne's head at the very time she was talking to Anatole about
12053. Paris. It was not calculation that guided her (she did not even for a
12054. moment consider what she should do), but all this had long been familiar
12055. to her, and now that Anatole had appeared it just grouped itself around
12056. him and she wished and tried to please him as much as possible.
12057. 
12058. The little princess, like an old war horse that hears the trumpet,
12059. unconsciously and quite forgetting her condition, prepared for the
12060. familiar gallop of coquetry, without any ulterior motive or any
12061. struggle, but with naive and lighthearted gaiety.
12062. 
12063. Although in female society Anatole usually assumed the role of a man
12064. tired of being run after by women, his vanity was flattered by the
12065. spectacle of his power over these three women. Besides that, he was
12066. beginning to feel for the pretty and provocative Mademoiselle Bourienne
12067. that passionate animal feeling which was apt to master him with great
12068. suddenness and prompt him to the coarsest and most reckless actions.
12069. 
12070. After tea, the company went into the sitting room and Princess Mary was
12071. asked to play on the clavichord. Anatole, laughing and in high spirits,
12072. came and leaned on his elbows, facing her and beside Mademoiselle
12073. Bourienne. Princess Mary felt his look with a painfully joyous emotion.
12074. Her favorite sonata bore her into a most intimately poetic world and the

12076. expression, though his eyes were fixed on her, referred not to her but

12078. then touching with his own under the clavichord. Mademoiselle Bourienne
12079. was also looking at Princess Mary, and in her lovely eyes there was a
12080. look of fearful joy and hope that was also new to the princess.
12081. 
12082. "How she loves me!" thought Princess Mary. "How happy I am now, and how
12083. happy I may be with such a friend and such a husband! Husband? Can it
12084. be possible?" she thought, not daring to look at his face, but still
12085. feeling his eyes gazing at her.
12086. 
12087. In the evening, after supper, when all were about to retire, Anatole

12099.

12141. The old prince did not sleep either. Tikhon, half asleep, heard him

12148. 
12149. "The first man that turns up--she forgets her father and everything

12299. Prince Vasili, with one leg thrown high over the other and a snuffbox in
12300. his hand, was sitting there with a smile of deep emotion on his face,
12301. as if stirred to his heart's core and himself regretting and laughing
12302. at his own sensibility, when Princess Mary entered. He hurriedly took a
12303. pinch of snuff.
12304. 
12305. "Ah, my dear, my dear!" he began, rising and taking her by both hands.
12306. Then, sighing, he added: "My son's fate is in your hands. Decide, my
12307. dear, good, gentle Marie, whom I have always loved as a daughter!"
12308. 
12309. He drew back and a real tear appeared in his eye.
12310. 
12311. "Fr... fr..." snorted Prince Bolkonski. "The prince is making a
12312. proposition to you in his pupil's--I mean, his son's--name. Do you
12313. wish or not to be Prince Anatole Kuragin's wife? Reply: yes or no," he
12314. shouted, "and then I shall reserve the right to state my opinion also.
12315. Yes, my opinion, and only my opinion," added Prince Bolkonski, turning
12316. to Prince Vasili and answering his imploring look. "Yes, or no?"
12317. 
12318. "My desire is never to leave you, Father, never to separate my life
12319. from yours. I don't wish to marry," she answered positively, glancing at
12320. Prince Vasili and at her father with her beautiful eyes.
12321. 
12322. "Humbug! Nonsense! Humbug, humbug, humbug!" cried Prince Bolkonski,
12323. frowning and taking his daughter's hand; he did not kiss her, but only
12324. bending his forehead to hers just touched it, and pressed her hand so
12325. that she winced and uttered a cry.
12326. 
12327. Prince Vasili rose.
12328. 
12329. "My dear, I must tell you that this is a moment I shall never, never
12330. forget. But, my dear, will you not give us a little hope of touching
12331. this heart, so kind and generous? Say 'perhaps'... The future is so
12332. long. Say 'perhaps.'"
12333. 
12334. "Prince, what I have said is all there is in my heart. I thank you for
12335. the honor, but I shall never be your son's wife."
12336. 
12337. "Well, so that's finished, my dear fellow! I am very glad to have seen
12338. you. Very glad! Go back to your rooms, Princess. Go!" said the old
12339. prince. "Very, very glad to have seen you," repeated he, embracing
12340. Prince Vasili.
12341. 
12342. "My vocation is a different one," thought Princess Mary. "My vocation
12343. is to be happy with another kind of happiness, the happiness of love
12344. and self-sacrifice. And cost what it may, I will arrange poor Amelie's
12345. happiness, she loves him so passionately, and so passionately repents. I
12346. will do all I can to arrange the match between them. If he is not rich I
12347. will give her the means; I will ask my father and Andrew. I shall be so
12348. happy when she is his wife. She is so unfortunate, a stranger, alone,
12349. helpless! And, oh God, how passionately she must love him if she could
12350. so far forget herself! Perhaps I might have done the same!..." thought
12351. Princess Mary.
12352. 
12353. 
12354. 
12355. 
12356. 
12357. CHAPTER VI
12358. 
12359. 
12360. It was long since the Rostovs had news of Nicholas. Not till
12361. midwinter was the count at last handed a letter addressed in his son's
12362. handwriting. On receiving it, he ran on tiptoe to his study in alarm and
12363. haste, trying to escape notice, closed the door, and began to read the
12364. letter.
12365. 
12366. Anna Mikhaylovna, who always knew everything that passed in the house,
12367. on hearing of the arrival of the letter went softly into the room and
12368. found the count with it in his hand, sobbing and laughing at the same
12369. time.
12370. 
12371. Anna Mikhaylovna, though her circumstances had improved, was still
12372. living with the Rostovs.
12373. 
12374. "My dear friend?" said she, in a tone of pathetic inquiry, prepared to
12375. sympathize in any way.
12376. 
12377. The count sobbed yet more.
12378. 
12379. "Nikolenka... a letter... wa... a... s... wounded... my darling boy...
12380. the countess... promoted to be an officer... thank God... How tell the
12381. little countess!"
12382. 
12383. Anna Mikhaylovna sat down beside him, with her own handkerchief wiped
12384. the tears from his eyes and from the letter, then having dried her
12385. own eyes she comforted the count, and decided that at dinner and till
12386. teatime she would prepare the countess, and after tea, with God's help,
12387. would inform her.
12388. 
12389. At dinner Anna Mikhaylovna talked the whole time about the war news and
12390. about Nikolenka, twice asked when the last letter had been received from
12391. him, though she knew that already, and remarked that they might very
12392. likely be getting a letter from him that day. Each time that these hints
12393. began to make the countess anxious and she glanced uneasily at the
12394. count and at Anna Mikhaylovna, the latter very adroitly turned the
12395. conversation to insignificant matters. Natasha, who, of the whole
12396. family, was the most gifted with a capacity to feel any shades of
12397. intonation, look, and expression, pricked up her ears from the beginning
12398. of the meal and was certain that there was some secret between her
12399. father and Anna Mikhaylovna, that it had something to do with her
12400. brother, and that Anna Mikhaylovna was preparing them for it. Bold as
12401. she was, Natasha, who knew how sensitive her mother was to anything
12402. relating to Nikolenka, did not venture to ask any questions at dinner,
12403. but she was too excited to eat anything and kept wriggling about on her
12404. chair regardless of her governess' remarks. After dinner, she rushed
12405. head long after Anna Mikhaylovna and, dashing at her, flung herself on
12406. her neck as soon as she overtook her in the sitting room.
12407. 
12408. "Auntie, darling, do tell me what it is!"
12409. 
12410. "Nothing, my dear."
12411. 
12412. "No, dearest, sweet one, honey, I won't give up--I know you know
12413. something."
12414. 
12415. Anna Mikhaylovna shook her head.
12416. 
12417. "You are a little slyboots," she said.
12418. 
12419. "A letter from Nikolenka! I'm sure of it!" exclaimed Natasha, reading
12420. confirmation in Anna Mikhaylovna's face.
12421. 
12422. "But for God's sake, be careful, you know how it may affect your mamma."
12423. 
12424. "I will, I will, only tell me! You won't? Then I will go and tell at
12425. once."
12426. 
12427. Anna Mikhaylovna, in a few words, told her the contents of the letter,
12428. on condition that she should tell no one.
12429. 
12430. "No, on my true word of honor," said Natasha, crossing herself, "I won't
12431. tell anyone!" and she ran off at once to Sonya.
12432. 
12433. "Nikolenka... wounded... a letter," she announced in gleeful triumph.
12434. 
12435. "Nicholas!" was all Sonya said, instantly turning white.
12436. 
12437. Natasha, seeing the impression the news of her brother's wound produced
12438. on Sonya, felt for the first time the sorrowful side of the news.
12439. 
12440. She rushed to Sonya, hugged her, and began to cry.
12441. 
12442. "A little wound, but he has been made an officer; he is well now, he
12443. wrote himself," said she through her tears.
12444. 
12445. "There now! It's true that all you women are crybabies," remarked Petya,
12446. pacing the room with large, resolute strides. "Now I'm very glad, very
12447. glad indeed, that my brother has distinguished himself so. You are all
12448. blubberers and understand nothing."
12449. 
12450. Natasha smiled through her tears.
12451. 
12452. "You haven't read the letter?" asked Sonya.
12453. 
12454. "No, but she said that it was all over and that he's now an officer."
12455. 
12456. "Thank God!" said Sonya, crossing herself. "But perhaps she deceived
12457. you. Let us go to Mamma."
12458. 
12459. Petya paced the room in silence for a time.
12460. 
12461. "If I'd been in Nikolenka's place I would have killed even more of those
12462. Frenchmen," he said. "What nasty brutes they are! I'd have killed so
12463. many that there'd have been a heap of them."
12464. 
12465. "Hold your tongue, Petya, what a goose you are!"
12466. 
12467. "I'm not a goose, but they are who cry about trifles," said Petya.
12468. 
12469. "Do you remember him?" Natasha suddenly asked, after a moment's silence.
12470. 
12471. Sonya smiled.
12472. 
12473. "Do I remember Nicholas?"
12474. 
12475. "No, Sonya, but do you remember so that you remember him perfectly,
12476. remember everything?" said Natasha, with an expressive gesture,
12477. evidently wishing to give her words a very definite meaning. "I remember
12478. Nikolenka too, I remember him well," she said. "But I don't remember
12479. Boris. I don't remember him a bit."
12480. 
12481. "What! You don't remember Boris?" asked Sonya in surprise.
12482. 
12483. "It's not that I don't remember--I know what he is like, but not as I
12484. remember Nikolenka. Him--I just shut my eyes and remember, but Boris...
12485. No!" (She shut her eyes.) "No! there's nothing at all."
12486. 
12487. "Oh, Natasha!" said Sonya, looking ecstatically and earnestly at her
12488. friend as if she did not consider her worthy to hear what she meant to
12489. say and as if she were saying it to someone else, with whom joking was
12490. out of the question, "I am in love with your brother once for all and,
12491. whatever may happen to him or to me, shall never cease to love him as
12492. long as I live."
12493. 
12494. Natasha looked at Sonya with wondering and inquisitive eyes, and said
12495. nothing. She felt that Sonya was speaking the truth, that there was such
12496. love as Sonya was speaking of. But Natasha had not yet felt anything
12497. like it. She believed it could be, but did not understand it.
12498. 
12499. "Shall you write to him?" she asked.
12500. 
12501. Sonya became thoughtful. The question of how to write to Nicholas, and
12502. whether she ought to write, tormented her. Now that he was already an
12503. officer and a wounded hero, would it be right to remind him of herself
12504. and, as it might seem, of the obligations to her he had taken on
12505. himself?
12506. 
12507. "I don't know. I think if he writes, I will write too," she said,
12508. blushing.
12509. 
12510. "And you won't feel ashamed to write to him?"
12511. 
12512. Sonya smiled.
12513. 
12514. "No."
12515. 
12516. "And I should be ashamed to write to Boris. I'm not going to."
12517. 
12518. "Why should you be ashamed?"
12519. 
12520. "Well, I don't know. It's awkward and would make me ashamed."
12521. 
12522. "And I know why she'd be ashamed," said Petya, offended by Natasha's
12523. previous remark. "It's because she was in love with that fat one in
12524. spectacles" (that was how Petya described his namesake, the new Count
12525. Bezukhov) "and now she's in love with that singer" (he meant Natasha's
12526. Italian singing master), "that's why she's ashamed!"
12527. 
12528. "Petya, you're a stupid!" said Natasha.
12529. 
12530. "Not more stupid than you, madam," said the nine-year-old Petya, with
12531. the air of an old brigadier.
12532. 
12533. The countess had been prepared by Anna Mikhaylovna's hints at dinner.
12534. On retiring to her own room, she sat in an armchair, her eyes fixed on a
12535. miniature portrait of her son on the lid of a snuffbox, while the tears
12536. kept coming into her eyes. Anna Mikhaylovna, with the letter, came on
12537. tiptoe to the countess' door and paused.
12538. 
12539. "Don't come in," she said to the old count who was following her. "Come
12540. later." And she went in, closing the door behind her.
12541. 
12542. The count put his ear to the keyhole and listened.
12543. 
12544. At first he heard the sound of indifferent voices, then Anna
12545. Mikhaylovna's voice alone in a long speech, then a cry, then silence,
12546. then both voices together with glad intonations, and then footsteps.
12547. Anna Mikhaylovna opened the door. Her face wore the proud expression of
12548. a surgeon who has just performed a difficult operation and admits the
12549. public to appreciate his skill.
12550. 
12551. "It is done!" she said to the count, pointing triumphantly to the
12552. countess, who sat holding in one hand the snuffbox with its portrait and
12553. in the other the letter, and pressing them alternately to her lips.
12554. 
12555. When she saw the count, she stretched out her arms to him, embraced his
12556. bald head, over which she again looked at the letter and the portrait,
12557. and in order to press them again to her lips, she slightly pushed away
12558. the bald head. Vera, Natasha, Sonya, and Petya now entered the room,
12559. and the reading of the letter began. After a brief description of
12560. the campaign and the two battles in which he had taken part, and his
12561. promotion, Nicholas said that he kissed his father's and mother's hands
12562. asking for their blessing, and that he kissed Vera, Natasha, and Petya.
12563. Besides that, he sent greetings to Monsieur Schelling, Madame Schoss,
12564. and his old nurse, and asked them to kiss for him "dear Sonya, whom he
12565. loved and thought of just the same as ever." When she heard this Sonya
12566. blushed so that tears came into her eyes and, unable to bear the looks
12567. turned upon her, ran away into the dancing hall, whirled round it at
12568. full speed with her dress puffed out like a balloon, and, flushed and
12569. smiling, plumped down on the floor. The countess was crying.
12570. 
12571. "Why are you crying, Mamma?" asked Vera. "From all he says one should be
12572. glad and not cry."
12573. 
12574. This was quite true, but the count, the countess, and Natasha looked
12575. at her reproachfully. "And who is it she takes after?" thought the
12576. countess.
12577. 
12578. Nicholas' letter was read over hundreds of times, and those who were
12579. considered worthy to hear it had to come to the countess, for she
12580. did not let it out of her hands. The tutors came, and the nurses, and
12581. Dmitri, and several acquaintances, and the countess reread the letter
12582. each time with fresh pleasure and each time discovered in it fresh
12583. proofs of Nikolenka's virtues. How strange, how extraordinary, how
12584. joyful it seemed, that her son, the scarcely perceptible motion of whose
12585. tiny limbs she had felt twenty years ago within her, that son about whom
12586. she used to have quarrels with the too indulgent count, that son who had
12587. first learned to say "pear" and then "granny," that this son should now
12588. be away in a foreign land amid strange surroundings, a manly warrior
12589. doing some kind of man's work of his own, without help or guidance.
12590. The universal experience of ages, showing that children do grow
12591. imperceptibly from the cradle to manhood, did not exist for the
12592. countess. Her son's growth toward manhood, at each of its stages,
12593. had seemed as extraordinary to her as if there had never existed the
12594. millions of human beings who grew up in the same way. As twenty
12595. years before, it seemed impossible that the little creature who lived
12596. somewhere under her heart would ever cry, suck her breast, and begin to
12597. speak, so now she could not believe that that little creature could be
12598. this strong, brave man, this model son and officer that, judging by this
12599. letter, he now was.
12600. 
12601. "What a style! How charmingly he describes!" said she, reading the
12602. descriptive part of the letter. "And what a soul! Not a word about
12603. himself.... Not a word! About some Denisov or other, though he himself,
12604. I dare say, is braver than any of them. He says nothing about his
12605. sufferings. What a heart! How like him it is! And how he has remembered
12606. everybody! Not forgetting anyone. I always said when he was only so
12607. high--I always said...."
12608. 
12609. For more than a week preparations were being made, rough drafts of
12610. letters to Nicholas from all the household were written and copied out,
12611. while under the supervision of the countess and the solicitude of the
12612. count, money and all things necessary for the uniform and equipment
12613. of the newly commissioned officer were collected. Anna Mikhaylovna,
12614. practical woman that she was, had even managed by favor with army
12615. authorities to secure advantageous means of communication for herself
12616. and her son. She had opportunities of sending her letters to the Grand
12617. Duke Constantine Pavlovich, who commanded the Guards. The Rostovs
12618. supposed that The Russian Guards, Abroad, was quite a definite address,
12619. and that if a letter reached the Grand Duke in command of the Guards
12620. there was no reason why it should not reach the Pavlograd regiment,
12621. which was presumably somewhere in the same neighborhood. And so it was
12622. decided to send the letters and money by the Grand Duke's courier to
12623. Boris and Boris was to forward them to Nicholas. The letters were
12624. from the old count, the countess, Petya, Vera, Natasha, and Sonya, and
12625. finally there were six thousand rubles for his outfit and various other
12626. things the old count sent to his son.
12627. 
12628. 
12629. 
12630. 
12631. 
12632. CHAPTER VII
12633. 
12634. 
12635. On the twelfth of November, Kutuzov's active army, in camp before
12636. Olmutz, was preparing to be reviewed next day by the two Emperors--the
12637. Russian and the Austrian. The Guards, just arrived from Russia, spent
12638. the night ten miles from Olmutz and next morning were to come straight
12639. to the review, reaching the field at Olmutz by ten o'clock.
12640. 
12641. That day Nicholas Rostov received a letter from Boris, telling him that
12642. the Ismaylov regiment was quartered for the night ten miles from Olmutz
12643. and that he wanted to see him as he had a letter and money for him.
12644. Rostov was particularly in need of money now that the troops, after
12645. their active service, were stationed near Olmutz and the camp swarmed
12646. with well-provisioned sutlers and Austrian Jews offering all sorts
12647. of tempting wares. The Pavlograds held feast after feast, celebrating
12648. awards they had received for the campaign, and made expeditions to
12649. Olmutz to visit a certain Caroline the Hungarian, who had recently
12650. opened a restaurant there with girls as waitresses. Rostov, who had
12651. just celebrated his promotion to a cornetcy and bought Denisov's horse,
12652. Bedouin, was in debt all round, to his comrades and the sutlers. On
12653. receiving Boris' letter he rode with a fellow officer to Olmutz, dined
12654. there, drank a bottle of wine, and then set off alone to the Guards'
12655. camp to find his old playmate. Rostov had not yet had time to get his
12656. uniform. He had on a shabby cadet jacket, decorated with a soldier's
12657. cross, equally shabby cadet's riding breeches lined with worn leather,
12658. and an officer's saber with a sword knot. The Don horse he was riding
12659. was one he had bought from a Cossack during the campaign, and he wore a
12660. crumpled hussar cap stuck jauntily back on one side of his head. As he
12661. rode up to the camp he thought how he would impress Boris and all his
12662. comrades of the Guards by his appearance--that of a fighting hussar who
12663. had been under fire.
12664. 
12665. The Guards had made their whole march as if on a pleasure trip, parading
12666. their cleanliness and discipline. They had come by easy stages, their
12667. knapsacks conveyed on carts, and the Austrian authorities had provided
12668. excellent dinners for the officers at every halting place. The regiments
12669. had entered and left the town with their bands playing, and by the Grand
12670. Duke's orders the men had marched all the way in step (a practice on
12671. which the Guards prided themselves), the officers on foot and at their
12672. proper posts. Boris had been quartered, and had marched all the way,
12673. with Berg who was already in command of a company. Berg, who had
12674. obtained his captaincy during the campaign, had gained the confidence of
12675. his superiors by his promptitude and accuracy and had arranged his money
12676. matters very satisfactorily. Boris, during the campaign, had made the
12677. acquaintance of many persons who might prove useful to him, and by
12678. a letter of recommendation he had brought from Pierre had become
12679. acquainted with Prince Andrew Bolkonski, through whom he hoped to obtain
12680. a post on the commander in chief's staff. Berg and Boris, having rested
12681. after yesterday's march, were sitting, clean and neatly dressed, at a
12682. round table in the clean quarters allotted to them, playing chess.
12683. Berg held a smoking pipe between his knees. Boris, in the accurate way
12684. characteristic of him, was building a little pyramid of chessmen with
12685. his delicate white fingers while awaiting Berg's move, and watched his
12686. opponent's face, evidently thinking about the game as he always thought
12687. only of whatever he was engaged on.
12688. 
12689. "Well, how are you going to get out of that?" he remarked.
12690. 
12691. "We'll try to," replied Berg, touching a pawn and then removing his
12692. hand.
12693. 
12694. At that moment the door opened.
12695. 
12696. "Here he is at last!" shouted Rostov. "And Berg too! Oh, you
12697. petisenfans, allay cushay dormir!" he exclaimed, imitating his Russian
12698. nurse's French, at which he and Boris used to laugh long ago.
12699. 
12700. "Dear me, how you have changed!"
12701. 
12702. Boris rose to meet Rostov, but in doing so did not omit to steady and
12703. replace some chessmen that were falling. He was about to embrace his
12704. friend, but Nicholas avoided him. With that peculiar feeling of youth,
12705. that dread of beaten tracks, and wish to express itself in a manner
12706. different from that of its elders which is often insincere, Nicholas
12707. wished to do something special on meeting his friend. He wanted to pinch
12708. him, push him, do anything but kiss him--a thing everybody did. But
12709. notwithstanding this, Boris embraced him in a quiet, friendly way and
12710. kissed him three times.
12711. 
12712. They had not met for nearly half a year and, being at the age when young
12713. men take their first steps on life's road, each saw immense changes in
12714. the other, quite a new reflection of the society in which they had taken
12715. those first steps. Both had changed greatly since they last met and both
12716. were in a hurry to show the changes that had taken place in them.
12717. 
12718. "Oh, you damned dandies! Clean and fresh as if you'd been to a fete,
12719. not like us sinners of the line," cried Rostov, with martial swagger
12720. and with baritone notes in his voice, new to Boris, pointing to his own
12721. mud-bespattered breeches. The German landlady, hearing Rostov's loud
12722. voice, popped her head in at the door.
12723. 
12724. "Eh, is she pretty?" he asked with a wink.
12725. 
12726. "Why do you shout so? You'll frighten them!" said Boris. "I did not
12727. expect you today," he added. "I only sent you the note yesterday by
12728. Bolkonski--an adjutant of Kutuzov's, who's a friend of mine. I did not
12729. think he would get it to you so quickly.... Well, how are you? Been
12730. under fire already?" asked Boris.
12731. 
12732. Without answering, Rostov shook the soldier's Cross of St. George
12733. fastened to the cording of his uniform and, indicating a bandaged arm,
12734. glanced at Berg with a smile.
12735. 
12736. "As you see," he said.
12737. 
12738. "Indeed? Yes, yes!" said Boris, with a smile. "And we too have had a
12739. splendid march. You know, of course, that His Imperial Highness rode
12740. with our regiment all the time, so that we had every comfort and every
12741. advantage. What receptions we had in Poland! What dinners and balls!
12742. I can't tell you. And the Tsarevich was very gracious to all our
12743. officers."
12744. 
12745. And the two friends told each other of their doings, the one of his
12746. hussar revels and life in the fighting line, the other of the pleasures
12747. and advantages of service under members of the Imperial family.
12748. 
12749. "Oh, you Guards!" said Rostov. "I say, send for some wine."
12750. 
12751. Boris made a grimace.
12752. 
12753. "If you really want it," said he.
12754. 
12755. He went to his bed, drew a purse from under the clean pillow, and sent
12756. for wine.
12757. 
12758. "Yes, and I have some money and a letter to give you," he added.
12759. 
12760. Rostov took the letter and, throwing the money on the sofa, put both
12761. arms on the table and began to read. After reading a few lines, he
12762. glanced angrily at Berg, then, meeting his eyes, hid his face behind the
12763. letter.
12764. 
12765. "Well, they've sent you a tidy sum," said Berg, eying the heavy purse
12766. that sank into the sofa. "As for us, Count, we get along on our pay. I
12767. can tell you for myself..."
12768. 
12769. "I say, Berg, my dear fellow," said Rostov, "when you get a letter from
12770. home and meet one of your own people whom you want to talk everything
12771. over with, and I happen to be there, I'll go at once, to be out of
12772. your way! Do go somewhere, anywhere... to the devil!" he exclaimed, and
12773. immediately seizing him by the shoulder and looking amiably into his
12774. face, evidently wishing to soften the rudeness of his words, he added,
12775. "Don't be hurt, my dear fellow; you know I speak from my heart as to an
12776. old acquaintance."
12777. 
12778. "Oh, don't mention it, Count! I quite understand," said Berg, getting up
12779. and speaking in a muffled and guttural voice.
12780. 
12781. "Go across to our hosts: they invited you," added Boris.
12782. 
12783. Berg put on the cleanest of coats, without a spot or speck of dust,
12784. stood before a looking glass and brushed the hair on his temples
12785. upwards, in the way affected by the Emperor Alexander, and, having
12786. assured himself from the way Rostov looked at it that his coat had been
12787. noticed, left the room with a pleasant smile.
12788. 
12789. "Oh dear, what a beast I am!" muttered Rostov, as he read the letter.
12790. 
12791. "Why?"
12792. 
12793. "Oh, what a pig I am, not to have written and to have given them such
12794. a fright! Oh, what a pig I am!" he repeated, flushing suddenly. "Well,
12795. have you sent Gabriel for some wine? All right let's have some!"
12796. 
12797. In the letter from his parents was enclosed a letter of recommendation
12798. to Bagration which the old countess at Anna Mikhaylovna's advice had
12799. obtained through an acquaintance and sent to her son, asking him to take
12800. it to its destination and make use of it.
12801. 
12802. "What nonsense! Much I need it!" said Rostov, throwing the letter under
12803. the table.
12804. 
12805. "Why have you thrown that away?" asked Boris.
12806. 
12807. "It is some letter of recommendation... what the devil do I want it
12808. for!"
12809. 
12810. "Why 'What the devil'?" said Boris, picking it up and reading the
12811. address. "This letter would be of great use to you."
12812. 
12813. "I want nothing, and I won't be anyone's adjutant."
12814. 
12815. "Why not?" inquired Boris.
12816. 
12817. "It's a lackey's job!"
12818. 
12819. "You are still the same dreamer, I see," remarked Boris, shaking his
12820. head.
12821. 
12822. "And you're still the same diplomatist! But that's not the point...
12823. Come, how are you?" asked Rostov.
12824. 
12825. "Well, as you see. So far everything's all right, but I confess I should
12826. much like to be an adjutant and not remain at the front."
12827. 
12828. "Why?"
12829. 
12830. "Because when once a man starts on military service, he should try to
12831. make as successful a career of it as possible."
12832. 
12833. "Oh, that's it!" said Rostov, evidently thinking of something else.
12834. 
12835. He looked intently and inquiringly into his friend's eyes, evidently
12836. trying in vain to find the answer to some question.
12837. 
12838. Old Gabriel brought in the wine.
12839. 
12840. "Shouldn't we now send for Berg?" asked Boris. "He would drink with you.
12841. I can't."
12842. 
12843. "Well, send for him... and how do you get on with that German?" asked
12844. Rostov, with a contemptuous smile.
12845. 
12846. "He is a very, very nice, honest, and pleasant fellow," answered Boris.
12847. 
12848. Again Rostov looked intently into Boris' eyes and sighed. Berg returned,
12849. and over the bottle of wine conversation between the three officers
12850. became animated. The Guardsmen told Rostov of their march and how they
12851. had been made much of in Russia, Poland, and abroad. They spoke of the
12852. sayings and doings of their commander, the Grand Duke, and told stories
12853. of his kindness and irascibility. Berg, as usual, kept silent when the
12854. subject did not relate to himself, but in connection with the stories
12855. of the Grand Duke's quick temper he related with gusto how in Galicia he
12856. had managed to deal with the Grand Duke when the latter made a tour of
12857. the regiments and was annoyed at the irregularity of a movement. With a
12858. pleasant smile Berg related how the Grand Duke had ridden up to him in
12859. a violent passion, shouting: "Arnauts!" ("Arnauts" was the Tsarevich's
12860. favorite expression when he was in a rage) and called for the company
12861. commander.
12862. 
12863. "Would you believe it, Count, I was not at all alarmed, because I knew
12864. I was right. Without boasting, you know, I may say that I know the Army
12865. Orders by heart and know the Regulations as well as I do the Lord's
12866. Prayer. So, Count, there never is any negligence in my company, and so
12867. my conscience was at ease. I came forward...." (Berg stood up and showed
12868. how he presented himself, with his hand to his cap, and really it
12869. would have been difficult for a face to express greater respect and
12870. self-complacency than his did.) "Well, he stormed at me, as the saying
12871. is, stormed and stormed and stormed! It was not a matter of life but
12872. rather of death, as the saying is. 'Albanians!' and 'devils!' and 'To
12873. Siberia!'" said Berg with a sagacious smile. "I knew I was in the right
12874. so I kept silent; was not that best, Count?... 'Hey, are you dumb?' he
12875. shouted. Still I remained silent. And what do you think, Count? The
12876. next day it was not even mentioned in the Orders of the Day. That's what
12877. keeping one's head means. That's the way, Count," said Berg, lighting
12878. his pipe and emitting rings of smoke.
12879. 
12880. "Yes, that was fine," said Rostov, smiling.
12881. 
12882. But Boris noticed that he was preparing to make fun of Berg, and
12883. skillfully changed the subject. He asked him to tell them how and where
12884. he got his wound. This pleased Rostov and he began talking about it, and
12885. as he went on became more and more animated. He told them of his Schon
12886. Grabern affair, just as those who have taken part in a battle generally
12887. do describe it, that is, as they would like it to have been, as they
12888. have heard it described by others, and as sounds well, but not at all as
12889. it really was. Rostov was a truthful young man and would on no
12890. account have told a deliberate lie. He began his story meaning to tell
12891. everything just as it happened, but imperceptibly, involuntarily, and
12892. inevitably he lapsed into falsehood. If he had told the truth to his
12893. hearers--who like himself had often heard stories of attacks and had
12894. formed a definite idea of what an attack was and were expecting to hear
12895. just such a story--they would either not have believed him or, still
12896. worse, would have thought that Rostov was himself to blame since what
