12897. generally happens to the narrators of cavalry attacks had not happened
12898. to him. He could not tell them simply that everyone went at a trot and
12899. that he fell off his horse and sprained his arm and then ran as hard as
12900. he could from a Frenchman into the wood. Besides, to tell everything as
12901. it really happened, it would have been necessary to make an effort of
12902. will to tell only what happened. It is very difficult to tell the truth,
12903. and young people are rarely capable of it. His hearers expected a story
12904. of how beside himself and all aflame with excitement, he had flown like
12905. a storm at the square, cut his way in, slashed right and left, how his
12906. saber had tasted flesh and he had fallen exhausted, and so on. And so he
12907. told them all that.
12908. 
12909. In the middle of his story, just as he was saying: "You cannot imagine
12910. what a strange frenzy one experiences during an attack," Prince Andrew,
12911. whom Boris was expecting, entered the room. Prince Andrew, who liked
12912. to help young men, was flattered by being asked for his assistance and
12913. being well disposed toward Boris, who had managed to please him the day
12914. before, he wished to do what the young man wanted. Having been sent with
12915. papers from Kutuzov to the Tsarevich, he looked in on Boris, hoping to
12916. find him alone. When he came in and saw an hussar of the line recounting
12917. his military exploits (Prince Andrew could not endure that sort of man),
12918. he gave Boris a pleasant smile, frowned as with half-closed eyes he
12919. looked at Rostov, bowed slightly and wearily, and sat down languidly
12920. on the sofa: he felt it unpleasant to have dropped in on bad company.
12921. Rostov flushed up on noticing this, but he did not care, this was a mere
12922. stranger. Glancing, however, at Boris, he saw that he too seemed ashamed
12923. of the hussar of the line.
12924. 
12925. In spite of Prince Andrew's disagreeable, ironical tone, in spite of
12926. the contempt with which Rostov, from his fighting army point of view,
12927. regarded all these little adjutants on the staff of whom the newcomer
12928. was evidently one, Rostov felt confused, blushed, and became silent.
12929. Boris inquired what news there might be on the staff, and what, without
12930. indiscretion, one might ask about our plans.
12931. 
12932. "We shall probably advance," replied Bolkonski, evidently reluctant to
12933. say more in the presence of a stranger.
12934. 
12935. Berg took the opportunity to ask, with great politeness, whether, as was
12936. rumored, the allowance of forage money to captains of companies would be
12937. doubled. To this Prince Andrew answered with a smile that he could
12938. give no opinion on such an important government order, and Berg laughed
12939. gaily.
12940. 
12941. "As to your business," Prince Andrew continued, addressing Boris, "we
12942. will talk of it later" (and he looked round at Rostov). "Come to me
12943. after the review and we will do what is possible."
12944. 
12945. And, having glanced round the room, Prince Andrew turned to Rostov,
12946. whose state of unconquerable childish embarrassment now changing to
12947. anger he did not condescend to notice, and said: "I think you were
12948. talking of the Schon Grabern affair? Were you there?"
12949. 
12950. "I was there," said Rostov angrily, as if intending to insult the
12951. aide-de-camp.
12952. 
12953. Bolkonski noticed the hussar's state of mind, and it amused him. With a
12954. slightly contemptuous smile, he said: "Yes, there are many stories now
12955. told about that affair!"
12956. 
12957. "Yes, stories!" repeated Rostov loudly, looking with eyes suddenly grown
12958. furious, now at Boris, now at Bolkonski. "Yes, many stories! But our
12959. stories are the stories of men who have been under the enemy's fire! Our
12960. stories have some weight, not like the stories of those fellows on the
12961. staff who get rewards without doing anything!"
12962. 
12963. "Of whom you imagine me to be one?" said Prince Andrew, with a quiet and
12964. particularly amiable smile.
12965. 
12966. A strange feeling of exasperation and yet of respect for this man's
12967. self-possession mingled at that moment in Rostov's soul.
12968. 
12969. "I am not talking about you," he said, "I don't know you and, frankly, I
12970. don't want to. I am speaking of the staff in general."
12971. 
12972. "And I will tell you this," Prince Andrew interrupted in a tone of quiet
12973. authority, "you wish to insult me, and I am ready to agree with you that
12974. it would be very easy to do so if you haven't sufficient self-respect,
12975. but admit that the time and place are very badly chosen. In a day or two
12976. we shall all have to take part in a greater and more serious duel, and
12977. besides, Drubetskoy, who says he is an old friend of yours, is not at
12978. all to blame that my face has the misfortune to displease you. However,"
12979. he added rising, "you know my name and where to find me, but don't
12980. forget that I do not regard either myself or you as having been at all
12981. insulted, and as a man older than you, my advice is to let the matter
12982. drop. Well then, on Friday after the review I shall expect you,
12983. Drubetskoy. Au revoir!" exclaimed Prince Andrew, and with a bow to them
12984. both he went out.
12985. 
12986. Only when Prince Andrew was gone did Rostov think of what he ought to
12987. have said. And he was still more angry at having omitted to say it. He
12988. ordered his horse at once and, coldly taking leave of Boris, rode
12989. home. Should he go to headquarters next day and challenge that affected
12990. adjutant, or really let the matter drop, was the question that worried
12991. him all the way. He thought angrily of the pleasure he would have at
12992. seeing the fright of that small and frail but proud man when covered by
12993. his pistol, and then he felt with surprise that of all the men he knew
12994. there was none he would so much like to have for a friend as that very
12995. adjutant whom he so hated.
12996. 
12997. 
12998. 
12999. 
13000. 
13001. CHAPTER VIII
13002. 
13003. 
13004. The day after Rostov had been to see Boris, a review was held of the
13005. Austrian and Russian troops, both those freshly arrived from Russia
13006. and those who had been campaigning under Kutuzov. The two Emperors, the
13007. Russian with his heir the Tsarevich, and the Austrian with the Archduke,
13008. inspected the allied army of eighty thousand men.
13009. 
13010. From early morning the smart clean troops were on the move, forming up
13011. on the field before the fortress. Now thousands of feet and bayonets
13012. moved and halted at the officers' command, turned with banners flying,
13013. formed up at intervals, and wheeled round other similar masses of
13014. infantry in different uniforms; now was heard the rhythmic beat of
13015. hoofs and the jingling of showy cavalry in blue, red, and green braided
13016. uniforms, with smartly dressed bandsmen in front mounted on black, roan,
13017. or gray horses; then again, spreading out with the brazen clatter of the
13018. polished shining cannon that quivered on the gun carriages and with
13019. the smell of linstocks, came the artillery which crawled between the
13020. infantry and cavalry and took up its appointed position. Not only the
13021. generals in full parade uniforms, with their thin or thick waists drawn
13022. in to the utmost, their red necks squeezed into their stiff collars, and
13023. wearing scarves and all their decorations, not only the elegant, pomaded
13024. officers, but every soldier with his freshly washed and shaven face and
13025. his weapons clean and polished to the utmost, and every horse groomed
13026. till its coat shone like satin and every hair of its wetted mane lay
13027. smooth--felt that no small matter was happening, but an important and
13028. solemn affair. Every general and every soldier was conscious of his own
13029. insignificance, aware of being but a drop in that ocean of men, and
13030. yet at the same time was conscious of his strength as a part of that
13031. enormous whole.
13032. 
13033. From early morning strenuous activities and efforts had begun and by ten
13034. o'clock all had been brought into due order. The ranks were drawn up on
13035. the vast field. The whole army was extended in three lines: the cavalry
13036. in front, behind it the artillery, and behind that again the infantry.
13037. 
13038. A space like a street was left between each two lines of troops. The
13039. three parts of that army were sharply distinguished: Kutuzov's fighting
13040. army (with the Pavlograds on the right flank of the front); those
13041. recently arrived from Russia, both Guards and regiments of the line;
13042. and the Austrian troops. But they all stood in the same lines, under one
13043. command, and in a like order.
13044. 
13045. Like wind over leaves ran an excited whisper: "They're coming! They're
13046. coming!" Alarmed voices were heard, and a stir of final preparation
13047. swept over all the troops.
13048. 
13049. From the direction of Olmutz in front of them, a group was seen
13050. approaching. And at that moment, though the day was still, a light gust
13051. of wind blowing over the army slightly stirred the streamers on the
13052. lances and the unfolded standards fluttered against their staffs. It
13053. looked as if by that slight motion the army itself was expressing its
13054. joy at the approach of the Emperors. One voice was heard shouting: "Eyes
13055. front!" Then, like the crowing of cocks at sunrise, this was repeated by
13056. others from various sides and all became silent.
13057. 
13058. In the deathlike stillness only the tramp of horses was heard. This
13059. was the Emperors' suites. The Emperors rode up to the flank, and the
13060. trumpets of the first cavalry regiment played the general march. It
13061. seemed as though not the trumpeters were playing, but as if the army
13062. itself, rejoicing at the Emperors' approach, had naturally burst into
13063. music. Amid these sounds, only the youthful kindly voice of the Emperor
13064. Alexander was clearly heard. He gave the words of greeting, and the
13065. first regiment roared "Hurrah!" so deafeningly, continuously, and
13066. joyfully that the men themselves were awed by their multitude and the
13067. immensity of the power they constituted.
13068. 
13069. Rostov, standing in the front lines of Kutuzov's army which the Tsar
13070. approached first, experienced the same feeling as every other man in
13071. that army: a feeling of self-forgetfulness, a proud consciousness of
13072. might, and a passionate attraction to him who was the cause of this
13073. triumph.
13074. 
13075. He felt that at a single word from that man all this vast mass (and he
13076. himself an insignificant atom in it) would go through fire and water,
13077. commit crime, die, or perform deeds of highest heroism, and so he could
13078. not but tremble and his heart stand still at the imminence of that word.
13079. 
13080. "Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!" thundered from all sides, one regiment after
13081. another greeting the Tsar with the strains of the march, and then
13082. "Hurrah!"... Then the general march, and again "Hurrah! Hurrah!" growing
13083. ever stronger and fuller and merging into a deafening roar.
13084. 
13085. Till the Tsar reached it, each regiment in its silence and immobility
13086. seemed like a lifeless body, but as soon as he came up it became alive,
13087. its thunder joining the roar of the whole line along which he had
13088. already passed. Through the terrible and deafening roar of those voices,
13089. amid the square masses of troops standing motionless as if turned to
13090. stone, hundreds of riders composing the suites moved carelessly but
13091. symmetrically and above all freely, and in front of them two men--the
13092. Emperors. Upon them the undivided, tensely passionate attention of that
13093. whole mass of men was concentrated.
13094. 
13095. The handsome young Emperor Alexander, in the uniform of the Horse
13096. Guards, wearing a cocked hat with its peaks front and back, with his
13097. pleasant face and resonant though not loud voice, attracted everyone's
13098. attention.
13099. 
13100. Rostov was not far from the trumpeters, and with his keen sight had
13101. recognized the Tsar and watched his approach. When he was within twenty
13102. paces, and Nicholas could clearly distinguish every detail of his
13103. handsome, happy young face, he experienced a feeling tenderness and
13104. ecstasy such as he had never before known. Every trait and every
13105. movement of the Tsar's seemed to him enchanting.
13106. 
13107. Stopping in front of the Pavlograds, the Tsar said something in French
13108. to the Austrian Emperor and smiled.
13109. 
13110. Seeing that smile, Rostov involuntarily smiled himself and felt a still
13111. stronger flow of love for his sovereign. He longed to show that love in
13112. some way and knowing that this was impossible was ready to cry. The Tsar
13113. called the colonel of the regiment and said a few words to him.
13114. 
13115. "Oh God, what would happen to me if the Emperor spoke to me?" thought
13116. Rostov. "I should die of happiness!"
13117. 
13118. The Tsar addressed the officers also: "I thank you all, gentlemen, I
13119. thank you with my whole heart." To Rostov every word sounded like a
13120. voice from heaven. How gladly would he have died at once for his Tsar!
13121. 
13122. "You have earned the St. George's standards and will be worthy of them."
13123. 
13124. "Oh, to die, to die for him," thought Rostov.
13125. 
13126. The Tsar said something more which Rostov did not hear, and the
13127. soldiers, straining their lungs, shouted "Hurrah!"
13128. 
13129. Rostov too, bending over his saddle, shouted "Hurrah!" with all his
13130. might, feeling that he would like to injure himself by that shout, if
13131. only to express his rapture fully.
13132. 
13133. The Tsar stopped a few minutes in front of the hussars as if undecided.
13134. 
13135. "How can the Emperor be undecided?" thought Rostov, but then even this
13136. indecision appeared to him majestic and enchanting, like everything else
13137. the Tsar did.
13138. 
13139. That hesitation lasted only an instant. The Tsar's foot, in the narrow
13140. pointed boot then fashionable, touched the groin of the bobtailed bay
13141. mare he rode, his hand in a white glove gathered up the reins, and he
13142. moved off accompanied by an irregularly swaying sea of aides-de-camp.
13143. Farther and farther he rode away, stopping at other regiments, till at
13144. last only his white plumes were visible to Rostov from amid the suites
13145. that surrounded the Emperors.
13146. 
13147. Among the gentlemen of the suite, Rostov noticed Bolkonski, sitting
13148. his horse indolently and carelessly. Rostov recalled their quarrel of
13149. yesterday and the question presented itself whether he ought or ought
13150. not to challenge Bolkonski. "Of course not!" he now thought. "Is it
13151. worth thinking or speaking of it at such a moment? At a time of such
13152. love, such rapture, and such self-sacrifice, what do any of our quarrels
13153. and affronts matter? I love and forgive everybody now."
13154. 
13155. When the Emperor had passed nearly all the regiments, the troops began
13156. a ceremonial march past him, and Rostov on Bedouin, recently purchased
13157. from Denisov, rode past too, at the rear of his squadron--that is, alone
13158. and in full view of the Emperor.
13159. 
13160. Before he reached him, Rostov, who was a splendid horseman, spurred
13161. Bedouin twice and successfully put him to the showy trot in which the
13162. animal went when excited. Bending his foaming muzzle to his chest, his
13163. tail extended, Bedouin, as if also conscious of the Emperor's eye
13164. upon him, passed splendidly, lifting his feet with a high and graceful
13165. action, as if flying through the air without touching the ground.
13166. 
13167. Rostov himself, his legs well back and his stomach drawn in and feeling
13168. himself one with his horse, rode past the Emperor with a frowning but
13169. blissful face "like a vewy devil," as Denisov expressed it.
13170. 
13171. "Fine fellows, the Pavlograds!" remarked the Emperor.
13172. 
13173. "My God, how happy I should be if he ordered me to leap into the fire
13174. this instant!" thought Rostov.
13175. 
13176. When the review was over, the newly arrived officers, and also
13177. Kutuzov's, collected in groups and began to talk about the awards, about
13178. the Austrians and their uniforms, about their lines, about Bonaparte,
13179. and how badly the latter would fare now, especially if the Essen corps
13180. arrived and Prussia took our side.
13181. 
13182. But the talk in every group was chiefly about the Emperor Alexander. His
13183. every word and movement was described with ecstasy.
13184. 
13185. They all had but one wish: to advance as soon as possible against the
13186. enemy under the Emperor's command. Commanded by the Emperor himself
13187. they could not fail to vanquish anyone, be it whom it might: so thought
13188. Rostov and most of the officers after the review.
13189. 
13190. All were then more confident of victory than the winning of two battles
13191. would have made them.
13192. 
13193. 
13194. 
13195. 
13196. 
13197. CHAPTER IX
13198. 
13199. 
13200. The day after the review, Boris, in his best uniform and with his
13201. comrade Berg's best wishes for success, rode to Olmutz to see Bolkonski,
13202. wishing to profit by his friendliness and obtain for himself the best
13203. post he could--preferably that of adjutant to some important personage,
13204. a position in the army which seemed to him most attractive. "It is all
13205. very well for Rostov, whose father sends him ten thousand rubles at a
13206. time, to talk about not wishing to cringe to anybody and not be anyone's
13207. lackey, but I who have nothing but my brains have to make a career
13208. and must not miss opportunities, but must avail myself of them!" he
13209. reflected.
13210. 
13211. He did not find Prince Andrew in Olmutz that day, but the appearance of
13212. the town where the headquarters and the diplomatic corps were stationed
13213. and the two Emperors were living with their suites, households, and
13214. courts only strengthened his desire to belong to that higher world.
13215. 
13216. He knew no one, and despite his smart Guardsman's uniform, all these
13217. exalted personages passing in the streets in their elegant carriages
13218. with their plumes, ribbons, and medals, both courtiers and military
13219. men, seemed so immeasurably above him, an insignificant officer of the
13220. Guards, that they not only did not wish to, but simply could not, be
13221. aware of his existence. At the quarters of the commander in chief,
13222. Kutuzov, where he inquired for Bolkonski, all the adjutants and even the
13223. orderlies looked at him as if they wished to impress on him that a great
13224. many officers like him were always coming there and that everybody was
13225. heartily sick of them. In spite of this, or rather because of it, next
13226. day, November 15, after dinner he again went to Olmutz and, entering the
13227. house occupied by Kutuzov, asked for Bolkonski. Prince Andrew was in and
13228. Boris was shown into a large hall probably formerly used for dancing,
13229. but in which five beds now stood, and furniture of various kinds: a
13230. table, chairs, and a clavichord. One adjutant, nearest the door, was
13231. sitting at the table in a Persian dressing gown, writing. Another,
13232. the red, stout Nesvitski, lay on a bed with his arms under his head,
13233. laughing with an officer who had sat down beside him. A third was
13234. playing a Viennese waltz on the clavichord, while a fourth, lying on
13235. the clavichord, sang the tune. Bolkonski was not there. None of these
13236. gentlemen changed his position on seeing Boris. The one who was writing
13237. and whom Boris addressed turned round crossly and told him Bolkonski
13238. was on duty and that he should go through the door on the left into the
13239. reception room if he wished to see him. Boris thanked him and went to
13240. the reception room, where he found some ten officers and generals.
13241. 
13242. When he entered, Prince Andrew, his eyes drooping contemptuously (with
13243. that peculiar expression of polite weariness which plainly says, "If it
13244. were not my duty I would not talk to you for a moment"), was listening
13245. to an old Russian general with decorations, who stood very erect, almost
13246. on tiptoe, with a soldier's obsequious expression on his purple face,
13247. reporting something.
13248. 
13249. "Very well, then, be so good as to wait," said Prince Andrew to the
13250. general, in Russian, speaking with the French intonation he affected
13251. when he wished to speak contemptuously, and noticing Boris, Prince
13252. Andrew, paying no more heed to the general who ran after him imploring
13253. him to hear something more, nodded and turned to him with a cheerful
13254. smile.
13255. 
13256. At that moment Boris clearly realized what he had before surmised, that
13257. in the army, besides the subordination and discipline prescribed in the
13258. military code, which he and the others knew in the regiment, there was
13259. another, more important, subordination, which made this tight-laced,
13260. purple-faced general wait respectfully while Captain Prince Andrew, for
13261. his own pleasure, chose to chat with Lieutenant Drubetskoy. More than
13262. ever was Boris resolved to serve in future not according to the written
13263. code, but under this unwritten law. He felt now that merely by having
13264. been recommended to Prince Andrew he had already risen above the general
13265. who at the front had the power to annihilate him, a lieutenant of the
13266. Guards. Prince Andrew came up to him and took his hand.
13267. 
13268. "I am very sorry you did not find me in yesterday. I was fussing about
13269. with Germans all day. We went with Weyrother to survey the dispositions.
13270. When Germans start being accurate, there's no end to it!"
13271. 
13272. Boris smiled, as if he understood what Prince Andrew was alluding to
13273. as something generally known. But it was the first time he had heard
13274. Weyrother's name, or even the term "dispositions."
13275. 
13276. "Well, my dear fellow, so you still want to be an adjutant? I have been
13277. thinking about you."
13278. 
13279. "Yes, I was thinking"--for some reason Boris could not help
13280. blushing--"of asking the commander in chief. He has had a letter from
13281. Prince Kuragin about me. I only wanted to ask because I fear the Guards
13282. won't be in action," he added as if in apology.
13283. 
13284. "All right, all right. We'll talk it over," replied Prince Andrew.
13285. "Only let me report this gentleman's business, and I shall be at your
13286. disposal."
13287. 
13288. While Prince Andrew went to report about the purple-faced general, that
13289. gentleman--evidently not sharing Boris' conception of the advantages
13290. of the unwritten code of subordination--looked so fixedly at the
13291. presumptuous lieutenant who had prevented his finishing what he had to
13292. say to the adjutant that Boris felt uncomfortable. He turned away and
13293. waited impatiently for Prince Andrew's return from the commander in
13294. chief's room.
13295. 
13296. "You see, my dear fellow, I have been thinking about you," said Prince
13297. Andrew when they had gone into the large room where the clavichord was.
13298. "It's no use your going to the commander in chief. He would say a lot of
13299. pleasant things, ask you to dinner" ("That would not be bad as regards
13300. the unwritten code," thought Boris), "but nothing more would come of it.
13301. There will soon be a battalion of us aides-de-camp and adjutants! But
13302. this is what we'll do: I have a good friend, an adjutant general and an
13303. excellent fellow, Prince Dolgorukov; and though you may not know it, the
13304. fact is that now Kutuzov with his staff and all of us count for
13305. nothing. Everything is now centered round the Emperor. So we will go to
13306. Dolgorukov; I have to go there anyhow and I have already spoken to him
13307. about you. We shall see whether he cannot attach you to himself or find
13308. a place for you somewhere nearer the sun."
13309. 
13310. Prince Andrew always became specially keen when he had to guide a young
13311. man and help him to worldly success. Under cover of obtaining help
13312. of this kind for another, which from pride he would never accept for
13313. himself, he kept in touch with the circle which confers success and
13314. which attracted him. He very readily took up Boris' cause and went with
13315. him to Dolgorukov.
13316. 
13317. It was late in the evening when they entered the palace at Olmutz
13318. occupied by the Emperors and their retinues.
13319. 
13320. That same day a council of war had been held in which all the members of
13321. the Hofkriegsrath and both Emperors took part. At that council, contrary
13322. to the views of the old generals Kutuzov and Prince Schwartzenberg, it
13323. had been decided to advance immediately and give battle to Bonaparte.
13324. The council of war was just over when Prince Andrew accompanied by Boris
13325. arrived at the palace to find Dolgorukov. Everyone at headquarters was
13326. still under the spell of the day's council, at which the party of the
13327. young had triumphed. The voices of those who counseled delay and advised
13328. waiting for something else before advancing had been so completely
13329. silenced and their arguments confuted by such conclusive evidence of the
13330. advantages of attacking that what had been discussed at the council--the
13331. coming battle and the victory that would certainly result from it--no
13332. longer seemed to be in the future but in the past. All the advantages
13333. were on our side. Our enormous forces, undoubtedly superior to
13334. Napoleon's, were concentrated in one place, the troops inspired by the
13335. Emperors' presence were eager for action. The strategic position where
13336. the operations would take place was familiar in all its details to
13337. the Austrian General Weyrother: a lucky accident had ordained that the
13338. Austrian army should maneuver the previous year on the very fields where
13339. the French had now to be fought; the adjacent locality was known and
13340. shown in every detail on the maps, and Bonaparte, evidently weakened,
13341. was undertaking nothing.
13342. 
13343. Dolgorukov, one of the warmest advocates of an attack, had just returned
13344. from the council, tired and exhausted but eager and proud of the victory
13345. that had been gained. Prince Andrew introduced his protege, but Prince
13346. Dolgorukov politely and firmly pressing his hand said nothing to Boris
13347. and, evidently unable to suppress the thoughts which were uppermost in
13348. his mind at that moment, addressed Prince Andrew in French.
13349. 
13350. "Ah, my dear fellow, what a battle we have gained! God grant that
13351. the one that will result from it will be as victorious! However, dear
13352. fellow," he said abruptly and eagerly, "I must confess to having been
13353. unjust to the Austrians and especially to Weyrother. What exactitude,
13354. what minuteness, what knowledge of the locality, what foresight for
13355. every eventuality, every possibility even to the smallest detail! No, my
13356. dear fellow, no conditions better than our present ones could have been
13357. devised. This combination of Austrian precision with Russian valor--what
13358. more could be wished for?"
13359. 
13360. "So the attack is definitely resolved on?" asked Bolkonski.
13361. 
13362. "And do you know, my dear fellow, it seems to me that Bonaparte has
13363. decidedly lost bearings, you know that a letter was received from him
13364. today for the Emperor." Dolgorukov smiled significantly.
13365. 
13366. "Is that so? And what did he say?" inquired Bolkonski.
13367. 
13368. "What can he say? Tra-di-ri-di-ra and so on... merely to gain time. I
13369. tell you he is in our hands, that's certain! But what was most amusing,"
13370. he continued, with a sudden, good-natured laugh, "was that we could not
13371. think how to address the reply! If not as 'Consul' and of course not as
13372. 'Emperor,' it seemed to me it should be to 'General Bonaparte.'"
13373. 
13374. "But between not recognizing him as Emperor and calling him General
13375. Bonaparte, there is a difference," remarked Bolkonski.
13376. 
13377. "That's just it," interrupted Dolgorukov quickly, laughing. "You know
13378. Bilibin--he's a very clever fellow. He suggested addressing him as
13379. 'Usurper and Enemy of Mankind.'"
13380. 
13381. Dolgorukov laughed merrily.
13382. 
13383. "Only that?" said Bolkonski.
13384. 
13385. "All the same, it was Bilibin who found a suitable form for the address.
13386. He is a wise and clever fellow."
13387. 
13388. "What was it?"
13389. 
13390. "To the Head of the French Government... Au chef du gouvernement
13391. francais," said Dolgorukov, with grave satisfaction. "Good, wasn't it?"
13392. 
13393. "Yes, but he will dislike it extremely," said Bolkonski.
13394. 
13395. "Oh yes, very much! My brother knows him, he's dined with him--the
13396. present Emperor--more than once in Paris, and tells me he never met a
13397. more cunning or subtle diplomatist--you know, a combination of French
13398. adroitness and Italian play-acting! Do you know the tale about him and
13399. Count Markov? Count Markov was the only man who knew how to handle him.
13400. You know the story of the handkerchief? It is delightful!"
13401. 
13402. And the talkative Dolgorukov, turning now to Boris, now to Prince
13403. Andrew, told how Bonaparte wishing to test Markov, our ambassador,
13404. purposely dropped a handkerchief in front of him and stood looking at
13405. Markov, probably expecting Markov to pick it up for him, and how Markov
13406. immediately dropped his own beside it and picked it up without touching
13407. Bonaparte's.
13408. 
13409. "Delightful!" said Bolkonski. "But I have come to you, Prince, as a
13410. petitioner on behalf of this young man. You see..." but before Prince
13411. Andrew could finish, an aide-de-camp came in to summon Dolgorukov to the
13412. Emperor.
13413. 
13414. "Oh, what a nuisance," said Dolgorukov, getting up hurriedly and
13415. pressing the hands of Prince Andrew and Boris. "You know I should be
13416. very glad to do all in my power both for you and for this dear young
13417. man." Again he pressed the hand of the latter with an expression of
13418. good-natured, sincere, and animated levity. "But you see... another
13419. time!"
13420. 
13421. Boris was excited by the thought of being so close to the higher powers
13422. as he felt himself to be at that moment. He was conscious that here
13423. he was in contact with the springs that set in motion the enormous
13424. movements of the mass of which in his regiment he felt himself a tiny,
13425. obedient, and insignificant atom. They followed Prince Dolgorukov out
13426. into the corridor and met--coming out of the door of the Emperor's room
13427. by which Dolgorukov had entered--a short man in civilian clothes with a
13428. clever face and sharply projecting jaw which, without spoiling his face,
13429. gave him a peculiar vivacity and shiftiness of expression. This short
13430. man nodded to Dolgorukov as to an intimate friend and stared at Prince
13431. Andrew with cool intensity, walking straight toward him and evidently
13432. expecting him to bow or to step out of his way. Prince Andrew did
13433. neither: a look of animosity appeared on his face and the other turned
13434. away and went down the side of the corridor.
13435. 
13436. "Who was that?" asked Boris.
13437. 
13438. "He is one of the most remarkable, but to me most unpleasant of men--the
13439. Minister of Foreign Affairs, Prince Adam Czartoryski.... It is such men
13440. as he who decide the fate of nations," added Bolkonski with a sigh he
13441. could not suppress, as they passed out of the palace.
13442. 
13443. Next day, the army began its campaign, and up to the very battle of
13444. Austerlitz, Boris was unable to see either Prince Andrew or Dolgorukov
13445. again and remained for a while with the Ismaylov regiment.
13446. 
13447. 
13448. 
13449. 
13450. 
13451. CHAPTER X
13452. 
13453. 
13454. At dawn on the sixteenth of November, Denisov's squadron, in which
13455. Nicholas Rostov served and which was in Prince Bagration's detachment,
13456. moved from the place where it had spent the night, advancing into action
13457. as arranged, and after going behind other columns for about two thirds
13458. of a mile was stopped on the highroad. Rostov saw the Cossacks and then
13459. the first and second squadrons of hussars and infantry battalions
13460. and artillery pass by and go forward and then Generals Bagration and
13461. Dolgorukov ride past with their adjutants. All the fear before action
13462. which he had experienced as previously, all the inner struggle to
13463. conquer that fear, all his dreams of distinguishing himself as a true
13464. hussar in this battle, had been wasted. Their squadron remained in
13465. reserve and Nicholas Rostov spent that day in a dull and wretched mood.
13466. At nine in the morning, he heard firing in front and shouts of hurrah,
13467. and saw wounded being brought back (there were not many of them), and
13468. at last he saw how a whole detachment of French cavalry was brought in,
13469. convoyed by a sotnya of Cossacks. Evidently the affair was over and,
13470. though not big, had been a successful engagement. The men and officers
13471. returning spoke of a brilliant victory, of the occupation of the town of
13472. Wischau and the capture of a whole French squadron. The day was bright
13473. and sunny after a sharp night frost, and the cheerful glitter of that
13474. autumn day was in keeping with the news of victory which was conveyed,
13475. not only by the tales of those who had taken part in it, but also by
13476. the joyful expression on the faces of soldiers, officers, generals, and
13477. adjutants, as they passed Rostov going or coming. And Nicholas, who had
13478. vainly suffered all the dread that precedes a battle and had spent that
13479. happy day in inactivity, was all the more depressed.
13480. 
13481. "Come here, Wostov. Let's dwink to dwown our gwief!" shouted Denisov,
13482. who had settled down by the roadside with a flask and some food.
13483. 
13484. The officers gathered round Denisov's canteen, eating and talking.
13485. 
13486. "There! They are bringing another!" cried one of the officers,
13487. indicating a captive French dragoon who was being brought in on foot by
13488. two Cossacks.
13489. 
13490. One of them was leading by the bridle a fine large French horse he had
13491. taken from the prisoner.
13492. 
13493. "Sell us that horse!" Denisov called out to the Cossacks.
13494. 
13495. "If you like, your honor!"
13496. 
13497. The officers got up and stood round the Cossacks and their prisoner.
13498. The French dragoon was a young Alsatian who spoke French with a German
13499. accent. He was breathless with agitation, his face was red, and when
13500. he heard some French spoken he at once began speaking to the officers,
13501. addressing first one, then another. He said he would not have been
13502. taken, it was not his fault but the corporal's who had sent him to seize
13503. some horsecloths, though he had told him the Russians were there. And at
13504. every word he added: "But don't hurt my little horse!" and stroked the
13505. animal. It was plain that he did not quite grasp where he was. Now
13506. he excused himself for having been taken prisoner and now, imagining
13507. himself before his own officers, insisted on his soldierly discipline
13508. and zeal in the service. He brought with him into our rearguard all the
13509. freshness of atmosphere of the French army, which was so alien to us.
13510. 
13511. The Cossacks sold the horse for two gold pieces, and Rostov, being the
13512. richest of the officers now that he had received his money, bought it.
13513. 
13514. "But don't hurt my little horse!" said the Alsatian good-naturedly to
13515. Rostov when the animal was handed over to the hussar.
13516. 
13517. Rostov smilingly reassured the dragoon and gave him money.
13518. 
13519. "Alley! Alley!" said the Cossack, touching the prisoner's arm to make
13520. him go on.
13521. 
13522. "The Emperor! The Emperor!" was suddenly heard among the hussars.
13523. 
13524. All began to run and bustle, and Rostov saw coming up the road behind
13525. him several riders with white plumes in their hats. In a moment everyone
13526. was in his place, waiting.
13527. 
13528. Rostov did not know or remember how he ran to his place and mounted.
13529. Instantly his regret at not having been in action and his dejected mood
13530. amid people of whom he was weary had gone, instantly every thought of
13531. himself had vanished. He was filled with happiness at his nearness to
13532. the Emperor. He felt that this nearness by itself made up to him for the
13533. day he had lost. He was happy as a lover when the longed-for moment of
13534. meeting arrives. Not daring to look round and without looking round, he
13535. was ecstatically conscious of his approach. He felt it not only from the
13536. sound of the hoofs of the approaching cavalcade, but because as he drew
13537. near everything grew brighter, more joyful, more significant, and more
13538. festive around him. Nearer and nearer to Rostov came that sun shedding
13539. beams of mild and majestic light around, and already he felt himself
13540. enveloped in those beams, he heard his voice, that kindly, calm, and
13541. majestic voice that was yet so simple! And as if in accord with
13542. Rostov's feeling, there was a deathly stillness amid which was heard the
13543. Emperor's voice.
13544. 
13545. "The Pavlograd hussars?" he inquired.
13546. 
13547. "The reserves, sire!" replied a voice, a very human one compared to that
13548. which had said: "The Pavlograd hussars?"
13549. 
13550. The Emperor drew level with Rostov and halted. Alexander's face was
13551. even more beautiful than it had been three days before at the review. It
13552. shone with such gaiety and youth, such innocent youth, that it suggested
13553. the liveliness of a fourteen-year-old boy, and yet it was the face
13554. of the majestic Emperor. Casually, while surveying the squadron, the
13555. Emperor's eyes met Rostov's and rested on them for not more than two
13556. seconds. Whether or no the Emperor understood what was going on in
13557. Rostov's soul (it seemed to Rostov that he understood everything), at
13558. any rate his light-blue eyes gazed for about two seconds into Rostov's
13559. face. A gentle, mild light poured from them. Then all at once he
13560. raised his eyebrows, abruptly touched his horse with his left foot, and
13561. galloped on.
13562. 
13563. The younger Emperor could not restrain his wish to be present at the
13564. battle and, in spite of the remonstrances of his courtiers, at twelve
13565. o'clock left the third column with which he had been and galloped toward
13566. the vanguard. Before he came up with the hussars, several adjutants met
13567. him with news of the successful result of the action.
13568. 
13569. This battle, which consisted in the capture of a French squadron, was
13570. represented as a brilliant victory over the French, and so the
13571. Emperor and the whole army, especially while the smoke hung over
13572. the battlefield, believed that the French had been defeated and were
13573. retreating against their will. A few minutes after the Emperor had
13574. passed, the Pavlograd division was ordered to advance. In Wischau
13575. itself, a petty German town, Rostov saw the Emperor again. In the
13576. market place, where there had been some rather heavy firing before the
13577. Emperor's arrival, lay several killed and wounded soldiers whom there
13578. had not been time to move. The Emperor, surrounded by his suite
13579. of officers and courtiers, was riding a bobtailed chestnut mare, a
13580. different one from that which he had ridden at the review, and bending
13581. to one side he gracefully held a gold lorgnette to his eyes and looked
13582. at a soldier who lay prone, with blood on his uncovered head. The
13583. wounded soldier was so dirty, coarse, and revolting that his proximity
13584. to the Emperor shocked Rostov. Rostov saw how the Emperor's rather round
13585. shoulders shuddered as if a cold shiver had run down them, how his left
13586. foot began convulsively tapping the horse's side with the spur, and how
13587. the well-trained horse looked round unconcerned and did not stir. An
13588. adjutant, dismounting, lifted the soldier under the arms to place him on
13589. a stretcher that had been brought. The soldier groaned.
13590. 
13591. "Gently, gently! Can't you do it more gently?" said the Emperor
13592. apparently suffering more than the dying soldier, and he rode away.
13593. 
13594. Rostov saw tears filling the Emperor's eyes and heard him, as he was
13595. riding away, say to Czartoryski: "What a terrible thing war is: what a
13596. terrible thing! Quelle terrible chose que la guerre!"
13597. 
13598. The troops of the vanguard were stationed before Wischau, within sight
13599. of the enemy's lines, which all day long had yielded ground to us at
13600. the least firing. The Emperor's gratitude was announced to the vanguard,
13601. rewards were promised, and the men received a double ration of vodka.
13602. The campfires crackled and the soldiers' songs resounded even more
13603. merrily than on the previous night. Denisov celebrated his promotion to
13604. the rank of major, and Rostov, who had already drunk enough, at the end
13605. of the feast proposed the Emperor's health. "Not 'our Sovereign, the
13606. Emperor,' as they say at official dinners," said he, "but the health of
13607. our Sovereign, that good, enchanting, and great man! Let us drink to his
13608. health and to the certain defeat of the French!"
13609. 
13610. "If we fought before," he said, "not letting the French pass, as at
13611. Schon Grabern, what shall we not do now when he is at the front? We will
13612. all die for him gladly! Is it not so, gentlemen? Perhaps I am not saying
13613. it right, I have drunk a good deal--but that is how I feel, and so do
13614. you too! To the health of Alexander the First! Hurrah!"
13615. 
13616. "Hurrah!" rang the enthusiastic voices of the officers.
13617. 
13618. And the old cavalry captain, Kirsten, shouted enthusiastically and no
13619. less sincerely than the twenty-year-old Rostov.
13620. 
13621. When the officers had emptied and smashed their glasses, Kirsten filled
13622. others and, in shirt sleeves and breeches, went glass in hand to the
13623. soldiers' bonfires and with his long gray mustache, his white chest
13624. showing under his open shirt, he stood in a majestic pose in the light
13625. of the campfire, waving his uplifted arm.
13626. 
13627. "Lads! here's to our Sovereign, the Emperor, and victory over our
13628. enemies! Hurrah!" he exclaimed in his dashing, old, hussar's baritone.
13629. 
13630. The hussars crowded round and responded heartily with loud shouts.
13631. 
13632. Late that night, when all had separated, Denisov with his short hand
13633. patted his favorite, Rostov, on the shoulder.
13634. 
13635. "As there's no one to fall in love with on campaign, he's fallen in love
13636. with the Tsar," he said.
13637. 
13638. "Denisov, don't make fun of it!" cried Rostov. "It is such a lofty,
13639. beautiful feeling, such a..."
13640. 
13641. "I believe it, I believe it, fwiend, and I share and appwove..."
13642. 
13643. "No, you don't understand!"
13644. 
13645. And Rostov got up and went wandering among the campfires, dreaming of
13646. what happiness it would be to die--not in saving the Emperor's life (he
13647. did not even dare to dream of that), but simply to die before his eyes.
13648. He really was in love with the Tsar and the glory of the Russian
13649. arms and the hope of future triumph. And he was not the only man to
13650. experience that feeling during those memorable days preceding the battle
13651. of Austerlitz: nine tenths of the men in the Russian army were then in
13652. love, though less ecstatically, with their Tsar and the glory of the
13653. Russian arms.
13654. 
13655. 
13656. 
13657. 
13658. 
13659. CHAPTER XI
13660. 
13661. 
13662. The next day the Emperor stopped at Wischau, and Villier, his physician,
13663. was repeatedly summoned to see him. At headquarters and among the troops
13664. near by the news spread that the Emperor was unwell. He ate nothing and
13665. had slept badly that night, those around him reported. The cause of this
13666. indisposition was the strong impression made on his sensitive mind by
13667. the sight of the killed and wounded.
13668. 
13669. At daybreak on the seventeenth, a French officer who had come with
13670. a flag of truce, demanding an audience with the Russian Emperor, was
13671. brought into Wischau from our outposts. This officer was Savary. The
13672. Emperor had only just fallen asleep and so Savary had to wait. At midday
13673. he was admitted to the Emperor, and an hour later he rode off with
13674. Prince Dolgorukov to the advanced post of the French army.
13675. 
13676. It was rumored that Savary had been sent to propose to Alexander
13677. a meeting with Napoleon. To the joy and pride of the whole army, a
13678. personal interview was refused, and instead of the Sovereign, Prince
13679. Dolgorukov, the victor at Wischau, was sent with Savary to negotiate
13680. with Napoleon if, contrary to expectations, these negotiations were
13681. actuated by a real desire for peace.
13682. 
13683. Toward evening Dolgorukov came back, went straight to the Tsar, and
13684. remained alone with him for a long time.
13685. 
13686. On the eighteenth and nineteenth of November, the army advanced two
13687. days' march and the enemy's outposts after a brief interchange of shots
13688. retreated. In the highest army circles from midday on the nineteenth, a
13689. great, excitedly bustling activity began which lasted till the morning
13690. of the twentieth, when the memorable battle of Austerlitz was fought.
13691. 
13692. Till midday on the nineteenth, the activity--the eager talk, running
13693. to and fro, and dispatching of adjutants--was confined to the Emperor's
13694. headquarters. But on the afternoon of that day, this activity reached
13695. Kutuzov's headquarters and the staffs of the commanders of columns. By
13696. evening, the adjutants had spread it to all ends and parts of the army,
13697. and in the night from the nineteenth to the twentieth, the whole eighty
13698. thousand allied troops rose from their bivouacs to the hum of voices,
13699. and the army swayed and started in one enormous mass six miles long.
13700. 
13701. The concentrated activity which had begun at the Emperor's headquarters
13702. in the morning and had started the whole movement that followed was like
13703. the first movement of the main wheel of a large tower clock. One wheel
13704. slowly moved, another was set in motion, and a third, and wheels began
13705. to revolve faster and faster, levers and cogwheels to work, chimes to
13706. play, figures to pop out, and the hands to advance with regular motion
13707. as a result of all that activity.
13708. 
13709. Just as in the mechanism of a clock, so in the mechanism of the military
13710. machine, an impulse once given leads to the final result; and just as
13711. indifferently quiescent till the moment when motion is transmitted
13712. to them are the parts of the mechanism which the impulse has not yet
13713. reached. Wheels creak on their axles as the cogs engage one another and
13714. the revolving pulleys whirr with the rapidity of their movement, but a
13715. neighboring wheel is as quiet and motionless as though it were prepared
13716. to remain so for a hundred years; but the moment comes when the lever
13717. catches it and obeying the impulse that wheel begins to creak and joins
13718. in the common motion the result and aim of which are beyond its ken.
13719. 
13720. Just as in a clock, the result of the complicated motion of innumerable
13721. wheels and pulleys is merely a slow and regular movement of the
13722. hands which show the time, so the result of all the complicated human
13723. activities of 160,000 Russians and French--all their passions, desires,
13724. remorse, humiliations, sufferings, outbursts of pride, fear, and
13725. enthusiasm--was only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz, the so-called
13726. battle of the three Emperors--that is to say, a slow movement of the
13727. hand on the dial of human history.
13728. 
13729. Prince Andrew was on duty that day and in constant attendance on the
13730. commander in chief.
13731. 
13732. At six in the evening, Kutuzov went to the Emperor's headquarters and
13733. after staying but a short time with the Tsar went to see the grand
13734. marshal of the court, Count Tolstoy.
13735. 
13736. Bolkonski took the opportunity to go in to get some details of the
13737. coming action from Dolgorukov. He felt that Kutuzov was upset and
13738. dissatisfied about something and that at headquarters they were
13739. dissatisfied with him, and also that at the Emperor's headquarters
13740. everyone adopted toward him the tone of men who know something others do
13741. not know: he therefore wished to speak to Dolgorukov.
13742. 
13743. "Well, how d'you do, my dear fellow?" said Dolgorukov, who was sitting
13744. at tea with Bilibin. "The fete is for tomorrow. How is your old fellow?
13745. Out of sorts?"
13746. 
13747. "I won't say he is out of sorts, but I fancy he would like to be heard."
13748. 
13749. "But they heard him at the council of war and will hear him when he
13750. talks sense, but to temporize and wait for something now when Bonaparte
13751. fears nothing so much as a general battle is impossible."
13752. 
13753. "Yes, you have seen him?" said Prince Andrew. "Well, what is Bonaparte
13754. like? How did he impress you?"
13755. 
13756. "Yes, I saw him, and am convinced that he fears nothing so much as a
13757. general engagement," repeated Dolgorukov, evidently prizing this general
13758. conclusion which he had arrived at from his interview with Napoleon.
13759. "If he weren't afraid of a battle why did he ask for that interview? Why
13760. negotiate, and above all why retreat, when to retreat is so contrary
13761. to his method of conducting war? Believe me, he is afraid, afraid of a
13762. general battle. His hour has come! Mark my words!"
13763. 
13764. "But tell me, what is he like, eh?" said Prince Andrew again.
13765. 
13766. "He is a man in a gray overcoat, very anxious that I should call him
13767. 'Your Majesty,' but who, to his chagrin, got no title from me! That's
13768. the sort of man he is, and nothing more," replied Dolgorukov, looking
13769. round at Bilibin with a smile.
13770. 
13771. "Despite my great respect for old Kutuzov," he continued, "we should be
13772. a nice set of fellows if we were to wait about and so give him a chance
13773. to escape, or to trick us, now that we certainly have him in our hands!
13774. No, we mustn't forget Suvorov and his rule--not to put yourself in a
13775. position to be attacked, but yourself to attack. Believe me in war the
13776. energy of young men often shows the way better than all the experience
13777. of old Cunctators."
13778. 
13779. "But in what position are we going to attack him? I have been at the
13780. outposts today and it is impossible to say where his chief forces are
13781. situated," said Prince Andrew.
13782. 
13783. He wished to explain to Dolgorukov a plan of attack he had himself
13784. formed.
13785. 
13786. "Oh, that is all the same," Dolgorukov said quickly, and getting up he
13787. spread a map on the table. "All eventualities have been foreseen. If he
13788. is standing before Brunn..."
13789. 
13790. And Prince Dolgorukov rapidly but indistinctly explained Weyrother's
13791. plan of a flanking movement.
13792. 
13793. Prince Andrew began to reply and to state his own plan, which might have
13794. been as good as Weyrother's, but for the disadvantage that Weyrother's
13795. had already been approved. As soon as Prince Andrew began to demonstrate
13796. the defects of the latter and the merits of his own plan, Prince
13797. Dolgorukov ceased to listen to him and gazed absent-mindedly not at the
13798. map, but at Prince Andrew's face.
13799. 
13800. "There will be a council of war at Kutuzov's tonight, though; you can
13801. say all this there," remarked Dolgorukov.
13802. 
13803. "I will do so," said Prince Andrew, moving away from the map.
13804. 
13805. "Whatever are you bothering about, gentlemen?" said Bilibin, who, till
13806. then, had listened with an amused smile to their conversation and now
13807. was evidently ready with a joke. "Whether tomorrow brings victory or
13808. defeat, the glory of our Russian arms is secure. Except your Kutuzov,
13809. there is not a single Russian in command of a column! The commanders
13810. are: Herr General Wimpfen, le Comte de Langeron, le Prince de
13811. Lichtenstein, le Prince, de Hohenlohe, and finally Prishprish, and so on
13812. like all those Polish names."
13813. 
13814. "Be quiet, backbiter!" said Dolgorukov. "It is not true; there are now
13815. two Russians, Miloradovich, and Dokhturov, and there would be a third,
13816. Count Arakcheev, if his nerves were not too weak."
13817. 
13818. "However, I think General Kutuzov has come out," said Prince Andrew. "I
13819. wish you good luck and success, gentlemen!" he added and went out after
13820. shaking hands with Dolgorukov and Bilibin.
13821. 
13822. On the way home, Prince Andrew could not refrain from asking Kutuzov,
13823. who was sitting silently beside him, what he thought of tomorrow's
13824. battle.
13825. 
13826. Kutuzov looked sternly at his adjutant and, after a pause, replied: "I
13827. think the battle will be lost, and so I told Count Tolstoy and asked
13828. him to tell the Emperor. What do you think he replied? 'But, my dear
13829. general, I am engaged with rice and cutlets, look after military matters
13830. yourself!' Yes... That was the answer I got!"
13831. 
13832. 
13833. 
13834. 
13835. 
13836. CHAPTER XII
13837. 
13838. 
13839. Shortly after nine o'clock that evening, Weyrother drove with his plans
13840. to Kutuzov's quarters where the council of war was to be held. All the
13841. commanders of columns were summoned to the commander in chief's and with
13842. the exception of Prince Bagration, who declined to come, were all there
13843. at the appointed time.
13844. 
13845. Weyrother, who was in full control of the proposed battle, by his
13846. eagerness and briskness presented a marked contrast to the dissatisfied
13847. and drowsy Kutuzov, who reluctantly played the part of chairman and
13848. president of the council of war. Weyrother evidently felt himself to be
13849. at the head of a movement that had already become unrestrainable. He was
13850. like a horse running downhill harnessed to a heavy cart. Whether he was
13851. pulling it or being pushed by it he did not know, but rushed along at
13852. headlong speed with no time to consider what this movement might lead
13853. to. Weyrother had been twice that evening to the enemy's picket line to
13854. reconnoiter personally, and twice to the Emperors, Russian and Austrian,
13855. to report and explain, and to his headquarters where he had dictated
13856. the dispositions in German, and now, much exhausted, he arrived at
13857. Kutuzov's.
13858. 
13859. He was evidently so busy that he even forgot to be polite to the
13860. commander in chief. He interrupted him, talked rapidly and indistinctly,
13861. without looking at the man he was addressing, and did not reply to
13862. questions put to him. He was bespattered with mud and had a pitiful,
13863. weary, and distracted air, though at the same time he was haughty and
13864. self-confident.
13865. 
13866. Kutuzov was occupying a nobleman's castle of modest dimensions near
13867. Ostralitz. In the large drawing room which had become the commander in
13868. chief's office were gathered Kutuzov himself, Weyrother, and the members
13869. of the council of war. They were drinking tea, and only awaited Prince
13870. Bagration to begin the council. At last Bagration's orderly came with
13871. the news that the prince could not attend. Prince Andrew came in
13872. to inform the commander in chief of this and, availing himself of
13873. permission previously given him by Kutuzov to be present at the council,
13874. he remained in the room.
13875. 
13876. "Since Prince Bagration is not coming, we may begin," said Weyrother,
13877. hurriedly rising from his seat and going up to the table on which an
13878. enormous map of the environs of Brunn was spread out.
13879. 
13880. Kutuzov, with his uniform unbuttoned so that his fat neck bulged over
13881. his collar as if escaping, was sitting almost asleep in a low chair,
13882. with his podgy old hands resting symmetrically on its arms. At the sound
13883. of Weyrother's voice, he opened his one eye with an effort.
13884. 
13885. "Yes, yes, if you please! It is already late," said he, and nodding his
13886. head he let it droop and again closed his eye.
13887. 
13888. If at first the members of the council thought that Kutuzov was
13889. pretending to sleep, the sounds his nose emitted during the reading that
13890. followed proved that the commander in chief at that moment was absorbed
13891. by a far more serious matter than a desire to show his contempt for
13892. the dispositions or anything else--he was engaged in satisfying the
13893. irresistible human need for sleep. He really was asleep. Weyrother, with
13894. the gesture of a man too busy to lose a moment, glanced at Kutuzov and,
13895. having convinced himself that he was asleep, took up a paper and in
13896. a loud, monotonous voice began to read out the dispositions for the
13897. impending battle, under a heading which he also read out:
13898. 
13899. "Dispositions for an attack on the enemy position behind Kobelnitz and
13900. Sokolnitz, November 30, 1805."
13901. 
13902. The dispositions were very complicated and difficult. They began as
13903. follows:
13904. 
13905. "As the enemy's left wing rests on wooded hills and his right extends
13906. along Kobelnitz and Sokolnitz behind the ponds that are there, while we,
13907. on the other hand, with our left wing by far outflank his right, it is
13908. advantageous to attack the enemy's latter wing especially if we occupy
13909. the villages of Sokolnitz and Kobelnitz, whereby we can both fall on
13910. his flank and pursue him over the plain between Schlappanitz and the
13911. Thuerassa forest, avoiding the defiles of Schlappanitz and Bellowitz
13912. which cover the enemy's front. For this object it is necessary that...
13913. The first column marches... The second column marches... The third
13914. column marches..." and so on, read Weyrother.
13915. 
13916. The generals seemed to listen reluctantly to the difficult dispositions.
13917. The tall, fair-haired General Buxhowden stood, leaning his back against
13918. the wall, his eyes fixed on a burning candle, and seemed not to listen
13919. or even to wish to be thought to listen. Exactly opposite Weyrother,
13920. with his glistening wide-open eyes fixed upon him and his mustache
13921. twisted upwards, sat the ruddy Miloradovich in a military pose, his
13922. elbows turned outwards, his hands on his knees, and his shoulders
13923. raised. He remained stubbornly silent, gazing at Weyrother's face, and
13924. only turned away his eyes when the Austrian chief of staff finished
13925. reading. Then Miloradovich looked round significantly at the other
13926. generals. But one could not tell from that significant look whether he
13927. agreed or disagreed and was satisfied or not with the arrangements. Next
13928. to Weyrother sat Count Langeron who, with a subtle smile that never left
13929. his typically southern French face during the whole time of the reading,
13930. gazed at his delicate fingers which rapidly twirled by its corners
13931. a gold snuffbox on which was a portrait. In the middle of one of the
13932. longest sentences, he stopped the rotary motion of the snuffbox, raised
13933. his head, and with inimical politeness lurking in the corners of his
13934. thin lips interrupted Weyrother, wishing to say something. But the
13935. Austrian general, continuing to read, frowned angrily and jerked his
13936. elbows, as if to say: "You can tell me your views later, but now be so
13937. good as to look at the map and listen." Langeron lifted his eyes with an
13938. expression of perplexity, turned round to Miloradovich as if seeking an
13939. explanation, but meeting the latter's impressive but meaningless gaze
13940. drooped his eyes sadly and again took to twirling his snuffbox.
13941. 
13942. "A geography lesson!" he muttered as if to himself, but loud enough to
13943. be heard.
13944. 
13945. Przebyszewski, with respectful but dignified politeness, held his
13946. hand to his ear toward Weyrother, with the air of a man absorbed in
13947. attention. Dohkturov, a little man, sat opposite Weyrother, with
13948. an assiduous and modest mien, and stooping over the outspread map
13949. conscientiously studied the dispositions and the unfamiliar locality. He
13950. asked Weyrother several times to repeat words he had not clearly heard
13951. and the difficult names of villages. Weyrother complied and Dohkturov
13952. noted them down.
13953. 
13954. When the reading which lasted more than an hour was over, Langeron again
13955. brought his snuffbox to rest and, without looking at Weyrother or at
13956. anyone in particular, began to say how difficult it was to carry out
13957. such a plan in which the enemy's position was assumed to be known,
13958. whereas it was perhaps not known, since the enemy was in movement.
13959. Langeron's objections were valid but it was obvious that their chief
13960. aim was to show General Weyrother--who had read his dispositions with as
13961. much self-confidence as if he were addressing school children--that he
13962. had to do, not with fools, but with men who could teach him something in
13963. military matters.
13964. 
13965. When the monotonous sound of Weyrother's voice ceased, Kutuzov opened
13966. his eye as a miller wakes up when the soporific drone of the mill wheel
13967. is interrupted. He listened to what Langeron said, as if remarking, "So
13968. you are still at that silly business!" quickly closed his eye again, and
13969. let his head sink still lower.
13970. 
13971. Langeron, trying as virulently as possible to sting Weyrother's vanity
13972. as author of the military plan, argued that Bonaparte might easily
13973. attack instead of being attacked, and so render the whole of this
13974. plan perfectly worthless. Weyrother met all objections with a firm and
13975. contemptuous smile, evidently prepared beforehand to meet all objections
13976. be they what they might.
13977. 
13978. "If he could attack us, he would have done so today," said he.
13979. 
13980. "So you think he is powerless?" said Langeron.
13981. 
13982. "He has forty thousand men at most," replied Weyrother, with the smile
13983. of a doctor to whom an old wife wishes to explain the treatment of a
13984. case.
13985. 
13986. "In that case he is inviting his doom by awaiting our attack," said
13987. Langeron, with a subtly ironical smile, again glancing round for support
13988. to Miloradovich who was near him.
13989. 
13990. But Miloradovich was at that moment evidently thinking of anything
13991. rather than of what the generals were disputing about.
13992. 
13993. "Ma foi!" said he, "tomorrow we shall see all that on the battlefield."
13994. 
13995. Weyrother again gave that smile which seemed to say that to him it was
13996. strange and ridiculous to meet objections from Russian generals and to
13997. have to prove to them what he had not merely convinced himself of, but
13998. had also convinced the sovereign Emperors of.
13999. 
14000. "The enemy has quenched his fires and a continual noise is heard from
14001. his camp," said he. "What does that mean? Either he is retreating, which
14002. is the only thing we need fear, or he is changing his position." (He
14003. smiled ironically.) "But even if he also took up a position in the
14004. Thuerassa, he merely saves us a great deal of trouble and all our
14005. arrangements to the minutest detail remain the same."
14006. 
14007. "How is that?..." began Prince Andrew, who had for long been waiting an
14008. opportunity to express his doubts.
14009. 
14010. Kutuzov here woke up, coughed heavily, and looked round at the generals.
14011. 
14012. "Gentlemen, the dispositions for tomorrow--or rather for today, for it
14013. is past midnight--cannot now be altered," said he. "You have heard them,
14014. and we shall all do our duty. But before a battle, there is nothing more
14015. important..." he paused, "than to have a good sleep."
14016. 
14017. He moved as if to rise. The generals bowed and retired. It was past
14018. midnight. Prince Andrew went out.
14019. 
14020. 
14021. The council of war, at which Prince Andrew had not been able to
14022. express his opinion as he had hoped to, left on him a vague and uneasy
14023. impression. Whether Dolgorukov and Weyrother, or Kutuzov, Langeron, and
14024. the others who did not approve of the plan of attack, were right--he did
14025. not know. "But was it really not possible for Kutuzov to state his views
14026. plainly to the Emperor? Is it possible that on account of court and
14027. personal considerations tens of thousands of lives, and my life, my
14028. life," he thought, "must be risked?"
14029. 
14030. "Yes, it is very likely that I shall be killed tomorrow," he thought.
14031. And suddenly, at this thought of death, a whole series of most distant,
14032. most intimate, memories rose in his imagination: he remembered his last
14033. parting from his father and his wife; he remembered the days when he
14034. first loved her. He thought of her pregnancy and felt sorry for her and
14035. for himself, and in a nervously emotional and softened mood he went out
14036. of the hut in which he was billeted with Nesvitski and began to walk up
14037. and down before it.
14038. 
14039. The night was foggy and through the fog the moonlight gleamed
14040. mysteriously. "Yes, tomorrow, tomorrow!" he thought. "Tomorrow
14041. everything may be over for me! All these memories will be no more, none
14042. of them will have any meaning for me. Tomorrow perhaps, even certainly,
14043. I have a presentiment that for the first time I shall have to show all I
14044. can do." And his fancy pictured the battle, its loss, the concentration
14045. of fighting at one point, and the hesitation of all the commanders. And
14046. then that happy moment, that Toulon for which he had so long waited,
14047. presents itself to him at last. He firmly and clearly expresses his
14048. opinion to Kutuzov, to Weyrother, and to the Emperors. All are struck by
14049. the justness of his views, but no one undertakes to carry them out, so
14050. he takes a regiment, a division-stipulates that no one is to interfere
14051. with his arrangements--leads his division to the decisive point, and
14052. gains the victory alone. "But death and suffering?" suggested another
14053. voice. Prince Andrew, however, did not answer that voice and went on
14054. dreaming of his triumphs. The dispositions for the next battle are
14055. planned by him alone. Nominally he is only an adjutant on Kutuzov's
14056. staff, but he does everything alone. The next battle is won by him
14057. alone. Kutuzov is removed and he is appointed... "Well and then?" asked
14058. the other voice. "If before that you are not ten times wounded, killed,
14059. or betrayed, well... what then?..." "Well then," Prince Andrew answered
14060. himself, "I don't know what will happen and don't want to know, and
14061. can't, but if I want this--want glory, want to be known to men, want to
14062. be loved by them, it is not my fault that I want it and want nothing
14063. but that and live only for that. Yes, for that alone! I shall never
14064. tell anyone, but, oh God! what am I to do if I love nothing but fame
14065. and men's esteem? Death, wounds, the loss of family--I fear nothing. And
14066. precious and dear as many persons are to me--father, sister, wife--those
14067. dearest to me--yet dreadful and unnatural as it seems, I would give them
14068. all at once for a moment of glory, of triumph over men, of love from men
14069. I don't know and never shall know, for the love of these men here," he
14070. thought, as he listened to voices in Kutuzov's courtyard. The voices
14071. were those of the orderlies who were packing up; one voice, probably a
14072. coachman's, was teasing Kutuzov's old cook whom Prince Andrew knew, and
14073. who was called Tit. He was saying, "Tit, I say, Tit!"
14074. 
14075. "Well?" returned the old man.
14076. 
14077. "Go, Tit, thresh a bit!" said the wag.
14078. 
14079. "Oh, go to the devil!" called out a voice, drowned by the laughter of
14080. the orderlies and servants.
14081. 
14082. "All the same, I love and value nothing but triumph over them all, I
14083. value this mystic power and glory that is floating here above me in this
14084. mist!"
14085. 
14086. 
14087. 
14088. 
14089. 
14090. CHAPTER XIII
14091. 
14092. 
14093. That same night, Rostov was with a platoon on skirmishing duty in front
14094. of Bagration's detachment. His hussars were placed along the line
14095. in couples and he himself rode along the line trying to master the
14096. sleepiness that kept coming over him. An enormous space, with our army's
14097. campfires dimly glowing in the fog, could be seen behind him; in front
14098. of him was misty darkness. Rostov could see nothing, peer as he would
14099. into that foggy distance: now something gleamed gray, now there was
14100. something black, now little lights seemed to glimmer where the enemy
14101. ought to be, now he fancied it was only something in his own eyes.
14102. His eyes kept closing, and in his fancy appeared--now the Emperor, now
14103. Denisov, and now Moscow memories--and he again hurriedly opened his eyes
14104. and saw close before him the head and ears of the horse he was riding,
14105. and sometimes, when he came within six paces of them, the black figures
14106. of hussars, but in the distance was still the same misty darkness. "Why
14107. not?... It might easily happen," thought Rostov, "that the Emperor will
14108. meet me and give me an order as he would to any other officer; he'll
14109. say: 'Go and find out what's there.' There are many stories of his
14110. getting to know an officer in just such a chance way and attaching him
14111. to himself! What if he gave me a place near him? Oh, how I would guard
14112. him, how I would tell him the truth, how I would unmask his deceivers!"
14113. And in order to realize vividly his love devotion to the sovereign,
14114. Rostov pictured to himself an enemy or a deceitful German, whom he would
14115. not only kill with pleasure but whom he would slap in the face before
14116. the Emperor. Suddenly a distant shout aroused him. He started and opened
14117. his eyes.
14118. 
14119. "Where am I? Oh yes, in the skirmishing line... pass and
14120. watchword--shaft, Olmutz. What a nuisance that our squadron will be in
14121. reserve tomorrow," he thought. "I'll ask leave to go to the front, this
14122. may be my only chance of seeing the Emperor. It won't be long now before
14123. I am off duty. I'll take another turn and when I get back I'll go to the
14124. general and ask him." He readjusted himself in the saddle and touched up
14125. his horse to ride once more round his hussars. It seemed to him that it
14126. was getting lighter. To the left he saw a sloping descent lit up, and
14127. facing it a black knoll that seemed as steep as a wall. On this knoll
14128. there was a white patch that Rostov could not at all make out: was it
14129. a glade in the wood lit up by the moon, or some unmelted snow, or some
14130. white houses? He even thought something moved on that white spot. "I
14131. expect it's snow... that spot... a spot--une tache," he thought. "There
14132. now... it's not a tache... Natasha... sister, black eyes... Na...
14133. tasha... (Won't she be surprised when I tell her how I've seen the
14134. Emperor?) Natasha... take my sabretache..."--"Keep to the right, your
14135. honor, there are bushes here," came the voice of an hussar, past whom
14136. Rostov was riding in the act of falling asleep. Rostov lifted his
14137. head that had sunk almost to his horse's mane and pulled up beside
14138. the hussar. He was succumbing to irresistible, youthful, childish
14139. drowsiness. "But what was I thinking? I mustn't forget. How shall
14140. I speak to the Emperor? No, that's not it--that's tomorrow. Oh yes!
14141. Natasha... sabretache... saber them... Whom? The hussars... Ah, the
14142. hussars with mustaches. Along the Tverskaya Street rode the hussar with
14143. mustaches... I thought about him too, just opposite Guryev's house...
14144. Old Guryev.... Oh, but Denisov's a fine fellow. But that's all nonsense.
14145. The chief thing is that the Emperor is here. How he looked at me and
14146. wished to say something, but dared not.... No, it was I who dared not.
14147. But that's nonsense, the chief thing is not to forget the important
14148. thing I was thinking of. Yes, Na-tasha, sabretache, oh, yes, yes! That's
14149. right!" And his head once more sank to his horse's neck. All at once it
14150. seemed to him that he was being fired at. "What? What? What?... Cut them
14151. down! What?..." said Rostov, waking up. At the moment he opened his eyes
14152. he heard in front of him, where the enemy was, the long-drawn shouts
14153. of thousands of voices. His horse and the horse of the hussar near him
14154. pricked their ears at these shouts. Over there, where the shouting came
14155. from, a fire flared up and went out again, then another, and all along
14156. the French line on the hill fires flared up and the shouting grew louder
14157. and louder. Rostov could hear the sound of French words but could not
14158. distinguish them. The din of many voices was too great; all he could
14159. hear was: "ahahah!" and "rrrr!"
14160. 
14161. "What's that? What do you make of it?" said Rostov to the hussar beside
14162. him. "That must be the enemy's camp!"
14163. 
14164. The hussar did not reply.
14165. 
14166. "Why, don't you hear it?" Rostov asked again, after waiting for a reply.
14167. 
14168. "Who can tell, your honor?" replied the hussar reluctantly.
14169. 
14170. "From the direction, it must be the enemy," repeated Rostov.
14171. 
14172. "It may be he or it may be nothing," muttered the hussar. "It's dark...
14173. Steady!" he cried to his fidgeting horse.
14174. 
14175. Rostov's horse was also getting restive: it pawed the frozen ground,
14176. pricking its ears at the noise and looking at the lights. The shouting
14177. grew still louder and merged into a general roar that only an army
14178. of several thousand men could produce. The lights spread farther and
14179. farther, probably along the line of the French camp. Rostov no longer
14180. wanted to sleep. The gay triumphant shouting of the enemy army had a
14181. stimulating effect on him. "Vive l'Empereur! L'Empereur!" he now heard
14182. distinctly.
14183. 
14184. "They can't be far off, probably just beyond the stream," he said to the
14185. hussar beside him.
14186. 
14187. The hussar only sighed without replying and coughed angrily. The sound
14188. of horse's hoofs approaching at a trot along the line of hussars was
14189. heard, and out of the foggy darkness the figure of a sergeant of hussars
14190. suddenly appeared, looming huge as an elephant.
14191. 
14192. "Your honor, the generals!" said the sergeant, riding up to Rostov.
14193. 
14194. Rostov, still looking round toward the fires and the shouts, rode with
14195. the sergeant to meet some mounted men who were riding along the line.
14196. One was on a white horse. Prince Bagration and Prince Dolgorukov with
14197. their adjutants had come to witness the curious phenomenon of the lights
14198. and shouts in the enemy's camp. Rostov rode up to Bagration, reported to
14199. him, and then joined the adjutants listening to what the generals were
14200. saying.
14201. 
14202. "Believe me," said Prince Dolgorukov, addressing Bagration, "it is
14203. nothing but a trick! He has retreated and ordered the rearguard to
14204. kindle fires and make a noise to deceive us."
14205. 
14206. "Hardly," said Bagration. "I saw them this evening on that knoll; if
14207. they had retreated they would have withdrawn from that too.... Officer!"
14208. said Bagration to Rostov, "are the enemy's skirmishers still there?"
14209. 
14210. "They were there this evening, but now I don't know, your excellency.
14211. Shall I go with some of my hussars to see?" replied Rostov.
14212. 
14213. Bagration stopped and, before replying, tried to see Rostov's face in
14214. the mist.
14215. 
14216. "Well, go and see," he said, after a pause.
14217. 
14218. "Yes, sir."
14219. 
14220. Rostov spurred his horse, called to Sergeant Fedchenko and two other
14221. hussars, told them to follow him, and trotted downhill in the direction
14222. from which the shouting came. He felt both frightened and pleased to be
14223. riding alone with three hussars into that mysterious and dangerous misty
14224. distance where no one had been before him. Bagration called to him from
14225. the hill not to go beyond the stream, but Rostov pretended not to hear
14226. him and did not stop but rode on and on, continually mistaking bushes
14227. for trees and gullies for men and continually discovering his mistakes.
14228. Having descended the hill at a trot, he no longer saw either our own or
14229. the enemy's fires, but heard the shouting of the French more loudly and
14230. distinctly. In the valley he saw before him something like a river, but
14231. when he reached it he found it was a road. Having come out onto the road
14232. he reined in his horse, hesitating whether to ride along it or cross it
14233. and ride over the black field up the hillside. To keep to the road which
14234. gleamed white in the mist would have been safer because it would be
14235. easier to see people coming along it. "Follow me!" said he, crossed the
14236. road, and began riding up the hill at a gallop toward the point where
14237. the French pickets had been standing that evening.
14238. 
14239. "Your honor, there he is!" cried one of the hussars behind him. And
