14240. before Rostov had time to make out what the black thing was that had
14241. suddenly appeared in the fog, there was a flash, followed by a report,
14242. and a bullet whizzing high up in the mist with a plaintive sound passed
14243. out of hearing. Another musket missed fire but flashed in the pan.
14244. Rostov turned his horse and galloped back. Four more reports followed
14245. at intervals, and the bullets passed somewhere in the fog singing in
14246. different tones. Rostov reined in his horse, whose spirits had risen,
14247. like his own, at the firing, and went back at a footpace. "Well, some
14248. more! Some more!" a merry voice was saying in his soul. But no more
14249. shots came.
14250. 
14251. Only when approaching Bagration did Rostov let his horse gallop again,
14252. and with his hand at the salute rode up to the general.
14253. 
14254. Dolgorukov was still insisting that the French had retreated and had
14255. only lit fires to deceive us.
14256. 
14257. "What does that prove?" he was saying as Rostov rode up. "They might
14258. retreat and leave the pickets."
14259. 
14260. "It's plain that they have not all gone yet, Prince," said Bagration.
14261. "Wait till tomorrow morning, we'll find out everything tomorrow."
14262. 
14263. "The picket is still on the hill, your excellency, just where it was
14264. in the evening," reported Rostov, stooping forward with his hand at the
14265. salute and unable to repress the smile of delight induced by his ride
14266. and especially by the sound of the bullets.
14267. 
14268. "Very good, very good," said Bagration. "Thank you, officer."
14269. 
14270. "Your excellency," said Rostov, "may I ask a favor?"
14271. 
14272. "What is it?"
14273. 
14274. "Tomorrow our squadron is to be in reserve. May I ask to be attached to
14275. the first squadron?"
14276. 
14277. "What's your name?"
14278. 
14279. "Count Rostov."
14280. 
14281. "Oh, very well, you may stay in attendance on me."
14282. 
14283. "Count Ilya Rostov's son?" asked Dolgorukov.
14284. 
14285. But Rostov did not reply.
14286. 
14287. "Then I may reckon on it, your excellency?"
14288. 
14289. "I will give the order."
14290. 
14291. "Tomorrow very likely I may be sent with some message to the Emperor,"
14292. thought Rostov.
14293. 
14294. "Thank God!"
14295. 
14296. 
14297. The fires and shouting in the enemy's army were occasioned by the fact
14298. that while Napoleon's proclamation was being read to the troops the
14299. Emperor himself rode round his bivouacs. The soldiers, on seeing him,
14300. lit wisps of straw and ran after him, shouting, "Vive l'Empereur!"
14301. Napoleon's proclamation was as follows:
14302. 
14303. 
14304. Soldiers! The Russian army is advancing against you to avenge the
14305. Austrian army of Ulm. They are the same battalions you broke at
14306. Hollabrunn and have pursued ever since to this place. The position we
14307. occupy is a strong one, and while they are marching to go round me on
14308. the right they will expose a flank to me. Soldiers! I will myself direct
14309. your battalions. I will keep out of fire if you with your habitual valor
14310. carry disorder and confusion into the enemy's ranks, but should victory
14311. be in doubt, even for a moment, you will see your Emperor exposing
14312. himself to the first blows of the enemy, for there must be no doubt of
14313. victory, especially on this day when what is at stake is the honor of
14314. the French infantry, so necessary to the honor of our nation.
14315. 
14316. Do not break your ranks on the plea of removing the wounded! Let every
14317. man be fully imbued with the thought that we must defeat these hirelings
14318. of England, inspired by such hatred of our nation! This victory will
14319. conclude our campaign and we can return to winter quarters, where fresh
14320. French troops who are being raised in France will join us, and the peace
14321. I shall conclude will be worthy of my people, of you, and of myself.
14322. 
14323. NAPOLEON
14324. 
14325. 
14326. 
14327. 
14328. 
14329. CHAPTER XIV
14330. 
14331. 
14332. At five in the morning it was still quite dark. The troops of the
14333. center, the reserves, and Bagration's right flank had not yet moved, but
14334. on the left flank the columns of infantry, cavalry, and artillery, which
14335. were to be the first to descend the heights to attack the French right
14336. flank and drive it into the Bohemian mountains according to plan, were
14337. already up and astir. The smoke of the campfires, into which they were
14338. throwing everything superfluous, made the eyes smart. It was cold and
14339. dark. The officers were hurriedly drinking tea and breakfasting, the
14340. soldiers, munching biscuit and beating a tattoo with their feet to
14341. warm themselves, gathering round the fires throwing into the flames the
14342. remains of sheds, chairs, tables, wheels, tubs, and everything that they
14343. did not want or could not carry away with them. Austrian column guides
14344. were moving in and out among the Russian troops and served as heralds
14345. of the advance. As soon as an Austrian officer showed himself near a
14346. commanding officer's quarters, the regiment began to move: the soldiers
14347. ran from the fires, thrust their pipes into their boots, their bags
14348. into the carts, got their muskets ready, and formed rank. The officers
14349. buttoned up their coats, buckled on their swords and pouches, and moved
14350. along the ranks shouting. The train drivers and orderlies harnessed and
14351. packed the wagons and tied on the loads. The adjutants and battalion
14352. and regimental commanders mounted, crossed themselves, gave final
14353. instructions, orders, and commissions to the baggage men who remained
14354. behind, and the monotonous tramp of thousands of feet resounded. The
14355. column moved forward without knowing where and unable, from the masses
14356. around them, the smoke and the increasing fog, to see either the place
14357. they were leaving or that to which they were going.
14358. 
14359. A soldier on the march is hemmed in and borne along by his regiment as
14360. much as a sailor is by his ship. However far he has walked, whatever
14361. strange, unknown, and dangerous places he reaches, just as a sailor is
14362. always surrounded by the same decks, masts, and rigging of his ship, so
14363. the soldier always has around him the same comrades, the same ranks,
14364. the same sergeant major Ivan Mitrich, the same company dog Jack, and the
14365. same commanders. The sailor rarely cares to know the latitude in which
14366. his ship is sailing, but on the day of battle--heaven knows how and
14367. whence--a stern note of which all are conscious sounds in the moral
14368. atmosphere of an army, announcing the approach of something decisive
14369. and solemn, and awakening in the men an unusual curiosity. On the day of
14370. battle the soldiers excitedly try to get beyond the interests of their
14371. regiment, they listen intently, look about, and eagerly ask concerning
14372. what is going on around them.
14373. 
14374. The fog had grown so dense that though it was growing light they could
14375. not see ten paces ahead. Bushes looked like gigantic trees and level
14376. ground like cliffs and slopes. Anywhere, on any side, one might
14377. encounter an enemy invisible ten paces off. But the columns advanced
14378. for a long time, always in the same fog, descending and ascending hills,
14379. avoiding gardens and enclosures, going over new and unknown ground, and
14380. nowhere encountering the enemy. On the contrary, the soldiers became
14381. aware that in front, behind, and on all sides, other Russian columns
14382. were moving in the same direction. Every soldier felt glad to know that
14383. to the unknown place where he was going, many more of our men were going
14384. too.
14385. 
14386. "There now, the Kurskies have also gone past," was being said in the
14387. ranks.
14388. 
14389. "It's wonderful what a lot of our troops have gathered, lads! Last
14390. night I looked at the campfires and there was no end of them. A regular
14391. Moscow!"
14392. 
14393. Though none of the column commanders rode up to the ranks or talked to
14394. the men (the commanders, as we saw at the council of war, were out of
14395. humor and dissatisfied with the affair, and so did not exert themselves
14396. to cheer the men but merely carried out the orders), yet the troops
14397. marched gaily, as they always do when going into action, especially to
14398. an attack. But when they had marched for about an hour in the dense fog,
14399. the greater part of the men had to halt and an unpleasant consciousness
14400. of some dislocation and blunder spread through the ranks. How such
14401. a consciousness is communicated is very difficult to define, but it
14402. certainly is communicated very surely, and flows rapidly, imperceptibly,
14403. and irrepressibly, as water does in a creek. Had the Russian army been
14404. alone without any allies, it might perhaps have been a long time before
14405. this consciousness of mismanagement became a general conviction, but as
14406. it was, the disorder was readily and naturally attributed to the stupid
14407. Germans, and everyone was convinced that a dangerous muddle had been
14408. occasioned by the sausage eaters.
14409. 
14410. "Why have we stopped? Is the way blocked? Or have we already come up
14411. against the French?"
14412. 
14413. "No, one can't hear them. They'd be firing if we had."
14414. 
14415. "They were in a hurry enough to start us, and now here we stand in
14416. the middle of a field without rhyme or reason. It's all those damned
14417. Germans' muddling! What stupid devils!"
14418. 
14419. "Yes, I'd send them on in front, but no fear, they're crowding up
14420. behind. And now here we stand hungry."
14421. 
14422. "I say, shall we soon be clear? They say the cavalry are blocking the
14423. way," said an officer.
14424. 
14425. "Ah, those damned Germans! They don't know their own country!" said
14426. another.
14427. 
14428. "What division are you?" shouted an adjutant, riding up.
14429. 
14430. "The Eighteenth."
14431. 
14432. "Then why are you here? You should have gone on long ago, now you won't
14433. get there till evening."
14434. 
14435. "What stupid orders! They don't themselves know what they are doing!"
14436. said the officer and rode off.
14437. 
14438. Then a general rode past shouting something angrily, not in Russian.
14439. 
14440. "Tafa-lafa! But what he's jabbering no one can make out," said a
14441. soldier, mimicking the general who had ridden away. "I'd shoot them, the
14442. scoundrels!"
14443. 
14444. "We were ordered to be at the place before nine, but we haven't got
14445. halfway. Fine orders!" was being repeated on different sides.
14446. 
14447. And the feeling of energy with which the troops had started began to
14448. turn into vexation and anger at the stupid arrangements and at the
14449. Germans.
14450. 
14451. The cause of the confusion was that while the Austrian cavalry was
14452. moving toward our left flank, the higher command found that our center
14453. was too far separated from our right flank and the cavalry were all
14454. ordered to turn back to the right. Several thousand cavalry crossed in
14455. front of the infantry, who had to wait.
14456. 
14457. At the front an altercation occurred between an Austrian guide and a
14458. Russian general. The general shouted a demand that the cavalry should be
14459. halted, the Austrian argued that not he, but the higher command, was to
14460. blame. The troops meanwhile stood growing listless and dispirited. After
14461. an hour's delay they at last moved on, descending the hill. The fog that
14462. was dispersing on the hill lay still more densely below, where they were
14463. descending. In front in the fog a shot was heard and then another, at
14464. first irregularly at varying intervals--trata... tat--and then more and
14465. more regularly and rapidly, and the action at the Goldbach Stream began.
14466. 
14467. Not expecting to come on the enemy down by the stream, and having
14468. stumbled on him in the fog, hearing no encouraging word from their
14469. commanders, and with a consciousness of being too late spreading through
14470. the ranks, and above all being unable to see anything in front or around
14471. them in the thick fog, the Russians exchanged shots with the enemy
14472. lazily and advanced and again halted, receiving no timely orders from
14473. the officers or adjutants who wandered about in the fog in those unknown
14474. surroundings unable to find their own regiments. In this way the action
14475. began for the first, second, and third columns, which had gone down
14476. into the valley. The fourth column, with which Kutuzov was, stood on the
14477. Pratzen Heights.
14478. 
14479. Below, where the fight was beginning, there was still thick fog; on the
14480. higher ground it was clearing, but nothing could be seen of what was
14481. going on in front. Whether all the enemy forces were, as we supposed,
14482. six miles away, or whether they were near by in that sea of mist, no one
14483. knew till after eight o'clock.
14484. 
14485. It was nine o'clock in the morning. The fog lay unbroken like a sea down
14486. below, but higher up at the village of Schlappanitz where Napoleon stood
14487. with his marshals around him, it was quite light. Above him was a clear
14488. blue sky, and the sun's vast orb quivered like a huge hollow, crimson
14489. float on the surface of that milky sea of mist. The whole French army,
14490. and even Napoleon himself with his staff, were not on the far side of
14491. the streams and hollows of Sokolnitz and Schlappanitz beyond which we
14492. intended to take up our position and begin the action, but were on this
14493. side, so close to our own forces that Napoleon with the naked eye could
14494. distinguish a mounted man from one on foot. Napoleon, in the blue cloak
14495. which he had worn on his Italian campaign, sat on his small gray Arab
14496. horse a little in front of his marshals. He gazed silently at the hills
14497. which seemed to rise out of the sea of mist and on which the Russian
14498. troops were moving in the distance, and he listened to the sounds of
14499. firing in the valley. Not a single muscle of his face--which in those
14500. days was still thin--moved. His gleaming eyes were fixed intently on one
14501. spot. His predictions were being justified. Part of the Russian force
14502. had already descended into the valley toward the ponds and lakes and
14503. part were leaving these Pratzen Heights which he intended to attack
14504. and regarded as the key to the position. He saw over the mist that in
14505. a hollow between two hills near the village of Pratzen, the Russian
14506. columns, their bayonets glittering, were moving continuously in one
14507. direction toward the valley and disappearing one after another into
14508. the mist. From information he had received the evening before, from the
14509. sound of wheels and footsteps heard by the outposts during the night,
14510. by the disorderly movement of the Russian columns, and from all
14511. indications, he saw clearly that the allies believed him to be far away
14512. in front of them, and that the columns moving near Pratzen constituted
14513. the center of the Russian army, and that that center was already
14514. sufficiently weakened to be successfully attacked. But still he did not
14515. begin the engagement.
14516. 
14517. Today was a great day for him--the anniversary of his coronation. Before
14518. dawn he had slept for a few hours, and refreshed, vigorous, and in good
14519. spirits, he mounted his horse and rode out into the field in that happy
14520. mood in which everything seems possible and everything succeeds. He sat
14521. motionless, looking at the heights visible above the mist, and his cold
14522. face wore that special look of confident, self-complacent happiness that
14523. one sees on the face of a boy happily in love. The marshals stood
14524. behind him not venturing to distract his attention. He looked now at the
14525. Pratzen Heights, now at the sun floating up out of the mist.
14526. 
14527. When the sun had entirely emerged from the fog, and fields and mist were
14528. aglow with dazzling light--as if he had only awaited this to begin the
14529. action--he drew the glove from his shapely white hand, made a sign
14530. with it to the marshals, and ordered the action to begin. The marshals,
14531. accompanied by adjutants, galloped off in different directions, and
14532. a few minutes later the chief forces of the French army moved rapidly
14533. toward those Pratzen Heights which were being more and more denuded by
14534. Russian troops moving down the valley to their left.
14535. 
14536. 
14537. 
14538. 
14539. 
14540. CHAPTER XV
14541. 
14542. 
14543. At eight o'clock Kutuzov rode to Pratzen at the head of the fourth
14544. column, Miloradovich's, the one that was to take the place of
14545. Przebyszewski's and Langeron's columns which had already gone down into
14546. the valley. He greeted the men of the foremost regiment and gave them
14547. the order to march, thereby indicating that he intended to lead that
14548. column himself. When he had reached the village of Pratzen he halted.
14549. Prince Andrew was behind, among the immense number forming the commander
14550. in chief's suite. He was in a state of suppressed excitement and
14551. irritation, though controlledly calm as a man is at the approach of a
14552. long-awaited moment. He was firmly convinced that this was the day of
14553. his Toulon, or his bridge of Arcola. How it would come about he did not
14554. know, but he felt sure it would do so. The locality and the position of
14555. our troops were known to him as far as they could be known to anyone
14556. in our army. His own strategic plan, which obviously could not now be
14557. carried out, was forgotten. Now, entering into Weyrother's plan, Prince
14558. Andrew considered possible contingencies and formed new projects such as
14559. might call for his rapidity of perception and decision.
14560. 
14561. To the left down below in the mist, the musketry fire of unseen forces
14562. could be heard. It was there Prince Andrew thought the fight would
14563. concentrate. "There we shall encounter difficulties, and there," thought
14564. he, "I shall be sent with a brigade or division, and there, standard in
14565. hand, I shall go forward and break whatever is in front of me."
14566. 
14567. He could not look calmly at the standards of the passing battalions.
14568. Seeing them he kept thinking, "That may be the very standard with which
14569. I shall lead the army."
14570. 
14571. In the morning all that was left of the night mist on the heights was
14572. a hoar frost now turning to dew, but in the valleys it still lay like a
14573. milk-white sea. Nothing was visible in the valley to the left into which
14574. our troops had descended and from whence came the sounds of firing.
14575. Above the heights was the dark clear sky, and to the right the vast orb
14576. of the sun. In front, far off on the farther shore of that sea of mist,
14577. some wooded hills were discernible, and it was there the enemy probably
14578. was, for something could be descried. On the right the Guards were
14579. entering the misty region with a sound of hoofs and wheels and now and
14580. then a gleam of bayonets; to the left beyond the village similar masses
14581. of cavalry came up and disappeared in the sea of mist. In front and
14582. behind moved infantry. The commander in chief was standing at the end of
14583. the village letting the troops pass by him. That morning Kutuzov seemed
14584. worn and irritable. The infantry passing before him came to a halt
14585. without any command being given, apparently obstructed by something in
14586. front.
14587. 
14588. "Do order them to form into battalion columns and go round the village!"
14589. he said angrily to a general who had ridden up. "Don't you understand,
14590. your excellency, my dear sir, that you must not defile through narrow
14591. village streets when we are marching against the enemy?"
14592. 
14593. "I intended to re-form them beyond the village, your excellency,"
14594. answered the general.
14595. 
14596. Kutuzov laughed bitterly.
14597. 
14598. "You'll make a fine thing of it, deploying in sight of the enemy! Very
14599. fine!"
14600. 
14601. "The enemy is still far away, your excellency. According to the
14602. dispositions..."
14603. 
14604. "The dispositions!" exclaimed Kutuzov bitterly. "Who told you that?...
14605. Kindly do as you are ordered."
14606. 
14607. "Yes, sir."
14608. 
14609. "My dear fellow," Nesvitski whispered to Prince Andrew, "the old man is
14610. as surly as a dog."
14611. 
14612. An Austrian officer in a white uniform with green plumes in his hat
14613. galloped up to Kutuzov and asked in the Emperor's name had the fourth
14614. column advanced into action.
14615. 
14616. Kutuzov turned round without answering and his eye happened to fall upon
14617. Prince Andrew, who was beside him. Seeing him, Kutuzov's malevolent and
14618. caustic expression softened, as if admitting that what was being done
14619. was not his adjutant's fault, and still not answering the Austrian
14620. adjutant, he addressed Bolkonski.
14621. 
14622. "Go, my dear fellow, and see whether the third division has passed the
14623. village. Tell it to stop and await my orders."
14624. 
14625. Hardly had Prince Andrew started than he stopped him.
14626. 
14627. "And ask whether sharpshooters have been posted," he added. "What are
14628. they doing? What are they doing?" he murmured to himself, still not
14629. replying to the Austrian.
14630. 
14631. Prince Andrew galloped off to execute the order.
14632. 
14633. Overtaking the battalions that continued to advance, he stopped
14634. the third division and convinced himself that there really were no
14635. sharpshooters in front of our columns. The colonel at the head of the
14636. regiment was much surprised at the commander in chief's order to throw
14637. out skirmishers. He had felt perfectly sure that there were other troops
14638. in front of him and that the enemy must be at least six miles away.
14639. There was really nothing to be seen in front except a barren descent
14640. hidden by dense mist. Having given orders in the commander in chief's
14641. name to rectify this omission, Prince Andrew galloped back. Kutuzov
14642. still in the same place, his stout body resting heavily in the saddle
14643. with the lassitude of age, sat yawning wearily with closed eyes. The
14644. troops were no longer moving, but stood with the butts of their muskets
14645. on the ground.
14646. 
14647. "All right, all right!" he said to Prince Andrew, and turned to a
14648. general who, watch in hand, was saying it was time they started as all
14649. the left-flank columns had already descended.
14650. 
14651. "Plenty of time, your excellency," muttered Kutuzov in the midst of a
14652. yawn. "Plenty of time," he repeated.
14653. 
14654. Just then at a distance behind Kutuzov was heard the sound of regiments
14655. saluting, and this sound rapidly came nearer along the whole extended
14656. line of the advancing Russian columns. Evidently the person they were
14657. greeting was riding quickly. When the soldiers of the regiment in front
14658. of which Kutuzov was standing began to shout, he rode a little to one
14659. side and looked round with a frown. Along the road from Pratzen galloped
14660. what looked like a squadron of horsemen in various uniforms. Two of them
14661. rode side by side in front, at full gallop. One in a black uniform with
14662. white plumes in his hat rode a bobtailed chestnut horse, the other who
14663. was in a white uniform rode a black one. These were the two Emperors
14664. followed by their suites. Kutuzov, affecting the manners of an old
14665. soldier at the front, gave the command "Attention!" and rode up to the
14666. Emperors with a salute. His whole appearance and manner were suddenly
14667. transformed. He put on the air of a subordinate who obeys without
14668. reasoning. With an affectation of respect which evidently struck
14669. Alexander unpleasantly, he rode up and saluted.
14670. 
14671. This unpleasant impression merely flitted over the young and happy face
14672. of the Emperor like a cloud of haze across a clear sky and vanished.
14673. After his illness he looked rather thinner that day than on the field of
14674. Olmutz where Bolkonski had seen him for the first time abroad, but there
14675. was still the same bewitching combination of majesty and mildness in his
14676. fine gray eyes, and on his delicate lips the same capacity for varying
14677. expression and the same prevalent appearance of goodhearted innocent
14678. youth.
14679. 
14680. At the Olmutz review he had seemed more majestic; here he seemed
14681. brighter and more energetic. He was slightly flushed after galloping two
14682. miles, and reining in his horse he sighed restfully and looked round
14683. at the faces of his suite, young and animated as his own. Czartoryski,
14684. Novosiltsev, Prince Volkonsky, Strogonov, and the others, all richly
14685. dressed gay young men on splendid, well-groomed, fresh, only slightly
14686. heated horses, exchanging remarks and smiling, had stopped behind the
14687. Emperor. The Emperor Francis, a rosy, long faced young man, sat very
14688. erect on his handsome black horse, looking about him in a leisurely and
14689. preoccupied manner. He beckoned to one of his white adjutants and asked
14690. some question--"Most likely he is asking at what o'clock they started,"
14691. thought Prince Andrew, watching his old acquaintance with a smile
14692. he could not repress as he recalled his reception at Brunn. In the
14693. Emperors' suite were the picked young orderly officers of the Guard and
14694. line regiments, Russian and Austrian. Among them were grooms leading the
14695. Tsar's beautiful relay horses covered with embroidered cloths.
14696. 
14697. As when a window is opened a whiff of fresh air from the fields enters
14698. a stuffy room, so a whiff of youthfulness, energy, and confidence of
14699. success reached Kutuzov's cheerless staff with the galloping advent of
14700. all these brilliant young men.
14701. 
14702. "Why aren't you beginning, Michael Ilarionovich?" said the Emperor
14703. Alexander hurriedly to Kutuzov, glancing courteously at the same time at
14704. the Emperor Francis.
14705. 
14706. "I am waiting, Your Majesty," answered Kutuzov, bending forward
14707. respectfully.
14708. 
14709. The Emperor, frowning slightly, bent his ear forward as if he had not
14710. quite heard.
14711. 
14712. "Waiting, Your Majesty," repeated Kutuzov. (Prince Andrew noted that
14713. Kutuzov's upper lip twitched unnaturally as he said the word "waiting.")
14714. "Not all the columns have formed up yet, Your Majesty."
14715. 
14716. The Tsar heard but obviously did not like the reply; he shrugged his
14717. rather round shoulders and glanced at Novosiltsev who was near him, as
14718. if complaining of Kutuzov.
14719. 
14720. "You know, Michael Ilarionovich, we are not on the Empress' Field where
14721. a parade does not begin till all the troops are assembled," said the
14722. Tsar with another glance at the Emperor Francis, as if inviting him if
14723. not to join in at least to listen to what he was saying. But the Emperor
14724. Francis continued to look about him and did not listen.
14725. 
14726. "That is just why I do not begin, sire," said Kutuzov in a resounding
14727. voice, apparently to preclude the possibility of not being heard, and
14728. again something in his face twitched--"That is just why I do not begin,
14729. sire, because we are not on parade and not on the Empress' Field," said
14730. clearly and distinctly.
14731. 
14732. In the Emperor's suite all exchanged rapid looks that expressed
14733. dissatisfaction and reproach. "Old though he may be, he should not, he
14734. certainly should not, speak like that," their glances seemed to say.
14735. 
14736. The Tsar looked intently and observantly into Kutuzov's eye waiting to
14737. hear whether he would say anything more. But Kutuzov, with respectfully
14738. bowed head, seemed also to be waiting. The silence lasted for about a
14739. minute.
14740. 
14741. "However, if you command it, Your Majesty," said Kutuzov, lifting his
14742. head and again assuming his former tone of a dull, unreasoning, but
14743. submissive general.
14744. 
14745. He touched his horse and having called Miloradovich, the commander of
14746. the column, gave him the order to advance.
14747. 
14748. The troops again began to move, and two battalions of the Novgorod and
14749. one of the Apsheron regiment went forward past the Emperor.
14750. 
14751. As this Apsheron battalion marched by, the red-faced Miloradovich,
14752. without his greatcoat, with his Orders on his breast and an enormous
14753. tuft of plumes in his cocked hat worn on one side with its corners front
14754. and back, galloped strenuously forward, and with a dashing salute reined
14755. in his horse before the Emperor.
14756. 
14757. "God be with you, general!" said the Emperor.
14758. 
14759. "Ma foi, sire, nous ferons ce qui sera dans notre possibilite, sire,"
14760. * he answered gaily, raising nevertheless ironic smiles among the
14761. gentlemen of the Tsar's suite by his poor French.
14762. 
14763. 
14764.      * "Indeed, Sire, we shall do everything it is possible to
14765.      do, Sire."
14766. 
14767. 
14768. Miloradovich wheeled his horse sharply and stationed himself a little
14769. behind the Emperor. The Apsheron men, excited by the Tsar's presence,
14770. passed in step before the Emperors and their suites at a bold, brisk
14771. pace.
14772. 
14773. "Lads!" shouted Miloradovich in a loud, self-confident, and cheery
14774. voice, obviously so elated by the sound of firing, by the prospect
14775. of battle, and by the sight of the gallant Apsherons, his comrades in
14776. Suvorov's time, now passing so gallantly before the Emperors, that
14777. he forgot the sovereigns' presence. "Lads, it's not the first village
14778. you've had to take," cried he.
14779. 
14780. "Glad to do our best!" shouted the soldiers.
14781. 
14782. The Emperor's horse started at the sudden cry. This horse that had
14783. carried the sovereign at reviews in Russia bore him also here on the
14784. field of Austerlitz, enduring the heedless blows of his left foot and
14785. pricking its ears at the sound of shots just as it had done on the
14786. Empress' Field, not understanding the significance of the firing, nor
14787. of the nearness of the Emperor Francis' black cob, nor of all that was
14788. being said, thought, and felt that day by its rider.
14789. 
14790. The Emperor turned with a smile to one of his followers and made a
14791. remark to him, pointing to the gallant Apsherons.
14792. 
14793. 
14794. 
14795. 
14796. 
14797. CHAPTER XVI
14798. 
14799. 
14800. Kutuzov accompanied by his adjutants rode at a walking pace behind the
14801. carabineers.
14802. 
14803. When he had gone less than half a mile in the rear of the column he
14804. stopped at a solitary, deserted house that had probably once been an
14805. inn, where two roads parted. Both of them led downhill and troops were
14806. marching along both.
14807. 
14808. The fog had begun to clear and enemy troops were already dimly visible
14809. about a mile and a half off on the opposite heights. Down below, on
14810. the left, the firing became more distinct. Kutuzov had stopped and was
14811. speaking to an Austrian general. Prince Andrew, who was a little behind
14812. looking at them, turned to an adjutant to ask him for a field glass.
14813. 
14814. "Look, look!" said this adjutant, looking not at the troops in the
14815. distance, but down the hill before him. "It's the French!"
14816. 
14817. The two generals and the adjutant took hold of the field glass, trying
14818. to snatch it from one another. The expression on all their faces
14819. suddenly changed to one of horror. The French were supposed to be a
14820. mile and a half away, but had suddenly and unexpectedly appeared just in
14821. front of us.
14822. 
14823. "It's the enemy?... No!... Yes, see it is!... for certain.... But how is
14824. that?" said different voices.
14825. 
14826. With the naked eye Prince Andrew saw below them to the right, not more
14827. than five hundred paces from where Kutuzov was standing, a dense French
14828. column coming up to meet the Apsherons.
14829. 
14830. "Here it is! The decisive moment has arrived. My turn has come," thought
14831. Prince Andrew, and striking his horse he rode up to Kutuzov.
14832. 
14833. "The Apsherons must be stopped, your excellency," cried he. But at that
14834. very instant a cloud of smoke spread all round, firing was heard quite
14835. close at hand, and a voice of naive terror barely two steps from Prince
14836. Andrew shouted, "Brothers! All's lost!" And at this as if at a command,
14837. everyone began to run.
14838. 
14839. Confused and ever-increasing crowds were running back to where five
14840. minutes before the troops had passed the Emperors. Not only would it
14841. have been difficult to stop that crowd, it was even impossible not to
14842. be carried back with it oneself. Bolkonski only tried not to lose touch
14843. with it, and looked around bewildered and unable to grasp what was
14844. happening in front of him. Nesvitski with an angry face, red and unlike
14845. himself, was shouting to Kutuzov that if he did not ride away at once
14846. he would certainly be taken prisoner. Kutuzov remained in the same place
14847. and without answering drew out a handkerchief. Blood was flowing from
14848. his cheek. Prince Andrew forced his way to him.
14849. 
14850. "You are wounded?" he asked, hardly able to master the trembling of his
14851. lower jaw.
14852. 
14853. "The wound is not here, it is there!" said Kutuzov, pressing the
14854. handkerchief to his wounded cheek and pointing to the fleeing soldiers.
14855. "Stop them!" he shouted, and at the same moment, probably realizing that
14856. it was impossible to stop them, spurred his horse and rode to the right.
14857. 
14858. A fresh wave of the flying mob caught him and bore him back with it.
14859. 
14860. The troops were running in such a dense mass that once surrounded by
14861. them it was difficult to get out again. One was shouting, "Get on! Why
14862. are you hindering us?" Another in the same place turned round and fired
14863. in the air; a third was striking the horse Kutuzov himself rode. Having
14864. by a great effort got away to the left from that flood of men, Kutuzov,
14865. with his suite diminished by more than half, rode toward a sound of
14866. artillery fire near by. Having forced his way out of the crowd of
14867. fugitives, Prince Andrew, trying to keep near Kutuzov, saw on the slope
14868. of the hill amid the smoke a Russian battery that was still firing and
14869. Frenchmen running toward it. Higher up stood some Russian infantry,
14870. neither moving forward to protect the battery nor backward with the
14871. fleeing crowd. A mounted general separated himself from the infantry and
14872. approached Kutuzov. Of Kutuzov's suite only four remained. They were all
14873. pale and exchanged looks in silence.
14874. 
14875. "Stop those wretches!" gasped Kutuzov to the regimental commander,
14876. pointing to the flying soldiers; but at that instant, as if to punish
14877. him for those words, bullets flew hissing across the regiment and across
14878. Kutuzov's suite like a flock of little birds.
14879. 
14880. The French had attacked the battery and, seeing Kutuzov, were firing
14881. at him. After this volley the regimental commander clutched at his leg;
14882. several soldiers fell, and a second lieutenant who was holding the
14883. flag let it fall from his hands. It swayed and fell, but caught on the
14884. muskets of the nearest soldiers. The soldiers started firing without
14885. orders.
14886. 
14887. "Oh! Oh! Oh!" groaned Kutuzov despairingly and looked around....
14888. "Bolkonski!" he whispered, his voice trembling from a consciousness
14889. of the feebleness of age, "Bolkonski!" he whispered, pointing to the
14890. disordered battalion and at the enemy, "what's that?"
14891. 
14892. But before he had finished speaking, Prince Andrew, feeling tears of
14893. shame and anger choking him, had already leapt from his horse and run to
14894. the standard.
14895. 
14896. "Forward, lads!" he shouted in a voice piercing as a child's.
14897. 
14898. "Here it is!" thought he, seizing the staff of the standard and hearing
14899. with pleasure the whistle of bullets evidently aimed at him. Several
14900. soldiers fell.
14901. 
14902. "Hurrah!" shouted Prince Andrew, and, scarcely able to hold up the heavy
14903. standard, he ran forward with full confidence that the whole battalion
14904. would follow him.
14905. 
14906. And really he only ran a few steps alone. One soldier moved and then
14907. another and soon the whole battalion ran forward shouting "Hurrah!" and
14908. overtook him. A sergeant of the battalion ran up and took the flag
14909. that was swaying from its weight in Prince Andrew's hands, but he
14910. was immediately killed. Prince Andrew again seized the standard and,
14911. dragging it by the staff, ran on with the battalion. In front he saw our
14912. artillerymen, some of whom were fighting, while others, having abandoned
14913. their guns, were running toward him. He also saw French infantry
14914. soldiers who were seizing the artillery horses and turning the guns
14915. round. Prince Andrew and the battalion were already within twenty paces
14916. of the cannon. He heard the whistle of bullets above him unceasingly and
14917. to right and left of him soldiers continually groaned and dropped. But
14918. he did not look at them: he looked only at what was going on in front
14919. of him--at the battery. He now saw clearly the figure of a red-haired
14920. gunner with his shako knocked awry, pulling one end of a mop while
14921. a French soldier tugged at the other. He could distinctly see the
14922. distraught yet angry expression on the faces of these two men, who
14923. evidently did not realize what they were doing.
14924. 
14925. "What are they about?" thought Prince Andrew as he gazed at them. "Why
14926. doesn't the red-haired gunner run away as he is unarmed? Why doesn't the
14927. Frenchman stab him? He will not get away before the Frenchman remembers
14928. his bayonet and stabs him...."
14929. 
14930. And really another French soldier, trailing his musket, ran up to
14931. the struggling men, and the fate of the red-haired gunner, who had
14932. triumphantly secured the mop and still did not realize what awaited him,
14933. was about to be decided. But Prince Andrew did not see how it ended. It
14934. seemed to him as though one of the soldiers near him hit him on the head
14935. with the full swing of a bludgeon. It hurt a little, but the worst of
14936. it was that the pain distracted him and prevented his seeing what he had
14937. been looking at.
14938. 
14939. "What's this? Am I falling? My legs are giving way," thought he, and
14940. fell on his back. He opened his eyes, hoping to see how the struggle of
14941. the Frenchmen with the gunners ended, whether the red-haired gunner had
14942. been killed or not and whether the cannon had been captured or saved.
14943. But he saw nothing. Above him there was now nothing but the sky--the
14944. lofty sky, not clear yet still immeasurably lofty, with gray clouds
14945. gliding slowly across it. "How quiet, peaceful, and solemn; not at all
14946. as I ran," thought Prince Andrew--"not as we ran, shouting and fighting,
14947. not at all as the gunner and the Frenchman with frightened and angry
14948. faces struggled for the mop: how differently do those clouds glide
14949. across that lofty infinite sky! How was it I did not see that lofty sky
14950. before? And how happy I am to have found it at last! Yes! All is vanity,
14951. all falsehood, except that infinite sky. There is nothing, nothing, but
14952. that. But even it does not exist, there is nothing but quiet and peace.
14953. Thank God!..."
14954. 
14955. 
14956. 
14957. 
14958. 
14959. CHAPTER XVII
14960. 
14961. 
14962. On our right flank commanded by Bagration, at nine o'clock the battle
14963. had not yet begun. Not wishing to agree to Dolgorukov's demand to
14964. commence the action, and wishing to avert responsibility from himself,
14965. Prince Bagration proposed to Dolgorukov to send to inquire of the
14966. commander in chief. Bagration knew that as the distance between the two
14967. flanks was more than six miles, even if the messenger were not killed
14968. (which he very likely would be), and found the commander in chief
14969. (which would be very difficult), he would not be able to get back before
14970. evening.
14971. 
14972. Bagration cast his large, expressionless, sleepy eyes round his suite,
14973. and the boyish face Rostov, breathless with excitement and hope, was the
14974. first to catch his eye. He sent him.
14975. 
14976. "And if I should meet His Majesty before I meet the commander in chief,
14977. your excellency?" said Rostov, with his hand to his cap.
14978. 
14979. "You can give the message to His Majesty," said Dolgorukov, hurriedly
14980. interrupting Bagration.
14981. 
14982. On being relieved from picket duty Rostov had managed to get a few
14983. hours' sleep before morning and felt cheerful, bold, and resolute, with
14984. elasticity of movement, faith in his good fortune, and generally in that
14985. state of mind which makes everything seem possible, pleasant, and easy.
14986. 
14987. All his wishes were being fulfilled that morning: there was to be a
14988. general engagement in which he was taking part, more than that, he was
14989. orderly to the bravest general, and still more, he was going with a
14990. message to Kutuzov, perhaps even to the sovereign himself. The morning
14991. was bright, he had a good horse under him, and his heart was full of
14992. joy and happiness. On receiving the order he gave his horse the rein and
14993. galloped along the line. At first he rode along the line of Bagration's
14994. troops, which had not yet advanced into action but were standing
14995. motionless; then he came to the region occupied by Uvarov's cavalry
14996. and here he noticed a stir and signs of preparation for battle; having
14997. passed Uvarov's cavalry he clearly heard the sound of cannon and
14998. musketry ahead of him. The firing grew louder and louder.
14999. 
15000. In the fresh morning air were now heard, not two or three musket shots
15001. at irregular intervals as before, followed by one or two cannon shots,
15002. but a roll of volleys of musketry from the slopes of the hill before
15003. Pratzen, interrupted by such frequent reports of cannon that sometimes
15004. several of them were not separated from one another but merged into a
15005. general roar.
15006. 
15007. He could see puffs of musketry smoke that seemed to chase one another
15008. down the hillsides, and clouds of cannon smoke rolling, spreading,
15009. and mingling with one another. He could also, by the gleam of bayonets
15010. visible through the smoke, make out moving masses of infantry and narrow
15011. lines of artillery with green caissons.
15012. 
15013. Rostov stopped his horse for a moment on a hillock to see what was going
15014. on, but strain his attention as he would he could not understand or make
15015. out anything of what was happening: there in the smoke men of some sort
15016. were moving about, in front and behind moved lines of troops; but why,
15017. whither, and who they were, it was impossible to make out. These sights
15018. and sounds had no depressing or intimidating effect on him; on the
15019. contrary, they stimulated his energy and determination.
15020. 
15021. "Go on! Go on! Give it them!" he mentally exclaimed at these sounds,
15022. and again proceeded to gallop along the line, penetrating farther and
15023. farther into the region where the army was already in action.
15024. 
15025. "How it will be there I don't know, but all will be well!" thought
15026. Rostov.
15027. 
15028. After passing some Austrian troops he noticed that the next part of the
15029. line (the Guards) was already in action.
15030. 
15031. "So much the better! I shall see it close," he thought.
15032. 
15033. He was riding almost along the front line. A handful of men came
15034. galloping toward him. They were our Uhlans who with disordered
15035. ranks were returning from the attack. Rostov got out of their way,
15036. involuntarily noticed that one of them was bleeding, and galloped on.
15037. 
15038. "That is no business of mine," he thought. He had not ridden many
15039. hundred yards after that before he saw to his left, across the whole
15040. width of the field, an enormous mass of cavalry in brilliant white
15041. uniforms, mounted on black horses, trotting straight toward him and
15042. across his path. Rostov put his horse to full gallop to get out of the
15043. way of these men, and he would have got clear had they continued at the
15044. same speed, but they kept increasing their pace, so that some of the
15045. horses were already galloping. Rostov heard the thud of their hoofs and
15046. the jingle of their weapons and saw their horses, their figures, and
15047. even their faces, more and more distinctly. They were our Horse Guards,
15048. advancing to attack the French cavalry that was coming to meet them.
15049. 
15050. The Horse Guards were galloping, but still holding in their horses.
15051. Rostov could already see their faces and heard the command: "Charge!"
15052. shouted by an officer who was urging his thoroughbred to full speed.
15053. Rostov, fearing to be crushed or swept into the attack on the French,
15054. galloped along the front as hard as his horse could go, but still was
15055. not in time to avoid them.
15056. 
15057. The last of the Horse Guards, a huge pockmarked fellow, frowned angrily
15058. on seeing Rostov before him, with whom he would inevitably collide.
15059. This Guardsman would certainly have bowled Rostov and his Bedouin over
15060. (Rostov felt himself quite tiny and weak compared to these gigantic men
15061. and horses) had it not occurred to Rostov to flourish his whip before
15062. the eyes of the Guardsman's horse. The heavy black horse, sixteen hands
15063. high, shied, throwing back its ears; but the pockmarked Guardsman drove
15064. his huge spurs in violently, and the horse, flourishing its tail and
15065. extending its neck, galloped on yet faster. Hardly had the Horse Guards
15066. passed Rostov before he heard them shout, "Hurrah!" and looking back saw
15067. that their foremost ranks were mixed up with some foreign cavalry
15068. with red epaulets, probably French. He could see nothing more, for
15069. immediately afterwards cannon began firing from somewhere and smoke
15070. enveloped everything.
15071. 
15072. At that moment, as the Horse Guards, having passed him, disappeared in
15073. the smoke, Rostov hesitated whether to gallop after them or to go where
15074. he was sent. This was the brilliant charge of the Horse Guards that
15075. amazed the French themselves. Rostov was horrified to hear later that
15076. of all that mass of huge and handsome men, of all those brilliant,
15077. rich youths, officers and cadets, who had galloped past him on their
15078. thousand-ruble horses, only eighteen were left after the charge.
15079. 
15080. "Why should I envy them? My chance is not lost, and maybe I shall see
15081. the Emperor immediately!" thought Rostov and galloped on.
15082. 
15083. When he came level with the Foot Guards he noticed that about them and
15084. around them cannon balls were flying, of which he was aware not so
15085. much because he heard their sound as because he saw uneasiness on
15086. the soldiers' faces and unnatural warlike solemnity on those of the
15087. officers.
15088. 
15089. Passing behind one of the lines of a regiment of Foot Guards he heard a
15090. voice calling him by name.
15091. 
15092. "Rostov!"
15093. 
15094. "What?" he answered, not recognizing Boris.
15095. 
15096. "I say, we've been in the front line! Our regiment attacked!" said Boris
15097. with the happy smile seen on the faces of young men who have been under
15098. fire for the first time.
15099. 
15100. Rostov stopped.
15101. 
15102. "Have you?" he said. "Well, how did it go?"
15103. 
15104. "We drove them back!" said Boris with animation, growing talkative. "Can
15105. you imagine it?" and he began describing how the Guards, having taken
15106. up their position and seeing troops before them, thought they were
15107. Austrians, and all at once discovered from the cannon balls discharged
15108. by those troops that they were themselves in the front line and had
15109. unexpectedly to go into action. Rostov without hearing Boris to the end
15110. spurred his horse.
15111. 
15112. "Where are you off to?" asked Boris.
15113. 
15114. "With a message to His Majesty."
15115. 
15116. "There he is!" said Boris, thinking Rostov had said "His Highness,"
15117. and pointing to the Grand Duke who with his high shoulders and frowning
15118. brows stood a hundred paces away from them in his helmet and Horse
15119. Guards' jacket, shouting something to a pale, white uniformed Austrian
15120. officer.
15121. 
15122. "But that's the Grand Duke, and I want the commander in chief or the
15123. Emperor," said Rostov, and was about to spur his horse.
15124. 
15125. "Count! Count!" shouted Berg who ran up from the other side as eager
15126. as Boris. "Count! I am wounded in my right hand" (and he showed his
15127. bleeding hand with a handkerchief tied round it) "and I remained at the
15128. front. I held my sword in my left hand, Count. All our family--the von
15129. Bergs--have been knights!"
15130. 
15131. He said something more, but Rostov did not wait to hear it and rode
15132. away.
15133. 
15134. Having passed the Guards and traversed an empty space, Rostov, to avoid
15135. again getting in front of the first line as he had done when the Horse
15136. Guards charged, followed the line of reserves, going far round the place
15137. where the hottest musket fire and cannonade were heard. Suddenly he
15138. heard musket fire quite close in front of him and behind our troops,
15139. where he could never have expected the enemy to be.
15140. 
15141. "What can it be?" he thought. "The enemy in the rear of our army?
15142. Impossible!" And suddenly he was seized by a panic of fear for himself
15143. and for the issue of the whole battle. "But be that what it may,"
15144. he reflected, "there is no riding round it now. I must look for the
15145. commander in chief here, and if all is lost it is for me to perish with
15146. the rest."
15147. 
15148. The foreboding of evil that had suddenly come over Rostov was more and
15149. more confirmed the farther he rode into the region behind the village of
15150. Pratzen, which was full of troops of all kinds.
15151. 
15152. "What does it mean? What is it? Whom are they firing at? Who is firing?"
15153. Rostov kept asking as he came up to Russian and Austrian soldiers
15154. running in confused crowds across his path.
15155. 
15156. "The devil knows! They've killed everybody! It's all up now!" he
15157. was told in Russian, German, and Czech by the crowd of fugitives who
15158. understood what was happening as little as he did.
15159. 
15160. "Kill the Germans!" shouted one.
15161. 
15162. "May the devil take them--the traitors!"
15163. 
15164. "Zum Henker diese Russen!" * muttered a German.
15165. 
15166. 
15167.     * "Hang these Russians!"
15168. 
15169. 
15170. Several wounded men passed along the road, and words of abuse, screams,
15171. and groans mingled in a general hubbub, then the firing died down.
15172. Rostov learned later that Russian and Austrian soldiers had been firing
15173. at one another.
15174. 
15175. "My God! What does it all mean?" thought he. "And here, where at any
15176. moment the Emperor may see them.... But no, these must be only a handful
15177. of scoundrels. It will soon be over, it can't be that, it can't be! Only
15178. to get past them quicker, quicker!"
15179. 
15180. The idea of defeat and flight could not enter Rostov's head. Though he
15181. saw French cannon and French troops on the Pratzen Heights just where he
15182. had been ordered to look for the commander in chief, he could not, did
15183. not wish to, believe that.
15184. 
15185. 
15186. 
15187. 
15188. 
15189. CHAPTER XVIII
15190. 
15191. 
15192. Rostov had been ordered to look for Kutuzov and the Emperor near the
15193. village of Pratzen. But neither they nor a single commanding officer
15194. were there, only disorganized crowds of troops of various kinds. He
15195. urged on his already weary horse to get quickly past these crowds, but
15196. the farther he went the more disorganized they were. The highroad on
15197. which he had come out was thronged with caleches, carriages of all
15198. sorts, and Russian and Austrian soldiers of all arms, some wounded and
15199. some not. This whole mass droned and jostled in confusion under the
15200. dismal influence of cannon balls flying from the French batteries
15201. stationed on the Pratzen Heights.
15202. 
15203. "Where is the Emperor? Where is Kutuzov?" Rostov kept asking everyone he
15204. could stop, but got no answer from anyone.
15205. 
15206. At last seizing a soldier by his collar he forced him to answer.
15207. 
15208. "Eh, brother! They've all bolted long ago!" said the soldier, laughing
15209. for some reason and shaking himself free.
15210. 
15211. Having left that soldier who was evidently drunk, Rostov stopped the
15212. horse of a batman or groom of some important personage and began to
15213. question him. The man announced that the Tsar had been driven in a
15214. carriage at full speed about an hour before along that very road and
15215. that he was dangerously wounded.
15216. 
15217. "It can't be!" said Rostov. "It must have been someone else."
15218. 
15219. "I saw him myself," replied the man with a self-confident smile of
15220. derision. "I ought to know the Emperor by now, after the times I've seen
15221. him in Petersburg. I saw him just as I see you.... There he sat in the
15222. carriage as pale as anything. How they made the four black horses fly!
15223. Gracious me, they did rattle past! It's time I knew the Imperial horses
15224. and Ilya Ivanych. I don't think Ilya drives anyone except the Tsar!"
15225. 
15226. Rostov let go of the horse and was about to ride on, when a wounded
15227. officer passing by addressed him:
15228. 
15229. "Who is it you want?" he asked. "The commander in chief? He was killed
15230. by a cannon ball--struck in the breast before our regiment."
15231. 
15232. "Not killed--wounded!" another officer corrected him.
15233. 
15234. "Who? Kutuzov?" asked Rostov.
15235. 
15236. "Not Kutuzov, but what's his name--well, never mind... there are not
15237. many left alive. Go that way, to that village, all the commanders are
15238. there," said the officer, pointing to the village of Hosjeradek, and he
15239. walked on.
15240. 
15241. Rostov rode on at a footpace not knowing why or to whom he was now
15242. going. The Emperor was wounded, the battle lost. It was impossible to
15243. doubt it now. Rostov rode in the direction pointed out to him, in which
15244. he saw turrets and a church. What need to hurry? What was he now to say
15245. to the Tsar or to Kutuzov, even if they were alive and unwounded?
15246. 
15247. "Take this road, your honor, that way you will be killed at once!" a
15248. soldier shouted to him. "They'd kill you there!"
15249. 
15250. "Oh, what are you talking about?" said another. "Where is he to go? That
15251. way is nearer."
15252. 
15253. Rostov considered, and then went in the direction where they said he
15254. would be killed.
15255. 
15256. "It's all the same now. If the Emperor is wounded, am I to try to save
15257. myself?" he thought. He rode on to the region where the greatest number
15258. of men had perished in fleeing from Pratzen. The French had not yet
15259. occupied that region, and the Russians--the uninjured and slightly
15260. wounded--had left it long ago. All about the field, like heaps of manure
15261. on well-kept plowland, lay from ten to fifteen dead and wounded to each
15262. couple of acres. The wounded crept together in twos and threes and one
15263. could hear their distressing screams and groans, sometimes feigned--or
15264. so it seemed to Rostov. He put his horse to a trot to avoid seeing all
15265. these suffering men, and he felt afraid--afraid not for his life, but
15266. for the courage he needed and which he knew would not stand the sight of
15267. these unfortunates.
15268. 
15269. The French, who had ceased firing at this field strewn with dead and
15270. wounded where there was no one left to fire at, on seeing an adjutant
15271. riding over it trained a gun on him and fired several shots. The
15272. sensation of those terrible whistling sounds and of the corpses around
15273. him merged in Rostov's mind into a single feeling of terror and pity for
15274. himself. He remembered his mother's last letter. "What would she feel,"
15275. thought he, "if she saw me here now on this field with the cannon aimed
15276. at me?"
15277. 
15278. In the village of Hosjeradek there were Russian troops retiring from
15279. the field of battle, who though still in some confusion were less
15280. disordered. The French cannon did not reach there and the musketry fire
15281. sounded far away. Here everyone clearly saw and said that the battle
15282. was lost. No one whom Rostov asked could tell him where the Emperor
15283. or Kutuzov was. Some said the report that the Emperor was wounded was
15284. correct, others that it was not, and explained the false rumor that had
15285. spread by the fact that the Emperor's carriage had really galloped from
15286. the field of battle with the pale and terrified Ober-Hofmarschal Count
15287. Tolstoy, who had ridden out to the battlefield with others in the
15288. Emperor's suite. One officer told Rostov that he had seen someone from
15289. headquarters behind the village to the left, and thither Rostov rode,
15290. not hoping to find anyone but merely to ease his conscience. When he had
15291. ridden about two miles and had passed the last of the Russian troops, he
15292. saw, near a kitchen garden with a ditch round it, two men on horseback
15293. facing the ditch. One with a white plume in his hat seemed familiar to
15294. Rostov; the other on a beautiful chestnut horse (which Rostov fancied he
15295. had seen before) rode up to the ditch, struck his horse with his spurs,
15296. and giving it the rein leaped lightly over. Only a little earth crumbled
15297. from the bank under the horse's hind hoofs. Turning the horse sharply,
15298. he again jumped the ditch, and deferentially addressed the horseman with
15299. the white plumes, evidently suggesting that he should do the same. The
15300. rider, whose figure seemed familiar to Rostov and involuntarily riveted
15301. his attention, made a gesture of refusal with his head and hand and
15302. by that gesture Rostov instantly recognized his lamented and adored
15303. monarch.
15304. 
15305. "But it can't be he, alone in the midst of this empty field!" thought
15306. Rostov. At that moment Alexander turned his head and Rostov saw the
15307. beloved features that were so deeply engraved on his memory. The Emperor
15308. was pale, his cheeks sunken and his eyes hollow, but the charm, the
15309. mildness of his features, was all the greater. Rostov was happy in the
15310. assurance that the rumors about the Emperor being wounded were false. He
15311. was happy to be seeing him. He knew that he might and even ought to
15312. go straight to him and give the message Dolgorukov had ordered him to
15313. deliver.
15314. 
15315. But as a youth in love trembles, is unnerved, and dares not utter the
15316. thoughts he has dreamed of for nights, but looks around for help or a
15317. chance of delay and flight when the longed-for moment comes and he is
15318. alone with her, so Rostov, now that he had attained what he had longed
15319. for more than anything else in the world, did not know how to approach
15320. the Emperor, and a thousand reasons occurred to him why it would be
15321. inconvenient, unseemly, and impossible to do so.
15322. 
15323. "What! It is as if I were glad of a chance to take advantage of his
15324. being alone and despondent! A strange face may seem unpleasant or
15325. painful to him at this moment of sorrow; besides, what can I say to him
15326. now, when my heart fails me and my mouth feels dry at the mere sight of
15327. him?" Not one of the innumerable speeches addressed to the Emperor that
15328. he had composed in his imagination could he now recall. Those speeches
15329. were intended for quite other conditions, they were for the most part
15330. to be spoken at a moment of victory and triumph, generally when he was
15331. dying of wounds and the sovereign had thanked him for heroic deeds, and
15332. while dying he expressed the love his actions had proved.
15333. 
15334. "Besides how can I ask the Emperor for his instructions for the right
15335. flank now that it is nearly four o'clock and the battle is lost?
15336. No, certainly I must not approach him, I must not intrude on his
15337. reflections. Better die a thousand times than risk receiving an unkind
15338. look or bad opinion from him," Rostov decided; and sorrowfully and with
15339. a heart full despair he rode away, continually looking back at the Tsar,
15340. who still remained in the same attitude of indecision.
15341. 
15342. While Rostov was thus arguing with himself and riding sadly away,
15343. Captain von Toll chanced to ride to the same spot, and seeing the
15344. Emperor at once rode up to him, offered his services, and assisted him
15345. to cross the ditch on foot. The Emperor, wishing to rest and feeling
15346. unwell, sat down under an apple tree and von Toll remained beside him.
15347. Rostov from a distance saw with envy and remorse how von Toll spoke
15348. long and warmly to the Emperor and how the Emperor, evidently weeping,
15349. covered his eyes with his hand and pressed von Toll's hand.
15350. 
15351. "And I might have been in his place!" thought Rostov, and hardly
15352. restraining his tears of pity for the Emperor, he rode on in utter
15353. despair, not knowing where to or why he was now riding.
15354. 
15355. His despair was all the greater from feeling that his own weakness was
15356. the cause of his grief.
15357. 
15358. He might... not only might but should, have gone up to the sovereign. It
15359. was a unique chance to show his devotion to the Emperor and he had not
15360. made use of it.... "What have I done?" thought he. And he turned round
15361. and galloped back to the place where he had seen the Emperor, but there
15362. was no one beyond the ditch now. Only some carts and carriages were
15363. passing by. From one of the drivers he learned that Kutuzov's staff were
15364. not far off, in the village the vehicles were going to. Rostov
15365. followed them. In front of him walked Kutuzov's groom leading horses
15366. in horsecloths. Then came a cart, and behind that walked an old,
15367. bandy-legged domestic serf in a peaked cap and sheepskin coat.
15368. 
15369. "Tit! I say, Tit!" said the groom.
15370. 
15371. "What?" answered the old man absent-mindedly.
15372. 
15373. "Go, Tit! Thresh a bit!"
15374. 
15375. "Oh, you fool!" said the old man, spitting angrily. Some time passed in
15376. silence, and then the same joke was repeated.
15377. 
15378. 
15379. Before five in the evening the battle had been lost at all points. More
15380. than a hundred cannon were already in the hands of the French.
15381. 
15382. Przebyszewski and his corps had laid down their arms. Other columns
15383. after losing half their men were retreating in disorderly confused
15384. masses.
15385. 
15386. The remains of Langeron's and Dokhturov's mingled forces were crowding
15387. around the dams and banks of the ponds near the village of Augesd.
15388. 
15389. After five o'clock it was only at the Augesd Dam that a hot cannonade
15390. (delivered by the French alone) was still to be heard from numerous
15391. batteries ranged on the slopes of the Pratzen Heights, directed at our
15392. retreating forces.
15393. 
15394. In the rearguard, Dokhturov and others rallying some battalions kept up
15395. a musketry fire at the French cavalry that was pursuing our troops. It
15396. was growing dusk. On the narrow Augesd Dam where for so many years the
15397. old miller had been accustomed to sit in his tasseled cap peacefully
15398. angling, while his grandson, with shirt sleeves rolled up, handled the
15399. floundering silvery fish in the watering can, on that dam over which for
15400. so many years Moravians in shaggy caps and blue jackets had peacefully
15401. driven their two-horse carts loaded with wheat and had returned dusty
15402. with flour whitening their carts--on that narrow dam amid the wagons and
15403. the cannon, under the horses' hoofs and between the wagon wheels, men
15404. disfigured by fear of death now crowded together, crushing one another,
15405. dying, stepping over the dying and killing one another, only to move on
15406. a few steps and be killed themselves in the same way.
15407. 
15408. Every ten seconds a cannon ball flew compressing the air around, or
15409. a shell burst in the midst of that dense throng, killing some and
15410. splashing with blood those near them.
15411. 
15412. Dolokhov--now an officer--wounded in the arm, and on foot, with the
15413. regimental commander on horseback and some ten men of his company,
15414. represented all that was left of that whole regiment. Impelled by the
15415. crowd, they had got wedged in at the approach to the dam and, jammed in
15416. on all sides, had stopped because a horse in front had fallen under a
15417. cannon and the crowd were dragging it out. A cannon ball killed someone
15418. behind them, another fell in front and splashed Dolokhov with blood.
15419. The crowd, pushing forward desperately, squeezed together, moved a few
15420. steps, and again stopped.
15421. 
15422. "Move on a hundred yards and we are certainly saved, remain here another
15423. two minutes and it is certain death," thought each one.
15424. 
15425. Dolokhov who was in the midst of the crowd forced his way to the edge of
15426. the dam, throwing two soldiers off their feet, and ran onto the slippery
15427. ice that covered the millpool.
15428. 
15429. "Turn this way!" he shouted, jumping over the ice which creaked under
15430. him; "turn this way!" he shouted to those with the gun. "It bears!..."
15431. 
15432. The ice bore him but it swayed and creaked, and it was plain that it
15433. would give way not only under a cannon or a crowd, but very soon even
15434. under his weight alone. The men looked at him and pressed to the
15435. bank, hesitating to step onto the ice. The general on horseback at the
15436. entrance to the dam raised his hand and opened his mouth to address
15437. Dolokhov. Suddenly a cannon ball hissed so low above the crowd that
15438. everyone ducked. It flopped into something moist, and the general fell
15439. from his horse in a pool of blood. Nobody gave him a look or thought of
15440. raising him.
15441. 
15442. "Get onto the ice, over the ice! Go on! Turn! Don't you hear? Go on!"
15443. innumerable voices suddenly shouted after the ball had struck the
15444. general, the men themselves not knowing what, or why, they were
15445. shouting.
15446. 
15447. One of the hindmost guns that was going onto the dam turned off onto the
15448. ice. Crowds of soldiers from the dam began running onto the frozen pond.
15449. The ice gave way under one of the foremost soldiers, and one leg slipped
15450. into the water. He tried to right himself but fell in up to his waist.
15451. The nearest soldiers shrank back, the gun driver stopped his horse, but
15452. from behind still came the shouts: "Onto the ice, why do you stop? Go
15453. on! Go on!" And cries of horror were heard in the crowd. The soldiers
15454. near the gun waved their arms and beat the horses to make them turn and
15455. move on. The horses moved off the bank. The ice, that had held under
15456. those on foot, collapsed in a great mass, and some forty men who were on
15457. it dashed, some forward and some back, drowning one another.
15458. 
15459. Still the cannon balls continued regularly to whistle and flop onto the
15460. ice and into the water and oftenest of all among the crowd that covered
15461. the dam, the pond, and the bank.
15462. 
15463. 
15464. 
15465. 
15466. 
15467. CHAPTER XIX
15468. 
15469. 
15470. On the Pratzen Heights, where he had fallen with the flagstaff in his
15471. hand, lay Prince Andrew Bolkonski bleeding profusely and unconsciously
15472. uttering a gentle, piteous, and childlike moan.
15473. 
15474. Toward evening he ceased moaning and became quite still. He did not know
15475. how long his unconsciousness lasted. Suddenly he again felt that he was
15476. alive and suffering from a burning, lacerating pain in his head.
15477. 
15478. "Where is it, that lofty sky that I did not know till now, but saw
15479. today?" was his first thought. "And I did not know this suffering
15480. either," he thought. "Yes, I did not know anything, anything at all till
15481. now. But where am I?"
15482. 
15483. He listened and heard the sound of approaching horses, and voices
15484. speaking French. He opened his eyes. Above him again was the same lofty
15485. sky with clouds that had risen and were floating still higher, and
15486. between them gleamed blue infinity. He did not turn his head and did not
15487. see those who, judging by the sound of hoofs and voices, had ridden up
15488. and stopped near him.
15489. 
15490. It was Napoleon accompanied by two aides-de-camp. Bonaparte riding
15491. over the battlefield had given final orders to strengthen the batteries
15492. firing at the Augesd Dam and was looking at the killed and wounded left
15493. on the field.
15494. 
15495. "Fine men!" remarked Napoleon, looking at a dead Russian grenadier,
15496. who, with his face buried in the ground and a blackened nape, lay on his
15497. stomach with an already stiffened arm flung wide.
15498. 
15499. "The ammunition for the guns in position is exhausted, Your Majesty,"
15500. said an adjutant who had come from the batteries that were firing at
15501. Augesd.
15502. 
15503. "Have some brought from the reserve," said Napoleon, and having gone on
15504. a few steps he stopped before Prince Andrew, who lay on his back with
15505. the flagstaff that had been dropped beside him. (The flag had already
15506. been taken by the French as a trophy.)
15507. 
15508. "That's a fine death!" said Napoleon as he gazed at Bolkonski.
15509. 
15510. Prince Andrew understood that this was said of him and that it was
15511. Napoleon who said it. He heard the speaker addressed as Sire. But he
15512. heard the words as he might have heard the buzzing of a fly. Not only
15513. did they not interest him, but he took no notice of them and at once
15514. forgot them. His head was burning, he felt himself bleeding to death,
15515. and he saw above him the remote, lofty, and everlasting sky. He knew it
15516. was Napoleon--his hero--but at that moment Napoleon seemed to him such a
15517. small, insignificant creature compared with what was passing now between
15518. himself and that lofty infinite sky with the clouds flying over it. At
15519. that moment it meant nothing to him who might be standing over him, or
15520. what was said of him; he was only glad that people were standing near
15521. him and only wished that they would help him and bring him back to
15522. life, which seemed to him so beautiful now that he had today learned to
15523. understand it so differently. He collected all his strength, to stir and
15524. utter a sound. He feebly moved his leg and uttered a weak, sickly groan
15525. which aroused his own pity.
15526. 
15527. "Ah! He is alive," said Napoleon. "Lift this young man up and carry him
15528. to the dressing station."
15529. 
15530. Having said this, Napoleon rode on to meet Marshal Lannes, who, hat in
15531. hand, rode up smiling to the Emperor to congratulate him on the victory.
15532. 
15533. Prince Andrew remembered nothing more: he lost consciousness from the
15534. terrible pain of being lifted onto the stretcher, the jolting while
15535. being moved, and the probing of his wound at the dressing station.
15536. He did not regain consciousness till late in the day, when with other
15537. wounded and captured Russian officers he was carried to the hospital.
15538. During this transfer he felt a little stronger and was able to look
15539. about him and even speak.
15540. 
15541. The first words he heard on coming to his senses were those of a French
15542. convoy officer, who said rapidly: "We must halt here: the Emperor
15543. will pass here immediately; it will please him to see these gentlemen
15544. prisoners."
15545. 
15546. "There are so many prisoners today, nearly the whole Russian army, that
15547. he is probably tired of them," said another officer.
15548. 
15549. "All the same! They say this one is the commander of all the Emperor
15550. Alexander's Guards," said the first one, indicating a Russian officer in
15551. the white uniform of the Horse Guards.
15552. 
15553. Bolkonski recognized Prince Repnin whom he had met in Petersburg
15554. society. Beside him stood a lad of nineteen, also a wounded officer of
15555. the Horse Guards.
15556. 
15557. Bonaparte, having come up at a gallop, stopped his horse.
15558. 
15559. "Which is the senior?" he asked, on seeing the prisoners.
15560. 
15561. They named the colonel, Prince Repnin.
15562. 
15563. "You are the commander of the Emperor Alexander's regiment of Horse
15564. Guards?" asked Napoleon.
15565. 
15566. "I commanded a squadron," replied Repnin.
15567. 
15568. "Your regiment fulfilled its duty honorably," said Napoleon.
15569. 
15570. "The praise of a great commander is a soldier's highest reward," said
15571. Repnin.
15572. 
15573. "I bestow it with pleasure," said Napoleon. "And who is that young man
15574. beside you?"
15575. 
15576. Prince Repnin named Lieutenant Sukhtelen.
15577. 
15578. After looking at him Napoleon smiled.
15579. 
15580. "He's very young to come to meddle with us."
15581. 
15582. "Youth is no hindrance to courage," muttered Sukhtelen in a failing
15583. voice.
15584. 
15585. "A splendid reply!" said Napoleon. "Young man, you will go far!"
15586. 
15587. Prince Andrew, who had also been brought forward before the Emperor's
15588. eyes to complete the show of prisoners, could not fail to attract his
15589. attention. Napoleon apparently remembered seeing him on the battlefield
15590. and, addressing him, again used the epithet "young man" that was
15591. connected in his memory with Prince Andrew.
15592. 
15593. "Well, and you, young man," said he. "How do you feel, mon brave?"
15594. 
15595. Though five minutes before, Prince Andrew had been able to say a few
15596. words to the soldiers who were carrying him, now with his eyes fixed
15597. straight on Napoleon, he was silent.... So insignificant at that moment
15598. seemed to him all the interests that engrossed Napoleon, so mean did his
15599. hero himself with his paltry vanity and joy in victory appear,
15600. compared to the lofty, equitable, and kindly sky which he had seen and
15601. understood, that he could not answer him.
15602. 
15603. Everything seemed so futile and insignificant in comparison with the
15604. stern and solemn train of thought that weakness from loss of blood,
15605. suffering, and the nearness of death aroused in him. Looking into
15606. Napoleon's eyes Prince Andrew thought of the insignificance of
15607. greatness, the unimportance of life which no one could understand, and
15608. the still greater unimportance of death, the meaning of which no one
15609. alive could understand or explain.
15610. 
15611. The Emperor without waiting for an answer turned away and said to one of
15612. the officers as he went: "Have these gentlemen attended to and taken
15613. to my bivouac; let my doctor, Larrey, examine their wounds. Au revoir,
15614. Prince Repnin!" and he spurred his horse and galloped away.
15615. 
15616. His face shone with self-satisfaction and pleasure.
15617. 
15618. The soldiers who had carried Prince Andrew had noticed and taken the
15619. little gold icon Princess Mary had hung round her brother's neck, but
15620. seeing the favor the Emperor showed the prisoners, they now hastened to
15621. return the holy image.
15622. 
15623. Prince Andrew did not see how and by whom it was replaced, but the
15624. little icon with its thin gold chain suddenly appeared upon his chest
15625. outside his uniform.
15626. 
15627. "It would be good," thought Prince Andrew, glancing at the icon his
15628. sister had hung round his neck with such emotion and reverence, "it
15629. would be good if everything were as clear and simple as it seems to
15630. Mary. How good it would be to know where to seek for help in this life,
15631. and what to expect after it beyond the grave! How happy and calm I
15632. should be if I could now say: 'Lord, have mercy on me!'... But to whom
15633. should I say that? Either to a Power indefinable, incomprehensible,
15634. which I not only cannot address but which I cannot even express in
15635. words--the Great All or Nothing-" said he to himself, "or to that God
15636. who has been sewn into this amulet by Mary! There is nothing certain,
15637. nothing at all except the unimportance of everything I understand, and
15638. the greatness of something incomprehensible but all-important."
15639. 
15640. The stretchers moved on. At every jolt he again felt unendurable pain;
15641. his feverishness increased and he grew delirious. Visions of his father,
15642. wife, sister, and future son, and the tenderness he had felt the night
15643. before the battle, the figure of the insignificant little Napoleon, and
15644. above all this the lofty sky, formed the chief subjects of his delirious
15645. fancies.
15646. 
15647. The quiet home life and peaceful happiness of Bald Hills presented
15648. itself to him. He was already enjoying that happiness when that
15649. little Napoleon had suddenly appeared with his unsympathizing look of
15650. shortsighted delight at the misery of others, and doubts and torments
15651. had followed, and only the heavens promised peace. Toward morning
15652. all these dreams melted and merged into the chaos and darkness of
15653. unconciousness and oblivion which in the opinion of Napoleon's doctor,
15654. Larrey, was much more likely to end in death than in convalescence.
15655.
