15656. "He is a nervous, bilious subject," said Larrey, "and will not recover."
15657. 
15658. And Prince Andrew, with others fatally wounded, was left to the care of
15659. the inhabitants of the district.
15660. 
15661. 
15662. 
15663. 
15664. 
15665. BOOK FOUR: 1806
15666. 
15667. 
15668. 
15669. 
15670. 
15671. CHAPTER I
15672. 
15673. 
15674. Early in the year 1806 Nicholas Rostov returned home on leave. Denisov
15675. was going home to Voronezh and Rostov persuaded him to travel with him
15676. as far as Moscow and to stay with him there. Meeting a comrade at the
15677. last post station but one before Moscow, Denisov had drunk three bottles
15678. of wine with him and, despite the jolting ruts across the snow-covered
15679. road, did not once wake up on the way to Moscow, but lay at the bottom
15680. of the sleigh beside Rostov, who grew more and more impatient the nearer
15681. they got to Moscow.
15682. 
15683. "How much longer? How much longer? Oh, these insufferable streets,
15684. shops, bakers' signboards, street lamps, and sleighs!" thought Rostov,
15685. when their leave permits had been passed at the town gate and they had
15686. entered Moscow.
15687. 
15688. "Denisov! We're here! He's asleep," he added, leaning forward with his
15689. whole body as if in that position he hoped to hasten the speed of the
15690. sleigh.
15691. 
15692. Denisov gave no answer.
15693. 
15694. "There's the corner at the crossroads, where the cabman, Zakhar, has his
15695. stand, and there's Zakhar himself and still the same horse! And here's
15696. the little shop where we used to buy gingerbread! Can't you hurry up?
15697. Now then!"
15698. 
15699. "Which house is it?" asked the driver.
15700. 
15701. "Why, that one, right at the end, the big one. Don't you see? That's our
15702. house," said Rostov. "Of course, it's our house! Denisov, Denisov! We're
15703. almost there!"
15704. 
15705. Denisov raised his head, coughed, and made no answer.
15706. 
15707. "Dmitri," said Rostov to his valet on the box, "those lights are in our
15708. house, aren't they?"
15709. 
15710. "Yes, sir, and there's a light in your father's study."
15711. 
15712. "Then they've not gone to bed yet? What do you think? Mind now,
15713. don't forget to put out my new coat," added Rostov, fingering his new
15714. mustache. "Now then, get on," he shouted to the driver. "Do wake up,
15715. Vaska!" he went on, turning to Denisov, whose head was again nodding.
15716. "Come, get on! You shall have three rubles for vodka--get on!" Rostov
15717. shouted, when the sleigh was only three houses from his door. It seemed
15718. to him the horses were not moving at all. At last the sleigh bore to the
15719. right, drew up at an entrance, and Rostov saw overhead the old familiar
15720. cornice with a bit of plaster broken off, the porch, and the post by the
15721. side of the pavement. He sprang out before the sleigh stopped, and ran
15722. into the hall. The house stood cold and silent, as if quite regardless
15723. of who had come to it. There was no one in the hall. "Oh God! Is
15724. everyone all right?" he thought, stopping for a moment with a sinking
15725. heart, and then immediately starting to run along the hall and up the
15726. warped steps of the familiar staircase. The well-known old door handle,
15727. which always angered the countess when it was not properly cleaned,
15728. turned as loosely as ever. A solitary tallow candle burned in the
15729. anteroom.
15730. 
15731. Old Michael was asleep on the chest. Prokofy, the footman, who was so
15732. strong that he could lift the back of the carriage from behind, sat
15733. plaiting slippers out of cloth selvedges. He looked up at the opening
15734. door and his expression of sleepy indifference suddenly changed to one
15735. of delighted amazement.
15736. 
15737. "Gracious heavens! The young count!" he cried, recognizing his
15738. young master. "Can it be? My treasure!" and Prokofy, trembling with
15739. excitement, rushed toward the drawing-room door, probably in order to
15740. announce him, but, changing his mind, came back and stooped to kiss the
15741. young man's shoulder.
15742. 
15743. "All well?" asked Rostov, drawing away his arm.
15744. 
15745. "Yes, God be thanked! Yes! They've just finished supper. Let me have a
15746. look at you, your excellency."
15747. 
15748. "Is everything quite all right?"
15749. 
15750. "The Lord be thanked, yes!"
15751. 
15752. Rostov, who had completely forgotten Denisov, not wishing anyone to
15753. forestall him, threw off his fur coat and ran on tiptoe through the
15754. large dark ballroom. All was the same: there were the same old card
15755. tables and the same chandelier with a cover over it; but someone had
15756. already seen the young master, and, before he had reached the drawing
15757. room, something flew out from a side door like a tornado and began
15758. hugging and kissing him. Another and yet another creature of the same
15759. kind sprang from a second door and a third; more hugging, more kissing,
15760. more outcries, and tears of joy. He could not distinguish which was
15761. Papa, which Natasha, and which Petya. Everyone shouted, talked, and
15762. kissed him at the same time. Only his mother was not there, he noticed
15763. that.
15764. 
15765. "And I did not know... Nicholas... My darling!..."
15766. 
15767. "Here he is... our own... Kolya, * dear fellow... How he has changed!...
15768. Where are the candles?... Tea!..."
15769. 
15770. 
15771.     * Nicholas.
15772. 
15773. 
15774. "And me, kiss me!"
15775. 
15776. "Dearest... and me!"
15777. 
15778. Sonya, Natasha, Petya, Anna Mikhaylovna, Vera, and the old count were
15779. all hugging him, and the serfs, men and maids, flocked into the room,
15780. exclaiming and oh-ing and ah-ing.
15781. 
15782. Petya, clinging to his legs, kept shouting, "And me too!"
15783. 
15784. Natasha, after she had pulled him down toward her and covered his face
15785. with kisses, holding him tight by the skirt of his coat, sprang away and
15786. pranced up and down in one place like a goat and shrieked piercingly.
15787. 
15788. All around were loving eyes glistening with tears of joy, and all around
15789. were lips seeking a kiss.
15790. 
15791. Sonya too, all rosy red, clung to his arm and, radiant with bliss,
15792. looked eagerly toward his eyes, waiting for the look for which she
15793. longed. Sonya now was sixteen and she was very pretty, especially at
15794. this moment of happy, rapturous excitement. She gazed at him, not taking
15795. her eyes off him, and smiling and holding her breath. He gave her a
15796. grateful look, but was still expectant and looking for someone. The old
15797. countess had not yet come. But now steps were heard at the door, steps
15798. so rapid that they could hardly be his mother's.
15799. 
15800. Yet it was she, dressed in a new gown which he did not know, made since
15801. he had left. All the others let him go, and he ran to her. When they
15802. met, she fell on his breast, sobbing. She could not lift her face, but
15803. only pressed it to the cold braiding of his hussar's jacket. Denisov,
15804. who had come into the room unnoticed by anyone, stood there and wiped
15805. his eyes at the sight.
15806. 
15807. "Vasili Denisov, your son's friend," he said, introducing himself to the
15808. count, who was looking inquiringly at him.
15809. 
15810. "You are most welcome! I know, I know," said the count, kissing and
15811. embracing Denisov. "Nicholas wrote us... Natasha, Vera, look! Here is
15812. Denisov!"
15813. 
15814. The same happy, rapturous faces turned to the shaggy figure of Denisov.
15815. 
15816. "Darling Denisov!" screamed Natasha, beside herself with rapture,
15817. springing to him, putting her arms round him, and kissing him. This
15818. escapade made everybody feel confused. Denisov blushed too, but smiled
15819. and, taking Natasha's hand, kissed it.
15820. 
15821. Denisov was shown to the room prepared for him, and the Rostovs all
15822. gathered round Nicholas in the sitting room.
15823. 
15824. The old countess, not letting go of his hand and kissing it every
15825. moment, sat beside him: the rest, crowding round him, watched every
15826. movement, word, or look of his, never taking their blissfully adoring
15827. eyes off him. His brother and sisters struggled for the places nearest
15828. to him and disputed with one another who should bring him his tea,
15829. handkerchief, and pipe.
15830. 
15831. Rostov was very happy in the love they showed him; but the first
15832. moment of meeting had been so beatific that his present joy seemed
15833. insufficient, and he kept expecting something more, more and yet more.
15834. 
15835. Next morning, after the fatigues of their journey, the travelers slept
15836. till ten o'clock.
15837. 
15838. In the room next their bedroom there was a confusion of sabers,
15839. satchels, sabretaches, open portmanteaus, and dirty boots. Two freshly
15840. cleaned pairs with spurs had just been placed by the wall. The servants
15841. were bringing in jugs and basins, hot water for shaving, and their
15842. well-brushed clothes. There was a masculine odor and a smell of tobacco.
15843. 
15844. "Hallo, Gwiska--my pipe!" came Vasili Denisov's husky voice. "Wostov,
15845. get up!"
15846. 
15847. Rostov, rubbing his eyes that seemed glued together, raised his
15848. disheveled head from the hot pillow.
15849. 
15850. "Why, is it late?"
15851. 
15852. "Late! It's nearly ten o'clock," answered Natasha's voice. A rustle of
15853. starched petticoats and the whispering and laughter of girls' voices
15854. came from the adjoining room. The door was opened a crack and there was
15855. a glimpse of something blue, of ribbons, black hair, and merry faces.
15856. It was Natasha, Sonya, and Petya, who had come to see whether they were
15857. getting up.
15858. 
15859. "Nicholas! Get up!" Natasha's voice was again heard at the door.
15860. 
15861. "Directly!"
15862. 
15863. Meanwhile, Petya, having found and seized the sabers in the outer room,
15864. with the delight boys feel at the sight of a military elder brother, and
15865. forgetting that it was unbecoming for the girls to see men undressed,
15866. opened the bedroom door.
15867. 
15868. "Is this your saber?" he shouted.
15869. 
15870. The girls sprang aside. Denisov hid his hairy legs under the blanket,
15871. looking with a scared face at his comrade for help. The door, having let
15872. Petya in, closed again. A sound of laughter came from behind it.
15873. 
15874. "Nicholas! Come out in your dressing gown!" said Natasha's voice.
15875. 
15876. "Is this your saber?" asked Petya. "Or is it yours?" he said, addressing
15877. the black-mustached Denisov with servile deference.
15878. 
15879. Rostov hurriedly put something on his feet, drew on his dressing gown,
15880. and went out. Natasha had put on one spurred boot and was just getting
15881. her foot into the other. Sonya, when he came in, was twirling round and
15882. was about to expand her dresses into a balloon and sit down. They were
15883. dressed alike, in new pale-blue frocks, and were both fresh, rosy, and
15884. bright. Sonya ran away, but Natasha, taking her brother's arm, led him
15885. into the sitting room, where they began talking. They hardly gave one
15886. another time to ask questions and give replies concerning a thousand
15887. little matters which could not interest anyone but themselves. Natasha
15888. laughed at every word he said or that she said herself, not because what
15889. they were saying was amusing, but because she felt happy and was unable
15890. to control her joy which expressed itself by laughter.
15891. 
15892. "Oh, how nice, how splendid!" she said to everything.
15893. 
15894. Rostov felt that, under the influence of the warm rays of love, that
15895. childlike smile which had not once appeared on his face since he left
15896. home now for the first time after eighteen months again brightened his
15897. soul and his face.
15898. 
15899. "No, but listen," she said, "now you are quite a man, aren't you? I'm
15900. awfully glad you're my brother." She touched his mustache. "I want to
15901. know what you men are like. Are you the same as we? No?"
15902. 
15903. "Why did Sonya run away?" asked Rostov.
15904. 
15905. "Ah, yes! That's a whole long story! How are you going to speak to
15906. her--thou or you?"
15907. 
15908. "As may happen," said Rostov.
15909. 
15910. "No, call her you, please! I'll tell you all about it some other time.
15911. No, I'll tell you now. You know Sonya's my dearest friend. Such a friend
15912. that I burned my arm for her sake. Look here!"
15913. 
15914. She pulled up her muslin sleeve and showed him a red scar on her long,
15915. slender, delicate arm, high above the elbow on that part that is covered
15916. even by a ball dress.
15917. 
15918. "I burned this to prove my love for her. I just heated a ruler in the
15919. fire and pressed it there!"
15920. 
15921. Sitting on the sofa with the little cushions on its arms, in what used
15922. to be his old schoolroom, and looking into Natasha's wildly bright eyes,
15923. Rostov re-entered that world of home and childhood which had no meaning
15924. for anyone else, but gave him some of the best joys of his life; and the
15925. burning of an arm with a ruler as a proof of love did not seem to him
15926. senseless, he understood and was not surprised at it.
15927. 
15928. "Well, and is that all?" he asked.
15929. 
15930. "We are such friends, such friends! All that ruler business was just
15931. nonsense, but we are friends forever. She, if she loves anyone, does it
15932. for life, but I don't understand that, I forget quickly."
15933. 
15934. "Well, what then?"
15935. 
15936. "Well, she loves me and you like that."
15937. 
15938. Natasha suddenly flushed.
15939. 
15940. "Why, you remember before you went away?... Well, she says you are to
15941. forget all that.... She says: 'I shall love him always, but let him be
15942. free.' Isn't that lovely and noble! Yes, very noble? Isn't it?" asked
15943. Natasha, so seriously and excitedly that it was evident that what she
15944. was now saying she had talked of before, with tears.
15945. 
15946. Rostov became thoughtful.
15947. 
15948. "I never go back on my word," he said. "Besides, Sonya is so charming
15949. that only a fool would renounce such happiness."
15950. 
15951. "No, no!" cried Natasha, "she and I have already talked it over. We knew
15952. you'd say so. But it won't do, because you see, if you say that--if you
15953. consider yourself bound by your promise--it will seem as if she had not
15954. meant it seriously. It makes it as if you were marrying her because you
15955. must, and that wouldn't do at all."
15956. 
15957. Rostov saw that it had been well considered by them. Sonya had already
15958. struck him by her beauty on the preceding day. Today, when he had caught
15959. a glimpse of her, she seemed still more lovely. She was a charming girl
15960. of sixteen, evidently passionately in love with him (he did not doubt
15961. that for an instant). Why should he not love her now, and even marry
15962. her, Rostov thought, but just now there were so many other pleasures
15963. and interests before him! "Yes, they have taken a wise decision," he
15964. thought, "I must remain free."
15965. 
15966. "Well then, that's excellent," said he. "We'll talk it over later on.
15967. Oh, how glad I am to have you!"
15968. 
15969. "Well, and are you still true to Boris?" he continued.
15970. 
15971. "Oh, what nonsense!" cried Natasha, laughing. "I don't think about him
15972. or anyone else, and I don't want anything of the kind."
15973. 
15974. "Dear me! Then what are you up to now?"
15975. 
15976. "Now?" repeated Natasha, and a happy smile lit up her face. "Have you
15977. seen Duport?"
15978. 
15979. "No."
15980. 
15981. "Not seen Duport--the famous dancer? Well then, you won't understand.
15982. That's what I'm up to."
15983. 
15984. Curving her arms, Natasha held out her skirts as dancers do, ran back
15985. a few steps, turned, cut a caper, brought her little feet sharply
15986. together, and made some steps on the very tips of her toes.
15987. 
15988. "See, I'm standing! See!" she said, but could not maintain herself on
15989. her toes any longer. "So that's what I'm up to! I'll never marry anyone,
15990. but will be a dancer. Only don't tell anyone."
15991. 
15992. Rostov laughed so loud and merrily that Denisov, in his bedroom, felt
15993. envious and Natasha could not help joining in.
15994. 
15995. "No, but don't you think it's nice?" she kept repeating.
15996. 
15997. "Nice! And so you no longer wish to marry Boris?"
15998. 
15999. Natasha flared up. "I don't want to marry anyone. And I'll tell him so
16000. when I see him!"
16001. 
16002. "Dear me!" said Rostov.
16003. 
16004. "But that's all rubbish," Natasha chattered on. "And is Denisov nice?"
16005. she asked.
16006. 
16007. "Yes, indeed!"
16008. 
16009. "Oh, well then, good-by: go and dress. Is he very terrible, Denisov?"
16010. 
16011. "Why terrible?" asked Nicholas. "No, Vaska is a splendid fellow."
16012. 
16013. "You call him Vaska? That's funny! And is he very nice?"
16014. 
16015. "Very."
16016. 
16017. "Well then, be quick. We'll all have breakfast together."
16018. 
16019. And Natasha rose and went out of the room on tiptoe, like a ballet
16020. dancer, but smiling as only happy girls of fifteen can smile. When
16021. Rostov met Sonya in the drawing room, he reddened. He did not know how
16022. to behave with her. The evening before, in the first happy moment of
16023. meeting, they had kissed each other, but today they felt it could not
16024. be done; he felt that everybody, including his mother and sisters, was
16025. looking inquiringly at him and watching to see how he would behave with
16026. her. He kissed her hand and addressed her not as thou but as you--Sonya.
16027. But their eyes met and said thou, and exchanged tender kisses. Her looks
16028. asked him to forgive her for having dared, by Natasha's intermediacy, to
16029. remind him of his promise, and then thanked him for his love. His looks
16030. thanked her for offering him his freedom and told her that one way or
16031. another he would never cease to love her, for that would be impossible.
16032. 
16033. "How strange it is," said Vera, selecting a moment when all were silent,
16034. "that Sonya and Nicholas now say you to one another and meet like
16035. strangers."
16036. 
16037. Vera's remark was correct, as her remarks always were, but, like most of
16038. her observations, it made everyone feel uncomfortable, not only Sonya,
16039. Nicholas, and Natasha, but even the old countess, who--dreading
16040. this love affair which might hinder Nicholas from making a brilliant
16041. match--blushed like a girl.
16042. 
16043. Denisov, to Rostov's surprise, appeared in the drawing room with pomaded
16044. hair, perfumed, and in a new uniform, looking just as smart as he made
16045. himself when going into battle, and he was more amiable to the ladies
16046. and gentlemen than Rostov had ever expected to see him.
16047. 
16048. 
16049. 
16050. 
16051. 
16052. CHAPTER II
16053. 
16054. 
16055. On his return to Moscow from the army, Nicholas Rostov was welcomed
16056. by his home circle as the best of sons, a hero, and their darling
16057. Nikolenka; by his relations as a charming, attractive, and polite young
16058. man; by his acquaintances as a handsome lieutenant of hussars, a good
16059. dancer, and one of the best matches in the city.
16060. 
16061. The Rostovs knew everybody in Moscow. The old count had money enough
16062. that year, as all his estates had been remortgaged, and so Nicholas,
16063. acquiring a trotter of his own, very stylish riding breeches of the
16064. latest cut, such as no one else yet had in Moscow, and boots of the
16065. latest fashion, with extremely pointed toes and small silver spurs,
16066. passed his time very gaily. After a short period of adapting himself
16067. to the old conditions of life, Nicholas found it very pleasant to be
16068. at home again. He felt that he had grown up and matured very much. His
16069. despair at failing in a Scripture examination, his borrowing money from
16070. Gavril to pay a sleigh driver, his kissing Sonya on the sly--he now
16071. recalled all this as childishness he had left immeasurably behind.
16072. Now he was a lieutenant of hussars, in a jacket laced with silver, and
16073. wearing the Cross of St. George, awarded to soldiers for bravery in
16074. action, and in the company of well-known, elderly, and respected racing
16075. men was training a trotter of his own for a race. He knew a lady on one
16076. of the boulevards whom he visited of an evening. He led the mazurka at
16077. the Arkharovs' ball, talked about the war with Field Marshal Kamenski,
16078. visited the English Club, and was on intimate terms with a colonel of
16079. forty to whom Denisov had introduced him.
16080. 
16081. His passion for the Emperor had cooled somewhat in Moscow. But still, as
16082. he did not see him and had no opportunity of seeing him, he often spoke
16083. about him and about his love for him, letting it be understood that he
16084. had not told all and that there was something in his feelings for the
16085. Emperor not everyone could understand, and with his whole soul he shared
16086. the adoration then common in Moscow for the Emperor, who was spoken of
16087. as the "angel incarnate."
16088. 
16089. During Rostov's short stay in Moscow, before rejoining the army, he did
16090. not draw closer to Sonya, but rather drifted away from her. She was very
16091. pretty and sweet, and evidently deeply in love with him, but he was at
16092. the period of youth when there seems so much to do that there is no time
16093. for that sort of thing and a young man fears to bind himself and prizes
16094. his freedom which he needs for so many other things. When he thought of
16095. Sonya, during this stay in Moscow, he said to himself, "Ah, there will
16096. be, and there are, many more such girls somewhere whom I do not yet
16097. know. There will be time enough to think about love when I want to, but
16098. now I have no time." Besides, it seemed to him that the society of women
16099. was rather derogatory to his manhood. He went to balls and into ladies'
16100. society with an affectation of doing so against his will. The races, the
16101. English Club, sprees with Denisov, and visits to a certain house--that
16102. was another matter and quite the thing for a dashing young hussar!
16103. 
16104. At the beginning of March, old Count Ilya Rostov was very busy arranging
16105. a dinner in honor of Prince Bagration at the English Club.
16106. 
16107. The count walked up and down the hall in his dressing gown, giving
16108. orders to the club steward and to the famous Feoktist, the Club's head
16109. cook, about asparagus, fresh cucumbers, strawberries, veal, and fish
16110. for this dinner. The count had been a member and on the committee of
16111. the Club from the day it was founded. To him the Club entrusted the
16112. arrangement of the festival in honor of Bagration, for few men knew so
16113. well how to arrange a feast on an open-handed, hospitable scale, and
16114. still fewer men would be so well able and willing to make up out of
16115. their own resources what might be needed for the success of the fete.
16116. The club cook and the steward listened to the count's orders with
16117. pleased faces, for they knew that under no other management could they
16118. so easily extract a good profit for themselves from a dinner costing
16119. several thousand rubles.
16120. 
16121. "Well then, mind and have cocks' comb in the turtle soup, you know!"
16122. 
16123. "Shall we have three cold dishes then?" asked the cook.
16124. 
16125. The count considered.
16126. 
16127. "We can't have less--yes, three... the mayonnaise, that's one," said he,
16128. bending down a finger.
16129. 
16130. "Then am I to order those large sterlets?" asked the steward.
16131. 
16132. "Yes, it can't be helped if they won't take less. Ah, dear me! I was
16133. forgetting. We must have another entree. Ah, goodness gracious!" he
16134. clutched at his head. "Who is going to get me the flowers? Dmitri! Eh,
16135. Dmitri! Gallop off to our Moscow estate," he said to the factotum who
16136. appeared at his call. "Hurry off and tell Maksim, the gardener, to set
16137. the serfs to work. Say that everything out of the hothouses must be
16138. brought here well wrapped up in felt. I must have two hundred pots here
16139. on Friday."
16140. 
16141. Having given several more orders, he was about to go to his "little
16142. countess" to have a rest, but remembering something else of importance,
16143. he returned again, called back the cook and the club steward, and again
16144. began giving orders. A light footstep and the clinking of spurs were
16145. heard at the door, and the young count, handsome, rosy, with a dark
16146. little mustache, evidently rested and made sleeker by his easy life in
16147. Moscow, entered the room.
16148. 
16149. "Ah, my boy, my head's in a whirl!" said the old man with a smile, as if
16150. he felt a little confused before his son. "Now, if you would only help
16151. a bit! I must have singers too. I shall have my own orchestra, but
16152. shouldn't we get the gypsy singers as well? You military men like that
16153. sort of thing."
16154. 
16155. "Really, Papa, I believe Prince Bagration worried himself less before
16156. the battle of Schon Grabern than you do now," said his son with a smile.
16157. 
16158. The old count pretended to be angry.
16159. 
16160. "Yes, you talk, but try it yourself!"
16161. 
16162. And the count turned to the cook, who, with a shrewd and respectful
16163. expression, looked observantly and sympathetically at the father and
16164. son.
16165. 
16166. "What have the young people come to nowadays, eh, Feoktist?" said he.
16167. "Laughing at us old fellows!"
16168. 
16169. "That's so, your excellency, all they have to do is to eat a good
16170. dinner, but providing it and serving it all up, that's not their
16171. business!"
16172. 
16173. "That's it, that's it!" exclaimed the count, and gaily seizing his son
16174. by both hands, he cried, "Now I've got you, so take the sleigh and pair
16175. at once, and go to Bezukhov's, and tell him 'Count Ilya has sent you
16176. to ask for strawberries and fresh pineapples.' We can't get them from
16177. anyone else. He's not there himself, so you'll have to go in and ask the
16178. princesses; and from there go on to the Rasgulyay--the coachman Ipatka
16179. knows--and look up the gypsy Ilyushka, the one who danced at Count
16180. Orlov's, you remember, in a white Cossack coat, and bring him along to
16181. me."
16182. 
16183. "And am I to bring the gypsy girls along with him?" asked Nicholas,
16184. laughing. "Dear, dear!..."
16185. 
16186. At that moment, with noiseless footsteps and with the businesslike,
16187. preoccupied, yet meekly Christian look which never left her face, Anna
16188. Mikhaylovna entered the hall. Though she came upon the count in his
16189. dressing gown every day, he invariably became confused and begged her to
16190. excuse his costume.
16191. 
16192. "No matter at all, my dear count," she said, meekly closing her eyes.
16193. "But I'll go to Bezukhov's myself. Pierre has arrived, and now we shall
16194. get anything we want from his hothouses. I have to see him in any case.
16195. He has forwarded me a letter from Boris. Thank God, Boris is now on the
16196. staff."
16197. 
16198. The count was delighted at Anna Mikhaylovna's taking upon herself one of
16199. his commissions and ordered the small closed carriage for her.
16200. 
16201. "Tell Bezukhov to come. I'll put his name down. Is his wife with him?"
16202. he asked.
16203. 
16204. Anna Mikhaylovna turned up her eyes, and profound sadness was depicted
16205. on her face.
16206. 
16207. "Ah, my dear friend, he is very unfortunate," she said. "If what we hear
16208. is true, it is dreadful. How little we dreamed of such a thing when we
16209. were rejoicing at his happiness! And such a lofty angelic soul as young
16210. Bezukhov! Yes, I pity him from my heart, and shall try to give him what
16211. consolation I can."
16212. 
16213. "Wh-what is the matter?" asked both the young and old Rostov.
16214. 
16215. Anna Mikhaylovna sighed deeply.
16216. 
16217. "Dolokhov, Mary Ivanovna's son," she said in a mysterious whisper, "has
16218. compromised her completely, they say. Pierre took him up, invited him to
16219. his house in Petersburg, and now... she has come here and that daredevil
16220. after her!" said Anna Mikhaylovna, wishing to show her sympathy for
16221. Pierre, but by involuntary intonations and a half smile betraying her
16222. sympathy for the "daredevil," as she called Dolokhov. "They say Pierre
16223. is quite broken by his misfortune."
16224. 
16225. "Dear, dear! But still tell him to come to the Club--it will all blow
16226. over. It will be a tremendous banquet."
16227. 
16228. Next day, the third of March, soon after one o'clock, two hundred and
16229. fifty members of the English Club and fifty guests were awaiting the
16230. guest of honor and hero of the Austrian campaign, Prince Bagration, to
16231. dinner.
16232. 
16233. On the first arrival of the news of the battle of Austerlitz, Moscow had
16234. been bewildered. At that time, the Russians were so used to victories
16235. that on receiving news of the defeat some would simply not believe it,
16236. while others sought some extraordinary explanation of so strange an
16237. event. In the English Club, where all who were distinguished, important,
16238. and well informed foregathered when the news began to arrive in
16239. December, nothing was said about the war and the last battle, as
16240. though all were in a conspiracy of silence. The men who set the tone in
16241. conversation--Count Rostopchin, Prince Yuri Dolgorukov, Valuev, Count
16242. Markov, and Prince Vyazemski--did not show themselves at the Club, but
16243. met in private houses in intimate circles, and the Moscovites who took
16244. their opinions from others--Ilya Rostov among them--remained for a
16245. while without any definite opinion on the subject of the war and without
16246. leaders. The Moscovites felt that something was wrong and that to
16247. discuss the bad news was difficult, and so it was best to be silent.
16248. But after a while, just as a jury comes out of its room, the bigwigs
16249. who guided the Club's opinion reappeared, and everybody began speaking
16250. clearly and definitely. Reasons were found for the incredible,
16251. unheard-of, and impossible event of a Russian defeat, everything became
16252. clear, and in all corners of Moscow the same things began to be
16253. said. These reasons were the treachery of the Austrians, a defective
16254. commissariat, the treachery of the Pole Przebyszewski and of the
16255. Frenchman Langeron, Kutuzov's incapacity, and (it was whispered) the
16256. youth and inexperience of the sovereign, who had trusted worthless and
16257. insignificant people. But the army, the Russian army, everyone declared,
16258. was extraordinary and had achieved miracles of valor. The soldiers,
16259. officers, and generals were heroes. But the hero of heroes was Prince
16260. Bagration, distinguished by his Schon Grabern affair and by the retreat
16261. from Austerlitz, where he alone had withdrawn his column unbroken and
16262. had all day beaten back an enemy force twice as numerous as his own.
16263. What also conduced to Bagration's being selected as Moscow's hero was
16264. the fact that he had no connections in the city and was a stranger
16265. there. In his person, honor was shown to a simple fighting Russian
16266. soldier without connections and intrigues, and to one who was associated
16267. by memories of the Italian campaign with the name of Suvorov.
16268. Moreover, paying such honor to Bagration was the best way of expressing
16269. disapproval and dislike of Kutuzov.
16270. 
16271. "Had there been no Bagration, it would have been necessary to invent
16272. him," said the wit Shinshin, parodying the words of Voltaire. Kutuzov
16273. no one spoke of, except some who abused him in whispers, calling him a
16274. court weathercock and an old satyr.
16275. 
16276. All Moscow repeated Prince Dolgorukov's saying: "If you go on modeling
16277. and modeling you must get smeared with clay," suggesting consolation
16278. for our defeat by the memory of former victories; and the words of
16279. Rostopchin, that French soldiers have to be incited to battle by
16280. highfalutin words, and Germans by logical arguments to show them that it
16281. is more dangerous to run away than to advance, but that Russian soldiers
16282. only need to be restrained and held back! On all sides, new and fresh
16283. anecdotes were heard of individual examples of heroism shown by our
16284. officers and men at Austerlitz. One had saved a standard, another had
16285. killed five Frenchmen, a third had loaded five cannon singlehanded. Berg
16286. was mentioned, by those who did not know him, as having, when wounded
16287. in the right hand, taken his sword in the left, and gone forward. Of
16288. Bolkonski, nothing was said, and only those who knew him intimately
16289. regretted that he had died so young, leaving a pregnant wife with his
16290. eccentric father.
16291. 
16292. 
16293. 
16294. 
16295. 
16296. CHAPTER III
16297. 
16298. 
16299. On that third of March, all the rooms in the English Club were filled
16300. with a hum of conversation, like the hum of bees swarming in springtime.
16301. The members and guests of the Club wandered hither and thither, sat,
16302. stood, met, and separated, some in uniform and some in evening dress,
16303. and a few here and there with powdered hair and in Russian kaftans.
16304. Powdered footmen, in livery with buckled shoes and smart stockings,
16305. stood at every door anxiously noting visitors' every movement in order
16306. to offer their services. Most of those present were elderly, respected
16307. men with broad, self-confident faces, fat fingers, and resolute gestures
16308. and voices. This class of guests and members sat in certain habitual
16309. places and met in certain habitual groups. A minority of those present
16310. were casual guests--chiefly young men, among whom were Denisov, Rostov,
16311. and Dolokhov--who was now again an officer in the Semenov regiment. The
16312. faces of these young people, especially those who were military men,
16313. bore that expression of condescending respect for their elders which
16314. seems to say to the older generation, "We are prepared to respect and
16315. honor you, but all the same remember that the future belongs to us."
16316. 
16317. Nesvitski was there as an old member of the Club. Pierre, who at his
16318. wife's command had let his hair grow and abandoned his spectacles, went
16319. about the rooms fashionably dressed but looking sad and dull. Here, as
16320. elsewhere, he was surrounded by an atmosphere of subservience to his
16321. wealth, and being in the habit of lording it over these people, he
16322. treated them with absent-minded contempt.
16323. 
16324. By his age he should have belonged to the younger men, but by his wealth
16325. and connections he belonged to the groups old and honored guests, and
16326. so he went from one group to another. Some of the most important old men
16327. were the center of groups which even strangers approached respectfully
16328. to hear the voices of well-known men. The largest circles formed round
16329. Count Rostopchin, Valuev, and Naryshkin. Rostopchin was describing how
16330. the Russians had been overwhelmed by flying Austrians and had had to
16331. force their way through them with bayonets.
16332. 
16333. Valuev was confidentially telling that Uvarov had been sent from
16334. Petersburg to ascertain what Moscow was thinking about Austerlitz.
16335. 
16336. In the third circle, Naryshkin was speaking of the meeting of the
16337. Austrian Council of War at which Suvorov crowed like a cock in reply to
16338. the nonsense talked by the Austrian generals. Shinshin, standing close
16339. by, tried to make a joke, saying that Kutuzov had evidently failed to
16340. learn from Suvorov even so simple a thing as the art of crowing like a
16341. cock, but the elder members glanced severely at the wit, making him
16342. feel that in that place and on that day, it was improper to speak so of
16343. Kutuzov.
16344. 
16345. Count Ilya Rostov, hurried and preoccupied, went about in his soft boots
16346. between the dining and drawing rooms, hastily greeting the important and
16347. unimportant, all of whom he knew, as if they were all equals, while his
16348. eyes occasionally sought out his fine well-set-up young son, resting
16349. on him and winking joyfully at him. Young Rostov stood at a window with
16350. Dolokhov, whose acquaintance he had lately made and highly valued. The
16351. old count came up to them and pressed Dolokhov's hand.
16352. 
16353. "Please come and visit us... you know my brave boy... been together out
16354. there... both playing the hero... Ah, Vasili Ignatovich... How d'ye do,
16355. old fellow?" he said, turning to an old man who was passing, but before
16356. he had finished his greeting there was a general stir, and a footman who
16357. had run in announced, with a frightened face: "He's arrived!"
16358. 
16359. Bells rang, the stewards rushed forward, and--like rye shaken together
16360. in a shovel--the guests who had been scattered about in different rooms
16361. came together and crowded in the large drawing room by the door of the
16362. ballroom.
16363. 
16364. Bagration appeared in the doorway of the anteroom without hat or sword,
16365. which, in accord with the Club custom, he had given up to the hall
16366. porter. He had no lambskin cap on his head, nor had he a loaded whip
16367. over his shoulder, as when Rostov had seen him on the eve of the battle
16368. of Austerlitz, but wore a tight new uniform with Russian and foreign
16369. Orders, and the Star of St. George on his left breast. Evidently just
16370. before coming to the dinner he had had his hair and whiskers trimmed,
16371. which changed his appearance for the worse. There was something naively
16372. festive in his air, which, in conjunction with his firm and virile
16373. features, gave him a rather comical expression. Bekleshev and Theodore
16374. Uvarov, who had arrived with him, paused at the doorway to allow him,
16375. as the guest of honor, to enter first. Bagration was embarrassed, not
16376. wishing to avail himself of their courtesy, and this caused some delay
16377. at the doors, but after all he did at last enter first. He walked shyly
16378. and awkwardly over the parquet floor of the reception room, not knowing
16379. what to do with his hands; he was more accustomed to walk over a plowed
16380. field under fire, as he had done at the head of the Kursk regiment at
16381. Schon Grabern--and he would have found that easier. The committeemen
16382. met him at the first door and, expressing their delight at seeing such a
16383. highly honored guest, took possession of him as it were, without waiting
16384. for his reply, surrounded him, and led him to the drawing room. It was
16385. at first impossible to enter the drawing-room door for the crowd of
16386. members and guests jostling one another and trying to get a good look at
16387. Bagration over each other's shoulders, as if he were some rare animal.
16388. Count Ilya Rostov, laughing and repeating the words, "Make way, dear
16389. boy! Make way, make way!" pushed through the crowd more energetically
16390. than anyone, led the guests into the drawing room, and seated them on
16391. the center sofa. The bigwigs, the most respected members of the Club,
16392. beset the new arrivals. Count Ilya, again thrusting his way through the
16393. crowd, went out of the drawing room and reappeared a minute later with
16394. another committeeman, carrying a large silver salver which he presented
16395. to Prince Bagration. On the salver lay some verses composed and printed
16396. in the hero's honor. Bagration, on seeing the salver, glanced around
16397. in dismay, as though seeking help. But all eyes demanded that he should
16398. submit. Feeling himself in their power, he resolutely took the salver
16399. with both hands and looked sternly and reproachfully at the count who
16400. had presented it to him. Someone obligingly took the dish from Bagration
16401. (or he would, it seemed, have held it till evening and have gone in to
16402. dinner with it) and drew his attention to the verses.
16403. 
16404. "Well, I will read them, then!" Bagration seemed to say, and, fixing
16405. his weary eyes on the paper, began to read them with a fixed and serious
16406. expression. But the author himself took the verses and began reading
16407. them aloud. Bagration bowed his head and listened:
16408. 
16409.    Bring glory then to Alexander's reign
16410.    And on the throne our Titus shield.
16411.    A dreaded foe be thou, kindhearted as a man,
16412.    A Rhipheus at home, a Caesar in the field!
16413.    E'en fortunate Napoleon
16414.    Knows by experience, now, Bagration,
16415.    And dare not Herculean Russians trouble...
16416. 
16417. But before he had finished reading, a stentorian major-domo announced
16418. that dinner was ready! The door opened, and from the dining room came
16419. the resounding strains of the polonaise:
16420. 
16421.    Conquest's joyful thunder waken,
16422.    Triumph, valiant Russians, now!...
16423. 
16424. and Count Rostov, glancing angrily at the author who went on reading his
16425. verses, bowed to Bagration. Everyone rose, feeling that dinner was more
16426. important than verses, and Bagration, again preceding all the rest,
16427. went in to dinner. He was seated in the place of honor between two
16428. Alexanders--Bekleshev and Naryshkin--which was a significant allusion to
16429. the name of the sovereign. Three hundred persons took their seats in the
16430. dining room, according to their rank and importance: the more important
16431. nearer to the honored guest, as naturally as water flows deepest where
16432. the land lies lowest.
16433. 
16434. Just before dinner, Count Ilya Rostov presented his son to Bagration,
16435. who recognized him and said a few words to him, disjointed and awkward,
16436. as were all the words he spoke that day, and Count Ilya looked joyfully
16437. and proudly around while Bagration spoke to his son.
16438. 
16439. Nicholas Rostov, with Denisov and his new acquaintance, Dolokhov, sat
16440. almost at the middle of the table. Facing them sat Pierre, beside Prince
16441. Nesvitski. Count Ilya Rostov with the other members of the committee sat
16442. facing Bagration and, as the very personification of Moscow hospitality,
16443. did the honors to the prince.
16444. 
16445. His efforts had not been in vain. The dinner, both the Lenten and the
16446. other fare, was splendid, yet he could not feel quite at ease till the
16447. end of the meal. He winked at the butler, whispered directions to the
16448. footmen, and awaited each expected dish with some anxiety. Everything
16449. was excellent. With the second course, a gigantic sterlet (at sight of
16450. which Ilya Rostov blushed with self-conscious pleasure), the footmen
16451. began popping corks and filling the champagne glasses. After the fish,
16452. which made a certain sensation, the count exchanged glances with the
16453. other committeemen. "There will be many toasts, it's time to begin," he
16454. whispered, and taking up his glass, he rose. All were silent, waiting
16455. for what he would say.
16456. 
16457. "To the health of our Sovereign, the Emperor!" he cried, and at the same
16458. moment his kindly eyes grew moist with tears of joy and enthusiasm. The
16459. band immediately struck up "Conquest's joyful thunder waken..." All rose
16460. and cried "Hurrah!" Bagration also rose and shouted "Hurrah!" in exactly
16461. the same voice in which he had shouted it on the field at Schon Grabern.
16462. Young Rostov's ecstatic voice could be heard above the three hundred
16463. others. He nearly wept. "To the health of our Sovereign, the Emperor!"
16464. he roared, "Hurrah!" and emptying his glass at one gulp he dashed it to
16465. the floor. Many followed his example, and the loud shouting continued
16466. for a long time. When the voices subsided, the footmen cleared away the
16467. broken glass and everybody sat down again, smiling at the noise they had
16468. made and exchanging remarks. The old count rose once more, glanced at a
16469. note lying beside his plate, and proposed a toast, "To the health of the
16470. hero of our last campaign, Prince Peter Ivanovich Bagration!" and again
16471. his blue eyes grew moist. "Hurrah!" cried the three hundred voices
16472. again, but instead of the band a choir began singing a cantata composed
16473. by Paul Ivanovich Kutuzov:
16474. 
16475.    Russians! O'er all barriers on!
16476.    Courage conquest guarantees;
16477.    Have we not Bagration?
16478.    He brings foe men to their knees,... etc.
16479. 
16480. 
16481. As soon as the singing was over, another and another toast was proposed
16482. and Count Ilya Rostov became more and more moved, more glass was
16483. smashed, and the shouting grew louder. They drank to Bekleshev,
16484. Naryshkin, Uvarov, Dolgorukov, Apraksin, Valuev, to the committee, to
16485. all the Club members and to all the Club guests, and finally to Count
16486. Ilya Rostov separately, as the organizer of the banquet. At that
16487. toast, the count took out his handkerchief and, covering his face, wept
16488. outright.
16489. 
16490. 
16491. 
16492. 
16493. 
16494. CHAPTER IV
16495. 
16496. 
16497. Pierre sat opposite Dolokhov and Nicholas Rostov. As usual, he ate and
16498. drank much, and eagerly. But those who knew him intimately noticed that
16499. some great change had come over him that day. He was silent all through
16500. dinner and looked about, blinking and scowling, or, with fixed eyes and
16501. a look of complete absent-mindedness, kept rubbing the bridge of his
16502. nose. His face was depressed and gloomy. He seemed to see and hear
16503. nothing of what was going on around him and to be absorbed by some
16504. depressing and unsolved problem.
16505. 
16506. The unsolved problem that tormented him was caused by hints given by the
16507. princess, his cousin, at Moscow, concerning Dolokhov's intimacy with his
16508. wife, and by an anonymous letter he had received that morning, which in
16509. the mean jocular way common to anonymous letters said that he saw badly
16510. through his spectacles, but that his wife's connection with Dolokhov was
16511. a secret to no one but himself. Pierre absolutely disbelieved both the
16512. princess' hints and the letter, but he feared now to look at Dolokhov,
16513. who was sitting opposite him. Every time he chanced to meet Dolokhov's
16514. handsome insolent eyes, Pierre felt something terrible and monstrous
16515. rising in his soul and turned quickly away. Involuntarily recalling his
16516. wife's past and her relations with Dolokhov, Pierre saw clearly that
16517. what was said in the letter might be true, or might at least seem to be
16518. true had it not referred to his wife. He involuntarily remembered
16519. how Dolokhov, who had fully recovered his former position after the
16520. campaign, had returned to Petersburg and come to him. Availing himself
16521. of his friendly relations with Pierre as a boon companion, Dolokhov
16522. had come straight to his house, and Pierre had put him up and lent him
16523. money. Pierre recalled how Helene had smilingly expressed disapproval of
16524. Dolokhov's living at their house, and how cynically Dolokhov had praised
16525. his wife's beauty to him and from that time till they came to Moscow had
16526. not left them for a day.
16527. 
16528. "Yes, he is very handsome," thought Pierre, "and I know him. It would be
16529. particularly pleasant to him to dishonor my name and ridicule me, just
16530. because I have exerted myself on his behalf, befriended him, and helped
16531. him. I know and understand what a spice that would add to the pleasure
16532. of deceiving me, if it really were true. Yes, if it were true, but I
16533. do not believe it. I have no right to, and can't, believe it." He
16534. remembered the expression Dolokhov's face assumed in his moments of
16535. cruelty, as when tying the policeman to the bear and dropping them into
16536. the water, or when he challenged a man to a duel without any reason,
16537. or shot a post-boy's horse with a pistol. That expression was often
16538. on Dolokhov's face when looking at him. "Yes, he is a bully," thought
16539. Pierre, "to kill a man means nothing to him. It must seem to him that
16540. everyone is afraid of him, and that must please him. He must think that
16541. I, too, am afraid of him--and in fact I am afraid of him," he thought,
16542. and again he felt something terrible and monstrous rising in his soul.
16543. Dolokhov, Denisov, and Rostov were now sitting opposite Pierre and
16544. seemed very gay. Rostov was talking merrily to his two friends, one of
16545. whom was a dashing hussar and the other a notorious duelist and
16546. rake, and every now and then he glanced ironically at Pierre, whose
16547. preoccupied, absent-minded, and massive figure was a very noticeable one
16548. at the dinner. Rostov looked inimically at Pierre, first because Pierre
16549. appeared to his hussar eyes as a rich civilian, the husband of a
16550. beauty, and in a word--an old woman; and secondly because Pierre in his
16551. preoccupation and absent-mindedness had not recognized Rostov and had
16552. not responded to his greeting. When the Emperor's health was drunk,
16553. Pierre, lost in thought, did not rise or lift his glass.
16554. 
16555. "What are you about?" shouted Rostov, looking at him in an ecstasy of
16556. exasperation. "Don't you hear it's His Majesty the Emperor's health?"
16557. 
16558. Pierre sighed, rose submissively, emptied his glass, and, waiting till
16559. all were seated again, turned with his kindly smile to Rostov.
16560. 
16561. "Why, I didn't recognize you!" he said. But Rostov was otherwise
16562. engaged; he was shouting "Hurrah!"
16563. 
16564. "Why don't you renew the acquaintance?" said Dolokhov to Rostov.
16565. 
16566. "Confound him, he's a fool!" said Rostov.
16567. 
16568. "One should make up to the husbands of pretty women," said Denisov.
16569. 
16570. Pierre did not catch what they were saying, but knew they were talking
16571. about him. He reddened and turned away.
16572. 
16573. "Well, now to the health of handsome women!" said Dolokhov, and with
16574. a serious expression, but with a smile lurking at the corners of his
16575. mouth, he turned with his glass to Pierre.
16576. 
16577. "Here's to the health of lovely women, Peterkin--and their lovers!" he
16578. added.
16579. 
16580. Pierre, with downcast eyes, drank out of his glass without looking at
16581. Dolokhov or answering him. The footman, who was distributing leaflets
16582. with Kutuzov's cantata, laid one before Pierre as one of the principal
16583. guests. He was just going to take it when Dolokhov, leaning across,
16584. snatched it from his hand and began reading it. Pierre looked at
16585. Dolokhov and his eyes dropped, the something terrible and monstrous that
16586. had tormented him all dinnertime rose and took possession of him. He
16587. leaned his whole massive body across the table.
16588. 
16589. "How dare you take it?" he shouted.
16590. 
16591. Hearing that cry and seeing to whom it was addressed, Nesvitski and the
16592. neighbor on his right quickly turned in alarm to Bezukhov.
16593. 
16594. "Don't! Don't! What are you about?" whispered their frightened voices.
16595. 
16596. Dolokhov looked at Pierre with clear, mirthful, cruel eyes, and that
16597. smile of his which seemed to say, "Ah! This is what I like!"
16598. 
16599. "You shan't have it!" he said distinctly.
16600. 
16601. Pale, with quivering lips, Pierre snatched the copy.
16602. 
16603. "You...! you... scoundrel! I challenge you!" he ejaculated, and, pushing
16604. back his chair, he rose from the table.
16605. 
16606. At the very instant he did this and uttered those words, Pierre felt
16607. that the question of his wife's guilt which had been tormenting him the
16608. whole day was finally and indubitably answered in the affirmative. He
16609. hated her and was forever sundered from her. Despite Denisov's request
16610. that he would take no part in the matter, Rostov agreed to be Dolokhov's
16611. second, and after dinner he discussed the arrangements for the duel with
16612. Nesvitski, Bezukhov's second. Pierre went home, but Rostov with Dolokhov
16613. and Denisov stayed on at the Club till late, listening to the gypsies
16614. and other singers.
16615. 
16616. "Well then, till tomorrow at Sokolniki," said Dolokhov, as he took leave
16617. of Rostov in the Club porch.
16618. 
16619. "And do you feel quite calm?" Rostov asked.
16620. 
16621. Dolokhov paused.
16622. 
16623. "Well, you see, I'll tell you the whole secret of dueling in two
16624. words. If you are going to fight a duel, and you make a will and write
16625. affectionate letters to your parents, and if you think you may be
16626. killed, you are a fool and are lost for certain. But go with the firm
16627. intention of killing your man as quickly and surely as possible, and
16628. then all will be right, as our bear huntsman at Kostroma used to tell
16629. me. 'Everyone fears a bear,' he says, 'but when you see one your fear's
16630. all gone, and your only thought is not to let him get away!' And that's
16631. how it is with me. A demain, mon cher." *
16632. 
16633. 
16634.     * Till tomorrow, my dear fellow.
16635. 
16636. 
16637. Next day, at eight in the morning, Pierre and Nesvitski drove to the
16638. Sokolniki forest and found Dolokhov, Denisov, and Rostov already there.
16639. Pierre had the air of a man preoccupied with considerations which had no
16640. connection with the matter in hand. His haggard face was yellow. He had
16641. evidently not slept that night. He looked about distractedly and screwed
16642. up his eyes as if dazzled by the sun. He was entirely absorbed by two
16643. considerations: his wife's guilt, of which after his sleepless night he
16644. had not the slightest doubt, and the guiltlessness of Dolokhov, who had
16645. no reason to preserve the honor of a man who was nothing to him.... "I
16646. should perhaps have done the same thing in his place," thought Pierre.
16647. "It's even certain that I should have done the same, then why this duel,
16648. this murder? Either I shall kill him, or he will hit me in the head,
16649. or elbow, or knee. Can't I go away from here, run away, bury myself
16650. somewhere?" passed through his mind. But just at moments when such
16651. thoughts occurred to him, he would ask in a particularly calm and
16652. absent-minded way, which inspired the respect of the onlookers, "Will it
16653. be long? Are things ready?"
16654. 
16655. When all was ready, the sabers stuck in the snow to mark the barriers,
16656. and the pistols loaded, Nesvitski went up to Pierre.
16657. 
16658. "I should not be doing my duty, Count," he said in timid tones, "and
16659. should not justify your confidence and the honor you have done me in
16660. choosing me for your second, if at this grave, this very grave, moment I
16661. did not tell you the whole truth. I think there is no sufficient ground
16662. for this affair, or for blood to be shed over it.... You were not right,
16663. not quite in the right, you were impetuous..."
16664. 
16665. "Oh yes, it is horribly stupid," said Pierre.
16666. 
16667. "Then allow me to express your regrets, and I am sure your opponent
16668. will accept them," said Nesvitski (who like the others concerned in the
16669. affair, and like everyone in similar cases, did not yet believe that the
16670. affair had come to an actual duel). "You know, Count, it is much more
16671. honorable to admit one's mistake than to let matters become irreparable.
16672. There was no insult on either side. Allow me to convey...."
16673. 
16674. "No! What is there to talk about?" said Pierre. "It's all the same....
16675. Is everything ready?" he added. "Only tell me where to go and where to
16676. shoot," he said with an unnaturally gentle smile.
16677. 
16678. He took the pistol in his hand and began asking about the working of the
16679. trigger, as he had not before held a pistol in his hand--a fact that he
16680. did not wish to confess.
16681. 
16682. "Oh yes, like that, I know, I only forgot," said he.
16683. 
16684. "No apologies, none whatever," said Dolokhov to Denisov (who on his
16685. side had been attempting a reconciliation), and he also went up to the
16686. appointed place.
16687. 
16688. The spot chosen for the duel was some eighty paces from the road,
16689. where the sleighs had been left, in a small clearing in the pine forest
16690. covered with melting snow, the frost having begun to break up during the
16691. last few days. The antagonists stood forty paces apart at the farther
16692. edge of the clearing. The seconds, measuring the paces, left tracks in
16693. the deep wet snow between the place where they had been standing and
16694. Nesvitski's and Dolokhov's sabers, which were stuck into the ground
16695. ten paces apart to mark the barrier. It was thawing and misty; at forty
16696. paces' distance nothing could be seen. For three minutes all had been
16697. ready, but they still delayed and all were silent.
16698. 
16699. 
16700. 
16701. 
16702. 
16703. CHAPTER V
16704. 
16705. 
16706. "Well begin!" said Dolokhov.
16707. 
16708. "All right," said Pierre, still smiling in the same way. A feeling of
16709. dread was in the air. It was evident that the affair so lightly begun
16710. could no longer be averted but was taking its course independently of
16711. men's will.
16712. 
16713. Denisov first went to the barrier and announced: "As the adve'sawies
16714. have wefused a weconciliation, please pwoceed. Take your pistols, and at
16715. the word thwee begin to advance.
16716. 
16717. "O-ne! T-wo! Thwee!" he shouted angrily and stepped aside.
16718. 
16719. The combatants advanced along the trodden tracks, nearer and nearer to
16720. one another, beginning to see one another through the mist. They had the
16721. right to fire when they liked as they approached the barrier. Dolokhov
16722. walked slowly without raising his pistol, looking intently with his
16723. bright, sparkling blue eyes into his antagonist's face. His mouth wore
16724. its usual semblance of a smile.
16725. 
16726. "So I can fire when I like!" said Pierre, and at the word "three," he
16727. went quickly forward, missing the trodden path and stepping into
16728. the deep snow. He held the pistol in his right hand at arm's length,
16729. apparently afraid of shooting himself with it. His left hand he held
16730. carefully back, because he wished to support his right hand with it and
16731. knew he must not do so. Having advanced six paces and strayed off
16732. the track into the snow, Pierre looked down at his feet, then quickly
16733. glanced at Dolokhov and, bending his finger as he had been shown, fired.
16734. Not at all expecting so loud a report, Pierre shuddered at the sound and
16735. then, smiling at his own sensations, stood still. The smoke, rendered
16736. denser by the mist, prevented him from seeing anything for an instant,
16737. but there was no second report as he had expected. He only heard
16738. Dolokhov's hurried steps, and his figure came in view through the smoke.
16739. He was pressing one hand to his left side, while the other clutched
16740. his drooping pistol. His face was pale. Rostov ran toward him and said
16741. something.
16742. 
16743. "No-o-o!" muttered Dolokhov through his teeth, "no, it's not over." And
16744. after stumbling a few staggering steps right up to the saber, he sank
16745. on the snow beside it. His left hand was bloody; he wiped it on his
16746. coat and supported himself with it. His frowning face was pallid and
16747. quivered.
16748. 
16749. "Plea..." began Dolokhov, but could not at first pronounce the word.
16750. 
16751. "Please," he uttered with an effort.
16752. 
16753. Pierre, hardly restraining his sobs, began running toward Dolokhov and
16754. was about to cross the space between the barriers, when Dolokhov cried:
16755. 
16756. "To your barrier!" and Pierre, grasping what was meant, stopped by his
16757. saber. Only ten paces divided them. Dolokhov lowered his head to the
16758. snow, greedily bit at it, again raised his head, adjusted himself, drew
16759. in his legs and sat up, seeking a firm center of gravity. He sucked and
16760. swallowed the cold snow, his lips quivered but his eyes, still smiling,
16761. glittered with effort and exasperation as he mustered his remaining
16762. strength. He raised his pistol and aimed.
16763. 
16764. "Sideways! Cover yourself with your pistol!" ejaculated Nesvitski.
16765. 
16766. "Cover yourself!" even Denisov cried to his adversary.
16767. 
16768. Pierre, with a gentle smile of pity and remorse, his arms and legs
16769. helplessly spread out, stood with his broad chest directly facing
16770. Dolokhov looked sorrowfully at him. Denisov, Rostov, and Nesvitski
16771. closed their eyes. At the same instant they heard a report and
16772. Dolokhov's angry cry.
16773. 
16774. "Missed!" shouted Dolokhov, and he lay helplessly, face downwards on the
16775. snow.
16776. 
16777. Pierre clutched his temples, and turning round went into the forest,
16778. trampling through the deep snow, and muttering incoherent words:
16779. 
16780. "Folly... folly! Death... lies..." he repeated, puckering his face.
16781. 
16782. Nesvitski stopped him and took him home.
16783. 
16784. Rostov and Denisov drove away with the wounded Dolokhov.
16785. 
16786. The latter lay silent in the sleigh with closed eyes and did not answer
16787. a word to the questions addressed to him. But on entering Moscow he
16788. suddenly came to and, lifting his head with an effort, took Rostov, who
16789. was sitting beside him, by the hand. Rostov was struck by the totally
16790. altered and unexpectedly rapturous and tender expression on Dolokhov's
16791. face.
16792. 
16793. "Well? How do you feel?" he asked.
16794. 
16795. "Bad! But it's not that, my friend-" said Dolokhov with a gasping voice.
16796. "Where are we? In Moscow, I know. I don't matter, but I have killed her,
16797. killed... She won't get over it! She won't survive...."
16798. 
16799. "Who?" asked Rostov.
16800. 
16801. "My mother! My mother, my angel, my adored angel mother," and Dolokhov
16802. pressed Rostov's hand and burst into tears.
16803. 
16804. When he had become a little quieter, he explained to Rostov that he was
16805. living with his mother, who, if she saw him dying, would not survive it.
16806. He implored Rostov to go on and prepare her.
16807. 
16808. Rostov went on ahead to do what was asked, and to his great surprise
16809. learned that Dolokhov the brawler, Dolokhov the bully, lived in Moscow
16810. with an old mother and a hunchback sister, and was the most affectionate
16811. of sons and brothers.
16812. 
16813. 
16814. 
16815. 
16816. 
16817. CHAPTER VI
16818. 
16819. 
16820. Pierre had of late rarely seen his wife alone. Both in Petersburg and in
16821. Moscow their house was always full of visitors. The night after the
16822. duel he did not go to his bedroom but, as he often did, remained in his
16823. father's room, that huge room in which Count Bezukhov had died.
16824. 
16825. He lay down on the sofa meaning to fall asleep and forget all that
16826. had happened to him, but could not do so. Such a storm of feelings,
16827. thoughts, and memories suddenly arose within him that he could not fall
16828. asleep, nor even remain in one place, but had to jump up and pace the
16829. room with rapid steps. Now he seemed to see her in the early days of
16830. their marriage, with bare shoulders and a languid, passionate look on
16831. her face, and then immediately he saw beside her Dolokhov's handsome,
16832. insolent, hard, and mocking face as he had seen it at the banquet, and
16833. then that same face pale, quivering, and suffering, as it had been when
16834. he reeled and sank on the snow.
16835. 
16836. "What has happened?" he asked himself. "I have killed her lover, yes,
16837. killed my wife's lover. Yes, that was it! And why? How did I come to do
16838. it?"--"Because you married her," answered an inner voice.
16839. 
16840. "But in what was I to blame?" he asked. "In marrying her without loving
16841. her; in deceiving yourself and her." And he vividly recalled that moment
16842. after supper at Prince Vasili's, when he spoke those words he had found
16843. so difficult to utter: "I love you." "It all comes from that! Even then
16844. I felt it," he thought. "I felt then that it was not so, that I had no
16845. right to do it. And so it turns out."
16846. 
16847. He remembered his honeymoon and blushed at the recollection.
16848. Particularly vivid, humiliating, and shameful was the recollection of
16849. how one day soon after his marriage he came out of the bedroom into his
16850. study a little before noon in his silk dressing gown and found his head
16851. steward there, who, bowing respectfully, looked into his face and at
16852. his dressing gown and smiled slightly, as if expressing respectful
16853. understanding of his employer's happiness.
16854. 
16855. "But how often I have felt proud of her, proud of her majestic beauty
16856. and social tact," thought he; "been proud of my house, in which she
16857. received all Petersburg, proud of her unapproachability and beauty. So
16858. this is what I was proud of! I then thought that I did not understand
16859. her. How often when considering her character I have told myself that
16860. I was to blame for not understanding her, for not understanding that
16861. constant composure and complacency and lack of all interests or desires,
16862. and the whole secret lies in the terrible truth that she is a depraved
16863. woman. Now I have spoken that terrible word to myself all has become
16864. clear.
16865. 
16866. "Anatole used to come to borrow money from her and used to kiss her
16867. naked shoulders. She did not give him the money, but let herself be
16868. kissed. Her father in jest tried to rouse her jealousy, and she replied
16869. with a calm smile that she was not so stupid as to be jealous: 'Let him
16870. do what he pleases,' she used to say of me. One day I asked her if she
16871. felt any symptoms of pregnancy. She laughed contemptuously and said she
16872. was not a fool to want to have children, and that she was not going to
16873. have any children by me."
16874. 
16875. Then he recalled the coarseness and bluntness of her thoughts and the
16876. vulgarity of the expressions that were natural to her, though she had
16877. been brought up in the most aristocratic circles.
16878. 
16879. "I'm not such a fool.... Just you try it on.... Allez-vous promener," *
16880. she used to say. Often seeing the success she had with young and old men
16881. and women Pierre could not understand why he did not love her.
16882. 
16883. 
16884.     * "You clear out of this."
16885. 
16886. 
16887. "Yes, I never loved her," said he to himself; "I knew she was a depraved
16888. woman," he repeated, "but dared not admit it to myself. And now there's
16889. Dolokhov sitting in the snow with a forced smile and perhaps dying,
16890. while meeting my remorse with some forced bravado!"
16891. 
16892. Pierre was one of those people who, in spite of an appearance of what
16893. is called weak character, do not seek a confidant in their troubles. He
16894. digested his sufferings alone.
16895. 
16896. "It is all, all her fault," he said to himself; "but what of that? Why
16897. did I bind myself to her? Why did I say 'Je vous aime' * to her, which
16898. was a lie, and worse than a lie? I am guilty and must endure... what?
16899. A slur on my name? A misfortune for life? Oh, that's nonsense," he
16900. thought. "The slur on my name and honor--that's all apart from myself."
16901. 
16902. 
16903.     * I love you.
16904. 
16905. 
16906. "Louis XVI was executed because they said he was dishonorable and a
16907. criminal," came into Pierre's head, "and from their point of view they
16908. were right, as were those too who canonized him and died a martyr's
16909. death for his sake. Then Robespierre was beheaded for being a despot.
16910. Who is right and who is wrong? No one! But if you are alive--live:
16911. tomorrow you'll die as I might have died an hour ago. And is it worth
16912. tormenting oneself, when one has only a moment of life in comparison
16913. with eternity?"
16914. 
16915. But at the moment when he imagined himself calmed by such reflections,
16916. she suddenly came into his mind as she was at the moments when he had
16917. most strongly expressed his insincere love for her, and he felt the
16918. blood rush to his heart and had again to get up and move about and break
16919. and tear whatever came to his hand. "Why did I tell her that 'Je vous
16920. aime'?" he kept repeating to himself. And when he had said it for the
16921. tenth time, Molibre's words: "Mais que diable alloit-il faire dans cette
16922. galere?" occurred to him, and he began to laugh at himself.
16923. 
16924. In the night he called his valet and told him to pack up to go to
16925. Petersburg. He could not imagine how he could speak to her now. He
16926. resolved to go away next day and leave a letter informing her of his
16927. intention to part from her forever.
16928. 
16929. Next morning when the valet came into the room with his coffee, Pierre
16930. was lying asleep on the ottoman with an open book in his hand.
16931. 
16932. He woke up and looked round for a while with a startled expression,
16933. unable to realize where he was.
16934. 
16935. "The countess told me to inquire whether your excellency was at home,"
16936. said the valet.
16937. 
16938. But before Pierre could decide what answer he would send, the countess
16939. herself in a white satin dressing gown embroidered with silver and with
16940. simply dressed hair (two immense plaits twice round her lovely head like
16941. a coronet) entered the room, calm and majestic, except that there was
16942. a wrathful wrinkle on her rather prominent marble brow. With her
16943. imperturbable calm she did not begin to speak in front of the valet.
16944. She knew of the duel and had come to speak about it. She waited till the
16945. valet had set down the coffee things and left the room. Pierre looked
16946. at her timidly over his spectacles, and like a hare surrounded by hounds
16947. who lays back her ears and continues to crouch motionless before her
16948. enemies, he tried to continue reading. But feeling this to be senseless
16949. and impossible, he again glanced timidly at her. She did not sit down
16950. but looked at him with a contemptuous smile, waiting for the valet to
16951. go.
16952. 
16953. "Well, what's this now? What have you been up to now, I should like to
16954. know?" she asked sternly.
16955. 
16956. "I? What have I...?" stammered Pierre.
16957. 
16958. "So it seems you're a hero, eh? Come now, what was this duel about? What
16959. is it meant to prove? What? I ask you."
16960. 
16961. Pierre turned over heavily on the ottoman and opened his mouth, but
16962. could not reply.
16963. 
16964. "If you won't answer, I'll tell you..." Helene went on. "You believe
16965. everything you're told. You were told..." Helene laughed, "that Dolokhov
16966. was my lover," she said in French with her coarse plainness of speech,
16967. uttering the word amant as casually as any other word, "and you believed
16968. it! Well, what have you proved? What does this duel prove? That you're
16969. a fool, que vous etes un sot, but everybody knew that. What will be the
16970. result? That I shall be the laughingstock of all Moscow, that everyone
16971. will say that you, drunk and not knowing what you were about, challenged
16972. a man you are jealous of without cause." Helene raised her voice and
16973. became more and more excited, "A man who's a better man than you in
16974. every way..."
16975. 
16976. "Hm... Hm...!" growled Pierre, frowning without looking at her, and not
16977. moving a muscle.
16978. 
16979. "And how could you believe he was my lover? Why? Because I like his
16980. company? If you were cleverer and more agreeable, I should prefer
16981. yours."
16982. 
16983. "Don't speak to me... I beg you," muttered Pierre hoarsely.
16984. 
16985. "Why shouldn't I speak? I can speak as I like, and I tell you plainly
16986. that there are not many wives with husbands such as you who would not
16987. have taken lovers (des amants), but I have not done so," said she.
16988. 
16989. Pierre wished to say something, looked at her with eyes whose strange
16990. expression she did not understand, and lay down again. He was suffering
16991. physically at that moment, there was a weight on his chest and he could
16992. not breathe. He knew that he must do something to put an end to this
16993. suffering, but what he wanted to do was too terrible.
16994. 
16995. "We had better separate," he muttered in a broken voice.
16996. 
16997. "Separate? Very well, but only if you give me a fortune," said Helene.
16998. "Separate! That's a thing to frighten me with!"
16999. 
17000. Pierre leaped up from the sofa and rushed staggering toward her.
17001. 
17002. "I'll kill you!" he shouted, and seizing the marble top of a table
17003. with a strength he had never before felt, he made a step toward her
17004. brandishing the slab.
17005. 
17006. Helene's face became terrible, she shrieked and sprang aside. His
17007. father's nature showed itself in Pierre. He felt the fascination and
17008. delight of frenzy. He flung down the slab, broke it, and swooping down
17009. on her with outstretched hands shouted, "Get out!" in such a terrible
17010. voice that the whole house heard it with horror. God knows what he would
17011. have done at that moment had Helene not fled from the room.
17012. 
17013. 
17014. A week later Pierre gave his wife full power to control all his estates
17015. in Great Russia, which formed the larger part of his property, and left
17016. for Petersburg alone.
17017. 
17018. 
17019. 
17020. 
17021. 
17022. CHAPTER VII
17023. 
17024. 
17025. Two months had elapsed since the news of the battle of Austerlitz and
17026. the loss of Prince Andrew had reached Bald Hills, and in spite of the
17027. letters sent through the embassy and all the searches made, his body had
17028. not been found nor was he on the list of prisoners. What was worst of
17029. all for his relations was the fact that there was still a possibility of
17030. his having been picked up on the battlefield by the people of the
17031. place and that he might now be lying, recovering or dying, alone among
17032. strangers and unable to send news of himself. The gazettes from which
17033. the old prince first heard of the defeat at Austerlitz stated, as usual
17034. very briefly and vaguely, that after brilliant engagements the Russians
17035. had had to retreat and had made their withdrawal in perfect order. The
17036. old prince understood from this official report that our army had been
17037. defeated. A week after the gazette report of the battle of Austerlitz
17038. came a letter from Kutuzov informing the prince of the fate that had
17039. befallen his son.
17040. 
17041. "Your son," wrote Kutuzov, "fell before my eyes, a standard in his hand
17042. and at the head of a regiment--he fell as a hero, worthy of his father
17043. and his fatherland. To the great regret of myself and of the whole army
17044. it is still uncertain whether he is alive or not. I comfort myself and
17045. you with the hope that your son is alive, for otherwise he would have
17046. been mentioned among the officers found on the field of battle, a list
17047. of whom has been sent me under flag of truce."
17048. 
17049. After receiving this news late in the evening, when he was alone in his
17050. study, the old prince went for his walk as usual next morning, but he
17051. was silent with his steward, the gardener, and the architect, and though
17052. he looked very grim he said nothing to anyone.
17053. 
17054. When Princess Mary went to him at the usual hour he was working at his
17055. lathe and, as usual, did not look round at her.
17056. 
17057. "Ah, Princess Mary!" he said suddenly in an unnatural voice, throwing
17058. down his chisel. (The wheel continued to revolve by its own impetus,
17059. and Princess Mary long remembered the dying creak of that wheel, which
17060. merged in her memory with what followed.)
17061. 
17062. She approached him, saw his face, and something gave way within her.
17063. Her eyes grew dim. By the expression of her father's face, not sad, not
17064. crushed, but angry and working unnaturally, she saw that hanging over
17065. her and about to crush her was some terrible misfortune, the worst
17066. in life, one she had not yet experienced, irreparable and
17067. incomprehensible--the death of one she loved.
17068. 
17069. "Father! Andrew!"--said the ungraceful, awkward princess with such an
17070. indescribable charm of sorrow and self-forgetfulness that her father
17071. could not bear her look but turned away with a sob.
17072. 
17073. "Bad news! He's not among the prisoners nor among the killed! Kutuzov
17074. writes..." and he screamed as piercingly as if he wished to drive the
17075. princess away by that scream... "Killed!"
17076. 
17077. The princess did not fall down or faint. She was already pale, but on
17078. hearing these words her face changed and something brightened in her
17079. beautiful, radiant eyes. It was as if joy--a supreme joy apart from the
17080. joys and sorrows of this world--overflowed the great grief within her.
17081. She forgot all fear of her father, went up to him, took his hand, and
17082. drawing him down put her arm round his thin, scraggy neck.
17083. 
17084. "Father," she said, "do not turn away from me, let us weep together."
17085. 
17086. "Scoundrels! Blackguards!" shrieked the old man, turning his face away
17087. from her. "Destroying the army, destroying the men! And why? Go, go and
17088. tell Lise."
17089. 
17090. The princess sank helplessly into an armchair beside her father and
17091. wept. She saw her brother now as he had been at the moment when he took
17092. leave of her and of Lise, his look tender yet proud. She saw him tender
17093. and amused as he was when he put on the little icon. "Did he believe?
17094. Had he repented of his unbelief? Was he now there? There in the realms
17095. of eternal peace and blessedness?" she thought.
17096. 
17097. "Father, tell me how it happened," she asked through her tears.
17098. 
17099. "Go! Go! Killed in battle, where the best of Russian men and Russia's
