17100. glory were led to destruction. Go, Princess Mary. Go and tell Lise. I
17101. will follow."
17102. 
17103. When Princess Mary returned from her father, the little princess sat
17104. working and looked up with that curious expression of inner, happy calm
17105. peculiar to pregnant women. It was evident that her eyes did not see
17106. Princess Mary but were looking within... into herself... at something
17107. joyful and mysterious taking place within her.
17108. 
17109. "Mary," she said, moving away from the embroidery frame and lying back,
17110. "give me your hand." She took her sister-in-law's hand and held it below
17111. her waist.
17112. 
17113. Her eyes were smiling expectantly, her downy lip rose and remained
17114. lifted in childlike happiness.
17115. 
17116. Princess Mary knelt down before her and hid her face in the folds of her
17117. sister-in-law's dress.
17118. 
17119. "There, there! Do you feel it? I feel so strange. And do you know, Mary,
17120. I am going to love him very much," said Lise, looking with bright and
17121. happy eyes at her sister-in-law.
17122. 
17123. Princess Mary could not lift her head, she was weeping.
17124. 
17125. "What is the matter, Mary?"
17126. 
17127. "Nothing... only I feel sad... sad about Andrew," she said, wiping away
17128. her tears on her sister-in-law's knee.
17129. 
17130. Several times in the course of the morning Princess Mary began trying to
17131. prepare her sister-in-law, and every time began to cry. Unobservant as
17132. was the little princess, these tears, the cause of which she did not
17133. understand, agitated her. She said nothing but looked about uneasily as
17134. if in search of something. Before dinner the old prince, of whom she was
17135. always afraid, came into her room with a peculiarly restless and malign
17136. expression and went out again without saying a word. She looked at
17137. Princess Mary, then sat thinking for a while with that expression of
17138. attention to something within her that is only seen in pregnant women,
17139. and suddenly began to cry.
17140. 
17141. "Has anything come from Andrew?" she asked.
17142. 
17143. "No, you know it's too soon for news. But my father is anxious and I
17144. feel afraid."
17145. 
17146. "So there's nothing?"
17147. 
17148. "Nothing," answered Princess Mary, looking firmly with her radiant eyes
17149. at her sister-in-law.
17150. 
17151. She had determined not to tell her and persuaded her father to hide the
17152. terrible news from her till after her confinement, which was expected
17153. within a few days. Princess Mary and the old prince each bore and hid
17154. their grief in their own way. The old prince would not cherish any hope:
17155. he made up his mind that Prince Andrew had been killed, and though he
17156. sent an official to Austria to seek for traces of his son, he ordered a
17157. monument from Moscow which he intended to erect in his own garden to his
17158. memory, and he told everybody that his son had been killed. He tried not
17159. to change his former way of life, but his strength failed him. He walked
17160. less, ate less, slept less, and became weaker every day. Princess Mary
17161. hoped. She prayed for her brother as living and was always awaiting news
17162. of his return.
17163. 
17164. 
17165. 
17166. 
17167. 
17168. CHAPTER VIII
17169. 
17170. 
17171. "Dearest," said the little princess after breakfast on the morning of
17172. the nineteenth March, and her downy little lip rose from old habit, but
17173. as sorrow was manifest in every smile, the sound of every word, and even
17174. every footstep in that house since the terrible news had come, so now
17175. the smile of the little princess--influenced by the general mood though
17176. without knowing its cause--was such as to remind one still more of the
17177. general sorrow.
17178. 
17179. "Dearest, I'm afraid this morning's fruschtique *--as Foka the cook
17180. calls it--has disagreed with me."
17181. 
17182. 
17183.     * Fruhstuck: breakfast.
17184. 
17185. 
17186. "What is the matter with you, my darling? You look pale. Oh, you
17187. are very pale!" said Princess Mary in alarm, running with her soft,
17188. ponderous steps up to her sister-in-law.
17189. 
17190. "Your excellency, should not Mary Bogdanovna be sent for?" said one
17191. of the maids who was present. (Mary Bogdanovna was a midwife from the
17192. neighboring town, who had been at Bald Hills for the last fortnight.)
17193. 
17194. "Oh yes," assented Princess Mary, "perhaps that's it. I'll go. Courage,
17195. my angel." She kissed Lise and was about to leave the room.
17196. 
17197. "Oh, no, no!" And besides the pallor and the physical suffering on the
17198. little princess' face, an expression of childish fear of inevitable pain
17199. showed itself.
17200. 
17201. "No, it's only indigestion?... Say it's only indigestion, say so,
17202. Mary! Say..." And the little princess began to cry capriciously like
17203. a suffering child and to wring her little hands even with some
17204. affectation. Princess Mary ran out of the room to fetch Mary Bogdanovna.
17205. 
17206. "Mon Dieu! Mon Dieu! Oh!" she heard as she left the room.
17207. 
17208. The midwife was already on her way to meet her, rubbing her small, plump
17209. white hands with an air of calm importance.
17210. 
17211. "Mary Bogdanovna, I think it's beginning!" said Princess Mary looking at
17212. the midwife with wide-open eyes of alarm.
17213. 
17214. "Well, the Lord be thanked, Princess," said Mary Bogdanovna, not
17215. hastening her steps. "You young ladies should not know anything about
17216. it."
17217. 
17218. "But how is it the doctor from Moscow is not here yet?" said the
17219. princess. (In accordance with Lise's and Prince Andrew's wishes they had
17220. sent in good time to Moscow for a doctor and were expecting him at any
17221. moment.)
17222. 
17223. "No matter, Princess, don't be alarmed," said Mary Bogdanovna. "We'll
17224. manage very well without a doctor."
17225. 
17226. Five minutes later Princess Mary from her room heard something heavy
17227. being carried by. She looked out. The men servants were carrying the
17228. large leather sofa from Prince Andrew's study into the bedroom. On their
17229. faces was a quiet and solemn look.
17230. 
17231. Princess Mary sat alone in her room listening to the sounds in the
17232. house, now and then opening her door when someone passed and watching
17233. what was going on in the passage. Some women passing with quiet steps in
17234. and out of the bedroom glanced at the princess and turned away. She did
17235. not venture to ask any questions, and shut the door again, now sitting
17236. down in her easy chair, now taking her prayer book, now kneeling before
17237. the icon stand. To her surprise and distress she found that her prayers
17238. did not calm her excitement. Suddenly her door opened softly and her old
17239. nurse, Praskovya Savishna, who hardly ever came to that room as the old
17240. prince had forbidden it, appeared on the threshold with a shawl round
17241. her head.
17242. 
17243. "I've come to sit with you a bit, Masha," said the nurse, "and here
17244. I've brought the prince's wedding candles to light before his saint, my
17245. angel," she said with a sigh.
17246. 
17247. "Oh, nurse, I'm so glad!"
17248. 
17249. "God is merciful, birdie."
17250. 
17251. The nurse lit the gilt candles before the icons and sat down by the door
17252. with her knitting. Princess Mary took a book and began reading. Only
17253. when footsteps or voices were heard did they look at one another, the
17254. princess anxious and inquiring, the nurse encouraging. Everyone in the
17255. house was dominated by the same feeling that Princess Mary experienced
17256. as she sat in her room. But owing to the superstition that the fewer
17257. the people who know of it the less a woman in travail suffers, everyone
17258. tried to pretend not to know; no one spoke of it, but apart from the
17259. ordinary staid and respectful good manners habitual in the prince's
17260. household, a common anxiety, a softening of the heart, and a
17261. consciousness that something great and mysterious was being accomplished
17262. at that moment made itself felt.
17263. 
17264. There was no laughter in the maids' large hall. In the men servants'
17265. hall all sat waiting, silently and alert. In the outlying serfs'
17266. quarters torches and candles were burning and no one slept. The old
17267. prince, stepping on his heels, paced up and down his study and sent
17268. Tikhon to ask Mary Bogdanovna what news.--"Say only that 'the prince
17269. told me to ask,' and come and tell me her answer."
17270. 
17271. "Inform the prince that labor has begun," said Mary Bogdanovna, giving
17272. the messenger a significant look.
17273. 
17274. Tikhon went and told the prince.
17275. 
17276. "Very good!" said the prince closing the door behind him, and Tikhon did
17277. not hear the slightest sound from the study after that.
17278. 
17279. After a while he re-entered it as if to snuff the candles, and, seeing
17280. the prince was lying on the sofa, looked at him, noticed his perturbed
17281. face, shook his head, and going up to him silently kissed him on the
17282. shoulder and left the room without snuffing the candles or saying why he
17283. had entered. The most solemn mystery in the world continued its course.
17284. Evening passed, night came, and the feeling of suspense and softening of
17285. heart in the presence of the unfathomable did not lessen but increased.
17286. No one slept.
17287. 
17288. It was one of those March nights when winter seems to wish to resume its
17289. sway and scatters its last snows and storms with desperate fury. A relay
17290. of horses had been sent up the highroad to meet the German doctor from
17291. Moscow who was expected every moment, and men on horseback with lanterns
17292. were sent to the crossroads to guide him over the country road with its
17293. hollows and snow-covered pools of water.
17294. 
17295. Princess Mary had long since put aside her book: she sat silent, her
17296. luminous eyes fixed on her nurse's wrinkled face (every line of which
17297. she knew so well), on the lock of gray hair that escaped from under the
17298. kerchief, and the loose skin that hung under her chin.
17299. 
17300. Nurse Savishna, knitting in hand, was telling in low tones, scarcely
17301. hearing or understanding her own words, what she had told hundreds of
17302. times before: how the late princess had given birth to Princess Mary
17303. in Kishenev with only a Moldavian peasant woman to help instead of a
17304. midwife.
17305. 
17306. "God is merciful, doctors are never needed," she said.
17307. 
17308. Suddenly a gust of wind beat violently against the casement of the
17309. window, from which the double frame had been removed (by order of the
17310. prince, one window frame was removed in each room as soon as the larks
17311. returned), and, forcing open a loosely closed latch, set the damask
17312. curtain flapping and blew out the candle with its chill, snowy draft.
17313. Princess Mary shuddered; her nurse, putting down the stocking she was
17314. knitting, went to the window and leaning out tried to catch the open
17315. casement. The cold wind flapped the ends of her kerchief and her loose
17316. locks of gray hair.
17317. 
17318. "Princess, my dear, there's someone driving up the avenue!" she said,
17319. holding the casement and not closing it. "With lanterns. Most likely the
17320. doctor."
17321. 
17322. "Oh, my God! thank God!" said Princess Mary. "I must go and meet him, he
17323. does not know Russian."
17324. 
17325. Princess Mary threw a shawl over her head and ran to meet the newcomer.
17326. As she was crossing the anteroom she saw through the window a carriage
17327. with lanterns, standing at the entrance. She went out on the stairs. On
17328. a banister post stood a tallow candle which guttered in the draft. On
17329. the landing below, Philip, the footman, stood looking scared and holding
17330. another candle. Still lower, beyond the turn of the staircase, one
17331. could hear the footstep of someone in thick felt boots, and a voice that
17332. seemed familiar to Princess Mary was saying something.
17333. 
17334. "Thank God!" said the voice. "And Father?"
17335. 
17336. "Gone to bed," replied the voice of Demyan the house steward, who was
17337. downstairs.
17338. 
17339. Then the voice said something more, Demyan replied, and the steps in the
17340. felt boots approached the unseen bend of the staircase more rapidly.
17341. 
17342. "It's Andrew!" thought Princess Mary. "No it can't be, that would be too
17343. extraordinary," and at the very moment she thought this, the face and
17344. figure of Prince Andrew, in a fur cloak the deep collar of which covered
17345. with snow, appeared on the landing where the footman stood with the
17346. candle. Yes, it was he, pale, thin, with a changed and strangely
17347. softened but agitated expression on his face. He came up the stairs and
17348. embraced his sister.
17349. 
17350. "You did not get my letter?" he asked, and not waiting for a
17351. reply--which he would not have received, for the princess was unable to
17352. speak--he turned back, rapidly mounted the stairs again with the doctor
17353. who had entered the hall after him (they had met at the last post
17354. station), and again embraced his sister.
17355. 
17356. "What a strange fate, Masha darling!" And having taken off his cloak and
17357. felt boots, he went to the little princess' apartment.
17358. 
17359. 
17360. 
17361. 
17362. 
17363. CHAPTER IX
17364. 
17365. 
17366. The little princess lay supported by pillows, with a white cap on her
17367. head (the pains had just left her). Strands of her black hair lay round
17368. her inflamed and perspiring cheeks, her charming rosy mouth with its
17369. downy lip was open and she was smiling joyfully. Prince Andrew entered
17370. and paused facing her at the foot of the sofa on which she was lying.
17371. Her glittering eyes, filled with childlike fear and excitement, rested
17372. on him without changing their expression. "I love you all and have done
17373. no harm to anyone; why must I suffer so? Help me!" her look seemed to
17374. say. She saw her husband, but did not realize the significance of his
17375. appearance before her now. Prince Andrew went round the sofa and kissed
17376. her forehead.
17377. 
17378. "My darling!" he said--a word he had never used to her before. "God is
17379. merciful...."
17380. 
17381. She looked at him inquiringly and with childlike reproach.
17382. 
17383. "I expected help from you and I get none, none from you either!" said
17384. her eyes. She was not surprised at his having come; she did not realize
17385. that he had come. His coming had nothing to do with her sufferings or
17386. with their relief. The pangs began again and Mary Bogdanovna advised
17387. Prince Andrew to leave the room.
17388. 
17389. The doctor entered. Prince Andrew went out and, meeting Princess Mary,
17390. again joined her. They began talking in whispers, but their talk broke
17391. off at every moment. They waited and listened.
17392. 
17393. "Go, dear," said Princess Mary.
17394. 
17395. Prince Andrew went again to his wife and sat waiting in the room next
17396. to hers. A woman came from the bedroom with a frightened face and became
17397. confused when she saw Prince Andrew. He covered his face with his hands
17398. and remained so for some minutes. Piteous, helpless, animal moans came
17399. through the door. Prince Andrew got up, went to the door, and tried to
17400. open it. Someone was holding it shut.
17401. 
17402. "You can't come in! You can't!" said a terrified voice from within.
17403. 
17404. He began pacing the room. The screaming ceased, and a few more seconds
17405. went by. Then suddenly a terrible shriek--it could not be hers, she
17406. could not scream like that--came from the bedroom. Prince Andrew ran to
17407. the door; the scream ceased and he heard the wail of an infant.
17408. 
17409. "What have they taken a baby in there for?" thought Prince Andrew in the
17410. first second. "A baby? What baby...? Why is there a baby there? Or is
17411. the baby born?"
17412. 
17413. Then suddenly he realized the joyful significance of that wail; tears
17414. choked him, and leaning his elbows on the window sill be began to cry,
17415. sobbing like a child. The door opened. The doctor with his shirt sleeves
17416. tucked up, without a coat, pale and with a trembling jaw, came out
17417. of the room. Prince Andrew turned to him, but the doctor gave him a
17418. bewildered look and passed by without a word. A woman rushed out and
17419. seeing Prince Andrew stopped, hesitating on the threshold. He went into
17420. his wife's room. She was lying dead, in the same position he had seen
17421. her in five minutes before and, despite the fixed eyes and the pallor of
17422. the cheeks, the same expression was on her charming childlike face with
17423. its upper lip covered with tiny black hair.
17424. 
17425. "I love you all, and have done no harm to anyone; and what have you done
17426. to me?"--said her charming, pathetic, dead face.
17427. 
17428. In a corner of the room something red and tiny gave a grunt and squealed
17429. in Mary Bogdanovna's trembling white hands.
17430. 
17431. 
17432. Two hours later Prince Andrew, stepping softly, went into his father's
17433. room. The old man already knew everything. He was standing close to
17434. the door and as soon as it opened his rough old arms closed like a vise
17435. round his son's neck, and without a word he began to sob like a child.
17436. 
17437. 
17438. Three days later the little princess was buried, and Prince Andrew went
17439. up the steps to where the coffin stood, to give her the farewell kiss.
17440. And there in the coffin was the same face, though with closed eyes. "Ah,
17441. what have you done to me?" it still seemed to say, and Prince Andrew
17442. felt that something gave way in his soul and that he was guilty of a sin
17443. he could neither remedy nor forget. He could not weep. The old man too
17444. came up and kissed the waxen little hands that lay quietly crossed one
17445. on the other on her breast, and to him, too, her face seemed to say:
17446. "Ah, what have you done to me, and why?" And at the sight the old man
17447. turned angrily away.
17448. 
17449. 
17450. Another five days passed, and then the young Prince Nicholas Andreevich
17451. was baptized. The wet nurse supported the coverlet with her chin,
17452. while the priest with a goose feather anointed the boy's little red and
17453. wrinkled soles and palms.
17454. 
17455. His grandfather, who was his godfather, trembling and afraid of dropping
17456. him, carried the infant round the battered tin font and handed him over
17457. to the godmother, Princess Mary. Prince Andrew sat in another room,
17458. faint with fear lest the baby should be drowned in the font, and awaited
17459. the termination of the ceremony. He looked up joyfully at the baby when
17460. the nurse brought it to him and nodded approval when she told him that
17461. the wax with the baby's hair had not sunk in the font but had floated.
17462. 
17463. 
17464. 
17465. 
17466. 
17467. CHAPTER X
17468. 
17469. 
17470. Rostov's share in Dolokhov's duel with Bezukhov was hushed up by the
17471. efforts of the old count, and instead of being degraded to the ranks
17472. as he expected he was appointed an adjutant to the governor general of
17473. Moscow. As a result he could not go to the country with the rest of the
17474. family, but was kept all summer in Moscow by his new duties. Dolokhov
17475. recovered, and Rostov became very friendly with him during his
17476. convalescence. Dolokhov lay ill at his mother's who loved him
17477. passionately and tenderly, and old Mary Ivanovna, who had grown fond of
17478. Rostov for his friendship to her Fedya, often talked to him about her
17479. son.
17480. 
17481. "Yes, Count," she would say, "he is too noble and pure-souled for
17482. our present, depraved world. No one now loves virtue; it seems like
17483. a reproach to everyone. Now tell me, Count, was it right, was it
17484. honorable, of Bezukhov? And Fedya, with his noble spirit, loved him and
17485. even now never says a word against him. Those pranks in Petersburg when
17486. they played some tricks on a policeman, didn't they do it together?
17487. And there! Bezukhov got off scotfree, while Fedya had to bear the whole
17488. burden on his shoulders. Fancy what he had to go through! It's true he
17489. has been reinstated, but how could they fail to do that? I think there
17490. were not many such gallant sons of the fatherland out there as he. And
17491. now--this duel! Have these people no feeling, or honor? Knowing him to
17492. be an only son, to challenge him and shoot so straight! It's well
17493. God had mercy on us. And what was it for? Who doesn't have intrigues
17494. nowadays? Why, if he was so jealous, as I see things he should have
17495. shown it sooner, but he lets it go on for months. And then to call him
17496. out, reckoning on Fedya not fighting because he owed him money! What
17497. baseness! What meanness! I know you understand Fedya, my dear count;
17498. that, believe me, is why I am so fond of you. Few people do understand
17499. him. He is such a lofty, heavenly soul!"
17500. 
17501. Dolokhov himself during his convalescence spoke to Rostov in a way no
17502. one would have expected of him.
17503. 
17504. "I know people consider me a bad man!" he said. "Let them! I don't care
17505. a straw about anyone but those I love; but those I love, I love so that
17506. I would give my life for them, and the others I'd throttle if they
17507. stood in my way. I have an adored, a priceless mother, and two or three
17508. friends--you among them--and as for the rest I only care about them
17509. in so far as they are harmful or useful. And most of them are harmful,
17510. especially the women. Yes, dear boy," he continued, "I have met loving,
17511. noble, high-minded men, but I have not yet met any women--countesses
17512. or cooks--who were not venal. I have not yet met that divine purity and
17513. devotion I look for in women. If I found such a one I'd give my life for
17514. her! But those!..." and he made a gesture of contempt. "And believe me,
17515. if I still value my life it is only because I still hope to meet such
17516. a divine creature, who will regenerate, purify, and elevate me. But you
17517. don't understand it."
17518. 
17519. "Oh, yes, I quite understand," answered Rostov, who was under his new
17520. friend's influence.
17521. 
17522. In the autumn the Rostovs returned to Moscow. Early in the winter
17523. Denisov also came back and stayed with them. The first half of the
17524. winter of 1806, which Nicholas Rostov spent in Moscow, was one of the
17525. happiest, merriest times for him and the whole family. Nicholas brought
17526. many young men to his parents' house. Vera was a handsome girl of
17527. twenty; Sonya a girl of sixteen with all the charm of an opening flower;
17528. Natasha, half grown up and half child, was now childishly amusing, now
17529. girlishly enchanting.
17530. 
17531. At that time in the Rostovs' house there prevailed an amorous atmosphere
17532. characteristic of homes where there are very young and very
17533. charming girls. Every young man who came to the house--seeing those
17534. impressionable, smiling young faces (smiling probably at their own
17535. happiness), feeling the eager bustle around him, and hearing the fitful
17536. bursts of song and music and the inconsequent but friendly prattle of
17537. young girls ready for anything and full of hope--experienced the
17538. same feeling; sharing with the young folk of the Rostovs' household a
17539. readiness to fall in love and an expectation of happiness.
17540. 
17541. Among the young men introduced by Rostov one of the first was Dolokhov,
17542. whom everyone in the house liked except Natasha. She almost quarreled
17543. with her brother about him. She insisted that he was a bad man, and
17544. that in the duel with Bezukhov, Pierre was right and Dolokhov wrong, and
17545. further that he was disagreeable and unnatural.
17546. 
17547. "There's nothing for me to understand," she cried out with resolute
17548. self-will, "he is wicked and heartless. There now, I like your Denisov
17549. though he is a rake and all that, still I like him; so you see I do
17550. understand. I don't know how to put it... with this one everything is
17551. calculated, and I don't like that. But Denisov..."
17552. 
17553. "Oh, Denisov is quite different," replied Nicholas, implying that even
17554. Denisov was nothing compared to Dolokhov--"you must understand what a
17555. soul there is in Dolokhov, you should see him with his mother. What a
17556. heart!"
17557. 
17558. "Well, I don't know about that, but I am uncomfortable with him. And do
17559. you know he has fallen in love with Sonya?"
17560. 
17561. "What nonsense..."
17562. 
17563. "I'm certain of it; you'll see."
17564. 
17565. Natasha's prediction proved true. Dolokhov, who did not usually care
17566. for the society of ladies, began to come often to the house, and the
17567. question for whose sake he came (though no one spoke of it) was soon
17568. settled. He came because of Sonya. And Sonya, though she would never
17569. have dared to say so, knew it and blushed scarlet every time Dolokhov
17570. appeared.
17571. 
17572. Dolokhov often dined at the Rostovs', never missed a performance at
17573. which they were present, and went to Iogel's balls for young people
17574. which the Rostovs always attended. He was pointedly attentive to Sonya
17575. and looked at her in such a way that not only could she not bear his
17576. glances without coloring, but even the old countess and Natasha blushed
17577. when they saw his looks.
17578. 
17579. It was evident that this strange, strong man was under the irresistible
17580. influence of the dark, graceful girl who loved another.
17581. 
17582. Rostov noticed something new in Dolokhov's relations with Sonya, but
17583. he did not explain to himself what these new relations were. "They're
17584. always in love with someone," he thought of Sonya and Natasha. But he
17585. was not as much at ease with Sonya and Dolokhov as before and was less
17586. frequently at home.
17587. 
17588. In the autumn of 1806 everybody had again begun talking of the war with
17589. Napoleon with even greater warmth than the year before. Orders were
17590. given to raise recruits, ten men in every thousand for the regular army,
17591. and besides this, nine men in every thousand for the militia. Everywhere
17592. Bonaparte was anathematized and in Moscow nothing but the coming war
17593. was talked of. For the Rostov family the whole interest of these
17594. preparations for war lay in the fact that Nicholas would not hear of
17595. remaining in Moscow, and only awaited the termination of Denisov's
17596. furlough after Christmas to return with him to their regiment. His
17597. approaching departure did not prevent his amusing himself, but rather
17598. gave zest to his pleasures. He spent the greater part of his time away
17599. from home, at dinners, parties, and balls.
17600. 
17601. 
17602. 
17603. 
17604. 
17605. CHAPTER XI
17606. 
17607. 
17608. On the third day after Christmas Nicholas dined at home, a thing he had
17609. rarely done of late. It was a grand farewell dinner, as he and Denisov
17610. were leaving to join their regiment after Epiphany. About twenty people
17611. were present, including Dolokhov and Denisov.
17612. 
17613. Never had love been so much in the air, and never had the amorous
17614. atmosphere made itself so strongly felt in the Rostovs' house as at this
17615. holiday time. "Seize the moments of happiness, love and be loved! That
17616. is the only reality in the world, all else is folly. It is the one thing
17617. we are interested in here," said the spirit of the place.
17618. 
17619. Nicholas, having as usual exhausted two pairs of horses, without
17620. visiting all the places he meant to go to and where he had been invited,
17621. returned home just before dinner. As soon as he entered he noticed and
17622. felt the tension of the amorous air in the house, and also noticed a
17623. curious embarrassment among some of those present. Sonya, Dolokhov,
17624. and the old countess were especially disturbed, and to a lesser degree
17625. Natasha. Nicholas understood that something must have happened between
17626. Sonya and Dolokhov before dinner, and with the kindly sensitiveness
17627. natural to him was very gentle and wary with them both at dinner. On
17628. that same evening there was to be one of the balls that Iogel (the
17629. dancing master) gave for his pupils during the holidays.
17630. 
17631. "Nicholas, will you come to Iogel's? Please do!" said Natasha. "He asked
17632. you, and Vasili Dmitrich * is also going."
17633. 
17634. 
17635.     * Denisov.
17636. 
17637. 
17638. "Where would I not go at the countess' command!" said Denisov, who at
17639. the Rostovs' had jocularly assumed the role of Natasha's knight. "I'm
17640. even weady to dance the pas de chale."
17641. 
17642. "If I have time," answered Nicholas. "But I promised the Arkharovs; they
17643. have a party."
17644. 
17645. "And you?" he asked Dolokhov, but as soon as he had asked the question
17646. he noticed that it should not have been put.
17647. 
17648. "Perhaps," coldly and angrily replied Dolokhov, glancing at Sonya, and,
17649. scowling, he gave Nicholas just such a look as he had given Pierre at
17650. the Club dinner.
17651. 
17652. "There is something up," thought Nicholas, and he was further confirmed
17653. in this conclusion by the fact that Dolokhov left immediately after
17654. dinner. He called Natasha and asked her what was the matter.
17655. 
17656. "And I was looking for you," said Natasha running out to him. "I told
17657. you, but you would not believe it," she said triumphantly. "He has
17658. proposed to Sonya!"
17659. 
17660. Little as Nicholas had occupied himself with Sonya of late, something
17661. seemed to give way within him at this news. Dolokhov was a suitable and
17662. in some respects a brilliant match for the dowerless, orphan girl. From
17663. the point of view of the old countess and of society it was out of the
17664. question for her to refuse him. And therefore Nicholas' first feeling
17665. on hearing the news was one of anger with Sonya.... He tried to say,
17666. "That's capital; of course she'll forget her childish promises and
17667. accept the offer," but before he had time to say it Natasha began again.
17668. 
17669. "And fancy! she refused him quite definitely!" adding, after a pause,
17670. "she told him she loved another."
17671. 
17672. "Yes, my Sonya could not have done otherwise!" thought Nicholas.
17673. 
17674. "Much as Mamma pressed her, she refused, and I know she won't change
17675. once she has said..."
17676. 
17677. "And Mamma pressed her!" said Nicholas reproachfully.
17678. 
17679. "Yes," said Natasha. "Do you know, Nicholas--don't be angry--but I know
17680. you will not marry her. I know, heaven knows how, but I know for certain
17681. that you won't marry her."
17682. 
17683. "Now you don't know that at all!" said Nicholas. "But I must talk to
17684. her. What a darling Sonya is!" he added with a smile.
17685. 
17686. "Ah, she is indeed a darling! I'll send her to you."
17687. 
17688. And Natasha kissed her brother and ran away.
17689. 
17690. A minute later Sonya came in with a frightened, guilty, and scared look.
17691. Nicholas went up to her and kissed her hand. This was the first time
17692. since his return that they had talked alone and about their love.
17693. 
17694. "Sophie," he began, timidly at first and then more and more boldly,
17695. "if you wish to refuse one who is not only a brilliant and advantageous
17696. match but a splendid, noble fellow... he is my friend..."
17697. 
17698. Sonya interrupted him.
17699. 
17700. "I have already refused," she said hurriedly.
17701. 
17702. "If you are refusing for my sake, I am afraid that I..."
17703. 
17704. Sonya again interrupted. She gave him an imploring, frightened look.
17705. 
17706. "Nicholas, don't tell me that!" she said.
17707. 
17708. "No, but I must. It may be arrogant of me, but still it is best to say
17709. it. If you refuse him on my account, I must tell you the whole truth. I
17710. love you, and I think I love you more than anyone else...."
17711. 
17712. "That is enough for me," said Sonya, blushing.
17713. 
17714. "No, but I have been in love a thousand times and shall fall in
17715. love again, though for no one have I such a feeling of friendship,
17716. confidence, and love as I have for you. Then I am young. Mamma does
17717. not wish it. In a word, I make no promise. And I beg you to consider
17718. Dolokhov's offer," he said, articulating his friend's name with
17719. difficulty.
17720. 
17721. "Don't say that to me! I want nothing. I love you as a brother and
17722. always shall, and I want nothing more."
17723. 
17724. "You are an angel: I am not worthy of you, but I am afraid of misleading
17725. you."
17726. 
17727. And Nicholas again kissed her hand.
17728. 
17729. 
17730. 
17731. 
17732. 
17733. CHAPTER XII
17734. 
17735. 
17736. Iogel's were the most enjoyable balls in Moscow. So said the mothers as
17737. they watched their young people executing their newly learned steps, and
17738. so said the youths and maidens themselves as they danced till they were
17739. ready to drop, and so said the grown-up young men and women who came to
17740. these balls with an air of condescension and found them most enjoyable.
17741. That year two marriages had come of these balls. The two pretty young
17742. Princesses Gorchakov met suitors there and were married and so further
17743. increased the fame of these dances. What distinguished them from others
17744. was the absence of host or hostess and the presence of the good-natured
17745. Iogel, flying about like a feather and bowing according to the rules of
17746. his art, as he collected the tickets from all his visitors. There was
17747. the fact that only those came who wished to dance and amuse themselves
17748. as girls of thirteen and fourteen do who are wearing long dresses for
17749. the first time. With scarcely any exceptions they all were, or seemed to
17750. be, pretty--so rapturous were their smiles and so sparkling their eyes.
17751. Sometimes the best of the pupils, of whom Natasha, who was exceptionally
17752. graceful, was first, even danced the pas de chale, but at this last ball
17753. only the ecossaise, the anglaise, and the mazurka, which was just coming
17754. into fashion, were danced. Iogel had taken a ballroom in Bezukhov's
17755. house, and the ball, as everyone said, was a great success. There were
17756. many pretty girls and the Rostov girls were among the prettiest. They
17757. were both particularly happy and gay. That evening, proud of Dolokhov's
17758. proposal, her refusal, and her explanation with Nicholas, Sonya twirled
17759. about before she left home so that the maid could hardly get her hair
17760. plaited, and she was transparently radiant with impulsive joy.
17761. 
17762. Natasha no less proud of her first long dress and of being at a real
17763. ball was even happier. They were both dressed in white muslin with pink
17764. ribbons.
17765. 
17766. Natasha fell in love the very moment she entered the ballroom. She
17767. was not in love with anyone in particular, but with everyone. Whatever
17768. person she happened to look at she was in love with for that moment.
17769. 
17770. "Oh, how delightful it is!" she kept saying, running up to Sonya.
17771. 
17772. Nicholas and Denisov were walking up and down, looking with kindly
17773. patronage at the dancers.
17774. 
17775. "How sweet she is--she will be a weal beauty!" said Denisov.
17776. 
17777. "Who?"
17778. 
17779. "Countess Natasha," answered Denisov.
17780. 
17781. "And how she dances! What gwace!" he said again after a pause.
17782. 
17783. "Who are you talking about?"
17784. 
17785. "About your sister," ejaculated Denisov testily.
17786. 
17787. Rostov smiled.
17788. 
17789. "My dear count, you were one of my best pupils--you must dance," said
17790. little Iogel coming up to Nicholas. "Look how many charming young
17791. ladies-" He turned with the same request to Denisov who was also a
17792. former pupil of his.
17793. 
17794. "No, my dear fellow, I'll be a wallflower," said Denisov. "Don't you
17795. wecollect what bad use I made of your lessons?"
17796. 
17797. "Oh no!" said Iogel, hastening to reassure him. "You were only
17798. inattentive, but you had talent--oh yes, you had talent!"
17799. 
17800.  The band struck up the newly introduced mazurka. Nicholas could not
17801. refuse Iogel and asked Sonya to dance. Denisov sat down by the old
17802. ladies and, leaning on his saber and beating time with his foot, told
17803. them something funny and kept them amused, while he watched the young
17804. people dancing, Iogel with Natasha, his pride and his best pupil, were
17805. the first couple. Noiselessly, skillfully stepping with his little feet
17806. in low shoes, Iogel flew first across the hall with Natasha, who, though
17807. shy, went on carefully executing her steps. Denisov did not take
17808. his eyes off her and beat time with his saber in a way that clearly
17809. indicated that if he was not dancing it was because he would not and not
17810. because he could not. In the middle of a figure he beckoned to Rostov
17811. who was passing:
17812. 
17813. "This is not at all the thing," he said. "What sort of Polish mazuwka is
17814. this? But she does dance splendidly."
17815. 
17816. Knowing that Denisov had a reputation even in Poland for the masterly
17817. way in which he danced the mazurka, Nicholas ran up to Natasha:
17818. 
17819. "Go and choose Denisov. He is a real dancer, a wonder!" he said.
17820. 
17821. When it came to Natasha's turn to choose a partner, she rose and,
17822. tripping rapidly across in her little shoes trimmed with bows, ran
17823. timidly to the corner where Denisov sat. She saw that everybody was
17824. looking at her and waiting. Nicholas saw that Denisov was refusing
17825. though he smiled delightedly. He ran up to them.
17826. 
17827. "Please, Vasili Dmitrich," Natasha was saying, "do come!"
17828. 
17829. "Oh no, let me off, Countess," Denisov replied.
17830. 
17831. "Now then, Vaska," said Nicholas.
17832. 
17833. "They coax me as if I were Vaska the cat!" said Denisov jokingly.
17834. 
17835. "I'll sing for you a whole evening," said Natasha.
17836. 
17837. "Oh, the faiwy! She can do anything with me!" said Denisov, and he
17838. unhooked his saber. He came out from behind the chairs, clasped his
17839. partner's hand firmly, threw back his head, and advanced his foot,
17840. waiting for the beat. Only on horse back and in the mazurka was
17841. Denisov's short stature not noticeable and he looked the fine fellow he
17842. felt himself to be. At the right beat of the music he looked sideways at
17843. his partner with a merry and triumphant air, suddenly stamped with one
17844. foot, bounded from the floor like a ball, and flew round the room taking
17845. his partner with him. He glided silently on one foot half across the
17846. room, and seeming not to notice the chairs was dashing straight at them,
17847. when suddenly, clinking his spurs and spreading out his legs, he stopped
17848. short on his heels, stood so a second, stamped on the spot clanking his
17849. spurs, whirled rapidly round, and, striking his left heel against his
17850. right, flew round again in a circle. Natasha guessed what he meant to
17851. do, and abandoning herself to him followed his lead hardly knowing how.
17852. First he spun her round, holding her now with his left, now with his
17853. right hand, then falling on one knee he twirled her round him, and again
17854. jumping up, dashed so impetuously forward that it seemed as if he would
17855. rush through the whole suite of rooms without drawing breath, and then
17856. he suddenly stopped and performed some new and unexpected steps. When at
17857. last, smartly whirling his partner round in front of her chair, he drew
17858. up with a click of his spurs and bowed to her, Natasha did not even make
17859. him a curtsy. She fixed her eyes on him in amazement, smiling as if she
17860. did not recognize him.
17861. 
17862. "What does this mean?" she brought out.
17863. 
17864. Although Iogel did not acknowledge this to be the real mazurka, everyone
17865. was delighted with Denisov's skill, he was asked again and again as a
17866. partner, and the old men began smilingly to talk about Poland and the
17867. good old days. Denisov, flushed after the mazurka and mopping himself
17868. with his handkerchief, sat down by Natasha and did not leave her for the
17869. rest of the evening.
17870. 
17871. 
17872. 
17873. 
17874. 
17875. CHAPTER XIII
17876. 
17877. 
17878. For two days after that Rostov did not see Dolokhov at his own or at
17879. Dolokhov's home: on the third day he received a note from him:
17880. 
17881. 
17882. As I do not intend to be at your house again for reasons you know
17883. of, and am going to rejoin my regiment, I am giving a farewell supper
17884. tonight to my friends--come to the English Hotel.
17885. 
17886. 
17887. About ten o'clock Rostov went to the English Hotel straight from the
17888. theater, where he had been with his family and Denisov. He was at once
17889. shown to the best room, which Dolokhov had taken for that evening. Some
17890. twenty men were gathered round a table at which Dolokhov sat between
17891. two candles. On the table was a pile of gold and paper money, and he was
17892. keeping the bank. Rostov had not seen him since his proposal and Sonya's
17893. refusal and felt uncomfortable at the thought of how they would meet.
17894. 
17895. Dolokhov's clear, cold glance met Rostov as soon as he entered the door,
17896. as though he had long expected him.
17897. 
17898. "It's a long time since we met," he said. "Thanks for coming. I'll just
17899. finish dealing, and then Ilyushka will come with his chorus."
17900. 
17901. "I called once or twice at your house," said Rostov, reddening.
17902. 
17903. Dolokhov made no reply.
17904. 
17905. "You may punt," he said.
17906. 
17907. Rostov recalled at that moment a strange conversation he had once had
17908. with Dolokhov. "None but fools trust to luck in play," Dolokhov had then
17909. said.
17910. 
17911. "Or are you afraid to play with me?" Dolokhov now asked as if guessing
17912. Rostov's thought.
17913. 
17914. Beneath his smile Rostov saw in him the mood he had shown at the Club
17915. dinner and at other times, when as if tired of everyday life he had felt
17916. a need to escape from it by some strange, and usually cruel, action.
17917. 
17918. Rostov felt ill at ease. He tried, but failed, to find some joke
17919. with which to reply to Dolokhov's words. But before he had thought
17920. of anything, Dolokhov, looking straight in his face, said slowly and
17921. deliberately so that everyone could hear:
17922. 
17923. "Do you remember we had a talk about cards... 'He's a fool who trusts to
17924. luck, one should make certain,' and I want to try."
17925. 
17926. "To try his luck or the certainty?" Rostov asked himself.
17927. 
17928. "Well, you'd better not play," Dolokhov added, and springing a new pack
17929. of cards said: "Bank, gentlemen!"
17930. 
17931. Moving the money forward he prepared to deal. Rostov sat down by his
17932. side and at first did not play. Dolokhov kept glancing at him.
17933. 
17934. "Why don't you play?" he asked.
17935. 
17936. And strange to say Nicholas felt that he could not help taking up a
17937. card, putting a small stake on it, and beginning to play.
17938. 
17939. "I have no money with me," he said.
17940. 
17941. "I'll trust you."
17942. 
17943. Rostov staked five rubles on a card and lost, staked again, and again
17944. lost. Dolokhov "killed," that is, beat, ten cards of Rostov's running.
17945. 
17946. "Gentlemen," said Dolokhov after he had dealt for some time. "Please
17947. place your money on the cards or I may get muddled in the reckoning."
17948. 
17949. One of the players said he hoped he might be trusted.
17950. 
17951. "Yes, you might, but I am afraid of getting the accounts mixed. So I
17952. ask you to put the money on your cards," replied Dolokhov. "Don't stint
17953. yourself, we'll settle afterwards," he added, turning to Rostov.
17954. 
17955. The game continued; a waiter kept handing round champagne.
17956. 
17957. All Rostov's cards were beaten and he had eight hundred rubles scored
17958. up against him. He wrote "800 rubles" on a card, but while the waiter
17959. filled his glass he changed his mind and altered it to his usual stake
17960. of twenty rubles.
17961. 
17962. "Leave it," said Dolokhov, though he did not seem to be even looking at
17963. Rostov, "you'll win it back all the sooner. I lose to the others but win
17964. from you. Or are you afraid of me?" he asked again.
17965. 
17966. Rostov submitted. He let the eight hundred remain and laid down a seven
17967. of hearts with a torn corner, which he had picked up from the floor. He
17968. well remembered that seven afterwards. He laid down the seven of hearts,
17969. on which with a broken bit of chalk he had written "800 rubles" in clear
17970. upright figures; he emptied the glass of warm champagne that was handed
17971. him, smiled at Dolokhov's words, and with a sinking heart, waiting for
17972. a seven to turn up, gazed at Dolokhov's hands which held the pack. Much
17973. depended on Rostov's winning or losing on that seven of hearts. On the
17974. previous Sunday the old count had given his son two thousand rubles,
17975. and though he always disliked speaking of money difficulties had told
17976. Nicholas that this was all he could let him have till May, and asked him
17977. to be more economical this time. Nicholas had replied that it would be
17978. more than enough for him and that he gave his word of honor not to take
17979. anything more till the spring. Now only twelve hundred rubles was left
17980. of that money, so that this seven of hearts meant for him not only the
17981. loss of sixteen hundred rubles, but the necessity of going back on his
17982. word. With a sinking heart he watched Dolokhov's hands and thought,
17983. "Now then, make haste and let me have this card and I'll take my cap
17984. and drive home to supper with Denisov, Natasha, and Sonya, and will
17985. certainly never touch a card again." At that moment his home life,
17986. jokes with Petya, talks with Sonya, duets with Natasha, piquet with his
17987. father, and even his comfortable bed in the house on the Povarskaya rose
17988. before him with such vividness, clearness, and charm that it seemed as
17989. if it were all a lost and unappreciated bliss, long past. He could not
17990. conceive that a stupid chance, letting the seven be dealt to the right
17991. rather than to the left, might deprive him of all this happiness, newly
17992. appreciated and newly illumined, and plunge him into the depths of
17993. unknown and undefined misery. That could not be, yet he awaited with
17994. a sinking heart the movement of Dolokhov's hands. Those broad, reddish
17995. hands, with hairy wrists visible from under the shirt cuffs, laid down
17996. the pack and took up a glass and a pipe that were handed him.
17997. 
17998. "So you are not afraid to play with me?" repeated Dolokhov, and as if
17999. about to tell a good story he put down the cards, leaned back in his
18000. chair, and began deliberately with a smile:
18001. 
18002. "Yes, gentlemen, I've been told there's a rumor going about Moscow that
18003. I'm a sharper, so I advise you to be careful."
18004. 
18005. "Come now, deal!" exclaimed Rostov.
18006. 
18007. "Oh, those Moscow gossips!" said Dolokhov, and he took up the cards with
18008. a smile.
18009. 
18010. "Aah!" Rostov almost screamed lifting both hands to his head. The seven
18011. he needed was lying uppermost, the first card in the pack. He had lost
18012. more than he could pay.
18013. 
18014. "Still, don't ruin yourself!" said Dolokhov with a side glance at Rostov
18015. as he continued to deal.
18016. 
18017. 
18018. 
18019. 
18020. 
18021. CHAPTER XIV
18022. 
18023. 
18024. An hour and a half later most of the players were but little interested
18025. in their own play.
18026. 
18027. The whole interest was concentrated on Rostov. Instead of sixteen
18028. hundred rubles he had a long column of figures scored against him,
18029. which he had reckoned up to ten thousand, but that now, as he vaguely
18030. supposed, must have risen to fifteen thousand. In reality it already
18031. exceeded twenty thousand rubles. Dolokhov was no longer listening to
18032. stories or telling them, but followed every movement of Rostov's hands
18033. and occasionally ran his eyes over the score against him. He had decided
18034. to play until that score reached forty-three thousand. He had fixed on
18035. that number because forty-three was the sum of his and Sonya's joint
18036. ages. Rostov, leaning his head on both hands, sat at the table which
18037. was scrawled over with figures, wet with spilled wine, and littered
18038. with cards. One tormenting impression did not leave him: that those
18039. broad-boned reddish hands with hairy wrists visible from under the shirt
18040. sleeves, those hands which he loved and hated, held him in their power.
18041. 
18042. "Six hundred rubles, ace, a corner, a nine... winning it back's
18043. impossible... Oh, how pleasant it was at home!... The knave, double
18044. or quits... it can't be!... And why is he doing this to me?" Rostov
18045. pondered. Sometimes he staked a large sum, but Dolokhov refused to
18046. accept it and fixed the stake himself. Nicholas submitted to him, and at
18047. one moment prayed to God as he had done on the battlefield at the bridge
18048. over the Enns, and then guessed that the card that came first to hand
18049. from the crumpled heap under the table would save him, now counted the
18050. cords on his coat and took a card with that number and tried staking the
18051. total of his losses on it, then he looked round for aid from the other
18052. players, or peered at the now cold face of Dolokhov and tried to read
18053. what was passing in his mind.
18054. 
18055. "He knows of course what this loss means to me. He can't want my ruin.
18056. Wasn't he my friend? Wasn't I fond of him? But it's not his fault.
18057. What's he to do if he has such luck?... And it's not my fault either,"
18058. he thought to himself, "I have done nothing wrong. Have I killed anyone,
18059. or insulted or wished harm to anyone? Why such a terrible misfortune?
18060. And when did it begin? Such a little while ago I came to this table with
18061. the thought of winning a hundred rubles to buy that casket for Mamma's
18062. name day and then going home. I was so happy, so free, so lighthearted!
18063. And I did not realize how happy I was! When did that end and when did
18064. this new, terrible state of things begin? What marked the change? I sat
18065. all the time in this same place at this table, chose and placed cards,
18066. and watched those broad-boned agile hands in the same way. When did it
18067. happen and what has happened? I am well and strong and still the same
18068. and in the same place. No, it can't be! Surely it will all end in
18069. nothing!"
18070. 
18071. He was flushed and bathed in perspiration, though the room was not hot.
18072. His face was terrible and piteous to see, especially from its helpless
18073. efforts to seem calm.
18074. 
18075. The score against him reached the fateful sum of forty-three thousand.
18076. Rostov had just prepared a card, by bending the corner of which he meant
18077. to double the three thousand just put down to his score, when Dolokhov,
18078. slamming down the pack of cards, put it aside and began rapidly adding
18079. up the total of Rostov's debt, breaking the chalk as he marked the
18080. figures in his clear, bold hand.
18081. 
18082. "Supper, it's time for supper! And here are the gypsies!"
18083. 
18084. Some swarthy men and women were really entering from the cold outside
18085. and saying something in their gypsy accents. Nicholas understood that it
18086. was all over; but he said in an indifferent tone:
18087. 
18088. "Well, won't you go on? I had a splendid card all ready," as if it were
18089. the fun of the game which interested him most.
18090. 
18091. "It's all up! I'm lost!" thought he. "Now a bullet through my
18092. brain--that's all that's left me!" And at the same time he said in a
18093. cheerful voice:
18094. 
18095. "Come now, just this one more little card!"
18096. 
18097. "All right!" said Dolokhov, having finished the addition. "All right!
18098. Twenty-one rubles," he said, pointing to the figure twenty-one by which
18099. the total exceeded the round sum of forty-three thousand; and taking up
18100. a pack he prepared to deal. Rostov submissively unbent the corner of his
18101. card and, instead of the six thousand he had intended, carefully wrote
18102. twenty-one.
18103. 
18104. "It's all the same to me," he said. "I only want to see whether you will
18105. let me win this ten, or beat it."
18106. 
18107. Dolokhov began to deal seriously. Oh, how Rostov detested at that moment
18108. those hands with their short reddish fingers and hairy wrists, which
18109. held him in their power.... The ten fell to him.
18110. 
18111. "You owe forty-three thousand, Count," said Dolokhov, and stretching
18112. himself he rose from the table. "One does get tired sitting so long," he
18113. added.
18114. 
18115. "Yes, I'm tired too," said Rostov.
18116. 
18117. Dolokhov cut him short, as if to remind him that it was not for him to
18118. jest.
18119. 
18120. "When am I to receive the money, Count?"
18121. 
18122. Rostov, flushing, drew Dolokhov into the next room.
18123. 
18124. "I cannot pay it all immediately. Will you take an I.O.U.?" he said.
18125. 
18126. "I say, Rostov," said Dolokhov clearly, smiling and looking Nicholas
18127. straight in the eyes, "you know the saying, 'Lucky in love, unlucky at
18128. cards.' Your cousin is in love with you, I know."
18129. 
18130. "Oh, it's terrible to feel oneself so in this man's power," thought
18131. Rostov. He knew what a shock he would inflict on his father and mother
18132. by the news of this loss, he knew what a relief it would be to escape
18133. it all, and felt that Dolokhov knew that he could save him from all this
18134. shame and sorrow, but wanted now to play with him as a cat does with a
18135. mouse.
18136. 
18137. "Your cousin..." Dolokhov started to say, but Nicholas interrupted him.
18138. 
18139. "My cousin has nothing to do with this and it's not necessary to mention
18140. her!" he exclaimed fiercely.
18141. 
18142. "Then when am I to have it?"
18143. 
18144. "Tomorrow," replied Rostov and left the room.
18145. 
18146. 
18147. 
18148. 
18149. 
18150. CHAPTER XV
18151. 
18152. 
18153. To say "tomorrow" and keep up a dignified tone was not difficult, but to
18154. go home alone, see his sisters, brother, mother, and father, confess
18155. and ask for money he had no right to after giving his word of honor, was
18156. terrible.
18157. 
18158. At home, they had not yet gone to bed. The young people, after returning
18159. from the theater, had had supper and were grouped round the clavichord.
18160. As soon as Nicholas entered, he was enfolded in that poetic atmosphere
18161. of love which pervaded the Rostov household that winter and, now after
18162. Dolokhov's proposal and Iogel's ball, seemed to have grown thicker
18163. round Sonya and Natasha as the air does before a thunderstorm. Sonya and
18164. Natasha, in the light-blue dresses they had worn at the theater, looking
18165. pretty and conscious of it, were standing by the clavichord, happy and
18166. smiling. Vera was playing chess with Shinshin in the drawing room. The
18167. old countess, waiting for the return of her husband and son, sat playing
18168. patience with the old gentlewoman who lived in their house. Denisov,
18169. with sparkling eyes and ruffled hair, sat at the clavichord striking
18170. chords with his short fingers, his legs thrown back and his eyes rolling
18171. as he sang, with his small, husky, but true voice, some verses called
18172. "Enchantress," which he had composed, and to which he was trying to fit
18173. music:
18174. 
18175.    Enchantress, say, to my forsaken lyre
18176.    What magic power is this recalls me still?
18177.    What spark has set my inmost soul on fire,
18178.    What is this bliss that makes my fingers thrill?
18179. 
18180. He was singing in passionate tones, gazing with his sparkling
18181. black-agate eyes at the frightened and happy Natasha.
18182. 
18183. "Splendid! Excellent!" exclaimed Natasha. "Another verse," she said,
18184. without noticing Nicholas.
18185. 
18186. "Everything's still the same with them," thought Nicholas, glancing into
18187. the drawing room, where he saw Vera and his mother with the old lady.
18188. 
18189. "Ah, and here's Nicholas!" cried Natasha, running up to him.
18190. 
18191. "Is Papa at home?" he asked.
18192. 
18193. "I am so glad you've come!" said Natasha, without answering him. "We are
18194. enjoying ourselves! Vasili Dmitrich is staying a day longer for my sake!
18195. Did you know?"
18196. 
18197. "No, Papa is not back yet," said Sonya.
18198. 
18199. "Nicholas, have you come? Come here, dear!" called the old countess from
18200. the drawing room.
18201. 
18202. Nicholas went to her, kissed her hand, and sitting down silently at her
18203. table began to watch her hands arranging the cards. From the dancing
18204. room, they still heard the laughter and merry voices trying to persuade
18205. Natasha to sing.
18206. 
18207. "All wight! All wight!" shouted Denisov. "It's no good making excuses
18208. now! It's your turn to sing the ba'cawolla--I entweat you!"
18209. 
18210. The countess glanced at her silent son.
18211. 
18212. "What is the matter?" she asked.
18213. 
18214. "Oh, nothing," said he, as if weary of being continually asked the same
18215. question. "Will Papa be back soon?"
18216. 
18217. "I expect so."
18218. 
18219. "Everything's the same with them. They know nothing about it! Where am I
18220. to go?" thought Nicholas, and went again into the dancing room where the
18221. clavichord stood.
18222. 
18223. Sonya was sitting at the clavichord, playing the prelude to Denisov's
18224. favorite barcarolle. Natasha was preparing to sing. Denisov was looking
18225. at her with enraptured eyes.
18226. 
18227. Nicholas began pacing up and down the room.
18228. 
18229. "Why do they want to make her sing? How can she sing? There's nothing to
18230. be happy about!" thought he.
18231. 
18232. Sonya struck the first chord of the prelude.
18233. 
18234. "My God, I'm a ruined and dishonored man! A bullet through my brain is
18235. the only thing left me--not singing!" his thoughts ran on. "Go away? But
18236. where to? It's one--let them sing!"
18237. 
18238. He continued to pace the room, looking gloomily at Denisov and the girls
18239. and avoiding their eyes.
18240. 
18241. "Nikolenka, what is the matter?" Sonya's eyes fixed on him seemed to
18242. ask. She noticed at once that something had happened to him.
18243. 
18244. Nicholas turned away from her. Natasha too, with her quick instinct, had
18245. instantly noticed her brother's condition. But, though she noticed it,
18246. she was herself in such high spirits at that moment, so far from sorrow,
18247. sadness, or self-reproach, that she purposely deceived herself as
18248. young people often do. "No, I am too happy now to spoil my enjoyment by
18249. sympathy with anyone's sorrow," she felt, and she said to herself: "No,
18250. I must be mistaken, he must be feeling happy, just as I am."
18251. 
18252. "Now, Sonya!" she said, going to the very middle of the room, where she
18253. considered the resonance was best.
18254. 
18255. Having lifted her head and let her arms droop lifelessly, as ballet
18256. dancers do, Natasha, rising energetically from her heels to her toes,
18257. stepped to the middle of the room and stood still.
18258. 
18259. "Yes, that's me!" she seemed to say, answering the rapt gaze with which
18260. Denisov followed her.
18261. 
18262. "And what is she so pleased about?" thought Nicholas, looking at his
18263. sister. "Why isn't she dull and ashamed?"
18264. 
18265. Natasha took the first note, her throat swelled, her chest rose,
18266. her eyes became serious. At that moment she was oblivious of her
18267. surroundings, and from her smiling lips flowed sounds which anyone may
18268. produce at the same intervals and hold for the same time, but which
18269. leave you cold a thousand times and the thousand and first time thrill
18270. you and make you weep.
18271. 
18272. Natasha, that winter, had for the first time begun to sing seriously,
18273. mainly because Denisov so delighted in her singing. She no longer sang
18274. as a child, there was no longer in her singing that comical, childish,
18275. painstaking effect that had been in it before; but she did not yet sing
18276. well, as all the connoisseurs who heard her said: "It is not trained,
18277. but it is a beautiful voice that must be trained." Only they generally
18278. said this some time after she had finished singing. While that untrained
18279. voice, with its incorrect breathing and labored transitions, was
18280. sounding, even the connoisseurs said nothing, but only delighted in
18281. it and wished to hear it again. In her voice there was a virginal
18282. freshness, an unconsciousness of her own powers, and an as yet untrained
18283. velvety softness, which so mingled with her lack of art in singing that
18284. it seemed as if nothing in that voice could be altered without spoiling
18285. it.
18286. 
18287. "What is this?" thought Nicholas, listening to her with widely opened
18288. eyes. "What has happened to her? How she is singing today!" And suddenly
18289. the whole world centered for him on anticipation of the next note, the
18290. next phrase, and everything in the world was divided into three beats:
18291. "Oh mio crudele affetto."... One, two, three... one, two, three...
18292. One... "Oh mio crudele affetto."... One, two, three... One. "Oh, this
18293. senseless life of ours!" thought Nicholas. "All this misery, and money,
18294. and Dolokhov, and anger, and honor--it's all nonsense... but this is
18295. real.... Now then, Natasha, now then, dearest! Now then, darling! How
18296. will she take that si? She's taken it! Thank God!" And without noticing
18297. that he was singing, to strengthen the si he sung a second, a third
18298. below the high note. "Ah, God! How fine! Did I really take it? How
18299. fortunate!" he thought.
18300. 
18301. Oh, how that chord vibrated, and how moved was something that was finest
18302. in Rostov's soul! And this something was apart from everything else
18303. in the world and above everything in the world. "What were losses, and
18304. Dolokhov, and words of honor?... All nonsense! One might kill and rob
18305. and yet be happy..."
18306. 
18307. 
18308. 
18309. 
18310. 
18311. CHAPTER XVI
18312. 
18313. 
18314. It was long since Rostov had felt such enjoyment from music as he did
18315. that day. But no sooner had Natasha finished her barcarolle than
18316. reality again presented itself. He got up without saying a word and went
18317. downstairs to his own room. A quarter of an hour later the old count
18318. came in from his Club, cheerful and contented. Nicholas, hearing him
18319. drive up, went to meet him.
18320. 
18321. "Well--had a good time?" said the old count, smiling gaily and proudly
18322. at his son.
18323. 
18324. Nicholas tried to say "Yes," but could not: and he nearly burst into
18325. sobs. The count was lighting his pipe and did not notice his son's
18326. condition.
18327. 
18328. "Ah, it can't be avoided!" thought Nicholas, for the first and last
18329. time. And suddenly, in the most casual tone, which made him feel ashamed
18330. of himself, he said, as if merely asking his father to let him have the
18331. carriage to drive to town:
18332. 
18333. "Papa, I have come on a matter of business. I was nearly forgetting. I
18334. need some money."
18335. 
18336. "Dear me!" said his father, who was in a specially good humor. "I told
18337. you it would not be enough. How much?"
18338. 
18339. "Very much," said Nicholas flushing, and with a stupid careless smile,
18340. for which he was long unable to forgive himself, "I have lost a little,
18341. I mean a good deal, a great deal--forty three thousand."
18342. 
18343. "What! To whom?... Nonsense!" cried the count, suddenly reddening with
18344. an apoplectic flush over neck and nape as old people do.
18345. 
18346. "I promised to pay tomorrow," said Nicholas.
18347. 
18348. "Well!..." said the old count, spreading out his arms and sinking
18349. helplessly on the sofa.
18350. 
18351. "It can't be helped It happens to everyone!" said the son, with a
18352. bold, free, and easy tone, while in his soul he regarded himself as a
18353. worthless scoundrel whose whole life could not atone for his crime. He
18354. longed to kiss his father's hands and kneel to beg his forgiveness, but
18355. said, in a careless and even rude voice, that it happens to everyone!
18356. 
18357. The old count cast down his eyes on hearing his son's words and began
18358. bustlingly searching for something.
18359. 
18360. "Yes, yes," he muttered, "it will be difficult, I fear, difficult to
18361. raise... happens to everybody! Yes, who has not done it?"
18362. 
18363. And with a furtive glance at his son's face, the count went out of the
18364. room.... Nicholas had been prepared for resistance, but had not at all
18365. expected this.
18366. 
18367. "Papa! Pa-pa!" he called after him, sobbing, "forgive me!" And seizing
18368. his father's hand, he pressed it to his lips and burst into tears.
18369. 
18370. While father and son were having their explanation, the mother and
18371. daughter were having one not less important. Natasha came running to her
18372. mother, quite excited.
18373. 
18374. "Mamma!... Mamma!... He has made me..."
18375. 
18376. "Made what?"
18377. 
18378. "Made, made me an offer, Mamma! Mamma!" she exclaimed.
18379. 
18380. The countess did not believe her ears. Denisov had proposed. To whom? To
18381. this chit of a girl, Natasha, who not so long ago was playing with dolls
18382. and who was still having lessons.
18383. 
18384. "Don't, Natasha! What nonsense!" she said, hoping it was a joke.
18385. 
18386. "Nonsense, indeed! I am telling you the fact," said Natasha indignantly.
18387. "I come to ask you what to do, and you call it 'nonsense!'"
18388. 
18389. The countess shrugged her shoulders.
18390. 
18391. "If it is true that Monsieur Denisov has made you a proposal, tell him
18392. he is a fool, that's all!"
18393. 
18394. "No, he's not a fool!" replied Natasha indignantly and seriously.
18395. 
18396. "Well then, what do you want? You're all in love nowadays. Well, if you
18397. are in love, marry him!" said the countess, with a laugh of annoyance.
18398. "Good luck to you!"
18399. 
18400. "No, Mamma, I'm not in love with him, I suppose I'm not in love with
18401. him."
18402. 
18403. "Well then, tell him so."
18404. 
18405. "Mamma, are you cross? Don't be cross, dear! Is it my fault?"
18406. 
18407. "No, but what is it, my dear? Do you want me to go and tell him?" said
18408. the countess smiling.
18409. 
18410. "No, I will do it myself, only tell me what to say. It's all very well
18411. for you," said Natasha, with a responsive smile. "You should have
18412. seen how he said it! I know he did not mean to say it, but it came out
18413. accidently."
18414. 
18415. "Well, all the same, you must refuse him."
18416. 
18417. "No, I mustn't. I am so sorry for him! He's so nice."
18418. 
18419. "Well then, accept his offer. It's high time for you to be married,"
18420. answered the countess sharply and sarcastically.
18421. 
18422. "No, Mamma, but I'm so sorry for him. I don't know how I'm to say it."
18423. 
18424. "And there's nothing for you to say. I shall speak to him myself," said
18425. the countess, indignant that they should have dared to treat this little
18426. Natasha as grown up.
18427. 
18428. "No, not on any account! I will tell him myself, and you'll listen at
18429. the door," and Natasha ran across the drawing room to the dancing hall,
18430. where Denisov was sitting on the same chair by the clavichord with his
18431. face in his hands.
18432. 
18433. He jumped up at the sound of her light step.
18434. 
18435. "Nataly," he said, moving with rapid steps toward her, "decide my fate.
18436. It is in your hands."
18437. 
18438. "Vasili Dmitrich, I'm so sorry for you!... No, but you are so nice...
18439. but it won't do...not that... but as a friend, I shall always love you."
18440. 
18441. Denisov bent over her hand and she heard strange sounds she did not
18442. understand. She kissed his rough curly black head. At this instant, they
18443. heard the quick rustle of the countess' dress. She came up to them.
18444. 
18445. "Vasili Dmitrich, I thank you for the honor," she said, with an
18446. embarrassed voice, though it sounded severe to Denisov--"but my daughter
18447. is so young, and I thought that, as my son's friend, you would have
18448. addressed yourself first to me. In that case you would not have obliged
18449. me to give this refusal."
18450. 
18451. "Countess..." said Denisov, with downcast eyes and a guilty face. He
18452. tried to say more, but faltered.
18453. 
18454. Natasha could not remain calm, seeing him in such a plight. She began to
18455. sob aloud.
18456. 
18457. "Countess, I have done w'ong," Denisov went on in an unsteady voice,
18458. "but believe me, I so adore your daughter and all your family that I
18459. would give my life twice over..." He looked at the countess, and seeing
18460. her severe face said: "Well, good-by, Countess," and kissing her
18461. hand, he left the room with quick resolute strides, without looking at
18462. Natasha.
18463. 
18464. 
18465. Next day Rostov saw Denisov off. He did not wish to stay another day in
18466. Moscow. All Denisov's Moscow friends gave him a farewell entertainment
18467. at the gypsies', with the result that he had no recollection of how he
18468. was put in the sleigh or of the first three stages of his journey.
18469. 
18470. After Denisov's departure, Rostov spent another fortnight in Moscow,
18471. without going out of the house, waiting for the money his father could
18472. not at once raise, and he spent most of his time in the girls' room.
18473. 
18474. Sonya was more tender and devoted to him than ever. It was as if she
18475. wanted to show him that his losses were an achievement that made her
18476. love him all the more, but Nicholas now considered himself unworthy of
18477. her.
18478. 
18479. He filled the girls' albums with verses and music, and having at last
18480. sent Dolokhov the whole forty-three thousand rubles and received his
18481. receipt, he left at the end of November, without taking leave of any of
18482. his acquaintances, to overtake his regiment which was already in Poland.
18483. 
18484. 
18485.

18488. BOOK FIVE: 1806 - 07
18489. 
18490. 
18491.
