18493. 
18494. CHAPTER I
18495. 
18496. 
18497. After his interview with his wife Pierre left for Petersburg. At the
18498. Torzhok post station, either there were no horses or the postmaster
18499. would not supply them. Pierre was obliged to wait. Without undressing,
18500. he lay down on the leather sofa in front of a round table, put his big
18501. feet in their overboots on the table, and began to reflect.
18502. 
18503. "Will you have the portmanteaus brought in? And a bed got ready, and
18504. tea?" asked his valet.
18505. 
18506. Pierre gave no answer, for he neither heard nor saw anything. He had
18507. begun to think of the last station and was still pondering on the same
18508. question--one so important that he took no notice of what went on around
18509. him. Not only was he indifferent as to whether he got to Petersburg
18510. earlier or later, or whether he secured accommodation at this station,
18511. but compared to the thoughts that now occupied him it was a matter of
18512. indifference whether he remained there for a few hours or for the rest
18513. of his life.
18514. 
18515. The postmaster, his wife, the valet, and a peasant woman selling Torzhok
18516. embroidery came into the room offering their services. Without changing
18517. his careless attitude, Pierre looked at them over his spectacles unable
18518. to understand what they wanted or how they could go on living without
18519. having solved the problems that so absorbed him. He had been engrossed
18520. by the same thoughts ever since the day he returned from Sokolniki after
18521. the duel and had spent that first agonizing, sleepless night. But now,
18522. in the solitude of the journey, they seized him with special force. No
18523. matter what he thought about, he always returned to these same questions
18524. which he could not solve and yet could not cease to ask himself. It was
18525. as if the thread of the chief screw which held his life together were
18526. stripped, so that the screw could not get in or out, but went on turning
18527. uselessly in the same place.
18528. 
18529. The postmaster came in and began obsequiously to beg his excellency to
18530. wait only two hours, when, come what might, he would let his excellency
18531. have the courier horses. It was plain that he was lying and only wanted
18532. to get more money from the traveler.
18533. 
18534. "Is this good or bad?" Pierre asked himself. "It is good for me, bad
18535. for another traveler, and for himself it's unavoidable, because he needs
18536. money for food; the man said an officer had once given him a thrashing
18537. for letting a private traveler have the courier horses. But the officer
18538. thrashed him because he had to get on as quickly as possible. And I,"
18539. continued Pierre, "shot Dolokhov because I considered myself injured,
18540. and Louis XVI was executed because they considered him a criminal, and
18541. a year later they executed those who executed him--also for some reason.
18542. What is bad? What is good? What should one love and what hate? What does
18543. one live for? And what am I? What is life, and what is death? What power
18544. governs all?"
18545. 
18546. There was no answer to any of these questions, except one, and that not
18547. a logical answer and not at all a reply to them. The answer was: "You'll
18548. die and all will end. You'll die and know all, or cease asking." But
18549. dying was also dreadful.
18550. 
18551. The Torzhok peddler woman, in a whining voice, went on offering her
18552. wares, especially a pair of goatskin slippers. "I have hundreds of
18553. rubles I don't know what to do with, and she stands in her tattered
18554. cloak looking timidly at me," he thought. "And what does she want the
18555. money for? As if that money could add a hair's breadth to happiness or
18556. peace of mind. Can anything in the world make her or me less a prey
18557. to evil and death?--death which ends all and must come today or
18558. tomorrow--at any rate, in an instant as compared with eternity." And
18559. again he twisted the screw with the stripped thread, and again it turned
18560. uselessly in the same place.
18561. 
18562. His servant handed him a half-cut novel, in the form of letters, by
18563. Madame de Souza. He began reading about the sufferings and virtuous
18564. struggles of a certain Emilie de Mansfeld. "And why did she resist her
18565. seducer when she loved him?" he thought. "God could not have put into
18566. her heart an impulse that was against His will. My wife--as she once
18567. was--did not struggle, and perhaps she was right. Nothing has been found
18568. out, nothing discovered," Pierre again said to himself. "All we can know
18569. is that we know nothing. And that's the height of human wisdom."
18570. 
18571. Everything within and around him seemed confused, senseless, and
18572. repellent. Yet in this very repugnance to all his circumstances Pierre
18573. found a kind of tantalizing satisfaction.
18574. 
18575. "I make bold to ask your excellency to move a little for this
18576. gentleman," said the postmaster, entering the room followed by another
18577. traveler, also detained for lack of horses.
18578. 
18579. The newcomer was a short, large-boned, yellow-faced, wrinkled old
18580. man, with gray bushy eyebrows overhanging bright eyes of an indefinite
18581. grayish color.
18582. 
18583. Pierre took his feet off the table, stood up, and lay down on a bed that
18584. had been got ready for him, glancing now and then at the newcomer, who,
18585. with a gloomy and tired face, was wearily taking off his wraps with the
18586. aid of his servant, and not looking at Pierre. With a pair of felt boots
18587. on his thin bony legs, and keeping on a worn, nankeen-covered, sheepskin
18588. coat, the traveler sat down on the sofa, leaned back his big head with
18589. its broad temples and close-cropped hair, and looked at Bezukhov. The
18590. stern, shrewd, and penetrating expression of that look struck Pierre. He
18591. felt a wish to speak to the stranger, but by the time he had made up his
18592. mind to ask him a question about the roads, the traveler had closed his
18593. eyes. His shriveled old hands were folded and on the finger of one of
18594. them Pierre noticed a large cast iron ring with a seal representing a
18595. death's head. The stranger sat without stirring, either resting or, as
18596. it seemed to Pierre, sunk in profound and calm meditation. His servant
18597. was also a yellow, wrinkled old man, without beard or mustache,
18598. evidently not because he was shaven but because they had never grown.
18599. This active old servant was unpacking the traveler's canteen and
18600. preparing tea. He brought in a boiling samovar. When everything was
18601. ready, the stranger opened his eyes, moved to the table, filled a
18602. tumbler with tea for himself and one for the beardless old man to whom
18603. he passed it. Pierre began to feel a sense of uneasiness, and the
18604. need, even the inevitability, of entering into conversation with this
18605. stranger.
18606. 
18607. The servant brought back his tumbler turned upside down, * with an
18608. unfinished bit of nibbled sugar, and asked if anything more would be
18609. wanted.
18610. 
18611. 
18612.     * To indicate he did not want more tea.
18613. 
18614. 
18615. "No. Give me the book," said the stranger.
18616. 
18617. The servant handed him a book which Pierre took to be a devotional work,
18618. and the traveler became absorbed in it. Pierre looked at him. All at
18619. once the stranger closed the book, putting in a marker, and again,
18620. leaning with his arms on the back of the sofa, sat in his former
18621. position with his eyes shut. Pierre looked at him and had not time
18622. to turn away when the old man, opening his eyes, fixed his steady and
18623. severe gaze straight on Pierre's face.
18624. 
18625. Pierre felt confused and wished to avoid that look, but the bright old
18626. eyes attracted him irresistibly.
18627. 
18628. 
18629. 
18630. 
18631. 
18632. CHAPTER II
18633. 
18634. 
18635. "I have the pleasure of addressing Count Bezukhov, if I am not
18636. mistaken," said the stranger in a deliberate and loud voice.
18637. 
18638. Pierre looked silently and inquiringly at him over his spectacles.
18639. 
18640. "I have heard of you, my dear sir," continued the stranger, "and of your
18641. misfortune." He seemed to emphasize the last word, as if to say--"Yes,
18642. misfortune! Call it what you please, I know that what happened to you in
18643. Moscow was a misfortune."--"I regret it very much, my dear sir."
18644. 
18645. Pierre flushed and, hurriedly putting his legs down from the bed, bent
18646. forward toward the old man with a forced and timid smile.
18647. 
18648. "I have not referred to this out of curiosity, my dear sir, but for
18649. greater reasons."
18650. 
18651. He paused, his gaze still on Pierre, and moved aside on the sofa by way
18652. of inviting the other to take a seat beside him. Pierre felt reluctant
18653. to enter into conversation with this old man, but, submitting to him
18654. involuntarily, came up and sat down beside him.
18655. 
18656. "You are unhappy, my dear sir," the stranger continued. "You are young
18657. and I am old. I should like to help you as far as lies in my power."
18658. 
18659. "Oh, yes!" said Pierre, with a forced smile. "I am very grateful to you.
18660. Where are you traveling from?"
18661. 
18662. The stranger's face was not genial, it was even cold and severe, but
18663. in spite of this, both the face and words of his new acquaintance were
18664. irresistibly attractive to Pierre.
18665. 
18666. "But if for reason you don't feel inclined to talk to me," said the old
18667. man, "say so, my dear sir." And he suddenly smiled, in an unexpected and
18668. tenderly paternal way.
18669. 
18670. "Oh no, not at all! On the contrary, I am very glad to make your
18671. acquaintance," said Pierre. And again, glancing at the stranger's hands,
18672. he looked more closely at the ring, with its skull--a Masonic sign.
18673. 
18674. "Allow me to ask," he said, "are you a Mason?"
18675. 
18676. "Yes, I belong to the Brotherhood of the Freemasons," said the stranger,
18677. looking deeper and deeper into Pierre's eyes. "And in their name and my
18678. own I hold out a brotherly hand to you."
18679. 
18680. "I am afraid," said Pierre, smiling, and wavering between the confidence
18681. the personality of the Freemason inspired in him and his own habit
18682. of ridiculing the Masonic beliefs--"I am afraid I am very far from
18683. understanding--how am I to put it?--I am afraid my way of looking at the
18684. world is so opposed to yours that we shall not understand one another."
18685. 
18686. "I know your outlook," said the Mason, "and the view of life you
18687. mention, and which you think is the result of your own mental efforts,
18688. is the one held by the majority of people, and is the invariable fruit
18689. of pride, indolence, and ignorance. Forgive me, my dear sir, but if I
18690. had not known it I should not have addressed you. Your view of life is a
18691. regrettable delusion."
18692. 
18693. "Just as I may suppose you to be deluded," said Pierre, with a faint
18694. smile.
18695. 
18696. "I should never dare to say that I know the truth," said the Mason,
18697. whose words struck Pierre more and more by their precision and firmness.
18698. "No one can attain to truth by himself. Only by laying stone on stone
18699. with the cooperation of all, by the millions of generations from our
18700. forefather Adam to our own times, is that temple reared which is to be a
18701. worthy dwelling place of the Great God," he added, and closed his eyes.
18702. 
18703. "I ought to tell you that I do not believe... do not believe in God,"
18704. said Pierre, regretfully and with an effort, feeling it essential to
18705. speak the whole truth.
18706. 
18707. The Mason looked intently at Pierre and smiled as a rich man with
18708. millions in hand might smile at a poor fellow who told him that he, poor
18709. man, had not the five rubles that would make him happy.
18710. 
18711. "Yes, you do not know Him, my dear sir," said the Mason. "You cannot
18712. know Him. You do not know Him and that is why you are unhappy."
18713. 
18714. "Yes, yes, I am unhappy," assented Pierre. "But what am I to do?"
18715. 
18716. "You know Him not, my dear sir, and so you are very unhappy. You do not
18717. know Him, but He is here, He is in me, He is in my words, He is in thee,
18718. and even in those blasphemous words thou hast just uttered!" pronounced
18719. the Mason in a stern and tremulous voice.
18720. 
18721. He paused and sighed, evidently trying to calm himself.
18722. 
18723. "If He were not," he said quietly, "you and I would not be speaking
18724. of Him, my dear sir. Of what, of whom, are we speaking? Whom hast thou
18725. denied?" he suddenly asked with exulting austerity and authority in
18726. his voice. "Who invented Him, if He did not exist? Whence came thy
18727. conception of the existence of such an incomprehensible Being? didst
18728. thou, and why did the whole world, conceive the idea of the existence
18729. of such an incomprehensible Being, a Being all-powerful, eternal, and
18730. infinite in all His attributes?..."
18731. 
18732. He stopped and remained silent for a long time.
18733. 
18734. Pierre could not and did not wish to break this silence.
18735. 
18736. "He exists, but to understand Him is hard," the Mason began again,
18737. looking not at Pierre but straight before him, and turning the leaves
18738. of his book with his old hands which from excitement he could not keep
18739. still. "If it were a man whose existence thou didst doubt I could bring
18740. him to thee, could take him by the hand and show him to thee. But how
18741. can I, an insignificant mortal, show His omnipotence, His infinity, and
18742. all His mercy to one who is blind, or who shuts his eyes that he may not
18743. see or understand Him and may not see or understand his own vileness and
18744. sinfulness?" He paused again. "Who art thou? Thou dreamest that thou art
18745. wise because thou couldst utter those blasphemous words," he went
18746. on, with a somber and scornful smile. "And thou art more foolish and
18747. unreasonable than a little child, who, playing with the parts of a
18748. skillfully made watch, dares to say that, as he does not understand
18749. its use, he does not believe in the master who made it. To know Him is
18750. hard.... For ages, from our forefather Adam to our own day, we labor to
18751. attain that knowledge and are still infinitely far from our aim; but
18752. in our lack of understanding we see only our weakness and His
18753. greatness...."
18754. 
18755. Pierre listened with swelling heart, gazing into the Mason's face with
18756. shining eyes, not interrupting or questioning him, but believing with
18757. his whole soul what the stranger said. Whether he accepted the wise
18758. reasoning contained in the Mason's words, or believed as a child
18759. believes, in the speaker's tone of conviction and earnestness, or the
18760. tremor of the speaker's voice--which sometimes almost broke--or those
18761. brilliant aged eyes grown old in this conviction, or the calm firmness
18762. and certainty of his vocation, which radiated from his whole being (and
18763. which struck Pierre especially by contrast with his own dejection and
18764. hopelessness)--at any rate, Pierre longed with his whole soul to believe
18765. and he did believe, and felt a joyful sense of comfort, regeneration,
18766. and return to life.
18767. 
18768. "He is not to be apprehended by reason, but by life," said the Mason.
18769. 
18770. "I do not understand," said Pierre, feeling with dismay doubts
18771. reawakening. He was afraid of any want of clearness, any weakness, in
18772. the Mason's arguments; he dreaded not to be able to believe in him.
18773. "I don't understand," he said, "how it is that the mind of man cannot
18774. attain the knowledge of which you speak."
18775. 
18776. The Mason smiled with his gentle fatherly smile.
18777. 
18778. "The highest wisdom and truth are like the purest liquid we may wish to
18779. imbibe," he said. "Can I receive that pure liquid into an impure vessel
18780. and judge of its purity? Only by the inner purification of myself can I
18781. retain in some degree of purity the liquid I receive."
18782. 
18783. "Yes, yes, that is so," said Pierre joyfully.
18784. 
18785. "The highest wisdom is not founded on reason alone, not on those worldly
18786. sciences of physics, history, chemistry, and the like, into which
18787. intellectual knowledge is divided. The highest wisdom is one. The
18788. highest wisdom has but one science--the science of the whole--the
18789. science explaining the whole creation and man's place in it. To receive
18790. that science it is necessary to purify and renew one's inner self, and
18791. so before one can know, it is necessary to believe and to perfect one's
18792. self. And to attain this end, we have the light called conscience that
18793. God has implanted in our souls."
18794. 
18795. "Yes, yes," assented Pierre.
18796. 
18797. "Look then at thy inner self with the eyes of the spirit, and ask
18798. thyself whether thou art content with thyself. What hast thou attained
18799. relying on reason only? What art thou? You are young, you are rich, you
18800. are clever, you are well educated. And what have you done with all these
18801. good gifts? Are you content with yourself and with your life?"
18802. 
18803. "No, I hate my life," Pierre muttered, wincing.
18804. 
18805. "Thou hatest it. Then change it, purify thyself; and as thou art
18806. purified, thou wilt gain wisdom. Look at your life, my dear sir.
18807. How have you spent it? In riotous orgies and debauchery, receiving
18808. everything from society and giving nothing in return. You have become
18809. the possessor of wealth. How have you used it? What have you done
18810. for your neighbor? Have you ever thought of your tens of thousands
18811. of slaves? Have you helped them physically and morally? No! You have
18812. profited by their toil to lead a profligate life. That is what you have
18813. done. Have you chosen a post in which you might be of service to your
18814. neighbor? No! You have spent your life in idleness. Then you married,
18815. my dear sir--took on yourself responsibility for the guidance of a young
18816. woman; and what have you done? You have not helped her to find the way
18817. of truth, my dear sir, but have thrust her into an abyss of deceit and
18818. misery. A man offended you and you shot him, and you say you do not know
18819. God and hate your life. There is nothing strange in that, my dear sir!"
18820. 
18821. After these words, the Mason, as if tired by his long discourse, again
18822. leaned his arms on the back of the sofa and closed his eyes. Pierre
18823. looked at that aged, stern, motionless, almost lifeless face and moved
18824. his lips without uttering a sound. He wished to say, "Yes, a vile, idle,
18825. vicious life!" but dared not break the silence.
18826. 
18827. The Mason cleared his throat huskily, as old men do, and called his
18828. servant.
18829. 
18830. "How about the horses?" he asked, without looking at Pierre.
18831. 
18832. "The exchange horses have just come," answered the servant. "Will you
18833. not rest here?"
18834. 
18835. "No, tell them to harness."
18836. 
18837. "Can he really be going away leaving me alone without having told me
18838. all, and without promising to help me?" thought Pierre, rising with
18839. downcast head; and he began to pace the room, glancing occasionally at
18840. the Mason. "Yes, I never thought of it, but I have led a contemptible
18841. and profligate life, though I did not like it and did not want to,"
18842. thought Pierre. "But this man knows the truth and, if he wished to,
18843. could disclose it to me."
18844. 
18845. Pierre wished to say this to the Mason, but did not dare to. The
18846. traveler, having packed his things with his practiced hands, began
18847. fastening his coat. When he had finished, he turned to Bezukhov, and
18848. said in a tone of indifferent politeness:
18849. 
18850. "Where are you going to now, my dear sir?"
18851. 
18852. "I?... I'm going to Petersburg," answered Pierre, in a childlike,
18853. hesitating voice. "I thank you. I agree with all you have said. But do
18854. not suppose me to be so bad. With my whole soul I wish to be what you
18855. would have me be, but I have never had help from anyone.... But it is
18856. I, above all, who am to blame for everything. Help me, teach me, and
18857. perhaps I may..."
18858. 
18859. Pierre could not go on. He gulped and turned away.
18860. 
18861. The Mason remained silent for a long time, evidently considering.
18862. 
18863. "Help comes from God alone," he said, "but such measure of help as
18864. our Order can bestow it will render you, my dear sir. You are going to
18865. Petersburg. Hand this to Count Willarski" (he took out his notebook and
18866. wrote a few words on a large sheet of paper folded in four). "Allow me
18867. to give you a piece of advice. When you reach the capital, first of all
18868. devote some time to solitude and self-examination and do not resume your
18869. former way of life. And now I wish you a good journey, my dear sir," he
18870. added, seeing that his servant had entered... "and success."
18871. 
18872. The traveler was Joseph Alexeevich Bazdeev, as Pierre saw from the
18873. postmaster's book. Bazdeev had been one of the best-known Freemasons and
18874. Martinists, even in Novikov's time. For a long while after he had gone,
18875. Pierre did not go to bed or order horses but paced up and down the room,
18876. pondering over his vicious past, and with a rapturous sense of beginning
18877. anew pictured to himself the blissful, irreproachable, virtuous future
18878. that seemed to him so easy. It seemed to him that he had been vicious
18879. only because he had somehow forgotten how good it is to be virtuous. Not
18880. a trace of his former doubts remained in his soul. He firmly believed
18881. in the possibility of the brotherhood of men united in the aim
18882. of supporting one another in the path of virtue, and that is how
18883. Freemasonry presented itself to him.
18884. 
18885. 
18886. 
18887. 
18888. 
18889. CHAPTER III
18890. 
18891. 
18892. On reaching Petersburg Pierre did not let anyone know of his arrival, he
18893. went nowhere and spent whole days in reading Thomas a Kempis, whose book
18894. had been sent him by someone unknown. One thing he continually realized
18895. as he read that book: the joy, hitherto unknown to him, of believing
18896. in the possibility of attaining perfection, and in the possibility of
18897. active brotherly love among men, which Joseph Alexeevich had revealed to
18898. him. A week after his arrival, the young Polish count, Willarski, whom
18899. Pierre had known slightly in Petersburg society, came into his room
18900. one evening in the official and ceremonious manner in which Dolokhov's
18901. second had called on him, and, having closed the door behind him and
18902. satisfied himself that there was nobody else in the room, addressed
18903. Pierre.
18904. 
18905. "I have come to you with a message and an offer, Count," he said without
18906. sitting down. "A person of very high standing in our Brotherhood has
18907. made application for you to be received into our Order before the usual
18908. term and has proposed to me to be your sponsor. I consider it a
18909. sacred duty to fulfill that person's wishes. Do you wish to enter the
18910. Brotherhood of Freemasons under my sponsorship?"
18911. 
18912. The cold, austere tone of this man, whom he had almost always before met
18913. at balls, amiably smiling in the society of the most brilliant women,
18914. surprised Pierre.
18915. 
18916. "Yes, I do wish it," said he.
18917. 
18918. Willarski bowed his head.
18919. 
18920. "One more question, Count," he said, "which I beg you to answer in
18921. all sincerity--not as a future Mason but as an honest man: have you
18922. renounced your former convictions--do you believe in God?"
18923. 
18924. Pierre considered.
18925. 
18926. "Yes... yes, I believe in God," he said.
18927. 
18928. "In that case..." began Willarski, but Pierre interrupted him.
18929. 
18930. "Yes, I do believe in God," he repeated.
18931. 
18932. "In that case we can go," said Willarski. "My carriage is at your
18933. service."
18934. 
18935. Willarski was silent throughout the drive. To Pierre's inquiries as to
18936. what he must do and how he should answer, Willarski only replied that
18937. brothers more worthy than he would test him and that Pierre had only to
18938. tell the truth.
18939. 
18940. Having entered the courtyard of a large house where the Lodge had its
18941. headquarters, and having ascended a dark staircase, they entered a small
18942. well-lit anteroom where they took off their cloaks without the aid of
18943. a servant. From there they passed into another room. A man in strange
18944. attire appeared at the door. Willarski, stepping toward him, said
18945. something to him in French in an undertone and then went up to a small
18946. wardrobe in which Pierre noticed garments such as he had never seen
18947. before. Having taken a kerchief from the cupboard, Willarski bound
18948. Pierre's eyes with it and tied it in a knot behind, catching some hairs
18949. painfully in the knot. Then he drew his face down, kissed him, and
18950. taking him by the hand led him forward. The hairs tied in the knot hurt
18951. Pierre and there were lines of pain on his face and a shamefaced smile.
18952. His huge figure, with arms hanging down and with a puckered, though
18953. smiling face, moved after Willarski with uncertain, timid steps.
18954. 
18955. Having led him about ten paces, Willarski stopped.
18956. 
18957. "Whatever happens to you," he said, "you must bear it all manfully
18958. if you have firmly resolved to join our Brotherhood." (Pierre nodded
18959. affirmatively.) "When you hear a knock at the door, you will uncover
18960. your eyes," added Willarski. "I wish you courage and success," and,
18961. pressing Pierre's hand, he went out.
18962. 
18963. Left alone, Pierre went on smiling in the same way. Once or twice he
18964. shrugged his and raised his hand to the kerchief, as if wishing to take
18965. it off, but let it drop again. The five minutes spent with his eyes
18966. bandaged seemed to him an hour. His arms felt numb, his legs almost gave
18967. way, it seemed to him that he was tired out. He experienced a variety of
18968. most complex sensations. He felt afraid of what would happen to him and
18969. still more afraid of showing his fear. He felt curious to know what was
18970. going to happen and what would be revealed to him; but most of all, he
18971. felt joyful that the moment had come when he would at last start on that
18972. path of regeneration and on the actively virtuous life of which he had
18973. been dreaming since he met Joseph Alexeevich. Loud knocks were heard at
18974. the door. Pierre took the bandage off his eyes and glanced around him.
18975. The room was in black darkness, only a small lamp was burning inside
18976. something white. Pierre went nearer and saw that the lamp stood on a
18977. black table on which lay an open book. The book was the Gospel, and the
18978. white thing with the lamp inside was a human skull with its cavities and
18979. teeth. After reading the first words of the Gospel: "In the beginning
18980. was the Word and the Word was with God," Pierre went round the table and
18981. saw a large open box filled with something. It was a coffin with bones
18982. inside. He was not at all surprised by what he saw. Hoping to enter on
18983. an entirely new life quite unlike the old one, he expected everything
18984. to be unusual, even more unusual than what he was seeing. A skull, a
18985. coffin, the Gospel--it seemed to him that he had expected all this and
18986. even more. Trying to stimulate his emotions he looked around. "God,
18987. death, love, the brotherhood of man," he kept saying to himself,
18988. associating these words with vague yet joyful ideas. The door opened and
18989. someone came in.
18990. 
18991. By the dim light, to which Pierre had already become accustomed, he
18992. saw rather short man. Having evidently come from the light into the
18993. darkness, the man paused, then moved with cautious steps toward the
18994. table and placed on it his small leather-gloved hands.
18995. 
18996. This short man had on a white leather apron which covered his chest and
18997. part of his legs; he had on a kind of necklace above which rose a high
18998. white ruffle, outlining his rather long face which was lit up from
18999. below.
19000. 
19001. "For what have you come hither?" asked the newcomer, turning in Pierre's
19002. direction at a slight rustle made by the latter. "Why have you, who do
19003. not believe in the truth of the light and who have not seen the light,
19004. come here? What do you seek from us? Wisdom, virtue, enlightenment?"
19005. 
19006. At the moment the door opened and the stranger came in, Pierre felt a
19007. sense of awe and veneration such as he had experienced in his boyhood at
19008. confession; he felt himself in the presence of one socially a complete
19009. stranger, yet nearer to him through the brotherhood of man. With bated
19010. breath and beating heart he moved toward the Rhetor (by which name the
19011. brother who prepared a seeker for entrance into the Brotherhood was
19012. known). Drawing nearer, he recognized in the Rhetor a man he knew,
19013. Smolyaninov, and it mortified him to think that the newcomer was an
19014. acquaintance--he wished him simply a brother and a virtuous instructor.
19015. For a long time he could not utter a word, so that the Rhetor had to
19016. repeat his question.
19017. 
19018. "Yes... I... I... desire regeneration," Pierre uttered with difficulty.
19019. 
19020. "Very well," said Smolyaninov, and went on at once: "Have you any idea
19021. of the means by which our holy Order will help you to reach your aim?"
19022. said he quietly and quickly.
19023. 
19024. "I... hope... for guidance... help... in regeneration," said Pierre,
19025. with a trembling voice and some difficulty in utterance due to his
19026. excitement and to being unaccustomed to speak of abstract matters in
19027. Russian.
19028. 
19029. "What is your conception of Freemasonry?"
19030. 
19031. "I imagine that Freemasonry is the fraternity and equality of men who
19032. have virtuous aims," said Pierre, feeling ashamed of the inadequacy of
19033. his words for the solemnity of the moment, as he spoke. "I imagine..."
19034. 
19035. "Good!" said the Rhetor quickly, apparently satisfied with this answer.
19036. "Have you sought for means of attaining your aim in religion?"
19037. 
19038. "No, I considered it erroneous and did not follow it," said Pierre,
19039. so softly that the Rhetor did not hear him and asked him what he was
19040. saying. "I have been an atheist," answered Pierre.
19041. 
19042. "You are seeking for truth in order to follow its laws in your life,
19043. therefore you seek wisdom and virtue. Is that not so?" said the Rhetor,
19044. after a moment's pause.
19045. 
19046. "Yes, yes," assented Pierre.
19047. 
19048. The Rhetor cleared his throat, crossed his gloved hands on his breast,
19049. and began to speak.
19050. 
19051. "Now I must disclose to you the chief aim of our Order," he said, "and
19052. if this aim coincides with yours, you may enter our Brotherhood with
19053. profit. The first and chief object of our Order, the foundation on which
19054. it rests and which no human power can destroy, is the preservation and
19055. handing on to posterity of a certain important mystery... which has come
19056. down to us from the remotest ages, even from the first man--a mystery on
19057. which perhaps the fate of mankind depends. But since this mystery is of
19058. such a nature that nobody can know or use it unless he be prepared by
19059. long and diligent self-purification, not everyone can hope to attain it
19060. quickly. Hence we have a secondary aim, that of preparing our members as
19061. much as possible to reform their hearts, to purify and enlighten their
19062. minds, by means handed on to us by tradition from those who have striven
19063. to attain this mystery, and thereby to render them capable of receiving
19064. it.
19065. 
19066. "By purifying and regenerating our members we try, thirdly, to improve
19067. the whole human race, offering it in our members an example of piety
19068. and virtue, and thereby try with all our might to combat the evil which
19069. sways the world. Think this over and I will come to you again."
19070. 
19071. "To combat the evil which sways the world..." Pierre repeated, and a
19072. mental image of his future activity in this direction rose in his mind.
19073. He imagined men such as he had himself been a fortnight ago, and he
19074. addressed an edifying exhortation to them. He imagined to himself
19075. vicious and unfortunate people whom he would assist by word and deed,
19076. imagined oppressors whose victims he would rescue. Of the three
19077. objects mentioned by the Rhetor, this last, that of improving mankind,
19078. especially appealed to Pierre. The important mystery mentioned by the
19079. Rhetor, though it aroused his curiosity, did not seem to him essential,
19080. and the second aim, that of purifying and regenerating himself, did not
19081. much interest him because at that moment he felt with delight that he
19082. was already perfectly cured of his former faults and was ready for all
19083. that was good.
19084. 
19085. Half an hour later, the Rhetor returned to inform the seeker of the
19086. seven virtues, corresponding to the seven steps of Solomon's temple,
19087. which every Freemason should cultivate in himself. These virtues were:
19088. 1. Discretion, the keeping of the secrets of the Order. 2. Obedience to
19089. those of higher ranks in the Order.  3. Morality.  4. Love of mankind.
19090. 5. Courage. 6. Generosity. 7. The love of death.
19091. 
19092. "In the seventh place, try, by the frequent thought of death," the
19093. Rhetor said, "to bring yourself to regard it not as a dreaded foe, but
19094. as a friend that frees the soul grown weary in the labors of virtue
19095. from this distressful life, and leads it to its place of recompense and
19096. peace."
19097. 
19098. "Yes, that must be so," thought Pierre, when after these words the
19099. Rhetor went away, leaving him to solitary meditation. "It must be so,
19100. but I am still so weak that I love my life, the meaning of which is only
19101. now gradually opening before me." But five of the other virtues which
19102. Pierre recalled, counting them on his fingers, he felt already in his
19103. soul: courage, generosity, morality, love of mankind, and especially
19104. obedience--which did not even seem to him a virtue, but a joy. (He now
19105. felt so glad to be free from his own lawlessness and to submit his will
19106. to those who knew the indubitable truth.) He forgot what the seventh
19107. virtue was and could not recall it.
19108. 
19109. The third time the Rhetor came back more quickly and asked Pierre
19110. whether he was still firm in his intention and determined to submit to
19111. all that would be required of him.
19112. 
19113. "I am ready for everything," said Pierre.
19114. 
19115. "I must also inform you," said the Rhetor, "that our Order delivers its
19116. teaching not in words only but also by other means, which may perhaps
19117. have a stronger effect on the sincere seeker after wisdom and virtue
19118. than mere words. This chamber with what you see therein should already
19119. have suggested to your heart, if it is sincere, more than words could
19120. do. You will perhaps also see in your further initiation a like
19121. method of enlightenment. Our Order imitates the ancient societies that
19122. explained their teaching by hieroglyphics. A hieroglyph," said the
19123. Rhetor, "is an emblem of something not cognizable by the senses but
19124. which possesses qualities resembling those of the symbol."
19125. 
19126. Pierre knew very well what a hieroglyph was, but dared not speak. He
19127. listened to the Rhetor in silence, feeling from all he said that his
19128. ordeal was about to begin.
19129. 
19130. "If you are resolved, I must begin your initiation," said the Rhetor
19131. coming closer to Pierre. "In token of generosity I ask you to give me
19132. all your valuables."
19133. 
19134. "But I have nothing here," replied Pierre, supposing that he was asked
19135. to give up all he possessed.
19136. 
19137. "What you have with you: watch, money, rings...."
19138. 
19139. Pierre quickly took out his purse and watch, but could not manage for
19140. some time to get the wedding ring off his fat finger. When that had been
19141. done, the Rhetor said:
19142. 
19143. "In token of obedience, I ask you to undress."
19144. 
19145. Pierre took off his coat, waistcoat, and left boot according to the
19146. Rhetor's instructions. The Mason drew the shirt back from Pierre's left
19147. breast, and stooping down pulled up the left leg of his trousers to
19148. above the knee. Pierre hurriedly began taking off his right boot also
19149. and was going to tuck up the other trouser leg to save this stranger the
19150. trouble, but the Mason told him that was not necessary and gave him
19151. a slipper for his left foot. With a childlike smile of embarrassment,
19152. doubt, and self-derision, which appeared on his face against his will,
19153. Pierre stood with his arms hanging down and legs apart, before his
19154. brother Rhetor, and awaited his further commands.
19155. 
19156. "And now, in token of candor, I ask you to reveal to me your chief
19157. passion," said the latter.
19158. 
19159. "My passion! I have had so many," replied Pierre.
19160. 
19161. "That passion which more than all others caused you to waver on the path
19162. of virtue," said the Mason.
19163. 
19164. Pierre paused, seeking a reply.
19165. 
19166. "Wine? Gluttony? Idleness? Laziness? Irritability? Anger? Women?" He
19167. went over his vices in his mind, not knowing to which of them to give
19168. the pre-eminence.
19169. 
19170. "Women," he said in a low, scarcely audible voice.
19171. 
19172. The Mason did not move and for a long time said nothing after this
19173. answer. At last he moved up to Pierre and, taking the kerchief that lay
19174. on the table, again bound his eyes.
19175. 
19176. "For the last time I say to you--turn all your attention upon yourself,
19177. put a bridle on your senses, and seek blessedness, not in passion but
19178. in your own heart. The source of blessedness is not without us but
19179. within...."
19180. 
19181. Pierre had already long been feeling in himself that refreshing source
19182. of blessedness which now flooded his heart with glad emotion.
19183. 
19184. 
19185. 
19186. 
19187. 
19188. CHAPTER IV
19189. 
19190. 
19191. Soon after this there came into the dark chamber to fetch Pierre, not
19192. the Rhetor but Pierre's sponsor, Willarski, whom he recognized by his
19193. voice. To fresh questions as to the firmness of his resolution Pierre
19194. replied: "Yes, yes, I agree," and with a beaming, childlike smile, his
19195. fat chest uncovered, stepping unevenly and timidly in one slippered and
19196. one booted foot, he advanced, while Willarski held a sword to his
19197. bare chest. He was conducted from that room along passages that turned
19198. backwards and forwards and was at last brought to the doors of the
19199. Lodge. Willarski coughed, he was answered by the Masonic knock with
19200. mallets, the doors opened before them. A bass voice (Pierre was still
19201. blindfolded) questioned him as to who he was, when and where he was
19202. born, and so on. Then he was again led somewhere still blindfolded,
19203. and as they went along he was told allegories of the toils of his
19204. pilgrimage, of holy friendship, of the Eternal Architect of the
19205. universe, and of the courage with which he should endure toils and
19206. dangers. During these wanderings, Pierre noticed that he was spoken of
19207. now as the "Seeker," now as the "Sufferer," and now as the "Postulant,"
19208. to the accompaniment of various knockings with mallets and swords. As he
19209. was being led up to some object he noticed a hesitation and uncertainty
19210. among his conductors. He heard those around him disputing in whispers
19211. and one of them insisting that he should be led along a certain carpet.
19212. After that they took his right hand, placed it on something, and told
19213. him to hold a pair of compasses to his left breast with the other hand
19214. and to repeat after someone who read aloud an oath of fidelity to the
19215. laws of the Order. The candles were then extinguished and some spirit
19216. lighted, as Pierre knew by the smell, and he was told that he would now
19217. see the lesser light. The bandage was taken off his eyes and, by the
19218. faint light of the burning spirit, Pierre, as in a dream, saw several
19219. men standing before him, wearing aprons like the Rhetor's and holding
19220. swords in their hands pointed at his breast. Among them stood a man
19221. whose white shirt was stained with blood. On seeing this, Pierre moved
19222. forward with his breast toward the swords, meaning them to pierce it.
19223. But the swords were drawn back from him and he was at once blindfolded
19224. again.
19225. 
19226. "Now thou hast seen the lesser light," uttered a voice. Then the candles
19227. were relit and he was told that he would see the full light; the bandage
19228. was again removed and more than ten voices said together: "Sic transit
19229. gloria mundi."
19230. 
19231. Pierre gradually began to recover himself and looked about at the room
19232. and at the people in it. Round a long table covered with black sat some
19233. twelve men in garments like those he had already seen. Some of them
19234. Pierre had met in Petersburg society. In the President's chair sat a
19235. young man he did not know, with a peculiar cross hanging from his neck.
19236. On his right sat the Italian abbe whom Pierre had met at Anna Pavlovna's
19237. two years before. There were also present a very distinguished dignitary
19238. and a Swiss who had formerly been tutor at the Kuragins'. All maintained
19239. a solemn silence, listening to the words of the President, who held a
19240. mallet in his hand. Let into the wall was a star-shaped light. At one
19241. side of the table was a small carpet with various figures worked upon
19242. it, at the other was something resembling an altar on which lay a
19243. Testament and a skull. Round it stood seven large candlesticks like
19244. those used in churches. Two of the brothers led Pierre up to the altar,
19245. placed his feet at right angles, and bade him lie down, saying that he
19246. must prostrate himself at the Gates of the Temple.
19247. 
19248. "He must first receive the trowel," whispered one of the brothers.
19249. 
19250. "Oh, hush, please!" said another.
19251. 
19252. Pierre, perplexed, looked round with his shortsighted eyes without
19253. obeying, and suddenly doubts arose in his mind. "Where am I? What am
19254. I doing? Aren't they laughing at me? Shan't I be ashamed to remember
19255. this?" But these doubts only lasted a moment. Pierre glanced at the
19256. serious faces of those around, remembered all he had already gone
19257. through, and realized that he could not stop halfway. He was aghast
19258. at his hesitation and, trying to arouse his former devotional feeling,
19259. prostrated himself before the Gates of the Temple. And really, the
19260. feeling of devotion returned to him even more strongly than before. When
19261. he had lain there some time, he was told to get up, and a white leather
19262. apron, such as the others wore, was put on him: he was given a trowel
19263. and three pairs of gloves, and then the Grand Master addressed him. He
19264. told him that he should try to do nothing to stain the whiteness of that
19265. apron, which symbolized strength and purity; then of the unexplained
19266. trowel, he told him to toil with it to cleanse his own heart from vice,
19267. and indulgently to smooth with it the heart of his neighbor. As to the
19268. first pair of gloves, a man's, he said that Pierre could not know their
19269. meaning but must keep them. The second pair of man's gloves he was
19270. to wear at the meetings, and finally of the third, a pair of women's
19271. gloves, he said: "Dear brother, these woman's gloves are intended for
19272. you too. Give them to the woman whom you shall honor most of all. This
19273. gift will be a pledge of your purity of heart to her whom you select to
19274. be your worthy helpmeet in Masonry." And after a pause, he added: "But
19275. beware, dear brother, that these gloves do not deck hands that are
19276. unclean." While the Grand Master said these last words it seemed
19277. to Pierre that he grew embarrassed. Pierre himself grew still more
19278. confused, blushed like a child till tears came to his eyes, began
19279. looking about him uneasily, and an awkward pause followed.
19280. 
19281. This silence was broken by one of the brethren, who led Pierre up to the
19282. rug and began reading to him from a manuscript book an explanation of
19283. all the figures on it: the sun, the moon, a hammer, a plumb line, a
19284. trowel, a rough stone and a squared stone, a pillar, three windows, and
19285. so on. Then a place was assigned to Pierre, he was shown the signs of
19286. the Lodge, told the password, and at last was permitted to sit down.
19287. The Grand Master began reading the statutes. They were very long, and
19288. Pierre, from joy, agitation, and embarrassment, was not in a state to
19289. understand what was being read. He managed to follow only the last words
19290. of the statutes and these remained in his mind.
19291. 
19292. "In our temples we recognize no other distinctions," read the Grand
19293. Master, "but those between virtue and vice. Beware of making any
19294. distinctions which may infringe equality. Fly to a brother's aid whoever
19295. he may be, exhort him who goeth astray, raise him that falleth, never
19296. bear malice or enmity toward thy brother. Be kindly and courteous.
19297. Kindle in all hearts the flame of virtue. Share thy happiness with thy
19298. neighbor, and may envy never dim the purity of that bliss. Forgive thy
19299. enemy, do not avenge thyself except by doing him good. Thus fulfilling
19300. the highest law thou shalt regain traces of the ancient dignity which
19301. thou hast lost."
19302. 
19303. He finished and, getting up, embraced and kissed Pierre, who, with tears
19304. of joy in his eyes, looked round him, not knowing how to answer the
19305. congratulations and greetings from acquaintances that met him on all
19306. sides. He acknowledged no acquaintances but saw in all these men only
19307. brothers, and burned with impatience to set to work with them.
19308. 
19309. The Grand Master rapped with his mallet. All the Masons sat down in
19310. their places, and one of them read an exhortation on the necessity of
19311. humility.
19312. 
19313. The Grand Master proposed that the last duty should be performed, and
19314. the distinguished dignitary who bore the title of "Collector of Alms"
19315. went round to all the brothers. Pierre would have liked to subscribe all
19316. he had, but fearing that it might look like pride subscribed the same
19317. amount as the others.
19318. 
19319. The meeting was at an end, and on reaching home Pierre felt as if he had
19320. returned from a long journey on which he had spent dozens of years, had
19321. become completely changed, and had quite left behind his former habits
19322. and way of life.
19323. 
19324. 
19325. 
19326. 
19327. 
19328. CHAPTER V
19329. 
19330. 
19331. The day after he had been received into the Lodge, Pierre was sitting at
19332. home reading a book and trying to fathom the significance of the Square,
19333. one side of which symbolized God, another moral things, a third
19334. physical things, and the fourth a combination of these. Now and then
19335. his attention wandered from the book and the Square and he formed in
19336. imagination a new plan of life. On the previous evening at the Lodge, he
19337. had heard that a rumor of his duel had reached the Emperor and that it
19338. would be wiser for him to leave Petersburg. Pierre proposed going to his
19339. estates in the south and there attending to the welfare of his serfs. He
19340. was joyfully planning this new life, when Prince Vasili suddenly entered
19341. the room.
19342. 
19343. "My dear fellow, what have you been up to in Moscow? Why have you
19344. quarreled with Helene, mon cher? You are under a delusion," said
19345. Prince Vasili, as he entered. "I know all about it, and I can tell you
19346. positively that Helene is as innocent before you as Christ was before
19347. the Jews."
19348. 
19349. Pierre was about to reply, but Prince Vasili interrupted him.
19350. 
19351. "And why didn't you simply come straight to me as to a friend? I know
19352. all about it and understand it all," he said. "You behaved as becomes
19353. a man who values his honor, perhaps too hastily, but we won't go into
19354. that. But consider the position in which you are placing her and me
19355. in the eyes of society, and even of the court," he added, lowering his
19356. voice. "She is living in Moscow and you are here. Remember, dear boy,"
19357. and he drew Pierre's arm downwards, "it is simply a misunderstanding. I
19358. expect you feel it so yourself. Let us write her a letter at once, and
19359. she'll come here and all will be explained, or else, my dear boy, let me
19360. tell you it's quite likely you'll have to suffer for it."
19361. 
19362. Prince Vasili gave Pierre a significant look.
19363. 
19364. "I know from reliable sources that the Dowager Empress is taking a keen
19365. interest in the whole affair. You know she is very gracious to Helene."
19366. 
19367. Pierre tried several times to speak, but, on one hand, Prince Vasili did
19368. not let him and, on the other, Pierre himself feared to begin to speak
19369. in the tone of decided refusal and disagreement in which he had firmly
19370. resolved to answer his father-in-law. Moreover, the words of the Masonic
19371. statutes, "be kindly and courteous," recurred to him. He blinked, went
19372. red, got up and sat down again, struggling with himself to do what was
19373. for him the most difficult thing in life--to say an unpleasant thing
19374. to a man's face, to say what the other, whoever he might be, did not
19375. expect. He was so used to submitting to Prince Vasili's tone of careless
19376. self-assurance that he felt he would be unable to withstand it now, but
19377. he also felt that on what he said now his future depended--whether he
19378. would follow the same old road, or that new path so attractively shown
19379. him by the Masons, on which he firmly believed he would be reborn to a
19380. new life.
19381. 
19382. "Now, dear boy," said Prince Vasili playfully, "say 'yes,' and I'll
19383. write to her myself, and we will kill the fatted calf."
19384. 
19385. But before Prince Vasili had finished his playful speech, Pierre,
19386. without looking at him, and with a kind of fury that made him like his
19387. father, muttered in a whisper:
19388. 
19389. "Prince, I did not ask you here. Go, please go!" And he jumped up and
19390. opened the door for him.
19391. 
19392. "Go!" he repeated, amazed at himself and glad to see the look of
19393. confusion and fear that showed itself on Prince Vasili's face.
19394. 
19395. "What's the matter with you? Are you ill?"
19396. 
19397. "Go!" the quivering voice repeated. And Prince Vasili had to go without
19398. receiving any explanation.
19399. 
19400. A week later, Pierre, having taken leave of his new friends, the Masons,
19401. and leaving large sums of money with them for alms, went away to his
19402. estates. His new brethren gave him letters to the Kiev and Odessa Masons
19403. and promised to write to him and guide him in his new activity.
19404.

19409. CHAPTER VI
19410. 
19411. 
19412. The duel between Pierre and Dolokhov was hushed up and, in spite of the
19413. Emperor's severity regarding duels at that time, neither the principals
19414. nor their seconds suffered for it. But the story of the duel, confirmed
19415. by Pierre's rupture with his wife, was the talk of society. Pierre
19416. who had been regarded with patronizing condescension when he was an
19417. illegitimate son, and petted and extolled when he was the best match
19418. in Russia, had sunk greatly in the esteem of society after his
19419. marriage--when the marriageable daughters and their mothers had nothing
19420. to hope from him--especially as he did not know how, and did not wish,
19421. to court society's favor. Now he alone was blamed for what had happened,
19422. he was said to be insanely jealous and subject like his father to fits
19423. of bloodthirsty rage. And when after Pierre's departure Helene returned
19424. to Petersburg, she was received by all her acquaintances not only
19425. cordially, but even with a shade of deference due to her misfortune.
19426. When conversation turned on her husband Helene assumed a dignified
19427. expression, which with characteristic tact she had acquired though she
19428. did not understand its significance. This expression suggested that she
19429. had resolved to endure her troubles uncomplainingly and that her husband
19430. was a cross laid upon her by God. Prince Vasili expressed his opinion
19431. more openly. He shrugged his shoulders when Pierre was mentioned and,
19432. pointing to his forehead, remarked:
19433. 
19434. "A bit touched--I always said so."
19435. 
19436. "I said from the first," declared Anna Pavlovna referring to Pierre, "I
19437. said at the time and before anyone else" (she insisted on her priority)
19438. "that that senseless young man was spoiled by the depraved ideas of
19439. these days. I said so even at the time when everybody was in raptures
19440. about him, when he had just returned from abroad, and when, if you
19441. remember, he posed as a sort of Marat at one of my soirees. And how has
19442. it ended? I was against this marriage even then and foretold all that
19443. has happened."
19444. 
19445. Anna Pavlovna continued to give on free evenings the same kind of
19446. soirees as before--such as she alone had the gift of arranging--at which
19447. was to be found "the cream of really good society, the bloom of the
19448. intellectual essence of Petersburg," as she herself put it. Besides
19449. this refined selection of society Anna Pavlovna's receptions were
19450. also distinguished by the fact that she always presented some new and
19451. interesting person to the visitors and that nowhere else was the state
19452. of the political thermometer of legitimate Petersburg court society so
19453. dearly and distinctly indicated.
19454. 
19455. Toward the end of 1806, when all the sad details of Napoleon's
19456. destruction of the Prussian army at Jena and Auerstadt and the surrender
19457. of most of the Prussian fortresses had been received, when our troops
19458. had already entered Prussia and our second war with Napoleon was
19459. beginning, Anna Pavlovna gave one of her soirees. The "cream of really
19460. good society" consisted of the fascinating Helene, forsaken by her
19461. husband, Mortemart, the delightful Prince Hippolyte who had just
19462. returned from Vienna, two diplomatists, the old aunt, a young man
19463. referred to in that drawing room as "a man of great merit" (un homme de
19464. beaucoup de merite), a newly appointed maid of honor and her mother, and
19465. several other less noteworthy persons.
19466. 
19467. The novelty Anna Pavlovna was setting before her guests that evening was
19468. Boris Drubetskoy, who had just arrived as a special messenger from the
19469. Prussian army and was aide-de-camp to a very important personage.
19470. 
19471. The temperature shown by the political thermometer to the company that
19472. evening was this:
19473. 
19474. "Whatever the European sovereigns and commanders may do to countenance
19475. Bonaparte, and to cause me, and us in general, annoyance and
19476. mortification, our opinion of Bonaparte cannot alter. We shall not cease
19477. to express our sincere views on that subject, and can only say to the
19478. King of Prussia and others: 'So much the worse for you. Tu l'as voulu,
19479. George Dandin,' that's all we have to say about it!"
19480. 
19481. When Boris, who was to be served up to the guests, entered the drawing
19482. room, almost all the company had assembled, and the conversation, guided
19483. by Anna Pavlovna, was about our diplomatic relations with Austria and
19484. the hope of an alliance with her.
19485. 
19486. Boris, grown more manly and looking fresh, rosy and self-possessed,
19487. entered the drawing room elegantly dressed in the uniform of an
19488. aide-de-camp and was duly conducted to pay his respects to the aunt and
19489. then brought back to the general circle.
19490. 
19491. Anna Pavlovna gave him her shriveled hand to kiss and introduced him to
19492. several persons whom he did not know, giving him a whispered description
19493. of each.
19494. 
19495. "Prince Hippolyte Kuragin, M. Krug, the charge d'affaires from
19496. Copenhagen--a profound intellect," and simply, "Mr. Shitov--a man of
19497. great merit"--this of the man usually so described.
19498. 
19499. Thanks to Anna Mikhaylovna's efforts, his own tastes, and the
19500. peculiarities of his reserved nature, Boris had managed during his
19501. service to place himself very advantageously. He was aide-de-camp to a
19502. very important personage, had been sent on a very important mission to
19503. Prussia, and had just returned from there as a special messenger. He had
19504. become thoroughly conversant with that unwritten code with which he had
19505. been so pleased at Olmutz and according to which an ensign might rank
19506. incomparably higher than a general, and according to which what was
19507. needed for success in the service was not effort or work, or courage, or
19508. perseverance, but only the knowledge of how to get on with those who can
19509. grant rewards, and he was himself often surprised at the rapidity of his
19510. success and at the inability of others to understand these things.
19511. In consequence of this discovery his whole manner of life, all
19512. his relations with old friends, all his plans for his future, were
19513. completely altered. He was not rich, but would spend his last groat to
19514. be better dressed than others, and would rather deprive himself of many
19515. pleasures than allow himself to be seen in a shabby equipage or appear
19516. in the streets of Petersburg in an old uniform. He made friends with
19517. and sought the acquaintance of only those above him in position and
19518. who could therefore be of use to him. He liked Petersburg and despised
19519. Moscow. The remembrance of the Rostovs' house and of his childish love
19520. for Natasha was unpleasant to him and he had not once been to see the
19521. Rostovs since the day of his departure for the army. To be in Anna
19522. Pavlovna's drawing room he considered an important step up in the
19523. service, and he at once understood his role, letting his hostess make
19524. use of whatever interest he had to offer. He himself carefully scanned
19525. each face, appraising the possibilities of establishing intimacy with
19526. each of those present, and the advantages that might accrue. He took the
19527. seat indicated to him beside the fair Helene and listened to the general
19528. conversation.
19529. 
19530. "Vienna considers the bases of the proposed treaty so unattainable that
19531. not even a continuity of most brilliant successes would secure them, and
19532. she doubts the means we have of gaining them. That is the actual phrase
19533. used by the Vienna cabinet," said the Danish charge d'affaires.
19534. 
19535. "The doubt is flattering," said "the man of profound intellect," with a
19536. subtle smile.
19537. 
19538. "We must distinguish between the Vienna cabinet and the Emperor of
19539. Austria," said Mortemart. "The Emperor of Austria can never have thought
19540. of such a thing, it is only the cabinet that says it."
19541. 
19542. "Ah, my dear vicomte," put in Anna Pavlovna, "L'Urope" (for some
19543. reason she called it Urope as if that were a specially refined French
19544. pronunciation which she could allow herself when conversing with a
19545. Frenchman), "L'Urope ne sera jamais notre alliee sincere." *
19546. 
19547. 
19548.     * "Europe will never be our sincere ally."
19549. 
19550. 
19551. After that Anna Pavlovna led up to the courage and firmness of the King

19553. 
19554. Boris listened attentively to each of the speakers, awaiting his turn,
19555. but managed meanwhile to look round repeatedly at his neighbor, the
19556. beautiful Helene, whose eyes several times met those of the handsome

19558. 
19559. Speaking of the position of Prussia, Anna Pavlovna very naturally asked

19569. of the Prussian army. As soon as he had finished she turned to him with
19570. her usual smile.
19571. 
19572. "You absolutely must come and see me," she said in a tone that implied

19575. 
19576. "On Tuesday between eight and nine. It will give me great pleasure."

19578. Boris promised to fulfill her wish and was about to begin a conversation

19581. 
19582. "You know her husband, of course?" said Anna Pavlovna, closing her eyes

19584. unfortunate and charming woman! Don't mention him before her--please

19591. CHAPTER VII
19592. 
19593. 
19594. When Boris and Anna Pavlovna returned to the others Prince Hippolyte had

19596.

19636.

19641. "Pardon me! A snuffbox with the Emperor's portrait is a reward but not a

19643. 
19644. "There are precedents, I may mention Schwarzenberg."
