19677. CHAPTER VIII
19678. 
19679. 
19680. The war was flaming up and nearing the Russian frontier. Everywhere
19681. one heard curses on Bonaparte, "the enemy of mankind." Militiamen and
19682. recruits were being enrolled in the villages, and from the seat of
19683. war came contradictory news, false as usual and therefore variously
19684. interpreted. The life of old Prince Bolkonski, Prince Andrew, and
19685. Princess Mary had greatly changed since 1805.
19686. 
19687. In 1806 the old prince was made one of the eight commanders in chief
19688. then appointed to supervise the enrollment decreed throughout Russia.
19689. Despite the weakness of age, which had become particularly noticeable
19690. since the time when he thought his son had been killed, he did not think
19691. it right to refuse a duty to which he had been appointed by the Emperor
19692. himself, and this fresh opportunity for action gave him new energy
19693. and strength. He was continually traveling through the three provinces
19694. entrusted to him, was pedantic in the fulfillment of his duties, severe
19695. to cruelty with his subordinates, and went into everything down to the
19696. minutest details himself. Princess Mary had ceased taking lessons in
19697. mathematics from her father, and when the old prince was at home went
19698. to his study with the wet nurse and little Prince Nicholas (as his
19699. grandfather called him). The baby Prince Nicholas lived with his wet
19700. nurse and nurse Savishna in the late princess' rooms and Princess Mary
19701. spent most of the day in the nursery, taking a mother's place to her
19702. little nephew as best she could. Mademoiselle Bourienne, too, seemed
19703. passionately fond of the boy, and Princess Mary often deprived herself
19704. to give her friend the pleasure of dandling the little angel--as she
19705. called her nephew--and playing with him.
19706. 
19707. Near the altar of the church at Bald Hills there was a chapel over the
19708. tomb of the little princess, and in this chapel was a marble monument
19709. brought from Italy, representing an angel with outspread wings ready to
19710. fly upwards. The angel's upper lip was slightly raised as though
19711. about to smile, and once on coming out of the chapel Prince Andrew and
19712. Princess Mary admitted to one another that the angel's face reminded
19713. them strangely of the little princess. But what was still stranger,
19714. though of this Prince Andrew said nothing to his sister, was that in the
19715. expression the sculptor had happened to give the angel's face, Prince
19716. Andrew read the same mild reproach he had read on the face of his dead
19717. wife: "Ah, why have you done this to me?"
19718. 
19719. Soon after Prince Andrew's return the old prince made over to him a
19720. large estate, Bogucharovo, about twenty-five miles from Bald Hills.
19721. Partly because of the depressing memories associated with Bald Hills,
19722. partly because Prince Andrew did not always feel equal to bearing with
19723. his father's peculiarities, and partly because he needed solitude,
19724. Prince Andrew made use of Bogucharovo, began building and spent most of
19725. his time there.
19726. 
19727. After the Austerlitz campaign Prince Andrew had firmly resolved not
19728. to continue his military service, and when the war recommenced
19729. and everybody had to serve, he took a post under his father in the
19730. recruitment so as to avoid active service. The old prince and his son
19731. seemed to have changed roles since the campaign of 1805. The old man,
19732. roused by activity, expected the best results from the new campaign,
19733. while Prince Andrew on the contrary, taking no part in the war and
19734. secretly regretting this, saw only the dark side.
19735. 
19736. On February 26, 1807, the old prince set off on one of his circuits.
19737. Prince Andrew remained at Bald Hills as usual during his father's
19738. absence. Little Nicholas had been unwell for four days. The coachman who
19739. had driven the old prince to town returned bringing papers and letters
19740. for Prince Andrew.
19741. 
19742. Not finding the young prince in his study the valet went with the
19743. letters to Princess Mary's apartments, but did not find him there. He
19744. was told that the prince had gone to the nursery.
19745. 
19746. "If you please, your excellency, Petrusha has brought some papers,"
19747. said one of the nursemaids to Prince Andrew who was sitting on a child's
19748. little chair while, frowning and with trembling hands, he poured drops
19749. from a medicine bottle into a wineglass half full of water.
19750. 
19751. "What is it?" he said crossly, and, his hand shaking unintentionally,
19752. he poured too many drops into the glass. He threw the mixture onto the
19753. floor and asked for some more water. The maid brought it.
19754. 
19755. There were in the room a child's cot, two boxes, two armchairs, a
19756. table, a child's table, and the little chair on which Prince Andrew was
19757. sitting. The curtains were drawn, and a single candle was burning on the
19758. table, screened by a bound music book so that the light did not fall on
19759. the cot.
19760. 
19761. "My dear," said Princess Mary, addressing her brother from beside the
19762. cot where she was standing, "better wait a bit... later..."
19763. 
19764. "Oh, leave off, you always talk nonsense and keep putting things
19765. off--and this is what comes of it!" said Prince Andrew in an exasperated
19766. whisper, evidently meaning to wound his sister.
19767. 
19768. "My dear, really... it's better not to wake him... he's asleep," said
19769. the princess in a tone of entreaty.
19770. 
19771. Prince Andrew got up and went on tiptoe up to the little bed, wineglass
19772. in hand.
19773. 
19774. "Perhaps we'd really better not wake him," he said hesitating.
19775. 
19776. "As you please... really... I think so... but as you please," said
19777. Princess Mary, evidently intimidated and confused that her opinion had
19778. prevailed. She drew her brother's attention to the maid who was calling
19779. him in a whisper.
19780. 
19781. It was the second night that neither of them had slept, watching the boy
19782. who was in a high fever. These last days, mistrusting their household
19783. doctor and expecting another for whom they had sent to town, they had
19784. been trying first one remedy and then another. Worn out by sleeplessness
19785. and anxiety they threw their burden of sorrow on one another and
19786. reproached and disputed with each other.
19787. 
19788. "Petrusha has come with papers from your father," whispered the maid.
19789. 
19790. Prince Andrew went out.
19791. 
19792. "Devil take them!" he muttered, and after listening to the verbal
19793. instructions his father had sent and taking the correspondence and his
19794. father's letter, he returned to the nursery.
19795. 
19796. "Well?" he asked.
19797. 
19798. "Still the same. Wait, for heaven's sake. Karl Ivanich always says that
19799. sleep is more important than anything," whispered Princess Mary with a
19800. sigh.
19801. 
19802. Prince Andrew went up to the child and felt him. He was burning hot.
19803. 
19804. "Confound you and your Karl Ivanich!" He took the glass with the drops
19805. and again went up to the cot.
19806. 
19807. "Andrew, don't!" said Princess Mary.
19808. 
19809. But he scowled at her angrily though also with suffering in his eyes,
19810. and stooped glass in hand over the infant.
19811. 
19812. "But I wish it," he said. "I beg you--give it him!"
19813. 
19814. Princess Mary shrugged her shoulders but took the glass submissively
19815. and calling the nurse began giving the medicine. The child screamed
19816. hoarsely. Prince Andrew winced and, clutching his head, went out and sat
19817. down on a sofa in the next room.
19818. 
19819. He still had all the letters in his hand. Opening them mechanically he
19820. began reading. The old prince, now and then using abbreviations, wrote
19821. in his large elongated hand on blue paper as follows:
19822. 
19823. 
19824. Have just this moment received by special messenger very joyful news--if
19825. it's not false. Bennigsen seems to have obtained a complete victory
19826. over Buonaparte at Eylau. In Petersburg everyone is rejoicing, and
19827. the rewards sent to the army are innumerable. Though he is a German--I
19828. congratulate him! I can't make out what the commander at Korchevo--a
19829. certain Khandrikov--is up to; till now the additional men and provisions
19830. have not arrived. Gallop off to him at once and say I'll have his head
19831. off if everything is not here in a week. Have received another letter
19832. about the Preussisch-Eylau battle from Petenka--he took part in it--and
19833. it's all true. When mischief-makers don't meddle even a German beats
19834. Buonaparte. He is said to be fleeing in great disorder. Mind you gallop
19835. off to Korchevo without delay and carry out instructions!
19836. 
19837. 
19838. Prince Andrew sighed and broke the seal of another envelope. It was
19839. a closely written letter of two sheets from Bilibin. He folded it up
19840. without reading it and reread his father's letter, ending with the
19841. words: "Gallop off to Korchevo and carry out instructions!"
19842. 
19843. "No, pardon me, I won't go now till the child is better," thought he,
19844. going to the door and looking into the nursery.
19845. 
19846. Princess Mary was still standing by the cot, gently rocking the baby.
19847. 
19848. "Ah yes, and what else did he say that's unpleasant?" thought Prince
19849. Andrew, recalling his father's letter. "Yes, we have gained a victory
19850. over Bonaparte, just when I'm not serving. Yes, yes, he's always poking
19851. fun at me.... Ah, well! Let him!" And he began reading Bilibin's letter
19852. which was written in French. He read without understanding half of it,
19853. read only to forget, if but for a moment, what he had too long been
19854. thinking of so painfully to the exclusion of all else.
19855. 
19856. 
19857. 
19858. 
19859. 
19860. CHAPTER IX
19861. 
19862. 
19863. Bilibin was now at army headquarters in a diplomatic capacity, and
19864. though he wrote in French and used French jests and French idioms,
19865. he described the whole campaign with a fearless self-censure and
19866. self-derision genuinely Russian. Bilibin wrote that the obligation of
19867. diplomatic discretion tormented him, and he was happy to have in Prince
19868. Andrew a reliable correspondent to whom he could pour out the bile he
19869. had accumulated at the sight of all that was being done in the army.
19870. The letter was old, having been written before the battle at
19871. Preussisch-Eylau.
19872. 
19873. "Since the day of our brilliant success at Austerlitz," wrote Bilibin,
19874. "as you know, my dear prince, I never leave headquarters. I have
19875. certainly acquired a taste for war, and it is just as well for me; what
19876. I have seen during these last three months is incredible.
19877. 
19878. "I begin ab ovo. 'The enemy of the human race,' as you know, attacks the
19879. Prussians. The Prussians are our faithful allies who have only betrayed
19880. us three times in three years. We take up their cause, but it turns out
19881. that 'the enemy of the human race' pays no heed to our fine speeches
19882. and in his rude and savage way throws himself on the Prussians without
19883. giving them time to finish the parade they had begun, and in two twists
19884. of the hand he breaks them to smithereens and installs himself in the
19885. palace at Potsdam.
19886. 
19887. "'I most ardently desire,' writes the King of Prussia to Bonaparte,
19888. 'that Your Majesty should be received and treated in my palace in a
19889. manner agreeable to yourself, and in so far as circumstances allowed, I
19890. have hastened to take all steps to that end. May I have succeeded!' The
19891. Prussian generals pride themselves on being polite to the French and lay
19892. down their arms at the first demand.
19893. 
19894. "The head of the garrison at Glogau, with ten thousand men, asks the
19895. King of Prussia what he is to do if he is summoned to surrender.... All
19896. this is absolutely true.
19897. 
19898. "In short, hoping to settle matters by taking up a warlike attitude, it
19899. turns out that we have landed ourselves in war, and what is more, in
19900. war on our own frontiers, with and for the King of Prussia. We have
19901. everything in perfect order, only one little thing is lacking, namely,
19902. a commander in chief. As it was considered that the Austerlitz success
19903. might have been more decisive had the commander in chief not been so
19904. young, all our octogenarians were reviewed, and of Prozorovski
19905. and Kamenski the latter was preferred. The general comes to us,
19906. Suvorov-like, in a kibitka, and is received with acclamations of joy and
19907. triumph.
19908. 
19909. "On the 4th, the first courier arrives from Petersburg. The mails
19910. are taken to the field marshal's room, for he likes to do everything
19911. himself. I am called in to help sort the letters and take those meant
19912. for us. The field marshal looks on and waits for letters addressed
19913. to him. We search, but none are to be found. The field marshal grows
19914. impatient and sets to work himself and finds letters from the Emperor
19915. to Count T., Prince V., and others. Then he bursts into one of his wild
19916. furies and rages at everyone and everything, seizes the letters, opens
19917. them, and reads those from the Emperor addressed to others. 'Ah! So
19918. that's the way they treat me! No confidence in me! Ah, ordered to keep
19919. an eye on me! Very well then! Get along with you!' So he writes the
19920. famous order of the day to General Bennigsen:
19921. 
19922. 'I am wounded and cannot ride and consequently cannot command the army.
19923. You have brought your army corps to Pultusk, routed: here it is exposed,
19924. and without fuel or forage, so something must be done, and, as you
19925. yourself reported to Count Buxhowden yesterday, you must think of
19926. retreating to our frontier--which do today.'
19927. 
19928. "'From all my riding,' he writes to the Emperor, 'I have got a saddle
19929. sore which, coming after all my previous journeys, quite prevents my
19930. riding and commanding so vast an army, so I have passed on the command
19931. to the general next in seniority, Count Buxhowden, having sent him my
19932. whole staff and all that belongs to it, advising him if there is a lack
19933. of bread, to move farther into the interior of Prussia, for only one
19934. day's ration of bread remains, and in some regiments none at all, as
19935. reported by the division commanders, Ostermann and Sedmoretzki, and
19936. all that the peasants had has been eaten up. I myself will remain in
19937. hospital at Ostrolenka till I recover. In regard to which I humbly
19938. submit my report, with the information that if the army remains in its
19939. present bivouac another fortnight there will not be a healthy man left
19940. in it by spring.
19941. 
19942. "'Grant leave to retire to his country seat to an old man who is already
19943. in any case dishonored by being unable to fulfill the great and
19944. glorious task for which he was chosen. I shall await your most gracious
19945. permission here in hospital, that I may not have to play the part of a
19946. secretary rather than commander in the army. My removal from the army
19947. does not produce the slightest stir--a blind man has left it. There are
19948. thousands such as I in Russia.'
19949. 
19950. "The field marshal is angry with the Emperor and he punishes us all,
19951. isn't it logical?
19952. 
19953. "This is the first act. Those that follow are naturally increasingly
19954. interesting and entertaining. After the field marshal's departure it
19955. appears that we are within sight of the enemy and must give battle.
19956. Buxhowden is commander in chief by seniority, but General Bennigsen does
19957. not quite see it; more particularly as it is he and his corps who are
19958. within sight of the enemy and he wishes to profit by the opportunity to
19959. fight a battle 'on his own hand' as the Germans say. He does so. This
19960. is the battle of Pultusk, which is considered a great victory but in my
19961. opinion was nothing of the kind. We civilians, as you know, have a very
19962. bad way of deciding whether a battle was won or lost. Those who retreat
19963. after a battle have lost it is what we say; and according to that it is
19964. we who lost the battle of Pultusk. In short, we retreat after the battle
19965. but send a courier to Petersburg with news of a victory, and General
19966. Bennigsen, hoping to receive from Petersburg the post of commander in
19967. chief as a reward for his victory, does not give up the command of
19968. the army to General Buxhowden. During this interregnum we begin a very
19969. original and interesting series of maneuvers. Our aim is no longer, as
19970. it should be, to avoid or attack the enemy, but solely to avoid
19971. General Buxhowden who by right of seniority should be our chief. So
19972. energetically do we pursue this aim that after crossing an unfordable
19973. river we burn the bridges to separate ourselves from our enemy, who at
19974. the moment is not Bonaparte but Buxhowden. General Buxhowden was all but
19975. attacked and captured by a superior enemy force as a result of one of
19976. these maneuvers that enabled us to escape him. Buxhowden pursues us--we
19977. scuttle. He hardly crosses the river to our side before we recross to
19978. the other. At last our enemy. Buxhowden, catches us and attacks. Both
19979. generals are angry, and the result is a challenge on Buxhowden's part
19980. and an epileptic fit on Bennigsen's. But at the critical moment the
19981. courier who carried the news of our victory at Pultusk to Petersburg
19982. returns bringing our appointment as commander in chief, and our first
19983. foe, Buxhowden, is vanquished; we can now turn our thoughts to the
19984. second, Bonaparte. But as it turns out, just at that moment a third
19985. enemy rises before us--namely the Orthodox Russian soldiers, loudly
19986. demanding bread, meat, biscuits, fodder, and whatnot! The stores are
19987. empty, the roads impassable. The Orthodox begin looting, and in a way
19988. of which our last campaign can give you no idea. Half the regiments form
19989. bands and scour the countryside and put everything to fire and sword.
19990. The inhabitants are totally ruined, the hospitals overflow with
19991. sick, and famine is everywhere. Twice the marauders even attack our
19992. headquarters, and the commander in chief has to ask for a battalion to
19993. disperse them. During one of these attacks they carried off my empty
19994. portmanteau and my dressing gown. The Emperor proposes to give all
19995. commanders of divisions the right to shoot marauders, but I much fear
19996. this will oblige one half the army to shoot the other."
19997. 
19998. At first Prince Andrew read with his eyes only, but after a while,
19999. in spite of himself (although he knew how far it was safe to trust
20000. Bilibin), what he had read began to interest him more and more. When he
20001. had read thus far, he crumpled the letter up and threw it away. It was
20002. not what he had read that vexed him, but the fact that the life out
20003. there in which he had now no part could perturb him. He shut his eyes,
20004. rubbed his forehead as if to rid himself of all interest in what he
20005. had read, and listened to what was passing in the nursery. Suddenly he
20006. thought he heard a strange noise through the door. He was seized with
20007. alarm lest something should have happened to the child while he was
20008. reading the letter. He went on tiptoe to the nursery door and opened it.
20009. 
20010. Just as he went in he saw that the nurse was hiding something from him
20011. with a scared look and that Princess Mary was no longer by the cot.
20012. 
20013. "My dear," he heard what seemed to him her despairing whisper behind
20014. him.
20015. 
20016. As often happens after long sleeplessness and long anxiety, he was
20017. seized by an unreasoning panic--it occurred to him that the child was
20018. dead. All that he saw and heard seemed to confirm this terror.
20019. 
20020. "All is over," he thought, and a cold sweat broke out on his forehead.
20021. He went to the cot in confusion, sure that he would find it empty and
20022. that the nurse had been hiding the dead baby. He drew the curtain aside
20023. and for some time his frightened, restless eyes could not find the baby.
20024. At last he saw him: the rosy boy had tossed about till he lay across the
20025. bed with his head lower than the pillow, and was smacking his lips in
20026. his sleep and breathing evenly.
20027. 
20028. Prince Andrew was as glad to find the boy like that, as if he had
20029. already lost him. He bent over him and, as his sister had taught him,
20030. tried with his lips whether the child was still feverish. The soft
20031. forehead was moist. Prince Andrew touched the head with his hand; even
20032. the hair was wet, so profusely had the child perspired. He was not dead,
20033. but evidently the crisis was over and he was convalescent. Prince Andrew
20034. longed to snatch up, to squeeze, to hold to his heart, this helpless
20035. little creature, but dared not do so. He stood over him, gazing at his
20036. head and at the little arms and legs which showed under the blanket. He
20037. heard a rustle behind him and a shadow appeared under the curtain of
20038. the cot. He did not look round, but still gazing at the infant's face
20039. listened to his regular breathing. The dark shadow was Princess Mary,
20040. who had come up to the cot with noiseless steps, lifted the curtain,
20041. and dropped it again behind her. Prince Andrew recognized her without
20042. looking and held out his hand to her. She pressed it.
20043. 
20044. "He has perspired," said Prince Andrew.
20045. 
20046. "I was coming to tell you so."
20047. 
20048. The child moved slightly in his sleep, smiled, and rubbed his forehead
20049. against the pillow.
20050. 
20051. Prince Andrew looked at his sister. In the dim shadow of the curtain her
20052. luminous eyes shone more brightly than usual from the tears of joy that
20053. were in them. She leaned over to her brother and kissed him, slightly
20054. catching the curtain of the cot. Each made the other a warning gesture
20055. and stood still in the dim light beneath the curtain as if not wishing
20056. to leave that seclusion where they three were shut off from all the
20057. world. Prince Andrew was the first to move away, ruffling his hair
20058. against the muslin of the curtain.
20059. 
20060. "Yes, this is the one thing left me now," he said with a sigh.
20061. 
20062. 
20063. 
20064. 
20065. 
20066. CHAPTER X
20067. 
20068. 
20069. Soon after his admission to the Masonic Brotherhood, Pierre went to the
20070. Kiev province, where he had the greatest number of serfs, taking with
20071. him full directions which he had written down for his own guidance as to
20072. what he should do on his estates.
20073. 
20074. When he reached Kiev he sent for all his stewards to the head office
20075. and explained to them his intentions and wishes. He told them that steps
20076. would be taken immediately to free his serfs--and that till then they
20077. were not to be overburdened with labor, women while nursing their babies
20078. were not to be sent to work, assistance was to be given to the serfs,
20079. punishments were to be admonitory and not corporal, and hospitals,
20080. asylums, and schools were to be established on all the estates. Some of
20081. the stewards (there were semiliterate foremen among them) listened with
20082. alarm, supposing these words to mean that the young count was displeased
20083. with their management and embezzlement of money, some after their first
20084. fright were amused by Pierre's lisp and the new words they had not heard
20085. before, others simply enjoyed hearing how the master talked, while the
20086. cleverest among them, including the chief steward, understood from this
20087. speech how they could best handle the master for their own ends.
20088. 
20089. The chief steward expressed great sympathy with Pierre's intentions, but
20090. remarked that besides these changes it would be necessary to go into the
20091. general state of affairs which was far from satisfactory.
20092. 
20093. Despite Count Bezukhov's enormous wealth, since he had come into an
20094. income which was said to amount to five hundred thousand rubles a year,
20095. Pierre felt himself far poorer than when his father had made him
20096. an allowance of ten thousand rubles. He had a dim perception of the
20097. following budget:
20098. 
20099. About 80,000 went in payments on all the estates to the Land Bank, about
20100. 30,000 went for the upkeep of the estate near Moscow, the town house,
20101. and the allowance to the three princesses; about 15,000 was given in
20102. pensions and the same amount for asylums; 150,000 alimony was sent to
20103. the countess; about 70,000 went for interest on debts. The building of a
20104. new church, previously begun, had cost about 10,000 in each of the last
20105. two years, and he did not know how the rest, about 100,000 rubles, was
20106. spent, and almost every year he was obliged to borrow. Besides this the
20107. chief steward wrote every year telling him of fires and bad harvests,
20108. or of the necessity of rebuilding factories and workshops. So the first
20109. task Pierre had to face was one for which he had very little aptitude or
20110. inclination--practical business.
20111. 
20112. He discussed estate affairs every day with his chief steward. But
20113. he felt that this did not forward matters at all. He felt that these
20114. consultations were detached from real affairs and did not link up with
20115. them or make them move. On the one hand, the chief steward put the state
20116. of things to him in the very worst light, pointing out the necessity of
20117. paying off the debts and undertaking new activities with serf labor,
20118. to which Pierre did not agree. On the other hand, Pierre demanded that
20119. steps should be taken to liberate the serfs, which the steward met by
20120. showing the necessity of first paying off the loans from the Land Bank,
20121. and the consequent impossibility of a speedy emancipation.
20122. 
20123. The steward did not say it was quite impossible, but suggested selling
20124. the forests in the province of Kostroma, the land lower down the river,
20125. and the Crimean estate, in order to make it possible: all of which
20126. operations according to him were connected with such complicated
20127. measures--the removal of injunctions, petitions, permits, and so
20128. on--that Pierre became quite bewildered and only replied:
20129. 
20130. "Yes, yes, do so."
20131. 
20132. Pierre had none of the practical persistence that would have enabled him
20133. to attend to the business himself and so he disliked it and only tried
20134. to pretend to the steward that he was attending to it. The steward
20135. for his part tried to pretend to the count that he considered these
20136. consultations very valuable for the proprietor and troublesome to
20137. himself.
20138. 
20139. In Kiev Pierre found some people he knew, and strangers hastened to make
20140. his acquaintance and joyfully welcomed the rich newcomer, the
20141. largest landowner of the province. Temptations to Pierre's greatest
20142. weakness--the one to which he had confessed when admitted to the
20143. Lodge--were so strong that he could not resist them. Again whole days,
20144. weeks, and months of his life passed in as great a rush and were as much
20145. occupied with evening parties, dinners, lunches, and balls, giving him
20146. no time for reflection, as in Petersburg. Instead of the new life he had
20147. hoped to lead he still lived the old life, only in new surroundings.
20148. 
20149. Of the three precepts of Freemasonry Pierre realized that he did not
20150. fulfill the one which enjoined every Mason to set an example of moral
20151. life, and that of the seven virtues he lacked two--morality and the love
20152. of death. He consoled himself with the thought that he fulfilled
20153. another of the precepts--that of reforming the human race--and had other
20154. virtues--love of his neighbor, and especially generosity.
20155. 
20156. In the spring of 1807 he decided to return to Petersburg. On the way he
20157. intended to visit all his estates and see for himself how far his orders
20158. had been carried out and in what state were the serfs whom God had
20159. entrusted to his care and whom he intended to benefit.
20160. 
20161. The chief steward, who considered the young count's attempts almost
20162. insane--unprofitable to himself, to the count, and to the serfs--made
20163. some concessions. Continuing to represent the liberation of the serfs as
20164. impracticable, he arranged for the erection of large buildings--schools,
20165. hospitals, and asylums--on all the estates before the master arrived.
20166. Everywhere preparations were made not for ceremonious welcomes (which
20167. he knew Pierre would not like), but for just such gratefully religious
20168. ones, with offerings of icons and the bread and salt of hospitality,
20169. as, according to his understanding of his master, would touch and delude
20170. him.
20171. 
20172. The southern spring, the comfortable rapid traveling in a Vienna
20173. carriage, and the solitude of the road, all had a gladdening effect on
20174. Pierre. The estates he had not before visited were each more picturesque
20175. than the other; the serfs everywhere seemed thriving and touchingly
20176. grateful for the benefits conferred on them. Everywhere were receptions,
20177. which though they embarrassed Pierre awakened a joyful feeling in the
20178. depth of his heart. In one place the peasants presented him with bread
20179. and salt and an icon of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, asking permission,
20180. as a mark of their gratitude for the benefits he had conferred on them,
20181. to build a new chantry to the church at their own expense in honor
20182. of Peter and Paul, his patron saints. In another place the women with
20183. infants in arms met him to thank him for releasing them from hard
20184. work. On a third estate the priest, bearing a cross, came to meet
20185. him surrounded by children whom, by the count's generosity, he was
20186. instructing in reading, writing, and religion. On all his estates Pierre
20187. saw with his own eyes brick buildings erected or in course of erection,
20188. all on one plan, for hospitals, schools, and almshouses, which were soon
20189. to be opened. Everywhere he saw the stewards' accounts, according to
20190. which the serfs' manorial labor had been diminished, and heard the
20191. touching thanks of deputations of serfs in their full-skirted blue
20192. coats.
20193. 
20194. What Pierre did not know was that the place where they presented him
20195. with bread and salt and wished to build a chantry in honor of Peter and
20196. Paul was a market village where a fair was held on St. Peter's day,
20197. and that the richest peasants (who formed the deputation) had begun
20198. the chantry long before, but that nine tenths of the peasants in that
20199. villages were in a state of the greatest poverty. He did not know that
20200. since the nursing mothers were no longer sent to work on his land, they
20201. did still harder work on their own land. He did not know that the priest
20202. who met him with the cross oppressed the peasants by his exactions, and
20203. that the pupils' parents wept at having to let him take their children
20204. and secured their release by heavy payments. He did not know that the
20205. brick buildings, built to plan, were being built by serfs whose manorial
20206. labor was thus increased, though lessened on paper. He did not know that
20207. where the steward had shown him in the accounts that the serfs' payments
20208. had been diminished by a third, their obligatory manorial work had been
20209. increased by a half. And so Pierre was delighted with his visit to his
20210. estates and quite recovered the philanthropic mood in which he had left
20211. Petersburg, and wrote enthusiastic letters to his "brother-instructor"
20212. as he called the Grand Master.
20213. 
20214. "How easy it is, how little effort it needs, to do so much good,"
20215. thought Pierre, "and how little attention we pay to it!"
20216. 
20217. He was pleased at the gratitude he received, but felt abashed at
20218. receiving it. This gratitude reminded him of how much more he might do
20219. for these simple, kindly people.
20220. 
20221. The chief steward, a very stupid but cunning man who saw perfectly
20222. through the naive and intelligent count and played with him as with
20223. a toy, seeing the effect these prearranged receptions had on Pierre,
20224. pressed him still harder with proofs of the impossibility and above all
20225. the uselessness of freeing the serfs, who were quite happy as it was.
20226. 
20227. Pierre in his secret soul agreed with the steward that it would be
20228. difficult to imagine happier people, and that God only knew what would
20229. happen to them when they were free, but he insisted, though reluctantly,
20230. on what he thought right. The steward promised to do all in his power
20231. to carry out the count's wishes, seeing clearly that not only would the
20232. count never be able to find out whether all measures had been taken for
20233. the sale of the land and forests and to release them from the Land Bank,
20234. but would probably never even inquire and would never know that the
20235. newly erected buildings were standing empty and that the serfs continued
20236. to give in money and work all that other people's serfs gave--that is to
20237. say, all that could be got out of them.
20238. 
20239. 
20240. 
20241. 
20242. 
20243. CHAPTER XI
20244. 
20245. 
20246. Returning from his journey through South Russia in the happiest state
20247. of mind, Pierre carried out an intention he had long had of visiting his
20248. friend Bolkonski, whom he had not seen for two years.
20249. 
20250. Bogucharovo lay in a flat uninteresting part of the country among fields
20251. and forests of fir and birch, which were partly cut down. The house lay
20252. behind a newly dug pond filled with water to the brink and with banks
20253. still bare of grass. It was at the end of a village that stretched
20254. along the highroad in the midst of a young copse in which were a few fir
20255. trees.
20256. 
20257. The homestead consisted of a threshing floor, outhouses, stables, a
20258. bathhouse, a lodge, and a large brick house with semicircular facade
20259. still in course of construction. Round the house was a garden newly laid
20260. out. The fences and gates were new and solid; two fire pumps and a
20261. water cart, painted green, stood in a shed; the paths were straight,
20262. the bridges were strong and had handrails. Everything bore an impress of
20263. tidiness and good management. Some domestic serfs Pierre met, in reply
20264. to inquiries as to where the prince lived, pointed out a small newly
20265. built lodge close to the pond. Anton, a man who had looked after Prince
20266. Andrew in his boyhood, helped Pierre out of his carriage, said that the
20267. prince was at home, and showed him into a clean little anteroom.
20268. 
20269. Pierre was struck by the modesty of the small though clean house after
20270. the brilliant surroundings in which he had last met his friend in
20271. Petersburg.
20272. 
20273. He quickly entered the small reception room with its still-unplastered
20274. wooden walls redolent of pine, and would have gone farther, but Anton
20275. ran ahead on tiptoe and knocked at a door.
20276. 
20277. "Well, what is it?" came a sharp, unpleasant voice.
20278. 
20279. "A visitor," answered Anton.
20280. 
20281. "Ask him to wait," and the sound was heard of a chair being pushed back.
20282. 
20283. Pierre went with rapid steps to the door and suddenly came face to
20284. face with Prince Andrew, who came out frowning and looking old. Pierre
20285. embraced him and lifting his spectacles kissed his friend on the cheek
20286. and looked at him closely.
20287. 
20288. "Well, I did not expect you, I am very glad," said Prince Andrew.
20289. 
20290. Pierre said nothing; he looked fixedly at his friend with surprise. He
20291. was struck by the change in him. His words were kindly and there was a
20292. smile on his lips and face, but his eyes were dull and lifeless and in
20293. spite of his evident wish to do so he could not give them a joyous
20294. and glad sparkle. Prince Andrew had grown thinner, paler, and more
20295. manly-looking, but what amazed and estranged Pierre till he got used
20296. to it were his inertia and a wrinkle on his brow indicating prolonged
20297. concentration on some one thought.
20298. 
20299. As is usually the case with people meeting after a prolonged separation,
20300. it was long before their conversation could settle on anything. They
20301. put questions and gave brief replies about things they knew ought to
20302. be talked over at length. At last the conversation gradually settled on
20303. some of the topics at first lightly touched on: their past life, plans
20304. for the future, Pierre's journeys and occupations, the war, and so
20305. on. The preoccupation and despondency which Pierre had noticed in his
20306. friend's look was now still more clearly expressed in the smile with
20307. which he listened to Pierre, especially when he spoke with joyful
20308. animation of the past or the future. It was as if Prince Andrew would
20309. have liked to sympathize with what Pierre was saying, but could not.
20310. The latter began to feel that it was in bad taste to speak of his
20311. enthusiasms, dreams, and hopes of happiness or goodness, in Prince
20312. Andrew's presence. He was ashamed to express his new Masonic views,
20313. which had been particularly revived and strengthened by his late tour.
20314. He checked himself, fearing to seem naive, yet he felt an irresistible
20315. desire to show his friend as soon as possible that he was now a quite
20316. different, and better, Pierre than he had been in Petersburg.
20317. 
20318. "I can't tell you how much I have lived through since then. I hardly
20319. know myself again."
20320. 
20321. "Yes, we have altered much, very much, since then," said Prince Andrew.
20322. 
20323. "Well, and you? What are your plans?"
20324. 
20325. "Plans!" repeated Prince Andrew ironically. "My plans?" he said, as if
20326. astonished at the word. "Well, you see, I'm building. I mean to settle
20327. here altogether next year...."
20328. 
20329. Pierre looked silently and searchingly into Prince Andrew's face, which
20330. had grown much older.
20331. 
20332. "No, I meant to ask..." Pierre began, but Prince Andrew interrupted him.
20333. 
20334. "But why talk of me?... Talk to me, yes, tell me about your travels and
20335. all you have been doing on your estates."
20336. 
20337. Pierre began describing what he had done on his estates, trying as far
20338. as possible to conceal his own part in the improvements that had been
20339. made. Prince Andrew several times prompted Pierre's story of what he had
20340. been doing, as though it were all an old-time story, and he listened not
20341. only without interest but even as if ashamed of what Pierre was telling
20342. him.
20343. 
20344. Pierre felt uncomfortable and even depressed in his friend's company and
20345. at last became silent.
20346. 
20347. "I'll tell you what, my dear fellow," said Prince Andrew, who evidently
20348. also felt depressed and constrained with his visitor, "I am only
20349. bivouacking here and have just come to look round. I am going back to
20350. my sister today. I will introduce you to her. But of course you know her
20351. already," he said, evidently trying to entertain a visitor with whom he
20352. now found nothing in common. "We will go after dinner. And would you now
20353. like to look round my place?"
20354. 
20355. They went out and walked about till dinnertime, talking of the political
20356. news and common acquaintances like people who do not know each other
20357. intimately. Prince Andrew spoke with some animation and interest only of
20358. the new homestead he was constructing and its buildings, but even here,
20359. while on the scaffolding, in the midst of a talk explaining the future
20360. arrangements of the house, he interrupted himself:
20361. 
20362. "However, this is not at all interesting. Let us have dinner, and then
20363. we'll set off."
20364. 
20365. At dinner, conversation turned on Pierre's marriage.
20366. 
20367. "I was very much surprised when I heard of it," said Prince Andrew.
20368. 
20369. Pierre blushed, as he always did when it was mentioned, and said
20370. hurriedly: "I will tell you some time how it all happened. But you know
20371. it is all over, and forever."
20372. 
20373. "Forever?" said Prince Andrew. "Nothing's forever."
20374. 
20375. "But you know how it all ended, don't you? You heard of the duel?"
20376. 
20377. "And so you had to go through that too!"
20378. 
20379. "One thing I thank God for is that I did not kill that man," said
20380. Pierre.
20381. 
20382. "Why so?" asked Prince Andrew. "To kill a vicious dog is a very good
20383. thing really."
20384. 
20385. "No, to kill a man is bad--wrong."
20386. 
20387. "Why is it wrong?" urged Prince Andrew. "It is not given to man to know
20388. what is right and what is wrong. Men always did and always will err, and
20389. in nothing more than in what they consider right and wrong."
20390. 
20391. "What does harm to another is wrong," said Pierre, feeling with pleasure
20392. that for the first time since his arrival Prince Andrew was roused, had
20393. begun to talk, and wanted to express what had brought him to his present
20394. state.
20395. 
20396. "And who has told you what is bad for another man?" he asked.
20397. 
20398. "Bad! Bad!" exclaimed Pierre. "We all know what is bad for ourselves."
20399. 
20400. "Yes, we know that, but the harm I am conscious of in myself is
20401. something I cannot inflict on others," said Prince Andrew, growing more
20402. and more animated and evidently wishing to express his new outlook to
20403. Pierre. He spoke in French. "I only know two very real evils in life:
20404. remorse and illness. The only good is the absence of those evils. To
20405. live for myself avoiding those two evils is my whole philosophy now."
20406. 
20407. "And love of one's neighbor, and self-sacrifice?" began Pierre. "No, I
20408. can't agree with you! To live only so as not to do evil and not to
20409. have to repent is not enough. I lived like that, I lived for myself
20410. and ruined my life. And only now when I am living, or at least trying"
20411. (Pierre's modesty made him correct himself) "to live for others, only
20412. now have I understood all the happiness of life. No, I shall not agree
20413. with you, and you do not really believe what you are saying." Prince
20414. Andrew looked silently at Pierre with an ironic smile.
20415. 
20416. "When you see my sister, Princess Mary, you'll get on with her," he
20417. said. "Perhaps you are right for yourself," he added after a short
20418. pause, "but everyone lives in his own way. You lived for yourself and
20419. say you nearly ruined your life and only found happiness when you
20420. began living for others. I experienced just the reverse. I lived for
20421. glory.--And after all what is glory? The same love of others, a desire
20422. to do something for them, a desire for their approval.--So I lived for
20423. others, and not almost, but quite, ruined my life. And I have become
20424. calmer since I began to live only for myself."
20425. 
20426. "But what do you mean by living only for yourself?" asked Pierre,
20427. growing excited. "What about your son, your sister, and your father?"
20428. 
20429. "But that's just the same as myself--they are not others," explained
20430. Prince Andrew. "The others, one's neighbors, le prochain, as you and
20431. Princess Mary call it, are the chief source of all error and evil. Le
20432. prochain--your Kiev peasants to whom you want to do good."
20433. 
20434. And he looked at Pierre with a mocking, challenging expression. He
20435. evidently wished to draw him on.
20436. 
20437. "You are joking," replied Pierre, growing more and more excited. "What
20438. error or evil can there be in my wishing to do good, and even doing a
20439. little--though I did very little and did it very badly? What evil can
20440. there be in it if unfortunate people, our serfs, people like ourselves,
20441. were growing up and dying with no idea of God and truth beyond
20442. ceremonies and meaningless prayers and are now instructed in a
20443. comforting belief in future life, retribution, recompense, and
20444. consolation? What evil and error are there in it, if people were dying
20445. of disease without help while material assistance could so easily be
20446. rendered, and I supplied them with a doctor, a hospital, and an asylum
20447. for the aged? And is it not a palpable, unquestionable good if a
20448. peasant, or a woman with a baby, has no rest day or night and I give
20449. them rest and leisure?" said Pierre, hurrying and lisping. "And I have
20450. done that though badly and to a small extent; but I have done something
20451. toward it and you cannot persuade me that it was not a good action,
20452. and more than that, you can't make me believe that you do not think so
20453. yourself. And the main thing is," he continued, "that I know, and know
20454. for certain, that the enjoyment of doing this good is the only sure
20455. happiness in life."
20456. 
20457. "Yes, if you put it like that it's quite a different matter," said
20458. Prince Andrew. "I build a house and lay out a garden, and you build
20459. hospitals. The one and the other may serve as a pastime. But what's
20460. right and what's good must be judged by one who knows all, but not by
20461. us. Well, you want an argument," he added, "come on then."
20462. 
20463. They rose from the table and sat down in the entrance porch which served
20464. as a veranda.
20465. 
20466. "Come, let's argue then," said Prince Andrew, "You talk of schools," he
20467. went on, crooking a finger, "education and so forth; that is, you want
20468. to raise him" (pointing to a peasant who passed by them taking off his
20469. cap) "from his animal condition and awaken in him spiritual needs, while
20470. it seems to me that animal happiness is the only happiness possible, and
20471. that is just what you want to deprive him of. I envy him, but you
20472. want to make him what I am, without giving him my means. Then you say,
20473. 'lighten his toil.' But as I see it, physical labor is as essential to
20474. him, as much a condition of his existence, as mental activity is to you
20475. or me. You can't help thinking. I go to bed after two in the morning,
20476. thoughts come and I can't sleep but toss about till dawn, because I
20477. think and can't help thinking, just as he can't help plowing and mowing;
20478. if he didn't, he would go to the drink shop or fall ill. Just as I could
20479. not stand his terrible physical labor but should die of it in a week, so
20480. he could not stand my physical idleness, but would grow fat and die.
20481. The third thing--what else was it you talked about?" and Prince Andrew
20482. crooked a third finger. "Ah, yes, hospitals, medicine. He has a fit,
20483. he is dying, and you come and bleed him and patch him up. He will drag
20484. about as a cripple, a burden to everybody, for another ten years. It
20485. would be far easier and simpler for him to die. Others are being born
20486. and there are plenty of them as it is. It would be different if you
20487. grudged losing a laborer--that's how I regard him--but you want to cure
20488. him from love of him. And he does not want that. And besides, what a
20489. notion that medicine ever cured anyone! Killed them, yes!" said he,
20490. frowning angrily and turning away from Pierre.
20491. 
20492. Prince Andrew expressed his ideas so clearly and distinctly that it was
20493. evident he had reflected on this subject more than once, and he spoke
20494. readily and rapidly like a man who has not talked for a long time. His
20495. glance became more animated as his conclusions became more hopeless.
20496. 
20497. "Oh, that is dreadful, dreadful!" said Pierre. "I don't understand how
20498. one can live with such ideas. I had such moments myself not long ago, in
20499. Moscow and when traveling, but at such times I collapsed so that I don't
20500. live at all--everything seems hateful to me... myself most of all. Then
20501. I don't eat, don't wash... and how is it with you?..."
20502. 
20503. "Why not wash? That is not cleanly," said Prince Andrew; "on the
20504. contrary one must try to make one's life as pleasant as possible. I'm
20505. alive, that is not my fault, so I must live out my life as best I can
20506. without hurting others."
20507. 
20508. "But with such ideas what motive have you for living? One would sit
20509. without moving, undertaking nothing...."
20510. 
20511. "Life as it is leaves one no peace. I should be thankful to do nothing,
20512. but here on the one hand the local nobility have done me the honor to
20513. choose me to be their marshal; it was all I could do to get out of it.
20514. They could not understand that I have not the necessary qualifications
20515. for it--the kind of good-natured, fussy shallowness necessary for the
20516. position. Then there's this house, which must be built in order to
20517. have a nook of one's own in which to be quiet. And now there's this
20518. recruiting."
20519. 
20520. "Why aren't you serving in the army?"
20521. 
20522. "After Austerlitz!" said Prince Andrew gloomily. "No, thank you very
20523. much! I have promised myself not to serve again in the active Russian
20524. army. And I won't--not even if Bonaparte were here at Smolensk
20525. threatening Bald Hills--even then I wouldn't serve in the Russian army!
20526. Well, as I was saying," he continued, recovering his composure, "now
20527. there's this recruiting. My father is chief in command of the Third
20528. District, and my only way of avoiding active service is to serve under
20529. him."
20530. 
20531. "Then you are serving?"
20532. 
20533. "I am."
20534. 
20535. He paused a little while.
20536. 
20537. "And why do you serve?"
20538. 
20539. "Why, for this reason! My father is one of the most remarkable men of
20540. his time. But he is growing old, and though not exactly cruel he has too
20541. energetic a character. He is so accustomed to unlimited power that he is
20542. terrible, and now he has this authority of a commander in chief of
20543. the recruiting, granted by the Emperor. If I had been two hours late
20544. a fortnight ago he would have had a paymaster's clerk at Yukhnovna
20545. hanged," said Prince Andrew with a smile. "So I am serving because I
20546. alone have any influence with my father, and now and then can save him
20547. from actions which would torment him afterwards."
20548. 
20549. "Well, there you see!"
20550. 
20551. "Yes, but it is not as you imagine," Prince Andrew continued. "I did
20552. not, and do not, in the least care about that scoundrel of a clerk who
20553. had stolen some boots from the recruits; I should even have been very
20554. glad to see him hanged, but I was sorry for my father--that again is for
20555. myself."
20556. 
20557. Prince Andrew grew more and more animated. His eyes glittered feverishly
20558. while he tried to prove to Pierre that in his actions there was no
20559. desire to do good to his neighbor.
20560. 
20561. "There now, you wish to liberate your serfs," he continued; "that is a
20562. very good thing, but not for you--I don't suppose you ever had anyone
20563. flogged or sent to Siberia--and still less for your serfs. If they are
20564. beaten, flogged, or sent to Siberia, I don't suppose they are any the
20565. worse off. In Siberia they lead the same animal life, and the stripes on
20566. their bodies heal, and they are happy as before. But it is a good thing
20567. for proprietors who perish morally, bring remorse upon themselves,
20568. stifle this remorse and grow callous, as a result of being able to
20569. inflict punishments justly and unjustly. It is those people I pity, and
20570. for their sake I should like to liberate the serfs. You may not have
20571. seen, but I have seen, how good men brought up in those traditions of
20572. unlimited power, in time when they grow more irritable, become cruel and
20573. harsh, are conscious of it, but cannot restrain themselves and grow more
20574. and more miserable."
20575. 
20576. Prince Andrew spoke so earnestly that Pierre could not help thinking
20577. that these thoughts had been suggested to Prince Andrew by his father's
20578. case.
20579. 
20580. He did not reply.
20581. 
20582. "So that's what I'm sorry for--human dignity, peace of mind, purity, and
20583. not the serfs' backs and foreheads, which, beat and shave as you may,
20584. always remain the same backs and foreheads."
20585. 
20586. "No, no! A thousand times no! I shall never agree with you," said
20587. Pierre.
20588. 
20589. 
20590. 
20591. 
20592. 
20593. CHAPTER XII
20594. 
20595. 
20596. In the evening Andrew and Pierre got into the open carriage and drove to
20597. Bald Hills. Prince Andrew, glancing at Pierre, broke the silence now and
20598. then with remarks which showed that he was in a good temper.
20599. 
20600. Pointing to the fields, he spoke of the improvements he was making in
20601. his husbandry.
20602. 
20603. Pierre remained gloomily silent, answering in monosyllables and
20604. apparently immersed in his own thoughts.
20605. 
20606. He was thinking that Prince Andrew was unhappy, had gone astray, did not
20607. see the true light, and that he, Pierre, ought to aid, enlighten, and
20608. raise him. But as soon as he thought of what he should say, he felt that
20609. Prince Andrew with one word, one argument, would upset all his teaching,
20610. and he shrank from beginning, afraid of exposing to possible ridicule
20611. what to him was precious and sacred.
20612. 
20613. "No, but why do you think so?" Pierre suddenly began, lowering his
20614. head and looking like a bull about to charge, "why do you think so? You
20615. should not think so."
20616. 
20617. "Think? What about?" asked Prince Andrew with surprise.
20618. 
20619. "About life, about man's destiny. It can't be so. I myself thought
20620. like that, and do you know what saved me? Freemasonry! No, don't smile.
20621. Freemasonry is not a religious ceremonial sect, as I thought it was:
20622. Freemasonry is the best expression of the best, the eternal, aspects of
20623. humanity."
20624. 
20625. And he began to explain Freemasonry as he understood it to Prince
20626. Andrew. He said that Freemasonry is the teaching of Christianity freed
20627. from the bonds of State and Church, a teaching of equality, brotherhood,
20628. and love.
20629. 
20630. "Only our holy brotherhood has the real meaning of life, all the rest
20631. is a dream," said Pierre. "Understand, my dear fellow, that outside this
20632. union all is filled with deceit and falsehood and I agree with you that
20633. nothing is left for an intelligent and good man but to live out
20634. his life, like you, merely trying not to harm others. But make our
20635. fundamental convictions your own, join our brotherhood, give yourself up
20636. to us, let yourself be guided, and you will at once feel yourself, as I
20637. have felt myself, a part of that vast invisible chain the beginning of
20638. which is hidden in heaven," said Pierre.
20639. 
20640. Prince Andrew, looking straight in front of him, listened in silence to
20641. Pierre's words. More than once, when the noise of the wheels prevented
20642. his catching what Pierre said, he asked him to repeat it, and by the
20643. peculiar glow that came into Prince Andrew's eyes and by his silence,
20644. Pierre saw that his words were not in vain and that Prince Andrew would
20645. not interrupt him or laugh at what he said.
20646. 
20647. They reached a river that had overflowed its banks and which they had to
20648. cross by ferry. While the carriage and horses were being placed on it,
20649. they also stepped on the raft.
20650. 
20651. Prince Andrew, leaning his arms on the raft railing, gazed silently at
20652. the flooding waters glittering in the setting sun.
20653. 
20654. "Well, what do you think about it?" Pierre asked. "Why are you silent?"
20655. 
20656. "What do I think about it? I am listening to you. It's all very well....
20657. You say: join our brotherhood and we will show you the aim of life, the
20658. destiny of man, and the laws which govern the world. But who are we?
20659. Men. How is it you know everything? Why do I alone not see what you see?
20660. You see a reign of goodness and truth on earth, but I don't see it."
20661. 
20662. Pierre interrupted him.
20663. 
20664. "Do you believe in a future life?" he asked.
20665. 
20666. "A future life?" Prince Andrew repeated, but Pierre, giving him no time
20667. to reply, took the repetition for a denial, the more readily as he knew
20668. Prince Andrew's former atheistic convictions.
20669. 
20670. "You say you can't see a reign of goodness and truth on earth. Nor could
20671. I, and it cannot be seen if one looks on our life here as the end
20672. of everything. On earth, here on this earth" (Pierre pointed to the
20673. fields), "there is no truth, all is false and evil; but in the universe,
20674. in the whole universe there is a kingdom of truth, and we who are now
20675. the children of earth are--eternally--children of the whole universe.
20676. Don't I feel in my soul that I am part of this vast harmonious whole?
20677. Don't I feel that I form one link, one step, between the lower and
20678. higher beings, in this vast harmonious multitude of beings in whom the
20679. Deity--the Supreme Power if you prefer the term--is manifest? If I see,
20680. clearly see, that ladder leading from plant to man, why should I suppose
20681. it breaks off at me and does not go farther and farther? I feel that I
20682. cannot vanish, since nothing vanishes in this world, but that I shall
20683. always exist and always have existed. I feel that beyond me and above me
20684. there are spirits, and that in this world there is truth."
20685. 
20686. "Yes, that is Herder's theory," said Prince Andrew, "but it is not that
20687. which can convince me, dear friend--life and death are what convince.
20688. What convinces is when one sees a being dear to one, bound up with one's
20689. own life, before whom one was to blame and had hoped to make it right"
20690. (Prince Andrew's voice trembled and he turned away), "and suddenly that
20691. being is seized with pain, suffers, and ceases to exist.... Why? It
20692. cannot be that there is no answer. And I believe there is.... That's
20693. what convinces, that is what has convinced me," said Prince Andrew.
20694. 
20695. "Yes, yes, of course," said Pierre, "isn't that what I'm saying?"
20696. 
20697. "No. All I say is that it is not argument that convinces me of the
20698. necessity of a future life, but this: when you go hand in hand with
20699. someone and all at once that person vanishes there, into nowhere, and
20700. you yourself are left facing that abyss, and look in. And I have looked
20701. in...."
20702. 
20703. "Well, that's it then! You know that there is a there and there is a
20704. Someone? There is the future life. The Someone is--God."
20705. 
20706. Prince Andrew did not reply. The carriage and horses had long since been
20707. taken off, onto the farther bank, and reharnessed. The sun had sunk half
20708. below the horizon and an evening frost was starring the puddles near
20709. the ferry, but Pierre and Andrew, to the astonishment of the footmen,
20710. coachmen, and ferrymen, still stood on the raft and talked.
20711. 
20712. "If there is a God and future life, there is truth and good, and man's
20713. highest happiness consists in striving to attain them. We must live, we
20714. must love, and we must believe that we live not only today on this scrap
20715. of earth, but have lived and shall live forever, there, in the Whole,"
20716. said Pierre, and he pointed to the sky.
20717. 
20718. Prince Andrew stood leaning on the railing of the raft listening to
20719. Pierre, and he gazed with his eyes fixed on the red reflection of the
20720. sun gleaming on the blue waters. There was perfect stillness. Pierre
20721. became silent. The raft had long since stopped and only the waves of the
20722. current beat softly against it below. Prince Andrew felt as if the sound
20723. of the waves kept up a refrain to Pierre's words, whispering:
20724. 
20725. "It is true, believe it."
20726. 
20727. He sighed, and glanced with a radiant, childlike, tender look at
20728. Pierre's face, flushed and rapturous, but yet shy before his superior
20729. friend.
20730. 
20731. "Yes, if it only were so!" said Prince Andrew. "However, it is time to
20732. get on," he added, and, stepping off the raft, he looked up at the sky
20733. to which Pierre had pointed, and for the first time since Austerlitz saw
20734. that high, everlasting sky he had seen while lying on that battlefield;
20735. and something that had long been slumbering, something that was best
20736. within him, suddenly awoke, joyful and youthful, in his soul. It
20737. vanished as soon as he returned to the customary conditions of his
20738. life, but he knew that this feeling which he did not know how to develop
20739. existed within him. His meeting with Pierre formed an epoch in Prince
20740. Andrew's life. Though outwardly he continued to live in the same old
20741. way, inwardly he began a new life.
20742. 
20743. 
20744. 
20745. 
20746. 
20747. CHAPTER XIII
20748. 
20749. 
20750. It was getting dusk when Prince Andrew and Pierre drove up to the front
20751. entrance of the house at Bald Hills. As they approached the house,
20752. Prince Andrew with a smile drew Pierre's attention to a commotion going
20753. on at the back porch. A woman, bent with age, with a wallet on her back,
20754. and a short, long-haired, young man in a black garment had rushed back
20755. to the gate on seeing the carriage driving up. Two women ran out after
20756. them, and all four, looking round at the carriage, ran in dismay up the
20757. steps of the back porch.
20758. 
20759. "Those are Mary's 'God's folk,'" said Prince Andrew. "They have mistaken
20760. us for my father. This is the one matter in which she disobeys him. He
20761. orders these pilgrims to be driven away, but she receives them."
20762. 
20763. "But what are 'God's folk'?" asked Pierre.
20764. 
20765. Prince Andrew had no time to answer. The servants came out to meet them,
20766. and he asked where the old prince was and whether he was expected back
20767. soon.
20768. 
20769. The old prince had gone to the town and was expected back any minute.
20770. 
20771. Prince Andrew led Pierre to his own apartments, which were always kept
20772. in perfect order and readiness for him in his father's house; he himself
20773. went to the nursery.
20774. 
20775. "Let us go and see my sister," he said to Pierre when he returned.
20776. "I have not found her yet, she is hiding now, sitting with her 'God's
20777. folk.' It will serve her right, she will be confused, but you will see
20778. her 'God's folk.' It's really very curious."
20779. 
20780. "What are 'God's folk'?" asked Pierre.
20781. 
20782. "Come, and you'll see for yourself."
20783. 
20784. Princess Mary really was disconcerted and red patches came on her face
20785. when they went in. In her snug room, with lamps burning before the icon
20786. stand, a young lad with a long nose and long hair, wearing a monk's
20787. cassock, sat on the sofa beside her, behind a samovar. Near them, in an
20788. armchair, sat a thin, shriveled, old woman, with a meek expression on
20789. her childlike face.
20790. 
20791. "Andrew, why didn't you warn me?" said the princess, with mild reproach,
20792. as she stood before her pilgrims like a hen before her chickens.
20793. 
20794. "Charmee de vous voir. Je suis tres contente de vous voir," * she said
20795. to Pierre as he kissed her hand. She had known him as a child, and now
20796. his friendship with Andrew, his misfortune with his wife, and above all
20797. his kindly, simple face disposed her favorably toward him. She looked at
20798. him with her beautiful radiant eyes and seemed to say, "I like you very
20799. much, but please don't laugh at my people." After exchanging the first
20800. greetings, they sat down.
20801. 
20802. 
20803.     * "Delighted to see you. I am very glad to see you."
20804. 
20805. 
20806. "Ah, and Ivanushka is here too!" said Prince Andrew, glancing with a
20807. smile at the young pilgrim.
20808. 
20809. "Andrew!" said Princess Mary, imploringly. "Il faut que vous sachiez que
20810. c'est une femme," * said Prince Andrew to Pierre.

20813. 
20814. 
20815.      * "You must know that this is a woman."
20816. 
20817.      * (2) "For heaven's sake."
20818. 
20819. 
20820. It was evident that Prince Andrew's ironical tone toward the pilgrims

20823.

20830.      me for explaining to Pierre your intimacy with this young

20839. Princess Mary's embarrassment on her people's account was quite
20840. unnecessary. They were not in the least abashed. The old woman, lowering
20841. her eyes but casting side glances at the newcomers, had turned her cup
20842. upside down and placed a nibbled bit of sugar beside it, and sat
20843. quietly in her armchair, though hoping to be offered another cup of tea.
20844. Ivanushka, sipping out of her saucer, looked with sly womanish eyes from
20845. under her brows at the young men.
20846. 
20847. "Where have you been? To Kiev?" Prince Andrew asked the old woman.
20848. 
20849. "I have, good sir," she answered garrulously. "Just at Christmastime I
20850. was deemed worthy to partake of the holy and heavenly sacrament at the
20851. shrine of the saint. And now I'm from Kolyazin, master, where a great
20852. and wonderful blessing has been revealed."
20853. 
20854. "And was Ivanushka with you?"
20855. 
20856. "I go by myself, benefactor," said Ivanushka, trying to speak in a bass
20857. voice. "I only came across Pelageya in Yukhnovo..."
20858. 
20859. Pelageya interrupted her companion; she evidently wished to tell what
20860. she had seen.
20861. 
20862. "In Kolyazin, master, a wonderful blessing has been revealed."
20863. 
20864. "What is it? Some new relics?" asked Prince Andrew.
20865. 
20866. "Andrew, do leave off," said Princess Mary. "Don't tell him, Pelageya."
20867. 
20868. "No... why not, my dear, why shouldn't I? I like him. He is kind, he is
20869. one of God's chosen, he's a benefactor, he once gave me ten rubles, I
20870. remember. When I was in Kiev, Crazy Cyril says to me (he's one of God's
20871. own and goes barefoot summer and winter), he says, 'Why are you not
20872. going to the right place? Go to Kolyazin where a wonder-working icon of
20873. the Holy Mother of God has been revealed.' On hearing those words I said
20874. good-by to the holy folk and went."
20875. 
20876. All were silent, only the pilgrim woman went on in measured tones,
20877. drawing in her breath.
20878.

20880. revealed, holy oil trickles from the cheeks of our blessed Mother, the
20881. Holy Virgin Mother of God'...."
20882.

20884. flushing.
20885. 
20886. "Let me ask her," said Pierre. "Did you see it yourselves?" he inquired.
20887. 
20888. "Oh, yes, master, I was found worthy. Such a brightness on the face like
20889. the light of heaven, and from the blessed Mother's cheek it drops and
20890. drops...."
20891. 
20892. "But, dear me, that must be a fraud!" said Pierre, naively, who had
20893. listened attentively to the pilgrim.
20894.

20896. turning to Princess Mary for support.
20897.

20899. 
20900. "Lord Jesus Christ!" exclaimed the pilgrim woman, crossing herself. "Oh,
20901. don't speak so, master! There was a general who did not believe, and
20902. said, 'The monks cheat,' and as soon as he'd said it he went blind. And
20903. he dreamed that the Holy Virgin Mother of the Kiev catacombs came to him
20904. and said, 'Believe in me and I will make you whole.' So he begged: 'Take
20905. me to her, take me to her.' It's the real truth I'm telling you, I saw
20906. it myself. So he was brought, quite blind, straight to her, and he goes
20907. up to her and falls down and says, 'Make me whole,' says he, 'and I'll
20908. give thee what the Tsar bestowed on me.' I saw it myself, master, the
20909. star is fixed into the icon. Well, and what do you think? He received
20910. his sight! It's a sin to speak so. God will punish you," she said

20912. 
20913. "How did the star get into the icon?" Pierre asked.
20914. 
20915. "And was the Holy Mother promoted to the rank of general?" said Prince
20916. Andrew, with a smile.
20917. 
20918. Pelageya suddenly grew quite pale and clasped her hands.
20919.

20922. forgive you!" And she crossed herself. "Lord forgive him! My dear, what
20923. does it mean?..." she asked, turning to Princess Mary. She got up

20925. frightened and ashamed to have accepted charity in a house where such

20927. forgo the charity of this house.
20928. 
20929. "Now, why need you do it?" said Princess Mary. "Why did you come to
20930. me?..."
20931. 
20932. "Come, Pelageya, I was joking," said Pierre. "Princesse, ma parole,
20933. je n'ai pas voulu l'offenser. * I did not mean anything, I was only
20934. joking," he said, smiling shyly and trying to efface his offense. "It
20935. was all my fault, and Andrew was only joking."
20936. 
20937. 
20938.     * "Princess, on my word, I did not wish to offend her."
20939. 
20940. 
20941. Pelageya stopped doubtfully, but in Pierre's face there was such a look
20942. of sincere penitence, and Prince Andrew glanced so meekly now at her and

20946.
