20949. CHAPTER XIV
20950. 
20951. 
20952. The pilgrim woman was appeased and, being encouraged to talk, gave a
20953. long account of Father Amphilochus, who led so holy a life that his
20954. hands smelled of incense, and how on her last visit to Kiev some monks
20955. she knew let her have the keys of the catacombs, and how she, taking
20956. some dried bread with her, had spent two days in the catacombs with the
20957. saints. "I'd pray awhile to one, ponder awhile, then go on to another.
20958. I'd sleep a bit and then again go and kiss the relics, and there was
20959. such peace all around, such blessedness, that one don't want to come
20960. out, even into the light of heaven again."
20961. 
20962. Pierre listened to her attentively and seriously. Prince Andrew went
20963. out of the room, and then, leaving "God's folk" to finish their tea,
20964. Princess Mary took Pierre into the drawing room.
20965. 
20966. "You are very kind," she said to him.
20967. 
20968. "Oh, I really did not mean to hurt her feelings. I understand them so
20969. well and have the greatest respect for them."
20970. 
20971. Princess Mary looked at him silently and smiled affectionately.
20972. 
20973. "I have known you a long time, you see, and am as fond of you as of a
20974. brother," she said. "How do you find Andrew?" she added hurriedly, not
20975. giving him time to reply to her affectionate words. "I am very anxious
20976. about him. His health was better in the winter, but last spring his
20977. wound reopened and the doctor said he ought to go away for a cure. And
20978. I am also very much afraid for him spiritually. He has not a character
20979. like us women who, when we suffer, can weep away our sorrows. He keeps
20980. it all within him. Today he is cheerful and in good spirits, but that
20981. is the effect of your visit--he is not often like that. If you could
20982. persuade him to go abroad. He needs activity, and this quiet regular
20983. life is very bad for him. Others don't notice it, but I see it."
20984. 
20985. Toward ten o'clock the men servants rushed to the front door, hearing
20986. the bells of the old prince's carriage approaching. Prince Andrew and
20987. Pierre also went out into the porch.
20988. 
20989. "Who's that?" asked the old prince, noticing Pierre as he got out of the
20990. carriage.
20991. 
20992. "Ah! Very glad! Kiss me," he said, having learned who the young stranger
20993. was.
20994. 
20995. The old prince was in a good temper and very gracious to Pierre.
20996. 
20997. Before supper, Prince Andrew, coming back to his father's study, found
20998. him disputing hotly with his visitor. Pierre was maintaining that a time
20999. would come when there would be no more wars. The old prince disputed it
21000. chaffingly, but without getting angry.
21001. 
21002. "Drain the blood from men's veins and put in water instead, then there
21003. will be no more war! Old women's nonsense--old women's nonsense!" he
21004. repeated, but still he patted Pierre affectionately on the shoulder, and
21005. then went up to the table where Prince Andrew, evidently not wishing
21006. to join in the conversation, was looking over the papers his father
21007. had brought from town. The old prince went up to him and began to talk
21008. business.
21009. 
21010. "The marshal, a Count Rostov, hasn't sent half his contingent. He
21011. came to town and wanted to invite me to dinner--I gave him a pretty
21012. dinner!... And there, look at this.... Well, my boy," the old prince
21013. went on, addressing his son and patting Pierre on the shoulder. "A fine
21014. fellow--your friend--I like him! He stirs me up. Another says clever
21015. things and one doesn't care to listen, but this one talks rubbish yet
21016. stirs an old fellow up. Well, go! Get along! Perhaps I'll come and sit
21017. with you at supper. We'll have another dispute. Make friends with my
21018. little fool, Princess Mary," he shouted after Pierre, through the door.
21019. 
21020. Only now, on his visit to Bald Hills, did Pierre fully realize the
21021. strength and charm of his friendship with Prince Andrew. That charm was
21022. not expressed so much in his relations with him as with all his family
21023. and with the household. With the stern old prince and the gentle, timid
21024. Princess Mary, though he had scarcely known them, Pierre at once felt
21025. like an old friend. They were all fond of him already. Not only Princess
21026. Mary, who had been won by his gentleness with the pilgrims, gave him her
21027. most radiant looks, but even the one-year-old "Prince Nicholas" (as his
21028. grandfather called him) smiled at Pierre and let himself be taken in
21029. his arms, and Michael Ivanovich and Mademoiselle Bourienne looked at him
21030. with pleasant smiles when he talked to the old prince.
21031. 
21032. The old prince came in to supper; this was evidently on Pierre's
21033. account. And during the two days of the young man's visit he was
21034. extremely kind to him and told him to visit them again.
21035. 
21036. When Pierre had gone and the members of the household met together, they
21037. began to express their opinions of him as people always do after a new
21038. acquaintance has left, but as seldom happens, no one said anything but
21039. what was good of him.
21040. 
21041. 
21042. 
21043. 
21044. 
21045. CHAPTER XV
21046. 
21047. 
21048. When returning from his leave, Rostov felt, for the first time, how
21049. close was the bond that united him to Denisov and the whole regiment.
21050. 
21051. On approaching it, Rostov felt as he had done when approaching his home
21052. in Moscow. When he saw the first hussar with the unbuttoned uniform of
21053. his regiment, when he recognized red-haired Dementyev and saw the
21054. picket ropes of the roan horses, when Lavrushka gleefully shouted to his
21055. master, "The count has come!" and Denisov, who had been asleep on his
21056. bed, ran all disheveled out of the mud hut to embrace him, and the
21057. officers collected round to greet the new arrival, Rostov experienced
21058. the same feeling as when his mother, his father, and his sister had
21059. embraced him, and tears of joy choked him so that he could not speak.
21060. The regiment was also a home, and as unalterably dear and precious as
21061. his parents' house.
21062. 
21063. When he had reported himself to the commander of the regiment and had
21064. been reassigned to his former squadron, had been on duty and had gone
21065. out foraging, when he had again entered into all the little interests
21066. of the regiment and felt himself deprived of liberty and bound in one
21067. narrow, unchanging frame, he experienced the same sense of peace, of
21068. moral support, and the same sense of being at home here in his own
21069. place, as he had felt under the parental roof. But here was none of
21070. all that turmoil of the world at large, where he did not know his right
21071. place and took mistaken decisions; here was no Sonya with whom he ought,
21072. or ought not, to have an explanation; here was no possibility of going
21073. there or not going there; here there were not twenty-four hours in the
21074. day which could be spent in such a variety of ways; there was not that
21075. innumerable crowd of people of whom not one was nearer to him or farther
21076. from him than another; there were none of those uncertain and undefined
21077. money relations with his father, and nothing to recall that terrible
21078. loss to Dolokhov. Here, in the regiment, all was clear and simple.
21079. The whole world was divided into two unequal parts: one, our Pavlograd
21080. regiment; the other, all the rest. And the rest was no concern of
21081. his. In the regiment, everything was definite: who was lieutenant, who
21082. captain, who was a good fellow, who a bad one, and most of all, who was
21083. a comrade. The canteenkeeper gave one credit, one's pay came every four
21084. months, there was nothing to think out or decide, you had only to do
21085. nothing that was considered bad in the Pavlograd regiment and, when
21086. given an order, to do what was clearly, distinctly, and definitely
21087. ordered--and all would be well.
21088. 
21089. Having once more entered into the definite conditions of this regimental
21090. life, Rostov felt the joy and relief a tired man feels on lying down to
21091. rest. Life in the regiment, during this campaign, was all the pleasanter
21092. for him, because, after his loss to Dolokhov (for which, in spite of all
21093. his family's efforts to console him, he could not forgive himself), he
21094. had made up his mind to atone for his fault by serving, not as he
21095. had done before, but really well, and by being a perfectly first-rate
21096. comrade and officer--in a word, a splendid man altogether, a thing which
21097. seemed so difficult out in the world, but so possible in the regiment.
21098. 
21099. After his losses, he had determined to pay back his debt to his parents
21100. in five years. He received ten thousand rubles a year, but now resolved
21101. to take only two thousand and leave the rest to repay the debt to his
21102. parents.
21103. 
21104. Our army, after repeated retreats and advances and battles at Pultusk
21105. and Preussisch-Eylau, was concentrated near Bartenstein. It was awaiting
21106. the Emperor's arrival and the beginning of a new campaign.
21107. 
21108. The Pavlograd regiment, belonging to that part of the army which had
21109. served in the 1805 campaign, had been recruiting up to strength in
21110. Russia, and arrived too late to take part in the first actions of the
21111. campaign. It had been neither at Pultusk nor at Preussisch-Eylau and,
21112. when it joined the army in the field in the second half of the campaign,
21113. was attached to Platov's division.
21114. 
21115. Platov's division was acting independently of the main army. Several
21116. times parts of the Pavlograd regiment had exchanged shots with the
21117. enemy, had taken prisoners, and once had even captured Marshal Oudinot's
21118. carriages. In April the Pavlograds were stationed immovably for some
21119. weeks near a totally ruined and deserted German village.
21120. 
21121. A thaw had set in, it was muddy and cold, the ice on the river broke,
21122. and the roads became impassable. For days neither provisions for the
21123. men nor fodder for the horses had been issued. As no transports could
21124. arrive, the men dispersed about the abandoned and deserted villages,
21125. searching for potatoes, but found few even of these.
21126. 
21127. Everything had been eaten up and the inhabitants had all fled--if any
21128. remained, they were worse than beggars and nothing more could be taken
21129. from them; even the soldiers, usually pitiless enough, instead of taking
21130. anything from them, often gave them the last of their rations.
21131. 
21132. The Pavlograd regiment had had only two men wounded in action, but had
21133. lost nearly half its men from hunger and sickness. In the hospitals,
21134. death was so certain that soldiers suffering from fever, or the swelling
21135. that came from bad food, preferred to remain on duty, and hardly able
21136. to drag their legs went to the front rather than to the hospitals.
21137. When spring came on, the soldiers found a plant just showing out of the
21138. ground that looked like asparagus, which, for some reason, they called
21139. "Mashka's sweet root." It was very bitter, but they wandered about the
21140. fields seeking it and dug it out with their sabers and ate it, though
21141. they were ordered not to do so, as it was a noxious plant. That spring a
21142. new disease broke out among the soldiers, a swelling of the arms, legs,
21143. and face, which the doctors attributed to eating this root. But in spite
21144. of all this, the soldiers of Denisov's squadron fed chiefly on "Mashka's
21145. sweet root," because it was the second week that the last of the
21146. biscuits were being doled out at the rate of half a pound a man and the
21147. last potatoes received had sprouted and frozen.
21148. 
21149. The horses also had been fed for a fortnight on straw from the thatched
21150. roofs and had become terribly thin, though still covered with tufts of
21151. felty winter hair.
21152. 
21153. Despite this destitution, the soldiers and officers went on living just
21154. as usual. Despite their pale swollen faces and tattered uniforms, the
21155. hussars formed line for roll call, kept things in order, groomed their
21156. horses, polished their arms, brought in straw from the thatched roofs in
21157. place of fodder, and sat down to dine round the caldrons from which
21158. they rose up hungry, joking about their nasty food and their hunger. As
21159. usual, in their spare time, they lit bonfires, steamed themselves before
21160. them naked; smoked, picked out and baked sprouting rotten potatoes, told
21161. and listened to stories of Potemkin's and Suvorov's campaigns, or to
21162. legends of Alesha the Sly, or the priest's laborer Mikolka.
21163. 
21164. The officers, as usual, lived in twos and threes in the roofless,
21165. half-ruined houses. The seniors tried to collect straw and potatoes and,
21166. in general, food for the men. The younger ones occupied themselves as
21167. before, some playing cards (there was plenty of money, though there was
21168. no food), some with more innocent games, such as quoits and skittles.
21169. The general trend of the campaign was rarely spoken of, partly because
21170. nothing certain was known about it, partly because there was a vague
21171. feeling that in the main it was going badly.
21172. 
21173. Rostov lived, as before, with Denisov, and since their furlough they had
21174. become more friendly than ever. Denisov never spoke of Rostov's family,
21175. but by the tender friendship his commander showed him, Rostov felt
21176. that the elder hussar's luckless love for Natasha played a part in
21177. strengthening their friendship. Denisov evidently tried to expose Rostov
21178. to danger as seldom as possible, and after an action greeted his safe
21179. return with evident joy. On one of his foraging expeditions, in
21180. a deserted and ruined village to which he had come in search of
21181. provisions, Rostov found a family consisting of an old Pole and his
21182. daughter with an infant in arms. They were half clad, hungry, too weak
21183. to get away on foot and had no means of obtaining a conveyance. Rostov
21184. brought them to his quarters, placed them in his own lodging, and
21185. kept them for some weeks while the old man was recovering. One of his
21186. comrades, talking of women, began chaffing Rostov, saying that he was
21187. more wily than any of them and that it would not be a bad thing if he
21188. introduced to them the pretty Polish girl he had saved. Rostov took the
21189. joke as an insult, flared up, and said such unpleasant things to the
21190. officer that it was all Denisov could do to prevent a duel. When the
21191. officer had gone away, Denisov, who did not himself know what Rostov's
21192. relations with the Polish girl might be, began to upbraid him for his
21193. quickness of temper, and Rostov replied:
21194. 
21195. "Say what you like.... She is like a sister to me, and I can't tell you
21196. how it offended me... because... well, for that reason...."
21197. 
21198. Denisov patted him on the shoulder and began rapidly pacing the room
21199. without looking at Rostov, as was his way at moments of deep feeling.
21200. 
21201. "Ah, what a mad bweed you Wostovs are!" he muttered, and Rostov noticed
21202. tears in his eyes.
21203. 
21204. 
21205. 
21206. 
21207. 
21208. CHAPTER XVI
21209. 
21210. 
21211. In April the troops were enlivened by news of the Emperor's arrival,
21212. but Rostov had no chance of being present at the review he held at
21213. Bartenstein, as the Pavlograds were at the outposts far beyond that
21214. place.
21215. 
21216. They were bivouacking. Denisov and Rostov were living in an earth hut,
21217. dug out for them by the soldiers and roofed with branches and turf. The
21218. hut was made in the following manner, which had then come into vogue. A
21219. trench was dug three and a half feet wide, four feet eight inches deep,
21220. and eight feet long. At one end of the trench, steps were cut out and
21221. these formed the entrance and vestibule. The trench itself was the room,
21222. in which the lucky ones, such as the squadron commander, had a board,
21223. lying on piles at the end opposite the entrance, to serve as a table. On
21224. each side of the trench, the earth was cut out to a breadth of about two
21225. and a half feet, and this did duty for bedsteads and couches. The roof
21226. was so constructed that one could stand up in the middle of the trench
21227. and could even sit up on the beds if one drew close to the table.
21228. Denisov, who was living luxuriously because the soldiers of his squadron
21229. liked him, had also a board in the roof at the farther end, with a piece
21230. of (broken but mended) glass in it for a window. When it was very cold,
21231. embers from the soldiers' campfire were placed on a bent sheet of iron
21232. on the steps in the "reception room"--as Denisov called that part of
21233. the hut--and it was then so warm that the officers, of whom there were
21234. always some with Denisov and Rostov, sat in their shirt sleeves.
21235. 
21236. In April, Rostov was on orderly duty. One morning, between seven and
21237. eight, returning after a sleepless night, he sent for embers, changed
21238. his rain-soaked underclothes, said his prayers, drank tea, got warm,
21239. then tidied up the things on the table and in his own corner, and,
21240. his face glowing from exposure to the wind and with nothing on but his
21241. shirt, lay down on his back, putting his arms under his head. He was
21242. pleasantly considering the probability of being promoted in a few days
21243. for his last reconnoitering expedition, and was awaiting Denisov, who
21244. had gone out somewhere and with whom he wanted a talk.
21245. 
21246. Suddenly he heard Denisov shouting in a vibrating voice behind the hut,
21247. evidently much excited. Rostov moved to the window to see whom he was
21248. speaking to, and saw the quartermaster, Topcheenko.
21249. 
21250. "I ordered you not to let them eat that Mashka woot stuff!" Denisov was
21251. shouting. "And I saw with my own eyes how Lazarchuk bwought some fwom
21252. the fields."
21253. 
21254. "I have given the order again and again, your honor, but they don't
21255. obey," answered the quartermaster.
21256. 
21257. Rostov lay down again on his bed and thought complacently: "Let him fuss
21258. and bustle now, my job's done and I'm lying down--capitally!" He could
21259. hear that Lavrushka--that sly, bold orderly of Denisov's--was talking,
21260. as well as the quartermaster. Lavrushka was saying something about
21261. loaded wagons, biscuits, and oxen he had seen when he had gone out for
21262. provisions.
21263. 
21264. Then Denisov's voice was heard shouting farther and farther away.
21265. "Saddle! Second platoon!"
21266. 
21267. "Where are they off to now?" thought Rostov.
21268. 
21269. Five minutes later, Denisov came into the hut, climbed with muddy boots
21270. on the bed, lit his pipe, furiously scattered his things about, took
21271. his leaded whip, buckled on his saber, and went out again. In answer
21272. to Rostov's inquiry where he was going, he answered vaguely and crossly
21273. that he had some business.
21274. 
21275. "Let God and our gweat monarch judge me afterwards!" said Denisov going
21276. out, and Rostov heard the hoofs of several horses splashing through the
21277. mud. He did not even trouble to find out where Denisov had gone. Having
21278. got warm in his corner, he fell asleep and did not leave the hut till
21279. toward evening. Denisov had not yet returned. The weather had cleared
21280. up, and near the next hut two officers and a cadet were playing svayka,
21281. laughing as they threw their missiles which buried themselves in the
21282. soft mud. Rostov joined them. In the middle of the game, the officers
21283. saw some wagons approaching with fifteen hussars on their skinny horses
21284. behind them. The wagons escorted by the hussars drew up to the picket
21285. ropes and a crowd of hussars surrounded them.
21286. 
21287. "There now, Denisov has been worrying," said Rostov, "and here are the
21288. provisions."
21289. 
21290. "So they are!" said the officers. "Won't the soldiers be glad!"
21291. 
21292. A little behind the hussars came Denisov, accompanied by two infantry
21293. officers with whom he was talking.
21294. 
21295. Rostov went to meet them.
21296. 
21297. "I warn you, Captain," one of the officers, a short thin man, evidently
21298. very angry, was saying.
21299. 
21300. "Haven't I told you I won't give them up?" replied Denisov.
21301. 
21302. "You will answer for it, Captain. It is mutiny--seizing the transport of
21303. one's own army. Our men have had nothing to eat for two days."
21304. 
21305. "And mine have had nothing for two weeks," said Denisov.
21306. 
21307. "It is robbery! You'll answer for it, sir!" said the infantry officer,
21308. raising his voice.
21309. 
21310. "Now, what are you pestewing me for?" cried Denisov, suddenly losing his
21311. temper. "I shall answer for it and not you, and you'd better not buzz
21312. about here till you get hurt. Be off! Go!" he shouted at the officers.
21313. 
21314. "Very well, then!" shouted the little officer, undaunted and not riding
21315. away. "If you are determined to rob, I'll..."
21316. 
21317. "Go to the devil! quick ma'ch, while you're safe and sound!" and Denisov
21318. turned his horse on the officer.
21319. 
21320. "Very well, very well!" muttered the officer, threateningly, and turning
21321. his horse he trotted away, jolting in his saddle.
21322. 
21323. "A dog astwide a fence! A weal dog astwide a fence!" shouted Denisov
21324. after him (the most insulting expression a cavalryman can address to a
21325. mounted infantryman) and riding up to Rostov, he burst out laughing.
21326. 
21327. "I've taken twansports from the infantwy by force!" he said. "After all,
21328. can't let our men starve."
21329. 
21330. The wagons that had reached the hussars had been consigned to an
21331. infantry regiment, but learning from Lavrushka that the transport
21332. was unescorted, Denisov with his hussars had seized it by force. The
21333. soldiers had biscuits dealt out to them freely, and they even shared
21334. them with the other squadrons.
21335. 
21336. The next day the regimental commander sent for Denisov, and holding his
21337. fingers spread out before his eyes said:
21338. 
21339. "This is how I look at this affair: I know nothing about it and won't
21340. begin proceedings, but I advise you to ride over to the staff and settle
21341. the business there in the commissariat department and if possible sign
21342. a receipt for such and such stores received. If not, as the demand was
21343. booked against an infantry regiment, there will be a row and the affair
21344. may end badly."
21345. 
21346. From the regimental commander's, Denisov rode straight to the staff with
21347. a sincere desire to act on this advice. In the evening he came back to
21348. his dugout in a state such as Rostov had never yet seen him in. Denisov
21349. could not speak and gasped for breath. When Rostov asked what was the
21350. matter, he only uttered some incoherent oaths and threats in a hoarse,
21351. feeble voice.
21352. 
21353. Alarmed at Denisov's condition, Rostov suggested that he should undress,
21354. drink some water, and send for the doctor.
21355. 
21356. "Twy me for wobbewy... oh! Some more water... Let them twy me, but I'll
21357. always thwash scoundwels... and I'll tell the Empewo'... Ice..." he
21358. muttered.
21359. 
21360. The regimental doctor, when he came, said it was absolutely necessary to
21361. bleed Denisov. A deep saucer of black blood was taken from his hairy arm
21362. and only then was he able to relate what had happened to him.
21363. 
21364. "I get there," began Denisov. "'Now then, where's your chief's
21365. quarters?' They were pointed out. 'Please to wait.' 'I've widden twenty
21366. miles and have duties to attend to and no time to wait. Announce me.'
21367. Vewy well, so out comes their head chief--also took it into his head to
21368. lecture me: 'It's wobbewy!'--'Wobbewy,' I say, 'is not done by man who
21369. seizes pwovisions to feed his soldiers, but by him who takes them to
21370. fill his own pockets!' 'Will you please be silent?' 'Vewy good!' Then he
21371. says: 'Go and give a weceipt to the commissioner, but your affair will
21372. be passed on to headquarters.' I go to the commissioner. I enter, and at
21373. the table... who do you think? No, but wait a bit!... Who is it that's
21374. starving us?" shouted Denisov, hitting the table with the fist of his
21375. newly bled arm so violently that the table nearly broke down and
21376. the tumblers on it jumped about. "Telyanin! 'What? So it's you who's
21377. starving us to death! Is it? Take this and this!' and I hit him so
21378. pat, stwaight on his snout... 'Ah, what a... what a...!' and I sta'ted
21379. fwashing him... Well, I've had a bit of fun I can tell you!" cried
21380. Denisov, gleeful and yet angry, his white teeth showing under his black
21381. mustache. "I'd have killed him if they hadn't taken him away!"
21382. 
21383. "But what are you shouting for? Calm yourself," said Rostov. "You've set
21384. your arm bleeding afresh. Wait, we must tie it up again."
21385. 
21386. Denisov was bandaged up again and put to bed. Next day he woke calm and
21387. cheerful.
21388. 
21389. But at noon the adjutant of the regiment came into Rostov's and
21390. Denisov's dugout with a grave and serious face and regretfully showed
21391. them a paper addressed to Major Denisov from the regimental commander
21392. in which inquiries were made about yesterday's occurrence. The adjutant
21393. told them that the affair was likely to take a very bad turn: that a
21394. court-martial had been appointed, and that in view of the severity with
21395. which marauding and insubordination were now regarded, degradation to
21396. the ranks would be the best that could be hoped for.
21397. 
21398. The case, as represented by the offended parties, was that, after
21399. seizing the transports, Major Denisov, being drunk, went to the chief
21400. quartermaster and without any provocation called him a thief, threatened
21401. to strike him, and on being led out had rushed into the office and given
21402. two officials a thrashing, and dislocated the arm of one of them.
21403. 
21404. In answer to Rostov's renewed questions, Denisov said, laughing, that he
21405. thought he remembered that some other fellow had got mixed up in it, but
21406. that it was all nonsense and rubbish, and he did not in the least fear
21407. any kind of trial, and that if those scoundrels dared attack him he
21408. would give them an answer that they would not easily forget.
21409. 
21410. Denisov spoke contemptuously of the whole matter, but Rostov knew him
21411. too well not to detect that (while hiding it from others) at heart
21412. he feared a court-martial and was worried over the affair, which was
21413. evidently taking a bad turn. Every day, letters of inquiry and notices
21414. from the court arrived, and on the first of May, Denisov was ordered to
21415. hand the squadron over to the next in seniority and appear before
21416. the staff of his division to explain his violence at the commissariat
21417. office. On the previous day Platov reconnoitered with two Cossack
21418. regiments and two squadrons of hussars. Denisov, as was his wont, rode
21419. out in front of the outposts, parading his courage. A bullet fired by
21420. a French sharpshooter hit him in the fleshy part of his leg. Perhaps at
21421. another time Denisov would not have left the regiment for so slight a
21422. wound, but now he took advantage of it to excuse himself from appearing
21423. at the staff and went into hospital.
21424. 
21425. 
21426. 
21427. 
21428. 
21429. CHAPTER XVII
21430. 
21431. 
21432. In June the battle of Friedland was fought, in which the Pavlograds did
21433. not take part, and after that an armistice was proclaimed. Rostov, who
21434. felt his friend's absence very much, having no news of him since he
21435. left and feeling very anxious about his wound and the progress of his
21436. affairs, took advantage of the armistice to get leave to visit Denisov
21437. in hospital.
21438. 
21439. The hospital was in a small Prussian town that had been twice devastated
21440. by Russian and French troops. Because it was summer, when it is so
21441. beautiful out in the fields, the little town presented a particularly
21442. dismal appearance with its broken roofs and fences, its foul streets,
21443. tattered inhabitants, and the sick and drunken soldiers wandering about.
21444. 
21445. The hospital was in a brick building with some of the window frames and
21446. panes broken and a courtyard surrounded by the remains of a wooden fence
21447. that had been pulled to pieces. Several bandaged soldiers, with pale
21448. swollen faces, were sitting or walking about in the sunshine in the
21449. yard.
21450. 
21451. Directly Rostov entered the door he was enveloped by a smell of
21452. putrefaction and hospital air. On the stairs he met a Russian army
21453. doctor smoking a cigar. The doctor was followed by a Russian assistant.
21454. 
21455. "I can't tear myself to pieces," the doctor was saying. "Come to Makar
21456. Alexeevich in the evening. I shall be there."
21457. 
21458. The assistant asked some further questions.
21459. 
21460. "Oh, do the best you can! Isn't it all the same?" The doctor noticed
21461. Rostov coming upstairs.
21462. 
21463. "What do you want, sir?" said the doctor. "What do you want? The bullets
21464. having spared you, do you want to try typhus? This is a pesthouse, sir."
21465. 
21466. "How so?" asked Rostov.
21467. 
21468. "Typhus, sir. It's death to go in. Only we two, Makeev and I" (he
21469. pointed to the assistant), "keep on here. Some five of us doctors have
21470. died in this place.... When a new one comes he is done for in a week,"
21471. said the doctor with evident satisfaction. "Prussian doctors have been
21472. invited here, but our allies don't like it at all."
21473. 
21474. Rostov explained that he wanted to see Major Denisov of the hussars, who
21475. was wounded.
21476. 
21477. "I don't know. I can't tell you, sir. Only think! I am alone in charge
21478. of three hospitals with more than four hundred patients! It's well that
21479. the charitable Prussian ladies send us two pounds of coffee and some
21480. lint each month or we should be lost!" he laughed. "Four hundred, sir,
21481. and they're always sending me fresh ones. There are four hundred? Eh?"
21482. he asked, turning to the assistant.
21483. 
21484. The assistant looked fagged out. He was evidently vexed and impatient
21485. for the talkative doctor to go.
21486. 
21487. "Major Denisov," Rostov said again. "He was wounded at Molliten."
21488. 
21489. "Dead, I fancy. Eh, Makeev?" queried the doctor, in a tone of
21490. indifference.
21491. 
21492. The assistant, however, did not confirm the doctor's words.
21493. 
21494. "Is he tall and with reddish hair?" asked the doctor.
21495. 
21496. Rostov described Denisov's appearance.
21497. 
21498. "There was one like that," said the doctor, as if pleased. "That one is
21499. dead, I fancy. However, I'll look up our list. We had a list. Have you
21500. got it, Makeev?"
21501. 
21502. "Makar Alexeevich has the list," answered the assistant. "But if you'll
21503. step into the officers' wards you'll see for yourself," he added,
21504. turning to Rostov.
21505. 
21506. "Ah, you'd better not go, sir," said the doctor, "or you may have to
21507. stay here yourself."
21508. 
21509. But Rostov bowed himself away from the doctor and asked the assistant to
21510. show him the way.
21511. 
21512. "Only don't blame me!" the doctor shouted up after him.
21513. 
21514. Rostov and the assistant went into the dark corridor. The smell was so
21515. strong there that Rostov held his nose and had to pause and collect
21516. his strength before he could go on. A door opened to the right, and an
21517. emaciated sallow man on crutches, barefoot and in underclothing, limped
21518. out and, leaning against the doorpost, looked with glittering envious
21519. eyes at those who were passing. Glancing in at the door, Rostov saw that
21520. the sick and wounded were lying on the floor on straw and overcoats.
21521. 
21522. "May I go in and look?"
21523. 
21524. "What is there to see?" said the assistant.
21525. 
21526. But, just because the assistant evidently did not want him to go in,
21527. Rostov entered the soldiers' ward. The foul air, to which he had already
21528. begun to get used in the corridor, was still stronger here. It was a
21529. little different, more pungent, and one felt that this was where it
21530. originated.
21531. 
21532. In the long room, brightly lit up by the sun through the large windows,
21533. the sick and wounded lay in two rows with their heads to the walls, and
21534. leaving a passage in the middle. Most of them were unconscious and
21535. paid no attention to the newcomers. Those who were conscious raised
21536. themselves or lifted their thin yellow faces, and all looked intently at
21537. Rostov with the same expression of hope, of relief, reproach, and envy
21538. of another's health. Rostov went to the middle of the room and looking
21539. through the open doors into the two adjoining rooms saw the same thing
21540. there. He stood still, looking silently around. He had not at all
21541. expected such a sight. Just before him, almost across the middle of the
21542. passage on the bare floor, lay a sick man, probably a Cossack to judge
21543. by the cut of his hair. The man lay on his back, his huge arms and legs
21544. outstretched. His face was purple, his eyes were rolled back so that
21545. only the whites were seen, and on his bare legs and arms which were
21546. still red, the veins stood out like cords. He was knocking the back of
21547. his head against the floor, hoarsely uttering some word which he kept
21548. repeating. Rostov listened and made out the word. It was "drink, drink,
21549. a drink!" Rostov glanced round, looking for someone who would put this
21550. man back in his place and bring him water.
21551. 
21552. "Who looks after the sick here?" he asked the assistant.
21553. 
21554. Just then a commissariat soldier, a hospital orderly, came in from the
21555. next room, marching stiffly, and drew up in front of Rostov.
21556. 
21557. "Good day, your honor!" he shouted, rolling his eyes at Rostov and
21558. evidently mistaking him for one of the hospital authorities.
21559. 
21560. "Get him to his place and give him some water," said Rostov, pointing to
21561. the Cossack.
21562. 
21563. "Yes, your honor," the soldier replied complacently, and rolling his
21564. eyes more than ever he drew himself up still straighter, but did not
21565. move.
21566. 
21567. "No, it's impossible to do anything here," thought Rostov, lowering his
21568. eyes, and he was going out, but became aware of an intense look fixed
21569. on him on his right, and he turned. Close to the corner, on an overcoat,
21570. sat an old, unshaven, gray-bearded soldier as thin as a skeleton, with a
21571. stern sallow face and eyes intently fixed on Rostov. The man's neighbor
21572. on one side whispered something to him, pointing at Rostov, who noticed
21573. that the old man wanted to speak to him. He drew nearer and saw that the
21574. old man had only one leg bent under him, the other had been amputated
21575. above the knee. His neighbor on the other side, who lay motionless some
21576. distance from him with his head thrown back, was a young soldier with
21577. a snub nose. His pale waxen face was still freckled and his eyes were
21578. rolled back. Rostov looked at the young soldier and a cold chill ran
21579. down his back.
21580. 
21581. "Why, this one seems..." he began, turning to the assistant.
21582. 
21583. "And how we've been begging, your honor," said the old soldier, his
21584. jaw quivering. "He's been dead since morning. After all we're men, not
21585. dogs."
21586. 
21587. "I'll send someone at once. He shall be taken away--taken away at once,"
21588. said the assistant hurriedly. "Let us go, your honor."
21589. 
21590. "Yes, yes, let us go," said Rostov hastily, and lowering his eyes and
21591. shrinking, he tried to pass unnoticed between the rows of reproachful
21592. envious eyes that were fixed upon him, and went out of the room.
21593. 
21594. 
21595. 
21596. 
21597. 
21598. CHAPTER XVIII
21599. 
21600. 
21601. Going along the corridor, the assistant led Rostov to the officers'
21602. wards, consisting of three rooms, the doors of which stood open. There
21603. were beds in these rooms and the sick and wounded officers were lying or
21604. sitting on them. Some were walking about the rooms in hospital dressing
21605. gowns. The first person Rostov met in the officers' ward was a thin
21606. little man with one arm, who was walking about the first room in a
21607. nightcap and hospital dressing gown, with a pipe between his teeth.
21608. Rostov looked at him, trying to remember where he had seen him before.
21609. 
21610. "See where we've met again!" said the little man. "Tushin, Tushin, don't
21611. you remember, who gave you a lift at Schon Grabern? And I've had a bit
21612. cut off, you see..." he went on with a smile, pointing to the empty
21613. sleeve of his dressing gown. "Looking for Vasili Dmitrich Denisov? My
21614. neighbor," he added, when he heard who Rostov wanted. "Here, here," and
21615. Tushin led him into the next room, from whence came sounds of several
21616. laughing voices.
21617. 
21618. "How can they laugh, or even live at all here?" thought Rostov, still
21619. aware of that smell of decomposing flesh that had been so strong in
21620. the soldiers' ward, and still seeming to see fixed on him those envious
21621. looks which had followed him out from both sides, and the face of that
21622. young soldier with eyes rolled back.
21623. 
21624. Denisov lay asleep on his bed with his head under the blanket, though it
21625. was nearly noon.
21626. 
21627. "Ah, Wostov? How are you, how are you?" he called out, still in the
21628. same voice as in the regiment, but Rostov noticed sadly that under this
21629. habitual ease and animation some new, sinister, hidden feeling showed
21630. itself in the expression of Denisov's face and the intonations of his
21631. voice.
21632. 
21633. His wound, though a slight one, had not yet healed even now, six weeks
21634. after he had been hit. His face had the same swollen pallor as the faces
21635. of the other hospital patients, but it was not this that struck Rostov.
21636. What struck him was that Denisov did not seem glad to see him, and
21637. smiled at him unnaturally. He did not ask about the regiment, nor about
21638. the general state of affairs, and when Rostov spoke of these matters did
21639. not listen.
21640. 
21641. Rostov even noticed that Denisov did not like to be reminded of the
21642. regiment, or in general of that other free life which was going on
21643. outside the hospital. He seemed to try to forget that old life and
21644. was only interested in the affair with the commissariat officers. On
21645. Rostov's inquiry as to how the matter stood, he at once produced from
21646. under his pillow a paper he had received from the commission and the
21647. rough draft of his answer to it. He became animated when he began
21648. reading his paper and specially drew Rostov's attention to the stinging
21649. rejoinders he made to his enemies. His hospital companions, who had
21650. gathered round Rostov--a fresh arrival from the world outside--gradually
21651. began to disperse as soon as Denisov began reading his answer. Rostov
21652. noticed by their faces that all those gentlemen had already heard that
21653. story more than once and were tired of it. Only the man who had the next
21654. bed, a stout Uhlan, continued to sit on his bed, gloomily frowning and
21655. smoking a pipe, and little one-armed Tushin still listened, shaking his
21656. head disapprovingly. In the middle of the reading, the Uhlan interrupted
21657. Denisov.
21658. 
21659. "But what I say is," he said, turning to Rostov, "it would be best
21660. simply to petition the Emperor for pardon. They say great rewards will
21661. now be distributed, and surely a pardon would be granted...."
21662. 
21663. "Me petition the Empewo'!" exclaimed Denisov, in a voice to which he
21664. tried hard to give the old energy and fire, but which sounded like an
21665. expression of irritable impotence. "What for? If I were a wobber I would
21666. ask mercy, but I'm being court-martialed for bwinging wobbers to book.
21667. Let them twy me, I'm not afwaid of anyone. I've served the Tsar and
21668. my countwy honowably and have not stolen! And am I to be degwaded?...
21669. Listen, I'm w'iting to them stwaight. This is what I say: 'If I had
21670. wobbed the Tweasuwy...'"
21671. 
21672. "It's certainly well written," said Tushin, "but that's not the point,
21673. Vasili Dmitrich," and he also turned to Rostov. "One has to submit, and
21674. Vasili Dmitrich doesn't want to. You know the auditor told you it was a
21675. bad business."
21676. 
21677. "Well, let it be bad," said Denisov.
21678. 
21679. "The auditor wrote out a petition for you," continued Tushin, "and
21680. you ought to sign it and ask this gentleman to take it. No doubt he"
21681. (indicating Rostov) "has connections on the staff. You won't find a
21682. better opportunity."
21683. 
21684. "Haven't I said I'm not going to gwovel?" Denisov interrupted him, went
21685. on reading his paper.
21686. 
21687. Rostov had not the courage to persuade Denisov, though he instinctively
21688. felt that the way advised by Tushin and the other officers was the
21689. safest, and though he would have been glad to be of service to Denisov.
21690. He knew his stubborn will and straightforward hasty temper.
21691. 
21692. When the reading of Denisov's virulent reply, which took more than an
21693. hour, was over, Rostov said nothing, and he spent the rest of the day in
21694. a most dejected state of mind amid Denisov's hospital comrades, who had
21695. gathered round him, telling them what he knew and listening to their
21696. stories. Denisov was moodily silent all the evening.
21697. 
21698. Late in the evening, when Rostov was about to leave, he asked Denisov
21699. whether he had no commission for him.
21700. 
21701. "Yes, wait a bit," said Denisov, glancing round at the officers, and
21702. taking his papers from under his pillow he went to the window, where he
21703. had an inkpot, and sat down to write.
21704. 
21705. "It seems it's no use knocking one's head against a wall!" he said,
21706. coming from the window and giving Rostov a large envelope. In it was
21707. the petition to the Emperor drawn up by the auditor, in which Denisov,
21708. without alluding to the offenses of the commissariat officials, simply
21709. asked for pardon.
21710. 
21711. "Hand it in. It seems..."
21712. 
21713. He did not finish, but gave a painfully unnatural smile.
21714. 
21715. 
21716. 
21717. 
21718. 
21719. CHAPTER XIX
21720. 
21721. 
21722. Having returned to the regiment and told the commander the state of
21723. Denisov's affairs, Rostov rode to Tilsit with the letter to the Emperor.
21724. 
21725. On the thirteenth of June the French and Russian Emperors arrived in
21726. Tilsit. Boris Drubetskoy had asked the important personage on whom he
21727. was in attendance, to include him in the suite appointed for the stay at
21728. Tilsit.
21729. 
21730. "I should like to see the great man," he said, alluding to Napoleon,
21731. whom hitherto he, like everyone else, had always called Buonaparte.
21732. 
21733. "You are speaking of Buonaparte?" asked the general, smiling.
21734. 
21735. Boris looked at his general inquiringly and immediately saw that he was
21736. being tested.
21737. 
21738. "I am speaking, Prince, of the Emperor Napoleon," he replied. The
21739. general patted him on the shoulder, with a smile.
21740. 
21741. "You will go far," he said, and took him to Tilsit with him.
21742. 
21743. Boris was among the few present at the Niemen on the day the two
21744. Emperors met. He saw the raft, decorated with monograms, saw Napoleon
21745. pass before the French Guards on the farther bank of the river, saw the
21746. pensive face of the Emperor Alexander as he sat in silence in a tavern
21747. on the bank of the Niemen awaiting Napoleon's arrival, saw both Emperors
21748. get into boats, and saw how Napoleon--reaching the raft first--stepped
21749. quickly forward to meet Alexander and held out his hand to him, and how
21750. they both retired into the pavilion. Since he had begun to move in the
21751. highest circles Boris had made it his habit to watch attentively all
21752. that went on around him and to note it down. At the time of the meeting
21753. at Tilsit he asked the names of those who had come with Napoleon and
21754. about the uniforms they wore, and listened attentively to words spoken
21755. by important personages. At the moment the Emperors went into the
21756. pavilion he looked at his watch, and did not forget to look at it
21757. again when Alexander came out. The interview had lasted an hour and
21758. fifty-three minutes. He noted this down that same evening, among other
21759. facts he felt to be of historic importance. As the Emperor's suite was
21760. a very small one, it was a matter of great importance, for a man who
21761. valued his success in the service, to be at Tilsit on the occasion of
21762. this interview between the two Emperors, and having succeeded in this,
21763. Boris felt that henceforth his position was fully assured. He had not
21764. only become known, but people had grown accustomed to him and accepted
21765. him. Twice he had executed commissions to the Emperor himself, so
21766. that the latter knew his face, and all those at court, far from
21767. cold-shouldering him as at first when they considered him a newcomer,
21768. would now have been surprised had he been absent.
21769. 
21770. Boris lodged with another adjutant, the Polish Count Zhilinski.
21771. Zhilinski, a Pole brought up in Paris, was rich, and passionately
21772. fond of the French, and almost every day of the stay at Tilsit, French
21773. officers of the Guard and from French headquarters were dining and
21774. lunching with him and Boris.
21775. 
21776. On the evening of the twenty-fourth of June, Count Zhilinski arranged a
21777. supper for his French friends. The guest of honor was an aide-de-camp of
21778. Napoleon's, there were also several French officers of the Guard, and
21779. a page of Napoleon's, a young lad of an old aristocratic French
21780. family. That same day, Rostov, profiting by the darkness to avoid being
21781. recognized in civilian dress, came to Tilsit and went to the lodging
21782. occupied by Boris and Zhilinski.
21783. 
21784. Rostov, in common with the whole army from which he came, was far
21785. from having experienced the change of feeling toward Napoleon and the
21786. French--who from being foes had suddenly become friends--that had taken
21787. place at headquarters and in Boris. In the army, Bonaparte and the
21788. French were still regarded with mingled feelings of anger, contempt,
21789. and fear. Only recently, talking with one of Platov's Cossack officers,
21790. Rostov had argued that if Napoleon were taken prisoner he would be
21791. treated not as a sovereign, but as a criminal. Quite lately, happening
21792. to meet a wounded French colonel on the road, Rostov had maintained with
21793. heat that peace was impossible between a legitimate sovereign and the
21794. criminal Bonaparte. Rostov was therefore unpleasantly struck by the
21795. presence of French officers in Boris' lodging, dressed in uniforms he
21796. had been accustomed to see from quite a different point of view from
21797. the outposts of the flank. As soon as he noticed a French officer, who
21798. thrust his head out of the door, that warlike feeling of hostility which
21799. he always experienced at the sight of the enemy suddenly seized him. He
21800. stopped at the threshold and asked in Russian whether Drubetskoy lived
21801. there. Boris, hearing a strange voice in the anteroom, came out to meet
21802. him. An expression of annoyance showed itself for a moment on his face
21803. on first recognizing Rostov.
21804. 
21805. "Ah, it's you? Very glad, very glad to see you," he said, however,
21806. coming toward him with a smile. But Rostov had noticed his first
21807. impulse.
21808. 
21809. "I've come at a bad time I think. I should not have come, but I have
21810. business," he said coldly.
21811. 
21812. "No, I only wonder how you managed to get away from your regiment. Dans
21813. un moment je suis a vous," * he said, answering someone who called him.
21814. 
21815. 
21816.     * "In a minute I shall be at your disposal."
21817. 
21818. 
21819. "I see I'm intruding," Rostov repeated.
21820. 
21821. The look of annoyance had already disappeared from Boris' face: having
21822. evidently reflected and decided how to act, he very quietly took
21823. both Rostov's hands and led him into the next room. His eyes, looking
21824. serenely and steadily at Rostov, seemed to be veiled by something, as if
21825. screened by blue spectacles of conventionality. So it seemed to Rostov.
21826. 
21827. "Oh, come now! As if you could come at a wrong time!" said Boris, and he
21828. led him into the room where the supper table was laid and introduced
21829. him to his guests, explaining that he was not a civilian, but an hussar
21830. officer, and an old friend of his.
21831.

21834. reluctantly, and remained silent.
21835. 
21836. Zhilinski evidently did not receive this new Russian person very
21837. willingly into his circle and did not speak to Rostov. Boris did not
21838. appear to notice the constraint the newcomer produced and, with the same
21839. pleasant composure and the same veiled look in his eyes with which he
21840. had met Rostov, tried to enliven the conversation. One of the Frenchmen,
21841. with the politeness characteristic of his countrymen, addressed the
21842. obstinately taciturn Rostov, saying that the latter had probably come to
21843. Tilsit to see the Emperor.
21844. 
21845. "No, I came on business," replied Rostov, briefly.
21846. 
21847. Rostov had been out of humor from the moment he noticed the look of
21848. dissatisfaction on Boris' face, and as always happens to those in a bad
21849. humor, it seemed to him that everyone regarded him with aversion and
21850. that he was in everybody's way. He really was in their way, for he alone
21851. took no part in the conversation which again became general. The looks
21852. the visitors cast on him seemed to say: "And what is he sitting here
21853. for?" He rose and went up to Boris.
21854. 
21855. "Anyhow, I'm in your way," he said in a low tone. "Come and talk over my
21856. business and I'll go away."
21857. 
21858. "Oh, no, not at all," said Boris. "But if you are tired, come and lie
21859. down in my room and have a rest."
21860. 
21861. "Yes, really..."
21862. 
21863. They went into the little room where Boris slept. Rostov, without

21873. eyes with the same veiled look. Each time this happened Rostov felt
21874. uncomfortable and cast down his eyes.
21875. 
21876. "I have heard of such cases and know that His Majesty is very severe
21877. in such affairs. I think it would be best not to bring it before the

21879. I think..."
21880. 
21881. "So you don't want to do anything? Well then, say so!" Rostov almost

21883. 
21884. Boris smiled.
21885.

21887. 
21888. At that moment Zhilinski's voice was heard calling Boris.

21899. 
21900. 
21901. Rostov had come to Tilsit the day least suitable for a petition on
21902. Denisov's behalf. He could not himself go to the general in attendance
21903. as he was in mufti and had come to Tilsit without permission to do

21906. signed. The Emperors exchanged decorations: Alexander received the Cross
21907. of the Legion of Honor and Napoleon the Order of St. Andrew of the
21908. First Degree, and a dinner had been arranged for the evening, given by
21909. a battalion of the French Guards to the Preobrazhensk battalion. The
21910. Emperors were to be present at that banquet.
21911. 
21912. Rostov felt so ill at ease and uncomfortable with Boris that, when the
21913. latter looked in after supper, he pretended to be asleep, and early next
21914. morning went away, avoiding Boris. In his civilian clothes and a
21915. round hat, he wandered about the town, staring at the French and their
21916. uniforms and at the streets and houses where the Russian and French
21917. Emperors were staying. In a square he saw tables being set up and
21918. preparations made for the dinner; he saw the Russian and French colors
21919. draped from side to side of the streets, with huge monograms A and N. In
21920. the windows of the houses also flags and bunting were displayed.
21921. 
21922. "Boris doesn't want to help me and I don't want to ask him. That's
21923. settled," thought Nicholas. "All is over between us, but I won't leave
21924. here without having done all I can for Denisov and certainly not without
21925. getting his letter to the Emperor. The Emperor!... He is here!" thought
21926. Rostov, who had unconsciously returned to the house where Alexander
21927. lodged.
21928. 
21929. Saddled horses were standing before the house and the suite were
21930. assembling, evidently preparing for the Emperor to come out.
21931. 
21932. "I may see him at any moment," thought Rostov. "If only I were to hand
21933. the letter direct to him and tell him all... could they really arrest me

21935. justice lies. He understands everything, knows everything. Who can be
21936. more just, more magnanimous than he? And even if they did arrest me for
21937. being here, what would it matter?" thought he, looking at an officer who
21938. was entering the house the Emperor occupied. "After all, people do go
21939. in.... It's all nonsense! I'll go in and hand the letter to the Emperor
21940. myself so much the worse for Drubetskoy who drives me to it!" And
21941. suddenly with a determination he himself did not expect, Rostov felt for
21942. the letter in his pocket and went straight to the house.
21943. 
21944. "No, I won't miss my opportunity now, as I did after Austerlitz," he
21945. thought, expecting every moment to meet the monarch, and conscious of
21946. the blood that rushed to his heart at the thought. "I will fall at his
21947. feet and beseech him. He will lift me up, will listen, and will even
21948. thank me. 'I am happy when I can do good, but to remedy injustice is the
21949. greatest happiness,'" Rostov fancied the sovereign saying. And passing
21950. people who looked after him with curiosity, he entered the porch of the
21951. Emperor's house.
21952. 
21953. A broad staircase led straight up from the entry, and to the right he
21954. saw a closed door. Below, under the staircase, was a door leading to the
21955. lower floor.
21956. 
21957. "Whom do you want?" someone inquired.
21958. 
21959. "To hand in a letter, a petition, to His Majesty," said Nicholas, with a
21960. tremor in his voice.
21961. 
21962. "A petition? This way, to the officer on duty" (he was shown the door
21963. leading downstairs), "only it won't be accepted."
21964. 
21965. On hearing this indifferent voice, Rostov grew frightened at what he

21967. fascinating and consequently so alarming that he was ready to run away,
21968. but the official who had questioned him opened the door, and Rostov
21969. entered.
21970. 
21971. A short stout man of about thirty, in white breeches and high boots and
21972. a batiste shirt that he had evidently only just put on, standing in that
21973. room, and his valet was buttoning on to the back of his breeches a

21976. adjoining room.
21977. 
21978. "A good figure and in her first bloom," he was saying, but on seeing

21982.

22222. Rostov stood at that corner for a long time, watching the feast from a

22257.

22271. banging the table--very little to the point as it seemed to his

22276.

22278. 
22279. "Yes, and to drink," assented Nicholas. "Hullo there! Another bottle!"
22280. he shouted.

22282. In 1808 the Emperor Alexander went to Erfurt for a fresh interview with

22284. much talk of the grandeur of this important meeting.

22292. 
22293. In 1809 the intimacy between "the world's two arbiters," as Napoleon
22294. and Alexander were called, was such that when Napoleon declared war on
22295. Austria a Russian corps crossed the frontier to co-operate with our
22296. old enemy Bonaparte against our old ally the Emperor of Austria, and in
22297. court circles the possibility of marriage between Napoleon and one of
22298. Alexander's sisters was spoken of. But besides considerations of
22299. foreign policy, the attention of Russian society was at that time keenly
22300. directed on the internal changes that were being undertaken in all the
22301. departments of government.
22302. 
22303. Life meanwhile--real life, with its essential interests of health and
22304. sickness, toil and rest, and its intellectual interests in thought,
22305. science, poetry, music, love, friendship, hatred, and passions--went on
22306. as usual, independently of and apart from political friendship or enmity
22307. with Napoleon Bonaparte and from all the schemes of reconstruction.
22308. 
22309. 
22310. 
22311. 
22312. 
22313. BOOK SIX: 1808 - 10
22314. 
22315. 
22316. 
22317. 
22318. 
22319. CHAPTER I
22320. 
22321. 
22322. Prince Andrew had spent two years continuously in the country.
22323. 
22324. All the plans Pierre had attempted on his estates--and constantly
22325. changing from one thing to another had never accomplished--were carried
22326. out by Prince Andrew without display and without perceptible difficulty.
22327. 
22328. He had in the highest degree a practical tenacity which Pierre lacked,
22329. and without fuss or strain on his part this set things going.
22330. 
22331. On one of his estates the three hundred serfs were liberated and became
22332. free agricultural laborers--this being one of the first examples of
22333. the kind in Russia. On other estates the serfs' compulsory labor was
22334. commuted for a quitrent. A trained midwife was engaged for Bogucharovo
22335. at his expense, and a priest was paid to teach reading and writing to
22336. the children of the peasants and household serfs.
22337. 
22338. Prince Andrew spent half his time at Bald Hills with his father and his
22339. son, who was still in the care of nurses. The other half he spent in
22340. "Bogucharovo Cloister," as his father called Prince Andrew's estate.
22341. Despite the indifference to the affairs of the world he had expressed
22342. to Pierre, he diligently followed all that went on, received many books,
22343. and to his surprise noticed that when he or his father had visitors
22344. from Petersburg, the very vortex of life, these people lagged behind
22345. himself--who never left the country--in knowledge of what was happening
22346. in home and foreign affairs.
22347. 
22348. Besides being occupied with his estates and reading a great variety of
22349. books, Prince Andrew was at this time busy with a critical survey of
22350. our last two unfortunate campaigns, and with drawing up a proposal for a
22351. reform of the army rules and regulations.
22352. 
22353. In the spring of 1809 he went to visit the Ryazan estates which had been
22354. inherited by his son, whose guardian he was.
22355. 
22356. Warmed by the spring sunshine he sat in the caleche looking at the new
22357. grass, the first leaves on the birches, and the first puffs of white
22358. spring clouds floating across the clear blue sky. He was not thinking of
22359. anything, but looked absent-mindedly and cheerfully from side to side.
22360. 
22361. They crossed the ferry where he had talked with Pierre the year before.
22362. They went through the muddy village, past threshing floors and green
22363. fields of winter rye, downhill where snow still lodged near the bridge,
22364. uphill where the clay had been liquefied by the rain, past strips of
22365. stubble land and bushes touched with green here and there, and into a
22366. birch forest growing on both sides of the road. In the forest it was
22367. almost hot, no wind could be felt. The birches with their sticky green
22368. leaves were motionless, and lilac-colored flowers and the first blades
22369. of green grass were pushing up and lifting last year's leaves. The
22370. coarse evergreen color of the small fir trees scattered here and there
22371. among the birches was an unpleasant reminder of winter. On entering the
22372. forest the horses began to snort and sweated visibly.
22373. 
22374. Peter the footman made some remark to the coachman; the latter assented.
22375. But apparently the coachman's sympathy was not enough for Peter, and he
22376. turned on the box toward his master.
22377. 
22378. "How pleasant it is, your excellency!" he said with a respectful smile.
22379. 
22380. "What?"
22381. 
22382. "It's pleasant, your excellency!"
22383. 
22384. "What is he talking about?" thought Prince Andrew. "Oh, the spring,
22385. I suppose," he thought as he turned round. "Yes, really everything is
22386. green already.... How early! The birches and cherry and alders too are
22387. coming out.... But the oaks show no sign yet. Ah, here is one oak!"
22388. 
22389.  At the edge of the road stood an oak. Probably ten times the age of
22390. the birches that formed the forest, it was ten times as thick and twice
22391. as tall as they. It was an enormous tree, its girth twice as great as a
22392. man could embrace, and evidently long ago some of its branches had been
22393. broken off and its bark scarred. With its huge ungainly limbs sprawling
22394. unsymmetrically, and its gnarled hands and fingers, it stood an aged,
22395. stern, and scornful monster among the smiling birch trees. Only the
22396. dead-looking evergreen firs dotted about in the forest, and this oak,
22397. refused to yield to the charm of spring or notice either the spring or
22398. the sunshine.
22399. 
22400. "Spring, love, happiness!" this oak seemed to say. "Are you not weary of
22401. that stupid, meaningless, constantly repeated fraud? Always the same and
22402. always a fraud? There is no spring, no sun, no happiness! Look at those
22403. cramped dead firs, ever the same, and at me too, sticking out my broken
22404. and barked fingers just where they have grown, whether from my back or
22405. my sides: as they have grown so I stand, and I do not believe in your
22406. hopes and your lies."
22407. 
22408. As he passed through the forest Prince Andrew turned several times to
22409. look at that oak, as if expecting something from it. Under the oak,
22410. too, were flowers and grass, but it stood among them scowling, rigid,
22411. misshapen, and grim as ever.
22412. 
22413. "Yes, the oak is right, a thousand times right," thought Prince Andrew.
22414. "Let others--the young--yield afresh to that fraud, but we know life,
22415. our life is finished!"
22416. 
22417. A whole sequence of new thoughts, hopeless but mournfully pleasant, rose
22418. in his soul in connection with that tree. During this journey he, as
22419. it were, considered his life afresh and arrived at his old conclusion,
22420. restful in its hopelessness: that it was not for him to begin anything
22421. anew--but that he must live out his life, content to do no harm, and not
22422. disturbing himself or desiring anything.
22423. 
22424. 
22425. 
22426. 
22427. 
22428. CHAPTER II
22429. 
22430. 
22431. Prince Andrew had to see the Marshal of the Nobility for the district
22432. in connection with the affairs of the Ryazan estate of which he was
22433. trustee. This Marshal was Count Ilya Rostov, and in the middle of May
22434. Prince Andrew went to visit him.
22435. 
22436. It was now hot spring weather. The whole forest was already clothed in
22437. green. It was dusty and so hot that on passing near water one longed to
22438. bathe.
22439. 
22440. Prince Andrew, depressed and preoccupied with the business about which
22441. he had to speak to the Marshal, was driving up the avenue in the grounds
22442. of the Rostovs' house at Otradnoe. He heard merry girlish cries behind
22443. some trees on the right and saw a group of girls running to cross
22444. the path of his caleche. Ahead of the rest and nearer to him ran a
22445. dark-haired, remarkably slim, pretty girl in a yellow chintz dress, with
22446. a white handkerchief on her head from under which loose locks of hair
22447. escaped. The girl was shouting something but, seeing that he was a
22448. stranger, ran back laughing without looking at him.
22449. 
22450. Suddenly, he did not know why, he felt a pang. The day was so beautiful,
22451. the sun so bright, everything around so gay, but that slim pretty girl
22452. did not know, or wish to know, of his existence and was contented and
22453. cheerful in her own separate--probably foolish--but bright and happy
22454. life. "What is she so glad about? What is she thinking of? Not of
22455. the military regulations or of the arrangement of the Ryazan serfs'
22456. quitrents. Of what is she thinking? Why is she so happy?" Prince Andrew
22457. asked himself with instinctive curiosity.
22458. 
22459. In 1809 Count Ilya Rostov was living at Otradnoe just as he had done
22460. in former years, that is, entertaining almost the whole province with
22461. hunts, theatricals, dinners, and music. He was glad to see Prince
22462. Andrew, as he was to see any new visitor, and insisted on his staying
22463. the night.
22464. 
22465. During the dull day, in the course of which he was entertained by his
22466. elderly hosts and by the more important of the visitors (the old count's
22467. house was crowded on account of an approaching name day), Prince Andrew
22468. repeatedly glanced at Natasha, gay and laughing among the younger
22469. members of the company, and asked himself each time, "What is she
22470. thinking about? Why is she so glad?"
22471. 
22472. That night, alone in new surroundings, he was long unable to sleep. He
22473. read awhile and then put out his candle, but relit it. It was hot in the
22474. room, the inside shutters of which were closed. He was cross with the
22475. stupid old man (as he called Rostov), who had made him stay by assuring
22476. him that some necessary documents had not yet arrived from town, and he
22477. was vexed with himself for having stayed.
22478. 
22479. He got up and went to the window to open it. As soon as he opened the
22480. shutters the moonlight, as if it had long been watching for this, burst
22481. into the room. He opened the casement. The night was fresh, bright, and
22482. very still. Just before the window was a row of pollard trees, looking
22483. black on one side and with a silvery light on the other. Beneath the
22484. trees grewsome kind of lush, wet, bushy vegetation with silver-lit
22485. leaves and stems here and there. Farther back beyond the dark trees a
22486. roof glittered with dew, to the right was a leafy tree with brilliantly
22487. white trunk and branches, and above it shone the moon, nearly at its
22488. full, in a pale, almost starless, spring sky. Prince Andrew leaned his
22489. elbows on the window ledge and his eyes rested on that sky.
22490. 
22491. His room was on the first floor. Those in the rooms above were also
22492. awake. He heard female voices overhead.
22493. 
22494. "Just once more," said a girlish voice above him which Prince Andrew
22495. recognized at once.
22496. 
22497. "But when are you coming to bed?" replied another voice.
22498. 
22499. "I won't, I can't sleep, what's the use? Come now for the last time."
22500. 
22501.  Two girlish voices sang a musical passage--the end of some song.
22502. 
22503. "Oh, how lovely! Now go to sleep, and there's an end of it."
22504. 
22505. "You go to sleep, but I can't," said the first voice, coming nearer to
22506. the window. She was evidently leaning right out, for the rustle of her
22507. dress and even her breathing could be heard. Everything was stone-still,
22508. like the moon and its light and the shadows. Prince Andrew, too, dared
22509. not stir, for fear of betraying his unintentional presence.
22510. 
22511. "Sonya! Sonya!" he again heard the first speaker. "Oh, how can you
22512. sleep? Only look how glorious it is! Ah, how glorious! Do wake up,
22513. Sonya!" she said almost with tears in her voice. "There never, never was
22514. such a lovely night before!"
22515. 
22516. Sonya made some reluctant reply.
22517. 
22518. "Do just come and see what a moon!... Oh, how lovely! Come here....
22519. Darling, sweetheart, come here! There, you see? I feel like sitting down
22520. on my heels, putting my arms round my knees like this, straining tight,
22521. as tight as possible, and flying away! Like this...."
22522. 
22523. "Take care, you'll fall out."
22524. 
22525. He heard the sound of a scuffle and Sonya's disapproving voice: "It's
22526. past one o'clock."
22527. 
22528. "Oh, you only spoil things for me. All right, go, go!"
22529. 
22530. Again all was silent, but Prince Andrew knew she was still sitting
22531. there. From time to time he heard a soft rustle and at times a sigh.
22532. 
22533. "O God, O God! What does it mean?" she suddenly exclaimed. "To bed then,
22534. if it must be!" and she slammed the casement.
22535. 
22536. "For her I might as well not exist!" thought Prince Andrew while he
22537. listened to her voice, for some reason expecting yet fearing that she
22538. might say something about him. "There she is again! As if it were on
22539. purpose," thought he.
22540. 
22541. In his soul there suddenly arose such an unexpected turmoil of youthful
22542. thoughts and hopes, contrary to the whole tenor of his life, that unable
22543. to explain his condition to himself he lay down and fell asleep at once.
22544. 
22545. 
22546. 
22547. 
22548. 
22549. CHAPTER III
22550. 
22551. 
22552. Next morning, having taken leave of no one but the count, and not
22553. waiting for the ladies to appear, Prince Andrew set off for home.
22554. 
22555. It was already the beginning of June when on his return journey he drove
22556. into the birch forest where the gnarled old oak had made so strange and
22557. memorable an impression on him. In the forest the harness bells sounded
22558. yet more muffled than they had done six weeks before, for now all was
22559. thick, shady, and dense, and the young firs dotted about in the forest
22560. did not jar on the general beauty but, lending themselves to the mood
22561. around, were delicately green with fluffy young shoots.
22562. 
22563. The whole day had been hot. Somewhere a storm was gathering, but only
22564. a small cloud had scattered some raindrops lightly, sprinkling the road
22565. and the sappy leaves. The left side of the forest was dark in the shade,
22566. the right side glittered in the sunlight, wet and shiny and scarcely
22567. swayed by the breeze. Everything was in blossom, the nightingales
22568. trilled, and their voices reverberated now near, now far away.
22569. 
22570. "Yes, here in this forest was that oak with which I agreed," thought
22571. Prince Andrew. "But where is it?" he again wondered, gazing at the left
22572. side of the road, and without recognizing it he looked with admiration
22573. at the very oak he sought. The old oak, quite transfigured, spreading
22574. out a canopy of sappy dark-green foliage, stood rapt and slightly
22575. trembling in the rays of the evening sun. Neither gnarled fingers nor
22576. old scars nor old doubts and sorrows were any of them in evidence now.
22577. Through the hard century-old bark, even where there were no twigs,
22578. leaves had sprouted such as one could hardly believe the old veteran
22579. could have produced.
22580. 
22581. "Yes, it is the same oak," thought Prince Andrew, and all at once he was
22582. seized by an unreasoning springtime feeling of joy and renewal. All the
22583. best moments of his life suddenly rose to his memory. Austerlitz with
22584. the lofty heavens, his wife's dead reproachful face, Pierre at the
22585. ferry, that girl thrilled by the beauty of the night, and that night
22586. itself and the moon, and.... all this rushed suddenly to his mind.
22587. 
22588. "No, life is not over at thirty-one!" Prince Andrew suddenly decided
22589. finally and decisively. "It is not enough for me to know what I have in
22590. me--everyone must know it: Pierre, and that young girl who wanted to
22591. fly away into the sky, everyone must know me, so that my life may not be
22592. lived for myself alone while others live so apart from it, but so that
22593. it may be reflected in them all, and they and I may live in harmony!"
22594. 
22595. 
22596. On reaching home Prince Andrew decided to go to Petersburg that autumn
22597. and found all sorts of reasons for this decision. A whole series of
22598. sensible and logical considerations showing it to be essential for him
22599. to go to Petersburg, and even to re-enter the service, kept springing
22600. up in his mind. He could not now understand how he could ever even have
22601. doubted the necessity of taking an active share in life, just as a month
22602. before he had not understood how the idea of leaving the quiet country
22603. could ever enter his head. It now seemed clear to him that all his
22604. experience of life must be senselessly wasted unless he applied it to
22605. some kind of work and again played an active part in life. He did not
22606. even remember how formerly, on the strength of similar wretched logical
22607. arguments, it had seemed obvious that he would be degrading himself if
22608. he now, after the lessons he had had in life, allowed himself to believe
22609. in the possibility of being useful and in the possibility of happiness
22610. or love. Now reason suggested quite the opposite. After that journey
22611. to Ryazan he found the country dull; his former pursuits no longer
22612. interested him, and often when sitting alone in his study he got up,
22613. went to the mirror, and gazed a long time at his own face. Then he would
22614. turn away to the portrait of his dead Lise, who with hair curled a la
22615. grecque looked tenderly and gaily at him out of the gilt frame. She
22616. did not now say those former terrible words to him, but looked simply,
22617. merrily, and inquisitively at him. And Prince Andrew, crossing his
22618. arms behind him, long paced the room, now frowning, now smiling, as
22619. he reflected on those irrational, inexpressible thoughts, secret as a
22620. crime, which altered his whole life and were connected with Pierre, with
22621. fame, with the girl at the window, the oak, and woman's beauty and love.
22622. And if anyone came into his room at such moments he was particularly
22623. cold, stern, and above all unpleasantly logical.
22624. 
22625. "My dear," Princess Mary entering at such a moment would say, "little
22626. Nicholas can't go out today, it's very cold."
22627. 
22628. "If it were hot," Prince Andrew would reply at such times very dryly
22629. to his sister, "he could go out in his smock, but as it is cold he must
22630. wear warm clothes, which were designed for that purpose. That is what
22631. follows from the fact that it is cold; and not that a child who needs
22632. fresh air should remain at home," he would add with extreme logic, as
22633. if punishing someone for those secret illogical emotions that stirred
22634. within him.
22635. 
22636. At such moments Princess Mary would think how intellectual work dries
22637. men up.
22638. 
22639. 
22640. 
22641. 
22642. 
22643. CHAPTER IV
22644. 
22645. 
22646. Prince Andrew arrived in Petersburg in August, 1809. It was the time
22647. when the youthful Speranski was at the zenith of his fame and his
22648. reforms were being pushed forward with the greatest energy. That same
22649. August the Emperor was thrown from his caleche, injured his leg, and
22650. remained three weeks at Peterhof, receiving Speranski every day and no
22651. one else. At that time the two famous decrees were being prepared that
22652. so agitated society--abolishing court ranks and introducing
22653. examinations to qualify for the grades of Collegiate Assessor and State
22654. Councilor--and not merely these but a whole state constitution,
22655. intended to change the existing order of government in Russia: legal,
22656. administrative, and financial, from the Council of State down to the
22657. district tribunals. Now those vague liberal dreams with which the
22658. Emperor Alexander had ascended the throne, and which he had tried to put
22659. into effect with the aid of his associates, Czartoryski, Novosiltsev,
22660. Kochubey, and Strogonov--whom he himself in jest had called his Comite
22661. de salut public--were taking shape and being realized.
22662. 
22663. Now all these men were replaced by Speranski on the civil side, and
22664. Arakcheev on the military. Soon after his arrival Prince Andrew, as a
22665. gentleman of the chamber, presented himself at court and at a levee. The
22666. Emperor, though he met him twice, did not favor him with a single word.
22667. It had always seemed to Prince Andrew before that he was antipathetic
22668. to the Emperor and that the latter disliked his face and personality
22669. generally, and in the cold, repellent glance the Emperor gave him, he
22670. now found further confirmation of this surmise. The courtiers explained
22671. the Emperor's neglect of him by His Majesty's displeasure at Bolkonski's
22672. not having served since 1805.
22673. 
22674. "I know myself that one cannot help one's sympathies and antipathies,"
22675. thought Prince Andrew, "so it will not do to present my proposal for
22676. the reform of the army regulations to the Emperor personally, but the
22677. project will speak for itself."
22678. 
22679. He mentioned what he had written to an old field marshal, a friend of
22680. his father's. The field marshal made an appointment to see him, received
22681. him graciously, and promised to inform the Emperor. A few days later
22682. Prince Andrew received notice that he was to go to see the Minister of
22683. War, Count Arakcheev.
22684. 
22685. 
22686. On the appointed day Prince Andrew entered Count Arakcheev's waiting
22687. room at nine in the morning.
22688. 
22689. He did not know Arakcheev personally, had never seen him, and all he had
22690. heard of him inspired him with but little respect for the man.
22691. 
22692. "He is Minister of War, a man trusted by the Emperor, and I need not
22693. concern myself about his personal qualities: he has been commissioned
