22694. to consider my project, so he alone can get it adopted," thought Prince
22695. Andrew as he waited among a number of important and unimportant people
22696. in Count Arakcheev's waiting room.
22697. 
22698. During his service, chiefly as an adjutant, Prince Andrew had seen the
22699. anterooms of many important men, and the different types of such rooms
22700. were well known to him. Count Arakcheev's anteroom had quite a special
22701. character. The faces of the unimportant people awaiting their turn for
22702. an audience showed embarrassment and servility; the faces of those of
22703. higher rank expressed a common feeling of awkwardness, covered by a mask
22704. of unconcern and ridicule of themselves, their situation, and the person
22705. for whom they were waiting. Some walked thoughtfully up and down,
22706. others whispered and laughed. Prince Andrew heard the nickname "Sila
22707. Andreevich" and the words, "Uncle will give it to us hot," in reference
22708. to Count Arakcheev. One general (an important personage), evidently
22709. feeling offended at having to wait so long, sat crossing and uncrossing
22710. his legs and smiling contemptuously to himself.
22711. 
22712. But the moment the door opened one feeling alone appeared on all
22713. faces--that of fear. Prince Andrew for the second time asked the
22714. adjutant on duty to take in his name, but received an ironical look and
22715. was told that his turn would come in due course. After some others had
22716. been shown in and out of the minister's room by the adjutant on duty,
22717. an officer who struck Prince Andrew by his humiliated and frightened
22718. air was admitted at that terrible door. This officer's audience lasted
22719. a long time. Then suddenly the grating sound of a harsh voice was heard
22720. from the other side of the door, and the officer--with pale face and
22721. trembling lips--came out and passed through the waiting room, clutching
22722. his head.
22723. 
22724. After this Prince Andrew was conducted to the door and the officer on
22725. duty said in a whisper, "To the right, at the window."
22726. 
22727. Prince Andrew entered a plain tidy room and saw at the table a man of
22728. forty with a long waist, a long closely cropped head, deep wrinkles,
22729. scowling brows above dull greenish-hazel eyes and an overhanging red
22730. nose. Arakcheev turned his head toward him without looking at him.
22731. 
22732. "What is your petition?" asked Arakcheev.
22733. 
22734. "I am not petitioning, your excellency," returned Prince Andrew quietly.
22735. 
22736. Arakcheev's eyes turned toward him.
22737. 
22738. "Sit down," said he. "Prince Bolkonski?"
22739. 
22740. "I am not petitioning about anything. His Majesty the Emperor has
22741. deigned to send your excellency a project submitted by me..."
22742. 
22743. "You see, my dear sir, I have read your project," interrupted Arakcheev,
22744. uttering only the first words amiably and then--again without looking
22745. at Prince Andrew--relapsing gradually into a tone of grumbling contempt.
22746. "You are proposing new military laws? There are many laws but no one to
22747. carry out the old ones. Nowadays everybody designs laws, it is easier
22748. writing than doing."
22749. 
22750. "I came at His Majesty the Emperor's wish to learn from your excellency
22751. how you propose to deal with the memorandum I have presented," said
22752. Prince Andrew politely.
22753. 
22754. "I have endorsed a resolution on your memorandum and sent it to the
22755. committee. I do not approve of it," said Arakcheev, rising and taking a
22756. paper from his writing table. "Here!" and he handed it to Prince Andrew.
22757. 
22758. Across the paper was scrawled in pencil, without capital letters,
22759. misspelled, and without punctuation: "Unsoundly constructed because
22760. resembles an imitation of the French military code and from the Articles
22761. of War needlessly deviating."
22762. 
22763. "To what committee has the memorandum been referred?" inquired Prince
22764. Andrew.
22765. 
22766. "To the Committee on Army Regulations, and I have recommended that your
22767. honor should be appointed a member, but without a salary."
22768. 
22769. Prince Andrew smiled.
22770. 
22771. "I don't want one."
22772. 
22773. "A member without salary," repeated Arakcheev. "I have the honor...
22774. Eh! Call the next one! Who else is there?" he shouted, bowing to Prince
22775. Andrew.
22776. 
22777. 
22778. 
22779. 
22780. 
22781. CHAPTER V
22782. 
22783. 
22784. While waiting for the announcement of his appointment to the committee
22785. Prince Andrew looked up his former acquaintances, particularly those he
22786. knew to be in power and whose aid he might need. In Petersburg he now
22787. experienced the same feeling he had had on the eve of a battle, when
22788. troubled by anxious curiosity and irresistibly attracted to the ruling
22789. circles where the future, on which the fate of millions depended, was
22790. being shaped. From the irritation of the older men, the curiosity of the
22791. uninitiated, the reserve of the initiated, the hurry and preoccupation
22792. of everyone, and the innumerable committees and commissions of whose
22793. existence he learned every day, he felt that now, in 1809, here in
22794. Petersburg a vast civil conflict was in preparation, the commander in
22795. chief of which was a mysterious person he did not know, but who
22796. was supposed to be a man of genius--Speranski. And this movement of
22797. reconstruction of which Prince Andrew had a vague idea, and Speranski
22798. its chief promoter, began to interest him so keenly that the question
22799. of the army regulations quickly receded to a secondary place in his
22800. consciousness.
22801. 
22802. Prince Andrew was most favorably placed to secure good reception in the
22803. highest and most diverse Petersburg circles of the day. The reforming
22804. party cordially welcomed and courted him, in the first place because
22805. he was reputed to be clever and very well read, and secondly because by
22806. liberating his serfs he had obtained the reputation of being a liberal.
22807. The party of the old and dissatisfied, who censured the innovations,
22808. turned to him expecting his sympathy in their disapproval of the
22809. reforms, simply because he was the son of his father. The feminine
22810. society world welcomed him gladly, because he was rich, distinguished, a
22811. good match, and almost a newcomer, with a halo of romance on account
22812. of his supposed death and the tragic loss of his wife. Besides this
22813. the general opinion of all who had known him previously was that he had
22814. greatly improved during these last five years, having softened and grown
22815. more manly, lost his former affectation, pride, and contemptuous irony,
22816. and acquired the serenity that comes with years. People talked about
22817. him, were interested in him, and wanted to meet him.
22818. 
22819. The day after his interview with Count Arakcheev, Prince Andrew spent
22820. the evening at Count Kochubey's. He told the count of his interview with
22821. Sila Andreevich (Kochubey spoke of Arakcheev by that nickname with the
22822. same vague irony Prince Andrew had noticed in the Minister of War's
22823. anteroom).
22824. 
22825. "Mon cher, even in this case you can't do without Michael Mikhaylovich
22826. Speranski. He manages everything. I'll speak to him. He has promised to
22827. come this evening."
22828. 
22829. "What has Speranski to do with the army regulations?" asked Prince
22830. Andrew.
22831. 
22832. Kochubey shook his head smilingly, as if surprised at Bolkonski's
22833. simplicity.
22834. 
22835. "We were talking to him about you a few days ago," Kochubey continued,
22836. "and about your freed plowmen."
22837. 
22838. "Oh, is it you, Prince, who have freed your serfs?" said an old man of
22839. Catherine's day, turning contemptuously toward Bolkonski.
22840. 
22841. "It was a small estate that brought in no profit," replied Prince
22842. Andrew, trying to extenuate his action so as not to irritate the old man
22843. uselessly.
22844. 
22845. "Afraid of being late..." said the old man, looking at Kochubey.
22846. 
22847. "There's one thing I don't understand," he continued. "Who will plow the
22848. land if they are set free? It is easy to write laws, but difficult to
22849. rule.... Just the same as now--I ask you, Count--who will be heads of
22850. the departments when everybody has to pass examinations?"
22851. 
22852. "Those who pass the examinations, I suppose," replied Kochubey, crossing
22853. his legs and glancing round.
22854. 
22855. "Well, I have Pryanichnikov serving under me, a splendid man, a
22856. priceless man, but he's sixty. Is he to go up for examination?"
22857. 
22858. "Yes, that's a difficulty, as education is not at all general, but..."
22859. 
22860. Count Kochubey did not finish. He rose, took Prince Andrew by the arm,
22861. and went to meet a tall, bald, fair man of about forty with a large open
22862. forehead and a long face of unusual and peculiar whiteness, who was
22863. just entering. The newcomer wore a blue swallow-tail coat with a cross
22864. suspended from his neck and a star on his left breast. It was Speranski.
22865. Prince Andrew recognized him at once, and felt a throb within him, as
22866. happens at critical moments of life. Whether it was from respect, envy,
22867. or anticipation, he did not know. Speranski's whole figure was of a
22868. peculiar type that made him easily recognizable. In the society in which
22869. Prince Andrew lived he had never seen anyone who together with awkward
22870. and clumsy gestures possessed such calmness and self-assurance; he
22871. had never seen so resolute yet gentle an expression as that in those
22872. half-closed, rather humid eyes, or so firm a smile that expressed
22873. nothing; nor had he heard such a refined, smooth, soft voice; above all
22874. he had never seen such delicate whiteness of face or hands--hands which
22875. were broad, but very plump, soft, and white. Such whiteness and softness
22876. Prince Andrew had only seen on the faces of soldiers who had been long
22877. in hospital. This was Speranski, Secretary of State, reporter to the
22878. Emperor and his companion at Erfurt, where he had more than once met and
22879. talked with Napoleon.
22880. 
22881. Speranski did not shift his eyes from one face to another as people
22882. involuntarily do on entering a large company and was in no hurry to
22883. speak. He spoke slowly, with assurance that he would be listened to, and
22884. he looked only at the person with whom he was conversing.
22885. 
22886. Prince Andrew followed Speranski's every word and movement with
22887. particular attention. As happens to some people, especially to men
22888. who judge those near to them severely, he always on meeting
22889. anyone new--especially anyone whom, like Speranski, he knew by
22890. reputation--expected to discover in him the perfection of human
22891. qualities.
22892. 
22893. Speranski told Kochubey he was sorry he had been unable to come sooner
22894. as he had been detained at the palace. He did not say that the Emperor
22895. had kept him, and Prince Andrew noticed this affectation of modesty.
22896. When Kochubey introduced Prince Andrew, Speranski slowly turned his eyes
22897. to Bolkonski with his customary smile and looked at him in silence.
22898. 
22899. "I am very glad to make your acquaintance. I had heard of you, as
22900. everyone has," he said after a pause.
22901. 
22902. Kochubey said a few words about the reception Arakcheev had given
22903. Bolkonski. Speranski smiled more markedly.
22904. 
22905. "The chairman of the Committee on Army Regulations is my good friend
22906. Monsieur Magnitski," he said, fully articulating every word and
22907. syllable, "and if you like I can put you in touch with him." He paused
22908. at the full stop. "I hope you will find him sympathetic and ready to
22909. co-operate in promoting all that is reasonable."
22910. 
22911. A circle soon formed round Speranski, and the old man who had talked
22912. about his subordinate Pryanichnikov addressed a question to him.
22913. 
22914. Prince Andrew without joining in the conversation watched every movement
22915. of Speranski's: this man, not long since an insignificant divinity
22916. student, who now, Bolkonski thought, held in his hands--those plump
22917. white hands--the fate of Russia. Prince Andrew was struck by the
22918. extraordinarily disdainful composure with which Speranski answered
22919. the old man. He appeared to address condescending words to him from an
22920. immeasurable height. When the old man began to speak too loud, Speranski
22921. smiled and said he could not judge of the advantage or disadvantage of
22922. what pleased the sovereign.
22923. 
22924. Having talked for a little while in the general circle, Speranski rose
22925. and coming up to Prince Andrew took him along to the other end of the
22926. room. It was clear that he thought it necessary to interest himself in
22927. Bolkonski.
22928. 
22929. "I had no chance to talk with you, Prince, during the animated
22930. conversation in which that venerable gentleman involved me," he said
22931. with a mildly contemptuous smile, as if intimating by that smile that he
22932. and Prince Andrew understood the insignificance of the people with whom
22933. he had just been talking. This flattered Prince Andrew. "I have known of
22934. you for a long time: first from your action with regard to your serfs,
22935. a first example, of which it is very desirable that there should be more
22936. imitators; and secondly because you are one of those gentlemen of the
22937. chamber who have not considered themselves offended by the new decree
22938. concerning the ranks allotted to courtiers, which is causing so much
22939. gossip and tittle-tattle."
22940. 
22941. "No," said Prince Andrew, "my father did not wish me to take advantage
22942. of the privilege. I began the service from the lower grade."
22943. 
22944. "Your father, a man of the last century, evidently stands above our
22945. contemporaries who so condemn this measure which merely reestablishes
22946. natural justice."
22947. 
22948. "I think, however, that these condemnations have some ground," returned
22949. Prince Andrew, trying to resist Speranski's influence, of which he began
22950. to be conscious. He did not like to agree with him in everything and
22951. felt a wish to contradict. Though he usually spoke easily and well,
22952. he felt a difficulty in expressing himself now while talking with
22953. Speranski. He was too much absorbed in observing the famous man's
22954. personality.
22955. 
22956. "Grounds of personal ambition maybe," Speranski put in quietly.
22957. 
22958. "And of state interest to some extent," said Prince Andrew.
22959. 
22960. "What do you mean?" asked Speranski quietly, lowering his eyes.
22961. 
22962. "I am an admirer of Montesquieu," replied Prince Andrew, "and his idea
22963. that le principe des monarchies est l'honneur me parait incontestable.
22964. Certains droits et privileges de la noblesse me paraissent etre des
22965. moyens de soutenir ce sentiment." *
22966. 
22967. 
22968.      * "The principle of monarchies is honor seems to me
22969.      incontestable. Certain rights and privileges for the
22970.      aristocracy appear to me a means of maintaining that
22971.      sentiment."
22972. 
22973. 
22974. The smile vanished from Speranski's white face, which was much improved
22975. by the change. Probably Prince Andrew's thought interested him.
22976. 
22977. "Si vous envisagez la question sous ce point de vue," * he began,
22978. pronouncing French with evident difficulty, and speaking even slower
22979. than in Russian but quite calmly.
22980. 
22981. 
22982.     * "If you regard the question from that point of view."
22983. 
22984. 
22985. Speranski went on to say that honor, l'honeur, cannot be upheld by
22986. privileges harmful to the service; that honor, l'honneur, is either a
22987. negative concept of not doing what is blameworthy or it is a source of
22988. emulation in pursuit of commendation and rewards, which recognize it.
22989. His arguments were concise, simple, and clear.
22990. 
22991. "An institution upholding honor, the source of emulation, is one similar
22992. to the Legion d'honneur of the great Emperor Napoleon, not harmful
22993. but helpful to the success of the service, but not a class or court
22994. privilege."
22995. 
22996. "I do not dispute that, but it cannot be denied that court privileges
22997. have attained the same end," returned Prince Andrew. "Every courtier
22998. considers himself bound to maintain his position worthily."
22999. 
23000. "Yet you do not care to avail yourself of the privilege, Prince," said
23001. Speranski, indicating by a smile that he wished to finish amiably an
23002. argument which was embarrassing for his companion. "If you will do
23003. me the honor of calling on me on Wednesday," he added, "I will, after
23004. talking with Magnitski, let you know what may interest you, and shall
23005. also have the pleasure of a more detailed chat with you."
23006. 
23007. Closing his eyes, he bowed a la francaise, without taking leave, and
23008. trying to attract as little attention as possible, he left the room.
23009. 
23010. 
23011. 
23012. 
23013. 
23014. CHAPTER VI
23015. 
23016. 
23017. During the first weeks of his stay in Petersburg Prince Andrew felt the
23018. whole trend of thought he had formed during his life of seclusion quite
23019. overshadowed by the trifling cares that engrossed him in that city.
23020. 
23021. On returning home in the evening he would jot down in his notebook four
23022. or five necessary calls or appointments for certain hours. The mechanism
23023. of life, the arrangement of the day so as to be in time everywhere,
23024. absorbed the greater part of his vital energy. He did nothing, did
23025. not even think or find time to think, but only talked, and talked
23026. successfully, of what he had thought while in the country.
23027. 
23028. He sometimes noticed with dissatisfaction that he repeated the same
23029. remark on the same day in different circles. But he was so busy for
23030. whole days together that he had no time to notice that he was thinking
23031. of nothing.
23032. 
23033. As he had done on their first meeting at Kochubey's, Speranski produced
23034. a strong impression on Prince Andrew on the Wednesday, when he
23035. received him tete-a-tate at his own house and talked to him long and
23036. confidentially.
23037. 
23038. To Bolkonski so many people appeared contemptible and insignificant
23039. creatures, and he so longed to find in someone the living ideal of that
23040. perfection toward which he strove, that he readily believed that in
23041. Speranski he had found this ideal of a perfectly rational and virtuous
23042. man. Had Speranski sprung from the same class as himself and possessed
23043. the same breeding and traditions, Bolkonski would soon have discovered
23044. his weak, human, unheroic sides; but as it was, Speranski's strange and
23045. logical turn of mind inspired him with respect all the more because he
23046. did not quite understand him. Moreover, Speranski, either because he
23047. appreciated the other's capacity or because he considered it necessary
23048. to win him to his side, showed off his dispassionate calm reasonableness
23049. before Prince Andrew and flattered him with that subtle flattery which
23050. goes hand in hand with self-assurance and consists in a tacit assumption
23051. that one's companion is the only man besides oneself capable of
23052. understanding the folly of the rest of mankind and the reasonableness
23053. and profundity of one's own ideas.
23054. 
23055. During their long conversation on Wednesday evening, Speranski more than
23056. once remarked: "We regard everything that is above the common level of
23057. rooted custom..." or, with a smile: "But we want the wolves to be fed
23058. and the sheep to be safe..." or: "They cannot understand this..." and
23059. all in a way that seemed to say: "We, you and I, understand what they
23060. are and who we are."
23061. 
23062. This first long conversation with Speranski only strengthened in Prince
23063. Andrew the feeling he had experienced toward him at their first meeting.
23064. He saw in him a remarkable, clear-thinking man of vast intellect who by
23065. his energy and persistence had attained power, which he was using solely
23066. for the welfare of Russia. In Prince Andrew's eyes Speranski was the man
23067. he would himself have wished to be--one who explained all the facts of
23068. life reasonably, considered important only what was rational, and was
23069. capable of applying the standard of reason to everything. Everything
23070. seemed so simple and clear in Speranski's exposition that Prince Andrew
23071. involuntarily agreed with him about everything. If he replied and
23072. argued, it was only because he wished to maintain his independence and
23073. not submit to Speranski's opinions entirely. Everything was right and
23074. everything was as it should be: only one thing disconcerted Prince
23075. Andrew. This was Speranski's cold, mirrorlike look, which did not allow
23076. one to penetrate to his soul, and his delicate white hands, which Prince
23077. Andrew involuntarily watched as one does watch the hands of those who
23078. possess power. This mirrorlike gaze and those delicate hands irritated
23079. Prince Andrew, he knew not why. He was unpleasantly struck, too, by the
23080. excessive contempt for others that he observed in Speranski, and by the
23081. diversity of lines of argument he used to support his opinions. He
23082. made use of every kind of mental device, except analogy, and passed too
23083. boldly, it seemed to Prince Andrew, from one to another. Now he would
23084. take up the position of a practical man and condemn dreamers; now that
23085. of a satirist, and laugh ironically at his opponents; now grow severely
23086. logical, or suddenly rise to the realm of metaphysics. (This last
23087. resource was one he very frequently employed.) He would transfer a
23088. question to metaphysical heights, pass on to definitions of space, time,
23089. and thought, and, having deduced the refutation he needed, would again
23090. descend to the level of the original discussion.
23091. 
23092. In general the trait of Speranski's mentality which struck Prince Andrew
23093. most was his absolute and unshakable belief in the power and authority
23094. of reason. It was evident that the thought could never occur to him
23095. which to Prince Andrew seemed so natural, namely, that it is after all
23096. impossible to express all one thinks; and that he had never felt the
23097. doubt, "Is not all I think and believe nonsense?" And it was just this
23098. peculiarity of Speranski's mind that particularly attracted Prince
23099. Andrew.
23100. 
23101. During the first period of their acquaintance Bolkonski felt a
23102. passionate admiration for him similar to that which he had once felt for
23103. Bonaparte. The fact that Speranski was the son of a village priest, and
23104. that stupid people might meanly despise him on account of his humble
23105. origin (as in fact many did), caused Prince Andrew to cherish his
23106. sentiment for him the more, and unconsciously to strengthen it.
23107. 
23108. On that first evening Bolkonski spent with him, having mentioned the
23109. Commission for the Revision of the Code of Laws, Speranski told him
23110. sarcastically that the Commission had existed for a hundred and fifty
23111. years, had cost millions, and had done nothing except that Rosenkampf
23112. had stuck labels on the corresponding paragraphs of the different codes.
23113. 
23114. "And that is all the state has for the millions it has spent," said he.
23115. "We want to give the Senate new juridical powers, but we have no laws.
23116. That is why it is a sin for men like you, Prince, not to serve in these
23117. times!"
23118. 
23119. Prince Andrew said that for that work an education in jurisprudence was
23120. needed which he did not possess.
23121. 
23122. "But nobody possesses it, so what would you have? It is a vicious circle
23123. from which we must break a way out."
23124. 
23125. A week later Prince Andrew was a member of the Committee on Army
23126. Regulations and--what he had not at all expected--was chairman of a
23127. section of the committee for the revision of the laws. At Speranski's
23128. request he took the first part of the Civil Code that was being drawn up
23129. and, with the aid of the Code Napoleon and the Institutes of Justinian,
23130. he worked at formulating the section on Personal Rights.
23131. 
23132. 
23133. 
23134. 
23135. 
23136. CHAPTER VII
23137. 
23138. 
23139. Nearly two years before this, in 1808, Pierre on returning to Petersburg
23140. after visiting his estates had involuntarily found himself in a leading
23141. position among the Petersburg Freemasons. He arranged dining and funeral
23142. lodge meetings, enrolled new members, and busied himself uniting various
23143. lodges and acquiring authentic charters. He gave money for the erection
23144. of temples and supplemented as far as he could the collection of alms,
23145. in regard to which the majority of members were stingy and irregular.
23146. He supported almost singlehanded a poorhouse the order had founded in
23147. Petersburg.
23148. 
23149. His life meanwhile continued as before, with the same infatuations and
23150. dissipations. He liked to dine and drink well, and though he considered
23151. it immoral and humiliating could not resist the temptations of the
23152. bachelor circles in which he moved.
23153. 
23154. Amid the turmoil of his activities and distractions, however, Pierre at
23155. the end of a year began to feel that the more firmly he tried to rest
23156. upon it, the more Masonic ground on which he stood gave way under him.
23157. At the same time he felt that the deeper the ground sank under him the
23158. closer bound he involuntarily became to the order. When he had joined
23159. the Freemasons he had experienced the feeling of one who confidently
23160. steps onto the smooth surface of a bog. When he put his foot down it
23161. sank in. To make quite sure of the firmness of the ground, he put
23162. his other foot down and sank deeper still, became stuck in it, and
23163. involuntarily waded knee-deep in the bog.
23164. 
23165. Joseph Alexeevich was not in Petersburg--he had of late stood aside
23166. from the affairs of the Petersburg lodges, and lived almost entirely in
23167. Moscow. All the members of the lodges were men Pierre knew in ordinary
23168. life, and it was difficult for him to regard them merely as Brothers in
23169. Freemasonry and not as Prince B. or Ivan Vasilevich D., whom he knew in
23170. society mostly as weak and insignificant men. Under the Masonic aprons
23171. and insignia he saw the uniforms and decorations at which they aimed in
23172. ordinary life. Often after collecting alms, and reckoning up twenty
23173. to thirty rubles received for the most part in promises from a dozen
23174. members, of whom half were as well able to pay as himself, Pierre
23175. remembered the Masonic vow in which each Brother promised to devote
23176. all his belongings to his neighbor, and doubts on which he tried not to
23177. dwell arose in his soul.
23178. 
23179. He divided the Brothers he knew into four categories. In the first he
23180. put those who did not take an active part in the affairs of the lodges
23181. or in human affairs, but were exclusively occupied with the mystical
23182. science of the order: with questions of the threefold designation of
23183. God, the three primordial elements--sulphur, mercury, and salt--or
23184. the meaning of the square and all the various figures of the temple of
23185. Solomon. Pierre respected this class of Brothers to which the elder ones
23186. chiefly belonged, including, Pierre thought, Joseph Alexeevich himself,
23187. but he did not share their interests. His heart was not in the mystical
23188. aspect of Freemasonry.
23189. 
23190. In the second category Pierre reckoned himself and others like him,
23191. seeking and vacillating, who had not yet found in Freemasonry a straight
23192. and comprehensible path, but hoped to do so.
23193. 
23194. In the third category he included those Brothers (the majority) who saw
23195. nothing in Freemasonry but the external forms and ceremonies, and prized
23196. the strict performance of these forms without troubling about their
23197. purport or significance. Such were Willarski and even the Grand Master
23198. of the principal lodge.
23199. 
23200. Finally, to the fourth category also a great many Brothers belonged,
23201. particularly those who had lately joined. These according to Pierre's
23202. observations were men who had no belief in anything, nor desire for
23203. anything, but joined the Freemasons merely to associate with the wealthy
23204. young Brothers who were influential through their connections or rank,
23205. and of whom there were very many in the lodge.
23206. 
23207. Pierre began to feel dissatisfied with what he was doing. Freemasonry,
23208. at any rate as he saw it here, sometimes seemed to him based merely
23209. on externals. He did not think of doubting Freemasonry itself, but
23210. suspected that Russian Masonry had taken a wrong path and deviated
23211. from its original principles. And so toward the end of the year he went
23212. abroad to be initiated into the higher secrets of the order.
23213. 
23214. In the summer of 1809 Pierre returned to Petersburg. Our Freemasons knew
23215. from correspondence with those abroad that Bezukhov had obtained the
23216. confidence of many highly placed persons, had been initiated into many
23217. mysteries, had been raised to a higher grade, and was bringing back with
23218. him much that might conduce to the advantage of the Masonic cause
23219. in Russia. The Petersburg Freemasons all came to see him, tried to
23220. ingratiate themselves with him, and it seemed to them all that he was
23221. preparing something for them and concealing it.
23222. 
23223. A solemn meeting of the lodge of the second degree was convened, at
23224. which Pierre promised to communicate to the Petersburg Brothers what
23225. he had to deliver to them from the highest leaders of their order. The
23226. meeting was a full one. After the usual ceremonies Pierre rose and began
23227. his address.
23228. 
23229. "Dear Brothers," he began, blushing and stammering, with a written
23230. speech in his hand, "it is not sufficient to observe our mysteries in
23231. the seclusion of our lodge--we must act--act! We are drowsing, but we
23232. must act." Pierre raised his notebook and began to read.
23233. 
23234. "For the dissemination of pure truth and to secure the triumph
23235. of virtue," he read, "we must cleanse men from prejudice, diffuse
23236. principles in harmony with the spirit of the times, undertake the
23237. education of the young, unite ourselves in indissoluble bonds with the
23238. wisest men, boldly yet prudently overcome superstitions, infidelity, and
23239. folly, and form of those devoted to us a body linked together by unity
23240. of purpose and possessed of authority and power.
23241. 
23242. "To attain this end we must secure a preponderance of virtue over vice
23243. and must endeavor to secure that the honest man may, even in this world,
23244. receive a lasting reward for his virtue. But in these great endeavors we
23245. are gravely hampered by the political institutions of today. What is
23246. to be done in these circumstances? To favor revolutions, overthrow
23247. everything, repel force by force?... No! We are very far from that.
23248. Every violent reform deserves censure, for it quite fails to remedy
23249. evil while men remain what they are, and also because wisdom needs no
23250. violence.
23251. 
23252. "The whole plan of our order should be based on the idea of preparing
23253. men of firmness and virtue bound together by unity of conviction--aiming
23254. at the punishment of vice and folly, and patronizing talent and virtue:
23255. raising worthy men from the dust and attaching them to our Brotherhood.
23256. Only then will our order have the power unobtrusively to bind the hands
23257. of the protectors of disorder and to control them without their being
23258. aware of it. In a word, we must found a form of government holding
23259. universal sway, which should be diffused over the whole world without
23260. destroying the bonds of citizenship, and beside which all other
23261. governments can continue in their customary course and do everything
23262. except what impedes the great aim of our order, which is to obtain for
23263. virtue the victory over vice. This aim was that of Christianity itself.
23264. It taught men to be wise and good and for their own benefit to follow
23265. the example and instruction of the best and wisest men.
23266. 
23267. "At that time, when everything was plunged in darkness, preaching alone
23268. was of course sufficient. The novelty of Truth endowed her with
23269. special strength, but now we need much more powerful methods. It is
23270. now necessary that man, governed by his senses, should find in virtue
23271. a charm palpable to those senses. It is impossible to eradicate the
23272. passions; but we must strive to direct them to a noble aim, and it is
23273. therefore necessary that everyone should be able to satisfy his passions
23274. within the limits of virtue. Our order should provide means to that end.
23275. 
23276. "As soon as we have a certain number of worthy men in every state,
23277. each of them again training two others and all being closely united,
23278. everything will be possible for our order, which has already in secret
23279. accomplished much for the welfare of mankind."
23280. 
23281. This speech not only made a strong impression, but created excitement in
23282. the lodge. The majority of the Brothers, seeing in it dangerous designs
23283. of Illuminism, * met it with a coldness that surprised Pierre. The Grand
23284. Master began answering him, and Pierre began developing his views with
23285. more and more warmth. It was long since there had been so stormy a
23286. meeting. Parties were formed, some accusing Pierre of Illuminism, others
23287. supporting him. At that meeting he was struck for the first time by
23288. the endless variety of men's minds, which prevents a truth from ever
23289. presenting itself identically to two persons. Even those members
23290. who seemed to be on his side understood him in their own way with
23291. limitations and alterations he could not agree to, as what he always
23292. wanted most was to convey his thought to others just as he himself
23293. understood it.
23294. 
23295. 
23296.      * The Illuminati sought to substitute republican for
23297.      monarchical institutions.
23298. 
23299. 
23300. At the end of the meeting the Grand Master with irony and ill-will
23301. reproved Bezukhov for his vehemence and said it was not love of virtue
23302. alone, but also a love of strife that had moved him in the dispute.
23303. Pierre did not answer him and asked briefly whether his proposal would
23304. be accepted. He was told that it would not, and without waiting for the
23305. usual formalities he left the lodge and went home.
23306. 
23307. 
23308. 
23309. 
23310. 
23311. CHAPTER VIII
23312. 
23313. 
23314. Again Pierre was overtaken by the depression he so dreaded. For three
23315. days after the delivery of his speech at the lodge he lay on a sofa at
23316. home receiving no one and going nowhere.
23317. 
23318. It was just then that he received a letter from his wife, who implored
23319. him to see her, telling him how grieved she was about him and how she
23320. wished to devote her whole life to him.
23321. 
23322. At the end of the letter she informed him that in a few days she would
23323. return to Petersburg from abroad.
23324. 
23325. Following this letter one of the Masonic Brothers whom Pierre respected
23326. less than the others forced his way in to see him and, turning the
23327. conversation upon Pierre's matrimonial affairs, by way of fraternal
23328. advice expressed the opinion that his severity to his wife was wrong
23329. and that he was neglecting one of the first rules of Freemasonry by not
23330. forgiving the penitent.
23331. 
23332. At the same time his mother-in-law, Prince Vasili's wife, sent to
23333. him imploring him to come if only for a few minutes to discuss a most
23334. important matter. Pierre saw that there was a conspiracy against him and
23335. that they wanted to reunite him with his wife, and in the mood he then
23336. was, this was not even unpleasant to him. Nothing mattered to him.
23337. Nothing in life seemed to him of much importance, and under the
23338. influence of the depression that possessed him he valued neither his
23339. liberty nor his resolution to punish his wife.
23340. 
23341. "No one is right and no one is to blame; so she too is not to blame," he
23342. thought.
23343. 
23344. If he did not at once give his consent to a reunion with his wife, it
23345. was only because in his state of depression he did not feel able to take
23346. any step. Had his wife come to him, he would not have turned her away.
23347. Compared to what preoccupied him, was it not a matter of indifference
23348. whether he lived with his wife or not?
23349. 
23350. Without replying either to his wife or his mother-in-law, Pierre late
23351. one night prepared for a journey and started for Moscow to see Joseph
23352. Alexeevich. This is what he noted in his diary:
23353. 
23354. 
23355. Moscow, 17th November
23356. 
23357. I have just returned from my benefactor, and hasten to write down what
23358. I have experienced. Joseph Alexeevich is living poorly and has for three
23359. years been suffering from a painful disease of the bladder. No one has
23360. ever heard him utter a groan or a word of complaint. From morning till
23361. late at night, except when he eats his very plain food, he is working
23362. at science. He received me graciously and made me sit down on the bed
23363. on which he lay. I made the sign of the Knights of the East and of
23364. Jerusalem, and he responded in the same manner, asking me with a mild
23365. smile what I had learned and gained in the Prussian and Scottish lodges.
23366. I told him everything as best I could, and told him what I had proposed
23367. to our Petersburg lodge, of the bad reception I had encountered, and of
23368. my rupture with the Brothers. Joseph Alexeevich, having remained silent
23369. and thoughtful for a good while, told me his view of the matter, which
23370. at once lit up for me my whole past and the future path I should follow.
23371. He surprised me by asking whether I remembered the threefold aim of
23372. the order: (1) The preservation and study of the mystery. (2) The
23373. purification and reformation of oneself for its reception, and (3) The
23374. improvement of the human race by striving for such purification. Which
23375. is the principal aim of these three? Certainly self-reformation and
23376. self-purification. Only to this aim can we always strive independently
23377. of circumstances. But at the same time just this aim demands the
23378. greatest efforts of us; and so, led astray by pride, losing sight of
23379. this aim, we occupy ourselves either with the mystery which in our
23380. impurity we are unworthy to receive, or seek the reformation of
23381. the human race while ourselves setting an example of baseness and
23382. profligacy. Illuminism is not a pure doctrine, just because it is
23383. attracted by social activity and puffed up by pride. On this ground
23384. Joseph Alexeevich condemned my speech and my whole activity, and in the
23385. depth of my soul I agreed with him. Talking of my family affairs he
23386. said to me, "the chief duty of a true Mason, as I have told you, lies in
23387. perfecting himself. We often think that by removing all the difficulties
23388. of our life we shall more quickly reach our aim, but on the contrary,
23389. my dear sir, it is only in the midst of worldly cares that we can attain
23390. our three chief aims: (1) Self-knowledge--for man can only know himself
23391. by comparison, (2) Self-perfecting, which can only be attained by
23392. conflict, and (3) The attainment of the chief virtue--love of death.
23393. Only the vicissitudes of life can show us its vanity and develop our
23394. innate love of death or of rebirth to a new life." These words are all
23395. the more remarkable because, in spite of his great physical sufferings,
23396. Joseph Alexeevich is never weary of life though he loves death, for
23397. which--in spite of the purity and loftiness of his inner man--he does
23398. not yet feel himself sufficiently prepared. My benefactor then explained
23399. to me fully the meaning of the Great Square of creation and pointed out
23400. to me that the numbers three and seven are the basis of everything. He
23401. advised me not to avoid intercourse with the Petersburg Brothers, but
23402. to take up only second-grade posts in the lodge, to try, while
23403. diverting the Brothers from pride, to turn them toward the true path
23404. self-knowledge and self-perfecting. Besides this he advised me for
23405. myself personally above all to keep a watch over myself, and to that end
23406. he gave me a notebook, the one I am now writing in and in which I will
23407. in future note down all my actions.
23408. 
23409. 
23410. Petersburg, 23rd November
23411. 
23412. I am again living with my wife. My mother-in-law came to me in tears and
23413. said that Helene was here and that she implored me to hear her; that she
23414. was innocent and unhappy at my desertion, and much more. I knew that if
23415. I once let myself see her I should not have strength to go on refusing
23416. what she wanted. In my perplexity I did not know whose aid and advice
23417. to seek. Had my benefactor been here he would have told me what to do.
23418. I went to my room and reread Joseph Alexeevich's letters and recalled
23419. my conversations with him, and deduced from it all that I ought not
23420. to refuse a suppliant, and ought to reach a helping hand to
23421. everyone--especially to one so closely bound to me--and that I must bear
23422. my cross. But if I forgive her for the sake of doing right, then let
23423. union with her have only a spiritual aim. That is what I decided, and
23424. what I wrote to Joseph Alexeevich. I told my wife that I begged her to
23425. forget the past, to forgive me whatever wrong I may have done her, and
23426. that I had nothing to forgive. It gave me joy to tell her this. She need
23427. not know how hard it was for me to see her again. I have settled on the
23428. upper floor of this big house and am experiencing a happy feeling of
23429. regeneration.
23430. 
23431. 
23432. 
23433. 
23434. 
23435. CHAPTER IX
23436. 
23437. 
23438. At that time, as always happens, the highest society that met at court
23439. and at the grand balls was divided into several circles, each with its
23440. own particular tone. The largest of these was the French circle of the
23441. Napoleonic alliance, the circle of Count Rumyantsev and Caulaincourt.
23442. In this group Helene, as soon as she had settled in Petersburg with her
23443. husband, took a very prominent place. She was visited by the members of
23444. the French embassy and by many belonging to that circle and noted for
23445. their intellect and polished manners.
23446. 
23447. Helene had been at Erfurt during the famous meeting of the Emperors
23448. and had brought from there these connections with the Napoleonic
23449. notabilities. At Erfurt her success had been brilliant. Napoleon himself
23450. had noticed her in the theater and said of her: "C'est un superbe
23451. animal." * Her success as a beautiful and elegant woman did not surprise
23452. Pierre, for she had become even handsomer than before. What did surprise
23453. him was that during these last two years his wife had succeeded in
23454. gaining the reputation "d' une femme charmante, aussi spirituelle que
23455. belle." *(2) The distinguished Prince de Ligne wrote her eight-page
23456. letters. Bilibin saved up his epigrams to produce them in Countess
23457. Bezukhova's presence. To be received in the Countess Bezukhova's salon
23458. was regarded as a diploma of intellect. Young men read books before
23459. attending Helene's evenings, to have something to say in her salon, and
23460. secretaries of the embassy, and even ambassadors, confided diplomatic
23461. secrets to her, so that in a way Helene was a power. Pierre, who knew
23462. she was very stupid, sometimes attended, with a strange feeling of
23463. perplexity and fear, her evenings and dinner parties, where politics,
23464. poetry, and philosophy were discussed. At these parties his feelings
23465. were like those of a conjuror who always expects his trick to be found
23466. out at any moment. But whether because stupidity was just what was
23467. needed to run such a salon, or because those who were deceived found
23468. pleasure in the deception, at any rate it remained unexposed and Helene
23469. Bezukhova's reputation as a lovely and clever woman became so firmly
23470. established that she could say the emptiest and stupidest things and
23471. everybody would go into raptures over every word of hers and look for a
23472. profound meaning in it of which she herself had no conception.
23473. 
23474. 
23475.      * "That's a superb animal."
23476. 
23477.      * (2) "Of a charming woman, as witty as she is lovely."
23478. 
23479. 
23480. Pierre was just the husband needed for a brilliant society woman. He was
23481. that absent-minded crank, a grand seigneur husband who was in no one's
23482. way, and far from spoiling the high tone and general impression of the
23483. drawing room, he served, by the contrast he presented to her, as an
23484. advantageous background to his elegant and tactful wife. Pierre during
23485. the last two years, as a result of his continual absorption in abstract
23486. interests and his sincere contempt for all else, had acquired in his
23487. wife's circle, which did not interest him, that air of unconcern,
23488. indifference, and benevolence toward all, which cannot be acquired
23489. artificially and therefore inspires involuntary respect. He entered
23490. his wife's drawing room as one enters a theater, was acquainted with
23491. everybody, equally pleased to see everyone, and equally indifferent to
23492. them all. Sometimes he joined in a conversation which interested him
23493. and, regardless of whether any "gentlemen of the embassy" were present
23494. or not, lispingly expressed his views, which were sometimes not at all
23495. in accord with the accepted tone of the moment. But the general opinion
23496. concerning the queer husband of "the most distinguished woman in
23497. Petersburg" was so well established that no one took his freaks
23498. seriously.
23499. 
23500. Among the many young men who frequented her house every day, Boris
23501. Drubetskoy, who had already achieved great success in the service, was
23502. the most intimate friend of the Bezukhov household since Helene's return
23503. from Erfurt. Helene spoke of him as "mon page" and treated him like a
23504. child. Her smile for him was the same as for everybody, but sometimes
23505. that smile made Pierre uncomfortable. Toward him Boris behaved with a
23506. particularly dignified and sad deference. This shade of deference also
23507. disturbed Pierre. He had suffered so painfully three years before
23508. from the mortification to which his wife had subjected him that he now
23509. protected himself from the danger of its repetition, first by not being
23510. a husband to his wife, and secondly by not allowing himself to suspect.
23511. 
23512. "No, now that she has become a bluestocking she has finally renounced
23513. her former infatuations," he told himself. "There has never been
23514. an instance of a bluestocking being carried away by affairs of the
23515. heart"--a statement which, though gathered from an unknown source, he
23516. believed implicitly. Yet strange to say Boris' presence in his wife's
23517. drawing room (and he was almost always there) had a physical effect upon
23518. Pierre; it constricted his limbs and destroyed the unconsciousness and
23519. freedom of his movements.
23520. 
23521. "What a strange antipathy," thought Pierre, "yet I used to like him very
23522. much."
23523. 
23524. In the eyes of the world Pierre was a great gentleman, the rather blind
23525. and absurd husband of a distinguished wife, a clever crank who did
23526. nothing but harmed nobody and was a first-rate, good-natured fellow. But
23527. a complex and difficult process of internal development was taking place
23528. all this time in Pierre's soul, revealing much to him and causing him
23529. many spiritual doubts and joys.
23530. 
23531. 
23532. 
23533. 
23534. 
23535. CHAPTER X
23536. 
23537. 
23538. Pierre went on with his diary, and this is what he wrote in it during
23539. that time:
23540. 
23541. 
23542. 24th November
23543. 
23544. Got up at eight, read the Scriptures, then went to my duties. (By Joseph
23545. Alexeevich's advice Pierre had entered the service of the state and
23546. served on one of the committees.) Returned home for dinner and dined
23547. alone--the countess had many visitors I do not like. I ate and drank
23548. moderately and after dinner copied out some passages for the Brothers.
23549. In the evening I went down to the countess and told a funny story about
23550. B., and only remembered that I ought not to have done so when everybody
23551. laughed loudly at it.
23552. 
23553. I am going to bed with a happy and tranquil mind. Great God, help me to
23554. walk in Thy paths, (1) to conquer anger by calmness and deliberation,
23555. (2) to vanquish lust by self-restraint and repulsion, (3) to withdraw
23556. from worldliness, but not avoid (a) the service of the state, (b) family
23557. duties, (c) relations with my friends, and the management of my affairs.
23558. 
23559. 
23560. 27th November
23561. 
23562. I got up late. On waking I lay long in bed yielding to sloth. O God,
23563. help and strengthen me that I may walk in Thy ways! Read the Scriptures,
23564. but without proper feeling. Brother Urusov came and we talked about
23565. worldly vanities. He told me of the Emperor's new projects. I began to
23566. criticize them, but remembered my rules and my benefactor's words--that
23567. a true Freemason should be a zealous worker for the state when his aid
23568. is required and a quiet onlooker when not called on to assist. My tongue
23569. is my enemy. Brothers G. V. and O. visited me and we had a preliminary
23570. talk about the reception of a new Brother. They laid on me the duty of
23571. Rhetor. I feel myself weak and unworthy. Then our talk turned to the
23572. interpretation of the seven pillars and steps of the Temple, the seven
23573. sciences, the seven virtues, the seven vices, and the seven gifts of the
23574. Holy Spirit. Brother O. was very eloquent. In the evening the admission
23575. took place. The new decoration of the Premises contributed much to the
23576. magnificence of the spectacle. It was Boris Drubetskoy who was admitted.
23577. I nominated him and was the Rhetor. A strange feeling agitated me all
23578. the time I was alone with him in the dark chamber. I caught myself
23579. harboring a feeling of hatred toward him which I vainly tried to
23580. overcome. That is why I should really like to save him from evil and
23581. lead him into the path of truth, but evil thoughts of him did not leave
23582. me. It seemed to me that his object in entering the Brotherhood was
23583. merely to be intimate and in favor with members of our lodge. Apart
23584. from the fact that he had asked me several times whether N. and S. were
23585. members of our lodge (a question to which I could not reply) and that
23586. according to my observation he is incapable of feeling respect for our
23587. holy order and is too preoccupied and satisfied with the outer man to
23588. desire spiritual improvement, I had no cause to doubt him, but he seemed
23589. to me insincere, and all the time I stood alone with him in the dark
23590. temple it seemed to me that he was smiling contemptuously at my words,
23591. and I wished really to stab his bare breast with the sword I held to it.
23592. I could not be eloquent, nor could I frankly mention my doubts to the
23593. Brothers and to the Grand Master. Great Architect of Nature, help me to
23594. find the true path out of the labyrinth of lies!
23595. 
23596. 
23597.  After this, three pages were left blank in the diary, and then
23598. the following was written:
23599. 
23600. 
23601. I have had a long and instructive talk alone with Brother V., who
23602. advised me to hold fast by brother A. Though I am unworthy, much was
23603. revealed to me. Adonai is the name of the creator of the world. Elohim
23604. is the name of the ruler of all. The third name is the name unutterable
23605. which means the All. Talks with Brother V. strengthen, refresh, and
23606. support me in the path of virtue. In his presence doubt has no place.
23607. The distinction between the poor teachings of mundane science and our
23608. sacred all-embracing teaching is clear to me. Human sciences dissect
23609. everything to comprehend it, and kill everything to examine it. In the
23610. holy science of our order all is one, all is known in its entirety and
23611. life. The Trinity--the three elements of matter--are sulphur, mercury,
23612. and salt. Sulphur is of an oily and fiery nature; in combination with
23613. salt by its fiery nature it arouses a desire in the latter by means
23614. of which it attracts mercury, seizes it, holds it, and in combination
23615. produces other bodies. Mercury is a fluid, volatile, spiritual essence.
23616. Christ, the Holy Spirit, Him!...
23617. 
23618. 
23619. 3rd December
23620. 
23621. Awoke late, read the Scriptures but was apathetic. Afterwards went and
23622. paced up and down the large hall. I wished to meditate, but instead my
23623. imagination pictured an occurrence of four years ago, when Dolokhov,
23624. meeting me in Moscow after our duel, said he hoped I was enjoying
23625. perfect peace of mind in spite of my wife's absence. At the time I gave
23626. him no answer. Now I recalled every detail of that meeting and in my
23627. mind gave him the most malevolent and bitter replies. I recollected
23628. myself and drove away that thought only when I found myself glowing with
23629. anger, but I did not sufficiently repent. Afterwards Boris Drubetskoy
23630. came and began relating various adventures. His coming vexed me from the
23631. first, and I said something disagreeable to him. He replied. I flared
23632. up and said much that was unpleasant and even rude to him. He became
23633. silent, and I recollected myself only when it was too late. My God, I
23634. cannot get on with him at all. The cause of this is my egotism. I set
23635. myself above him and so become much worse than he, for he is lenient
23636. to my rudeness while I on the contrary nourish contempt for him. O God,
23637. grant that in his presence I may rather see my own vileness, and behave
23638. so that he too may benefit. After dinner I fell asleep and as I was
23639. drowsing off I clearly heard a voice saying in my left ear, "Thy day!"
23640. 
23641. I dreamed that I was walking in the dark and was suddenly surrounded by
23642. dogs, but I went on undismayed. Suddenly a smallish dog seized my left
23643. thigh with its teeth and would not let go. I began to throttle it with
23644. my hands. Scarcely had I torn it off before another, a bigger one, began
23645. biting me. I lifted it up, but the higher I lifted it the bigger and
23646. heavier it grew. And suddenly Brother A. came and, taking my arm, led
23647. me to a building to enter which we had to pass along a narrow plank.
23648. I stepped on it, but it bent and gave way and I began to clamber up a
23649. fence which I could scarcely reach with my hands. After much effort I
23650. dragged myself up, so that my leg hung down on one side and my body on
23651. the other. I looked round and saw Brother A. standing on the fence and
23652. pointing me to a broad avenue and garden, and in the garden was a large
23653. and beautiful building. I woke up. O Lord, great Architect of Nature,
23654. help me to tear from myself these dogs--my passions especially the last,
23655. which unites in itself the strength of all the former ones, and aid me
23656. to enter that temple of virtue to a vision of which I attained in my
23657. dream.
23658. 
23659. 
23660. 7th December
23661. 
23662. I dreamed that Joseph Alexeevich was sitting in my house, and that I
23663. was very glad and wished to entertain him. It seemed as if I chattered
23664. incessantly with other people and suddenly remembered that this could
23665. not please him, and I wished to come close to him and embrace him. But
23666. as soon as I drew near I saw that his face had changed and grown young,
23667. and he was quietly telling me something about the teaching of our order,
23668. but so softly that I could not hear it. Then it seemed that we all left
23669. the room and something strange happened. We were sitting or lying on
23670. the floor. He was telling me something, and I wished to show him my
23671. sensibility, and not listening to what he was saying I began picturing
23672. to myself the condition of my inner man and the grace of God sanctifying
23673. me. And tears came into my eyes, and I was glad he noticed this. But he
23674. looked at me with vexation and jumped up, breaking off his remarks. I
23675. felt abashed and asked whether what he had been saying did not concern
23676. me; but he did not reply, gave me a kind look, and then we suddenly
23677. found ourselves in my bedroom where there is a double bed. He lay down
23678. on the edge of it and I burned with longing to caress him and lie down
23679. too. And he said, "Tell me frankly what is your chief temptation? Do
23680. you know it? I think you know it already." Abashed by this question,
23681. I replied that sloth was my chief temptation. He shook his head
23682. incredulously; and even more abashed, I said that though I was living
23683. with my wife as he advised, I was not living with her as her husband. To
23684. this he replied that one should not deprive a wife of one's embraces and
23685. gave me to understand that that was my duty. But I replied that I should
23686. be ashamed to do it, and suddenly everything vanished. And I awoke and
23687. found in my mind the text from the Gospel: "The life was the light of
23688. men. And the light shineth in darkness; and the darkness comprehended it
23689. not." Joseph Alexeevich's face had looked young and bright. That day I
23690. received a letter from my benefactor in which he wrote about "conjugal
23691. duties."
23692. 
23693. 
23694. 9th December
23695. 
23696. I had a dream from which I awoke with a throbbing heart. I saw that
23697. I was in Moscow in my house, in the big sitting room, and Joseph
23698. Alexeevich came in from the drawing room. I seemed to know at once that
23699. the process of regeneration had already taken place in him, and I rushed
23700. to meet him. I embraced him and kissed his hands, and he said, "Hast
23701. thou noticed that my face is different?" I looked at him, still holding
23702. him in my arms, and saw that his face was young, but that he had no hair
23703. on his head and his features were quite changed. And I said, "I should
23704. have known you had I met you by chance," and I thought to myself, "Am I
23705. telling the truth?" And suddenly I saw him lying like a dead body; then
23706. he gradually recovered and went with me into my study carrying a large
23707. book of sheets of drawing paper; I said, "I drew that," and he answered
23708. by bowing his head. I opened the book, and on all the pages there
23709. were excellent drawings. And in my dream I knew that these drawings
23710. represented the love adventures of the soul with its beloved. And on
23711. its pages I saw a beautiful representation of a maiden in transparent
23712. garments and with a transparent body, flying up to the clouds. And I
23713. seemed to know that this maiden was nothing else than a representation
23714. of the Song of Songs. And looking at those drawings I dreamed I felt
23715. that I was doing wrong, but could not tear myself away from them. Lord,
23716. help me! My God, if Thy forsaking me is Thy doing, Thy will be done; but
23717. if I am myself the cause, teach me what I should do! I shall perish of
23718. my debauchery if Thou utterly desertest me!
23719. 
23720. 
23721. 
23722. 
23723. 
23724. CHAPTER XI
23725. 
23726. 
23727. The Rostovs' monetary affairs had not improved during the two years they
23728. had spent in the country.
23729. 
23730. Though Nicholas Rostov had kept firmly to his resolution and was still
23731. serving modestly in an obscure regiment, spending comparatively little,
23732. the way of life at Otradnoe--Mitenka's management of affairs, in
23733. particular--was such that the debts inevitably increased every year. The
23734. only resource obviously presenting itself to the old count was to apply
23735. for an official post, so he had come to Petersburg to look for one and
23736. also, as he said, to let the lassies enjoy themselves for the last time.
23737. 
23738. Soon after their arrival in Petersburg Berg proposed to Vera and was
23739. accepted.
23740. 
23741. Though in Moscow the Rostovs belonged to the best society without
23742. themselves giving it a thought, yet in Petersburg their circle of
23743. acquaintances was a mixed and indefinite one. In Petersburg they were
23744. provincials, and the very people they had entertained in Moscow without
23745. inquiring to what set they belonged, here looked down on them.
23746. 
23747. The Rostovs lived in the same hospitable way in Petersburg as in Moscow,
23748. and the most diverse people met at their suppers. Country neighbors from
23749. Otradnoe, impoverished old squires and their daughters, Peronskaya a
23750. maid of honor, Pierre Bezukhov, and the son of their district postmaster
23751. who had obtained a post in Petersburg. Among the men who very soon
23752. became frequent visitors at the Rostovs' house in Petersburg were Boris,
23753. Pierre whom the count had met in the street and dragged home with
23754. him, and Berg who spent whole days at the Rostovs' and paid the eldest
23755. daughter, Countess Vera, the attentions a young man pays when he intends
23756. to propose.
23757. 
23758. Not in vain had Berg shown everybody his right hand wounded at
23759. Austerlitz and held a perfectly unnecessary sword in his left. He
23760. narrated that episode so persistently and with so important an air that
23761. everyone believed in the merit and usefulness of his deed, and he had
23762. obtained two decorations for Austerlitz.
23763. 
23764. In the Finnish war he also managed to distinguish himself. He had picked
23765. up the scrap of a grenade that had killed an aide-de-camp standing near
23766. the commander in chief and had taken it to his commander. Just as he had
23767. done after Austerlitz, he related this occurrence at such length and
23768. so insistently that everyone again believed it had been necessary to do
23769. this, and he received two decorations for the Finnish war also. In
23770. 1809 he was a captain in the Guards, wore medals, and held some special
23771. lucrative posts in Petersburg.
23772. 
23773. Though some skeptics smiled when told of Berg's merits, it could not be
23774. denied that he was a painstaking and brave officer, on excellent terms
23775. with his superiors, and a moral young man with a brilliant career before
23776. him and an assured position in society.
23777. 
23778. Four years before, meeting a German comrade in the stalls of a Moscow
23779. theater, Berg had pointed out Vera Rostova to him and had said in
23780. German, "das soll mein Weib werden," * and from that moment had made up
23781. his mind to marry her. Now in Petersburg, having considered the Rostovs'
23782. position and his own, he decided that the time had come to propose.
23783. 
23784. 
23785.     * "That girl shall be my wife."
23786. 
23787. 
23788. Berg's proposal was at first received with a perplexity that was not
23789. flattering to him. At first it seemed strange that the son of an obscure
23790. Livonian gentleman should propose marriage to a Countess Rostova; but
23791. Berg's chief characteristic was such a naive and good natured egotism
23792. that the Rostovs involuntarily came to think it would be a good thing,
23793. since he himself was so firmly convinced that it was good, indeed
23794. excellent. Moreover, the Rostovs' affairs were seriously embarrassed, as
23795. the suitor could not but know; and above all, Vera was twenty-four, had
23796. been taken out everywhere, and though she was certainly good-looking
23797. and sensible, no one up to now had proposed to her. So they gave their
23798. consent.
23799. 
23800. "You see," said Berg to his comrade, whom he called "friend" only
23801. because he knew that everyone has friends, "you see, I have considered
23802. it all, and should not marry if I had not thought it all out or if it
23803. were in any way unsuitable. But on the contrary, my papa and mamma
23804. are now provided for--I have arranged that rent for them in the Baltic
23805. Provinces--and I can live in Petersburg on my pay, and with her fortune
23806. and my good management we can get along nicely. I am not marrying for
23807. money--I consider that dishonorable--but a wife should bring her
23808. share and a husband his. I have my position in the service, she has
23809. connections and some means. In our times that is worth something, isn't
23810. it? But above all, she is a handsome, estimable girl, and she loves
23811. me..."
23812. 
23813. Berg blushed and smiled.
23814. 
23815. "And I love her, because her character is sensible and very good.
23816. Now the other sister, though they are the same family, is quite
23817. different--an unpleasant character and has not the same intelligence.
23818. She is so... you know?... Unpleasant... But my fiancee!... Well, you
23819. will be coming," he was going to say, "to dine," but changed his mind
23820. and said "to take tea with us," and quickly doubling up his tongue he
23821. blew a small round ring of tobacco smoke, perfectly embodying his dream
23822. of happiness.
23823. 
23824. After the first feeling of perplexity aroused in the parents by Berg's
23825. proposal, the holiday tone of joyousness usual at such times took
23826. possession of the family, but the rejoicing was external and insincere.
23827. In the family's feeling toward this wedding a certain awkwardness and
23828. constraint was evident, as if they were ashamed of not having loved Vera
23829. sufficiently and of being so ready to get her off their hands. The old
23830. count felt this most. He would probably have been unable to state
23831. the cause of his embarrassment, but it resulted from the state of his
23832. affairs. He did not know at all how much he had, what his debts amounted
23833. to, or what dowry he could give Vera. When his daughters were born
23834. he had assigned to each of them, for her dowry, an estate with three
23835. hundred serfs; but one of these estates had already been sold, and the
23836. other was mortgaged and the interest so much in arrears that it would
23837. have to be sold, so that it was impossible to give it to Vera. Nor had
23838. he any money.
23839. 
23840. Berg had already been engaged a month, and only a week remained before
23841. the wedding, but the count had not yet decided in his own mind the
23842. question of the dowry, nor spoken to his wife about it. At one time the
23843. count thought of giving her the Ryazan estate or of selling a forest, at
23844. another time of borrowing money on a note of hand. A few days before
23845. the wedding Berg entered the count's study early one morning and, with
23846. a pleasant smile, respectfully asked his future father-in-law to let him
23847. know what Vera's dowry would be. The count was so disconcerted by this
23848. long-foreseen inquiry that without consideration he gave the first reply
23849. that came into his head. "I like your being businesslike about it.... I
23850. like it. You shall be satisfied...."
23851. 
23852. And patting Berg on the shoulder he got up, wishing to end the
23853. conversation. But Berg, smiling pleasantly, explained that if he did not
23854. know for certain how much Vera would have and did not receive at least
23855. part of the dowry in advance, he would have to break matters off.
23856. 
23857. "Because, consider, Count--if I allowed myself to marry now without
23858. having definite means to maintain my wife, I should be acting badly...."
23859. 
23860. The conversation ended by the count, who wished to be generous and to
23861. avoid further importunity, saying that he would give a note of hand
23862. for eighty thousand rubles. Berg smiled meekly, kissed the count on the
23863. shoulder, and said that he was very grateful, but that it was impossible
23864. for him to arrange his new life without receiving thirty thousand in
23865. ready money. "Or at least twenty thousand, Count," he added, "and then a
23866. note of hand for only sixty thousand."
23867. 
23868. "Yes, yes, all right!" said the count hurriedly. "Only excuse me, my
23869. dear fellow, I'll give you twenty thousand and a note of hand for eighty
23870. thousand as well. Yes, yes! Kiss me."
23871. 
23872. 
23873. 
23874. 
23875. 
23876. CHAPTER XII
23877. 
23878. 
23879. Natasha was sixteen and it was the year 1809, the very year to which she
23880. had counted on her fingers with Boris after they had kissed four years
23881. ago. Since then she had not seen him. Before Sonya and her mother, if
23882. Boris happened to be mentioned, she spoke quite freely of that
23883. episode as of some childish, long-forgotten matter that was not worth
23884. mentioning. But in the secret depths of her soul the question whether
23885. her engagement to Boris was a jest or an important, binding promise
23886. tormented her.
23887. 
23888. Since Boris left Moscow in 1805 to join the army he had not seen the
23889. Rostovs. He had been in Moscow several times, and had passed near
23890. Otradnoe, but had never been to see them.
23891. 
23892. Sometimes it occurred to Natasha that he did not wish to see her, and
23893. this conjecture was confirmed by the sad tone in which her elders spoke
23894. of him.
23895. 
23896. "Nowadays old friends are not remembered," the countess would say when
23897. Boris was mentioned.
23898. 
23899. Anna Mikhaylovna also had of late visited them less frequently, seemed
23900. to hold herself with particular dignity, and always spoke rapturously
23901. and gratefully of the merits of her son and the brilliant career on
23902. which he had entered. When the Rostovs came to Petersburg Boris called
23903. on them.
23904. 
23905. He drove to their house in some agitation. The memory of Natasha was his
23906. most poetic recollection. But he went with the firm intention of letting
23907. her and her parents feel that the childish relations between himself and
23908. Natasha could not be binding either on her or on him. He had a brilliant
23909. position in society thanks to his intimacy with Countess Bezukhova,
23910. a brilliant position in the service thanks to the patronage of an
23911. important personage whose complete confidence he enjoyed, and he was
23912. beginning to make plans for marrying one of the richest heiresses in
23913. Petersburg, plans which might very easily be realized. When he entered
23914. the Rostovs' drawing room Natasha was in her own room. When she heard
23915. of his arrival she almost ran into the drawing room, flushed and beaming
23916. with a more than cordial smile.
23917. 
23918. Boris remembered Natasha in a short dress, with dark eyes shining from
23919. under her curls and boisterous, childish laughter, as he had known her
23920. four years before; and so he was taken aback when quite a different
23921. Natasha entered, and his face expressed rapturous astonishment. This
23922. expression on his face pleased Natasha.
23923. 
23924. "Well, do you recognize your little madcap playmate?" asked the
23925. countess.
23926. 
23927. Boris kissed Natasha's hand and said that he was astonished at the
23928. change in her.
23929. 
23930. "How handsome you have grown!"
23931. 
23932. "I should think so!" replied Natasha's laughing eyes.
23933. 
23934. "And is Papa older?" she asked.
23935. 
23936. Natasha sat down and, without joining in Boris' conversation with the
23937. countess, silently and minutely studied her childhood's suitor. He felt
23938. the weight of that resolute and affectionate scrutiny and glanced at her
23939. occasionally.
23940. 
23941. Boris' uniform, spurs, tie, and the way his hair was brushed were all
23942. comme il faut and in the latest fashion. This Natasha noticed at once.
23943. He sat rather sideways in the armchair next to the countess, arranging
23944. with his right hand the cleanest of gloves that fitted his left hand
23945. like a skin, and he spoke with a particularly refined compression of his
23946. lips about the amusements of the highest Petersburg society, recalling
23947. with mild irony old times in Moscow and Moscow acquaintances. It was
23948. not accidentally, Natasha felt, that he alluded, when speaking of the
23949. highest aristocracy, to an ambassador's ball he had attended, and to
23950. invitations he had received from N.N. and S.S.
23951. 
23952. All this time Natasha sat silent, glancing up at him from under her
23953. brows. This gaze disturbed and confused Boris more and more. He looked
23954. round more frequently toward her, and broke off in what he was saying.
23955. He did not stay more than ten minutes, then rose and took his leave. The
23956. same inquisitive, challenging, and rather mocking eyes still looked at
23957. him. After his first visit Boris said to himself that Natasha attracted
23958. him just as much as ever, but that he must not yield to that feeling,
23959. because to marry her, a girl almost without fortune, would mean ruin to
23960. his career, while to renew their former relations without intending to
23961. marry her would be dishonorable. Boris made up his mind to avoid meeting
23962. Natasha, but despite that resolution he called again a few days later
23963. and began calling often and spending whole days at the Rostovs'. It
23964. seemed to him that he ought to have an explanation with Natasha and tell
23965. her that the old times must be forgotten, that in spite of everything...
23966. she could not be his wife, that he had no means, and they would never
23967. let her marry him. But he failed to do so and felt awkward about
23968. entering on such an explanation. From day to day he became more and more
23969. entangled. It seemed to her mother and Sonya that Natasha was in love
23970. with Boris as of old. She sang him his favorite songs, showed him her
23971. album, making him write in it, did not allow him to allude to the past,
23972. letting it be understood how delightful was the present; and every day
23973. he went away in a fog, without having said what he meant to, and not
23974. knowing what he was doing or why he came, or how it would all end. He
23975. left off visiting Helene and received reproachful notes from her every
23976. day, and yet he continued to spend whole days with the Rostovs.
23977. 
23978. 
23979. 
23980. 
23981. 
23982. CHAPTER XIII
23983. 
23984. 
23985. One night when the old countess, in nightcap and dressing jacket,
23986. without her false curls, and with her poor little knob of hair showing
23987. under her white cotton cap, knelt sighing and groaning on a rug and
23988. bowing to the ground in prayer, her door creaked and Natasha, also in
23989. a dressing jacket with slippers on her bare feet and her hair in
23990. curlpapers, ran in. The countess--her prayerful mood dispelled--looked
23991. round and frowned. She was finishing her last prayer: "Can it be that
23992. this couch will be my grave?" Natasha, flushed and eager, seeing
23993. her mother in prayer, suddenly checked her rush, half sat down, and
23994. unconsciously put out her tongue as if chiding herself. Seeing that
23995. her mother was still praying she ran on tiptoe to the bed and, rapidly
23996. slipping one little foot against the other, pushed off her slippers and
23997. jumped onto the bed the countess had feared might become her grave. This
23998. couch was high, with a feather bed and five pillows each smaller than
23999. the one below. Natasha jumped on it, sank into the feather bed, rolled
24000. over to the wall, and began snuggling up the bedclothes as she settled
24001. down, raising her knees to her chin, kicking out and laughing almost
24002. inaudibly, now covering herself up head and all, and now peeping at her
24003. mother. The countess finished her prayers and came to the bed with a
24004. stern face, but seeing, that Natasha's head was covered, she smiled in
24005. her kind, weak way.
24006. 
24007. "Now then, now then!" said she.
24008. 
24009. "Mamma, can we have a talk? Yes?" said Natasha. "Now, just one on your
24010. throat and another... that'll do!" And seizing her mother round the
24011. neck, she kissed her on the throat. In her behavior to her mother
24012. Natasha seemed rough, but she was so sensitive and tactful that however
24013. she clasped her mother she always managed to do it without hurting her
24014. or making her feel uncomfortable or displeased.
24015. 
24016. "Well, what is it tonight?" said the mother, having arranged her pillows
24017. and waited until Natasha, after turning over a couple of times, had
24018. settled down beside her under the quilt, spread out her arms, and
24019. assumed a serious expression.
24020. 
24021. These visits of Natasha's at night before the count returned from his
24022. club were one of the greatest pleasures of both mother, and daughter.
24023. 
24024. "What is it tonight?--But I have to tell you..."
24025. 
24026. Natasha put her hand on her mother's mouth.
24027. 
24028. "About Boris... I know," she said seriously; "that's what I have come
24029. about. Don't say it--I know. No, do tell me!" and she removed her hand.
24030. "Tell me, Mamma! He's nice?"
24031. 
24032. "Natasha, you are sixteen. At your age I was married. You say Boris is
24033. nice. He is very nice, and I love him like a son. But what then?...
24034. What are you thinking about? You have quite turned his head, I can see
24035. that...."
24036.
