24037. As she said this the countess looked round at her daughter. Natasha
24038. was lying looking steadily straight before her at one of the mahogany
24039. sphinxes carved on the corners of the bedstead, so that the countess
24040. only saw her daughter's face in profile. That face struck her by its
24041. peculiarly serious and concentrated expression.
24042. 
24043. Natasha was listening and considering.
24044. 
24045. "Well, what then?" said she.
24046. 
24047. "You have quite turned his head, and why? What do you want of him? You
24048. know you can't marry him."
24049. 
24050. "Why not?" said Natasha, without changing her position.
24051. 
24052. "Because he is young, because he is poor, because he is a relation...
24053. and because you yourself don't love him."
24054. 
24055. "How do you know?"
24056. 
24057. "I know. It is not right, darling!"
24058. 
24059.  "But if I want to..." said Natasha.
24060. 
24061. "Leave off talking nonsense," said the countess.
24062. 
24063. "But if I want to..."
24064. 
24065. "Natasha, I am in earnest..."
24066. 
24067. Natasha did not let her finish. She drew the countess' large hand to
24068. her, kissed it on the back and then on the palm, then again turned it
24069. over and began kissing first one knuckle, then the space between the
24070. knuckles, then the next knuckle, whispering, "January, February, March,
24071. April, May. Speak, Mamma, why don't you say anything? Speak!" said she,
24072. turning to her mother, who was tenderly gazing at her daughter and in
24073. that contemplation seemed to have forgotten all she had wished to say.
24074. 
24075. "It won't do, my love! Not everyone will understand this friendship
24076. dating from your childish days, and to see him so intimate with you may
24077. injure you in the eyes of other young men who visit us, and above all
24078. it torments him for nothing. He may already have found a suitable and
24079. wealthy match, and now he's half crazy."
24080. 
24081. "Crazy?" repeated Natasha.
24082. 
24083. "I'll tell you some things about myself. I had a cousin..."
24084. 
24085. "I know! Cyril Matveich... but he is old."
24086. 
24087. "He was not always old. But this is what I'll do, Natasha, I'll have a
24088. talk with Boris. He need not come so often...."
24089. 
24090. "Why not, if he likes to?"
24091. 
24092. "Because I know it will end in nothing...."
24093. 
24094. "How can you know? No, Mamma, don't speak to him! What nonsense!" said
24095. Natasha in the tone of one being deprived of her property. "Well, I
24096. won't marry, but let him come if he enjoys it and I enjoy it." Natasha
24097. smiled and looked at her mother. "Not to marry, but just so," she added.
24098. 
24099. "How so, my pet?"
24100. 
24101. "Just so. There's no need for me to marry him. But... just so."
24102. 
24103. "Just so, just so," repeated the countess, and shaking all over, she
24104. went off into a good humored, unexpected, elderly laugh.
24105. 
24106. "Don't laugh, stop!" cried Natasha. "You're shaking the whole bed!
24107. You're awfully like me, just such another giggler.... Wait..." and she
24108. seized the countess' hands and kissed a knuckle of the little finger,
24109. saying, "June," and continued, kissing, "July, August," on the other
24110. hand. "But, Mamma, is he very much in love? What do you think? Was
24111. anybody ever so much in love with you? And he's very nice, very, very
24112. nice. Only not quite my taste--he is so narrow, like the dining-room
24113. clock.... Don't you understand? Narrow, you know--gray, light gray..."
24114. 
24115. "What rubbish you're talking!" said the countess.
24116. 
24117. Natasha continued: "Don't you really understand? Nicholas would
24118. understand.... Bezukhov, now, is blue, dark-blue and red, and he is
24119. square."
24120. 
24121. "You flirt with him too," said the countess, laughing.
24122. 
24123. "No, he is a Freemason, I have found out. He is fine, dark-blue and
24124. red.... How can I explain it to you?"
24125. 
24126. "Little countess!" the count's voice called from behind the door.
24127. "You're not asleep?" Natasha jumped up, snatched up her slippers, and
24128. ran barefoot to her own room.
24129. 
24130. It was a long time before she could sleep. She kept thinking that no one
24131. could understand all that she understood and all there was in her.
24132. 
24133. "Sonya?" she thought, glancing at that curled-up, sleeping little kitten
24134. with her enormous plait of hair. "No, how could she? She's virtuous. She
24135. fell in love with Nicholas and does not wish to know anything more. Even
24136. Mamma does not understand. It is wonderful how clever I am and how...
24137. charming she is," she went on, speaking of herself in the third person,
24138. and imagining it was some very wise man--the wisest and best of
24139. men--who was saying it of her. "There is everything, everything in her,"
24140. continued this man. "She is unusually intelligent, charming... and
24141. then she is pretty, uncommonly pretty, and agile--she swims and rides
24142. splendidly... and her voice! One can really say it's a wonderful voice!"
24143. 
24144. She hummed a scrap from her favorite opera by Cherubini, threw herself
24145. on her bed, laughed at the pleasant thought that she would immediately
24146. fall asleep, called Dunyasha the maid to put out the candle, and before
24147. Dunyasha had left the room had already passed into yet another happier
24148. world of dreams, where everything was as light and beautiful as in
24149. reality, and even more so because it was different.
24150. 
24151. 
24152. Next day the countess called Boris aside and had a talk with him, after
24153. which he ceased coming to the Rostovs'.
24154. 
24155. 
24156. 
24157. 
24158. 
24159. CHAPTER XIV
24160. 
24161. 
24162. On the thirty-first of December, New Year's Eve, 1809 - 10 an old
24163. grandee of Catherine's day was giving a ball and midnight supper. The
24164. diplomatic corps and the Emperor himself were to be present.
24165. 
24166. The grandee's well-known mansion on the English Quay glittered with
24167. innumerable lights. Police were stationed at the brightly lit entrance
24168. which was carpeted with red baize, and not only gendarmes but dozens of
24169. police officers and even the police master himself stood at the porch.
24170. Carriages kept driving away and fresh ones arriving, with red-liveried
24171. footmen and footmen in plumed hats. From the carriages emerged men
24172. wearing uniforms, stars, and ribbons, while ladies in satin and ermine
24173. cautiously descended the carriage steps which were let down for them
24174. with a clatter, and then walked hurriedly and noiselessly over the baize
24175. at the entrance.
24176. 
24177. Almost every time a new carriage drove up a whisper ran through the
24178. crowd and caps were doffed.
24179. 
24180. "The Emperor?... No, a minister.... prince... ambassador. Don't you see
24181. the plumes?..." was whispered among the crowd.
24182. 
24183. One person, better dressed than the rest, seemed to know everyone and
24184. mentioned by name the greatest dignitaries of the day.
24185. 
24186. A third of the visitors had already arrived, but the Rostovs, who were
24187. to be present, were still hurrying to get dressed.
24188. 
24189. There had been many discussions and preparations for this ball in the
24190. Rostov family, many fears that the invitation would not arrive, that the
24191. dresses would not be ready, or that something would not be arranged as
24192. it should be.
24193. 
24194. Marya Ignatevna Peronskaya, a thin and shallow maid of honor at the
24195. court of the Dowager Empress, who was a friend and relation of the
24196. countess and piloted the provincial Rostovs in Petersburg high society,
24197. was to accompany them to the ball.
24198. 
24199. They were to call for her at her house in the Taurida Gardens at ten
24200. o'clock, but it was already five minutes to ten, and the girls were not
24201. yet dressed.
24202. 
24203. Natasha was going to her first grand ball. She had got up at eight that
24204. morning and had been in a fever of excitement and activity all day. All
24205. her powers since morning had been concentrated on ensuring that they
24206. all--she herself, Mamma, and Sonya--should be as well dressed as
24207. possible. Sonya and her mother put themselves entirely in her hands. The
24208. countess was to wear a claret-colored velvet dress, and the two girls
24209. white gauze over pink silk slips, with roses on their bodices and their
24210. hair dressed a la grecque.
24211. 
24212. Everything essential had already been done; feet, hands, necks, and
24213. ears washed, perfumed, and powdered, as befits a ball; the openwork
24214. silk stockings and white satin shoes with ribbons were already on; the
24215. hairdressing was almost done. Sonya was finishing dressing and so was
24216. the countess, but Natasha, who had bustled about helping them all, was
24217. behindhand. She was still sitting before a looking-glass with a dressing
24218. jacket thrown over her slender shoulders. Sonya stood ready dressed in
24219. the middle of the room and, pressing the head of a pin till it hurt her
24220. dainty finger, was fixing on a last ribbon that squeaked as the pin went
24221. through it.
24222. 
24223. "That's not the way, that's not the way, Sonya!" cried Natasha turning
24224. her head and clutching with both hands at her hair which the maid who
24225. was dressing it had not time to release. "That bow is not right. Come
24226. here!"
24227. 
24228. Sonya sat down and Natasha pinned the ribbon on differently.
24229. 
24230. "Allow me, Miss! I can't do it like that," said the maid who was holding
24231. Natasha's hair.
24232. 
24233. "Oh, dear! Well then, wait. That's right, Sonya."
24234. 
24235. "Aren't you ready? It is nearly ten," came the countess' voice.
24236. 
24237. "Directly! Directly! And you, Mamma?"
24238. 
24239. "I have only my cap to pin on."
24240. 
24241. "Don't do it without me!" called Natasha. "You won't do it right."
24242. 
24243. "But it's already ten."
24244. 
24245. They had decided to be at the ball by half past ten, and Natasha had
24246. still to get dressed and they had to call at the Taurida Gardens.
24247. 
24248. When her hair was done, Natasha, in her short petticoat from under which
24249. her dancing shoes showed, and in her mother's dressing jacket, ran up to
24250. Sonya, scrutinized her, and then ran to her mother. Turning her mother's
24251. head this way and that, she fastened on the cap and, hurriedly kissing
24252. her gray hair, ran back to the maids who were turning up the hem of her
24253. skirt.
24254. 
24255. The cause of the delay was Natasha's skirt, which was too long. Two
24256. maids were turning up the hem and hurriedly biting off the ends of
24257. thread. A third with pins in her mouth was running about between the
24258. countess and Sonya, and a fourth held the whole of the gossamer garment
24259. up high on one uplifted hand.
24260. 
24261. "Mavra, quicker, darling!"
24262. 
24263. "Give me my thimble, Miss, from there..."
24264. 
24265. "Whenever will you be ready?" asked the count coming to the door. "Here
24266. is some scent. Peronskaya must be tired of waiting."
24267. 
24268. "It's ready, Miss," said the maid, holding up the shortened gauze dress
24269. with two fingers, and blowing and shaking something off it, as if by
24270. this to express a consciousness of the airiness and purity of what she
24271. held.
24272. 
24273. Natasha began putting on the dress.
24274. 
24275. "In a minute! In a minute! Don't come in, Papa!" she cried to her father
24276. as he opened the door--speaking from under the filmy skirt which still
24277. covered her whole face.
24278. 
24279. Sonya slammed the door to. A minute later they let the count in. He was
24280. wearing a blue swallow-tail coat, shoes and stockings, and was perfumed
24281. and his hair pomaded.
24282. 
24283. "Oh, Papa! how nice you look! Charming!" cried Natasha, as she stood in
24284. the middle of the room smoothing out the folds of the gauze.
24285. 
24286. "If you please, Miss! allow me," said the maid, who on her knees was
24287. pulling the skirt straight and shifting the pins from one side of her
24288. mouth to the other with her tongue.
24289. 
24290. "Say what you like," exclaimed Sonya, in a despairing voice as she
24291. looked at Natasha, "say what you like, it's still too long."
24292. 
24293. Natasha stepped back to look at herself in the pier glass. The dress was
24294. too long.
24295. 
24296. "Really, madam, it is not at all too long," said Mavra, crawling on her
24297. knees after her young lady.
24298. 
24299. "Well, if it's too long we'll take it up... we'll tack it up in one
24300. minute," said the resolute Dunyasha taking a needle that was stuck on
24301. the front of her little shawl and, still kneeling on the floor, set to
24302. work once more.
24303. 
24304. At that moment, with soft steps, the countess came in shyly, in her cap
24305. and velvet gown.
24306. 
24307. "Oo-oo, my beauty!" exclaimed the count, "she looks better than any of
24308. you!"
24309. 
24310. He would have embraced her but, blushing, she stepped aside fearing to
24311. be rumpled.
24312. 
24313. "Mamma, your cap, more to this side," said Natasha. "I'll arrange it,"
24314. and she rushed forward so that the maids who were tacking up her skirt
24315. could not move fast enough and a piece of gauze was torn off.
24316. 
24317. "Oh goodness! What has happened? Really it was not my fault!"
24318. 
24319. "Never mind, I'll run it up, it won't show," said Dunyasha.
24320. 
24321. "What a beauty--a very queen!" said the nurse as she came to the door.
24322. "And Sonya! They are lovely!"
24323. 
24324. At a quarter past ten they at last got into their carriages and started.
24325. But they had still to call at the Taurida Gardens.
24326. 
24327. Peronskaya was quite ready. In spite of her age and plainness she had
24328. gone through the same process as the Rostovs, but with less flurry--for
24329. to her it was a matter of routine. Her ugly old body was washed,
24330. perfumed, and powdered in just the same way. She had washed behind her
24331. ears just as carefully, and when she entered her drawing room in her
24332. yellow dress, wearing her badge as maid of honor, her old lady's maid
24333. was as full of rapturous admiration as the Rostovs' servants had been.
24334. 
24335. She praised the Rostovs' toilets. They praised her taste and toilet, and
24336. at eleven o'clock, careful of their coiffures and dresses, they settled
24337. themselves in their carriages and drove off.
24338. 
24339. 
24340. 
24341. 
24342. 
24343. CHAPTER XV
24344. 
24345. 
24346. Natasha had not had a moment free since early morning and had not once
24347. had time to think of what lay before her.
24348. 
24349. In the damp chill air and crowded closeness of the swaying carriage, she
24350. for the first time vividly imagined what was in store for her there at
24351. the ball, in those brightly lighted rooms--with music, flowers, dances,
24352. the Emperor, and all the brilliant young people of Petersburg. The
24353. prospect was so splendid that she hardly believed it would come true,
24354. so out of keeping was it with the chill darkness and closeness of the
24355. carriage. She understood all that awaited her only when, after stepping
24356. over the red baize at the entrance, she entered the hall, took off her
24357. fur cloak, and, beside Sonya and in front of her mother, mounted the
24358. brightly illuminated stairs between the flowers. Only then did she
24359. remember how she must behave at a ball, and tried to assume the majestic
24360. air she considered indispensable for a girl on such an occasion. But,
24361. fortunately for her, she felt her eyes growing misty, she saw nothing
24362. clearly, her pulse beat a hundred to the minute, and the blood throbbed
24363. at her heart. She could not assume that pose, which would have made her
24364. ridiculous, and she moved on almost fainting from excitement and trying
24365. with all her might to conceal it. And this was the very attitude that
24366. became her best. Before and behind them other visitors were entering,
24367. also talking in low tones and wearing ball dresses. The mirrors on the
24368. landing reflected ladies in white, pale-blue, and pink dresses, with
24369. diamonds and pearls on their bare necks and arms.
24370. 
24371. Natasha looked in the mirrors and could not distinguish her reflection
24372. from the others. All was blended into one brilliant procession.
24373. On entering the ballroom the regular hum of voices, footsteps, and
24374. greetings deafened Natasha, and the light and glitter dazzled her still
24375. more. The host and hostess, who had already been standing at the door
24376. for half an hour repeating the same words to the various arrivals,
24377. "Charme de vous voir," * greeted the Rostovs and Peronskaya in the same
24378. manner.
24379. 
24380. 
24381.     * "Delighted to see you."
24382. 
24383. 
24384. The two girls in their white dresses, each with a rose in her black
24385. hair, both curtsied in the same way, but the hostess' eye involuntarily
24386. rested longer on the slim Natasha. She looked at her and gave her alone
24387. a special smile in addition to her usual smile as hostess. Looking at
24388. her she may have recalled the golden, irrecoverable days of her own
24389. girlhood and her own first ball. The host also followed Natasha with his
24390. eyes and asked the count which was his daughter.
24391. 
24392. "Charming!" said he, kissing the tips of his fingers.
24393. 
24394. In the ballroom guests stood crowding at the entrance doors awaiting
24395. the Emperor. The countess took up a position in one of the front rows of
24396. that crowd. Natasha heard and felt that several people were asking about
24397. her and looking at her. She realized that those noticing her liked her,
24398. and this observation helped to calm her.
24399. 
24400. "There are some like ourselves and some worse," she thought.
24401. 
24402. Peronskaya was pointing out to the countess the most important people at
24403. the ball.
24404. 
24405. "That is the Dutch ambassador, do you see? That gray-haired man," she
24406. said, indicating an old man with a profusion of silver-gray curly hair,
24407. who was surrounded by ladies laughing at something he said.
24408. 
24409. "Ah, here she is, the Queen of Petersburg, Countess Bezukhova," said
24410. Peronskaya, indicating Helene who had just entered. "How lovely! She
24411. is quite equal to Marya Antonovna. See how the men, young and old, pay
24412. court to her. Beautiful and clever... they say Prince--is quite mad
24413. about her. But see, those two, though not good-looking, are even more
24414. run after."
24415. 
24416. She pointed to a lady who was crossing the room followed by a very plain
24417. daughter.
24418. 
24419. "She is a splendid match, a millionairess," said Peronskaya. "And look,
24420. here come her suitors."
24421. 
24422. "That is Bezukhova's brother, Anatole Kuragin," she said, indicating a
24423. handsome officer of the Horse Guards who passed by them with head erect,
24424. looking at something over the heads of the ladies. "He's handsome,
24425. isn't he? I hear they will marry him to that rich girl. But your cousin,
24426. Drubetskoy, is also very attentive to her. They say she has millions. Oh
24427. yes, that's the French ambassador himself!" she replied to the countess'
24428. inquiry about Caulaincourt. "Looks as if he were a king! All the same,
24429. the French are charming, very charming. No one more charming in society.
24430. Ah, here she is! Yes, she is still the most beautiful of them all, our
24431. Marya Antonovna! And how simply she is dressed! Lovely! And that stout
24432. one in spectacles is the universal Freemason," she went on, indicating
24433. Pierre. "Put him beside his wife and he looks a regular buffoon!"
24434. 
24435. Pierre, swaying his stout body, advanced, making way through the crowd
24436. and nodding to right and left as casually and good-naturedly as if he
24437. were passing through a crowd at a fair. He pushed through, evidently
24438. looking for someone.
24439. 
24440. Natasha looked joyfully at the familiar face of Pierre, "the buffoon,"
24441. as Peronskaya had called him, and knew he was looking for them, and
24442. for her in particular. He had promised to be at the ball and introduce
24443. partners to her.
24444. 
24445. But before he reached them Pierre stopped beside a very handsome, dark
24446. man of middle height, and in a white uniform, who stood by a window
24447. talking to a tall man wearing stars and a ribbon. Natasha at once
24448. recognized the shorter and younger man in the white uniform: it was
24449. Bolkonski, who seemed to her to have grown much younger, happier, and
24450. better-looking.
24451. 
24452. "There's someone else we know--Bolkonski, do you see, Mamma?" said
24453. Natasha, pointing out Prince Andrew. "You remember, he stayed a night
24454. with us at Otradnoe."
24455. 
24456. "Oh, you know him?" said Peronskaya. "I can't bear him. Il fait a
24457. present la pluie et le beau temps. * He's too proud for anything. Takes
24458. after his father. And he's hand in glove with Speranski, writing some
24459. project or other. Just look how he treats the ladies! There's one
24460. talking to him and he has turned away," she said, pointing at him. "I'd
24461. give it to him if he treated me as he does those ladies."
24462. 
24463. 
24464.     * "He is all the rage just now."
24465. 
24466. 
24467. 
24468. 
24469. 
24470. CHAPTER XVI
24471. 
24472. 
24473. Suddenly everybody stirred, began talking, and pressed forward and then
24474. back, and between the two rows, which separated, the Emperor entered to
24475. the sounds of music that had immediately struck up. Behind him walked
24476. his host and hostess. He walked in rapidly, bowing to right and left
24477. as if anxious to get the first moments of the reception over. The band
24478. played the polonaise in vogue at that time on account of the words that
24479. had been set to it, beginning: "Alexander, Elisaveta, all our hearts you
24480. ravish quite..." The Emperor passed on to the drawing room, the crowd
24481. made a rush for the doors, and several persons with excited faces
24482. hurried there and back again. Then the crowd hastily retired from
24483. the drawing-room door, at which the Emperor reappeared talking to the
24484. hostess. A young man, looking distraught, pounced down on the ladies,
24485. asking them to move aside. Some ladies, with faces betraying complete
24486. forgetfulness of all the rules of decorum, pushed forward to the
24487. detriment of their toilets. The men began to choose partners and take
24488. their places for the polonaise.
24489. 
24490. Everyone moved back, and the Emperor came smiling out of the drawing
24491. room leading his hostess by the hand but not keeping time to the
24492. music. The host followed with Marya Antonovna Naryshkina; then came
24493. ambassadors, ministers, and various generals, whom Peronskaya diligently
24494. named. More than half the ladies already had partners and were taking
24495. up, or preparing to take up, their positions for the polonaise. Natasha
24496. felt that she would be left with her mother and Sonya among a minority
24497. of women who crowded near the wall, not having been invited to dance.
24498. She stood with her slender arms hanging down, her scarcely defined bosom
24499. rising and falling regularly, and with bated breath and glittering,
24500. frightened eyes gazed straight before her, evidently prepared for the
24501. height of joy or misery. She was not concerned about the Emperor or any
24502. of those great people whom Peronskaya was pointing out--she had but one
24503. thought: "Is it possible no one will ask me, that I shall not be among
24504. the first to dance? Is it possible that not one of all these men will
24505. notice me? They do not even seem to see me, or if they do they look as
24506. if they were saying, 'Ah, she's not the one I'm after, so it's not worth
24507. looking at her!' No, it's impossible," she thought. "They must know
24508. how I long to dance, how splendidly I dance, and how they would enjoy
24509. dancing with me."
24510. 
24511. The strains of the polonaise, which had continued for a considerable
24512. time, had begun to sound like a sad reminiscence to Natasha's ears. She
24513. wanted to cry. Peronskaya had left them. The count was at the other end
24514. of the room. She and the countess and Sonya were standing by themselves
24515. as in the depths of a forest amid that crowd of strangers, with no one
24516. interested in them and not wanted by anyone. Prince Andrew with a lady
24517. passed by, evidently not recognizing them. The handsome Anatole was
24518. smilingly talking to a partner on his arm and looked at Natasha as one
24519. looks at a wall. Boris passed them twice and each time turned away. Berg
24520. and his wife, who were not dancing, came up to them.
24521. 
24522. This family gathering seemed humiliating to Natasha--as if there were
24523. nowhere else for the family to talk but here at the ball. She did not
24524. listen to or look at Vera, who was telling her something about her own
24525. green dress.
24526. 
24527. At last the Emperor stopped beside his last partner (he had danced
24528. with three) and the music ceased. A worried aide-de-camp ran up to the
24529. Rostovs requesting them to stand farther back, though as it was they
24530. were already close to the wall, and from the gallery resounded the
24531. distinct, precise, enticingly rhythmical strains of a waltz. The Emperor
24532. looked smilingly down the room. A minute passed but no one had yet begun
24533. dancing. An aide-de-camp, the Master of Ceremonies, went up to Countess
24534. Bezukhova and asked her to dance. She smilingly raised her hand and laid
24535. it on his shoulder without looking at him. The aide-de-camp, an adept
24536. in his art, grasping his partner firmly round her waist, with confident
24537. deliberation started smoothly, gliding first round the edge of the
24538. circle, then at the corner of the room he caught Helene's left hand
24539. and turned her, the only sound audible, apart from the ever-quickening
24540. music, being the rhythmic click of the spurs on his rapid, agile feet,
24541. while at every third beat his partner's velvet dress spread out and
24542. seemed to flash as she whirled round. Natasha gazed at them and was
24543. ready to cry because it was not she who was dancing that first turn of
24544. the waltz.
24545. 
24546. Prince Andrew, in the white uniform of a cavalry colonel, wearing
24547. stockings and dancing shoes, stood looking animated and bright in the
24548. front row of the circle not far from the Rostovs. Baron Firhoff was
24549. talking to him about the first sitting of the Council of State to be
24550. held next day. Prince Andrew, as one closely connected with Speranski
24551. and participating in the work of the legislative commission, could give
24552. reliable information about that sitting, concerning which various rumors
24553. were current. But not listening to what Firhoff was saying, he was
24554. gazing now at the sovereign and now at the men intending to dance who
24555. had not yet gathered courage to enter the circle.
24556. 
24557. Prince Andrew was watching these men abashed by the Emperor's presence,
24558. and the women who were breathlessly longing to be asked to dance.
24559. 
24560. Pierre came up to him and caught him by the arm.
24561. 
24562. "You always dance. I have a protegee, the young Rostova, here. Ask her,"
24563. he said.
24564. 
24565. "Where is she?" asked Bolkonski. "Excuse me!" he added, turning to the
24566. baron, "we will finish this conversation elsewhere--at a ball one
24567. must dance." He stepped forward in the direction Pierre indicated. The
24568. despairing, dejected expression of Natasha's face caught his eye.
24569. He recognized her, guessed her feelings, saw that it was her debut,
24570. remembered her conversation at the window, and with an expression of
24571. pleasure on his face approached Countess Rostova.
24572. 
24573. "Allow me to introduce you to my daughter," said the countess, with
24574. heightened color.
24575. 
24576. "I have the pleasure of being already acquainted, if the countess
24577. remembers me," said Prince Andrew with a low and courteous bow quite
24578. belying Peronskaya's remarks about his rudeness, and approaching Natasha
24579. he held out his arm to grasp her waist before he had completed his
24580. invitation. He asked her to waltz. That tremulous expression on
24581. Natasha's face, prepared either for despair or rapture, suddenly
24582. brightened into a happy, grateful, childlike smile.
24583. 
24584. "I have long been waiting for you," that frightened happy little girl
24585. seemed to say by the smile that replaced the threatened tears, as she
24586. raised her hand to Prince Andrew's shoulder. They were the second couple
24587. to enter the circle. Prince Andrew was one of the best dancers of his
24588. day and Natasha danced exquisitely. Her little feet in their white satin
24589. dancing shoes did their work swiftly, lightly, and independently of
24590. herself, while her face beamed with ecstatic happiness. Her slender bare
24591. arms and neck were not beautiful--compared to Helene's her shoulders
24592. looked thin and her bosom undeveloped. But Helene seemed, as it were,
24593. hardened by a varnish left by the thousands of looks that had scanned
24594. her person, while Natasha was like a girl exposed for the first time,
24595. who would have felt very much ashamed had she not been assured that this
24596. was absolutely necessary.
24597. 
24598. Prince Andrew liked dancing, and wishing to escape as quickly as
24599. possible from the political and clever talk which everyone addressed
24600. to him, wishing also to break up the circle of restraint he disliked,
24601. caused by the Emperor's presence, he danced, and had chosen Natasha
24602. because Pierre pointed her out to him and because she was the first
24603. pretty girl who caught his eye; but scarcely had he embraced that
24604. slender supple figure and felt her stirring so close to him and smiling
24605. so near him than the wine of her charm rose to his head, and he
24606. felt himself revived and rejuvenated when after leaving her he stood
24607. breathing deeply and watching the other dancers.
24608. 
24609. 
24610. 
24611. 
24612. 
24613. CHAPTER XVII
24614. 
24615. 
24616. After Prince Andrew, Boris came up to ask Natasha for a dance, and then
24617. the aide-de-camp who had opened the ball, and several other young men,
24618. so that, flushed and happy, and passing on her superfluous partners to
24619. Sonya, she did not cease dancing all the evening. She noticed and saw
24620. nothing of what occupied everyone else. Not only did she fail to notice
24621. that the Emperor talked a long time with the French ambassador, and how
24622. particularly gracious he was to a certain lady, or that Prince So-and-so
24623. and So-and-so did and said this and that, and that Helene had great
24624. success and was honored by the special attention of So-and-so, but she
24625. did not even see the Emperor, and only noticed that he had gone because
24626. the ball became livelier after his departure. For one of the merry
24627. cotillions before supper Prince Andrew was again her partner. He
24628. reminded her of their first encounter in the Otradnoe avenue, and how
24629. she had been unable to sleep that moonlight night, and told her how he
24630. had involuntarily overheard her. Natasha blushed at that recollection
24631. and tried to excuse herself, as if there had been something to be
24632. ashamed of in what Prince Andrew had overheard.
24633. 
24634. Like all men who have grown up in society, Prince Andrew liked meeting
24635. someone there not of the conventional society stamp. And such was
24636. Natasha, with her surprise, her delight, her shyness, and even her
24637. mistakes in speaking French. With her he behaved with special care and
24638. tenderness, sitting beside her and talking of the simplest and most
24639. unimportant matters; he admired her shy grace. In the middle of the
24640. cotillion, having completed one of the figures, Natasha, still out of
24641. breath, was returning to her seat when another dancer chose her. She was
24642. tired and panting and evidently thought of declining, but immediately
24643. put her hand gaily on the man's shoulder, smiling at Prince Andrew.
24644. 
24645. "I'd be glad to sit beside you and rest: I'm tired; but you see how they
24646. keep asking me, and I'm glad of it, I'm happy and I love everybody, and
24647. you and I understand it all," and much, much more was said in her smile.
24648. When her partner left her Natasha ran across the room to choose two
24649. ladies for the figure.
24650. 
24651. "If she goes to her cousin first and then to another lady, she will be
24652. my wife," said Prince Andrew to himself quite to his own surprise, as he
24653. watched her. She did go first to her cousin.
24654. 
24655. "What rubbish sometimes enters one's head!" thought Prince Andrew, "but
24656. what is certain is that that girl is so charming, so original, that she
24657. won't be dancing here a month before she will be married.... Such as
24658. she are rare here," he thought, as Natasha, readjusting a rose that was
24659. slipping on her bodice, settled herself beside him.
24660. 
24661. When the cotillion was over the old count in his blue coat came up to
24662. the dancers. He invited Prince Andrew to come and see them, and asked
24663. his daughter whether she was enjoying herself. Natasha did not answer at
24664. once but only looked up with a smile that said reproachfully: "How can
24665. you ask such a question?"
24666. 
24667. "I have never enjoyed myself so much before!" she said, and Prince
24668. Andrew noticed how her thin arms rose quickly as if to embrace her
24669. father and instantly dropped again. Natasha was happier than she had
24670. ever been in her life. She was at that height of bliss when one becomes
24671. completely kind and good and does not believe in the possibility of
24672. evil, unhappiness, or sorrow.
24673. 
24674. At that ball Pierre for the first time felt humiliated by the position
24675. his wife occupied in court circles. He was gloomy and absent-minded. A
24676. deep furrow ran across his forehead, and standing by a window he stared
24677. over his spectacles seeing no one.
24678. 
24679. On her way to supper Natasha passed him.
24680. 
24681. Pierre's gloomy, unhappy look struck her. She stopped in front of him.
24682. She wished to help him, to bestow on him the superabundance of her own
24683. happiness.
24684. 
24685. "How delightful it is, Count!" said she. "Isn't it?"
24686. 
24687. Pierre smiled absent-mindedly, evidently not grasping what she said.
24688. 
24689. "Yes, I am very glad," he said.
24690. 
24691. "How can people be dissatisfied with anything?" thought Natasha.
24692. "Especially such a capital fellow as Bezukhov!" In Natasha's eyes all
24693. the people at the ball alike were good, kind, and splendid people,
24694. loving one another; none of them capable of injuring another--and so
24695. they ought all to be happy.
24696. 
24697. 
24698. 
24699. 
24700. 
24701. CHAPTER XVIII
24702. 
24703. 
24704. Next day Prince Andrew thought of the ball, but his mind did not dwell
24705. on it long. "Yes, it was a very brilliant ball," and then... "Yes, that
24706. little Rostova is very charming. There's something fresh, original,
24707. un-Petersburg-like about her that distinguishes her." That was all he
24708. thought about yesterday's ball, and after his morning tea he set to
24709. work.
24710. 
24711. But either from fatigue or want of sleep he was ill-disposed for work
24712. and could get nothing done. He kept criticizing his own work, as he
24713. often did, and was glad when he heard someone coming.
24714. 
24715. The visitor was Bitski, who served on various committees, frequented all
24716. the societies in Petersburg, and a passionate devotee of the new ideas
24717. and of Speranski, and a diligent Petersburg newsmonger--one of those men
24718. who choose their opinions like their clothes according to the fashion,
24719. but who for that very reason appear to be the warmest partisans. Hardly
24720. had he got rid of his hat before he ran into Prince Andrew's room with a
24721. preoccupied air and at once began talking. He had just heard particulars
24722. of that morning's sitting of the Council of State opened by the Emperor,
24723. and he spoke of it enthusiastically. The Emperor's speech had been
24724. extraordinary. It had been a speech such as only constitutional monarchs
24725. deliver. "The Sovereign plainly said that the Council and Senate are
24726. estates of the realm, he said that the government must rest not on
24727. authority but on secure bases. The Emperor said that the fiscal system
24728. must be reorganized and the accounts published," recounted Bitski,
24729. emphasizing certain words and opening his eyes significantly.
24730. 
24731. "Ah, yes! Today's events mark an epoch, the greatest epoch in our
24732. history," he concluded.
24733. 
24734. Prince Andrew listened to the account of the opening of the Council of
24735. State, which he had so impatiently awaited and to which he had attached
24736. such importance, and was surprised that this event, now that it had
24737. taken place, did not affect him, and even seemed quite insignificant. He
24738. listened with quiet irony to Bitski's enthusiastic account of it. A very
24739. simple thought occurred to him: "What does it matter to me or to Bitski
24740. what the Emperor was pleased to say at the Council? Can all that make me
24741. any happier or better?"
24742. 
24743. And this simple reflection suddenly destroyed all the interest Prince
24744. Andrew had felt in the impending reforms. He was going to dine that
24745. evening at Speranski's, "with only a few friends," as the host had said
24746. when inviting him. The prospect of that dinner in the intimate home
24747. circle of the man he so admired had greatly interested Prince
24748. Andrew, especially as he had not yet seen Speranski in his domestic
24749. surroundings, but now he felt disinclined to go to it.
24750. 
24751. At the appointed hour, however, he entered the modest house Speranski
24752. owned in the Taurida Gardens. In the parqueted dining room this small
24753. house, remarkable for its extreme cleanliness (suggesting that of a
24754. monastery), Prince Andrew, who was rather late, found the friendly
24755. gathering of Speranski's intimate acquaintances already assembled at
24756. five o'clock. There were no ladies present except Speranski's little
24757. daughter (long-faced like her father) and her governess. The other
24758. guests were Gervais, Magnitski, and Stolypin. While still in the
24759. anteroom Prince Andrew heard loud voices and a ringing staccato
24760. laugh--a laugh such as one hears on the stage. Someone--it sounded like
24761. Speranski--was distinctly ejaculating ha-ha-ha. Prince Andrew had never
24762. before heard Speranski's famous laugh, and this ringing, high pitched
24763. laughter from a statesman made a strange impression on him.
24764. 
24765. He entered the dining room. The whole company were standing between two
24766. windows at a small table laid with hors-d'oeuvres. Speranski, wearing
24767. a gray swallow-tail coat with a star on the breast, and evidently still
24768. the same waistcoat and high white stock he had worn at the meeting of
24769. the Council of State, stood at the table with a beaming countenance. His
24770. guests surrounded him. Magnitski, addressing himself to Speranski, was
24771. relating an anecdote, and Speranski was laughing in advance at what
24772. Magnitski was going to say. When Prince Andrew entered the room
24773. Magnitski's words were again crowned by laughter. Stolypin gave a deep
24774. bass guffaw as he munched a piece of bread and cheese. Gervais laughed
24775. softly with a hissing chuckle, and Speranski in a high-pitched staccato
24776. manner.
24777. 
24778. Still laughing, Speranski held out his soft white hand to Prince Andrew.
24779. 
24780. "Very pleased to see you, Prince," he said. "One moment..." he went on,
24781. turning to Magnitski and interrupting his story. "We have agreed that
24782. this is a dinner for recreation, with not a word about business!" and
24783. turning again to the narrator he began to laugh afresh.
24784. 
24785. Prince Andrew looked at the laughing Speranski with astonishment,
24786. regret, and disillusionment. It seemed to him that this was not
24787. Speranski but someone else. Everything that had formerly appeared
24788. mysterious and fascinating in Speranski suddenly became plain and
24789. unattractive.
24790. 
24791. At dinner the conversation did not cease for a moment and seemed to
24792. consist of the contents of a book of funny anecdotes. Before Magnitski
24793. had finished his story someone else was anxious to relate something
24794. still funnier. Most of the anecdotes, if not relating to the state
24795. service, related to people in the service. It seemed that in this
24796. company the insignificance of those people was so definitely accepted
24797. that the only possible attitude toward them was one of good humored
24798. ridicule. Speranski related how at the Council that morning a deaf
24799. dignitary, when asked his opinion, replied that he thought so too.
24800. Gervais gave a long account of an official revision, remarkable for the
24801. stupidity of everybody concerned. Stolypin, stuttering, broke into the
24802. conversation and began excitedly talking of the abuses that existed
24803. under the former order of things--threatening to give a serious turn
24804. to the conversation. Magnitski starting quizzing Stolypin about his
24805. vehemence. Gervais intervened with a joke, and the talk reverted to its
24806. former lively tone.
24807. 
24808. Evidently Speranski liked to rest after his labors and find amusement
24809. in a circle of friends, and his guests, understanding his wish, tried
24810. to enliven him and amuse themselves. But their gaiety seemed to Prince
24811. Andrew mirthless and tiresome. Speranski's high-pitched voice struck
24812. him unpleasantly, and the incessant laughter grated on him like a false
24813. note. Prince Andrew did not laugh and feared that he would be a damper
24814. on the spirits of the company, but no one took any notice of his being
24815. out of harmony with the general mood. They all seemed very gay.
24816. 
24817. He tried several times to join in the conversation, but his remarks were
24818. tossed aside each time like a cork thrown out of the water, and he could
24819. not jest with them.
24820. 
24821. There was nothing wrong or unseemly in what they said, it was witty and
24822. might have been funny, but it lacked just that something which is the
24823. salt of mirth, and they were not even aware that such a thing existed.
24824. 
24825. After dinner Speranski's daughter and her governess rose. He patted the
24826. little girl with his white hand and kissed her. And that gesture, too,
24827. seemed unnatural to Prince Andrew.
24828. 
24829. The men remained at table over their port--English fashion. In the midst
24830. of a conversation that was started about Napoleon's Spanish affairs,
24831. which they all agreed in approving, Prince Andrew began to express a
24832. contrary opinion. Speranski smiled and, with an evident wish to prevent
24833. the conversation from taking an unpleasant course, told a story that had
24834. no connection with the previous conversation. For a few moments all were
24835. silent.
24836. 
24837. Having sat some time at table, Speranski corked a bottle of wine and,
24838. remarking, "Nowadays good wine rides in a carriage and pair," passed it
24839. to the servant and got up. All rose and continuing to talk loudly went
24840. into the drawing room. Two letters brought by a courier were handed to
24841. Speranski and he took them to his study. As soon as he had left the room
24842. the general merriment stopped and the guests began to converse sensibly
24843. and quietly with one another.
24844. 
24845. "Now for the recitation!" said Speranski on returning from his study. "A
24846. wonderful talent!" he said to Prince Andrew, and Magnitski immediately
24847. assumed a pose and began reciting some humorous verses in French which
24848. he had composed about various well-known Petersburg people. He was
24849. interrupted several times by applause. When the verses were finished
24850. Prince Andrew went up to Speranski and took his leave.
24851. 
24852. "Where are you off to so early?" asked Speranski.
24853. 
24854. "I promised to go to a reception."
24855. 
24856. They said no more. Prince Andrew looked closely into those mirrorlike,
24857. impenetrable eyes, and felt that it had been ridiculous of him to have
24858. expected anything from Speranski and from any of his own activities
24859. connected with him, or ever to have attributed importance to what
24860. Speranski was doing. That precise, mirthless laughter rang in Prince
24861. Andrew's ears long after he had left the house.
24862. 
24863. When he reached home Prince Andrew began thinking of his life in
24864. Petersburg during those last four months as if it were something new. He
24865. recalled his exertions and solicitations, and the history of his project
24866. of army reform, which had been accepted for consideration and which they
24867. were trying to pass over in silence simply because another, a very poor
24868. one, had already been prepared and submitted to the Emperor. He thought
24869. of the meetings of a committee of which Berg was a member. He remembered
24870. how carefully and at what length everything relating to form and
24871. procedure was discussed at those meetings, and how sedulously and
24872. promptly all that related to the gist of the business was evaded. He
24873. recalled his labors on the Legal Code, and how painstakingly he had
24874. translated the articles of the Roman and French codes into Russian,
24875. and he felt ashamed of himself. Then he vividly pictured to himself
24876. Bogucharovo, his occupations in the country, his journey to Ryazan;
24877. he remembered the peasants and Dron the village elder, and mentally
24878. applying to them the Personal Rights he had divided into paragraphs, he
24879. felt astonished that he could have spent so much time on such useless
24880. work.
24881. 
24882. 
24883. 
24884. 
24885. 
24886. CHAPTER XIX
24887. 
24888. 
24889. Next day Prince Andrew called at a few houses he had not visited before,
24890. and among them at the Rostovs' with whom he had renewed acquaintance
24891. at the ball. Apart from considerations of politeness which demanded the
24892. call, he wanted to see that original, eager girl who had left such a
24893. pleasant impression on his mind, in her own home.
24894. 
24895. Natasha was one of the first to meet him. She was wearing a dark-blue
24896. house dress in which Prince Andrew thought her even prettier than in her
24897. ball dress. She and all the Rostov family welcomed him as an old friend,
24898. simply and cordially. The whole family, whom he had formerly judged
24899. severely, now seemed to him to consist of excellent, simple, and kindly
24900. people. The old count's hospitality and good nature, which struck one
24901. especially in Petersburg as a pleasant surprise, were such that Prince
24902. Andrew could not refuse to stay to dinner. "Yes," he thought, "they
24903. are capital people, who of course have not the slightest idea what a
24904. treasure they possess in Natasha; but they are kindly folk and form
24905. the best possible setting for this strikingly poetic, charming girl,
24906. overflowing with life!"
24907. 
24908. In Natasha Prince Andrew was conscious of a strange world completely
24909. alien to him and brimful of joys unknown to him, a different world,
24910. that in the Otradnoe avenue and at the window that moonlight night had
24911. already begun to disconcert him. Now this world disconcerted him no
24912. longer and was no longer alien to him, but he himself having entered it
24913. found in it a new enjoyment.
24914. 
24915. After dinner Natasha, at Prince Andrew's request, went to the clavichord
24916. and began singing. Prince Andrew stood by a window talking to the ladies
24917. and listened to her. In the midst of a phrase he ceased speaking and
24918. suddenly felt tears choking him, a thing he had thought impossible for
24919. him. He looked at Natasha as she sang, and something new and joyful
24920. stirred in his soul. He felt happy and at the same time sad. He had
24921. absolutely nothing to weep about yet he was ready to weep. What about?
24922. His former love? The little princess? His disillusionments?... His hopes
24923. for the future?... Yes and no. The chief reason was a sudden, vivid
24924. sense of the terrible contrast between something infinitely great and
24925. illimitable within him and that limited and material something that he,
24926. and even she, was. This contrast weighed on and yet cheered him while
24927. she sang.
24928. 
24929. As soon as Natasha had finished she went up to him and asked how he
24930. liked her voice. She asked this and then became confused, feeling that
24931. she ought not to have asked it. He smiled, looking at her, and said he
24932. liked her singing as he liked everything she did.
24933. 
24934. Prince Andrew left the Rostovs' late in the evening. He went to bed from
24935. habit, but soon realized that he could not sleep. Having lit his candle
24936. he sat up in bed, then got up, then lay down again not at all troubled
24937. by his sleeplessness: his soul was as fresh and joyful as if he had
24938. stepped out of a stuffy room into God's own fresh air. It did not enter
24939. his head that he was in love with Natasha; he was not thinking about
24940. her, but only picturing her to himself, and in consequence all life
24941. appeared in a new light. "Why do I strive, why do I toil in this narrow,
24942. confined frame, when life, all life with all its joys, is open to me?"
24943. said he to himself. And for the first time for a very long while he
24944. began making happy plans for the future. He decided that he must attend
24945. to his son's education by finding a tutor and putting the boy in his
24946. charge, then he ought to retire from the service and go abroad, and see
24947. England, Switzerland and Italy. "I must use my freedom while I feel so
24948. much strength and youth in me," he said to himself. "Pierre was right
24949. when he said one must believe in the possibility of happiness in order
24950. to be happy, and now I do believe in it. Let the dead bury their dead,
24951. but while one has life one must live and be happy!" thought he.
24952. 
24953. 
24954. 
24955. 
24956. 
24957. CHAPTER XX
24958. 
24959. 
24960. One morning Colonel Berg, whom Pierre knew as he knew everybody in
24961. Moscow and Petersburg, came to see him. Berg arrived in an immaculate
24962. brand-new uniform, with his hair pomaded and brushed forward over his
24963. temples as the Emperor Alexander wore his hair.
24964. 
24965. "I have just been to see the countess, your wife. Unfortunately she
24966. could not grant my request, but I hope, Count, I shall be more fortunate
24967. with you," he said with a smile.
24968. 
24969. "What is it you wish, Colonel? I am at your service."
24970. 
24971. "I have now quite settled in my new rooms, Count" (Berg said this with
24972. perfect conviction that this information could not but be agreeable),
24973. "and so I wish to arrange just a small party for my own and my wife's
24974. friends." (He smiled still more pleasantly.) "I wished to ask the
24975. countess and you to do me the honor of coming to tea and to supper."
24976. 
24977. Only Countess Helene, considering the society of such people as the
24978. Bergs beneath her, could be cruel enough to refuse such an invitation.
24979. Berg explained so clearly why he wanted to collect at his house a small
24980. but select company, and why this would give him pleasure, and why though
24981. he grudged spending money on cards or anything harmful, he was prepared
24982. to run into some expense for the sake of good society--that Pierre could
24983. not refuse, and promised to come.
24984. 
24985. "But don't be late, Count, if I may venture to ask; about ten minutes to
24986. eight, please. We shall make up a rubber. Our general is coming. He
24987. is very good to me. We shall have supper, Count. So you will do me the
24988. favor."
24989. 
24990. Contrary to his habit of being late, Pierre on that day arrived at the
24991. Bergs' house, not at ten but at fifteen minutes to eight.
24992. 
24993. Having prepared everything necessary for the party, the Bergs were ready
24994. for their guests' arrival.
24995. 
24996. In their new, clean, and light study with its small busts and pictures
24997. and new furniture sat Berg and his wife. Berg, closely buttoned up in
24998. his new uniform, sat beside his wife explaining to her that one always
24999. could and should be acquainted with people above one, because only then
25000. does one get satisfaction from acquaintances.
25001. 
25002. "You can get to know something, you can ask for something. See how I
25003. managed from my first promotion." (Berg measured his life not by years
25004. but by promotions.) "My comrades are still nobodies, while I am only
25005. waiting for a vacancy to command a regiment, and have the happiness to
25006. be your husband." (He rose and kissed Vera's hand, and on the way to
25007. her straightened out a turned-up corner of the carpet.) "And how have I
25008. obtained all this? Chiefly by knowing how to choose my aquaintances. It
25009. goes without saying that one must be conscientious and methodical."
25010. 
25011. Berg smiled with a sense of his superiority over a weak woman, and
25012. paused, reflecting that this dear wife of his was after all but a weak
25013. woman who could not understand all that constitutes a man's dignity,
25014. what it was ein Mann zu sein. * Vera at the same time smiling with a
25015. sense of superiority over her good, conscientious husband, who all the
25016. same understood life wrongly, as according to Vera all men did. Berg,
25017. judging by his wife, thought all women weak and foolish. Vera, judging
25018. only by her husband and generalizing from that observation, supposed
25019. that all men, though they understand nothing and are conceited and
25020. selfish, ascribe common sense to themselves alone.
25021. 
25022. 
25023.     * To be a man.
25024. 
25025. 
25026. Berg rose and embraced his wife carefully, so as not to crush her lace
25027. fichu for which he had paid a good price, kissing her straight on the
25028. lips.
25029. 
25030. "The only thing is, we mustn't have children too soon," he continued,
25031. following an unconscious sequence of ideas.
25032. 
25033. "Yes," answered Vera, "I don't at all want that. We must live for
25034. society."
25035. 
25036. "Princess Yusupova wore one exactly like this," said Berg, pointing to
25037. the fichu with a happy and kindly smile.
25038. 
25039. Just then Count Bezukhov was announced. Husband and wife glanced at one
25040. another, both smiling with self-satisfaction, and each mentally claiming
25041. the honor of this visit.
25042. 
25043. "This is what comes of knowing how to make acquaintances," thought Berg.
25044. "This is what comes of knowing how to conduct oneself."
25045. 
25046. "But please don't interrupt me when I am entertaining the guests," said
25047. Vera, "because I know what interests each of them and what to say to
25048. different people."
25049. 
25050. Berg smiled again.
25051. 
25052. "It can't be helped: men must sometimes have masculine conversation,"
25053. said he.
25054. 
25055. They received Pierre in their small, new drawing-room, where it was
25056. impossible to sit down anywhere without disturbing its symmetry,
25057. neatness, and order; so it was quite comprehensible and not strange that
25058. Berg, having generously offered to disturb the symmetry of an armchair
25059. or of the sofa for his dear guest, but being apparently painfully
25060. undecided on the matter himself, eventually left the visitor to settle
25061. the question of selection. Pierre disturbed the symmetry by moving a
25062. chair for himself, and Berg and Vera immediately began their evening
25063. party, interrupting each other in their efforts to entertain their
25064. guest.
25065. 
25066. Vera, having decided in her own mind that Pierre ought to be entertained
25067. with conversation about the French embassy, at once began accordingly.
25068. Berg, having decided that masculine conversation was required,
25069. interrupted his wife's remarks and touched on the question of the war
25070. with Austria, and unconsciously jumped from the general subject to
25071. personal considerations as to the proposals made him to take part in the
25072. Austrian campaign and the reasons why he had declined them. Though the
25073. conversation was very incoherent and Vera was angry at the intrusion
25074. of the masculine element, both husband and wife felt with satisfaction
25075. that, even if only one guest was present, their evening had begun very
25076. well and was as like as two peas to every other evening party with its
25077. talk, tea, and lighted candles.
25078. 
25079. Before long Boris, Berg's old comrade, arrived. There was a shade of
25080. condescension and patronage in his treatment of Berg and Vera. After
25081. Boris came a lady with the colonel, then the general himself, then the
25082. Rostovs, and the party became unquestionably exactly like all other
25083. evening parties. Berg and Vera could not repress their smiles of
25084. satisfaction at the sight of all this movement in their drawing room,
25085. at the sound of the disconnected talk, the rustling of dresses, and the
25086. bowing and scraping. Everything was just as everybody always has it,
25087. especially so the general, who admired the apartment, patted Berg on the
25088. shoulder, and with parental authority superintended the setting out of
25089. the table for boston. The general sat down by Count Ilya Rostov, who was
25090. next to himself the most important guest. The old people sat with the
25091. old, the young with the young, and the hostess at the tea table, on
25092. which stood exactly the same kind of cakes in a silver cake basket as
25093. the Panins had at their party. Everything was just as it was everywhere
25094. else.
25095. 
25096. 
25097. 
25098. 
25099. 
25100. CHAPTER XXI
25101. 
25102. 
25103. Pierre, as one of the principal guests, had to sit down to boston
25104. with Count Rostov, the general, and the colonel. At the card table he
25105. happened to be directly facing Natasha, and was struck by a curious
25106. change that had come over her since the ball. She was silent, and not
25107. only less pretty than at the ball, but only redeemed from plainness by
25108. her look of gentle indifference to everything around.
25109. 
25110. "What's the matter with her?" thought Pierre, glancing at her. She was
25111. sitting by her sister at the tea table, and reluctantly, without looking
25112. at him, made some reply to Boris who sat down beside her. After playing
25113. out a whole suit and to his partner's delight taking five tricks,
25114. Pierre, hearing greetings and the steps of someone who had entered the
25115. room while he was picking up his tricks, glanced again at Natasha.
25116. 
25117. "What has happened to her?" he asked himself with still greater
25118. surprise.
25119. 
25120. Prince Andrew was standing before her, saying something to her with a
25121. look of tender solicitude. She, having raised her head, was looking up
25122. at him, flushed and evidently trying to master her rapid breathing. And
25123. the bright glow of some inner fire that had been suppressed was again
25124. alight in her. She was completely transformed and from a plain girl had
25125. again become what she had been at the ball.
25126. 
25127. Prince Andrew went up to Pierre, and the latter noticed a new and
25128. youthful expression in his friend's face.
25129. 
25130. Pierre changed places several times during the game, sitting now with
25131. his back to Natasha and now facing her, but during the whole of the six
25132. rubbers he watched her and his friend.
25133. 
25134. "Something very important is happening between them," thought Pierre,
25135. and a feeling that was both joyful and painful agitated him and made him
25136. neglect the game.
25137. 
25138. After six rubbers the general got up, saying that it was no use playing
25139. like that, and Pierre was released. Natasha on one side was talking with
25140. Sonya and Boris, and Vera with a subtle smile was saying something to
25141. Prince Andrew. Pierre went up to his friend and, asking whether they
25142. were talking secrets, sat down beside them. Vera, having noticed Prince
25143. Andrew's attentions to Natasha, decided that at a party, a real evening
25144. party, subtle allusions to the tender passion were absolutely necessary
25145. and, seizing a moment when Prince Andrew was alone, began a conversation
25146. with him about feelings in general and about her sister. With so
25147. intellectual a guest as she considered Prince Andrew to be, she felt
25148. that she had to employ her diplomatic tact.
25149. 
25150. When Pierre went up to them he noticed that Vera was being carried away
25151. by her self-satisfied talk, but that Prince Andrew seemed embarrassed, a
25152. thing that rarely happened with him.
25153. 
25154. "What do you think?" Vera was saying with an arch smile. "You are so
25155. discerning, Prince, and understand people's characters so well at a
25156. glance. What do you think of Natalie? Could she be constant in her
25157. attachments? Could she, like other women" (Vera meant herself), "love a
25158. man once for all and remain true to him forever? That is what I consider
25159. true love. What do you think, Prince?"
25160. 
25161. "I know your sister too little," replied Prince Andrew, with a sarcastic
25162. smile under which he wished to hide his embarrassment, "to be able to
25163. solve so delicate a question, and then I have noticed that the less
25164. attractive a woman is the more constant she is likely to be," he added,
25165. and looked up at Pierre who was just approaching them.
25166. 
25167. "Yes, that is true, Prince. In our days," continued Vera--mentioning
25168. "our days" as people of limited intelligence are fond of doing,
25169. imagining that they have discovered and appraised the peculiarities of
25170. "our days" and that human characteristics change with the times--"in our
25171. days a girl has so much freedom that the pleasure of being courted often
25172. stifles real feeling in her. And it must be confessed that Natalie is
25173. very susceptible." This return to the subject of Natalie caused Prince
25174. Andrew to knit his brows with discomfort: he was about to rise, but Vera
25175. continued with a still more subtle smile:
25176. 
25177. "I think no one has been more courted than she," she went on, "but till
25178. quite lately she never cared seriously for anyone. Now you know, Count,"
25179. she said to Pierre, "even our dear cousin Boris, who, between ourselves,
25180. was very far gone in the land of tenderness..." (alluding to a map of
25181. love much in vogue at that time).
25182. 
25183. Prince Andrew frowned and remained silent.
25184. 
25185. "You are friendly with Boris, aren't you?" asked Vera.
25186. 
25187. "Yes, I know him..."
25188. 
25189. "I expect he has told you of his childish love for Natasha?"
25190. 
25191. "Oh, there was childish love?" suddenly asked Prince Andrew, blushing
25192. unexpectedly.
25193. 
25194. "Yes, you know between cousins intimacy often leads to love. Le
25195. cousinage est un dangereux voisinage. * Don't you think so?"
25196. 
25197. 
25198.     * "Cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood."
25199. 
25200. 
25201. "Oh, undoubtedly!" said Prince Andrew, and with sudden and unnatural
25202. liveliness he began chaffing Pierre about the need to be very careful
25203. with his fifty-year-old Moscow cousins, and in the midst of these
25204. jesting remarks he rose, taking Pierre by the arm, and drew him aside.
25205. 
25206. "Well?" asked Pierre, seeing his friend's strange animation with
25207. surprise, and noticing the glance he turned on Natasha as he rose.
25208. 
25209. "I must... I must have a talk with you," said Prince Andrew. "You know
25210. that pair of women's gloves?" (He referred to the Masonic gloves given
25211. to a newly initiated Brother to present to the woman he loved.) "I...
25212. but no, I will talk to you later on," and with a strange light in his
25213. eyes and restlessness in his movements, Prince Andrew approached
25214. Natasha and sat down beside her. Pierre saw how Prince Andrew asked her
25215. something and how she flushed as she replied.
25216. 
25217. But at that moment Berg came to Pierre and began insisting that he
25218. should take part in an argument between the general and the colonel on
25219. the affairs in Spain.
25220. 
25221. Berg was satisfied and happy. The smile of pleasure never left his face.
25222. The party was very successful and quite like other parties he had seen.
25223. Everything was similar: the ladies' subtle talk, the cards, the general
25224. raising his voice at the card table, and the samovar and the tea cakes;
25225. only one thing was lacking that he had always seen at the evening
25226. parties he wished to imitate. They had not yet had a loud conversation
25227. among the men and a dispute about something important and clever. Now
25228. the general had begun such a discussion and so Berg drew Pierre to it.
25229. 
25230. 
25231. 
25232. 
25233. 
25234. CHAPTER XXII
25235. 
25236. 
25237. Next day, having been invited by the count, Prince Andrew dined with the
25238. Rostovs and spent the rest of the day there.
25239. 
25240. Everyone in the house realized for whose sake Prince Andrew came, and
25241. without concealing it he tried to be with Natasha all day. Not only in
25242. the soul of the frightened yet happy and enraptured Natasha, but in the
25243. whole house, there was a feeling of awe at something important that was
25244. bound to happen. The countess looked with sad and sternly serious eyes
25245. at Prince Andrew when he talked to Natasha and timidly started some
25246. artificial conversation about trifles as soon as he looked her way.
25247. Sonya was afraid to leave Natasha and afraid of being in the way when
25248. she was with them. Natasha grew pale, in a panic of expectation, when
25249. she remained alone with him for a moment. Prince Andrew surprised her by
25250. his timidity. She felt that he wanted to say something to her but could
25251. not bring himself to do so.
25252. 
25253. In the evening, when Prince Andrew had left, the countess went up to
25254. Natasha and whispered: "Well, what?"
25255. 
25256. "Mamma! For heaven's sake don't ask me anything now! One can't talk
25257. about that," said Natasha.
25258. 
25259. But all the same that night Natasha, now agitated and now frightened,
25260. lay a long time in her mother's bed gazing straight before her. She told
25261. her how he had complimented her, how he told her he was going abroad,
25262. asked her where they were going to spend the summer, and then how he had
25263. asked her about Boris.
25264. 
25265. "But such a... such a... never happened to me before!" she said. "Only I
25266. feel afraid in his presence. I am always afraid when I'm with him. What
25267. does that mean? Does it mean that it's the real thing? Yes? Mamma, are
25268. you asleep?"
25269. 
25270. "No, my love; I am frightened myself," answered her mother. "Now go!"
25271. 
25272. "All the same I shan't sleep. What silliness, to sleep! Mummy! Mummy!
25273. such a thing never happened to me before," she said, surprised and
25274. alarmed at the feeling she was aware of in herself. "And could we ever
25275. have thought!..."
25276. 
25277. It seemed to Natasha that even at the time she first saw Prince Andrew
25278. at Otradnoe she had fallen in love with him. It was as if she feared
25279. this strange, unexpected happiness of meeting again the very man she had
25280. then chosen (she was firmly convinced she had done so) and of finding
25281. him, as it seemed, not indifferent to her.
25282. 
25283. "And it had to happen that he should come specially to Petersburg while

25285. It is fate. Clearly it is fate that everything led up to this! Already
25286. then, directly I saw him I felt something peculiar."
25287. 
25288. "What else did he say to you? What are those verses? Read them..." said
25289. her mother, thoughtfully, referring to some verses Prince Andrew had
25290. written in Natasha's album.
25291. 
25292. "Mamma, one need not be ashamed of his being a widower?"
25293. 
25294. "Don't, Natasha! Pray to God. 'Marriages are made in heaven,'" said her
25295. mother.
25296. 
25297. "Darling Mummy, how I love you! How happy I am!" cried Natasha, shedding
25298. tears of joy and excitement and embracing her mother.
25299. 
25300. At that very time Prince Andrew was sitting with Pierre and telling him
25301. of his love for Natasha and his firm resolve to make her his wife.
25302. 
25303. That day Countess Helene had a reception at her house. The French
25304. ambassador was there, and a foreign prince of the blood who had of
25305. late become a frequent visitor of hers, and many brilliant ladies and
25306. gentlemen. Pierre, who had come downstairs, walked through the rooms and
25307. struck everyone by his preoccupied, absent-minded, and morose air.
25308. 
25309. Since the ball he had felt the approach of a fit of nervous depression
25310. and had made desperate efforts to combat it. Since the intimacy of
25311. his wife with the royal prince, Pierre had unexpectedly been made a
25312. gentleman of the bedchamber, and from that time he had begun to feel
25313. oppressed and ashamed in court society, and dark thoughts of the vanity
25314. of all things human came to him oftener than before. At the same time
25315. the feeling he had noticed between his protegee Natasha and Prince
25316. Andrew accentuated his gloom by the contrast between his own position
25317. and his friend's. He tried equally to avoid thinking about his wife,
25318. and about Natasha and Prince Andrew; and again everything seemed to him
25319. insignificant in comparison with eternity; again the question: for what?
25320. presented itself; and he forced himself to work day and night at Masonic
25321. labors, hoping to drive away the evil spirit that threatened him. Toward
25322. midnight, after he had left the countess' apartments, he was sitting
25323. upstairs in a shabby dressing gown, copying out the original transaction
25324. of the Scottish lodge of Freemasons at a table in his low room cloudy
25325. with tobacco smoke, when someone came in. It was Prince Andrew.
25326. 
25327. "Ah, it's you!" said Pierre with a preoccupied, dissatisfied air. "And
25328. I, you see, am hard at it." He pointed to his manuscript book with that
25329. air of escaping from the ills of life with which unhappy people look at
25330. their work.
25331. 
25332. Prince Andrew, with a beaming, ecstatic expression of renewed life on
25333. his face, paused in front of Pierre and, not noticing his sad look,
25334. smiled at him with the egotism of joy.
25335. 
25336. "Well, dear heart," said he, "I wanted to tell you about it yesterday
25337. and I have come to do so today. I never experienced anything like it
25338. before. I am in love, my friend!"
25339. 
25340. Suddenly Pierre heaved a deep sigh and dumped his heavy person down on
25341. the sofa beside Prince Andrew.
25342. 
25343. "With Natasha Rostova, yes?" said he.
25344. 
25345. "Yes, yes! Who else should it be? I should never have believed it,
25346. but the feeling is stronger than I. Yesterday I tormented myself and
25347. suffered, but I would not exchange even that torment for anything in
25348. the world, I have not lived till now. At last I live, but I can't live
25349. without her! But can she love me?... I am too old for her.... Why don't
25350. you speak?"
25351. 
25352. "I? I? What did I tell you?" said Pierre suddenly, rising and beginning
25353. to pace up and down the room. "I always thought it.... That girl is
25354. such a treasure... she is a rare girl.... My dear friend, I entreat you,
25355. don't philosophize, don't doubt, marry, marry, marry.... And I am sure
25356. there will not be a happier man than you."
25357. 
25358. "But what of her?"
25359. 
25360. "She loves you."
25361. 
25362. "Don't talk rubbish..." said Prince Andrew, smiling and looking into
25363. Pierre's eyes.
25364. 
25365. "She does, I know," Pierre cried fiercely.
25366. 
25367. "But do listen," returned Prince Andrew, holding him by the arm. "Do you
25368. know the condition I am in? I must talk about it to someone."
25369. 
25370. "Well, go on, go on. I am very glad," said Pierre, and his face really
25371. changed, his brow became smooth, and he listened gladly to Prince
25372. Andrew. Prince Andrew seemed, and really was, quite a different, quite
25373. a new man. Where was his spleen, his contempt for life, his
25374. disillusionment? Pierre was the only person to whom he made up his mind
25375. to speak openly; and to him he told all that was in his soul. Now he
25376. boldly and lightly made plans for an extended future, said he could not
25377. sacrifice his own happiness to his father's caprice, and spoke of how he
25378. would either make his father consent to this marriage and love her, or
25379. would do without his consent; then he marveled at the feeling that had
25380. mastered him as at something strange, apart from and independent of
25381. himself.
25382. 
25383. "I should not have believed anyone who told me that I was capable of
25384. such love," said Prince Andrew. "It is not at all the same feeling
25385. that I knew in the past. The whole world is now for me divided into two
25386. halves: one half is she, and there all is joy, hope, light: the
25387. other half is everything where she is not, and there is all gloom and
25388. darkness...."
25389. 
25390. "Darkness and gloom," reiterated Pierre: "yes, yes, I understand that."
25391. 
25392. "I cannot help loving the light, it is not my fault. And I am very
25393. happy! You understand me? I know you are glad for my sake."
25394. 
25395. "Yes, yes," Pierre assented, looking at his friend with a touched and
25396. sad expression in his eyes. The brighter Prince Andrew's lot appeared to
25397. him, the gloomier seemed his own.
25398. 
25399. 
25400. 
25401. 
25402. 
25403. CHAPTER XXIII
25404. 
25405. 
25406. Prince Andrew needed his father's consent to his marriage, and to obtain
25407. this he started for the country next day.
25408. 
25409. His father received his son's communication with external composure, but
25410. inward wrath. He could not comprehend how anyone could wish to alter his
25411. life or introduce anything new into it, when his own life was already
25412. ending. "If only they would let me end my days as I want to," thought
25413. the old man, "then they might do as they please." With his son, however,
25414. he employed the diplomacy he reserved for important occasions and,
25415. adopting a quiet tone, discussed the whole matter.
25416. 
25417. In the first place the marriage was not a brilliant one as regards
25418. birth, wealth, or rank. Secondly, Prince Andrew was no longer as young
25419. as he had been and his health was poor (the old man laid special stress
25420. on this), while she was very young. Thirdly, he had a son whom it would
25421. be a pity to entrust to a chit of a girl. "Fourthly and finally," the
25422. father said, looking ironically at his son, "I beg you to put it off for
25423. a year: go abroad, take a cure, look out as you wanted to for a German
25424. tutor for Prince Nicholas. Then if your love or passion or obstinacy--as
25425. you please--is still as great, marry! And that's my last word on it.
25426. Mind, the last..." concluded the prince, in a tone which showed that
25427. nothing would make him alter his decision.
25428. 
25429. Prince Andrew saw clearly that the old man hoped that his feelings, or
25430. his fiancee's, would not stand a year's test, or that he (the old
25431. prince himself) would die before then, and he decided to conform to his
25432. father's wish--to propose, and postpone the wedding for a year.
25433. 
25434. Three weeks after the last evening he had spent with the Rostovs, Prince
25435. Andrew returned to Petersburg.
25436. 
25437. 
25438. Next day after her talk with her mother Natasha expected Bolkonski all
25439. day, but he did not come. On the second and third day it was the same.
25440. Pierre did not come either and Natasha, not knowing that Prince Andrew
25441. had gone to see his father, could not explain his absence to herself.
25442. 
25443. Three weeks passed in this way. Natasha had no desire to go out anywhere
25444. and wandered from room to room like a shadow, idle and listless; she
25445. wept secretly at night and did not go to her mother in the evenings. She
25446. blushed continually and was irritable. It seemed to her that everybody
25447. knew about her disappointment and was laughing at her and pitying her.
25448. Strong as was her inward grief, this wound to her vanity intensified her
25449. misery.
25450. 
25451. Once she came to her mother, tried to say something, and suddenly began
25452. to cry. Her tears were those of an offended child who does not know why
25453. it is being punished.
25454. 
25455. The countess began to soothe Natasha, who after first listening to her
25456. mother's words, suddenly interrupted her:
25457. 
25458. "Leave off, Mamma! I don't think, and don't want to think about it! He
25459. just came and then left off, left off..."
25460. 
25461. Her voice trembled, and she again nearly cried, but recovered and went
25462. on quietly:
25463. 
25464. "And I don't at all want to get married. And I am afraid of him; I have
25465. now become quite calm, quite calm."
25466. 
25467. The day after this conversation Natasha put on the old dress which
25468. she knew had the peculiar property of conducing to cheerfulness in the
25469. mornings, and that day she returned to the old way of life which she had
25470. abandoned since the ball. Having finished her morning tea she went to
25471. the ballroom, which she particularly liked for its loud resonance, and
25472. began singing her solfeggio. When she had finished her first exercise
25473. she stood still in the middle of the room and sang a musical phrase that
