25474. particularly pleased her. She listened joyfully (as though she had not
25475. expected it) to the charm of the notes reverberating, filling the
25476. whole empty ballroom, and slowly dying away; and all at once she felt
25477. cheerful. "What's the good of making so much of it? Things are nice as
25478. it is," she said to herself, and she began walking up and down the room,
25479. not stepping simply on the resounding parquet but treading with each
25480. step from the heel to the toe (she had on a new and favorite pair of
25481. shoes) and listening to the regular tap of the heel and creak of the toe
25482. as gladly as she had to the sounds of her own voice. Passing a mirror
25483. she glanced into it. "There, that's me!" the expression of her face
25484. seemed to say as she caught sight of herself. "Well, and very nice too!
25485. I need nobody."
25486. 
25487. A footman wanted to come in to clear away something in the room but she
25488. would not let him, and having closed the door behind him continued her
25489. walk. That morning she had returned to her favorite mood--love of, and
25490. delight in, herself. "How charming that Natasha is!" she said again,
25491. speaking as some third, collective, male person. "Pretty, a good voice,
25492. young, and in nobody's way if only they leave her in peace." But
25493. however much they left her in peace she could not now be at peace, and
25494. immediately felt this.
25495. 
25496. In the hall the porch door opened, and someone asked, "At home?" and
25497. then footsteps were heard. Natasha was looking at the mirror, but did
25498. not see herself. She listened to the sounds in the hall. When she saw
25499. herself, her face was pale. It was he. She knew this for certain, though
25500. she hardly heard his voice through the closed doors.
25501. 
25502. Pale and agitated, Natasha ran into the drawing room.
25503. 
25504. "Mamma! Bolkonski has come!" she said. "Mamma, it is awful, it is
25505. unbearable! I don't want... to be tormented? What am I to do?..."
25506. 
25507. Before the countess could answer, Prince Andrew entered the room with
25508. an agitated and serious face. As soon as he saw Natasha his face
25509. brightened. He kissed the countess' hand and Natasha's, and sat down
25510. beside the sofa.
25511. 
25512. "It is long since we had the pleasure..." began the countess, but Prince
25513. Andrew interrupted her by answering her intended question, obviously in
25514. haste to say what he had to.
25515. 
25516. "I have not been to see you all this time because I have been at my
25517. father's. I had to talk over a very important matter with him. I only
25518. got back last night," he said glancing at Natasha; "I want to have a
25519. talk with you, Countess," he added after a moment's pause.
25520. 
25521. The countess lowered her eyes, sighing deeply.
25522. 
25523. "I am at your disposal," she murmured.
25524. 
25525. Natasha knew that she ought to go away, but was unable to do so:
25526. something gripped her throat, and regardless of manners she stared
25527. straight at Prince Andrew with wide-open eyes.
25528. 
25529. "At once? This instant!... No, it can't be!" she thought.
25530. 
25531. Again he glanced at her, and that glance convinced her that she was not
25532. mistaken. Yes, at once, that very instant, her fate would be decided.
25533. 
25534. "Go, Natasha! I will call you," said the countess in a whisper.
25535. 
25536. Natasha glanced with frightened imploring eyes at Prince Andrew and at
25537. her mother and went out.
25538. 
25539. "I have come, Countess, to ask for your daughter's hand," said Prince
25540. Andrew.
25541. 
25542. The countess' face flushed hotly, but she said nothing.
25543. 
25544. "Your offer..." she began at last sedately. He remained silent, looking
25545. into her eyes. "Your offer..." (she grew confused) "is agreeable to us,
25546. and I accept your offer. I am glad. And my husband... I hope... but it
25547. will depend on her...."
25548. 
25549. "I will speak to her when I have your consent.... Do you give it to me?"
25550. said Prince Andrew.
25551. 
25552. "Yes," replied the countess. She held out her hand to him, and with a
25553. mixed feeling of estrangement and tenderness pressed her lips to his
25554. forehead as he stooped to kiss her hand. She wished to love him as a
25555. son, but felt that to her he was a stranger and a terrifying man. "I am
25556. sure my husband will consent," said the countess, "but your father..."
25557. 
25558. "My father, to whom I have told my plans, has made it an express
25559. condition of his consent that the wedding is not to take place for a
25560. year. And I wished to tell you of that," said Prince Andrew.
25561. 
25562. "It is true that Natasha is still young, but--so long as that?..."
25563. 
25564. "It is unavoidable," said Prince Andrew with a sigh.
25565. 
25566. "I will send her to you," said the countess, and left the room.
25567. 
25568. "Lord have mercy upon us!" she repeated while seeking her daughter.
25569. 
25570. Sonya said that Natasha was in her bedroom. Natasha was sitting on
25571. the bed, pale and dry eyed, and was gazing at the icons and whispering
25572. something as she rapidly crossed herself. Seeing her mother she jumped
25573. up and flew to her.
25574. 
25575. "Well, Mamma?... Well?..."
25576. 
25577. "Go, go to him. He is asking for your hand," said the countess,
25578. coldly it seemed to Natasha. "Go... go," said the mother, sadly and
25579. reproachfully, with a deep sigh, as her daughter ran away.
25580. 
25581. Natasha never remembered how she entered the drawing room. When she came
25582. in and saw him she paused. "Is it possible that this stranger has now
25583. become everything to me?" she asked herself, and immediately answered,
25584. "Yes, everything! He alone is now dearer to me than everything in the
25585. world." Prince Andrew came up to her with downcast eyes.
25586. 
25587. "I have loved you from the very first moment I saw you. May I hope?"
25588. 
25589. He looked at her and was struck by the serious impassioned expression of
25590. her face. Her face said: "Why ask? Why doubt what you cannot but know?
25591. Why speak, when words cannot express what one feels?"
25592. 
25593. She drew near to him and stopped. He took her hand and kissed it.
25594. 
25595. "Do you love me?"
25596. 
25597. "Yes, yes!" Natasha murmured as if in vexation. Then she sighed loudly
25598. and, catching her breath more and more quickly, began to sob.
25599. 
25600. "What is it? What's the matter?"
25601. 
25602. "Oh, I am so happy!" she replied, smiled through her tears, bent over
25603. closer to him, paused for an instant as if asking herself whether she
25604. might, and then kissed him.
25605. 
25606. Prince Andrew held her hands, looked into her eyes, and did not find
25607. in his heart his former love for her. Something in him had suddenly
25608. changed; there was no longer the former poetic and mystic charm of
25609. desire, but there was pity for her feminine and childish weakness, fear
25610. at her devotion and trustfulness, and an oppressive yet joyful sense of
25611. the duty that now bound him to her forever. The present feeling, though
25612. not so bright and poetic as the former, was stronger and more serious.
25613. 
25614. "Did your mother tell you that it cannot be for a year?" asked Prince
25615. Andrew, still looking into her eyes.
25616. 
25617. "Is it possible that I--the 'chit of a girl,' as everybody called me,"
25618. thought Natasha--"is it possible that I am now to be the wife and the
25619. equal of this strange, dear, clever man whom even my father looks up to?
25620. Can it be true? Can it be true that there can be no more playing with
25621. life, that now I am grown up, that on me now lies a responsibility for
25622. my every word and deed? Yes, but what did he ask me?"
25623. 
25624. "No," she replied, but she had not understood his question.
25625. 
25626. "Forgive me!" he said. "But you are so young, and I have already been
25627. through so much in life. I am afraid for you, you do not yet know
25628. yourself."
25629. 
25630. Natasha listened with concentrated attention, trying but failing to take
25631. in the meaning of his words.
25632. 
25633. "Hard as this year which delays my happiness will be," continued Prince
25634. Andrew, "it will give you time to be sure of yourself. I ask you to
25635. make me happy in a year, but you are free: our engagement shall remain a
25636. secret, and should you find that you do not love me, or should you come
25637. to love..." said Prince Andrew with an unnatural smile.
25638. 
25639. "Why do you say that?" Natasha interrupted him. "You know that from the
25640. very day you first came to Otradnoe I have loved you," she cried, quite
25641. convinced that she spoke the truth.
25642. 
25643. "In a year you will learn to know yourself...."
25644. 
25645. "A whole year!" Natasha repeated suddenly, only now realizing that
25646. the marriage was to be postponed for a year. "But why a year? Why a
25647. year?..."
25648. 
25649. Prince Andrew began to explain to her the reasons for this delay.
25650. Natasha did not hear him.
25651. 
25652. "And can't it be helped?" she asked. Prince Andrew did not reply, but
25653. his face expressed the impossibility of altering that decision.
25654. 
25655. "It's awful! Oh, it's awful! awful!" Natasha suddenly cried, and again
25656. burst into sobs. "I shall die, waiting a year: it's impossible, it's
25657. awful!" She looked into her lover's face and saw in it a look of
25658. commiseration and perplexity.
25659. 
25660. "No, no! I'll do anything!" she said, suddenly checking her tears. "I am
25661. so happy."
25662. 
25663. The father and mother came into the room and gave the betrothed couple
25664. their blessing.
25665. 
25666. From that day Prince Andrew began to frequent the Rostovs' as Natasha's
25667. affianced lover.
25668. 
25669. 
25670. 
25671. 
25672. 
25673. CHAPTER XXIV
25674. 
25675. 
25676. No betrothal ceremony took place and Natasha's engagement to Bolkonski
25677. was not announced; Prince Andrew insisted on that. He said that as he
25678. was responsible for the delay he ought to bear the whole burden of it;
25679. that he had given his word and bound himself forever, but that he did
25680. not wish to bind Natasha and gave her perfect freedom. If after six
25681. months she felt that she did not love him she would have full right to
25682. reject him. Naturally neither Natasha nor her parents wished to hear of
25683. this, but Prince Andrew was firm. He came every day to the Rostovs',
25684. but did not behave to Natasha as an affianced lover: he did not use
25685. the familiar thou, but said you to her, and kissed only her hand. After
25686. their engagement, quite different, intimate, and natural relations
25687. sprang up between them. It was as if they had not known each other till
25688. now. Both liked to recall how they had regarded each other when as
25689. yet they were nothing to one another; they felt themselves now quite
25690. different beings: then they were artificial, now natural and sincere. At
25691. first the family felt some constraint in intercourse with Prince Andrew;
25692. he seemed a man from another world, and for a long time Natasha trained
25693. the family to get used to him, proudly assuring them all that he only
25694. appeared to be different, but was really just like all of them, and that
25695. she was not afraid of him and no one else ought to be. After a few
25696. days they grew accustomed to him, and without restraint in his presence
25697. pursued their usual way of life, in which he took his part. He could
25698. talk about rural economy with the count, fashions with the countess
25699. and Natasha, and about albums and fancywork with Sonya. Sometimes the
25700. household both among themselves and in his presence expressed their
25701. wonder at how it had all happened, and at the evident omens there had
25702. been of it: Prince Andrew's coming to Otradnoe and their coming to
25703. Petersburg, and the likeness between Natasha and Prince Andrew which
25704. her nurse had noticed on his first visit, and Andrew's encounter with
25705. Nicholas in 1805, and many other incidents betokening that it had to be.
25706. 
25707. In the house that poetic dullness and quiet reigned which always
25708. accompanies the presence of a betrothed couple. Often when all sitting
25709. together everyone kept silent. Sometimes the others would get up and
25710. go away and the couple, left alone, still remained silent. They rarely
25711. spoke of their future life. Prince Andrew was afraid and ashamed to
25712. speak of it. Natasha shared this as she did all his feelings, which she
25713. constantly divined. Once she began questioning him about his son. Prince
25714. Andrew blushed, as he often did now--Natasha particularly liked it in
25715. him--and said that his son would not live with them.
25716. 
25717. "Why not?" asked Natasha in a frightened tone.
25718. 
25719. "I cannot take him away from his grandfather, and besides..."
25720. 
25721. "How I should have loved him!" said Natasha, immediately guessing his
25722. thought; "but I know you wish to avoid any pretext for finding fault
25723. with us."
25724. 
25725. Sometimes the old count would come up, kiss Prince Andrew, and ask his
25726. advice about Petya's education or Nicholas' service. The old countess
25727. sighed as she looked at them; Sonya was always getting frightened lest
25728. she should be in the way and tried to find excuses for leaving them
25729. alone, even when they did not wish it. When Prince Andrew spoke (he
25730. could tell a story very well), Natasha listened to him with pride; when
25731. she spoke she noticed with fear and joy that he gazed attentively and
25732. scrutinizingly at her. She asked herself in perplexity: "What does he
25733. look for in me? He is trying to discover something by looking at me!
25734. What if what he seeks in me is not there?" Sometimes she fell into one
25735. of the mad, merry moods characteristic of her, and then she particularly
25736. loved to hear and see how Prince Andrew laughed. He seldom laughed, but
25737. when he did he abandoned himself entirely to his laughter, and after
25738. such a laugh she always felt nearer to him. Natasha would have been
25739. completely happy if the thought of the separation awaiting her and
25740. drawing near had not terrified her, just as the mere thought of it made
25741. him turn pale and cold.
25742. 
25743. On the eve of his departure from Petersburg Prince Andrew brought with
25744. him Pierre, who had not been to the Rostovs' once since the ball. Pierre
25745. seemed disconcerted and embarrassed. He was talking to the countess,
25746. and Natasha sat down beside a little chess table with Sonya, thereby
25747. inviting Prince Andrew to come too. He did so.
25748. 
25749. "You have known Bezukhov a long time?" he asked. "Do you like him?"
25750. 
25751. "Yes, he's a dear, but very absurd."
25752. 
25753. And as usual when speaking of Pierre, she began to tell anecdotes of his
25754. absent-mindedness, some of which had even been invented about him.
25755. 
25756. "Do you know I have entrusted him with our secret? I have known him from
25757. childhood. He has a heart of gold. I beg you, Natalie," Prince Andrew
25758. said with sudden seriousness--"I am going away and heaven knows what may
25759. happen. You may cease to... all right, I know I am not to say that. Only
25760. this, then: whatever may happen to you when I am not here..."
25761. 
25762. "What can happen?"
25763. 
25764. "Whatever trouble may come," Prince Andrew continued, "I beg you,
25765. Mademoiselle Sophie, whatever may happen, to turn to him alone for
25766. advice and help! He is a most absent-minded and absurd fellow, but he
25767. has a heart of gold."
25768. 
25769. Neither her father, nor her mother, nor Sonya, nor Prince Andrew himself
25770. could have foreseen how the separation from her lover would act on
25771. Natasha. Flushed and agitated she went about the house all that day,
25772. dry-eyed, occupied with most trivial matters as if not understanding
25773. what awaited her. She did not even cry when, on taking leave, he kissed
25774. her hand for the last time. "Don't go!" she said in a tone that made him
25775. wonder whether he really ought not to stay and which he remembered long
25776. afterwards. Nor did she cry when he was gone; but for several days she
25777. sat in her room dry-eyed, taking no interest in anything and only saying
25778. now and then, "Oh, why did he go away?"
25779. 
25780. But a fortnight after his departure, to the surprise of those around
25781. her, she recovered from her mental sickness just as suddenly and became
25782. her old self again, but with a change in her moral physiognomy, as a
25783. child gets up after a long illness with a changed expression of face.
25784. 
25785. 
25786. 
25787. 
25788. 
25789. CHAPTER XXV
25790. 
25791. 
25792. During that year after his son's departure, Prince Nicholas Bolkonski's
25793. health and temper became much worse. He grew still more irritable, and
25794. it was Princess Mary who generally bore the brunt of his frequent fits
25795. of unprovoked anger. He seemed carefully to seek out her tender spots so
25796. as to torture her mentally as harshly as possible. Princess Mary had
25797. two passions and consequently two joys--her nephew, little Nicholas, and
25798. religion--and these were the favorite subjects of the prince's attacks
25799. and ridicule. Whatever was spoken of he would bring round to the
25800. superstitiousness of old maids, or the petting and spoiling of children.
25801. "You want to make him"--little Nicholas--"into an old maid like
25802. yourself! A pity! Prince Andrew wants a son and not an old maid," he
25803. would say. Or, turning to Mademoiselle Bourienne, he would ask her in
25804. Princess Mary's presence how she liked our village priests and icons and
25805. would joke about them.
25806. 
25807. He continually hurt Princess Mary's feelings and tormented her, but it
25808. cost her no effort to forgive him. Could he be to blame toward her, or
25809. could her father, whom she knew loved her in spite of it all, be unjust?
25810. And what is justice? The princess never thought of that proud word
25811. "justice." All the complex laws of man centered for her in one clear
25812. and simple law--the law of love and self-sacrifice taught us by Him who
25813. lovingly suffered for mankind though He Himself was God. What had she to
25814. do with the justice or injustice of other people? She had to endure and
25815. love, and that she did.
25816. 
25817. During the winter Prince Andrew had come to Bald Hills and had been gay,
25818. gentle, and more affectionate than Princess Mary had known him for a
25819. long time past. She felt that something had happened to him, but he said
25820. nothing to her about his love. Before he left he had a long talk with
25821. his father about something, and Princess Mary noticed that before his
25822. departure they were dissatisfied with one another.
25823. 
25824. Soon after Prince Andrew had gone, Princess Mary wrote to her friend
25825. Julie Karagina in Petersburg, whom she had dreamed (as all girls dream)
25826. of marrying to her brother, and who was at that time in mourning for her
25827. own brother, killed in Turkey.
25828. 
25829. 
25830. Sorrow, it seems, is our common lot, my dear, tender friend Julie.
25831. 
25832. Your loss is so terrible that I can only explain it to myself as a
25833. special providence of God who, loving you, wishes to try you and your
25834. excellent mother. Oh, my friend! Religion, and religion alone, can--I
25835. will not say comfort us--but save us from despair. Religion alone can
25836. explain to us what without its help man cannot comprehend: why, for what
25837. cause, kind and noble beings able to find happiness in life--not merely
25838. harming no one but necessary to the happiness of others--are called away
25839. to God, while cruel, useless, harmful persons, or such as are a burden
25840. to themselves and to others, are left living. The first death I saw,
25841. and one I shall never forget--that of my dear sister-in-law--left that
25842. impression on me. Just as you ask destiny why your splendid brother
25843. had to die, so I asked why that angel Lise, who not only never wronged
25844. anyone, but in whose soul there were never any unkind thoughts, had to
25845. die. And what do you think, dear friend? Five years have passed since
25846. then, and already I, with my petty understanding, begin to see clearly
25847. why she had to die, and in what way that death was but an expression
25848. of the infinite goodness of the Creator, whose every action, though
25849. generally incomprehensible to us, is but a manifestation of His infinite
25850. love for His creatures. Perhaps, I often think, she was too angelically
25851. innocent to have the strength to perform all a mother's duties. As a
25852. young wife she was irreproachable; perhaps she could not have been so
25853. as a mother. As it is, not only has she left us, and particularly Prince
25854. Andrew, with the purest regrets and memories, but probably she will
25855. there receive a place I dare not hope for myself. But not to speak of
25856. her alone, that early and terrible death has had the most beneficent
25857. influence on me and on my brother in spite of all our grief. Then, at
25858. the moment of our loss, these thoughts could not occur to me; I should
25859. then have dismissed them with horror, but now they are very clear and
25860. certain. I write all this to you, dear friend, only to convince you
25861. of the Gospel truth which has become for me a principle of life: not
25862. a single hair of our heads will fall without His will. And His will is
25863. governed only by infinite love for us, and so whatever befalls us is for
25864. our good.
25865. 
25866. You ask whether we shall spend next winter in Moscow. In spite of my
25867. wish to see you, I do not think so and do not want to do so. You will
25868. be surprised to hear that the reason for this is Buonaparte! The case
25869. is this: my father's health is growing noticeably worse, he cannot stand
25870. any contradiction and is becoming irritable. This irritability is, as
25871. you know, chiefly directed to political questions. He cannot endure
25872. the notion that Buonaparte is negotiating on equal terms with all the
25873. sovereigns of Europe and particularly with our own, the grandson of the
25874. Great Catherine! As you know, I am quite indifferent to politics, but
25875. from my father's remarks and his talks with Michael Ivanovich I know all
25876. that goes on in the world and especially about the honors conferred on
25877. Buonaparte, who only at Bald Hills in the whole world, it seems, is not
25878. accepted as a great man, still less as Emperor of France. And my father
25879. cannot stand this. It seems to me that it is chiefly because of his
25880. political views that my father is reluctant to speak of going to
25881. Moscow; for he foresees the encounters that would result from his way
25882. of expressing his views regardless of anybody. All the benefit he might
25883. derive from a course of treatment he would lose as a result of the
25884. disputes about Buonaparte which would be inevitable. In any case it will
25885. be decided very shortly.
25886. 
25887. Our family life goes on in the old way except for my brother Andrew's
25888. absence. He, as I wrote you before, has changed very much of late. After
25889. his sorrow he only this year quite recovered his spirits. He has again
25890. become as I used to know him when a child: kind, affectionate, with that
25891. heart of gold to which I know no equal. He has realized, it seems to me,
25892. that life is not over for him. But together with this mental change
25893. he has grown physically much weaker. He has become thinner and more
25894. nervous. I am anxious about him and glad he is taking this trip abroad
25895. which the doctors recommended long ago. I hope it will cure him. You
25896. write that in Petersburg he is spoken of as one of the most active,
25897. cultivated, and capable of the young men. Forgive my vanity as a
25898. relation, but I never doubted it. The good he has done to everybody
25899. here, from his peasants up to the gentry, is incalculable. On his
25900. arrival in Petersburg he received only his due. I always wonder at the
25901. way rumors fly from Petersburg to Moscow, especially such false ones as
25902. that you write about--I mean the report of my brother's betrothal to
25903. the little Rostova. I do not think my brother will ever marry again, and
25904. certainly not her; and this is why: first, I know that though he rarely
25905. speaks about the wife he has lost, the grief of that loss has gone too
25906. deep in his heart for him ever to decide to give her a successor and our
25907. little angel a stepmother. Secondly because, as far as I know, that girl
25908. is not the kind of girl who could please Prince Andrew. I do not think
25909. he would choose her for a wife, and frankly I do not wish it. But I am
25910. running on too long and am at the end of my second sheet. Good-by,
25911. my dear friend. May God keep you in His holy and mighty care. My dear
25912. friend, Mademoiselle Bourienne, sends you kisses.
25913. 
25914. MARY
25915. 
25916. 
25917. 
25918. 
25919. 
25920. CHAPTER XXVI
25921. 
25922. 
25923. In the middle of the summer Princess Mary received an unexpected letter
25924. from Prince Andrew in Switzerland in which he gave her strange and
25925. surprising news. He informed her of his engagement to Natasha Rostova.
25926. The whole letter breathed loving rapture for his betrothed and tender
25927. and confiding affection for his sister. He wrote that he had never loved
25928. as he did now and that only now did he understand and know what life
25929. was. He asked his sister to forgive him for not having told her of his
25930. resolve when he had last visited Bald Hills, though he had spoken of it
25931. to his father. He had not done so for fear Princess Mary should ask her
25932. father to give his consent, irritating him and having to bear the brunt
25933. of his displeasure without attaining her object. "Besides," he wrote,
25934. "the matter was not then so definitely settled as it is now. My father
25935. then insisted on a delay of a year and now already six months, half of
25936. that period, have passed, and my resolution is firmer than ever. If the
25937. doctors did not keep me here at the spas I should be back in Russia, but
25938. as it is I have to postpone my return for three months. You know me
25939. and my relations with Father. I want nothing from him. I have been and
25940. always shall be independent; but to go against his will and arouse his
25941. anger, now that he may perhaps remain with us such a short time, would
25942. destroy half my happiness. I am now writing to him about the same
25943. question, and beg you to choose a good moment to hand him the letter
25944. and to let me know how he looks at the whole matter and whether there is
25945. hope that he may consent to reduce the term by four months."
25946. 
25947. After long hesitations, doubts, and prayers, Princess Mary gave the
25948. letter to her father. The next day the old prince said to her quietly:
25949. 
25950. "Write and tell your brother to wait till I am dead.... It won't be
25951. long--I shall soon set him free."
25952. 
25953. The princess was about to reply, but her father would not let her speak
25954. and, raising his voice more and more, cried:
25955. 
25956. "Marry, marry, my boy!... A good family!... Clever people, eh? Rich,
25957. eh? Yes, a nice stepmother little Nicholas will have! Write and tell
25958. him that he may marry tomorrow if he likes. She will be little Nicholas'
25959. stepmother and I'll marry Bourienne!... Ha, ha, ha! He mustn't be
25960. without a stepmother either! Only one thing, no more women are wanted
25961. in my house--let him marry and live by himself. Perhaps you will go and
25962. live with him too?" he added, turning to Princess Mary. "Go in heavens
25963. name! Go out into the frost... the frost... the frost!"
25964. 
25965. After this outburst the prince did not speak any more about the matter.
25966. But repressed vexation at his son's poor-spirited behavior found
25967. expression in his treatment of his daughter. To his former pretexts
25968. for irony a fresh one was now added--allusions to stepmothers and
25969. amiabilities to Mademoiselle Bourienne.
25970. 
25971. "Why shouldn't I marry her?" he asked his daughter. "She'll make a
25972. splendid princess!"
25973. 
25974. And latterly, to her surprise and bewilderment, Princess Mary
25975. noticed that her father was really associating more and more with the
25976. Frenchwoman. She wrote to Prince Andrew about the reception of his
25977. letter, but comforted him with hopes of reconciling their father to the
25978. idea.
25979. 
25980. Little Nicholas and his education, her brother Andrew, and religion were
25981. Princess Mary's joys and consolations; but besides that, since everyone
25982. must have personal hopes, Princess Mary in the profoundest depths of her
25983. heart had a hidden dream and hope that supplied the chief consolation
25984. of her life. This comforting dream and hope were given her by God's
25985. folk--the half-witted and other pilgrims who visited her without the
25986. prince's knowledge. The longer she lived, the more experience and
25987. observation she had of life, the greater was her wonder at the
25988. short-sightedness of men who seek enjoyment and happiness here on earth:
25989. toiling, suffering, struggling, and harming one another, to obtain that
25990. impossible, visionary, sinful happiness. Prince Andrew had loved his
25991. wife, she died, but that was not enough: he wanted to bind his happiness
25992. to another woman. Her father objected to this because he wanted a more
25993. distinguished and wealthier match for Andrew. And they all struggled
25994. and suffered and tormented one another and injured their souls, their
25995. eternal souls, for the attainment of benefits which endure but for an
25996. instant. Not only do we know this ourselves, but Christ, the Son of God,
25997. came down to earth and told us that this life is but for a moment and is
25998. a probation; yet we cling to it and think to find happiness in it. "How
25999. is it that no one realizes this?" thought Princess Mary. "No one except
26000. these despised God's folk who, wallet on back, come to me by the back
26001. door, afraid of being seen by the prince, not for fear of ill-usage by
26002. him but for fear of causing him to sin. To leave family, home, and all
26003. the cares of worldly welfare, in order without clinging to anything to
26004. wander in hempen rags from place to place under an assumed name, doing
26005. no one any harm but praying for all--for those who drive one away as
26006. well as for those who protect one: higher than that life and truth there
26007. is no life or truth!"
26008. 
26009. There was one pilgrim, a quiet pockmarked little woman of fifty called
26010. Theodosia, who for over thirty years had gone about barefoot and worn
26011. heavy chains. Princess Mary was particularly fond of her. Once, when in
26012. a room with a lamp dimly lit before the icon Theodosia was talking of
26013. her life, the thought that Theodosia alone had found the true path of
26014. life suddenly came to Princess Mary with such force that she resolved to
26015. become a pilgrim herself. When Theodosia had gone to sleep Princess Mary
26016. thought about this for a long time, and at last made up her mind that,
26017. strange as it might seem, she must go on a pilgrimage. She disclosed
26018. this thought to no one but to her confessor, Father Akinfi, the monk,
26019. and he approved of her intention. Under guise of a present for the
26020. pilgrims, Princess Mary prepared a pilgrim's complete costume for
26021. herself: a coarse smock, bast shoes, a rough coat, and a black kerchief.
26022. Often, approaching the chest of drawers containing this secret treasure,
26023. Princess Mary paused, uncertain whether the time had not already come to
26024. put her project into execution.
26025. 
26026. Often, listening to the pilgrims' tales, she was so stimulated by their
26027. simple speech, mechanical to them but to her so full of deep meaning,
26028. that several times she was on the point of abandoning everything and
26029. running away from home. In imagination she already pictured herself by
26030. Theodosia's side, dressed in coarse rags, walking with a staff, a wallet
26031. on her back, along the dusty road, directing her wanderings from one
26032. saint's shrine to another, free from envy, earthly love, or desire, and
26033. reaching at last the place where there is no more sorrow or sighing, but
26034. eternal joy and bliss.
26035. 
26036. "I shall come to a place and pray there, and before having time to get
26037. used to it or getting to love it, I shall go farther. I will go on till
26038. my legs fail, and I'll lie down and die somewhere, and shall at last
26039. reach that eternal, quiet haven, where there is neither sorrow nor
26040. sighing..." thought Princess Mary.
26041. 
26042. But afterwards, when she saw her father and especially little Koko
26043. (Nicholas), her resolve weakened. She wept quietly, and felt that she
26044. was a sinner who loved her father and little nephew more than God.
26045. 
26046. 
26047. 
26048. 
26049. 
26050. BOOK SEVEN: 1810 - 11
26051. 
26052. 
26053. 
26054. 
26055. 
26056. CHAPTER I
26057. 
26058. 
26059. The Bible legend tells us that the absence of labor--idleness--was a
26060. condition of the first man's blessedness before the Fall. Fallen man has
26061. retained a love of idleness, but the curse weighs on the race not only
26062. because we have to seek our bread in the sweat of our brows, but because
26063. our moral nature is such that we cannot be both idle and at ease. An
26064. inner voice tells us we are in the wrong if we are idle. If man could
26065. find a state in which he felt that though idle he was fulfilling his
26066. duty, he would have found one of the conditions of man's primitive
26067. blessedness. And such a state of obligatory and irreproachable idleness
26068. is the lot of a whole class--the military. The chief attraction of
26069. military service has consisted and will consist in this compulsory and
26070. irreproachable idleness.
26071. 
26072. Nicholas Rostov experienced this blissful condition to the full when,
26073. after 1807, he continued to serve in the Pavlograd regiment, in which he
26074. already commanded the squadron he had taken over from Denisov.
26075. 
26076. Rostov had become a bluff, good-natured fellow, whom his Moscow
26077. acquaintances would have considered rather bad form, but who was liked
26078. and respected by his comrades, subordinates, and superiors, and was well
26079. contented with his life. Of late, in 1809, he found in letters from home
26080. more frequent complaints from his mother that their affairs were falling
26081. into greater and greater disorder, and that it was time for him to come
26082. back to gladden and comfort his old parents.
26083. 
26084. Reading these letters, Nicholas felt a dread of their wanting to
26085. take him away from surroundings in which, protected from all the
26086. entanglements of life, he was living so calmly and quietly. He felt that
26087. sooner or later he would have to re-enter that whirlpool of life, with
26088. its embarrassments and affairs to be straightened out, its accounts with
26089. stewards, quarrels, and intrigues, its ties, society, and with Sonya's
26090. love and his promise to her. It was all dreadfully difficult and
26091. complicated; and he replied to his mother in cold, formal letters in
26092. French, beginning: "My dear Mamma," and ending: "Your obedient son,"
26093. which said nothing of when he would return. In 1810 he received letters
26094. from his parents, in which they told him of Natasha's engagement to
26095. Bolkonski, and that the wedding would be in a year's time because
26096. the old prince made difficulties. This letter grieved and mortified
26097. Nicholas. In the first place he was sorry that Natasha, for whom he
26098. cared more than for anyone else in the family, should be lost to the
26099. home; and secondly, from his hussar point of view, he regretted not to
26100. have been there to show that fellow Bolkonski that connection with him
26101. was no such great honor after all, and that if he loved Natasha he
26102. might dispense with permission from his dotard father. For a moment he
26103. hesitated whether he should not apply for leave in order to see Natasha
26104. before she was married, but then came the maneuvers, and considerations
26105. about Sonya and about the confusion of their affairs, and Nicholas again
26106. put it off. But in the spring of that year, he received a letter from
26107. his mother, written without his father's knowledge, and that letter
26108. persuaded him to return. She wrote that if he did not come and take
26109. matters in hand, their whole property would be sold by auction and they
26110. would all have to go begging. The count was so weak, and trusted Mitenka
26111. so much, and was so good-natured, that everybody took advantage of him
26112. and things were going from bad to worse. "For God's sake, I implore
26113. you, come at once if you do not wish to make me and the whole family
26114. wretched," wrote the countess.
26115. 
26116. This letter touched Nicholas. He had that common sense of a
26117. matter-of-fact man which showed him what he ought to do.
26118. 
26119. The right thing now was, if not to retire from the service, at any rate
26120. to go home on leave. Why he had to go he did not know; but after his
26121. after-dinner nap he gave orders to saddle Mars, an extremely vicious
26122. gray stallion that had not been ridden for a long time, and when
26123. he returned with the horse all in a lather, he informed Lavrushka
26124. (Denisov's servant who had remained with him) and his comrades who
26125. turned up in the evening that he was applying for leave and was going
26126. home. Difficult and strange as it was for him to reflect that he would
26127. go away without having heard from the staff--and this interested him
26128. extremely--whether he was promoted to a captaincy or would receive the
26129. Order of St. Anne for the last maneuvers; strange as it was to think
26130. that he would go away without having sold his three roans to the Polish
26131. Count Golukhovski, who was bargaining for the horses Rostov had betted
26132. he would sell for two thousand rubles; incomprehensible as it
26133. seemed that the ball the hussars were giving in honor of the Polish
26134. Mademoiselle Przazdziecka (out of rivalry to the Uhlans who had given
26135. one in honor of their Polish Mademoiselle Borzozowska) would take place
26136. without him--he knew he must go away from this good, bright world to
26137. somewhere where everything was stupid and confused. A week later he
26138. obtained his leave. His hussar comrades--not only those of his own
26139. regiment, but the whole brigade--gave Rostov a dinner to which the
26140. subscription was fifteen rubles a head, and at which there were two
26141. bands and two choirs of singers. Rostov danced the Trepak with Major
26142. Basov; the tipsy officers tossed, embraced, and dropped Rostov; the
26143. soldiers of the third squadron tossed him too, and shouted "hurrah!"
26144. and then they put him in his sleigh and escorted him as far as the first
26145. post station.
26146. 
26147. During the first half of the journey--from Kremenchug to Kiev--all
26148. Rostov's thoughts, as is usual in such cases, were behind him, with the
26149. squadron; but when he had gone more than halfway he began to forget his
26150. three roans and Dozhoyveyko, his quartermaster, and to wonder anxiously
26151. how things would be at Otradnoe and what he would find there. Thoughts
26152. of home grew stronger the nearer he approached it--far stronger, as
26153. though this feeling of his was subject to the law by which the force of
26154. attraction is in inverse proportion to the square of the distance. At
26155. the last post station before Otradnoe he gave the driver a three-ruble
26156. tip, and on arriving he ran breathlessly, like a boy, up the steps of
26157. his home.
26158. 
26159. After the rapture of meeting, and after that odd feeling of unsatisfied
26160. expectation--the feeling that "everything is just the same, so why did I
26161. hurry?"--Nicholas began to settle down in his old home world. His father
26162. and mother were much the same, only a little older. What was new in them
26163. was a certain uneasiness and occasional discord, which there used not to
26164. be, and which, as Nicholas soon found out, was due to the bad state of
26165. their affairs. Sonya was nearly twenty; she had stopped growing prettier
26166. and promised nothing more than she was already, but that was enough.
26167. She exhaled happiness and love from the time Nicholas returned, and the
26168. faithful, unalterable love of this girl had a gladdening effect on him.
26169. Petya and Natasha surprised Nicholas most. Petya was a big handsome
26170. boy of thirteen, merry, witty, and mischievous, with a voice that was
26171. already breaking. As for Natasha, for a long while Nicholas wondered and
26172. laughed whenever he looked at her.
26173. 
26174. "You're not the same at all," he said.
26175. 
26176. "How? Am I uglier?"
26177. 
26178. "On the contrary, but what dignity? A princess!" he whispered to her.
26179. 
26180. "Yes, yes, yes!" cried Natasha, joyfully.
26181. 
26182. She told him about her romance with Prince Andrew and of his visit to
26183. Otradnoe and showed him his last letter.
26184. 
26185. "Well, are you glad?" Natasha asked. "I am so tranquil and happy now."
26186. 
26187. "Very glad," answered Nicholas. "He is an excellent fellow.... And are
26188. you very much in love?"
26189. 
26190. "How shall I put it?" replied Natasha. "I was in love with Boris, with
26191. my teacher, and with Denisov, but this is quite different. I feel at
26192. peace and settled. I know that no better man than he exists, and I am
26193. calm and contented now. Not at all as before."
26194. 
26195. Nicholas expressed his disapproval of the postponement of the marriage
26196. for a year; but Natasha attacked her brother with exasperation, proving
26197. to him that it could not be otherwise, and that it would be a bad thing
26198. to enter a family against the father's will, and that she herself wished
26199. it so.
26200. 
26201. "You don't at all understand," she said.
26202. 
26203. Nicholas was silent and agreed with her.
26204. 
26205. Her brother often wondered as he looked at her. She did not seem at
26206. all like a girl in love and parted from her affianced husband. She was
26207. even-tempered and calm and quite as cheerful as of old. This amazed
26208. Nicholas and even made him regard Bolkonski's courtship skeptically.
26209. He could not believe that her fate was sealed, especially as he had
26210. not seen her with Prince Andrew. It always seemed to him that there was
26211. something not quite right about this intended marriage.
26212. 
26213. "Why this delay? Why no betrothal?" he thought. Once, when he had
26214. touched on this topic with his mother, he discovered, to his surprise
26215. and somewhat to his satisfaction, that in the depth of her soul she too
26216. had doubts about this marriage.
26217. 
26218. "You see he writes," said she, showing her son a letter of Prince
26219. Andrew's, with that latent grudge a mother always has in regard to
26220. a daughter's future married happiness, "he writes that he won't come
26221. before December. What can be keeping him? Illness, probably! His health
26222. is very delicate. Don't tell Natasha. And don't attach importance to her
26223. being so bright: that's because she's living through the last days of
26224. her girlhood, but I know what she is like every time we receive a letter
26225. from him! However, God grant that everything turns out well!" (She
26226. always ended with these words.) "He is an excellent man!"
26227. 
26228. 
26229. 
26230. 
26231. 
26232. CHAPTER II
26233. 
26234. 
26235. After reaching home Nicholas was at first serious and even dull. He was
26236. worried by the impending necessity of interfering in the stupid business
26237. matters for which his mother had called him home. To throw off this
26238. burden as quickly as possible, on the third day after his arrival he
26239. went, angry and scowling and without answering questions as to where he
26240. was going, to Mitenka's lodge and demanded an account of everything. But
26241. what an account of everything might be Nicholas knew even less than the
26242. frightened and bewildered Mitenka. The conversation and the examination
26243. of the accounts with Mitenka did not last long. The village elder,
26244. a peasant delegate, and the village clerk, who were waiting in the
26245. passage, heard with fear and delight first the young count's voice
26246. roaring and snapping and rising louder and louder, and then words of
26247. abuse, dreadful words, ejaculated one after the other.
26248. 
26249. "Robber!... Ungrateful wretch!... I'll hack the dog to pieces! I'm not
26250. my father!... Robbing us!..." and so on.
26251. 
26252. Then with no less fear and delight they saw how the young count, red in
26253. the face and with bloodshot eyes, dragged Mitenka out by the scruff of
26254. the neck and applied his foot and knee to his behind with great agility
26255. at convenient moments between the words, shouting, "Be off! Never let me
26256. see your face here again, you villain!"
26257. 
26258. Mitenka flew headlong down the six steps and ran away into the
26259. shrubbery. (This shrubbery was a well-known haven of refuge for culprits
26260. at Otradnoe. Mitenka himself, returning tipsy from the town, used to
26261. hide there, and many of the residents at Otradnoe, hiding from Mitenka,
26262. knew of its protective qualities.)
26263. 
26264. Mitenka's wife and sisters-in-law thrust their heads and frightened
26265. faces out of the door of a room where a bright samovar was boiling and
26266. where the steward's high bedstead stood with its patchwork quilt.
26267. 
26268. The young count paid no heed to them, but, breathing hard, passed by
26269. with resolute strides and went into the house.
26270. 
26271. The countess, who heard at once from the maids what had happened at the
26272. lodge, was calmed by the thought that now their affairs would certainly
26273. improve, but on the other hand felt anxious as to the effect this
26274. excitement might have on her son. She went several times to his door on
26275. tiptoe and listened, as he lighted one pipe after another.
26276. 
26277. Next day the old count called his son aside and, with an embarrassed
26278. smile, said to him:
26279. 
26280. "But you know, my dear boy, it's a pity you got excited! Mitenka has
26281. told me all about it."
26282. 
26283. "I knew," thought Nicholas, "that I should never understand anything in
26284. this crazy world."
26285. 
26286. "You were angry that he had not entered those 700 rubles. But they were
26287. carried forward--and you did not look at the other page."
26288. 
26289. "Papa, he is a blackguard and a thief! I know he is! And what I have
26290. done, I have done; but, if you like, I won't speak to him again."
26291. 
26292. "No, my dear boy" (the count, too, felt embarrassed. He knew he had
26293. mismanaged his wife's property and was to blame toward his children,
26294. but he did not know how to remedy it). "No, I beg you to attend to the
26295. business. I am old. I..."
26296. 
26297. "No, Papa. Forgive me if I have caused you unpleasantness. I understand
26298. it all less than you do."
26299. 
26300. "Devil take all these peasants, and money matters, and carryings forward
26301. from page to page," he thought. "I used to understand what a 'corner'
26302. and the stakes at cards meant, but carrying forward to another page I
26303. don't understand at all," said he to himself, and after that he did not
26304. meddle in business affairs. But once the countess called her son and
26305. informed him that she had a promissory note from Anna Mikhaylovna for
26306. two thousand rubles, and asked him what he thought of doing with it.
26307. 
26308. "This," answered Nicholas. "You say it rests with me. Well, I don't like
26309. Anna Mikhaylovna and I don't like Boris, but they were our friends and
26310. poor. Well then, this!" and he tore up the note, and by so doing caused
26311. the old countess to weep tears of joy. After that, young Rostov took
26312. no further part in any business affairs, but devoted himself with
26313. passionate enthusiasm to what was to him a new pursuit--the chase--for
26314. which his father kept a large establishment.
26315. 
26316. 
26317. 
26318. 
26319. 
26320. CHAPTER III
26321. 
26322. 
26323. The weather was already growing wintry and morning frosts congealed
26324. an earth saturated by autumn rains. The verdure had thickened and its
26325. bright green stood out sharply against the brownish strips of winter rye
26326. trodden down by the cattle, and against the pale-yellow stubble of the
26327. spring buckwheat. The wooded ravines and the copses, which at the end of
26328. August had still been green islands amid black fields and stubble, had
26329. become golden and bright-red islands amid the green winter rye. The
26330. hares had already half changed their summer coats, the fox cubs were
26331. beginning to scatter, and the young wolves were bigger than dogs. It was
26332. the best time of the year for the chase. The hounds of that ardent young
26333. sportsman Rostov had not merely reached hard winter condition, but were
26334. so jaded that at a meeting of the huntsmen it was decided to give them
26335. a three days' rest and then, on the sixteenth of September, to go on
26336. a distant expedition, starting from the oak grove where there was an
26337. undisturbed litter of wolf cubs.
26338. 
26339. All that day the hounds remained at home. It was frosty and the air was
26340. sharp, but toward evening the sky became overcast and it began to thaw.
26341. On the fifteenth, when young Rostov, in his dressing gown, looked out of
26342. the window, he saw it was an unsurpassable morning for hunting: it was
26343. as if the sky were melting and sinking to the earth without any wind.
26344. The only motion in the air was that of the dripping, microscopic
26345. particles of drizzling mist. The bare twigs in the garden were hung with
26346. transparent drops which fell on the freshly fallen leaves. The earth in
26347. the kitchen garden looked wet and black and glistened like poppy seed
26348. and at a short distance merged into the dull, moist veil of mist.
26349. Nicholas went out into the wet and muddy porch. There was a smell of
26350. decaying leaves and of dog. Milka, a black-spotted, broad-haunched bitch
26351. with prominent black eyes, got up on seeing her master, stretched her
26352. hind legs, lay down like a hare, and then suddenly jumped up and licked
26353. him right on his nose and mustache. Another borzoi, a dog, catching
26354. sight of his master from the garden path, arched his back and, rushing
26355. headlong toward the porch with lifted tail, began rubbing himself
26356. against his legs.
26357. 
26358. "O-hoy!" came at that moment, that inimitable huntsman's call which
26359. unites the deepest bass with the shrillest tenor, and round the corner
26360. came Daniel the head huntsman and head kennelman, a gray, wrinkled old
26361. man with hair cut straight over his forehead, Ukrainian fashion, a
26362. long bent whip in his hand, and that look of independence and scorn of
26363. everything that is only seen in huntsmen. He doffed his Circassian cap
26364. to his master and looked at him scornfully. This scorn was not offensive
26365. to his master. Nicholas knew that this Daniel, disdainful of everybody
26366. and who considered himself above them, was all the same his serf and
26367. huntsman.
26368. 
26369. "Daniel!" Nicholas said timidly, conscious at the sight of the weather,
26370. the hounds, and the huntsman that he was being carried away by that
26371. irresistible passion for sport which makes a man forget all his previous
26372. resolutions, as a lover forgets in the presence of his mistress.
26373. 
26374. "What orders, your excellency?" said the huntsman in his deep bass, deep
26375. as a proto-deacon's and hoarse with hallooing--and two flashing black
26376. eyes gazed from under his brows at his master, who was silent. "Can you
26377. resist it?" those eyes seemed to be asking.
26378. 
26379. "It's a good day, eh? For a hunt and a gallop, eh?" asked Nicholas,
26380. scratching Milka behind the ears.
26381. 
26382. Daniel did not answer, but winked instead.
26383. 
26384. "I sent Uvarka at dawn to listen," his bass boomed out after a minute's
26385. pause. "He says she's moved them into the Otradnoe enclosure. They were
26386. howling there." (This meant that the she-wolf, about whom they both
26387. knew, had moved with her cubs to the Otradnoe copse, a small place a
26388. mile and a half from the house.)
26389. 
26390. "We ought to go, don't you think so?" said Nicholas. "Come to me with
26391. Uvarka."
26392. 
26393. "As you please."
26394. 
26395. "Then put off feeding them."
26396. 
26397. "Yes, sir."
26398. 
26399. Five minutes later Daniel and Uvarka were standing in Nicholas' big
26400. study. Though Daniel was not a big man, to see him in a room was
26401. like seeing a horse or a bear on the floor among the furniture and
26402. surroundings of human life. Daniel himself felt this, and as usual stood
26403. just inside the door, trying to speak softly and not move, for fear of
26404. breaking something in the master's apartment, and he hastened to say all
26405. that was necessary so as to get from under that ceiling, out into the
26406. open under the sky once more.
26407. 
26408. Having finished his inquiries and extorted from Daniel an opinion that
26409. the hounds were fit (Daniel himself wished to go hunting), Nicholas
26410. ordered the horses to be saddled. But just as Daniel was about to
26411. go Natasha came in with rapid steps, not having done up her hair or
26412. finished dressing and with her old nurse's big shawl wrapped round her.
26413. Petya ran in at the same time.
26414. 
26415. "You are going?" asked Natasha. "I knew you would! Sonya said you
26416. wouldn't go, but I knew that today is the sort of day when you couldn't
26417. help going."
26418. 
26419. "Yes, we are going," replied Nicholas reluctantly, for today, as he
26420. intended to hunt seriously, he did not want to take Natasha and Petya.
26421. "We are going, but only wolf hunting: it would be dull for you."
26422. 
26423. "You know it is my greatest pleasure," said Natasha. "It's not fair; you
26424. are going by yourself, are having the horses saddled and said nothing to
26425. us about it."
26426. 
26427. "'No barrier bars a Russian's path'--we'll go!" shouted Petya.
26428. 
26429. "But you can't. Mamma said you mustn't," said Nicholas to Natasha.
26430. 
26431. "Yes, I'll go. I shall certainly go," said Natasha decisively. "Daniel,
26432. tell them to saddle for us, and Michael must come with my dogs," she
26433. added to the huntsman.
26434. 
26435. It seemed to Daniel irksome and improper to be in a room at all, but to
26436. have anything to do with a young lady seemed to him impossible. He
26437. cast down his eyes and hurried out as if it were none of his business,
26438. careful as he went not to inflict any accidental injury on the young
26439. lady.
26440. 
26441. 
26442. 
26443. 
26444. 
26445. CHAPTER IV
26446. 
26447. 
26448. The old count, who had always kept up an enormous hunting establishment
26449. but had now handed it all completely over to his son's care, being in
26450. very good spirits on this fifteenth of September, prepared to go out
26451. with the others.
26452. 
26453. In an hour's time the whole hunting party was at the porch. Nicholas,
26454. with a stern and serious air which showed that now was no time for
26455. attending to trifles, went past Natasha and Petya who were trying to
26456. tell him something. He had a look at all the details of the hunt, sent
26457. a pack of hounds and huntsmen on ahead to find the quarry, mounted his
26458. chestnut Donets, and whistling to his own leash of borzois, set off
26459. across the threshing ground to a field leading to the Otradnoe wood.
26460. The old count's horse, a sorrel gelding called Viflyanka, was led by the
26461. groom in attendance on him, while the count himself was to drive in a
26462. small trap straight to a spot reserved for him.
26463. 
26464. They were taking fifty-four hounds, with six hunt attendants and
26465. whippers-in. Besides the family, there were eight borzoi kennelmen
26466. and more than forty borzois, so that, with the borzois on the leash
26467. belonging to members of the family, there were about a hundred and
26468. thirty dogs and twenty horsemen.
26469. 
26470. Each dog knew its master and its call. Each man in the hunt knew his
26471. business, his place, what he had to do. As soon as they had passed the
26472. fence they all spread out evenly and quietly, without noise or talk,
26473. along the road and field leading to the Otradnoe covert.
26474. 
26475. The horses stepped over the field as over a thick carpet, now and then
26476. splashing into puddles as they crossed a road. The misty sky still
26477. seemed to descend evenly and imperceptibly toward the earth, the air
26478. was still, warm, and silent. Occasionally the whistle of a huntsman,
26479. the snort of a horse, the crack of a whip, or the whine of a straggling
26480. hound could be heard.
26481. 
26482. When they had gone a little less than a mile, five more riders with
26483. dogs appeared out of the mist, approaching the Rostovs. In front rode a
26484. fresh-looking, handsome old man with a large gray mustache.
26485. 
26486. "Good morning, Uncle!" said Nicholas, when the old man drew near.
26487. 
26488. "That's it. Come on!... I was sure of it," began "Uncle." (He was
26489. a distant relative of the Rostovs', a man of small means, and their
26490. neighbor.) "I knew you wouldn't be able to resist it and it's a good
26491. thing you're going. That's it! Come on!" (This was "Uncle's" favorite
26492. expression.) "Take the covert at once, for my Girchik says the Ilagins
26493. are at Korniki with their hounds. That's it. Come on!... They'll take
26494. the cubs from under your very nose."
26495. 
26496. "That's where I'm going. Shall we join up our packs?" asked Nicholas.
26497. 
26498. The hounds were joined into one pack, and "Uncle" and Nicholas rode on
26499. side by side. Natasha, muffled up in shawls which did not hide her eager
26500. face and shining eyes, galloped up to them. She was followed by Petya
26501. who always kept close to her, by Michael, a huntsman, and by a groom
26502. appointed to look after her. Petya, who was laughing, whipped and pulled
26503. at his horse. Natasha sat easily and confidently on her black Arabchik
26504. and reined him in without effort with a firm hand.
26505. 
26506. "Uncle" looked round disapprovingly at Petya and Natasha. He did not
26507. like to combine frivolity with the serious business of hunting.
26508. 
26509. "Good morning, Uncle! We are going too!" shouted Petya.
26510. 
26511. "Good morning, good morning! But don't go overriding the hounds," said
26512. "Uncle" sternly.
26513. 
26514. "Nicholas, what a fine dog Trunila is! He knew me," said Natasha,
26515. referring to her favorite hound.
26516. 
26517. "In the first place, Trunila is not a 'dog,' but a harrier," thought
26518. Nicholas, and looked sternly at his sister, trying to make her feel the
26519. distance that ought to separate them at that moment. Natasha understood
26520. it.
26521. 
26522. "You mustn't think we'll be in anyone's way, Uncle," she said. "We'll go
26523. to our places and won't budge."
26524. 
26525. "A good thing too, little countess," said "Uncle," "only mind you don't
26526. fall off your horse," he added, "because--that's it, come on!--you've
26527. nothing to hold on to."
26528. 
26529. The oasis of the Otradnoe covert came in sight a few hundred yards off,
26530. the huntsmen were already nearing it. Rostov, having finally settled
26531. with "Uncle" where they should set on the hounds, and having shown
26532. Natasha where she was to stand--a spot where nothing could possibly run
26533. out--went round above the ravine.
26534. 
26535. "Well, nephew, you're going for a big wolf," said "Uncle." "Mind and
26536. don't let her slip!"
26537. 
26538. "That's as may happen," answered Rostov. "Karay, here!" he shouted,
26539. answering "Uncle's" remark by this call to his borzoi. Karay was a
26540. shaggy old dog with a hanging jowl, famous for having tackled a big wolf
26541. unaided. They all took up their places.
26542. 
26543. The old count, knowing his son's ardor in the hunt, hurried so as not
26544. to be late, and the huntsmen had not yet reached their places when Count
26545. Ilya Rostov, cheerful, flushed, and with quivering cheeks, drove up
26546. with his black horses over the winter rye to the place reserved for him,
26547. where a wolf might come out. Having straightened his coat and fastened
26548. on his hunting knives and horn, he mounted his good, sleek, well-fed,
26549. and comfortable horse, Viflyanka, which was turning gray, like himself.
26550. His horses and trap were sent home. Count Ilya Rostov, though not at
26551. heart a keen sportsman, knew the rules of the hunt well, and rode to
26552. the bushy edge of the road where he was to stand, arranged his reins,
26553. settled himself in the saddle, and, feeling that he was ready, looked
26554. about with a smile.
26555. 
26556. Beside him was Simon Chekmar, his personal attendant, an old horseman
26557. now somewhat stiff in the saddle. Chekmar held in leash three formidable
26558. wolfhounds, who had, however, grown fat like their master and his horse.
26559. Two wise old dogs lay down unleashed. Some hundred paces farther along
26560. the edge of the wood stood Mitka, the count's other groom, a daring
26561. horseman and keen rider to hounds. Before the hunt, by old custom, the
26562. count had drunk a silver cupful of mulled brandy, taken a snack, and
26563. washed it down with half a bottle of his favorite Bordeaux.
26564. 
26565. He was somewhat flushed with the wine and the drive. His eyes were
26566. rather moist and glittered more than usual, and as he sat in his saddle,
26567. wrapped up in his fur coat, he looked like a child taken out for an
26568. outing.
26569. 
26570. The thin, hollow-cheeked Chekmar, having got everything ready, kept
26571. glancing at his master with whom he had lived on the best of terms for
26572. thirty years, and understanding the mood he was in expected a pleasant
26573. chat. A third person rode up circumspectly through the wood (it was
26574. plain that he had had a lesson) and stopped behind the count. This
26575. person was a gray-bearded old man in a woman's cloak, with a tall
26576. peaked cap on his head. He was the buffoon, who went by a woman's name,
26577. Nastasya Ivanovna.
26578. 
26579. "Well, Nastasya Ivanovna!" whispered the count, winking at him. "If you
26580. scare away the beast, Daniel'll give it you!"
26581. 
26582. "I know a thing or two myself!" said Nastasya Ivanovna.
26583. 
26584. "Hush!" whispered the count and turned to Simon. "Have you seen the
26585. young countess?" he asked. "Where is she?"
26586. 
26587. "With young Count Peter, by the Zharov rank grass," answered Simon,
26588. smiling. "Though she's a lady, she's very fond of hunting."
26589. 
26590. "And you're surprised at the way she rides, Simon, eh?" said the count.
26591. "She's as good as many a man!"
26592. 
26593. "Of course! It's marvelous. So bold, so easy!"
26594. 
26595. "And Nicholas? Where is he? By the Lyadov upland, isn't he?"
26596. 
26597. "Yes, sir. He knows where to stand. He understands the matter so well
26598. that Daniel and I are often quite astounded," said Simon, well knowing
26599. what would please his master.
26600. 
26601. "Rides well, eh? And how well he looks on his horse, eh?"
26602. 
26603. "A perfect picture! How he chased a fox out of the rank grass by the
26604. Zavarzinsk thicket the other day! Leaped a fearful place; what a sight
26605. when they rushed from the covert... the horse worth a thousand rubles
26606. and the rider beyond all price! Yes, one would have to search far to
26607. find another as smart."
26608. 
26609. "To search far..." repeated the count, evidently sorry Simon had not
26610. said more. "To search far," he said, turning back the skirt of his coat
26611. to get at his snuffbox.
26612. 
26613. "The other day when he came out from Mass in full uniform, Michael
26614. Sidorych..." Simon did not finish, for on the still air he had
26615. distinctly caught the music of the hunt with only two or three hounds
26616. giving tongue. He bent down his head and listened, shaking a warning
26617. finger at his master. "They are on the scent of the cubs..." he
26618. whispered, "straight to the Lyadov uplands."
26619. 
26620. The count, forgetting to smooth out the smile on his face, looked into
26621. the distance straight before him, down the narrow open space, holding
26622. the snuffbox in his hand but not taking any. After the cry of the hounds
26623. came the deep tones of the wolf call from Daniel's hunting horn; the
26624. pack joined the first three hounds and they could be heard in full cry,
26625. with that peculiar lift in the note that indicates that they are after
26626. a wolf. The whippers-in no longer set on the hounds, but changed to the
26627. cry of ulyulyu, and above the others rose Daniel's voice, now a deep
26628. bass, now piercingly shrill. His voice seemed to fill the whole wood and
26629. carried far beyond out into the open field.
26630. 
26631. After listening a few moments in silence, the count and his attendant
26632. convinced themselves that the hounds had separated into two packs: the
26633. sound of the larger pack, eagerly giving tongue, began to die away in
26634. the distance, the other pack rushed by the wood past the count, and it
26635. was with this that Daniel's voice was heard calling ulyulyu. The sounds
26636. of both packs mingled and broke apart again, but both were becoming more
26637. distant.
26638. 
26639. Simon sighed and stooped to straighten the leash a young borzoi had
26640. entangled; the count too sighed and, noticing the snuffbox in his hand,
26641. opened it and took a pinch. "Back!" cried Simon to a borzoi that was
26642. pushing forward out of the wood. The count started and dropped the
26643. snuffbox. Nastasya Ivanovna dismounted to pick it up. The count and
26644. Simon were looking at him.
26645. 
26646. Then, unexpectedly, as often happens, the sound of the hunt suddenly
26647. approached, as if the hounds in full cry and Daniel ulyulyuing were just
26648. in front of them.
26649. 
26650. The count turned and saw on his right Mitka staring at him with eyes
26651. starting out of his head, raising his cap and pointing before him to the
26652. other side.
26653. 
26654. "Look out!" he shouted, in a voice plainly showing that he had long
26655. fretted to utter that word, and letting the borzois slip he galloped
26656. toward the count.
26657. 
26658. The count and Simon galloped out of the wood and saw on their left a
26659. wolf which, softly swaying from side to side, was coming at a quiet
26660. lope farther to the left to the very place where they were standing.
26661. The angry borzois whined and getting free of the leash rushed past the
26662. horses' feet at the wolf.
26663. 
26664. The wolf paused, turned its heavy forehead toward the dogs awkwardly,
26665. like a man suffering from the quinsy, and, still slightly swaying
26666. from side to side, gave a couple of leaps and with a swish of its tail
26667. disappeared into the skirt of the wood. At the same instant, with a cry
26668. like a wail, first one hound, then another, and then another, sprang
26669. helter-skelter from the wood opposite and the whole pack rushed across
26670. the field toward the very spot where the wolf had disappeared. The hazel
26671. bushes parted behind the hounds and Daniel's chestnut horse appeared,
26672. dark with sweat. On its long back sat Daniel, hunched forward, capless,
26673. his disheveled gray hair hanging over his flushed, perspiring face.
26674. 
26675. "Ulyulyulyu! ulyulyu!..." he cried. When he caught sight of the count
26676. his eyes flashed lightning.
26677. 
26678. "Blast you!" he shouted, holding up his whip threateningly at the count.
26679. 
26680. "You've let the wolf go!... What sportsmen!" and as if scorning to
26681. say more to the frightened and shamefaced count, he lashed the heaving
26682. flanks of his sweating chestnut gelding with all the anger the count
26683. had aroused and flew off after the hounds. The count, like a punished
26684. schoolboy, looked round, trying by a smile to win Simon's sympathy for
26685. his plight. But Simon was no longer there. He was galloping round by the
26686. bushes while the field was coming up on both sides, all trying to head
26687. the wolf, but it vanished into the wood before they could do so.
26688. 
26689. 
26690. 
26691. 
26692. 
26693. CHAPTER V
26694. 
26695. 
26696. Nicholas Rostov meanwhile remained at his post, waiting for the wolf. By
26697. the way the hunt approached and receded, by the cries of the dogs
26698. whose notes were familiar to him, by the way the voices of the huntsmen
26699. approached, receded, and rose, he realized what was happening at the
26700. copse. He knew that young and old wolves were there, that the hounds had
26701. separated into two packs, that somewhere a wolf was being chased, and
26702. that something had gone wrong. He expected the wolf to come his way any
26703. moment. He made thousands of different conjectures as to where and
26704. from what side the beast would come and how he would set upon it. Hope
26705. alternated with despair. Several times he addressed a prayer to God
26706. that the wolf should come his way. He prayed with that passionate and
26707. shamefaced feeling with which men pray at moments of great excitement
26708. arising from trivial causes. "What would it be to Thee to do this for
26709. me?" he said to God. "I know Thou art great, and that it is a sin to ask
26710. this of Thee, but for God's sake do let the old wolf come my way and
26711. let Karay spring at it--in sight of 'Uncle' who is watching from over
26712. there--and seize it by the throat in a death grip!" A thousand times
26713. during that half-hour Rostov cast eager and restless glances over the
26714. edge of the wood, with the two scraggy oaks rising above the aspen
26715. undergrowth and the gully with its water-worn side and "Uncle's" cap
26716. just visible above the bush on his right.
26717. 
26718. "No, I shan't have such luck," thought Rostov, "yet what wouldn't it
26719. be worth! It is not to be! Everywhere, at cards and in war, I am always
26720. unlucky." Memories of Austerlitz and of Dolokhov flashed rapidly and
26721. clearly through his mind. "Only once in my life to get an old wolf, I
26722. want only that!" thought he, straining eyes and ears and looking to the
26723. left and then to the right and listening to the slightest variation of
26724. note in the cries of the dogs.
26725. 
26726. Again he looked to the right and saw something running toward him across
26727. the deserted field. "No, it can't be!" thought Rostov, taking a deep
26728. breath, as a man does at the coming of something long hoped for. The
26729. height of happiness was reached--and so simply, without warning, or
26730. noise, or display, that Rostov could not believe his eyes and remained
26731. in doubt for over a second. The wolf ran forward and jumped heavily over
26732. a gully that lay in her path. She was an old animal with a gray back and
26733. big reddish belly. She ran without hurry, evidently feeling sure that
26734. no one saw her. Rostov, holding his breath, looked round at the borzois.
26735. They stood or lay not seeing the wolf or understanding the situation.
26736. Old Karay had turned his head and was angrily searching for fleas,
26737. baring his yellow teeth and snapping at his hind legs.
26738. 
26739. "Ulyulyulyu!" whispered Rostov, pouting his lips. The borzois jumped up,
26740. jerking the rings of the leashes and pricking their ears. Karay finished
26741. scratching his hindquarters and, cocking his ears, got up with quivering
26742. tail from which tufts of matted hair hung down.
26743. 
26744. "Shall I loose them or not?" Nicholas asked himself as the wolf
26745. approached him coming from the copse. Suddenly the wolf's whole
26746. physiognomy changed: she shuddered, seeing what she had probably never
26747. seen before--human eyes fixed upon her--and turning her head a little
26748. toward Rostov, she paused.
26749. 
26750. "Back or forward? Eh, no matter, forward..." the wolf seemed to say to
26751. herself, and she moved forward without again looking round and with a
26752. quiet, long, easy yet resolute lope.
26753. 
26754. "Ulyulyu!" cried Nicholas, in a voice not his own, and of its own accord
26755. his good horse darted headlong downhill, leaping over gullies to head
26756. off the wolf, and the borzois passed it, running faster still. Nicholas
26757. did not hear his own cry nor feel that he was galloping, nor see the
26758. borzois, nor the ground over which he went: he saw only the wolf, who,
26759. increasing her speed, bounded on in the same direction along the hollow.
26760. The first to come into view was Milka, with her black markings and
26761. powerful quarters, gaining upon the wolf. Nearer and nearer... now she
26762. was ahead of it; but the wolf turned its head to face her, and instead
26763. of putting on speed as she usually did Milka suddenly raised her tail
26764. and stiffened her forelegs.
26765. 
26766. "Ulyulyulyulyu!" shouted Nicholas.
26767. 
26768. The reddish Lyubim rushed forward from behind Milka, sprang impetuously
26769. at the wolf, and seized it by its hindquarters, but immediately jumped
26770. aside in terror. The wolf crouched, gnashed her teeth, and again rose
26771. and bounded forward, followed at the distance of a couple of feet by all
26772. the borzois, who did not get any closer to her.
26773. 
26774. "She'll get away! No, it's impossible!" thought Nicholas, still shouting
26775. with a hoarse voice.
26776. 
26777. "Karay, ulyulyu!..." he shouted, looking round for the old borzoi who
26778. was now his only hope. Karay, with all the strength age had left him,
26779. stretched himself to the utmost and, watching the wolf, galloped heavily
26780. aside to intercept it. But the quickness of the wolf's lope and the
26781. borzoi's slower pace made it plain that Karay had miscalculated.
26782. Nicholas could already see not far in front of him the wood where the
26783. wolf would certainly escape should she reach it. But, coming toward
26784. him, he saw hounds and a huntsman galloping almost straight at the wolf.
26785. There was still hope. A long, yellowish young borzoi, one Nicholas did
26786. not know, from another leash, rushed impetuously at the wolf from in
26787. front and almost knocked her over. But the wolf jumped up more quickly
26788. than anyone could have expected and, gnashing her teeth, flew at the
26789. yellowish borzoi, which, with a piercing yelp, fell with its head on the
26790. ground, bleeding from a gash in its side.
26791. 
26792. "Karay? Old fellow!..." wailed Nicholas.
26793. 
26794. Thanks to the delay caused by this crossing of the wolf's path, the old
26795. dog with its felted hair hanging from its thigh was within five paces of
26796. it. As if aware of her danger, the wolf turned her eyes on Karay, tucked
26797. her tail yet further between her legs, and increased her speed. But
26798. here Nicholas only saw that something happened to Karay--the borzoi was
26799. suddenly on the wolf, and they rolled together down into a gully just in
26800. front of them.
26801. 
26802. That instant, when Nicholas saw the wolf struggling in the gully
26803. with the dogs, while from under them could be seen her gray hair and
26804. outstretched hind leg and her frightened choking head, with her ears
26805. laid back (Karay was pinning her by the throat), was the happiest moment
26806. of his life. With his hand on his saddlebow, he was ready to dismount
26807. and stab the wolf, when she suddenly thrust her head up from among that
26808. mass of dogs, and then her forepaws were on the edge of the gully. She
26809. clicked her teeth (Karay no longer had her by the throat), leaped with
26810. a movement of her hind legs out of the gully, and having disengaged
26811. herself from the dogs, with tail tucked in again, went forward. Karay,
26812. his hair bristling, and probably bruised or wounded, climbed with
26813. difficulty out of the gully.
26814. 
26815. "Oh my God! Why?" Nicholas cried in despair.
26816. 
26817. "Uncle's" huntsman was galloping from the other side across the wolf's
26818. path and his borzois once more stopped the animal's advance. She was
26819. again hemmed in.
26820. 
26821. Nicholas and his attendant, with "Uncle" and his huntsman, were all
26822. riding round the wolf, crying "ulyulyu!" shouting and preparing to
26823. dismount each moment that the wolf crouched back, and starting forward
26824. again every time she shook herself and moved toward the wood where she
26825. would be safe.
26826. 
26827. Already, at the beginning of this chase, Daniel, hearing the ulyulyuing,
26828. had rushed out from the wood. He saw Karay seize the wolf, and checked
26829. his horse, supposing the affair to be over. But when he saw that the
26830. horsemen did not dismount and that the wolf shook herself and ran for
26831. safety, Daniel set his chestnut galloping, not at the wolf but straight
26832. toward the wood, just as Karay had run to cut the animal off. As a
26833. result of this, he galloped up to the wolf just when she had been
26834. stopped a second time by "Uncle's" borzois.
26835. 
26836. Daniel galloped up silently, holding a naked dagger in his left hand and
26837. thrashing the laboring sides of his chestnut horse with his whip as if
26838. it were a flail.
26839. 
26840. Nicholas neither saw nor heard Daniel until the chestnut, breathing
26841. heavily, panted past him, and he heard the fall of a body and saw Daniel
26842. lying on the wolf's back among the dogs, trying to seize her by the
