26843. ears. It was evident to the dogs, the hunters, and to the wolf herself
26844. that all was now over. The terrified wolf pressed back her ears and
26845. tried to rise, but the borzois stuck to her. Daniel rose a little, took
26846. a step, and with his whole weight, as if lying down to rest, fell on
26847. the wolf, seizing her by the ears. Nicholas was about to stab her, but
26848. Daniel whispered, "Don't! We'll gag her!" and, changing his position,
26849. set his foot on the wolf's neck. A stick was thrust between her jaws
26850. and she was fastened with a leash, as if bridled, her legs were bound
26851. together, and Daniel rolled her over once or twice from side to side.
26852. 
26853. With happy, exhausted faces, they laid the old wolf, alive, on a shying
26854. and snorting horse and, accompanied by the dogs yelping at her, took her
26855. to the place where they were all to meet. The hounds had killed two of
26856. the cubs and the borzois three. The huntsmen assembled with their booty
26857. and their stories, and all came to look at the wolf, which, with her
26858. broad-browed head hanging down and the bitten stick between her jaws,
26859. gazed with great glassy eyes at this crowd of dogs and men surrounding
26860. her. When she was touched, she jerked her bound legs and looked wildly
26861. yet simply at everybody. Old Count Rostov also rode up and touched the
26862. wolf.
26863. 
26864. "Oh, what a formidable one!" said he. "A formidable one, eh?" he asked
26865. Daniel, who was standing near.
26866. 
26867. "Yes, your excellency," answered Daniel, quickly doffing his cap.
26868. 
26869. The count remembered the wolf he had let slip and his encounter with
26870. Daniel.
26871. 
26872. "Ah, but you are a crusty fellow, friend!" said the count.
26873. 
26874. For sole reply Daniel gave him a shy, childlike, meek, and amiable
26875. smile.
26876. 
26877. 
26878. 
26879. 
26880. 
26881. CHAPTER VI
26882. 
26883. 
26884. The old count went home, and Natasha and Petya promised to return very
26885. soon, but as it was still early the hunt went farther. At midday
26886. they put the hounds into a ravine thickly overgrown with young trees.
26887. Nicholas standing in a fallow field could see all his whips.
26888. 
26889. Facing him lay a field of winter rye, there his own huntsman stood alone
26890. in a hollow behind a hazel bush. The hounds had scarcely been loosed
26891. before Nicholas heard one he knew, Voltorn, giving tongue at intervals;
26892. other hounds joined in, now pausing and now again giving tongue. A
26893. moment later he heard a cry from the wooded ravine that a fox had been
26894. found, and the whole pack, joining together, rushed along the ravine
26895. toward the ryefield and away from Nicholas.
26896. 
26897. He saw the whips in their red caps galloping along the edge of the
26898. ravine, he even saw the hounds, and was expecting a fox to show itself
26899. at any moment on the ryefield opposite.
26900. 
26901. The huntsman standing in the hollow moved and loosed his borzois, and
26902. Nicholas saw a queer, short-legged red fox with a fine brush going hard
26903. across the field. The borzois bore down on it.... Now they drew close
26904. to the fox which began to dodge between the field in sharper and sharper
26905. curves, trailing its brush, when suddenly a strange white borzoi dashed
26906. in followed by a black one, and everything was in confusion; the borzois
26907. formed a star-shaped figure, scarcely swaying their bodies and with
26908. tails turned away from the center of the group. Two huntsmen galloped up
26909. to the dogs; one in a red cap, the other, a stranger, in a green coat.
26910. 
26911. "What's this?" thought Nicholas. "Where's that huntsman from? He is not
26912. 'Uncle's' man."
26913. 
26914. The huntsmen got the fox, but stayed there a long time without strapping
26915. it to the saddle. Their horses, bridled and with high saddles, stood
26916. near them and there too the dogs were lying. The huntsmen waved their
26917. arms and did something to the fox. Then from that spot came the sound of
26918. a horn, with the signal agreed on in case of a fight.
26919. 
26920. "That's Ilagin's huntsman having a row with our Ivan," said Nicholas'
26921. groom.
26922. 
26923. Nicholas sent the man to call Natasha and Petya to him, and rode at a
26924. footpace to the place where the whips were getting the hounds together.
26925. Several of the field galloped to the spot where the fight was going on.
26926. 
26927. Nicholas dismounted, and with Natasha and Petya, who had ridden up,
26928. stopped near the hounds, waiting to see how the matter would end. Out of
26929. the bushes came the huntsman who had been fighting and rode toward
26930. his young master, with the fox tied to his crupper. While still at a
26931. distance he took off his cap and tried to speak respectfully, but he was
26932. pale and breathless and his face was angry. One of his eyes was black,
26933. but he probably was not even aware of it.
26934. 
26935. "What has happened?" asked Nicholas.
26936. 
26937. "A likely thing, killing a fox our dogs had hunted! And it was my gray
26938. bitch that caught it! Go to law, indeed!... He snatches at the fox! I
26939. gave him one with the fox. Here it is on my saddle! Do you want a taste
26940. of this?..." said the huntsman, pointing to his dagger and probably
26941. imagining himself still speaking to his foe.
26942. 
26943. Nicholas, not stopping to talk to the man, asked his sister and Petya to
26944. wait for him and rode to the spot where the enemy's, Ilagin's, hunting
26945. party was.
26946. 
26947. The victorious huntsman rode off to join the field, and there,
26948. surrounded by inquiring sympathizers, recounted his exploits.
26949. 
26950. The facts were that Ilagin, with whom the Rostovs had a quarrel and were
26951. at law, hunted over places that belonged by custom to the Rostovs, and
26952. had now, as if purposely, sent his men to the very woods the Rostovs
26953. were hunting and let his man snatch a fox their dogs had chased.
26954. 
26955. Nicholas, though he had never seen Ilagin, with his usual absence
26956. of moderation in judgment, hated him cordially from reports of his
26957. arbitrariness and violence, and regarded him as his bitterest foe. He
26958. rode in angry agitation toward him, firmly grasping his whip and fully
26959. prepared to take the most resolute and desperate steps to punish his
26960. enemy.
26961. 
26962. Hardly had he passed an angle of the wood before a stout gentleman in
26963. a beaver cap came riding toward him on a handsome raven-black horse,
26964. accompanied by two hunt servants.
26965. 
26966. Instead of an enemy, Nicholas found in Ilagin a stately and courteous
26967. gentleman who was particularly anxious to make the young count's
26968. acquaintance. Having ridden up to Nicholas, Ilagin raised his beaver
26969. cap and said he much regretted what had occurred and would have the man
26970. punished who had allowed himself to seize a fox hunted by someone else's
26971. borzois. He hoped to become better acquainted with the count and invited
26972. him to draw his covert.
26973. 
26974. Natasha, afraid that her brother would do something dreadful, had
26975. followed him in some excitement. Seeing the enemies exchanging friendly
26976. greetings, she rode up to them. Ilagin lifted his beaver cap still
26977. higher to Natasha and said, with a pleasant smile, that the young
26978. countess resembled Diana in her passion for the chase as well as in her
26979. beauty, of which he had heard much.
26980. 
26981. To expiate his huntsman's offense, Ilagin pressed the Rostovs to come to
26982. an upland of his about a mile away which he usually kept for himself and
26983. which, he said, swarmed with hares. Nicholas agreed, and the hunt, now
26984. doubled, moved on.
26985. 
26986. The way to Iligin's upland was across the fields. The hunt servants fell
26987. into line. The masters rode together. "Uncle," Rostov, and Ilagin kept
26988. stealthily glancing at one another's dogs, trying not to be observed by
26989. their companions and searching uneasily for rivals to their own borzois.
26990. 
26991. Rostov was particularly struck by the beauty of a small, pure-bred,
26992. red-spotted bitch on Ilagin's leash, slender but with muscles like
26993. steel, a delicate muzzle, and prominent black eyes. He had heard of the
26994. swiftness of Ilagin's borzois, and in that beautiful bitch saw a rival
26995. to his own Milka.
26996. 
26997. In the middle of a sober conversation begun by Ilagin about the year's
26998. harvest, Nicholas pointed to the red-spotted bitch.
26999. 
27000. "A fine little bitch, that!" said he in a careless tone. "Is she swift?"
27001. 
27002. "That one? Yes, she's a good dog, gets what she's after," answered
27003. Ilagin indifferently, of the red-spotted bitch Erza, for which, a year
27004. before, he had given a neighbor three families of house serfs. "So in
27005. your parts, too, the harvest is nothing to boast of, Count?" he went on,
27006. continuing the conversation they had begun. And considering it polite
27007. to return the young count's compliment, Ilagin looked at his borzois
27008. and picked out Milka who attracted his attention by her breadth. "That
27009. black-spotted one of yours is fine--well shaped!" said he.
27010. 
27011. "Yes, she's fast enough," replied Nicholas, and thought: "If only a
27012. full-grown hare would cross the field now I'd show you what sort of
27013. borzoi she is," and turning to his groom, he said he would give a ruble
27014. to anyone who found a hare.
27015. 
27016. "I don't understand," continued Ilagin, "how some sportsmen can be so
27017. jealous about game and dogs. For myself, I can tell you, Count, I enjoy
27018. riding in company such as this... what could be better?" (he again
27019. raised his cap to Natasha) "but as for counting skins and what one
27020. takes, I don't care about that."
27021. 
27022. "Of course not!"
27023. 
27024. "Or being upset because someone else's borzoi and not mine catches
27025. something. All I care about is to enjoy seeing the chase, is it not so,
27026. Count? For I consider that..."
27027. 
27028. "A-tu!" came the long-drawn cry of one of the borzoi whippers-in, who
27029. had halted. He stood on a knoll in the stubble, holding his whip aloft,
27030. and again repeated his long-drawn cry, "A-tu!" (This call and the
27031. uplifted whip meant that he saw a sitting hare.)
27032. 
27033. "Ah, he has found one, I think," said Ilagin carelessly. "Yes, we must
27034. ride up.... Shall we both course it?" answered Nicholas, seeing in Erza
27035. and "Uncle's" red Rugay two rivals he had never yet had a chance of
27036. pitting against his own borzois. "And suppose they outdo my Milka at
27037. once!" he thought as he rode with "Uncle" and Ilagin toward the hare.
27038. 
27039. "A full-grown one?" asked Ilagin as he approached the whip who had
27040. sighted the hare--and not without agitation he looked round and whistled
27041. to Erza.
27042. 
27043. "And you, Michael Nikanorovich?" he said, addressing "Uncle."
27044. 
27045. The latter was riding with a sullen expression on his face.
27046. 
27047. "How can I join in? Why, you've given a village for each of your
27048. borzois! That's it, come on! Yours are worth thousands. Try yours
27049. against one another, you two, and I'll look on!"
27050. 
27051. "Rugay, hey, hey!" he shouted. "Rugayushka!" he added, involuntarily by
27052. this diminutive expressing his affection and the hopes he placed on this
27053. red borzoi. Natasha saw and felt the agitation the two elderly men and
27054. her brother were trying to conceal, and was herself excited by it.
27055. 
27056. The huntsman stood halfway up the knoll holding up his whip and the
27057. gentlefolk rode up to him at a footpace; the hounds that were far off
27058. on the horizon turned away from the hare, and the whips, but not the
27059. gentlefolk, also moved away. All were moving slowly and sedately.
27060. 
27061. "How is it pointing?" asked Nicholas, riding a hundred paces toward the
27062. whip who had sighted the hare.
27063. 
27064. But before the whip could reply, the hare, scenting the frost coming
27065. next morning, was unable to rest and leaped up. The pack on leash rushed
27066. downhill in full cry after the hare, and from all sides the borzois that
27067. were not on leash darted after the hounds and the hare. All the hunt,
27068. who had been moving slowly, shouted, "Stop!" calling in the hounds,
27069. while the borzoi whips, with a cry of "A-tu!" galloped across the field
27070. setting the borzois on the hare. The tranquil Ilagin, Nicholas, Natasha,
27071. and "Uncle" flew, reckless of where and how they went, seeing only the
27072. borzois and the hare and fearing only to lose sight even for an instant
27073. of the chase. The hare they had started was a strong and swift one. When
27074. he jumped up he did not run at once, but pricked his ears listening to
27075. the shouting and trampling that resounded from all sides at once. He
27076. took a dozen bounds, not very quickly, letting the borzois gain on him,
27077. and, finally having chosen his direction and realized his danger, laid
27078. back his ears and rushed off headlong. He had been lying in the stubble,
27079. but in front of him was the autumn sowing where the ground was soft.
27080. The two borzois of the huntsman who had sighted him, having been the
27081. nearest, were the first to see and pursue him, but they had not gone far
27082. before Ilagin's red-spotted Erza passed them, got within a length, flew
27083. at the hare with terrible swiftness aiming at his scut, and, thinking
27084. she had seized him, rolled over like a ball. The hare arched his
27085. back and bounded off yet more swiftly. From behind Erza rushed the
27086. broad-haunched, black-spotted Milka and began rapidly gaining on the
27087. hare.
27088. 
27089. "Milashka, dear!" rose Nicholas' triumphant cry. It looked as if Milka
27090. would immediately pounce on the hare, but she overtook him and flew
27091. past. The hare had squatted. Again the beautiful Erza reached him, but
27092. when close to the hare's scut paused as if measuring the distance, so as
27093. not to make a mistake this time but seize his hind leg.
27094. 
27095. "Erza, darling!" Ilagin wailed in a voice unlike his own. Erza did not
27096. hearken to his appeal. At the very moment when she would have seized her
27097. prey, the hare moved and darted along the balk between the winter rye
27098. and the stubble. Again Erza and Milka were abreast, running like a pair
27099. of carriage horses, and began to overtake the hare, but it was easier
27100. for the hare to run on the balk and the borzois did not overtake him so
27101. quickly.
27102. 
27103. "Rugay, Rugayushka! That's it, come on!" came a third voice just then,
27104. and "Uncle's" red borzoi, straining and curving its back, caught up
27105. with the two foremost borzois, pushed ahead of them regardless of the
27106. terrible strain, put on speed close to the hare, knocked it off the balk
27107. onto the ryefield, again put on speed still more viciously, sinking to
27108. his knees in the muddy field, and all one could see was how, muddying
27109. his back, he rolled over with the hare. A ring of borzois surrounded
27110. him. A moment later everyone had drawn up round the crowd of dogs. Only
27111. the delighted "Uncle" dismounted, and cut off a pad, shaking the hare
27112. for the blood to drip off, and anxiously glancing round with restless
27113. eyes while his arms and legs twitched. He spoke without himself knowing
27114. whom to or what about. "That's it, come on! That's a dog!... There,
27115. it has beaten them all, the thousand-ruble as well as the one-ruble
27116. borzois. That's it, come on!" said he, panting and looking wrathfully
27117. around as if he were abusing someone, as if they were all his enemies
27118. and had insulted him, and only now had he at last succeeded in
27119. justifying himself. "There are your thousand-ruble ones.... That's it,
27120. come on!..."
27121. 
27122. "Rugay, here's a pad for you!" he said, throwing down the hare's muddy
27123. pad. "You've deserved it, that's it, come on!"
27124. 
27125. "She'd tired herself out, she'd run it down three times by herself,"
27126. said Nicholas, also not listening to anyone and regardless of whether he
27127. were heard or not.
27128. 
27129. "But what is there in running across it like that?" said Ilagin's groom.
27130. 
27131. "Once she had missed it and turned it away, any mongrel could take it,"
27132. Ilagin was saying at the same time, breathless from his gallop and his
27133. excitement. At the same moment Natasha, without drawing breath, screamed
27134. joyously, ecstatically, and so piercingly that it set everyone's ear
27135. tingling. By that shriek she expressed what the others expressed by all
27136. talking at once, and it was so strange that she must herself have been
27137. ashamed of so wild a cry and everyone else would have been amazed at it
27138. at any other time. "Uncle" himself twisted up the hare, threw it neatly
27139. and smartly across his horse's back as if by that gesture he meant to
27140. rebuke everybody, and, with an air of not wishing to speak to anyone,
27141. mounted his bay and rode off. The others all followed, dispirited and
27142. shamefaced, and only much later were they able to regain their former
27143. affectation of indifference. For a long time they continued to look at
27144. red Rugay who, his arched back spattered with mud and clanking the ring
27145. of his leash, walked along just behind "Uncle's" horse with the serene
27146. air of a conqueror.
27147. 
27148. "Well, I am like any other dog as long as it's not a question of
27149. coursing. But when it is, then look out!" his appearance seemed to
27150. Nicholas to be saying.
27151. 
27152. When, much later, "Uncle" rode up to Nicholas and began talking to him,
27153. he felt flattered that, after what had happened, "Uncle" deigned to
27154. speak to him.
27155. 
27156. 
27157. 
27158. 
27159. 
27160. CHAPTER VII
27161. 
27162. 
27163. Toward evening Ilagin took leave of Nicholas, who found that they were
27164. so far from home that he accepted "Uncle's" offer that the hunting party
27165. should spend the night in his little village of Mikhaylovna.
27166. 
27167. "And if you put up at my house that will be better still. That's it,
27168. come on!" said "Uncle." "You see it's damp weather, and you could rest,
27169. and the little countess could be driven home in a trap."
27170. 
27171. "Uncle's" offer was accepted. A huntsman was sent to Otradnoe for a
27172. trap, while Nicholas rode with Natasha and Petya to "Uncle's" house.
27173. 
27174. Some five male domestic serfs, big and little, rushed out to the front
27175. porch to meet their master. A score of women serfs, old and young, as
27176. well as children, popped out from the back entrance to have a look at
27177. the hunters who were arriving. The presence of Natasha--a woman, a lady,
27178. and on horseback--raised the curiosity of the serfs to such a degree
27179. that many of them came up to her, stared her in the face, and unabashed
27180. by her presence made remarks about her as though she were some prodigy
27181. on show and not a human being able to hear or understand what was said
27182. about her.
27183. 
27184. "Arinka! Look, she sits sideways! There she sits and her skirt
27185. dangles.... See, she's got a little hunting horn!"
27186. 
27187. "Goodness gracious! See her knife?..."
27188. 
27189. "Isn't she a Tartar!"
27190. 
27191. "How is it you didn't go head over heels?" asked the boldest of all,
27192. addressing Natasha directly.
27193. 
27194. "Uncle" dismounted at the porch of his little wooden house which
27195. stood in the midst of an overgrown garden and, after a glance at his
27196. retainers, shouted authoritatively that the superfluous ones should take
27197. themselves off and that all necessary preparations should be made to
27198. receive the guests and the visitors.
27199. 
27200. The serfs all dispersed. "Uncle" lifted Natasha off her horse and taking
27201. her hand led her up the rickety wooden steps of the porch. The house,
27202. with its bare, unplastered log walls, was not overclean--it did not seem
27203. that those living in it aimed at keeping it spotless--but neither was
27204. it noticeably neglected. In the entry there was a smell of fresh apples,
27205. and wolf and fox skins hung about.
27206. 
27207. "Uncle" led the visitors through the anteroom into a small hall with a
27208. folding table and red chairs, then into the drawing room with a round
27209. birchwood table and a sofa, and finally into his private room where
27210. there was a tattered sofa, a worn carpet, and portraits of Suvorov, of
27211. the host's father and mother, and of himself in military uniform. The
27212. study smelt strongly of tobacco and dogs. "Uncle" asked his visitors
27213. to sit down and make themselves at home, and then went out of the room.
27214. Rugay, his back still muddy, came into the room and lay down on the
27215. sofa, cleaning himself with his tongue and teeth. Leading from the study
27216. was a passage in which a partition with ragged curtains could be seen.
27217. From behind this came women's laughter and whispers. Natasha, Nicholas,
27218. and Petya took off their wraps and sat down on the sofa. Petya, leaning
27219. on his elbow, fell asleep at once. Natasha and Nicholas were silent.
27220. Their faces glowed, they were hungry and very cheerful. They looked
27221. at one another (now that the hunt was over and they were in the house,
27222. Nicholas no longer considered it necessary to show his manly superiority
27223. over his sister), Natasha gave him a wink, and neither refrained long
27224. from bursting into a peal of ringing laughter even before they had a
27225. pretext ready to account for it.
27226. 
27227. After a while "Uncle" came in, in a Cossack coat, blue trousers, and
27228. small top boots. And Natasha felt that this costume, the very one she
27229. had regarded with surprise and amusement at Otradnoe, was just the right
27230. thing and not at all worse than a swallow-tail or frock coat. "Uncle"
27231. too was in high spirits and far from being offended by the brother's
27232. and sister's laughter (it could never enter his head that they might be
27233. laughing at his way of life) he himself joined in the merriment.
27234. 
27235. "That's right, young countess, that's it, come on! I never saw anyone
27236. like her!" said he, offering Nicholas a pipe with a long stem and, with
27237. a practiced motion of three fingers, taking down another that had been
27238. cut short. "She's ridden all day like a man, and is as fresh as ever!"
27239. 
27240. Soon after "Uncle's" reappearance the door was opened, evidently from
27241. the sound by a barefooted girl, and a stout, rosy, good-looking woman
27242. of about forty, with a double chin and full red lips, entered carrying a
27243. large loaded tray. With hospitable dignity and cordiality in her glance
27244. and in every motion, she looked at the visitors and, with a pleasant
27245. smile, bowed respectfully. In spite of her exceptional stoutness, which
27246. caused her to protrude her chest and stomach and throw back her head,
27247. this woman (who was "Uncle's" housekeeper) trod very lightly. She went
27248. to the table, set down the tray, and with her plump white hands deftly
27249. took from it the bottles and various hors d'oeuvres and dishes and
27250. arranged them on the table. When she had finished, she stepped aside and
27251. stopped at the door with a smile on her face. "Here I am. I am she! Now
27252. do you understand 'Uncle'?" her expression said to Rostov. How could one
27253. help understanding? Not only Nicholas, but even Natasha understood
27254. the meaning of his puckered brow and the happy complacent smile that
27255. slightly puckered his lips when Anisya Fedorovna entered. On the tray
27256. was a bottle of herb wine, different kinds of vodka, pickled mushrooms,
27257. rye cakes made with buttermilk, honey in the comb, still mead and
27258. sparkling mead, apples, nuts (raw and roasted), and nut-and-honey
27259. sweets. Afterwards she brought a freshly roasted chicken, ham, preserves
27260. made with honey, and preserves made with sugar.
27261. 
27262. All this was the fruit of Anisya Fedorovna's housekeeping, gathered and
27263. prepared by her. The smell and taste of it all had a smack of Anisya
27264. Fedorovna herself: a savor of juiciness, cleanliness, whiteness, and
27265. pleasant smiles.
27266. 
27267. "Take this, little Lady-Countess!" she kept saying, as she offered
27268. Natasha first one thing and then another.
27269. 
27270. Natasha ate of everything and thought she had never seen or eaten such
27271. buttermilk cakes, such aromatic jam, such honey-and-nut sweets, or such
27272. a chicken anywhere. Anisya Fedorovna left the room.
27273. 
27274. After supper, over their cherry brandy, Rostov and "Uncle" talked of
27275. past and future hunts, of Rugay and Ilagin's dogs, while Natasha sat
27276. upright on the sofa and listened with sparkling eyes. She tried several
27277. times to wake Petya that he might eat something, but he only muttered
27278. incoherent words without waking up. Natasha felt so lighthearted and
27279. happy in these novel surroundings that she only feared the trap would
27280. come for her too soon. After a casual pause, such as often occurs
27281. when receiving friends for the first time in one's own house, "Uncle,"
27282. answering a thought that was in his visitors' mind, said:
27283. 
27284. "This, you see, is how I am finishing my days... Death will come. That's
27285. it, come on! Nothing will remain. Then why harm anyone?"
27286. 
27287. "Uncle's" face was very significant and even handsome as he said this.
27288. Involuntarily Rostov recalled all the good he had heard about him from
27289. his father and the neighbors. Throughout the whole province "Uncle" had
27290. the reputation of being the most honorable and disinterested of cranks.
27291. They called him in to decide family disputes, chose him as executor,
27292. confided secrets to him, elected him to be a justice and to other posts;
27293. but he always persistently refused public appointments, passing the
27294. autumn and spring in the fields on his bay gelding, sitting at home in
27295. winter, and lying in his overgrown garden in summer.
27296. 
27297. "Why don't you enter the service, Uncle?"
27298. 
27299. "I did once, but gave it up. I am not fit for it. That's it, come on! I
27300. can't make head or tail of it. That's for you--I haven't brains enough.
27301. Now, hunting is another matter--that's it, come on! Open the door,
27302. there!" he shouted. "Why have you shut it?"
27303. 
27304. The door at the end of the passage led to the huntsmen's room, as they
27305. called the room for the hunt servants.
27306. 
27307. There was a rapid patter of bare feet, and an unseen hand opened the
27308. door into the huntsmen's room, from which came the clear sounds of a
27309. balalayka on which someone, who was evidently a master of the art, was
27310. playing. Natasha had been listening to those strains for some time and
27311. now went out into the passage to hear better.
27312. 
27313. "That's Mitka, my coachman.... I have got him a good balalayka. I'm fond
27314. of it," said "Uncle."
27315. 
27316. It was the custom for Mitka to play the balalayka in the huntsmen's room
27317. when "Uncle" returned from the chase. "Uncle" was fond of such music.
27318. 
27319. "How good! Really very good!" said Nicholas with some unintentional
27320. superciliousness, as if ashamed to confess that the sounds pleased him
27321. very much.
27322. 
27323. "Very good?" said Natasha reproachfully, noticing her brother's tone.
27324. "Not 'very good' it's simply delicious!"
27325. 
27326. Just as "Uncle's" pickled mushrooms, honey, and cherry brandy had seemed
27327. to her the best in the world, so also that song, at that moment, seemed
27328. to her the acme of musical delight.
27329. 
27330. "More, please, more!" cried Natasha at the door as soon as the balalayka
27331. ceased. Mitka tuned up afresh, and recommenced thrumming the balalayka
27332. to the air of My Lady, with trills and variations. "Uncle" sat
27333. listening, slightly smiling, with his head on one side. The air was
27334. repeated a hundred times. The balalayka was retuned several times and
27335. the same notes were thrummed again, but the listeners did not grow weary
27336. of it and wished to hear it again and again. Anisya Fedorovna came in
27337. and leaned her portly person against the doorpost.
27338. 
27339. "You like listening?" she said to Natasha, with a smile extremely like
27340. "Uncle's." "That's a good player of ours," she added.
27341. 
27342. "He doesn't play that part right!" said "Uncle" suddenly, with an
27343. energetic gesture. "Here he ought to burst out--that's it, come
27344. on!--ought to burst out."
27345. 
27346. "Do you play then?" asked Natasha.
27347. 
27348. "Uncle" did not answer, but smiled.
27349. 
27350. "Anisya, go and see if the strings of my guitar are all right. I haven't
27351. touched it for a long time. That's it--come on! I've given it up."
27352. 
27353. Anisya Fedorovna, with her light step, willingly went to fulfill her
27354. errand and brought back the guitar.
27355. 
27356. Without looking at anyone, "Uncle" blew the dust off it and, tapping the
27357. case with his bony fingers, tuned the guitar and settled himself in his
27358. armchair. He took the guitar a little above the fingerboard, arching
27359. his left elbow with a somewhat theatrical gesture, and, with a wink at
27360. Anisya Fedorovna, struck a single chord, pure and sonorous, and then
27361. quietly, smoothly, and confidently began playing in very slow time, not
27362. My Lady, but the well-known song: Came a maiden down the street. The
27363. tune, played with precision and in exact time, began to thrill in the
27364. hearts of Nicholas and Natasha, arousing in them the same kind of sober
27365. mirth as radiated from Anisya Fedorovna's whole being. Anisya Fedorovna
27366. flushed, and drawing her kerchief over her face went laughing out of
27367. the room. "Uncle" continued to play correctly, carefully, with energetic
27368. firmness, looking with a changed and inspired expression at the spot
27369. where Anisya Fedorovna had just stood. Something seemed to be laughing
27370. a little on one side of his face under his gray mustaches, especially as
27371. the song grew brisker and the time quicker and when, here and there, as
27372. he ran his fingers over the strings, something seemed to snap.
27373. 
27374. "Lovely, lovely! Go on, Uncle, go on!" shouted Natasha as soon as he had
27375. finished. She jumped up and hugged and kissed him. "Nicholas, Nicholas!"
27376. she said, turning to her brother, as if asking him: "What is it moves me
27377. so?"
27378. 
27379. Nicholas too was greatly pleased by "Uncle's" playing, and "Uncle"
27380. played the piece over again. Anisya Fedorovna's smiling face reappeared
27381. in the doorway and behind hers other faces...
27382. 
27383.     Fetching water clear and sweet,
27384.     Stop, dear maiden, I entreat--
27385. 
27386. played "Uncle" once more, running his fingers skillfully over the
27387. strings, and then he stopped short and jerked his shoulders.
27388. 
27389. "Go on, Uncle dear," Natasha wailed in an imploring tone as if her life
27390. depended on it.
27391. 
27392. "Uncle" rose, and it was as if there were two men in him: one of them
27393. smiled seriously at the merry fellow, while the merry fellow struck a
27394. naive and precise attitude preparatory to a folk dance.
27395. 
27396. "Now then, niece!" he exclaimed, waving to Natasha the hand that had
27397. just struck a chord.
27398. 
27399. Natasha threw off the shawl from her shoulders, ran forward to face
27400. "Uncle," and setting her arms akimbo also made a motion with her
27401. shoulders and struck an attitude.
27402. 
27403. Where, how, and when had this young countess, educated by an emigree
27404. French governess, imbibed from the Russian air she breathed that spirit
27405. and obtained that manner which the pas de chale * would, one would have
27406. supposed, long ago have effaced? But the spirit and the movements were
27407. those inimitable and unteachable Russian ones that "Uncle" had expected
27408. of her. As soon as she had struck her pose, and smiled triumphantly,
27409. proudly, and with sly merriment, the fear that had at first seized
27410. Nicholas and the others that she might not do the right thing was at an
27411. end, and they were already admiring her.
27412. 
27413. 
27414.     * The French shawl dance.
27415. 
27416. 
27417. She did the right thing with such precision, such complete precision,
27418. that Anisya Fedorovna, who had at once handed her the handkerchief she
27419. needed for the dance, had tears in her eyes, though she laughed as she
27420. watched this slim, graceful countess, reared in silks and velvets and so
27421. different from herself, who yet was able to understand all that was in
27422. Anisya and in Anisya's father and mother and aunt, and in every Russian
27423. man and woman.
27424. 
27425. "Well, little countess; that's it--come on!" cried "Uncle," with a
27426. joyous laugh, having finished the dance. "Well done, niece! Now a fine
27427. young fellow must be found as husband for you. That's it--come on!"
27428. 
27429. "He's chosen already," said Nicholas smiling.
27430. 
27431. "Oh?" said "Uncle" in surprise, looking inquiringly at Natasha, who
27432. nodded her head with a happy smile.
27433. 
27434. "And such a one!" she said. But as soon as she had said it a new train
27435. of thoughts and feelings arose in her. "What did Nicholas' smile mean
27436. when he said 'chosen already'? Is he glad of it or not? It is as if he
27437. thought my Bolkonski would not approve of or understand our gaiety. But
27438. he would understand it all. Where is he now?" she thought, and her face
27439. suddenly became serious. But this lasted only a second. "Don't dare
27440. to think about it," she said to herself, and sat down again smilingly
27441. beside "Uncle," begging him to play something more.
27442. 
27443. "Uncle" played another song and a valse; then after a pause he cleared
27444. his throat and sang his favorite hunting song:
27445. 
27446.     As 'twas growing dark last night
27447.     Fell the snow so soft and light...
27448. 
27449. 
27450. "Uncle" sang as peasants sing, with full and naive conviction that the
27451. whole meaning of a song lies in the words and that the tune comes of
27452. itself, and that apart from the words there is no tune, which exists
27453. only to give measure to the words. As a result of this the unconsidered
27454. tune, like the song of a bird, was extraordinarily good. Natasha was in
27455. ecstasies over "Uncle's" singing. She resolved to give up learning the
27456. harp and to play only the guitar. She asked "Uncle" for his guitar and
27457. at once found the chords of the song.
27458. 
27459. After nine o'clock two traps and three mounted men, who had been sent
27460. to look for them, arrived to fetch Natasha and Petya. The count and
27461. countess did not know where they were and were very anxious, said one of
27462. the men.
27463. 
27464. Petya was carried out like a log and laid in the larger of the two
27465. traps. Natasha and Nicholas got into the other. "Uncle" wrapped
27466. Natasha up warmly and took leave of her with quite a new tenderness. He
27467. accompanied them on foot as far as the bridge that could not be crossed,
27468. so that they had to go round by the ford, and he sent huntsmen to ride
27469. in front with lanterns.
27470. 
27471. "Good-by, dear niece," his voice called out of the darkness--not the
27472. voice Natasha had known previously, but the one that had sung As 'twas
27473. growing dark last night.
27474. 
27475. In the village through which they passed there were red lights and a
27476. cheerful smell of smoke.
27477. 
27478. "What a darling Uncle is!" said Natasha, when they had come out onto the
27479. highroad.
27480. 
27481. "Yes," returned Nicholas. "You're not cold?"
27482. 
27483. "No. I'm quite, quite all right. I feel so comfortable!" answered
27484. Natasha, almost perplexed by her feelings. They remained silent a long
27485. while. The night was dark and damp. They could not see the horses, but
27486. only heard them splashing through the unseen mud.
27487. 
27488. What was passing in that receptive childlike soul that so eagerly caught
27489. and assimilated all the diverse impressions of life? How did they all
27490. find place in her? But she was very happy. As they were nearing home she
27491. suddenly struck up the air of As 'twas growing dark last night--the tune
27492. of which she had all the way been trying to get and had at last caught.
27493. 
27494. "Got it?" said Nicholas.
27495. 
27496. "What were you thinking about just now, Nicholas?" inquired Natasha.
27497. 
27498. They were fond of asking one another that question.
27499. 
27500. "I?" said Nicholas, trying to remember. "Well, you see, first I thought
27501. that Rugay, the red hound, was like Uncle, and that if he were a man he
27502. would always keep Uncle near him, if not for his riding, then for his
27503. manner. What a good fellow Uncle is! Don't you think so?... Well, and
27504. you?"
27505. 
27506. "I? Wait a bit, wait.... Yes, first I thought that we are driving along
27507. and imagining that we are going home, but that heaven knows where we are
27508. really going in the darkness, and that we shall arrive and suddenly find
27509. that we are not in Otradnoe, but in Fairyland. And then I thought... No,
27510. nothing else."
27511. 
27512. "I know, I expect you thought of him," said Nicholas, smiling as Natasha
27513. knew by the sound of his voice.
27514. 
27515. "No," said Natasha, though she had in reality been thinking about Prince
27516. Andrew at the same time as of the rest, and of how he would have liked
27517. "Uncle." "And then I was saying to myself all the way, 'How well Anisya
27518. carried herself, how well!'" And Nicholas heard her spontaneous, happy,
27519. ringing laughter. "And do you know," she suddenly said, "I know that I
27520. shall never again be as happy and tranquil as I am now."
27521. 
27522. "Rubbish, nonsense, humbug!" exclaimed Nicholas, and he thought: "How
27523. charming this Natasha of mine is! I have no other friend like her and
27524. never shall have. Why should she marry? We might always drive about
27525. together!"
27526. 
27527. "What a darling this Nicholas of mine is!" thought Natasha.
27528. 
27529. "Ah, there are still lights in the drawingroom!" she said, pointing to
27530. the windows of the house that gleamed invitingly in the moist velvety
27531. darkness of the night.
27532. 
27533. 
27534. 
27535. 
27536. 
27537. CHAPTER VIII
27538. 
27539. 
27540. Count Ilya Rostov had resigned the position of Marshal of the Nobility
27541. because it involved him in too much expense, but still his affairs did
27542. not improve. Natasha and Nicholas often noticed their parents conferring
27543. together anxiously and privately and heard suggestions of selling the
27544. fine ancestral Rostov house and estate near Moscow. It was not necessary
27545. to entertain so freely as when the count had been Marshal, and life at
27546. Otradnoe was quieter than in former years, but still the enormous house
27547. and its lodges were full of people and more than twenty sat down to
27548. table every day. These were all their own people who had settled down
27549. in the house almost as members of the family, or persons who were, it
27550. seemed, obliged to live in the count's house. Such were Dimmler the
27551. musician and his wife, Vogel the dancing master and his family, Belova,
27552. an old maiden lady, an inmate of the house, and many others such as
27553. Petya's tutors, the girls' former governess, and other people who simply
27554. found it preferable and more advantageous to live in the count's house
27555. than at home. They had not as many visitors as before, but the old
27556. habits of life without which the count and countess could not
27557. conceive of existence remained unchanged. There was still the hunting
27558. establishment which Nicholas had even enlarged, the same fifty horses
27559. and fifteen grooms in the stables, the same expensive presents and
27560. dinner parties to the whole district on name days; there were still the
27561. count's games of whist and boston, at which--spreading out his cards so
27562. that everybody could see them--he let himself be plundered of hundreds
27563. of rubles every day by his neighbors, who looked upon an opportunity to
27564. play a rubber with Count Rostov as a most profitable source of income.
27565. 
27566. The count moved in his affairs as in a huge net, trying not to believe
27567. that he was entangled but becoming more and more so at every step, and
27568. feeling too feeble to break the meshes or to set to work carefully and
27569. patiently to disentangle them. The countess, with her loving heart, felt
27570. that her children were being ruined, that it was not the count's fault
27571. for he could not help being what he was--that (though he tried to
27572. hide it) he himself suffered from the consciousness of his own and his
27573. children's ruin, and she tried to find means of remedying the position.
27574. From her feminine point of view she could see only one solution, namely,
27575. for Nicholas to marry a rich heiress. She felt this to be their last
27576. hope and that if Nicholas refused the match she had found for him, she
27577. would have to abandon the hope of ever getting matters right. This match
27578. was with Julie Karagina, the daughter of excellent and virtuous parents,
27579. a girl the Rostovs had known from childhood, and who had now become a
27580. wealthy heiress through the death of the last of her brothers.
27581. 
27582. The countess had written direct to Julie's mother in Moscow suggesting a
27583. marriage between their children and had received a favorable answer
27584. from her. Karagina had replied that for her part she was agreeable, and
27585. everything depend on her daughter's inclination. She invited Nicholas to
27586. come to Moscow.
27587. 
27588. Several times the countess, with tears in her eyes, told her son that
27589. now both her daughters were settled, her only wish was to see him
27590. married. She said she could lie down in her grave peacefully if that
27591. were accomplished. Then she told him that she knew of a splendid girl
27592. and tried to discover what he thought about marriage.
27593. 
27594. At other times she praised Julie to him and advised him to go to Moscow
27595. during the holidays to amuse himself. Nicholas guessed what his mother's
27596. remarks were leading to and during one of these conversations induced
27597. her to speak quite frankly. She told him that her only hope of getting
27598. their affairs disentangled now lay in his marrying Julie Karagina.
27599. 
27600. "But, Mamma, suppose I loved a girl who has no fortune, would you expect
27601. me to sacrifice my feelings and my honor for the sake of money?" he
27602. asked his mother, not realizing the cruelty of his question and only
27603. wishing to show his noble-mindedness.
27604. 
27605. "No, you have not understood me," said his mother, not knowing how to
27606. justify herself. "You have not understood me, Nikolenka. It is your
27607. happiness I wish for," she added, feeling that she was telling an
27608. untruth and was becoming entangled. She began to cry.
27609. 
27610. "Mamma, don't cry! Only tell me that you wish it, and you know I will
27611. give my life, anything, to put you at ease," said Nicholas. "I would
27612. sacrifice anything for you--even my feelings."
27613. 
27614. But the countess did not want the question put like that: she did not
27615. want a sacrifice from her son, she herself wished to make a sacrifice
27616. for him.
27617. 
27618. "No, you have not understood me, don't let us talk about it," she
27619. replied, wiping away her tears.
27620. 
27621. "Maybe I do love a poor girl," said Nicholas to himself. "Am I to
27622. sacrifice my feelings and my honor for money? I wonder how Mamma could
27623. speak so to me. Because Sonya is poor I must not love her," he thought,
27624. "must not respond to her faithful, devoted love? Yet I should certainly
27625. be happier with her than with some doll-like Julie. I can always
27626. sacrifice my feelings for my family's welfare," he said to himself,
27627. "but I can't coerce my feelings. If I love Sonya, that feeling is for me
27628. stronger and higher than all else."
27629. 
27630. Nicholas did not go to Moscow, and the countess did not renew the
27631. conversation with him about marriage. She saw with sorrow, and sometimes
27632. with exasperation, symptoms of a growing attachment between her son and
27633. the portionless Sonya. Though she blamed herself for it, she could
27634. not refrain from grumbling at and worrying Sonya, often pulling her
27635. up without reason, addressing her stiffly as "my dear," and using the
27636. formal "you" instead of the intimate "thou" in speaking to her. The
27637. kindhearted countess was the more vexed with Sonya because that poor,
27638. dark-eyed niece of hers was so meek, so kind, so devotedly grateful to
27639. her benefactors, and so faithfully, unchangingly, and unselfishly in
27640. love with Nicholas, that there were no grounds for finding fault with
27641. her.
27642. 
27643. Nicholas was spending the last of his leave at home. A fourth letter had
27644. come from Prince Andrew, from Rome, in which he wrote that he would have
27645. been on his way back to Russia long ago had not his wound unexpectedly
27646. reopened in the warm climate, which obliged him to defer his return till
27647. the beginning of the new year. Natasha was still as much in love with
27648. her betrothed, found the same comfort in that love, and was still as
27649. ready to throw herself into all the pleasures of life as before; but at
27650. the end of the fourth month of their separation she began to have fits
27651. of depression which she could not master. She felt sorry for herself:
27652. sorry that she was being wasted all this time and of no use to
27653. anyone--while she felt herself so capable of loving and being loved.
27654. 
27655. Things were not cheerful in the Rostovs' home.
27656. 
27657. 
27658. 
27659. 
27660. 
27661. CHAPTER IX
27662. 
27663. 
27664. Christmas came and except for the ceremonial Mass, the solemn and
27665. wearisome Christmas congratulations from neighbors and servants, and the
27666. new dresses everyone put on, there were no special festivities, though
27667. the calm frost of twenty degrees Reaumur, the dazzling sunshine by day,
27668. and the starlight of the winter nights seemed to call for some special
27669. celebration of the season.
27670. 
27671. On the third day of Christmas week, after the midday dinner, all the
27672. inmates of the house dispersed to various rooms. It was the dullest time
27673. of the day. Nicholas, who had been visiting some neighbors that morning,
27674. was asleep on the sitting-room sofa. The old count was resting in his
27675. study. Sonya sat in the drawing room at the round table, copying a
27676. design for embroidery. The countess was playing patience. Nastasya
27677. Ivanovna the buffoon sat with a sad face at the window with two old
27678. ladies. Natasha came into the room, went up to Sonya, glanced at
27679. what she was doing, and then went up to her mother and stood without
27680. speaking.
27681. 
27682. "Why are you wandering about like an outcast?" asked her mother. "What
27683. do you want?"
27684. 
27685. "Him... I want him... now, this minute! I want him!" said Natasha, with
27686. glittering eyes and no sign of a smile.
27687. 
27688. The countess lifted her head and looked attentively at her daughter.
27689. 
27690. "Don't look at me, Mamma! Don't look; I shall cry directly."
27691. 
27692. "Sit down with me a little," said the countess.
27693. 
27694. "Mamma, I want him. Why should I be wasted like this, Mamma?"
27695. 
27696. Her voice broke, tears gushed from her eyes, and she turned quickly to
27697. hide them and left the room.
27698. 
27699. She passed into the sitting room, stood there thinking awhile, and then
27700. went into the maids' room. There an old maidservant was grumbling at a
27701. young girl who stood panting, having just run in through the cold from
27702. the serfs' quarters.
27703. 
27704. "Stop playing--there's a time for everything," said the old woman.
27705. 
27706. "Let her alone, Kondratevna," said Natasha. "Go, Mavrushka, go."
27707. 
27708. Having released Mavrushka, Natasha crossed the dancing hall and went
27709. to the vestibule. There an old footman and two young ones were playing
27710. cards. They broke off and rose as she entered.
27711. 
27712. "What can I do with them?" thought Natasha.
27713. 
27714. "Oh, Nikita, please go... where can I send him?... Yes, go to the yard
27715. and fetch a fowl, please, a cock, and you, Misha, bring me some oats."
27716. 
27717. "Just a few oats?" said Misha, cheerfully and readily.
27718. 
27719. "Go, go quickly," the old man urged him.
27720. 
27721. "And you, Theodore, get me a piece of chalk."
27722. 
27723. On her way past the butler's pantry she told them to set a samovar,
27724. though it was not at all the time for tea.
27725. 
27726. Foka, the butler, was the most ill-tempered person in the house. Natasha
27727. liked to test her power over him. He distrusted the order and asked
27728. whether the samovar was really wanted.
27729. 
27730. "Oh dear, what a young lady!" said Foka, pretending to frown at Natasha.
27731. 
27732. No one in the house sent people about or gave them as much trouble as
27733. Natasha did. She could not see people unconcernedly, but had to send
27734. them on some errand. She seemed to be trying whether any of them would
27735. get angry or sulky with her; but the serfs fulfilled no one's orders so
27736. readily as they did hers. "What can I do, where can I go?" thought she,
27737. as she went slowly along the passage.
27738. 
27739. "Nastasya Ivanovna, what sort of children shall I have?" she asked the
27740. buffoon, who was coming toward her in a woman's jacket.
27741. 
27742. "Why, fleas, crickets, grasshoppers," answered the buffoon.
27743. 
27744. "O Lord, O Lord, it's always the same! Oh, where am I to go? What am I
27745. to do with myself?" And tapping with her heels, she ran quickly upstairs
27746. to see Vogel and his wife who lived on the upper story.
27747. 
27748. Two governesses were sitting with the Vogels at a table, on which were
27749. plates of raisins, walnuts, and almonds. The governesses were discussing
27750. whether it was cheaper to live in Moscow or Odessa. Natasha sat down,
27751. listened to their talk with a serious and thoughtful air, and then got
27752. up again.
27753. 
27754. "The island of Madagascar," she said, "Ma-da-gas-car," she repeated,
27755. articulating each syllable distinctly, and, not replying to Madame
27756. Schoss who asked her what she was saying, she went out of the room.
27757. 
27758. Her brother Petya was upstairs too; with the man in attendance on him he
27759. was preparing fireworks to let off that night.
27760. 
27761. "Petya! Petya!" she called to him. "Carry me downstairs."
27762. 
27763. Petya ran up and offered her his back. She jumped on it, putting her
27764. arms round his neck, and he pranced along with her.
27765. 
27766. "No, don't... the island of Madagascar!" she said, and jumping off his
27767. back she went downstairs.
27768. 
27769. Having as it were reviewed her kingdom, tested her power, and made sure
27770. that everyone was submissive, but that all the same it was dull, Natasha
27771. betook herself to the ballroom, picked up her guitar, sat down in a dark
27772. corner behind a bookcase, and began to run her fingers over the strings
27773. in the bass, picking out a passage she recalled from an opera she had
27774. heard in Petersburg with Prince Andrew. What she drew from the guitar
27775. would have had no meaning for other listeners, but in her imagination
27776. a whole series of reminiscences arose from those sounds. She sat behind
27777. the bookcase with her eyes fixed on a streak of light escaping from the
27778. pantry door and listened to herself and pondered. She was in a mood for
27779. brooding on the past.
27780. 
27781. Sonya passed to the pantry with a glass in her hand. Natasha glanced at
27782. her and at the crack in the pantry door, and it seemed to her that she
27783. remembered the light falling through that crack once before and Sonya
27784. passing with a glass in her hand. "Yes it was exactly the same," thought
27785. Natasha.
27786. 
27787. "Sonya, what is this?" she cried, twanging a thick string.
27788. 
27789. "Oh, you are there!" said Sonya with a start, and came near and
27790. listened. "I don't know. A storm?" she ventured timidly, afraid of being
27791. wrong.
27792. 
27793. "There! That's just how she started and just how she came up smiling
27794. timidly when all this happened before," thought Natasha, "and in just
27795. the same way I thought there was something lacking in her."
27796. 
27797. "No, it's the chorus from The Water-Carrier, listen!" and Natasha sang
27798. the air of the chorus so that Sonya should catch it. "Where were you
27799. going?" she asked.
27800. 
27801. "To change the water in this glass. I am just finishing the design."
27802. 
27803. "You always find something to do, but I can't," said Natasha. "And
27804. where's Nicholas?"
27805. 
27806. "Asleep, I think."
27807. 
27808. "Sonya, go and wake him," said Natasha. "Tell him I want him to come and
27809. sing."
27810. 
27811. She sat awhile, wondering what the meaning of it all having happened
27812. before could be, and without solving this problem, or at all regretting
27813. not having done so, she again passed in fancy to the time when she was
27814. with him and he was looking at her with a lover's eyes.
27815. 
27816. "Oh, if only he would come quicker! I am so afraid it will never be!
27817. And, worst of all, I am growing old--that's the thing! There won't then
27818. be in me what there is now. But perhaps he'll come today, will come
27819. immediately. Perhaps he has come and is sitting in the drawing room.
27820. Perhaps he came yesterday and I have forgotten it." She rose, put down
27821. the guitar, and went to the drawing room.
27822. 
27823. All the domestic circle, tutors, governesses, and guests, were already
27824. at the tea table. The servants stood round the table--but Prince Andrew
27825. was not there and life was going on as before.
27826. 
27827. "Ah, here she is!" said the old count, when he saw Natasha enter. "Well,
27828. sit down by me." But Natasha stayed by her mother and glanced round as
27829. if looking for something.
27830. 
27831. "Mamma!" she muttered, "give him to me, give him, Mamma, quickly,
27832. quickly!" and she again had difficulty in repressing her sobs.
27833. 
27834. She sat down at the table and listened to the conversation between the
27835. elders and Nicholas, who had also come to the table. "My God, my God!
27836. The same faces, the same talk, Papa holding his cup and blowing in the
27837. same way!" thought Natasha, feeling with horror a sense of repulsion
27838. rising up in her for the whole household, because they were always the
27839. same.
27840. 
27841. After tea, Nicholas, Sonya, and Natasha went to the sitting room, to
27842. their favorite corner where their most intimate talks always began.
27843. 
27844. 
27845. 
27846. 
27847. 
27848. CHAPTER X
27849. 
27850. 
27851. "Does it ever happen to you," said Natasha to her brother, when they
27852. settled down in the sitting room, "does it ever happen to you to feel
27853. as if there were nothing more to come--nothing; that everything good is
27854. past? And to feel not exactly dull, but sad?"
27855. 
27856. "I should think so!" he replied. "I have felt like that when everything
27857. was all right and everyone was cheerful. The thought has come into my
27858. mind that I was already tired of it all, and that we must all die.
27859. Once in the regiment I had not gone to some merrymaking where there was
27860. music... and suddenly I felt so depressed..."
27861. 
27862. "Oh yes, I know, I know, I know!" Natasha interrupted him. "When I was
27863. quite little that used to be so with me. Do you remember when I was
27864. punished once about some plums? You were all dancing, and I sat sobbing
27865. in the schoolroom? I shall never forget it: I felt sad and sorry for
27866. everyone, for myself, and for everyone. And I was innocent--that was the
27867. chief thing," said Natasha. "Do you remember?"
27868. 
27869. "I remember," answered Nicholas. "I remember that I came to you
27870. afterwards and wanted to comfort you, but do you know, I felt ashamed
27871. to. We were terribly absurd. I had a funny doll then and wanted to give
27872. it to you. Do you remember?"
27873. 
27874. "And do you remember," Natasha asked with a pensive smile, "how once,
27875. long, long ago, when we were quite little, Uncle called us into the
27876. study--that was in the old house--and it was dark--we went in and
27877. suddenly there stood..."
27878. 
27879. "A Negro," chimed in Nicholas with a smile of delight. "Of course I
27880. remember. Even now I don't know whether there really was a Negro, or if
27881. we only dreamed it or were told about him."
27882. 
27883. "He was gray, you remember, and had white teeth, and stood and looked at
27884. us..."
27885. 
27886. "Sonya, do you remember?" asked Nicholas.
27887. 
27888. "Yes, yes, I do remember something too," Sonya answered timidly.
27889. 
27890. "You know I have asked Papa and Mamma about that Negro," said Natasha,
27891. "and they say there was no Negro at all. But you see, you remember!"
27892. 
27893. "Of course I do, I remember his teeth as if I had just seen them."
27894. 
27895. "How strange it is! It's as if it were a dream! I like that."
27896. 
27897. "And do you remember how we rolled hard-boiled eggs in the ballroom, and
27898. suddenly two old women began spinning round on the carpet? Was that real
27899. or not? Do you remember what fun it was?"
27900. 
27901. "Yes, and you remember how Papa in his blue overcoat fired a gun in the
27902. porch?"
27903. 
27904. So they went through their memories, smiling with pleasure: not the sad
27905. memories of old age, but poetic, youthful ones--those impressions of
27906. one's most distant past in which dreams and realities blend--and they
27907. laughed with quiet enjoyment.
27908. 
27909. Sonya, as always, did not quite keep pace with them, though they shared
27910. the same reminiscences.
27911. 
27912. Much that they remembered had slipped from her mind, and what she
27913. recalled did not arouse the same poetic feeling as they experienced. She
27914. simply enjoyed their pleasure and tried to fit in with it.
27915. 
27916. She only really took part when they recalled Sonya's first arrival. She
27917. told them how afraid she had been of Nicholas because he had on a corded
27918. jacket and her nurse had told her that she, too, would be sewn up with
27919. cords.
27920. 
27921. "And I remember their telling me that you had been born under a
27922. cabbage," said Natasha, "and I remember that I dared not disbelieve it
27923. then, but knew that it was not true, and I felt so uncomfortable."
27924. 
27925. While they were talking a maid thrust her head in at the other door of
27926. the sitting room.
27927. 
27928. "They have brought the cock, Miss," she said in a whisper.
27929. 
27930. "It isn't wanted, Petya. Tell them to take it away," replied Natasha.
27931. 
27932. In the middle of their talk in the sitting room, Dimmler came in and
27933. went up to the harp that stood there in a corner. He took off its cloth
27934. covering, and the harp gave out a jarring sound.
27935. 
27936. "Mr. Dimmler, please play my favorite nocturne by Field," came the old
27937. countess' voice from the drawing room.
27938. 
27939. Dimmler struck a chord and, turning to Natasha, Nicholas, and Sonya,
27940. remarked: "How quiet you young people are!"
27941. 
27942. "Yes, we're philosophizing," said Natasha, glancing round for a moment
27943. and then continuing the conversation. They were now discussing dreams.
27944. 
27945. Dimmler began to play; Natasha went on tiptoe noiselessly to the table,
27946. took up a candle, carried it out, and returned, seating herself quietly
27947. in her former place. It was dark in the room especially where they were
27948. sitting on the sofa, but through the big windows the silvery light of
27949. the full moon fell on the floor. Dimmler had finished the piece but
27950. still sat softly running his fingers over the strings, evidently
27951. uncertain whether to stop or to play something else.
27952. 
27953. "Do you know," said Natasha in a whisper, moving closer to Nicholas and
27954. Sonya, "that when one goes on and on recalling memories, one at last
27955. begins to remember what happened before one was in the world..."
27956. 
27957. "That is metempsychosis," said Sonya, who had always learned well, and
27958. remembered everything. "The Egyptians believed that our souls have lived
27959. in animals, and will go back into animals again."
27960. 
27961. "No, I don't believe we ever were in animals," said Natasha, still in
27962. a whisper though the music had ceased. "But I am certain that we
27963. were angels somewhere there, and have been here, and that is why we
27964. remember...."
27965. 
27966. "May I join you?" said Dimmler who had come up quietly, and he sat down
27967. by them.
27968. 
27969. "If we have been angels, why have we fallen lower?" said Nicholas. "No,
27970. that can't be!"
27971. 
27972. "Not lower, who said we were lower?... How do I know what I was before?"
27973. Natasha rejoined with conviction. "The soul is immortal--well then, if I
27974. shall always live I must have lived before, lived for a whole eternity."
27975. 
27976. "Yes, but it is hard for us to imagine eternity," remarked Dimmler,
27977. who had joined the young folk with a mildly condescending smile but now
27978. spoke as quietly and seriously as they.
27979. 
27980. "Why is it hard to imagine eternity?" said Natasha. "It is now today,
27981. and it will be tomorrow, and always; and there was yesterday, and the
27982. day before..."
27983. 
27984. "Natasha! Now it's your turn. Sing me something," they heard the
27985. countess say. "Why are you sitting there like conspirators?"
27986. 
27987. "Mamma, I don't at all want to," replied Natasha, but all the same she
27988. rose.
27989. 
27990. None of them, not even the middle-aged Dimmler, wanted to break off
27991. their conversation and quit that corner in the sitting room, but Natasha
27992. got up and Nicholas sat down at the clavichord. Standing as usual in the
27993. middle of the hall and choosing the place where the resonance was best,
27994. Natasha began to sing her mother's favorite song.
27995. 
27996. She had said she did not want to sing, but it was long since she had
27997. sung, and long before she again sang, as she did that evening. The
27998. count, from his study where he was talking to Mitenka, heard her and,
27999. like a schoolboy in a hurry to run out to play, blundered in his talk
28000. while giving orders to the steward, and at last stopped, while Mitenka
28001. stood in front of him also listening and smiling. Nicholas did not take
28002. his eyes off his sister and drew breath in time with her. Sonya, as she
28003. listened, thought of the immense difference there was between herself
28004. and her friend, and how impossible it was for her to be anything like as
28005. bewitching as her cousin. The old countess sat with a blissful yet sad
28006. smile and with tears in her eyes, occasionally shaking her head. She
28007. thought of Natasha and of her own youth, and of how there was something
28008. unnatural and dreadful in this impending marriage of Natasha and Prince
28009. Andrew.
28010. 
28011. Dimmler, who had seated himself beside the countess, listened with
28012. closed eyes.
28013. 
28014. "Ah, Countess," he said at last, "that's a European talent, she has
28015. nothing to learn--what softness, tenderness, and strength...."
28016. 
28017. "Ah, how afraid I am for her, how afraid I am!" said the countess, not
28018. realizing to whom she was speaking. Her maternal instinct told her that
28019. Natasha had too much of something, and that because of this she would
28020. not be happy. Before Natasha had finished singing, fourteen-year-old
28021. Petya rushed in delightedly, to say that some mummers had arrived.
28022. 
28023. Natasha stopped abruptly.
28024. 
28025. "Idiot!" she screamed at her brother and, running to a chair, threw
28026. herself on it, sobbing so violently that she could not stop for a long
28027. time.
28028. 
28029. "It's nothing, Mamma, really it's nothing; only Petya startled me," she
28030. said, trying to smile, but her tears still flowed and sobs still choked
28031. her.
28032. 
28033. The mummers (some of the house serfs) dressed up as bears, Turks,
28034. innkeepers, and ladies--frightening and funny--bringing in with them the
28035. cold from outside and a feeling of gaiety, crowded, at first timidly,
28036. into the anteroom, then hiding behind one another they pushed into
28037. the ballroom where, shyly at first and then more and more merrily and
28038. heartily, they started singing, dancing, and playing Christmas games.
28039. The countess, when she had identified them and laughed at their
28040. costumes, went into the drawing room. The count sat in the ballroom,
28041. smiling radiantly and applauding the players. The young people had
28042. disappeared.
28043. 
28044. Half an hour later there appeared among the other mummers in the
28045. ballroom an old lady in a hooped skirt--this was Nicholas. A Turkish
28046. girl was Petya. A clown was Dimmler. An hussar was Natasha, and a
28047. Circassian was Sonya with burnt-cork mustache and eyebrows.
28048. 
28049. After the condescending surprise, nonrecognition, and praise, from those
28050. who were not themselves dressed up, the young people decided that their
28051. costumes were so good that they ought to be shown elsewhere.
28052. 
28053. Nicholas, who, as the roads were in splendid condition, wanted to take
28054. them all for a drive in his troyka, proposed to take with them about a
28055. dozen of the serf mummers and drive to "Uncle's."
28056. 
28057. "No, why disturb the old fellow?" said the countess. "Besides, you
28058. wouldn't have room to turn round there. If you must go, go to the
28059. Melyukovs'."
28060. 
28061. Melyukova was a widow, who, with her family and their tutors and
28062. governesses, lived three miles from the Rostovs.
28063. 
28064. "That's right, my dear," chimed in the old count, thoroughly aroused.
28065. "I'll dress up at once and go with them. I'll make Pashette open her
28066. eyes."
28067. 
28068. But the countess would not agree to his going; he had had a bad leg all
28069. these last days. It was decided that the count must not go, but that
28070. if Louisa Ivanovna (Madame Schoss) would go with them, the young ladies
28071. might go to the Melyukovs', Sonya, generally so timid and shy, more
28072. urgently than anyone begging Louisa Ivanovna not to refuse.
28073. 
28074. Sonya's costume was the best of all. Her mustache and eyebrows were
28075. extraordinarily becoming. Everyone told her she looked very handsome,
28076. and she was in a spirited and energetic mood unusual with her. Some
28077. inner voice told her that now or never her fate would be decided, and
28078. in her male attire she seemed quite a different person. Louisa Ivanovna
28079. consented to go, and in half an hour four troyka sleighs with large and
28080. small bells, their runners squeaking and whistling over the frozen snow,
28081. drove up to the porch.
28082. 
28083. Natasha was foremost in setting a merry holiday tone, which, passing
28084. from one to another, grew stronger and reached its climax when they all
28085. came out into the frost and got into the sleighs, talking, calling to
28086. one another, laughing, and shouting.
28087. 
28088. Two of the troykas were the usual household sleighs, the third was
28089. the old count's with a trotter from the Orlov stud as shaft horse,
28090. the fourth was Nicholas' own with a short shaggy black shaft horse.
28091. Nicholas, in his old lady's dress over which he had belted his hussar
28092. overcoat, stood in the middle of the sleigh, reins in hand.
28093. 
28094. It was so light that he could see the moonlight reflected from the metal
28095. harness disks and from the eyes of the horses, who looked round in alarm
28096. at the noisy party under the shadow of the porch roof.
28097. 
28098. Natasha, Sonya, Madame Schoss, and two maids got into Nicholas' sleigh;
28099. Dimmler, his wife, and Petya, into the old count's, and the rest of the
28100. mummers seated themselves in the other two sleighs.
28101. 
28102. "You go ahead, Zakhar!" shouted Nicholas to his father's coachman,
28103. wishing for a chance to race past him.
28104. 
28105. The old count's troyka, with Dimmler and his party, started forward,
28106. squeaking on its runners as though freezing to the snow, its deep-toned
28107. bell clanging. The side horses, pressing against the shafts of the
28108. middle horse, sank in the snow, which was dry and glittered like sugar,
28109. and threw it up.
28110. 
28111. Nicholas set off, following the first sleigh; behind him the others
28112. moved noisily, their runners squeaking. At first they drove at a steady
28113. trot along the narrow road. While they drove past the garden the shadows
28114. of the bare trees often fell across the road and hid the brilliant
28115. moonlight, but as soon as they were past the fence, the snowy plain
28116. bathed in moonlight and motionless spread out before them glittering
28117. like diamonds and dappled with bluish shadows. Bang, bang! went the
28118. first sleigh over a cradle hole in the snow of the road, and each of
28119. the other sleighs jolted in the same way, and rudely breaking the
28120. frost-bound stillness, the troykas began to speed along the road, one
28121. after the other.
28122. 
28123. "A hare's track, a lot of tracks!" rang out Natasha's voice through the
28124. frost-bound air.
28125. 
28126. "How light it is, Nicholas!" came Sonya's voice.
28127. 
28128. Nicholas glanced round at Sonya, and bent down to see her face closer.
28129. Quite a new, sweet face with black eyebrows and mustaches peeped up at
28130. him from her sable furs--so close and yet so distant--in the moonlight.
28131. 
28132. "That used to be Sonya," thought he, and looked at her closer and
28133. smiled.
28134. 
28135. "What is it, Nicholas?"
28136. 
28137. "Nothing," said he and turned again to the horses.
28138. 
28139. When they came out onto the beaten highroad--polished by sleigh runners
28140. and cut up by rough-shod hoofs, the marks of which were visible in the
28141. moonlight--the horses began to tug at the reins of their own accord and
28142. increased their pace. The near side horse, arching his head and breaking
28143. into a short canter, tugged at his traces. The shaft horse swayed from
28144. side to side, moving his ears as if asking: "Isn't it time to begin
28145. now?" In front, already far ahead the deep bell of the sleigh ringing
28146. farther and farther off, the black horses driven by Zakhar could be
28147. clearly seen against the white snow. From that sleigh one could hear the
28148. shouts, laughter, and voices of the mummers.
28149. 
28150. "Gee up, my darlings!" shouted Nicholas, pulling the reins to one side
28151. and flourishing the whip.
28152. 
28153. It was only by the keener wind that met them and the jerks given by the
28154. side horses who pulled harder--ever increasing their gallop--that one
28155. noticed how fast the troyka was flying. Nicholas looked back. With
28156. screams squeals, and waving of whips that caused even the shaft horses
28157. to gallop--the other sleighs followed. The shaft horse swung steadily
28158. beneath the bow over its head, with no thought of slackening pace and
28159. ready to put on speed when required.
28160. 
28161. Nicholas overtook the first sleigh. They were driving downhill and
28162. coming out upon a broad trodden track across a meadow, near a river.
28163. 
28164. "Where are we?" thought he. "It's the Kosoy meadow, I suppose. But
28165. no--this is something new I've never seen before. This isn't the Kosoy
28166. meadow nor the Demkin hill, and heaven only knows what it is! It is
28167. something new and enchanted. Well, whatever it may be..." And shouting
28168. to his horses, he began to pass the first sleigh.
28169. 
28170. Zakhar held back his horses and turned his face, which was already
28171. covered with hoarfrost to his eyebrows.
28172. 
28173. Nicholas gave the horses the rein, and Zakhar, stretching out his arms,
28174. clucked his tongue and let his horses go.
28175. 
28176. "Now, look out, master!" he cried.
28177. 
28178. Faster still the two troykas flew side by side, and faster moved the
28179. feet of the galloping side horses. Nicholas began to draw ahead. Zakhar,
28180. while still keeping his arms extended, raised one hand with the reins.
28181. 
28182. "No you won't, master!" he shouted.
28183. 
28184. Nicholas put all his horses to a gallop and passed Zakhar. The horses
28185. showered the fine dry snow on the faces of those in the sleigh--beside
28186. them sounded quick ringing bells and they caught confused glimpses of
28187. swiftly moving legs and the shadows of the troyka they were passing.
28188. The whistling sound of the runners on the snow and the voices of girls
28189. shrieking were heard from different sides.
28190. 
28191. Again checking his horses, Nicholas looked around him. They were still
28192. surrounded by the magic plain bathed in moonlight and spangled with
28193. stars.
28194. 
28195. "Zakhar is shouting that I should turn to the left, but why to the
28196. left?" thought Nicholas. "Are we getting to the Melyukovs'? Is this
28197. Melyukovka? Heaven only knows where we are going, and heaven knows what
28198. is happening to us--but it is very strange and pleasant whatever it is."
28199. And he looked round in the sleigh.
28200. 
28201. "Look, his mustache and eyelashes are all white!" said one of the
28202. strange, pretty, unfamiliar people--the one with fine eyebrows and
28203. mustache.
28204. 
28205. "I think this used to be Natasha," thought Nicholas, "and that was
28206. Madame Schoss, but perhaps it's not, and this Circassian with the
28207. mustache I don't know, but I love her."
28208. 
28209. "Aren't you cold?" he asked.
28210. 
28211. They did not answer but began to laugh. Dimmler from the sleigh behind
28212. shouted something--probably something funny--but they could not make out
28213. what he said.
28214. 
28215. "Yes, yes!" some voices answered, laughing.
28216. 
28217. "But here was a fairy forest with black moving shadows, and a glitter
28218. of diamonds and a flight of marble steps and the silver roofs of fairy
28219. buildings and the shrill yells of some animals. And if this is really
28220. Melyukovka, it is still stranger that we drove heaven knows where and
28221. have come to Melyukovka," thought Nicholas.
28222. 
28223. It really was Melyukovka, and maids and footmen with merry faces came
28224. running, out to the porch carrying candles.
28225. 
28226. "Who is it?" asked someone in the porch.
28227. 
28228. "The mummers from the count's. I know by the horses," replied some
28229. voices.
28230. 
28231. 
28232. 
28233. 
28234. 
28235. CHAPTER XI
28236. 
28237. 
28238. Pelageya Danilovna Melyukova, a broadly built, energetic woman wearing
28239. spectacles, sat in the drawing room in a loose dress, surrounded by
28240. her daughters whom she was trying to keep from feeling dull. They were
28241. quietly dropping melted wax into snow and looking at the shadows the wax
28242. figures would throw on the wall, when they heard the steps and voices of
28243. new arrivals in the vestibule.
28244. 
28245. Hussars, ladies, witches, clowns, and bears, after clearing their
28246. throats and wiping the hoarfrost from their faces in the vestibule,
28247. came into the ballroom where candles were hurriedly lighted. The
28248. clown--Dimmler--and the lady--Nicholas--started a dance. Surrounded by
28249. the screaming children the mummers, covering their faces and disguising
28250. their voices, bowed to their hostess and arranged themselves about the
28251. room.
28252. 
28253. "Dear me! there's no recognizing them! And Natasha! See whom she looks
28254. like! She really reminds me of somebody. But Herr Dimmler--isn't
28255. he good! I didn't know him! And how he dances. Dear me, there's a
28256. Circassian. Really, how becoming it is to dear Sonya. And who is that?
28257. Well, you have cheered us up! Nikita and Vanya--clear away the tables!
28258. And we were sitting so quietly. Ha, ha, ha!... The hussar, the hussar!
28259. Just like a boy! And the legs!... I can't look at him..." different
28260. voices were saying.
28261. 
28262. Natasha, the young Melyukovs' favorite, disappeared with them into the
28263. back rooms where a cork and various dressing gowns and male garments
28264. were called for and received from the footman by bare girlish arms from
28265. behind the door. Ten minutes later, all the young Melyukovs joined the
28266. mummers.
28267. 
28268. Pelageya Danilovna, having given orders to clear the rooms for the
28269. visitors and arranged about refreshments for the gentry and the serfs,
28270. went about among the mummers without removing her spectacles, peering
28271. into their faces with a suppressed smile and failing to recognize any of
28272. them. It was not merely Dimmler and the Rostovs she failed to recognize,
28273. she did not even recognize her own daughters, or her late husband's,
28274. dressing gowns and uniforms, which they had put on.
28275. 
28276. "And who is this?" she asked her governess, peering into the face of her
28277. own daughter dressed up as a Kazan-Tartar. "I suppose it is one of the
28278. Rostovs! Well, Mr. Hussar, and what regiment do you serve in?" she asked
28279. Natasha. "Here, hand some fruit jelly to the Turk!" she ordered the
28280. butler who was handing things round. "That's not forbidden by his law."
28281. 
28282. Sometimes, as she looked at the strange but amusing capers cut by the
28283. dancers, who--having decided once for all that being disguised, no one
28284. would recognize them--were not at all shy, Pelageya Danilovna hid
