28285. her face in her handkerchief, and her whole stout body shook with
28286. irrepressible, kindly, elderly laughter.
28287. 
28288. "My little Sasha! Look at Sasha!" she said.
28289. 
28290. After Russian country dances and chorus dances, Pelageya Danilovna made
28291. the serfs and gentry join in one large circle: a ring, a string, and a
28292. silver ruble were fetched and they all played games together.
28293. 
28294. In an hour, all the costumes were crumpled and disordered. The corked
28295. eyebrows and mustaches were smeared over the perspiring, flushed, and
28296. merry faces. Pelageya Danilovna began to recognize the mummers, admired
28297. their cleverly contrived costumes, and particularly how they suited the
28298. young ladies, and she thanked them all for having entertained her so
28299. well. The visitors were invited to supper in the drawing room, and the
28300. serfs had something served to them in the ballroom.
28301. 
28302. "Now to tell one's fortune in the empty bathhouse is frightening!" said
28303. an old maid who lived with the Melyukovs, during supper.
28304. 
28305. "Why?" said the eldest Melyukov girl.
28306. 
28307. "You wouldn't go, it takes courage..."
28308. 
28309. "I'll go," said Sonya.
28310. 
28311. "Tell what happened to the young lady!" said the second Melyukov girl.
28312. 
28313. "Well," began the old maid, "a young lady once went out, took a cock,
28314. laid the table for two, all properly, and sat down. After sitting a
28315. while, she suddenly hears someone coming... a sleigh drives up with
28316. harness bells; she hears him coming! He comes in, just in the shape of a
28317. man, like an officer--comes in and sits down to table with her."
28318. 
28319. "Ah! ah!" screamed Natasha, rolling her eyes with horror.
28320. 
28321. "Yes? And how... did he speak?"
28322. 
28323. "Yes, like a man. Everything quite all right, and he began persuading
28324. her; and she should have kept him talking till cockcrow, but she got
28325. frightened, just got frightened and hid her face in her hands. Then he
28326. caught her up. It was lucky the maids ran in just then..."
28327. 
28328. "Now, why frighten them?" said Pelageya Danilovna.
28329. 
28330. "Mamma, you used to try your fate yourself..." said her daughter.
28331. 
28332. "And how does one do it in a barn?" inquired Sonya.
28333. 
28334. "Well, say you went to the barn now, and listened. It depends on what
28335. you hear; hammering and knocking--that's bad; but a sound of shifting
28336. grain is good and one sometimes hears that, too."
28337. 
28338. "Mamma, tell us what happened to you in the barn."
28339. 
28340. Pelageya Danilovna smiled.
28341. 
28342. "Oh, I've forgotten..." she replied. "But none of you would go?"
28343. 
28344. "Yes, I will; Pelageya Danilovna, let me! I'll go," said Sonya.
28345. 
28346. "Well, why not, if you're not afraid?"
28347. 
28348. "Louisa Ivanovna, may I?" asked Sonya.
28349. 
28350. Whether they were playing the ring and string game or the ruble game or
28351. talking as now, Nicholas did not leave Sonya's side, and gazed at her
28352. with quite new eyes. It seemed to him that it was only today, thanks
28353. to that burnt-cork mustache, that he had fully learned to know her. And
28354. really, that evening, Sonya was brighter, more animated, and prettier
28355. than Nicholas had ever seen her before.
28356. 
28357. "So that's what she is like; what a fool I have been!" he thought gazing
28358. at her sparkling eyes, and under the mustache a happy rapturous smile
28359. dimpled her cheeks, a smile he had never seen before.
28360. 
28361. "I'm not afraid of anything," said Sonya. "May I go at once?" She got
28362. up.
28363. 
28364. They told her where the barn was and how she should stand and listen,
28365. and they handed her a fur cloak. She threw this over her head and
28366. shoulders and glanced at Nicholas.
28367. 
28368. "What a darling that girl is!" thought he. "And what have I been
28369. thinking of till now?"
28370. 
28371. Sonya went out into the passage to go to the barn. Nicholas went hastily
28372. to the front porch, saying he felt too hot. The crowd of people really
28373. had made the house stuffy.
28374. 
28375. Outside, there was the same cold stillness and the same moon, but even
28376. brighter than before. The light was so strong and the snow sparkled with
28377. so many stars that one did not wish to look up at the sky and the real
28378. stars were unnoticed. The sky was black and dreary, while the earth was
28379. gay.
28380. 
28381. "I am a fool, a fool! what have I been waiting for?" thought Nicholas,
28382. and running out from the porch he went round the corner of the house and
28383. along the path that led to the back porch. He knew Sonya would pass
28384. that way. Halfway lay some snow-covered piles of firewood and across and
28385. along them a network of shadows from the bare old lime trees fell on the
28386. snow and on the path. This path led to the barn. The log walls of the
28387. barn and its snow-covered roof, that looked as if hewn out of some
28388. precious stone, sparkled in the moonlight. A tree in the garden snapped
28389. with the frost, and then all was again perfectly silent. His bosom
28390. seemed to inhale not air but the strength of eternal youth and gladness.
28391. 
28392. From the back porch came the sound of feet descending the steps, the
28393. bottom step upon which snow had fallen gave a ringing creak and he heard
28394. the voice of an old maidservant saying, "Straight, straight, along the
28395. path, Miss. Only, don't look back."
28396. 
28397. "I am not afraid," answered Sonya's voice, and along the path toward
28398. Nicholas came the crunching, whistling sound of Sonya's feet in her thin
28399. shoes.
28400. 
28401. Sonya came along, wrapped in her cloak. She was only a couple of paces
28402. away when she saw him, and to her too he was not the Nicholas she
28403. had known and always slightly feared. He was in a woman's dress, with
28404. tousled hair and a happy smile new to Sonya. She ran rapidly toward him.
28405. 
28406. "Quite different and yet the same," thought Nicholas, looking at her
28407. face all lit up by the moonlight. He slipped his arms under the cloak
28408. that covered her head, embraced her, pressed her to him, and kissed her
28409. on the lips that wore a mustache and had a smell of burnt cork. Sonya
28410. kissed him full on the lips, and disengaging her little hands pressed
28411. them to his cheeks.
28412. 
28413. "Sonya!... Nicholas!"... was all they said. They ran to the barn and
28414. then back again, re-entering, he by the front and she by the back porch.
28415. 
28416. 
28417. 
28418. 
28419. 
28420. CHAPTER XII
28421. 
28422. 
28423. When they all drove back from Pelageya Danilovna's, Natasha, who always
28424. saw and noticed everything, arranged that she and Madame Schoss should
28425. go back in the sleigh with Dimmler, and Sonya with Nicholas and the
28426. maids.
28427. 
28428. On the way back Nicholas drove at a steady pace instead of racing and
28429. kept peering by that fantastic all-transforming light into Sonya's face
28430. and searching beneath the eyebrows and mustache for his former and his
28431. present Sonya from whom he had resolved never to be parted again. He
28432. looked and recognizing in her both the old and the new Sonya, and
28433. being reminded by the smell of burnt cork of the sensation of her kiss,
28434. inhaled the frosty air with a full breast and, looking at the ground
28435. flying beneath him and at the sparkling sky, felt himself again in
28436. fairyland.
28437. 
28438. "Sonya, is it well with thee?" he asked from time to time.
28439. 
28440. "Yes!" she replied. "And with thee?"
28441. 
28442. When halfway home Nicholas handed the reins to the coachman and ran for
28443. a moment to Natasha's sleigh and stood on its wing.
28444. 
28445. "Natasha!" he whispered in French, "do you know I have made up my mind
28446. about Sonya?"
28447. 
28448. "Have you told her?" asked Natasha, suddenly beaming all over with joy.
28449. 
28450. "Oh, how strange you are with that mustache and those eyebrows!...
28451. Natasha--are you glad?"
28452. 
28453. "I am so glad, so glad! I was beginning to be vexed with you. I did not
28454. tell you, but you have been treating her badly. What a heart she has,
28455. Nicholas! I am horrid sometimes, but I was ashamed to be happy while
28456. Sonya was not," continued Natasha. "Now I am so glad! Well, run back to
28457. her."
28458. 
28459. "No, wait a bit.... Oh, how funny you look!" cried Nicholas, peering
28460. into her face and finding in his sister too something new, unusual, and
28461. bewitchingly tender that he had not seen in her before. "Natasha, it's
28462. magical, isn't it?"
28463. 
28464. "Yes," she replied. "You have done splendidly."
28465. 
28466. "Had I seen her before as she is now," thought Nicholas, "I should long
28467. ago have asked her what to do and have done whatever she told me, and
28468. all would have been well."
28469. 
28470. "So you are glad and I have done right?"
28471. 
28472. "Oh, quite right! I had a quarrel with Mamma some time ago about it.
28473. Mamma said she was angling for you. How could she say such a thing! I
28474. nearly stormed at Mamma. I will never let anyone say anything bad of
28475. Sonya, for there is nothing but good in her."
28476. 
28477. "Then it's all right?" said Nicholas, again scrutinizing the expression
28478. of his sister's face to see if she was in earnest. Then he jumped down
28479. and, his boots scrunching the snow, ran back to his sleigh. The same
28480. happy, smiling Circassian, with mustache and beaming eyes looking up
28481. from under a sable hood, was still sitting there, and that Circassian
28482. was Sonya, and that Sonya was certainly his future happy and loving
28483. wife.
28484. 
28485. When they reached home and had told their mother how they had spent the
28486. evening at the Melyukovs', the girls went to their bedroom. When they
28487. had undressed, but without washing off the cork mustaches, they sat a
28488. long time talking of their happiness. They talked of how they would live
28489. when they were married, how their husbands would be friends, and how
28490. happy they would be. On Natasha's table stood two looking glasses which
28491. Dunyasha had prepared beforehand.
28492. 
28493. "Only when will all that be? I am afraid never.... It would be too
28494. good!" said Natasha, rising and going to the looking glasses.
28495. 
28496. "Sit down, Natasha; perhaps you'll see him," said Sonya.
28497. 
28498. Natasha lit the candles, one on each side of one of the looking glasses,
28499. and sat down.
28500. 
28501. "I see someone with a mustache," said Natasha, seeing her own face.
28502. 
28503. "You mustn't laugh, Miss," said Dunyasha.
28504. 
28505. With Sonya's help and the maid's, Natasha got the glass she held into
28506. the right position opposite the other; her face assumed a serious
28507. expression and she sat silent. She sat a long time looking at the
28508. receding line of candles reflected in the glasses and expecting (from
28509. tales she had heard) to see a coffin, or him, Prince Andrew, in that
28510. last dim, indistinctly outlined square. But ready as she was to take the
28511. smallest speck for the image of a man or of a coffin, she saw nothing.
28512. She began blinking rapidly and moved away from the looking glasses.
28513. 
28514. "Why is it others see things and I don't?" she said. "You sit down now,
28515. Sonya. You absolutely must, tonight! Do it for me.... Today I feel so
28516. frightened!"
28517. 
28518. Sonya sat down before the glasses, got the right position, and began
28519. looking.
28520. 
28521. "Now, Miss Sonya is sure to see something," whispered Dunyasha; "while
28522. you do nothing but laugh."
28523. 
28524. Sonya heard this and Natasha's whisper:
28525. 
28526. "I know she will. She saw something last year."
28527. 
28528. For about three minutes all were silent.
28529. 
28530. "Of course she will!" whispered Natasha, but did not finish... suddenly
28531. Sonya pushed away the glass she was holding and covered her eyes with
28532. her hand.
28533. 
28534. "Oh, Natasha!" she cried.
28535. 
28536. "Did you see? Did you? What was it?" exclaimed Natasha, holding up the
28537. looking glass.
28538. 
28539. Sonya had not seen anything, she was just wanting to blink and to get
28540. up when she heard Natasha say, "Of course she will!" She did not wish to
28541. disappoint either Dunyasha or Natasha, but it was hard to sit still.
28542. She did not herself know how or why the exclamation escaped her when she
28543. covered her eyes.
28544. 
28545. "You saw him?" urged Natasha, seizing her hand.
28546. 
28547. "Yes. Wait a bit... I... saw him," Sonya could not help saying, not yet
28548. knowing whom Natasha meant by him, Nicholas or Prince Andrew.
28549. 
28550. "But why shouldn't I say I saw something? Others do see! Besides who can
28551. tell whether I saw anything or not?" flashed through Sonya's mind.
28552. 
28553. "Yes, I saw him," she said.
28554. 
28555. "How? Standing or lying?"
28556. 
28557. "No, I saw... At first there was nothing, then I saw him lying down."
28558. 
28559. "Andrew lying? Is he ill?" asked Natasha, her frightened eyes fixed on
28560. her friend.
28561. 
28562. "No, on the contrary, on the contrary! His face was cheerful, and he
28563. turned to me." And when saying this she herself fancied she had really
28564. seen what she described.
28565. 
28566. "Well, and then, Sonya?..."
28567. 
28568. "After that, I could not make out what there was; something blue and
28569. red..."
28570. 
28571. "Sonya! When will he come back? When shall I see him! O, God, how afraid
28572. I am for him and for myself and about everything!..." Natasha began, and
28573. without replying to Sonya's words of comfort she got into bed, and long
28574. after her candle was out lay open-eyed and motionless, gazing at the
28575. moonlight through the frosty windowpanes.
28576. 
28577. 
28578. 
28579. 
28580. 
28581. CHAPTER XIII
28582. 
28583. 
28584. Soon after the Christmas holidays Nicholas told his mother of his love
28585. for Sonya and of his firm resolve to marry her. The countess, who had
28586. long noticed what was going on between them and was expecting this
28587. declaration, listened to him in silence and then told her son that he
28588. might marry whom he pleased, but that neither she nor his father would
28589. give their blessing to such a marriage. Nicholas, for the first time,
28590. felt that his mother was displeased with him and that, despite her love
28591. for him, she would not give way. Coldly, without looking at her son,
28592. she sent for her husband and, when he came, tried briefly and coldly to
28593. inform him of the facts, in her son's presence, but unable to restrain
28594. herself she burst into tears of vexation and left the room. The old
28595. count began irresolutely to admonish Nicholas and beg him to abandon his
28596. purpose. Nicholas replied that he could not go back on his word, and his
28597. father, sighing and evidently disconcerted, very soon became silent and
28598. went in to the countess. In all his encounters with his son, the count
28599. was always conscious of his own guilt toward him for having wasted the
28600. family fortune, and so he could not be angry with him for refusing to
28601. marry an heiress and choosing the dowerless Sonya. On this occasion, he
28602. was only more vividly conscious of the fact that if his affairs had not
28603. been in disorder, no better wife for Nicholas than Sonya could have
28604. been wished for, and that no one but himself with his Mitenka and
28605. his uncomfortable habits was to blame for the condition of the family
28606. finances.
28607. 
28608. The father and mother did not speak of the matter to their son again,
28609. but a few days later the countess sent for Sonya and, with a cruelty
28610. neither of them expected, reproached her niece for trying to catch
28611. Nicholas and for ingratitude. Sonya listened silently with downcast eyes
28612. to the countess' cruel words, without understanding what was required
28613. of her. She was ready to sacrifice everything for her benefactors.
28614. Self-sacrifice was her most cherished idea but in this case she could
28615. not see what she ought to sacrifice, or for whom. She could not help
28616. loving the countess and the whole Rostov family, but neither could she
28617. help loving Nicholas and knowing that his happiness depended on that
28618. love. She was silent and sad and did not reply. Nicholas felt the
28619. situation to be intolerable and went to have an explanation with his
28620. mother. He first implored her to forgive him and Sonya and consent to
28621. their marriage, then he threatened that if she molested Sonya he would
28622. at once marry her secretly.
28623. 
28624. The countess, with a coldness her son had never seen in her before,
28625. replied that he was of age, that Prince Andrew was marrying without his
28626. father's consent, and he could do the same, but that she would never
28627. receive that intriguer as her daughter.
28628. 
28629. Exploding at the word intriguer, Nicholas, raising his voice, told
28630. his mother he had never expected her to try to force him to sell his
28631. feelings, but if that were so, he would say for the last time.... But he
28632. had no time to utter the decisive word which the expression of his face
28633. caused his mother to await with terror, and which would perhaps have
28634. forever remained a cruel memory to them both. He had not time to say it,
28635. for Natasha, with a pale and set face, entered the room from the door at
28636. which she had been listening.
28637. 
28638. "Nicholas, you are talking nonsense! Be quiet, be quiet, be quiet, I
28639. tell you!..." she almost screamed, so as to drown his voice.
28640. 
28641. "Mamma darling, it's not at all so... my poor, sweet darling," she
28642. said to her mother, who conscious that they had been on the brink of
28643. a rupture gazed at her son with terror, but in the obstinacy and
28644. excitement of the conflict could not and would not give way.
28645. 
28646. "Nicholas, I'll explain to you. Go away! Listen, Mamma darling," said
28647. Natasha.
28648. 
28649. Her words were incoherent, but they attained the purpose at which she
28650. was aiming.
28651. 
28652. The countess, sobbing heavily, hid her face on her daughter's breast,
28653. while Nicholas rose, clutching his head, and left the room.
28654. 
28655. Natasha set to work to effect a reconciliation, and so far succeeded
28656. that Nicholas received a promise from his mother that Sonya should not
28657. be troubled, while he on his side promised not to undertake anything
28658. without his parents' knowledge.
28659. 
28660. Firmly resolved, after putting his affairs in order in the regiment,
28661. to retire from the army and return and marry Sonya, Nicholas, serious,
28662. sorrowful, and at variance with his parents, but, as it seemed to him,
28663. passionately in love, left at the beginning of January to rejoin his
28664. regiment.
28665. 
28666. After Nicholas had gone things in the Rostov household were more
28667. depressing than ever, and the countess fell ill from mental agitation.
28668. 
28669. Sonya was unhappy at the separation from Nicholas and still more so on
28670. account of the hostile tone the countess could not help adopting toward
28671. her. The count was more perturbed than ever by the condition of his
28672. affairs, which called for some decisive action. Their town house and
28673. estate near Moscow had inevitably to be sold, and for this they had
28674. to go to Moscow. But the countess' health obliged them to delay their
28675. departure from day to day.
28676. 
28677. Natasha, who had borne the first period of separation from her betrothed
28678. lightly and even cheerfully, now grew more agitated and impatient every
28679. day. The thought that her best days, which she would have employed
28680. in loving him, were being vainly wasted, with no advantage to anyone,
28681. tormented her incessantly. His letters for the most part irritated her.
28682. It hurt her to think that while she lived only in the thought of him, he
28683. was living a real life, seeing new places and new people that interested
28684. him. The more interesting his letters were the more vexed she felt.
28685. Her letters to him, far from giving her any comfort, seemed to her a
28686. wearisome and artificial obligation. She could not write, because she
28687. could not conceive the possibility of expressing sincerely in a letter
28688. even a thousandth part of what she expressed by voice, smile, and
28689. glance. She wrote to him formal, monotonous, and dry letters, to which
28690. she attached no importance herself, and in the rough copies of which the
28691. countess corrected her mistakes in spelling.
28692. 
28693. There was still no improvement in the countess' health, but it was
28694. impossible to defer the journey to Moscow any longer. Natasha's
28695. trousseau had to be ordered and the house sold. Moreover, Prince Andrew
28696. was expected in Moscow, where old Prince Bolkonski was spending the
28697. winter, and Natasha felt sure he had already arrived.
28698. 
28699. So the countess remained in the country, and the count, taking Sonya and
28700. Natasha with him, went to Moscow at the end of January.
28701. 
28702. 
28703. 
28704. 
28705. 
28706. BOOK EIGHT: 1811 - 12
28707. 
28708. 
28709. 
28710. 
28711. 
28712. CHAPTER I
28713. 
28714. 
28715. After Prince Andrews engagement to Natasha, Pierre without any apparent
28716. cause suddenly felt it impossible to go on living as before. Firmly
28717. convinced as he was of the truths revealed to him by his benefactor,
28718. and happy as he had been in perfecting his inner man, to which he had
28719. devoted himself with such ardor--all the zest of such a life vanished
28720. after the engagement of Andrew and Natasha and the death of Joseph
28721. Alexeevich, the news of which reached him almost at the same time.
28722. Only the skeleton of life remained: his house, a brilliant wife who now
28723. enjoyed the favors of a very important personage, acquaintance with all
28724. Petersburg, and his court service with its dull formalities. And this
28725. life suddenly seemed to Pierre unexpectedly loathsome. He ceased keeping
28726. a diary, avoided the company of the Brothers, began going to the Club
28727. again, drank a great deal, and came once more in touch with the bachelor
28728. sets, leading such a life that the Countess Helene thought it necessary
28729. to speak severely to him about it. Pierre felt that she was right, and
28730. to avoid compromising her went away to Moscow.
28731. 
28732. In Moscow as soon as he entered his huge house in which the faded and
28733. fading princesses still lived, with its enormous retinue; as soon as,
28734. driving through the town, he saw the Iberian shrine with innumerable
28735. tapers burning before the golden covers of the icons, the Kremlin Square
28736. with its snow undisturbed by vehicles, the sleigh drivers and hovels of
28737. the Sivtsev Vrazhok, those old Moscovites who desired nothing, hurried
28738. nowhere, and were ending their days leisurely; when he saw those old
28739. Moscow ladies, the Moscow balls, and the English Club, he felt himself
28740. at home in a quiet haven. In Moscow he felt at peace, at home, warm and
28741. dirty as in an old dressing gown.
28742. 
28743. Moscow society, from the old women down to the children, received Pierre
28744. like a long-expected guest whose place was always ready awaiting him.
28745. For Moscow society Pierre was the nicest, kindest, most intellectual,
28746. merriest, and most magnanimous of cranks, a heedless, genial nobleman of
28747. the old Russian type. His purse was always empty because it was open to
28748. everyone.
28749. 
28750. Benefit performances, poor pictures, statues, benevolent societies,
28751. gypsy choirs, schools, subscription dinners, sprees, Freemasons,
28752. churches, and books--no one and nothing met with a refusal from him, and
28753. had it not been for two friends who had borrowed large sums from him and
28754. taken him under their protection, he would have given everything away.
28755. There was never a dinner or soiree at the Club without him. As soon as
28756. he sank into his place on the sofa after two bottles of Margaux he was
28757. surrounded, and talking, disputing, and joking began. When there
28758. were quarrels, his kindly smile and well-timed jests reconciled the
28759. antagonists. The Masonic dinners were dull and dreary when he was not
28760. there.
28761. 
28762. When after a bachelor supper he rose with his amiable and kindly smile,
28763. yielding to the entreaties of the festive company to drive off somewhere
28764. with them, shouts of delight and triumph arose among the young men.
28765. At balls he danced if a partner was needed. Young ladies, married and
28766. unmarried, liked him because without making love to any of them, he was
28767. equally amiable to all, especially after supper. "Il est charmant; il
28768. n'a pas de sexe," * they said of him.
28769. 
28770. 
28771.     * "He is charming; he has no sex."
28772. 
28773. 
28774. Pierre was one of those retired gentlemen-in-waiting of whom there were
28775. hundreds good-humoredly ending their days in Moscow.
28776. 
28777. How horrified he would have been seven years before, when he first
28778. arrived from abroad, had he been told that there was no need for him
28779. to seek or plan anything, that his rut had long been shaped, eternally
28780. predetermined, and that wriggle as he might, he would be what all in
28781. his position were. He could not have believed it! Had he not at one
28782. time longed with all his heart to establish a republic in Russia;
28783. then himself to be a Napoleon; then to be a philosopher; and then
28784. a strategist and the conqueror of Napoleon? Had he not seen the
28785. possibility of, and passionately desired, the regeneration of the sinful
28786. human race, and his own progress to the highest degree of perfection?
28787. Had he not established schools and hospitals and liberated his serfs?
28788. 
28789. But instead of all that--here he was, the wealthy husband of an
28790. unfaithful wife, a retired gentleman-in-waiting, fond of eating and
28791. drinking and, as he unbuttoned his waistcoat, of abusing the government
28792. a bit, a member of the Moscow English Club, and a universal favorite in
28793. Moscow society. For a long time he could not reconcile himself to the
28794. idea that he was one of those same retired Moscow gentlemen-in-waiting
28795. he had so despised seven years before.
28796. 
28797. Sometimes he consoled himself with the thought that he was only living
28798. this life temporarily; but then he was shocked by the thought of how
28799. many, like himself, had entered that life and that Club temporarily,
28800. with all their teeth and hair, and had only left it when not a single
28801. tooth or hair remained.
28802. 
28803. In moments of pride, when he thought of his position it seemed to
28804. him that he was quite different and distinct from those other retired
28805. gentlemen-in-waiting he had formerly despised: they were empty, stupid,
28806. contented fellows, satisfied with their position, "while I am still
28807. discontented and want to do something for mankind. But perhaps all these
28808. comrades of mine struggled just like me and sought something new, a
28809. path in life of their own, and like me were brought by force of
28810. circumstances, society, and race--by that elemental force against which
28811. man is powerless--to the condition I am in," said he to himself in
28812. moments of humility; and after living some time in Moscow he no longer
28813. despised, but began to grow fond of, to respect, and to pity his
28814. comrades in destiny, as he pitied himself.
28815. 
28816. Pierre no longer suffered moments of despair, hypochondria, and disgust
28817. with life, but the malady that had formerly found expression in such
28818. acute attacks was driven inwards and never left him for a moment.
28819. "What for? Why? What is going on in the world?" he would ask himself in
28820. perplexity several times a day, involuntarily beginning to reflect anew
28821. on the meaning of the phenomena of life; but knowing by experience that
28822. there were no answers to these questions he made haste to turn away
28823. from them, and took up a book, or hurried of to the Club or to Apollon
28824. Nikolaevich's, to exchange the gossip of the town.
28825. 
28826. "Helene, who has never cared for anything but her own body and is one
28827. of the stupidest women in the world," thought Pierre, "is regarded by
28828. people as the acme of intelligence and refinement, and they pay homage
28829. to her. Napoleon Bonaparte was despised by all as long as he was great,
28830. but now that he has become a wretched comedian the Emperor Francis wants
28831. to offer him his daughter in an illegal marriage. The Spaniards, through
28832. the Catholic clergy, offer praise to God for their victory over the
28833. French on the fourteenth of June, and the French, also through the
28834. Catholic clergy, offer praise because on that same fourteenth of June
28835. they defeated the Spaniards. My brother Masons swear by the blood that
28836. they are ready to sacrifice everything for their neighbor, but they
28837. do not give a ruble each to the collections for the poor, and they
28838. intrigue, the Astraea Lodge against the Manna Seekers, and fuss about an
28839. authentic Scotch carpet and a charter that nobody needs, and the meaning
28840. of which the very man who wrote it does not understand. We all profess
28841. the Christian law of forgiveness of injuries and love of our neighbors,
28842. the law in honor of which we have built in Moscow forty times forty
28843. churches--but yesterday a deserter was knouted to death and a minister
28844. of that same law of love and forgiveness, a priest, gave the soldier a
28845. cross to kiss before his execution." So thought Pierre, and the whole of
28846. this general deception which everyone accepts, accustomed as he was to
28847. it, astonished him each time as if it were something new. "I understand
28848. the deception and confusion," he thought, "but how am I to tell them
28849. all that I see? I have tried, and have always found that they too in the
28850. depths of their souls understand it as I do, and only try not to see
28851. it. So it appears that it must be so! But I--what is to become of
28852. me?" thought he. He had the unfortunate capacity many men, especially
28853. Russians, have of seeing and believing in the possibility of goodness
28854. and truth, but of seeing the evil and falsehood of life too clearly
28855. to be able to take a serious part in it. Every sphere of work was
28856. connected, in his eyes, with evil and deception. Whatever he tried to
28857. be, whatever he engaged in, the evil and falsehood of it repulsed him
28858. and blocked every path of activity. Yet he had to live and to find
28859. occupation. It was too dreadful to be under the burden of these
28860. insoluble problems, so he abandoned himself to any distraction in order
28861. to forget them. He frequented every kind of society, drank much, bought
28862. pictures, engaged in building, and above all--read.
28863. 
28864. He read, and read everything that came to hand. On coming home, while
28865. his valets were still taking off his things, he picked up a book and
28866. began to read. From reading he passed to sleeping, from sleeping to
28867. gossip in drawing rooms of the Club, from gossip to carousals and women;
28868. from carousals back to gossip, reading, and wine. Drinking became more
28869. and more a physical and also a moral necessity. Though the doctors
28870. warned him that with his corpulence wine was dangerous for him, he
28871. drank a great deal. He was only quite at ease when having poured several
28872. glasses of wine mechanically into his large mouth he felt a pleasant
28873. warmth in his body, an amiability toward all his fellows, and a
28874. readiness to respond superficially to every idea without probing it
28875. deeply. Only after emptying a bottle or two did he feel dimly that the
28876. terribly tangled skein of life which previously had terrified him was
28877. not as dreadful as he had thought. He was always conscious of some
28878. aspect of that skein, as with a buzzing in his head after dinner or
28879. supper he chatted or listened to conversation or read. But under the
28880. influence of wine he said to himself: "It doesn't matter. I'll get it
28881. unraveled. I have a solution ready, but have no time now--I'll think it
28882. all out later on!" But the later on never came.
28883. 
28884. In the morning, on an empty stomach, all the old questions appeared as
28885. insoluble and terrible as ever, and Pierre hastily picked up a book, and
28886. if anyone came to see him he was glad.
28887. 
28888. Sometimes he remembered how he had heard that soldiers in war when
28889. entrenched under the enemy's fire, if they have nothing to do, try hard
28890. to find some occupation the more easily to bear the danger. To Pierre
28891. all men seemed like those soldiers, seeking refuge from life: some in
28892. ambition, some in cards, some in framing laws, some in women, some in
28893. toys, some in horses, some in politics, some in sport, some in wine,
28894. and some in governmental affairs. "Nothing is trivial, and nothing is
28895. important, it's all the same--only to save oneself from it as best one
28896. can," thought Pierre. "Only not to see it, that dreadful it!"
28897. 
28898. 
28899. 
28900. 
28901. 
28902. CHAPTER II
28903. 
28904. 
28905. At the beginning of winter Prince Nicholas Bolkonski and his daughter
28906. moved to Moscow. At that time enthusiasm for the Emperor Alexander's
28907. regime had weakened and a patriotic and anti-French tendency prevailed
28908. there, and this, together with his past and his intellect and his
28909. originality, at once made Prince Nicholas Bolkonski an object of
28910. particular respect to the Moscovites and the center of the Moscow
28911. opposition to the government.
28912. 
28913. The prince had aged very much that year. He showed marked signs of
28914. senility by a tendency to fall asleep, forgetfulness of quite recent
28915. events, remembrance of remote ones, and the childish vanity with which
28916. he accepted the role of head of the Moscow opposition. In spite of this
28917. the old man inspired in all his visitors alike a feeling of respectful
28918. veneration--especially of an evening when he came in to tea in his
28919. old-fashioned coat and powdered wig and, aroused by anyone, told his
28920. abrupt stories of the past, or uttered yet more abrupt and scathing
28921. criticisms of the present. For them all, that old-fashioned house with
28922. its gigantic mirrors, pre-Revolution furniture, powdered footmen, and
28923. the stern shrewd old man (himself a relic of the past century) with his
28924. gentle daughter and the pretty Frenchwoman who were reverently devoted
28925. to him presented a majestic and agreeable spectacle. But the visitors
28926. did not reflect that besides the couple of hours during which they saw
28927. their host, there were also twenty-two hours in the day during which the
28928. private and intimate life of the house continued.
28929. 
28930. Latterly that private life had become very trying for Princess Mary.
28931. There in Moscow she was deprived of her greatest pleasures--talks with
28932. the pilgrims and the solitude which refreshed her at Bald Hills--and she
28933. had none of the advantages and pleasures of city life. She did not go
28934. out into society; everyone knew that her father would not let her go
28935. anywhere without him, and his failing health prevented his going out
28936. himself, so that she was not invited to dinners and evening parties. She
28937. had quite abandoned the hope of getting married. She saw the coldness
28938. and malevolence with which the old prince received and dismissed the
28939. young men, possible suitors, who sometimes appeared at their house. She
28940. had no friends: during this visit to Moscow she had been disappointed in
28941. the two who had been nearest to her. Mademoiselle Bourienne, with whom
28942. she had never been able to be quite frank, had now become unpleasant to
28943. her, and for various reasons Princess Mary avoided her. Julie, with whom
28944. she had corresponded for the last five years, was in Moscow, but proved
28945. to be quite alien to her when they met. Just then Julie, who by the
28946. death of her brothers had become one of the richest heiresses in Moscow,
28947. was in the full whirl of society pleasures. She was surrounded by young
28948. men who, she fancied, had suddenly learned to appreciate her worth.
28949. Julie was at that stage in the life of a society woman when she feels
28950. that her last chance of marrying has come and that her fate must be
28951. decided now or never. On Thursdays Princess Mary remembered with a
28952. mournful smile that she now had no one to write to, since Julie--whose
28953. presence gave her no pleasure was here and they met every week. Like
28954. the old emigre who declined to marry the lady with whom he had spent his
28955. evenings for years, she regretted Julie's presence and having no one to
28956. write to. In Moscow Princess Mary had no one to talk to, no one to whom
28957. to confide her sorrow, and much sorrow fell to her lot just then. The
28958. time for Prince Andrew's return and marriage was approaching, but his
28959. request to her to prepare his father for it had not been carried out; in
28960. fact, it seemed as if matters were quite hopeless, for at every mention
28961. of the young Countess Rostova the old prince (who apart from that was
28962. usually in a bad temper) lost control of himself. Another lately added
28963. sorrow arose from the lessons she gave her six year-old nephew. To her
28964. consternation she detected in herself in relation to little Nicholas
28965. some symptoms of her father's irritability. However often she told
28966. herself that she must not get irritable when teaching her nephew, almost
28967. every time that, pointer in hand, she sat down to show him the French
28968. alphabet, she so longed to pour her own knowledge quickly and easily
28969. into the child--who was already afraid that Auntie might at any moment
28970. get angry--that at his slightest inattention she trembled, became
28971. flustered and heated, raised her voice, and sometimes pulled him by the
28972. arm and put him in the corner. Having put him in the corner she would
28973. herself begin to cry over her cruel, evil nature, and little Nicholas,
28974. following her example, would sob, and without permission would leave his
28975. corner, come to her, pull her wet hands from her face, and comfort
28976. her. But what distressed the princess most of all was her father's
28977. irritability, which was always directed against her and had of late
28978. amounted to cruelty. Had he forced her to prostrate herself to the
28979. ground all night, had he beaten her or made her fetch wood or water, it
28980. would never have entered her mind to think her position hard; but this
28981. loving despot--the more cruel because he loved her and for that reason
28982. tormented himself and her--knew how not merely to hurt and humiliate
28983. her deliberately, but to show her that she was always to blame for
28984. everything. Of late he had exhibited a new trait that tormented Princess
28985. Mary more than anything else; this was his ever-increasing intimacy with
28986. Mademoiselle Bourienne. The idea that at the first moment of receiving
28987. the news of his son's intentions had occurred to him in jest--that
28988. if Andrew got married he himself would marry Bourienne--had evidently
28989. pleased him, and latterly he had persistently, and as it seemed to
28990. Princess Mary merely to offend her, shown special endearments to
28991. the companion and expressed his dissatisfaction with his daughter by
28992. demonstrations of love of Bourienne.
28993. 
28994. One day in Moscow in Princess Mary's presence (she thought her father
28995. did it purposely when she was there) the old prince kissed Mademoiselle
28996. Bourienne's hand and, drawing her to him, embraced her affectionately.
28997. Princess Mary flushed and ran out of the room. A few minutes later
28998. Mademoiselle Bourienne came into Princess Mary's room smiling and making
28999. cheerful remarks in her agreeable voice. Princess Mary hastily wiped
29000. away her tears, went resolutely up to Mademoiselle Bourienne, and
29001. evidently unconscious of what she was doing began shouting in angry
29002. haste at the Frenchwoman, her voice breaking: "It's horrible, vile,
29003. inhuman, to take advantage of the weakness..." She did not finish.
29004. "Leave my room," she exclaimed, and burst into sobs.
29005. 
29006. Next day the prince did not say a word to his daughter, but she noticed
29007. that at dinner he gave orders that Mademoiselle Bourienne should be
29008. served first. After dinner, when the footman handed coffee and from
29009. habit began with the princess, the prince suddenly grew furious,
29010. threw his stick at Philip, and instantly gave instructions to have him
29011. conscripted for the army.
29012. 
29013. "He doesn't obey... I said it twice... and he doesn't obey! She is the
29014. first person in this house; she's my best friend," cried the prince.
29015. "And if you allow yourself," he screamed in a fury, addressing Princess
29016. Mary for the first time, "to forget yourself again before her as you
29017. dared to do yesterday, I will show you who is master in this house. Go!
29018. Don't let me set eyes on you; beg her pardon!"
29019. 
29020. Princess Mary asked Mademoiselle Bourienne's pardon, and also her
29021. father's pardon for herself and for Philip the footman, who had begged
29022. for her intervention.
29023. 
29024. At such moments something like a pride of sacrifice gathered in her
29025. soul. And suddenly that father whom she had judged would look for his
29026. spectacles in her presence, fumbling near them and not seeing them, or
29027. would forget something that had just occurred, or take a false step with
29028. his failing legs and turn to see if anyone had noticed his feebleness,
29029. or, worst of all, at dinner when there were no visitors to excite him
29030. would suddenly fall asleep, letting his napkin drop and his shaking head
29031. sink over his plate. "He is old and feeble, and I dare to condemn
29032. him!" she thought at such moments, with a feeling of revulsion against
29033. herself.
29034. 
29035. 
29036. 
29037. 
29038. 
29039. CHAPTER III
29040. 
29041. 
29042. In 1811 there was living in Moscow a French doctor--Metivier--who had
29043. rapidly become the fashion. He was enormously tall, handsome, amiable
29044. as Frenchmen are, and was, as all Moscow said, an extraordinarily clever
29045. doctor. He was received in the best houses not merely as a doctor, but
29046. as an equal.
29047. 
29048. Prince Nicholas had always ridiculed medicine, but latterly on
29049. Mademoiselle Bourienne's advice had allowed this doctor to visit him and
29050. had grown accustomed to him. Metivier came to see the prince about twice
29051. a week.
29052. 
29053. On December 6--St. Nicholas' Day and the prince's name day--all Moscow
29054. came to the prince's front door but he gave orders to admit no one
29055. and to invite to dinner only a small number, a list of whom he gave to
29056. Princess Mary.
29057. 
29058. Metivier, who came in the morning with his felicitations, considered
29059. it proper in his quality of doctor de forcer la consigne, * as he told
29060. Princess Mary, and went in to see the prince. It happened that on that
29061. morning of his name day the prince was in one of his worst moods. He had
29062. been going about the house all the morning finding fault with everyone
29063. and pretending not to understand what was said to him and not to be
29064. understood himself. Princess Mary well knew this mood of quiet absorbed
29065. querulousness, which generally culminated in a burst of rage, and she
29066. went about all that morning as though facing a cocked and loaded gun and
29067. awaited the inevitable explosion. Until the doctor's arrival the morning
29068. had passed off safely. After admitting the doctor, Princess Mary sat
29069. down with a book in the drawing room near the door through which she
29070. could hear all that passed in the study.
29071. 
29072. 
29073.     * To force the guard.
29074. 
29075. 
29076. At first she heard only Metivier's voice, then her father's, then both
29077. voices began speaking at the same time, the door was flung open, and
29078. on the threshold appeared the handsome figure of the terrified Metivier
29079. with his shock of black hair, and the prince in his dressing gown and
29080. fez, his face distorted with fury and the pupils of his eyes rolled
29081. downwards.
29082. 
29083. "You don't understand?" shouted the prince, "but I do! French spy, slave
29084. of Buonaparte, spy, get out of my house! Be off, I tell you..."
29085. 
29086. Metivier, shrugging his shoulders, went up to Mademoiselle Bourienne who
29087. at the sound of shouting had run in from an adjoining room.
29088. 
29089. "The prince is not very well: bile and rush of blood to the head.
29090. Keep calm, I will call again tomorrow," said Metivier; and putting his
29091. fingers to his lips he hastened away.
29092. 
29093. Through the study door came the sound of slippered feet and the cry:
29094. "Spies, traitors, traitors everywhere! Not a moment's peace in my own
29095. house!"
29096. 
29097. After Metivier's departure the old prince called his daughter in, and
29098. the whole weight of his wrath fell on her. She was to blame that a spy
29099. had been admitted. Had he not told her, yes, told her to make a list,
29100. and not to admit anyone who was not on that list? Then why was that
29101. scoundrel admitted? She was the cause of it all. With her, he said, he
29102. could not have a moment's peace and could not die quietly.
29103. 
29104. "No, ma'am! We must part, we must part! Understand that, understand
29105. it! I cannot endure any more," he said, and left the room. Then, as if
29106. afraid she might find some means of consolation, he returned and trying
29107. to appear calm added: "And don't imagine I have said this in a moment of
29108. anger. I am calm. I have thought it over, and it will be carried
29109. out--we must part; so find some place for yourself...." But he could not
29110. restrain himself and with the virulence of which only one who loves
29111. is capable, evidently suffering himself, he shook his fists at her and
29112. screamed:
29113. 
29114. "If only some fool would marry her!" Then he slammed the door, sent for
29115. Mademoiselle Bourienne, and subsided into his study.
29116. 
29117. At two o'clock the six chosen guests assembled for dinner.
29118. 
29119. These guests--the famous Count Rostopchin, Prince Lopukhin with his
29120. nephew, General Chatrov an old war comrade of the prince's, and of the
29121. younger generation Pierre and Boris Drubetskoy--awaited the prince in
29122. the drawing room.
29123. 
29124. Boris, who had come to Moscow on leave a few days before, had been
29125. anxious to be presented to Prince Nicholas Bolkonski, and had contrived
29126. to ingratiate himself so well that the old prince in his case made an
29127. exception to the rule of not receiving bachelors in his house.
29128. 
29129. The prince's house did not belong to what is known as fashionable
29130. society, but his little circle--though not much talked about in
29131. town--was one it was more flattering to be received in than any other.
29132. Boris had realized this the week before when the commander in chief
29133. in his presence invited Rostopchin to dinner on St. Nicholas' Day, and
29134. Rostopchin had replied that he could not come:
29135. 
29136. "On that day I always go to pay my devotions to the relics of Prince
29137. Nicholas Bolkonski."
29138. 
29139. "Oh, yes, yes!" replied the commander in chief. "How is he?..."
29140. 
29141. The small group that assembled before dinner in the lofty old-fashioned
29142. drawing room with its old furniture resembled the solemn gathering of
29143. a court of justice. All were silent or talked in low tones. Prince
29144. Nicholas came in serious and taciturn. Princess Mary seemed even quieter
29145. and more diffident than usual. The guests were reluctant to address her,
29146. feeling that she was in no mood for their conversation. Count Rostopchin
29147. alone kept the conversation going, now relating the latest town news,
29148. and now the latest political gossip.
29149. 
29150. Lopukhin and the old general occasionally took part in the conversation.
29151. Prince Bolkonski listened as a presiding judge receives a report, only
29152. now and then, silently or by a brief word, showing that he took heed of
29153. what was being reported to him. The tone of the conversation was such as
29154. indicated that no one approved of what was being done in the political
29155. world. Incidents were related evidently confirming the opinion that
29156. everything was going from bad to worse, but whether telling a story or
29157. giving an opinion the speaker always stopped, or was stopped, at the
29158. point beyond which his criticism might touch the sovereign himself.
29159. 
29160. At dinner the talk turned on the latest political news: Napoleon's
29161. seizure of the Duke of Oldenburg's territory, and the Russian Note,
29162. hostile to Napoleon, which had been sent to all the European courts.
29163. 
29164. "Bonaparte treats Europe as a pirate does a captured vessel," said Count
29165. Rostopchin, repeating a phrase he had uttered several times before. "One
29166. only wonders at the long-suffering or blindness of the crowned heads.
29167. Now the Pope's turn has come and Bonaparte doesn't scruple to depose the
29168. head of the Catholic Church--yet all keep silent! Our sovereign alone
29169. has protested against the seizure of the Duke of Oldenburg's territory,
29170. and even..." Count Rostopchin paused, feeling that he had reached the
29171. limit beyond which censure was impossible.
29172. 
29173. "Other territories have been offered in exchange for the Duchy of
29174. Oldenburg," said Prince Bolkonski. "He shifts the Dukes about as I might
29175. move my serfs from Bald Hills to Bogucharovo or my Ryazan estates."
29176. 
29177. "The Duke of Oldenburg bears his misfortunes with admirable strength of
29178. character and resignation," remarked Boris, joining in respectfully.
29179. 
29180. He said this because on his journey from Petersburg he had had the honor
29181. of being presented to the Duke. Prince Bolkonski glanced at the young
29182. man as if about to say something in reply, but changed his mind,
29183. evidently considering him too young.
29184. 
29185. "I have read our protests about the Oldenburg affair and was surprised
29186. how badly the Note was worded," remarked Count Rostopchin in the casual
29187. tone of a man dealing with a subject quite familiar to him.
29188. 
29189. Pierre looked at Rostopchin with naive astonishment, not understanding
29190. why he should be disturbed by the bad composition of the Note.
29191. 
29192. "Does it matter, Count, how the Note is worded," he asked, "so long as
29193. its substance is forcible?"
29194. 
29195. "My dear fellow, with our five hundred thousand troops it should be easy
29196. to have a good style," returned Count Rostopchin.
29197. 
29198. Pierre now understood the count's dissatisfaction with the wording of
29199. the Note.
29200. 
29201. "One would have thought quill drivers enough had sprung up," remarked
29202. the old prince. "There in Petersburg they are always writing--not notes
29203. only but even new laws. My Andrew there has written a whole volume
29204. of laws for Russia. Nowadays they are always writing!" and he laughed
29205. unnaturally.
29206. 
29207. There was a momentary pause in the conversation; the old general cleared
29208. his throat to draw attention.
29209. 
29210. "Did you hear of the last event at the review in Petersburg? The figure
29211. cut by the new French ambassador."
29212. 
29213. "Eh? Yes, I heard something: he said something awkward in His Majesty's
29214. presence."
29215. 
29216. "His Majesty drew attention to the Grenadier division and to the march
29217. past," continued the general, "and it seems the ambassador took no
29218. notice and allowed himself to reply that: 'We in France pay no attention
29219. to such trifles!' The Emperor did not condescend to reply. At the next
29220. review, they say, the Emperor did not once deign to address him."
29221. 
29222. All were silent. On this fact relating to the Emperor personally, it was
29223. impossible to pass any judgment.
29224. 
29225. "Impudent fellows!" said the prince. "You know Metivier? I turned him
29226. out of my house this morning. He was here; they admitted him in spite of
29227. my request that they should let no one in," he went on, glancing angrily
29228. at his daughter.
29229. 
29230. And he narrated his whole conversation with the French doctor and the
29231. reasons that convinced him that Metivier was a spy. Though these reasons
29232. were very insufficient and obscure, no one made any rejoinder.
29233. 
29234. After the roast, champagne was served. The guests rose to congratulate
29235. the old prince. Princess Mary, too, went round to him.
29236. 
29237. He gave her a cold, angry look and offered her his wrinkled,
29238. clean-shaven cheek to kiss. The whole expression of his face told her
29239. that he had not forgotten the morning's talk, that his decision remained
29240. in force, and only the presence of visitors hindered his speaking of it
29241. to her now.
29242. 
29243. When they went into the drawing room where coffee was served, the old
29244. men sat together.
29245. 
29246. Prince Nicholas grew more animated and expressed his views on the
29247. impending war.
29248. 
29249. He said that our wars with Bonaparte would be disastrous so long as we
29250. sought alliances with the Germans and thrust ourselves into European
29251. affairs, into which we had been drawn by the Peace of Tilsit. "We ought
29252. not to fight either for or against Austria. Our political interests are
29253. all in the East, and in regard to Bonaparte the only thing is to have
29254. an armed frontier and a firm policy, and he will never dare to cross the
29255. Russian frontier, as was the case in 1807!"
29256. 
29257. "How can we fight the French, Prince?" said Count Rostopchin. "Can we
29258. arm ourselves against our teachers and divinities? Look at our youths,
29259. look at our ladies! The French are our Gods: Paris is our Kingdom of
29260. Heaven."
29261. 
29262. He began speaking louder, evidently to be heard by everyone.
29263. 
29264. "French dresses, French ideas, French feelings! There now, you turned
29265. Metivier out by the scruff of his neck because he is a Frenchman and a
29266. scoundrel, but our ladies crawl after him on their knees. I went to
29267. a party last night, and there out of five ladies three were Roman
29268. Catholics and had the Pope's indulgence for doing woolwork on Sundays.
29269. And they themselves sit there nearly naked, like the signboards at our
29270. Public Baths if I may say so. Ah, when one looks at our young people,
29271. Prince, one would like to take Peter the Great's old cudgel out of the
29272. museum and belabor them in the Russian way till all the nonsense jumps
29273. out of them."
29274. 
29275. All were silent. The old prince looked at Rostopchin with a smile and
29276. wagged his head approvingly.
29277. 
29278. "Well, good-by, your excellency, keep well!" said Rostopchin, getting up
29279. with characteristic briskness and holding out his hand to the prince.
29280. 
29281. "Good-by, my dear fellow.... His words are music, I never tire of
29282. hearing him!" said the old prince, keeping hold of the hand and offering
29283. his cheek to be kissed.
29284. 
29285. Following Rostopchin's example the others also rose.
29286. 
29287. 
29288. 
29289. 
29290. 
29291. CHAPTER IV
29292. 
29293. 
29294. Princess Mary as she sat listening to the old men's talk and
29295. faultfinding, understood nothing of what she heard; she only wondered
29296. whether the guests had all observed her father's hostile attitude toward
29297. her. She did not even notice the special attentions and amiabilities
29298. shown her during dinner by Boris Drubetskoy, who was visiting them for
29299. the third time already.
29300. 
29301. Princess Mary turned with absent-minded questioning look to Pierre, who
29302. hat in hand and with a smile on his face was the last of the guests to
29303. approach her after the old prince had gone out and they were left alone
29304. in the drawing room.
29305. 
29306. "May I stay a little longer?" he said, letting his stout body sink into
29307. an armchair beside her.
29308. 
29309. "Oh yes," she answered. "You noticed nothing?" her look asked.
29310. 
29311. Pierre was in an agreeable after-dinner mood. He looked straight before
29312. him and smiled quietly.
29313. 
29314. "Have you known that young man long, Princess?" he asked.
29315. 
29316. "Who?"
29317. 
29318. "Drubetskoy."
29319. 
29320. "No, not long..."
29321. 
29322. "Do you like him?"
29323. 
29324. "Yes, he is an agreeable young man.... Why do you ask me that?" said
29325. Princess Mary, still thinking of that morning's conversation with her
29326. father.
29327. 
29328. "Because I have noticed that when a young man comes on leave from
29329. Petersburg to Moscow it is usually with the object of marrying an
29330. heiress."
29331. 
29332. "You have observed that?" said Princess Mary.
29333. 
29334. "Yes," returned Pierre with a smile, "and this young man now manages
29335. matters so that where there is a wealthy heiress there he is too. I
29336. can read him like a book. At present he is hesitating whom to lay siege
29337. to--you or Mademoiselle Julie Karagina. He is very attentive to her."
29338. 
29339. "He visits them?"
29340. 
29341. "Yes, very often. And do you know the new way of courting?" said Pierre
29342. with an amused smile, evidently in that cheerful mood of good humored
29343. raillery for which he so often reproached himself in his diary.
29344. 
29345. "No," replied Princess Mary.
29346. 
29347. "To please Moscow girls nowadays one has to be melancholy. He is very
29348. melancholy with Mademoiselle Karagina," said Pierre.
29349. 
29350. "Really?" asked Princess Mary, looking into Pierre's kindly face and
29351. still thinking of her own sorrow. "It would be a relief," thought she,
29352. "if I ventured to confide what I am feeling to someone. I should like
29353. to tell everything to Pierre. He is kind and generous. It would be a
29354. relief. He would give me advice."
29355. 
29356. "Would you marry him?"
29357. 
29358. "Oh, my God, Count, there are moments when I would marry anybody!" she
29359. cried suddenly to her own surprise and with tears in her voice. "Ah, how
29360. bitter it is to love someone near to you and to feel that..." she went
29361. on in a trembling voice, "that you can do nothing for him but grieve
29362. him, and to know that you cannot alter this. Then there is only one
29363. thing left--to go away, but where could I go?"
29364. 
29365. "What is wrong? What is it, Princess?"
29366. 
29367. But without finishing what she was saying, Princess Mary burst into
29368. tears.
29369. 
29370. "I don't know what is the matter with me today. Don't take any
29371. notice--forget what I have said!"
29372. 
29373. Pierre's gaiety vanished completely. He anxiously questioned the
29374. princess, asked her to speak out fully and confide her grief to him; but
29375. she only repeated that she begged him to forget what she had said, that
29376. she did not remember what she had said, and that she had no trouble
29377. except the one he knew of--that Prince Andrew's marriage threatened to
29378. cause a rupture between father and son.
29379. 
29380. "Have you any news of the Rostovs?" she asked, to change the subject.
29381. "I was told they are coming soon. I am also expecting Andrew any day. I
29382. should like them to meet here."
29383. 
29384. "And how does he now regard the matter?" asked Pierre, referring to the
29385. old prince.
29386. 
29387. Princess Mary shook her head.
29388. 
29389. "What is to be done? In a few months the year will be up. The thing is
29390. impossible. I only wish I could spare my brother the first moments. I
29391. wish they would come sooner. I hope to be friends with her. You have
29392. known them a long time," said Princess Mary. "Tell me honestly the whole
29393. truth: what sort of girl is she, and what do you think of her?--The real
29394. truth, because you know Andrew is risking so much doing this against his
29395. father's will that I should like to know..."
29396. 
29397. An undefined instinct told Pierre that these explanations, and repeated
29398. requests to be told the whole truth, expressed ill-will on the
29399. princess' part toward her future sister-in-law and a wish that he should
29400. disapprove of Andrew's choice; but in reply he said what he felt rather
29401. than what he thought.
29402. 
29403. "I don't know how to answer your question," he said, blushing without
29404. knowing why. "I really don't know what sort of girl she is; I can't
29405. analyze her at all. She is enchanting, but what makes her so I don't
29406. know. That is all one can say about her."
29407. 
29408. Princess Mary sighed, and the expression on her face said: "Yes, that's
29409. what I expected and feared."
29410. 
29411. "Is she clever?" she asked.
29412. 
29413. Pierre considered.
29414. 
29415. "I think not," he said, "and yet--yes. She does not deign to be
29416. clever.... Oh no, she is simply enchanting, and that is all."
29417. 
29418. Princess Mary again shook her head disapprovingly.
29419. 
29420. "Ah, I so long to like her! Tell her so if you see her before I do."
29421. 
29422. "I hear they are expected very soon," said Pierre.
29423. 
29424. Princess Mary told Pierre of her plan to become intimate with her future
29425. sister-in-law as soon as the Rostovs arrived and to try to accustom the
29426. old prince to her.
29427. 
29428. 
29429. 
29430. 
29431. 
29432. CHAPTER V
29433. 
29434. 
29435. Boris had not succeeded in making a wealthy match in Petersburg, so with
29436. the same object in view he came to Moscow. There he wavered between the
29437. two richest heiresses, Julie and Princess Mary. Though Princess Mary
29438. despite her plainness seemed to him more attractive than Julie, he,
29439. without knowing why, felt awkward about paying court to her. When they
29440. had last met on the old prince's name day, she had answered at random
29441. all his attempts to talk sentimentally, evidently not listening to what
29442. he was saying.
29443. 
29444. Julie on the contrary accepted his attentions readily, though in a
29445. manner peculiar to herself.
29446. 
29447. She was twenty-seven. After the death of her brothers she had become
29448. very wealthy. She was by now decidedly plain, but thought herself not
29449. merely as good-looking as before but even far more attractive. She
29450. was confirmed in this delusion by the fact that she had become a very
29451. wealthy heiress and also by the fact that the older she grew the less
29452. dangerous she became to men, and the more freely they could associate
29453. with her and avail themselves of her suppers, soirees, and the animated
29454. company that assembled at her house, without incurring any obligation.
29455. A man who would have been afraid ten years before of going every day
29456. to the house when there was a girl of seventeen there, for fear of
29457. compromising her and committing himself, would now go boldly every day
29458. and treat her not as a marriageable girl but as a sexless acquaintance.
29459. 
29460. That winter the Karagins' house was the most agreeable and hospitable
29461. in Moscow. In addition to the formal evening and dinner parties, a large
29462. company, chiefly of men, gathered there every day, supping at midnight
29463. and staying till three in the morning. Julie never missed a ball, a
29464. promenade, or a play. Her dresses were always of the latest fashion.
29465. But in spite of that she seemed to be disillusioned about everything and
29466. told everyone that she did not believe either in friendship or in
29467. love, or any of the joys of life, and expected peace only "yonder." She
29468. adopted the tone of one who has suffered a great disappointment, like a
29469. girl who has either lost the man she loved or been cruelly deceived by
29470. him. Though nothing of the kind had happened to her she was regarded in
29471. that light, and had even herself come to believe that she had suffered
29472. much in life. This melancholy, which did not prevent her amusing
29473. herself, did not hinder the young people who came to her house from
29474. passing the time pleasantly. Every visitor who came to the house paid
29475. his tribute to the melancholy mood of the hostess, and then amused
29476. himself with society gossip, dancing, intellectual games, and bouts
29477. rimes, which were in vogue at the Karagins'. Only a few of these young
29478. men, among them Boris, entered more deeply into Julie's melancholy, and
29479. with these she had prolonged conversations in private on the vanity
29480. of all worldly things, and to them she showed her albums filled with
29481. mournful sketches, maxims, and verses.
29482. 
29483. To Boris, Julie was particularly gracious: she regretted his early
29484. disillusionment with life, offered him such consolation of friendship
29485. as she who had herself suffered so much could render, and showed him her
29486. album. Boris sketched two trees in the album and wrote: "Rustic trees,
29487. your dark branches shed gloom and melancholy upon me."
29488. 
29489. On another page he drew a tomb, and wrote:
29490. 
29491.     La mort est secourable et la mort est tranquille.
29492.     Ah! contre les douleurs il n'y a pas d'autre asile. *
29493. 
29494. 
29495.     * Death gives relief and death is peaceful.
29496. 
29497. 
29498. Ah! from suffering there is no other refuge.
29499. 
29500. Julie said this was charming
29501. 
29502. "There is something so enchanting in the smile of melancholy," she said
29503. to Boris, repeating word for word a passage she had copied from a book.
29504. "It is a ray of light in the darkness, a shade between sadness and
29505. despair, showing the possibility of consolation."
29506. 
29507. In reply Boris wrote these lines:
29508. 
29509.     Aliment de poison d'une ame trop sensible,
29510.     Toi, sans qui le bonheur me serait impossible,
29511.     Tendre melancholie, ah, viens me consoler,
29512.     Viens calmer les tourments de ma sombre retraite,
29513.     Et mele une douceur secrete
29514.     A ces pleurs que je sens couler. *
29515. 
29516. 
29517.       *Poisonous nourishment of a too sensitive soul,
29518.      Thou, without whom happiness would for me be impossible,
29519.      Tender melancholy, ah, come to console me,
29520.      Come to calm the torments of my gloomy retreat,
29521.      And mingle a secret sweetness
29522.      With these tears that I feel to be flowing.
29523. 
29524. 
29525. For Boris, Julie played most doleful nocturnes on her harp. Boris read
29526. Poor Liza aloud to her, and more than once interrupted the reading
29527. because of the emotions that choked him. Meeting at large gatherings
29528. Julie and Boris looked on one another as the only souls who understood
29529. one another in a world of indifferent people.
29530. 
29531. Anna Mikhaylovna, who often visited the Karagins, while playing cards
29532. with the mother made careful inquiries as to Julie's dowry (she was to
29533. have two estates in Penza and the Nizhegorod forests). Anna Mikhaylovna
29534. regarded the refined sadness that united her son to the wealthy Julie
29535. with emotion, and resignation to the Divine will.
29536. 
29537. "You are always charming and melancholy, my dear Julie," she said to
29538. the daughter. "Boris says his soul finds repose at your house. He has
29539. suffered so many disappointments and is so sensitive," said she to the
29540. mother. "Ah, my dear, I can't tell you how fond I have grown of Julie
29541. latterly," she said to her son. "But who could help loving her? She is
29542. an angelic being! Ah, Boris, Boris!"--she paused. "And how I pity her
29543. mother," she went on; "today she showed me her accounts and letters from
29544. Penza (they have enormous estates there), and she, poor thing, has no
29545. one to help her, and they do cheat her so!"
29546. 
29547. Boris smiled almost imperceptibly while listening to his mother. He
29548. laughed blandly at her naive diplomacy but listened to what she had
29549. to say, and sometimes questioned her carefully about the Penza and
29550. Nizhegorod estates.
29551. 
29552. Julie had long been expecting a proposal from her melancholy adorer and
29553. was ready to accept it; but some secret feeling of repulsion for her,
29554. for her passionate desire to get married, for her artificiality, and
29555. a feeling of horror at renouncing the possibility of real love still
29556. restrained Boris. His leave was expiring. He spent every day and whole
29557. days at the Karagins', and every day on thinking the matter over told
29558. himself that he would propose tomorrow. But in Julie's presence, looking
29559. at her red face and chin (nearly always powdered), her moist eyes, and
29560. her expression of continual readiness to pass at once from melancholy
29561. to an unnatural rapture of married bliss, Boris could not utter the
29562. decisive words, though in imagination he had long regarded himself as
29563. the possessor of those Penza and Nizhegorod estates and had apportioned
29564. the use of the income from them. Julie saw Boris' indecision, and
29565. sometimes the thought occurred to her that she was repulsive to him, but
29566. her feminine self-deception immediately supplied her with consolation,
29567. and she told herself that he was only shy from love. Her melancholy,
29568. however, began to turn to irritability, and not long before Boris'
29569. departure she formed a definite plan of action. Just as Boris' leave of
29570. absence was expiring, Anatole Kuragin made his appearance in Moscow, and
29571. of course in the Karagins' drawing room, and Julie, suddenly abandoning
29572. her melancholy, became cheerful and very attentive to Kuragin.
29573. 
29574. "My dear," said Anna Mikhaylovna to her son, "I know from a reliable
29575. source that Prince Vasili has sent his son to Moscow to get him married
29576. to Julie. I am so fond of Julie that I should be sorry for her. What do
29577. you think of it, my dear?"
29578. 
29579. The idea of being made a fool of and of having thrown away that whole
29580. month of arduous melancholy service to Julie, and of seeing all the
29581. revenue from the Penza estates which he had already mentally apportioned
29582. and put to proper use fall into the hands of another, and especially
29583. into the hands of that idiot Anatole, pained Boris. He drove to the
29584. Karagins' with the firm intention of proposing. Julie met him in a gay,
29585. careless manner, spoke casually of how she had enjoyed yesterday's ball,
29586. and asked when he was leaving. Though Boris had come intentionally to
29587. speak of his love and therefore meant to be tender, he began speaking
29588. irritably of feminine inconstancy, of how easily women can turn from
29589. sadness to joy, and how their moods depend solely on who happens to be
29590. paying court to them. Julie was offended and replied that it was true
29591. that a woman needs variety, and the same thing over and over again would
29592. weary anyone.
29593. 
29594. "Then I should advise you..." Boris began, wishing to sting her; but at
29595. that instant the galling thought occurred to him that he might have to
29596. leave Moscow without having accomplished his aim, and have vainly wasted
29597. his efforts--which was a thing he never allowed to happen.
29598. 
29599. He checked himself in the middle of the sentence, lowered his eyes to
29600. avoid seeing her unpleasantly irritated and irresolute face, and said:
29601. 
29602. "I did not come here at all to quarrel with you. On the contrary..."
29603. 
29604. He glanced at her to make sure that he might go on. Her irritability had
29605. suddenly quite vanished, and her anxious, imploring eyes were fixed on
29606. him with greedy expectation. "I can always arrange so as not to see her
29607. often," thought Boris. "The affair has been begun and must be finished!"
29608. He blushed hotly, raised his eyes to hers, and said:
29609. 
29610. "You know my feelings for you!"
29611. 
29612. There was no need to say more: Julie's face shone with triumph and
29613. self-satisfaction; but she forced Boris to say all that is said on such
29614. occasions--that he loved her and had never loved any other woman more
29615. than her. She knew that for the Penza estates and Nizhegorod forests she
29616. could demand this, and she received what she demanded.
29617. 
29618. The affianced couple, no longer alluding to trees that shed gloom and
29619. melancholy upon them, planned the arrangements of a splendid house in
29620. Petersburg, paid calls, and prepared everything for a brilliant wedding.
29621. 
29622. 
29623. 
29624. 
29625. 
29626. CHAPTER VI
29627. 
29628. 
29629. At the end of January old Count Rostov went to Moscow with Natasha and
29630. Sonya. The countess was still unwell and unable to travel but it was
29631. impossible to wait for her recovery. Prince Andrew was expected in
29632. Moscow any day, the trousseau had to be ordered and the estate near
29633. Moscow had to be sold, besides which the opportunity of presenting his
29634. future daughter-in-law to old Prince Bolkonski while he was in Moscow
29635. could not be missed. The Rostovs' Moscow house had not been heated that
29636. winter and, as they had come only for a short time and the countess
29637. was not with them, the count decided to stay with Marya Dmitrievna
29638. Akhrosimova, who had long been pressing her hospitality on them.
29639. 
29640. Late one evening the Rostovs' four sleighs drove into Marya Dmitrievna's
29641. courtyard in the old Konyusheny street. Marya Dmitrievna lived alone.
29642. She had already married off her daughter, and her sons were all in the
29643. service.
29644. 
29645. She held herself as erect, told everyone her opinion as candidly,
29646. loudly, and bluntly as ever, and her whole bearing seemed a reproach
29647. to others for any weakness, passion, or temptation--the possibility of
29648. which she did not admit. From early in the morning, wearing a dressing
29649. jacket, she attended to her household affairs, and then she drove out:
29650. on holy days to church and after the service to jails and prisons on
29651. affairs of which she never spoke to anyone. On ordinary days, after
29652. dressing, she received petitioners of various classes, of whom there
29653. were always some. Then she had dinner, a substantial and appetizing meal
29654. at which there were always three or four guests; after dinner she played
29655. a game of boston, and at night she had the newspapers or a new book read
29656. to her while she knitted. She rarely made an exception and went out to
29657. pay visits, and then only to the most important persons in the town.
29658. 
29659. She had not yet gone to bed when the Rostovs arrived and the pulley of
29660. the hall door squeaked from the cold as it let in the Rostovs and their
29661. servants. Marya Dmitrievna, with her spectacles hanging down on her nose
29662. and her head flung back, stood in the hall doorway looking with a stern,
29663. grim face at the new arrivals. One might have thought she was angry with
29664. the travelers and would immediately turn them out, had she not at the
29665. same time been giving careful instructions to the servants for the
29666. accommodation of the visitors and their belongings.
29667. 
29668. "The count's things? Bring them here," she said, pointing to the
29669. portmanteaus and not greeting anyone. "The young ladies'? There to the
29670. left. Now what are you dawdling for?" she cried to the maids. "Get the
29671. samovar ready!... You've grown plumper and prettier," she remarked,
29672. drawing Natasha (whose cheeks were glowing from the cold) to her by the
29673. hood. "Foo! You are cold! Now take off your things, quick!" she shouted
29674. to the count who was going to kiss her hand. "You're half frozen,
29675. I'm sure! Bring some rum for tea!... Bonjour, Sonya dear!" she added,
29676. turning to Sonya and indicating by this French greeting her slightly
29677. contemptuous though affectionate attitude toward her.
29678. 
29679. When they came in to tea, having taken off their outdoor things and
29680. tidied themselves up after their journey, Marya Dmitrievna kissed them
29681. all in due order.
29682. 
29683. "I'm heartily glad you have come and are staying with me. It was high
29684. time," she said, giving Natasha a significant look. "The old man is here
29685. and his son's expected any day. You'll have to make his acquaintance.
29686. But we'll speak of that later on," she added, glancing at Sonya with a
29687. look that showed she did not want to speak of it in her presence. "Now
29688. listen," she said to the count. "What do you want tomorrow? Whom will
29689. you send for? Shinshin?" she crooked one of her fingers. "The sniveling
29690. Anna Mikhaylovna? That's two. She's here with her son. The son is
29691. getting married! Then Bezukhov, eh? He is here too, with his wife. He
29692. ran away from her and she came galloping after him. He dined with me on
29693. Wednesday. As for them"--and she pointed to the girls--"tomorrow I'll
29694. take them first to the Iberian shrine of the Mother of God, and then
29695. we'll drive to the Super-Rogue's. I suppose you'll have everything new.
29696. Don't judge by me: sleeves nowadays are this size! The other day young
29697. Princess Irina Vasilevna came to see me; she was an awful sight--looked
29698. as if she had put two barrels on her arms. You know not a day passes
29699. now without some new fashion.... And what have you to do yourself?" she
29700. asked the count sternly.
29701. 
29702. "One thing has come on top of another: her rags to buy, and now a
29703. purchaser has turned up for the Moscow estate and for the house. If you
