29704. will be so kind, I'll fix a time and go down to the estate just for a
29705. day, and leave my lassies with you."
29706. 
29707. "All right. All right. They'll be safe with me, as safe as in Chancery!
29708. I'll take them where they must go, scold them a bit, and pet them a
29709. bit," said Marya Dmitrievna, touching her goddaughter and favorite,
29710. Natasha, on the cheek with her large hand.
29711. 
29712. Next morning Marya Dmitrievna took the young ladies to the Iberian
29713. shrine of the Mother of God and to Madame Suppert-Roguet, who was so
29714. afraid of Marya Dmitrievna that she always let her have costumes at a
29715. loss merely to get rid of her. Marya Dmitrievna ordered almost the
29716. whole trousseau. When they got home she turned everybody out of the room
29717. except Natasha, and then called her pet to her armchair.
29718. 
29719. "Well, now we'll talk. I congratulate you on your betrothed. You've
29720. hooked a fine fellow! I am glad for your sake and I've known him since
29721. he was so high." She held her hand a couple of feet from the ground.
29722. Natasha blushed happily. "I like him and all his family. Now listen! You
29723. know that old Prince Nicholas much dislikes his son's marrying. The old
29724. fellow's crotchety! Of course Prince Andrew is not a child and can shift
29725. without him, but it's not nice to enter a family against a father's
29726. will. One wants to do it peacefully and lovingly. You're a clever girl
29727. and you'll know how to manage. Be kind, and use your wits. Then all will
29728. be well."
29729. 
29730. Natasha remained silent, from shyness Marya Dmitrievna supposed, but
29731. really because she disliked anyone interfering in what touched her love
29732. of Prince Andrew, which seemed to her so apart from all human affairs
29733. that no one could understand it. She loved and knew Prince Andrew, he
29734. loved her only, and was to come one of these days and take her. She
29735. wanted nothing more.
29736. 
29737. "You see I have known him a long time and am also fond of Mary, your
29738. future sister-in-law. 'Husbands' sisters bring up blisters,' but this
29739. one wouldn't hurt a fly. She has asked me to bring you two together.
29740. Tomorrow you'll go with your father to see her. Be very nice and
29741. affectionate to her: you're younger than she. When he comes, he'll find
29742. you already know his sister and father and are liked by them. Am I right
29743. or not? Won't that be best?"
29744. 
29745. "Yes, it will," Natasha answered reluctantly.
29746. 
29747. 
29748. 
29749. 
29750. 
29751. CHAPTER VII
29752. 
29753. 
29754. Next day, by Marya Dmitrievna's advice, Count Rostov took Natasha to
29755. call on Prince Nicholas Bolkonski. The count did not set out cheerfully
29756. on this visit, at heart he felt afraid. He well remembered the last
29757. interview he had had with the old prince at the time of the enrollment,
29758. when in reply to an invitation to dinner he had had to listen to an
29759. angry reprimand for not having provided his full quota of men. Natasha,
29760. on the other hand, having put on her best gown, was in the highest
29761. spirits. "They can't help liking me," she thought. "Everybody always has
29762. liked me, and I am so willing to do anything they wish, so ready to
29763. be fond of him--for being his father--and of her--for being his
29764. sister--that there is no reason for them not to like me..."
29765. 
29766. They drove up to the gloomy old house on the Vozdvizhenka and entered
29767. the vestibule.
29768. 
29769. "Well, the Lord have mercy on us!" said the count, half in jest, half
29770. in earnest; but Natasha noticed that her father was flurried on entering
29771. the anteroom and inquired timidly and softly whether the prince and
29772. princess were at home.
29773. 
29774. When they had been announced a perturbation was noticeable among the
29775. servants. The footman who had gone to announce them was stopped by
29776. another in the large hall and they whispered to one another. Then a
29777. maidservant ran into the hall and hurriedly said something, mentioning
29778. the princess. At last an old, cross looking footman came and announced
29779. to the Rostovs that the prince was not receiving, but that the princess
29780. begged them to walk up. The first person who came to meet the visitors
29781. was Mademoiselle Bourienne. She greeted the father and daughter with
29782. special politeness and showed them to the princess' room. The princess,
29783. looking excited and nervous, her face flushed in patches, ran in to meet
29784. the visitors, treading heavily, and vainly trying to appear cordial and
29785. at ease. From the first glance Princess Mary did not like Natasha. She
29786. thought her too fashionably dressed, frivolously gay and vain. She did
29787. not at all realize that before having seen her future sister-in-law she
29788. was prejudiced against her by involuntary envy of her beauty, youth, and
29789. happiness, as well as by jealousy of her brother's love for her. Apart
29790. from this insuperable antipathy to her, Princess Mary was agitated just
29791. then because on the Rostovs' being announced, the old prince had shouted
29792. that he did not wish to see them, that Princess Mary might do so if
29793. she chose, but they were not to be admitted to him. She had decided to
29794. receive them, but feared lest the prince might at any moment indulge in
29795. some freak, as he seemed much upset by the Rostovs' visit.
29796. 
29797. "There, my dear princess, I've brought you my songstress," said the
29798. count, bowing and looking round uneasily as if afraid the old prince
29799. might appear. "I am so glad you should get to know one another... very
29800. sorry the prince is still ailing," and after a few more commonplace
29801. remarks he rose. "If you'll allow me to leave my Natasha in your
29802. hands for a quarter of an hour, Princess, I'll drive round to see Anna
29803. Semenovna, it's quite near in the Dogs' Square, and then I'll come back
29804. for her."
29805. 
29806. The count had devised this diplomatic ruse (as he afterwards told his
29807. daughter) to give the future sisters-in-law an opportunity to talk
29808. to one another freely, but another motive was to avoid the danger of
29809. encountering the old prince, of whom he was afraid. He did not mention
29810. this to his daughter, but Natasha noticed her father's nervousness
29811. and anxiety and felt mortified by it. She blushed for him, grew still
29812. angrier at having blushed, and looked at the princess with a bold and
29813. defiant expression which said that she was not afraid of anybody. The
29814. princess told the count that she would be delighted, and only begged him
29815. to stay longer at Anna Semenovna's, and he departed.
29816. 
29817. Despite the uneasy glances thrown at her by Princess Mary--who wished to
29818. have a tete-a-tete with Natasha--Mademoiselle Bourienne remained in
29819. the room and persistently talked about Moscow amusements and theaters.
29820. Natasha felt offended by the hesitation she had noticed in the anteroom,
29821. by her father's nervousness, and by the unnatural manner of the princess
29822. who--she thought--was making a favor of receiving her, and so everything
29823. displeased her. She did not like Princess Mary, whom she thought very
29824. plain, affected, and dry. Natasha suddenly shrank into herself and
29825. involuntarily assumed an offhand air which alienated Princess Mary still
29826. more. After five minutes of irksome, constrained conversation, they
29827. heard the sound of slippered feet rapidly approaching. Princess Mary
29828. looked frightened.
29829. 
29830. The door opened and the old prince, in a dressing gown and a white
29831. nightcap, came in.
29832. 
29833. "Ah, madam!" he began. "Madam, Countess... Countess Rostova, if I am
29834. not mistaken... I beg you to excuse me, to excuse me... I did not know,
29835. madam. God is my witness, I did not know you had honored us with a
29836. visit, and I came in such a costume only to see my daughter. I beg
29837. you to excuse me... God is my witness, I didn't know-" he repeated,
29838. stressing the word "God" so unnaturally and so unpleasantly that
29839. Princess Mary stood with downcast eyes not daring to look either at her
29840. father or at Natasha.
29841. 
29842. Nor did the latter, having risen and curtsied, know what to do.
29843. Mademoiselle Bourienne alone smiled agreeably.
29844. 
29845. "I beg you to excuse me, excuse me! God is my witness, I did not know,"
29846. muttered the old man, and after looking Natasha over from head to foot
29847. he went out.
29848. 
29849. Mademoiselle Bourienne was the first to recover herself after this
29850. apparition and began speaking about the prince's indisposition. Natasha
29851. and Princess Mary looked at one another in silence, and the longer they
29852. did so without saying what they wanted to say, the greater grew their
29853. antipathy to one another.
29854. 
29855. When the count returned, Natasha was impolitely pleased and hastened
29856. to get away: at that moment she hated the stiff, elderly princess, who
29857. could place her in such an embarrassing position and had spent half an
29858. hour with her without once mentioning Prince Andrew. "I couldn't begin
29859. talking about him in the presence of that Frenchwoman," thought Natasha.
29860. The same thought was meanwhile tormenting Princess Mary. She knew what
29861. she ought to have said to Natasha, but she had been unable to say it
29862. because Mademoiselle Bourienne was in the way, and because, without
29863. knowing why, she felt it very difficult to speak of the marriage. When
29864. the count was already leaving the room, Princess Mary went up hurriedly
29865. to Natasha, took her by the hand, and said with a deep sigh:
29866. 
29867. "Wait, I must..."
29868. 
29869. Natasha glanced at her ironically without knowing why.
29870. 
29871. "Dear Natalie," said Princess Mary, "I want you to know that I am glad
29872. my brother has found happiness...."
29873. 
29874. She paused, feeling that she was not telling the truth. Natasha noticed
29875. this and guessed its reason.
29876. 
29877. "I think, Princess, it is not convenient to speak of that now," she said
29878. with external dignity and coldness, though she felt the tears choking
29879. her.
29880. 
29881. "What have I said and what have I done?" thought she, as soon as she was
29882. out of the room.
29883. 
29884. They waited a long time for Natasha to come to dinner that day. She sat
29885. in her room crying like a child, blowing her nose and sobbing. Sonya
29886. stood beside her, kissing her hair.
29887. 
29888. "Natasha, what is it about?" she asked. "What do they matter to you? It
29889. will all pass, Natasha."
29890. 
29891. "But if you only knew how offensive it was... as if I..."
29892. 
29893. "Don't talk about it, Natasha. It wasn't your fault so why should you
29894. mind? Kiss me," said Sonya.
29895. 
29896. Natasha raised her head and, kissing her friend on the lips, pressed her
29897. wet face against her.
29898. 
29899. "I can't tell you, I don't know. No one's to blame," said Natasha--"It's
29900. my fault. But it all hurts terribly. Oh, why doesn't he come?..."
29901. 
29902. She came in to dinner with red eyes. Marya Dmitrievna, who knew how
29903. the prince had received the Rostovs, pretended not to notice how upset
29904. Natasha was and jested resolutely and loudly at table with the count and
29905. the other guests.
29906. 
29907. 
29908. 
29909. 
29910. 
29911. CHAPTER VIII
29912. 
29913. 
29914. That evening the Rostovs went to the Opera, for which Marya Dmitrievna
29915. had taken a box.
29916. 
29917. Natasha did not want to go, but could not refuse Marya Dmitrievna's kind
29918. offer which was intended expressly for her. When she came ready dressed
29919. into the ballroom to await her father, and looking in the large mirror
29920. there saw that she was pretty, very pretty, she felt even more sad, but
29921. it was a sweet, tender sadness.
29922. 
29923. "O God, if he were here now I would not behave as I did then, but
29924. differently. I would not be silly and afraid of things, I would simply
29925. embrace him, cling to him, and make him look at me with those searching
29926. inquiring eyes with which he has so often looked at me, and then I would
29927. make him laugh as he used to laugh. And his eyes--how I see those eyes!"
29928. thought Natasha. "And what do his father and sister matter to me? I
29929. love him alone, him, him, with that face and those eyes, with his smile,
29930. manly and yet childlike.... No, I had better not think of him; not think
29931. of him but forget him, quite forget him for the present. I can't bear
29932. this waiting and I shall cry in a minute!" and she turned away from the
29933. glass, making an effort not to cry. "And how can Sonya love Nicholas
29934. so calmly and quietly and wait so long and so patiently?" thought she,
29935. looking at Sonya, who also came in quite ready, with a fan in her hand.
29936. "No, she's altogether different. I can't!"
29937. 
29938. Natasha at that moment felt so softened and tender that it was not
29939. enough for her to love and know she was beloved, she wanted now, at
29940. once, to embrace the man she loved, to speak and hear from him words of
29941. love such as filled her heart. While she sat in the carriage beside her
29942. father, pensively watching the lights of the street lamps flickering on
29943. the frozen window, she felt still sadder and more in love, and forgot
29944. where she was going and with whom. Having fallen into the line of
29945. carriages, the Rostovs' carriage drove up to the theater, its wheels
29946. squeaking over the snow. Natasha and Sonya, holding up their dresses,
29947. jumped out quickly. The count got out helped by the footmen, and,
29948. passing among men and women who were entering and the program sellers,
29949. they all three went along the corridor to the first row of boxes.
29950. Through the closed doors the music was already audible.
29951. 
29952. "Natasha, your hair!..." whispered Sonya.
29953. 
29954. An attendant deferentially and quickly slipped before the ladies and
29955. opened the door of their box. The music sounded louder and through the
29956. door rows of brightly lit boxes in which ladies sat with bare arms and
29957. shoulders, and noisy stalls brilliant with uniforms, glittered before
29958. their eyes. A lady entering the next box shot a glance of feminine envy
29959. at Natasha. The curtain had not yet risen and the overture was being
29960. played. Natasha, smoothing her gown, went in with Sonya and sat down,
29961. scanning the brilliant tiers of boxes opposite. A sensation she had not
29962. experienced for a long time--that of hundreds of eyes looking at
29963. her bare arms and neck--suddenly affected her both agreeably and
29964. disagreeably and called up a whole crowd of memories, desires and
29965. emotions associated with that feeling.
29966. 
29967. The two remarkably pretty girls, Natasha and Sonya, with Count Rostov
29968. who had not been seen in Moscow for a long time, attracted general
29969. attention. Moreover, everybody knew vaguely of Natasha's engagement to
29970. Prince Andrew, and knew that the Rostovs had lived in the country ever
29971. since, and all looked with curiosity at a fiancee who was making one of
29972. the best matches in Russia.
29973. 
29974. Natasha's looks, as everyone told her, had improved in the country, and
29975. that evening thanks to her agitation she was particularly pretty. She
29976. struck those who saw her by her fullness of life and beauty, combined
29977. with her indifference to everything about her. Her black eyes looked at
29978. the crowd without seeking anyone, and her delicate arm, bare to
29979. above the elbow, lay on the velvet edge of the box, while, evidently
29980. unconsciously, she opened and closed her hand in time to the music,
29981. crumpling her program. "Look, there's Alenina," said Sonya, "with her
29982. mother, isn't it?"
29983. 
29984. "Dear me, Michael Kirilovich has grown still stouter!" remarked the
29985. count.
29986. 
29987. "Look at our Anna Mikhaylovna--what a headdress she has on!"
29988. 
29989. "The Karagins, Julie--and Boris with them. One can see at once that
29990. they're engaged...."
29991. 
29992. "Drubetskoy has proposed?"
29993. 
29994. "Oh yes, I heard it today," said Shinshin, coming into the Rostovs' box.
29995. 
29996. Natasha looked in the direction in which her father's eyes were turned
29997. and saw Julie sitting beside her mother with a happy look on her face
29998. and a string of pearls round her thick red neck--which Natasha knew was
29999. covered with powder. Behind them, wearing a smile and leaning over with
30000. an ear to Julie's mouth, was Boris' handsome smoothly brushed head. He
30001. looked at the Rostovs from under his brows and said something, smiling,
30002. to his betrothed.
30003. 
30004. "They are talking about us, about me and him!" thought Natasha. "And he
30005. no doubt is calming her jealousy of me. They needn't trouble themselves!
30006. If only they knew how little I am concerned about any of them."
30007. 
30008. Behind them sat Anna Mikhaylovna wearing a green headdress and with a
30009. happy look of resignation to the will of God on her face. Their box was
30010. pervaded by that atmosphere of an affianced couple which Natasha knew so
30011. well and liked so much. She turned away and suddenly remembered all that
30012. had been so humiliating in her morning's visit.
30013. 
30014. "What right has he not to wish to receive me into his family? Oh, better
30015. not think of it--not till he comes back!" she told herself, and began
30016. looking at the faces, some strange and some familiar, in the stalls. In
30017. the front, in the very center, leaning back against the orchestra rail,
30018. stood Dolokhov in a Persian dress, his curly hair brushed up into a huge
30019. shock. He stood in full view of the audience, well aware that he was
30020. attracting everyone's attention, yet as much at ease as though he were
30021. in his own room. Around him thronged Moscow's most brilliant young men,
30022. whom he evidently dominated.
30023. 
30024. The count, laughing, nudged the blushing Sonya and pointed to her former
30025. adorer.
30026. 
30027. "Do you recognize him?" said he. "And where has he sprung from?" he
30028. asked, turning to Shinshin. "Didn't he vanish somewhere?"
30029. 
30030. "He did," replied Shinshin. "He was in the Caucasus and ran away from
30031. there. They say he has been acting as minister to some ruling prince in
30032. Persia, where he killed the Shah's brother. Now all the Moscow ladies
30033. are mad about him! It's 'Dolokhov the Persian' that does it! We never
30034. hear a word but Dolokhov is mentioned. They swear by him, they offer
30035. him to you as they would a dish of choice sterlet. Dolokhov and Anatole
30036. Kuragin have turned all our ladies' heads."
30037. 
30038. A tall, beautiful woman with a mass of plaited hair and much exposed
30039. plump white shoulders and neck, round which she wore a double string of
30040. large pearls, entered the adjoining box rustling her heavy silk dress
30041. and took a long time settling into her place.
30042. 
30043. Natasha involuntarily gazed at that neck, those shoulders, and pearls
30044. and coiffure, and admired the beauty of the shoulders and the pearls.
30045. While Natasha was fixing her gaze on her for the second time the lady
30046. looked round and, meeting the count's eyes, nodded to him and smiled.
30047. She was the Countess Bezukhova, Pierre's wife, and the count, who knew
30048. everyone in society, leaned over and spoke to her.
30049. 
30050. "Have you been here long, Countess?" he inquired. "I'll call, I'll call
30051. to kiss your hand. I'm here on business and have brought my girls with
30052. me. They say Semenova acts marvelously. Count Pierre never used to
30053. forget us. Is he here?"
30054. 
30055. "Yes, he meant to look in," answered Helene, and glanced attentively at
30056. Natasha.
30057. 
30058. Count Rostov resumed his seat.
30059. 
30060. "Handsome, isn't she?" he whispered to Natasha.
30061. 
30062. "Wonderful!" answered Natasha. "She's a woman one could easily fall in
30063. love with."
30064. 
30065. Just then the last chords of the overture were heard and the conductor
30066. tapped with his stick. Some latecomers took their seats in the stalls,
30067. and the curtain rose.
30068. 
30069. As soon as it rose everyone in the boxes and stalls became silent, and
30070. all the men, old and young, in uniform and evening dress, and all the
30071. women with gems on their bare flesh, turned their whole attention with
30072. eager curiosity to the stage. Natasha too began to look at it.
30073. 
30074. 
30075. 
30076. 
30077. 
30078. CHAPTER IX
30079. 
30080. 
30081. The floor of the stage consisted of smooth boards, at the sides was
30082. some painted cardboard representing trees, and at the back was a cloth
30083. stretched over boards. In the center of the stage sat some girls in red
30084. bodices and white skirts. One very fat girl in a white silk dress sat
30085. apart on a low bench, to the back of which a piece of green cardboard
30086. was glued. They all sang something. When they had finished their song
30087. the girl in white went up to the prompter's box and a man with tight
30088. silk trousers over his stout legs, and holding a plume and a dagger,
30089. went up to her and began singing, waving his arms about.
30090. 
30091. First the man in the tight trousers sang alone, then she sang, then they
30092. both paused while the orchestra played and the man fingered the hand
30093. of the girl in white, obviously awaiting the beat to start singing with
30094. her. They sang together and everyone in the theater began clapping
30095. and shouting, while the man and woman on the stage--who represented
30096. lovers--began smiling, spreading out their arms, and bowing.
30097. 
30098. After her life in the country, and in her present serious mood, all this
30099. seemed grotesque and amazing to Natasha. She could not follow the opera
30100. nor even listen to the music; she saw only the painted cardboard and the
30101. queerly dressed men and women who moved, spoke, and sang so strangely in
30102. that brilliant light. She knew what it was all meant to represent, but
30103. it was so pretentiously false and unnatural that she first felt ashamed
30104. for the actors and then amused at them. She looked at the faces of the
30105. audience, seeking in them the same sense of ridicule and perplexity she
30106. herself experienced, but they all seemed attentive to what was happening
30107. on the stage, and expressed delight which to Natasha seemed feigned. "I
30108. suppose it has to be like this!" she thought. She kept looking round in
30109. turn at the rows of pomaded heads in the stalls and then at the
30110. seminude women in the boxes, especially at Helene in the next box,
30111. who--apparently quite unclothed--sat with a quiet tranquil smile, not
30112. taking her eyes off the stage. And feeling the bright light that flooded
30113. the whole place and the warm air heated by the crowd, Natasha little
30114. by little began to pass into a state of intoxication she had not
30115. experienced for a long while. She did not realize who and where she
30116. was, nor what was going on before her. As she looked and thought, the
30117. strangest fancies unexpectedly and disconnectedly passed through her
30118. mind: the idea occurred to her of jumping onto the edge of the box and
30119. singing the air the actress was singing, then she wished to touch with
30120. her fan an old gentleman sitting not far from her, then to lean over to
30121. Helene and tickle her.
30122. 
30123. At a moment when all was quiet before the commencement of a song, a door
30124. leading to the stalls on the side nearest the Rostovs' box creaked, and
30125. the steps of a belated arrival were heard. "There's Kuragin!" whispered
30126. Shinshin. Countess Bezukhova turned smiling to the newcomer, and
30127. Natasha, following the direction of that look, saw an exceptionally
30128. handsome adjutant approaching their box with a self-assured yet
30129. courteous bearing. This was Anatole Kuragin whom she had seen and
30130. noticed long ago at the ball in Petersburg. He was now in an adjutant's
30131. uniform with one epaulet and a shoulder knot. He moved with a restrained
30132. swagger which would have been ridiculous had he not been so good-looking
30133. and had his handsome face not worn such an expression of good-humored
30134. complacency and gaiety. Though the performance was proceeding, he walked
30135. deliberately down the carpeted gangway, his sword and spurs slightly
30136. jingling and his handsome perfumed head held high. Having looked at
30137. Natasha he approached his sister, laid his well gloved hand on the edge
30138. of her box, nodded to her, and leaning forward asked a question, with a
30139. motion toward Natasha.
30140. 
30141. "Mais charmante!" said he, evidently referring to Natasha, who did not
30142. exactly hear his words but understood them from the movement of his
30143. lips. Then he took his place in the first row of the stalls and sat down
30144. beside Dolokhov, nudging with his elbow in a friendly and offhand way
30145. that Dolokhov whom others treated so fawningly. He winked at him gaily,
30146. smiled, and rested his foot against the orchestra screen.
30147. 
30148. "How like the brother is to the sister," remarked the count. "And how
30149. handsome they both are!"
30150. 
30151. Shinshin, lowering his voice, began to tell the count of some intrigue
30152. of Kuragin's in Moscow, and Natasha tried to overhear it just because he
30153. had said she was "charmante."
30154. 
30155. The first act was over. In the stalls everyone began moving about, going
30156. out and coming in.
30157. 
30158. Boris came to the Rostovs' box, received their congratulations very
30159. simply, and raising his eyebrows with an absent-minded smile conveyed
30160. to Natasha and Sonya his fiancee's invitation to her wedding, and
30161. went away. Natasha with a gay, coquettish smile talked to him, and
30162. congratulated on his approaching wedding that same Boris with whom she
30163. had formerly been in love. In the state of intoxication she was in,
30164. everything seemed simple and natural.
30165. 
30166. The scantily clad Helene smiled at everyone in the same way, and Natasha
30167. gave Boris a similar smile.
30168. 
30169. Helene's box was filled and surrounded from the stalls by the most
30170. distinguished and intellectual men, who seemed to vie with one another
30171. in their wish to let everyone see that they knew her.
30172. 
30173. During the whole of that entr'acte Kuragin stood with Dolokhov in front
30174. of the orchestra partition, looking at the Rostovs' box. Natasha knew he
30175. was talking about her and this afforded her pleasure. She even turned so
30176. that he should see her profile in what she thought was its most becoming
30177. aspect. Before the beginning of the second act Pierre appeared in the
30178. stalls. The Rostovs had not seen him since their arrival. His face
30179. looked sad, and he had grown still stouter since Natasha last saw him.
30180. He passed up to the front rows, not noticing anyone. Anatole went up to
30181. him and began speaking to him, looking at and indicating the Rostovs'
30182. box. On seeing Natasha Pierre grew animated and, hastily passing between
30183. the rows, came toward their box. When he got there he leaned on his
30184. elbows and, smiling, talked to her for a long time. While conversing
30185. with Pierre, Natasha heard a man's voice in Countess Bezukhova's box and
30186. something told her it was Kuragin. She turned and their eyes met.
30187. Almost smiling, he gazed straight into her eyes with such an enraptured
30188. caressing look that it seemed strange to be so near him, to look at him
30189. like that, to be so sure he admired her, and not to be acquainted with
30190. him.
30191. 
30192. In the second act there was scenery representing tombstones, there was a
30193. round hole in the canvas to represent the moon, shades were raised over
30194. the footlights, and from horns and contrabass came deep notes while many
30195. people appeared from right and left wearing black cloaks and holding
30196. things like daggers in their hands. They began waving their arms. Then
30197. some other people ran in and began dragging away the maiden who had been
30198. in white and was now in light blue. They did not drag her away at once,
30199. but sang with her for a long time and then at last dragged her off, and
30200. behind the scenes something metallic was struck three times and
30201. everyone knelt down and sang a prayer. All these things were repeatedly
30202. interrupted by the enthusiastic shouts of the audience.
30203. 
30204. During this act every time Natasha looked toward the stalls she saw
30205. Anatole Kuragin with an arm thrown across the back of his chair, staring
30206. at her. She was pleased to see that he was captivated by her and it did
30207. not occur to her that there was anything wrong in it.
30208. 
30209. When the second act was over Countess Bezukhova rose, turned to the
30210. Rostovs' box--her whole bosom completely exposed--beckoned the old count
30211. with a gloved finger, and paying no attention to those who had entered
30212. her box began talking to him with an amiable smile.
30213. 
30214. "Do make me acquainted with your charming daughters," said she. "The
30215. whole town is singing their praises and I don't even know then!"
30216. 
30217. Natasha rose and curtsied to the splendid countess. She was so pleased
30218. by praise from this brilliant beauty that she blushed with pleasure.
30219. 
30220. "I want to become a Moscovite too, now," said Helene. "How is it you're
30221. not ashamed to bury such pearls in the country?"
30222. 
30223. Countess Bezukhova quite deserved her reputation of being a fascinating
30224. woman. She could say what she did not think--especially what was
30225. flattering--quite simply and naturally.
30226. 
30227. "Dear count, you must let me look after your daughters! Though I am not
30228. staying here long this time--nor are you--I will try to amuse them. I
30229. have already heard much of you in Petersburg and wanted to get to know
30230. you," said she to Natasha with her stereotyped and lovely smile. "I had
30231. heard about you from my page, Drubetskoy. Have you heard he is getting
30232. married? And also from my husband's friend Bolkonski, Prince Andrew
30233. Bolkonski," she went on with special emphasis, implying that she knew of
30234. his relation to Natasha. To get better acquainted she asked that one
30235. of the young ladies should come into her box for the rest of the
30236. performance, and Natasha moved over to it.
30237. 
30238. The scene of the third act represented a palace in which many candles
30239. were burning and pictures of knights with short beards hung on the
30240. walls. In the middle stood what were probably a king and a queen. The
30241. king waved his right arm and, evidently nervous, sang something badly
30242. and sat down on a crimson throne. The maiden who had been first in white
30243. and then in light blue, now wore only a smock, and stood beside the
30244. throne with her hair down. She sang something mournfully, addressing the
30245. queen, but the king waved his arm severely, and men and women with bare
30246. legs came in from both sides and began dancing all together. Then the
30247. violins played very shrilly and merrily and one of the women with thick
30248. bare legs and thin arms, separating from the others, went behind the
30249. wings, adjusted her bodice, returned to the middle of the stage, and
30250. began jumping and striking one foot rapidly against the other. In the
30251. stalls everyone clapped and shouted "bravo!" Then one of the men went
30252. into a corner of the stage. The cymbals and horns in the orchestra
30253. struck up more loudly, and this man with bare legs jumped very high and
30254. waved his feet about very rapidly. (He was Duport, who received sixty
30255. thousand rubles a year for this art.) Everybody in the stalls, boxes,
30256. and galleries began clapping and shouting with all their might, and the
30257. man stopped and began smiling and bowing to all sides. Then other men
30258. and women danced with bare legs. Then the king again shouted to the
30259. sound of music, and they all began singing. But suddenly a storm
30260. came on, chromatic scales and diminished sevenths were heard in the
30261. orchestra, everyone ran off, again dragging one of their number away,
30262. and the curtain dropped. Once more there was a terrible noise and
30263. clatter among the audience, and with rapturous faces everyone began
30264. shouting: "Duport! Duport! Duport!" Natasha no longer thought this
30265. strange. She looked about with pleasure, smiling joyfully.
30266. 
30267. "Isn't Duport delightful?" Helene asked her.
30268. 
30269. "Oh, yes," replied Natasha.
30270. 
30271. 
30272. 
30273. 
30274. 
30275. CHAPTER X
30276. 
30277. 
30278. During the entr'acte a whiff of cold air came into Helene's box, the
30279. door opened, and Anatole entered, stooping and trying not to brush
30280. against anyone.
30281. 
30282. "Let me introduce my brother to you," said Helene, her eyes shifting
30283. uneasily from Natasha to Anatole.
30284. 
30285. Natasha turned her pretty little head toward the elegant young officer
30286. and smiled at him over her bare shoulder. Anatole, who was as handsome
30287. at close quarters as at a distance, sat down beside her and told her he
30288. had long wished to have this happiness--ever since the Naryshkins' ball
30289. in fact, at which he had had the well-remembered pleasure of seeing her.
30290. Kuragin was much more sensible and simple with women than among men.
30291. He talked boldly and naturally, and Natasha was strangely and agreeably
30292. struck by the fact that there was nothing formidable in this man about
30293. whom there was so much talk, but that on the contrary his smile was most
30294. naive, cheerful, and good-natured.
30295. 
30296. Kuragin asked her opinion of the performance and told her how at a
30297. previous performance Semenova had fallen down on the stage.
30298. 
30299. "And do you know, Countess," he said, suddenly addressing her as an
30300. old, familiar acquaintance, "we are getting up a costume tournament; you
30301. ought to take part in it! It will be great fun. We shall all meet at the
30302. Karagins'! Please come! No! Really, eh?" said he.
30303. 
30304. While saying this he never removed his smiling eyes from her face, her
30305. neck, and her bare arms. Natasha knew for certain that he was enraptured
30306. by her. This pleased her, yet his presence made her feel constrained and
30307. oppressed. When she was not looking at him she felt that he was looking
30308. at her shoulders, and she involuntarily caught his eye so that he should
30309. look into hers rather than this. But looking into his eyes she was
30310. frightened, realizing that there was not that barrier of modesty she had
30311. always felt between herself and other men. She did not know how it was
30312. that within five minutes she had come to feel herself terribly near to
30313. this man. When she turned away she feared he might seize her from behind
30314. by her bare arm and kiss her on the neck. They spoke of most ordinary
30315. things, yet she felt that they were closer to one another than she had
30316. ever been to any man. Natasha kept turning to Helene and to her father,
30317. as if asking what it all meant, but Helene was engaged in conversation
30318. with a general and did not answer her look, and her father's eyes said
30319. nothing but what they always said: "Having a good time? Well, I'm glad
30320. of it!"
30321. 
30322. During one of these moments of awkward silence when Anatole's prominent
30323. eyes were gazing calmly and fixedly at her, Natasha, to break the
30324. silence, asked him how he liked Moscow. She asked the question and
30325. blushed. She felt all the time that by talking to him she was doing
30326. something improper. Anatole smiled as though to encourage her.
30327. 
30328. "At first I did not like it much, because what makes a town pleasant
30329. ce sont les jolies femmes, * isn't that so? But now I like it very much
30330. indeed," he said, looking at her significantly. "You'll come to the
30331. costume tournament, Countess? Do come!" and putting out his hand to her
30332. bouquet and dropping his voice, he added, "You will be the prettiest
30333. there. Do come, dear countess, and give me this flower as a pledge!"
30334. 
30335. 
30336.     * Are the pretty women.
30337. 
30338. 
30339. Natasha did not understand what he was saying any more than he did
30340. himself, but she felt that his incomprehensible words had an improper
30341. intention. She did not know what to say and turned away as if she had
30342. not heard his remark. But as soon as she had turned away she felt that
30343. he was there, behind, so close behind her.
30344. 
30345. "How is he now? Confused? Angry? Ought I to put it right?" she asked
30346. herself, and she could not refrain from turning round. She looked
30347. straight into his eyes, and his nearness, self-assurance, and the
30348. good-natured tenderness of his smile vanquished her. She smiled just
30349. as he was doing, gazing straight into his eyes. And again she felt with
30350. horror that no barrier lay between him and her.
30351. 
30352. The curtain rose again. Anatole left the box, serene and gay. Natasha
30353. went back to her father in the other box, now quite submissive to the
30354. world she found herself in. All that was going on before her now seemed
30355. quite natural, but on the other hand all her previous thoughts of her
30356. betrothed, of Princess Mary, or of life in the country did not once
30357. recur to her mind and were as if belonging to a remote past.
30358. 
30359. In the fourth act there was some sort of devil who sang waving his arm
30360. about, till the boards were withdrawn from under him and he disappeared
30361. down below. That was the only part of the fourth act that Natasha saw.
30362. She felt agitated and tormented, and the cause of this was Kuragin whom
30363. she could not help watching. As they were leaving the theater Anatole
30364. came up to them, called their carriage, and helped them in. As he was
30365. putting Natasha in he pressed her arm above the elbow. Agitated and
30366. flushed she turned round. He was looking at her with glittering eyes,
30367. smiling tenderly.
30368. 
30369. 
30370. Only after she had reached home was Natasha able clearly to think over
30371. what had happened to her, and suddenly remembering Prince Andrew she
30372. was horrified, and at tea to which all had sat down after the opera, she
30373. gave a loud exclamation, flushed, and ran out of the room.
30374. 
30375. "O God! I am lost!" she said to herself. "How could I let him?" She sat
30376. for a long time hiding her flushed face in her hands trying to realize
30377. what had happened to her, but was unable either to understand what
30378. had happened or what she felt. Everything seemed dark, obscure,
30379. and terrible. There in that enormous, illuminated theater where the
30380. bare-legged Duport, in a tinsel-decorated jacket, jumped about to the
30381. music on wet boards, and young girls and old men, and the nearly naked
30382. Helene with her proud, calm smile, rapturously cried "bravo!"--there in
30383. the presence of that Helene it had all seemed clear and simple; but now,
30384. alone by herself, it was incomprehensible. "What is it? What was that
30385. terror I felt of him? What is this gnawing of conscience I am feeling
30386. now?" she thought.
30387. 
30388. Only to the old countess at night in bed could Natasha have told all she
30389. was feeling. She knew that Sonya with her severe and simple views
30390. would either not understand it at all or would be horrified at such a
30391. confession. So Natasha tried to solve what was torturing her by herself.
30392. 
30393. "Am I spoiled for Andrew's love or not?" she asked herself, and with
30394. soothing irony replied: "What a fool I am to ask that! What did happen
30395. to me? Nothing! I have done nothing, I didn't lead him on at all. Nobody
30396. will know and I shall never see him again," she told herself. "So it is
30397. plain that nothing has happened and there is nothing to repent of, and
30398. Andrew can love me still. But why 'still?' O God, why isn't he here?"
30399. Natasha quieted herself for a moment, but again some instinct told her
30400. that though all this was true, and though nothing had happened, yet the
30401. former purity of her love for Prince Andrew had perished. And again in
30402. imagination she went over her whole conversation with Kuragin, and again
30403. saw the face, gestures, and tender smile of that bold handsome man when
30404. he pressed her arm.
30405. 
30406. 
30407. 
30408. 
30409. 
30410. CHAPTER XI
30411. 
30412. 
30413. Anatole Kuragin was staying in Moscow because his father had sent him
30414. away from Petersburg, where he had been spending twenty thousand rubles
30415. a year in cash, besides running up debts for as much more, which his
30416. creditors demanded from his father.
30417. 
30418. His father announced to him that he would now pay half his debts for the
30419. last time, but only on condition that he went to Moscow as adjutant
30420. to the commander in chief--a post his father had procured for him--and
30421. would at last try to make a good match there. He indicated to him
30422. Princess Mary and Julie Karagina.
30423. 
30424. Anatole consented and went to Moscow, where he put up at Pierre's house.
30425. Pierre received him unwillingly at first, but got used to him after a
30426. while, sometimes even accompanied him on his carousals, and gave him
30427. money under the guise of loans.
30428. 
30429. As Shinshin had remarked, from the time of his arrival Anatole had
30430. turned the heads of the Moscow ladies, especially by the fact that
30431. he slighted them and plainly preferred the gypsy girls and French
30432. actresses--with the chief of whom, Mademoiselle George, he was said to
30433. be on intimate relations. He had never missed a carousal at Danilov's
30434. or other Moscow revelers', drank whole nights through, outvying everyone
30435. else, and was at all the balls and parties of the best society. There
30436. was talk of his intrigues with some of the ladies, and he flirted with a
30437. few of them at the balls. But he did not run after the unmarried girls,
30438. especially the rich heiresses who were most of them plain. There was a
30439. special reason for this, as he had got married two years before--a fact
30440. known only to his most intimate friends. At that time while with his
30441. regiment in Poland, a Polish landowner of small means had forced him to
30442. marry his daughter. Anatole had very soon abandoned his wife and, for a
30443. payment which he agreed to send to his father-in-law, had arranged to be
30444. free to pass himself off as a bachelor.
30445. 
30446. Anatole was always content with his position, with himself, and with
30447. others. He was instinctively and thoroughly convinced that it was
30448. impossible for him to live otherwise than as he did and that he had
30449. never in his life done anything base. He was incapable of considering
30450. how his actions might affect others or what the consequences of this or
30451. that action of his might be. He was convinced that, as a duck is so made
30452. that it must live in water, so God had made him such that he must spend
30453. thirty thousand rubles a year and always occupy a prominent position in
30454. society. He believed this so firmly that others, looking at him, were
30455. persuaded of it too and did not refuse him either a leading place
30456. in society or money, which he borrowed from anyone and everyone and
30457. evidently would not repay.
30458. 
30459. He was not a gambler, at any rate he did not care about winning. He was
30460. not vain. He did not mind what people thought of him. Still less could
30461. he be accused of ambition. More than once he had vexed his father by
30462. spoiling his own career, and he laughed at distinctions of all kinds. He
30463. was not mean, and did not refuse anyone who asked of him. All he cared
30464. about was gaiety and women, and as according to his ideas there
30465. was nothing dishonorable in these tastes, and he was incapable of
30466. considering what the gratification of his tastes entailed for others,
30467. he honestly considered himself irreproachable, sincerely despised rogues
30468. and bad people, and with a tranquil conscience carried his head high.
30469. 
30470. Rakes, those male Magdalenes, have a secret feeling of innocence
30471. similar to that which female Magdalenes have, based on the same hope of
30472. forgiveness. "All will be forgiven her, for she loved much; and all will
30473. be forgiven him, for he enjoyed much."
30474. 
30475. Dolokhov, who had reappeared that year in Moscow after his exile and
30476. his Persian adventures, and was leading a life of luxury, gambling, and
30477. dissipation, associated with his old Petersburg comrade Kuragin and made
30478. use of him for his own ends.
30479. 
30480. Anatole was sincerely fond of Dolokhov for his cleverness and audacity.
30481. Dolokhov, who needed Anatole Kuragin's name, position, and connections
30482. as a bait to draw rich young men into his gambling set, made use of him
30483. and amused himself at his expense without letting the other feel it.
30484. Apart from the advantage he derived from Anatole, the very process
30485. of dominating another's will was in itself a pleasure, a habit, and a
30486. necessity to Dolokhov.
30487. 
30488. Natasha had made a strong impression on Kuragin. At supper after
30489. the opera he described to Dolokhov with the air of a connoisseur the
30490. attractions of her arms, shoulders, feet, and hair and expressed his
30491. intention of making love to her. Anatole had no notion and was incapable
30492. of considering what might come of such love-making, as he never had any
30493. notion of the outcome of any of his actions.
30494. 
30495. "She's first-rate, my dear fellow, but not for us," replied Dolokhov.
30496. 
30497. "I will tell my sister to ask her to dinner," said Anatole. "Eh?"
30498. 
30499. "You'd better wait till she's married...."
30500. 
30501. "You know, I adore little girls, they lose their heads at once," pursued
30502. Anatole.
30503. 
30504. "You have been caught once already by a 'little girl,'" said Dolokhov
30505. who knew of Kuragin's marriage. "Take care!"
30506. 
30507. "Well, that can't happen twice! Eh?" said Anatole, with a good-humored
30508. laugh.
30509.

30514. CHAPTER XII
30515. 
30516. 
30517. The day after the opera the Rostovs went nowhere and nobody came to see
30518. them. Marya Dmitrievna talked to the count about something which they
30519. concealed from Natasha. Natasha guessed they were talking about the old
30520. prince and planning something, and this disquieted and offended her.
30521. She was expecting Prince Andrew any moment and twice that day sent a
30522. manservant to the Vozdvizhenka to ascertain whether he had come. He had
30523. not arrived. She suffered more now than during her first days in Moscow.
30524. To her impatience and pining for him were now added the unpleasant
30525. recollection of her interview with Princess Mary and the old prince,
30526. and a fear and anxiety of which she did not understand the cause. She
30527. continually fancied that either he would never come or that something
30528. would happen to her before he came. She could no longer think of him by
30529. herself calmly and continuously as she had done before. As soon as she
30530. began to think of him, the recollection of the old prince, of Princess
30531. Mary, of the theater, and of Kuragin mingled with her thoughts. The
30532. question again presented itself whether she was not guilty, whether she
30533. had not already broken faith with Prince Andrew, and again she found
30534. herself recalling to the minutest detail every word, every gesture, and
30535. every shade in the play of expression on the face of the man who had
30536. been able to arouse in her such an incomprehensible and terrifying
30537. feeling. To the family Natasha seemed livelier than usual, but she was
30538. far less tranquil and happy than before.
30539. 
30540. On Sunday morning Marya Dmitrievna invited her visitors to Mass at her
30541. parish church--the Church of the Assumption built over the graves of
30542. victims of the plague.
30543. 
30544. "I don't like those fashionable churches," she said, evidently priding
30545. herself on her independence of thought. "God is the same every where.
30546. We have an excellent priest, he conducts the service decently and with
30547. dignity, and the deacon is the same. What holiness is there in giving
30548. concerts in the choir? I don't like it, it's just self-indulgence!"
30549. 
30550. Marya Dmitrievna liked Sundays and knew how to keep them. Her whole
30551. house was scrubbed and cleaned on Saturdays; neither she nor the
30552. servants worked, and they all wore holiday dress and went to church. At
30553. her table there were extra dishes at dinner, and the servants had vodka
30554. and roast goose or suckling pig. But in nothing in the house was the
30555. holiday so noticeable as in Marya Dmitrievna's broad, stern face, which
30556. on that day wore an invariable look of solemn festivity.
30557. 
30558. After Mass, when they had finished their coffee in the dining room
30559. where the loose covers had been removed from the furniture, a servant
30560. announced that the carriage was ready, and Marya Dmitrievna rose with
30561. a stern air. She wore her holiday shawl, in which she paid calls, and
30562. announced that she was going to see Prince Nicholas Bolkonski to have an
30563. explanation with him about Natasha.
30564. 
30565. After she had gone, a dressmaker from Madame Suppert-Roguet waited
30566. on the Rostovs, and Natasha, very glad of this diversion, having shut
30567. herself into a room adjoining the drawing room, occupied herself trying
30568. on the new dresses. Just as she had put on a bodice without sleeves and
30569. only tacked together, and was turning her head to see in the glass how

30571. her father's voice and another's--a woman's--that made her flush. It
30572. was Helene. Natasha had not time to take off the bodice before the door
30573. opened and Countess Bezukhova, dressed in a purple velvet gown with
30574. a high collar, came into the room beaming with good-humored amiable
30575. smiles.
30576. 
30577. "Oh, my enchantress!" she cried to the blushing Natasha. "Charming! No,
30578. this is really beyond anything, my dear count," said she to Count Rostov

30580. I won't let you off! Mademoiselle George will recite at my house
30581. tonight and there'll be some people, and if you don't bring your lovely
30582. girls--who are prettier than Mademoiselle George--I won't know you! My
30583. husband is away in Tver or I would send him to fetch you. You must come.
30584. You positively must! Between eight and nine."
30585. 
30586. She nodded to the dressmaker, whom she knew and who had curtsied
30587. respectfully to her, and seated herself in an armchair beside the
30588. looking glass, draping the folds of her velvet dress picturesquely. She
30589. did not cease chattering good-naturedly and gaily, continually praising
30590. Natasha's beauty. She looked at Natasha's dresses and praised them, as
30591. well as a new dress of her own made of "metallic gauze," which she had
30592. received from Paris, and advised Natasha to have one like it.
30593. 
30594. "But anything suits you, my charmer!" she remarked.
30595. 
30596. A smile of pleasure never left Natasha's face. She felt happy and as if
30597. she were blossoming under the praise of this dear Countess Bezukhova who
30598. had formerly seemed to her so unapproachable and important and was now
30599. so kind to her. Natasha brightened up and felt almost in love with
30600. this woman, who was so beautiful and so kind. Helene for her part was
30601. sincerely delighted with Natasha and wished to give her a good time.
30602. Anatole had asked her to bring him and Natasha together, and she was
30603. calling on the Rostovs for that purpose. The idea of throwing her
30604. brother and Natasha together amused her.
30605. 
30606. Though at one time, in Petersburg, she had been annoyed with Natasha for
30607. drawing Boris away, she did not think of that now, and in her own way
30608. heartily wished Natasha well. As she was leaving the Rostovs she called
30609. her protegee aside.
30610. 
30611. "My brother dined with me yesterday--we nearly died of laughter--he ate
30612. nothing and kept sighing for you, my charmer! He is madly, quite madly,
30613. in love with you, my dear."
30614. 
30615. Natasha blushed scarlet when she heard this.
30616. 
30617. "How she blushes, how she blushes, my pretty!" said Helene. "You must
30618. certainly come. If you love somebody, my charmer, that is not a reason
30619. to shut yourself up. Even if you are engaged, I am sure your fiance
30620. would wish you to go into society rather than be bored to death."
30621. 
30622. "So she knows I am engaged, and she and her husband Pierre--that good
30623. Pierre--have talked and laughed about this. So it's all right." And
30624. again, under Helene's influence, what had seemed terrible now seemed
30625. simple and natural. "And she is such a grande dame, so kind, and
30626. evidently likes me so much. And why not enjoy myself?" thought Natasha,
30627. gazing at Helene with wide-open, wondering eyes.
30628. 
30629. Marya Dmitrievna came back to dinner taciturn and serious, having
30630. evidently suffered a defeat at the old prince's. She was still too
30631. agitated by the encounter to be able to talk of the affair calmly. In
30632. answer to the count's inquiries she replied that things were all right
30633. and that she would tell about it next day. On hearing of Countess
30634. Bezukhova's visit and the invitation for that evening, Marya Dmitrievna
30635. remarked:
30636. 
30637. "I don't care to have anything to do with Bezukhova and don't advise you
30638. to; however, if you've promised--go. It will divert your thoughts," she

30641. 
30642. 
30643. 
30644. 
30645. CHAPTER XIII
30646. 
30647. 
30648. Count Rostov took the girls to Countess Bezukhova's. There were a good
30649. many people there, but nearly all strangers to Natasha. Count Rostov was
30650. displeased to see that the company consisted almost entirely of men and

30654. Helene reached Moscow had been an intimate in her house. The count
30655. decided not to sit down to cards or let his girls out of his sight and
30656. to get away as soon as Mademoiselle George's performance was over.
30657. 
30658. Anatole was at the door, evidently on the lookout for the Rostovs.
30659. Immediately after greeting the count he went up to Natasha and followed
30660. her. As soon as she saw him she was seized by the same feeling she had

30663. 
30664. Helene welcomed Natasha delightedly and was loud in admiration of her

30670. 
30671. Mademoiselle George, with her bare, fat, dimpled arms, and a red shawl

30674. 
30675. Mademoiselle George looked sternly and gloomily at the audience and

30680.

30689. expectancy.
30690. 
30691. After the first monologue the whole company rose and surrounded
30692. Mademoiselle George, expressing their enthusiasm.
30693. 
30694. "How beautiful she is!" Natasha remarked to her father who had also
30695. risen and was moving through the crowd toward the actress.
30696.

30701. "Come, come, Natasha!" said the count, as he turned back for his

30705. 
30706. After giving several recitations, Mademoiselle George left, and Countess

30708. 
30709. The count wished to go home, but Helene entreated him not to spoil her

30718. 
30719. "Don't say such things to me. I am betrothed and love another," she said
30720. rapidly.... She glanced at him.
30721. 
30722. Anatole was not upset or pained by what she had said.
30723. 
30724. "Don't speak to me of that! What can I do?" said he. "I tell you I
30725. am madly, madly, in love with you! Is it my fault that you are
30726. enchanting?... It's our turn to begin."
30727. 
30728. Natasha, animated and excited, looked about her with wide-open
30729. frightened eyes and seemed merrier than usual. She understood hardly
30730. anything that went on that evening. They danced the ecossaise and the
30731. Grossvater. Her father asked her to come home, but she begged to remain.
30732. Wherever she went and whomever she was speaking to, she felt his eyes
30733. upon her. Later on she recalled how she had asked her father to let her
30734. go to the dressing room to rearrange her dress, that Helene had followed
30735. her and spoken laughingly of her brother's love, and that she again met
30736. Anatole in the little sitting room. Helene had disappeared leaving them
30737. alone, and Anatole had taken her hand and said in a tender voice:
30738. 
30739. "I cannot come to visit you but is it possible that I shall never see
30740. you? I love you madly. Can I never...?" and, blocking her path, he
30741. brought his face close to hers.
30742. 
30743. His large, glittering, masculine eyes were so close to hers that she saw
30744. nothing but them.
30745. 
30746. "Natalie?" he whispered inquiringly while she felt her hands being
30747. painfully pressed. "Natalie?"
30748. 
30749. "I don't understand. I have nothing to say," her eyes replied.
30750. 
30751. Burning lips were pressed to hers, and at the same instant she felt
30752. herself released, and Helene's footsteps and the rustle of her dress
30753. were heard in the room. Natasha looked round at her, and then, red
30754. and trembling, threw a frightened look of inquiry at Anatole and moved
30755. toward the door.
30756. 
30757. "One word, just one, for God's sake!" cried Anatole.
30758. 
30759. She paused. She so wanted a word from him that would explain to her what
30760. had happened and to which she could find no answer.
30761. 
30762. "Natalie, just a word, only one!" he kept repeating, evidently not
30763. knowing what to say and he repeated it till Helene came up to them.
30764. 
30765. Helene returned with Natasha to the drawing room. The Rostovs went away
30766. without staying for supper.
30767. 
30768. After reaching home Natasha did not sleep all night. She was tormented
30769. by the insoluble question whether she loved Anatole or Prince Andrew.
30770. She loved Prince Andrew--she remembered distinctly how deeply she loved
30771. him. But she also loved Anatole, of that there was no doubt. "Else how
30772. could all this have happened?" thought she. "If, after that, I could
30773. return his smile when saying good-by, if I was able to let it come to
30774. that, it means that I loved him from the first. It means that he is
30775. kind, noble, and splendid, and I could not help loving him. What am I
30776. to do if I love him and the other one too?" she asked herself, unable to
30777. find an answer to these terrible questions.
30778. 
30779. 
30780. 
30781. 
30782. 
30783. CHAPTER XIV
30784. 
30785. 
30786. Morning came with its cares and bustle. Everyone got up and began to
30787. move about and talk, dressmakers came again. Marya Dmitrievna appeared,
30788. and they were called to breakfast. Natasha kept looking uneasily at
30789. everybody with wide-open eyes, as if wishing to intercept every glance
30790. directed toward her, and tried to appear the same as usual.
30791. 
30792. After breakfast, which was her best time, Marya Dmitrievna sat down in
30793. her armchair and called Natasha and the count to her.
30794. 
30795. "Well, friends, I have now thought the whole matter over and this is
30796. my advice," she began. "Yesterday, as you know, I went to see Prince
30797. Bolkonski. Well, I had a talk with him.... He took it into his head to
30798. begin shouting, but I am not one to be shouted down. I said what I had
30799. to say!"
30800. 
30801. "Well, and he?" asked the count.
30802. 
30803. "He? He's crazy... he did not want to listen. But what's the use
30804. of talking? As it is we have worn the poor girl out," said Marya
30805. Dmitrievna. "My advice to you is finish your business and go back home

30807.

30809. 
30810. "Yes, go back," said Marya Dmitrievna, "and wait there. If your

30813. 
30814. Count Rostov approved of this suggestion, appreciating its

30816. visit him in Moscow or at Bald Hills later on; and if not, the wedding,
30817. against his wishes, could only be arranged at Otradnoe.
30818. 
30819. "That is perfectly true. And I am sorry I went to see him and took her,"

30821.

30827. 
30828. Having found what she was looking for in the reticule she handed it to
30829. Natasha. It was a letter from Princess Mary.
30830. 
30831. "She has written to you. How she torments herself, poor thing! She's
30832. afraid you might think that she does not like you."
30833. 
30834. "But she doesn't like me," said Natasha.
30835. 
30836. "Don't talk nonsense!" cried Marya Dmitrievna.
30837. 
30838. "I shan't believe anyone, I know she doesn't like me," replied Natasha

30841. to frown.
30842. 
30843. "Don't answer like that, my good girl!" she said. "What I say is true!
30844. Write an answer!" Natasha did not reply and went to her own room to read
30845. Princess Mary's letter.
30846. 
30847. Princess Mary wrote that she was in despair at the misunderstanding that
30848. had occurred between them. Whatever her father's feelings might be, she
30849. begged Natasha to believe that she could not help loving her as the one
30850. chosen by her brother, for whose happiness she was ready to sacrifice
30851. everything.
30852. 
30853. "Do not think, however," she wrote, "that my father is ill-disposed
30854. toward you. He is an invalid and an old man who must be forgiven; but
30855. he is good and magnanimous and will love her who makes his son happy."
30856. Princess Mary went on to ask Natasha to fix a time when she could see
30857. her again.
30858. 
30859. After reading the letter Natasha sat down at the writing table to answer
30860. it. "Dear Princess," she wrote in French quickly and mechanically, and
30861. then paused. What more could she write after all that had happened
30862. the evening before? "Yes, yes! All that has happened, and now all is
30863. changed," she thought as she sat with the letter she had begun before
30864. her. "Must I break off with him? Must I really? That's awful..." and to
30865. escape from these dreadful thoughts she went to Sonya and began sorting
30866. patterns with her.
30867. 
30868. After dinner Natasha went to her room and again took up Princess Mary's
30869. letter. "Can it be that it is all over?" she thought. "Can it be
30870. that all this has happened so quickly and has destroyed all that went
30871. before?" She recalled her love for Prince Andrew in all its former
30872. strength, and at the same time felt that she loved Kuragin. She vividly
30873. pictured herself as Prince Andrew's wife, and the scenes of happiness
30874. with him she had so often repeated in her imagination, and at the
30875. same time, aglow with excitement, recalled every detail of yesterday's
30876. interview with Anatole.
30877. 
30878. "Why could that not be as well?" she sometimes asked herself in complete
30879. bewilderment. "Only so could I be completely happy; but now I have to
30880. choose, and I can't be happy without either of them. Only," she thought,
30881. "to tell Prince Andrew what has happened or to hide it from him are
30882. both equally impossible. But with that one nothing is spoiled. But am
30883. I really to abandon forever the joy of Prince Andrew's love, in which I
30884. have lived so long?"
30885. 
30886. "Please, Miss!" whispered a maid entering the room with a mysterious
30887. air. "A man told me to give you this-" and she handed Natasha a letter.
30888. 
30889. "Only, for Christ's sake..." the girl went on, as Natasha, without
30890. thinking, mechanically broke the seal and read a love letter from
30891. Anatole, of which, without taking in a word, she understood only that
30892. it was a letter from him--from the man she loved. Yes, she loved him, or
30893. else how could that have happened which had happened? And how could she
30894. have a love letter from him in her hand?
30895. 
30896. With trembling hands Natasha held that passionate love letter which
30897. Dolokhov had composed for Anatole, and as she read it she found in it an
30898. echo of all that she herself imagined she was feeling.
30899. 
30900. "Since yesterday evening my fate has been sealed; to be loved by you or
30901. to die. There is no other way for me," the letter began. Then he went
30902. on to say that he knew her parents would not give her to him--for this
30903. there were secret reasons he could reveal only to her--but that if
30904. she loved him she need only say the word yes, and no human power could
30905. hinder their bliss. Love would conquer all. He would steal her away and
30906. carry her off to the ends of the earth.
30907. 
30908. "Yes, yes! I love him!" thought Natasha, reading the letter for the
30909. twentieth time and finding some peculiarly deep meaning in each word of
30910. it.
30911. 
30912. That evening Marya Dmitrievna was going to the Akharovs' and proposed to
30913. take the girls with her. Natasha, pleading a headache, remained at home.
30914. 
30915. 
30916. 
30917.

30919. CHAPTER XV
30920. 
30921. 
30922. On returning late in the evening Sonya went to Natasha's room, and to

30925. 
30926. As she read she glanced at the sleeping Natasha, trying to find in her
30927. face an explanation of what she was reading, but did not find it. Her
30928. face was calm, gentle, and happy. Clutching her breast to keep herself
30929. from choking, Sonya, pale and trembling with fear and agitation, sat
30930. down in an armchair and burst into tears.
30931. 
30932. "How was it I noticed nothing? How could it go so far? Can she have
30933. left off loving Prince Andrew? And how could she let Kuragin go to
30934. such lengths? He is a deceiver and a villain, that's plain! What will
30935. Nicholas, dear noble Nicholas, do when he hears of it? So this is

30937. yesterday, yesterday, and today," thought Sonya. "But it can't be that
30938. she loves him! She probably opened the letter without knowing who it was
30939. from. Probably she is offended by it. She could not do such a thing!"
30940. 
30941. Sonya wiped away her tears and went up to Natasha, again scanning her
30942. face.
30943. 
30944. "Natasha!" she said, just audibly.
30945. 
30946. Natasha awoke and saw Sonya.
30947. 
30948. "Ah, you're back?"
30949. 
30950. And with the decision and tenderness that often come at the moment
30951. of awakening, she embraced her friend, but noticing Sonya's look of
30952. embarrassment, her own face expressed confusion and suspicion.
30953. 
30954. "Sonya, you've read that letter?" she demanded.
30955. 
30956. "Yes," answered Sonya softly.
30957. 
30958. Natasha smiled rapturously.
30959. 
30960. "No, Sonya, I can't any longer!" she said. "I can't hide it from you
30961. any longer. You know, we love one another! Sonya, darling, he writes...
30962. Sonya..."
30963. 
30964. Sonya stared open-eyed at Natasha, unable to believe her ears.
30965. 
30966. "And Bolkonski?" she asked.
30967. 
30968. "Ah, Sonya, if you only knew how happy I am!" cried Natasha. "You don't
30969. know what love is...."
30970. 
30971. "But, Natasha, can that be all over?"
30972. 
30973. Natasha looked at Sonya with wide-open eyes as if she could not grasp
30974. the question.
30975. 
30976. "Well, then, are you refusing Prince Andrew?" said Sonya.
30977. 
30978. "Oh, you don't understand anything! Don't talk nonsense, just listen!"

30980. 
30981. "But I can't believe it," insisted Sonya. "I don't understand. How is it
30982. you have loved a man for a whole year and suddenly... Why, you have only
30983. seen him three times! Natasha, I don't believe you, you're joking! In

30985. 
30986. "Three days?" said Natasha. "It seems to me I've loved him a hundred
30987. years. It seems to me that I have never loved anyone before. You can't

30990. 
30991. "I had heard that it happens like this, and you must have heard it too,

30993. As soon as I saw him I felt he was my master and I his slave, and that

30995. do. You don't understand that. What can I do? What can I do, Sonya?"
30996. cried Natasha with a happy yet frightened expression.
30997. 
30998. "But think what you are doing," cried Sonya. "I can't leave it like
30999. this. This secret correspondence... How could you let him go so far?"

31001. 
31002. "I told you that I have no will," Natasha replied. "Why can't you
31003. understand? I love him!"
31004. 
31005. "Then I won't let it come to that... I shall tell!" cried Sonya,

31007.

31015. "But what has happened between you?" she asked. "What has he said to

31017.

31019. 
31020. "For God's sake, Sonya, don't tell anyone, don't torture me," Natasha

31036. 
31037. "If there were reasons..." she began.
31038. 
31039. But Natasha, guessing her doubts, interrupted her in alarm.

31043. 
31044. "Does he love you?"
31045.

31069.

31078. 
31079. 
31080. On Friday the Rostovs were to return to the country, but on Wednesday

31098.

31101. 
31102. Sonya sighed sorrowfully.
31103. 
31104. "But you haven't refused Bolkonski?" said she.
31105. 
31106. "Perhaps I have. Perhaps all is over between me and Bolkonski. Why do

31108.

31110. 
31111. "Wait a bit, Sonya, you'll understand everything. You'll see what a man

31115. Sonya did not succumb to the tender tone Natasha used toward her. The

31122. 
31123. "Again, again!" interrupted Natasha.
31124. 
31125. "Natasha, I am afraid for you!"
31126.

31131. 
31132. Anger again showed in Natasha's face.
31133.

31137. 
31138. "Natasha!" moaned Sonya, aghast.
31139. 
31140. "I hate you, I hate you! You're my enemy forever!" And Natasha ran out

31142. 
31143. Natasha did not speak to Sonya again and avoided her. With the same
31144. expression of agitated surprise and guilt she went about the house,

31146. 
31147. Hard as it was for Sonya, she watched her friend and did not let her out
31148. of her sight.
31149. 
31150. The day before the count was to return, Sonya noticed that Natasha sat
31151. by the drawingroom window all the morning as if expecting something and
31152. that she made a sign to an officer who drove past, whom Sonya took to be
31153. Anatole.
31154. 
31155. Sonya began watching her friend still more attentively and noticed that
31156. at dinner and all that evening Natasha was in a strange and unnatural
31157. state. She answered questions at random, began sentences she did not
31158. finish, and laughed at everything.
31159. 
31160. After tea Sonya noticed a housemaid at Natasha's door timidly waiting
31161. to let her pass. She let the girl go in, and then listening at the door
31162. learned that another letter had been delivered.
31163. 
31164. Then suddenly it became clear to Sonya that Natasha had some dreadful
31165. plan for that evening. Sonya knocked at her door. Natasha did not let
31166. her in.
31167. 
31168. "She will run away with him!" thought Sonya. "She is capable of
31169. anything. There was something particularly pathetic and resolute in her
31170. face today. She cried as she said good-by to Uncle," Sonya remembered.

31173. had some terrible intention. "The count is away. What am I to do? Write
31174. to Kuragin demanding an explanation? But what is there to oblige him
31175. to reply? Write to Pierre, as Prince Andrew asked me to in case of some
31176. misfortune?... But perhaps she really has already refused Bolkonski--she

31179. "Well, anyway," thought Sonya as she stood in the dark passage, "now or
31180. never I must prove that I remember the family's goodness to me and that
31181. I love Nicholas. Yes! If I don't sleep for three nights I'll not leave
31182. this passage and will hold her back by force and will and not let the
31183. family be disgraced," thought she.
31184.
