31189. CHAPTER XVI
31190. 
31191. 
31192. Anatole had lately moved to Dolokhov's. The plan for Natalie Rostova's
31193. abduction had been arranged and the preparations made by Dolokhov a few
31194. days before, and on the day that Sonya, after listening at Natasha's
31195. door, resolved to safeguard her, it was to have been put into execution.
31196. Natasha had promised to come out to Kuragin at the back porch at ten
31197. that evening. Kuragin was to put her into a troyka he would have
31198. ready and to drive her forty miles to the village of Kamenka, where an
31199. unfrocked priest was in readiness to perform a marriage ceremony over
31200. them. At Kamenka a relay of horses was to wait which would take them to
31201. the Warsaw highroad, and from there they would hasten abroad with post
31202. horses.
31203. 
31204. Anatole had a passport, an order for post horses, ten thousand rubles
31205. he had taken from his sister and another ten thousand borrowed with
31206. Dolokhov's help.
31207. 
31208. Two witnesses for the mock marriage--Khvostikov, a retired petty
31209. official whom Dolokhov made use of in his gambling transactions, and
31210. Makarin, a retired hussar, a kindly, weak fellow who had an unbounded
31211. affection for Kuragin--were sitting at tea in Dolokhov's front room.
31212. 
31213. In his large study, the walls of which were hung to the ceiling with
31214. Persian rugs, bearskins, and weapons, sat Dolokhov in a traveling cloak
31215. and high boots, at an open desk on which lay abacus and some bundles of
31216. paper money. Anatole, with uniform unbuttoned, walked to and fro from
31217. the room where the witnesses were sitting, through the study to the room
31218. behind, where his French valet and others were packing the last of his
31219. things. Dolokhov was counting the money and noting something down.
31220. 
31221. "Well," he said, "Khvostikov must have two thousand."
31222. 
31223. "Give it to him, then," said Anatole.
31224. 
31225. "Makarka" (their name for Makarin) "will go through fire and water for
31226. you for nothing. So here are our accounts all settled," said Dolokhov,
31227. showing him the memorandum. "Is that right?"
31228. 
31229. "Yes, of course," returned Anatole, evidently not listening to Dolokhov
31230. and looking straight before him with a smile that did not leave his
31231. face.
31232. 
31233. Dolokhov banged down the lid of his desk and turned to Anatole with an
31234. ironic smile:
31235. 
31236. "Do you know? You'd really better drop it all. There's still time!"
31237. 
31238. "Fool," retorted Anatole. "Don't talk nonsense! If you only knew... it's
31239. the devil knows what!"
31240. 
31241. "No, really, give it up!" said Dolokhov. "I am speaking seriously. It's
31242. no joke, this plot you've hatched."
31243. 
31244. "What, teasing again? Go to the devil! Eh?" said Anatole, making a
31245. grimace. "Really it's no time for your stupid jokes," and he left the
31246. room.
31247. 
31248. Dolokhov smiled contemptuously and condescendingly when Anatole had gone
31249. out.
31250. 
31251. "You wait a bit," he called after him. "I'm not joking, I'm talking
31252. sense. Come here, come here!"
31253. 
31254. Anatole returned and looked at Dolokhov, trying to give him his
31255. attention and evidently submitting to him involuntarily.
31256. 
31257. "Now listen to me. I'm telling you this for the last time. Why should
31258. I joke about it? Did I hinder you? Who arranged everything for you? Who
31259. found the priest and got the passport? Who raised the money? I did it
31260. all."
31261. 
31262. "Well, thank you for it. Do you think I am not grateful?" And Anatole
31263. sighed and embraced Dolokhov.
31264. 
31265. "I helped you, but all the same I must tell you the truth; it is a
31266. dangerous business, and if you think about it--a stupid business. Well,
31267. you'll carry her off--all right! Will they let it stop at that? It
31268. will come out that you're already married. Why, they'll have you in the
31269. criminal court...."
31270. 
31271. "Oh, nonsense, nonsense!" Anatole ejaculated and again made a grimace.
31272. "Didn't I explain to you? What?" And Anatole, with the partiality
31273. dull-witted people have for any conclusion they have reached by their
31274. own reasoning, repeated the argument he had already put to Dolokhov
31275. a hundred times. "Didn't I explain to you that I have come to this
31276. conclusion: if this marriage is invalid," he went on, crooking one
31277. finger, "then I have nothing to answer for; but if it is valid, no
31278. matter! Abroad no one will know anything about it. Isn't that so? And
31279. don't talk to me, don't, don't."
31280. 
31281. "Seriously, you'd better drop it! You'll only get yourself into a mess!"
31282. 
31283. "Go to the devil!" cried Anatole and, clutching his hair, left the room,
31284. but returned at once and dropped into an armchair in front of Dolokhov
31285. with his feet turned under him. "It's the very devil! What? Feel how it
31286. beats!" He took Dolokhov's hand and put it on his heart. "What a foot,
31287. my dear fellow! What a glance! A goddess!" he added in French. "What?"
31288. 
31289. Dolokhov with a cold smile and a gleam in his handsome insolent eyes
31290. looked at him--evidently wishing to get some more amusement out of him.
31291. 
31292. "Well and when the money's gone, what then?"
31293. 
31294. "What then? Eh?" repeated Anatole, sincerely perplexed by a thought
31295. of the future. "What then?... Then, I don't know.... But why talk
31296. nonsense!" He glanced at his watch. "It's time!"
31297. 
31298. Anatole went into the back room.
31299. 
31300. "Now then! Nearly ready? You're dawdling!" he shouted to the servants.
31301. 
31302. Dolokhov put away the money, called a footman whom he ordered to bring
31303. something for them to eat and drink before the journey, and went into
31304. the room where Khvostikov and Makarin were sitting.
31305. 
31306. Anatole lay on the sofa in the study leaning on his elbow and smiling
31307. pensively, while his handsome lips muttered tenderly to himself.
31308. 
31309. "Come and eat something. Have a drink!" Dolokhov shouted to him from the
31310. other room.
31311. 
31312. "I don't want to," answered Anatole continuing to smile.
31313. 
31314. "Come! Balaga is here."
31315. 
31316. Anatole rose and went into the dining room. Balaga was a famous troyka
31317. driver who had known Dolokhov and Anatole some six years and had given
31318. them good service with his troykas. More than once when Anatole's
31319. regiment was stationed at Tver he had taken him from Tver in the
31320. evening, brought him to Moscow by daybreak, and driven him back again
31321. the next night. More than once he had enabled Dolokhov to escape when
31322. pursued. More than once he had driven them through the town with gypsies
31323. and "ladykins" as he called the cocottes. More than once in their
31324. service he had run over pedestrians and upset vehicles in the streets
31325. of Moscow and had always been protected from the consequences by "my
31326. gentlemen" as he called them. He had ruined more than one horse in their
31327. service. More than once they had beaten him, and more than once they
31328. had made him drunk on champagne and Madeira, which he loved; and he knew
31329. more than one thing about each of them which would long ago have sent an
31330. ordinary man to Siberia. They often called Balaga into their orgies and
31331. made him drink and dance at the gypsies', and more than one thousand
31332. rubles of their money had passed through his hands. In their service he
31333. risked his skin and his life twenty times a year, and in their service
31334. had lost more horses than the money he had from them would buy. But
31335. he liked them; liked that mad driving at twelve miles an hour, liked
31336. upsetting a driver or running down a pedestrian, and flying at full
31337. gallop through the Moscow streets. He liked to hear those wild, tipsy
31338. shouts behind him: "Get on! Get on!" when it was impossible to go any
31339. faster. He liked giving a painful lash on the neck to some peasant
31340. who, more dead than alive, was already hurrying out of his way. "Real
31341. gentlemen!" he considered them.
31342. 
31343. Anatole and Dolokhov liked Balaga too for his masterly driving and
31344. because he liked the things they liked. With others Balaga bargained,
31345. charging twenty-five rubles for a two hours' drive, and rarely drove
31346. himself, generally letting his young men do so. But with "his gentlemen"
31347. he always drove himself and never demanded anything for his work. Only
31348. a couple of times a year--when he knew from their valets that they had
31349. money in hand--he would turn up of a morning quite sober and with a deep
31350. bow would ask them to help him. The gentlemen always made him sit down.
31351. 
31352. "Do help me out, Theodore Ivanych, sir," or "your excellency," he would
31353. say. "I am quite out of horses. Let me have what you can to go to the
31354. fair."
31355. 
31356. And Anatole and Dolokhov, when they had money, would give him a thousand
31357. or a couple of thousand rubles.
31358. 
31359. Balaga was a fair-haired, short, and snub-nosed peasant of about
31360. twenty-seven; red-faced, with a particularly red thick neck, glittering
31361. little eyes, and a small beard. He wore a fine, dark-blue, silk-lined
31362. cloth coat over a sheepskin.
31363. 
31364. On entering the room now he crossed himself, turning toward the front
31365. corner of the room, and went up to Dolokhov, holding out a small, black
31366. hand.
31367. 
31368. "Theodore Ivanych!" he said, bowing.
31369. 
31370. "How d'you do, friend? Well, here he is!"
31371. 
31372. "Good day, your excellency!" he said, again holding out his hand to
31373. Anatole who had just come in.
31374. 
31375. "I say, Balaga," said Anatole, putting his hands on the man's shoulders,
31376. "do you care for me or not? Eh? Now, do me a service.... What horses
31377. have you come with? Eh?"
31378. 
31379. "As your messenger ordered, your special beasts," replied Balaga.
31380. 
31381. "Well, listen, Balaga! Drive all three to death but get me there in
31382. three hours. Eh?"
31383. 
31384. "When they are dead, what shall I drive?" said Balaga with a wink.
31385. 
31386. "Mind, I'll smash your face in! Don't make jokes!" cried Anatole,
31387. suddenly rolling his eyes.
31388. 
31389. "Why joke?" said the driver, laughing. "As if I'd grudge my gentlemen
31390. anything! As fast as ever the horses can gallop, so fast we'll go!"
31391. 
31392. "Ah!" said Anatole. "Well, sit down."
31393. 
31394. "Yes, sit down!" said Dolokhov.
31395. 
31396. "I'll stand, Theodore Ivanych."
31397. 
31398. "Sit down; nonsense! Have a drink!" said Anatole, and filled a large
31399. glass of Madeira for him.
31400. 
31401. The driver's eyes sparkled at the sight of the wine. After refusing
31402. it for manners' sake, he drank it and wiped his mouth with a red silk
31403. handkerchief he took out of his cap.
31404. 
31405. "And when are we to start, your excellency?"
31406. 
31407. "Well..." Anatole looked at his watch. "We'll start at once. Mind,
31408. Balaga! You'll get there in time? Eh?"
31409. 
31410. "That depends on our luck in starting, else why shouldn't we be there
31411. in time?" replied Balaga. "Didn't we get you to Tver in seven hours? I
31412. think you remember that, your excellency?"
31413. 
31414. "Do you know, one Christmas I drove from Tver," said Anatole, smilingly
31415. at the recollection and turning to Makarin who gazed rapturously at him
31416. with wide-open eyes. "Will you believe it, Makarka, it took one's breath
31417. away, the rate we flew. We came across a train of loaded sleighs and
31418. drove right over two of them. Eh?"
31419. 
31420. "Those were horses!" Balaga continued the tale. "That time I'd harnessed
31421. two young side horses with the bay in the shafts," he went on, turning
31422. to Dolokhov. "Will you believe it, Theodore Ivanych, those animals flew
31423. forty miles? I couldn't hold them in, my hands grew numb in the sharp
31424. frost so that I threw down the reins--'Catch hold yourself, your
31425. excellency!' says I, and I just tumbled on the bottom of the sleigh and
31426. sprawled there. It wasn't a case of urging them on, there was no holding
31427. them in till we reached the place. The devils took us there in three
31428. hours! Only the near one died of it."
31429. 
31430. 
31431. 
31432. 
31433. 
31434. CHAPTER XVII
31435. 
31436. 
31437. Anatole went out of the room and returned a few minutes later wearing
31438. a fur coat girt with a silver belt, and a sable cap jauntily set on one
31439. side and very becoming to his handsome face. Having looked in a mirror,
31440. and standing before Dolokhov in the same pose he had assumed before it,
31441. he lifted a glass of wine.
31442. 
31443. "Well, good-by, Theodore. Thank you for everything and farewell!" said
31444. Anatole. "Well, comrades and friends..." he considered for a moment
31445. "...of my youth, farewell!" he said, turning to Makarin and the others.
31446. 
31447. Though they were all going with him, Anatole evidently wished to make
31448. something touching and solemn out of this address to his comrades. He
31449. spoke slowly in a loud voice and throwing out his chest slightly swayed
31450. one leg.
31451. 
31452. "All take glasses; you too, Balaga. Well, comrades and friends of my
31453. youth, we've had our fling and lived and reveled. Eh? And now, when
31454. shall we meet again? I am going abroad. We have had a good time--now
31455. farewell, lads! To our health! Hurrah!..." he cried, and emptying his
31456. glass flung it on the floor.
31457. 
31458. "To your health!" said Balaga who also emptied his glass, and wiped his
31459. mouth with his handkerchief.
31460. 
31461. Makarin embraced Anatole with tears in his eyes.
31462. 
31463. "Ah, Prince, how sorry I am to part from you!
31464. 
31465. "Let's go. Let's go!" cried Anatole.
31466. 
31467. Balaga was about to leave the room.
31468. 
31469. "No, stop!" said Anatole. "Shut the door; we have first to sit down.
31470. That's the way."
31471. 
31472. They shut the door and all sat down.
31473. 
31474. "Now, quick march, lads!" said Anatole, rising.
31475. 
31476. Joseph, his valet, handed him his sabretache and saber, and they all
31477. went out into the vestibule.
31478. 
31479. "And where's the fur cloak?" asked Dolokhov. "Hey, Ignatka! Go to
31480. Matrena Matrevna and ask her for the sable cloak. I have heard what
31481. elopements are like," continued Dolokhov with a wink. "Why, she'll rush
31482. out more dead than alive just in the things she is wearing; if you delay
31483. at all there'll be tears and 'Papa' and 'Mamma,' and she's frozen in
31484. a minute and must go back--but you wrap the fur cloak round her first
31485. thing and carry her to the sleigh."
31486. 
31487. The valet brought a woman's fox-lined cloak.
31488. 
31489. "Fool, I told you the sable one! Hey, Matrena, the sable!" he shouted so
31490. that his voice rang far through the rooms.
31491. 
31492. A handsome, slim, and pale-faced gypsy girl with glittering black eyes
31493. and curly blue-black hair, wearing a red shawl, ran out with a sable
31494. mantle on her arm.
31495. 
31496. "Here, I don't grudge it--take it!" she said, evidently afraid of her
31497. master and yet regretful of her cloak.
31498. 
31499. Dolokhov, without answering, took the cloak, threw it over Matrena, and
31500. wrapped her up in it.
31501. 
31502. "That's the way," said Dolokhov, "and then so!" and he turned the collar
31503. up round her head, leaving only a little of the face uncovered. "And
31504. then so, do you see?" and he pushed Anatole's head forward to meet the
31505. gap left by the collar, through which Matrena's brilliant smile was
31506. seen.
31507. 
31508. "Well, good-by, Matrena," said Anatole, kissing her. "Ah, my revels here
31509. are over. Remember me to Steshka. There, good-by! Good-by, Matrena, wish
31510. me luck!"
31511. 
31512. "Well, Prince, may God give you great luck!" said Matrena in her gypsy
31513. accent.
31514. 
31515. Two troykas were standing before the porch and two young drivers were
31516. holding the horses. Balaga took his seat in the front one and holding
31517. his elbows high arranged the reins deliberately. Anatole and Dolokhov
31518. got in with him. Makarin, Khvostikov, and a valet seated themselves in
31519. the other sleigh.
31520. 
31521. "Well, are you ready?" asked Balaga.
31522. 
31523. "Go!" he cried, twisting the reins round his hands, and the troyka tore
31524. down the Nikitski Boulevard.
31525. 
31526. "Tproo! Get out of the way! Hi!... Tproo!..." The shouting of Balaga
31527. and of the sturdy young fellow seated on the box was all that could
31528. be heard. On the Arbat Square the troyka caught against a carriage;
31529. something cracked, shouts were heard, and the troyka flew along the
31530. Arbat Street.
31531. 
31532. After taking a turn along the Podnovinski Boulevard, Balaga began to
31533. rein in, and turning back drew up at the crossing of the old Konyusheny
31534. Street.
31535. 
31536. The young fellow on the box jumped down to hold the horses and Anatole
31537. and Dolokhov went along the pavement. When they reached the gate
31538. Dolokhov whistled. The whistle was answered, and a maidservant ran out.
31539. 
31540. "Come into the courtyard or you'll be seen; she'll come out directly,"
31541. said she.
31542. 
31543. Dolokhov stayed by the gate. Anatole followed the maid into the
31544. courtyard, turned the corner, and ran up into the porch.
31545. 
31546. He was met by Gabriel, Marya Dmitrievna's gigantic footman.
31547. 
31548. "Come to the mistress, please," said the footman in his deep bass,
31549. intercepting any retreat.
31550. 
31551. "To what Mistress? Who are you?" asked Anatole in a breathless whisper.
31552. 
31553. "Kindly step in, my orders are to bring you in."
31554. 
31555. "Kuragin! Come back!" shouted Dolokhov. "Betrayed! Back!"
31556. 
31557. Dolokhov, after Anatole entered, had remained at the wicket gate and was
31558. struggling with the yard porter who was trying to lock it. With a last
31559. desperate effort Dolokhov pushed the porter aside, and when Anatole ran
31560. back seized him by the arm, pulled him through the wicket, and ran back
31561. with him to the troyka.
31562. 
31563. 
31564. 
31565. 
31566. 
31567. CHAPTER XVIII
31568. 
31569. 
31570. Marya Dmitrievna, having found Sonya weeping in the corridor, made her
31571. confess everything, and intercepting the note to Natasha she read it and
31572. went into Natasha's room with it in her hand.
31573. 
31574. "You shameless good-for-nothing!" said she. "I won't hear a word."
31575. 
31576. Pushing back Natasha who looked at her with astonished but tearless
31577. eyes, she locked her in; and having given orders to the yard porter to
31578. admit the persons who would be coming that evening, but not to let them
31579. out again, and having told the footman to bring them up to her, she
31580. seated herself in the drawing room to await the abductors.
31581. 
31582. When Gabriel came to inform her that the men who had come had run
31583. away again, she rose frowning, and clasping her hands behind her paced
31584. through the rooms a long time considering what she should do. Toward
31585. midnight she went to Natasha's room fingering the key in her pocket.
31586. Sonya was sitting sobbing in the corridor. "Marya Dmitrievna, for God's
31587. sake let me in to her!" she pleaded, but Marya Dmitrievna unlocked
31588. the door and went in without giving her an answer.... "Disgusting,
31589. abominable... In my house... horrid girl, hussy! I'm only sorry for her
31590. father!" thought she, trying to restrain her wrath. "Hard as it may
31591. be, I'll tell them all to hold their tongues and will hide it from the
31592. count." She entered the room with resolute steps. Natasha lying on the
31593. sofa, her head hidden in her hands, and she did not stir. She was in
31594. just the same position in which Marya Dmitrievna had left her.
31595. 
31596. "A nice girl! Very nice!" said Marya Dmitrievna. "Arranging meetings
31597. with lovers in my house! It's no use pretending: you listen when I speak
31598. to you!" And Marya Dmitrievna touched her arm. "Listen when I speak!
31599. You've disgraced yourself like the lowest of hussies. I'd treat you
31600. differently, but I'm sorry for your father, so I will conceal it."
31601. 
31602. Natasha did not change her position, but her whole body heaved with
31603. noiseless, convulsive sobs which choked her. Marya Dmitrievna glanced
31604. round at Sonya and seated herself on the sofa beside Natasha.
31605. 
31606. "It's lucky for him that he escaped me; but I'll find him!" she said in
31607. her rough voice. "Do you hear what I am saying or not?" she added.
31608. 
31609. She put her large hand under Natasha's face and turned it toward her.
31610. Both Marya Dmitrievna and Sonya were amazed when they saw how Natasha
31611. looked. Her eyes were dry and glistening, her lips compressed, her
31612. cheeks sunken.
31613. 
31614. "Let me be!... What is it to me?... I shall die!" she muttered,
31615. wrenching herself from Marya Dmitrievna's hands with a vicious effort
31616. and sinking down again into her former position.
31617. 
31618. "Natalie!" said Marya Dmitrievna. "I wish for your good. Lie still,
31619. stay like that then, I won't touch you. But listen. I won't tell you how
31620. guilty you are. You know that yourself. But when your father comes back
31621. tomorrow what am I to tell him? Eh?"
31622. 
31623. Again Natasha's body shook with sobs.
31624. 
31625. "Suppose he finds out, and your brother, and your betrothed?"
31626. 
31627. "I have no betrothed: I have refused him!" cried Natasha.
31628. 
31629. "That's all the same," continued Marya Dmitrievna. "If they hear of
31630. this, will they let it pass? He, your father, I know him... if he
31631. challenges him to a duel will that be all right? Eh?"
31632. 
31633. "Oh, let me be! Why have you interfered at all? Why? Why? Who asked
31634. you to?" shouted Natasha, raising herself on the sofa and looking
31635. malignantly at Marya Dmitrievna.
31636. 
31637. "But what did you want?" cried Marya Dmitrievna, growing angry again.
31638. "Were you kept under lock and key? Who hindered his coming to the house?
31639. Why carry you off as if you were some gypsy singing girl?... Well, if he
31640. had carried you off... do you think they wouldn't have found him?
31641. Your father, or brother, or your betrothed? And he's a scoundrel, a
31642. wretch--that's a fact!"
31643. 
31644. "He is better than any of you!" exclaimed Natasha getting up. "If you
31645. hadn't interfered... Oh, my God! What is it all? What is it? Sonya,
31646. why?... Go away!"
31647. 
31648. And she burst into sobs with the despairing vehemence with which people
31649. bewail disasters they feel they have themselves occasioned. Marya
31650. Dmitrievna was to speak again but Natasha cried out:
31651. 
31652. "Go away! Go away! You all hate and despise me!" and she threw herself
31653. back on the sofa.
31654. 
31655. Marya Dmitrievna went on admonishing her for some time, enjoining on her
31656. that it must all be kept from her father and assuring her that nobody
31657. would know anything about it if only Natasha herself would undertake
31658. to forget it all and not let anyone see that something had happened.
31659. Natasha did not reply, nor did she sob any longer, but she grew cold
31660. and had a shivering fit. Marya Dmitrievna put a pillow under her head,
31661. covered her with two quilts, and herself brought her some lime-flower
31662. water, but Natasha did not respond to her.
31663. 
31664. "Well, let her sleep," said Marya Dmitrievna as she went out of the room
31665. supposing Natasha to be asleep.
31666. 
31667. But Natasha was not asleep; with pale face and fixed wide-open eyes she
31668. looked straight before her. All that night she did not sleep or weep and
31669. did not speak to Sonya who got up and went to her several times.
31670. 
31671. Next day Count Rostov returned from his estate near Moscow in time for
31672. lunch as he had promised. He was in very good spirits; the affair with
31673. the purchaser was going on satisfactorily, and there was nothing to keep
31674. him any longer in Moscow, away from the countess whom he missed. Marya
31675. Dmitrievna met him and told him that Natasha had been very unwell the
31676. day before and that they had sent for the doctor, but that she was
31677. better now. Natasha had not left her room that morning. With compressed
31678. and parched lips and dry fixed eyes, she sat at the window, uneasily
31679. watching the people who drove past and hurriedly glancing round at
31680. anyone who entered the room. She was evidently expecting news of him and
31681. that he would come or would write to her.
31682. 
31683. When the count came to see her she turned anxiously round at the sound
31684. of a man's footstep, and then her face resumed its cold and malevolent
31685. expression. She did not even get up to greet him. "What is the matter
31686. with you, my angel? Are you ill?" asked the count.
31687. 
31688. After a moment's silence Natasha answered: "Yes, ill."
31689. 
31690. In reply to the count's anxious inquiries as to why she was so dejected
31691. and whether anything had happened to her betrothed, she assured him
31692. that nothing had happened and asked him not to worry. Marya Dmitrievna
31693. confirmed Natasha's assurances that nothing had happened. From
31694. the pretense of illness, from his daughter's distress, and by the
31695. embarrassed faces of Sonya and Marya Dmitrievna, the count saw clearly
31696. that something had gone wrong during his absence, but it was so terrible
31697. for him to think that anything disgraceful had happened to his beloved
31698. daughter, and he so prized his own cheerful tranquillity, that he
31699. avoided inquiries and tried to assure himself that nothing particularly
31700. had happened; and he was only dissatisfied that her indisposition
31701. delayed their return to the country.
31702. 
31703. 
31704. 
31705. 
31706. 
31707. CHAPTER XIX
31708. 
31709. 
31710. From the day his wife arrived in Moscow Pierre had been intending to go
31711. away somewhere, so as not to be near her. Soon after the Rostovs came
31712. to Moscow the effect Natasha had on him made him hasten to carry out
31713. his intention. He went to Tver to see Joseph Alexeevich's widow, who
31714. had long since promised to hand over to him some papers of her deceased
31715. husband's.
31716. 
31717. When he returned to Moscow Pierre was handed a letter from Marya
31718. Dmitrievna asking him to come and see her on a matter of great
31719. importance relating to Andrew Bolkonski and his betrothed. Pierre had
31720. been avoiding Natasha because it seemed to him that his feeling for her
31721. was stronger than a married man's should be for his friend's fiancee.
31722. Yet some fate constantly threw them together.
31723. 
31724. "What can have happened? And what can they want with me?" thought he
31725. as he dressed to go to Marya Dmitrievna's. "If only Prince Andrew would
31726. hurry up and come and marry her!" thought he on his way to the house.
31727. 
31728. On the Tverskoy Boulevard a familiar voice called to him.
31729. 
31730. "Pierre! Been back long?" someone shouted. Pierre raised his head. In
31731. a sleigh drawn by two gray trotting-horses that were bespattering the
31732. dashboard with snow, Anatole and his constant companion Makarin dashed
31733. past. Anatole was sitting upright in the classic pose of military
31734. dandies, the lower part of his face hidden by his beaver collar and his
31735. head slightly bent. His face was fresh and rosy, his white-plumed hat,
31736. tilted to one side, disclosed his curled and pomaded hair besprinkled
31737. with powdery snow.
31738. 
31739. "Yes, indeed, that's a true sage," thought Pierre. "He sees nothing
31740. beyond the pleasure of the moment, nothing troubles him and so he is
31741. always cheerful, satisfied, and serene. What wouldn't I give to be like
31742. him!" he thought enviously.
31743. 
31744. In Marya Dmitrievna's anteroom the footman who helped him off with his
31745. fur coat said that the mistress asked him to come to her bedroom.
31746. 
31747. When he opened the ballroom door Pierre saw Natasha sitting at the
31748. window, with a thin, pale, and spiteful face. She glanced round at him,
31749. frowned, and left the room with an expression of cold dignity.
31750. 
31751. "What has happened?" asked Pierre, entering Marya Dmitrievna's room.
31752. 
31753. "Fine doings!" answered Dmitrievna. "For fifty-eight years have I lived
31754. in this world and never known anything so disgraceful!"
31755. 
31756. And having put him on his honor not to repeat anything she told him,
31757. Marya Dmitrievna informed him that Natasha had refused Prince Andrew
31758. without her parents' knowledge and that the cause of this was Anatole
31759. Kuragin into whose society Pierre's wife had thrown her and with whom
31760. Natasha had tried to elope during her father's absence, in order to be
31761. married secretly.
31762. 
31763. Pierre raised his shoulders and listened open-mouthed to what was told
31764. him, scarcely able to believe his own ears. That Prince Andrew's
31765. deeply loved affianced wife--the same Natasha Rostova who used to be so
31766. charming--should give up Bolkonski for that fool Anatole who was already
31767. secretly married (as Pierre knew), and should be so in love with him as
31768. to agree to run away with him, was something Pierre could not conceive
31769. and could not imagine.
31770. 
31771. He could not reconcile the charming impression he had of Natasha, whom
31772. he had known from a child, with this new conception of her baseness,
31773. folly, and cruelty. He thought of his wife. "They are all alike!" he
31774. said to himself, reflecting that he was not the only man unfortunate
31775. enough to be tied to a bad woman. But still he pitied Prince Andrew to
31776. the point of tears and sympathized with his wounded pride, and the more
31777. he pitied his friend the more did he think with contempt and even with
31778. disgust of that Natasha who had just passed him in the ballroom with
31779. such a look of cold dignity. He did not know that Natasha's soul was
31780. overflowing with despair, shame, and humiliation, and that it was not
31781. her fault that her face happened to assume an expression of calm dignity
31782. and severity.
31783. 
31784. "But how get married?" said Pierre, in answer to Marya Dmitrievna. "He
31785. could not marry--he is married!"
31786. 
31787. "Things get worse from hour to hour!" ejaculated Marya Dmitrievna. "A
31788. nice youth! What a scoundrel! And she's expecting him--expecting
31789. him since yesterday. She must be told! Then at least she won't go on
31790. expecting him."
31791. 
31792. After hearing the details of Anatole's marriage from Pierre, and giving
31793. vent to her anger against Anatole in words of abuse, Marya Dmitrievna
31794. told Pierre why she had sent for him. She was afraid that the count or
31795. Bolkonski, who might arrive at any moment, if they knew of this affair
31796. (which she hoped to hide from them) might challenge Anatole to a duel,
31797. and she therefore asked Pierre to tell his brother-in-law in her name to
31798. leave Moscow and not dare to let her set eyes on him again. Pierre--only
31799. now realizing the danger to the old count, Nicholas, and Prince
31800. Andrew--promised to do as she wished. Having briefly and exactly
31801. explained her wishes to him, she let him go to the drawing room.
31802. 
31803. "Mind, the count knows nothing. Behave as if you know nothing either,"
31804. she said. "And I will go and tell her it is no use expecting him! And
31805. stay to dinner if you care to!" she called after Pierre.
31806. 
31807. Pierre met the old count, who seemed nervous and upset. That morning
31808. Natasha had told him that she had rejected Bolkonski.
31809. 
31810. "Troubles, troubles, my dear fellow!" he said to Pierre. "What troubles
31811. one has with these girls without their mother! I do so regret having
31812. come here.... I will be frank with you. Have you heard she has broken
31813. off her engagement without consulting anybody? It's true this engagement
31814. never was much to my liking. Of course he is an excellent man, but
31815. still, with his father's disapproval they wouldn't have been happy, and
31816. Natasha won't lack suitors. Still, it has been going on so long, and
31817. to take such a step without father's or mother's consent! And now she's
31818. ill, and God knows what! It's hard, Count, hard to manage daughters in
31819. their mother's absence...."
31820. 
31821. Pierre saw that the count was much upset and tried to change the
31822. subject, but the count returned to his troubles.
31823. 
31824. Sonya entered the room with an agitated face.
31825. 
31826. "Natasha is not quite well; she's in her room and would like to see you.
31827. Marya Dmitrievna is with her and she too asks you to come."
31828. 
31829. "Yes, you are a great friend of Bolkonski's, no doubt she wants to send
31830. him a message," said the count. "Oh dear! Oh dear! How happy it all
31831. was!"
31832. 
31833. And clutching the spare gray locks on his temples the count left the
31834. room.
31835. 
31836. When Marya Dmitrievna told Natasha that Anatole was married, Natasha
31837. did not wish to believe it and insisted on having it confirmed by Pierre
31838. himself. Sonya told Pierre this as she led him along the corridor to
31839. Natasha's room.
31840. 
31841. Natasha, pale and stern, was sitting beside Marya Dmitrievna, and her
31842. eyes, glittering feverishly, met Pierre with a questioning look the
31843. moment he entered. She did not smile or nod, but only gazed fixedly at
31844. him, and her look asked only one thing: was he a friend, or like the
31845. others an enemy in regard to Anatole? As for Pierre, he evidently did
31846. not exist for her.
31847. 
31848. "He knows all about it," said Marya Dmitrievna pointing to Pierre and
31849. addressing Natasha. "Let him tell you whether I have told the truth."
31850. 
31851. Natasha looked from one to the other as a hunted and wounded animal
31852. looks at the approaching dogs and sportsmen.
31853. 
31854. "Natalya Ilynichna," Pierre began, dropping his eyes with a feeling of
31855. pity for her and loathing for the thing he had to do, "whether it is
31856. true or not should make no difference to you, because..."
31857. 
31858. "Then it is not true that he's married!"
31859. 
31860. "Yes, it is true."
31861. 
31862. "Has he been married long?" she asked. "On your honor?..."
31863. 
31864. Pierre gave his word of honor.
31865. 
31866. "Is he still here?" she asked, quickly.
31867. 
31868. "Yes, I have just seen him."
31869. 
31870. She was evidently unable to speak and made a sign with her hands that
31871. they should leave her alone.
31872. 
31873. 
31874. 
31875. 
31876. 
31877. CHAPTER XX
31878. 
31879. 
31880. Pierre did not stay for dinner, but left the room and went away at once.
31881. He drove through the town seeking Anatole Kuragin, at the thought of
31882. whom now the blood rushed to his heart and he felt a difficulty in
31883. breathing. He was not at the ice hills, nor at the gypsies', nor at

31885. usual. The members who were assembling for dinner were sitting about

31893. said it was nonsense for he had just come from the Rostovs'. He asked
31894. everyone about Anatole. One man told him he had not come yet, and

31896. calm, indifferent crowd of people unaware of what was going on in his

31898. as Anatole had not turned up did not stay for dinner but drove home.
31899. 
31900. Anatole, for whom Pierre was looking, dined that day with Dolokhov,
31901. consulting him as to how to remedy this unfortunate affair. It seemed to
31902. him essential to see Natasha. In the evening he drove to his sister's
31903. to discuss with her how to arrange a meeting. When Pierre returned home

31905. Anatole was with the countess. The countess' drawing room was full of
31906. guests.
31907. 
31908. Pierre without greeting his wife whom he had not seen since his
31909. return--at that moment she was more repulsive to him than ever--entered
31910. the drawing room and seeing Anatole went up to him.
31911. 
31912. "Ah, Pierre," said the countess going up to her husband. "You don't know
31913. what a plight our Anatole..."
31914. 
31915. She stopped, seeing in the forward thrust of her husband's head, in his
31916. glowing eyes and his resolute gait, the terrible indications of that
31917. rage and strength which she knew and had herself experienced after his

31919. 
31920. "Where you are, there is vice and evil!" said Pierre to his wife.
31921. "Anatole, come with me! I must speak to you," he added in French.
31922. 
31923. Anatole glanced round at his sister and rose submissively, ready to
31924. follow Pierre. Pierre, taking him by the arm, pulled him toward himself
31925. and was leading him from the room.
31926. 
31927. "If you allow yourself in my drawing room..." whispered Helene, but
31928. Pierre did not reply and went out of the room.
31929. 
31930. Anatole followed him with his usual jaunty step but his face betrayed
31931. anxiety.
31932. 
31933. Having entered his study Pierre closed the door and addressed Anatole
31934. without looking at him.
31935. 
31936. "You promised Countess Rostova to marry her and were about to elope with
31937. her, is that so?"
31938. 
31939. "Mon cher," answered Anatole (their whole conversation was in French),

31941. tone."
31942. 
31943. Pierre's face, already pale, became distorted by fury. He seized Anatole
31944. by the collar of his uniform with his big hand and shook him from side

31946. 
31947. "When I tell you that I must talk to you!..." repeated Pierre.
31948. 
31949. "Come now, this is stupid. What?" said Anatole, fingering a button of
31950. his collar that had been wrenched loose with a bit of the cloth.
31951. 
31952. "You're a scoundrel and a blackguard, and I don't know what deprives
31953. me from the pleasure of smashing your head with this!" said Pierre,
31954. expressing himself so artificially because he was talking French.
31955. 
31956. He took a heavy paperweight and lifted it threateningly, but at once put
31957. it back in its place.
31958. 
31959. "Did you promise to marry her?"
31960. 
31961. "I... I didn't think of it. I never promised, because..."
31962. 
31963. Pierre interrupted him.
31964. 
31965. "Have you any letters of hers? Any letters?" he said, moving toward
31966. Anatole.
31967. 
31968. Anatole glanced at him and immediately thrust his hand into his pocket
31969. and drew out his pocketbook.
31970. 
31971. Pierre took the letter Anatole handed him and, pushing aside a table
31972. that stood in his way, threw himself on the sofa.
31973. 
31974. "I shan't be violent, don't be afraid!" said Pierre in answer to a
31975. frightened gesture of Anatole's. "First, the letters," said he, as if
31976. repeating a lesson to himself. "Secondly," he continued after a short
31977. pause, again rising and again pacing the room, "tomorrow you must get
31978. out of Moscow."
31979. 
31980. "But how can I?..."
31981. 
31982. "Thirdly," Pierre continued without listening to him, "you must never
31983. breathe a word of what has passed between you and Countess Rostova.
31984. I know I can't prevent your doing so, but if you have a spark of
31985. conscience..." Pierre paced the room several times in silence.
31986. 
31987. Anatole sat at a table frowning and biting his lips.
31988. 
31989. "After all, you must understand that besides your pleasure there is such
31990. a thing as other people's happiness and peace, and that you are ruining
31991. a whole life for the sake of amusing yourself! Amuse yourself with women
31992. like my wife--with them you are within your rights, for they know what
31993. you want of them. They are armed against you by the same experience
31994. of debauchery; but to promise a maid to marry her... to deceive, to
31995. kidnap.... Don't you understand that it is as mean as beating an old man
31996. or a child?..."
31997. 
31998. Pierre paused and looked at Anatole no longer with an angry but with a
31999. questioning look.
32000. 
32001. "I don't know about that, eh?" said Anatole, growing more confident as
32002. Pierre mastered his wrath. "I don't know that and don't want to," he
32003. said, not looking at Pierre and with a slight tremor of his lower jaw,
32004. "but you have used such words to me--'mean' and so on--which as a man of
32005. honor I can't allow anyone to use."
32006. 
32007. Pierre glanced at him with amazement, unable to understand what he
32008. wanted.
32009. 
32010. "Though it was tete-a-tete," Anatole continued, "still I can't..."
32011. 
32012. "Is it satisfaction you want?" said Pierre ironically.
32013. 
32014. "You could at least take back your words. What? If you want me to do as
32015. you wish, eh?"
32016. 
32017. "I take them back, I take them back!" said Pierre, "and I ask you to
32018. forgive me." Pierre involuntarily glanced at the loose button. "And if
32019. you require money for your journey..."
32020. 
32021. Anatole smiled. The expression of that base and cringing smile, which
32022. Pierre knew so well in his wife, revolted him.
32023. 
32024. "Oh, vile and heartless brood!" he exclaimed, and left the room.
32025. 
32026. Next day Anatole left for Petersburg.
32027. 
32028. 
32029. 
32030. 
32031. 
32032. CHAPTER XXI
32033. 
32034. 
32035. Pierre drove to Marya Dmitrievna's to tell her of the fulfillment of her
32036. wish that Kuragin should be banished from Moscow. The whole house was in
32037. a state of alarm and commotion. Natasha was very ill, having, as Marya
32038. Dmitrievna told him in secret, poisoned herself the night after she had
32039. been told that Anatole was married, with some arsenic she had stealthily
32040. procured. After swallowing a little she had been so frightened that she
32041. woke Sonya and told her what she had done. The necessary antidotes had
32042. been administered in time and she was now out of danger, though still so
32043. weak that it was out of the question to move her to the country, and
32044. so the countess had been sent for. Pierre saw the distracted count, and
32045. Sonya, who had a tear-stained face, but he could not see Natasha.
32046. 
32047. Pierre dined at the club that day and heard on all sides gossip about
32048. the attempted abduction of Rostova. He resolutely denied these
32049. rumors, assuring everyone that nothing had happened except that his
32050. brother-in-law had proposed to her and been refused. It seemed to
32051. Pierre that it was his duty to conceal the whole affair and re-establish
32052. Natasha's reputation.
32053. 
32054. He was awaiting Prince Andrew's return with dread and went every day to
32055. the old prince's for news of him.
32056. 
32057. Old Prince Bolkonski heard all the rumors current in the town from
32058. Mademoiselle Bourienne and had read the note to Princess Mary in which
32059. Natasha had broken off her engagement. He seemed in better spirits than
32060. usual and awaited his son with great impatience.
32061. 
32062. Some days after Anatole's departure Pierre received a note from Prince
32063. Andrew, informing him of his arrival and asking him to come to see him.
32064. 
32065. As soon as he reached Moscow, Prince Andrew had received from his
32066. father Natasha's note to Princess Mary breaking off her engagement
32067. (Mademoiselle Bourienne had purloined it from Princess Mary and given
32068. it to the old prince), and he heard from him the story of Natasha's
32069. elopement, with additions.
32070. 
32071. Prince Andrew had arrived in the evening and Pierre came to see him next
32072. morning. Pierre expected to find Prince Andrew in almost the same state
32073. as Natasha and was therefore surprised on entering the drawing room
32074. to hear him in the study talking in a loud animated voice about some
32075. intrigue going on in Petersburg. The old prince's voice and another now
32076. and then interrupted him. Princess Mary came out to meet Pierre. She
32077. sighed, looking toward the door of the room where Prince Andrew was,
32078. evidently intending to express her sympathy with his sorrow, but Pierre
32079. saw by her face that she was glad both at what had happened and at the
32080. way her brother had taken the news of Natasha's faithlessness.
32081. 
32082. "He says he expected it," she remarked. "I know his pride will not let
32083. him express his feelings, but still he has taken it better, far better,
32084. than I expected. Evidently it had to be...."
32085. 
32086. "But is it possible that all is really ended?" asked Pierre.
32087. 
32088. Princess Mary looked at him with astonishment. She did not understand
32089. how he could ask such a question. Pierre went into the study. Prince
32090. Andrew, greatly changed and plainly in better health, but with a fresh
32091. horizontal wrinkle between his brows, stood in civilian dress facing
32092. his father and Prince Meshcherski, warmly disputing and vigorously
32093. gesticulating. The conversation was about Speranski--the news of whose
32094. sudden exile and alleged treachery had just reached Moscow.
32095. 
32096. "Now he is censured and accused by all who were enthusiastic about him
32097. a month ago," Prince Andrew was saying, "and by those who were unable to
32098. understand his aims. To judge a man who is in disfavor and to throw on
32099. him all the blame of other men's mistakes is very easy, but I maintain
32100. that if anything good has been accomplished in this reign it was done by
32101. him, by him alone."
32102. 
32103. He paused at the sight of Pierre. His face quivered and immediately
32104. assumed a vindictive expression.
32105. 
32106. "Posterity will do him justice," he concluded, and at once turned to
32107. Pierre.
32108. 
32109. "Well, how are you? Still getting stouter?" he said with animation, but
32110. the new wrinkle on his forehead deepened. "Yes, I am well," he said in
32111. answer to Pierre's question, and smiled.
32112. 
32113. To Pierre that smile said plainly: "I am well, but my health is now of
32114. no use to anyone."
32115. 
32116. After a few words to Pierre about the awful roads from the Polish

32121.

32215. CHAPTER XXII
32216. 
32217. 
32218. That same evening Pierre went to the Rostovs' to fulfill the commission

32299.

32304. 
32305. He knew he had something more to say to her. But when he said it he was
32306. amazed at his own words.
32307. 
32308. "Stop, stop! You have your whole life before you," said he to her.
32309. 
32310. "Before me? No! All is over for me," she replied with shame and
32311. self-abasement.
32312. 
32313.  "All over?" he repeated. "If I were not myself, but the handsomest,
32314. cleverest, and best man in the world, and were free, I would this moment
32315. ask on my knees for your hand and your love!"
32316. 
32317. For the first time for many days Natasha wept tears of gratitude and
32318. tenderness, and glancing at Pierre she went out of the room.
32319. 
32320. Pierre too when she had gone almost ran into the anteroom, restraining
32321. tears of tenderness and joy that choked him, and without finding the
32322. sleeves of his fur cloak threw it on and got into his sleigh.
32323. 
32324. "Where to now, your excellency?" asked the coachman.
32325. 
32326. "Where to?" Pierre asked himself. "Where can I go now? Surely not to the
32327. Club or to pay calls?" All men seemed so pitiful, so poor, in comparison
32328. with this feeling of tenderness and love he experienced: in comparison
32329. with that softened, grateful, last look she had given him through her
32330. tears.
32331. 
32332. "Home!" said Pierre, and despite twenty-two degrees of frost Fahrenheit
32333. he threw open the bearskin cloak from his broad chest and inhaled the
32334. air with joy.
32335. 
32336. It was clear and frosty. Above the dirty, ill-lit streets, above the
32337. black roofs, stretched the dark starry sky. Only looking up at the sky
32338. did Pierre cease to feel how sordid and humiliating were all mundane
32339. things compared with the heights to which his soul had just been raised.
32340. At the entrance to the Arbat Square an immense expanse of dark starry
32341. sky presented itself to his eyes. Almost in the center of it, above the
32342. Prechistenka Boulevard, surrounded and sprinkled on all sides by stars
32343. but distinguished from them all by its nearness to the earth, its white
32344. light, and its long uplifted tail, shone the enormous and brilliant
32345. comet of 1812--the comet which was said to portend all kinds of woes
32346. and the end of the world. In Pierre, however, that comet with its long
32347. luminous tail aroused no feeling of fear. On the contrary he gazed
32348. joyfully, his eyes moist with tears, at this bright comet which, having
32349. traveled in its orbit with inconceivable velocity through immeasurable
32350. space, seemed suddenly--like an arrow piercing the earth--to remain
32351. fixed in a chosen spot, vigorously holding its tail erect, shining and
32352. displaying its white light amid countless other scintillating stars. It
32353. seemed to Pierre that this comet fully responded to what was passing in
32354. his own softened and uplifted soul, now blossoming into a new life.
32355. 
32356. 
32357. 
32358. 
32359. 
32360. BOOK NINE: 1812
32361. 
32362. 
32363. 
32364. 
32365. 
32366. CHAPTER I
32367. 
32368. 
32369. From the close of the year 1811 intensified arming and concentrating of
32370. the forces of Western Europe began, and in 1812 these forces--millions
32371. of men, reckoning those transporting and feeding the army--moved from
32372. the west eastwards to the Russian frontier, toward which since 1811
32373. Russian forces had been similarly drawn. On the twelfth of June, 1812,
32374. the forces of Western Europe crossed the Russian frontier and war
32375. began, that is, an event took place opposed to human reason and to human
32376. nature. Millions of men perpetrated against one another such innumerable
32377. crimes, frauds, treacheries, thefts, forgeries, issues of false money,
32378. burglaries, incendiarisms, and murders as in whole centuries are not
32379. recorded in the annals of all the law courts of the world, but which
32380. those who committed them did not at the time regard as being crimes.
32381. 
32382. What produced this extraordinary occurrence? What were its causes? The
32383. historians tell us with naive assurance that its causes were the wrongs
32384. inflicted on the Duke of Oldenburg, the nonobservance of the Continental
32385. System, the ambition of Napoleon, the firmness of Alexander, the
32386. mistakes of the diplomatists, and so on.
32387. 
32388. Consequently, it would only have been necessary for Metternich,
32389. Rumyantsev, or Talleyrand, between a levee and an evening party, to have
32390. taken proper pains and written a more adroit note, or for Napoleon to
32391. have written to Alexander: "My respected Brother, I consent to restore
32392. the duchy to the Duke of Oldenburg"--and there would have been no war.
32393. 
32394. We can understand that the matter seemed like that to contemporaries.
32395. It naturally seemed to Napoleon that the war was caused by England's
32396. intrigues (as in fact he said on the island of St. Helena). It naturally
32397. seemed to members of the English Parliament that the cause of the war
32398. was Napoleon's ambition; to the Duke of Oldenburg, that the cause of the
32399. war was the violence done to him; to businessmen that the cause of the
32400. war was the Continental System which was ruining Europe; to the generals
32401. and old soldiers that the chief reason for the war was the necessity of
32402. giving them employment; to the legitimists of that day that it was the
32403. need of re-establishing les bons principes, and to the diplomatists of
32404. that time that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance between
32405. Russia and Austria in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealed
32406. from Napoleon, and from the awkward wording of Memorandum No. 178. It
32407. is natural that these and a countless and infinite quantity of other
32408. reasons, the number depending on the endless diversity of points
32409. of view, presented themselves to the men of that day; but to us, to
32410. posterity who view the thing that happened in all its magnitude and
32411. perceive its plain and terrible meaning, these causes seem insufficient.
32412. To us it is incomprehensible that millions of Christian men killed and
32413. tortured each other either because Napoleon was ambitious or Alexander
32414. was firm, or because England's policy was astute or the Duke of
32415. Oldenburg wronged. We cannot grasp what connection such circumstances
32416. have with the actual fact of slaughter and violence: why because the
32417. Duke was wronged, thousands of men from the other side of Europe killed
32418. and ruined the people of Smolensk and Moscow and were killed by them.
32419. 
32420. To us, their descendants, who are not historians and are not carried
32421. away by the process of research and can therefore regard the event
32422. with unclouded common sense, an incalculable number of causes present
32423. themselves. The deeper we delve in search of these causes the more of
32424. them we find; and each separate cause or whole series of causes appears
32425. to us equally valid in itself and equally false by its insignificance
32426. compared to the magnitude of the events, and by its impotence--apart
32427. from the cooperation of all the other coincident causes--to occasion the
32428. event. To us, the wish or objection of this or that French corporal to
32429. serve a second term appears as much a cause as Napoleon's refusal to
32430. withdraw his troops beyond the Vistula and to restore the duchy of
32431. Oldenburg; for had he not wished to serve, and had a second, a third,
32432. and a thousandth corporal and private also refused, there would have
32433. been so many less men in Napoleon's army and the war could not have
32434. occurred.
32435. 
32436. Had Napoleon not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraw
32437. beyond the Vistula, and not ordered his troops to advance, there would
32438. have been no war; but had all his sergeants objected to serving a second
32439. term then also there could have been no war. Nor could there have been
32440. a war had there been no English intrigues and no Duke of Oldenburg, and
32441. had Alexander not felt insulted, and had there not been an autocratic
32442. government in Russia, or a Revolution in France and a subsequent
32443. dictatorship and Empire, or all the things that produced the French
32444. Revolution, and so on. Without each of these causes nothing could have
32445. happened. So all these causes--myriads of causes--coincided to bring it
32446. about. And so there was no one cause for that occurrence, but it had
32447. to occur because it had to. Millions of men, renouncing their human
32448. feelings and reason, had to go from west to east to slay their fellows,
32449. just as some centuries previously hordes of men had come from the east
32450. to the west, slaying their fellows.
32451. 
32452. The actions of Napoleon and Alexander, on whose words the event seemed
32453. to hang, were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier who was
32454. drawn into the campaign by lot or by conscription. This could not be
32455. otherwise, for in order that the will of Napoleon and Alexander (on whom
32456. the event seemed to depend) should be carried out, the concurrence of
32457. innumerable circumstances was needed without any one of which the event
32458. could not have taken place. It was necessary that millions of men in
32459. whose hands lay the real power--the soldiers who fired, or transported
32460. provisions and guns--should consent to carry out the will of these weak
32461. individuals, and should have been induced to do so by an infinite number
32462. of diverse and complex causes.
32463. 
32464. We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrational
32465. events (that is to say, events the reasonableness of which we do
32466. not understand). The more we try to explain such events in history
32467. reasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do they become to
32468. us.
32469. 
32470. Each man lives for himself, using his freedom to attain his personal
32471. aims, and feels with his whole being that he can now do or abstain from
32472. doing this or that action; but as soon as he has done it, that action
32473. performed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable and belongs to
32474. history, in which it has not a free but a predestined significance.
32475. 
32476. There are two sides to the life of every man, his individual life, which
32477. is the more free the more abstract its interests, and his elemental hive
32478. life in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him.
32479. 
32480. Man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in
32481. the attainment of the historic, universal, aims of humanity. A deed done
32482. is irrevocable, and its result coinciding in time with the actions of
32483. millions of other men assumes an historic significance. The higher a man
32484. stands on the social ladder, the more people he is connected with
32485. and the more power he has over others, the more evident is the
32486. predestination and inevitability of his every action.
32487. 
32488. "The king's heart is in the hands of the Lord."
32489. 
32490. A king is history's slave.
32491. 
32492. History, that is, the unconscious, general, hive life of mankind, uses
32493. every moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes.
32494. 
32495. Though Napoleon at that time, in 1812, was more convinced than ever that
32496. it depended on him, verser (ou ne pas verser) le sang de ses peuples
32497. *--as Alexander expressed it in the last letter he wrote him--he had
32498. never been so much in the grip of inevitable laws, which compelled him,
32499. while thinking that he was acting on his own volition, to perform
32500. for the hive life--that is to say, for history--whatever had to be
32501. performed.
32502. 
32503. 
32504.     * "To shed (or not to shed) the blood of his peoples."
32505. 
32506. 
32507. The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men, and
32508. by the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in and
32509. co-ordinated to produce that movement and war: reproaches for the
32510. nonobservance of the Continental System, the Duke of Oldenburg's
32511. wrongs, the movement of troops into Prussia--undertaken (as it seemed
32512. to Napoleon) only for the purpose of securing an armed peace, the
32513. French Emperor's love and habit of war coinciding with his people's
32514. inclinations, allurement by the grandeur of the preparations, and the
32515. expenditure on those preparations and the need of obtaining advantages
32516. to compensate for that expenditure, the intoxicating honors he received
32517. in Dresden, the diplomatic negotiations which, in the opinion of
32518. contemporaries, were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace,
32519. but which only wounded the self-love of both sides, and millions of
32520. other causes that adapted themselves to the event that was happening or
32521. coincided with it.
32522. 
32523. When an apple has ripened and falls, why does it fall? Because of its
32524. attraction to the earth, because its stalk withers, because it is dried
32525. by the sun, because it grows heavier, because the wind shakes it, or
32526. because the boy standing below wants to eat it?
32527. 
32528. Nothing is the cause. All this is only the coincidence of conditions in
32529. which all vital organic and elemental events occur. And the botanist
32530. who finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissue decays and so
32531. forth is equally right with the child who stands under the tree and says
32532. the apple fell because he wanted to eat it and prayed for it. Equally
32533. right or wrong is he who says that Napoleon went to Moscow because he
32534. wanted to, and perished because Alexander desired his destruction, and
32535. he who says that an undermined hill weighing a million tons fell because
32536. the last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock. In historic
32537. events the so-called great men are labels giving names to events, and
32538. like labels they have but the smallest connection with the event itself.
32539. 
32540. Every act of theirs, which appears to them an act of their own will, is
32541. in an historical sense involuntary and is related to the whole course of
32542. history and predestined from eternity.
32543. 
32544. 
32545. 
32546. 
32547. 
32548. CHAPTER II
32549. 
32550. 
32551. On the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden, where he had spent
32552. three weeks surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kings,
32553. and even an emperor. Before leaving, Napoleon showed favor to the
32554. emperor, kings, and princes who had deserved it, reprimanded the kings
32555. and princes with whom he was dissatisfied, presented pearls and diamonds
32556. of his own--that is, which he had taken from other kings--to the Empress
32557. of Austria, and having, as his historian tells us, tenderly embraced
32558. the Empress Marie Louise--who regarded him as her husband, though he had
32559. left another wife in Paris--left her grieved by the parting which
32560. she seemed hardly able to bear. Though the diplomatists still firmly
32561. believed in the possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end,
32562. and though the Emperor Napoleon himself wrote a letter to Alexander,
32563. calling him Monsieur mon frere, and sincerely assured him that he did
32564. not want war and would always love and honor him--yet he set off to
32565. join his army, and at every station gave fresh orders to accelerate the
32566. movement of his troops from west to east. He went in a traveling coach
32567. with six horses, surrounded by pages, aides-de-camp, and an escort,
32568. along the road to Posen, Thorn, Danzig, and Konigsberg. At each of these
32569. towns thousands of people met him with excitement and enthusiasm.
32570. 
32571. The army was moving from west to east, and relays of six horses carried
32572. him in the same direction. On the tenth of June, * coming up with the
32573. army, he spent the night in apartments prepared for him on the estate of
32574. a Polish count in the Vilkavisski forest.
32575. 
32576. 
32577.     * Old style.
32578. 
32579. 
32580. Next day, overtaking the army, he went in a carriage to the Niemen, and,
32581. changing into a Polish uniform, he drove to the riverbank in order to
32582. select a place for the crossing.
32583. 
32584. Seeing, on the other side, some Cossacks (les Cosaques) and the
32585. wide-spreading steppes in the midst of which lay the holy city of Moscow
32586. (Moscou, la ville sainte), the capital of a realm such as the Scythia
32587. into which Alexander the Great had marched--Napoleon unexpectedly, and
32588. contrary alike to strategic and diplomatic considerations, ordered an
32589. advance, and the next day his army began to cross the Niemen.
32590. 
32591. Early in the morning of the twelfth of June he came out of his tent,
32592. which was pitched that day on the steep left bank of the Niemen, and
32593. looked through a spyglass at the streams of his troops pouring out of
32594. the Vilkavisski forest and flowing over the three bridges thrown across
32595. the river. The troops, knowing of the Emperor's presence, were on the
32596. lookout for him, and when they caught sight of a figure in an overcoat
32597. and a cocked hat standing apart from his suite in front of his tent on
32598. the hill, they threw up their caps and shouted: "Vive l'Empereur!" and
32599. one after another poured in a ceaseless stream out of the vast forest
32600. that had concealed them and, separating, flowed on and on by the three
32601. bridges to the other side.
32602. 
32603. "Now we'll go into action. Oh, when he takes it in hand himself, things
32604. get hot... by heaven!... There he is!... Vive l'Empereur! So these
32605. are the steppes of Asia! It's a nasty country all the same. Au revoir,
32606. Beauche; I'll keep the best palace in Moscow for you! Au revoir. Good
32607. luck!... Did you see the Emperor? Vive l'Empereur!... preur!--If
32608. they make me Governor of India, Gerard, I'll make you Minister of
32609. Kashmir--that's settled. Vive l'Empereur! Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah! The
32610. Cossacks--those rascals--see how they run! Vive l'Empereur! There he
32611. is, do you see him? I've seen him twice, as I see you now. The little
32612. corporal... I saw him give the cross to one of the veterans.... Vive
32613. l'Empereur!" came the voices of men, old and young, of most diverse
32614. characters and social positions. On the faces of all was one common
32615. expression of joy at the commencement of the long-expected campaign and
32616. of rapture and devotion to the man in the gray coat who was standing on
32617. the hill.
32618. 
32619. On the thirteenth of June a rather small, thoroughbred Arab horse was
32620. brought to Napoleon. He mounted it and rode at a gallop to one of the
32621. bridges over the Niemen, deafened continually by incessant and rapturous
32622. acclamations which he evidently endured only because it was impossible
32623. to forbid the soldiers to express their love of him by such shouting,
32624. but the shouting which accompanied him everywhere disturbed him and
32625. distracted him from the military cares that had occupied him from the
32626. time he joined the army. He rode across one of the swaying pontoon
32627. bridges to the farther side, turned sharply to the left, and galloped in
32628. the direction of Kovno, preceded by enraptured, mounted chasseurs of the
32629. Guard who, breathless with delight, galloped ahead to clear a path for
32630. him through the troops. On reaching the broad river Viliya, he stopped
32631. near a regiment of Polish Uhlans stationed by the river.
32632. 
32633. "Vivat!" shouted the Poles, ecstatically, breaking their ranks and
32634. pressing against one another to see him.
32635. 
32636. Napoleon looked up and down the river, dismounted, and sat down on a log
32637. that lay on the bank. At a mute sign from him, a telescope was handed
32638. him which he rested on the back of a happy page who had run up to him,
32639. and he gazed at the opposite bank. Then he became absorbed in a map laid
32640. out on the logs. Without lifting his head he said something, and two of
32641. his aides-de-camp galloped off to the Polish Uhlans.
32642. 
32643. "What? What did he say?" was heard in the ranks of the Polish Uhlans
32644. when one of the aides-de-camp rode up to them.
32645. 
32646. The order was to find a ford and to cross the river. The colonel of the
32647. Polish Uhlans, a handsome old man, flushed and, fumbling in his speech
32648. from excitement, asked the aide-de-camp whether he would be permitted
32649. to swim the river with his Uhlans instead of seeking a ford. In evident
32650. fear of refusal, like a boy asking for permission to get on a horse, he
32651. begged to be allowed to swim across the river before the Emperor's
32652. eyes. The aide-de-camp replied that probably the Emperor would not be
32653. displeased at this excess of zeal.
32654. 
32655. As soon as the aide-de-camp had said this, the old mustached officer,
32656. with happy face and sparkling eyes, raised his saber, shouted "Vivat!"
32657. and, commanding the Uhlans to follow him, spurred his horse and galloped
32658. into the river. He gave an angry thrust to his horse, which had grown
32659. restive under him, and plunged into the water, heading for the deepest
32660. part where the current was swift. Hundreds of Uhlans galloped in after
32661. him. It was cold and uncanny in the rapid current in the middle of the
32662. stream, and the Uhlans caught hold of one another as they fell off their
32663. horses. Some of the horses were drowned and some of the men; the others
32664. tried to swim on, some in the saddle and some clinging to their horses'
32665. manes. They tried to make their way forward to the opposite bank and,
32666. though there was a ford one third of a mile away, were proud that they
32667. were swimming and drowning in this river under the eyes of the man who
32668. sat on the log and was not even looking at what they were doing. When
32669. the aide-de-camp, having returned and choosing an opportune moment,
32670. ventured to draw the Emperor's attention to the devotion of the Poles
32671. to his person, the little man in the gray overcoat got up and, having
32672. summoned Berthier, began pacing up and down the bank with him, giving
32673. him instructions and occasionally glancing disapprovingly at the
32674. drowning Uhlans who distracted his attention.
32675. 
32676. For him it was no new conviction that his presence in any part of
32677. the world, from Africa to the steppes of Muscovy alike, was enough to
32678. dumfound people and impel them to insane self-oblivion. He called for
32679. his horse and rode to his quarters.
32680. 
32681. Some forty Uhlans were drowned in the river, though boats were sent to
32682. their assistance. The majority struggled back to the bank from which
32683. they had started. The colonel and some of his men got across and with
32684. difficulty clambered out on the further bank. And as soon as they had
32685. got out, in their soaked and streaming clothes, they shouted "Vivat!"
32686. and looked ecstatically at the spot where Napoleon had been but where he
32687. no longer was and at that moment considered themselves happy.
32688. 
32689. That evening, between issuing one order that the forged Russian paper
32690. money prepared for use in Russia should be delivered as quickly as
32691. possible and another that a Saxon should be shot, on whom a letter
32692. containing information about the orders to the French army had been
32693. found, Napoleon also gave instructions that the Polish colonel who
32694. had needlessly plunged into the river should be enrolled in the Legion
32695. d'honneur of which Napoleon was himself the head.
32696. 
32697. Quos vult perdere dementat. *
32698. 
32699. 
32700.     * Those whom (God) wishes to destroy he drives mad.
32701. 
32702. 
32703. 
32704. 
32705. 
32706. CHAPTER III
32707. 
32708. 
32709. The Emperor of Russia had, meanwhile, been in Vilna for more than a
32710. month, reviewing troops and holding maneuvers. Nothing was ready for the
32711. war that everyone expected and to prepare for which the Emperor had come
32712. from Petersburg. There was no general plan of action. The vacillation
32713. between the various plans that were proposed had even increased after
32714. the Emperor had been at headquarters for a month. Each of the three
32715. armies had its own commander in chief, but there was no supreme
32716. commander of all the forces, and the Emperor did not assume that
32717. responsibility himself.
32718. 
32719. The longer the Emperor remained in Vilna the less did everybody--tired
32720. of waiting--prepare for the war. All the efforts of those who surrounded
32721. the sovereign seemed directed merely to making him spend his time
32722. pleasantly and forget that war was impending.
32723. 
32724. In June, after many balls and fetes given by the Polish magnates, by the
32725. courtiers, and by the Emperor himself, it occurred to one of the Polish
32726. aides-de-camp in attendance that a dinner and ball should be given for
32727. the Emperor by his aides-de-camp. This idea was eagerly received.
32728. The Emperor gave his consent. The aides-de-camp collected money by
32729. subscription. The lady who was thought to be most pleasing to the
32730. Emperor was invited to act as hostess. Count Bennigsen, being a
32731. landowner in the Vilna province, offered his country house for the fete,
32732. and the thirteenth of June was fixed for a ball, dinner, regatta, and
32733. fireworks at Zakret, Count Bennigsen's country seat.
32734. 
32735. The very day that Napoleon issued the order to cross the Niemen, and
32736. his vanguard, driving off the Cossacks, crossed the Russian frontier,
32737. Alexander spent the evening at the entertainment given by his
32738. aides-de-camp at Bennigsen's country house.
32739. 
32740. It was a gay and brilliant fete. Connoisseurs of such matters declared
32741. that rarely had so many beautiful women been assembled in one place.
32742. Countess Bezukhova was present among other Russian ladies who had
32743. followed the sovereign from Petersburg to Vilna and eclipsed the refined
32744. Polish ladies by her massive, so called Russian type of beauty. The
32745. Emperor noticed her and honored her with a dance.
32746. 
32747. Boris Drubetskoy, having left his wife in Moscow and being for the
32748. present en garcon (as he phrased it), was also there and, though not an
32749. aide-de-camp, had subscribed a large sum toward the expenses. Boris
32750. was now a rich man who had risen to high honors and no longer sought
32751. patronage but stood on an equal footing with the highest of those of his
32752. own age. He was meeting Helene in Vilna after not having seen her for
32753. a long time and did not recall the past, but as Helene was enjoying
32754. the favors of a very important personage and Boris had only recently
32755. married, they met as good friends of long standing.
32756. 
32757. At midnight dancing was still going on. Helene, not having a suitable
32758. partner, herself offered to dance the mazurka with Boris. They were the
32759. third couple. Boris, coolly looking at Helene's dazzling bare shoulders
32760. which emerged from a dark, gold-embroidered, gauze gown, talked to her
32761. of old acquaintances and at the same time, unaware of it himself and
32762. unnoticed by others, never for an instant ceased to observe the Emperor
32763. who was in the same room. The Emperor was not dancing, he stood in the
32764. doorway, stopping now one pair and now another with gracious words which
32765. he alone knew how to utter.
32766. 
32767. As the mazurka began, Boris saw that Adjutant General Balashev, one of
32768. those in closest attendance on the Emperor, went up to him and contrary
32769. to court etiquette stood near him while he was talking to a Polish
32770. lady. Having finished speaking to her, the Emperor looked inquiringly
32771. at Balashev and, evidently understanding that he only acted thus because
32772. there were important reasons for so doing, nodded slightly to the lady
32773. and turned to him. Hardly had Balashev begun to speak before a look of
32774. amazement appeared on the Emperor's face. He took Balashev by the arm
32775. and crossed the room with him, unconsciously clearing a path seven
32776. yards wide as the people on both sides made way for him. Boris noticed
32777. Arakcheev's excited face when the sovereign went out with Balashev.
32778. Arakcheev looked at the Emperor from under his brow and, sniffing with
32779. his red nose, stepped forward from the crowd as if expecting the Emperor
32780. to address him. (Boris understood that Arakcheev envied Balashev and
32781. was displeased that evidently important news had reached the Emperor
32782. otherwise than through himself.)
32783. 
32784. But the Emperor and Balashev passed out into the illuminated garden
32785. without noticing Arakcheev who, holding his sword and glancing
32786. wrathfully around, followed some twenty paces behind them.
32787. 
32788. All the time Boris was going through the figures of the mazurka, he was
32789. worried by the question of what news Balashev had brought and how he
32790. could find it out before others. In the figure in which he had to choose
32791. two ladies, he whispered to Helene that he meant to choose Countess
32792. Potocka who, he thought, had gone out onto the veranda, and glided over
32793. the parquet to the door opening into the garden, where, seeing Balashev
32794. and the Emperor returning to the veranda, he stood still. They were
32795. moving toward the door. Boris, fluttering as if he had not had time to
32796. withdraw, respectfully pressed close to the doorpost with bowed head.
32797. 
32798. The Emperor, with the agitation of one who has been personally
32799. affronted, was finishing with these words:
32800. 
32801. "To enter Russia without declaring war! I will not make peace as long as
32802. a single armed enemy remains in my country!" It seemed to Boris that it
32803. gave the Emperor pleasure to utter these words. He was satisfied with
32804. the form in which he had expressed his thoughts, but displeased that
32805. Boris had overheard it.
32806. 
32807. "Let no one know of it!" the Emperor added with a frown.
32808. 
32809. Boris understood that this was meant for him and, closing his eyes,
32810. slightly bowed his head. The Emperor re-entered the ballroom and
32811. remained there about another half-hour.
32812. 
32813. Boris was thus the first to learn the news that the French army had
32814. crossed the Niemen and, thanks to this, was able to show certain
32815. important personages that much that was concealed from others was
32816. usually known to him, and by this means he rose higher in their
32817. estimation.
32818. 
32819. 
32820. The unexpected news of the French having crossed the Niemen was
32821. particularly startling after a month of unfulfilled expectations, and at
32822. a ball. On first receiving the news, under the influence of indignation
32823. and resentment the Emperor had found a phrase that pleased him, fully
32824. expressed his feelings, and has since become famous. On returning home
32825. at two o'clock that night he sent for his secretary, Shishkov, and told
32826. him to write an order to the troops and a rescript to Field Marshal
32827. Prince Saltykov, in which he insisted on the words being inserted that
32828. he would not make peace so long as a single armed Frenchman remained on
32829. Russian soil.
32830. 
32831. Next day the following letter was sent to Napoleon:
32832. 
32833. 
32834. Monsieur mon frere,
32835. 
32836. Yesterday I learned that, despite the loyalty with which I have kept
32837. my engagements with Your Majesty, your troops have crossed the Russian
32838. frontier, and I have this moment received from Petersburg a note, in
32839. which Count Lauriston informs me, as a reason for this aggression, that
32840. Your Majesty has considered yourself to be in a state of war with me
32841. from the time Prince Kuragin asked for his passports. The reasons on
32842. which the Duc de Bassano based his refusal to deliver them to him would
