32843. never have led me to suppose that that could serve as a pretext for
32844. aggression. In fact, the ambassador, as he himself has declared, was
32845. never authorized to make that demand, and as soon as I was informed of
32846. it I let him know how much I disapproved of it and ordered him to remain
32847. at his post. If Your Majesty does not intend to shed the blood of our
32848. peoples for such a misunderstanding, and consents to withdraw your
32849. troops from Russian territory, I will regard what has passed as not
32850. having occurred and an understanding between us will be possible. In
32851. the contrary case, Your Majesty, I shall see myself forced to repel an
32852. attack that nothing on my part has provoked. It still depends on Your
32853. Majesty to preserve humanity from the calamity of another war. I am,
32854. etc.,
32855. 
32856. (signed) Alexander.
32857. 
32858. 
32859. 
32860. 
32861. 
32862. CHAPTER IV
32863. 
32864. 
32865. At two in the morning of the fourteenth of June, the Emperor, having
32866. sent for Balashev and read him his letter to Napoleon, ordered him to
32867. take it and hand it personally to the French Emperor. When dispatching
32868. Balashev, the Emperor repeated to him the words that he would not make
32869. peace so long as a single armed enemy remained on Russian soil and told
32870. him to transmit those words to Napoleon. Alexander did not insert them
32871. in his letter to Napoleon, because with his characteristic tact he felt
32872. it would be injudicious to use them at a moment when a last attempt at
32873. reconciliation was being made, but he definitely instructed Balashev to
32874. repeat them personally to Napoleon.
32875. 
32876. Having set off in the small hours of the fourteenth, accompanied by a
32877. bugler and two Cossacks, Balashev reached the French outposts at the
32878. village of Rykonty, on the Russian side of the Niemen, by dawn. There he
32879. was stopped by French cavalry sentinels.
32880. 
32881. A French noncommissioned officer of hussars, in crimson uniform and a
32882. shaggy cap, shouted to the approaching Balashev to halt. Balashev did
32883. not do so at once, but continued to advance along the road at a walking
32884. pace.
32885. 
32886. The noncommissioned officer frowned and, muttering words of abuse,
32887. advanced his horse's chest against Balashev, put his hand to his saber,
32888. and shouted rudely at the Russian general, asking: was he deaf that
32889. he did not do as he was told? Balashev mentioned who he was. The
32890. noncommissioned officer began talking with his comrades about regimental
32891. matters without looking at the Russian general.
32892. 
32893. After living at the seat of the highest authority and power, after
32894. conversing with the Emperor less than three hours before, and in general
32895. being accustomed to the respect due to his rank in the service, Balashev
32896. found it very strange here on Russian soil to encounter this hostile,
32897. and still more this disrespectful, application of brute force to
32898. himself.
32899. 
32900. The sun was only just appearing from behind the clouds, the air was
32901. fresh and dewy. A herd of cattle was being driven along the road from
32902. the village, and over the fields the larks rose trilling, one after
32903. another, like bubbles rising in water.
32904. 
32905. Balashev looked around him, awaiting the arrival of an officer from the
32906. village. The Russian Cossacks and bugler and the French hussars looked
32907. silently at one another from time to time.
32908. 
32909. A French colonel of hussars, who had evidently just left his bed, came
32910. riding from the village on a handsome sleek gray horse, accompanied
32911. by two hussars. The officer, the soldiers, and their horses all looked
32912. smart and well kept.
32913. 
32914. It was that first period of a campaign when troops are still in full
32915. trim, almost like that of peacetime maneuvers, but with a shade of
32916. martial swagger in their clothes, and a touch of the gaiety and spirit
32917. of enterprise which always accompany the opening of a campaign.
32918. 
32919. The French colonel with difficulty repressed a yawn, but was polite and
32920. evidently understood Balashev's importance. He led him past his soldiers
32921. and behind the outposts and told him that his wish to be presented to
32922. the Emperor would most likely be satisfied immediately, as the Emperor's
32923. quarters were, he believed, not far off.
32924. 
32925. They rode through the village of Rykonty, past tethered French hussar
32926. horses, past sentinels and men who saluted their colonel and stared with
32927. curiosity at a Russian uniform, and came out at the other end of the
32928. village. The colonel said that the commander of the division was a mile
32929. and a quarter away and would receive Balashev and conduct him to his
32930. destination.
32931. 
32932. The sun had by now risen and shone gaily on the bright verdure.
32933. 
32934. They had hardly ridden up a hill, past a tavern, before they saw a group
32935. of horsemen coming toward them. In front of the group, on a black horse
32936. with trappings that glittered in the sun, rode a tall man with plumes
32937. in his hat and black hair curling down to his shoulders. He wore a red
32938. mantle, and stretched his long legs forward in French fashion. This man
32939. rode toward Balashev at a gallop, his plumes flowing and his gems and
32940. gold lace glittering in the bright June sunshine.
32941. 
32942. Balashev was only two horses' length from the equestrian with the
32943. bracelets, plumes, necklaces, and gold embroidery, who was galloping
32944. toward him with a theatrically solemn countenance, when Julner, the
32945. French colonel, whispered respectfully: "The King of Naples!" It was,
32946. in fact, Murat, now called "King of Naples." Though it was quite
32947. incomprehensible why he should be King of Naples, he was called so,
32948. and was himself convinced that he was so, and therefore assumed a more
32949. solemn and important air than formerly. He was so sure that he really
32950. was the King of Naples that when, on the eve of his departure from that
32951. city, while walking through the streets with his wife, some Italians
32952. called out to him: "Viva il re!" * he turned to his wife with a pensive
32953. smile and said: "Poor fellows, they don't know that I am leaving them
32954. tomorrow!"
32955. 
32956. 
32957.     * "Long live the king."
32958. 
32959. 
32960. But though he firmly believed himself to be King of Naples and pitied
32961. the grief felt by the subjects he was abandoning, latterly, after he
32962. had been ordered to return to military service--and especially since his
32963. last interview with Napoleon in Danzig, when his august brother-in-law
32964. had told him: "I made you King that you should reign in my way, but not
32965. in yours!"--he had cheerfully taken up his familiar business, and--like
32966. a well-fed but not overfat horse that feels himself in harness and grows
32967. skittish between the shafts--he dressed up in clothes as variegated
32968. and expensive as possible, and gaily and contentedly galloped along the
32969. roads of Poland, without himself knowing why or whither.
32970. 
32971. On seeing the Russian general he threw back his head, with its long hair
32972. curling to his shoulders, in a majestically royal manner, and looked
32973. inquiringly at the French colonel. The colonel respectfully informed His
32974. Majesty of Balashev's mission, whose name he could not pronounce.
32975. 
32976. "De Bal-macheve!" said the King (overcoming by his assurance the
32977. difficulty that had presented itself to the colonel). "Charmed to
32978. make your acquaintance, General!" he added, with a gesture of kingly
32979. condescension.
32980. 
32981. As soon as the King began to speak loud and fast his royal dignity
32982. instantly forsook him, and without noticing it he passed into his
32983. natural tone of good-natured familiarity. He laid his hand on the
32984. withers of Balashev's horse and said:
32985. 
32986. "Well, General, it all looks like war," as if regretting a circumstance
32987. of which he was unable to judge.
32988. 
32989. "Your Majesty," replied Balashev, "my master, the Emperor, does not
32990. desire war and as Your Majesty sees..." said Balashev, using the words
32991. Your Majesty at every opportunity, with the affectation unavoidable in
32992. frequently addressing one to whom the title was still a novelty.
32993. 
32994. Murat's face beamed with stupid satisfaction as he listened to "Monsieur
32995. de Bal-macheve." But royaute oblige! * and he felt it incumbent on
32996. him, as a king and an ally, to confer on state affairs with Alexander's
32997. envoy. He dismounted, took Balashev's arm, and moving a few steps away
32998. from his suite, which waited respectfully, began to pace up and down
32999. with him, trying to speak significantly. He referred to the fact that
33000. the Emperor Napoleon had resented the demand that he should withdraw his
33001. troops from Prussia, especially when that demand became generally known
33002. and the dignity of France was thereby offended.
33003. 
33004. 
33005.     * "Royalty has its obligations."
33006. 
33007. 
33008. Balashev replied that there was "nothing offensive in the demand,
33009. because..." but Murat interrupted him.
33010. 
33011. "Then you don't consider the Emperor Alexander the aggressor?" he asked
33012. unexpectedly, with a kindly and foolish smile.
33013. 
33014. Balashev told him why he considered Napoleon to be the originator of the
33015. war.
33016. 
33017. "Oh, my dear general!" Murat again interrupted him, "with all my heart I
33018. wish the Emperors may arrange the affair between them, and that the war
33019. begun by no wish of mine may finish as quickly as possible!" said he,
33020. in the tone of a servant who wants to remain good friends with another
33021. despite a quarrel between their masters.
33022. 
33023. And he went on to inquiries about the Grand Duke and the state of his
33024. health, and to reminiscences of the gay and amusing times he had spent
33025. with him in Naples. Then suddenly, as if remembering his royal dignity,
33026. Murat solemnly drew himself up, assumed the pose in which he had stood
33027. at his coronation, and, waving his right arm, said:
33028. 
33029. "I won't detain you longer, General. I wish success to your mission,"
33030. and with his embroidered red mantle, his flowing feathers, and his
33031. glittering ornaments, he rejoined his suite who were respectfully
33032. awaiting him.
33033. 
33034. Balashev rode on, supposing from Murat's words that he would very soon
33035. be brought before Napoleon himself. But instead of that, at the next
33036. village the sentinels of Davout's infantry corps detained him as
33037. the pickets of the vanguard had done, and an adjutant of the corps
33038. commander, who was fetched, conducted him into the village to Marshal
33039. Davout.
33040. 
33041. 
33042. 
33043. 
33044. 
33045. CHAPTER V
33046. 
33047. 
33048. Davout was to Napoleon what Arakcheev was to Alexander--though not a
33049. coward like Arakcheev, he was as precise, as cruel, and as unable to
33050. express his devotion to his monarch except by cruelty.
33051. 
33052. In the organism of states such men are necessary, as wolves are
33053. necessary in the organism of nature, and they always exist, always
33054. appear and hold their own, however incongruous their presence and their
33055. proximity to the head of the government may be. This inevitability alone
33056. can explain how the cruel Arakcheev, who tore out a grenadier's mustache
33057. with his own hands, whose weak nerves rendered him unable to face
33058. danger, and who was neither an educated man nor a courtier, was able to
33059. maintain his powerful position with Alexander, whose own character was
33060. chivalrous, noble, and gentle.
33061. 
33062. Balashev found Davout seated on a barrel in the shed of a peasant's hut,
33063. writing--he was auditing accounts. Better quarters could have been
33064. found him, but Marshal Davout was one of those men who purposely put
33065. themselves in most depressing conditions to have a justification for
33066. being gloomy. For the same reason they are always hard at work and in a
33067. hurry. "How can I think of the bright side of life when, as you see, I
33068. am sitting on a barrel and working in a dirty shed?" the expression of
33069. his face seemed to say. The chief pleasure and necessity of such men,
33070. when they encounter anyone who shows animation, is to flaunt their own
33071. dreary, persistent activity. Davout allowed himself that pleasure when
33072. Balashev was brought in. He became still more absorbed in his task when
33073. the Russian general entered, and after glancing over his spectacles at
33074. Balashev's face, which was animated by the beauty of the morning and
33075. by his talk with Murat, he did not rise or even stir, but scowled still
33076. more and sneered malevolently.
33077. 
33078. When he noticed in Balashev's face the disagreeable impression this
33079. reception produced, Davout raised his head and coldly asked what he
33080. wanted.
33081. 
33082. Thinking he could have been received in such a manner only because
33083. Davout did not know that he was adjutant general to the Emperor
33084. Alexander and even his envoy to Napoleon, Balashev hastened to inform
33085. him of his rank and mission. Contrary to his expectation, Davout, after
33086. hearing him, became still surlier and ruder.
33087. 
33088. "Where is your dispatch?" he inquired. "Give it to me. I will send it to
33089. the Emperor."
33090. 
33091. Balashev replied that he had been ordered to hand it personally to the
33092. Emperor.
33093. 
33094. "Your Emperor's orders are obeyed in your army, but here," said Davout,
33095. "you must do as you're told."
33096. 
33097. And, as if to make the Russian general still more conscious of his
33098. dependence on brute force, Davout sent an adjutant to call the officer
33099. on duty.
33100. 
33101. Balashev took out the packet containing the Emperor's letter and laid it
33102. on the table (made of a door with its hinges still hanging on it, laid
33103. across two barrels). Davout took the packet and read the inscription.
33104. 
33105. "You are perfectly at liberty to treat me with respect or not,"
33106. protested Balashev, "but permit me to observe that I have the honor to
33107. be adjutant general to His Majesty...."
33108. 
33109. Davout glanced at him silently and plainly derived pleasure from the
33110. signs of agitation and confusion which appeared on Balashev's face.
33111. 
33112. "You will be treated as is fitting," said he and, putting the packet in
33113. his pocket, left the shed.
33114. 
33115. A minute later the marshal's adjutant, de Castres, came in and conducted
33116. Balashev to the quarters assigned him.
33117. 
33118. That day he dined with the marshal, at the same board on the barrels.
33119. 
33120. Next day Davout rode out early and, after asking Balashev to come to
33121. him, peremptorily requested him to remain there, to move on with the
33122. baggage train should orders come for it to move, and to talk to no one
33123. except Monsieur de Castres.
33124. 
33125. After four days of solitude, ennui, and consciousness of his impotence
33126. and insignificance--particularly acute by contrast with the sphere of
33127. power in which he had so lately moved--and after several marches with
33128. the marshal's baggage and the French army, which occupied the
33129. whole district, Balashev was brought to Vilna--now occupied by the
33130. French--through the very gate by which he had left it four days
33131. previously.
33132. 
33133. Next day the imperial gentleman-in-waiting, the Comte de Turenne, came
33134. to Balashev and informed him of the Emperor Napoleon's wish to honor him
33135. with an audience.
33136. 
33137. Four days before, sentinels of the Preobrazhensk regiment had stood in
33138. front of the house to which Balashev was conducted, and now two French
33139. grenadiers stood there in blue uniforms unfastened in front and with
33140. shaggy caps on their heads, and an escort of hussars and Uhlans and a
33141. brilliant suite of aides-de-camp, pages, and generals, who were waiting
33142. for Napoleon to come out, were standing at the porch, round his saddle
33143. horse and his Mameluke, Rustan. Napoleon received Balashev in the very
33144. house in Vilna from which Alexander had dispatched him on his mission.
33145. 
33146. 
33147. 
33148. 
33149. 
33150. CHAPTER VI
33151. 
33152. 
33153. Though Balashev was used to imperial pomp, he was amazed at the luxury
33154. and magnificence of Napoleon's court.
33155. 
33156. The Comte de Turenne showed him into a big reception room where many
33157. generals, gentlemen-in-waiting, and Polish magnates--several of whom
33158. Balashev had seen at the court of the Emperor of Russia--were waiting.
33159. Duroc said that Napoleon would receive the Russian general before going
33160. for his ride.
33161. 
33162. After some minutes, the gentleman-in-waiting who was on duty came into
33163. the great reception room and, bowing politely, asked Balashev to follow
33164. him.
33165. 
33166. Balashev went into a small reception room, one door of which led into a
33167. study, the very one from which the Russian Emperor had dispatched him
33168. on his mission. He stood a minute or two, waiting. He heard hurried
33169. footsteps beyond the door, both halves of it were opened rapidly; all
33170. was silent and then from the study the sound was heard of other steps,
33171. firm and resolute--they were those of Napoleon. He had just finished
33172. dressing for his ride, and wore a blue uniform, opening in front over
33173. a white waistcoat so long that it covered his rotund stomach, white
33174. leather breeches tightly fitting the fat thighs of his short legs, and
33175. Hessian boots. His short hair had evidently just been brushed, but one
33176. lock hung down in the middle of his broad forehead. His plump white neck
33177. stood out sharply above the black collar of his uniform, and he smelled
33178. of Eau de Cologne. His full face, rather young-looking, with its
33179. prominent chin, wore a gracious and majestic expression of imperial
33180. welcome.
33181. 
33182. He entered briskly, with a jerk at every step and his head slightly
33183. thrown back. His whole short corpulent figure with broad thick
33184. shoulders, and chest and stomach involuntarily protruding, had that
33185. imposing and stately appearance one sees in men of forty who live in
33186. comfort. It was evident, too, that he was in the best of spirits that
33187. day.
33188. 
33189. He nodded in answer to Balashav's low and respectful bow, and coming up
33190. to him at once began speaking like a man who values every moment of his
33191. time and does not condescend to prepare what he has to say but is sure
33192. he will always say the right thing and say it well.
33193. 
33194. "Good day, General!" said he. "I have received the letter you brought
33195. from the Emperor Alexander and am very glad to see you." He glanced with
33196. his large eyes into Balashav's face and immediately looked past him.
33197. 
33198. It was plain that Balashev's personality did not interest him at all.
33199. Evidently only what took place within his own mind interested him.
33200. Nothing outside himself had any significance for him, because everything
33201. in the world, it seemed to him, depended entirely on his will.
33202. 
33203. "I do not, and did not, desire war," he continued, "but it has been
33204. forced on me. Even now" (he emphasized the word) "I am ready to receive
33205. any explanations you can give me."
33206. 
33207. And he began clearly and concisely to explain his reasons for
33208. dissatisfaction with the Russian government. Judging by the calmly
33209. moderate and amicable tone in which the French Emperor spoke, Balashev
33210. was firmly persuaded that he wished for peace and intended to enter into
33211. negotiations.
33212. 
33213. When Napoleon, having finished speaking, looked inquiringly at the
33214. Russian envoy, Balashev began a speech he had prepared long before:
33215. "Sire! The Emperor, my master..." but the sight of the Emperor's eyes
33216. bent on him confused him. "You are flurried--compose yourself!" Napoleon
33217. seemed to say, as with a scarcely perceptible smile he looked at
33218. Balashev's uniform and sword.
33219. 
33220. Balashev recovered himself and began to speak. He said that the
33221. Emperor Alexander did not consider Kurakin's demand for his passports a
33222. sufficient cause for war; that Kurakin had acted on his own initiative
33223. and without his sovereign's assent, that the Emperor Alexander did not
33224. desire war, and had no relations with England.
33225. 
33226. "Not yet!" interposed Napoleon, and, as if fearing to give vent to his
33227. feelings, he frowned and nodded slightly as a sign that Balashev might
33228. proceed.
33229. 
33230. After saying all he had been instructed to say, Balashev added that
33231. the Emperor Alexander wished for peace, but would not enter into
33232. negotiations except on condition that... Here Balashev hesitated:
33233. he remembered the words the Emperor Alexander had not written in his
33234. letter, but had specially inserted in the rescript to Saltykov and had
33235. told Balashev to repeat to Napoleon. Balashev remembered these words,
33236. "So long as a single armed foe remains on Russian soil," but some
33237. complex feeling restrained him. He could not utter them, though he
33238. wished to do so. He grew confused and said: "On condition that the
33239. French army retires beyond the Niemen."
33240. 
33241. Napoleon noticed Balashev's embarrassment when uttering these last
33242. words; his face twitched and the calf of his left leg began to quiver
33243. rhythmically. Without moving from where he stood he began speaking in
33244. a louder tone and more hurriedly than before. During the speech that
33245. followed, Balashev, who more than once lowered his eyes, involuntarily
33246. noticed the quivering of Napoleon's left leg which increased the more
33247. Napoleon raised his voice.
33248. 
33249. "I desire peace, no less than the Emperor Alexander," he began. "Have
33250. I not for eighteen months been doing everything to obtain it? I
33251. have waited eighteen months for explanations. But in order to begin
33252. negotiations, what is demanded of me?" he said, frowning and making an
33253. energetic gesture of inquiry with his small white plump hand.
33254. 
33255. "The withdrawal of your army beyond the Niemen, sire," replied Balashev.
33256. 
33257. "The Niemen?" repeated Napoleon. "So now you want me to retire beyond
33258. the Niemen--only the Niemen?" repeated Napoleon, looking straight at
33259. Balashev.
33260. 
33261. The latter bowed his head respectfully.
33262. 
33263. Instead of the demand of four months earlier to withdraw from Pomerania,
33264. only a withdrawal beyond the Niemen was now demanded. Napoleon turned
33265. quickly and began to pace the room.
33266. 
33267. "You say the demand now is that I am to withdraw beyond the Niemen
33268. before commencing negotiations, but in just the same way two months ago
33269. the demand was that I should withdraw beyond the Vistula and the Oder,
33270. and yet you are willing to negotiate."
33271. 
33272. He went in silence from one corner of the room to the other and again
33273. stopped in front of Balashev. Balashev noticed that his left leg was
33274. quivering faster than before and his face seemed petrified in its stern
33275. expression. This quivering of his left leg was a thing Napoleon was
33276. conscious of. "The vibration of my left calf is a great sign with me,"
33277. he remarked at a later date.
33278. 
33279. "Such demands as to retreat beyond the Vistula and Oder may be made to a
33280. Prince of Baden, but not to me!" Napoleon almost screamed, quite to his
33281. own surprise. "If you gave me Petersburg and Moscow I could not accept
33282. such conditions. You say I have begun this war! But who first joined his
33283. army? The Emperor Alexander, not I! And you offer me negotiations when I
33284. have expended millions, when you are in alliance with England, and when
33285. your position is a bad one. You offer me negotiations! But what is the
33286. aim of your alliance with England? What has she given you?" he continued
33287. hurriedly, evidently no longer trying to show the advantages of peace
33288. and discuss its possibility, but only to prove his own rectitude and
33289. power and Alexander's errors and duplicity.
33290. 
33291. The commencement of his speech had obviously been made with the
33292. intention of demonstrating the advantages of his position and showing
33293. that he was nevertheless willing to negotiate. But he had begun talking,
33294. and the more he talked the less could he control his words.
33295. 
33296. The whole purport of his remarks now was evidently to exalt himself and
33297. insult Alexander--just what he had least desired at the commencement of
33298. the interview.
33299. 
33300. "I hear you have made peace with Turkey?"
33301. 
33302. Balashev bowed his head affirmatively.
33303. 
33304. "Peace has been concluded..." he began.
33305. 
33306. But Napoleon did not let him speak. He evidently wanted to do all the
33307. talking himself, and continued to talk with the sort of eloquence and
33308. unrestrained irritability to which spoiled people are so prone.
33309. 
33310. "Yes, I know you have made peace with the Turks without obtaining
33311. Moldavia and Wallachia; I would have given your sovereign those
33312. provinces as I gave him Finland. Yes," he went on, "I promised and would
33313. have given the Emperor Alexander Moldavia and Wallachia, and now he
33314. won't have those splendid provinces. Yet he might have united them to
33315. his empire and in a single reign would have extended Russia from the
33316. Gulf of Bothnia to the mouths of the Danube. Catherine the Great could
33317. not have done more," said Napoleon, growing more and more excited as he
33318. paced up and down the room, repeating to Balashev almost the very words
33319. he had used to Alexander himself at Tilsit. "All that, he would have
33320. owed to my friendship. Oh, what a splendid reign!" he repeated several
33321. times, then paused, drew from his pocket a gold snuffbox, lifted it to
33322. his nose, and greedily sniffed at it.
33323. 
33324. "What a splendid reign the Emperor Alexander's might have been!"
33325. 
33326. He looked compassionately at Balashev, and as soon as the latter tried
33327. to make some rejoinder hastily interrupted him.
33328. 
33329. "What could he wish or look for that he would not have obtained
33330. through my friendship?" demanded Napoleon, shrugging his shoulders
33331. in perplexity. "But no, he has preferred to surround himself with
33332. my enemies, and with whom? With Steins, Armfeldts, Bennigsens, and
33333. Wintzingerodes! Stein, a traitor expelled from his own country;
33334. Armfeldt, a rake and an intriguer; Wintzingerode, a fugitive French
33335. subject; Bennigsen, rather more of a soldier than the others, but all
33336. the same an incompetent who was unable to do anything in 1807 and who
33337. should awaken terrible memories in the Emperor Alexander's mind....
33338. Granted that were they competent they might be made use of," continued
33339. Napoleon--hardly able to keep pace in words with the rush of thoughts
33340. that incessantly sprang up, proving how right and strong he was (in his
33341. perception the two were one and the same)--"but they are not even that!
33342. They are neither fit for war nor peace! Barclay is said to be the
33343. most capable of them all, but I cannot say so, judging by his first
33344. movements. And what are they doing, all these courtiers? Pfuel proposes,
33345. Armfeldt disputes, Bennigsen considers, and Barclay, called on to act,
33346. does not know what to decide on, and time passes bringing no result.
33347. Bagration alone is a military man. He's stupid, but he has experience,
33348. a quick eye, and resolution.... And what role is your young monarch
33349. playing in that monstrous crowd? They compromise him and throw on him
33350. the responsibility for all that happens. A sovereign should not be with
33351. the army unless he is a general!" said Napoleon, evidently uttering
33352. these words as a direct challenge to the Emperor. He knew how Alexander
33353. desired to be a military commander.
33354. 
33355. "The campaign began only a week ago, and you haven't even been able to
33356. defend Vilna. You are cut in two and have been driven out of the Polish
33357. provinces. Your army is grumbling."
33358. 
33359. "On the contrary, Your Majesty," said Balashev, hardly able to remember
33360. what had been said to him and following these verbal fireworks with
33361. difficulty, "the troops are burning with eagerness..."
33362. 
33363. "I know everything!" Napoleon interrupted him. "I know everything. I
33364. know the number of your battalions as exactly as I know my own. You have
33365. not two hundred thousand men, and I have three times that number. I give
33366. you my word of honor," said Napoleon, forgetting that his word of honor
33367. could carry no weight--"I give you my word of honor that I have five
33368. hundred and thirty thousand men this side of the Vistula. The Turks will
33369. be of no use to you; they are worth nothing and have shown it by making
33370. peace with you. As for the Swedes--it is their fate to be governed
33371. by mad kings. Their king was insane and they changed him for
33372. another--Bernadotte, who promptly went mad--for no Swede would ally
33373. himself with Russia unless he were mad."
33374. 
33375. Napoleon grinned maliciously and again raised his snuffbox to his nose.
33376. 
33377. Balashev knew how to reply to each of Napoleon's remarks, and would
33378. have done so; he continually made the gesture of a man wishing to say
33379. something, but Napoleon always interrupted him. To the alleged insanity
33380. of the Swedes, Balashev wished to reply that when Russia is on her side
33381. Sweden is practically an island: but Napoleon gave an angry exclamation
33382. to drown his voice. Napoleon was in that state of irritability in which
33383. a man has to talk, talk, and talk, merely to convince himself that he is
33384. in the right. Balashev began to feel uncomfortable: as envoy he feared
33385. to demean his dignity and felt the necessity of replying; but, as a man,
33386. he shrank before the transport of groundless wrath that had evidently
33387. seized Napoleon. He knew that none of the words now uttered by Napoleon
33388. had any significance, and that Napoleon himself would be ashamed of them
33389. when he came to his senses. Balashev stood with downcast eyes, looking
33390. at the movements of Napoleon's stout legs and trying to avoid meeting
33391. his eyes.
33392. 
33393. "But what do I care about your allies?" said Napoleon. "I have
33394. allies--the Poles. There are eighty thousand of them and they fight like
33395. lions. And there will be two hundred thousand of them."
33396. 
33397. And probably still more perturbed by the fact that he had uttered this
33398. obvious falsehood, and that Balashev still stood silently before him in
33399. the same attitude of submission to fate, Napoleon abruptly turned
33400. round, drew close to Balashev's face, and, gesticulating rapidly and
33401. energetically with his white hands, almost shouted:
33402. 
33403. "Know that if you stir up Prussia against me, I'll wipe it off the map
33404. of Europe!" he declared, his face pale and distorted by anger, and he
33405. struck one of his small hands energetically with the other. "Yes, I
33406. will throw you back beyond the Dvina and beyond the Dnieper, and will
33407. re-erect against you that barrier which it was criminal and blind of
33408. Europe to allow to be destroyed. Yes, that is what will happen to you.
33409. That is what you have gained by alienating me!" And he walked silently
33410. several times up and down the room, his fat shoulders twitching.
33411. 
33412. He put his snuffbox into his waistcoat pocket, took it out again, lifted
33413. it several times to his nose, and stopped in front of Balashev. He
33414. paused, looked ironically straight into Balashev's eyes, and said in a
33415. quiet voice:
33416. 
33417. "And yet what a splendid reign your master might have had!"
33418. 
33419. Balashev, feeling it incumbent on him to reply, said that from the
33420. Russian side things did not appear in so gloomy a light. Napoleon was
33421. silent, still looking derisively at him and evidently not listening to
33422. him. Balashev said that in Russia the best results were expected from
33423. the war. Napoleon nodded condescendingly, as if to say, "I know it's
33424. your duty to say that, but you don't believe it yourself. I have
33425. convinced you."
33426. 
33427. When Balashev had ended, Napoleon again took out his snuffbox, sniffed
33428. at it, and stamped his foot twice on the floor as a signal. The door
33429. opened, a gentleman-in-waiting, bending respectfully, handed the Emperor
33430. his hat and gloves; another brought him a pocket handkerchief. Napoleon,
33431. without giving them a glance, turned to Balashev:
33432. 
33433. "Assure the Emperor Alexander from me," said he, taking his hat, "that
33434. I am as devoted to him as before: I know him thoroughly and very highly
33435. esteem his lofty qualities. I will detain you no longer, General; you
33436. shall receive my letter to the Emperor."
33437. 
33438. And Napoleon went quickly to the door. Everyone in the reception room
33439. rushed forward and descended the staircase.
33440. 
33441. 
33442. 
33443. 
33444. 
33445. CHAPTER VII
33446. 
33447. 
33448. After all that Napoleon had said to him--those bursts of anger and the
33449. last dryly spoken words: "I will detain you no longer, General; you
33450. shall receive my letter," Balashev felt convinced that Napoleon would
33451. not wish to see him, and would even avoid another meeting with him--an
33452. insulted envoy--especially as he had witnessed his unseemly anger. But,
33453. to his surprise, Balashev received, through Duroc, an invitation to dine
33454. with the Emperor that day.
33455. 
33456. Bessieres, Caulaincourt, and Berthier were present at that dinner.
33457. 
33458. Napoleon met Balashev cheerfully and amiably. He not only showed no sign
33459. of constraint or self-reproach on account of his outburst that morning,
33460. but, on the contrary, tried to reassure Balashev. It was evident that
33461. he had long been convinced that it was impossible for him to make a
33462. mistake, and that in his perception whatever he did was right, not
33463. because it harmonized with any idea of right and wrong, but because he
33464. did it.
33465. 
33466. The Emperor was in very good spirits after his ride through Vilna, where
33467. crowds of people had rapturously greeted and followed him. From all
33468. the windows of the streets through which he rode, rugs, flags, and his
33469. monogram were displayed, and the Polish ladies, welcoming him, waved
33470. their handkerchiefs to him.
33471. 
33472. At dinner, having placed Balashev beside him, Napoleon not only treated
33473. him amiably but behaved as if Balashev were one of his own courtiers,
33474. one of those who sympathized with his plans and ought to rejoice at
33475. his success. In the course of conversation he mentioned Moscow and
33476. questioned Balashev about the Russian capital, not merely as an
33477. interested traveler asks about a new city he intends to visit, but as
33478. if convinced that Balashev, as a Russian, must be flattered by his
33479. curiosity.
33480. 
33481. "How many inhabitants are there in Moscow? How many houses? Is it true
33482. that Moscow is called 'Holy Moscow'? How many churches are there in
33483. Moscow?" he asked.
33484. 
33485. And receiving the reply that there were more than two hundred churches,
33486. he remarked:
33487. 
33488. "Why such a quantity of churches?"
33489. 
33490. "The Russians are very devout," replied Balashev.
33491. 
33492. "But a large number of monasteries and churches is always a sign of the
33493. backwardness of a people," said Napoleon, turning to Caulaincourt for
33494. appreciation of this remark.
33495. 
33496. Balashev respectfully ventured to disagree with the French Emperor.
33497. 
33498. "Every country has its own character," said he.
33499. 
33500. "But nowhere in Europe is there anything like that," said Napoleon.
33501. 
33502. "I beg your Majesty's pardon," returned Balashev, "besides Russia there
33503. is Spain, where there are also many churches and monasteries."
33504. 
33505. This reply of Balashev's, which hinted at the recent defeats of the
33506. French in Spain, was much appreciated when he related it at Alexander's
33507. court, but it was not much appreciated at Napoleon's dinner, where it
33508. passed unnoticed.
33509. 
33510. The uninterested and perplexed faces of the marshals showed that they
33511. were puzzled as to what Balashev's tone suggested. "If there is a point
33512. we don't see it, or it is not at all witty," their expressions seemed
33513. to say. So little was his rejoinder appreciated that Napoleon did not
33514. notice it at all and naively asked Balashev through what towns the
33515. direct road from there to Moscow passed. Balashev, who was on the alert
33516. all through the dinner, replied that just as "all roads lead to Rome,"
33517. so all roads lead to Moscow: there were many roads, and "among them the
33518. road through Poltava, which Charles XII chose." Balashev involuntarily
33519. flushed with pleasure at the aptitude of this reply, but hardly had
33520. he uttered the word Poltava before Caulaincourt began speaking of the
33521. badness of the road from Petersburg to Moscow and of his Petersburg
33522. reminiscences.
33523. 
33524. After dinner they went to drink coffee in Napoleon's study, which four
33525. days previously had been that of the Emperor Alexander. Napoleon sat
33526. down, toying with his Sevres coffee cup, and motioned Balashev to a
33527. chair beside him.
33528. 
33529. Napoleon was in that well-known after-dinner mood which, more than
33530. any reasoned cause, makes a man contented with himself and disposed to
33531. consider everyone his friend. It seemed to him that he was surrounded
33532. by men who adored him: and he felt convinced that, after his dinner,
33533. Balashev too was his friend and worshiper. Napoleon turned to him with a
33534. pleasant, though slightly ironic, smile.
33535. 
33536. "They tell me this is the room the Emperor Alexander occupied? Strange,
33537. isn't it, General?" he said, evidently not doubting that this remark
33538. would be agreeable to his hearer since it went to prove his, Napoleon's,
33539. superiority to Alexander.
33540. 
33541. Balashev made no reply and bowed his head in silence.
33542. 
33543. "Yes. Four days ago in this room, Wintzingerode and Stein were
33544. deliberating," continued Napoleon with the same derisive and
33545. self-confident smile. "What I can't understand," he went on, "is that
33546. the Emperor Alexander has surrounded himself with my personal enemies.
33547. That I do not... understand. Has he not thought that I may do the same?"
33548. and he turned inquiringly to Balashev, and evidently this thought turned
33549. him back on to the track of his morning's anger, which was still fresh
33550. in him.
33551. 
33552. "And let him know that I will do so!" said Napoleon, rising and pushing
33553. his cup away with his hand. "I'll drive all his Wurttemberg, Baden, and
33554. Weimar relations out of Germany.... Yes. I'll drive them out. Let him
33555. prepare an asylum for them in Russia!"
33556. 
33557. Balashev bowed his head with an air indicating that he would like to
33558. make his bow and leave, and only listened because he could not help
33559. hearing what was said to him. Napoleon did not notice this expression;
33560. he treated Balashev not as an envoy from his enemy, but as a man
33561. now fully devoted to him and who must rejoice at his former master's
33562. humiliation.
33563. 
33564. "And why has the Emperor Alexander taken command of the armies? What is
33565. the good of that? War is my profession, but his business is to reign
33566. and not to command armies! Why has he taken on himself such a
33567. responsibility?"
33568. 
33569. Again Napoleon brought out his snuffbox, paced several times up and down
33570. the room in silence, and then, suddenly and unexpectedly, went up to
33571. Balashev and with a slight smile, as confidently, quickly, and simply
33572. as if he were doing something not merely important but pleasing to
33573. Balashev, he raised his hand to the forty-year-old Russian general's
33574. face and, taking him by the ear, pulled it gently, smiling with his lips
33575. only.
33576. 
33577. To have one's ear pulled by the Emperor was considered the greatest
33578. honor and mark of favor at the French court.
33579. 
33580. "Well, adorer and courtier of the Emperor Alexander, why don't you say
33581. anything?" said he, as if it was ridiculous, in his presence, to be the
33582. adorer and courtier of anyone but himself, Napoleon. "Are the horses
33583. ready for the general?" he added, with a slight inclination of his head
33584. in reply to Balashev's bow. "Let him have mine, he has a long way to
33585. go!"
33586. 
33587. The letter taken by Balashev was the last Napoleon sent to Alexander.
33588. Every detail of the interview was communicated to the Russian monarch,
33589. and the war began...
33590. 
33591. 
33592. 
33593. 
33594. 
33595. CHAPTER VIII
33596. 
33597. 
33598. After his interview with Pierre in Moscow, Prince Andrew went to
33599. Petersburg, on business as he told his family, but really to meet
33600. Anatole Kuragin whom he felt it necessary to encounter. On reaching
33601. Petersburg he inquired for Kuragin but the latter had already left the
33602. city. Pierre had warned his brother-in-law that Prince Andrew was on
33603. his track. Anatole Kuragin promptly obtained an appointment from
33604. the Minister of War and went to join the army in Moldavia. While in
33605. Petersburg Prince Andrew met Kutuzov, his former commander who was
33606. always well disposed toward him, and Kutuzov suggested that he should
33607. accompany him to the army in Moldavia, to which the old general had
33608. been appointed commander in chief. So Prince Andrew, having received an
33609. appointment on the headquarters staff, left for Turkey.
33610. 
33611. Prince Andrew did not think it proper to write and challenge Kuragin.
33612. He thought that if he challenged him without some fresh cause it might
33613. compromise the young Countess Rostova and so he wanted to meet Kuragin
33614. personally in order to find a fresh pretext for a duel. But he again
33615. failed to meet Kuragin in Turkey, for soon after Prince Andrew arrived,
33616. the latter returned to Russia. In a new country, amid new conditions,
33617. Prince Andrew found life easier to bear. After his betrothed had broken
33618. faith with him--which he felt the more acutely the more he tried to
33619. conceal its effects--the surroundings in which he had been happy became
33620. trying to him, and the freedom and independence he had once prized
33621. so highly were still more so. Not only could he no longer think the
33622. thoughts that had first come to him as he lay gazing at the sky on the
33623. field of Austerlitz and had later enlarged upon with Pierre, and which
33624. had filled his solitude at Bogucharovo and then in Switzerland and Rome,
33625. but he even dreaded to recall them and the bright and boundless horizons
33626. they had revealed. He was now concerned only with the nearest practical
33627. matters unrelated to his past interests, and he seized on these the more
33628. eagerly the more those past interests were closed to him. It was as if
33629. that lofty, infinite canopy of heaven that had once towered above him
33630. had suddenly turned into a low, solid vault that weighed him down, in
33631. which all was clear, but nothing eternal or mysterious.
33632. 
33633. Of the activities that presented themselves to him, army service was the
33634. simplest and most familiar. As a general on duty on Kutuzov's staff,
33635. he applied himself to business with zeal and perseverance and surprised
33636. Kutuzov by his willingness and accuracy in work. Not having found
33637. Kuragin in Turkey, Prince Andrew did not think it necessary to rush back
33638. to Russia after him, but all the same he knew that however long it might
33639. be before he met Kuragin, despite his contempt for him and despite all
33640. the proofs he deduced to convince himself that it was not worth stooping
33641. to a conflict with him--he knew that when he did meet him he would not
33642. be able to resist calling him out, any more than a ravenous man can help
33643. snatching at food. And the consciousness that the insult was not yet
33644. avenged, that his rancor was still unspent, weighed on his heart and
33645. poisoned the artificial tranquillity which he managed to obtain in
33646. Turkey by means of restless, plodding, and rather vainglorious and
33647. ambitious activity.
33648. 
33649. In the year 1812, when news of the war with Napoleon reached
33650. Bucharest--where Kutuzov had been living for two months, passing his
33651. days and nights with a Wallachian woman--Prince Andrew asked Kutuzov
33652. to transfer him to the Western Army. Kutuzov, who was already weary of
33653. Bolkonski's activity which seemed to reproach his own idleness, very
33654. readily let him go and gave him a mission to Barclay de Tolly.
33655. 
33656. Before joining the Western Army which was then, in May, encamped at
33657. Drissa, Prince Andrew visited Bald Hills which was directly on his way,
33658. being only two miles off the Smolensk highroad. During the last three
33659. years there had been so many changes in his life, he had thought, felt,
33660. and seen so much (having traveled both in the east and the west), that
33661. on reaching Bald Hills it struck him as strange and unexpected to find
33662. the way of life there unchanged and still the same in every detail.
33663. He entered through the gates with their stone pillars and drove up
33664. the avenue leading to the house as if he were entering an enchanted,
33665. sleeping castle. The same old stateliness, the same cleanliness, the
33666. same stillness reigned there, and inside there was the same furniture,
33667. the same walls, sounds, and smell, and the same timid faces, only
33668. somewhat older. Princess Mary was still the same timid, plain maiden
33669. getting on in years, uselessly and joylessly passing the best years of
33670. her life in fear and constant suffering. Mademoiselle Bourienne was
33671. the same coquettish, self-satisfied girl, enjoying every moment of her
33672. existence and full of joyous hopes for the future. She had merely become
33673. more self-confident, Prince Andrew thought. Dessalles, the tutor he had
33674. brought from Switzerland, was wearing a coat of Russian cut and
33675. talking broken Russian to the servants, but was still the same narrowly
33676. intelligent, conscientious, and pedantic preceptor. The old prince
33677. had changed in appearance only by the loss of a tooth, which left a
33678. noticeable gap on one side of his mouth; in character he was the same as
33679. ever, only showing still more irritability and skepticism as to what was
33680. happening in the world. Little Nicholas alone had changed. He had grown,
33681. become rosier, had curly dark hair, and, when merry and laughing, quite
33682. unconsciously lifted the upper lip of his pretty little mouth just
33683. as the little princess used to do. He alone did not obey the law of
33684. immutability in the enchanted, sleeping castle. But though externally
33685. all remained as of old, the inner relations of all these people had
33686. changed since Prince Andrew had seen them last. The household was
33687. divided into two alien and hostile camps, who changed their habits for
33688. his sake and only met because he was there. To the one camp belonged
33689. the old prince, Mademoiselle Bourienne, and the architect; to the other
33690. Princess Mary, Dessalles, little Nicholas, and all the old nurses and
33691. maids.
33692. 
33693. During his stay at Bald Hills all the family dined together, but they
33694. were ill at ease and Prince Andrew felt that he was a visitor for whose
33695. sake an exception was being made and that his presence made them all
33696. feel awkward. Involuntarily feeling this at dinner on the first day, he
33697. was taciturn, and the old prince noticing this also became morosely dumb
33698. and retired to his apartments directly after dinner. In the evening,
33699. when Prince Andrew went to him and, trying to rouse him, began to
33700. tell him of the young Count Kamensky's campaign, the old prince
33701. began unexpectedly to talk about Princess Mary, blaming her for her
33702. superstitions and her dislike of Mademoiselle Bourienne, who, he said,
33703. was the only person really attached to him.
33704. 
33705. The old prince said that if he was ill it was only because of Princess
33706. Mary: that she purposely worried and irritated him, and that by
33707. indulgence and silly talk she was spoiling little Prince Nicholas. The
33708. old prince knew very well that he tormented his daughter and that her
33709. life was very hard, but he also knew that he could not help tormenting
33710. her and that she deserved it. "Why does Prince Andrew, who sees this,
33711. say nothing to me about his sister? Does he think me a scoundrel, or an
33712. old fool who, without any reason, keeps his own daughter at a distance
33713. and attaches this Frenchwoman to himself? He doesn't understand, so I
33714. must explain it, and he must hear me out," thought the old prince.
33715. And he began explaining why he could not put up with his daughter's
33716. unreasonable character.
33717. 
33718. "If you ask me," said Prince Andrew, without looking up (he was
33719. censuring his father for the first time in his life), "I did not wish to
33720. speak about it, but as you ask me I will give you my frank opinion. If
33721. there is any misunderstanding and discord between you and Mary, I can't
33722. blame her for it at all. I know how she loves and respects you. Since
33723. you ask me," continued Prince Andrew, becoming irritable--as he was
33724. always liable to do of late--"I can only say that if there are any
33725. misunderstandings they are caused by that worthless woman, who is not
33726. fit to be my sister's companion."
33727. 
33728. The old man at first stared fixedly at his son, and an unnatural smile
33729. disclosed the fresh gap between his teeth to which Prince Andrew could
33730. not get accustomed.
33731. 
33732. "What companion, my dear boy? Eh? You've already been talking it over!
33733. Eh?"
33734. 
33735. "Father, I did not want to judge," said Prince Andrew, in a hard and
33736. bitter tone, "but you challenged me, and I have said, and always shall
33737. say, that Mary is not to blame, but those to blame--the one to blame--is
33738. that Frenchwoman."
33739. 
33740. "Ah, he has passed judgment... passed judgement!" said the old man in a
33741. low voice and, as it seemed to Prince Andrew, with some embarrassment,
33742. but then he suddenly jumped up and cried: "Be off, be off! Let not a
33743. trace of you remain here!..."
33744. 
33745. 
33746. Prince Andrew wished to leave at once, but Princess Mary persuaded him
33747. to stay another day. That day he did not see his father, who did not
33748. leave his room and admitted no one but Mademoiselle Bourienne and
33749. Tikhon, but asked several times whether his son had gone. Next day,
33750. before leaving, Prince Andrew went to his son's rooms. The boy,
33751. curly-headed like his mother and glowing with health, sat on his knee,
33752. and Prince Andrew began telling him the story of Bluebeard, but fell
33753. into a reverie without finishing the story. He thought not of this
33754. pretty child, his son whom he held on his knee, but of himself. He
33755. sought in himself either remorse for having angered his father or regret
33756. at leaving home for the first time in his life on bad terms with him,
33757. and was horrified to find neither. What meant still more to him was that
33758. he sought and did not find in himself the former tenderness for his son
33759. which he had hoped to reawaken by caressing the boy and taking him on
33760. his knee.
33761. 
33762. "Well, go on!" said his son.
33763. 
33764. Prince Andrew, without replying, put him down from his knee and went out
33765. of the room.
33766. 
33767. As soon as Prince Andrew had given up his daily occupations, and
33768. especially on returning to the old conditions of life amid which he had
33769. been happy, weariness of life overcame him with its former intensity,
33770. and he hastened to escape from these memories and to find some work as
33771. soon as possible.
33772. 
33773. "So you've decided to go, Andrew?" asked his sister.
33774. 
33775. "Thank God that I can," replied Prince Andrew. "I am very sorry you
33776. can't."
33777. 
33778. "Why do you say that?" replied Princess Mary. "Why do you say that,
33779. when you are going to this terrible war, and he is so old? Mademoiselle
33780. Bourienne says he has been asking about you...."
33781. 
33782. As soon as she began to speak of that, her lips trembled and her tears
33783. began to fall. Prince Andrew turned away and began pacing the room.
33784. 
33785. "Ah, my God! my God! When one thinks who and what--what trash--can cause
33786. people misery!" he said with a malignity that alarmed Princess Mary.
33787. 
33788. She understood that when speaking of "trash" he referred not only to
33789. Mademoiselle Bourienne, the cause of her misery, but also to the man who
33790. had ruined his own happiness.
33791. 
33792. "Andrew! One thing I beg, I entreat of you!" she said, touching his
33793. elbow and looking at him with eyes that shone through her tears. "I
33794. understand you" (she looked down). "Don't imagine that sorrow is the
33795. work of men. Men are His tools." She looked a little above Prince
33796. Andrew's head with the confident, accustomed look with which one looks
33797. at the place where a familiar portrait hangs. "Sorrow is sent by Him,
33798. not by men. Men are His instruments, they are not to blame. If you think
33799. someone has wronged you, forget it and forgive! We have no right to
33800. punish. And then you will know the happiness of forgiving."
33801. 
33802. "If I were a woman I would do so, Mary. That is a woman's virtue. But
33803. a man should not and cannot forgive and forget," he replied, and though
33804. till that moment he had not been thinking of Kuragin, all his unexpended
33805. anger suddenly swelled up in his heart.
33806. 
33807. "If Mary is already persuading me forgive, it means that I ought long
33808. ago to have punished him," he thought. And giving her no further reply,
33809. he began thinking of the glad vindictive moment when he would meet
33810. Kuragin who he knew was now in the army.
33811. 
33812. Princess Mary begged him to stay one day more, saying that she knew how
33813. unhappy her father would be if Andrew left without being reconciled to
33814. him, but Prince Andrew replied that he would probably soon be back again
33815. from the army and would certainly write to his father, but that the
33816. longer he stayed now the more embittered their differences would become.
33817. 
33818. "Good-by, Andrew! Remember that misfortunes come from God, and men are
33819. never to blame," were the last words he heard from his sister when he
33820. took leave of her.
33821. 
33822. "Then it must be so!" thought Prince Andrew as he drove out of the
33823. avenue from the house at Bald Hills. "She, poor innocent creature, is
33824. left to be victimized by an old man who has outlived his wits. The old
33825. man feels he is guilty, but cannot change himself. My boy is growing up
33826. and rejoices in life, in which like everybody else he will deceive or be
33827. deceived. And I am off to the army. Why? I myself don't know. I want
33828. to meet that man whom I despise, so as to give him a chance to kill and
33829. laugh at me!"
33830. 
33831. These conditions of life had been the same before, but then they were
33832. all connected, while now they had all tumbled to pieces. Only senseless
33833. things, lacking coherence, presented themselves one after another to
33834. Prince Andrew's mind.
33835. 
33836. 
33837. 
33838. 
33839. 
33840. CHAPTER IX
33841. 
33842. 
33843. Prince Andrew reached the general headquarters of the army at the end of
33844. June. The first army, with which was the Emperor, occupied the fortified
33845. camp at Drissa; the second army was retreating, trying to effect a
33846. junction with the first one from which it was said to be cut off by
33847. large French forces. Everyone was dissatisfied with the general course
33848. of affairs in the Russian army, but no one anticipated any danger of
33849. invasion of the Russian provinces, and no one thought the war would
33850. extend farther than the western, the Polish, provinces.
33851. 
33852. Prince Andrew found Barclay de Tolly, to whom he had been assigned, on
33853. the bank of the Drissa. As there was not a single town or large
33854. village in the vicinity of the camp, the immense number of generals and
33855. courtiers accompanying the army were living in the best houses of the
33856. villages on both sides of the river, over a radius of six miles. Barclay
33857. de Tolly was quartered nearly three miles from the Emperor. He received
33858. Bolkonski stiffly and coldly and told him in his foreign accent that he
33859. would mention him to the Emperor for a decision as to his employment,
33860. but asked him meanwhile to remain on his staff. Anatole Kuragin, whom
33861. Prince Andrew had hoped to find with the army, was not there. He had
33862. gone to Petersburg, but Prince Andrew was glad to hear this. His mind
33863. was occupied by the interests of the center that was conducting
33864. a gigantic war, and he was glad to be free for a while from the
33865. distraction caused by the thought of Kuragin. During the first four
33866. days, while no duties were required of him, Prince Andrew rode round the
33867. whole fortified camp and, by the aid of his own knowledge and by
33868. talks with experts, tried to form a definite opinion about it. But the
33869. question whether the camp was advantageous or disadvantageous remained
33870. for him undecided. Already from his military experience and what he had
33871. seen in the Austrian campaign, he had come to the conclusion that in
33872. war the most deeply considered plans have no significance and that all
33873. depends on the way unexpected movements of the enemy--that cannot be
33874. foreseen--are met, and on how and by whom the whole matter is handled.
33875. To clear up this last point for himself, Prince Andrew, utilizing his
33876. position and acquaintances, tried to fathom the character of the control
33877. of the army and of the men and parties engaged in it, and he deduced for
33878. himself the following of the state of affairs.
33879. 
33880. While the Emperor had still been at Vilna, the forces had been divided
33881. into three armies. First, the army under Barclay de Tolly, secondly, the
33882. army under Bagration, and thirdly, the one commanded by Tormasov. The
33883. Emperor was with the first army, but not as commander in chief. In the
33884. orders issued it was stated, not that the Emperor would take command,
33885. but only that he would be with the army. The Emperor, moreover, had
33886. with him not a commander in chief's staff but the imperial headquarters
33887. staff. In attendance on him was the head of the imperial staff,
33888. Quartermaster General Prince Volkonski, as well as generals, imperial
33889. aides-de-camp, diplomatic officials, and a large number of foreigners,
33890. but not the army staff. Besides these, there were in attendance on the
33891. Emperor without any definite appointments: Arakcheev, the ex-Minister
33892. of War; Count Bennigsen, the senior general in rank; the Grand Duke
33893. Tsarevich Constantine Pavlovich; Count Rumyantsev, the Chancellor;
33894. Stein, a former Prussian minister; Armfeldt, a Swedish general; Pfuel,
33895. the chief author of the plan of campaign; Paulucci, an adjutant general
33896. and Sardinian emigre; Wolzogen--and many others. Though these men had
33897. no military appointment in the army, their position gave them influence,
33898. and often a corps commander, or even the commander in chief, did not
33899. know in what capacity he was questioned by Bennigsen, the Grand Duke,
33900. Arakcheev, or Prince Volkonski, or was given this or that advice and did
33901. not know whether a certain order received in the form of advice emanated
33902. from the man who gave it or from the Emperor and whether it had to be
33903. executed or not. But this was only the external condition; the essential
33904. significance of the presence of the Emperor and of all these people,
33905. from a courtier's point of view (and in an Emperor's vicinity all became
33906. courtiers), was clear to everyone. It was this: the Emperor did not
33907. assume the title of commander in chief, but disposed of all the armies;
33908. the men around him were his assistants. Arakcheev was a faithful
33909. custodian to enforce order and acted as the sovereign's bodyguard.
33910. Bennigsen was a landlord in the Vilna province who appeared to be doing
33911. the honors of the district, but was in reality a good general, useful
33912. as an adviser and ready at hand to replace Barclay. The Grand Duke
33913. was there because it suited him to be. The ex-Minister Stein was there
33914. because his advice was useful and the Emperor Alexander held him in high
33915. esteem personally. Armfeldt virulently hated Napoleon and was a general
33916. full of self-confidence, a quality that always influenced Alexander.
33917. Paulucci was there because he was bold and decided in speech. The
33918. adjutants general were there because they always accompanied the
33919. Emperor, and lastly and chiefly Pfuel was there because he had drawn up
33920. the plan of campaign against Napoleon and, having induced Alexander to
33921. believe in the efficacy of that plan, was directing the whole business
33922. of the war. With Pfuel was Wolzogen, who expressed Pfuel's thoughts in
33923. a more comprehensible way than Pfuel himself (who was a harsh, bookish
33924. theorist, self-confident to the point of despising everyone else) was
33925. able to do.
33926. 
33927. Besides these Russians and foreigners who propounded new and unexpected
33928. ideas every day--especially the foreigners, who did so with a boldness
33929. characteristic of people employed in a country not their own--there were
33930. many secondary personages accompanying the army because their principals
33931. were there.
33932. 
33933. Among the opinions and voices in this immense, restless, brilliant,
33934. and proud sphere, Prince Andrew noticed the following sharply defined
33935. subdivisions of tendencies and parties:
33936. 
33937. The first party consisted of Pfuel and his adherents--military theorists
33938. who believed in a science of war with immutable laws--laws of oblique
33939. movements, outflankings, and so forth. Pfuel and his adherents demanded
33940. a retirement into the depths of the country in accordance with precise
33941. laws defined by a pseudo-theory of war, and they saw only barbarism,
33942. ignorance, or evil intention in every deviation from that theory. To
33943. this party belonged the foreign nobles, Wolzogen, Wintzingerode, and
33944. others, chiefly Germans.
33945. 
33946. The second party was directly opposed to the first; one extreme, as
33947. always happens, was met by representatives of the other. The members of
33948. this party were those who had demanded an advance from Vilna into Poland
33949. and freedom from all prearranged plans. Besides being advocates of bold
33950. action, this section also represented nationalism, which made them still
33951. more one-sided in the dispute. They were Russians: Bagration, Ermolov
33952. (who was beginning to come to the front), and others. At that time a
33953. famous joke of Ermolov's was being circulated, that as a great favor he
33954. had petitioned the Emperor to make him a German. The men of that party,
33955. remembering Suvorov, said that what one had to do was not to reason,
33956. or stick pins into maps, but to fight, beat the enemy, keep him out of
33957. Russia, and not let the army get discouraged.
33958. 
33959. To the third party--in which the Emperor had most confidence--belonged
33960. the courtiers who tried to arrange compromises between the other two.
33961. The members of this party, chiefly civilians and to whom Arakcheev
33962. belonged, thought and said what men who have no convictions but wish
33963. to seem to have some generally say. They said that undoubtedly war,
33964. particularly against such a genius as Bonaparte (they called him
33965. Bonaparte now), needs most deeply devised plans and profound scientific
33966. knowledge and in that respect Pfuel was a genius, but at the same time
33967. it had to be acknowledged that the theorists are often one sided, and
33968. therefore one should not trust them absolutely, but should also listen
33969. to what Pfuel's opponents and practical men of experience in warfare had
33970. to say, and then choose a middle course. They insisted on the retention
33971. of the camp at Drissa, according to Pfuel's plan, but on changing the
33972. movements of the other armies. Though, by this course, neither one aim
33973. nor the other could be attained, yet it seemed best to the adherents of
33974. this third party.
33975. 
33976. Of a fourth opinion the most conspicuous representative was the
33977. Tsarevich, who could not forget his disillusionment at Austerlitz, where
33978. he had ridden out at the head of the Guards, in his casque and cavalry
33979. uniform as to a review, expecting to crush the French gallantly; but
33980. unexpectedly finding himself in the front line had narrowly escaped amid
33981. the general confusion. The men of this party had both the quality
33982. and the defect of frankness in their opinions. They feared Napoleon,
33983. recognized his strength and their own weakness, and frankly said so.
33984. They said: "Nothing but sorrow, shame, and ruin will come of all this!
33985. We have abandoned Vilna and Vitebsk and shall abandon Drissa. The only
33986. reasonable thing left to do is to conclude peace as soon as possible,
33987. before we are turned out of Petersburg."
33988. 
33989. This view was very general in the upper army circles and found support
33990. also in Petersburg and from the chancellor, Rumyantsev, who, for other
33991. reasons of state, was in favor of peace.
33992. 
33993. The fifth party consisted of those who were adherents of Barclay de
33994. Tolly, not so much as a man but as minister of war and commander in
33995. chief. "Be he what he may" (they always began like that), "he is an
33996. honest, practical man and we have nobody better. Give him real power,
33997. for war cannot be conducted successfully without unity of command, and
33998. he will show what he can do, as he did in Finland. If our army is well
33999. organized and strong and has withdrawn to Drissa without suffering
34000. any defeats, we owe this entirely to Barclay. If Barclay is now to
34001. be superseded by Bennigsen all will be lost, for Bennigsen showed his
34002. incapacity already in 1807."
34003. 
34004. The sixth party, the Bennigsenites, said, on the contrary, that at any
34005. rate there was no one more active and experienced than Bennigsen: "and
34006. twist about as you may, you will have to come to Bennigsen eventually.
34007. Let the others make mistakes now!" said they, arguing that our
34008. retirement to Drissa was a most shameful reverse and an unbroken series
34009. of blunders. "The more mistakes that are made the better. It will at any
34010. rate be understood all the sooner that things cannot go on like this.
34011. What is wanted is not some Barclay or other, but a man like Bennigsen,
34012. who made his mark in 1807, and to whom Napoleon himself did justice--a
34013. man whose authority would be willingly recognized, and Bennigsen is the
34014. only such man."
34015. 
34016. The seventh party consisted of the sort of people who are always to
34017. be found, especially around young sovereigns, and of whom there were
34018. particularly many round Alexander--generals and imperial aides-de-camp
34019. passionately devoted to the Emperor, not merely as a monarch but as a
34020. man, adoring him sincerely and disinterestedly, as Rostov had done
34021. in 1805, and who saw in him not only all the virtues but all human
34022. capabilities as well. These men, though enchanted with the sovereign
34023. for refusing the command of the army, yet blamed him for such excessive
34024. modesty, and only desired and insisted that their adored sovereign
34025. should abandon his diffidence and openly announce that he would place
34026. himself at the head of the army, gather round him a commander in chief's
34027. staff, and, consulting experienced theoreticians and practical men where
34028. necessary, would himself lead the troops, whose spirits would thereby be
34029. raised to the highest pitch.
34030. 
34031. The eighth and largest group, which in its enormous numbers was to the
34032. others as ninety-nine to one, consisted of men who desired neither
34033. peace nor war, neither an advance nor a defensive camp at the Drissa
34034. or anywhere else, neither Barclay nor the Emperor, neither Pfuel nor
34035. Bennigsen, but only the one most essential thing--as much advantage
34036. and pleasure for themselves as possible. In the troubled waters of
34037. conflicting and intersecting intrigues that eddied about the Emperor's
34038. headquarters, it was possible to succeed in many ways unthinkable at
34039. other times. A man who simply wished to retain his lucrative post would
34040. today agree with Pfuel, tomorrow with his opponent, and the day after,
34041. merely to avoid responsibility or to please the Emperor, would declare
34042. that he had no opinion at all on the matter. Another who wished to
34043. gain some advantage would attract the Emperor's attention by loudly
34044. advocating the very thing the Emperor had hinted at the day before,
34045. and would dispute and shout at the council, beating his breast and
34046. challenging those who did not agree with him to duels, thereby proving
34047. that he was prepared to sacrifice himself for the common good. A third,
34048. in the absence of opponents, between two councils would simply solicit
34049. a special gratuity for his faithful services, well knowing that at that
34050. moment people would be too busy to refuse him. A fourth while seemingly
34051. overwhelmed with work would often come accidentally under the Emperor's
34052. eye. A fifth, to achieve his long-cherished aim of dining with the
34053. Emperor, would stubbornly insist on the correctness or falsity of some
34054. newly emerging opinion and for this object would produce arguments more
34055. or less forcible and correct.
34056. 
34057. All the men of this party were fishing for rubles, decorations, and
34058. promotions, and in this pursuit watched only the weathercock of imperial
34059. favor, and directly they noticed it turning in any direction, this whole
34060. drone population of the army began blowing hard that way, so that it
34061. was all the harder for the Emperor to turn it elsewhere. Amid the
34062. uncertainties of the position, with the menace of serious danger giving
34063. a peculiarly threatening character to everything, amid this vortex of
34064. intrigue, egotism, conflict of views and feelings, and the diversity
34065. of race among these people--this eighth and largest party of those
34066. preoccupied with personal interests imparted great confusion and
34067. obscurity to the common task. Whatever question arose, a swarm of these
34068. drones, without having finished their buzzing on a previous theme, flew
34069. over to the new one and by their hum drowned and obscured the voices of
34070. those who were disputing honestly.
34071. 
34072. From among all these parties, just at the time Prince Andrew reached
34073. the army, another, a ninth party, was being formed and was beginning
34074. to raise its voice. This was the party of the elders, reasonable men
34075. experienced and capable in state affairs, who, without sharing any of
34076. those conflicting opinions, were able to take a detached view of what
34077. was going on at the staff at headquarters and to consider means of
34078. escape from this muddle, indecision, intricacy, and weakness.
34079. 
34080. The men of this party said and thought that what was wrong resulted
34081. chiefly from the Emperor's presence in the army with his military court
34082. and from the consequent presence there of an indefinite, conditional,
34083. and unsteady fluctuation of relations, which is in place at court but
34084. harmful in an army; that a sovereign should reign but not command the
34085. army, and that the only way out of the position would be for the Emperor
34086. and his court to leave the army; that the mere presence of the Emperor
34087. paralyzed the action of fifty thousand men required to secure his
34088. personal safety, and that the worst commander in chief if independent
34089. would be better than the very best one trammeled by the presence and
34090. authority of the monarch.
34091. 
34092. Just at the time Prince Andrew was living unoccupied at Drissa,
34093. Shishkov, the Secretary of State and one of the chief representatives of
34094. this party, wrote a letter to the Emperor which Arakcheev and Balashev
34095. agreed to sign. In this letter, availing himself of permission given him
34096. by the Emperor to discuss the general course of affairs, he respectfully
34097. suggested--on the plea that it was necessary for the sovereign to arouse
34098. a warlike spirit in the people of the capital--that the Emperor should
34099. leave the army.
34100. 
34101. That arousing of the people by their sovereign and his call to them to
34102. defend their country--the very incitement which was the chief cause of
34103. Russia's triumph in so far as it was produced by the Tsar's personal
34104. presence in Moscow--was suggested to the Emperor, and accepted by him,
34105. as a pretext for quitting the army.
34106. 
34107. 
34108. 
34109. 
34110. 
34111. CHAPTER X
34112. 
34113. 
34114. This letter had not yet been presented to the Emperor when Barclay, one
34115. day at dinner, informed Bolkonski that the sovereign wished to see him
34116. personally, to question him about Turkey, and that Prince Andrew was to
34117. present himself at Bennigsen's quarters at six that evening.
34118. 
34119. News was received at the Emperor's quarters that very day of a fresh
34120. movement by Napoleon which might endanger the army--news subsequently
34121. found to be false. And that morning Colonel Michaud had ridden round the
34122. Drissa fortifications with the Emperor and had pointed out to him that
34123. this fortified camp constructed by Pfuel, and till then considered
34124. a chef-d'oeuvre of tactical science which would ensure Napoleon's
34125. destruction, was an absurdity, threatening the destruction of the
34126. Russian army.
34127. 
34128. Prince Andrew arrived at Bennigsen's quarters--a country gentleman's
34129. house of moderate size, situated on the very banks of the river. Neither
34130. Bennigsen nor the Emperor was there, but Chernyshev, the Emperor's
34131. aide-de-camp, received Bolkonski and informed him that the Emperor,
34132. accompanied by General Bennigsen and Marquis Paulucci, had gone a second
34133. time that day to inspect the fortifications of the Drissa camp, of the
34134. suitability of which serious doubts were beginning to be felt.
34135. 
34136. Chernyshev was sitting at a window in the first room with a French novel
34137. in his hand. This room had probably been a music room; there was still
34138. an organ in it on which some rugs were piled, and in one corner stood
34139. the folding bedstead of Bennigsen's adjutant. This adjutant was also
34140. there and sat dozing on the rolled-up bedding, evidently exhausted by
34141. work or by feasting. Two doors led from the room, one straight on into
34142. what had been the drawing room, and another, on the right, to the study.
34143. Through the first door came the sound of voices conversing in German
34144. and occasionally in French. In that drawing room were gathered, by
34145. the Emperor's wish, not a military council (the Emperor preferred
34146. indefiniteness), but certain persons whose opinions he wished to know in
34147. view of the impending difficulties. It was not a council of war, but,
34148. as it were, a council to elucidate certain questions for the Emperor
34149. personally. To this semicouncil had been invited the Swedish General
34150. Armfeldt, Adjutant General Wolzogen, Wintzingerode (whom Napoleon had
34151. referred to as a renegade French subject), Michaud, Toll, Count Stein
34152. who was not a military man at all, and Pfuel himself, who, as Prince
34153. Andrew had heard, was the mainspring of the whole affair. Prince Andrew
34154. had an opportunity of getting a good look at him, for Pfuel arrived soon
34155. after himself and, in passing through to the drawing room, stopped a
34156. minute to speak to Chernyshev.
34157. 
34158. At first sight, Pfuel, in his ill-made uniform of a Russian general,
34159. which fitted him badly like a fancy costume, seemed familiar to Prince
34160. Andrew, though he saw him now for the first time. There was about
34161. him something of Weyrother, Mack, and Schmidt, and many other German
34162. theorist-generals whom Prince Andrew had seen in 1805, but he was more
34163. typical than any of them. Prince Andrew had never yet seen a German
34164. theorist in whom all the characteristics of those others were united to
34165. such an extent.
34166. 
34167. Pfuel was short and very thin but broad-boned, of coarse, robust build,
34168. broad in the hips, and with prominent shoulder blades. His face was
34169. much wrinkled and his eyes deep set. His hair had evidently been hastily
34170. brushed smooth in front of the temples, but stuck up behind in quaint
