34171. little tufts. He entered the room, looking restlessly and angrily
34172. around, as if afraid of everything in that large apartment. Awkwardly
34173. holding up his sword, he addressed Chernyshev and asked in German where
34174. the Emperor was. One could see that he wished to pass through the rooms
34175. as quickly as possible, finish with the bows and greetings, and sit down
34176. to business in front of a map, where he would feel at home. He nodded
34177. hurriedly in reply to Chernyshev, and smiled ironically on hearing that
34178. the sovereign was inspecting the fortifications that he, Pfuel, had
34179. planned in accord with his theory. He muttered something to himself
34180. abruptly and in a bass voice, as self-assured Germans do--it might
34181. have been "stupid fellow"... or "the whole affair will be ruined," or
34182. "something absurd will come of it."... Prince Andrew did not catch
34183. what he said and would have passed on, but Chernyshev introduced him to
34184. Pfuel, remarking that Prince Andrew was just back from Turkey where the
34185. war had terminated so fortunately. Pfuel barely glanced--not so much at
34186. Prince Andrew as past him--and said, with a laugh: "That must have been
34187. a fine tactical war"; and, laughing contemptuously, went on into the
34188. room from which the sound of voices was heard.
34189. 
34190. Pfuel, always inclined to be irritably sarcastic, was particularly
34191. disturbed that day, evidently by the fact that they had dared to inspect
34192. and criticize his camp in his absence. From this short interview with
34193. Pfuel, Prince Andrew, thanks to his Austerlitz experiences, was able to
34194. form a clear conception of the man. Pfuel was one of those hopelessly
34195. and immutably self-confident men, self-confident to the point of
34196. martyrdom as only Germans are, because only Germans are self-confident
34197. on the basis of an abstract notion--science, that is, the supposed
34198. knowledge of absolute truth. A Frenchman is self-assured because he
34199. regards himself personally, both in mind and body, as irresistibly
34200. attractive to men and women. An Englishman is self-assured, as being a
34201. citizen of the best-organized state in the world, and therefore as an
34202. Englishman always knows what he should do and knows that all he does as
34203. an Englishman is undoubtedly correct. An Italian is self-assured because
34204. he is excitable and easily forgets himself and other people. A Russian
34205. is self-assured just because he knows nothing and does not want to know
34206. anything, since he does not believe that anything can be known. The
34207. German's self-assurance is worst of all, stronger and more
34208. repulsive than any other, because he imagines that he knows the
34209. truth--science--which he himself has invented but which is for him the
34210. absolute truth.
34211. 
34212. Pfuel was evidently of that sort. He had a science--the theory of
34213. oblique movements deduced by him from the history of Frederick the
34214. Great's wars, and all he came across in the history of more recent
34215. warfare seemed to him absurd and barbarous--monstrous collisions in
34216. which so many blunders were committed by both sides that these wars
34217. could not be called wars, they did not accord with the theory, and
34218. therefore could not serve as material for science.
34219. 
34220. In 1806 Pfuel had been one of those responsible, for the plan of
34221. campaign that ended in Jena and Auerstadt, but he did not see the least
34222. proof of the fallibility of his theory in the disasters of that war. On
34223. the contrary, the deviations made from his theory were, in his opinion,
34224. the sole cause of the whole disaster, and with characteristically
34225. gleeful sarcasm he would remark, "There, I said the whole affair would
34226. go to the devil!" Pfuel was one of those theoreticians who so love
34227. their theory that they lose sight of the theory's object--its practical
34228. application. His love of theory made him hate everything practical, and
34229. he would not listen to it. He was even pleased by failures, for failures
34230. resulting from deviations in practice from the theory only proved to him
34231. the accuracy of his theory.
34232. 
34233. He said a few words to Prince Andrew and Chernyshev about the present
34234. war, with the air of a man who knows beforehand that all will go wrong,
34235. and who is not displeased that it should be so. The unbrushed tufts
34236. of hair sticking up behind and the hastily brushed hair on his temples
34237. expressed this most eloquently.
34238. 
34239. He passed into the next room, and the deep, querulous sounds of his
34240. voice were at once heard from there.
34241. 
34242. 
34243. 
34244. 
34245. 
34246. CHAPTER XI
34247. 
34248. 
34249. Prince Andrew's eyes were still following Pfuel out of the room when
34250. Count Bennigsen entered hurriedly, and nodding to Bolkonski, but not
34251. pausing, went into the study, giving instructions to his adjutant as he
34252. went. The Emperor was following him, and Bennigsen had hastened on
34253. to make some preparations and to be ready to receive the sovereign.
34254. Chernyshev and Prince Andrew went out into the porch, where the Emperor,
34255. who looked fatigued, was dismounting. Marquis Paulucci was talking to
34256. him with particular warmth and the Emperor, with his head bent to the
34257. left, was listening with a dissatisfied air. The Emperor moved forward
34258. evidently wishing to end the conversation, but the flushed and excited
34259. Italian, oblivious of decorum, followed him and continued to speak.
34260. 
34261. "And as for the man who advised forming this camp--the Drissa camp,"
34262. said Paulucci, as the Emperor mounted the steps and noticing Prince
34263. Andrew scanned his unfamiliar face, "as to that person, sire..."
34264. continued Paulucci, desperately, apparently unable to restrain himself,
34265. "the man who advised the Drissa camp--I see no alternative but the
34266. lunatic asylum or the gallows!"
34267. 
34268. Without heeding the end of the Italian's remarks, and as though
34269. not hearing them, the Emperor, recognizing Bolkonski, addressed him
34270. graciously.
34271. 
34272. "I am very glad to see you! Go in there where they are meeting, and wait
34273. for me."
34274. 
34275. The Emperor went into the study. He was followed by Prince Peter
34276. Mikhaylovich Volkonski and Baron Stein, and the door closed behind them.
34277. Prince Andrew, taking advantage of the Emperor's permission, accompanied
34278. Paulucci, whom he had known in Turkey, into the drawing room where the
34279. council was assembled.
34280. 
34281. Prince Peter Mikhaylovich Volkonski occupied the position, as it were,
34282. of chief of the Emperor's staff. He came out of the study into the
34283. drawing room with some maps which he spread on a table, and put
34284. questions on which he wished to hear the opinion of the gentlemen
34285. present. What had happened was that news (which afterwards proved to be
34286. false) had been received during the night of a movement by the French to
34287. outflank the Drissa camp.
34288. 
34289. The first to speak was General Armfeldt who, to meet the difficulty that
34290. presented itself, unexpectedly proposed a perfectly new position
34291. away from the Petersburg and Moscow roads. The reason for this was
34292. inexplicable (unless he wished to show that he, too, could have an
34293. opinion), but he urged that at this point the army should unite and
34294. there await the enemy. It was plain that Armfeldt had thought out that
34295. plan long ago and now expounded it not so much to answer the questions
34296. put--which, in fact, his plan did not answer--as to avail himself of the
34297. opportunity to air it. It was one of the millions of proposals, one as
34298. good as another, that could be made as long as it was quite unknown
34299. what character the war would take. Some disputed his arguments, others
34300. defended them. Young Count Toll objected to the Swedish general's views
34301. more warmly than anyone else, and in the course of the dispute drew from
34302. his side pocket a well-filled notebook, which he asked permission to
34303. read to them. In these voluminous notes Toll suggested another scheme,
34304. totally different from Armfeldt's or Pfuel's plan of campaign. In answer
34305. to Toll, Paulucci suggested an advance and an attack, which, he urged,
34306. could alone extricate us from the present uncertainty and from the trap
34307. (as he called the Drissa camp) in which we were situated.
34308. 
34309. During all these discussions Pfuel and his interpreter, Wolzogen
34310. (his "bridge" in court relations), were silent. Pfuel only snorted
34311. contemptuously and turned away, to show that he would never demean
34312. himself by replying to such nonsense as he was now hearing. So when
34313. Prince Volkonski, who was in the chair, called on him to give his
34314. opinion, he merely said:
34315. 
34316. "Why ask me? General Armfeldt has proposed a splendid position with an
34317. exposed rear, or why not this Italian gentleman's attack--very fine, or
34318. a retreat, also good! Why ask me?" said he. "Why, you yourselves know
34319. everything better than I do."
34320. 
34321. But when Volkonski said, with a frown, that it was in the Emperor's name
34322. that he asked his opinion, Pfuel rose and, suddenly growing animated,
34323. began to speak:
34324. 
34325. "Everything has been spoiled, everything muddled, everybody thought they
34326. knew better than I did, and now you come to me! How mend matters? There
34327. is nothing to mend! The principles laid down by me must be strictly
34328. adhered to," said he, drumming on the table with his bony fingers. "What
34329. is the difficulty? Nonsense, childishness!"
34330. 
34331. He went up to the map and speaking rapidly began proving that no
34332. eventuality could alter the efficiency of the Drissa camp, that
34333. everything had been foreseen, and that if the enemy were really going to
34334. outflank it, the enemy would inevitably be destroyed.
34335. 
34336. Paulucci, who did not know German, began questioning him in French.
34337. Wolzogen came to the assistance of his chief, who spoke French badly,
34338. and began translating for him, hardly able to keep pace with Pfuel, who
34339. was rapidly demonstrating that not only all that had happened, but all
34340. that could happen, had been foreseen in his scheme, and that if there
34341. were now any difficulties the whole fault lay in the fact that his plan
34342. had not been precisely executed. He kept laughing sarcastically, he
34343. demonstrated, and at last contemptuously ceased to demonstrate, like
34344. a mathematician who ceases to prove in various ways the accuracy of
34345. a problem that has already been proved. Wolzogen took his place and
34346. continued to explain his views in French, every now and then turning to
34347. Pfuel and saying, "Is it not so, your excellency?" But Pfuel, like a man
34348. heated in a fight who strikes those on his own side, shouted angrily at
34349. his own supporter, Wolzogen:
34350. 
34351. "Well, of course, what more is there to explain?"
34352. 
34353. Paulucci and Michaud both attacked Wolzogen simultaneously in French.
34354. Armfeldt addressed Pfuel in German. Toll explained to Volkonski in
34355. Russian. Prince Andrew listened and observed in silence.
34356. 
34357. Of all these men Prince Andrew sympathized most with Pfuel, angry,
34358. determined, and absurdly self-confident as he was. Of all those present,
34359. evidently he alone was not seeking anything for himself, nursed no
34360. hatred against anyone, and only desired that the plan, formed on a
34361. theory arrived at by years of toil, should be carried out. He was
34362. ridiculous, and unpleasantly sarcastic, but yet he inspired involuntary
34363. respect by his boundless devotion to an idea. Besides this, the remarks
34364. of all except Pfuel had one common trait that had not been noticeable
34365. at the council of war in 1805: there was now a panic fear of Napoleon's
34366. genius, which, though concealed, was noticeable in every rejoinder.
34367. Everything was assumed to be possible for Napoleon, they expected him
34368. from every side, and invoked his terrible name to shatter each other's
34369. proposals. Pfuel alone seemed to consider Napoleon a barbarian like
34370. everyone else who opposed his theory. But besides this feeling of
34371. respect, Pfuel evoked pity in Prince Andrew. From the tone in which
34372. the courtiers addressed him and the way Paulucci had allowed himself to
34373. speak of him to the Emperor, but above all from a certain desperation
34374. in Pfuel's own expressions, it was clear that the others knew, and Pfuel
34375. himself felt, that his fall was at hand. And despite his self-confidence
34376. and grumpy German sarcasm he was pitiable, with his hair smoothly
34377. brushed on the temples and sticking up in tufts behind. Though he
34378. concealed the fact under a show of irritation and contempt, he was
34379. evidently in despair that the sole remaining chance of verifying his
34380. theory by a huge experiment and proving its soundness to the whole world
34381. was slipping away from him.
34382. 
34383. The discussions continued a long time, and the longer they lasted
34384. the more heated became the disputes, culminating in shouts and
34385. personalities, and the less was it possible to arrive at any general
34386. conclusion from all that had been said. Prince Andrew, listening to this
34387. polyglot talk and to these surmises, plans, refutations, and shouts,
34388. felt nothing but amazement at what they were saying. A thought that had
34389. long since and often occurred to him during his military activities--the
34390. idea that there is not and cannot be any science of war, and that
34391. therefore there can be no such thing as a military genius--now appeared
34392. to him an obvious truth. "What theory and science is possible about a
34393. matter the conditions and circumstances of which are unknown and cannot
34394. be defined, especially when the strength of the acting forces cannot be
34395. ascertained? No one was or is able to foresee in what condition our or
34396. the enemy's armies will be in a day's time, and no one can gauge the
34397. force of this or that detachment. Sometimes--when there is not a coward
34398. at the front to shout, 'We are cut off!' and start running, but a brave
34399. and jolly lad who shouts, 'Hurrah!'--a detachment of five thousand
34400. is worth thirty thousand, as at Schon Grabern, while at times fifty
34401. thousand run from eight thousand, as at Austerlitz. What science can
34402. there be in a matter in which, as in all practical matters, nothing
34403. can be defined and everything depends on innumerable conditions, the
34404. significance of which is determined at a particular moment which arrives
34405. no one knows when? Armfeldt says our army is cut in half, and Paulucci
34406. says we have got the French army between two fires; Michaud says that
34407. the worthlessness of the Drissa camp lies in having the river behind it,
34408. and Pfuel says that is what constitutes its strength; Toll proposes
34409. one plan, Armfeldt another, and they are all good and all bad, and the
34410. advantages of any suggestions can be seen only at the moment of trial.
34411. And why do they all speak of a 'military genius'? Is a man a genius who
34412. can order bread to be brought up at the right time and say who is to go
34413. to the right and who to the left? It is only because military men are
34414. invested with pomp and power and crowds of sychophants flatter power,
34415. attributing to it qualities of genius it does not possess. The best
34416. generals I have known were, on the contrary, stupid or absent-minded
34417. men. Bagration was the best, Napoleon himself admitted that. And of
34418. Bonaparte himself! I remember his limited, self-satisfied face on the
34419. field of Austerlitz. Not only does a good army commander not need any
34420. special qualities, on the contrary he needs the absence of the highest
34421. and best human attributes--love, poetry, tenderness, and philosophic
34422. inquiring doubt. He should be limited, firmly convinced that what he
34423. is doing is very important (otherwise he will not have sufficient
34424. patience), and only then will he be a brave leader. God forbid that he
34425. should be humane, should love, or pity, or think of what is just
34426. and unjust. It is understandable that a theory of their 'genius' was
34427. invented for them long ago because they have power! The success of a
34428. military action depends not on them, but on the man in the ranks who
34429. shouts, 'We are lost!' or who shouts, 'Hurrah!' And only in the ranks
34430. can one serve with assurance of being useful."
34431. 
34432. So thought Prince Andrew as he listened to the talking, and he roused
34433. himself only when Paulucci called him and everyone was leaving.
34434. 
34435. At the review next day the Emperor asked Prince Andrew where he would
34436. like to serve, and Prince Andrew lost his standing in court circles
34437. forever by not asking to remain attached to the sovereign's person, but
34438. for permission to serve in the army.
34439. 
34440. 
34441. 
34442. 
34443. 
34444. CHAPTER XII
34445. 
34446. 
34447. Before the beginning of the campaign, Rostov had received a letter from
34448. his parents in which they told him briefly of Natasha's illness and the
34449. breaking off of her engagement to Prince Andrew (which they explained by
34450. Natasha's having rejected him) and again asked Nicholas to retire from
34451. the army and return home. On receiving this letter, Nicholas did not
34452. even make any attempt to get leave of absence or to retire from the
34453. army, but wrote to his parents that he was sorry Natasha was ill and her
34454. engagement broken off, and that he would do all he could to meet their
34455. wishes. To Sonya he wrote separately.
34456. 
34457. "Adored friend of my soul!" he wrote. "Nothing but honor could keep
34458. me from returning to the country. But now, at the commencement of the
34459. campaign, I should feel dishonored, not only in my comrades' eyes but
34460. in my own, if I preferred my own happiness to my love and duty to the
34461. Fatherland. But this shall be our last separation. Believe me, directly
34462. the war is over, if I am still alive and still loved by you, I will
34463. throw up everything and fly to you, to press you forever to my ardent
34464. breast."
34465. 
34466. It was, in fact, only the commencement of the campaign that prevented
34467. Rostov from returning home as he had promised and marrying Sonya. The
34468. autumn in Otradnoe with the hunting, and the winter with the Christmas
34469. holidays and Sonya's love, had opened out to him a vista of tranquil
34470. rural joys and peace such as he had never known before, and which now
34471. allured him. "A splendid wife, children, a good pack of hounds, a
34472. dozen leashes of smart borzois, agriculture, neighbors, service by
34473. election..." thought he. But now the campaign was beginning, and he had
34474. to remain with his regiment. And since it had to be so, Nicholas Rostov,
34475. as was natural to him, felt contented with the life he led in the
34476. regiment and was able to find pleasure in that life.
34477. 
34478. On his return from his furlough Nicholas, having been joyfully welcomed
34479. by his comrades, was sent to obtain remounts and brought back from the
34480. Ukraine excellent horses which pleased him and earned him commendation
34481. from his commanders. During his absence he had been promoted captain,
34482. and when the regiment was put on war footing with an increase in
34483. numbers, he was again allotted his old squadron.
34484. 
34485. The campaign began, the regiment was moved into Poland on double pay,
34486. new officers arrived, new men and horses, and above all everybody was
34487. infected with the merrily excited mood that goes with the commencement
34488. of a war, and Rostov, conscious of his advantageous position in the
34489. regiment, devoted himself entirely to the pleasures and interests of
34490. military service, though he knew that sooner or later he would have to
34491. relinquish them.
34492. 
34493. The troops retired from Vilna for various complicated reasons of state,
34494. political and strategic. Each step of the retreat was accompanied by
34495. a complicated interplay of interests, arguments, and passions at
34496. headquarters. For the Pavlograd hussars, however, the whole of this
34497. retreat during the finest period of summer and with sufficient supplies
34498. was a very simple and agreeable business.
34499. 
34500. It was only at headquarters that there was depression, uneasiness, and
34501. intriguing; in the body of the army they did not ask themselves where
34502. they were going or why. If they regretted having to retreat, it was only
34503. because they had to leave billets they had grown accustomed to, or some
34504. pretty young Polish lady. If the thought that things looked bad chanced
34505. to enter anyone's head, he tried to be as cheerful as befits a good
34506. soldier and not to think of the general trend of affairs, but only of
34507. the task nearest to hand. First they camped gaily before Vilna, making
34508. acquaintance with the Polish landowners, preparing for reviews and being
34509. reviewed by the Emperor and other high commanders. Then came an order
34510. to retreat to Sventsyani and destroy any provisions they could not carry
34511. away with them. Sventsyani was remembered by the hussars only as the
34512. drunken camp, a name the whole army gave to their encampment there,
34513. and because many complaints were made against the troops, who, taking
34514. advantage of the order to collect provisions, took also horses,
34515. carriages, and carpets from the Polish proprietors. Rostov remembered
34516. Sventsyani, because on the first day of their arrival at that small town
34517. he changed his sergeant major and was unable to manage all the drunken
34518. men of his squadron who, unknown to him, had appropriated five barrels
34519. of old beer. From Sventsyani they retired farther and farther to Drissa,
34520. and thence again beyond Drissa, drawing near to the frontier of Russia
34521. proper.
34522. 
34523. On the thirteenth of July the Pavlograds took part in a serious action
34524. for the first time.
34525. 
34526. On the twelfth of July, on the eve of that action, there was a heavy
34527. storm of rain and hail. In general, the summer of 1812 was remarkable
34528. for its storms.
34529. 
34530. The two Pavlograd squadrons were bivouacking on a field of rye, which
34531. was already in ear but had been completely trodden down by cattle and
34532. horses. The rain was descending in torrents, and Rostov, with a young
34533. officer named Ilyin, his protege, was sitting in a hastily constructed
34534. shelter. An officer of their regiment, with long mustaches extending
34535. onto his cheeks, who after riding to the staff had been overtaken by the
34536. rain, entered Rostov's shelter.
34537. 
34538. "I have come from the staff, Count. Have you heard of Raevski's
34539. exploit?"
34540. 
34541. And the officer gave them details of the Saltanov battle, which he had
34542. heard at the staff.
34543. 
34544. Rostov, smoking his pipe and turning his head about as the water
34545. trickled down his neck, listened inattentively, with an occasional
34546. glance at Ilyin, who was pressing close to him. This officer, a lad
34547. of sixteen who had recently joined the regiment, was now in the same
34548. relation to Nicholas that Nicholas had been to Denisov seven years
34549. before. Ilyin tried to imitate Rostov in everything and adored him as a
34550. girl might have done.
34551. 
34552. Zdrzhinski, the officer with the long mustache, spoke grandiloquently of
34553. the Saltanov dam being "a Russian Thermopylae," and of how a deed worthy
34554. of antiquity had been performed by General Raevski. He recounted how
34555. Raevski had led his two sons onto the dam under terrific fire and had
34556. charged with them beside him. Rostov heard the story and not only said
34557. nothing to encourage Zdrzhinski's enthusiasm but, on the contrary,
34558. looked like a man ashamed of what he was hearing, though with no
34559. intention of contradicting it. Since the campaigns of Austerlitz and
34560. of 1807 Rostov knew by experience that men always lie when describing
34561. military exploits, as he himself had done when recounting them; besides
34562. that, he had experience enough to know that nothing happens in war at
34563. all as we can imagine or relate it. And so he did not like Zdrzhinski's
34564. tale, nor did he like Zdrzhinski himself who, with his mustaches
34565. extending over his cheeks, bent low over the face of his hearer, as was
34566. his habit, and crowded Rostov in the narrow shanty. Rostov looked at him
34567. in silence. "In the first place, there must have been such a confusion
34568. and crowding on the dam that was being attacked that if Raevski did lead
34569. his sons there, it could have had no effect except perhaps on some dozen
34570. men nearest to him," thought he, "the rest could not have seen how or
34571. with whom Raevski came onto the dam. And even those who did see it
34572. would not have been much stimulated by it, for what had they to do with
34573. Raevski's tender paternal feelings when their own skins were in danger?
34574. And besides, the fate of the Fatherland did not depend on whether
34575. they took the Saltanov dam or not, as we are told was the case at
34576. Thermopylae. So why should he have made such a sacrifice? And why expose
34577. his own children in the battle? I would not have taken my brother Petya
34578. there, or even Ilyin, who's a stranger to me but a nice lad, but would
34579. have tried to put them somewhere under cover," Nicholas continued
34580. to think, as he listened to Zdrzhinski. But he did not express his
34581. thoughts, for in such matters, too, he had gained experience. He knew
34582. that this tale redounded to the glory of our arms and so one had to
34583. pretend not to doubt it. And he acted accordingly.
34584. 
34585. "I can't stand this any more," said Ilyin, noticing that Rostov did not
34586. relish Zdrzhinski's conversation. "My stockings and shirt... and the
34587. water is running on my seat! I'll go and look for shelter. The rain
34588. seems less heavy."
34589. 
34590. Ilyin went out and Zdrzhinski rode away.
34591. 
34592. Five minutes later Ilyin, splashing through the mud, came running back
34593. to the shanty.
34594. 
34595. "Hurrah! Rostov, come quick! I've found it! About two hundred yards away
34596. there's a tavern where ours have already gathered. We can at least get
34597. dry there, and Mary Hendrikhovna's there."
34598. 
34599. Mary Hendrikhovna was the wife of the regimental doctor, a pretty young
34600. German woman he had married in Poland. The doctor, whether from lack
34601. of means or because he did not like to part from his young wife in
34602. the early days of their marriage, took her about with him wherever the
34603. hussar regiment went and his jealousy had become a standing joke among
34604. the hussar officers.
34605. 
34606. Rostov threw his cloak over his shoulders, shouted to Lavrushka to
34607. follow with the things, and--now slipping in the mud, now splashing
34608. right through it--set off with Ilyin in the lessening rain and the
34609. darkness that was occasionally rent by distant lightning.
34610. 
34611. "Rostov, where are you?"
34612. 
34613. "Here. What lightning!" they called to one another.
34614. 
34615. 
34616. 
34617. 
34618. 
34619. CHAPTER XIII
34620. 
34621. 
34622. In the tavern, before which stood the doctor's covered cart, there were
34623. already some five officers. Mary Hendrikhovna, a plump little blonde
34624. German, in a dressing jacket and nightcap, was sitting on a broad bench
34625. in the front corner. Her husband, the doctor, lay asleep behind her.
34626. Rostov and Ilyin, on entering the room, were welcomed with merry shouts
34627. and laughter.
34628. 
34629. "Dear me, how jolly we are!" said Rostov laughing.
34630. 
34631. "And why do you stand there gaping?"
34632. 
34633. "What swells they are! Why, the water streams from them! Don't make our
34634. drawing room so wet."
34635. 
34636. "Don't mess Mary Hendrikhovna's dress!" cried other voices.
34637. 
34638. Rostov and Ilyin hastened to find a corner where they could change into
34639. dry clothes without offending Mary Hendrikhovna's modesty. They were
34640. going into a tiny recess behind a partition to change, but found it
34641. completely filled by three officers who sat playing cards by the light
34642. of a solitary candle on an empty box, and these officers would on no
34643. account yield their position. Mary Hendrikhovna obliged them with the
34644. loan of a petticoat to be used as a curtain, and behind that screen
34645. Rostov and Ilyin, helped by Lavrushka who had brought their kits,
34646. changed their wet things for dry ones.
34647. 
34648. A fire was made up in the dilapidated brick stove. A board was found,
34649. fixed on two saddles and covered with a horsecloth, a small samovar was
34650. produced and a cellaret and half a bottle of rum, and having asked Mary
34651. Hendrikhovna to preside, they all crowded round her. One offered her a
34652. clean handkerchief to wipe her charming hands, another spread a jacket
34653. under her little feet to keep them from the damp, another hung his coat
34654. over the window to keep out the draft, and yet another waved the flies
34655. off her husband's face, lest he should wake up.
34656. 
34657. "Leave him alone," said Mary Hendrikhovna, smiling timidly and happily.
34658. "He is sleeping well as it is, after a sleepless night."
34659. 
34660. "Oh, no, Mary Hendrikhovna," replied the officer, "one must look after
34661. the doctor. Perhaps he'll take pity on me someday, when it comes to
34662. cutting off a leg or an arm for me."
34663. 
34664. There were only three tumblers, the water was so muddy that one could
34665. not make out whether the tea was strong or weak, and the samovar held
34666. only six tumblers of water, but this made it all the pleasanter to
34667. take turns in order of seniority to receive one's tumbler from Mary
34668. Hendrikhovna's plump little hands with their short and not overclean
34669. nails. All the officers appeared to be, and really were, in love with
34670. her that evening. Even those playing cards behind the partition soon
34671. left their game and came over to the samovar, yielding to the general
34672. mood of courting Mary Hendrikhovna. She, seeing herself surrounded by
34673. such brilliant and polite young men, beamed with satisfaction, try as
34674. she might to hide it, and perturbed as she evidently was each time her
34675. husband moved in his sleep behind her.
34676. 
34677. There was only one spoon, sugar was more plentiful than anything
34678. else, but it took too long to dissolve, so it was decided that Mary
34679. Hendrikhovna should stir the sugar for everyone in turn. Rostov received
34680. his tumbler, and adding some rum to it asked Mary Hendrikhovna to stir
34681. it.
34682. 
34683. "But you take it without sugar?" she said, smiling all the time, as if
34684. everything she said and everything the others said was very amusing and
34685. had a double meaning.
34686. 
34687. "It is not the sugar I want, but only that your little hand should stir
34688. my tea."
34689. 
34690. Mary Hendrikhovna assented and began looking for the spoon which someone
34691. meanwhile had pounced on.
34692. 
34693. "Use your finger, Mary Hendrikhovna, it will be still nicer," said
34694. Rostov.
34695. 
34696. "Too hot!" she replied, blushing with pleasure.
34697. 
34698. Ilyin put a few drops of rum into the bucket of water and brought it to
34699. Mary Hendrikhovna, asking her to stir it with her finger.
34700. 
34701. "This is my cup," said he. "Only dip your finger in it and I'll drink it
34702. all up."
34703. 
34704. When they had emptied the samovar, Rostov took a pack of cards and
34705. proposed that they should play "Kings" with Mary Hendrikhovna. They drew
34706. lots to settle who should make up her set. At Rostov's suggestion it
34707. was agreed that whoever became "King" should have the right to kiss Mary
34708. Hendrikhovna's hand, and that the "Booby" should go to refill and reheat
34709. the samovar for the doctor when the latter awoke.
34710. 
34711. "Well, but supposing Mary Hendrikhovna is 'King'?" asked Ilyin.
34712. 
34713. "As it is, she is Queen, and her word is law!"
34714. 
34715. They had hardly begun to play before the doctor's disheveled head
34716. suddenly appeared from behind Mary Hendrikhovna. He had been awake for
34717. some time, listening to what was being said, and evidently found nothing
34718. entertaining or amusing in what was going on. His face was sad and
34719. depressed. Without greeting the officers, he scratched himself and asked
34720. to be allowed to pass as they were blocking the way. As soon as he
34721. had left the room all the officers burst into loud laughter and Mary
34722. Hendrikhovna blushed till her eyes filled with tears and thereby became
34723. still more attractive to them. Returning from the yard, the doctor
34724. told his wife (who had ceased to smile so happily, and looked at him in
34725. alarm, awaiting her sentence) that the rain had ceased and they must go
34726. to sleep in their covered cart, or everything in it would be stolen.
34727. 
34728. "But I'll send an orderly.... Two of them!" said Rostov. "What an idea,
34729. doctor!"
34730. 
34731. "I'll stand guard on it myself!" said Ilyin.
34732. 
34733. "No, gentlemen, you have had your sleep, but I have not slept for two
34734. nights," replied the doctor, and he sat down morosely beside his wife,
34735. waiting for the game to end.
34736. 
34737. Seeing his gloomy face as he frowned at his wife, the officers grew
34738. still merrier, and some of them could not refrain from laughter, for
34739. which they hurriedly sought plausible pretexts. When he had gone, taking
34740. his wife with him, and had settled down with her in their covered cart,
34741. the officers lay down in the tavern, covering themselves with their
34742. wet cloaks, but they did not sleep for a long time; now they exchanged
34743. remarks, recalling the doctor's uneasiness and his wife's delight, now
34744. they ran out into the porch and reported what was taking place in the
34745. covered trap. Several times Rostov, covering his head, tried to go
34746. to sleep, but some remark would arouse him and conversation would be
34747. resumed, to the accompaniment of unreasoning, merry, childlike laughter.
34748. 
34749. 
34750. 
34751. 
34752. 
34753. CHAPTER XIV
34754. 
34755. 
34756. It was nearly three o'clock but no one was yet asleep, when the
34757. quartermaster appeared with an order to move on to the little town
34758. of Ostrovna. Still laughing and talking, the officers began hurriedly
34759. getting ready and again boiled some muddy water in the samovar. But
34760. Rostov went off to his squadron without waiting for tea. Day was
34761. breaking, the rain had ceased, and the clouds were dispersing. It felt
34762. damp and cold, especially in clothes that were still moist. As they left
34763. the tavern in the twilight of the dawn, Rostov and Ilyin both glanced
34764. under the wet and glistening leather hood of the doctor's cart, from
34765. under the apron of which his feet were sticking out, and in the middle
34766. of which his wife's nightcap was visible and her sleepy breathing
34767. audible.
34768. 
34769. "She really is a dear little thing," said Rostov to Ilyin, who was
34770. following him.
34771. 
34772. "A charming woman!" said Ilyin, with all the gravity of a boy of
34773. sixteen.
34774. 
34775. Half an hour later the squadron was lined up on the road. The command
34776. was heard to "mount" and the soldiers crossed themselves and mounted.
34777. Rostov riding in front gave the order "Forward!" and the hussars, with
34778. clanking sabers and subdued talk, their horses' hoofs splashing in the
34779. mud, defiled in fours and moved along the broad road planted with birch
34780. trees on each side, following the infantry and a battery that had gone
34781. on in front.
34782. 
34783. Tattered, blue-purple clouds, reddening in the east, were scudding
34784. before the wind. It was growing lighter and lighter. That curly grass
34785. which always grows by country roadsides became clearly visible, still
34786. wet with the night's rain; the drooping branches of the birches, also
34787. wet, swayed in the wind and flung down bright drops of water to one
34788. side. The soldiers' faces were more and more clearly visible. Rostov,
34789. always closely followed by Ilyin, rode along the side of the road
34790. between two rows of birch trees.
34791. 
34792. When campaigning, Rostov allowed himself the indulgence of riding not
34793. a regimental but a Cossack horse. A judge of horses and a sportsman,
34794. he had lately procured himself a large, fine, mettlesome, Donets horse,
34795. dun-colored, with light mane and tail, and when he rode it no one could
34796. outgallop him. To ride this horse was a pleasure to him, and he thought
34797. of the horse, of the morning, of the doctor's wife, but not once of the
34798. impending danger.
34799. 
34800. Formerly, when going into action, Rostov had felt afraid; now he had
34801. not the least feeling of fear. He was fearless, not because he had grown
34802. used to being under fire (one cannot grow used to danger), but because
34803. he had learned how to manage his thoughts when in danger. He had grown
34804. accustomed when going into action to think about anything but what would
34805. seem most likely to interest him--the impending danger. During the
34806. first period of his service, hard as he tried and much as he reproached
34807. himself with cowardice, he had not been able to do this, but with time
34808. it had come of itself. Now he rode beside Ilyin under the birch trees,
34809. occasionally plucking leaves from a branch that met his hand, sometimes
34810. touching his horse's side with his foot, or, without turning round,
34811. handing a pipe he had finished to an hussar riding behind him, with as
34812. calm and careless an air as though he were merely out for a ride. He
34813. glanced with pity at the excited face of Ilyin, who talked much and in
34814. great agitation. He knew from experience the tormenting expectation of
34815. terror and death the cornet was suffering and knew that only time could
34816. help him.
34817. 
34818. As soon as the sun appeared in a clear strip of sky beneath the clouds,
34819. the wind fell, as if it dared not spoil the beauty of the summer morning
34820. after the storm; drops still continued to fall, but vertically now, and
34821. all was still. The whole sun appeared on the horizon and disappeared
34822. behind a long narrow cloud that hung above it. A few minutes later it
34823. reappeared brighter still from behind the top of the cloud, tearing its
34824. edge. Everything grew bright and glittered. And with that light, and as
34825. if in reply to it, came the sound of guns ahead of them.
34826. 
34827. Before Rostov had had time to consider and determine the distance of
34828. that firing, Count Ostermann-Tolstoy's adjutant came galloping from
34829. Vitebsk with orders to advance at a trot along the road.
34830. 
34831. The squadron overtook and passed the infantry and the battery--which
34832. had also quickened their pace--rode down a hill, and passing through an
34833. empty and deserted village again ascended. The horses began to lather
34834. and the men to flush.
34835. 
34836. "Halt! Dress your ranks!" the order of the regimental commander was
34837. heard ahead. "Forward by the left. Walk, march!" came the order from in
34838. front.
34839. 
34840. And the hussars, passing along the line of troops on the left flank of
34841. our position, halted behind our Uhlans who were in the front line. To
34842. the right stood our infantry in a dense column: they were the reserve.
34843. Higher up the hill, on the very horizon, our guns were visible through
34844. the wonderfully clear air, brightly illuminated by slanting morning
34845. sunbeams. In front, beyond a hollow dale, could be seen the enemy's
34846. columns and guns. Our advanced line, already in action, could be heard
34847. briskly exchanging shots with the enemy in the dale.
34848. 
34849. At these sounds, long unheard, Rostov's spirits rose, as at the strains
34850. of the merriest music. Trap-ta-ta-tap! cracked the shots, now together,
34851. now several quickly one after another. Again all was silent and then
34852. again it sounded as if someone were walking on detonators and exploding
34853. them.
34854. 
34855. The hussars remained in the same place for about an hour. A cannonade
34856. began. Count Ostermann with his suite rode up behind the squadron,
34857. halted, spoke to the commander of the regiment, and rode up the hill to
34858. the guns.
34859. 
34860. After Ostermann had gone, a command rang out to the Uhlans.
34861. 
34862. "Form column! Prepare to charge!"
34863. 
34864. The infantry in front of them parted into platoons to allow the cavalry
34865. to pass. The Uhlans started, the streamers on their spears fluttering,
34866. and trotted downhill toward the French cavalry which was seen below to
34867. the left.
34868. 
34869. As soon as the Uhlans descended the hill, the hussars were ordered up
34870. the hill to support the battery. As they took the places vacated by the
34871. Uhlans, bullets came from the front, whining and whistling, but fell
34872. spent without taking effect.
34873. 
34874. The sounds, which he had not heard for so long, had an even more
34875. pleasurable and exhilarating effect on Rostov than the previous sounds
34876. of firing. Drawing himself up, he viewed the field of battle opening out
34877. before him from the hill, and with his whole soul followed the movement
34878. of the Uhlans. They swooped down close to the French dragoons, something
34879. confused happened there amid the smoke, and five minutes later our
34880. Uhlans were galloping back, not to the place they had occupied but more
34881. to the left, and among the orange-colored Uhlans on chestnut horses and
34882. behind them, in a large group, blue French dragoons on gray horses could
34883. be seen.
34884. 
34885. 
34886. 
34887. 
34888. 
34889. CHAPTER XV
34890. 
34891. 
34892. Rostov, with his keen sportsman's eye, was one of the first to catch
34893. sight of these blue French dragoons pursuing our Uhlans. Nearer and
34894. nearer in disorderly crowds came the Uhlans and the French dragoons
34895. pursuing them. He could already see how these men, who looked so small
34896. at the foot of the hill, jostled and overtook one another, waving their
34897. arms and their sabers in the air.
34898. 
34899. Rostov gazed at what was happening before him as at a hunt. He felt
34900. instinctively that if the hussars struck at the French dragoons now, the
34901. latter could not withstand them, but if a charge was to be made it must
34902. be done now, at that very moment, or it would be too late. He looked
34903. around. A captain, standing beside him, was gazing like himself with
34904. eyes fixed on the cavalry below them.
34905. 
34906. "Andrew Sevastyanych!" said Rostov. "You know, we could crush them...."
34907. 
34908. "A fine thing too!" replied the captain, "and really..."
34909. 
34910. Rostov, without waiting to hear him out, touched his horse, galloped to
34911. the front of his squadron, and before he had time to finish giving the
34912. word of command, the whole squadron, sharing his feeling, was following
34913. him. Rostov himself did not know how or why he did it. He acted as he
34914. did when hunting, without reflecting or considering. He saw the dragoons
34915. near and that they were galloping in disorder; he knew they could not
34916. withstand an attack--knew there was only that moment and that if he let
34917. it slip it would not return. The bullets were whining and whistling so
34918. stimulatingly around him and his horse was so eager to go that he could
34919. not restrain himself. He touched his horse, gave the word of command,
34920. and immediately, hearing behind him the tramp of the horses of his
34921. deployed squadron, rode at full trot downhill toward the dragoons.
34922. Hardly had they reached the bottom of the hill before their pace
34923. instinctively changed to a gallop, which grew faster and faster as they
34924. drew nearer to our Uhlans and the French dragoons who galloped after
34925. them. The dragoons were now close at hand. On seeing the hussars, the
34926. foremost began to turn, while those behind began to halt. With the same
34927. feeling with which he had galloped across the path of a wolf, Rostov
34928. gave rein to his Donets horse and galloped to intersect the path of the
34929. dragoons' disordered lines. One Uhlan stopped, another who was on foot
34930. flung himself to the ground to avoid being knocked over, and a riderless
34931. horse fell in among the hussars. Nearly all the French dragoons were
34932. galloping back. Rostov, picking out one on a gray horse, dashed after
34933. him. On the way he came upon a bush, his gallant horse cleared it, and
34934. almost before he had righted himself in his saddle he saw that he would
34935. immediately overtake the enemy he had selected. That Frenchman, by his
34936. uniform an officer, was going at a gallop, crouching on his gray horse
34937. and urging it on with his saber. In another moment Rostov's horse dashed
34938. its breast against the hindquarters of the officer's horse, almost
34939. knocking it over, and at the same instant Rostov, without knowing why,
34940. raised his saber and struck the Frenchman with it.
34941. 
34942. The instant he had done this, all Rostov's animation vanished. The
34943. officer fell, not so much from the blow--which had but slightly cut his
34944. arm above the elbow--as from the shock to his horse and from fright.
34945. Rostov reined in his horse, and his eyes sought his foe to see whom he
34946. had vanquished. The French dragoon officer was hopping with one foot on
34947. the ground, the other being caught in the stirrup. His eyes, screwed
34948. up with fear as if he every moment expected another blow, gazed up at
34949. Rostov with shrinking terror. His pale and mud-stained face--fair and
34950. young, with a dimple in the chin and light-blue eyes--was not an enemy's
34951. face at all suited to a battlefield, but a most ordinary, homelike face.
34952. Before Rostov had decided what to do with him, the officer cried, "I
34953. surrender!" He hurriedly but vainly tried to get his foot out of the
34954. stirrup and did not remove his frightened blue eyes from Rostov's face.
34955. Some hussars who galloped up disengaged his foot and helped him into the
34956. saddle. On all sides, the hussars were busy with the dragoons; one was
34957. wounded, but though his face was bleeding, he would not give up his
34958. horse; another was perched up behind an hussar with his arms round him;
34959. a third was being helped by an hussar to mount his horse. In front, the
34960. French infantry were firing as they ran. The hussars galloped hastily
34961. back with their prisoners. Rostov galloped back with the rest, aware of
34962. an unpleasant feeling of depression in his heart. Something vague and
34963. confused, which he could not at all account for, had come over him with
34964. the capture of that officer and the blow he had dealt him.
34965. 
34966. Count Ostermann-Tolstoy met the returning hussars, sent for Rostov,
34967. thanked him, and said he would report his gallant deed to the Emperor
34968. and would recommend him for a St. George's Cross. When sent for by Count
34969. Ostermann, Rostov, remembering that he had charged without orders,
34970. felt sure his commander was sending for him to punish him for breach of
34971. discipline. Ostermann's flattering words and promise of a reward should
34972. therefore have struck him all the more pleasantly, but he still felt
34973. that same vaguely disagreeable feeling of moral nausea. "But what
34974. on earth is worrying me?" he asked himself as he rode back from the
34975. general. "Ilyin? No, he's safe. Have I disgraced myself in any way? No,
34976. that's not it." Something else, resembling remorse, tormented him. "Yes,
34977. oh yes, that French officer with the dimple. And I remember how my arm
34978. paused when I raised it."
34979. 
34980. Rostov saw the prisoners being led away and galloped after them to have
34981. a look at his Frenchman with the dimple on his chin. He was sitting in
34982. his foreign uniform on an hussar packhorse and looked anxiously about
34983. him; The sword cut on his arm could scarcely be called a wound. He
34984. glanced at Rostov with a feigned smile and waved his hand in greeting.
34985. Rostov still had the same indefinite feeling, as of shame.
34986. 
34987. All that day and the next his friends and comrades noticed that Rostov,
34988. without being dull or angry, was silent, thoughtful, and preoccupied.
34989. He drank reluctantly, tried to remain alone, and kept turning something
34990. over in his mind.
34991. 
34992. Rostov was always thinking about that brilliant exploit of his, which to
34993. his amazement had gained him the St. George's Cross and even given him
34994. a reputation for bravery, and there was something he could not at all
34995. understand. "So others are even more afraid than I am!" he thought. "So
34996. that's all there is in what is called heroism! And did I do it for my
34997. country's sake? And how was he to blame, with his dimple and blue eyes?
34998. And how frightened he was! He thought that I should kill him. Why should
34999. I kill him? My hand trembled. And they have given me a St. George's
35000. Cross.... I can't make it out at all."
35001. 
35002. But while Nicholas was considering these questions and still could reach
35003. no clear solution of what puzzled him so, the wheel of fortune in the
35004. service, as often happens, turned in his favor. After the affair at
35005. Ostrovna he was brought into notice, received command of an hussar
35006. battalion, and when a brave officer was needed he was chosen.
35007. 
35008. 
35009. 
35010. 
35011. 
35012. CHAPTER XVI
35013. 
35014. 
35015. On receiving news of Natasha's illness, the countess, though not quite
35016. well yet and still weak, went to Moscow with Petya and the rest of the
35017. household, and the whole family moved from Marya Dmitrievna's house to
35018. their own and settled down in town.
35019. 
35020. Natasha's illness was so serious that, fortunately for her and for
35021. her parents, the consideration of all that had caused the illness,
35022. her conduct and the breaking off of her engagement, receded into the
35023. background. She was so ill that it was impossible for them to consider
35024. in how far she was to blame for what had happened. She could not eat
35025. or sleep, grew visibly thinner, coughed, and, as the doctors made them
35026. feel, was in danger. They could not think of anything but how to help
35027. her. Doctors came to see her singly and in consultation, talked much in
35028. French, German, and Latin, blamed one another, and prescribed a great
35029. variety of medicines for all the diseases known to them, but the simple
35030. idea never occurred to any of them that they could not know the disease
35031. Natasha was suffering from, as no disease suffered by a live man can be
35032. known, for every living person has his own peculiarities and always
35033. has his own peculiar, personal, novel, complicated disease, unknown to
35034. medicine--not a disease of the lungs, liver, skin, heart, nerves, and
35035. so on mentioned in medical books, but a disease consisting of one of the
35036. innumerable combinations of the maladies of those organs. This simple
35037. thought could not occur to the doctors (as it cannot occur to a wizard
35038. that he is unable to work his charms) because the business of their
35039. lives was to cure, and they received money for it and had spent the best
35040. years of their lives on that business. But, above all, that thought
35041. was kept out of their minds by the fact that they saw they were
35042. really useful, as in fact they were to the whole Rostov family. Their
35043. usefulness did not depend on making the patient swallow substances for
35044. the most part harmful (the harm was scarcely perceptible, as they
35045. were given in small doses), but they were useful, necessary, and
35046. indispensable because they satisfied a mental need of the invalid and
35047. of those who loved her--and that is why there are, and always will be,
35048. pseudo-healers, wise women, homeopaths, and allopaths. They satisfied
35049. that eternal human need for hope of relief, for sympathy, and that
35050. something should be done, which is felt by those who are suffering. They
35051. satisfied the need seen in its most elementary form in a child, when it
35052. wants to have a place rubbed that has been hurt. A child knocks itself
35053. and runs at once to the arms of its mother or nurse to have the aching
35054. spot rubbed or kissed, and it feels better when this is done. The child
35055. cannot believe that the strongest and wisest of its people have no
35056. remedy for its pain, and the hope of relief and the expression of its
35057. mother's sympathy while she rubs the bump comforts it. The doctors were
35058. of use to Natasha because they kissed and rubbed her bump, assuring her
35059. that it would soon pass if only the coachman went to the chemist's in
35060. the Arbat and got a powder and some pills in a pretty box for a ruble
35061. and seventy kopeks, and if she took those powders in boiled water at
35062. intervals of precisely two hours, neither more nor less.
35063. 
35064. What would Sonya and the count and countess have done, how would they
35065. have looked, if nothing had been done, if there had not been those pills
35066. to give by the clock, the warm drinks, the chicken cutlets, and all the
35067. other details of life ordered by the doctors, the carrying out of which
35068. supplied an occupation and consolation to the family circle? How would
35069. the count have borne his dearly loved daughter's illness had he not
35070. known that it was costing him a thousand rubles, and that he would not
35071. grudge thousands more to benefit her, or had he not known that if her
35072. illness continued he would not grudge yet other thousands and would take
35073. her abroad for consultations there, and had he not been able to explain
35074. the details of how Metivier and Feller had not understood the symptoms,
35075. but Frise had, and Mudrov had diagnosed them even better? What would the
35076. countess have done had she not been able sometimes to scold the invalid
35077. for not strictly obeying the doctor's orders?
35078. 
35079. "You'll never get well like that," she would say, forgetting her grief
35080. in her vexation, "if you won't obey the doctor and take your medicine at
35081. the right time! You mustn't trifle with it, you know, or it may turn to
35082. pneumonia," she would go on, deriving much comfort from the utterance of
35083. that foreign word, incomprehensible to others as well as to herself.
35084. 
35085. What would Sonya have done without the glad consciousness that she had
35086. not undressed during the first three nights, in order to be ready to
35087. carry out all the doctor's injunctions with precision, and that she
35088. still kept awake at night so as not to miss the proper time when the
35089. slightly harmful pills in the little gilt box had to be administered?
35090. Even to Natasha herself it was pleasant to see that so many sacrifices
35091. were being made for her sake, and to know that she had to take medicine
35092. at certain hours, though she declared that no medicine would cure her
35093. and that it was all nonsense. And it was even pleasant to be able to
35094. show, by disregarding the orders, that she did not believe in medical
35095. treatment and did not value her life.
35096. 
35097. The doctor came every day, felt her pulse, looked at her tongue, and
35098. regardless of her grief-stricken face joked with her. But when he had
35099. gone into another room, to which the countess hurriedly followed him, he
35100. assumed a grave air and thoughtfully shaking his head said that though
35101. there was danger, he had hopes of the effect of this last medicine and
35102. one must wait and see, that the malady was chiefly mental, but... And
35103. the countess, trying to conceal the action from herself and from him,
35104. slipped a gold coin into his hand and always returned to the patient
35105. with a more tranquil mind.
35106. 
35107. The symptoms of Natasha's illness were that she ate little, slept
35108. little, coughed, and was always low-spirited. The doctors said that
35109. she could not get on without medical treatment, so they kept her in the
35110. stifling atmosphere of the town, and the Rostovs did not move to the
35111. country that summer of 1812.
35112. 
35113. In spite of the many pills she swallowed and the drops and powders out
35114. of the little bottles and boxes of which Madame Schoss who was fond of
35115. such things made a large collection, and in spite of being deprived of
35116. the country life to which she was accustomed, youth prevailed. Natasha's
35117. grief began to be overlaid by the impressions of daily life, it ceased
35118. to press so painfully on her heart, it gradually faded into the past,
35119. and she began to recover physically.
35120. 
35121. 
35122. 
35123. 
35124. 
35125. CHAPTER XVII
35126. 
35127. 
35128. Natasha was calmer but no happier. She not merely avoided all external
35129. forms of pleasure--balls, promenades, concerts, and theaters--but she
35130. never laughed without a sound of tears in her laughter. She could not
35131. sing. As soon as she began to laugh, or tried to sing by herself, tears
35132. choked her: tears of remorse, tears at the recollection of those pure
35133. times which could never return, tears of vexation that she should so
35134. uselessly have ruined her young life which might have been so happy.
35135. Laughter and singing in particular seemed to her like a blasphemy,
35136. in face of her sorrow. Without any need of self-restraint, no wish to
35137. coquet ever entered her head. She said and felt at that time that no
35138. man was more to her than Nastasya Ivanovna, the buffoon. Something stood
35139. sentinel within her and forbade her every joy. Besides, she had lost all
35140. the old interests of her carefree girlish life that had been so full
35141. of hope. The previous autumn, the hunting, "Uncle," and the Christmas
35142. holidays spent with Nicholas at Otradnoe were what she recalled oftenest
35143. and most painfully. What would she not have given to bring back even a
35144. single day of that time! But it was gone forever. Her presentiment at
35145. the time had not deceived her--that that state of freedom and readiness
35146. for any enjoyment would not return again. Yet it was necessary to live
35147. on.
35148. 
35149. It comforted her to reflect that she was not better as she had formerly
35150. imagined, but worse, much worse, than anybody else in the world. But
35151. this was not enough. She knew that, and asked herself, "What next?"
35152. But there was nothing to come. There was no joy in life, yet life was
35153. passing. Natasha apparently tried not to be a burden or a hindrance to
35154. anyone, but wanted nothing for herself. She kept away from everyone in
35155. the house and felt at ease only with her brother Petya. She liked to
35156. be with him better than with the others, and when alone with him she
35157. sometimes laughed. She hardly ever left the house and of those who came
35158. to see them was glad to see only one person, Pierre. It would have been
35159. impossible to treat her with more delicacy, greater care, and at the
35160. same time more seriously than did Count Bezukhov. Natasha unconsciously
35161. felt this delicacy and so found great pleasure in his society. But
35162. she was not even grateful to him for it; nothing good on Pierre's part
35163. seemed to her to be an effort, it seemed so natural for him to be kind
35164. to everyone that there was no merit in his kindness. Sometimes Natasha
35165. noticed embarrassment and awkwardness on his part in her presence,
35166. especially when he wanted to do something to please her, or feared that
35167. something they spoke of would awaken memories distressing to her. She
35168. noticed this and attributed it to his general kindness and shyness,
35169. which she imagined must be the same toward everyone as it was to her.
35170. After those involuntary words--that if he were free he would have asked
35171. on his knees for her hand and her love--uttered at a moment when she was
35172. so strongly agitated, Pierre never spoke to Natasha of his feelings;
35173. and it seemed plain to her that those words, which had then so comforted
35174. her, were spoken as all sorts of meaningless words are spoken to comfort
35175. a crying child. It was not because Pierre was a married man, but because
35176. Natasha felt very strongly with him that moral barrier the absence of
35177. which she had experienced with Kuragin that it never entered her head
35178. that the relations between him and herself could lead to love on her
35179. part, still less on his, or even to the kind of tender, self-conscious,
35180. romantic friendship between a man and a woman of which she had known
35181. several instances.
35182. 
35183. Before the end of the fast of St. Peter, Agrafena Ivanovna Belova, a
35184. country neighbor of the Rostovs, came to Moscow to pay her devotions at
35185. the shrines of the Moscow saints. She suggested that Natasha should fast
35186. and prepare for Holy Communion, and Natasha gladly welcomed the idea.
35187. Despite the doctor's orders that she should not go out early in the
35188. morning, Natasha insisted on fasting and preparing for the sacrament,
35189. not as they generally prepared for it in the Rostov family by attending
35190. three services in their own house, but as Agrafena Ivanovna did, by
35191. going to church every day for a week and not once missing Vespers,
35192. Matins, or Mass.
35193. 
35194. The countess was pleased with Natasha's zeal; after the poor results of
35195. the medical treatment, in the depths of her heart she hoped that prayer
35196. might help her daughter more than medicines and, though not without
35197. fear and concealing it from the doctor, she agreed to Natasha's wish and
35198. entrusted her to Belova. Agrafena Ivanovna used to come to wake Natasha
35199. at three in the morning, but generally found her already awake. She was
35200. afraid of being late for Matins. Hastily washing, and meekly putting on
35201. her shabbiest dress and an old mantilla, Natasha, shivering in the fresh
35202. air, went out into the deserted streets lit by the clear light of dawn.
35203. By Agrafena Ivanovna's advice Natasha prepared herself not in their
35204. own parish, but at a church where, according to the devout Agrafena
35205. Ivanovna, the priest was a man of very severe and lofty life. There were
35206. never many people in the church; Natasha always stood beside Belova in
35207. the customary place before an icon of the Blessed Virgin, let into the
35208. screen before the choir on the left side, and a feeling, new to her, of
35209. humility before something great and incomprehensible, seized her when
35210. at that unusual morning hour, gazing at the dark face of the Virgin
35211. illuminated by the candles burning before it and by the morning light
35212. falling from the window, she listened to the words of the service which
35213. she tried to follow with understanding. When she understood them her
35214. personal feeling became interwoven in the prayers with shades of its
35215. own. When she did not understand, it was sweeter still to think that
35216. the wish to understand everything is pride, that it is impossible to
35217. understand all, that it is only necessary to believe and to commit
35218. oneself to God, whom she felt guiding her soul at those moments. She
35219. crossed herself, bowed low, and when she did not understand, in horror
35220. at her own vileness, simply asked God to forgive her everything,
35221. everything, to have mercy upon her. The prayers to which she surrendered
35222. herself most of all were those of repentance. On her way home at an
35223. early hour when she met no one but bricklayers going to work or men
35224. sweeping the street, and everybody within the houses was still asleep,
35225. Natasha experienced a feeling new to her, a sense of the possibility
35226. of correcting her faults, the possibility of a new, clean life, and of
35227. happiness.
35228. 
35229. During the whole week she spent in this way, that feeling grew every
35230. day. And the happiness of taking communion, or "communing" as Agrafena
35231. Ivanovna, joyously playing with the word, called it, seemed to Natasha
35232. so great that she felt she should never live till that blessed Sunday.
35233. 
35234. But the happy day came, and on that memorable Sunday, when, dressed in
35235. white muslin, she returned home after communion, for the first time for
35236. many months she felt calm and not oppressed by the thought of the life
35237. that lay before her.
35238. 
35239. The doctor who came to see her that day ordered her to continue the
35240. powders he had prescribed a fortnight previously.
35241. 
35242. "She must certainly go on taking them morning and evening," said
35243. he, evidently sincerely satisfied with his success. "Only, please be
35244. particular about it.
35245. 
35246. "Be quite easy," he continued playfully, as he adroitly took the gold
35247. coin in his palm. "She will soon be singing and frolicking about. The
35248. last medicine has done her a very great deal of good. She has freshened
35249. up very much."
35250. 
35251. The countess, with a cheerful expression on her face, looked down at her
35252. nails and spat a little for luck as she returned to the drawing room.
35253. 
35254. 
35255. 
35256. 
35257. 
35258. CHAPTER XVIII
35259. 
35260. 
35261. At the beginning of July more and more disquieting reports about the war
35262. began to spread in Moscow; people spoke of an appeal by the Emperor to
35263. the people, and of his coming himself from the army to Moscow. And as
35264. up to the eleventh of July no manifesto or appeal had been received,
35265. exaggerated reports became current about them and about the position of
35266. Russia. It was said that the Emperor was leaving the army because it was
35267. in danger, it was said that Smolensk had surrendered, that Napoleon had
35268. an army of a million and only a miracle could save Russia.
35269. 
35270. On the eleventh of July, which was Saturday, the manifesto was received
35271. but was not yet in print, and Pierre, who was at the Rostovs', promised
35272. to come to dinner next day, Sunday, and bring a copy of the manifesto
35273. and appeal, which he would obtain from Count Rostopchin.
35274. 
35275. That Sunday, the Rostovs went to Mass at the Razumovskis' private chapel
35276. as usual. It was a hot July day. Even at ten o'clock, when the Rostovs
35277. got out of their carriage at the chapel, the sultry air, the shouts of
35278. hawkers, the light and gay summer clothes of the crowd, the dusty leaves
35279. of the trees on the boulevard, the sounds of the band and the white
35280. trousers of a battalion marching to parade, the rattling of wheels on
35281. the cobblestones, and the brilliant, hot sunshine were all full of that
35282. summer languor, that content and discontent with the present, which
35283. is most strongly felt on a bright, hot day in town. All the Moscow
35284. notabilities, all the Rostovs' acquaintances, were at the Razumovskis'
35285. chapel, for, as if expecting something to happen, many wealthy families
35286. who usually left town for their country estates had not gone away that
35287. summer. As Natasha, at her mother's side, passed through the crowd
35288. behind a liveried footman who cleared the way for them, she heard a
35289. young man speaking about her in too loud a whisper.
35290. 
35291. "That's Rostova, the one who..."
35292. 
35293. "She's much thinner, but all the same she's pretty!"
35294. 
35295. She heard, or thought she heard, the names of Kuragin and Bolkonski. But
35296. she was always imagining that. It always seemed to her that everyone
35297. who looked at her was thinking only of what had happened to her. With a
35298. sinking heart, wretched as she always was now when she found herself
35299. in a crowd, Natasha in her lilac silk dress trimmed with black lace
35300. walked--as women can walk--with the more repose and stateliness the
35301. greater the pain and shame in her soul. She knew for certain that she
35302. was pretty, but this no longer gave her satisfaction as it used to.
35303. On the contrary it tormented her more than anything else of late, and
35304. particularly so on this bright, hot summer day in town. "It's Sunday
35305. again--another week past," she thought, recalling that she had been here
35306. the Sunday before, "and always the same life that is no life, and the
35307. same surroundings in which it used to be so easy to live. I'm pretty,
35308. I'm young, and I know that now I am good. I used to be bad, but now I
35309. know I am good," she thought, "but yet my best years are slipping by
35310. and are no good to anyone." She stood by her mother's side and exchanged
35311. nods with acquaintances near her. From habit she scrutinized the ladies'
35312. dresses, condemned the bearing of a lady standing close by who was not
35313. crossing herself properly but in a cramped manner, and again she thought
35314. with vexation that she was herself being judged and was judging others,
35315. and suddenly, at the sound of the service, she felt horrified at her own
35316. vileness, horrified that the former purity of her soul was again lost to
35317. her.
35318. 
35319. A comely, fresh-looking old man was conducting the service with that
35320. mild solemnity which has so elevating and soothing an effect on the
35321. souls of the worshipers. The gates of the sanctuary screen were closed,
35322. the curtain was slowly drawn, and from behind it a soft mysterious voice
35323. pronounced some words. Tears, the cause of which she herself did not
35324. understand, made Natasha's breast heave, and a joyous but oppressive
35325. feeling agitated her.
35326. 
35327. "Teach me what I should do, how to live my life, how I may grow good
35328. forever, forever!" she pleaded.
35329. 
35330. The deacon came out onto the raised space before the altar screen and,
35331. holding his thumb extended, drew his long hair from under his dalmatic
35332. and, making the sign of the cross on his breast, began in a loud and
35333. solemn voice to recite the words of the prayer...
35334. 
35335. "In peace let us pray unto the Lord."
35336. 
35337. "As one community, without distinction of class, without enmity, united
35338. by brotherly love--let us pray!" thought Natasha.
35339. 
35340. "For the peace that is from above, and for the salvation of our souls."
35341. 
35342. "For the world of angels and all the spirits who dwell above us," prayed
35343. Natasha.
35344. 
35345. When they prayed for the warriors, she thought of her brother and
35346. Denisov. When they prayed for all traveling by land and sea, she
35347. remembered Prince Andrew, prayed for him, and asked God to forgive her
35348. all the wrongs she had done him. When they prayed for those who love us,
35349. she prayed for the members of her own family, her father and mother and
35350. Sonya, realizing for the first time how wrongly she had acted toward
35351. them, and feeling all the strength of her love for them. When they
35352. prayed for those who hate us, she tried to think of her enemies and
35353. people who hated her, in order to pray for them. She included among her
35354. enemies the creditors and all who had business dealings with her
35355. father, and always at the thought of enemies and those who hated her she
35356. remembered Anatole who had done her so much harm--and though he did not
35357. hate her she gladly prayed for him as for an enemy. Only at prayer did
35358. she feel able to think clearly and calmly of Prince Andrew and Anatole,
35359. as men for whom her feelings were as nothing compared with her awe and
35360. devotion to God. When they prayed for the Imperial family and the Synod,
35361. she bowed very low and made the sign of the cross, saying to herself
35362. that even if she did not understand, still she could not doubt, and at
35363. any rate loved the governing Synod and prayed for it.
35364. 
35365. When he had finished the Litany the deacon crossed the stole over his
35366. breast and said, "Let us commit ourselves and our whole lives to Christ
35367. the Lord!"
35368. 
35369. "Commit ourselves to God," Natasha inwardly repeated. "Lord God, I
35370. submit myself to Thy will!" she thought. "I want nothing, wish for
35371. nothing; teach me what to do and how to use my will! Take me, take
35372. me!" prayed Natasha, with impatient emotion in her heart, not crossing
35373. herself but letting her slender arms hang down as if expecting some
35374. invisible power at any moment to take her and deliver her from herself,
35375. from her regrets, desires, remorse, hopes, and sins.
35376. 
35377. The countess looked round several times at her daughter's softened face
35378. and shining eyes and prayed God to help her.
35379. 
35380. Unexpectedly, in the middle of the service, and not in the usual order
35381. Natasha knew so well, the deacon brought out a small stool, the one he
35382. knelt on when praying on Trinity Sunday, and placed it before the doors
35383. of the sanctuary screen. The priest came out with his purple velvet
35384. biretta on his head, adjusted his hair, and knelt down with an effort.
35385. Everybody followed his example and they looked at one another in
35386. surprise. Then came the prayer just received from the Synod--a prayer
35387. for the deliverance of Russia from hostile invasion.
35388. 
35389. "Lord God of might, God of our salvation!" began the priest in that
35390. voice, clear, not grandiloquent but mild, in which only the Slav clergy
35391. read and which acts so irresistibly on a Russian heart.
35392. 
35393. "Lord God of might, God of our salvation! Look this day in mercy and
35394. blessing on Thy humble people, and graciously hear us, spare us, and
35395. have mercy upon us! This foe confounding Thy land, desiring to lay
35396. waste the whole world, rises against us; these lawless men are gathered
35397. together to overthrow Thy kingdom, to destroy Thy dear Jerusalem, Thy
35398. beloved Russia; to defile Thy temples, to overthrow Thine altars, and to
35399. desecrate our holy shrines. How long, O Lord, how long shall the wicked
35400. triumph? How long shall they wield unlawful power?
35401. 
35402. "Lord God! Hear us when we pray to Thee; strengthen with Thy might
35403. our most gracious sovereign lord, the Emperor Alexander Pavlovich; be
35404. mindful of his uprightness and meekness, reward him according to his
35405. righteousness, and let it preserve us, Thy chosen Israel! Bless his
35406. counsels, his undertakings, and his work; strengthen his kingdom by
35407. Thine almighty hand, and give him victory over his enemy, even as Thou
35408. gavest Moses the victory over Amalek, Gideon over Midian, and David over
35409. Goliath. Preserve his army, put a bow of brass in the hands of those who
35410. have armed themselves in Thy Name, and gird their loins with strength
35411. for the fight. Take up the spear and shield and arise to help us;
35412. confound and put to shame those who have devised evil against us, may
35413. they be before the faces of Thy faithful warriors as dust before the
35414. wind, and may Thy mighty Angel confound them and put them to flight; may
35415. they be ensnared when they know it not, and may the plots they have laid
35416. in secret be turned against them; let them fall before Thy servants'
35417. feet and be laid low by our hosts! Lord, Thou art able to save both
35418. great and small; Thou art God, and man cannot prevail against Thee!
35419. 
35420. "God of our fathers! Remember Thy bounteous mercy and loving-kindness
35421. which are from of old; turn not Thy face from us, but be gracious to our
35422. unworthiness, and in Thy great goodness and Thy many mercies regard not
35423. our transgressions and iniquities! Create in us a clean heart and renew
35424. a right spirit within us, strengthen us all in Thy faith, fortify our
35425. hope, inspire us with true love one for another, arm us with unity of
35426. spirit in the righteous defense of the heritage Thou gavest to us and
35427. to our fathers, and let not the scepter of the wicked be exalted against
35428. the destiny of those Thou hast sanctified.
35429. 
35430. "O Lord our God, in whom we believe and in whom we put our trust, let us
35431. not be confounded in our hope of Thy mercy, and give us a token of Thy
35432. blessing, that those who hate us and our Orthodox faith may see it and
35433. be put to shame and perish, and may all the nations know that Thou art
35434. the Lord and we are Thy people. Show Thy mercy upon us this day, O Lord,
35435. and grant us Thy salvation; make the hearts of Thy servants to rejoice
35436. in Thy mercy; smite down our enemies and destroy them swiftly beneath
35437. the feet of Thy faithful servants! For Thou art the defense, the succor,
35438. and the victory of them that put their trust in Thee, and to Thee be all
35439. glory, to Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, now and forever, world without
35440. end. Amen."
35441. 
35442. In Natasha's receptive condition of soul this prayer affected her
35443. strongly. She listened to every word about the victory of Moses over
35444. Amalek, of Gideon over Midian, and of David over Goliath, and about
35445. the destruction of "Thy Jerusalem," and she prayed to God with the
35446. tenderness and emotion with which her heart was overflowing, but without
35447. fully understanding what she was asking of God in that prayer. She
35448. shared with all her heart in the prayer for the spirit of righteousness,
35449. for the strengthening of the heart by faith and hope, and its animation
