36868. Princess Mary saw Dessalles' embarrassed and astonished look fixed on
36869. her father, noticed his silence, and was struck by the fact that her
36870. father had forgotten his son's letter on the drawing-room table; but she
36871. was not only afraid to speak of it and ask Dessalles the reason of his
36872. confusion and silence, but was afraid even to think about it.
36873. 
36874. In the evening Michael Ivanovich, sent by the prince, came to Princess
36875. Mary for Prince Andrew's letter which had been forgotten in the drawing
36876. room. She gave it to him and, unpleasant as it was to her to do so,
36877. ventured to ask him what her father was doing.
36878. 
36879. "Always busy," replied Michael Ivanovich with a respectfully ironic
36880. smile which caused Princess Mary to turn pale. "He's worrying very much
36881. about the new building. He has been reading a little, but now"--Michael
36882. Ivanovich went on, lowering his voice--"now he's at his desk, busy with
36883. his will, I expect." (One of the prince's favorite occupations of late
36884. had been the preparation of some papers he meant to leave at his death
36885. and which he called his "will.")
36886. 
36887. "And Alpatych is being sent to Smolensk?" asked Princess Mary.
36888. 
36889. "Oh, yes, he has been waiting to start for some time."
36890. 
36891. 
36892. 
36893. 
36894. 
36895. CHAPTER III
36896. 
36897. 
36898. When Michael Ivanovich returned to the study with the letter, the old
36899. prince, with spectacles on and a shade over his eyes, was sitting at his
36900. open bureau with screened candles, holding a paper in his
36901. outstretched hand, and in a somewhat dramatic attitude was reading his
36902. manuscript--his "Remarks" as he termed it--which was to be transmitted
36903. to the Emperor after his death.
36904. 
36905. When Michael Ivanovich went in there were tears in the prince's eyes
36906. evoked by the memory of the time when the paper he was now reading had
36907. been written. He took the letter from Michael Ivanovich's hand, put it
36908. in his pocket, folded up his papers, and called in Alpatych who had long
36909. been waiting.
36910. 
36911. The prince had a list of things to be bought in Smolensk and, walking
36912. up and down the room past Alpatych who stood by the door, he gave his
36913. instructions.
36914. 
36915. "First, notepaper--do you hear? Eight quires, like this sample,
36916. gilt-edged... it must be exactly like the sample. Varnish, sealing wax,
36917. as in Michael Ivanovich's list."
36918. 
36919. He paced up and down for a while and glanced at his notes.
36920. 
36921. "Then hand to the governor in person a letter about the deed."
36922. 
36923. Next, bolts for the doors of the new building were wanted and had to be
36924. of a special shape the prince had himself designed, and a leather case
36925. had to be ordered to keep the "will" in.
36926. 
36927. The instructions to Alpatych took over two hours and still the prince
36928. did not let him go. He sat down, sank into thought, closed his eyes, and
36929. dozed off. Alpatych made a slight movement.
36930. 
36931. "Well, go, go! If anything more is wanted I'll send after you."
36932. 
36933. Alpatych went out. The prince again went to his bureau, glanced into it,
36934. fingered his papers, closed the bureau again, and sat down at the table
36935. to write to the governor.
36936. 
36937. It was already late when he rose after sealing the letter. He wished
36938. to sleep, but he knew he would not be able to and that most depressing
36939. thoughts came to him in bed. So he called Tikhon and went through the
36940. rooms with him to show him where to set up the bed for that night.
36941. 
36942. He went about looking at every corner. Every place seemed
36943. unsatisfactory, but worst of all was his customary couch in the study.
36944. That couch was dreadful to him, probably because of the oppressive
36945. thoughts he had had when lying there. It was unsatisfactory everywhere,
36946. but the corner behind the piano in the sitting room was better than
36947. other places: he had never slept there yet.
36948. 
36949. With the help of a footman Tikhon brought in the bedstead and began
36950. putting it up.
36951. 
36952. "That's not right! That's not right!" cried the prince, and himself
36953. pushed it a few inches from the corner and then closer in again.
36954. 
36955. "Well, at last I've finished, now I'll rest," thought the prince, and
36956. let Tikhon undress him.
36957. 
36958. Frowning with vexation at the effort necessary to divest himself of his
36959. coat and trousers, the prince undressed, sat down heavily on the
36960. bed, and appeared to be meditating as he looked contemptuously at his
36961. withered yellow legs. He was not meditating, but only deferring the
36962. moment of making the effort to lift those legs up and turn over on the
36963. bed. "Ugh, how hard it is! Oh, that this toil might end and you would
36964. release me!" thought he. Pressing his lips together he made that effort
36965. for the twenty-thousandth time and lay down. But hardly had he done so
36966. before he felt the bed rocking backwards and forwards beneath him as if
36967. it were breathing heavily and jolting. This happened to him almost every
36968. night. He opened his eyes as they were closing.
36969. 
36970. "No peace, damn them!" he muttered, angry he knew not with whom. "Ah
36971. yes, there was something else important, very important, that I was
36972. keeping till I should be in bed. The bolts? No, I told him about them.
36973. No, it was something, something in the drawing room. Princess Mary
36974. talked some nonsense. Dessalles, that fool, said something. Something in
36975. my pocket--can't remember..."
36976. 
36977. "Tikhon, what did we talk about at dinner?"
36978. 
36979. "About Prince Michael..."
36980. 
36981. "Be quiet, quiet!" The prince slapped his hand on the table. "Yes, I
36982. know, Prince Andrew's letter! Princess Mary read it. Dessalles said
36983. something about Vitebsk. Now I'll read it."
36984. 
36985. He had the letter taken from his pocket and the table--on which stood a
36986. glass of lemonade and a spiral wax candle--moved close to the bed, and
36987. putting on his spectacles he began reading. Only now in the stillness of
36988. the night, reading it by the faint light under the green shade, did he
36989. grasp its meaning for a moment.
36990. 
36991. "The French at Vitebsk, in four days' march they may be at Smolensk;
36992. perhaps are already there! Tikhon!" Tikhon jumped up. "No, no, I don't
36993. want anything!" he shouted.
36994. 
36995. He put the letter under the candlestick and closed his eyes. And there
36996. rose before him the Danube at bright noonday: reeds, the Russian
36997. camp, and himself a young general without a wrinkle on his ruddy face,
36998. vigorous and alert, entering Potemkin's gaily colored tent, and a
36999. burning sense of jealousy of "the favorite" agitated him now as strongly
37000. as it had done then. He recalled all the words spoken at that
37001. first meeting with Potemkin. And he saw before him a plump, rather
37002. sallow-faced, short, stout woman, the Empress Mother, with her smile
37003. and her words at her first gracious reception of him, and then that same
37004. face on the catafalque, and the encounter he had with Zubov over her
37005. coffin about his right to kiss her hand.
37006. 
37007. "Oh, quicker, quicker! To get back to that time and have done with all
37008. the present! Quicker, quicker--and that they should leave me in peace!"
37009. 
37010. 
37011. 
37012. 
37013. 
37014. CHAPTER IV
37015. 
37016. 
37017. Bald Hills, Prince Nicholas Bolkonski's estate, lay forty miles east
37018. from Smolensk and two miles from the main road to Moscow.
37019. 
37020. The same evening that the prince gave his instructions to Alpatych,
37021. Dessalles, having asked to see Princess Mary, told her that, as the
37022. prince was not very well and was taking no steps to secure his safety,
37023. though from Prince Andrew's letter it was evident that to remain at Bald
37024. Hills might be dangerous, he respectfully advised her to send a letter
37025. by Alpatych to the Provincial Governor at Smolensk, asking him to let
37026. her know the state of affairs and the extent of the danger to which
37027. Bald Hills was exposed. Dessalles wrote this letter to the Governor
37028. for Princess Mary, she signed it, and it was given to Alpatych with
37029. instructions to hand it to the Governor and to come back as quickly as
37030. possible if there was danger.
37031. 
37032. Having received all his orders Alpatych, wearing a white beaver hat--a
37033. present from the prince--and carrying a stick as the prince did,
37034. went out accompanied by his family. Three well-fed roans stood ready
37035. harnessed to a small conveyance with a leather hood.
37036. 
37037. The larger bell was muffled and the little bells on the harness stuffed
37038. with paper. The prince allowed no one at Bald Hills to drive with
37039. ringing bells; but on a long journey Alpatych liked to have them. His
37040. satellites--the senior clerk, a countinghouse clerk, a scullery maid,
37041. a cook, two old women, a little pageboy, the coachman, and various
37042. domestic serfs--were seeing him off.
37043. 
37044. His daughter placed chintz-covered down cushions for him to sit on and
37045. behind his back. His old sister-in-law popped in a small bundle, and one
37046. of the coachmen helped him into the vehicle.
37047. 
37048. "There! There! Women's fuss! Women, women!" said Alpatych, puffing and
37049. speaking rapidly just as the prince did, and he climbed into the trap.
37050. 
37051. After giving the clerk orders about the work to be done, Alpatych, not
37052. trying to imitate the prince now, lifted the hat from his bald head and
37053. crossed himself three times.
37054. 
37055. "If there is anything... come back, Yakov Alpatych! For Christ's sake
37056. think of us!" cried his wife, referring to the rumors of war and the
37057. enemy.
37058. 
37059. "Women, women! Women's fuss!" muttered Alpatych to himself and started
37060. on his journey, looking round at the fields of yellow rye and the
37061. still-green, thickly growing oats, and at other quite black fields just
37062. being plowed a second time.
37063. 
37064. As he went along he looked with pleasure at the year's splendid crop
37065. of corn, scrutinized the strips of ryefield which here and there were
37066. already being reaped, made his calculations as to the sowing and the
37067. harvest, and asked himself whether he had not forgotten any of the
37068. prince's orders.
37069. 
37070. Having baited the horses twice on the way, he arrived at the town toward
37071. evening on the fourth of August.
37072. 
37073. Alpatych kept meeting and overtaking baggage trains and troops on the
37074. road. As he approached Smolensk he heard the sounds of distant firing,
37075. but these did not impress him. What struck him most was the sight of a
37076. splendid field of oats in which a camp had been pitched and which
37077. was being mown down by the soldiers, evidently for fodder. This fact
37078. impressed Alpatych, but in thinking about his own business he soon
37079. forgot it.
37080. 
37081. All the interests of his life for more than thirty years had been
37082. bounded by the will of the prince, and he never went beyond that limit.
37083. Everything not connected with the execution of the prince's orders did
37084. not interest and did not even exist for Alpatych.
37085. 
37086. On reaching Smolensk on the evening of the fourth of August he put up
37087. in the Gachina suburb across the Dnieper, at the inn kept by Ferapontov,
37088. where he had been in the habit of putting up for the last thirty years.
37089. Some thirty years ago Ferapontov, by Alpatych's advice, had bought a
37090. wood from the prince, had begun to trade, and now had a house, an
37091. inn, and a corn dealer's shop in that province. He was a stout, dark,
37092. red-faced peasant in the forties, with thick lips, a broad knob of a
37093. nose, similar knobs over his black frowning brows, and a round belly.
37094. 
37095. Wearing a waistcoat over his cotton shirt, Ferapontov was standing
37096. before his shop which opened onto the street. On seeing Alpatych he went
37097. up to him.
37098. 
37099. "You're welcome, Yakov Alpatych. Folks are leaving the town, but you
37100. have come to it," said he.
37101. 
37102. "Why are they leaving the town?" asked Alpatych.
37103. 
37104. "That's what I say. Folks are foolish! Always afraid of the French."
37105. 
37106. "Women's fuss, women's fuss!" said Alpatych.
37107. 
37108. "Just what I think, Yakov Alpatych. What I say is: orders have been
37109. given not to let them in, so that must be right. And the peasants are
37110. asking three rubles for carting--it isn't Christian!"
37111. 
37112. Yakov Alpatych heard without heeding. He asked for a samovar and for hay
37113. for his horses, and when he had had his tea he went to bed.
37114. 
37115. All night long troops were moving past the inn. Next morning Alpatych
37116. donned a jacket he wore only in town and went out on business. It was a
37117. sunny morning and by eight o'clock it was already hot. "A good day for
37118. harvesting," thought Alpatych.
37119. 
37120. From beyond the town firing had been heard since early morning. At eight
37121. o'clock the booming of cannon was added to the sound of musketry. Many
37122. people were hurrying through the streets and there were many soldiers,
37123. but cabs were still driving about, tradesmen stood at their shops, and
37124. service was being held in the churches as usual. Alpatych went to the
37125. shops, to government offices, to the post office, and to the Governor's.
37126. In the offices and shops and at the post office everyone was talking
37127. about the army and about the enemy who was already attacking the town,
37128. everybody was asking what should be done, and all were trying to calm
37129. one another.
37130. 
37131. In front of the Governor's house Alpatych found a large number of
37132. people, Cossacks, and a traveling carriage of the Governor's. At the
37133. porch he met two of the landed gentry, one of whom he knew. This man, an
37134. ex-captain of police, was saying angrily:
37135. 
37136. "It's no joke, you know! It's all very well if you're single. 'One man
37137. though undone is but one,' as the proverb says, but with thirteen in
37138. your family and all the property... They've brought us to utter ruin!
37139. What sort of governors are they to do that? They ought to be hanged--the
37140. brigands!..."
37141. 
37142. "Oh come, that's enough!" said the other.
37143. 
37144. "What do I care? Let him hear! We're not dogs," said the ex-captain of
37145. police, and looking round he noticed Alpatych.
37146. 
37147. "Oh, Yakov Alpatych! What have you come for?"
37148. 
37149. "To see the Governor by his excellency's order," answered Alpatych,
37150. lifting his head and proudly thrusting his hand into the bosom of his
37151. coat as he always did when he mentioned the prince.... "He has ordered
37152. me to inquire into the position of affairs," he added.
37153. 
37154. "Yes, go and find out!" shouted the angry gentleman. "They've brought
37155. things to such a pass that there are no carts or anything!... There it
37156. is again, do you hear?" said he, pointing in the direction whence came
37157. the sounds of firing.
37158. 
37159. "They've brought us all to ruin... the brigands!" he repeated, and
37160. descended the porch steps.
37161. 
37162. Alpatych swayed his head and went upstairs. In the waiting room were
37163. tradesmen, women, and officials, looking silently at one another. The
37164. door of the Governor's room opened and they all rose and moved forward.
37165. An official ran out, said some words to a merchant, called a stout
37166. official with a cross hanging on his neck to follow him, and vanished
37167. again, evidently wishing to avoid the inquiring looks and questions
37168. addressed to him. Alpatych moved forward and next time the official came
37169. out addressed him, one hand placed in the breast of his buttoned coat,
37170. and handed him two letters.
37171. 
37172. "To his Honor Baron Asch, from General-in-Chief Prince Bolkonski," he
37173. announced with such solemnity and significance that the official turned
37174. to him and took the letters.
37175. 
37176. A few minutes later the Governor received Alpatych and hurriedly said to
37177. him:
37178. 
37179. "Inform the prince and princess that I knew nothing: I acted on the
37180. highest instructions--here..." and he handed a paper to Alpatych.
37181. "Still, as the prince is unwell my advice is that they should go to
37182. Moscow. I am just starting myself. Inform them..."
37183. 
37184. But the Governor did not finish: a dusty perspiring officer ran into the
37185. room and began to say something in French. The Governor's face expressed
37186. terror.
37187. 
37188. "Go," he said, nodding his head to Alpatych, and began questioning the
37189. officer.
37190. 
37191. Eager, frightened, helpless glances were turned on Alpatych when he came
37192. out of the Governor's room. Involuntarily listening now to the firing,
37193. which had drawn nearer and was increasing in strength, Alpatych hurried
37194. to his inn. The paper handed to him by the Governor said this:
37195. 
37196. 
37197. "I assure you that the town of Smolensk is not in the slightest danger
37198. as yet and it is unlikely that it will be threatened with any. I from
37199. the one side and Prince Bagration from the other are marching to unite
37200. our forces before Smolensk, which junction will be effected on the
37201. 22nd instant, and both armies with their united forces will defend our
37202. compatriots of the province entrusted to your care till our efforts
37203. shall have beaten back the enemies of our Fatherland, or till the last
37204. warrior in our valiant ranks has perished. From this you will see that
37205. you have a perfect right to reassure the inhabitants of Smolensk, for
37206. those defended by two such brave armies may feel assured of victory."
37207. (Instructions from Barclay de Tolly to Baron Asch, the civil governor of
37208. Smolensk, 1812.)
37209. 
37210. 
37211. People were anxiously roaming about the streets.
37212. 
37213. Carts piled high with household utensils, chairs, and cupboards kept
37214. emerging from the gates of the yards and moving along the streets.
37215. Loaded carts stood at the house next to Ferapontov's and women were
37216. wailing and lamenting as they said good-by. A small watchdog ran round
37217. barking in front of the harnessed horses.
37218. 
37219. Alpatych entered the innyard at a quicker pace than usual and went
37220. straight to the shed where his horses and trap were. The coachman was
37221. asleep. He woke him up, told him to harness, and went into the passage.
37222. From the host's room came the sounds of a child crying, the despairing
37223. sobs of a woman, and the hoarse angry shouting of Ferapontov. The cook
37224. began running hither and thither in the passage like a frightened hen,
37225. just as Alpatych entered.
37226. 
37227. "He's done her to death. Killed the mistress!... Beat her... dragged her
37228. about so!..."
37229. 
37230. "What for?" asked Alpatych.
37231. 
37232. "She kept begging to go away. She's a woman! 'Take me away,' says she,
37233. 'don't let me perish with my little children! Folks,' she says, 'are all
37234. gone, so why,' she says, 'don't we go?' And he began beating and pulling
37235. her about so!"
37236. 
37237. At these words Alpatych nodded as if in approval, and not wishing to
37238. hear more went to the door of the room opposite the innkeeper's, where
37239. he had left his purchases.
37240. 
37241. "You brute, you murderer!" screamed a thin, pale woman who, with a baby
37242. in her arms and her kerchief torn from her head, burst through the door
37243. at that moment and down the steps into the yard.
37244. 
37245. Ferapontov came out after her, but on seeing Alpatych adjusted his
37246. waistcoat, smoothed his hair, yawned, and followed Alpatych into the
37247. opposite room.
37248. 
37249. "Going already?" said he.
37250. 
37251. Alpatych, without answering or looking at his host, sorted his packages
37252. and asked how much he owed.
37253. 
37254. "We'll reckon up! Well, have you been to the Governor's?" asked
37255. Ferapontov. "What has been decided?"
37256. 
37257. Alpatych replied that the Governor had not told him anything definite.
37258. 
37259. "With our business, how can we get away?" said Ferapontov. "We'd have
37260. to pay seven rubles a cartload to Dorogobuzh and I tell them they're
37261. not Christians to ask it! Selivanov, now, did a good stroke last
37262. Thursday--sold flour to the army at nine rubles a sack. Will you have
37263. some tea?" he added.
37264. 
37265. While the horses were being harnessed Alpatych and Ferapontov over their
37266. tea talked of the price of corn, the crops, and the good weather for
37267. harvesting.
37268. 
37269. "Well, it seems to be getting quieter," remarked Ferapontov, finishing
37270. his third cup of tea and getting up. "Ours must have got the best of it.
37271. The orders were not to let them in. So we're in force, it seems....
37272. They say the other day Matthew Ivanych Platov drove them into the river
37273. Marina and drowned some eighteen thousand in one day."
37274. 
37275. Alpatych collected his parcels, handed them to the coachman who had come
37276. in, and settled up with the innkeeper. The noise of wheels, hoofs, and
37277. bells was heard from the gateway as a little trap passed out.
37278. 
37279. It was by now late in the afternoon. Half the street was in shadow, the
37280. other half brightly lit by the sun. Alpatych looked out of the window
37281. and went to the door. Suddenly the strange sound of a far-off whistling
37282. and thud was heard, followed by a boom of cannon blending into a dull
37283. roar that set the windows rattling.
37284. 
37285. He went out into the street: two men were running past toward the
37286. bridge. From different sides came whistling sounds and the thud of
37287. cannon balls and bursting shells falling on the town. But these sounds
37288. were hardly heard in comparison with the noise of the firing outside the
37289. town and attracted little attention from the inhabitants. The town was
37290. being bombarded by a hundred and thirty guns which Napoleon had ordered
37291. up after four o'clock. The people did not at once realize the meaning of
37292. this bombardment.
37293. 
37294. At first the noise of the falling bombs and shells only aroused
37295. curiosity. Ferapontov's wife, who till then had not ceased wailing under
37296. the shed, became quiet and with the baby in her arms went to the gate,
37297. listening to the sounds and looking in silence at the people.
37298. 
37299. The cook and a shop assistant came to the gate. With lively curiosity
37300. everyone tried to get a glimpse of the projectiles as they flew over
37301. their heads. Several people came round the corner talking eagerly.
37302. 
37303. "What force!" remarked one. "Knocked the roof and ceiling all to
37304. splinters!"
37305. 
37306. "Routed up the earth like a pig," said another.
37307. 
37308. "That's grand, it bucks one up!" laughed the first. "Lucky you jumped
37309. aside, or it would have wiped you out!"
37310. 
37311. Others joined those men and stopped and told how cannon balls had fallen
37312. on a house close to them. Meanwhile still more projectiles, now with
37313. the swift sinister whistle of a cannon ball, now with the agreeable
37314. intermittent whistle of a shell, flew over people's heads incessantly,
37315. but not one fell close by, they all flew over. Alpatych was getting into
37316. his trap. The innkeeper stood at the gate.
37317. 
37318. "What are you staring at?" he shouted to the cook, who in her red skirt,
37319. with sleeves rolled up, swinging her bare elbows, had stepped to the
37320. corner to listen to what was being said.
37321. 
37322. "What marvels!" she exclaimed, but hearing her master's voice she turned
37323. back, pulling down her tucked-up skirt.
37324. 
37325. Once more something whistled, but this time quite close, swooping
37326. downwards like a little bird; a flame flashed in the middle of the
37327. street, something exploded, and the street was shrouded in smoke.
37328. 
37329. "Scoundrel, what are you doing?" shouted the innkeeper, rushing to the
37330. cook.
37331. 
37332. At that moment the pitiful wailing of women was heard from different
37333. sides, the frightened baby began to cry, and people crowded silently
37334. with pale faces round the cook. The loudest sound in that crowd was her
37335. wailing.
37336. 
37337. "Oh-h-h! Dear souls, dear kind souls! Don't let me die! My good
37338. souls!..."
37339. 
37340. Five minutes later no one remained in the street. The cook, with her
37341. thigh broken by a shell splinter, had been carried into the kitchen.
37342. Alpatych, his coachman, Ferapontov's wife and children and the house
37343. porter were all sitting in the cellar, listening. The roar of guns, the
37344. whistling of projectiles, and the piteous moaning of the cook, which
37345. rose above the other sounds, did not cease for a moment. The mistress
37346. rocked and hushed her baby and when anyone came into the cellar asked
37347. in a pathetic whisper what had become of her husband who had remained
37348. in the street. A shopman who entered told her that her husband had
37349. gone with others to the cathedral, whence they were fetching the
37350. wonder-working icon of Smolensk.
37351. 
37352. Toward dusk the cannonade began to subside. Alpatych left the cellar
37353. and stopped in the doorway. The evening sky that had been so clear was
37354. clouded with smoke, through which, high up, the sickle of the new moon
37355. shone strangely. Now that the terrible din of the guns had ceased a hush
37356. seemed to reign over the town, broken only by the rustle of footsteps,
37357. the moaning, the distant cries, and the crackle of fires which seemed
37358. widespread everywhere. The cook's moans had now subsided. On two sides
37359. black curling clouds of smoke rose and spread from the fires. Through
37360. the streets soldiers in various uniforms walked or ran confusedly in
37361. different directions like ants from a ruined ant-hill. Several of them
37362. ran into Ferapontov's yard before Alpatych's eyes. Alpatych went out
37363. to the gate. A retreating regiment, thronging and hurrying, blocked the
37364. street.
37365. 
37366. Noticing him, an officer said: "The town is being abandoned. Get away,
37367. get away!" and then, turning to the soldiers, shouted:
37368. 
37369. "I'll teach you to run into the yards!"
37370. 
37371. Alpatych went back to the house, called the coachman, and told him to
37372. set off. Ferapontov's whole household came out too, following Alpatych
37373. and the coachman. The women, who had been silent till then, suddenly
37374. began to wail as they looked at the fires--the smoke and even the flames
37375. of which could be seen in the failing twilight--and as if in reply
37376. the same kind of lamentation was heard from other parts of the street.
37377. Inside the shed Alpatych and the coachman arranged the tangled reins and
37378. traces of their horses with trembling hands.
37379. 
37380. As Alpatych was driving out of the gate he saw some ten soldiers in
37381. Ferapontov's open shop, talking loudly and filling their bags and
37382. knapsacks with flour and sunflower seeds. Just then Ferapontov returned
37383. and entered his shop. On seeing the soldiers he was about to shout at
37384. them, but suddenly stopped and, clutching at his hair, burst into sobs
37385. and laughter:
37386. 
37387. "Loot everything, lads! Don't let those devils get it!" he cried, taking
37388. some bags of flour himself and throwing them into the street.
37389. 
37390. Some of the soldiers were frightened and ran away, others went on
37391. filling their bags. On seeing Alpatych, Ferapontov turned to him:
37392. 
37393. "Russia is done for!" he cried. "Alpatych, I'll set the place on fire
37394. myself. We're done for!..." and Ferapontov ran into the yard.
37395. 
37396. Soldiers were passing in a constant stream along the street blocking
37397. it completely, so that Alpatych could not pass out and had to wait.
37398. Ferapontov's wife and children were also sitting in a cart waiting till
37399. it was possible to drive out.
37400. 
37401. Night had come. There were stars in the sky and the new moon shone out
37402. amid the smoke that screened it. On the sloping descent to the Dnieper
37403. Alpatych's cart and that of the innkeeper's wife, which were slowly
37404. moving amid the rows of soldiers and of other vehicles, had to stop.
37405. In a side street near the crossroads where the vehicles had stopped, a
37406. house and some shops were on fire. This fire was already burning itself
37407. out. The flames now died down and were lost in the black smoke, now
37408. suddenly flared up again brightly, lighting up with strange distinctness
37409. the faces of the people crowding at the crossroads. Black figures
37410. flitted about before the fire, and through the incessant crackling of
37411. the flames talking and shouting could be heard. Seeing that his trap
37412. would not be able to move on for some time, Alpatych got down and turned
37413. into the side street to look at the fire. Soldiers were continually
37414. rushing backwards and forwards near it, and he saw two of them and a
37415. man in a frieze coat dragging burning beams into another yard across the
37416. street, while others carried bundles of hay.
37417. 
37418. Alpatych went up to a large crowd standing before a high barn which was
37419. blazing briskly. The walls were all on fire and the back wall had fallen
37420. in, the wooden roof was collapsing, and the rafters were alight. The
37421. crowd was evidently watching for the roof to fall in, and Alpatych
37422. watched for it too.
37423. 
37424. "Alpatych!" a familiar voice suddenly hailed the old man.
37425. 
37426. "Mercy on us! Your excellency!" answered Alpatych, immediately
37427. recognizing the voice of his young prince.
37428. 
37429. Prince Andrew in his riding cloak, mounted on a black horse, was looking
37430. at Alpatych from the back of the crowd.
37431. 
37432. "Why are you here?" he asked.
37433. 
37434. "Your... your excellency," stammered Alpatych and broke into sobs. "Are
37435. we really lost? Master!..."
37436. 
37437. "Why are you here?" Prince Andrew repeated.
37438. 
37439. At that moment the flames flared up and showed his young master's pale
37440. worn face. Alpatych told how he had been sent there and how difficult it
37441. was to get away.
37442. 
37443. "Are we really quite lost, your excellency?" he asked again.
37444. 
37445. Prince Andrew without replying took out a notebook and raising his knee
37446. began writing in pencil on a page he tore out. He wrote to his sister:
37447. 
37448. 
37449. "Smolensk is being abandoned. Bald Hills will be occupied by the enemy
37450. within a week. Set off immediately for Moscow. Let me know at once when
37451. you will start. Send by special messenger to Usvyazh."
37452. 
37453. 
37454. Having written this and given the paper to Alpatych, he told him how
37455. to arrange for departure of the prince, the princess, his son, and the
37456. boy's tutor, and how and where to let him know immediately. Before
37457. he had had time to finish giving these instructions, a chief of staff
37458. followed by a suite galloped up to him.
37459. 
37460. "You are a colonel?" shouted the chief of staff with a German accent,
37461. in a voice familiar to Prince Andrew. "Houses are set on fire in your
37462. presence and you stand by! What does this mean? You will answer for
37463. it!" shouted Berg, who was now assistant to the chief of staff of the
37464. commander of the left flank of the infantry of the first army, a place,
37465. as Berg said, "very agreeable and well en evidence."
37466. 
37467. Prince Andrew looked at him and without replying went on speaking to
37468. Alpatych.
37469. 
37470. "So tell them that I shall await a reply till the tenth, and if by the
37471. tenth I don't receive news that they have all got away I shall have to
37472. throw up everything and come myself to Bald Hills."
37473. 
37474. "Prince," said Berg, recognizing Prince Andrew, "I only spoke because
37475. I have to obey orders, because I always do obey exactly.... You must
37476. please excuse me," he went on apologetically.
37477. 
37478. Something cracked in the flames. The fire died down for a moment and
37479. wreaths of black smoke rolled from under the roof. There was another
37480. terrible crash and something huge collapsed.
37481. 
37482. "Ou-rou-rou!" yelled the crowd, echoing the crash of the collapsing roof
37483. of the barn, the burning grain in which diffused a cakelike aroma all
37484. around. The flames flared up again, lighting the animated, delighted,
37485. exhausted faces of the spectators.
37486. 
37487. The man in the frieze coat raised his arms and shouted:
37488. 
37489. "It's fine, lads! Now it's raging... It's fine!"
37490. 
37491. "That's the owner himself," cried several voices.
37492. 
37493. "Well then," continued Prince Andrew to Alpatych, "report to them as I
37494. have told you"; and not replying a word to Berg who was now mute beside
37495. him, he touched his horse and rode down the side street.
37496. 
37497. 
37498. 
37499. 
37500. 
37501. CHAPTER V
37502. 
37503. 
37504. From Smolensk the troops continued to retreat, followed by the enemy.
37505. On the tenth of August the regiment Prince Andrew commanded was marching
37506. along the highroad past the avenue leading to Bald Hills. Heat and
37507. drought had continued for more than three weeks. Each day fleecy clouds
37508. floated across the sky and occasionally veiled the sun, but toward
37509. evening the sky cleared again and the sun set in reddish-brown mist.
37510. Heavy night dews alone refreshed the earth. The unreaped corn was
37511. scorched and shed its grain. The marshes dried up. The cattle lowed from
37512. hunger, finding no food on the sun-parched meadows. Only at night and
37513. in the forests while the dew lasted was there any freshness. But on the
37514. road, the highroad along which the troops marched, there was no such
37515. freshness even at night or when the road passed through the forest; the
37516. dew was imperceptible on the sandy dust churned up more than six inches
37517. deep. As soon as day dawned the march began. The artillery and baggage
37518. wagons moved noiselessly through the deep dust that rose to the very
37519. hubs of the wheels, and the infantry sank ankle-deep in that soft,
37520. choking, hot dust that never cooled even at night. Some of this dust
37521. was kneaded by the feet and wheels, while the rest rose and hung like a
37522. cloud over the troops, settling in eyes, ears, hair, and nostrils, and
37523. worst of all in the lungs of the men and beasts as they moved along that
37524. road. The higher the sun rose the higher rose that cloud of dust, and
37525. through the screen of its hot fine particles one could look with naked
37526. eye at the sun, which showed like a huge crimson ball in the unclouded
37527. sky. There was no wind, and the men choked in that motionless
37528. atmosphere. They marched with handkerchiefs tied over their noses and
37529. mouths. When they passed through a village they all rushed to the wells
37530. and fought for the water and drank it down to the mud.
37531. 
37532. Prince Andrew was in command of a regiment, and the management of that
37533. regiment, the welfare of the men and the necessity of receiving
37534. and giving orders, engrossed him. The burning of Smolensk and its
37535. abandonment made an epoch in his life. A novel feeling of anger against
37536. the foe made him forget his own sorrow. He was entirely devoted to the
37537. affairs of his regiment and was considerate and kind to his men and
37538. officers. In the regiment they called him "our prince," were proud
37539. of him and loved him. But he was kind and gentle only to those of his
37540. regiment, to Timokhin and the like--people quite new to him, belonging
37541. to a different world and who could not know and understand his past. As
37542. soon as he came across a former acquaintance or anyone from the
37543. staff, he bristled up immediately and grew spiteful, ironical, and
37544. contemptuous. Everything that reminded him of his past was repugnant to
37545. him, and so in his relations with that former circle he confined himself
37546. to trying to do his duty and not to be unfair.
37547. 
37548. In truth everything presented itself in a dark and gloomy light to
37549. Prince Andrew, especially after the abandonment of Smolensk on the sixth
37550. of August (he considered that it could and should have been defended)
37551. and after his sick father had had to flee to Moscow, abandoning to
37552. pillage his dearly beloved Bald Hills which he had built and peopled.
37553. But despite this, thanks to his regiment, Prince Andrew had something to
37554. think about entirely apart from general questions. Two days previously
37555. he had received news that his father, son, and sister had left for
37556. Moscow; and though there was nothing for him to do at Bald Hills, Prince
37557. Andrew with a characteristic desire to foment his own grief decided that
37558. he must ride there.
37559. 
37560. He ordered his horse to be saddled and, leaving his regiment on the
37561. march, rode to his father's estate where he had been born and spent his
37562. childhood. Riding past the pond where there used always to be dozens
37563. of women chattering as they rinsed their linen or beat it with wooden
37564. beetles, Prince Andrew noticed that there was not a soul about and that
37565. the little washing wharf, torn from its place and half submerged, was
37566. floating on its side in the middle of the pond. He rode to the keeper's
37567. lodge. No one at the stone entrance gates of the drive and the door
37568. stood open. Grass had already begun to grow on the garden paths, and
37569. horses and calves were straying in the English park. Prince Andrew rode
37570. up to the hothouse; some of the glass panes were broken, and of the
37571. trees in tubs some were overturned and others dried up. He called for
37572. Taras the gardener, but no one replied. Having gone round the corner
37573. of the hothouse to the ornamental garden, he saw that the carved garden
37574. fence was broken and branches of the plum trees had been torn off with
37575. the fruit. An old peasant whom Prince Andrew in his childhood had often
37576. seen at the gate was sitting on a green garden seat, plaiting a bast
37577. shoe.
37578. 
37579. He was deaf and did not hear Prince Andrew ride up. He was sitting on
37580. the seat the old prince used to like to sit on, and beside him strips of
37581. bast were hanging on the broken and withered branch of a magnolia.
37582. 
37583. Prince Andrew rode up to the house. Several limes in the old garden had
37584. been cut down and a piebald mare and her foal were wandering in front of
37585. the house among the rosebushes. The shutters were all closed, except at
37586. one window which was open. A little serf boy, seeing Prince Andrew, ran
37587. into the house. Alpatych, having sent his family away, was alone at
37588. Bald Hills and was sitting indoors reading the Lives of the Saints. On
37589. hearing that Prince Andrew had come, he went out with his spectacles on
37590. his nose, buttoning his coat, and, hastily stepping up, without a word
37591. began weeping and kissing Prince Andrew's knee.
37592. 
37593. Then, vexed at his own weakness, he turned away and began to report
37594. on the position of affairs. Everything precious and valuable had been
37595. removed to Bogucharovo. Seventy quarters of grain had also been carted
37596. away. The hay and the spring corn, of which Alpatych said there had been
37597. a remarkable crop that year, had been commandeered by the troops and
37598. mown down while still green. The peasants were ruined; some of them too
37599. had gone to Bogucharovo, only a few remained.
37600. 
37601. Without waiting to hear him out, Prince Andrew asked:
37602. 
37603. "When did my father and sister leave?" meaning when did they leave for
37604. Moscow.
37605. 
37606. Alpatych, understanding the question to refer to their departure for
37607. Bogucharovo, replied that they had left on the seventh and again went
37608. into details concerning the estate management, asking for instructions.
37609. 
37610. "Am I to let the troops have the oats, and to take a receipt for them?
37611. We have still six hundred quarters left," he inquired.
37612. 
37613. "What am I to say to him?" thought Prince Andrew, looking down on the
37614. old man's bald head shining in the sun and seeing by the expression on
37615. his face that the old man himself understood how untimely such questions
37616. were and only asked them to allay his grief.
37617. 
37618. "Yes, let them have it," replied Prince Andrew.
37619. 
37620. "If you noticed some disorder in the garden," said Alpatych, "it was
37621. impossible to prevent it. Three regiments have been here and spent
37622. the night, dragoons mostly. I took down the name and rank of their
37623. commanding officer, to hand in a complaint about it."
37624. 
37625. "Well, and what are you going to do? Will you stay here if the enemy
37626. occupies the place?" asked Prince Andrew.
37627. 
37628. Alpatych turned his face to Prince Andrew, looked at him, and suddenly
37629. with a solemn gesture raised his arm.
37630. 
37631. "He is my refuge! His will be done!" he exclaimed.
37632. 
37633. A group of bareheaded peasants was approaching across the meadow toward
37634. the prince.
37635. 
37636. "Well, good-by!" said Prince Andrew, bending over to Alpatych. "You
37637. must go away too, take away what you can and tell the serfs to go to the
37638. Ryazan estate or to the one near Moscow."
37639. 
37640. Alpatych clung to Prince Andrew's leg and burst into sobs. Gently
37641. disengaging himself, the prince spurred his horse and rode down the
37642. avenue at a gallop.
37643. 
37644. The old man was still sitting in the ornamental garden, like a fly
37645. impassive on the face of a loved one who is dead, tapping the last on
37646. which he was making the bast shoe, and two little girls, running out
37647. from the hot house carrying in their skirts plums they had plucked from
37648. the trees there, came upon Prince Andrew. On seeing the young master,
37649. the elder one with frightened look clutched her younger companion by the
37650. hand and hid with her behind a birch tree, not stopping to pick up some
37651. green plums they had dropped.
37652. 
37653. Prince Andrew turned away with startled haste, unwilling to let them
37654. see that they had been observed. He was sorry for the pretty frightened
37655. little girl, was afraid of looking at her, and yet felt an irresistible
37656. desire to do so. A new sensation of comfort and relief came over him
37657. when, seeing these girls, he realized the existence of other human
37658. interests entirely aloof from his own and just as legitimate as those
37659. that occupied him. Evidently these girls passionately desired one
37660. thing--to carry away and eat those green plums without being caught--and
37661. Prince Andrew shared their wish for the success of their enterprise. He
37662. could not resist looking at them once more. Believing their danger past,
37663. they sprang from their ambush and, chirruping something in their shrill
37664. little voices and holding up their skirts, their bare little sunburned
37665. feet scampered merrily and quickly across the meadow grass.
37666. 
37667. Prince Andrew was somewhat refreshed by having ridden off the dusty
37668. highroad along which the troops were moving. But not far from Bald Hills
37669. he again came out on the road and overtook his regiment at its halting
37670. place by the dam of a small pond. It was past one o'clock. The sun,
37671. a red ball through the dust, burned and scorched his back intolerably
37672. through his black coat. The dust always hung motionless above the buzz
37673. of talk that came from the resting troops. There was no wind. As he
37674. crossed the dam Prince Andrew smelled the ooze and freshness of the
37675. pond. He longed to get into that water, however dirty it might be, and
37676. he glanced round at the pool from whence came sounds of shrieks and
37677. laughter. The small, muddy, green pond had risen visibly more than a
37678. foot, flooding the dam, because it was full of the naked white bodies
37679. of soldiers with brick-red hands, necks, and faces, who were splashing
37680. about in it. All this naked white human flesh, laughing and shrieking,
37681. floundered about in that dirty pool like carp stuffed into a watering
37682. can, and the suggestion of merriment in that floundering mass rendered
37683. it specially pathetic.
37684. 
37685. One fair-haired young soldier of the third company, whom Prince Andrew
37686. knew and who had a strap round the calf of one leg, crossed himself,
37687. stepped back to get a good run, and plunged into the water; another,
37688. a dark noncommissioned officer who was always shaggy, stood up to his
37689. waist in the water joyfully wriggling his muscular figure and snorted
37690. with satisfaction as he poured the water over his head with hands
37691. blackened to the wrists. There were sounds of men slapping one another,
37692. yelling, and puffing.
37693. 
37694. Everywhere on the bank, on the dam, and in the pond, there was healthy,
37695. white, muscular flesh. The officer, Timokhin, with his red little nose,
37696. standing on the dam wiping himself with a towel, felt confused at seeing
37697. the prince, but made up his mind to address him nevertheless.
37698. 
37699. "It's very nice, your excellency! Wouldn't you like to?" said he.
37700. 
37701. "It's dirty," replied Prince Andrew, making a grimace.
37702. 
37703. "We'll clear it out for you in a minute," said Timokhin, and, still
37704. undressed, ran off to clear the men out of the pond.
37705. 
37706. "The prince wants to bathe."
37707. 
37708. "What prince? Ours?" said many voices, and the men were in such haste
37709. to clear out that the prince could hardly stop them. He decided that he
37710. would rather wash himself with water in the barn.
37711. 
37712. "Flesh, bodies, cannon fodder!" he thought, and he looked at his own
37713. naked body and shuddered, not from cold but from a sense of disgust
37714. and horror he did not himself understand, aroused by the sight of that
37715. immense number of bodies splashing about in the dirty pond.
37716. 
37717. 
37718. On the seventh of August Prince Bagration wrote as follows from his
37719. quarters at Mikhaylovna on the Smolensk road:
37720. 
37721. 
37722. Dear Count Alexis Andreevich--(He was writing to Arakcheev but knew that
37723. his letter would be read by the Emperor, and therefore weighed every
37724. word in it to the best of his ability.)
37725. 
37726. I expect the Minister (Barclay de Tolly) has already reported the
37727. abandonment of Smolensk to the enemy. It is pitiable and sad, and
37728. the whole army is in despair that this most important place has been
37729. wantonly abandoned. I, for my part, begged him personally most urgently
37730. and finally wrote him, but nothing would induce him to consent. I swear
37731. to you on my honor that Napoleon was in such a fix as never before and
37732. might have lost half his army but could not have taken Smolensk. Our
37733. troops fought, and are fighting, as never before. With fifteen thousand
37734. men I held the enemy at bay for thirty-five hours and beat him; but he
37735. would not hold out even for fourteen hours. It is disgraceful, a stain
37736. on our army, and as for him, he ought, it seems to me, not to live. If
37737. he reports that our losses were great, it is not true; perhaps about
37738. four thousand, not more, and not even that; but even were they ten
37739. thousand, that's war! But the enemy has lost masses...
37740. 
37741. What would it have cost him to hold out for another two days? They would
37742. have had to retire of their own accord, for they had no water for men
37743. or horses. He gave me his word he would not retreat, but suddenly sent
37744. instructions that he was retiring that night. We cannot fight in this
37745. way, or we may soon bring the enemy to Moscow...
37746. 
37747. There is a rumor that you are thinking of peace. God forbid that you
37748. should make peace after all our sacrifices and such insane retreats! You
37749. would set all Russia against you and every one of us would feel ashamed
37750. to wear the uniform. If it has come to this--we must fight as long as
37751. Russia can and as long as there are men able to stand...
37752. 
37753. One man ought to be in command, and not two. Your Minister may perhaps
37754. be good as a Minister, but as a general he is not merely bad but
37755. execrable, yet to him is entrusted the fate of our whole country.... I
37756. am really frantic with vexation; forgive my writing boldly. It is clear
37757. that the man who advocates the conclusion of a peace, and that the
37758. Minister should command the army, does not love our sovereign and
37759. desires the ruin of us all. So I write you frankly: call out the
37760. militia. For the Minister is leading these visitors after him to Moscow
37761. in a most masterly way. The whole army feels great suspicion of the
37762. Imperial aide-de-camp Wolzogen. He is said to be more Napoleon's man
37763. than ours, and he is always advising the Minister. I am not merely civil
37764. to him but obey him like a corporal, though I am his senior. This is
37765. painful, but, loving my benefactor and sovereign, I submit. Only I am
37766. sorry for the Emperor that he entrusts our fine army to such as he.
37767. Consider that on our retreat we have lost by fatigue and left in the
37768. hospital more than fifteen thousand men, and had we attacked this would
37769. not have happened. Tell me, for God's sake, what will Russia, our mother
37770. Russia, say to our being so frightened, and why are we abandoning our
37771. good and gallant Fatherland to such rabble and implanting feelings of
37772. hatred and shame in all our subjects? What are we scared at and of whom
37773. are we afraid? I am not to blame that the Minister is vacillating,
37774. a coward, dense, dilatory, and has all bad qualities. The whole army
37775. bewails it and calls down curses upon him...
37776. 
37777. 
37778. 
37779. 
37780. 
37781. CHAPTER VI
37782. 
37783. 
37784. Among the innumerable categories applicable to the phenomena of human
37785. life one may discriminate between those in which substance prevails
37786. and those in which form prevails. To the latter--as distinguished
37787. from village, country, provincial, or even Moscow life--we may allot
37788. Petersburg life, and especially the life of its salons. That life of
37789. the salons is unchanging. Since the year 1805 we had made peace and had
37790. again quarreled with Bonaparte and had made constitutions and unmade
37791. them again, but the salons of Anna Pavlovna and Helene remained just as
37792. they had been--the one seven and the other five years before. At Anna
37793. Pavlovna's they talked with perplexity of Bonaparte's successes just
37794. as before and saw in them and in the subservience shown to him by the
37795. European sovereigns a malicious conspiracy, the sole object of which was
37796. to cause unpleasantness and anxiety to the court circle of which Anna
37797. Pavlovna was the representative. And in Helene's salon, which Rumyantsev
37798. himself honored with his visits, regarding Helene as a remarkably
37799. intelligent woman, they talked with the same ecstasy in 1812 as in 1808
37800. of the "great nation" and the "great man," and regretted our rupture
37801. with France, a rupture which, according to them, ought to be promptly
37802. terminated by peace.
37803. 
37804. Of late, since the Emperor's return from the army, there had been some
37805. excitement in these conflicting salon circles and some demonstrations
37806. of hostility to one another, but each camp retained its own tendency.
37807. In Anna Pavlovna's circle only those Frenchmen were admitted who were
37808. deep-rooted legitimists, and patriotic views were expressed to the
37809. effect that one ought not to go to the French theater and that to
37810. maintain the French troupe was costing the government as much as a whole
37811. army corps. The progress of the war was eagerly followed, and only
37812. the reports most flattering to our army were circulated. In the French
37813. circle of Helene and Rumyantsev the reports of the cruelty of the
37814. enemy and of the war were contradicted and all Napoleon's attempts at
37815. conciliation were discussed. In that circle they discountenanced those
37816. who advised hurried preparations for a removal to Kazan of the court and
37817. the girls' educational establishments under the patronage of the Dowager
37818. Empress. In Helene's circle the war in general was regarded as a series
37819. of formal demonstrations which would very soon end in peace, and the
37820. view prevailed expressed by Bilibin--who now in Petersburg was quite
37821. at home in Helene's house, which every clever man was obliged to
37822. visit--that not by gunpowder but by those who invented it would matters
37823. be settled. In that circle the Moscow enthusiasm--news of which had
37824. reached Petersburg simultaneously with the Emperor's return--was
37825. ridiculed sarcastically and very cleverly, though with much caution.
37826. 
37827. Anna Pavlovna's circle on the contrary was enraptured by this enthusiasm
37828. and spoke of it as Plutarch speaks of the deeds of the ancients.
37829. Prince Vasili, who still occupied his former important posts, formed a
37830. connecting link between these two circles. He visited his "good friend
37831. Anna Pavlovna" as well as his daughter's "diplomatic salon," and often
37832. in his constant comings and goings between the two camps became confused
37833. and said at Helene's what he should have said at Anna Pavlovna's and
37834. vice versa.
37835. 
37836. Soon after the Emperor's return Prince Vasili in a conversation about
37837. the war at Anna Pavlovna's severely condemned Barclay de Tolly, but was
37838. undecided as to who ought to be appointed commander in chief. One of the
37839. visitors, usually spoken of as "a man of great merit," having described
37840. how he had that day seen Kutuzov, the newly chosen chief of the
37841. Petersburg militia, presiding over the enrollment of recruits at the
37842. Treasury, cautiously ventured to suggest that Kutuzov would be the man
37843. to satisfy all requirements.
37844. 
37845. Anna Pavlovna remarked with a melancholy smile that Kutuzov had done
37846. nothing but cause the Emperor annoyance.
37847. 
37848. "I have talked and talked at the Assembly of the Nobility," Prince
37849. Vasili interrupted, "but they did not listen to me. I told them his
37850. election as chief of the militia would not please the Emperor. They did
37851. not listen to me.
37852. 
37853. "It's all this mania for opposition," he went on. "And who for? It is
37854. all because we want to ape the foolish enthusiasm of those Muscovites,"
37855. Prince Vasili continued, forgetting for a moment that though at Helene's
37856. one had to ridicule the Moscow enthusiasm, at Anna Pavlovna's one had to
37857. be ecstatic about it. But he retrieved his mistake at once. "Now, is
37858. it suitable that Count Kutuzov, the oldest general in Russia, should
37859. preside at that tribunal? He will get nothing for his pains! How could
37860. they make a man commander in chief who cannot mount a horse, who drops
37861. asleep at a council, and has the very worst morals! A good reputation
37862. he made for himself at Bucharest! I don't speak of his capacity as a
37863. general, but at a time like this how they appoint a decrepit, blind old
37864. man, positively blind? A fine idea to have a blind general! He can't see
37865. anything. To play blindman's bluff? He can't see at all!"
37866. 
37867. No one replied to his remarks.
37868. 
37869. This was quite correct on the twenty-fourth of July. But on the
37870. twenty-ninth of July Kutuzov received the title of Prince. This might
37871. indicate a wish to get rid of him, and therefore Prince Vasili's opinion
37872. continued to be correct though he was not now in any hurry to express
37873. it. But on the eighth of August a committee, consisting of Field Marshal
37874. Saltykov, Arakcheev, Vyazmitinov, Lopukhin, and Kochubey met to consider
37875. the progress of the war. This committee came to the conclusion that
37876. our failures were due to a want of unity in the command and though the
37877. members of the committee were aware of the Emperor's dislike of Kutuzov,
37878. after a short deliberation they agreed to advise his appointment as
37879. commander in chief. That same day Kutuzov was appointed commander
37880. in chief with full powers over the armies and over the whole region
37881. occupied by them.
37882. 
37883. On the ninth of August Prince Vasili at Anna Pavlovna's again met the
37884. "man of great merit." The latter was very attentive to Anna Pavlovna
37885. because he wanted to be appointed director of one of the educational
37886. establishments for young ladies. Prince Vasili entered the room with the
37887. air of a happy conqueror who has attained the object of his desires.
37888. 
37889. "Well, have you heard the great news? Prince Kutuzov is field marshal!
37890. All dissensions are at an end! I am so glad, so delighted! At last
37891. we have a man!" said he, glancing sternly and significantly round at
37892. everyone in the drawing room.
37893. 
37894. The "man of great merit," despite his desire to obtain the post of
37895. director, could not refrain from reminding Prince Vasili of his former
37896. opinion. Though this was impolite to Prince Vasili in Anna Pavlovna's
37897. drawing room, and also to Anna Pavlovna herself who had received the
37898. news with delight, he could not resist the temptation.
37899. 
37900. "But, Prince, they say he is blind!" said he, reminding Prince Vasili of
37901. his own words.
37902. 
37903. "Eh? Nonsense! He sees well enough," said Prince Vasili rapidly, in a
37904. deep voice and with a slight cough--the voice and cough with which he
37905. was wont to dispose of all difficulties.
37906. 
37907. "He sees well enough," he added. "And what I am so pleased about," he
37908. went on, "is that our sovereign has given him full powers over all
37909. the armies and the whole region--powers no commander in chief ever had
37910. before. He is a second autocrat," he concluded with a victorious smile.
37911. 
37912. "God grant it! God grant it!" said Anna Pavlovna.
37913. 
37914. The "man of great merit," who was still a novice in court circles,
37915. wishing to flatter Anna Pavlovna by defending her former position on
37916. this question, observed:
37917. 
37918. "It is said that the Emperor was reluctant to give Kutuzov those powers.
37919. They say he blushed like a girl to whom Joconde is read, when he said to
37920. Kutuzov: 'Your Emperor and the Fatherland award you this honor.'"
37921. 
37922. "Perhaps the heart took no part in that speech," said Anna Pavlovna.
37923. 
37924. "Oh, no, no!" warmly rejoined Prince Vasili, who would not now yield
37925. Kutuzov to anyone; in his opinion Kutuzov was not only admirable
37926. himself, but was adored by everybody. "No, that's impossible," said he,
37927. "for our sovereign appreciated him so highly before."
37928. 
37929. "God grant only that Prince Kutuzov assumes real power and does not
37930. allow anyone to put a spoke in his wheel," observed Anna Pavlovna.
37931. 
37932. Understanding at once to whom she alluded, Prince Vasili said in a
37933. whisper:
37934. 
37935. "I know for a fact that Kutuzov made it an absolute condition that the
37936. Tsarevich should not be with the army. Do you know what he said to the
37937. Emperor?"
37938. 
37939. And Prince Vasili repeated the words supposed to have been spoken by
37940. Kutuzov to the Emperor. "I can neither punish him if he does wrong nor
37941. reward him if he does right."
37942. 
37943. "Oh, a very wise man is Prince Kutuzov! I have known him a long time!"
37944. 
37945. "They even say," remarked the "man of great merit" who did not yet
37946. possess courtly tact, "that his excellency made it an express condition
37947. that the sovereign himself should not be with the army."
37948. 
37949. As soon as he said this both Prince Vasili and Anna Pavlovna turned away
37950. from him and glanced sadly at one another with a sigh at his naivete.
37951. 
37952. 
37953. 
37954. 
37955. 
37956. CHAPTER VII
37957. 
37958. 
37959. While this was taking place in Petersburg the French had already passed
37960. Smolensk and were drawing nearer and nearer to Moscow. Napoleon's
37961. historian Thiers, like other of his historians, trying to justify his
37962. hero says that he was drawn to the walls of Moscow against his will. He
37963. is as right as other historians who look for the explanation of historic
37964. events in the will of one man; he is as right as the Russian historians
37965. who maintain that Napoleon was drawn to Moscow by the skill of the
37966. Russian commanders. Here besides the law of retrospection, which regards
37967. all the past as a preparation for events that subsequently occur,
37968. the law of reciprocity comes in, confusing the whole matter. A good
37969. chessplayer having lost a game is sincerely convinced that his loss
37970. resulted from a mistake he made and looks for that mistake in the
37971. opening, but forgets that at each stage of the game there were similar
37972. mistakes and that none of his moves were perfect. He only notices the
37973. mistake to which he pays attention, because his opponent took advantage
37974. of it. How much more complex than this is the game of war, which
37975. occurs under certain limits of time, and where it is not one will that
37976. manipulates lifeless objects, but everything results from innumerable
37977. conflicts of various wills!
37978. 
37979. After Smolensk Napoleon sought a battle beyond Dorogobuzh at Vyazma, and
37980. then at Tsarevo-Zaymishche, but it happened that owing to a conjunction
37981. of innumerable circumstances the Russians could not give battle till
37982. they reached Borodino, seventy miles from Moscow. From Vyazma Napoleon
37983. ordered a direct advance on Moscow.
37984. 
37985. Moscou, la capitale asiatique de ce grand empire, la ville sacree des
37986. peuples d'Alexandre, Moscou avec ses innombrables eglises en forme de
37987. pagodes chinoises, * this Moscow gave Napoleon's imagination no rest.
37988. On the march from Vyazma to Tsarevo-Zaymishche he rode his light bay
37989. bobtailed ambler accompanied by his Guards, his bodyguard, his pages,
37990. and aides-de-camp. Berthier, his chief of staff, dropped behind to
37991. question a Russian prisoner captured by the cavalry. Followed by
37992. Lelorgne d'Ideville, an interpreter, he overtook Napoleon at a gallop
37993. and reined in his horse with an amused expression.
37994. 
37995. 
37996.      * "Moscow, the Asiatic capital of this great empire, the
37997.      sacred city of Alexander's people, Moscow with its
37998.      innumerable churches shaped like Chinese pagodas."
37999. 
38000. 
38001. "Well?" asked Napoleon.
38002. 
38003. "One of Platov's Cossacks says that Platov's corps is joining up with
38004. the main army and that Kutuzov has been appointed commander in chief. He
38005. is a very shrewd and garrulous fellow."
38006. 
38007. Napoleon smiled and told them to give the Cossack a horse and bring the
38008. man to him. He wished to talk to him himself. Several adjutants galloped
38009. off, and an hour later, Lavrushka, the serf Denisov had handed over
38010. to Rostov, rode up to Napoleon in an orderly's jacket and on a French
38011. cavalry saddle, with a merry, and tipsy face. Napoleon told him to ride
38012. by his side and began questioning him.
38013. 
38014. "You are a Cossack?"
38015. 
38016. "Yes, a Cossack, your Honor."
38017. 
38018. "The Cossack, not knowing in what company he was, for Napoleon's plain
38019. appearance had nothing about it that would reveal to an Oriental mind
38020. the presence of a monarch, talked with extreme familiarity of the
38021. incidents of the war," says Thiers, narrating this episode. In
38022. reality Lavrushka, having got drunk the day before and left his master
38023. dinnerless, had been whipped and sent to the village in quest of
38024. chickens, where he engaged in looting till the French took him prisoner.
38025. Lavrushka was one of those coarse, bare-faced lackeys who have seen all
38026. sorts of things, consider it necessary to do everything in a mean and
38027. cunning way, are ready to render any sort of service to their master,
38028. and are keen at guessing their master's baser impulses, especially those
38029. prompted by vanity and pettiness.
38030. 
38031. Finding himself in the company of Napoleon, whose identity he had easily
38032. and surely recognized, Lavrushka was not in the least abashed but merely
38033. did his utmost to gain his new master's favor.
38034. 
38035. He knew very well that this was Napoleon, but Napoleon's presence could
38036. no more intimidate him than Rostov's, or a sergeant major's with the
38037. rods, would have done, for he had nothing that either the sergeant major
38038. or Napoleon could deprive him of.
38039. 
38040. So he rattled on, telling all the gossip he had heard among the
38041. orderlies. Much of it true. But when Napoleon asked him whether the
38042. Russians thought they would beat Bonaparte or not, Lavrushka screwed up
38043. his eyes and considered.
38044. 
38045. In this question he saw subtle cunning, as men of his type see cunning
38046. in everything, so he frowned and did not answer immediately.
38047. 
38048. "It's like this," he said thoughtfully, "if there's a battle soon, yours
38049. will win. That's right. But if three days pass, then after that, well,
38050. then that same battle will not soon be over."
38051. 
38052. Lelorgne d'Ideville smilingly interpreted this speech to Napoleon thus:
38053. "If a battle takes place within the next three days the French will
38054. win, but if later, God knows what will happen." Napoleon did not smile,
38055. though he was evidently in high good humor, and he ordered these words
38056. to be repeated.
38057. 
38058. Lavrushka noticed this and to entertain him further, pretending not to
38059. know who Napoleon was, added:
38060. 
38061. "We know that you have Bonaparte and that he has beaten everybody in
38062. the world, but we are a different matter..."--without knowing why or how
38063. this bit of boastful patriotism slipped out at the end.
38064. 
38065. The interpreter translated these words without the last phrase, and
38066. Bonaparte smiled. "The young Cossack made his mighty interlocutor
38067. smile," says Thiers. After riding a few paces in silence, Napoleon
38068. turned to Berthier and said he wished to see how the news that he was
38069. talking to the Emperor himself, to that very Emperor who had written his
38070. immortally victorious name on the Pyramids, would affect this enfant du
38071. Don. *
38072. 
38073. 
38074.     * "Child of the Don."
38075. 
38076. 
38077. The fact was accordingly conveyed to Lavrushka.
38078. 
38079. Lavrushka, understanding that this was done to perplex him and that
38080. Napoleon expected him to be frightened, to gratify his new masters
38081. promptly pretended to be astonished and awe-struck, opened his eyes
38082. wide, and assumed the expression he usually put on when taken to be
38083. whipped. "As soon as Napoleon's interpreter had spoken," says Thiers,
38084. "the Cossack, seized by amazement, did not utter another word, but rode
38085. on, his eyes fixed on the conqueror whose fame had reached him across
38086. the steppes of the East. All his loquacity was suddenly arrested and
38087. replaced by a naive and silent feeling of admiration. Napoleon, after
38088. making the Cossack a present, had him set free like a bird restored to
38089. its native fields."
38090. 
38091. Napoleon rode on, dreaming of the Moscow that so appealed to his
38092. imagination, and "the bird restored to its native fields" galloped to
38093. our outposts, inventing on the way all that had not taken place but that
38094. he meant to relate to his comrades. What had really taken place he did
38095. not wish to relate because it seemed to him not worth telling. He
38096. found the Cossacks, inquired for the regiment operating with Platov's
38097. detachment and by evening found his master, Nicholas Rostov, quartered
38098. at Yankovo. Rostov was just mounting to go for a ride round the
38099. neighboring villages with Ilyin; he let Lavrushka have another horse and
38100. took him along with him.
38101. 
38102. 
38103. 
38104. 
38105. 
38106. CHAPTER VIII
38107. 
38108. 
38109. Princess Mary was not in Moscow and out of danger as Prince Andrew
38110. supposed.
38111. 
38112. After the return of Alpatych from Smolensk the old prince suddenly
38113. seemed to awake as from a dream. He ordered the militiamen to be called
38114. up from the villages and armed, and wrote a letter to the commander in
38115. chief informing him that he had resolved to remain at Bald Hills to the
38116. last extremity and to defend it, leaving to the commander in chief's
38117. discretion to take measures or not for the defense of Bald Hills, where
38118. one of Russia's oldest generals would be captured or killed, and he
38119. announced to his household that he would remain at Bald Hills.
38120. 
38121. But while himself remaining, he gave instructions for the departure of
38122. the princess and Dessalles with the little prince to Bogucharovo and
38123. thence to Moscow. Princess Mary, alarmed by her father's feverish and
38124. sleepless activity after his previous apathy, could not bring herself to
38125. leave him alone and for the first time in her life ventured to disobey
38126. him. She refused to go away and her father's fury broke over her in a
38127. terrible storm. He repeated every injustice he had ever inflicted on
38128. her. Trying to convict her, he told her she had worn him out, had caused
38129. his quarrel with his son, had harbored nasty suspicions of him, making
38130. it the object of her life to poison his existence, and he drove her from
38131. his study telling her that if she did not go away it was all the same
38132. to him. He declared that he did not wish to remember her existence and
38133. warned her not to dare to let him see her. The fact that he did not, as
38134. she had feared, order her to be carried away by force but only told her
38135. not to let him see her cheered Princess Mary. She knew it was a proof
38136. that in the depth of his soul he was glad she was remaining at home and
38137. had not gone away.
38138. 
38139. The morning after little Nicholas had left, the old prince donned his
38140. full uniform and prepared to visit the commander in chief. His caleche
38141. was already at the door. Princess Mary saw him walk out of the house in
38142. his uniform wearing all his orders and go down the garden to review his
38143. armed peasants and domestic serfs. She sat by the window listening to
38144. his voice which reached her from the garden. Suddenly several men came
38145. running up the avenue with frightened faces.
38146. 
38147. Princess Mary ran out to the porch, down the flower-bordered path, and
38148. into the avenue. A large crowd of militiamen and domestics were moving
38149. toward her, and in their midst several men were supporting by
38150. the armpits and dragging along a little old man in a uniform and
38151. decorations. She ran up to him and, in the play of the sunlight that
38152. fell in small round spots through the shade of the lime-tree avenue,
38153. could not be sure what change there was in his face. All she could see
38154. was that his former stern and determined expression had altered to one
38155. of timidity and submission. On seeing his daughter he moved his helpless
38156. lips and made a hoarse sound. It was impossible to make out what he
38157. wanted. He was lifted up, carried to his study, and laid on the very
38158. couch he had so feared of late.
38159. 
38160. The doctor, who was fetched that same night, bled him and said that the
38161. prince had had a seizure paralyzing his right side.
38162. 
38163. It was becoming more and more dangerous to remain at Bald Hills, and
38164. next day they moved the prince to Bogucharovo, the doctor accompanying
38165. him.
38166. 
38167. By the time they reached Bogucharovo, Dessalles and the little prince
38168. had already left for Moscow.
38169. 
38170. For three weeks the old prince lay stricken by paralysis in the new
38171. house Prince Andrew had built at Bogucharovo, ever in the same state,
38172. getting neither better nor worse. He was unconscious and lay like
38173. a distorted corpse. He muttered unceasingly, his eyebrows and lips
38174. twitching, and it was impossible to tell whether he understood what was
38175. going on around him or not. One thing was certain--that he was suffering
38176. and wished to say something. But what it was, no one could tell: it
38177. might be some caprice of a sick and half-crazy man, or it might relate
38178. to public affairs, or possibly to family concerns.
38179. 
38180. The doctor said this restlessness did not mean anything and was due
38181. to physical causes; but Princess Mary thought he wished to tell
38182. her something, and the fact that her presence always increased his
38183. restlessness confirmed her opinion.
38184. 
38185. He was evidently suffering both physically and mentally. There was no
38186. hope of recovery. It was impossible for him to travel, it would not do
38187. to let him die on the road. "Would it not be better if the end did come,
38188. the very end?" Princess Mary sometimes thought. Night and day, hardly
38189. sleeping at all, she watched him and, terrible to say, often watched
38190. him not with hope of finding signs of improvement but wishing to find
38191. symptoms of the approach of the end.
38192. 
38193. Strange as it was to her to acknowledge this feeling in herself, yet
38194. there it was. And what seemed still more terrible to her was that since
38195. her father's illness began (perhaps even sooner, when she stayed with
38196. him expecting something to happen), all the personal desires and hopes
38197. that had been forgotten or sleeping within her had awakened. Thoughts
38198. that had not entered her mind for years--thoughts of a life free from
38199. the fear of her father, and even the possibility of love and of family
38200. happiness--floated continually in her imagination like temptations
38201. of the devil. Thrust them aside as she would, questions continually
38202. recurred to her as to how she would order her life now, after that.
38203. These were temptations of the devil and Princess Mary knew it. She knew
38204. that the sole weapon against him was prayer, and she tried to pray. She
38205. assumed an attitude of prayer, looked at the icons, repeated the words
38206. of a prayer, but she could not pray. She felt that a different world had
38207. now taken possession of her--the life of a world of strenuous and free
38208. activity, quite opposed to the spiritual world in which till now she
38209. had been confined and in which her greatest comfort had been prayer.
38210. She could not pray, could not weep, and worldly cares took possession of
38211. her.
38212. 
38213. It was becoming dangerous to remain in Bogucharovo. News of the approach
38214. of the French came from all sides, and in one village, ten miles from
38215. Bogucharovo, a homestead had been looted by French marauders.
38216. 
38217. The doctor insisted on the necessity of moving the prince; the
38218. provincial Marshal of the Nobility sent an official to Princess Mary
38219. to persuade her to get away as quickly as possible, and the head of the
38220. rural police having come to Bogucharovo urged the same thing, saying
38221. that the French were only some twenty-five miles away, that French
38222. proclamations were circulating in the villages, and that if the princess
38223. did not take her father away before the fifteenth, he could not answer
38224. for the consequences.
38225. 
38226. The princess decided to leave on the fifteenth. The cares of preparation
38227. and giving orders, for which everyone came to her, occupied her all day.
38228. She spent the night of the fourteenth as usual, without undressing, in
38229. the room next to the one where the prince lay. Several times, waking up,
38230. she heard his groans and muttering, the creak of his bed, and the steps
38231. of Tikhon and the doctor when they turned him over. Several times she
38232. listened at the door, and it seemed to her that his mutterings were
38233. louder than usual and that they turned him over oftener. She could not
38234. sleep and several times went to the door and listened, wishing to enter
38235. but not deciding to do so. Though he did not speak, Princess Mary saw
38236. and knew how unpleasant every sign of anxiety on his account was to him.
38237. She had noticed with what dissatisfaction he turned from the look she
38238. sometimes involuntarily fixed on him. She knew that her going in during
38239. the night at an unusual hour would irritate him.
38240. 
38241. But never had she felt so grieved for him or so much afraid of losing
38242. him. She recalled all her life with him and in every word and act of his
38243. found an expression of his love of her. Occasionally amid these memories
38244. temptations of the devil would surge into her imagination: thoughts of
38245. how things would be after his death, and how her new, liberated life
38246. would be ordered. But she drove these thoughts away with disgust. Toward
38247. morning he became quiet and she fell asleep.
38248. 
38249. She woke late. That sincerity which often comes with waking showed her
38250. clearly what chiefly concerned her about her father's illness. On waking
38251. she listened to what was going on behind the door and, hearing him
38252. groan, said to herself with a sigh that things were still the same.
38253. 
38254. "But what could have happened? What did I want? I want his death!" she
38255. cried with a feeling of loathing for herself.
38256. 
38257. She washed, dressed, said her prayers, and went out to the porch. In
