38258. front of it stood carriages without horses and things were being packed
38259. into the vehicles.
38260. 
38261. It was a warm, gray morning. Princess Mary stopped at the porch, still
38262. horrified by her spiritual baseness and trying to arrange her thoughts
38263. before going to her father. The doctor came downstairs and went out to
38264. her.
38265. 
38266. "He is a little better today," said he. "I was looking for you. One can
38267. make out something of what he is saying. His head is clearer. Come in,
38268. he is asking for you..."
38269. 
38270. Princess Mary's heart beat so violently at this news that she grew pale
38271. and leaned against the wall to keep from falling. To see him, talk to
38272. him, feel his eyes on her now that her whole soul was overflowing with
38273. those dreadful, wicked temptations, was a torment of joy and terror.
38274. 
38275. "Come," said the doctor.
38276. 
38277. Princess Mary entered her father's room and went up to his bed. He was
38278. lying on his back propped up high, and his small bony hands with
38279. their knotted purple veins were lying on the quilt; his left eye gazed
38280. straight before him, his right eye was awry, and his brows and lips
38281. motionless. He seemed altogether so thin, small, and pathetic. His face
38282. seemed to have shriveled or melted; his features had grown smaller.
38283. Princess Mary went up and kissed his hand. His left hand pressed hers
38284. so that she understood that he had long been waiting for her to come. He
38285. twitched her hand, and his brows and lips quivered angrily.
38286. 
38287. She looked at him in dismay trying to guess what he wanted of her. When
38288. she changed her position so that his left eye could see her face he
38289. calmed down, not taking his eyes off her for some seconds. Then his lips
38290. and tongue moved, sounds came, and he began to speak, gazing timidly and
38291. imploringly at her, evidently afraid that she might not understand.
38292. 
38293. Straining all her faculties Princess Mary looked at him. The comic
38294. efforts with which he moved his tongue made her drop her eyes and with
38295. difficulty repress the sobs that rose to her throat. He said something,
38296. repeating the same words several times. She could not understand them,
38297. but tried to guess what he was saying and inquiringly repeated the words
38298. he uttered.
38299. 
38300. "Mmm...ar...ate...ate..." he repeated several times.
38301. 
38302. It was quite impossible to understand these sounds. The doctor thought
38303. he had guessed them, and inquiringly repeated: "Mary, are you afraid?"
38304. The prince shook his head, again repeated the same sounds.
38305. 
38306. "My mind, my mind aches?" questioned Princess Mary.
38307. 
38308. He made a mumbling sound in confirmation of this, took her hand, and
38309. began pressing it to different parts of his breast as if trying to find
38310. the right place for it.
38311. 
38312. "Always thoughts... about you... thoughts..." he then uttered much
38313. more clearly than he had done before, now that he was sure of being
38314. understood.
38315. 
38316. Princess Mary pressed her head against his hand, trying to hide her sobs
38317. and tears.
38318. 
38319. He moved his hand over her hair.
38320. 
38321. "I have been calling you all night..." he brought out.
38322. 
38323. "If only I had known..." she said through her tears. "I was afraid to
38324. come in."
38325. 
38326. He pressed her hand.
38327. 
38328. "Weren't you asleep?"
38329. 
38330. "No, I did not sleep," said Princess Mary, shaking her head.
38331. 
38332. Unconsciously imitating her father, she now tried to express herself as
38333. he did, as much as possible by signs, and her tongue too seemed to move
38334. with difficulty.
38335. 
38336. "Dear one... Dearest..." Princess Mary could not quite make out what he
38337. had said, but from his look it was clear that he had uttered a tender
38338. caressing word such as he had never used to her before. "Why didn't you
38339. come in?"
38340. 
38341. "And I was wishing for his death!" thought Princess Mary.
38342. 
38343. He was silent awhile.
38344. 
38345. "Thank you... daughter dear!... for all, for all... forgive!... thank
38346. you!... forgive!... thank you!..." and tears began to flow from his
38347. eyes. "Call Andrew!" he said suddenly, and a childish, timid expression
38348. of doubt showed itself on his face as he spoke.
38349. 
38350. He himself seemed aware that his demand was meaningless. So at least it
38351. seemed to Princess Mary.
38352. 
38353. "I have a letter from him," she replied.
38354. 
38355. He glanced at her with timid surprise.
38356. 
38357. "Where is he?"
38358. 
38359. "He's with the army, Father, at Smolensk."
38360. 
38361. He closed his eyes and remained silent a long time. Then as if in
38362. answer to his doubts and to confirm the fact that now he understood and
38363. remembered everything, he nodded his head and reopened his eyes.
38364. 
38365. "Yes," he said, softly and distinctly. "Russia has perished. They've
38366. destroyed her."
38367. 
38368. And he began to sob, and again tears flowed from his eyes. Princess Mary
38369. could no longer restrain herself and wept while she gazed at his face.
38370. 
38371. Again he closed his eyes. His sobs ceased, he pointed to his eyes, and
38372. Tikhon, understanding him, wiped away the tears.
38373. 
38374. Then he again opened his eyes and said something none of them could
38375. understand for a long time, till at last Tikhon understood and repeated
38376. it. Princess Mary had sought the meaning of his words in the mood in
38377. which he had just been speaking. She thought he was speaking of Russia,
38378. or Prince Andrew, of herself, of his grandson, or of his own death, and
38379. so she could not guess his words.
38380. 
38381. "Put on your white dress. I like it," was what he said.
38382. 
38383. Having understood this Princess Mary sobbed still louder, and the doctor
38384. taking her arm led her out to the veranda, soothing her and trying to
38385. persuade her to prepare for her journey. When she had left the room the
38386. prince again began speaking about his son, about the war, and about the
38387. Emperor, angrily twitching his brows and raising his hoarse voice, and
38388. then he had a second and final stroke.
38389. 
38390. Princess Mary stayed on the veranda. The day had cleared, it was hot and
38391. sunny. She could understand nothing, think of nothing and feel nothing,
38392. except passionate love for her father, love such as she thought she had
38393. never felt till that moment. She ran out sobbing into the garden and as
38394. far as the pond, along the avenues of young lime trees Prince Andrew had
38395. planted.
38396. 
38397. "Yes... I... I... I wished for his death! Yes, I wanted it to end
38398. quicker.... I wished to be at peace.... And what will become of me? What
38399. use will peace be when he is no longer here?" Princess Mary murmured,
38400. pacing the garden with hurried steps and pressing her hands to her bosom
38401. which heaved with convulsive sobs.
38402. 
38403. When she had completed the tour of the garden, which brought her again
38404. to the house, she saw Mademoiselle Bourienne--who had remained at
38405. Bogucharovo and did not wish to leave it--coming toward her with a
38406. stranger. This was the Marshal of the Nobility of the district, who
38407. had come personally to point out to the princess the necessity for her
38408. prompt departure. Princess Mary listened without understanding him; she
38409. led him to the house, offered him lunch, and sat down with him. Then,
38410. excusing herself, she went to the door of the old prince's room. The
38411. doctor came out with an agitated face and said she could not enter.
38412. 
38413. "Go away, Princess! Go away... go away!"
38414. 
38415. She returned to the garden and sat down on the grass at the foot of the
38416. slope by the pond, where no one could see her. She did not know how
38417. long she had been there when she was aroused by the sound of a woman's
38418. footsteps running along the path. She rose and saw Dunyasha her maid,
38419. who was evidently looking for her, and who stopped suddenly as if in
38420. alarm on seeing her mistress.
38421. 
38422. "Please come, Princess... The Prince," said Dunyasha in a breaking
38423. voice.
38424. 
38425. "Immediately, I'm coming, I'm coming!" replied the princess hurriedly,
38426. not giving Dunyasha time to finish what she was saying, and trying to
38427. avoid seeing the girl she ran toward the house.
38428. 
38429. "Princess, it's God's will! You must be prepared for everything," said
38430. the Marshal, meeting her at the house door.
38431. 
38432. "Let me alone; it's not true!" she cried angrily to him.
38433. 
38434. The doctor tried to stop her. She pushed him aside and ran to her
38435. father's door. "Why are these people with frightened faces stopping me?
38436. I don't want any of them! And what are they doing here?" she thought.
38437. She opened the door and the bright daylight in that previously darkened
38438. room startled her. In the room were her nurse and other women. They all
38439. drew back from the bed, making way for her. He was still lying on the
38440. bed as before, but the stern expression of his quiet face made Princess
38441. Mary stop short on the threshold.
38442. 
38443. "No, he's not dead--it's impossible!" she told herself and approached
38444. him, and repressing the terror that seized her, she pressed her lips
38445. to his cheek. But she stepped back immediately. All the force of the
38446. tenderness she had been feeling for him vanished instantly and was
38447. replaced by a feeling of horror at what lay there before her. "No, he
38448. is no more! He is not, but here where he was is something unfamiliar and
38449. hostile, some dreadful, terrifying, and repellent mystery!" And hiding
38450. her face in her hands, Princess Mary sank into the arms of the doctor,
38451. who held her up.
38452. 
38453. 
38454. In the presence of Tikhon and the doctor the women washed what had been
38455. the prince, tied his head up with a handkerchief that the mouth should
38456. not stiffen while open, and with another handkerchief tied together the
38457. legs that were already spreading apart. Then they dressed him in uniform
38458. with his decorations and placed his shriveled little body on a table.
38459. Heaven only knows who arranged all this and when, but it all got done
38460. as if of its own accord. Toward night candles were burning round his
38461. coffin, a pall was spread over it, the floor was strewn with sprays of
38462. juniper, a printed band was tucked in under his shriveled head, and in a
38463. corner of the room sat a chanter reading the psalms.
38464. 
38465. Just as horses shy and snort and gather about a dead horse, so the
38466. inmates of the house and strangers crowded into the drawing room round
38467. the coffin--the Marshal, the village Elder, peasant women--and all with
38468. fixed and frightened eyes, crossing themselves, bowed and kissed the old
38469. prince's cold and stiffened hand.
38470. 
38471. 
38472. 
38473. 
38474. 
38475. CHAPTER IX
38476. 
38477. 
38478. Until Prince Andrew settled in Bogucharovo its owners had always been
38479. absentees, and its peasants were of quite a different character from
38480. those of Bald Hills. They differed from them in speech, dress, and
38481. disposition. They were called steppe peasants. The old prince used to
38482. approve of them for their endurance at work when they came to Bald Hills
38483. to help with the harvest or to dig ponds, and ditches, but he disliked
38484. them for their boorishness.
38485. 
38486. Prince Andrew's last stay at Bogucharovo, when he introduced hospitals
38487. and schools and reduced the quitrent the peasants had to pay, had not
38488. softened their disposition but had on the contrary strengthened in
38489. them the traits of character the old prince called boorishness. Various
38490. obscure rumors were always current among them: at one time a rumor that
38491. they would all be enrolled as Cossacks; at another of a new religion to
38492. which they were all to be converted; then of some proclamation of the
38493. Tsar's and of an oath to the Tsar Paul in 1797 (in connection with which
38494. it was rumored that freedom had been granted them but the landowners had
38495. stopped it), then of Peter Fedorovich's return to the throne in seven
38496. years' time, when everything would be made free and so "simple" that
38497. there would be no restrictions. Rumors of the war with Bonaparte and
38498. his invasion were connected in their minds with the same sort of vague
38499. notions of Antichrist, the end of the world, and "pure freedom."
38500. 
38501. In the vicinity of Bogucharovo were large villages belonging to the
38502. crown or to owners whose serfs paid quitrent and could work where they
38503. pleased. There were very few resident landlords in the neighborhood
38504. and also very few domestic or literate serfs, and in the lives of the
38505. peasantry of those parts the mysterious undercurrents in the life of
38506. the Russian people, the causes and meaning of which are so baffling to
38507. contemporaries, were more clearly and strongly noticeable than among
38508. others. One instance, which had occurred some twenty years before, was
38509. a movement among the peasants to emigrate to some unknown "warm rivers."
38510. Hundreds of peasants, among them the Bogucharovo folk, suddenly began
38511. selling their cattle and moving in whole families toward the southeast.
38512. As birds migrate to somewhere beyond the sea, so these men with their
38513. wives and children streamed to the southeast, to parts where none of
38514. them had ever been. They set off in caravans, bought their freedom one
38515. by one or ran away, and drove or walked toward the "warm rivers." Many
38516. of them were punished, some sent to Siberia, many died of cold and
38517. hunger on the road, many returned of their own accord, and the movement
38518. died down of itself just as it had sprung up, without apparent reason.
38519. But such undercurrents still existed among the people and gathered new
38520. forces ready to manifest themselves just as strangely, unexpectedly, and
38521. at the same time simply, naturally, and forcibly. Now in 1812, to anyone
38522. living in close touch with these people it was apparent that these
38523. undercurrents were acting strongly and nearing an eruption.
38524. 
38525. Alpatych, who had reached Bogucharovo shortly before the old prince's
38526. death, noticed an agitation among the peasants, and that contrary to
38527. what was happening in the Bald Hills district, where over a radius of
38528. forty miles all the peasants were moving away and leaving their villages
38529. to be devastated by the Cossacks, the peasants in the steppe region
38530. round Bogucharovo were, it was rumored, in touch with the French,
38531. received leaflets from them that passed from hand to hand, and did not
38532. migrate. He learned from domestic serfs loyal to him that the peasant
38533. Karp, who possessed great influence in the village commune and had
38534. recently been away driving a government transport, had returned with
38535. news that the Cossacks were destroying deserted villages, but that the
38536. French did not harm them. Alpatych also knew that on the previous day
38537. another peasant had even brought from the village of Visloukhovo, which
38538. was occupied by the French, a proclamation by a French general that no
38539. harm would be done to the inhabitants, and if they remained they would
38540. be paid for anything taken from them. As proof of this the peasant had
38541. brought from Visloukhovo a hundred rubles in notes (he did not know that
38542. they were false) paid to him in advance for hay.
38543. 
38544. More important still, Alpatych learned that on the morning of the
38545. very day he gave the village Elder orders to collect carts to move the
38546. princess' luggage from Bogucharovo, there had been a village meeting at
38547. which it had been decided not to move but to wait. Yet there was no
38548. time to waste. On the fifteenth, the day of the old prince's death,
38549. the Marshal had insisted on Princess Mary's leaving at once, as it was
38550. becoming dangerous. He had told her that after the sixteenth he could
38551. not be responsible for what might happen. On the evening of the day the
38552. old prince died the Marshal went away, promising to return next day for
38553. the funeral. But this he was unable to do, for he received tidings that
38554. the French had unexpectedly advanced, and had barely time to remove his
38555. own family and valuables from his estate.
38556. 
38557. For some thirty years Bogucharovo had been managed by the village Elder,
38558. Dron, whom the old prince called by the diminutive "Dronushka."
38559. 
38560. Dron was one of those physically and mentally vigorous peasants who grow
38561. big beards as soon as they are of age and go on unchanged till they
38562. are sixty or seventy, without a gray hair or the loss of a tooth, as
38563. straight and strong at sixty as at thirty.
38564. 
38565. Soon after the migration to the "warm rivers," in which he had taken
38566. part like the rest, Dron was made village Elder and overseer of
38567. Bogucharovo, and had since filled that post irreproachably for
38568. twenty-three years. The peasants feared him more than they did their
38569. master. The masters, both the old prince and the young, and the steward
38570. respected him and jestingly called him "the Minister." During the
38571. whole time of his service Dron had never been drunk or ill, never after
38572. sleepless nights or the hardest tasks had he shown the least fatigue,
38573. and though he could not read he had never forgotten a single money
38574. account or the number of quarters of flour in any of the endless
38575. cartloads he sold for the prince, nor a single shock of the whole corn
38576. crop on any single acre of the Bogucharovo fields.
38577. 
38578. Alpatych, arriving from the devastated Bald Hills estate, sent for his
38579. Dron on the day of the prince's funeral and told him to have twelve
38580. horses got ready for the princess' carriages and eighteen carts for
38581. the things to be removed from Bogucharovo. Though the peasants paid
38582. quitrent, Alpatych thought no difficulty would be made about complying
38583. with this order, for there were two hundred and thirty households at
38584. work in Bogucharovo and the peasants were well to do. But on hearing the
38585. order Dron lowered his eyes and remained silent. Alpatych named certain
38586. peasants he knew, from whom he told him to take the carts.
38587. 
38588. Dron replied that the horses of these peasants were away carting.
38589. Alpatych named others, but they too, according to Dron, had no horses
38590. available: some horses were carting for the government, others were too
38591. weak, and others had died for want of fodder. It seemed that no horses
38592. could be had even for the carriages, much less for the carting.
38593. 
38594. Alpatych looked intently at Dron and frowned. Just as Dron was a model
38595. village Elder, so Alpatych had not managed the prince's estates for
38596. twenty years in vain. He was a model steward, possessing in the highest
38597. degree the faculty of divining the needs and instincts of those he dealt
38598. with. Having glanced at Dron he at once understood that his answers did
38599. not express his personal views but the general mood of the Bogucharovo
38600. commune, by which the Elder had already been carried away. But he also
38601. knew that Dron, who had acquired property and was hated by the commune,
38602. must be hesitating between the two camps: the masters' and the serfs'.
38603. He noticed this hesitation in Dron's look and therefore frowned and
38604. moved closer up to him.
38605. 
38606. "Now just listen, Dronushka," said he. "Don't talk nonsense to me. His
38607. excellency Prince Andrew himself gave me orders to move all the people
38608. away and not leave them with the enemy, and there is an order from the
38609. Tsar about it too. Anyone who stays is a traitor to the Tsar. Do you
38610. hear?"
38611. 
38612. "I hear," Dron answered without lifting his eyes.
38613. 
38614. Alpatych was not satisfied with this reply.
38615. 
38616. "Eh, Dron, it will turn out badly!" he said, shaking his head.
38617. 
38618. "The power is in your hands," Dron rejoined sadly.
38619. 
38620. "Eh, Dron, drop it!" Alpatych repeated, withdrawing his hand from his
38621. bosom and solemnly pointing to the floor at Dron's feet. "I can see
38622. through you and three yards into the ground under you," he continued,
38623. gazing at the floor in front of Dron.
38624. 
38625. Dron was disconcerted, glanced furtively at Alpatych and again lowered
38626. his eyes.
38627. 
38628. "You drop this nonsense and tell the people to get ready to leave their
38629. homes and go to Moscow and to get carts ready for tomorrow morning
38630. for the princess' things. And don't go to any meeting yourself, do you
38631. hear?"
38632. 
38633. Dron suddenly fell on his knees.
38634. 
38635. "Yakov Alpatych, discharge me! Take the keys from me and discharge me,
38636. for Christ's sake!"
38637. 
38638. "Stop that!" cried Alpatych sternly. "I see through you and three yards
38639. under you," he repeated, knowing that his skill in beekeeping, his
38640. knowledge of the right time to sow the oats, and the fact that he had
38641. been able to retain the old prince's favor for twenty years had long
38642. since gained him the reputation of being a wizard, and that the power of
38643. seeing three yards under a man is considered an attribute of wizards.
38644. 
38645. Dron got up and was about to say something, but Alpatych interrupted
38646. him.
38647. 
38648. "What is it you have got into your heads, eh?... What are you thinking
38649. of, eh?"
38650. 
38651. "What am I to do with the people?" said Dron. "They're quite beside
38652. themselves; I have already told them..."
38653. 
38654. "'Told them,' I dare say!" said Alpatych. "Are they drinking?" he asked
38655. abruptly.
38656. 
38657. "Quite beside themselves, Yakov Alpatych; they've fetched another
38658. barrel."
38659. 
38660. "Well, then, listen! I'll go to the police officer, and you tell them
38661. so, and that they must stop this and the carts must be got ready."
38662. 
38663. "I understand."
38664. 
38665. Alpatych did not insist further. He had managed people for a long time
38666. and knew that the chief way to make them obey is to show no suspicion
38667. that they can possibly disobey. Having wrung a submissive "I understand"
38668. from Dron, Alpatych contented himself with that, though he not only
38669. doubted but felt almost certain that without the help of troops the
38670. carts would not be forthcoming.
38671. 
38672. And so it was, for when evening came no carts had been provided. In the
38673. village, outside the drink shop, another meeting was being held, which
38674. decided that the horses should be driven out into the woods and the
38675. carts should not be provided. Without saying anything of this to the
38676. princess, Alpatych had his own belongings taken out of the carts which
38677. had arrived from Bald Hills and had those horses got ready for
38678. the princess' carriages. Meanwhile he went himself to the police
38679. authorities.
38680. 
38681. 
38682. 
38683. 
38684. 
38685. CHAPTER X
38686. 
38687. 
38688. After her father's funeral Princess Mary shut herself up in her room and
38689. did not admit anyone. A maid came to the door to say that Alpatych was
38690. asking for orders about their departure. (This was before his talk with
38691. Dron.) Princess Mary raised herself on the sofa on which she had been
38692. lying and replied through the closed door that she did not mean to go
38693. away and begged to be left in peace.
38694. 
38695. The windows of the room in which she was lying looked westward. She
38696. lay on the sofa with her face to the wall, fingering the buttons of the
38697. leather cushion and seeing nothing but that cushion, and her confused
38698. thoughts were centered on one subject--the irrevocability of death and
38699. her own spiritual baseness, which she had not suspected, but which had
38700. shown itself during her father's illness. She wished to pray but did not
38701. dare to, dared not in her present state of mind address herself to God.
38702. She lay for a long time in that position.
38703. 
38704. The sun had reached the other side of the house, and its slanting rays
38705. shone into the open window, lighting up the room and part of the morocco
38706. cushion at which Princess Mary was looking. The flow of her thoughts
38707. suddenly stopped. Unconsciously she sat up, smoothed her hair, got up,
38708. and went to the window, involuntarily inhaling the freshness of the
38709. clear but windy evening.
38710. 
38711. "Yes, you can well enjoy the evening now! He is gone and no one will
38712. hinder you," she said to herself, and sinking into a chair she let her
38713. head fall on the window sill.
38714. 
38715. Someone spoke her name in a soft and tender voice from the garden and
38716. kissed her head. She looked up. It was Mademoiselle Bourienne in a black
38717. dress and weepers. She softly approached Princess Mary, sighed, kissed
38718. her, and immediately began to cry. The princess looked up at her. All
38719. their former disharmony and her own jealousy recurred to her mind.
38720. But she remembered too how he had changed of late toward Mademoiselle
38721. Bourienne and could not bear to see her, thereby showing how unjust were
38722. the reproaches Princess Mary had mentally addressed to her. "Besides,
38723. is it for me, for me who desired his death, to condemn anyone?" she
38724. thought.
38725. 
38726. Princess Mary vividly pictured to herself the position of Mademoiselle
38727. Bourienne, whom she had of late kept at a distance, but who yet was
38728. dependent on her and living in her house. She felt sorry for her
38729. and held out her hand with a glance of gentle inquiry. Mademoiselle
38730. Bourienne at once began crying again and kissed that hand, speaking of
38731. the princess' sorrow and making herself a partner in it. She said her
38732. only consolation was the fact that the princess allowed her to share her
38733. sorrow, that all the old misunderstandings should sink into nothing but
38734. this great grief; that she felt herself blameless in regard to everyone,
38735. and that he, from above, saw her affection and gratitude. The princess
38736. heard her, not heeding her words but occasionally looking up at her and
38737. listening to the sound of her voice.
38738. 
38739. "Your position is doubly terrible, dear princess," said Mademoiselle
38740. Bourienne after a pause. "I understand that you could not, and cannot,
38741. think of yourself, but with my love for you I must do so.... Has
38742. Alpatych been to you? Has he spoken to you of going away?" she asked.
38743. 
38744. Princess Mary did not answer. She did not understand who was to go or
38745. where to. "Is it possible to plan or think of anything now? Is it not
38746. all the same?" she thought, and did not reply.
38747. 
38748. "You know, chere Marie," said Mademoiselle Bourienne, "that we are in
38749. danger--are surrounded by the French. It would be dangerous to move now.
38750. If we go we are almost sure to be taken prisoners, and God knows..."
38751. 
38752. Princess Mary looked at her companion without understanding what she was
38753. talking about.
38754. 
38755. "Oh, if anyone knew how little anything matters to me now," she said.
38756. "Of course I would on no account wish to go away from him.... Alpatych
38757. did say something about going.... Speak to him; I can do nothing,
38758. nothing, and don't want to...."
38759. 
38760. "I've spoken to him. He hopes we should be in time to get away tomorrow,
38761. but I think it would now be better to stay here," said Mademoiselle
38762. Bourienne. "Because, you will agree, chere Marie, to fall into the hands
38763. of the soldiers or of riotous peasants would be terrible."
38764. 
38765. Mademoiselle Bourienne took from her reticule a proclamation (not
38766. printed on ordinary Russian paper) of General Rameau's, telling people
38767. not to leave their homes and that the French authorities would afford
38768. them proper protection. She handed this to the princess.
38769. 
38770. "I think it would be best to appeal to that general," she continued,
38771. "and I am sure that all due respect would be shown you."
38772. 
38773. Princess Mary read the paper, and her face began to quiver with stifled
38774. sobs.
38775. 
38776. "From whom did you get this?" she asked.
38777. 
38778. "They probably recognized that I am French, by my name," replied
38779. Mademoiselle Bourienne blushing.
38780. 
38781. Princess Mary, with the paper in her hand, rose from the window and with
38782. a pale face went out of the room and into what had been Prince Andrew's
38783. study.
38784. 
38785. "Dunyasha, send Alpatych, or Dronushka, or somebody to me!" she said,
38786. "and tell Mademoiselle Bourienne not to come to me," she added, hearing
38787. Mademoiselle Bourienne's voice. "We must go at once, at once!" she said,
38788. appalled at the thought of being left in the hands of the French.
38789. 
38790. "If Prince Andrew heard that I was in the power of the French! That
38791. I, the daughter of Prince Nicholas Bolkonski, asked General Rameau for
38792. protection and accepted his favor!" This idea horrified her, made her
38793. shudder, blush, and feel such a rush of anger and pride as she had never
38794. experienced before. All that was distressing, and especially all that
38795. was humiliating, in her position rose vividly to her mind. "They, the
38796. French, would settle in this house: M. le General Rameau would occupy
38797. Prince Andrew's study and amuse himself by looking through and reading
38798. his letters and papers. Mademoiselle Bourienne would do the honors of
38799. Bogucharovo for him. I should be given a small room as a favor, the
38800. soldiers would violate my father's newly dug grave to steal his crosses
38801. and stars, they would tell me of their victories over the Russians, and
38802. would pretend to sympathize with my sorrow..." thought Princess Mary,
38803. not thinking her own thoughts but feeling bound to think like her father
38804. and her brother. For herself she did not care where she remained or what
38805. happened to her, but she felt herself the representative of her dead
38806. father and of Prince Andrew. Involuntarily she thought their thoughts
38807. and felt their feelings. What they would have said and what they would
38808. have done she felt bound to say and do. She went into Prince Andrew's
38809. study, trying to enter completely into his ideas, and considered her
38810. position.
38811. 
38812. The demands of life, which had seemed to her annihilated by her father's
38813. death, all at once rose before her with a new, previously unknown force
38814. and took possession of her.
38815. 
38816. Agitated and flushed she paced the room, sending now for Michael
38817. Ivanovich and now for Tikhon or Dron. Dunyasha, the nurse, and the other
38818. maids could not say in how far Mademoiselle Bourienne's statement was
38819. correct. Alpatych was not at home, he had gone to the police. Neither
38820. could the architect Michael Ivanovich, who on being sent for came in
38821. with sleepy eyes, tell Princess Mary anything. With just the same smile
38822. of agreement with which for fifteen years he had been accustomed to
38823. answer the old prince without expressing views of his own, he now
38824. replied to Princess Mary, so that nothing definite could be got from his
38825. answers. The old valet Tikhon, with sunken, emaciated face that bore the
38826. stamp of inconsolable grief, replied: "Yes, Princess" to all Princess
38827. Mary's questions and hardly refrained from sobbing as he looked at her.
38828. 
38829. At length Dron, the village Elder, entered the room and with a deep bow
38830. to Princess Mary came to a halt by the doorpost.
38831. 
38832. Princess Mary walked up and down the room and stopped in front of him.
38833. 
38834. "Dronushka," she said, regarding as a sure friend this Dronushka who
38835. always used to bring a special kind of gingerbread from his visit to the
38836. fair at Vyazma every year and smilingly offer it to her, "Dronushka, now
38837. since our misfortune..." she began, but could not go on.
38838. 
38839. "We are all in God's hands," said he, with a sigh.
38840. 
38841. They were silent for a while.
38842. 
38843. "Dronushka, Alpatych has gone off somewhere and I have no one to turn
38844. to. Is it true, as they tell me, that I can't even go away?"
38845. 
38846. "Why shouldn't you go away, your excellency? You can go," said Dron.
38847. 
38848. "I was told it would be dangerous because of the enemy. Dear friend, I
38849. can do nothing. I understand nothing. I have nobody! I want to go away
38850. tonight or early tomorrow morning."
38851. 
38852. Dron paused. He looked askance at Princess Mary and said: "There are no
38853. horses; I told Yakov Alpatych so."
38854. 
38855. "Why are there none?" asked the princess.
38856. 
38857. "It's all God's scourge," said Dron. "What horses we had have been
38858. taken for the army or have died--this is such a year! It's not a case of
38859. feeding horses--we may die of hunger ourselves! As it is, some go three
38860. days without eating. We've nothing, we've been ruined."
38861. 
38862. Princess Mary listened attentively to what he told her.
38863. 
38864. "The peasants are ruined? They have no bread?" she asked.
38865. 
38866. "They're dying of hunger," said Dron. "It's not a case of carting."
38867. 
38868. "But why didn't you tell me, Dronushka? Isn't it possible to help them?
38869. I'll do all I can...."
38870. 
38871. To Princess Mary it was strange that now, at a moment when such sorrow
38872. was filling her soul, there could be rich people and poor, and the rich
38873. could refrain from helping the poor. She had heard vaguely that there
38874. was such a thing as "landlord's corn" which was sometimes given to the
38875. peasants. She also knew that neither her father nor her brother would
38876. refuse to help the peasants in need, she only feared to make some
38877. mistake in speaking about the distribution of the grain she wished to
38878. give. She was glad such cares presented themselves, enabling her
38879. without scruple to forget her own grief. She began asking Dron about the
38880. peasants' needs and what there was in Bogucharovo that belonged to the
38881. landlord.
38882. 
38883. "But we have grain belonging to my brother?" she said.
38884. 
38885. "The landlord's grain is all safe," replied Dron proudly. "Our prince
38886. did not order it to be sold."
38887. 
38888. "Give it to the peasants, let them have all they need; I give you leave
38889. in my brother's name," said she.
38890. 
38891. Dron made no answer but sighed deeply.
38892. 
38893. "Give them that corn if there is enough of it. Distribute it all. I
38894. give this order in my brother's name; and tell them that what is ours is
38895. theirs. We do not grudge them anything. Tell them so."
38896. 
38897. Dron looked intently at the princess while she was speaking.
38898. 
38899. "Discharge me, little mother, for God's sake! Order the keys to be taken
38900. from me," said he. "I have served twenty-three years and have done no
38901. wrong. Discharge me, for God's sake!"
38902. 
38903. Princess Mary did not understand what he wanted of her or why he was
38904. asking to be discharged. She replied that she had never doubted his
38905. devotion and that she was ready to do anything for him and for the
38906. peasants.
38907. 
38908. 
38909. 
38910. 
38911. 
38912. CHAPTER XI
38913. 
38914. 
38915. An hour later Dunyasha came to tell the princess that Dron had come, and
38916. all the peasants had assembled at the barn by the princess' order and
38917. wished to have word with their mistress.
38918. 
38919. "But I never told them to come," said Princess Mary. "I only told Dron
38920. to let them have the grain."
38921. 
38922. "Only, for God's sake, Princess dear, have them sent away and don't go
38923. out to them. It's all a trick," said Dunyasha, "and when Yakov Alpatych
38924. returns let us get away... and please don't..."
38925. 
38926. "What is a trick?" asked Princess Mary in surprise.
38927. 
38928. "I know it is, only listen to me for God's sake! Ask nurse too. They say
38929. they don't agree to leave Bogucharovo as you ordered."
38930. 
38931. "You're making some mistake. I never ordered them to go away," said
38932. Princess Mary. "Call Dronushka."
38933. 
38934. Dron came and confirmed Dunyasha's words; the peasants had come by the
38935. princess' order.
38936. 
38937. "But I never sent for them," declared the princess. "You must have given
38938. my message wrong. I only said that you were to give them the grain."
38939. 
38940. Dron only sighed in reply.
38941. 
38942. "If you order it they will go away," said he.
38943. 
38944. "No, no. I'll go out to them," said Princess Mary, and in spite of
38945. the nurse's and Dunyasha's protests she went out into the porch; Dron,
38946. Dunyasha, the nurse, and Michael Ivanovich following her.
38947. 
38948. "They probably think I am offering them the grain to bribe them to
38949. remain here, while I myself go away leaving them to the mercy of the
38950. French," thought Princess Mary. "I will offer them monthly rations and
38951. housing at our Moscow estate. I am sure Andrew would do even more in
38952. my place," she thought as she went out in the twilight toward the crowd
38953. standing on the pasture by the barn.
38954. 
38955. The men crowded closer together, stirred, and rapidly took off their
38956. hats. Princess Mary lowered her eyes and, tripping over her skirt, came
38957. close up to them. So many different eyes, old and young, were fixed
38958. on her, and there were so many different faces, that she could not
38959. distinguish any of them and, feeling that she must speak to them all
38960. at once, did not know how to do it. But again the sense that she
38961. represented her father and her brother gave her courage, and she boldly
38962. began her speech.
38963. 
38964. "I am very glad you have come," she said without raising her eyes, and
38965. feeling her heart beating quickly and violently. "Dronushka tells me
38966. that the war has ruined you. That is our common misfortune, and I
38967. shall grudge nothing to help you. I am myself going away because it
38968. is dangerous here... the enemy is near... because... I am giving you
38969. everything, my friends, and I beg you to take everything, all our grain,
38970. so that you may not suffer want! And if you have been told that I
38971. am giving you the grain to keep you here--that is not true. On the
38972. contrary, I ask you to go with all your belongings to our estate near
38973. Moscow, and I promise you I will see to it that there you shall want for
38974. nothing. You shall be given food and lodging."
38975. 
38976. The princess stopped. Sighs were the only sound heard in the crowd.
38977. 
38978. "I am not doing this on my own account," she continued, "I do it in the
38979. name of my dead father, who was a good master to you, and of my brother
38980. and his son."
38981. 
38982. Again she paused. No one broke the silence.
38983. 
38984. "Ours is a common misfortune and we will share it together. All that is
38985. mine is yours," she concluded, scanning the faces before her.
38986. 
38987. All eyes were gazing at her with one and the same expression. She
38988. could not fathom whether it was curiosity, devotion, gratitude, or
38989. apprehension and distrust--but the expression on all the faces was
38990. identical.
38991. 
38992. "We are all very thankful for your bounty, but it won't do for us to
38993. take the landlord's grain," said a voice at the back of the crowd.
38994. 
38995. "But why not?" asked the princess.
38996. 
38997. No one replied and Princess Mary, looking round at the crowd, found that
38998. every eye she met now was immediately dropped.
38999. 
39000. "But why don't you want to take it?" she asked again.
39001. 
39002. No one answered.
39003. 
39004. The silence began to oppress the princess and she tried to catch
39005. someone's eye.
39006. 
39007. "Why don't you speak?" she inquired of a very old man who stood just
39008. in front of her leaning on his stick. "If you think something more is
39009. wanted, tell me! I will do anything," said she, catching his eye.
39010. 
39011. But as if this angered him, he bent his head quite low and muttered:
39012. 
39013. "Why should we agree? We don't want the grain."
39014. 
39015. "Why should we give up everything? We don't agree. Don't agree.... We
39016. are sorry for you, but we're not willing. Go away yourself, alone..."
39017. came from various sides of the crowd.
39018. 
39019. And again all the faces in that crowd bore an identical expression,
39020. though now it was certainly not an expression of curiosity or gratitude,
39021. but of angry resolve.
39022. 
39023. "But you can't have understood me," said Princess Mary with a sad smile.
39024. "Why don't you want to go? I promise to house and feed you, while here
39025. the enemy would ruin you..."
39026. 
39027. But her voice was drowned by the voices of the crowd.
39028. 
39029. "We're not willing. Let them ruin us! We won't take your grain. We don't
39030. agree."
39031. 
39032. Again Princess Mary tried to catch someone's eye, but not a single eye
39033. in the crowd was turned to her; evidently they were all trying to avoid
39034. her look. She felt strange and awkward.
39035. 
39036. "Oh yes, an artful tale! Follow her into slavery! Pull down your houses
39037. and go into bondage! I dare say! 'I'll give you grain, indeed!' she
39038. says," voices in the crowd were heard saying.
39039. 
39040. With drooping head Princess Mary left the crowd and went back to the
39041. house. Having repeated her order to Dron to have horses ready for her
39042. departure next morning, she went to her room and remained alone with her
39043. own thoughts.
39044. 
39045. 
39046. 
39047. 
39048. 
39049. CHAPTER XII
39050. 
39051. 
39052. For a long time that night Princess Mary sat by the open window of her
39053. room hearing the sound of the peasants' voices that reached her from
39054. the village, but it was not of them she was thinking. She felt that she
39055. could not understand them however much she might think about them. She
39056. thought only of one thing, her sorrow, which, after the break caused
39057. by cares for the present, seemed already to belong to the past. Now she
39058. could remember it and weep or pray.
39059. 
39060. After sunset the wind had dropped. The night was calm and fresh. Toward
39061. midnight the voices began to subside, a cock crowed, the full moon began
39062. to show from behind the lime trees, a fresh white dewy mist began to
39063. rise, and stillness reigned over the village and the house.
39064. 
39065. Pictures of the near past--her father's illness and last moments--rose
39066. one after another to her memory. With mournful pleasure she now lingered
39067. over these images, repelling with horror only the last one, the
39068. picture of his death, which she felt she could not contemplate even in
39069. imagination at this still and mystic hour of night. And these pictures
39070. presented themselves to her so clearly and in such detail that they
39071. seemed now present, now past, and now future.
39072. 
39073. She vividly recalled the moment when he had his first stroke and was
39074. being dragged along by his armpits through the garden at Bald Hills,
39075. muttering something with his helpless tongue, twitching his gray
39076. eyebrows and looking uneasily and timidly at her.
39077. 
39078. "Even then he wanted to tell me what he told me the day he died," she
39079. thought. "He had always thought what he said then." And she recalled in
39080. all its detail the night at Bald Hills before he had the last stroke,
39081. when with a foreboding of disaster she had remained at home against his
39082. will. She had not slept and had stolen downstairs on tiptoe, and going
39083. to the door of the conservatory where he slept that night had listened
39084. at the door. In a suffering and weary voice he was saying something to
39085. Tikhon, speaking of the Crimea and its warm nights and of the Empress.
39086. Evidently he had wanted to talk. "And why didn't he call me? Why didn't
39087. he let me be there instead of Tikhon?" Princess Mary had thought and
39088. thought again now. "Now he will never tell anyone what he had in his
39089. soul. Never will that moment return for him or for me when he might have
39090. said all he longed to say, and not Tikhon but I might have heard and
39091. understood him. Why didn't I enter the room?" she thought. "Perhaps he
39092. would then have said to me what he said the day he died. While talking
39093. to Tikhon he asked about me twice. He wanted to see me, and I was
39094. standing close by, outside the door. It was sad and painful for him
39095. to talk to Tikhon who did not understand him. I remember how he began
39096. speaking to him about Lise as if she were alive--he had forgotten she
39097. was dead--and Tikhon reminded him that she was no more, and he shouted,
39098. 'Fool!' He was greatly depressed. From behind the door I heard how he
39099. lay down on his bed groaning and loudly exclaimed, 'My God!' Why didn't
39100. I go in then? What could he have done to me? What could I have lost? And
39101. perhaps he would then have been comforted and would have said that word
39102. to me." And Princess Mary uttered aloud the caressing word he had said
39103. to her on the day of his death. "Dear-est!" she repeated, and began
39104. sobbing, with tears that relieved her soul. She now saw his face before
39105. her. And not the face she had known ever since she could remember and
39106. had always seen at a distance, but the timid, feeble face she had seen
39107. for the first time quite closely, with all its wrinkles and details,
39108. when she stooped near to his mouth to catch what he said.
39109. 
39110. "Dear-est!" she repeated again.
39111. 
39112. "What was he thinking when he uttered that word? What is he thinking
39113. now?" This question suddenly presented itself to her, and in answer she
39114. saw him before her with the expression that was on his face as he lay
39115. in his coffin with his chin bound up with a white handkerchief. And the
39116. horror that had seized her when she touched him and convinced herself
39117. that that was not he, but something mysterious and horrible, seized her
39118. again. She tried to think of something else and to pray, but could do
39119. neither. With wide-open eyes she gazed at the moonlight and the shadows,
39120. expecting every moment to see his dead face, and she felt that the
39121. silence brooding over the house and within it held her fast.
39122. 
39123. "Dunyasha," she whispered. "Dunyasha!" she screamed wildly, and tearing
39124. herself out of this silence she ran to the servants' quarters to meet
39125. her old nurse and the maidservants who came running toward her.
39126. 
39127. 
39128. 
39129. 
39130. 
39131. CHAPTER XIII
39132. 
39133. 
39134. On the seventeenth of August Rostov and Ilyin, accompanied by Lavrushka
39135. who had just returned from captivity and by an hussar orderly, left
39136. their quarters at Yankovo, ten miles from Bogucharovo, and went for a
39137. ride--to try a new horse Ilyin had bought and to find out whether there
39138. was any hay to be had in the villages.
39139. 
39140. For the last three days Bogucharovo had lain between the two hostile
39141. armies, so that it was as easy for the Russian rearguard to get to it as
39142. for the French vanguard; Rostov, as a careful squadron commander, wished
39143. to take such provisions as remained at Bogucharovo before the French
39144. could get them.
39145. 
39146. Rostov and Ilyin were in the merriest of moods. On the way to
39147. Bogucharovo, a princely estate with a dwelling house and farm where
39148. they hoped to find many domestic serfs and pretty girls, they questioned
39149. Lavrushka about Napoleon and laughed at his stories, and raced one
39150. another to try Ilyin's horse.
39151. 
39152. Rostov had no idea that the village he was entering was the property of
39153. that very Bolkonski who had been engaged to his sister.
39154. 
39155. Rostov and Ilyin gave rein to their horses for a last race along the
39156. incline before reaching Bogucharovo, and Rostov, outstripping Ilyin, was
39157. the first to gallop into the village street.
39158. 
39159. "You're first!" cried Ilyin, flushed.
39160. 
39161. "Yes, always first both on the grassland and here," answered Rostov,
39162. stroking his heated Donets horse.
39163. 
39164. "And I'd have won on my Frenchy, your excellency," said Lavrushka
39165. from behind, alluding to his shabby cart horse, "only I didn't wish to
39166. mortify you."
39167. 
39168. They rode at a footpace to the barn, where a large crowd of peasants was
39169. standing.
39170. 
39171. Some of the men bared their heads, others stared at the new arrivals
39172. without doffing their caps. Two tall old peasants with wrinkled faces
39173. and scanty beards emerged from the tavern, smiling, staggering, and
39174. singing some incoherent song, and approached the officers.
39175. 
39176. "Fine fellows!" said Rostov laughing. "Is there any hay here?"
39177. 
39178. "And how like one another," said Ilyin.
39179. 
39180. "A mo-o-st me-r-r-y co-o-m-pa...!" sang one of the peasants with a
39181. blissful smile.
39182. 
39183. One of the men came out of the crowd and went up to Rostov.
39184. 
39185. "Who do you belong to?" he asked.
39186. 
39187. "The French," replied Ilyin jestingly, "and here is Napoleon
39188. himself"--and he pointed to Lavrushka.
39189. 
39190. "Then you are Russians?" the peasant asked again.
39191. 
39192. "And is there a large force of you here?" said another, a short man,
39193. coming up.
39194. 
39195. "Very large," answered Rostov. "But why have you collected here?" he
39196. added. "Is it a holiday?"
39197. 
39198. "The old men have met to talk over the business of the commune," replied
39199. the peasant, moving away.
39200. 
39201. At that moment, on the road leading from the big house, two women and a
39202. man in a white hat were seen coming toward the officers.
39203. 
39204. "The one in pink is mine, so keep off!" said Ilyin on seeing Dunyasha
39205. running resolutely toward him.
39206. 
39207. "She'll be ours!" said Lavrushka to Ilyin, winking.
39208. 
39209. "What do you want, my pretty?" said Ilyin with a smile.
39210. 
39211. "The princess ordered me to ask your regiment and your name."
39212. 
39213. "This is Count Rostov, squadron commander, and I am your humble
39214. servant."
39215. 
39216. "Co-o-om-pa-ny!" roared the tipsy peasant with a beatific smile as
39217. he looked at Ilyin talking to the girl. Following Dunyasha, Alpatych
39218. advanced to Rostov, having bared his head while still at a distance.
39219. 
39220. "May I make bold to trouble your honor?" said he respectfully, but with
39221. a shade of contempt for the youthfulness of this officer and with a hand
39222. thrust into his bosom. "My mistress, daughter of General in Chief Prince
39223. Nicholas Bolkonski who died on the fifteenth of this month, finding
39224. herself in difficulties owing to the boorishness of these people"--he
39225. pointed to the peasants--"asks you to come up to the house.... Won't
39226. you, please, ride on a little farther," said Alpatych with a melancholy
39227. smile, "as it is not convenient in the presence of...?" He pointed to
39228. the two peasants who kept as close to him as horseflies to a horse.
39229. 
39230. "Ah!... Alpatych... Ah, Yakov Alpatych... Grand! Forgive us for Christ's
39231. sake, eh?" said the peasants, smiling joyfully at him.
39232. 
39233. Rostov looked at the tipsy peasants and smiled.
39234. 
39235. "Or perhaps they amuse your honor?" remarked Alpatych with a staid air,
39236. as he pointed at the old men with his free hand.
39237. 
39238. "No, there's not much to be amused at here," said Rostov, and rode on a
39239. little way. "What's the matter?" he asked.
39240. 
39241. "I make bold to inform your honor that the rude peasants here don't
39242. wish to let the mistress leave the estate, and threaten to unharness her
39243. horses, so that though everything has been packed up since morning, her
39244. excellency cannot get away."
39245. 
39246. "Impossible!" exclaimed Rostov.
39247. 
39248. "I have the honor to report to you the actual truth," said Alpatych.
39249. 
39250. Rostov dismounted, gave his horse to the orderly, and followed Alpatych
39251. to the house, questioning him as to the state of affairs. It appeared
39252. that the princess' offer of corn to the peasants the previous day, and
39253. her talk with Dron and at the meeting, had actually had so bad an effect
39254. that Dron had finally given up the keys and joined the peasants and had
39255. not appeared when Alpatych sent for him; and that in the morning when
39256. the princess gave orders to harness for her journey, the peasants had
39257. come in a large crowd to the barn and sent word that they would not let
39258. her leave the village: that there was an order not to move, and that
39259. they would unharness the horses. Alpatych had gone out to admonish them,
39260. but was told (it was chiefly Karp who did the talking, Dron not showing
39261. himself in the crowd) that they could not let the princess go, that
39262. there was an order to the contrary, but that if she stayed they would
39263. serve her as before and obey her in everything.
39264. 
39265. At the moment when Rostov and Ilyin were galloping along the road,
39266. Princess Mary, despite the dissuasions of Alpatych, her nurse, and the
39267. maids, had given orders to harness and intended to start, but when the
39268. cavalrymen were espied they were taken for Frenchmen, the coachman ran
39269. away, and the women in the house began to wail.
39270. 
39271. "Father! Benefactor! God has sent you!" exclaimed deeply moved voices as
39272. Rostov passed through the anteroom.
39273. 
39274. Princess Mary was sitting helpless and bewildered in the large sitting
39275. room, when Rostov was shown in. She could not grasp who he was and why
39276. he had come, or what was happening to her. When she saw his Russian
39277. face, and by his walk and the first words he uttered recognized him as a
39278. man of her own class, she glanced at him with her deep radiant look and
39279. began speaking in a voice that faltered and trembled with emotion. This
39280. meeting immediately struck Rostov as a romantic event. "A helpless girl
39281. overwhelmed with grief, left to the mercy of coarse, rioting peasants!
39282. And what a strange fate sent me here! What gentleness and nobility there
39283. are in her features and expression!" thought he as he looked at her and
39284. listened to her timid story.
39285. 
39286. When she began to tell him that all this had happened the day after her
39287. father's funeral, her voiced trembled. She turned away, and then, as if
39288. fearing he might take her words as meant to move him to pity, looked at
39289. him with an apprehensive glance of inquiry. There were tears in Rostov's
39290. eyes. Princess Mary noticed this and glanced gratefully at him with that
39291. radiant look which caused the plainness of her face to be forgotten.
39292. 
39293. "I cannot express, Princess, how glad I am that I happened to ride here
39294. and am able to show my readiness to serve you," said Rostov, rising. "Go
39295. when you please, and I give you my word of honor that no one shall dare
39296. to cause you annoyance if only you will allow me to act as your escort."
39297. And bowing respectfully, as if to a lady of royal blood, he moved toward
39298. the door.
39299. 
39300. Rostov's deferential tone seemed to indicate that though he would
39301. consider himself happy to be acquainted with her, he did not wish to
39302. take advantage of her misfortunes to intrude upon her.
39303. 
39304. Princess Mary understood this and appreciated his delicacy.
39305. 
39306. "I am very, very grateful to you," she said in French, "but I hope it
39307. was all a misunderstanding and that no one is to blame for it." She
39308. suddenly began to cry.
39309. 
39310. "Excuse me!" she said.
39311. 
39312. Rostov, knitting his brows, left the room with another low bow.
39313. 
39314. 
39315. 
39316. 
39317. 
39318. CHAPTER XIV
39319. 
39320. 
39321. "Well, is she pretty? Ah, friend--my pink one is delicious; her name is
39322. Dunyasha...."
39323. 
39324. But on glancing at Rostov's face Ilyin stopped short. He saw that his
39325. hero and commander was following quite a different train of thought.
39326. 
39327. Rostov glanced angrily at Ilyin and without replying strode off with
39328. rapid steps to the village.
39329. 
39330. "I'll show them; I'll give it to them, the brigands!" said he to
39331. himself.
39332. 
39333. Alpatych at a gliding trot, only just managing not to run, kept up with
39334. him with difficulty.
39335. 
39336. "What decision have you been pleased to come to?" said he.
39337. 
39338. Rostov stopped and, clenching his fists, suddenly and sternly turned on
39339. Alpatych.
39340. 
39341. "Decision? What decision? Old dotard!..." cried he. "What have you been
39342. about? Eh? The peasants are rioting, and you can't manage them? You're
39343. a traitor yourself! I know you. I'll flay you all alive!..." And as if
39344. afraid of wasting his store of anger, he left Alpatych and went rapidly
39345. forward. Alpatych, mastering his offended feelings, kept pace with
39346. Rostov at a gliding gait and continued to impart his views. He said
39347. the peasants were obdurate and that at the present moment it would be
39348. imprudent to "overresist" them without an armed force, and would it not
39349. be better first to send for the military?
39350. 
39351. "I'll give them armed force... I'll 'overresist' them!" uttered Rostov
39352. meaninglessly, breathless with irrational animal fury and the need to
39353. vent it.
39354. 
39355. Without considering what he would do he moved unconciously with quick,
39356. resolute steps toward the crowd. And the nearer he drew to it the more
39357. Alpatych felt that this unreasonable action might produce good results.
39358. The peasants in the crowd were similarly impressed when they saw
39359. Rostov's rapid, firm steps and resolute, frowning face.
39360. 
39361. After the hussars had come to the village and Rostov had gone to see the
39362. princess, a certain confusion and dissension had arisen among the crowd.
39363. Some of the peasants said that these new arrivals were Russians and
39364. might take it amiss that the mistress was being detained. Dron was of
39365. this opinion, but as soon as he expressed it Karp and others attacked
39366. their ex-Elder.
39367. 
39368. "How many years have you been fattening on the commune?" Karp shouted at
39369. him. "It's all one to you! You'll dig up your pot of money and take
39370. it away with you.... What does it matter to you whether our homes are
39371. ruined or not?"
39372. 
39373. "We've been told to keep order, and that no one is to leave their homes
39374. or take away a single grain, and that's all about it!" cried another.
39375. 
39376. "It was your son's turn to be conscripted, but no fear! You begrudged
39377. your lump of a son," a little old man suddenly began attacking
39378. Dron--"and so they took my Vanka to be shaved for a soldier! But we all
39379. have to die."
39380. 
39381. "To be sure, we all have to die. I'm not against the commune," said
39382. Dron.
39383. 
39384. "That's it--not against it! You've filled your belly...."
39385. 
39386. The two tall peasants had their say. As soon as Rostov, followed by
39387. Ilyin, Lavrushka, and Alpatych, came up to the crowd, Karp, thrusting
39388. his fingers into his belt and smiling a little, walked to the front.
39389. Dron on the contrary retired to the rear and the crowd drew closer
39390. together.
39391. 
39392. "Who is your Elder here? Hey?" shouted Rostov, coming up to the crowd
39393. with quick steps.
39394. 
39395. "The Elder? What do you want with him?..." asked Karp.
39396. 
39397. But before the words were well out of his mouth, his cap flew off and a
39398. fierce blow jerked his head to one side.
39399. 
39400. "Caps off, traitors!" shouted Rostov in a wrathful voice. "Where's the
39401. Elder?" he cried furiously.
39402. 
39403. "The Elder.... He wants the Elder!... Dron Zakharych, you!" meek and
39404. flustered voices here and there were heard calling and caps began to
39405. come off their heads.
39406. 
39407. "We don't riot, we're following the orders," declared Karp, and at that
39408. moment several voices began speaking together.
39409. 
39410. "It's as the old men have decided--there's too many of you giving
39411. orders."
39412. 
39413. "Arguing? Mutiny!... Brigands! Traitors!" cried Rostov unmeaningly in a
39414. voice not his own, gripping Karp by the collar. "Bind him, bind him!" he
39415. shouted, though there was no one to bind him but Lavrushka and Alpatych.
39416. 
39417. Lavrushka, however, ran up to Karp and seized him by the arms from
39418. behind.
39419. 
39420. "Shall I call up our men from beyond the hill?" he called out.
39421. 
39422. Alpatych turned to the peasants and ordered two of them by name to come
39423. and bind Karp. The men obediently came out of the crowd and began taking
39424. off their belts.
39425. 
39426. "Where's the Elder?" demanded Rostov in a loud voice.
39427. 
39428. With a pale and frowning face Dron stepped out of the crowd.
39429. 
39430. "Are you the Elder? Bind him, Lavrushka!" shouted Rostov, as if that
39431. order, too, could not possibly meet with any opposition.
39432. 
39433. And in fact two more peasants began binding Dron, who took off his own
39434. belt and handed it to them, as if to aid them.
39435. 
39436. "And you all listen to me!" said Rostov to the peasants. "Be off to your
39437. houses at once, and don't let one of your voices be heard!"
39438. 
39439. "Why, we've not done any harm! We did it just out of foolishness. It's
39440. all nonsense... I said then that it was not in order," voices were heard
39441. bickering with one another.
39442. 
39443. "There! What did I say?" said Alpatych, coming into his own again. "It's
39444. wrong, lads!"
39445. 
39446.  "All our stupidity, Yakov Alpatych," came the answers, and the
39447. crowd began at once to disperse through the village.
39448. 
39449. The two bound men were led off to the master's house. The two drunken
39450. peasants followed them.
39451. 
39452. "Aye, when I look at you!..." said one of them to Karp.
39453. 
39454. "How can one talk to the masters like that? What were you thinking of,
39455. you fool?" added the other--"A real fool!"
39456. 
39457. Two hours later the carts were standing in the courtyard of the
39458. Bogucharovo house. The peasants were briskly carrying out the
39459. proprietor's goods and packing them on the carts, and Dron, liberated at
39460. Princess Mary's wish from the cupboard where he had been confined, was
39461. standing in the yard directing the men.
39462. 
39463. "Don't put it in so carelessly," said one of the peasants, a man with a
39464. round smiling face, taking a casket from a housemaid. "You know it has
39465. cost money! How can you chuck it in like that or shove it under the cord
39466. where it'll get rubbed? I don't like that way of doing things. Let it
39467. all be done properly, according to rule. Look here, put it under the
39468. bast matting and cover it with hay--that's the way!"
39469. 
39470. "Eh, books, books!" said another peasant, bringing out Prince Andrew's
39471. library cupboards. "Don't catch up against it! It's heavy, lads--solid
39472. books."
39473. 
39474. "Yes, they worked all day and didn't play!" remarked the tall,
39475. round-faced peasant gravely, pointing with a significant wink at the
39476. dictionaries that were on the top.
39477. 
39478. 
39479. Unwilling to obtrude himself on the princess, Rostov did not go back to
39480. the house but remained in the village awaiting her departure. When her
39481. carriage drove out of the house, he mounted and accompanied her eight
39482. miles from Bogucharovo to where the road was occupied by our troops. At
39483. the inn at Yankovo he respectfully took leave of her, for the first time
39484. permitting himself to kiss her hand.
39485. 
39486. "How can you speak so!" he blushingly replied to Princess Mary's
39487. expressions of gratitude for her deliverance, as she termed what had
39488. occurred. "Any police officer would have done as much! If we had had
39489. only peasants to fight, we should not have let the enemy come so far,"
39490. said he with a sense of shame and wishing to change the subject. "I
39491. am only happy to have had the opportunity of making your acquaintance.
39492. Good-by, Princess. I wish you happiness and consolation and hope to meet
39493. you again in happier circumstances. If you don't want to make me blush,
39494. please don't thank me!"
39495. 
39496. But the princess, if she did not again thank him in words, thanked
39497. him with the whole expression of her face, radiant with gratitude and
39498. tenderness. She could not believe that there was nothing to thank him
39499. for. On the contrary, it seemed to her certain that had he not been
39500. there she would have perished at the hands of the mutineers and of the
39501. French, and that he had exposed himself to terrible and obvious danger
39502. to save her, and even more certain was it that he was a man of lofty and
39503. noble soul, able to understand her position and her sorrow. His kind,
39504. honest eyes, with the tears rising in them when she herself had begun to
39505. cry as she spoke of her loss, did not leave her memory.
39506. 
39507. When she had taken leave of him and remained alone she suddenly felt
39508. her eyes filling with tears, and then not for the first time the strange
39509. question presented itself to her: did she love him?
39510. 
39511. On the rest of the way to Moscow, though the princess' position was not
39512. a cheerful one, Dunyasha, who went with her in the carriage, more than
39513. once noticed that her mistress leaned out of the window and smiled at
39514. something with an expression of mingled joy and sorrow.
39515. 
39516. "Well, supposing I do love him?" thought Princess Mary.
39517. 
39518. Ashamed as she was of acknowledging to herself that she had fallen in
39519. love with a man who would perhaps never love her, she comforted herself
39520. with the thought that no one would ever know it and that she would not
39521. be to blame if, without ever speaking of it to anyone, she continued to
39522. the end of her life to love the man with whom she had fallen in love for
39523. the first and last time in her life.
39524. 
39525. Sometimes when she recalled his looks, his sympathy, and his words,
39526. happiness did not appear impossible to her. It was at those moments that
39527. Dunyasha noticed her smiling as she looked out of the carriage window.
39528. 
39529. "Was it not fate that brought him to Bogucharovo, and at that very
39530. moment?" thought Princess Mary. "And that caused his sister to refuse my
39531. brother?" And in all this Princess Mary saw the hand of Providence.
39532. 
39533. The impression the princess made on Rostov was a very agreeable one. To
39534. remember her gave him pleasure, and when his comrades, hearing of his
39535. adventure at Bogucharovo, rallied him on having gone to look for hay
39536. and having picked up one of the wealthiest heiresses in Russia, he grew
39537. angry. It made him angry just because the idea of marrying the gentle
39538. Princess Mary, who was attractive to him and had an enormous fortune,
39539. had against his will more than once entered his head. For himself
39540. personally Nicholas could not wish for a better wife: by marrying her
39541. he would make the countess his mother happy, would be able to put his
39542. father's affairs in order, and would even--he felt it--ensure Princess
39543. Mary's happiness.
39544. 
39545. But Sonya? And his plighted word? That was why Rostov grew angry when he
39546. was rallied about Princess Bolkonskaya.
39547. 
39548. 
39549. 
39550. 
39551. 
39552. CHAPTER XV
39553. 
39554. 
39555. On receiving command of the armies Kutuzov remembered Prince Andrew and
39556. sent an order for him to report at headquarters.
39557. 
39558. Prince Andrew arrived at Tsarevo-Zaymishche on the very day and at the
39559. very hour that Kutuzov was reviewing the troops for the first time. He
39560. stopped in the village at the priest's house in front of which stood the
39561. commander in chief's carriage, and he sat down on the bench at the gate
39562. awaiting his Serene Highness, as everyone now called Kutuzov. From the
39563. field beyond the village came now sounds of regimental music and now the
39564. roar of many voices shouting "Hurrah!" to the new commander in chief.
39565. Two orderlies, a courier and a major-domo, stood near by, some ten paces
39566. from Prince Andrew, availing themselves of Kutuzov's absence and of the
39567. fine weather. A short, swarthy lieutenant colonel of hussars with thick
39568. mustaches and whiskers rode up to the gate and, glancing at Prince
39569. Andrew, inquired whether his Serene Highness was putting up there and
39570. whether he would soon be back.
39571. 
39572. Prince Andrew replied that he was not on his Serene Highness' staff
39573. but was himself a new arrival. The lieutenant colonel turned to a smart
39574. orderly, who, with the peculiar contempt with which a commander in
39575. chief's orderly speaks to officers, replied:
39576. 
39577. "What? His Serene Highness? I expect he'll be here soon. What do you
39578. want?"
39579. 
39580. The lieutenant colonel of hussars smiled beneath his mustache at the
39581. orderly's tone, dismounted, gave his horse to a dispatch runner, and
39582. approached Bolkonski with a slight bow. Bolkonski made room for him on
39583. the bench and the lieutenant colonel sat down beside him.
39584. 
39585. "You're also waiting for the commander in chief?" said he. "They say he
39586. weceives evewyone, thank God!... It's awful with those sausage eaters!
39587. Ermolov had weason to ask to be pwomoted to be a German! Now p'waps
39588. Wussians will get a look in. As it was, devil only knows what was
39589. happening. We kept wetweating and wetweating. Did you take part in the
39590. campaign?" he asked.
39591. 
39592. "I had the pleasure," replied Prince Andrew, "not only of taking part
39593. in the retreat but of losing in that retreat all I held dear--not to
39594. mention the estate and home of my birth--my father, who died of grief. I
39595. belong to the province of Smolensk."
39596. 
39597. "Ah? You're Pwince Bolkonski? Vewy glad to make your acquaintance! I'm
39598. Lieutenant Colonel Denisov, better known as 'Vaska,'" said Denisov,
39599. pressing Prince Andrew's hand and looking into his face with a
39600. particularly kindly attention. "Yes, I heard," said he sympathetically,
39601. and after a short pause added: "Yes, it's Scythian warfare. It's all
39602. vewy well--only not for those who get it in the neck. So you are Pwince
39603. Andwew Bolkonski?" He swayed his head. "Vewy pleased, Pwince, to make
39604. your acquaintance!" he repeated again, smiling sadly, and he again
39605. pressed Prince Andrew's hand.
39606. 
39607. Prince Andrew knew Denisov from what Natasha had told him of her first
39608. suitor. This memory carried him sadly and sweetly back to those painful
39609. feelings of which he had not thought lately, but which still found
39610. place in his soul. Of late he had received so many new and very serious
39611. impressions--such as the retreat from Smolensk, his visit to Bald Hills,
39612. and the recent news of his father's death--and had experienced so many
39613. emotions, that for a long time past those memories had not entered his
39614. mind, and now that they did, they did not act on him with nearly their
39615. former strength. For Denisov, too, the memories awakened by the name of
39616. Bolkonski belonged to a distant, romantic past, when after supper and
39617. after Natasha's singing he had proposed to a little girl of fifteen
39618. without realizing what he was doing. He smiled at the recollection of
39619. that time and of his love for Natasha, and passed at once to what now
39620. interested him passionately and exclusively. This was a plan of campaign
39621. he had devised while serving at the outposts during the retreat. He had
39622. proposed that plan to Barclay de Tolly and now wished to propose it
39623. to Kutuzov. The plan was based on the fact that the French line
39624. of operation was too extended, and it proposed that instead of, or
39625. concurrently with, action on the front to bar the advance of the French,
39626. we should attack their line of communication. He began explaining his
39627. plan to Prince Andrew.
39628. 
39629. "They can't hold all that line. It's impossible. I will undertake to
39630. bweak thwough. Give me five hundwed men and I will bweak the line,
39631. that's certain! There's only one way--guewilla warfare!"
39632. 
39633. Denisov rose and began gesticulating as he explained his plan to
39634. Bolkonski. In the midst of his explanation shouts were heard from the
39635. army, growing more incoherent and more diffused, mingling with music
39636. and songs and coming from the field where the review was held. Sounds of
39637. hoofs and shouts were nearing the village.
39638. 
39639. "He's coming! He's coming!" shouted a Cossack standing at the gate.
39640. 
39641. Bolkonski and Denisov moved to the gate, at which a knot of soldiers
39642. (a guard of honor) was standing, and they saw Kutuzov coming down the
39643. street mounted on a rather small sorrel horse. A huge suite of generals
39644. rode behind him. Barclay was riding almost beside him, and a crowd of
39645. officers ran after and around them shouting, "Hurrah!"
39646. 
39647. His adjutants galloped into the yard before him. Kutuzov was impatiently
39648. urging on his horse, which ambled smoothly under his weight, and he
39649. raised his hand to his white Horse Guard's cap with a red band and no
39650. peak, nodding his head continually. When he came up to the guard of
39651. honor, a fine set of Grenadiers mostly wearing decorations, who were
39652. giving him the salute, he looked at them silently and attentively for
39653. nearly a minute with the steady gaze of a commander and then turned to
39654. the crowd of generals and officers surrounding him. Suddenly his face
39655. assumed a subtle expression, he shrugged his shoulders with an air of
39656. perplexity.
39657. 
39658. "And with such fine fellows to retreat and retreat! Well, good-by,
39659. General," he added, and rode into the yard past Prince Andrew and
39660. Denisov.
39661. 
39662. "Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah!" shouted those behind him.
39663. 
39664. Since Prince Andrew had last seen him Kutuzov had grown still more
39665. corpulent, flaccid, and fat. But the bleached eyeball, the scar, and the
39666. familiar weariness of his expression were still the same. He was wearing
39667. the white Horse Guard's cap and a military overcoat with a whip hanging
39668. over his shoulder by a thin strap. He sat heavily and swayed limply on
39669. his brisk little horse.
39670. 
39671. "Whew... whew... whew!" he whistled just audibly as he rode into the
39672. yard. His face expressed the relief of relaxed strain felt by a man who
39673. means to rest after a ceremony. He drew his left foot out of the stirrup
39674. and, lurching with his whole body and puckering his face with the
39675. effort, raised it with difficulty onto the saddle, leaned on his knee,
39676. groaned, and slipped down into the arms of the Cossacks and adjutants
39677. who stood ready to assist him.
39678. 
39679. He pulled himself together, looked round, screwing up his eyes, glanced
39680. at Prince Andrew, and, evidently not recognizing him, moved with his
39681. waddling gait to the porch. "Whew... whew... whew!" he whistled, and
39682. again glanced at Prince Andrew. As often occurs with old men, it was
39683. only after some seconds that the impression produced by Prince Andrew's
39684. face linked itself up with Kutuzov's remembrance of his personality.
39685. 
39686. "Ah, how do you do, my dear prince? How do you do, my dear boy? Come
39687. along..." said he, glancing wearily round, and he stepped onto the porch
39688. which creaked under his weight.
39689. 
39690. He unbuttoned his coat and sat down on a bench in the porch.
39691. 
39692. "And how's your father?"
39693. 
39694. "I received news of his death, yesterday," replied Prince Andrew
39695. abruptly.
39696. 
39697. Kutuzov looked at him with eyes wide open with dismay and then took off
39698. his cap and crossed himself:
39699. 
39700. "May the kingdom of Heaven be his! God's will be done to us all!" He
39701. sighed deeply, his whole chest heaving, and was silent for a while. "I
39702. loved him and respected him, and sympathize with you with all my heart."
39703. 
39704. He embraced Prince Andrew, pressing him to his fat breast, and for some
39705. time did not let him go. When he released him Prince Andrew saw that
39706. Kutuzov's flabby lips were trembling and that tears were in his eyes. He
39707. sighed and pressed on the bench with both hands to raise himself.
39708. 
39709. "Come! Come with me, we'll have a talk," said he.
39710. 
39711. But at that moment Denisov, no more intimidated by his superiors than by
39712. the enemy, came with jingling spurs up the steps of the porch, despite
39713. the angry whispers of the adjutants who tried to stop him. Kutuzov, his
39714. hands still pressed on the seat, glanced at him glumly. Denisov, having
39715. given his name, announced that he had to communicate to his Serene
39716. Highness a matter of great importance for their country's welfare.
39717. Kutuzov looked wearily at him and, lifting his hands with a gesture of
39718. annoyance, folded them across his stomach, repeating the words: "For our
39719. country's welfare? Well, what is it? Speak!" Denisov blushed like a
39720. girl (it was strange to see the color rise in that shaggy, bibulous,
39721. time-worn face) and boldly began to expound his plan of cutting the
39722. enemy's lines of communication between Smolensk and Vyazma. Denisov came
39723. from those parts and knew the country well. His plan seemed decidedly
