39724. a good one, especially from the strength of conviction with which he
39725. spoke. Kutuzov looked down at his own legs, occasionally glancing at the
39726. door of the adjoining hut as if expecting something unpleasant to emerge
39727. from it. And from that hut, while Denisov was speaking, a general with a
39728. portfolio under his arm really did appear.
39729. 
39730. "What?" said Kutuzov, in the midst of Denisov's explanations, "are you
39731. ready so soon?"
39732. 
39733. "Ready, your Serene Highness," replied the general.
39734. 
39735. Kutuzov swayed his head, as much as to say: "How is one man to deal with
39736. it all?" and again listened to Denisov.

39739. can bweak Napoleon's line of communication!"

39743.

39754. papers have to be signed."

39758. was disengaged. He made a grimace...

39763. 
39764. While this was being given, Prince Andrew heard the whisper of a woman's
39765. voice and the rustle of a silk dress behind the door. Several times on
39766. glancing that way he noticed behind that door a plump, rosy, handsome
39767. woman in a pink dress with a lilac silk kerchief on her head, holding
39768. a dish and evidently awaiting the entrance of the commander in chief.

39770. the priest whose home it was, and that she intended to offer his Serene
39771. Highness bread and salt. "Her husband has welcomed his Serene Highness
39772. with the cross at the church, and she intends to welcome him in the
39773. house.... She's very pretty," added the adjutant with a smile. At
39774. those words Kutuzov looked round. He was listening to the general's
39775. report--which consisted chiefly of a criticism of the position at
39776. Tsarevo-Zaymishche--as he had listened to Denisov, and seven years
39777. previously had listened to the discussion at the Austerlitz council of
39778. war. He evidently listened only because he had ears which, though there
39779. was a piece of tow in one of them, could not help hearing; but it
39780. was evident that nothing the general could say would surprise or even
39781. interest him, that he knew all that would be said beforehand, and heard
39782. it all only because he had to, as one has to listen to the chanting of
39783. a service of prayer. All that Denisov had said was clever and to the
39784. point. What the general was saying was even more clever and to
39785. the point, but it was evident that Kutuzov despised knowledge
39786. and cleverness, and knew of something else that would decide the
39787. matter--something independent of cleverness and knowledge. Prince

39789. expression he could see there was one of boredom, curiosity as to the
39790. meaning of the feminine whispering behind the door, and a desire to
39791. observe propriety. It was evident that Kutuzov despised cleverness and
39792. learning and even the patriotic feeling shown by Denisov, but despised
39793. them not because of his own intellect, feelings, or knowledge--he did
39794. not try to display any of these--but because of something else. He
39795. despised them because of his old age and experience of life. The only
39796. instruction Kutuzov gave of his own accord during that report referred
39797. to looting by the Russian troops. At the end of the report the general
39798. put before him for signature a paper relating to the recovery of payment
39799. from army commanders for green oats mown down by the soldiers, when
39800. landowners lodged petitions for compensation.
39801. 
39802. After hearing the matter, Kutuzov smacked his lips together and shook
39803. his head.
39804. 
39805. "Into the stove... into the fire with it! I tell you once for all, my
39806. dear fellow," said he, "into the fire with all such things! Let them cut
39807. the crops and burn wood to their hearts' content. I don't order it
39808. or allow it, but I don't exact compensation either. One can't get on
39809. without it. 'When wood is chopped the chips will fly.'" He looked at the
39810. paper again. "Oh, this German precision!" he muttered, shaking his head.

39841.

39853. agitating conversation, and added: "I sent for you to keep you with me."

39933. 
39934. Prince Andrew could not have explained how or why it was, but after that
39935. interview with Kutuzov he went back to his regiment reassured as to
39936. the general course of affairs and as to the man to whom it had been
39937. entrusted. The more he realized the absence of all personal motive in
39938. that old man--in whom there seemed to remain only the habit of passions,
39939. and in place of an intellect (grouping events and drawing conclusions)
39940. only the capacity calmly to contemplate the course of events--the more
39941. reassured he was that everything would be as it should. "He will not
39942. bring in any plan of his own. He will not devise or undertake
39943. anything," thought Prince Andrew, "but he will hear everything, remember
39944. everything, and put everything in its place. He will not hinder
39945. anything useful nor allow anything harmful. He understands that there is
39946. something stronger and more important than his own will--the inevitable
39947. course of events, and he can see them and grasp their significance,
39948. and seeing that significance can refrain from meddling and renounce his
39949. personal wish directed to something else. And above all," thought Prince
39950. Andrew, "one believes in him because he's Russian, despite the novel
39951. by Genlis and the French proverbs, and because his voice shook when he
39952. said: 'What they have brought us to!' and had a sob in it when he said
39953. he would 'make them eat horseflesh!'"
39954. 
39955. On such feelings, more or less dimly shared by all, the unanimity and
39956. general approval were founded with which, despite court influences, the
39957. popular choice of Kutuzov as commander in chief was received.

39963. CHAPTER XVII
39964. 
39965. 
39966. After the Emperor had left Moscow, life flowed on there in its usual
39967. course, and its course was so very usual that it was difficult to
39968. remember the recent days of patriotic elation and ardor, hard to believe
39969. that Russia was really in danger and that the members of the English
39970. Club were also sons of the Fatherland ready to sacrifice everything
39971. for it. The one thing that recalled the patriotic fervor everyone had
39972. displayed during the Emperor's stay was the call for contributions of
39973. men and money, a necessity that as soon as the promises had been made
39974. assumed a legal, official form and became unavoidable.
39975. 
39976. With the enemy's approach to Moscow, the Moscovites' view of their
39977. situation did not grow more serious but on the contrary became even
39978. more frivolous, as always happens with people who see a great danger
39979. approaching. At the approach of danger there are always two voices that
39980. speak with equal power in the human soul: one very reasonably tells a
39981. man to consider the nature of the danger and the means of escaping it;
39982. the other, still more reasonably, says that it is too depressing and
39983. painful to think of the danger, since it is not in man's power to
39984. foresee everything and avert the general course of events, and it is
39985. therefore better to disregard what is painful till it comes, and to
39986. think about what is pleasant. In solitude a man generally listens to
39987. the first voice, but in society to the second. So it was now with the
39988. inhabitants of Moscow. It was long since people had been as gay in
39989. Moscow as that year.
39990. 
39991. Rostopchin's broadsheets, headed by woodcuts of a drink shop, a potman,
39992. and a Moscow burgher called Karpushka Chigirin, "who--having been
39993. a militiaman and having had rather too much at the pub--heard that
39994. Napoleon wished to come to Moscow, grew angry, abused the French in very
39995. bad language, came out of the drink shop, and, under the sign of the
39996. eagle, began to address the assembled people," were read and discussed,
39997. together with the latest of Vasili Lvovich Pushkin's bouts rimes.
39998. 
39999. In the corner room at the Club, members gathered to read these

40001. saying: "They will swell up with Russian cabbage, burst with our
40002. buckwheat porridge, and choke themselves with cabbage soup. They are all
40003. dwarfs and one peasant woman will toss three of them with a hayfork."

40007. among them; but this was told chiefly to introduce Rostopchin's witty

40186. CHAPTER XVIII

40189. When Pierre returned home he was handed two of Rostopchin's broadsheets

40191. 
40192. The first declared that the report that Count Rostopchin had forbidden
40193. people to leave Moscow was false; on the contrary he was glad that

40203. Chigirin talks. Pierre pondered over these broadsheets. Evidently the
40204. terrible stormcloud he had desired with the whole strength of his soul
40205. but which yet aroused involuntary horror in him was drawing near.

40207. "Shall I join the army and enter the service, or wait?" he asked himself
40208. for the hundredth time. He took a pack of cards that lay on the table
40209. and began to lay them out for a game of patience.
40210. 
40211. "If this patience comes out," he said to himself after shuffling the

40213. it means... what does it mean?"
40214.

40220. 
40221. Only the eldest princess, the one with the stony face and long waist,
40222. was still living in Pierre's house. The two younger ones had both
40223. married.
40224. 
40225. "Excuse my coming to you, cousin," she said in a reproachful and
40226. agitated voice. "You know some decision must be come to. What is going
40227. to happen? Everyone has left Moscow and the people are rioting. How is
40228. it that we are staying on?"
40229. 
40230. "On the contrary, things seem satisfactory, ma cousine," said Pierre
40231. in the bantering tone he habitually adopted toward her, always feeling
40232. uncomfortable in the role of her benefactor.
40233. 
40234. "Satisfactory, indeed! Very satisfactory! Barbara Ivanovna told me today
40235. how our troops are distinguishing themselves. It certainly does them
40236. credit! And the people too are quite mutinous--they no longer obey,
40237. even my maid has taken to being rude. At this rate they will soon begin
40238. beating us. One can't walk in the streets. But, above all, the French
40239. will be here any day now, so what are we waiting for? I ask just one
40240. thing of you, cousin," she went on, "arrange for me to be taken to
40241. Petersburg. Whatever I may be, I can't live under Bonaparte's rule."
40242. 
40243. "Oh, come, ma cousine! Where do you get your information from? On the
40244. contrary..."
40245. 
40246. "I won't submit to your Napoleon! Others may if they please.... If you
40247. don't want to do this..."
40248. 
40249. "But I will, I'll give the order at once."
40250. 
40251. The princess was apparently vexed at not having anyone to be angry with.
40252. Muttering to herself, she sat down on a chair.
40253. 
40254. "But you have been misinformed," said Pierre. "Everything is quiet in
40255. the city and there is not the slightest danger. See! I've just been
40256. reading..." He showed her the broadsheet. "Count Rostopchin writes that
40257. he will stake his life on it that the enemy will not enter Moscow."
40258. 
40259. "Oh, that count of yours!" said the princess malevolently. "He is a
40260. hypocrite, a rascal who has himself roused the people to riot. Didn't
40261. he write in those idiotic broadsheets that anyone, 'whoever it might be,
40262. should be dragged to the lockup by his hair'? (How silly!) 'And honor
40263. and glory to whoever captures him,' he says. This is what his cajolery
40264. has brought us to! Barbara Ivanovna told me the mob near killed her
40265. because she said something in French."
40266. 
40267. "Oh, but it's so... You take everything so to heart," said Pierre, and
40268. began laying out his cards for patience.
40269. 
40270. Although that patience did come out, Pierre did not join the army,
40271. but remained in deserted Moscow ever in the same state of agitation,
40272. irresolution, and alarm, yet at the same time joyfully expecting
40273. something terrible.
40274. 
40275. Next day toward evening the princess set off, and Pierre's head steward
40276. came to inform him that the money needed for the equipment of his
40277. regiment could not be found without selling one of the estates. In
40278. general the head steward made out to Pierre that his project of raising
40279. a regiment would ruin him. Pierre listened to him, scarcely able to
40280. repress a smile.
40281. 
40282. "Well then, sell it," said he. "What's to be done? I can't draw back
40283. now!"
40284. 
40285. The worse everything became, especially his own affairs, the better
40286. was Pierre pleased and the more evident was it that the catastrophe he
40287. expected was approaching. Hardly anyone he knew was left in town. Julie
40288. had gone, and so had Princess Mary. Of his intimate friends only the
40289. Rostovs remained, but he did not go to see them.
40290. 
40291. To distract his thoughts he drove that day to the village of Vorontsovo
40292. to see the great balloon Leppich was constructing to destroy the foe,
40293. and a trial balloon that was to go up next day. The balloon was not yet
40294. ready, but Pierre learned that it was being constructed by the Emperor's
40295. desire. The Emperor had written to Count Rostopchin as follows:
40296. 
40297. 
40298. As soon as Leppich is ready, get together a crew of reliable and
40299. intelligent men for his car and send a courier to General Kutuzov to let
40300. him know. I have informed him of the matter.
40301. 
40302. Please impress upon Leppich to be very careful where he descends for
40303. the first time, that he may not make a mistake and fall into the enemy's
40304. hands. It is essential for him to combine his movements with those of
40305. the commander in chief.
40306. 
40307. 
40308. On his way home from Vorontsovo, as he was passing the Bolotnoe Place
40309. Pierre, seeing a large crowd round the Lobnoe Place, stopped and got out
40310. of his trap. A French cook accused of being a spy was being flogged. The
40311. flogging was only just over, and the executioner was releasing from the
40312. flogging bench a stout man with red whiskers, in blue stockings and
40313. a green jacket, who was moaning piteously. Another criminal, thin and
40314. pale, stood near. Judging by their faces they were both Frenchmen. With
40315. a frightened and suffering look resembling that on the thin Frenchman's
40316. face, Pierre pushed his way in through the crowd.
40317. 
40318. "What is it? Who is it? What is it for?" he kept asking.
40319. 
40320. But the attention of the crowd--officials, burghers, shopkeepers,
40321. peasants, and women in cloaks and in pelisses--was so eagerly centered
40322. on what was passing in Lobnoe Place that no one answered him. The stout
40323. man rose, frowned, shrugged his shoulders, and evidently trying to
40324. appear firm began to pull on his jacket without looking about him, but
40325. suddenly his lips trembled and he began to cry, in the way full-blooded
40326. grown-up men cry, though angry with himself for doing so. In the crowd
40327. people began talking loudly, to stifle their feelings of pity as it
40328. seemed to Pierre.
40329. 
40330. "He's cook to some prince."
40331. 
40332. "Eh, mounseer, Russian sauce seems to be sour to a Frenchman... sets his
40333. teeth on edge!" said a wrinkled clerk who was standing behind Pierre,
40334. when the Frenchman began to cry.
40335. 
40336. The clerk glanced round, evidently hoping that his joke would be
40337. appreciated. Some people began to laugh, others continued to watch in
40338. dismay the executioner who was undressing the other man.
40339. 
40340. Pierre choked, his face puckered, and he turned hastily away, went back
40341. to his trap muttering something to himself as he went, and took his
40342. seat. As they drove along he shuddered and exclaimed several times so
40343. audibly that the coachman asked him:
40344. 
40345. "What is your pleasure?"
40346. 
40347. "Where are you going?" shouted Pierre to the man, who was driving to
40348. Lubyanka Street.
40349. 
40350. "To the Governor's, as you ordered," answered the coachman.
40351. 
40352. "Fool! Idiot!" shouted Pierre, abusing his coachman--a thing he rarely
40353. did. "Home, I told you! And drive faster, blockhead!" "I must get away
40354. this very day," he murmured to himself.
40355. 
40356. At the sight of the tortured Frenchman and the crowd surrounding the
40357. Lobnoe Place, Pierre had so definitely made up his mind that he could no
40358. longer remain in Moscow and would leave for the army that very day that
40359. it seemed to him that either he had told the coachman this or that the
40360. man ought to have known it for himself.
40361. 
40362. On reaching home Pierre gave orders to Evstafey--his head coachman who
40363. knew everything, could do anything, and was known to all Moscow--that
40364. he would leave that night for the army at Mozhaysk, and that his saddle
40365. horses should be sent there. This could not all be arranged that day,
40366. so on Evstafey's representation Pierre had to put off his departure till
40367. next day to allow time for the relay horses to be sent on in advance.
40368. 
40369. On the twenty-fourth the weather cleared up after a spell of rain, and
40370. after dinner Pierre left Moscow. When changing horses that night
40371. in Perkhushkovo, he learned that there had been a great battle that
40372. evening. (This was the battle of Shevardino.) He was told that there in
40373. Perkhushkovo the earth trembled from the firing, but nobody could answer
40374. his questions as to who had won. At dawn next day Pierre was approaching
40375. Mozhaysk.
40376. 
40377. Every house in Mozhaysk had soldiers quartered in it, and at the hostel
40378. where Pierre was met by his groom and coachman there was no room to be
40379. had. It was full of officers.
40380. 
40381. Everywhere in Mozhaysk and beyond it, troops were stationed or on the
40382. march. Cossacks, foot and horse soldiers, wagons, caissons, and cannon
40383. were everywhere. Pierre pushed forward as fast as he could, and the
40384. farther he left Moscow behind and the deeper he plunged into that sea
40385. of troops the more was he overcome by restless agitation and a new and
40386. joyful feeling he had not experienced before. It was a feeling akin to
40387. what he had felt at the Sloboda Palace during the Emperor's visit--a
40388. sense of the necessity of undertaking something and sacrificing
40389. something. He now experienced a glad consciousness that everything that
40390. constitutes men's happiness--the comforts of life, wealth, even
40391. life itself--is rubbish it is pleasant to throw away, compared with
40392. something... With what? Pierre could not say, and he did not try to
40393. determine for whom and for what he felt such particular delight in
40394. sacrificing everything. He was not occupied with the question of what to
40395. sacrifice for; the fact of sacrificing in itself afforded him a new and
40396. joyous sensation.
40397. 
40398. 
40399. 
40400. 
40401. 
40402. CHAPTER XIX
40403. 
40404. 
40405. On the twenty-fourth of August the battle of the Shevardino Redoubt was
40406. fought, on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by either side, and on
40407. the twenty-sixth the battle of Borodino itself took place.
40408. 
40409. Why and how were the battles of Shevardino and Borodino given and
40410. accepted? Why was the battle of Borodino fought? There was not the least
40411. sense in it for either the French or the Russians. Its immediate result
40412. for the Russians was, and was bound to be, that we were brought nearer
40413. to the destruction of Moscow--which we feared more than anything in
40414. the world; and for the French its immediate result was that they were
40415. brought nearer to the destruction of their whole army--which they feared
40416. more than anything in the world. What the result must be was quite
40417. obvious, and yet Napoleon offered and Kutuzov accepted that battle.
40418. 
40419. If the commanders had been guided by reason, it would seem that it must
40420. have been obvious to Napoleon that by advancing thirteen hundred miles
40421. and giving battle with a probability of losing a quarter of his army,
40422. he was advancing to certain destruction, and it must have been equally
40423. clear to Kutuzov that by accepting battle and risking the loss of a
40424. quarter of his army he would certainly lose Moscow. For Kutuzov this was
40425. mathematically clear, as it is that if when playing draughts I have one
40426. man less and go on exchanging, I shall certainly lose, and therefore
40427. should not exchange. When my opponent has sixteen men and I have
40428. fourteen, I am only one eighth weaker than he, but when I have exchanged
40429. thirteen more men he will be three times as strong as I am.
40430. 
40431. Before the battle of Borodino our strength in proportion to the French
40432. was about as five to six, but after that battle it was little more than
40433. one to two: previously we had a hundred thousand against a hundred and
40434. twenty thousand; afterwards little more than fifty thousand against a
40435. hundred thousand. Yet the shrewd and experienced Kutuzov accepted the
40436. battle, while Napoleon, who was said to be a commander of genius,
40437. gave it, losing a quarter of his army and lengthening his lines of
40438. communication still more. If it is said that he expected to end the
40439. campaign by occupying Moscow as he had ended a previous campaign by
40440. occupying Vienna, there is much evidence to the contrary. Napoleon's
40441. historians themselves tell us that from Smolensk onwards he wished
40442. to stop, knew the danger of his extended position, and knew that the
40443. occupation of Moscow would not be the end of the campaign, for he had
40444. seen at Smolensk the state in which Russian towns were left to him, and
40445. had not received a single reply to his repeated announcements of his
40446. wish to negotiate.
40447. 
40448. In giving and accepting battle at Borodino, Kutuzov acted involuntarily
40449. and irrationally. But later on, to fit what had occurred, the historians
40450. provided cunningly devised evidence of the foresight and genius of the
40451. generals who, of all the blind tools of history were the most enslaved
40452. and involuntary.
40453. 
40454. The ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroes furnish
40455. the whole interest of the story, and we are still unable to accustom
40456. ourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of that kind are
40457. meaningless.
40458. 
40459. On the other question, how the battle of Borodino and the preceding
40460. battle of Shevardino were fought, there also exists a definite and
40461. well-known, but quite false, conception. All the historians describe the
40462. affair as follows:
40463. 
40464. The Russian army, they say, in its retreat from Smolensk sought out
40465. for itself the best position for a general engagement and found such a
40466. position at Borodino.
40467. 
40468. The Russians, they say, fortified this position in advance on the left
40469. of the highroad (from Moscow to Smolensk) and almost at a right angle
40470. to it, from Borodino to Utitsa, at the very place where the battle was
40471. fought.
40472. 
40473. In front of this position, they say, a fortified outpost was set up on
40474. the Shevardino mound to observe the enemy. On the twenty-fourth, we
40475. are told, Napoleon attacked this advanced post and took it, and, on the
40476. twenty-sixth, attacked the whole Russian army, which was in position on
40477. the field of Borodino.
40478. 
40479. So the histories say, and it is all quite wrong, as anyone who cares to
40480. look into the matter can easily convince himself.
40481. 
40482. The Russians did not seek out the best position but, on the contrary,
40483. during the retreat passed many positions better than Borodino. They did
40484. not stop at any one of these positions because Kutuzov did not wish to
40485. occupy a position he had not himself chosen, because the popular demand
40486. for a battle had not yet expressed itself strongly enough, and because
40487. Miloradovich had not yet arrived with the militia, and for many other
40488. reasons. The fact is that other positions they had passed were stronger,
40489. and that the position at Borodino (the one where the battle was fought),
40490. far from being strong, was no more a position than any other spot one
40491. might find in the Russian Empire by sticking a pin into the map at
40492. hazard.
40493. 
40494. Not only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field of
40495. Borodino to the left of, and at a right angle to, the highroad (that
40496. is, the position on which the battle took place), but never till the
40497. twenty-fifth of August, 1812, did they think that a battle might be
40498. fought there. This was shown first by the fact that there were no
40499. entrenchments there by the twenty fifth and that those begun on the
40500. twenty-fifth and twenty-sixth were not completed, and secondly, by the
40501. position of the Shevardino Redoubt. That redoubt was quite senseless
40502. in front of the position where the battle was accepted. Why was it
40503. more strongly fortified than any other post? And why were all efforts
40504. exhausted and six thousand men sacrificed to defend it till late at
40505. night on the twenty-fourth? A Cossack patrol would have sufficed to
40506. observe the enemy. Thirdly, as proof that the position on which the
40507. battle was fought had not been foreseen and that the Shevardino Redoubt
40508. was not an advanced post of that position, we have the fact that up to
40509. the twenty-fifth, Barclay de Tolly and Bagration were convinced that the
40510. Shevardino Redoubt was the left flank of the position, and that Kutuzov
40511. himself in his report, written in hot haste after the battle, speaks of
40512. the Shevardino Redoubt as the left flank of the position. It was much
40513. later, when reports on the battle of Borodino were written at leisure,
40514. that the incorrect and extraordinary statement was invented (probably to
40515. justify the mistakes of a commander in chief who had to be represented
40516. as infallible) that the Shevardino Redoubt was an advanced post--whereas
40517. in reality it was simply a fortified point on the left flank--and
40518. that the battle of Borodino was fought by us on an entrenched position
40519. previously selected, where as it was fought on a quite unexpected spot
40520. which was almost unentrenched.
40521. 
40522. The case was evidently this: a position was selected along the river
40523. Kolocha--which crosses the highroad not at a right angle but at an acute
40524. angle--so that the left flank was at Shevardino, the right flank near
40525. the village of Novoe, and the center at Borodino at the confluence of
40526. the rivers Kolocha and Voyna.
40527. 
40528. To anyone who looks at the field of Borodino without thinking of how
40529. the battle was actually fought, this position, protected by the river
40530. Kolocha, presents itself as obvious for an army whose object was to
40531. prevent an enemy from advancing along the Smolensk road to Moscow.
40532. 
40533. Napoleon, riding to Valuevo on the twenty-fourth, did not see (as the
40534. history books say he did) the position of the Russians from Utitsa
40535. to Borodino (he could not have seen that position because it did not
40536. exist), nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army, but while
40537. pursuing the Russian rearguard he came upon the left flank of the
40538. Russian position--at the Shevardino Redoubt--and unexpectedly for the
40539. Russians moved his army across the Kolocha. And the Russians, not having
40540. time to begin a general engagement, withdrew their left wing from the
40541. position they had intended to occupy and took up a new position which
40542. had not been foreseen and was not fortified. By crossing to the other
40543. side of the Kolocha to the left of the highroad, Napoleon shifted the
40544. whole forthcoming battle from right to left (looking from the Russian
40545. side) and transferred it to the plain between Utitsa, Semenovsk, and
40546. Borodino--a plain no more advantageous as a position than any other
40547. plain in Russia--and there the whole battle of the twenty-sixth of
40548. August took place.
40549. 
40550. Had Napoleon not ridden out on the evening of the twenty-fourth to the
40551. Kolocha, and had he not then ordered an immediate attack on the redoubt
40552. but had begun the attack next morning, no one would have doubted that
40553. the Shevardino Redoubt was the left flank of our position, and the
40554. battle would have taken place where we expected it. In that case
40555. we should probably have defended the Shevardino Redoubt--our left
40556. flank--still more obstinately. We should have attacked Napoleon in the
40557. center or on the right, and the engagement would have taken place on the
40558. twenty-fifth, in the position we intended and had fortified. But as the
40559. attack on our left flank took place in the evening after the retreat of
40560. our rear guard (that is, immediately after the fight at Gridneva), and
40561. as the Russian commanders did not wish, or were not in time, to begin a
40562. general engagement then on the evening of the twenty-fourth, the first
40563. and chief action of the battle of Borodino was already lost on the
40564. twenty-fourth, and obviously led to the loss of the one fought on the
40565. twenty-sixth.
40566. 
40567. After the loss of the Shevardino Redoubt, we found ourselves on the
40568. morning of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank, and
40569. were forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where it chanced to
40570. be.
40571. 
40572. Not only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended by weak,
40573. unfinished entrenchments, but the disadvantage of that position was
40574. increased by the fact that the Russian commanders--not having fully
40575. realized what had happened, namely the loss of our position on the left
40576. flank and the shifting of the whole field of the forthcoming battle from
40577. right to left--maintained their extended position from the village of
40578. Novoe to Utitsa, and consequently had to move their forces from right to
40579. left during the battle. So it happened that throughout the whole battle
40580. the Russians opposed the entire French army launched against our left
40581. flank with but half as many men. (Poniatowski's action against Utitsa,
40582. and Uvarov's on the right flank against the French, were actions
40583. distinct from the main course of the battle.) So the battle of Borodino
40584. did not take place at all as (in an effort to conceal our commanders'
40585. mistakes even at the cost of diminishing the glory due to the Russian
40586. army and people) it has been described. The battle of Borodino was not
40587. fought on a chosen and entrenched position with forces only slightly
40588. weaker than those of the enemy, but, as a result of the loss of the
40589. Shevardino Redoubt, the Russians fought the battle of Borodino on an
40590. open and almost unentrenched position, with forces only half as numerous
40591. as the French; that is to say, under conditions in which it was not
40592. merely unthinkable to fight for ten hours and secure an indecisive
40593. result, but unthinkable to keep an army even from complete
40594. disintegration and flight.
40595. 
40596. 
40597. 
40598. 
40599. 
40600. CHAPTER XX
40601. 
40602. 
40603. On the morning of the twenty-fifth Pierre was leaving Mozhaysk. At the
40604. descent of the high steep hill, down which a winding road led out of the
40605. town past the cathedral on the right, where a service was being held and
40606. the bells were ringing, Pierre got out of his vehicle and proceeded on
40607. foot. Behind him a cavalry regiment was coming down the hill preceded by
40608. its singers. Coming up toward him was a train of carts carrying men who
40609. had been wounded in the engagement the day before. The peasant drivers,
40610. shouting and lashing their horses, kept crossing from side to side. The
40611. carts, in each of which three or four wounded soldiers were lying
40612. or sitting, jolted over the stones that had been thrown on the steep
40613. incline to make it something like a road. The wounded, bandaged with
40614. rags, with pale cheeks, compressed lips, and knitted brows, held on to
40615. the sides of the carts as they were jolted against one another. Almost
40616. all of them stared with naive, childlike curiosity at Pierre's white hat
40617. and green swallow-tail coat.
40618. 
40619. Pierre's coachman shouted angrily at the convoy of wounded to keep to
40620. one side of the road. The cavalry regiment, as it descended the hill
40621. with its singers, surrounded Pierre's carriage and blocked the road.
40622. Pierre stopped, being pressed against the side of the cutting in which
40623. the road ran. The sunshine from behind the hill did not penetrate into
40624. the cutting and there it was cold and damp, but above Pierre's head was
40625. the bright August sunshine and the bells sounded merrily. One of the
40626. carts with wounded stopped by the side of the road close to Pierre. The
40627. driver in his bast shoes ran panting up to it, placed a stone under one
40628. of its tireless hind wheels, and began arranging the breech-band on his
40629. little horse.
40630. 
40631. One of the wounded, an old soldier with a bandaged arm who was following
40632. the cart on foot, caught hold of it with his sound hand and turned to
40633. look at Pierre.
40634. 
40635. "I say, fellow countryman! Will they set us down here or take us on to
40636. Moscow?" he asked.
40637. 
40638. Pierre was so deep in thought that he did not hear the question. He was
40639. looking now at the cavalry regiment that had met the convoy of wounded,
40640. now at the cart by which he was standing, in which two wounded men
40641. were sitting and one was lying. One of those sitting up in the cart had
40642. probably been wounded in the cheek. His whole head was wrapped in rags
40643. and one cheek was swollen to the size of a baby's head. His nose
40644. and mouth were twisted to one side. This soldier was looking at the
40645. cathedral and crossing himself. Another, a young lad, a fair-haired
40646. recruit as white as though there was no blood in his thin face, looked
40647. at Pierre kindly, with a fixed smile. The third lay prone so that his
40648. face was not visible. The cavalry singers were passing close by:
40649. 
40650.    Ah lost, quite lost... is my head so keen,
40651.    Living in a foreign land.
40652. 
40653. they sang their soldiers' dance song.
40654. 
40655. As if responding to them but with a different sort of merriment, the
40656. metallic sound of the bells reverberated high above and the hot rays of
40657. the sun bathed the top of the opposite slope with yet another sort of
40658. merriment. But beneath the slope, by the cart with the wounded near the
40659. panting little nag where Pierre stood, it was damp, somber, and sad.
40660. 
40661. The soldier with the swollen cheek looked angrily at the cavalry
40662. singers.
40663. 
40664. "Oh, the coxcombs!" he muttered reproachfully.
40665. 
40666. "It's not the soldiers only, but I've seen peasants today, too....
40667. The peasants--even they have to go," said the soldier behind the cart,
40668. addressing Pierre with a sad smile. "No distinctions made nowadays....
40669. They want the whole nation to fall on them--in a word, it's Moscow! They
40670. want to make an end of it."
40671. 
40672. In spite of the obscurity of the soldier's words Pierre understood what
40673. he wanted to say and nodded approval.
40674. 
40675. The road was clear again; Pierre descended the hill and drove on.
40676. 
40677. He kept looking to either side of the road for familiar faces, but only
40678. saw everywhere the unfamiliar faces of various military men of different
40679. branches of the service, who all looked with astonishment at his white
40680. hat and green tail coat.
40681. 
40682. Having gone nearly three miles he at last met an acquaintance and
40683. eagerly addressed him. This was one of the head army doctors. He was
40684. driving toward Pierre in a covered gig, sitting beside a young surgeon,
40685. and on recognizing Pierre he told the Cossack who occupied the driver's
40686. seat to pull up.
40687. 
40688. "Count! Your excellency, how come you to be here?" asked the doctor.
40689. 
40690. "Well, you know, I wanted to see..."
40691. 
40692. "Yes, yes, there will be something to see...."
40693. 
40694. Pierre got out and talked to the doctor, explaining his intention of
40695. taking part in a battle.
40696. 
40697. The doctor advised him to apply direct to Kutuzov.
40698. 
40699. "Why should you be God knows where out of sight, during the battle?" he
40700. said, exchanging glances with his young companion. "Anyhow his Serene
40701. Highness knows you and will receive you graciously. That's what you must
40702. do."
40703. 
40704. The doctor seemed tired and in a hurry.
40705. 
40706. "You think so?... Ah, I also wanted to ask you where our position is
40707. exactly?" said Pierre.
40708. 
40709. "The position?" repeated the doctor. "Well, that's not my line. Drive
40710. past Tatarinova, a lot of digging is going on there. Go up the hillock
40711. and you'll see."
40712. 
40713. "Can one see from there?... If you would..."
40714. 
40715. But the doctor interrupted him and moved toward his gig.
40716. 
40717. "I would go with you but on my honor I'm up to here"--and he pointed to
40718. his throat. "I'm galloping to the commander of the corps. How do matters
40719. stand?... You know, Count, there'll be a battle tomorrow. Out of an army
40720. of a hundred thousand we must expect at least twenty thousand wounded,
40721. and we haven't stretchers, or bunks, or dressers, or doctors enough for
40722. six thousand. We have ten thousand carts, but we need other things as
40723. well--we must manage as best we can!"
40724. 
40725. The strange thought that of the thousands of men, young and old, who
40726. had stared with merry surprise at his hat (perhaps the very men he had
40727. noticed), twenty thousand were inevitably doomed to wounds and death
40728. amazed Pierre.
40729. 
40730. "They may die tomorrow; why are they thinking of anything but death?"
40731. And by some latent sequence of thought the descent of the Mozhaysk hill,
40732. the carts with the wounded, the ringing bells, the slanting rays of the
40733. sun, and the songs of the cavalrymen vividly recurred to his mind.
40734. 
40735. "The cavalry ride to battle and meet the wounded and do not for a moment
40736. think of what awaits them, but pass by, winking at the wounded. Yet from
40737. among these men twenty thousand are doomed to die, and they wonder at my
40738. hat! Strange!" thought Pierre, continuing his way to Tatarinova.
40739. 
40740. In front of a landowner's house to the left of the road stood carriages,
40741. wagons, and crowds of orderlies and sentinels. The commander in chief
40742. was putting up there, but just when Pierre arrived he was not in and
40743. hardly any of the staff were there--they had gone to the church service.
40744. Pierre drove on toward Gorki.
40745. 
40746. When he had ascended the hill and reached the little village street, he
40747. saw for the first time peasant militiamen in their white shirts and with
40748. crosses on their caps, who, talking and laughing loudly, animated and
40749. perspiring, were at work on a huge knoll overgrown with grass to the
40750. right of the road.
40751. 
40752. Some of them were digging, others were wheeling barrowloads of earth
40753. along planks, while others stood about doing nothing.
40754. 
40755. Two officers were standing on the knoll, directing the men. On seeing
40756. these peasants, who were evidently still amused by the novelty of their
40757. position as soldiers, Pierre once more thought of the wounded men at
40758. Mozhaysk and understood what the soldier had meant when he said: "They
40759. want the whole nation to fall on them." The sight of these bearded
40760. peasants at work on the battlefield, with their queer, clumsy boots
40761. and perspiring necks, and their shirts opening from the left toward
40762. the middle, unfastened, exposing their sunburned collarbones, impressed
40763. Pierre more strongly with the solemnity and importance of the moment
40764. than anything he had yet seen or heard.
40765. 
40766. 
40767. 
40768. 
40769. 
40770. CHAPTER XXI
40771. 
40772. 
40773. Pierre stepped out of his carriage and, passing the toiling militiamen,
40774. ascended the knoll from which, according to the doctor, the battlefield
40775. could be seen.
40776. 
40777. It was about eleven o'clock. The sun shone somewhat to the left and
40778. behind him and brightly lit up the enormous panorama which, rising like
40779. an amphitheater, extended before him in the clear rarefied atmosphere.
40780. 
40781. From above on the left, bisecting that amphitheater, wound the Smolensk
40782. highroad, passing through a village with a white church some five
40783. hundred paces in front of the knoll and below it. This was Borodino.
40784. Below the village the road crossed the river by a bridge and, winding
40785. down and up, rose higher and higher to the village of Valuevo visible
40786. about four miles away, where Napoleon was then stationed. Beyond Valuevo
40787. the road disappeared into a yellowing forest on the horizon. Far in
40788. the distance in that birch and fir forest to the right of the road, the
40789. cross and belfry of the Kolocha Monastery gleamed in the sun. Here and
40790. there over the whole of that blue expanse, to right and left of the
40791. forest and the road, smoking campfires could be seen and indefinite
40792. masses of troops--ours and the enemy's. The ground to the right--along
40793. the course of the Kolocha and Moskva rivers--was broken and hilly.
40794. Between the hollows the villages of Bezubova and Zakharino showed in the
40795. distance. On the left the ground was more level; there were fields of
40796. grain, and the smoking ruins of Semenovsk, which had been burned down,
40797. could be seen.
40798. 
40799. All that Pierre saw was so indefinite that neither the left nor the
40800. right side of the field fully satisfied his expectations. Nowhere
40801. could he see the battlefield he had expected to find, but only fields,
40802. meadows, troops, woods, the smoke of campfires, villages, mounds, and
40803. streams; and try as he would he could descry no military "position" in
40804. this place which teemed with life, nor could he even distinguish our
40805. troops from the enemy's.
40806. 
40807. "I must ask someone who knows," he thought, and addressed an officer who
40808. was looking with curiosity at his huge unmilitary figure.
40809. 
40810. "May I ask you," said Pierre, "what village that is in front?"
40811. 
40812. "Burdino, isn't it?" said the officer, turning to his companion.
40813. 
40814. "Borodino," the other corrected him.
40815. 
40816. The officer, evidently glad of an opportunity for a talk, moved up to
40817. Pierre.
40818. 
40819. "Are those our men there?" Pierre inquired.
40820. 
40821. "Yes, and there, further on, are the French," said the officer. "There
40822. they are, there... you can see them."
40823. 
40824. "Where? Where?" asked Pierre.
40825. 
40826. "One can see them with the naked eye... Why, there!"
40827. 
40828. The officer pointed with his hand to the smoke visible on the left
40829. beyond the river, and the same stern and serious expression that Pierre
40830. had noticed on many of the faces he had met came into his face.
40831. 
40832. "Ah, those are the French! And over there?..." Pierre pointed to a knoll
40833. on the left, near which some troops could be seen.
40834. 
40835. "Those are ours."
40836. 
40837. "Ah, ours! And there?..." Pierre pointed to another knoll in the
40838. distance with a big tree on it, near a village that lay in a hollow
40839. where also some campfires were smoking and something black was visible.
40840. 
40841. "That's his again," said the officer. (It was the Shevardino Redoubt.)
40842. "It was ours yesterday, but now it is his."
40843. 
40844. "Then how about our position?"
40845. 
40846. "Our position?" replied the officer with a smile of satisfaction. "I
40847. can tell you quite clearly, because I constructed nearly all our
40848. entrenchments. There, you see? There's our center, at Borodino, just
40849. there," and he pointed to the village in front of them with the white
40850. church. "That's where one crosses the Kolocha. You see down there where
40851. the rows of hay are lying in the hollow, there's the bridge. That's our
40852. center. Our right flank is over there"--he pointed sharply to the right,
40853. far away in the broken ground--"That's where the Moskva River is, and
40854. we have thrown up three redoubts there, very strong ones. The left
40855. flank..." here the officer paused. "Well, you see, that's difficult to
40856. explain.... Yesterday our left flank was there at Shevardino, you see,
40857. where the oak is, but now we have withdrawn our left wing--now it is
40858. over there, do you see that village and the smoke? That's Semenovsk,
40859. yes, there," he pointed to Raevski's knoll. "But the battle will hardly
40860. be there. His having moved his troops there is only a ruse; he will
40861. probably pass round to the right of the Moskva. But wherever it may be,
40862. many a man will be missing tomorrow!" he remarked.
40863. 
40864. An elderly sergeant who had approached the officer while he was giving
40865. these explanations had waited in silence for him to finish speaking, but
40866. at this point, evidently not liking the officer's remark, interrupted
40867. him.
40868. 
40869. "Gabions must be sent for," said he sternly.
40870. 
40871. The officer appeared abashed, as though he understood that one might
40872. think of how many men would be missing tomorrow but ought not to speak
40873. of it.
40874. 
40875. "Well, send number three company again," the officer replied hurriedly.
40876. 
40877. "And you, are you one of the doctors?"
40878. 
40879. "No, I've come on my own," answered Pierre, and he went down the hill
40880. again, passing the militiamen.
40881. 
40882. "Oh, those damned fellows!" muttered the officer who followed him,
40883. holding his nose as he ran past the men at work.
40884. 
40885. "There they are... bringing her, coming... There they are... They'll be
40886. here in a minute..." voices were suddenly heard saying; and officers,
40887. soldiers, and militiamen began running forward along the road.
40888. 
40889. A church procession was coming up the hill from Borodino. First along
40890. the dusty road came the infantry in ranks, bareheaded and with arms
40891. reversed. From behind them came the sound of church singing.
40892. 
40893. Soldiers and militiamen ran bareheaded past Pierre toward the
40894. procession.
40895. 
40896. "They are bringing her, our Protectress!... The Iberian Mother of God!"
40897. someone cried.
40898. 
40899. "The Smolensk Mother of God," another corrected him.
40900. 
40901. The militiamen, both those who had been in the village and those who had
40902. been at work on the battery, threw down their spades and ran to meet the
40903. church procession. Following the battalion that marched along the dusty
40904. road came priests in their vestments--one little old man in a hood with
40905. attendants and singers. Behind them soldiers and officers bore a large,
40906. dark-faced icon with an embossed metal cover. This was the icon that had
40907. been brought from Smolensk and had since accompanied the army. Behind,
40908. before, and on both sides, crowds of militiamen with bared heads walked,
40909. ran, and bowed to the ground.
40910. 
40911. At the summit of the hill they stopped with the icon; the men who had
40912. been holding it up by the linen bands attached to it were relieved by
40913. others, the chanters relit their censers, and service began. The hot
40914. rays of the sun beat down vertically and a fresh soft wind played with
40915. the hair of the bared heads and with the ribbons decorating the icon.
40916. The singing did not sound loud under the open sky. An immense crowd
40917. of bareheaded officers, soldiers, and militiamen surrounded the icon.
40918. Behind the priest and a chanter stood the notabilities on a spot
40919. reserved for them. A bald general with a St. George's Cross on his neck
40920. stood just behind the priest's back, and without crossing himself (he
40921. was evidently a German) patiently awaited the end of the service, which
40922. he considered it necessary to hear to the end, probably to arouse the
40923. patriotism of the Russian people. Another general stood in a martial
40924. pose, crossing himself by shaking his hand in front of his chest
40925. while looking about him. Standing among the crowd of peasants, Pierre
40926. recognized several acquaintances among these notables, but did not
40927. look at them--his whole attention was absorbed in watching the serious
40928. expression on the faces of the crowd of soldiers and militiamen who were
40929. all gazing eagerly at the icon. As soon as the tired chanters, who were
40930. singing the service for the twentieth time that day, began lazily and
40931. mechanically to sing: "Save from calamity Thy servants, O Mother of
40932. God," and the priest and deacon chimed in: "For to Thee under God we all
40933. flee as to an inviolable bulwark and protection," there again kindled in
40934. all those faces the same expression of consciousness of the solemnity
40935. of the impending moment that Pierre had seen on the faces at the foot of
40936. the hill at Mozhaysk and momentarily on many and many faces he had met
40937. that morning; and heads were bowed more frequently and hair tossed back,
40938. and sighs and the sound men made as they crossed themselves were heard.
40939. 
40940. The crowd round the icon suddenly parted and pressed against Pierre.
40941. Someone, a very important personage judging by the haste with which way
40942. was made for him, was approaching the icon.
40943. 
40944. It was Kutuzov, who had been riding round the position and on his way
40945. back to Tatarinova had stopped where the service was being held. Pierre
40946. recognized him at once by his peculiar figure, which distinguished him
40947. from everybody else.
40948. 
40949. With a long overcoat on his exceedingly stout, round-shouldered body,
40950. with uncovered white head and puffy face showing the white ball of the
40951. eye he had lost, Kutuzov walked with plunging, swaying gait into
40952. the crowd and stopped behind the priest. He crossed himself with an
40953. accustomed movement, bent till he touched the ground with his hand, and
40954. bowed his white head with a deep sigh. Behind Kutuzov was Bennigsen and
40955. the suite. Despite the presence of the commander in chief, who attracted
40956. the attention of all the superior officers, the militiamen and soldiers
40957. continued their prayers without looking at him.
40958. 
40959. When the service was over, Kutuzov stepped up to the icon, sank heavily
40960. to his knees, bowed to the ground, and for a long time tried vainly to
40961. rise, but could not do so on account of his weakness and weight. His
40962. white head twitched with the effort. At last he rose, kissed the icon as
40963. a child does with naively pouting lips, and again bowed till he touched
40964. the ground with his hand. The other generals followed his example,
40965. then the officers, and after them with excited faces, pressing on one
40966. another, crowding, panting, and pushing, scrambled the soldiers and
40967. militiamen.
40968. 
40969. 
40970. 
40971. 
40972. 
40973. CHAPTER XXII
40974. 
40975. 
40976. Staggering amid the crush, Pierre looked about him.
40977. 
40978. "Count Peter Kirilovich! How did you get here?" said a voice.
40979. 
40980. Pierre looked round. Boris Drubetskoy, brushing his knees with his hand
40981. (he had probably soiled them when he, too, had knelt before the icon),
40982. came up to him smiling. Boris was elegantly dressed, with a slightly
40983. martial touch appropriate to a campaign. He wore a long coat and like
40984. Kutuzov had a whip slung across his shoulder.
40985. 
40986. Meanwhile Kutuzov had reached the village and seated himself in the
40987. shade of the nearest house, on a bench which one Cossack had run
40988. to fetch and another had hastily covered with a rug. An immense and
40989. brilliant suite surrounded him.
40990. 
40991. The icon was carried further, accompanied by the throng. Pierre stopped
40992. some thirty paces from Kutuzov, talking to Boris.
40993. 
40994. He explained his wish to be present at the battle and to see the
40995. position.
40996. 
40997. "This is what you must do," said Boris. "I will do the honors of the
40998. camp to you. You will see everything best from where Count Bennigsen
40999. will be. I am in attendance on him, you know; I'll mention it to him.
41000. But if you want to ride round the position, come along with us. We are
41001. just going to the left flank. Then when we get back, do spend the night
41002. with me and we'll arrange a game of cards. Of course you know Dmitri
41003. Sergeevich? Those are his quarters," and he pointed to the third house
41004. in the village of Gorki.
41005. 
41006. "But I should like to see the right flank. They say it's very strong,"
41007. said Pierre. "I should like to start from the Moskva River and ride
41008. round the whole position."
41009. 
41010. "Well, you can do that later, but the chief thing is the left flank."
41011. 
41012. "Yes, yes. But where is Prince Bolkonski's regiment? Can you point it
41013. out to me?"
41014. 
41015. "Prince Andrew's? We shall pass it and I'll take you to him."
41016. 
41017. "What about the left flank?" asked Pierre
41018. 
41019. "To tell you the truth, between ourselves, God only knows what state our
41020. left flank is in," said Boris confidentially lowering his voice. "It is
41021. not at all what Count Bennigsen intended. He meant to fortify that knoll
41022. quite differently, but..." Boris shrugged his shoulders, "his Serene
41023. Highness would not have it, or someone persuaded him. You see..." but
41024. Boris did not finish, for at that moment Kaysarov, Kutuzov's adjutant,
41025. came up to Pierre. "Ah, Kaysarov!" said Boris, addressing him with an
41026. unembarrassed smile, "I was just trying to explain our position to
41027. the count. It is amazing how his Serene Highness could so foresee the
41028. intentions of the French!"
41029. 
41030. "You mean the left flank?" asked Kaysarov.
41031. 
41032. "Yes, exactly; the left flank is now extremely strong."
41033. 
41034. Though Kutuzov had dismissed all unnecessary men from the staff, Boris
41035. had contrived to remain at headquarters after the changes. He had
41036. established himself with Count Bennigsen, who, like all on whom Boris
41037. had been in attendance, considered young Prince Drubetskoy an invaluable
41038. man.
41039. 
41040. In the higher command there were two sharply defined parties: Kutuzov's
41041. party and that of Bennigsen, the chief of staff. Boris belonged to the
41042. latter and no one else, while showing servile respect to Kutuzov, could
41043. so create an impression that the old fellow was not much good and that
41044. Bennigsen managed everything. Now the decisive moment of battle had come
41045. when Kutuzov would be destroyed and the power pass to Bennigsen, or even
41046. if Kutuzov won the battle it would be felt that everything was done by
41047. Bennigsen. In any case many great rewards would have to be given for
41048. tomorrow's action, and new men would come to the front. So Boris was
41049. full of nervous vivacity all day.
41050. 
41051. After Kaysarov, others whom Pierre knew came up to him, and he had not
41052. time to reply to all the questions about Moscow that were showered upon
41053. him, or to listen to all that was told him. The faces all expressed
41054. animation and apprehension, but it seemed to Pierre that the cause of
41055. the excitement shown in some of these faces lay chiefly in questions
41056. of personal success; his mind, however, was occupied by the different
41057. expression he saw on other faces--an expression that spoke not of
41058. personal matters but of the universal questions of life and death.
41059. Kutuzov noticed Pierre's figure and the group gathered round him.
41060. 
41061. "Call him to me," said Kutuzov.
41062. 
41063. An adjutant told Pierre of his Serene Highness' wish, and Pierre went
41064. toward Kutuzov's bench. But a militiaman got there before him. It was
41065. Dolokhov.
41066. 
41067. "How did that fellow get here?" asked Pierre.
41068. 
41069. "He's a creature that wriggles in anywhere!" was the answer. "He
41070. has been degraded, you know. Now he wants to bob up again. He's been
41071. proposing some scheme or other and has crawled into the enemy's picket
41072. line at night.... He's a brave fellow."
41073. 
41074. Pierre took off his hat and bowed respectfully to Kutuzov.
41075. 
41076. "I concluded that if I reported to your Serene Highness you might send
41077. me away or say that you knew what I was reporting, but then I shouldn't
41078. lose anything..." Dolokhov was saying.
41079. 
41080. "Yes, yes."
41081. 
41082. "But if I were right, I should be rendering a service to my Fatherland
41083. for which I am ready to die."
41084. 
41085. "Yes, yes."
41086. 
41087. "And should your Serene Highness require a man who will not spare his
41088. skin, please think of me.... Perhaps I may prove useful to your Serene
41089. Highness."
41090. 
41091. "Yes... Yes..." Kutuzov repeated, his laughing eye narrowing more and
41092. more as he looked at Pierre.
41093. 
41094. Just then Boris, with his courtierlike adroitness, stepped up to
41095. Pierre's side near Kutuzov and in a most natural manner, without
41096. raising his voice, said to Pierre, as though continuing an interrupted
41097. conversation:
41098. 
41099. "The militia have put on clean white shirts to be ready to die. What
41100. heroism, Count!"
41101. 
41102. Boris evidently said this to Pierre in order to be overheard by his
41103. Serene Highness. He knew Kutuzov's attention would be caught by those
41104. words, and so it was.
41105. 
41106. "What are you saying about the militia?" he asked Boris.
41107. 
41108. "Preparing for tomorrow, your Serene Highness--for death--they have put
41109. on clean shirts."
41110. 
41111. "Ah... a wonderful, a matchless people!" said Kutuzov; and he closed his
41112. eyes and swayed his head. "A matchless people!" he repeated with a sigh.
41113. 
41114. "So you want to smell gunpowder?" he said to Pierre. "Yes, it's a
41115. pleasant smell. I have the honor to be one of your wife's adorers. Is
41116. she well? My quarters are at your service."
41117. 
41118. And as often happens with old people, Kutuzov began looking about
41119. absent-mindedly as if forgetting all he wanted to say or do.
41120. 
41121. Then, evidently remembering what he wanted, he beckoned to Andrew
41122. Kaysarov, his adjutant's brother.
41123. 
41124. "Those verses... those verses of Marin's... how do they go, eh? Those he
41125. wrote about Gerakov: 'Lectures for the corps inditing'... Recite them,
41126. recite them!" said he, evidently preparing to laugh.
41127. 
41128. Kaysarov recited.... Kutuzov smilingly nodded his head to the rhythm of
41129. the verses.
41130. 
41131. When Pierre had left Kutuzov, Dolokhov came up to him and took his hand.
41132. 
41133. "I am very glad to meet you here, Count," he said aloud, regardless
41134. of the presence of strangers and in a particularly resolute and solemn
41135. tone. "On the eve of a day when God alone knows who of us is fated to
41136. survive, I am glad of this opportunity to tell you that I regret the
41137. misunderstandings that occurred between us and should wish you not to
41138. have any ill feeling for me. I beg you to forgive me."
41139. 
41140. Pierre looked at Dolokhov with a smile, not knowing what to say to him.
41141. With tears in his eyes Dolokhov embraced Pierre and kissed him.
41142. 
41143. Boris said a few words to his general, and Count Bennigsen turned to
41144. Pierre and proposed that he should ride with him along the line.
41145. 
41146. "It will interest you," said he.
41147. 
41148. "Yes, very much," replied Pierre.
41149. 
41150. Half an hour later Kutuzov left for Tatarinova, and Bennigsen and his
41151. suite, with Pierre among them, set out on their ride along the line.
41152. 
41153. 
41154. 
41155. 
41156. 
41157. CHAPTER XXIII
41158. 
41159. 
41160. From Gorki, Bennigsen descended the highroad to the bridge which, when
41161. they had looked at it from the hill, the officer had pointed out as
41162. being the center of our position and where rows of fragrant new-mown hay
41163. lay by the riverside. They rode across that bridge into the village of
41164. Borodino and thence turned to the left, passing an enormous number of
41165. troops and guns, and came to a high knoll where militiamen were digging.
41166. This was the redoubt, as yet unnamed, which afterwards became known as
41167. the Raevski Redoubt, or the Knoll Battery, but Pierre paid no special
41168. attention to it. He did not know that it would become more memorable to
41169. him than any other spot on the plain of Borodino.
41170. 
41171. They then crossed the hollow to Semenovsk, where the soldiers were
41172. dragging away the last logs from the huts and barns. Then they rode
41173. downhill and uphill, across a ryefield trodden and beaten down as if by
41174. hail, following a track freshly made by the artillery over the furrows
41175. of the plowed land, and reached some fleches * which were still being
41176. dug.
41177. 
41178. 
41179.     * A kind of entrenchment.
41180. 
41181. 
41182. At the fleches Bennigsen stopped and began looking at the Shevardino
41183. Redoubt opposite, which had been ours the day before and where several
41184. horsemen could be descried. The officers said that either Napoleon or
41185. Murat was there, and they all gazed eagerly at this little group of
41186. horsemen. Pierre also looked at them, trying to guess which of the
41187. scarcely discernible figures was Napoleon. At last those mounted men
41188. rode away from the mound and disappeared.
41189. 
41190. Bennigsen spoke to a general who approached him, and began explaining
41191. the whole position of our troops. Pierre listened to him, straining each
41192. faculty to understand the essential points of the impending battle, but
41193. was mortified to feel that his mental capacity was inadequate for the
41194. task. He could make nothing of it. Bennigsen stopped speaking and,
41195. noticing that Pierre was listening, suddenly said to him:
41196. 
41197. "I don't think this interests you?"
41198. 
41199. "On the contrary it's very interesting!" replied Pierre not quite
41200. truthfully.
41201. 
41202. From the fleches they rode still farther to the left, along a road
41203. winding through a thick, low-growing birch wood. In the middle of the
41204. wood a brown hare with white feet sprang out and, scared by the tramp of
41205. the many horses, grew so confused that it leaped along the road in front
41206. of them for some time, arousing general attention and laughter, and only
41207. when several voices shouted at it did it dart to one side and disappear
41208. in the thicket. After going through the wood for about a mile and a half
41209. they came out on a glade where troops of Tuchkov's corps were stationed
41210. to defend the left flank.
41211. 
41212. Here, at the extreme left flank, Bennigsen talked a great deal and with
41213. much heat, and, as it seemed to Pierre, gave orders of great military
41214. importance. In front of Tuchkov's troops was some high ground not
41215. occupied by troops. Bennigsen loudly criticized this mistake, saying
41216. that it was madness to leave a height which commanded the country around
41217. unoccupied and to place troops below it. Some of the generals expressed
41218. the same opinion. One in particular declared with martial heat that they
41219. were put there to be slaughtered. Bennigsen on his own authority ordered
41220. the troops to occupy the high ground. This disposition on the left flank
41221. increased Pierre's doubt of his own capacity to understand military
41222. matters. Listening to Bennigsen and the generals criticizing the
41223. position of the troops behind the hill, he quite understood them and
41224. shared their opinion, but for that very reason he could not understand
41225. how the man who put them there behind the hill could have made so gross
41226. and palpable a blunder.
41227. 
41228. Pierre did not know that these troops were not, as Bennigsen supposed,
41229. put there to defend the position, but were in a concealed position as
41230. an ambush, that they should not be seen and might be able to strike an
41231. approaching enemy unexpectedly. Bennigsen did not know this and moved
41232. the troops forward according to his own ideas without mentioning the
41233. matter to the commander in chief.
41234. 
41235. 
41236. 
41237. 
41238. 
41239. CHAPTER XXIV
41240. 
41241. 
41242. On that bright evening of August 25, Prince Andrew lay leaning on his
41243. elbow in a broken-down shed in the village of Knyazkovo at the further
41244. end of his regiment's encampment. Through a gap in the broken wall he
41245. could see, beside the wooden fence, a row of thirty year-old birches
41246. with their lower branches lopped off, a field on which shocks of
41247. oats were standing, and some bushes near which rose the smoke of
41248. campfires--the soldiers' kitchens.
41249. 
41250. Narrow and burdensome and useless to anyone as his life now seemed to
41251. him, Prince Andrew on the eve of battle felt agitated and irritable as
41252. he had done seven years before at Austerlitz.
41253. 
41254. He had received and given the orders for next day's battle and had
41255. nothing more to do. But his thoughts--the simplest, clearest, and
41256. therefore most terrible thoughts--would give him no peace. He knew that
41257. tomorrow's battle would be the most terrible of all he had taken
41258. part in, and for the first time in his life the possibility of death
41259. presented itself to him--not in relation to any worldly matter or with
41260. reference to its effect on others, but simply in relation to himself, to
41261. his own soul--vividly, plainly, terribly, and almost as a certainty. And
41262. from the height of this perception all that had previously tormented and
41263. preoccupied him suddenly became illumined by a cold white light without
41264. shadows, without perspective, without distinction of outline. All life
41265. appeared to him like magic-lantern pictures at which he had long been
41266. gazing by artificial light through a glass. Now he suddenly saw those
41267. badly daubed pictures in clear daylight and without a glass. "Yes,
41268. yes! There they are, those false images that agitated, enraptured,
41269. and tormented me," said he to himself, passing in review the principal
41270. pictures of the magic lantern of life and regarding them now in the cold
41271. white daylight of his clear perception of death. "There they are, those
41272. rudely painted figures that once seemed splendid and mysterious.
41273. Glory, the good of society, love of a woman, the Fatherland itself--how
41274. important these pictures appeared to me, with what profound meaning they
41275. seemed to be filled! And it is all so simple, pale, and crude in the
41276. cold white light of this morning which I feel is dawning for me." The
41277. three great sorrows of his life held his attention in particular: his
41278. love for a woman, his father's death, and the French invasion which had
41279. overrun half Russia. "Love... that little girl who seemed to me brimming
41280. over with mystic forces! Yes, indeed, I loved her. I made romantic plans
41281. of love and happiness with her! Oh, what a boy I was!" he said aloud
41282. bitterly. "Ah me! I believed in some ideal love which was to keep her
41283. faithful to me for the whole year of my absence! Like the gentle dove
41284. in the fable she was to pine apart from me.... But it was much simpler
41285. really.... It was all very simple and horrible."
41286. 
41287. "When my father built Bald Hills he thought the place was his: his
41288. land, his air, his peasants. But Napoleon came and swept him aside,
41289. unconscious of his existence, as he might brush a chip from his path,
41290. and his Bald Hills and his whole life fell to pieces. Princess Mary says
41291. it is a trial sent from above. What is the trial for, when he is not
41292. here and will never return? He is not here! For whom then is the trial
41293. intended? The Fatherland, the destruction of Moscow! And tomorrow I
41294. shall be killed, perhaps not even by a Frenchman but by one of our own
41295. men, by a soldier discharging a musket close to my ear as one of them
41296. did yesterday, and the French will come and take me by head and heels
41297. and fling me into a hole that I may not stink under their noses, and new
41298. conditions of life will arise, which will seem quite ordinary to others
41299. and about which I shall know nothing. I shall not exist..."
41300. 
41301. He looked at the row of birches shining in the sunshine, with their
41302. motionless green and yellow foliage and white bark. "To die... to be
41303. killed tomorrow... That I should not exist... That all this should still
41304. be, but no me...."
41305. 
41306. And the birches with their light and shade, the curly clouds, the
41307. smoke of the campfires, and all that was around him changed and seemed
41308. terrible and menacing. A cold shiver ran down his spine. He rose
41309. quickly, went out of the shed, and began to walk about.
41310. 
41311. After he had returned, voices were heard outside the shed. "Who's that?"
41312. he cried.
41313. 
41314. The red-nosed Captain Timokhin, formerly Dolokhov's squadron commander,
41315. but now from lack of officers a battalion commander, shyly entered the
41316. shed followed by an adjutant and the regimental paymaster.
41317. 
41318. Prince Andrew rose hastily, listened to the business they had come
41319. about, gave them some further instructions, and was about to dismiss
41320. them when he heard a familiar, lisping, voice behind the shed.
41321. 
41322. "Devil take it!" said the voice of a man stumbling over something.
41323. 
41324. Prince Andrew looked out of the shed and saw Pierre, who had tripped
41325. over a pole on the ground and had nearly fallen, coming his way. It was
41326. unpleasant to Prince Andrew to meet people of his own set in general,
41327. and Pierre especially, for he reminded him of all the painful moments of
41328. his last visit to Moscow.
41329. 
41330. "You? What a surprise!" said he. "What brings you here? This is
41331. unexpected!"
41332. 
41333. As he said this his eyes and face expressed more than coldness--they
41334. expressed hostility, which Pierre noticed at once. He had approached
41335. the shed full of animation, but on seeing Prince Andrew's face he felt
41336. constrained and ill at ease.
41337. 
41338. "I have come... simply... you know... come... it interests me," said
41339. Pierre, who had so often that day senselessly repeated that word
41340. "interesting." "I wish to see the battle."
41341. 
41342. "Oh yes, and what do the Masonic brothers say about war? How would they
41343. stop it?" said Prince Andrew sarcastically. "Well, and how's Moscow? And
41344. my people? Have they reached Moscow at last?" he asked seriously.
41345. 
41346. "Yes, they have. Julie Drubetskaya told me so. I went to see them, but
41347. missed them. They have gone to your estate near Moscow."
41348. 
41349. 
41350. 
41351. 
41352. 
41353. CHAPTER XXV
41354. 
41355. 
41356. The officers were about to take leave, but Prince Andrew, apparently
41357. reluctant to be left alone with his friend, asked them to stay and have
41358. tea. Seats were brought in and so was the tea. The officers gazed with
41359. surprise at Pierre's huge stout figure and listened to his talk of
41360. Moscow and the position of our army, round which he had ridden. Prince
41361. Andrew remained silent, and his expression was so forbidding that Pierre
41362. addressed his remarks chiefly to the good-natured battalion commander.
41363. 
41364. "So you understand the whole position of our troops?" Prince Andrew
41365. interrupted him.
41366. 
41367. "Yes--that is, how do you mean?" said Pierre. "Not being a military man
41368. I can't say I have understood it fully, but I understand the general
41369. position."
41370. 
41371. "Well, then, you know more than anyone else, be it who it may," said
41372. Prince Andrew.
41373. 
41374. "Oh!" said Pierre, looking over his spectacles in perplexity at Prince
41375. Andrew. "Well, and what do you think of Kutuzov's appointment?" he
41376. asked.
41377. 
41378. "I was very glad of his appointment, that's all I know," replied Prince
41379. Andrew.
41380. 
41381. "And tell me your opinion of Barclay de Tolly. In Moscow they are saying
41382. heaven knows what about him.... What do you think of him?"
41383. 
41384. "Ask them," replied Prince Andrew, indicating the officers.
41385. 
41386. Pierre looked at Timokhin with the condescendingly interrogative smile
41387. with which everybody involuntarily addressed that officer.
41388. 
41389. "We see light again, since his Serenity has been appointed, your
41390. excellency," said Timokhin timidly, and continually turning to glance at
41391. his colonel.
41392. 
41393. "Why so?" asked Pierre.
41394. 
41395. "Well, to mention only firewood and fodder, let me inform you. Why, when
41396. we were retreating from Sventsyani we dare not touch a stick or a wisp
41397. of hay or anything. You see, we were going away, so he would get it all;
41398. wasn't it so, your excellency?" and again Timokhin turned to the prince.
41399. "But we daren't. In our regiment two officers were court-martialed for
41400. that kind of thing. But when his Serenity took command everything became
41401. straight forward. Now we see light..."
41402. 
41403. "Then why was it forbidden?"
41404. 
41405. Timokhin looked about in confusion, not knowing what or how to answer
41406. such a question. Pierre put the same question to Prince Andrew.
41407. 
41408. "Why, so as not to lay waste the country we were abandoning to the
41409. enemy," said Prince Andrew with venomous irony. "It is very sound:
41410. one can't permit the land to be pillaged and accustom the troops to
41411. marauding. At Smolensk too he judged correctly that the French might
41412. outflank us, as they had larger forces. But he could not understand
41413. this," cried Prince Andrew in a shrill voice that seemed to escape him
41414. involuntarily: "he could not understand that there, for the first time,
41415. we were fighting for Russian soil, and that there was a spirit in the
41416. men such as I had never seen before, that we had held the French for
41417. two days, and that that success had increased our strength tenfold. He
41418. ordered us to retreat, and all our efforts and losses went for nothing.
41419. He had no thought of betraying us, he tried to do the best he could,
41420. he thought out everything, and that is why he is unsuitable. He is
41421. unsuitable now, just because he plans out everything very thoroughly and
41422. accurately as every German has to. How can I explain?... Well, say your
41423. father has a German valet, and he is a splendid valet and satisfies your
41424. father's requirements better than you could, then it's all right to let
41425. him serve. But if your father is mortally sick you'll send the valet
41426. away and attend to your father with your own unpracticed, awkward hands,
41427. and will soothe him better than a skilled man who is a stranger could.
41428. So it has been with Barclay. While Russia was well, a foreigner could
41429. serve her and be a splendid minister; but as soon as she is in danger
41430. she needs one of her own kin. But in your Club they have been making him
41431. out a traitor! They slander him as a traitor, and the only result will
41432. be that afterwards, ashamed of their false accusations, they will make
41433. him out a hero or a genius instead of a traitor, and that will be still
41434. more unjust. He is an honest and very punctilious German."
41435. 
41436. "And they say he's a skillful commander," rejoined Pierre.
41437. 
41438. "I don't understand what is meant by 'a skillful commander,'" replied
41439. Prince Andrew ironically.
41440. 
41441. "A skillful commander?" replied Pierre. "Why, one who foresees all
41442. contingencies... and foresees the adversary's intentions."
41443. 
41444. "But that's impossible," said Prince Andrew as if it were a matter
41445. settled long ago.
41446. 
41447. Pierre looked at him in surprise.
41448. 
41449. "And yet they say that war is like a game of chess?" he remarked.
41450. 
41451. "Yes," replied Prince Andrew, "but with this little difference, that
41452. in chess you may think over each move as long as you please and are not
41453. limited for time, and with this difference too, that a knight is always
41454. stronger than a pawn, and two pawns are always stronger than one, while
41455. in war a battalion is sometimes stronger than a division and sometimes
41456. weaker than a company. The relative strength of bodies of troops can
41457. never be known to anyone. Believe me," he went on, "if things
41458. depended on arrangements made by the staff, I should be there making
41459. arrangements, but instead of that I have the honor to serve here in
41460. the regiment with these gentlemen, and I consider that on us tomorrow's
41461. battle will depend and not on those others.... Success never depends,
41462. and never will depend, on position, or equipment, or even on numbers,
41463. and least of all on position."
41464. 
41465. "But on what then?"
41466. 
41467. "On the feeling that is in me and in him," he pointed to Timokhin, "and
41468. in each soldier."
41469. 
41470. Prince Andrew glanced at Timokhin, who looked at his commander in alarm
41471. and bewilderment. In contrast to his former reticent taciturnity
41472. Prince Andrew now seemed excited. He could apparently not refrain from
41473. expressing the thoughts that had suddenly occurred to him.
41474. 
41475. "A battle is won by those who firmly resolve to win it! Why did we lose
41476. the battle at Austerlitz? The French losses were almost equal to ours,
