41477. but very early we said to ourselves that we were losing the battle,
41478. and we did lose it. And we said so because we had nothing to fight for
41479. there, we wanted to get away from the battlefield as soon as we could.
41480. 'We've lost, so let us run,' and we ran. If we had not said that till
41481. the evening, heaven knows what might not have happened. But tomorrow we
41482. shan't say it! You talk about our position, the left flank weak and the
41483. right flank too extended," he went on. "That's all nonsense, there's
41484. nothing of the kind. But what awaits us tomorrow? A hundred million most
41485. diverse chances which will be decided on the instant by the fact that
41486. our men or theirs run or do not run, and that this man or that man is
41487. killed, but all that is being done at present is only play. The fact is
41488. that those men with whom you have ridden round the position not only
41489. do not help matters, but hinder. They are only concerned with their own
41490. petty interests."
41491. 
41492. "At such a moment?" said Pierre reproachfully.
41493. 
41494. "At such a moment!" Prince Andrew repeated. "To them it is only a moment
41495. affording opportunities to undermine a rival and obtain an extra cross
41496. or ribbon. For me tomorrow means this: a Russian army of a hundred
41497. thousand and a French army of a hundred thousand have met to fight, and
41498. the thing is that these two hundred thousand men will fight and the side
41499. that fights more fiercely and spares itself least will win. And if you
41500. like I will tell you that whatever happens and whatever muddles those at
41501. the top may make, we shall win tomorrow's battle. Tomorrow, happen what
41502. may, we shall win!"
41503. 
41504. "There now, your excellency! That's the truth, the real truth," said
41505. Timokhin. "Who would spare himself now? The soldiers in my battalion,
41506. believe me, wouldn't drink their vodka! 'It's not the day for that!'
41507. they say."
41508. 
41509. All were silent. The officers rose. Prince Andrew went out of the shed
41510. with them, giving final orders to the adjutant. After they had gone
41511. Pierre approached Prince Andrew and was about to start a conversation
41512. when they heard the clatter of three horses' hoofs on the road not far
41513. from the shed, and looking in that direction Prince Andrew recognized
41514. Wolzogen and Clausewitz accompanied by a Cossack. They rode close by
41515. continuing to converse, and Prince Andrew involuntarily heard these
41516. words:
41517. 
41518. "Der Krieg muss in Raum verlegt werden. Der Ansicht kann ich nicht genug
41519. Preis geben," * said one of them.
41520. 
41521. 
41522.      * "The war must be extended widely. I cannot sufficiently
41523.      commend that view."
41524. 
41525. 
41526. "Oh, ja," said the other, "der Zweck ist nur den Feind zu schwachen,
41527. so kann man gewiss nicht den Verlust der Privat-Personen in Achtung
41528. nehmen." *
41529. 
41530. 
41531.      * "Oh, yes, the only aim is to weaken the enemy, so of
41532.      course one cannot take into account the loss of private
41533.      individuals."
41534. 
41535. 
41536. "Oh, no," agreed the other.
41537. 
41538. "Extend widely!" said Prince Andrew with an angry snort, when they had
41539. ridden past. "In that 'extend' were my father, son, and sister, at
41540. Bald Hills. That's all the same to him! That's what I was saying to
41541. you--those German gentlemen won't win the battle tomorrow but will only
41542. make all the mess they can, because they have nothing in their German
41543. heads but theories not worth an empty eggshell and haven't in their
41544. hearts the one thing needed tomorrow--that which Timokhin has. They
41545. have yielded up all Europe to him, and have now come to teach us. Fine
41546. teachers!" and again his voice grew shrill.
41547. 
41548. "So you think we shall win tomorrow's battle?" asked Pierre.
41549. 
41550. "Yes, yes," answered Prince Andrew absently. "One thing I would do if
41551. I had the power," he began again, "I would not take prisoners. Why take
41552. prisoners? It's chivalry! The French have destroyed my home and are on
41553. their way to destroy Moscow, they have outraged and are outraging me
41554. every moment. They are my enemies. In my opinion they are all criminals.
41555. And so thinks Timokhin and the whole army. They should be executed!
41556. Since they are my foes they cannot be my friends, whatever may have been
41557. said at Tilsit."
41558. 
41559. "Yes, yes," muttered Pierre, looking with shining eyes at Prince Andrew.
41560. "I quite agree with you!"
41561. 
41562. The question that had perturbed Pierre on the Mozhaysk hill and all
41563. that day now seemed to him quite clear and completely solved. He now
41564. understood the whole meaning and importance of this war and of the
41565. impending battle. All he had seen that day, all the significant and
41566. stern expressions on the faces he had seen in passing, were lit up
41567. for him by a new light. He understood that latent heat (as they say in
41568. physics) of patriotism which was present in all these men he had seen,
41569. and this explained to him why they all prepared for death calmly, and as
41570. it were lightheartedly.
41571. 
41572. "Not take prisoners," Prince Andrew continued: "That by itself would
41573. quite change the whole war and make it less cruel. As it is we have
41574. played at war--that's what's vile! We play at magnanimity and all that
41575. stuff. Such magnanimity and sensibility are like the magnanimity and
41576. sensibility of a lady who faints when she sees a calf being killed: she
41577. is so kindhearted that she can't look at blood, but enjoys eating the
41578. calf served up with sauce. They talk to us of the rules of war, of
41579. chivalry, of flags of truce, of mercy to the unfortunate and so on. It's
41580. all rubbish! I saw chivalry and flags of truce in 1805; they humbugged
41581. us and we humbugged them. They plunder other people's houses, issue
41582. false paper money, and worst of all they kill my children and my
41583. father, and then talk of rules of war and magnanimity to foes! Take no
41584. prisoners, but kill and be killed! He who has come to this as I have
41585. through the same sufferings..."
41586. 
41587. Prince Andrew, who had thought it was all the same to him whether or
41588. not Moscow was taken as Smolensk had been, was suddenly checked in his
41589. speech by an unexpected cramp in his throat. He paced up and down a
41590. few times in silence, but his eyes glittered feverishly and his lips
41591. quivered as he began speaking.
41592. 
41593. "If there was none of this magnanimity in war, we should go to war only
41594. when it was worth while going to certain death, as now. Then there would
41595. not be war because Paul Ivanovich had offended Michael Ivanovich. And
41596. when there was a war, like this one, it would be war! And then the
41597. determination of the troops would be quite different. Then all these
41598. Westphalians and Hessians whom Napoleon is leading would not follow
41599. him into Russia, and we should not go to fight in Austria and Prussia
41600. without knowing why. War is not courtesy but the most horrible thing in
41601. life; and we ought to understand that and not play at war. We ought to
41602. accept this terrible necessity sternly and seriously. It all lies in
41603. that: get rid of falsehood and let war be war and not a game. As it is
41604. now, war is the favorite pastime of the idle and frivolous. The military
41605. calling is the most highly honored.
41606. 
41607. "But what is war? What is needed for success in warfare? What are the
41608. habits of the military? The aim of war is murder; the methods of war
41609. are spying, treachery, and their encouragement, the ruin of a country's
41610. inhabitants, robbing them or stealing to provision the army, and fraud
41611. and falsehood termed military craft. The habits of the military class
41612. are the absence of freedom, that is, discipline, idleness, ignorance,
41613. cruelty, debauchery, and drunkenness. And in spite of all this it is the
41614. highest class, respected by everyone. All the kings, except the Chinese,
41615. wear military uniforms, and he who kills most people receives the
41616. highest rewards.
41617. 
41618. "They meet, as we shall meet tomorrow, to murder one another; they kill
41619. and maim tens of thousands, and then have thanksgiving services for
41620. having killed so many people (they even exaggerate the number), and they
41621. announce a victory, supposing that the more people they have killed
41622. the greater their achievement. How does God above look at them and hear
41623. them?" exclaimed Prince Andrew in a shrill, piercing voice. "Ah, my
41624. friend, it has of late become hard for me to live. I see that I have
41625. begun to understand too much. And it doesn't do for man to taste of the
41626. tree of knowledge of good and evil.... Ah, well, it's not for long!" he
41627. added.
41628. 
41629. "However, you're sleepy, and it's time for me to sleep. Go back to
41630. Gorki!" said Prince Andrew suddenly.
41631. 
41632. "Oh no!" Pierre replied, looking at Prince Andrew with frightened,
41633. compassionate eyes.
41634. 
41635. "Go, go! Before a battle one must have one's sleep out," repeated Prince
41636. Andrew.
41637. 
41638. He came quickly up to Pierre and embraced and kissed him. "Good-by, be
41639. off!" he shouted. "Whether we meet again or not..." and turning away
41640. hurriedly he entered the shed.
41641. 
41642. It was already dark, and Pierre could not make out whether the
41643. expression of Prince Andrew's face was angry or tender.
41644. 
41645. For some time he stood in silence considering whether he should follow
41646. him or go away. "No, he does not want it!" Pierre concluded. "And I know
41647. that this is our last meeting!" He sighed deeply and rode back to Gorki.
41648. 
41649. On re-entering the shed Prince Andrew lay down on a rug, but he could
41650. not sleep.
41651. 
41652. He closed his eyes. One picture succeeded another in his imagination. On
41653. one of them he dwelt long and joyfully. He vividly recalled an evening
41654. in Petersburg. Natasha with animated and excited face was telling him
41655. how she had gone to look for mushrooms the previous summer and had lost
41656. her way in the big forest. She incoherently described the depths of
41657. the forest, her feelings, and a talk with a beekeeper she met, and
41658. constantly interrupted her story to say: "No, I can't! I'm not telling
41659. it right; no, you don't understand," though he encouraged her by saying
41660. that he did understand, and he really had understood all she wanted to
41661. say. But Natasha was not satisfied with her own words: she felt that
41662. they did not convey the passionately poetic feeling she had experienced
41663. that day and wished to convey. "He was such a delightful old man, and
41664. it was so dark in the forest... and he had such kind... No, I can't
41665. describe it," she had said, flushed and excited. Prince Andrew smiled
41666. now the same happy smile as then when he had looked into her eyes. "I
41667. understood her," he thought. "I not only understood her, but it was
41668. just that inner, spiritual force, that sincerity, that frankness of
41669. soul--that very soul of hers which seemed to be fettered by her body--it
41670. was that soul I loved in her... loved so strongly and happily..." and
41671. suddenly he remembered how his love had ended. "He did not need anything
41672. of that kind. He neither saw nor understood anything of the sort. He
41673. only saw in her a pretty and fresh young girl, with whom he did not
41674. deign to unite his fate. And I?... and he is still alive and gay!"
41675. 
41676. Prince Andrew jumped up as if someone had burned him, and again began
41677. pacing up and down in front of the shed.
41678. 
41679. 
41680. 
41681. 
41682. 
41683. CHAPTER XXVI
41684. 
41685. 
41686. On August 25, the eve of the battle of Borodino, M. de Beausset, prefect
41687. of the French Emperor's palace, arrived at Napoleon's quarters at
41688. Valuevo with Colonel Fabvier, the former from Paris and the latter from
41689. Madrid.
41690. 
41691. Donning his court uniform, M. de Beausset ordered a box he had
41692. brought for the Emperor to be carried before him and entered the first
41693. compartment of Napoleon's tent, where he began opening the box while
41694. conversing with Napoleon's aides-de-camp who surrounded him.
41695. 
41696. Fabvier, not entering the tent, remained at the entrance talking to some
41697. generals of his acquaintance.
41698. 
41699. The Emperor Napoleon had not yet left his bedroom and was finishing his
41700. toilet. Slightly snorting and grunting, he presented now his back and
41701. now his plump hairy chest to the brush with which his valet was rubbing
41702. him down. Another valet, with his finger over the mouth of a bottle,
41703. was sprinkling Eau de Cologne on the Emperor's pampered body with an
41704. expression which seemed to say that he alone knew where and how much Eau
41705. de Cologne should be sprinkled. Napoleon's short hair was wet and
41706. matted on the forehead, but his face, though puffy and yellow, expressed
41707. physical satisfaction. "Go on, harder, go on!" he muttered to the valet
41708. who was rubbing him, slightly twitching and grunting. An aide-de-camp,
41709. who had entered the bedroom to report to the Emperor the number of
41710. prisoners taken in yesterday's action, was standing by the door after
41711. delivering his message, awaiting permission to withdraw. Napoleon,
41712. frowning, looked at him from under his brows.
41713. 
41714. "No prisoners!" said he, repeating the aide-de-camp's words. "They
41715. are forcing us to exterminate them. So much the worse for the Russian
41716. army.... Go on... harder, harder!" he muttered, hunching his back and
41717. presenting his fat shoulders.
41718. 
41719. "All right. Let Monsieur de Beausset enter, and Fabvier too," he said,
41720. nodding to the aide-de-camp.
41721. 
41722. "Yes, sire," and the aide-de-camp disappeared through the door of the
41723. tent.
41724. 
41725. Two valets rapidly dressed His Majesty, and wearing the blue uniform of
41726. the Guards he went with firm quick steps to the reception room.
41727. 
41728. De Beausset's hands meanwhile were busily engaged arranging the present
41729. he had brought from the Empress, on two chairs directly in front of the
41730. entrance. But Napoleon had dressed and come out with such unexpected
41731. rapidity that he had not time to finish arranging the surprise.
41732. 
41733. Napoleon noticed at once what they were about and guessed that they were
41734. not ready. He did not wish to deprive them of the pleasure of giving him
41735. a surprise, so he pretended not to see de Beausset and called Fabvier to
41736. him, listening silently and with a stern frown to what Fabvier told him
41737. of the heroism and devotion of his troops fighting at Salamanca, at
41738. the other end of Europe, with but one thought--to be worthy of their
41739. Emperor--and but one fear--to fail to please him. The result of
41740. that battle had been deplorable. Napoleon made ironic remarks during
41741. Fabvier's account, as if he had not expected that matters could go
41742. otherwise in his absence.
41743. 
41744. "I must make up for that in Moscow," said Napoleon. "I'll see you
41745. later," he added, and summoned de Beausset, who by that time had
41746. prepared the surprise, having placed something on the chairs and covered
41747. it with a cloth.
41748. 
41749. De Beausset bowed low, with that courtly French bow which only the
41750. old retainers of the Bourbons knew how to make, and approached him,
41751. presenting an envelope.
41752. 
41753. Napoleon turned to him gaily and pulled his ear.
41754. 
41755. "You have hurried here. I am very glad. Well, what is Paris saying?" he
41756. asked, suddenly changing his former stern expression for a most cordial
41757. tone.
41758. 
41759. "Sire, all Paris regrets your absence," replied de Beausset as was
41760. proper.
41761. 
41762. But though Napoleon knew that de Beausset had to say something of this
41763. kind, and though in his lucid moments he knew it was untrue, he was
41764. pleased to hear it from him. Again he honored him by touching his ear.
41765. 
41766. "I am very sorry to have made you travel so far," said he.
41767. 
41768. "Sire, I expected nothing less than to find you at the gates of Moscow,"
41769. replied de Beausset.
41770. 
41771. Napoleon smiled and, lifting his head absent-mindedly, glanced to the
41772. right. An aide-de-camp approached with gliding steps and offered him a
41773. gold snuffbox, which he took.
41774. 
41775. "Yes, it has happened luckily for you," he said, raising the open
41776. snuffbox to his nose. "You are fond of travel, and in three days you
41777. will see Moscow. You surely did not expect to see that Asiatic capital.
41778. You will have a pleasant journey."
41779. 
41780. De Beausset bowed gratefully at this regard for his taste for travel (of
41781. which he had not till then been aware).
41782. 
41783. "Ha, what's this?" asked Napoleon, noticing that all the courtiers were
41784. looking at something concealed under a cloth.
41785. 
41786. With courtly adroitness de Beausset half turned and without turning his
41787. back to the Emperor retired two steps, twitching off the cloth at the
41788. same time, and said:
41789. 
41790. "A present to Your Majesty from the Empress."
41791. 
41792. It was a portrait, painted in bright colors by Gerard, of the son borne
41793. to Napoleon by the daughter of the Emperor of Austria, the boy whom for
41794. some reason everyone called "The King of Rome."
41795. 
41796. A very pretty curly-headed boy with a look of the Christ in the Sistine
41797. Madonna was depicted playing at stick and ball. The ball represented the
41798. terrestrial globe and the stick in his other hand a scepter.
41799. 
41800. Though it was not clear what the artist meant to express by depicting
41801. the so-called King of Rome spiking the earth with a stick, the allegory
41802. apparently seemed to Napoleon, as it had done to all who had seen it in
41803. Paris, quite clear and very pleasing.
41804. 
41805. "The King of Rome!" he said, pointing to the portrait with a graceful
41806. gesture. "Admirable!"
41807. 
41808. With the natural capacity of an Italian for changing the expression of
41809. his face at will, he drew nearer to the portrait and assumed a look
41810. of pensive tenderness. He felt that what he now said and did would
41811. be historical, and it seemed to him that it would now be best for
41812. him--whose grandeur enabled his son to play stick and ball with the
41813. terrestrial globe--to show, in contrast to that grandeur, the simplest
41814. paternal tenderness. His eyes grew dim, he moved forward, glanced round
41815. at a chair (which seemed to place itself under him), and sat down on it
41816. before the portrait. At a single gesture from him everyone went out on
41817. tiptoe, leaving the great man to himself and his emotion.
41818. 
41819. Having sat still for a while he touched--himself not knowing why--the
41820. thick spot of paint representing the highest light in the portrait,
41821. rose, and recalled de Beausset and the officer on duty. He ordered the
41822. portrait to be carried outside his tent, that the Old Guard, stationed
41823. round it, might not be deprived of the pleasure of seeing the King of
41824. Rome, the son and heir of their adored monarch.
41825. 
41826. And while he was doing M. de Beausset the honor of breakfasting with
41827. him, they heard, as Napoleon had anticipated, the rapturous cries of the
41828. officers and men of the Old Guard who had run up to see the portrait.
41829. 
41830. "Vive l'Empereur! Vive le roi de Rome! Vive l'Empereur!" came those
41831. ecstatic cries.
41832. 
41833. After breakfast Napoleon in de Beausset's presence dictated his order of
41834. the day to the army.
41835. 
41836. "Short and energetic!" he remarked when he had read over the
41837. proclamation which he had dictated straight off without corrections. It
41838. ran:
41839. 
41840. 
41841. Soldiers! This is the battle you have so longed for. Victory depends on
41842. you. It is essential for us; it will give us all we need: comfortable
41843. quarters and a speedy return to our country. Behave as you did at
41844. Austerlitz, Friedland, Vitebsk, and Smolensk. Let our remotest posterity
41845. recall your achievements this day with pride. Let it be said of each of
41846. you: "He was in the great battle before Moscow!"
41847. 
41848. 
41849. "Before Moscow!" repeated Napoleon, and inviting M. de Beausset, who was
41850. so fond of travel, to accompany him on his ride, he went out of the tent
41851. to where the horses stood saddled.
41852. 
41853. "Your Majesty is too kind!" replied de Beausset to the invitation to
41854. accompany the Emperor; he wanted to sleep, did not know how to ride and
41855. was afraid of doing so.
41856. 
41857. But Napoleon nodded to the traveler, and de Beausset had to mount. When
41858. Napoleon came out of the tent the shouting of the Guards before his
41859. son's portrait grew still louder. Napoleon frowned.
41860. 
41861. "Take him away!" he said, pointing with a gracefully majestic gesture to
41862. the portrait. "It is too soon for him to see a field of battle."
41863. 
41864. De Beausset closed his eyes, bowed his head, and sighed deeply, to
41865. indicate how profoundly he valued and comprehended the Emperor's words.
41866. 
41867. 
41868. 
41869. 
41870. 
41871. CHAPTER XXVII
41872. 
41873. 
41874. On the twenty-fifth of August, so his historians tell us, Napoleon spent
41875. the whole day on horseback inspecting the locality, considering plans
41876. submitted to him by his marshals, and personally giving commands to his
41877. generals.
41878. 
41879. The original line of the Russian forces along the river Kolocha had
41880. been dislocated by the capture of the Shevardino Redoubt on the
41881. twenty-fourth, and part of the line--the left flank--had been drawn
41882. back. That part of the line was not entrenched and in front of it the
41883. ground was more open and level than elsewhere. It was evident to anyone,
41884. military or not, that it was here the French should attack. It would
41885. seem that not much consideration was needed to reach this conclusion,
41886. nor any particular care or trouble on the part of the Emperor and his
41887. marshals, nor was there any need of that special and supreme quality
41888. called genius that people are so apt to ascribe to Napoleon; yet the
41889. historians who described the event later and the men who then surrounded
41890. Napoleon, and he himself, thought otherwise.
41891. 
41892. Napoleon rode over the plain and surveyed the locality with a profound
41893. air and in silence, nodded with approval or shook his head dubiously,
41894. and without communicating to the generals around him the profound
41895. course of ideas which guided his decisions merely gave them his final
41896. conclusions in the form of commands. Having listened to a suggestion
41897. from Davout, who was now called Prince d'Eckmuhl, to turn the Russian
41898. left wing, Napoleon said it should not be done, without explaining
41899. why not. To a proposal made by General Campan (who was to attack the
41900. fleches) to lead his division through the woods, Napoleon agreed, though
41901. the so-called Duke of Elchingen (Ney) ventured to remark that a movement
41902. through the woods was dangerous and might disorder the division.
41903. 
41904. Having inspected the country opposite the Shevardino Redoubt, Napoleon
41905. pondered a little in silence and then indicated the spots where two
41906. batteries should be set up by the morrow to act against the Russian
41907. entrenchments, and the places where, in line with them, the field
41908. artillery should be placed.
41909. 
41910. After giving these and other commands he returned to his tent, and the
41911. dispositions for the battle were written down from his dictation.
41912. 
41913. These dispositions, of which the French historians write with enthusiasm
41914. and other historians with profound respect, were as follows:
41915. 
41916. 
41917. At dawn the two new batteries established during the night on the
41918. plain occupied by the Prince d'Eckmuhl will open fire on the opposing
41919. batteries of the enemy.
41920. 
41921. At the same time the commander of the artillery of the 1st Corps,
41922. General Pernetti, with thirty cannon of Campan's division and all the
41923. howitzers of Dessaix's and Friant's divisions, will move forward, open
41924. fire, and overwhelm with shellfire the enemy's battery, against which
41925. will operate:
41926. 
41927.         24 guns of the artillery of the Guards
41928.         30 guns of Campan's division
41929. 
41930.  and     8 guns of Friant's and Dessaix's divisions
41931.         --
41932. 
41933.  in all 62 guns.
41934. 
41935. 
41936. The commander of the artillery of the 3rd Corps, General Fouche, will
41937. place the howitzers of the 3rd and 8th Corps, sixteen in all, on the
41938. flanks of the battery that is to bombard the entrenchment on the left,
41939. which will have forty guns in all directed against it.
41940. 
41941. General Sorbier must be ready at the first order to advance with all the
41942. howitzers of the Guard's artillery against either one or other of the
41943. entrenchments.
41944. 
41945. During the cannonade Prince Poniatowski is to advance through the wood
41946. on the village and turn the enemy's position.
41947. 
41948. General Campan will move through the wood to seize the first
41949. fortification.
41950. 
41951. After the advance has begun in this manner, orders will be given in
41952. accordance with the enemy's movements.
41953. 
41954. The cannonade on the left flank will begin as soon as the guns of the
41955. right wing are heard. The sharpshooters of Morand's division and of
41956. the vice-King's division will open a heavy fire on seeing the attack
41957. commence on the right wing.
41958. 
41959. The vice-King will occupy the village and cross by its three bridges,
41960. advancing to the same heights as Morand's and Gibrard's divisions, which
41961. under his leadership will be directed against the redoubt and come into
41962. line with the rest of the forces.
41963. 
41964. All this must be done in good order (le tout se fera avec ordre et
41965. methode) as far as possible retaining troops in reserve.
41966. 
41967. The Imperial Camp near Mozhaysk,
41968. 
41969. September, 6, 1812.
41970. 
41971. 
41972. 
41973. These dispositions, which are very obscure and confused if one allows
41974. oneself to regard the arrangements without religious awe of his genius,
41975. related to Napoleon's orders to deal with four points--four different
41976. orders. Not one of these was, or could be, carried out.
41977. 
41978. In the disposition it is said first that the batteries placed on the
41979. spot chosen by Napoleon, with the guns of Pernetti and Fouche; which
41980. were to come in line with them, 102 guns in all, were to open fire and
41981. shower shells on the Russian fleches and redoubts. This could not be
41982. done, as from the spots selected by Napoleon the projectiles did not
41983. carry to the Russian works, and those 102 guns shot into the air until
41984. the nearest commander, contrary to Napoleon's instructions, moved them
41985. forward.
41986. 
41987. The second order was that Poniatowski, moving to the village through the
41988. wood, should turn the Russian left flank. This could not be done and
41989. was not done, because Poniatowski, advancing on the village through the
41990. wood, met Tuchkov there barring his way, and could not and did not turn
41991. the Russian position.
41992. 
41993. The third order was: General Campan will move through the wood to seize
41994. the first fortification. General Campan's division did not seize the
41995. first fortification but was driven back, for on emerging from the wood
41996. it had to reform under grapeshot, of which Napoleon was unaware.
41997. 
41998. The fourth order was: The vice-King will occupy the village (Borodino)
41999. and cross by its three bridges, advancing to the same heights as
42000. Morand's and Gdrard's divisions (for whose movements no directions are
42001. given), which under his leadership will be directed against the redoubt
42002. and come into line with the rest of the forces.
42003. 
42004. As far as one can make out, not so much from this unintelligible
42005. sentence as from the attempts the vice-King made to execute the orders
42006. given him, he was to advance from the left through Borodino to the
42007. redoubt while the divisions of Morand and Gerard were to advance
42008. simultaneously from the front.
42009. 
42010. All this, like the other parts of the disposition, was not and could
42011. not be executed. After passing through Borodino the vice-King was driven
42012. back to the Kolocha and could get no farther; while the divisions of
42013. Morand and Gerard did not take the redoubt but were driven back, and the
42014. redoubt was only taken at the end of the battle by the cavalry (a thing
42015. probably unforeseen and not heard of by Napoleon). So not one of
42016. the orders in the disposition was, or could be, executed. But in the
42017. disposition it is said that, after the fight has commenced in this
42018. manner, orders will be given in accordance with the enemy's movements,
42019. and so it might be supposed that all necessary arrangements would be
42020. made by Napoleon during the battle. But this was not and could not be
42021. done, for during the whole battle Napoleon was so far away that, as
42022. appeared later, he could not know the course of the battle and not one
42023. of his orders during the fight could be executed.
42024. 
42025. 
42026. 
42027. 
42028. 
42029. CHAPTER XXVIII
42030. 
42031. 
42032. Many historians say that the French did not win the battle of Borodino
42033. because Napoleon had a cold, and that if he had not had a cold the
42034. orders he gave before and during the battle would have been still more
42035. full of genius and Russia would have been lost and the face of the world
42036. have been changed. To historians who believe that Russia was shaped by
42037. the will of one man--Peter the Great--and that France from a republic
42038. became an empire and French armies went to Russia at the will of one
42039. man--Napoleon--to say that Russia remained a power because Napoleon
42040. had a bad cold on the twenty-fourth of August may seem logical and
42041. convincing.
42042. 
42043. If it had depended on Napoleon's will to fight or not to fight the
42044. battle of Borodino, and if this or that other arrangement depended on
42045. his will, then evidently a cold affecting the manifestation of his will
42046. might have saved Russia, and consequently the valet who omitted to bring
42047. Napoleon his waterproof boots on the twenty-fourth would have been
42048. the savior of Russia. Along that line of thought such a deduction is
42049. indubitable, as indubitable as the deduction Voltaire made in jest
42050. (without knowing what he was jesting at) when he saw that the Massacre
42051. of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IX's stomach being deranged. But
42052. to men who do not admit that Russia was formed by the will of one man,
42053. Peter I, or that the French Empire was formed and the war with Russia
42054. begun by the will of one man, Napoleon, that argument seems not merely
42055. untrue and irrational, but contrary to all human reality. To the
42056. question of what causes historic events another answer presents itself,
42057. namely, that the course of human events is predetermined from on
42058. high--depends on the coincidence of the wills of all who take part
42059. in the events, and that a Napoleon's influence on the course of these
42060. events is purely external and fictitious.
42061. 
42062. Strange as at first glance it may seem to suppose that the Massacre of
42063. St. Bartholomew was not due to Charles IX's will, though he gave the
42064. order for it and thought it was done as a result of that order; and
42065. strange as it may seem to suppose that the slaughter of eighty thousand
42066. men at Borodino was not due to Napoleon's will, though he ordered the
42067. commencement and conduct of the battle and thought it was done
42068. because he ordered it; strange as these suppositions appear, yet human
42069. dignity--which tells me that each of us is, if not more at least not
42070. less a man than the great Napoleon--demands the acceptance of that
42071. solution of the question, and historic investigation abundantly confirms
42072. it.
42073. 
42074. At the battle of Borodino Napoleon shot at no one and killed no one.
42075. That was all done by the soldiers. Therefore it was not he who killed
42076. people.
42077. 
42078. The French soldiers went to kill and be killed at the battle of Borodino
42079. not because of Napoleon's orders but by their own volition. The whole
42080. army--French, Italian, German, Polish, and Dutch--hungry, ragged, and
42081. weary of the campaign, felt at the sight of an army blocking their road
42082. to Moscow that the wine was drawn and must be drunk. Had Napoleon then
42083. forbidden them to fight the Russians, they would have killed him and
42084. have proceeded to fight the Russians because it was inevitable.
42085. 
42086. When they heard Napoleon's proclamation offering them, as compensation
42087. for mutilation and death, the words of posterity about their having been
42088. in the battle before Moscow, they cried "Vive l'Empereur!" just as they
42089. had cried "Vive l'Empereur!" at the sight of the portrait of the boy
42090. piercing the terrestrial globe with a toy stick, and just as they would
42091. have cried "Vive l'Empereur!" at any nonsense that might be told them.
42092. There was nothing left for them to do but cry "Vive l'Empereur!" and go
42093. to fight, in order to get food and rest as conquerors in Moscow. So it
42094. was not because of Napoleon's commands that they killed their fellow
42095. men.
42096. 
42097. And it was not Napoleon who directed the course of the battle, for none
42098. of his orders were executed and during the battle he did not know what
42099. was going on before him. So the way in which these people killed one
42100. another was not decided by Napoleon's will but occurred independently of
42101. him, in accord with the will of hundreds of thousands of people who took
42102. part in the common action. It only seemed to Napoleon that it all took
42103. place by his will. And so the question whether he had or had not a
42104. cold has no more historic interest than the cold of the least of the
42105. transport soldiers.
42106. 
42107. Moreover, the assertion made by various writers that his cold was
42108. the cause of his dispositions not being as well planned as on former
42109. occasions, and of his orders during the battle not being as good as
42110. previously, is quite baseless, which again shows that Napoleon's cold on
42111. the twenty-sixth of August was unimportant.
42112. 
42113. The dispositions cited above are not at all worse, but are even
42114. better, than previous dispositions by which he had won victories. His
42115. pseudo-orders during the battle were also no worse than formerly, but
42116. much the same as usual. These dispositions and orders only seem worse
42117. than previous ones because the battle of Borodino was the first Napoleon
42118. did not win. The profoundest and most excellent dispositions and orders
42119. seem very bad, and every learned militarist criticizes them with looks
42120. of importance, when they relate to a battle that has been lost, and the
42121. very worst dispositions and orders seem very good, and serious people
42122. fill whole volumes to demonstrate their merits, when they relate to a
42123. battle that has been won.
42124. 
42125. The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were
42126. a model of perfection for that kind of composition, but still they were
42127. criticized--criticized for their very perfection, for their excessive
42128. minuteness.
42129. 
42130. Napoleon at the battle of Borodino fulfilled his office as
42131. representative of authority as well as, and even better than, at other
42132. battles. He did nothing harmful to the progress of the battle; he
42133. inclined to the most reasonable opinions, he made no confusion, did not
42134. contradict himself, did not get frightened or run away from the field of
42135. battle, but with his great tact and military experience carried out his
42136. role of appearing to command, calmly and with dignity.
42137. 
42138. 
42139. 
42140. 
42141. 
42142. CHAPTER XXIX
42143. 
42144. 
42145. On returning from a second inspection of the lines, Napoleon remarked:
42146. 
42147. "The chessmen are set up, the game will begin tomorrow!"
42148. 
42149. Having ordered punch and summoned de Beausset, he began to talk to him
42150. about Paris and about some changes he meant to make in the Empress'
42151. household, surprising the prefect by his memory of minute details
42152. relating to the court.
42153. 
42154. He showed an interest in trifles, joked about de Beausset's love of
42155. travel, and chatted carelessly, as a famous, self-confident surgeon who
42156. knows his job does when turning up his sleeves and putting on his apron
42157. while a patient is being strapped to the operating table. "The matter is
42158. in my hands and is clear and definite in my head. When the time comes to
42159. set to work I shall do it as no one else could, but now I can jest, and
42160. the more I jest and the calmer I am the more tranquil and confident you
42161. ought to be, and the more amazed at my genius."
42162. 
42163. Having finished his second glass of punch, Napoleon went to rest before
42164. the serious business which, he considered, awaited him next day. He
42165. was so much interested in that task that he was unable to sleep, and
42166. in spite of his cold which had grown worse from the dampness of the
42167. evening, he went into the large division of the tent at three o'clock in
42168. the morning, loudly blowing his nose. He asked whether the Russians had
42169. not withdrawn, and was told that the enemy's fires were still in the
42170. same places. He nodded approval.
42171. 
42172. The adjutant in attendance came into the tent.
42173. 
42174. "Well, Rapp, do you think we shall do good business today?" Napoleon
42175. asked him.
42176. 
42177. "Without doubt, sire," replied Rapp.
42178. 
42179. Napoleon looked at him.
42180. 
42181. "Do you remember, sire, what you did me the honor to say at Smolensk?"
42182. continued Rapp. "The wine is drawn and must be drunk."
42183. 
42184. Napoleon frowned and sat silent for a long time leaning his head on his
42185. hand.
42186. 
42187. "This poor army!" he suddenly remarked. "It has diminished greatly since
42188. Smolensk. Fortune is frankly a courtesan, Rapp. I have always said so
42189. and I am beginning to experience it. But the Guards, Rapp, the Guards
42190. are intact?" he remarked interrogatively.
42191. 
42192. "Yes, sire," replied Rapp.
42193. 
42194. Napoleon took a lozenge, put it in his mouth, and glanced at his watch.
42195. He was not sleepy and it was still not nearly morning. It was impossible
42196. to give further orders for the sake of killing time, for the orders had
42197. all been given and were now being executed.
42198. 
42199. "Have the biscuits and rice been served out to the regiments of the
42200. Guards?" asked Napoleon sternly.
42201. 
42202. "Yes, sire."
42203. 
42204. "The rice too?"
42205. 
42206. Rapp replied that he had given the Emperor's order about the rice, but
42207. Napoleon shook his head in dissatisfaction as if not believing that
42208. his order had been executed. An attendant came in with punch. Napoleon
42209. ordered another glass to be brought for Rapp, and silently sipped his
42210. own.
42211. 
42212. "I have neither taste nor smell," he remarked, sniffing at his glass.
42213. "This cold is tiresome. They talk about medicine--what is the good of
42214. medicine when it can't cure a cold! Corvisart gave me these lozenges but
42215. they don't help at all. What can doctors cure? One can't cure anything.
42216. Our body is a machine for living. It is organized for that, it is its
42217. nature. Let life go on in it unhindered and let it defend itself, it
42218. will do more than if you paralyze it by encumbering it with remedies.
42219. Our body is like a perfect watch that should go for a certain time; the
42220. watchmaker cannot open it, he can only adjust it by fumbling, and that
42221. blindfold.... Yes, our body is just a machine for living, that is all."
42222. 
42223. And having entered on the path of definition, of which he was fond,
42224. Napoleon suddenly and unexpectedly gave a new one.
42225. 
42226. "Do you know, Rapp, what military art is?" asked he. "It is the art of
42227. being stronger than the enemy at a given moment. That's all."
42228. 
42229. Rapp made no reply.
42230. 
42231. "Tomorrow we shall have to deal with Kutuzov!" said Napoleon. "We shall
42232. see! Do you remember at Braunau he commanded an army for three weeks
42233. and did not once mount a horse to inspect his entrenchments.... We shall
42234. see!"
42235. 
42236. He looked at his watch. It was still only four o'clock. He did not feel
42237. sleepy. The punch was finished and there was still nothing to do. He
42238. rose, walked to and fro, put on a warm overcoat and a hat, and went
42239. out of the tent. The night was dark and damp, a scarcely perceptible
42240. moisture was descending from above. Near by, the campfires were dimly
42241. burning among the French Guards, and in the distance those of the
42242. Russian line shone through the smoke. The weather was calm, and the
42243. rustle and tramp of the French troops already beginning to move to take
42244. up their positions were clearly audible.
42245. 
42246. Napoleon walked about in front of his tent, looked at the fires and
42247. listened to these sounds, and as he was passing a tall guardsman in
42248. a shaggy cap, who was standing sentinel before his tent and had drawn
42249. himself up like a black pillar at sight of the Emperor, Napoleon stopped
42250. in front of him.
42251. 
42252. "What year did you enter the service?" he asked with that affectation
42253. of military bluntness and geniality with which he always addressed the
42254. soldiers.
42255. 
42256. The man answered the question.
42257. 
42258. "Ah! One of the old ones! Has your regiment had its rice?"
42259. 
42260. "It has, Your Majesty."
42261. 
42262. Napoleon nodded and walked away.
42263. 
42264. 
42265. At half-past five Napoleon rode to the village of Shevardino.
42266. 
42267. It was growing light, the sky was clearing, only a single cloud lay in
42268. the east. The abandoned campfires were burning themselves out in the
42269. faint morning light.
42270. 
42271. On the right a single deep report of a cannon resounded and died away in
42272. the prevailing silence. Some minutes passed. A second and a third report
42273. shook the air, then a fourth and a fifth boomed solemnly near by on the
42274. right.
42275. 
42276. The first shots had not yet ceased to reverberate before others rang out
42277. and yet more were heard mingling with and overtaking one another.
42278. 
42279. Napoleon with his suite rode up to the Shevardino Redoubt where he
42280. dismounted. The game had begun.
42281. 
42282. 
42283. 
42284. 
42285. 
42286. CHAPTER XXX
42287. 
42288. 
42289. On returning to Gorki after having seen Prince Andrew, Pierre ordered
42290. his groom to get the horses ready and to call him early in the morning,
42291. and then immediately fell asleep behind a partition in a corner Boris
42292. had given up to him.
42293. 
42294. Before he was thoroughly awake next morning everybody had already left
42295. the hut. The panes were rattling in the little windows and his groom was
42296. shaking him.
42297. 
42298. "Your excellency! Your excellency! Your excellency!" he kept repeating
42299. pertinaciously while he shook Pierre by the shoulder without looking at
42300. him, having apparently lost hope of getting him to wake up.
42301. 
42302. "What? Has it begun? Is it time?" Pierre asked, waking up.
42303. 
42304. "Hear the firing," said the groom, a discharged soldier. "All the
42305. gentlemen have gone out, and his Serene Highness himself rode past long
42306. ago."
42307. 
42308. Pierre dressed hastily and ran out to the porch. Outside all was bright,
42309. fresh, dewy, and cheerful. The sun, just bursting forth from behind a
42310. cloud that had concealed it, was shining, with rays still half broken
42311. by the clouds, over the roofs of the street opposite, on the
42312. dew-besprinkled dust of the road, on the walls of the houses, on the
42313. windows, the fence, and on Pierre's horses standing before the hut. The
42314. roar of guns sounded more distinct outside. An adjutant accompanied by a
42315. Cossack passed by at a sharp trot.
42316. 
42317. "It's time, Count; it's time!" cried the adjutant.
42318. 
42319. Telling the groom to follow him with the horses, Pierre went down the
42320. street to the knoll from which he had looked at the field of battle the
42321. day before. A crowd of military men was assembled there, members of the
42322. staff could be heard conversing in French, and Kutuzov's gray head in
42323. a white cap with a red band was visible, his gray nape sunk between his
42324. shoulders. He was looking through a field glass down the highroad before
42325. him.
42326. 
42327. Mounting the steps to the knoll Pierre looked at the scene before him,
42328. spellbound by beauty. It was the same panorama he had admired from that
42329. spot the day before, but now the whole place was full of troops and
42330. covered by smoke clouds from the guns, and the slanting rays of the
42331. bright sun, rising slightly to the left behind Pierre, cast upon it
42332. through the clear morning air penetrating streaks of rosy, golden tinted
42333. light and long dark shadows. The forest at the farthest extremity of
42334. the panorama seemed carved in some precious stone of a yellowish-green
42335. color; its undulating outline was silhouetted against the horizon and
42336. was pierced beyond Valuevo by the Smolensk highroad crowded with troops.
42337. Nearer at hand glittered golden cornfields interspersed with copses.
42338. There were troops to be seen everywhere, in front and to the right and
42339. left. All this was vivid, majestic, and unexpected; but what impressed
42340. Pierre most of all was the view of the battlefield itself, of Borodino
42341. and the hollows on both sides of the Kolocha.
42342. 
42343. Above the Kolocha, in Borodino and on both sides of it, especially to
42344. the left where the Voyna flowing between its marshy banks falls into
42345. the Kolocha, a mist had spread which seemed to melt, to dissolve, and to
42346. become translucent when the brilliant sun appeared and magically colored
42347. and outlined everything. The smoke of the guns mingled with this mist,
42348. and over the whole expanse and through that mist the rays of the morning
42349. sun were reflected, flashing back like lightning from the water, from
42350. the dew, and from the bayonets of the troops crowded together by the
42351. riverbanks and in Borodino. A white church could be seen through the
42352. mist, and here and there the roofs of huts in Borodino as well as dense
42353. masses of soldiers, or green ammunition chests and ordnance. And all
42354. this moved, or seemed to move, as the smoke and mist spread out over
42355. the whole space. Just as in the mist-enveloped hollow near Borodino, so
42356. along the entire line outside and above it and especially in the woods
42357. and fields to the left, in the valleys and on the summits of the high
42358. ground, clouds of powder smoke seemed continually to spring up out of
42359. nothing, now singly, now several at a time, some translucent, others
42360. dense, which, swelling, growing, rolling, and blending, extended over
42361. the whole expanse.
42362. 
42363. These puffs of smoke and (strange to say) the sound of the firing
42364. produced the chief beauty of the spectacle.
42365. 
42366. "Puff!"--suddenly a round compact cloud of smoke was seen merging from
42367. violet into gray and milky white, and "boom!" came the report a second
42368. later.
42369. 
42370. "Puff! puff!"--and two clouds arose pushing one another and blending
42371. together; and "boom, boom!" came the sounds confirming what the eye had
42372. seen.
42373. 
42374. Pierre glanced round at the first cloud, which he had seen as a round
42375. compact ball, and in its place already were balloons of smoke floating
42376. to one side, and--"puff" (with a pause)--"puff, puff!" three and
42377. then four more appeared and then from each, with the same
42378. interval--"boom--boom, boom!" came the fine, firm, precise sounds in
42379. reply. It seemed as if those smoke clouds sometimes ran and sometimes
42380. stood still while woods, fields, and glittering bayonets ran past them.
42381. From the left, over fields and bushes, those large balls of smoke were
42382. continually appearing followed by their solemn reports, while nearer
42383. still, in the hollows and woods, there burst from the muskets small
42384. cloudlets that had no time to become balls, but had their little echoes
42385. in just the same way. "Trakh-ta-ta-takh!" came the frequent crackle of
42386. musketry, but it was irregular and feeble in comparison with the reports
42387. of the cannon.
42388. 
42389. Pierre wished to be there with that smoke, those shining bayonets, that
42390. movement, and those sounds. He turned to look at Kutuzov and his suite,
42391. to compare his impressions with those of others. They were all looking
42392. at the field of battle as he was, and, as it seemed to him, with the
42393. same feelings. All their faces were now shining with that latent warmth
42394. of feeling Pierre had noticed the day before and had fully understood
42395. after his talk with Prince Andrew.
42396. 
42397. "Go, my dear fellow, go... and Christ be with you!" Kutuzov was
42398. saying to a general who stood beside him, not taking his eye from the
42399. battlefield.
42400. 
42401. Having received this order the general passed by Pierre on his way down
42402. the knoll.
42403. 
42404. "To the crossing!" said the general coldly and sternly in reply to one
42405. of the staff who asked where he was going.
42406. 
42407. "I'll go there too, I too!" thought Pierre, and followed the general.
42408. 
42409. The general mounted a horse a Cossack had brought him. Pierre went to
42410. his groom who was holding his horses and, asking which was the quietest,
42411. clambered onto it, seized it by the mane, and turning out his toes
42412. pressed his heels against its sides and, feeling that his spectacles
42413. were slipping off but unable to let go of the mane and reins, he
42414. galloped after the general, causing the staff officers to smile as they
42415. watched him from the knoll.
42416. 
42417. 
42418. 
42419. 
42420. 
42421. CHAPTER XXXI
42422. 
42423. 
42424. Having descended the hill the general after whom Pierre was galloping
42425. turned sharply to the left, and Pierre, losing sight of him, galloped
42426. in among some ranks of infantry marching ahead of him. He tried to pass
42427. either in front of them or to the right or left, but there were soldiers
42428. everywhere, all with the same preoccupied expression and busy with
42429. some unseen but evidently important task. They all gazed with the same
42430. dissatisfied and inquiring expression at this stout man in a white hat,
42431. who for some unknown reason threatened to trample them under his horse's
42432. hoofs.
42433. 
42434. "Why ride into the middle of the battalion?" one of them shouted at him.
42435. 
42436. Another prodded his horse with the butt end of a musket, and Pierre,
42437. bending over his saddlebow and hardly able to control his shying horse,
42438. galloped ahead of the soldiers where there was a free space.
42439. 
42440. There was a bridge ahead of him, where other soldiers stood firing.
42441. Pierre rode up to them. Without being aware of it he had come to the
42442. bridge across the Kolocha between Gorki and Borodino, which the French
42443. (having occupied Borodino) were attacking in the first phase of the
42444. battle. Pierre saw that there was a bridge in front of him and that
42445. soldiers were doing something on both sides of it and in the meadow,
42446. among the rows of new-mown hay which he had taken no notice of amid the
42447. smoke of the campfires the day before; but despite the incessant firing
42448. going on there he had no idea that this was the field of battle. He did
42449. not notice the sound of the bullets whistling from every side, or the
42450. projectiles that flew over him, did not see the enemy on the other side
42451. of the river, and for a long time did not notice the killed and wounded,
42452. though many fell near him. He looked about him with a smile which did
42453. not leave his face.
42454. 
42455. "Why's that fellow in front of the line?" shouted somebody at him again.
42456. 
42457. "To the left!... Keep to the right!" the men shouted to him.
42458. 
42459. Pierre went to the right, and unexpectedly encountered one of Raevski's
42460. adjutants whom he knew. The adjutant looked angrily at him, evidently
42461. also intending to shout at him, but on recognizing him he nodded.
42462. 
42463. "How have you got here?" he said, and galloped on.
42464. 
42465. Pierre, feeling out of place there, having nothing to do, and afraid of
42466. getting in someone's way again, galloped after the adjutant.
42467. 
42468. "What's happening here? May I come with you?" he asked.
42469. 
42470. "One moment, one moment!" replied the adjutant, and riding up to a stout
42471. colonel who was standing in the meadow, he gave him some message and
42472. then addressed Pierre.
42473. 
42474. "Why have you come here, Count?" he asked with a smile. "Still
42475. inquisitive?"
42476. 
42477. "Yes, yes," assented Pierre.
42478. 
42479. But the adjutant turned his horse about and rode on.
42480. 
42481. "Here it's tolerable," said he, "but with Bagration on the left flank
42482. they're getting it frightfully hot."
42483. 
42484. "Really?" said Pierre. "Where is that?"
42485. 
42486. "Come along with me to our knoll. We can get a view from there and in
42487. our battery it is still bearable," said the adjutant. "Will you come?"
42488. 
42489. "Yes, I'll come with you," replied Pierre, looking round for his groom.
42490. 
42491. It was only now that he noticed wounded men staggering along or being
42492. carried on stretchers. On that very meadow he had ridden over the day
42493. before, a soldier was lying athwart the rows of scented hay, with his
42494. head thrown awkwardly back and his shako off.
42495. 
42496. "Why haven't they carried him away?" Pierre was about to ask, but seeing
42497. the stern expression of the adjutant who was also looking that way, he
42498. checked himself.
42499. 
42500. Pierre did not find his groom and rode along the hollow with the
42501. adjutant to Raevski's Redoubt. His horse lagged behind the adjutant's
42502. and jolted him at every step.
42503. 
42504. "You don't seem to be used to riding, Count?" remarked the adjutant.
42505. 
42506. "No it's not that, but her action seems so jerky," said Pierre in a
42507. puzzled tone.
42508. 
42509. "Why... she's wounded!" said the adjutant. "In the off foreleg above the
42510. knee. A bullet, no doubt. I congratulate you, Count, on your baptism of
42511. fire!"
42512. 
42513. Having ridden in the smoke past the Sixth Corps, behind the artillery
42514. which had been moved forward and was in action, deafening them with the
42515. noise of firing, they came to a small wood. There it was cool and quiet,
42516. with a scent of autumn. Pierre and the adjutant dismounted and walked up
42517. the hill on foot.
42518. 
42519. "Is the general here?" asked the adjutant on reaching the knoll.
42520. 
42521. "He was here a minute ago but has just gone that way," someone told him,
42522. pointing to the right.
42523. 
42524. The adjutant looked at Pierre as if puzzled what to do with him now.
42525. 
42526. "Don't trouble about me," said Pierre. "I'll go up onto the knoll if I
42527. may?"
42528. 
42529. "Yes, do. You'll see everything from there and it's less dangerous, and
42530. I'll come for you."
42531. 
42532. Pierre went to the battery and the adjutant rode on. They did not meet
42533. again, and only much later did Pierre learn that he lost an arm that
42534. day.
42535. 
42536. The knoll to which Pierre ascended was that famous one afterwards known
42537. to the Russians as the Knoll Battery or Raevski's Redoubt, and to the
42538. French as la grande redoute, la fatale redoute, la redoute du centre,
42539. around which tens of thousands fell, and which the French regarded as
42540. the key to the whole position.
42541. 
42542. This redoubt consisted of a knoll, on three sides of which trenches had
42543. been dug. Within the entrenchment stood ten guns that were being fired
42544. through openings in the earthwork.
42545. 
42546. In line with the knoll on both sides stood other guns which also fired
42547. incessantly. A little behind the guns stood infantry. When ascending
42548. that knoll Pierre had no notion that this spot, on which small trenches
42549. had been dug and from which a few guns were firing, was the most
42550. important point of the battle.
42551. 
42552. On the contrary, just because he happened to be there he thought it one
42553. of the least significant parts of the field.
42554. 
42555. Having reached the knoll, Pierre sat down at one end of a trench
42556. surrounding the battery and gazed at what was going on around him with
42557. an unconsciously happy smile. Occasionally he rose and walked about the
42558. battery still with that same smile, trying not to obstruct the soldiers
42559. who were loading, hauling the guns, and continually running past
42560. him with bags and charges. The guns of that battery were being fired
42561. continually one after another with a deafening roar, enveloping the
42562. whole neighborhood in powder smoke.
42563. 
42564. In contrast with the dread felt by the infantrymen placed in support,
42565. here in the battery where a small number of men busy at their work were
42566. separated from the rest by a trench, everyone experienced a common and
42567. as it were family feeling of animation.
42568. 
42569. The intrusion of Pierre's nonmilitary figure in a white hat made an
42570. unpleasant impression at first. The soldiers looked askance at him with
42571. surprise and even alarm as they went past him. The senior artillery
42572. officer, a tall, long-legged, pockmarked man, moved over to Pierre as if
42573. to see the action of the farthest gun and looked at him with curiosity.
42574. 
42575. A young round-faced officer, quite a boy still and evidently only just
42576. out of the Cadet College, who was zealously commanding the two guns
42577. entrusted to him, addressed Pierre sternly.
42578. 
42579. "Sir," he said, "permit me to ask you to stand aside. You must not be
42580. here."
42581. 
42582. The soldiers shook their heads disapprovingly as they looked at Pierre.
42583. But when they had convinced themselves that this man in the white hat
42584. was doing no harm, but either sat quietly on the slope of the trench
42585. with a shy smile or, politely making way for the soldiers, paced up
42586. and down the battery under fire as calmly as if he were on a boulevard,
42587. their feeling of hostile distrust gradually began to change into a
42588. kindly and bantering sympathy, such as soldiers feel for their dogs,
42589. cocks, goats, and in general for the animals that live with the
42590. regiment. The men soon accepted Pierre into their family, adopted him,
42591. gave him a nickname ("our gentleman"), and made kindly fun of him among
42592. themselves.
42593. 
42594. A shell tore up the earth two paces from Pierre and he looked around
42595. with a smile as he brushed from his clothes some earth it had thrown up.
42596. 
42597. "And how's it you're not afraid, sir, really now?" a red-faced,
42598. broad-shouldered soldier asked Pierre, with a grin that disclosed a set
42599. of sound, white teeth.
42600. 
42601. "Are you afraid, then?" said Pierre.
42602. 
42603. "What else do you expect?" answered the soldier. "She has no mercy, you
42604. know! When she comes spluttering down, out go your innards. One can't
42605. help being afraid," he said laughing.
42606. 
42607. Several of the men, with bright kindly faces, stopped beside Pierre.
42608. They seemed not to have expected him to talk like anybody else, and the
42609. discovery that he did so delighted them.
42610. 
42611. "It's the business of us soldiers. But in a gentleman it's wonderful!
42612. There's a gentleman for you!"
42613. 
42614. "To your places!" cried the young officer to the men gathered round
42615. Pierre.
42616. 
42617. The young officer was evidently exercising his duties for the first or
42618. second time and therefore treated both his superiors and the men with
42619. great precision and formality.
42620. 
42621. The booming cannonade and the fusillade of musketry were growing more
42622. intense over the whole field, especially to the left where Bagration's
42623. fleches were, but where Pierre was the smoke of the firing made it
42624. almost impossible to distinguish anything. Moreover, his whole attention
42625. was engrossed by watching the family circle--separated from all
42626. else--formed by the men in the battery. His first unconscious feeling
42627. of joyful animation produced by the sights and sounds of the battlefield
42628. was now replaced by another, especially since he had seen that soldier
42629. lying alone in the hayfield. Now, seated on the slope of the trench, he
42630. observed the faces of those around him.
42631. 
42632. By ten o'clock some twenty men had already been carried away from the
42633. battery; two guns were smashed and cannon balls fell more and more
42634. frequently on the battery and spent bullets buzzed and whistled around.
42635. But the men in the battery seemed not to notice this, and merry voices
42636. and jokes were heard on all sides.
42637. 
42638. "A live one!" shouted a man as a whistling shell approached.
42639. 
42640. "Not this way! To the infantry!" added another with loud laughter,
42641. seeing the shell fly past and fall into the ranks of the supports.
42642. 
42643. "Are you bowing to a friend, eh?" remarked another, chaffing a peasant
42644. who ducked low as a cannon ball flew over.
42645. 
42646. Several soldiers gathered by the wall of the trench, looking out to see
42647. what was happening in front.
42648. 
42649. "They've withdrawn the front line, it has retired," said they, pointing
42650. over the earthwork.
42651. 
42652. "Mind your own business," an old sergeant shouted at them. "If they've
42653. retired it's because there's work for them to do farther back."
42654. 
42655. And the sergeant, taking one of the men by the shoulders, gave him a
42656. shove with his knee. This was followed by a burst of laughter.
42657. 
42658. "To the fifth gun, wheel it up!" came shouts from one side.
42659. 
42660. "Now then, all together, like bargees!" rose the merry voices of those
42661. who were moving the gun.
42662. 
42663. "Oh, she nearly knocked our gentleman's hat off!" cried the red-faced
42664. humorist, showing his teeth chaffing Pierre. "Awkward baggage!" he added
42665. reproachfully to a cannon ball that struck a cannon wheel and a man's
42666. leg.
42667. 
42668. "Now then, you foxes!" said another, laughing at some militiamen who,
42669. stooping low, entered the battery to carry away the wounded man.
42670. 
42671. "So this gruel isn't to your taste? Oh, you crows! You're scared!" they
42672. shouted at the militiamen who stood hesitating before the man whose leg
42673. had been torn off.
42674. 
42675. "There, lads... oh, oh!" they mimicked the peasants, "they don't like it
42676. at all!"
42677. 
42678. Pierre noticed that after every ball that hit the redoubt, and after
42679. every loss, the liveliness increased more and more.
42680. 
42681. As the flames of the fire hidden within come more and more vividly and
42682. rapidly from an approaching thundercloud, so, as if in opposition to
42683. what was taking place, the lightning of hidden fire growing more and
42684. more intense glowed in the faces of these men.
42685. 
42686. Pierre did not look out at the battlefield and was not concerned to know
42687. what was happening there; he was entirely absorbed in watching this fire
42688. which burned ever more brightly and which he felt was flaming up in the
42689. same way in his own soul.
42690. 
42691. At ten o'clock the infantry that had been among the bushes in front of
42692. the battery and along the Kamenka streamlet retreated. From the battery
42693. they could be seen running back past it carrying their wounded on
42694. their muskets. A general with his suite came to the battery, and after
42695. speaking to the colonel gave Pierre an angry look and went away again
42696. having ordered the infantry supports behind the battery to lie down,
42697. so as to be less exposed to fire. After this from amid the ranks of
42698. infantry to the right of the battery came the sound of a drum and shouts
42699. of command, and from the battery one saw how those ranks of infantry
42700. moved forward.
42701. 
42702. Pierre looked over the wall of the trench and was particularly struck
42703. by a pale young officer who, letting his sword hang down, was walking
42704. backwards and kept glancing uneasily around.
42705. 
42706. The ranks of the infantry disappeared amid the smoke but their
42707. long-drawn shout and rapid musketry firing could still be heard. A few
42708. minutes later crowds of wounded men and stretcher-bearers came back from
42709. that direction. Projectiles began to fall still more frequently in the
42710. battery. Several men were lying about who had not been removed. Around
42711. the cannon the men moved still more briskly and busily. No one any
42712. longer took notice of Pierre. Once or twice he was shouted at for being
42713. in the way. The senior officer moved with big, rapid strides from one
42714. gun to another with a frowning face. The young officer, with his face
42715. still more flushed, commanded the men more scrupulously than ever. The
42716. soldiers handed up the charges, turned, loaded, and did their business
42717. with strained smartness. They gave little jumps as they walked, as
42718. though they were on springs.
42719. 
42720. The stormcloud had come upon them, and in every face the fire which
42721. Pierre had watched kindle burned up brightly. Pierre standing beside the
42722. commanding officer. The young officer, his hand to his shako, ran up to
42723. his superior.
42724. 
42725. "I have the honor to report, sir, that only eight rounds are left. Are
42726. we to continue firing?" he asked.
42727. 
42728. "Grapeshot!" the senior shouted, without answering the question, looking
42729. over the wall of the trench.
42730. 
42731. Suddenly something happened: the young officer gave a gasp and bending
42732. double sat down on the ground like a bird shot on the wing. Everything
42733. became strange, confused, and misty in Pierre's eyes.
42734. 
42735. One cannon ball after another whistled by and struck the earthwork, a
42736. soldier, or a gun. Pierre, who had not noticed these sounds before,
42737. now heard nothing else. On the right of the battery soldiers shouting
42738. "Hurrah!" were running not forwards but backwards, it seemed to Pierre.
42739. 
42740. A cannon ball struck the very end of the earth work by which he was
42741. standing, crumbling down the earth; a black ball flashed before his eyes
42742. and at the same instant plumped into something. Some militiamen who were
42743. entering the battery ran back.
42744. 
42745. "All with grapeshot!" shouted the officer.
42746. 
42747. The sergeant ran up to the officer and in a frightened whisper informed
42748. him (as a butler at dinner informs his master that there is no more of
42749. some wine asked for) that there were no more charges.
42750. 
42751. "The scoundrels! What are they doing?" shouted the officer, turning to
42752. Pierre.
42753. 
42754. The officer's face was red and perspiring and his eyes glittered under
42755. his frowning brow.
42756. 
42757. "Run to the reserves and bring up the ammunition boxes!" he yelled,
42758. angrily avoiding Pierre with his eyes and speaking to his men.
42759. 
42760. "I'll go," said Pierre.
42761. 
42762. The officer, without answering him, strode across to the opposite side.
42763. 
42764. "Don't fire.... Wait!" he shouted.
42765. 
42766. The man who had been ordered to go for ammunition stumbled against
42767. Pierre.
42768. 
42769. "Eh, sir, this is no place for you," said he, and ran down the slope.
42770. 
42771. Pierre ran after him, avoiding the spot where the young officer was
42772. sitting.
42773. 
42774. One cannon ball, another, and a third flew over him, falling in front,
42775. beside, and behind him. Pierre ran down the slope. "Where am I going?"
42776. he suddenly asked himself when he was already near the green ammunition
42777. wagons. He halted irresolutely, not knowing whether to return or go on.
42778. Suddenly a terrible concussion threw him backwards to the ground. At the
42779. same instant he was dazzled by a great flash of flame, and immediately a
42780. deafening roar, crackling, and whistling made his ears tingle.
42781. 
42782. When he came to himself he was sitting on the ground leaning on his
42783. hands; the ammunition wagons he had been approaching no longer existed,
42784. only charred green boards and rags littered the scorched grass, and a
42785. horse, dangling fragments of its shaft behind it, galloped past, while
42786. another horse lay, like Pierre, on the ground, uttering prolonged and
42787. piercing cries.
42788. 
42789. 
42790. 
42791. 
42792. 
42793. CHAPTER XXXII
42794. 
42795. 
42796. Beside himself with terror Pierre jumped up and ran back to the battery,
42797. as to the only refuge from the horrors that surrounded him.
42798. 
42799. On entering the earthwork he noticed that there were men doing something
42800. there but that no shots were being fired from the battery. He had no
42801. time to realize who these men were. He saw the senior officer lying on
42802. the earth wall with his back turned as if he were examining something
42803. down below and that one of the soldiers he had noticed before was
42804. struggling forward shouting "Brothers!" and trying to free himself from
42805. some men who were holding him by the arm. He also saw something else
42806. that was strange.
42807. 
42808. But he had not time to realize that the colonel had been killed, that
42809. the soldier shouting "Brothers!" was a prisoner, and that another man
42810. had been bayoneted in the back before his eyes, for hardly had he run
42811. into the redoubt before a thin, sallow-faced, perspiring man in a blue
42812. uniform rushed on him sword in hand, shouting something. Instinctively
42813. guarding against the shock--for they had been running together at full
42814. speed before they saw one another--Pierre put out his hands and seized
42815. the man (a French officer) by the shoulder with one hand and by the
42816. throat with the other. The officer, dropping his sword, seized Pierre by
42817. his collar.
42818. 
42819. For some seconds they gazed with frightened eyes at one another's
42820. unfamiliar faces and both were perplexed at what they had done and
42821. what they were to do next. "Am I taken prisoner or have I taken him
42822. prisoner?" each was thinking. But the French officer was evidently more
42823. inclined to think he had been taken prisoner because Pierre's strong
42824. hand, impelled by instinctive fear, squeezed his throat ever tighter and
42825. tighter. The Frenchman was about to say something, when just above their
42826. heads, terrible and low, a cannon ball whistled, and it seemed to Pierre
42827. that the French officer's head had been torn off, so swiftly had he
42828. ducked it.
42829. 
42830. Pierre too bent his head and let his hands fall. Without further thought
42831. as to who had taken whom prisoner, the Frenchman ran back to the battery
42832. and Pierre ran down the slope stumbling over the dead and wounded who,
42833. it seemed to him, caught at his feet. But before he reached the foot
42834. of the knoll he was met by a dense crowd of Russian soldiers who,
42835. stumbling, tripping up, and shouting, ran merrily and wildly toward
42836. the battery. (This was the attack for which Ermolov claimed the credit,
42837. declaring that only his courage and good luck made such a feat possible:
42838. it was the attack in which he was said to have thrown some St. George's
42839. Crosses he had in his pocket into the battery for the first soldiers to
42840. take who got there.)
42841. 
42842. The French who had occupied the battery fled, and our troops shouting
42843. "Hurrah!" pursued them so far beyond the battery that it was difficult
42844. to call them back.
42845. 
42846. The prisoners were brought down from the battery and among them was
42847. a wounded French general, whom the officers surrounded. Crowds of
42848. wounded--some known to Pierre and some unknown--Russians and French,
42849. with faces distorted by suffering, walked, crawled, and were carried on
42850. stretchers from the battery. Pierre again went up onto the knoll where
42851. he had spent over an hour, and of that family circle which had received
42852. him as a member he did not find a single one. There were many dead whom
42853. he did not know, but some he recognized. The young officer still sat in
42854. the same way, bent double, in a pool of blood at the edge of the earth
42855. wall. The red-faced man was still twitching, but they did not carry him
42856. away.
42857. 
42858. Pierre ran down the slope once more.
42859. 
42860. "Now they will stop it, now they will be horrified at what they have
42861. done!" he thought, aimlessly going toward a crowd of stretcher bearers
42862. moving from the battlefield.
42863. 
42864. But behind the veil of smoke the sun was still high, and in front and
42865. especially to the left, near Semenovsk, something seemed to be seething
42866. in the smoke, and the roar of cannon and musketry did not diminish, but
42867. even increased to desperation like a man who, straining himself, shrieks
42868. with all his remaining strength.
42869. 
42870. 
42871. 
42872. 
42873. 
42874. CHAPTER XXXIII
42875. 
42876. 
42877. The chief action of the battle of Borodino was fought within the seven
42878. thousand feet between Borodino and Bagration's fleches. Beyond that
42879. space there was, on the one side, a demonstration made by the Russians
42880. with Uvarov's cavalry at midday, and on the other side, beyond Utitsa,
42881. Poniatowski's collision with Tuchkov; but these two were detached and
42882. feeble actions in comparison with what took place in the center of the
42883. battlefield. On the field between Borodino and the fleches, beside the
42884. wood, the chief action of the day took place on an open space visible
42885. from both sides and was fought in the simplest and most artless way.
42886. 
42887. The battle began on both sides with a cannonade from several hundred
42888. guns.
42889. 
42890. Then when the whole field was covered with smoke, two divisions,
42891. Campan's and Dessaix's, advanced from the French right, while Murat's
42892. troops advanced on Borodino from their left.
42893. 
42894. From the Shevardino Redoubt where Napoleon was standing the fleches were
42895. two thirds of a mile away, and it was more than a mile as the crow flies
42896. to Borodino, so that Napoleon could not see what was happening there,
42897. especially as the smoke mingling with the mist hid the whole locality.
42898. The soldiers of Dessaix's division advancing against the fleches could
42899. only be seen till they had entered the hollow that lay between them and
42900. the fleches. As soon as they had descended into that hollow, the smoke
42901. of the guns and musketry on the fleches grew so dense that it covered
42902. the whole approach on that side of it. Through the smoke glimpses could
42903. be caught of something black--probably men--and at times the glint of
42904. bayonets. But whether they were moving or stationary, whether they were
42905. French or Russian, could not be discovered from the Shevardino Redoubt.
42906. 
42907. The sun had risen brightly and its slanting rays struck straight into
42908. Napoleon's face as, shading his eyes with his hand, he looked at the
42909. fleches. The smoke spread out before them, and at times it looked as if
42910. the smoke were moving, at times as if the troops moved. Sometimes shouts
42911. were heard through the firing, but it was impossible to tell what was
42912. being done there.
42913. 
42914. Napoleon, standing on the knoll, looked through a field glass, and in
42915. its small circlet saw smoke and men, sometimes his own and sometimes
42916. Russians, but when he looked again with the naked eye, he could not tell
42917. where what he had seen was.
42918. 
42919. He descended the knoll and began walking up and down before it.
42920. 
42921. Occasionally he stopped, listened to the firing, and gazed intently at
42922. the battlefield.
42923. 
42924. But not only was it impossible to make out what was happening from where
42925. he was standing down below, or from the knoll above on which some of his
42926. generals had taken their stand, but even from the fleches themselves--in
42927. which by this time there were now Russian and now French soldiers,
42928. alternately or together, dead, wounded, alive, frightened, or
42929. maddened--even at those fleches themselves it was impossible to make out
42930. what was taking place. There for several hours amid incessant cannon and
42931. musketry fire, now Russians were seen alone, now Frenchmen alone, now
42932. infantry, and now cavalry: they appeared, fired, fell, collided, not
42933. knowing what to do with one another, screamed, and ran back again.
42934. 
42935. From the battlefield adjutants he had sent out, and orderlies from his
42936. marshals, kept galloping up to Napoleon with reports of the progress
42937. of the action, but all these reports were false, both because it was
42938. impossible in the heat of battle to say what was happening at any given
