42939. moment and because many of the adjutants did not go to the actual place
42940. of conflict but reported what they had heard from others; and also
42941. because while an adjutant was riding more than a mile to Napoleon
42942. circumstances changed and the news he brought was already becoming
42943. false. Thus an adjutant galloped up from Murat with tidings that
42944. Borodino had been occupied and the bridge over the Kolocha was in the
42945. hands of the French. The adjutant asked whether Napoleon wished the
42946. troops to cross it? Napoleon gave orders that the troops should form up
42947. on the farther side and wait. But before that order was given--almost
42948. as soon in fact as the adjutant had left Borodino--the bridge had been
42949. retaken by the Russians and burned, in the very skirmish at which Pierre
42950. had been present at the beginning of the battle.
42951. 
42952. An adjutant galloped up from the fleches with a pale and frightened face
42953. and reported to Napoleon that their attack had been repulsed, Campan
42954. wounded, and Davout killed; yet at the very time the adjutant had been
42955. told that the French had been repulsed, the fleches had in fact been
42956. recaptured by other French troops, and Davout was alive and only
42957. slightly bruised. On the basis of these necessarily untrustworthy
42958. reports Napoleon gave his orders, which had either been executed before
42959. he gave them or could not be and were not executed.
42960. 
42961. The marshals and generals, who were nearer to the field of battle
42962. but, like Napoleon, did not take part in the actual fighting and only
42963. occasionally went within musket range, made their own arrangements
42964. without asking Napoleon and issued orders where and in what direction to
42965. fire and where cavalry should gallop and infantry should run. But even
42966. their orders, like Napoleon's, were seldom carried out, and then but
42967. partially. For the most part things happened contrary to their orders.
42968. Soldiers ordered to advance ran back on meeting grapeshot; soldiers
42969. ordered to remain where they were, suddenly, seeing Russians
42970. unexpectedly before them, sometimes rushed back and sometimes forward,
42971. and the cavalry dashed without orders in pursuit of the flying Russians.
42972. In this way two cavalry regiments galloped through the Semenovsk hollow
42973. and as soon as they reached the top of the incline turned round and
42974. galloped full speed back again. The infantry moved in the same way,
42975. sometimes running to quite other places than those they were ordered to
42976. go to. All orders as to where and when to move the guns, when to send
42977. infantry to shoot or horsemen to ride down the Russian infantry--all
42978. such orders were given by the officers on the spot nearest to the
42979. units concerned, without asking either Ney, Davout, or Murat, much less
42980. Napoleon. They did not fear getting into trouble for not fulfilling
42981. orders or for acting on their own initiative, for in battle what is at
42982. stake is what is dearest to man--his own life--and it sometimes seems
42983. that safety lies in running back, sometimes in running forward; and
42984. these men who were right in the heat of the battle acted according to
42985. the mood of the moment. In reality, however, all these movements forward
42986. and backward did not improve or alter the position of the troops. All
42987. their rushing and galloping at one another did little harm, the harm of
42988. disablement and death was caused by the balls and bullets that flew over
42989. the fields on which these men were floundering about. As soon as they
42990. left the place where the balls and bullets were flying about, their
42991. superiors, located in the background, re-formed them and brought them
42992. under discipline and under the influence of that discipline led them
42993. back to the zone of fire, where under the influence of fear of death
42994. they lost their discipline and rushed about according to the chance
42995. promptings of the throng.
42996. 
42997. 
42998. 
42999. 
43000. 
43001. CHAPTER XXXIV
43002. 
43003. 
43004. Napoleon's generals--Davout, Ney, and Murat, who were near that region
43005. of fire and sometimes even entered it--repeatedly led into it huge
43006. masses of well-ordered troops. But contrary to what had always happened
43007. in their former battles, instead of the news they expected of the
43008. enemy's flight, these orderly masses returned thence as disorganized
43009. and terrified mobs. The generals re-formed them, but their numbers
43010. constantly decreased. In the middle of the day Murat sent his adjutant
43011. to Napoleon to demand reinforcements.
43012. 
43013. Napoleon sat at the foot of the knoll, drinking punch, when Murat's
43014. adjutant galloped up with an assurance that the Russians would be routed
43015. if His Majesty would let him have another division.
43016. 
43017. "Reinforcements?" said Napoleon in a tone of stern surprise, looking at
43018. the adjutant--a handsome lad with long black curls arranged like Murat's
43019. own--as though he did not understand his words.
43020. 
43021. "Reinforcements!" thought Napoleon to himself. "How can they need
43022. reinforcements when they already have half the army directed against a
43023. weak, unentrenched Russian wing?"
43024. 
43025. "Tell the King of Naples," said he sternly, "that it is not noon yet,
43026. and I don't yet see my chessboard clearly. Go!..."
43027. 
43028. The handsome boy adjutant with the long hair sighed deeply without
43029. removing his hand from his hat and galloped back to where men were being
43030. slaughtered.
43031. 
43032. Napoleon rose and having summoned Caulaincourt and Berthier began
43033. talking to them about matters unconnected with the battle.
43034. 
43035. In the midst of this conversation, which was beginning to interest
43036. Napoleon, Berthier's eyes turned to look at a general with a suite, who
43037. was galloping toward the knoll on a lathering horse. It was Belliard.
43038. Having dismounted he went up to the Emperor with rapid strides and in
43039. a loud voice began boldly demonstrating the necessity of sending
43040. reinforcements. He swore on his honor that the Russians were lost if the
43041. Emperor would give another division.
43042. 
43043. Napoleon shrugged his shoulders and continued to pace up and down
43044. without replying. Belliard began talking loudly and eagerly to the
43045. generals of the suite around him.
43046. 
43047. "You are very fiery, Belliard," said Napoleon, when he again came up to
43048. the general. "In the heat of a battle it is easy to make a mistake. Go
43049. and have another look and then come back to me."
43050. 
43051. Before Belliard was out of sight, a messenger from another part of the
43052. battlefield galloped up.
43053. 
43054. "Now then, what do you want?" asked Napoleon in the tone of a man
43055. irritated at being continually disturbed.
43056. 
43057. "Sire, the prince..." began the adjutant.
43058. 
43059. "Asks for reinforcements?" said Napoleon with an angry gesture.
43060. 
43061. The adjutant bent his head affirmatively and began to report, but the
43062. Emperor turned from him, took a couple of steps, stopped, came back, and
43063. called Berthier.
43064. 
43065. "We must give reserves," he said, moving his arms slightly apart.
43066. "Who do you think should be sent there?" he asked of Berthier (whom he
43067. subsequently termed "that gosling I have made an eagle").
43068. 
43069. "Send Claparede's division, sire," replied Berthier, who knew all the
43070. divisions regiments, and battalions by heart.
43071. 
43072. Napoleon nodded assent.
43073. 
43074. The adjutant galloped to Claparede's division and a few minutes later
43075. the Young Guards stationed behind the knoll moved forward. Napoleon
43076. gazed silently in that direction.
43077. 
43078. "No!" he suddenly said to Berthier. "I can't send Claparede. Send
43079. Friant's division."
43080. 
43081. Though there was no advantage in sending Friant's division instead of
43082. Claparede's, and even in obvious inconvenience and delay in stopping
43083. Claparede and sending Friant now, the order was carried out exactly.
43084. Napoleon did not notice that in regard to his army he was playing the
43085. part of a doctor who hinders by his medicines--a role he so justly
43086. understood and condemned.
43087. 
43088. Friant's division disappeared as the others had done into the smoke
43089. of the battlefield. From all sides adjutants continued to arrive at a
43090. gallop and as if by agreement all said the same thing. They all asked
43091. for reinforcements and all said that the Russians were holding their
43092. positions and maintaining a hellish fire under which the French army was
43093. melting away.
43094. 
43095. Napoleon sat on a campstool, wrapped in thought.
43096. 
43097. M. de Beausset, the man so fond of travel, having fasted since morning,
43098. came up to the Emperor and ventured respectfully to suggest lunch to His
43099. Majesty.
43100. 
43101. "I hope I may now congratulate Your Majesty on a victory?" said he.
43102. 
43103. Napoleon silently shook his head in negation. Assuming the negation to
43104. refer only to the victory and not to the lunch, M. de Beausset ventured
43105. with respectful jocularity to remark that there is no reason for not
43106. having lunch when one can get it.
43107. 
43108. "Go away..." exclaimed Napoleon suddenly and morosely, and turned aside.
43109. 
43110. A beatific smile of regret, repentance, and ecstasy beamed on M. de
43111. Beausset's face and he glided away to the other generals.
43112. 
43113. Napoleon was experiencing a feeling of depression like that of an
43114. ever-lucky gambler who, after recklessly flinging money about and always
43115. winning, suddenly just when he has calculated all the chances of the
43116. game, finds that the more he considers his play the more surely he
43117. loses.
43118. 
43119. His troops were the same, his generals the same, the same preparations
43120. had been made, the same dispositions, and the same proclamation courte
43121. et energique, he himself was still the same: he knew that and knew that
43122. he was now even more experienced and skillful than before. Even the
43123. enemy was the same as at Austerlitz and Friedland--yet the terrible
43124. stroke of his arm had supernaturally become impotent.
43125. 
43126. All the old methods that had been unfailingly crowned with success: the
43127. concentration of batteries on one point, an attack by reserves to break
43128. the enemy's line, and a cavalry attack by "the men of iron," all these
43129. methods had already been employed, yet not only was there no victory,
43130. but from all sides came the same news of generals killed and wounded,
43131. of reinforcements needed, of the impossibility of driving back the
43132. Russians, and of disorganization among his own troops.
43133. 
43134. Formerly, after he had given two or three orders and uttered a
43135. few phrases, marshals and adjutants had come galloping up with
43136. congratulations and happy faces, announcing the trophies taken, the
43137. corps of prisoners, bundles of enemy eagles and standards, cannon and
43138. stores, and Murat had only begged leave to loose the cavalry to gather
43139. in the baggage wagons. So it had been at Lodi, Marengo, Arcola, Jena,
43140. Austerlitz, Wagram, and so on. But now something strange was happening
43141. to his troops.
43142. 
43143. Despite news of the capture of the fleches, Napoleon saw that this was
43144. not the same, not at all the same, as what had happened in his former
43145. battles. He saw that what he was feeling was felt by all the men about
43146. him experienced in the art of war. All their faces looked dejected, and
43147. they all shunned one another's eyes--only a de Beausset could fail to
43148. grasp the meaning of what was happening.
43149. 
43150. But Napoleon with his long experience of war well knew the meaning of
43151. a battle not gained by the attacking side in eight hours, after all
43152. efforts had been expended. He knew that it was a lost battle and that
43153. the least accident might now--with the fight balanced on such a strained
43154. center--destroy him and his army.
43155. 
43156. When he ran his mind over the whole of this strange Russian campaign in
43157. which not one battle had been won, and in which not a flag, or cannon,
43158. or army corps had been captured in two months, when he looked at the
43159. concealed depression on the faces around him and heard reports of the
43160. Russians still holding their ground--a terrible feeling like a nightmare
43161. took possession of him, and all the unlucky accidents that might destroy
43162. him occurred to his mind. The Russians might fall on his left wing,
43163. might break through his center, he himself might be killed by a stray
43164. cannon ball. All this was possible. In former battles he had only
43165. considered the possibilities of success, but now innumerable unlucky
43166. chances presented themselves, and he expected them all. Yes, it was like
43167. a dream in which a man fancies that a ruffian is coming to attack him,
43168. and raises his arm to strike that ruffian a terrible blow which he knows
43169. should annihilate him, but then feels that his arm drops powerless and
43170. limp like a rag, and the horror of unavoidable destruction seizes him in
43171. his helplessness.
43172. 
43173. The news that the Russians were attacking the left flank of the French
43174. army aroused that horror in Napoleon. He sat silently on a campstool
43175. below the knoll, with head bowed and elbows on his knees. Berthier
43176. approached and suggested that they should ride along the line to
43177. ascertain the position of affairs.
43178. 
43179. "What? What do you say?" asked Napoleon. "Yes, tell them to bring me my
43180. horse."
43181. 
43182. He mounted and rode toward Semenovsk.
43183. 
43184. Amid the powder smoke, slowly dispersing over the whole space through
43185. which Napoleon rode, horses and men were lying in pools of blood, singly
43186. or in heaps. Neither Napoleon nor any of his generals had ever before
43187. seen such horrors or so many slain in such a small area. The roar of
43188. guns, that had not ceased for ten hours, wearied the ear and gave
43189. a peculiar significance to the spectacle, as music does to tableaux
43190. vivants. Napoleon rode up the high ground at Semenovsk, and through the
43191. smoke saw ranks of men in uniforms of a color unfamiliar to him. They
43192. were Russians.
43193. 
43194. The Russians stood in serried ranks behind Semenovsk village and its
43195. knoll, and their guns boomed incessantly along their line and sent
43196. forth clouds of smoke. It was no longer a battle: it was a continuous
43197. slaughter which could be of no avail either to the French or the
43198. Russians. Napoleon stopped his horse and again fell into the reverie
43199. from which Berthier had aroused him. He could not stop what was going on
43200. before him and around him and was supposed to be directed by him and to
43201. depend on him, and from its lack of success this affair, for the first
43202. time, seemed to him unnecessary and horrible.
43203. 
43204. One of the generals rode up to Napoleon and ventured to offer to lead
43205. the Old Guard into action. Ney and Berthier, standing near Napoleon,
43206. exchanged looks and smiled contemptuously at this general's senseless
43207. offer.
43208. 
43209. Napoleon bowed his head and remained silent a long time.
43210. 
43211. "At eight hundred leagues from France, I will not have my Guard
43212. destroyed!" he said, and turning his horse rode back to Shevardino.
43213. 
43214. 
43215. 
43216. 
43217. 
43218. CHAPTER XXXV
43219. 
43220. 
43221. On the rug-covered bench where Pierre had seen him in the morning sat
43222. Kutuzov, his gray head hanging, his heavy body relaxed. He gave no
43223. orders, but only assented to or dissented from what others suggested.
43224. 
43225. "Yes, yes, do that," he replied to various proposals. "Yes, yes: go,
43226. dear boy, and have a look," he would say to one or another of those
43227. about him; or, "No, don't, we'd better wait!" He listened to the reports
43228. that were brought him and gave directions when his subordinates demanded
43229. that of him; but when listening to the reports it seemed as if he
43230. were not interested in the import of the words spoken, but rather in
43231. something else--in the expression of face and tone of voice of those who
43232. were reporting. By long years of military experience he knew, and with
43233. the wisdom of age understood, that it is impossible for one man to
43234. direct hundreds of thousands of others struggling with death, and he
43235. knew that the result of a battle is decided not by the orders of a
43236. commander in chief, nor the place where the troops are stationed, nor by
43237. the number of cannon or of slaughtered men, but by that intangible force
43238. called the spirit of the army, and he watched this force and guided it
43239. in as far as that was in his power.
43240. 
43241. Kutuzov's general expression was one of concentrated quiet attention,
43242. and his face wore a strained look as if he found it difficult to master
43243. the fatigue of his old and feeble body.
43244. 
43245. At eleven o'clock they brought him news that the fleches captured by the
43246. French had been retaken, but that Prince Bagration was wounded. Kutuzov
43247. groaned and swayed his head.
43248. 
43249. "Ride over to Prince Peter Ivanovich and find out about it exactly," he
43250. said to one of his adjutants, and then turned to the Duke of Wurttemberg
43251. who was standing behind him.
43252. 
43253. "Will Your Highness please take command of the first army?"
43254. 
43255. Soon after the duke's departure--before he could possibly have reached
43256. Semenovsk--his adjutant came back from him and told Kutuzov that the
43257. duke asked for more troops.
43258. 
43259. Kutuzov made a grimace and sent an order to Dokhturov to take over the
43260. command of the first army, and a request to the duke--whom he said he
43261. could not spare at such an important moment--to return to him. When
43262. they brought him news that Murat had been taken prisoner, and the staff
43263. officers congratulated him, Kutuzov smiled.
43264. 
43265. "Wait a little, gentlemen," said he. "The battle is won, and there is
43266. nothing extraordinary in the capture of Murat. Still, it is better to
43267. wait before we rejoice."
43268. 
43269. But he sent an adjutant to take the news round the army.
43270. 
43271. When Scherbinin came galloping from the left flank with news that the
43272. French had captured the fleches and the village of Semenovsk, Kutuzov,
43273. guessing by the sounds of the battle and by Scherbinin's looks that the
43274. news was bad, rose as if to stretch his legs and, taking Scherbinin's
43275. arm, led him aside.
43276. 
43277. "Go, my dear fellow," he said to Ermolov, "and see whether something
43278. can't be done."
43279. 
43280. Kutuzov was in Gorki, near the center of the Russian position. The
43281. attack directed by Napoleon against our left flank had been several
43282. times repulsed. In the center the French had not got beyond Borodino,
43283. and on their left flank Uvarov's cavalry had put the French to flight.
43284. 
43285. Toward three o'clock the French attacks ceased. On the faces of all
43286. who came from the field of battle, and of those who stood around him,
43287. Kutuzov noticed an expression of extreme tension. He was satisfied with
43288. the day's success--a success exceeding his expectations, but the old
43289. man's strength was failing him. Several times his head dropped low as if
43290. it were falling and he dozed off. Dinner was brought him.
43291. 
43292. Adjutant General Wolzogen, the man who when riding past Prince Andrew
43293. had said, "the war should be extended widely," and whom Bagration so
43294. detested, rode up while Kutuzov was at dinner. Wolzogen had come from
43295. Barclay de Tolly to report on the progress of affairs on the left flank.
43296. The sagacious Barclay de Tolly, seeing crowds of wounded men running
43297. back and the disordered rear of the army, weighed all the circumstances,
43298. concluded that the battle was lost, and sent his favorite officer to the
43299. commander in chief with that news.
43300. 
43301. Kutuzov was chewing a piece of roast chicken with difficulty and glanced
43302. at Wolzogen with eyes that brightened under their puckering lids.
43303. 
43304. Wolzogen, nonchalantly stretching his legs, approached Kutuzov with a
43305. half-contemptuous smile on his lips, scarcely touching the peak of his
43306. cap.
43307. 
43308. He treated his Serene Highness with a somewhat affected nonchalance
43309. intended to show that, as a highly trained military man, he left it to
43310. Russians to make an idol of this useless old man, but that he knew whom
43311. he was dealing with. "Der alte Herr" (as in their own set the Germans
43312. called Kutuzov) "is making himself very comfortable," thought Wolzogen,
43313. and looking severely at the dishes in front of Kutuzov he began to
43314. report to "the old gentleman" the position of affairs on the left flank
43315. as Barclay had ordered him to and as he himself had seen and understood
43316. it.
43317. 
43318. "All the points of our position are in the enemy's hands and we cannot
43319. dislodge them for lack of troops, the men are running away and it is
43320. impossible to stop them," he reported.
43321. 
43322. Kutuzov ceased chewing and fixed an astonished gaze on Wolzogen, as
43323. if not understanding what was said to him. Wolzogen, noticing "the old
43324. gentleman's" agitation, said with a smile:
43325. 
43326. "I have not considered it right to conceal from your Serene Highness
43327. what I have seen. The troops are in complete disorder..."
43328. 
43329. "You have seen? You have seen?..." Kutuzov shouted frowning, and rising
43330. quickly he went up to Wolzogen.
43331. 
43332. "How... how dare you!..." he shouted, choking and making a threatening
43333. gesture with his trembling arms: "How dare you, sir, say that to me? You
43334. know nothing about it. Tell General Barclay from me that his information
43335. is incorrect and that the real course of the battle is better known to
43336. me, the commander in chief, than to him."
43337. 
43338. Wolzogen was about to make a rejoinder, but Kutuzov interrupted him.
43339. 
43340. "The enemy has been repulsed on the left and defeated on the right
43341. flank. If you have seen amiss, sir, do not allow yourself to say what
43342. you don't know! Be so good as to ride to General Barclay and inform
43343. him of my firm intention to attack the enemy tomorrow," said Kutuzov
43344. sternly.
43345. 
43346. All were silent, and the only sound audible was the heavy breathing of
43347. the panting old general.
43348. 
43349. "They are repulsed everywhere, for which I thank God and our brave army!
43350. The enemy is beaten, and tomorrow we shall drive him from the sacred
43351. soil of Russia," said Kutuzov crossing himself, and he suddenly sobbed
43352. as his eyes filled with tears.
43353. 
43354. Wolzogen, shrugging his shoulders and curling his lips, stepped silently
43355. aside, marveling at "the old gentleman's" conceited stupidity.
43356. 
43357. "Ah, here he is, my hero!" said Kutuzov to a portly, handsome,
43358. dark-haired general who was just ascending the knoll.
43359. 
43360. This was Raevski, who had spent the whole day at the most important part
43361. of the field of Borodino.
43362. 
43363. Raevski reported that the troops were firmly holding their ground and
43364. that the French no longer ventured to attack.
43365. 
43366. After hearing him, Kutuzov said in French:
43367. 
43368. "Then you do not think, like some others, that we must retreat?"
43369. 
43370. "On the contrary, your Highness, in indecisive actions it is always
43371. the most stubborn who remain victors," replied Raevski, "and in my
43372. opinion..."
43373. 
43374. "Kaysarov!" Kutuzov called to his adjutant. "Sit down and write out
43375. the order of the day for tomorrow. And you," he continued, addressing
43376. another, "ride along the line and announce that tomorrow we attack."
43377. 
43378. While Kutuzov was talking to Raevski and dictating the order of the day,
43379. Wolzogen returned from Barclay and said that General Barclay wished to
43380. have written confirmation of the order the field marshal had given.
43381. 
43382. Kutuzov, without looking at Wolzogen, gave directions for the order to
43383. be written out which the former commander in chief, to avoid personal
43384. responsibility, very judiciously wished to receive.
43385. 
43386. And by means of that mysterious indefinable bond which maintains
43387. throughout an army one and the same temper, known as "the spirit of
43388. the army," and which constitutes the sinew of war, Kutuzov's words, his
43389. order for a battle next day, immediately became known from one end of
43390. the army to the other.
43391. 
43392. It was far from being the same words or the same order that reached the
43393. farthest links of that chain. The tales passing from mouth to mouth at
43394. different ends of the army did not even resemble what Kutuzov had said,
43395. but the sense of his words spread everywhere because what he said was
43396. not the outcome of cunning calculations, but of a feeling that lay in
43397. the commander in chief's soul as in that of every Russian.
43398. 
43399. And on learning that tomorrow they were to attack the enemy, and hearing
43400. from the highest quarters a confirmation of what they wanted to believe,
43401. the exhausted, wavering men felt comforted and inspirited.
43402. 
43403. 
43404. 
43405. 
43406. 
43407. CHAPTER XXXVI
43408. 
43409. 
43410. Prince Andrew's regiment was among the reserves which till after one
43411. o'clock were stationed inactive behind Semenovsk, under heavy artillery
43412. fire. Toward two o'clock the regiment, having already lost more than
43413. two hundred men, was moved forward into a trampled oatfield in the gap
43414. between Semenovsk and the Knoll Battery, where thousands of men perished
43415. that day and on which an intense, concentrated fire from several hundred
43416. enemy guns was directed between one and two o'clock.
43417. 
43418. Without moving from that spot or firing a single shot the regiment here
43419. lost another third of its men. From in front and especially from the
43420. right, in the unlifting smoke the guns boomed, and out of the mysterious
43421. domain of smoke that overlay the whole space in front, quick hissing
43422. cannon balls and slow whistling shells flew unceasingly. At times, as
43423. if to allow them a respite, a quarter of an hour passed during which
43424. the cannon balls and shells all flew overhead, but sometimes several men
43425. were torn from the regiment in a minute and the slain were continually
43426. being dragged away and the wounded carried off.
43427. 
43428. With each fresh blow less and less chance of life remained for those not
43429. yet killed. The regiment stood in columns of battalion, three hundred
43430. paces apart, but nevertheless the men were always in one and the same
43431. mood. All alike were taciturn and morose. Talk was rarely heard in the
43432. ranks, and it ceased altogether every time the thud of a successful
43433. shot and the cry of "stretchers!" was heard. Most of the time, by their
43434. officers' order, the men sat on the ground. One, having taken off his
43435. shako, carefully loosened the gathers of its lining and drew them tight
43436. again; another, rubbing some dry clay between his palms, polished
43437. his bayonet; another fingered the strap and pulled the buckle of his
43438. bandolier, while another smoothed and refolded his leg bands and put
43439. his boots on again. Some built little houses of the tufts in the plowed
43440. ground, or plaited baskets from the straw in the cornfield. All seemed
43441. fully absorbed in these pursuits. When men were killed or wounded, when
43442. rows of stretchers went past, when some troops retreated, and when great
43443. masses of the enemy came into view through the smoke, no one paid any
43444. attention to these things. But when our artillery or cavalry advanced or
43445. some of our infantry were seen to move forward, words of approval
43446. were heard on all sides. But the liveliest attention was attracted by
43447. occurrences quite apart from, and unconnected with, the battle. It was
43448. as if the minds of these morally exhausted men found relief in everyday,
43449. commonplace occurrences. A battery of artillery was passing in front of
43450. the regiment. The horse of an ammunition cart put its leg over a trace.
43451. "Hey, look at the trace horse!... Get her leg out! She'll fall.... Ah,
43452. they don't see it!" came identical shouts from the ranks all along the
43453. regiment. Another time, general attention was attracted by a small brown
43454. dog, coming heaven knows whence, which trotted in a preoccupied manner
43455. in front of the ranks with tail stiffly erect till suddenly a shell fell
43456. close by, when it yelped, tucked its tail between its legs, and darted
43457. aside. Yells and shrieks of laughter rose from the whole regiment. But
43458. such distractions lasted only a moment, and for eight hours the men had
43459. been inactive, without food, in constant fear of death, and their pale
43460. and gloomy faces grew ever paler and gloomier.
43461. 
43462. Prince Andrew, pale and gloomy like everyone in the regiment, paced up
43463. and down from the border of one patch to another, at the edge of the
43464. meadow beside an oatfield, with head bowed and arms behind his back.
43465. There was nothing for him to do and no orders to be given. Everything
43466. went on of itself. The killed were dragged from the front, the wounded
43467. carried away, and the ranks closed up. If any soldiers ran to the
43468. rear they returned immediately and hastily. At first Prince Andrew,
43469. considering it his duty to rouse the courage of the men and to set them
43470. an example, walked about among the ranks, but he soon became convinced
43471. that this was unnecessary and that there was nothing he could teach
43472. them. All the powers of his soul, as of every soldier there, were
43473. unconsciously bent on avoiding the contemplation of the horrors of their
43474. situation. He walked along the meadow, dragging his feet, rustling the
43475. grass, and gazing at the dust that covered his boots; now he took big
43476. strides trying to keep to the footprints left on the meadow by the
43477. mowers, then he counted his steps, calculating how often he must walk
43478. from one strip to another to walk a mile, then he stripped the flowers
43479. from the wormwood that grew along a boundary rut, rubbed them in his
43480. palms, and smelled their pungent, sweetly bitter scent. Nothing remained
43481. of the previous day's thoughts. He thought of nothing. He listened with
43482. weary ears to the ever-recurring sounds, distinguishing the whistle
43483. of flying projectiles from the booming of the reports, glanced at the
43484. tiresomely familiar faces of the men of the first battalion, and
43485. waited. "Here it comes... this one is coming our way again!" he thought,
43486. listening to an approaching whistle in the hidden region of smoke. "One,
43487. another! Again! It has hit...." He stopped and looked at the ranks. "No,
43488. it has gone over. But this one has hit!" And again he started trying
43489. to reach the boundary strip in sixteen paces. A whizz and a thud! Five
43490. paces from him, a cannon ball tore up the dry earth and disappeared. A
43491. chill ran down his back. Again he glanced at the ranks. Probably many
43492. had been hit--a large crowd had gathered near the second battalion.
43493. 
43494. "Adjutant!" he shouted. "Order them not to crowd together."
43495. 
43496. The adjutant, having obeyed this instruction, approached Prince Andrew.
43497. From the other side a battalion commander rode up.
43498. 
43499. "Look out!" came a frightened cry from a soldier and, like a bird
43500. whirring in rapid flight and alighting on the ground, a shell dropped
43501. with little noise within two steps of Prince Andrew and close to the
43502. battalion commander's horse. The horse first, regardless of whether it
43503. was right or wrong to show fear, snorted, reared almost throwing the
43504. major, and galloped aside. The horse's terror infected the men.
43505. 
43506. "Lie down!" cried the adjutant, throwing himself flat on the ground.
43507. 
43508. Prince Andrew hesitated. The smoking shell spun like a top between him
43509. and the prostrate adjutant, near a wormwood plant between the field and
43510. the meadow.
43511. 
43512. "Can this be death?" thought Prince Andrew, looking with a quite new,
43513. envious glance at the grass, the wormwood, and the streamlet of smoke
43514. that curled up from the rotating black ball. "I cannot, I do not wish
43515. to die. I love life--I love this grass, this earth, this air...." He
43516. thought this, and at the same time remembered that people were looking
43517. at him.
43518. 
43519. "It's shameful, sir!" he said to the adjutant. "What..."
43520. 
43521. He did not finish speaking. At one and the same moment came the sound of
43522. an explosion, a whistle of splinters as from a breaking window frame,
43523. a suffocating smell of powder, and Prince Andrew started to one side,
43524. raising his arm, and fell on his chest. Several officers ran up to him.
43525. From the right side of his abdomen, blood was welling out making a large
43526. stain on the grass.
43527. 
43528. The militiamen with stretchers who were called up stood behind the
43529. officers. Prince Andrew lay on his chest with his face in the grass,
43530. breathing heavily and noisily.
43531. 
43532. "What are you waiting for? Come along!"
43533. 
43534. The peasants went up and took him by his shoulders and legs, but he
43535. moaned piteously and, exchanging looks, they set him down again.
43536. 
43537. "Pick him up, lift him, it's all the same!" cried someone.
43538. 
43539. They again took him by the shoulders and laid him on the stretcher.
43540. 
43541. "Ah, God! My God! What is it? The stomach? That means death! My
43542. God!"--voices among the officers were heard saying.
43543. 
43544. "It flew a hair's breadth past my ear," said the adjutant.
43545. 
43546. The peasants, adjusting the stretcher to their shoulders, started
43547. hurriedly along the path they had trodden down, to the dressing station.
43548. 
43549. "Keep in step! Ah... those peasants!" shouted an officer, seizing by
43550. their shoulders and checking the peasants, who were walking unevenly and
43551. jolting the stretcher.
43552. 
43553. "Get into step, Fedor... I say, Fedor!" said the foremost peasant.
43554. 
43555. "Now that's right!" said the one behind joyfully, when he had got into
43556. step.
43557. 
43558. "Your excellency! Eh, Prince!" said the trembling voice of Timokhin, who
43559. had run up and was looking down on the stretcher.
43560. 
43561. Prince Andrew opened his eyes and looked up at the speaker from the
43562. stretcher into which his head had sunk deep and again his eyelids
43563. drooped.
43564. 
43565. 
43566. The militiamen carried Prince Andrew to the dressing station by the
43567. wood, where wagons were stationed. The dressing station consisted of
43568. three tents with flaps turned back, pitched at the edge of a birch wood.
43569. In the wood, wagons and horses were standing. The horses were eating
43570. oats from their movable troughs and sparrows flew down and pecked the
43571. grains that fell. Some crows, scenting blood, flew among the birch
43572. trees cawing impatiently. Around the tents, over more than five acres,
43573. bloodstained men in various garbs stood, sat, or lay. Around the wounded
43574. stood crowds of soldier stretcher-bearers with dismal and attentive
43575. faces, whom the officers keeping order tried in vain to drive from the
43576. spot. Disregarding the officers' orders, the soldiers stood leaning
43577. against their stretchers and gazing intently, as if trying to comprehend
43578. the difficult problem of what was taking place before them. From the
43579. tents came now loud angry cries and now plaintive groans. Occasionally
43580. dressers ran out to fetch water, or to point out those who were to be
43581. brought in next. The wounded men awaiting their turn outside the tents
43582. groaned, sighed, wept, screamed, swore, or asked for vodka. Some were
43583. delirious. Prince Andrew's bearers, stepping over the wounded who had
43584. not yet been bandaged, took him, as a regimental commander, close up to
43585. one of the tents and there stopped, awaiting instructions. Prince Andrew
43586. opened his eyes and for a long time could not make out what was going
43587. on around him. He remembered the meadow, the wormwood, the field, the
43588. whirling black ball, and his sudden rush of passionate love of life.
43589. Two steps from him, leaning against a branch and talking loudly and
43590. attracting general attention, stood a tall, handsome, black-haired
43591. noncommissioned officer with a bandaged head. He had been wounded in the
43592. head and leg by bullets. Around him, eagerly listening to his talk, a
43593. crowd of wounded and stretcher-bearers was gathered.
43594. 
43595. "We kicked him out from there so that he chucked everything, we grabbed
43596. the King himself!" cried he, looking around him with eyes that glittered
43597. with fever. "If only reserves had come up just then, lads, there
43598. wouldn't have been nothing left of him! I tell you surely..."
43599. 
43600. Like all the others near the speaker, Prince Andrew looked at him with
43601. shining eyes and experienced a sense of comfort. "But isn't it all the
43602. same now?" thought he. "And what will be there, and what has there been
43603. here? Why was I so reluctant to part with life? There was something in
43604. this life I did not and do not understand."
43605. 
43606. 
43607. 
43608. 
43609. 
43610. CHAPTER XXXVII
43611. 
43612. 
43613. One of the doctors came out of the tent in a bloodstained apron,
43614. holding a cigar between the thumb and little finger of one of his small
43615. bloodstained hands, so as not to smear it. He raised his head and looked
43616. about him, but above the level of the wounded men. He evidently wanted a
43617. little respite. After turning his head from right to left for some time,
43618. he sighed and looked down.
43619. 
43620. "All right, immediately," he replied to a dresser who pointed Prince
43621. Andrew out to him, and he told them to carry him into the tent.
43622. 
43623. Murmurs arose among the wounded who were waiting.
43624. 
43625. "It seems that even in the next world only the gentry are to have a
43626. chance!" remarked one.
43627. 
43628. Prince Andrew was carried in and laid on a table that had only just been
43629. cleared and which a dresser was washing down. Prince Andrew could not
43630. make out distinctly what was in that tent. The pitiful groans from all
43631. sides and the torturing pain in his thigh, stomach, and back distracted
43632. him. All he saw about him merged into a general impression of naked,
43633. bleeding human bodies that seemed to fill the whole of the low tent, as
43634. a few weeks previously, on that hot August day, such bodies had filled
43635. the dirty pond beside the Smolensk road. Yes, it was the same flesh,
43636. the same chair a canon, the sight of which had even then filled him with
43637. horror, as by a presentiment.
43638. 
43639. There were three operating tables in the tent. Two were occupied, and
43640. on the third they placed Prince Andrew. For a little while he was left
43641. alone and involuntarily witnessed what was taking place on the other two
43642. tables. On the nearest one sat a Tartar, probably a Cossack, judging by
43643. the uniform thrown down beside him. Four soldiers were holding him, and
43644. a spectacled doctor was cutting into his muscular brown back.
43645. 
43646. "Ooh, ooh, ooh!" grunted the Tartar, and suddenly lifting up his swarthy
43647. snub-nosed face with its high cheekbones, and baring his white teeth,
43648. he began to wriggle and twitch his body and utter piercing, ringing,
43649. and prolonged yells. On the other table, round which many people were
43650. crowding, a tall well-fed man lay on his back with his head thrown back.
43651. His curly hair, its color, and the shape of his head seemed strangely
43652. familiar to Prince Andrew. Several dressers were pressing on his chest
43653. to hold him down. One large, white, plump leg twitched rapidly all
43654. the time with a feverish tremor. The man was sobbing and choking
43655. convulsively. Two doctors--one of whom was pale and trembling--were
43656. silently doing something to this man's other, gory leg. When he had
43657. finished with the Tartar, whom they covered with an overcoat, the
43658. spectacled doctor came up to Prince Andrew, wiping his hands.
43659. 
43660. He glanced at Prince Andrew's face and quickly turned away.
43661. 
43662. "Undress him! What are you waiting for?" he cried angrily to the
43663. dressers.
43664. 
43665. His very first, remotest recollections of childhood came back to Prince
43666. Andrew's mind when the dresser with sleeves rolled up began hastily to
43667. undo the buttons of his clothes and undressed him. The doctor bent
43668. down over the wound, felt it, and sighed deeply. Then he made a sign to
43669. someone, and the torturing pain in his abdomen caused Prince Andrew to
43670. lose consciousness. When he came to himself the splintered portions of
43671. his thighbone had been extracted, the torn flesh cut away, and the
43672. wound bandaged. Water was being sprinkled on his face. As soon as Prince
43673. Andrew opened his eyes, the doctor bent over, kissed him silently on the
43674. lips, and hurried away.
43675. 
43676. After the sufferings he had been enduring, Prince Andrew enjoyed a
43677. blissful feeling such as he had not experienced for a long time. All
43678. the best and happiest moments of his life--especially his earliest
43679. childhood, when he used to be undressed and put to bed, and when leaning
43680. over him his nurse sang him to sleep and he, burying his head in the
43681. pillow, felt happy in the mere consciousness of life--returned to his
43682. memory, not merely as something past but as something present.
43683. 
43684. The doctors were busily engaged with the wounded man the shape of whose
43685. head seemed familiar to Prince Andrew: they were lifting him up and
43686. trying to quiet him.
43687. 
43688. "Show it to me.... Oh, ooh... Oh! Oh, ooh!" his frightened moans could
43689. be heard, subdued by suffering and broken by sobs.
43690. 
43691. Hearing those moans Prince Andrew wanted to weep. Whether because he
43692. was dying without glory, or because he was sorry to part with life,
43693. or because of those memories of a childhood that could not return, or
43694. because he was suffering and others were suffering and that man near him
43695. was groaning so piteously--he felt like weeping childlike, kindly, and
43696. almost happy tears.
43697. 
43698. The wounded man was shown his amputated leg stained with clotted blood
43699. and with the boot still on.
43700. 
43701. "Oh! Oh, ooh!" he sobbed, like a woman.
43702. 
43703. The doctor who had been standing beside him, preventing Prince Andrew
43704. from seeing his face, moved away.
43705. 
43706. "My God! What is this? Why is he here?" said Prince Andrew to himself.
43707. 
43708. In the miserable, sobbing, enfeebled man whose leg had just been
43709. amputated, he recognized Anatole Kuragin. Men were supporting him in
43710. their arms and offering him a glass of water, but his trembling, swollen
43711. lips could not grasp its rim. Anatole was sobbing painfully. "Yes, it is
43712. he! Yes, that man is somehow closely and painfully connected with me,"
43713. thought Prince Andrew, not yet clearly grasping what he saw before him.
43714. "What is the connection of that man with my childhood and life?" he
43715. asked himself without finding an answer. And suddenly a new unexpected
43716. memory from that realm of pure and loving childhood presented itself to
43717. him. He remembered Natasha as he had seen her for the first time at the
43718. ball in 1810, with her slender neck and arms and with a frightened happy
43719. face ready for rapture, and love and tenderness for her, stronger
43720. and more vivid than ever, awoke in his soul. He now remembered the
43721. connection that existed between himself and this man who was dimly
43722. gazing at him through tears that filled his swollen eyes. He remembered
43723. everything, and ecstatic pity and love for that man overflowed his happy
43724. heart.
43725. 
43726. Prince Andrew could no longer restrain himself and wept tender loving
43727. tears for his fellow men, for himself, and for his own and their errors.
43728. 
43729. "Compassion, love of our brothers, for those who love us and for those
43730. who hate us, love of our enemies; yes, that love which God preached on
43731. earth and which Princess Mary taught me and I did not understand--that
43732. is what made me sorry to part with life, that is what remained for me
43733. had I lived. But now it is too late. I know it!"
43734. 
43735. 
43736. 
43737. 
43738. 
43739. CHAPTER XXXVIII
43740. 
43741. 
43742. The terrible spectacle of the battlefield covered with dead and wounded,
43743. together with the heaviness of his head and the news that some twenty
43744. generals he knew personally had been killed or wounded, and the
43745. consciousness of the impotence of his once mighty arm, produced an
43746. unexpected impression on Napoleon who usually liked to look at the
43747. killed and wounded, thereby, he considered, testing his strength of
43748. mind. This day the horrible appearance of the battlefield overcame
43749. that strength of mind which he thought constituted his merit and his
43750. greatness. He rode hurriedly from the battlefield and returned to the
43751. Shevardino knoll, where he sat on his campstool, his sallow face
43752. swollen and heavy, his eyes dim, his nose red, and his voice hoarse,
43753. involuntarily listening, with downcast eyes, to the sounds of firing.
43754. With painful dejection he awaited the end of this action, in which he
43755. regarded himself as a participant and which he was unable to arrest.
43756. A personal, human feeling for a brief moment got the better of the
43757. artificial phantasm of life he had served so long. He felt in his own
43758. person the sufferings and death he had witnessed on the battlefield.
43759. The heaviness of his head and chest reminded him of the possibility
43760. of suffering and death for himself. At that moment he did not desire
43761. Moscow, or victory, or glory (what need had he for any more glory?). The
43762. one thing he wished for was rest, tranquillity, and freedom. But when he
43763. had been on the Semenovsk heights the artillery commander had proposed
43764. to him to bring several batteries of artillery up to those heights to
43765. strengthen the fire on the Russian troops crowded in front of Knyazkovo.
43766. Napoleon had assented and had given orders that news should be brought
43767. to him of the effect those batteries produced.
43768. 
43769. An adjutant came now to inform him that the fire of two hundred guns
43770. had been concentrated on the Russians, as he had ordered, but that they
43771. still held their ground.
43772. 
43773. "Our fire is mowing them down by rows, but still they hold on," said the
43774. adjutant.
43775. 
43776. "They want more!..." said Napoleon in a hoarse voice.
43777. 
43778. "Sire?" asked the adjutant who had not heard the remark.
43779. 
43780. "They want more!" croaked Napoleon frowning. "Let them have it!"
43781. 
43782. Even before he gave that order the thing he did not desire, and for
43783. which he gave the order only because he thought it was expected of him,
43784. was being done. And he fell back into that artificial realm of imaginary
43785. greatness, and again--as a horse walking a treadmill thinks it is doing
43786. something for itself--he submissively fulfilled the cruel, sad, gloomy,
43787. and inhuman role predestined for him.
43788. 
43789. And not for that day and hour alone were the mind and conscience
43790. darkened of this man on whom the responsibility for what was happening
43791. lay more than on all the others who took part in it. Never to the end
43792. of his life could he understand goodness, beauty, or truth, or the
43793. significance of his actions which were too contrary to goodness and
43794. truth, too remote from everything human, for him ever to be able to
43795. grasp their meaning. He could not disavow his actions, belauded as they
43796. were by half the world, and so he had to repudiate truth, goodness, and
43797. all humanity.
43798. 
43799. Not only on that day, as he rode over the battlefield strewn with men
43800. killed and maimed (by his will as he believed), did he reckon as he
43801. looked at them how many Russians there were for each Frenchman and,
43802. deceiving himself, find reason for rejoicing in the calculation that
43803. there were five Russians for every Frenchman. Not on that day alone
43804. did he write in a letter to Paris that "the battle field was superb,"
43805. because fifty thousand corpses lay there, but even on the island of St.
43806. Helena in the peaceful solitude where he said he intended to devote his
43807. leisure to an account of the great deeds he had done, he wrote:
43808. 
43809. 
43810. The Russian war should have been the most popular war of modern times:
43811. it was a war of good sense, for real interests, for the tranquillity and
43812. security of all; it was purely pacific and conservative.
43813. 
43814. It was a war for a great cause, the end of uncertainties and the
43815. beginning of security. A new horizon and new labors were opening out,
43816. full of well-being and prosperity for all. The European system was
43817. already founded; all that remained was to organize it.
43818. 
43819. Satisfied on these great points and with tranquility everywhere, I
43820. too should have had my Congress and my Holy Alliance. Those ideas were
43821. stolen from me. In that reunion of great sovereigns we should have
43822. discussed our interests like one family, and have rendered account to
43823. the peoples as clerk to master.
43824. 
43825. Europe would in this way soon have been, in fact, but one people, and
43826. anyone who traveled anywhere would have found himself always in the
43827. common fatherland. I should have demanded the freedom of all navigable
43828. rivers for everybody, that the seas should be common to all, and that
43829. the great standing armies should be reduced henceforth to mere guards
43830. for the sovereigns.
43831. 
43832. On returning to France, to the bosom of the great, strong, magnificent,
43833. peaceful, and glorious fatherland, I should have proclaimed
43834. her frontiers immutable; all future wars purely defensive, all
43835. aggrandizement antinational. I should have associated my son in the
43836. Empire; my dictatorship would have been finished, and his constitutional
43837. reign would have begun.
43838. 
43839. Paris would have been the capital of the world, and the French the envy
43840. of the nations!
43841. 
43842. My leisure then, and my old age, would have been devoted, in company
43843. with the Empress and during the royal apprenticeship of my son, to
43844. leisurely visiting, with our own horses and like a true country couple,
43845. every corner of the Empire, receiving complaints, redressing wrongs,
43846. and scattering public buildings and benefactions on all sides and
43847. everywhere.
43848. 
43849. 
43850. Napoleon, predestined by Providence for the gloomy role of executioner
43851. of the peoples, assured himself that the aim of his actions had been the
43852. peoples' welfare and that he could control the fate of millions and by
43853. the employment of power confer benefactions.
43854. 
43855. 
43856. "Of four hundred thousand who crossed the Vistula," he wrote further
43857. of the Russian war, "half were Austrians, Prussians, Saxons, Poles,
43858. Bavarians, Wurttembergers, Mecklenburgers, Spaniards, Italians, and
43859. Neapolitans. The Imperial army, strictly speaking, was one third
43860. composed of Dutch, Belgians, men from the borders of the Rhine,
43861. Piedmontese, Swiss, Genevese, Tuscans, Romans, inhabitants of the
43862. Thirty-second Military Division, of Bremen, of Hamburg, and so on: it
43863. included scarcely a hundred and forty thousand who spoke French. The
43864. Russian expedition actually cost France less than fifty thousand men;
43865. the Russian army in its retreat from Vilna to Moscow lost in the various
43866. battles four times more men than the French army; the burning of Moscow
43867. cost the lives of a hundred thousand Russians who died of cold and want
43868. in the woods; finally, in its march from Moscow to the Oder the Russian
43869. army also suffered from the severity of the season; so that by the time
43870. it reached Vilna it numbered only fifty thousand, and at Kalisch less
43871. than eighteen thousand."
43872. 
43873. 
43874. He imagined that the war with Russia came about by his will, and the
43875. horrors that occurred did not stagger his soul. He boldly took the
43876. whole responsibility for what happened, and his darkened mind found
43877. justification in the belief that among the hundreds of thousands who
43878. perished there were fewer Frenchmen than Hessians and Bavarians.
43879. 
43880. 
43881. 
43882. 
43883. 
43884. CHAPTER XXXIX
43885. 
43886. 
43887. Several tens of thousands of the slain lay in diverse postures and
43888. various uniforms on the fields and meadows belonging to the Davydov
43889. family and to the crown serfs--those fields and meadows where for
43890. hundreds of years the peasants of Borodino, Gorki, Shevardino, and
43891. Semenovsk had reaped their harvests and pastured their cattle. At the
43892. dressing stations the grass and earth were soaked with blood for a space
43893. of some three acres around. Crowds of men of various arms, wounded and
43894. unwounded, with frightened faces, dragged themselves back to Mozhaysk
43895. from the one army and back to Valuevo from the other. Other crowds,
43896. exhausted and hungry, went forward led by their officers. Others held
43897. their ground and continued to fire.
43898. 
43899. Over the whole field, previously so gaily beautiful with the glitter of
43900. bayonets and cloudlets of smoke in the morning sun, there now spread a
43901. mist of damp and smoke and a strange acid smell of saltpeter and blood.
43902. Clouds gathered and drops of rain began to fall on the dead and wounded,
43903. on the frightened, exhausted, and hesitating men, as if to say: "Enough,
43904. men! Enough! Cease... bethink yourselves! What are you doing?"
43905. 
43906. To the men of both sides alike, worn out by want of food and rest,
43907. it began equally to appear doubtful whether they should continue to
43908. slaughter one another; all the faces expressed hesitation, and the
43909. question arose in every soul: "For what, for whom, must I kill and be
43910. killed?... You may go and kill whom you please, but I don't want to do
43911. so anymore!" By evening this thought had ripened in every soul. At any
43912. moment these men might have been seized with horror at what they were
43913. doing and might have thrown up everything and run away anywhere.
43914. 
43915. But though toward the end of the battle the men felt all the horror of
43916. what they were doing, though they would have been glad to leave off,
43917. some incomprehensible, mysterious power continued to control them, and
43918. they still brought up the charges, loaded, aimed, and applied the match,
43919. though only one artilleryman survived out of every three, and though
43920. they stumbled and panted with fatigue, perspiring and stained with blood
43921. and powder. The cannon balls flew just as swiftly and cruelly from both
43922. sides, crushing human bodies, and that terrible work which was not done
43923. by the will of a man but at the will of Him who governs men and worlds
43924. continued.
43925. 
43926. Anyone looking at the disorganized rear of the Russian army would have
43927. said that, if only the French made one more slight effort, it would
43928. disappear; and anyone looking at the rear of the French army would have
43929. said that the Russians need only make one more slight effort and the
43930. French would be destroyed. But neither the French nor the Russians made
43931. that effort, and the flame of battle burned slowly out.
43932. 
43933. The Russians did not make that effort because they were not attacking
43934. the French. At the beginning of the battle they stood blocking the
43935. way to Moscow and they still did so at the end of the battle as at the
43936. beginning. But even had the aim of the Russians been to drive the French
43937. from their positions, they could not have made this last effort, for all
43938. the Russian troops had been broken up, there was no part of the Russian
43939. army that had not suffered in the battle, and though still holding their
43940. positions they had lost ONE HALF of their army.
43941. 
43942. The French, with the memory of all their former victories during
43943. fifteen years, with the assurance of Napoleon's invincibility, with the
43944. consciousness that they had captured part of the battlefield and had
43945. lost only a quarter of their men and still had their Guards intact,
43946. twenty thousand strong, might easily have made that effort. The French
43947. who had attacked the Russian army in order to drive it from its position
43948. ought to have made that effort, for as long as the Russians continued to
43949. block the road to Moscow as before, the aim of the French had not been
43950. attained and all their efforts and losses were in vain. But the French
43951. did not make that effort. Some historians say that Napoleon need only
43952. have used his Old Guards, who were intact, and the battle would have
43953. been won. To speak of what would have happened had Napoleon sent his
43954. Guards is like talking of what would happen if autumn became spring. It
43955. could not be. Napoleon did not give his Guards, not because he did not
43956. want to, but because it could not be done. All the generals, officers,
43957. and soldiers of the French army knew it could not be done, because the
43958. flagging spirit of the troops would not permit it.
43959. 
43960. It was not Napoleon alone who had experienced that nightmare feeling
43961. of the mighty arm being stricken powerless, but all the generals and
43962. soldiers of his army whether they had taken part in the battle or not,
43963. after all their experience of previous battles--when after one tenth of
43964. such efforts the enemy had fled--experienced a similar feeling of terror
43965. before an enemy who, after losing HALF his men, stood as threateningly
43966. at the end as at the beginning of the battle. The moral force of the
43967. attacking French army was exhausted. Not that sort of victory which is
43968. defined by the capture of pieces of material fastened to sticks, called
43969. standards, and of the ground on which the troops had stood and were
43970. standing, but a moral victory that convinces the enemy of the moral
43971. superiority of his opponent and of his own impotence was gained by the
43972. Russians at Borodino. The French invaders, like an infuriated animal
43973. that has in its onslaught received a mortal wound, felt that they were
43974. perishing, but could not stop, any more than the Russian army, weaker
43975. by one half, could help swerving. By impetus gained, the French army was
43976. still able to roll forward to Moscow, but there, without further effort
43977. on the part of the Russians, it had to perish, bleeding from the mortal
43978. wound it had received at Borodino. The direct consequence of the battle
43979. of Borodino was Napoleon's senseless flight from Moscow, his retreat
43980. along the old Smolensk road, the destruction of the invading army of
43981. five hundred thousand men, and the downfall of Napoleonic France, on
43982. which at Borodino for the first time the hand of an opponent of stronger
43983. spirit had been laid.
43984. 
43985. 
43986. 
43987. 
43988. 
43989. BOOK ELEVEN: 1812
43990. 
43991. 
43992. 
43993. 
43994. 
43995. CHAPTER I
43996. 
43997. 
43998. Absolute continuity of motion is not comprehensible to the human mind.
43999. Laws of motion of any kind become comprehensible to man only when he
44000. examines arbitrarily selected elements of that motion; but at the
44001. same time, a large proportion of human error comes from the arbitrary
44002. division of continuous motion into discontinuous elements. There is a
44003. well known, so-called sophism of the ancients consisting in this, that
44004. Achilles could never catch up with a tortoise he was following, in spite
44005. of the fact that he traveled ten times as fast as the tortoise. By
44006. the time Achilles has covered the distance that separated him from the
44007. tortoise, the tortoise has covered one tenth of that distance ahead
44008. of him: when Achilles has covered that tenth, the tortoise has covered
44009. another one hundredth, and so on forever. This problem seemed to
44010. the ancients insoluble. The absurd answer (that Achilles could never
44011. overtake the tortoise) resulted from this: that motion was arbitrarily
44012. divided into discontinuous elements, whereas the motion both of Achilles
44013. and of the tortoise was continuous.
44014. 
44015. By adopting smaller and smaller elements of motion we only approach a
44016. solution of the problem, but never reach it. Only when we have admitted
44017. the conception of the infinitely small, and the resulting geometrical
44018. progression with a common ratio of one tenth, and have found the sum of
44019. this progression to infinity, do we reach a solution of the problem.
44020. 
44021. A modern branch of mathematics having achieved the art of dealing with
44022. the infinitely small can now yield solutions in other more complex
44023. problems of motion which used to appear insoluble.
44024. 
44025. This modern branch of mathematics, unknown to the ancients, when dealing
44026. with problems of motion admits the conception of the infinitely small,
44027. and so conforms to the chief condition of motion (absolute continuity)
44028. and thereby corrects the inevitable error which the human mind cannot
44029. avoid when it deals with separate elements of motion instead of
44030. examining continuous motion.
44031. 
44032. In seeking the laws of historical movement just the same thing happens.
44033. The movement of humanity, arising as it does from innumerable arbitrary
44034. human wills, is continuous.
44035. 
44036. To understand the laws of this continuous movement is the aim of
44037. history. But to arrive at these laws, resulting from the sum of all
44038. those human wills, man's mind postulates arbitrary and disconnected
44039. units. The first method of history is to take an arbitrarily selected
44040. series of continuous events and examine it apart from others, though
44041. there is and can be no beginning to any event, for one event always
44042. flows uninterruptedly from another.
44043. 
44044. The second method is to consider the actions of some one man--a king or
44045. a commander--as equivalent to the sum of many individual wills; whereas
44046. the sum of individual wills is never expressed by the activity of a
44047. single historic personage.
44048. 
44049. Historical science in its endeavor to draw nearer to truth continually
44050. takes smaller and smaller units for examination. But however small the
44051. units it takes, we feel that to take any unit disconnected from others,
44052. or to assume a beginning of any phenomenon, or to say that the will of
44053. many men is expressed by the actions of any one historic personage, is
44054. in itself false.
44055. 
44056. It needs no critical exertion to reduce utterly to dust any deductions
44057. drawn from history. It is merely necessary to select some larger or
44058. smaller unit as the subject of observation--as criticism has every
44059. right to do, seeing that whatever unit history observes must always be
44060. arbitrarily selected.
44061. 
44062. Only by taking infinitesimally small units for observation (the
44063. differential of history, that is, the individual tendencies of men) and
44064. attaining to the art of integrating them (that is, finding the sum of
44065. these infinitesimals) can we hope to arrive at the laws of history.
44066. 
44067. The first fifteen years of the nineteenth century in Europe present an
44068. extraordinary movement of millions of people. Men leave their customary
44069. pursuits, hasten from one side of Europe to the other, plunder and
44070. slaughter one another, triumph and are plunged in despair, and for some
44071. years the whole course of life is altered and presents an intensive
44072. movement which first increases and then slackens. What was the cause of
44073. this movement, by what laws was it governed? asks the mind of man.
44074. 
44075. The historians, replying to this question, lay before us the sayings and
44076. doings of a few dozen men in a building in the city of Paris, calling
44077. these sayings and doings "the Revolution"; then they give a detailed
44078. biography of Napoleon and of certain people favorable or hostile to him;
44079. tell of the influence some of these people had on others, and say: that
44080. is why this movement took place and those are its laws.
44081. 
44082. But the mind of man not only refuses to believe this explanation, but
44083. plainly says that this method of explanation is fallacious, because in
44084. it a weaker phenomenon is taken as the cause of a stronger. The sum of
44085. human wills produced the Revolution and Napoleon, and only the sum of
44086. those wills first tolerated and then destroyed them.
44087. 
44088. "But every time there have been conquests there have been conquerors;
44089. every time there has been a revolution in any state there have been
44090. great men," says history. And, indeed, human reason replies: every time
44091. conquerors appear there have been wars, but this does not prove that the
44092. conquerors caused the wars and that it is possible to find the laws of
44093. a war in the personal activity of a single man. Whenever I look at my
44094. watch and its hands point to ten, I hear the bells of the neighboring
44095. church; but because the bells begin to ring when the hands of the clock
44096. reach ten, I have no right to assume that the movement of the bells is
44097. caused by the position of the hands of the watch.
44098. 
44099. Whenever I see the movement of a locomotive I hear the whistle and see
44100. the valves opening and wheels turning; but I have no right to conclude
44101. that the whistling and the turning of wheels are the cause of the
44102. movement of the engine.
44103. 
44104. The peasants say that a cold wind blows in late spring because the oaks
44105. are budding, and really every spring cold winds do blow when the oak
44106. is budding. But though I do not know what causes the cold winds to blow
44107. when the oak buds unfold, I cannot agree with the peasants that the
44108. unfolding of the oak buds is the cause of the cold wind, for the
44109. force of the wind is beyond the influence of the buds. I see only a
44110. coincidence of occurrences such as happens with all the phenomena of
44111. life, and I see that however much and however carefully I observe the
44112. hands of the watch, and the valves and wheels of the engine, and the
44113. oak, I shall not discover the cause of the bells ringing, the engine
44114. moving, or of the winds of spring. To that I must entirely change my
44115. point of view and study the laws of the movement of steam, of the
44116. bells, and of the wind. History must do the same. And attempts in this
44117. direction have already been made.
44118. 
44119. To study the laws of history we must completely change the subject of
44120. our observation, must leave aside kings, ministers, and generals, and
44121. study the common, infinitesimally small elements by which the masses are
44122. moved. No one can say in how far it is possible for man to advance
44123. in this way toward an understanding of the laws of history; but it is
44124. evident that only along that path does the possibility of discovering
44125. the laws of history lie, and that as yet not a millionth part as much
44126. mental effort has been applied in this direction by historians as has
44127. been devoted to describing the actions of various kings, commanders,
44128. and ministers and propounding the historians' own reflections concerning
44129. these actions.
44130. 
44131. 
44132. 
44133. 
44134. 
44135. CHAPTER II
44136. 
44137. 
44138. The forces of a dozen European nations burst into Russia. The Russian
44139. army and people avoided a collision till Smolensk was reached, and again
44140. from Smolensk to Borodino. The French army pushed on to Moscow, its
44141. goal, its impetus ever increasing as it neared its aim, just as the
44142. velocity of a falling body increases as it approaches the earth. Behind
44143. it were seven hundred miles of hunger-stricken, hostile country; ahead
44144. were a few dozen miles separating it from its goal. Every soldier in
44145. Napoleon's army felt this and the invasion moved on by its own momentum.
44146. 
44147. The more the Russian army retreated the more fiercely a spirit of hatred
44148. of the enemy flared up, and while it retreated the army increased and
44149. consolidated. At Borodino a collision took place. Neither army was
44150. broken up, but the Russian army retreated immediately after the
44151. collision as inevitably as a ball recoils after colliding with another
44152. having a greater momentum, and with equal inevitability the ball
44153. of invasion that had advanced with such momentum rolled on for some
44154. distance, though the collision had deprived it of all its force.
44155. 
44156. The Russians retreated eighty miles--to beyond Moscow--and the French
44157. reached Moscow and there came to a standstill. For five weeks after that
44158. there was not a single battle. The French did not move. As a bleeding,
44159. mortally wounded animal licks its wounds, they remained inert in Moscow
44160. for five weeks, and then suddenly, with no fresh reason, fled back:
44161. they made a dash for the Kaluga road, and (after a victory--for at
44162. Malo-Yaroslavets the field of conflict again remained theirs) without
44163. undertaking a single serious battle, they fled still more rapidly back
44164. to Smolensk, beyond Smolensk, beyond the Berezina, beyond Vilna, and
44165. farther still.
44166. 
44167. On the evening of the twenty-sixth of August, Kutuzov and the whole
44168. Russian army were convinced that the battle of Borodino was a victory.
44169. Kutuzov reported so to the Emperor. He gave orders to prepare for a
44170. fresh conflict to finish the enemy and did this not to deceive anyone,
44171. but because he knew that the enemy was beaten, as everyone who had taken
44172. part in the battle knew it.
44173. 
44174. But all that evening and next day reports came in one after another
44175. of unheard-of losses, of the loss of half the army, and a fresh battle
44176. proved physically impossible.
44177. 
44178. It was impossible to give battle before information had been collected,
44179. the wounded gathered in, the supplies of ammunition replenished, the
44180. slain reckoned up, new officers appointed to replace those who had been
44181. killed, and before the men had had food and sleep. And meanwhile, the
44182. very next morning after the battle, the French army advanced of itself
44183. upon the Russians, carried forward by the force of its own momentum now
44184. seemingly increased in inverse proportion to the square of the distance
44185. from its aim. Kutuzov's wish was to attack next day, and the whole
44186. army desired to do so. But to make an attack the wish to do so is not
44187. sufficient, there must also be a possibility of doing it, and that
44188. possibility did not exist. It was impossible not to retreat a day's
44189. march, and then in the same way it was impossible not to retreat another
44190. and a third day's march, and at last, on the first of September when
44191. the army drew near Moscow--despite the strength of the feeling that had
44192. arisen in all ranks--the force of circumstances compelled it to retire
44193. beyond Moscow. And the troops retired one more, last, day's march, and
44194. abandoned Moscow to the enemy.
44195. 
44196. For people accustomed to think that plans of campaign and battles are
44197. made by generals--as any one of us sitting over a map in his study may
44198. imagine how he would have arranged things in this or that battle--the
44199. questions present themselves: Why did Kutuzov during the retreat not do
44200. this or that? Why did he not take up a position before reaching Fili?
44201. Why did he not retire at once by the Kaluga road, abandoning Moscow? and
44202. so on. People accustomed to think in that way forget, or do not know,
44203. the inevitable conditions which always limit the activities of any
44204. commander in chief. The activity of a commander in chief does not at all
44205. resemble the activity we imagine to ourselves when we sit at ease in
44206. our studies examining some campaign on the map, with a certain number of
44207. troops on this and that side in a certain known locality, and begin our
44208. plans from some given moment. A commander in chief is never dealing
44209. with the beginning of any event--the position from which we always
44210. contemplate it. The commander in chief is always in the midst of a
44211. series of shifting events and so he never can at any moment consider the
44212. whole import of an event that is occurring. Moment by moment the event
44213. is imperceptibly shaping itself, and at every moment of this continuous,
44214. uninterrupted shaping of events the commander in chief is in the
44215. midst of a most complex play of intrigues, worries, contingencies,
44216. authorities, projects, counsels, threats, and deceptions and is
44217. continually obliged to reply to innumerable questions addressed to him,
44218. which constantly conflict with one another.
44219. 
44220. Learned military authorities quite seriously tell us that Kutuzov should
44221. have moved his army to the Kaluga road long before reaching Fili, and
44222. that somebody actually submitted such a proposal to him. But a commander
44223. in chief, especially at a difficult moment, has always before him not
44224. one proposal but dozens simultaneously. And all these proposals, based
44225. on strategics and tactics, contradict each other.
44226. 
44227. A commander in chief's business, it would seem, is simply to choose one
44228. of these projects. But even that he cannot do. Events and time do not
44229. wait. For instance, on the twenty-eighth it is suggested to him to
44230. cross to the Kaluga road, but just then an adjutant gallops up from
44231. Miloradovich asking whether he is to engage the French or retire. An
44232. order must be given him at once, that instant. And the order to retreat
44233. carries us past the turn to the Kaluga road. And after the adjutant
44234. comes the commissary general asking where the stores are to be taken,
44235. and the chief of the hospitals asks where the wounded are to go, and a
44236. courier from Petersburg brings a letter from the sovereign which does
44237. not admit of the possibility of abandoning Moscow, and the commander in
44238. chief's rival, the man who is undermining him (and there are always
44239. not merely one but several such), presents a new project diametrically
44240. opposed to that of turning to the Kaluga road, and the commander in
44241. chief himself needs sleep and refreshment to maintain his energy and
44242. a respectable general who has been overlooked in the distribution of
44243. rewards comes to complain, and the inhabitants of the district pray to
44244. be defended, and an officer sent to inspect the locality comes in and
44245. gives a report quite contrary to what was said by the officer
44246. previously sent; and a spy, a prisoner, and a general who has been
44247. on reconnaissance, all describe the position of the enemy's army
44248. differently. People accustomed to misunderstand or to forget these
44249. inevitable conditions of a commander in chief's actions describe to
44250. us, for instance, the position of the army at Fili and assume that the
44251. commander in chief could, on the first of September, quite freely decide
44252. whether to abandon Moscow or defend it; whereas, with the Russian army
44253. less than four miles from Moscow, no such question existed. When had
44254. that question been settled? At Drissa and at Smolensk and most
44255. palpably of all on the twenty-fourth of August at Shevardino and on
44256. the twenty-sixth at Borodino, and each day and hour and minute of the
44257. retreat from Borodino to Fili.
44258. 
44259. 
44260. 
44261. 
44262. 
44263. CHAPTER III
44264. 
44265. 
44266. When Ermolov, having been sent by Kutuzov to inspect the position, told
44267. the field marshal that it was impossible to fight there before Moscow
44268. and that they must retreat, Kutuzov looked at him in silence.
44269. 
44270. "Give me your hand," said he and, turning it over so as to feel the
44271. pulse, added: "You are not well, my dear fellow. Think what you are
44272. saying!"
44273. 
44274. Kutuzov could not yet admit the possibility of retreating beyond Moscow
44275. without a battle.
44276. 
44277. On the Poklonny Hill, four miles from the Dorogomilov gate of Moscow,
44278. Kutuzov got out of his carriage and sat down on a bench by the roadside.
44279. A great crowd of generals gathered round him, and Count Rostopchin, who
44280. had come out from Moscow, joined them. This brilliant company separated
44281. into several groups who all discussed the advantages and disadvantages
44282. of the position, the state of the army, the plans suggested, the
44283. situation of Moscow, and military questions generally. Though they had
44284. not been summoned for the purpose, and though it was not so called, they
44285. all felt that this was really a council of war. The conversations all
