44286. dealt with public questions. If anyone gave or asked for personal
44287. news, it was done in a whisper and they immediately reverted to general
44288. matters. No jokes, or laughter, or smiles even, were seen among all
44289. these men. They evidently all made an effort to hold themselves at the
44290. height the situation demanded. And all these groups, while talking
44291. among themselves, tried to keep near the commander in chief (whose
44292. bench formed the center of the gathering) and to speak so that he might
44293. overhear them. The commander in chief listened to what was being said
44294. and sometimes asked them to repeat their remarks, but did not himself
44295. take part in the conversations or express any opinion. After hearing
44296. what was being said by one or other of these groups he generally turned
44297. away with an air of disappointment, as though they were not speaking of
44298. anything he wished to hear. Some discussed the position that had been
44299. chosen, criticizing not the position itself so much as the mental
44300. capacity of those who had chosen it. Others argued that a mistake had
44301. been made earlier and that a battle should have been fought two days
44302. before. Others again spoke of the battle of Salamanca, which was
44303. described by Crosart, a newly arrived Frenchman in a Spanish uniform.
44304. (This Frenchman and one of the German princes serving with the Russian
44305. army were discussing the siege of Saragossa and considering the
44306. possibility of defending Moscow in a similar manner.) Count Rostopchin
44307. was telling a fourth group that he was prepared to die with the city
44308. train bands under the walls of the capital, but that he still could not
44309. help regretting having been left in ignorance of what was happening, and
44310. that had he known it sooner things would have been different.... A
44311. fifth group, displaying the profundity of their strategic perceptions,
44312. discussed the direction the troops would now have to take. A sixth group
44313. was talking absolute nonsense. Kutuzov's expression grew more and more
44314. preoccupied and gloomy. From all this talk he saw only one thing: that
44315. to defend Moscow was a physical impossibility in the full meaning of
44316. those words, that is to say, so utterly impossible that if any senseless
44317. commander were to give orders to fight, confusion would result but the
44318. battle would still not take place. It would not take place because the
44319. commanders not merely all recognized the position to be impossible, but
44320. in their conversations were only discussing what would happen after its
44321. inevitable abandonment. How could the commanders lead their troops to
44322. a field of battle they considered impossible to hold? The lower-grade
44323. officers and even the soldiers (who too reason) also considered the
44324. position impossible and therefore could not go to fight, fully convinced
44325. as they were of defeat. If Bennigsen insisted on the position being
44326. defended and others still discussed it, the question was no longer
44327. important in itself but only as a pretext for disputes and intrigue.
44328. This Kutuzov knew well.
44329. 
44330. Bennigsen, who had chosen the position, warmly displayed his Russian
44331. patriotism (Kutuzov could not listen to this without wincing) by
44332. insisting that Moscow must be defended. His aim was as clear as daylight
44333. to Kutuzov: if the defense failed, to throw the blame on Kutuzov who had
44334. brought the army as far as the Sparrow Hills without giving battle; if
44335. it succeeded, to claim the success as his own; or if battle were not
44336. given, to clear himself of the crime of abandoning Moscow. But this
44337. intrigue did not now occupy the old man's mind. One terrible question
44338. absorbed him and to that question he heard no reply from anyone. The
44339. question for him now was: "Have I really allowed Napoleon to reach
44340. Moscow, and when did I do so? When was it decided? Can it have been
44341. yesterday when I ordered Platov to retreat, or was it the evening
44342. before, when I had a nap and told Bennigsen to issue orders? Or was it
44343. earlier still?... When, when was this terrible affair decided? Moscow
44344. must be abandoned. The army must retreat and the order to do so must
44345. be given." To give that terrible order seemed to him equivalent to
44346. resigning the command of the army. And not only did he love power to
44347. which he was accustomed (the honours awarded to Prince Prozorovski,
44348. under whom he had served in Turkey, galled him), but he was convinced
44349. that he was destined to save Russia and that that was why, against
44350. the Emperor's wish and by the will of the people, he had been chosen
44351. commander in chief. He was convinced that he alone could maintain
44352. command of the army in these difficult circumstances, and that in all
44353. the world he alone could encounter the invincible Napoleon without fear,
44354. and he was horrified at the thought of the order he had to issue. But
44355. something had to be decided, and these conversations around him which
44356. were assuming too free a character must be stopped.
44357. 
44358. He called the most important generals to him.
44359. 
44360. "My head, be it good or bad, must depend on itself," said he, rising
44361. from the bench, and he rode to Fili where his carriages were waiting.
44362. 
44363. 
44364. 
44365. 
44366. 
44367. CHAPTER IV
44368. 
44369. 
44370. The Council of War began to assemble at two in the afternoon in the
44371. better and roomier part of Andrew Savostyanov's hut. The men, women, and
44372. children of the large peasant family crowded into the back room across
44373. the passage. Only Malasha, Andrew's six-year-old granddaughter whom
44374. his Serene Highness had petted and to whom he had given a lump of sugar
44375. while drinking his tea, remained on the top of the brick oven in the
44376. larger room. Malasha looked down from the oven with shy delight at the
44377. faces, uniforms, and decorations of the generals, who one after another
44378. came into the room and sat down on the broad benches in the corner
44379. under the icons. "Granddad" himself, as Malasha in her own mind called
44380. Kutuzov, sat apart in a dark corner behind the oven. He sat, sunk deep
44381. in a folding armchair, and continually cleared his throat and pulled at
44382. the collar of his coat which, though it was unbuttoned, still seemed
44383. to pinch his neck. Those who entered went up one by one to the field
44384. marshal; he pressed the hands of some and nodded to others. His adjutant
44385. Kaysarov was about to draw back the curtain of the window facing
44386. Kutuzov, but the latter moved his hand angrily and Kaysarov understood
44387. that his Serene Highness did not wish his face to be seen.
44388. 
44389. Round the peasant's deal table, on which lay maps, plans, pencils, and
44390. papers, so many people gathered that the orderlies brought in another
44391. bench and put it beside the table. Ermolov, Kaysarov, and Toll, who had
44392. just arrived, sat down on this bench. In the foremost place, immediately
44393. under the icons, sat Barclay de Tolly, his high forehead merging into
44394. his bald crown. He had a St. George's Cross round his neck and looked
44395. pale and ill. He had been feverish for two days and was now shivering
44396. and in pain. Beside him sat Uvarov, who with rapid gesticulations was
44397. giving him some information, speaking in low tones as they all did.
44398. Chubby little Dokhturov was listening attentively with eyebrows
44399. raised and arms folded on his stomach. On the other side sat Count
44400. Ostermann-Tolstoy, seemingly absorbed in his own thoughts. His broad
44401. head with its bold features and glittering eyes was resting on his hand.
44402. Raevski, twitching forward the black hair on his temples as was his
44403. habit, glanced now at Kutuzov and now at the door with a look of
44404. impatience. Konovnitsyn's firm, handsome, and kindly face was lit up by
44405. a tender, sly smile. His glance met Malasha's, and the expression of his
44406. eyes caused the little girl to smile.
44407. 
44408. They were all waiting for Bennigsen, who on the pretext of inspecting
44409. the position was finishing his savory dinner. They waited for him from
44410. four till six o'clock and did not begin their deliberations all that
44411. time but talked in low tones of other matters.
44412. 
44413. Only when Bennigsen had entered the hut did Kutuzov leave his corner and
44414. draw toward the table, but not near enough for the candles that had been
44415. placed there to light up his face.
44416. 
44417. Bennigsen opened the council with the question: "Are we to abandon
44418. Russia's ancient and sacred capital without a struggle, or are we to
44419. defend it?" A prolonged and general silence followed. There was a frown
44420. on every face and only Kutuzov's angry grunts and occasional cough
44421. broke the silence. All eyes were gazing at him. Malasha too looked at
44422. "Granddad." She was nearest to him and saw how his face puckered; he
44423. seemed about to cry, but this did not last long.
44424. 
44425. "Russia's ancient and sacred capital!" he suddenly said, repeating
44426. Bennigsen's words in an angry voice and thereby drawing attention to the
44427. false note in them. "Allow me to tell you, your excellency, that that
44428. question has no meaning for a Russian." (He lurched his heavy body
44429. forward.) "Such a question cannot be put; it is senseless! The question
44430. I have asked these gentlemen to meet to discuss is a military one.
44431. The question is that of saving Russia. Is it better to give up Moscow
44432. without a battle, or by accepting battle to risk losing the army as well
44433. as Moscow? That is the question on which I want your opinion," and he
44434. sank back in his chair.
44435. 
44436. The discussion began. Bennigsen did not yet consider his game lost.
44437. Admitting the view of Barclay and others that a defensive battle at
44438. Fili was impossible, but imbued with Russian patriotism and the love
44439. of Moscow, he proposed to move troops from the right to the left flank
44440. during the night and attack the French right flank the following day.
44441. Opinions were divided, and arguments were advanced for and against that
44442. project. Ermolov, Dokhturov, and Raevski agreed with Bennigsen. Whether
44443. feeling it necessary to make a sacrifice before abandoning the capital
44444. or guided by other, personal considerations, these generals seemed not
44445. to understand that this council could not alter the inevitable course
44446. of events and that Moscow was in effect already abandoned. The other
44447. generals, however, understood it and, leaving aside the question of
44448. Moscow, spoke of the direction the army should take in its retreat.
44449. Malasha, who kept her eyes fixed on what was going on before her,
44450. understood the meaning of the council differently. It seemed to her that
44451. it was only a personal struggle between "Granddad" and "Long-coat" as
44452. she termed Bennigsen. She saw that they grew spiteful when they spoke to
44453. one another, and in her heart she sided with "Granddad." In the midst of
44454. the conversation she noticed "Granddad" give Bennigsen a quick, subtle
44455. glance, and then to her joys he saw that "Granddad" said something to
44456. "Long-coat" which settled him. Bennigsen suddenly reddened and paced
44457. angrily up and down the room. What so affected him was Kutuzov's calm
44458. and quiet comment on the advantage or disadvantage of Bennigsen's
44459. proposal to move troops by night from the right to the left flank to
44460. attack the French right wing.
44461. 
44462. "Gentlemen," said Kutuzov, "I cannot approve of the count's plan. Moving
44463. troops in close proximity to an enemy is always dangerous, and military
44464. history supports that view. For instance..." Kutuzov seemed to reflect,
44465. searching for an example, then with a clear, naive look at Bennigsen he
44466. added: "Oh yes; take the battle of Friedland, which I think the count
44467. well remembers, and which was... not fully successful, only because our
44468. troops were rearranged too near the enemy..."
44469. 
44470. There followed a momentary pause, which seemed very long to them all.
44471. 
44472. The discussion recommenced, but pauses frequently occurred and they all
44473. felt that there was no more to be said.
44474. 
44475. During one of these pauses Kutuzov heaved a deep sigh as if preparing to
44476. speak. They all looked at him.
44477. 
44478. "Well, gentlemen, I see that it is I who will have to pay for the broken
44479. crockery," said he, and rising slowly he moved to the table. "Gentlemen,
44480. I have heard your views. Some of you will not agree with me. But I," he
44481. paused, "by the authority entrusted to me by my Sovereign and country,
44482. order a retreat."
44483. 
44484. After that the generals began to disperse with the solemnity and
44485. circumspect silence of people who are leaving, after a funeral.
44486. 
44487. Some of the generals, in low tones and in a strain very different from
44488. the way they had spoken during the council, communicated something to
44489. their commander in chief.
44490. 
44491. Malasha, who had long been expected for supper, climbed carefully
44492. backwards down from the oven, her bare little feet catching at its
44493. projections, and slipping between the legs of the generals she darted
44494. out of the room.
44495. 
44496. When he had dismissed the generals Kutuzov sat a long time with his
44497. elbows on the table, thinking always of the same terrible question:
44498. "When, when did the abandonment of Moscow become inevitable? When was
44499. that done which settled the matter? And who was to blame for it?"
44500. 
44501. "I did not expect this," said he to his adjutant Schneider when the
44502. latter came in late that night. "I did not expect this! I did not think
44503. this would happen."
44504. 
44505. "You should take some rest, your Serene Highness," replied Schneider.
44506. 
44507. "But no! They shall eat horseflesh yet, like the Turks!" exclaimed
44508. Kutuzov without replying, striking the table with his podgy fist. "They
44509. shall too, if only..."
44510. 
44511. 
44512. 
44513. 
44514. 
44515. CHAPTER V
44516. 
44517. 
44518. At that very time, in circumstances even more important than retreating
44519. without a battle, namely the evacuation and burning of Moscow,
44520. Rostopchin, who is usually represented as being the instigator of that
44521. event, acted in an altogether different manner from Kutuzov.
44522. 
44523. After the battle of Borodino the abandonment and burning of Moscow was
44524. as inevitable as the retreat of the army beyond Moscow without fighting.
44525. 
44526. Every Russian might have predicted it, not by reasoning but by the
44527. feeling implanted in each of us and in our fathers.
44528. 
44529. The same thing that took place in Moscow had happened in all the towns
44530. and villages on Russian soil beginning with Smolensk, without the
44531. participation of Count Rostopchin and his broadsheets. The people
44532. awaited the enemy unconcernedly, did not riot or become excited or tear
44533. anyone to pieces, but faced its fate, feeling within it the strength to
44534. find what it should do at that most difficult moment. And as soon as the
44535. enemy drew near the wealthy classes went away abandoning their property,
44536. while the poorer remained and burned and destroyed what was left.
44537. 
44538. The consciousness that this would be so and would always be so was and
44539. is present in the heart of every Russian. And a consciousness of this,
44540. and a foreboding that Moscow would be taken, was present in Russian
44541. Moscow society in 1812. Those who had quitted Moscow already in July
44542. and at the beginning of August showed that they expected this. Those who
44543. went away, taking what they could and abandoning their houses and half
44544. their belongings, did so from the latent patriotism which expresses
44545. itself not by phrases or by giving one's children to save the fatherland
44546. and similar unnatural exploits, but unobtrusively, simply, organically,
44547. and therefore in the way that always produces the most powerful results.
44548. 
44549. "It is disgraceful to run away from danger; only cowards are running
44550. away from Moscow," they were told. In his broadsheets Rostopchin
44551. impressed on them that to leave Moscow was shameful. They were ashamed
44552. to be called cowards, ashamed to leave, but still they left, knowing
44553. it had to be done. Why did they go? It is impossible to suppose that
44554. Rostopchin had scared them by his accounts of horrors Napoleon had
44555. committed in conquered countries. The first people to go away were the
44556. rich educated people who knew quite well that Vienna and Berlin had
44557. remained intact and that during Napoleon's occupation the inhabitants
44558. had spent their time pleasantly in the company of the charming Frenchmen
44559. whom the Russians, and especially the Russian ladies, then liked so
44560. much.
44561. 
44562. They went away because for Russians there could be no question as to
44563. whether things would go well or ill under French rule in Moscow. It was
44564. out of the question to be under French rule, it would be the worst thing
44565. that could happen. They went away even before the battle of Borodino and
44566. still more rapidly after it, despite Rostopchin's calls to defend Moscow
44567. or the announcement of his intention to take the wonder-working icon of
44568. the Iberian Mother of God and go to fight, or of the balloons that were
44569. to destroy the French, and despite all the nonsense Rostopchin wrote in
44570. his broadsheets. They knew that it was for the army to fight, and that
44571. if it could not succeed it would not do to take young ladies and house
44572. serfs to the Three Hills quarter of Moscow to fight Napoleon, and that
44573. they must go away, sorry as they were to abandon their property
44574. to destruction. They went away without thinking of the tremendous
44575. significance of that immense and wealthy city being given over to
44576. destruction, for a great city with wooden buildings was certain when
44577. abandoned by its inhabitants to be burned. They went away each on his
44578. own account, and yet it was only in consequence of their going away
44579. that the momentous event was accomplished that will always remain the
44580. greatest glory of the Russian people. The lady who, afraid of being
44581. stopped by Count Rostopchin's orders, had already in June moved with her
44582. Negroes and her women jesters from Moscow to her Saratov estate, with
44583. a vague consciousness that she was not Bonaparte's servant, was really,
44584. simply, and truly carrying out the great work which saved Russia. But
44585. Count Rostopchin, who now taunted those who left Moscow and now had the
44586. government offices removed; now distributed quite useless weapons to
44587. the drunken rabble; now had processions displaying the icons, and now
44588. forbade Father Augustin to remove icons or the relics of saints; now
44589. seized all the private carts in Moscow and on one hundred and thirty-six
44590. of them removed the balloon that was being constructed by Leppich; now
44591. hinted that he would burn Moscow and related how he had set fire to his
44592. own house; now wrote a proclamation to the French solemnly upbraiding
44593. them for having destroyed his Orphanage; now claimed the glory of
44594. having hinted that he would burn Moscow and now repudiated the deed;
44595. now ordered the people to catch all spies and bring them to him, and now
44596. reproached them for doing so; now expelled all the French residents from
44597. Moscow, and now allowed Madame Aubert-Chalme (the center of the whole
44598. French colony in Moscow) to remain, but ordered the venerable old
44599. postmaster Klyucharev to be arrested and exiled for no particular
44600. offense; now assembled the people at the Three Hills to fight the French
44601. and now, to get rid of them, handed over to them a man to be killed
44602. and himself drove away by a back gate; now declared that he would
44603. not survive the fall of Moscow, and now wrote French verses in albums
44604. concerning his share in the affair--this man did not understand the
44605. meaning of what was happening but merely wanted to do something himself
44606. that would astonish people, to perform some patriotically heroic
44607. feat; and like a child he made sport of the momentous, and unavoidable
44608. event--the abandonment and burning of Moscow--and tried with his puny
44609. hand now to speed and now to stay the enormous, popular tide that bore
44610. him along with it.
44611. 
44612. 
44613. 
44614. 
44615. 
44616. CHAPTER VI
44617. 
44618. 
44619. Helene, having returned with the court from Vilna to Petersburg, found
44620. herself in a difficult position.
44621. 
44622. In Petersburg she had enjoyed the special protection of a grandee who
44623. occupied one of the highest posts in the Empire. In Vilna she had formed
44624. an intimacy with a young foreign prince. When she returned to Petersburg
44625. both the magnate and the prince were there, and both claimed their
44626. rights. Helene was faced by a new problem--how to preserve her intimacy
44627. with both without offending either.
44628. 
44629. What would have seemed difficult or even impossible to another woman did
44630. not cause the least embarrassment to Countess Bezukhova, who evidently
44631. deserved her reputation of being a very clever woman. Had she attempted
44632. concealment, or tried to extricate herself from her awkward position
44633. by cunning, she would have spoiled her case by acknowledging herself
44634. guilty. But Helene, like a really great man who can do whatever
44635. he pleases, at once assumed her own position to be correct, as she
44636. sincerely believed it to be, and that everyone else was to blame.
44637. 
44638. The first time the young foreigner allowed himself to reproach her, she
44639. lifted her beautiful head and, half turning to him, said firmly: "That's
44640. just like a man--selfish and cruel! I expected nothing else. A woman
44641. sacrifices herself for you, she suffers, and this is her reward! What
44642. right have you, monseigneur, to demand an account of my attachments and
44643. friendships? He is a man who has been more than a father to me!" The
44644. prince was about to say something, but Helene interrupted him.
44645. 
44646. "Well, yes," said she, "it may be that he has other sentiments for me
44647. than those of a father, but that is not a reason for me to shut my door
44648. on him. I am not a man, that I should repay kindness with ingratitude!
44649. Know, monseigneur, that in all that relates to my intimate feelings I
44650. render account only to God and to my conscience," she concluded, laying
44651. her hand on her beautiful, fully expanded bosom and looking up to
44652. heaven.
44653. 
44654. "But for heaven's sake listen to me!"
44655. 
44656. "Marry me, and I will be your slave!"
44657. 
44658. "But that's impossible."
44659. 
44660. "You won't deign to demean yourself by marrying me, you..." said Helene,
44661. beginning to cry.
44662. 
44663. The prince tried to comfort her, but Helene, as if quite distraught,
44664. said through her tears that there was nothing to prevent her marrying,
44665. that there were precedents (there were up to that time very few, but
44666. she mentioned Napoleon and some other exalted personages), that she had
44667. never been her husband's wife, and that she had been sacrificed.
44668. 
44669. "But the law, religion..." said the prince, already yielding.
44670. 
44671. "The law, religion... What have they been invented for if they can't
44672. arrange that?" said Helene.
44673. 
44674. The prince was surprised that so simple an idea had not occurred to him,
44675. and he applied for advice to the holy brethren of the Society of Jesus,
44676. with whom he was on intimate terms.
44677. 
44678. A few days later at one of those enchanting fetes which Helene gave at
44679. her country house on the Stone Island, the charming Monsieur de Jobert,
44680. a man no longer young, with snow white hair and brilliant black eyes,
44681. a Jesuit a robe courte * was presented to her, and in the garden by the
44682. light of the illuminations and to the sound of music talked to her for a
44683. long time of the love of God, of Christ, of the Sacred Heart, and of the
44684. consolations the one true Catholic religion affords in this world and
44685. the next. Helene was touched, and more than once tears rose to her eyes
44686. and to those of Monsieur de Jobert and their voices trembled. A dance,
44687. for which her partner came to seek her, put an end to her discourse with
44688. her future directeur de conscience, but the next evening Monsieur de
44689. Jobert came to see Helene when she was alone, and after that often came
44690. again.
44691. 
44692. 
44693.     * Lay member of the Society of Jesus.
44694. 
44695. 
44696. One day he took the countess to a Roman Catholic church, where she knelt
44697. down before the altar to which she was led. The enchanting, middle-aged
44698. Frenchman laid his hands on her head and, as she herself afterward
44699. described it, she felt something like a fresh breeze wafted into her
44700. soul. It was explained to her that this was la grace.
44701. 
44702. After that a long-frocked abbe was brought to her. She confessed to
44703. him, and he absolved her from her sins. Next day she received a box
44704. containing the Sacred Host, which was left at her house for her to
44705. partake of. A few days later Helene learned with pleasure that she had
44706. now been admitted to the true Catholic Church and that in a few days the
44707. Pope himself would hear of her and would send her a certain document.
44708. 
44709. All that was done around her and to her at this time, all the attention
44710. devoted to her by so many clever men and expressed in such pleasant,
44711. refined ways, and the state of dove-like purity she was now in (she wore
44712. only white dresses and white ribbons all that time) gave her pleasure,
44713. but her pleasure did not cause her for a moment to forget her aim. And
44714. as it always happens in contests of cunning that a stupid person gets
44715. the better of cleverer ones, Helene--having realized that the main
44716. object of all these words and all this trouble was, after converting her
44717. to Catholicism, to obtain money from her for Jesuit institutions (as to
44718. which she received indications)-before parting with her money insisted
44719. that the various operations necessary to free her from her husband
44720. should be performed. In her view the aim of every religion was merely
44721. to preserve certain proprieties while affording satisfaction to
44722. human desires. And with this aim, in one of her talks with her Father
44723. Confessor, she insisted on an answer to the question, in how far was she
44724. bound by her marriage?
44725. 
44726. They were sitting in the twilight by a window in the drawing room.
44727. The scent of flowers came in at the window. Helene was wearing a white
44728. dress, transparent over her shoulders and bosom. The abbe, a well-fed
44729. man with a plump, clean-shaven chin, a pleasant firm mouth, and white
44730. hands meekly folded on his knees, sat close to Helene and, with a
44731. subtle smile on his lips and a peaceful look of delight at her beauty,
44732. occasionally glanced at her face as he explained his opinion on the
44733. subject. Helene with an uneasy smile looked at his curly hair and his
44734. plump, clean-shaven, blackish cheeks and every moment expected the
44735. conversation to take a fresh turn. But the abbe, though he evidently
44736. enjoyed the beauty of his companion, was absorbed in his mastery of the
44737. matter.
44738. 
44739. The course of the Father Confessor's arguments ran as follows: "Ignorant
44740. of the import of what you were undertaking, you made a vow of conjugal
44741. fidelity to a man who on his part, by entering the married state without
44742. faith in the religious significance of marriage, committed an act of
44743. sacrilege. That marriage lacked the dual significance it should have
44744. had. Yet in spite of this your vow was binding. You swerved from it.
44745. What did you commit by so acting? A venial, or a mortal, sin? A venial
44746. sin, for you acted without evil intention. If now you married again
44747. with the object of bearing children, your sin might be forgiven. But the
44748. question is again a twofold one: firstly..."
44749. 
44750. But suddenly Helene, who was getting bored, said with one of her
44751. bewitching smiles: "But I think that having espoused the true religion I
44752. cannot be bound by what a false religion laid upon me."
44753. 
44754. The director of her conscience was astounded at having the case
44755. presented to him thus with the simplicity of Columbus' egg. He was
44756. delighted at the unexpected rapidity of his pupil's progress, but could
44757. not abandon the edifice of argument he had laboriously constructed.
44758. 
44759. "Let us understand one another, Countess," said he with a smile, and
44760. began refuting his spiritual daughter's arguments.
44761. 
44762. 
44763. 
44764. 
44765. 
44766. CHAPTER VII
44767. 
44768. 
44769. Helene understood that the question was very simple and easy from
44770. the ecclesiastical point of view, and that her directors were making
44771. difficulties only because they were apprehensive as to how the matter
44772. would be regarded by the secular authorities.
44773. 
44774. So she decided that it was necessary to prepare the opinion of society.
44775. She provoked the jealousy of the elderly magnate and told him what she
44776. had told her other suitor; that is, she put the matter so that the only
44777. way for him to obtain a right over her was to marry her. The elderly
44778. magnate was at first as much taken aback by this suggestion of marriage
44779. with a woman whose husband was alive, as the younger man had been, but
44780. Helene's imperturbable conviction that it was as simple and natural as
44781. marrying a maiden had its effect on him too. Had Helene herself shown
44782. the least sign of hesitation, shame, or secrecy, her cause would
44783. certainly have been lost; but not only did she show no signs of secrecy
44784. or shame, on the contrary, with good-natured naivete she told her
44785. intimate friends (and these were all Petersburg) that both the prince
44786. and the magnate had proposed to her and that she loved both and was
44787. afraid of grieving either.
44788. 
44789. A rumor immediately spread in Petersburg, not that Helene wanted to
44790. be divorced from her husband (had such a report spread many would have
44791. opposed so illegal an intention) but simply that the unfortunate and
44792. interesting Helene was in doubt which of the two men she should marry.
44793. The question was no longer whether this was possible, but only which was
44794. the better match and how the matter would be regarded at court. There
44795. were, it is true, some rigid individuals unable to rise to the height of
44796. such a question, who saw in the project a desecration of the sacrament
44797. of marriage, but there were not many such and they remained silent,
44798. while the majority were interested in Helene's good fortune and in the
44799. question which match would be the more advantageous. Whether it was
44800. right or wrong to remarry while one had a husband living they did not
44801. discuss, for that question had evidently been settled by people "wiser
44802. than you or me," as they said, and to doubt the correctness of that
44803. decision would be to risk exposing one's stupidity and incapacity to
44804. live in society.
44805. 
44806. Only Marya Dmitrievna Akhrosimova, who had come to Petersburg that
44807. summer to see one of her sons, allowed herself plainly to express
44808. an opinion contrary to the general one. Meeting Helene at a ball she
44809. stopped her in the middle of the room and, amid general silence, said
44810. in her gruff voice: "So wives of living men have started marrying
44811. again! Perhaps you think you have invented a novelty? You have been
44812. forestalled, my dear! It was thought of long ago. It is done in all the
44813. brothels," and with these words Marya Dmitrievna, turning up her wide
44814. sleeves with her usual threatening gesture and glancing sternly round,
44815. moved across the room.
44816. 
44817. Though people were afraid of Marya Dmitrievna she was regarded in
44818. Petersburg as a buffoon, and so of what she had said they only noticed,
44819. and repeated in a whisper, the one coarse word she had used, supposing
44820. the whole sting of her remark to lie in that word.
44821. 
44822. Prince Vasili, who of late very often forgot what he had said and
44823. repeated one and the same thing a hundred times, remarked to his
44824. daughter whenever he chanced to see her:
44825. 
44826. "Helene, I have a word to say to you," and he would lead her
44827. aside, drawing her hand downward. "I have heard of certain projects
44828. concerning... you know. Well my dear child, you know how your father's
44829. heart rejoices to know that you... You have suffered so much.... But, my
44830. dear child, consult only your own heart. That is all I have to say," and
44831. concealing his unvarying emotion he would press his cheek against his
44832. daughter's and move away.
44833. 
44834. Bilibin, who had not lost his reputation of an exceedingly clever man,
44835. and who was one of the disinterested friends so brilliant a woman as
44836. Helene always has--men friends who can never change into lovers--once
44837. gave her his view of the matter at a small and intimate gathering.
44838. 
44839. "Listen, Bilibin," said Helene (she always called friends of that sort
44840. by their surnames), and she touched his coat sleeve with her white,
44841. beringed fingers. "Tell me, as you would a sister, what I ought to do.
44842. Which of the two?"
44843. 
44844. Bilibin wrinkled up the skin over his eyebrows and pondered, with a
44845. smile on his lips.
44846. 
44847. "You are not taking me unawares, you know," said he. "As a true friend,
44848. I have thought and thought again about your affair. You see, if you
44849. marry the prince"--he meant the younger man--and he crooked one finger,
44850. "you forever lose the chance of marrying the other, and you will
44851. displease the court besides. (You know there is some kind of
44852. connection.) But if you marry the old count you will make his last days
44853. happy, and as widow of the Grand... the prince would no longer be making
44854. a mesalliance by marrying you," and Bilibin smoothed out his forehead.
44855. 
44856. "That's a true friend!" said Helene beaming, and again touching
44857. Bilibin's sleeve. "But I love them, you know, and don't want to distress
44858. either of them. I would give my life for the happiness of them both."
44859. 
44860. Bilibin shrugged his shoulders, as much as to say that not even he could
44861. help in that difficulty.
44862. 
44863. "Une maitresse-femme! * That's what is called putting things squarely.
44864. She would like to be married to all three at the same time," thought he.
44865. 
44866. 
44867.     * A masterly woman.
44868. 
44869. 
44870. "But tell me, how will your husband look at the matter?" Bilibin asked,
44871. his reputation being so well established that he did not fear to ask so
44872. naive a question. "Will he agree?"
44873. 
44874. "Oh, he loves me so!" said Helene, who for some reason imagined that
44875. Pierre too loved her. "He will do anything for me."
44876. 
44877. Bilibin puckered his skin in preparation for something witty.
44878. 
44879. "Even divorce you?" said he.
44880. 
44881. Helene laughed.
44882. 
44883. Among those who ventured to doubt the justifiability of the proposed
44884. marriage was Helene's mother, Princess Kuragina. She was continually
44885. tormented by jealousy of her daughter, and now that jealousy concerned
44886. a subject near to her own heart, she could not reconcile herself to the
44887. idea. She consulted a Russian priest as to the possibility of divorce
44888. and remarriage during a husband's lifetime, and the priest told her that
44889. it was impossible, and to her delight showed her a text in the Gospel
44890. which (as it seemed to him) plainly forbids remarriage while the husband
44891. is alive.
44892. 
44893. Armed with these arguments, which appeared to her unanswerable, she
44894. drove to her daughter's early one morning so as to find her alone.
44895. 
44896. Having listened to her mother's objections, Helene smiled blandly and
44897. ironically.
44898. 
44899. "But it says plainly: 'Whosoever shall marry her that is divorced...'"
44900. said the old princess.
44901. 
44902. "Ah, Maman, ne dites pas de betises. Vous ne comprenez rein. Dans ma
44903. position j'ai des devoirs," * said Helene changing from Russian, in
44904. which language she always felt that her case did not sound quite clear,
44905. into French which suited it better.
44906. 
44907. 
44908.      * "Oh, Mamma, don't talk nonsense! You don't understand
44909.      anything. In my position I have obligations."
44910. 
44911. 
44912. "But, my dear...."
44913. 
44914. "Oh, Mamma, how is it you don't understand that the Holy Father, who has
44915. the right to grant dispensations..."
44916. 
44917. Just then the lady companion who lived with Helene came in to announce
44918. that His Highness was in the ballroom and wished to see her.
44919. 
44920. "Non, dites-lui que je ne veux pas le voir, que je suis furieuse contre
44921. lui, parce qu'il m'a manque parole." *
44922. 
44923. 
44924.      * "No, tell him I don't wish to see him, I am furious with
44925.      him for not keeping his word to me."
44926. 
44927. 
44928. "Comtesse, a tout peche misericorde," * said a fair-haired young man
44929. with a long face and nose, as he entered the room.
44930. 
44931. 
44932.     * "Countess, there is mercy for every sin."
44933. 
44934. 
44935. The old princess rose respectfully and curtsied. The young man who had
44936. entered took no notice of her. The princess nodded to her daughter and
44937. sidled out of the room.
44938. 
44939. "Yes, she is right," thought the old princess, all her convictions
44940. dissipated by the appearance of His Highness. "She is right, but how
44941. is it that we in our irrecoverable youth did not know it? Yet it is so
44942. simple," she thought as she got into her carriage.
44943. 
44944. 
44945. By the beginning of August Helene's affairs were clearly defined and
44946. she wrote a letter to her husband--who, as she imagined, loved her very
44947. much--informing him of her intention to marry N.N. and of her having
44948. embraced the one true faith, and asking him to carry out all the
44949. formalities necessary for a divorce, which would be explained to him by
44950. the bearer of the letter.
44951. 
44952. 
44953. And so I pray God to have you, my friend, in His holy and powerful
44954. keeping--Your friend Helene.
44955. 
44956. 
44957. This letter was brought to Pierre's house when he was on the field of
44958. Borodino.
44959. 
44960. 
44961. 
44962. 
44963. 
44964. CHAPTER VIII
44965. 
44966. 
44967. Toward the end of the battle of Borodino, Pierre, having run down
44968. from Raevski's battery a second time, made his way through a gully to
44969. Knyazkovo with a crowd of soldiers, reached the dressing station, and
44970. seeing blood and hearing cries and groans hurried on, still entangled in
44971. the crowds of soldiers.
44972. 
44973. The one thing he now desired with his whole soul was to get away quickly
44974. from the terrible sensations amid which he had lived that day and return
44975. to ordinary conditions of life and sleep quietly in a room in his own
44976. bed. He felt that only in the ordinary conditions of life would he
44977. be able to understand himself and all he had seen and felt. But such
44978. ordinary conditions of life were nowhere to be found.
44979. 
44980. Though shells and bullets did not whistle over the road along which he
44981. was going, still on all sides there was what there had been on the field
44982. of battle. There were still the same suffering, exhausted, and sometimes
44983. strangely indifferent faces, the same blood, the same soldiers'
44984. overcoats, the same sounds of firing which, though distant now, still
44985. aroused terror, and besides this there were the foul air and the dust.
44986. 
44987. Having gone a couple of miles along the Mozhaysk road, Pierre sat down
44988. by the roadside.
44989. 
44990. Dusk had fallen, and the roar of guns died away. Pierre lay leaning on
44991. his elbow for a long time, gazing at the shadows that moved past him in
44992. the darkness. He was continually imagining that a cannon ball was flying
44993. toward him with a terrific whizz, and then he shuddered and sat up. He
44994. had no idea how long he had been there. In the middle of the night three
44995. soldiers, having brought some firewood, settled down near him and began
44996. lighting a fire.
44997. 
44998. The soldiers, who threw sidelong glances at Pierre, got the fire to burn
44999. and placed an iron pot on it into which they broke some dried bread and
45000. put a little dripping. The pleasant odor of greasy viands mingled with
45001. the smell of smoke. Pierre sat up and sighed. The three soldiers were
45002. eating and talking among themselves, taking no notice of him.
45003. 
45004. "And who may you be?" one of them suddenly asked Pierre, evidently
45005. meaning what Pierre himself had in mind, namely: "If you want to eat
45006. we'll give you some food, only let us know whether you are an honest
45007. man."
45008. 
45009. "I, I..." said Pierre, feeling it necessary to minimize his social
45010. position as much as possible so as to be nearer to the soldiers and
45011. better understood by them. "By rights I am a militia officer, but my men
45012. are not here. I came to the battle and have lost them."
45013. 
45014. "There now!" said one of the soldiers.
45015. 
45016. Another shook his head.
45017. 
45018. "Would you like a little mash?" the first soldier asked, and handed
45019. Pierre a wooden spoon after licking it clean.
45020. 
45021. Pierre sat down by the fire and began eating the mash, as they called
45022. the food in the cauldron, and he thought it more delicious than any food
45023. he had ever tasted. As he sat bending greedily over it, helping himself
45024. to large spoonfuls and chewing one after another, his face was lit up by
45025. the fire and the soldiers looked at him in silence.
45026. 
45027. "Where have you to go to? Tell us!" said one of them.
45028. 
45029. "To Mozhaysk."
45030. 
45031. "You're a gentleman, aren't you?"
45032. 
45033. "Yes."
45034. 
45035. "And what's your name?"
45036. 
45037. "Peter Kirilych."
45038. 
45039. "Well then, Peter Kirilych, come along with us, we'll take you there."
45040. 
45041. In the total darkness the soldiers walked with Pierre to Mozhaysk.
45042. 
45043. By the time they got near Mozhaysk and began ascending the steep hill
45044. into the town, the cocks were already crowing. Pierre went on with the
45045. soldiers, quite forgetting that his inn was at the bottom of the hill
45046. and that he had already passed it. He would not soon have remembered
45047. this, such was his state of forgetfulness, had he not halfway up the
45048. hill stumbled upon his groom, who had been to look for him in the
45049. town and was returning to the inn. The groom recognized Pierre in the
45050. darkness by his white hat.
45051. 
45052. "Your excellency!" he said. "Why, we were beginning to despair! How is
45053. it you are on foot? And where are you going, please?"
45054. 
45055. "Oh, yes!" said Pierre.
45056. 
45057. The soldiers stopped.
45058. 
45059. "So you've found your folk?" said one of them. "Well, good-by, Peter
45060. Kirilych--isn't it?"
45061. 
45062. "Good-by, Peter Kirilych!" Pierre heard the other voices repeat.
45063. 
45064. "Good-by!" he said and turned with his groom toward the inn.
45065. 
45066. "I ought to give them something!" he thought, and felt in his pocket.
45067. "No, better not!" said another, inner voice.
45068. 
45069. There was not a room to be had at the inn, they were all occupied.
45070. Pierre went out into the yard and, covering himself up head and all, lay
45071. down in his carriage.
45072. 
45073. 
45074. 
45075. 
45076. 
45077. CHAPTER IX
45078. 
45079. 
45080. Scarcely had Pierre laid his head on the pillow before he felt himself
45081. falling asleep, but suddenly, almost with the distinctness of reality,
45082. he heard the boom, boom, boom of firing, the thud of projectiles, groans
45083. and cries, and smelled blood and powder, and a feeling of horror and
45084. dread of death seized him. Filled with fright he opened his eyes and
45085. lifted his head from under his cloak. All was tranquil in the yard. Only
45086. someone's orderly passed through the gateway, splashing through the mud,
45087. and talked to the innkeeper. Above Pierre's head some pigeons, disturbed
45088. by the movement he had made in sitting up, fluttered under the dark roof
45089. of the penthouse. The whole courtyard was permeated by a strong peaceful
45090. smell of stable yards, delightful to Pierre at that moment. He could see
45091. the clear starry sky between the dark roofs of two penthouses.
45092. 
45093. "Thank God, there is no more of that!" he thought, covering up his head
45094. again. "Oh, what a terrible thing is fear, and how shamefully I yielded
45095. to it! But they... they were steady and calm all the time, to the
45096. end..." thought he.
45097. 
45098. They, in Pierre's mind, were the soldiers, those who had been at the
45099. battery, those who had given him food, and those who had prayed before
45100. the icon. They, those strange men he had not previously known, stood out
45101. clearly and sharply from everyone else.
45102. 
45103. "To be a soldier, just a soldier!" thought Pierre as he fell asleep,
45104. "to enter communal life completely, to be imbued by what makes them what
45105. they are. But how cast off all the superfluous, devilish burden of my
45106. outer man? There was a time when I could have done it. I could have run
45107. away from my father, as I wanted to. Or I might have been sent to serve
45108. as a soldier after the duel with Dolokhov." And the memory of the dinner
45109. at the English Club when he had challenged Dolokhov flashed through
45110. Pierre's mind, and then he remembered his benefactor at Torzhok. And now
45111. a picture of a solemn meeting of the lodge presented itself to his mind.
45112. It was taking place at the English Club and someone near and dear to him
45113. sat at the end of the table. "Yes, that is he! It is my benefactor.
45114. But he died!" thought Pierre. "Yes, he died, and I did not know he was
45115. alive. How sorry I am that he died, and how glad I am that he is alive
45116. again!" On one side of the table sat Anatole, Dolokhov, Nesvitski,
45117. Denisov, and others like them (in his dream the category to which these
45118. men belonged was as clearly defined in his mind as the category of
45119. those he termed they), and he heard those people, Anatole and Dolokhov,
45120. shouting and singing loudly; yet through their shouting the voice of his
45121. benefactor was heard speaking all the time and the sound of his words
45122. was as weighty and uninterrupted as the booming on the battlefield, but
45123. pleasant and comforting. Pierre did not understand what his benefactor
45124. was saying, but he knew (the categories of thoughts were also quite
45125. distinct in his dream) that he was talking of goodness and the
45126. possibility of being what they were. And they with their simple, kind,
45127. firm faces surrounded his benefactor on all sides. But though they were
45128. kindly they did not look at Pierre and did not know him. Wishing to
45129. speak and to attract their attention, he got up, but at that moment his
45130. legs grew cold and bare.
45131. 
45132. He felt ashamed, and with one arm covered his legs from which his cloak
45133. had in fact slipped. For a moment as he was rearranging his cloak Pierre
45134. opened his eyes and saw the same penthouse roofs, posts, and yard, but
45135. now they were all bluish, lit up, and glittering with frost or dew.
45136. 
45137. "It is dawn," thought Pierre. "But that's not what I want. I want to
45138. hear and understand my benefactor's words." Again he covered himself up
45139. with his cloak, but now neither the lodge nor his benefactor was there.
45140. There were only thoughts clearly expressed in words, thoughts that
45141. someone was uttering or that he himself was formulating.
45142. 
45143. Afterwards when he recalled those thoughts Pierre was convinced that
45144. someone outside himself had spoken them, though the impressions of that
45145. day had evoked them. He had never, it seemed to him, been able to think
45146. and express his thoughts like that when awake.
45147. 
45148. "To endure war is the most difficult subordination of man's freedom to
45149. the law of God," the voice had said. "Simplicity is submission to the
45150. will of God; you cannot escape from Him. And they are simple. They do
45151. not talk, but act. The spoken word is silver but the unspoken is golden.
45152. Man can be master of nothing while he fears death, but he who does not
45153. fear it possesses all. If there were no suffering, man would not know
45154. his limitations, would not know himself. The hardest thing (Pierre went
45155. on thinking, or hearing, in his dream) is to be able in your soul to
45156. unite the meaning of all. To unite all?" he asked himself. "No, not
45157. to unite. Thoughts cannot be united, but to harness all these thoughts
45158. together is what we need! Yes, one must harness them, must harness
45159. them!" he repeated to himself with inward rapture, feeling that these
45160. words and they alone expressed what he wanted to say and solved the
45161. question that tormented him.
45162. 
45163. "Yes, one must harness, it is time to harness."
45164. 
45165. "Time to harness, time to harness, your excellency! Your excellency!"
45166. some voice was repeating. "We must harness, it is time to harness...."
45167. 
45168. It was the voice of the groom, trying to wake him. The sun shone
45169. straight into Pierre's face. He glanced at the dirty innyard in the
45170. middle of which soldiers were watering their lean horses at the pump
45171. while carts were passing out of the gate. Pierre turned away with
45172. repugnance, and closing his eyes quickly fell back on the carriage seat.
45173. "No, I don't want that, I don't want to see and understand that. I want
45174. to understand what was revealing itself to me in my dream. One second
45175. more and I should have understood it all! But what am I to do? Harness,
45176. but how can I harness everything?" and Pierre felt with horror that the
45177. meaning of all he had seen and thought in the dream had been destroyed.
45178. 
45179. The groom, the coachman, and the innkeeper told Pierre that an officer
45180. had come with news that the French were already near Mozhaysk and that
45181. our men were leaving it.
45182. 
45183. Pierre got up and, having told them to harness and overtake him, went on
45184. foot through the town.
45185. 
45186. The troops were moving on, leaving about ten thousand wounded behind
45187. them. There were wounded in the yards, at the windows of the houses, and
45188. the streets were crowded with them. In the streets, around carts that
45189. were to take some of the wounded away, shouts, curses, and blows could
45190. be heard. Pierre offered the use of his carriage, which had overtaken
45191. him, to a wounded general he knew, and drove with him to Moscow. On the
45192. way Pierre was told of the death of his brother-in-law Anatole and of
45193. that of Prince Andrew.
45194. 
45195. 
45196. 
45197. 
45198. 
45199. CHAPTER X
45200. 
45201. 
45202. On the thirteenth of August Pierre reached Moscow. Close to the gates of
45203. the city he was met by Count Rostopchin's adjutant.
45204. 
45205. "We have been looking for you everywhere," said the adjutant. "The count
45206. wants to see you particularly. He asks you to come to him at once on a
45207. very important matter."
45208. 
45209. Without going home, Pierre took a cab and drove to see the Moscow
45210. commander in chief.
45211. 
45212. Count Rostopchin had only that morning returned to town from his summer
45213. villa at Sokolniki. The anteroom and reception room of his house
45214. were full of officials who had been summoned or had come for orders.
45215. Vasilchikov and Platov had already seen the count and explained to him
45216. that it was impossible to defend Moscow and that it would have to be
45217. surrendered. Though this news was being concealed from the inhabitants,
45218. the officials--the heads of the various government departments--knew
45219. that Moscow would soon be in the enemy's hands, just as Count Rostopchin
45220. himself knew it, and to escape personal responsibility they had all
45221. come to the governor to ask how they were to deal with their various
45222. departments.
45223. 
45224. As Pierre was entering the reception room a courier from the army came
45225. out of Rostopchin's private room.
45226. 
45227. In answer to questions with which he was greeted, the courier made a
45228. despairing gesture with his hand and passed through the room.
45229. 
45230. While waiting in the reception room Pierre with weary eyes watched the
45231. various officials, old and young, military and civilian, who were there.
45232. They all seemed dissatisfied and uneasy. Pierre went up to a group of
45233. men, one of whom he knew. After greeting Pierre they continued their
45234. conversation.
45235. 
45236. "If they're sent out and brought back again later on it will do no harm,
45237. but as things are now one can't answer for anything."
45238. 
45239. "But you see what he writes..." said another, pointing to a printed
45240. sheet he held in his hand.
45241. 
45242. "That's another matter. That's necessary for the people," said the
45243. first.
45244. 
45245. "What is it?" asked Pierre.
45246. 
45247. "Oh, it's a fresh broadsheet."
45248. 
45249. Pierre took it and began reading.
45250. 
45251. 
45252. His Serene Highness has passed through Mozhaysk in order to join up with
45253. the troops moving toward him and has taken up a strong position where
45254. the enemy will not soon attack him. Forty eight guns with ammunition
45255. have been sent him from here, and his Serene Highness says he will
45256. defend Moscow to the last drop of blood and is even ready to fight in
45257. the streets. Do not be upset, brothers, that the law courts are closed;
45258. things have to be put in order, and we will deal with villains in our
45259. own way! When the time comes I shall want both town and peasant lads and
45260. will raise the cry a day or two beforehand, but they are not wanted yet
45261. so I hold my peace. An ax will be useful, a hunting spear not bad, but a
45262. three-pronged fork will be best of all: a Frenchman is no heavier than a
45263. sheaf of rye. Tomorrow after dinner I shall take the Iberian icon of
45264. the Mother of God to the wounded in the Catherine Hospital where we will
45265. have some water blessed. That will help them to get well quicker. I,
45266. too, am well now: one of my eyes was sore but now I am on the lookout
45267. with both.
45268. 
45269. 
45270. "But military men have told me that it is impossible to fight in the
45271. town," said Pierre, "and that the position..."
45272. 
45273. "Well, of course! That's what we were saying," replied the first
45274. speaker.
45275. 
45276. "And what does he mean by 'One of my eyes was sore but now I am on the
45277. lookout with both'?" asked Pierre.
45278. 
45279. "The count had a sty," replied the adjutant smiling, "and was very much
45280. upset when I told him people had come to ask what was the matter with
45281. him. By the by, Count," he added suddenly, addressing Pierre with a
45282. smile, "we heard that you have family troubles and that the countess,
45283. your wife..."
45284. 
45285. "I have heard nothing," Pierre replied unconcernedly. "But what have you
45286. heard?"
45287. 
45288. "Oh, well, you know people often invent things. I only say what I
45289. heard."
45290. 
45291. "But what did you hear?"
45292. 
45293. "Well, they say," continued the adjutant with the same smile, "that
45294. the countess, your wife, is preparing to go abroad. I expect it's
45295. nonsense...."
45296. 
45297. "Possibly," remarked Pierre, looking about him absent-mindedly. "And who
45298. is that?" he asked, indicating a short old man in a clean blue peasant
45299. overcoat, with a big snow-white beard and eyebrows and a ruddy face.
45300. 
45301. "He? That's a tradesman, that is to say, he's the restaurant
45302. keeper, Vereshchagin. Perhaps you have heard of that affair with the
45303. proclamation."
45304. 
45305. "Oh, so that is Vereshchagin!" said Pierre, looking at the firm, calm
45306. face of the old man and seeking any indication of his being a traitor.
45307. 
45308. "That's not he himself, that's the father of the fellow who wrote the
45309. proclamation," said the adjutant. "The young man is in prison and I
45310. expect it will go hard with him."
45311. 
45312. An old gentleman wearing a star and another official, a German wearing a
45313. cross round his neck, approached the speaker.
45314. 
45315. "It's a complicated story, you know," said the adjutant. "That
45316. proclamation appeared about two months ago. The count was informed of
45317. it. He gave orders to investigate the matter. Gabriel Ivanovich
45318. here made the inquiries. The proclamation had passed through exactly
45319. sixty-three hands. He asked one, 'From whom did you get it?' 'From
45320. so-and-so.' He went to the next one. 'From whom did you get it?' and so
45321. on till he reached Vereshchagin, a half educated tradesman, you know, 'a
45322. pet of a trader,'" said the adjutant smiling. "They asked him, 'Who gave
45323. it you?' And the point is that we knew whom he had it from. He could
45324. only have had it from the Postmaster. But evidently they had come to
45325. some understanding. He replied: 'From no one; I made it up myself.'
45326. They threatened and questioned him, but he stuck to that: 'I made it
45327. up myself.' And so it was reported to the count, who sent for the man.
45328. 'From whom did you get the proclamation?' 'I wrote it myself.' Well, you
45329. know the count," said the adjutant cheerfully, with a smile of pride,
45330. "he flared up dreadfully--and just think of the fellow's audacity,
45331. lying, and obstinacy!"
45332. 
45333.  "And the count wanted him to say it was from Klyucharev? I
45334. understand!" said Pierre.
45335. 
45336. "Not at all," rejoined the adjutant in dismay. "Klyucharev had his own
45337. sins to answer for without that and that is why he has been banished.
45338. But the point is that the count was much annoyed. 'How could you have
45339. written it yourself?' said he, and he took up the Hamburg Gazette that
45340. was lying on the table. 'Here it is! You did not write it yourself but
45341. translated it, and translated it abominably, because you don't even know
45342. French, you fool.' And what do you think? 'No,' said he, 'I have not
45343. read any papers, I made it up myself.' 'If that's so, you're a traitor
45344. and I'll have you tried, and you'll be hanged! Say from whom you had
45345. it.' 'I have seen no papers, I made it up myself.' And that was the end
45346. of it. The count had the father fetched, but the fellow stuck to it.
45347. He was sent for trial and condemned to hard labor, I believe. Now the
45348. father has come to intercede for him. But he's a good-for-nothing lad!
45349. You know that sort of tradesman's son, a dandy and lady-killer. He
45350. attended some lectures somewhere and imagines that the devil is no match
45351. for him. That's the sort of fellow he is. His father keeps a cookshop
45352. here by the Stone Bridge, and you know there was a large icon of God
45353. Almighty painted with a scepter in one hand and an orb in the other.
45354. Well, he took that icon home with him for a few days and what did he do?
45355. He found some scoundrel of a painter..."
45356. 
45357. 
45358. 
45359. 
45360. 
45361. CHAPTER XI
45362. 
45363. 
45364. In the middle of this fresh tale Pierre was summoned to the commander in
45365. chief.
45366. 
45367. When he entered the private room Count Rostopchin, puckering his face,
45368. was rubbing his forehead and eyes with his hand. A short man was saying
45369. something, but when Pierre entered he stopped speaking and went out.
45370. 
45371. "Ah, how do you do, great warrior?" said Rostopchin as soon as the short
45372. man had left the room. "We have heard of your prowess. But that's not
45373. the point. Between ourselves, mon cher, do you belong to the Masons?" he
45374. went on severely, as though there were something wrong about it which
45375. he nevertheless intended to pardon. Pierre remained silent. "I am well
45376. informed, my friend, but I am aware that there are Masons and I hope
45377. that you are not one of those who on pretense of saving mankind wish to
45378. ruin Russia."
45379. 
45380. "Yes, I am a Mason," Pierre replied.
45381. 
45382. "There, you see, mon cher! I expect you know that Messrs. Speranski and
45383. Magnitski have been deported to their proper place. Mr. Klyucharev has
45384. been treated in the same way, and so have others who on the plea of
45385. building up the temple of Solomon have tried to destroy the temple of
45386. their fatherland. You can understand that there are reasons for this and
45387. that I could not have exiled the Postmaster had he not been a harmful
45388. person. It has now come to my knowledge that you lent him your carriage
45389. for his removal from town, and that you have even accepted papers from
45390. him for safe custody. I like you and don't wish you any harm and--as
45391. you are only half my age--I advise you, as a father would, to cease
45392. all communication with men of that stamp and to leave here as soon as
45393. possible."
45394. 
45395. "But what did Klyucharev do wrong, Count?" asked Pierre.
45396. 
45397. "That is for me to know, but not for you to ask," shouted Rostopchin.
45398. 
45399. "If he is accused of circulating Napoleon's proclamation it is not
45400. proved that he did so," said Pierre without looking at Rostopchin, "and
45401. Vereshchagin..."
45402. 
45403. "There we are!" Rostopchin shouted at Pierre louder than before,
45404. frowning suddenly. "Vereshchagin is a renegade and a traitor who will
45405. be punished as he deserves," said he with the vindictive heat with which
45406. people speak when recalling an insult. "But I did not summon you to
45407. discuss my actions, but to give you advice--or an order if you prefer
45408. it. I beg you to leave the town and break off all communication
45409. with such men as Klyucharev. And I will knock the nonsense out of
45410. anybody"--but probably realizing that he was shouting at Bezukhov who
45411. so far was not guilty of anything, he added, taking Pierre's hand in a
45412. friendly manner, "We are on the eve of a public disaster and I haven't
45413. time to be polite to everybody who has business with me. My head is
45414. sometimes in a whirl. Well, mon cher, what are you doing personally?"
45415. 
45416. "Why, nothing," answered Pierre without raising his eyes or changing the
45417. thoughtful expression of his face.
45418. 
45419. The count frowned.
45420. 
45421. "A word of friendly advice, mon cher. Be off as soon as you can, that's
45422. all I have to tell you. Happy he who has ears to hear. Good-by, my dear
45423. fellow. Oh, by the by!" he shouted through the doorway after Pierre,
45424. "is it true that the countess has fallen into the clutches of the holy
45425. fathers of the Society of Jesus?"
45426. 
45427. Pierre did not answer and left Rostopchin's room more sullen and angry
45428. than he had ever before shown himself.
45429. 
45430. When he reached home it was already getting dark. Some eight people had
45431. come to see him that evening: the secretary of a committee, the colonel
45432. of his battalion, his steward, his major-domo, and various petitioners.
45433. They all had business with Pierre and wanted decisions from him. Pierre
45434. did not understand and was not interested in any of these questions and
45435. only answered them in order to get rid of these people. When left alone
45436. at last he opened and read his wife's letter.
45437. 
45438. "They, the soldiers at the battery, Prince Andrew killed... that old
45439. man... Simplicity is submission to God. Suffering is necessary... the
45440. meaning of all... one must harness... my wife is getting married... One
45441. must forget and understand..." And going to his bed he threw himself on
45442. it without undressing and immediately fell asleep.
45443. 
45444. When he awoke next morning the major-domo came to inform him that a
45445. special messenger, a police officer, had come from Count Rostopchin to
45446. know whether Count Bezukhov had left or was leaving the town.
45447. 
45448. A dozen persons who had business with Pierre were awaiting him in the
45449. drawing room. Pierre dressed hurriedly and, instead of going to see
45450. them, went to the back porch and out through the gate.
45451. 
45452. From that time till the end of the destruction of Moscow no one of
45453. Bezukhov's household, despite all the search they made, saw Pierre again
45454. or knew where he was.
45455. 
45456. 
45457. 
45458. 
45459. 
45460. CHAPTER XII
45461. 
45462. 
45463. The Rostovs remained in Moscow till the first of September, that is,
45464. till the eve of the enemy's entry into the city.
45465. 
45466. After Petya had joined Obolenski's regiment of Cossacks and left for
45467. Belaya Tserkov where that regiment was forming, the countess was seized
45468. with terror. The thought that both her sons were at the war, had both
45469. gone from under her wing, that today or tomorrow either or both of them
45470. might be killed like the three sons of one of her acquaintances, struck
45471. her that summer for the first time with cruel clearness. She tried to
45472. get Nicholas back and wished to go herself to join Petya, or to get
45473. him an appointment somewhere in Petersburg, but neither of these proved
45474. possible. Petya could not return unless his regiment did so or unless
45475. he was transferred to another regiment on active service. Nicholas was
45476. somewhere with the army and had not sent a word since his last letter,
45477. in which he had given a detailed account of his meeting with Princess
45478. Mary. The countess did not sleep at night, or when she did fall asleep
45479. dreamed that she saw her sons lying dead. After many consultations and
45480. conversations, the count at last devised means to tranquillize her. He
45481. got Petya transferred from Obolenski's regiment to Bezukhov's, which was
45482. in training near Moscow. Though Petya would remain in the service, this
45483. transfer would give the countess the consolation of seeing at least one
45484. of her sons under her wing, and she hoped to arrange matters for her
45485. Petya so as not to let him go again, but always get him appointed to
45486. places where he could not possibly take part in a battle. As long as
45487. Nicholas alone was in danger the countess imagined that she loved her
45488. first-born more than all her other children and even reproached herself
45489. for it; but when her youngest: the scapegrace who had been bad at
45490. lessons, was always breaking things in the house and making himself a
45491. nuisance to everybody, that snub-nosed Petya with his merry black eyes
45492. and fresh rosy cheeks where soft down was just beginning to show--when
45493. he was thrown amid those big, dreadful, cruel men who were fighting
45494. somewhere about something and apparently finding pleasure in it--then
45495. his mother thought she loved him more, much more, than all her other
45496. children. The nearer the time came for Petya to return, the more uneasy
45497. grew the countess. She began to think she would never live to see such
45498. happiness. The presence of Sonya, of her beloved Natasha, or even of
45499. her husband irritated her. "What do I want with them? I want no one but
45500. Petya," she thought.
45501. 
45502. At the end of August the Rostovs received another letter from Nicholas.
45503. He wrote from the province of Voronezh where he had been sent to procure
45504. remounts, but that letter did not set the countess at ease. Knowing that
45505. one son was out of danger she became the more anxious about Petya.
45506. 
45507. Though by the twentieth of August nearly all the Rostovs' acquaintances
45508. had left Moscow, and though everybody tried to persuade the countess to
45509. get away as quickly as possible, she would not hear of leaving before
45510. her treasure, her adored Petya, returned. On the twenty-eighth of August
45511. he arrived. The passionate tenderness with which his mother received him
45512. did not please the sixteen-year-old officer. Though she concealed from
45513. him her intention of keeping him under her wing, Petya guessed her
45514. designs, and instinctively fearing that he might give way to emotion
45515. when with her--might "become womanish" as he termed it to himself--he
45516. treated her coldly, avoided her, and during his stay in Moscow attached
45517. himself exclusively to Natasha for whom he had always had a particularly
45518. brotherly tenderness, almost lover-like.
45519. 
45520. Owing to the count's customary carelessness nothing was ready for their
45521. departure by the twenty-eighth of August and the carts that were to
45522. come from their Ryazan and Moscow estates to remove their household
45523. belongings did not arrive till the thirtieth.
45524. 
45525. From the twenty-eighth till the thirty-first all Moscow was in a bustle
45526. and commotion. Every day thousands of men wounded at Borodino were
45527. brought in by the Dorogomilov gate and taken to various parts of Moscow,
45528. and thousands of carts conveyed the inhabitants and their possessions
45529. out by the other gates. In spite of Rostopchin's broadsheets, or because
45530. of them or independently of them, the strangest and most contradictory
45531. rumors were current in the town. Some said that no one was to be allowed
45532. to leave the city, others on the contrary said that all the icons had
45533. been taken out of the churches and everybody was to be ordered to leave.
45534. Some said there had been another battle after Borodino at which the
45535. French had been routed, while others on the contrary reported that the
45536. Russian army had been destroyed. Some talked about the Moscow militia
45537. which, preceded by the clergy, would go to the Three Hills; others
45538. whispered that Augustin had been forbidden to leave, that traitors had
45539. been seized, that the peasants were rioting and robbing people on their
45540. way from Moscow, and so on. But all this was only talk; in reality
45541. (though the Council of Fili, at which it was decided to abandon Moscow,
45542. had not yet been held) both those who went away and those who remained
45543. behind felt, though they did not show it, that Moscow would certainly
45544. be abandoned, and that they ought to get away as quickly as possible and
45545. save their belongings. It was felt that everything would suddenly break
45546. up and change, but up to the first of September nothing had done so.
45547. As a criminal who is being led to execution knows that he must die
45548. immediately, but yet looks about him and straightens the cap that is
45549. awry on his head, so Moscow involuntarily continued its wonted life,
45550. though it knew that the time of its destruction was near when the
45551. conditions of life to which its people were accustomed to submit would
45552. be completely upset.
45553. 
45554. During the three days preceding the occupation of Moscow the whole
45555. Rostov family was absorbed in various activities. The head of the
45556. family, Count Ilya Rostov, continually drove about the city collecting
45557. the current rumors from all sides and gave superficial and hasty orders
45558. at home about the preparations for their departure.
45559. 
45560. The countess watched the things being packed, was dissatisfied with
45561. everything, was constantly in pursuit of Petya who was always running
45562. away from her, and was jealous of Natasha with whom he spent all his
45563. time. Sonya alone directed the practical side of matters by getting
45564. things packed. But of late Sonya had been particularly sad and silent.
45565. Nicholas' letter in which he mentioned Princess Mary had elicited, in
45566. her presence, joyous comments from the countess, who saw an intervention
45567. of Providence in this meeting of the princess and Nicholas.
45568. 
45569. "I was never pleased at Bolkonski's engagement to Natasha," said the
45570. countess, "but I always wanted Nicholas to marry the princess, and had a
45571. presentiment that it would happen. What a good thing it would be!"
45572. 
45573. Sonya felt that this was true: that the only possibility of retrieving
45574. the Rostovs' affairs was by Nicholas marrying a rich woman, and that the
45575. princess was a good match. It was very bitter for her. But despite
45576. her grief, or perhaps just because of it, she took on herself all the
45577. difficult work of directing the storing and packing of their things and
45578. was busy for whole days. The count and countess turned to her when they
45579. had any orders to give. Petya and Natasha on the contrary, far from
45580. helping their parents, were generally a nuisance and a hindrance to
45581. everyone. Almost all day long the house resounded with their running
45582. feet, their cries, and their spontaneous laughter. They laughed and were
45583. gay not because there was any reason to laugh, but because gaiety and
45584. mirth were in their hearts and so everything that happened was a cause
45585. for gaiety and laughter to them. Petya was in high spirits because
45586. having left home a boy he had returned (as everybody told him) a fine
45587. young man, because he was at home, because he had left Belaya Tserkov
45588. where there was no hope of soon taking part in a battle and had come to
45589. Moscow where there was to be fighting in a few days, and chiefly because
45590. Natasha, whose lead he always followed, was in high spirits. Natasha was
45591. gay because she had been sad too long and now nothing reminded her of
45592. the cause of her sadness, and because she was feeling well. She was also
45593. happy because she had someone to adore her: the adoration of others
45594. was a lubricant the wheels of her machine needed to make them run
45595. freely--and Petya adored her. Above all, they were gay because there was
45596. a war near Moscow, there would be fighting at the town gates, arms were
45597. being given out, everybody was escaping--going away somewhere, and
45598. in general something extraordinary was happening, and that is always
45599. exciting, especially to the young.
45600. 
45601. 
45602. 
45603. 
45604. 
45605. CHAPTER XIII
45606. 
45607. 
45608. On Saturday, the thirty-first of August, everything in the Rostovs'
45609. house seemed topsy-turvy. All the doors were open, all the furniture was
45610. being carried out or moved about, and the mirrors and pictures had been
45611. taken down. There were trunks in the rooms, and hay, wrapping paper, and
45612. ropes were scattered about. The peasants and house serfs carrying out
45613. the things were treading heavily on the parquet floors. The yard was
45614. crowded with peasant carts, some loaded high and already corded up,
45615. others still empty.
45616. 
45617. The voices and footsteps of the many servants and of the peasants who
45618. had come with the carts resounded as they shouted to one another in
45619. the yard and in the house. The count had been out since morning. The
45620. countess had a headache brought on by all the noise and turmoil and was
45621. lying down in the new sitting room with a vinegar compress on her head.
45622. Petya was not at home, he had gone to visit a friend with whom he meant
45623. to obtain a transfer from the militia to the active army. Sonya was in
45624. the ballroom looking after the packing of the glass and china. Natasha
45625. was sitting on the floor of her dismantled room with dresses, ribbons,
45626. and scarves strewn all about her, gazing fixedly at the floor and
45627. holding in her hands the old ball dress (already out of fashion) which
45628. she had worn at her first Petersburg ball.
45629. 
45630. Natasha was ashamed of doing nothing when everyone else was so busy, and
45631. several times that morning had tried to set to work, but her heart was
45632. not in it, and she could not and did not know how to do anything except
45633. with all her heart and all her might. For a while she had stood beside
45634. Sonya while the china was being packed and tried to help, but soon gave
45635. it up and went to her room to pack her own things. At first she found it
45636. amusing to give away dresses and ribbons to the maids, but when that was
45637. done and what was left had still to be packed, she found it dull.
45638. 
45639. "Dunyasha, you pack! You will, won't you, dear?" And when Dunyasha
45640. willingly promised to do it all for her, Natasha sat down on the floor,
45641. took her old ball dress, and fell into a reverie quite unrelated to what
45642. ought to have occupied her thoughts now. She was roused from her reverie
45643. by the talk of the maids in the next room (which was theirs) and by the
45644. sound of their hurried footsteps going to the back porch. Natasha got
45645. up and looked out of the window. An enormously long row of carts full of
45646. wounded men had stopped in the street.
45647. 
45648. The housekeeper, the old nurse, the cooks, coachmen, maids, footmen,
45649. postilions, and scullions stood at the gate, staring at the wounded.
45650. 
45651. Natasha, throwing a clean pocket handkerchief over her hair and holding
45652. an end of it in each hand, went out into the street.
45653. 
45654. The former housekeeper, old Mavra Kuzminichna, had stepped out of the
