45655. crowd by the gate, gone up to a cart with a hood constructed of bast
45656. mats, and was speaking to a pale young officer who lay inside.
45657. Natasha moved a few steps forward and stopped shyly, still holding her
45658. handkerchief, and listened to what the housekeeper was saying.
45659. 
45660. "Then you have nobody in Moscow?" she was saying. "You would be more
45661. comfortable somewhere in a house... in ours, for instance... the family
45662. are leaving."
45663. 
45664. "I don't know if it would be allowed," replied the officer in a weak
45665. voice. "Here is our commanding officer... ask him," and he pointed to a
45666. stout major who was walking back along the street past the row of carts.
45667. 
45668. Natasha glanced with frightened eyes at the face of the wounded officer
45669. and at once went to meet the major.
45670. 
45671. "May the wounded men stay in our house?" she asked.
45672. 
45673. The major raised his hand to his cap with a smile.
45674. 
45675. "Which one do you want, Ma'am'selle?" said he, screwing up his eyes and
45676. smiling.
45677. 
45678. Natasha quietly repeated her question, and her face and whole
45679. manner were so serious, though she was still holding the ends of
45680. her handkerchief, that the major ceased smiling and after some
45681. reflection--as if considering in how far the thing was possible--replied
45682. in the affirmative.
45683. 
45684. "Oh yes, why not? They may," he said.
45685. 
45686. With a slight inclination of her head, Natasha stepped back quickly to
45687. Mavra Kuzminichna, who stood talking compassionately to the officer.
45688. 
45689. "They may. He says they may!" whispered Natasha.
45690. 
45691. The cart in which the officer lay was turned into the Rostovs' yard,
45692. and dozens of carts with wounded men began at the invitation of the
45693. townsfolk to turn into the yards and to draw up at the entrances of the
45694. houses in Povarskaya Street. Natasha was evidently pleased to be dealing
45695. with new people outside the ordinary routine of her life. She and Mavra
45696. Kuzminichna tried to get as many of the wounded as possible into their
45697. yard.
45698. 
45699. "Your Papa must be told, though," said Mavra Kuzminichna.
45700. 
45701. "Never mind, never mind, what does it matter? For one day we can move
45702. into the drawing room. They can have all our half of the house."
45703. 
45704. "There now, young lady, you do take things into your head! Even if we
45705. put them into the wing, the men's room, or the nurse's room, we must ask
45706. permission."
45707. 
45708. "Well, I'll ask."
45709. 
45710. Natasha ran into the house and went on tiptoe through the half-open door
45711. into the sitting room, where there was a smell of vinegar and Hoffman's
45712. drops.
45713. 
45714. "Are you asleep, Mamma?"
45715. 
45716. "Oh, what sleep-?" said the countess, waking up just as she was dropping
45717. into a doze.
45718. 
45719. "Mamma darling!" said Natasha, kneeling by her mother and bringing her
45720. face close to her mother's, "I am sorry, forgive me, I'll never do it
45721. again; I woke you up! Mavra Kuzminichna has sent me: they have brought
45722. some wounded here--officers. Will you let them come? They have nowhere
45723. to go. I knew you'd let them come!" she said quickly all in one breath.
45724. 
45725. "What officers? Whom have they brought? I don't understand anything
45726. about it," said the countess.
45727. 
45728. Natasha laughed, and the countess too smiled slightly.
45729. 
45730. "I knew you'd give permission... so I'll tell them," and, having kissed
45731. her mother, Natasha got up and went to the door.
45732. 
45733. In the hall she met her father, who had returned with bad news.
45734. 
45735. "We've stayed too long!" said the count with involuntary vexation. "The
45736. Club is closed and the police are leaving."
45737. 
45738. "Papa, is it all right--I've invited some of the wounded into the
45739. house?" said Natasha.
45740. 
45741. "Of course it is," he answered absently. "That's not the point. I beg
45742. you not to indulge in trifles now, but to help to pack, and tomorrow we
45743. must go, go, go!...."
45744. 
45745. And the count gave a similar order to the major-domo and the servants.
45746. 
45747. At dinner Petya having returned home told them the news he had heard.
45748. He said the people had been getting arms in the Kremlin, and that though
45749. Rostopchin's broadsheet had said that he would sound a call two or three
45750. days in advance, the order had certainly already been given for everyone
45751. to go armed to the Three Hills tomorrow, and that there would be a big
45752. battle there.
45753. 
45754. The countess looked with timid horror at her son's eager, excited face
45755. as he said this. She realized that if she said a word about his not
45756. going to the battle (she knew he enjoyed the thought of the impending
45757. engagement) he would say something about men, honor, and the
45758. fatherland--something senseless, masculine, and obstinate which there
45759. would be no contradicting, and her plans would be spoiled; and so,
45760. hoping to arrange to leave before then and take Petya with her as their
45761. protector and defender, she did not answer him, but after dinner called
45762. the count aside and implored him with tears to take her away quickly,
45763. that very night if possible. With a woman's involuntary loving cunning
45764. she, who till then had not shown any alarm, said that she would die of
45765. fright if they did not leave that very night. Without any pretense she
45766. was now afraid of everything.
45767. 
45768. 
45769. 
45770. 
45771. 
45772. CHAPTER XIV
45773. 
45774. 
45775. Madame Schoss, who had been out to visit her daughter, increased the
45776. countess' fears still more by telling what she had seen at a spirit
45777. dealer's in Myasnitski Street. When returning by that street she had
45778. been unable to pass because of a drunken crowd rioting in front of
45779. the shop. She had taken a cab and driven home by a side street and the
45780. cabman had told her that the people were breaking open the barrels at
45781. the drink store, having received orders to do so.
45782. 
45783. After dinner the whole Rostov household set to work with enthusiastic
45784. haste packing their belongings and preparing for their departure. The
45785. old count, suddenly setting to work, kept passing from the yard to the
45786. house and back again, shouting confused instructions to the hurrying
45787. people, and flurrying them still more. Petya directed things in the
45788. yard. Sonya, owing to the count's contradictory orders, lost her head
45789. and did not know what to do. The servants ran noisily about the house
45790. and yard, shouting and disputing. Natasha, with the ardor characteristic
45791. of all she did suddenly set to work too. At first her intervention in
45792. the business of packing was received skeptically. Everybody expected
45793. some prank from her and did not wish to obey her; but she resolutely
45794. and passionately demanded obedience, grew angry and nearly cried because
45795. they did not heed her, and at last succeeded in making them believe her.
45796. Her first exploit, which cost her immense effort and established her
45797. authority, was the packing of the carpets. The count had valuable
45798. Gobelin tapestries and Persian carpets in the house. When Natasha set
45799. to work two cases were standing open in the ballroom, one almost full
45800. up with crockery, the other with carpets. There was also much china
45801. standing on the tables, and still more was being brought in from the
45802. storeroom. A third case was needed and servants had gone to fetch it.
45803. 
45804. "Sonya, wait a bit--we'll pack everything into these," said Natasha.
45805. 
45806. "You can't, Miss, we have tried to," said the butler's assistant.
45807. 
45808. "No, wait a minute, please."
45809. 
45810. And Natasha began rapidly taking out of the case dishes and plates
45811. wrapped in paper.
45812. 
45813. "The dishes must go in here among the carpets," said she.
45814. 
45815. "Why, it's a mercy if we can get the carpets alone into three cases,"
45816. said the butler's assistant.
45817. 
45818. "Oh, wait, please!" And Natasha began rapidly and deftly sorting out the
45819. things. "These aren't needed," said she, putting aside some plates of
45820. Kiev ware. "These--yes, these must go among the carpets," she said,
45821. referring to the Saxony china dishes.
45822. 
45823. "Don't, Natasha! Leave it alone! We'll get it all packed," urged Sonya
45824. reproachfully.
45825. 
45826. "What a young lady she is!" remarked the major-domo.
45827. 
45828. But Natasha would not give in. She turned everything out and began
45829. quickly repacking, deciding that the inferior Russian carpets and
45830. unnecessary crockery should not be taken at all. When everything had
45831. been taken out of the cases, they recommenced packing, and it turned
45832. out that when the cheaper things not worth taking had nearly all been
45833. rejected, the valuable ones really did all go into the two cases. Only
45834. the lid of the case containing the carpets would not shut down. A few
45835. more things might have been taken out, but Natasha insisted on having
45836. her own way. She packed, repacked, pressed, made the butler's assistant
45837. and Petya--whom she had drawn into the business of packing--press on the
45838. lid, and made desperate efforts herself.
45839. 
45840. "That's enough, Natasha," said Sonya. "I see you were right, but just
45841. take out the top one."
45842. 
45843. "I won't!" cried Natasha, with one hand holding back the hair that hung
45844. over her perspiring face, while with the other she pressed down the
45845. carpets. "Now press, Petya! Press, Vasilich, press hard!" she cried.
45846. 
45847. The carpets yielded and the lid closed; Natasha, clapping her hands,
45848. screamed with delight and tears fell from her eyes. But this only
45849. lasted a moment. She at once set to work afresh and they now trusted her
45850. completely. The count was not angry even when they told him that Natasha
45851. had countermanded an order of his, and the servants now came to her
45852. to ask whether a cart was sufficiently loaded, and whether it might
45853. be corded up. Thanks to Natasha's directions the work now went on
45854. expeditiously, unnecessary things were left, and the most valuable
45855. packed as compactly as possible.
45856. 
45857. But hard as they all worked till quite late that night, they could not
45858. get everything packed. The countess had fallen asleep and the count,
45859. having put off their departure till next morning, went to bed.
45860. 
45861. Sonya and Natasha slept in the sitting room without undressing.
45862. 
45863. That night another wounded man was driven down the Povarskaya, and Mavra
45864. Kuzminichna, who was standing at the gate, had him brought into the
45865. Rostovs' yard. Mavra Kuzminichna concluded that he was a very important
45866. man. He was being conveyed in a caleche with a raised hood, and was
45867. quite covered by an apron. On the box beside the driver sat a venerable
45868. old attendant. A doctor and two soldiers followed the carriage in a
45869. cart.
45870. 
45871. "Please come in here. The masters are going away and the whole house
45872. will be empty," said the old woman to the old attendant.
45873. 
45874. "Well, perhaps," said he with a sigh. "We don't expect to get him home
45875. alive! We have a house of our own in Moscow, but it's a long way from
45876. here, and there's nobody living in it."
45877. 
45878. "Do us the honor to come in, there's plenty of everything in the
45879. master's house. Come in," said Mavra Kuzminichna. "Is he very ill?" she
45880. asked.
45881. 
45882. The attendant made a hopeless gesture.
45883. 
45884. "We don't expect to get him home! We must ask the doctor."
45885. 
45886. And the old servant got down from the box and went up to the cart.
45887. 
45888. "All right!" said the doctor.
45889. 
45890. The old servant returned to the caleche, looked into it, shook his
45891. head disconsolately, told the driver to turn into the yard, and stopped
45892. beside Mavra Kuzminichna.
45893. 
45894. "O, Lord Jesus Christ!" she murmured.
45895. 
45896. She invited them to take the wounded man into the house.
45897. 
45898. "The masters won't object..." she said.
45899. 
45900. But they had to avoid carrying the man upstairs, and so they took him
45901. into the wing and put him in the room that had been Madame Schoss'.
45902. 
45903. This wounded man was Prince Andrew Bolkonski.
45904. 
45905. 
45906. 
45907. 
45908. 
45909. CHAPTER XV
45910. 
45911. 
45912. Moscow's last day had come. It was a clear bright autumn day, a Sunday.
45913. The church bells everywhere were ringing for service, just as usual on
45914. Sundays. Nobody seemed yet to realize what awaited the city.
45915. 
45916. Only two things indicated the social condition of Moscow--the rabble,
45917. that is the poor people, and the price of commodities. An enormous crowd
45918. of factory hands, house serfs, and peasants, with whom some officials,
45919. seminarists, and gentry were mingled, had gone early that morning to
45920. the Three Hills. Having waited there for Rostopchin who did not turn
45921. up, they became convinced that Moscow would be surrendered, and then
45922. dispersed all about the town to the public houses and cookshops. Prices
45923. too that day indicated the state of affairs. The price of weapons, of
45924. gold, of carts and horses, kept rising, but the value of paper money and
45925. city articles kept falling, so that by midday there were instances of
45926. carters removing valuable goods, such as cloth, and receiving in payment
45927. a half of what they carted, while peasant horses were fetching five
45928. hundred rubles each, and furniture, mirrors, and bronzes were being
45929. given away for nothing.
45930. 
45931. In the Rostovs' staid old-fashioned house the dissolution of former
45932. conditions of life was but little noticeable. As to the serfs the only
45933. indication was that three out of their huge retinue disappeared
45934. during the night, but nothing was stolen; and as to the value of their
45935. possessions, the thirty peasant carts that had come in from their
45936. estates and which many people envied proved to be extremely valuable and
45937. they were offered enormous sums of money for them. Not only were huge
45938. sums offered for the horses and carts, but on the previous evening and
45939. early in the morning of the first of September, orderlies and servants
45940. sent by wounded officers came to the Rostovs' and wounded men dragged
45941. themselves there from the Rostovs' and from neighboring houses where
45942. they were accommodated, entreating the servants to try to get them
45943. a lift out of Moscow. The major-domo to whom these entreaties were
45944. addressed, though he was sorry for the wounded, resolutely refused,
45945. saying that he dare not even mention the matter to the count. Pity these
45946. wounded men as one might, it was evident that if they were given one
45947. cart there would be no reason to refuse another, or all the carts and
45948. one's own carriages as well. Thirty carts could not save all the wounded
45949. and in the general catastrophe one could not disregard oneself and one's
45950. own family. So thought the major-domo on his master's behalf.
45951. 
45952. On waking up that morning Count Ilya Rostov left his bedroom softly, so
45953. as not to wake the countess who had fallen asleep only toward morning,
45954. and came out to the porch in his lilac silk dressing gown. In the yard
45955. stood the carts ready corded. The carriages were at the front porch.
45956. The major-domo stood at the porch talking to an elderly orderly and to
45957. a pale young officer with a bandaged arm. On seeing the count the
45958. major-domo made a significant and stern gesture to them both to go away.
45959. 
45960. "Well, Vasilich, is everything ready?" asked the count, and stroking his
45961. bald head he looked good-naturedly at the officer and the orderly and
45962. nodded to them. (He liked to see new faces.)
45963. 
45964. "We can harness at once, your excellency."
45965. 
45966. "Well, that's right. As soon as the countess wakes we'll be off, God
45967. willing! What is it, gentlemen?" he added, turning to the officer. "Are
45968. you staying in my house?"
45969. 
45970. The officer came nearer and suddenly his face flushed crimson.
45971. 
45972. "Count, be so good as to allow me... for God's sake, to get into some
45973. corner of one of your carts! I have nothing here with me.... I shall be
45974. all right on a loaded cart..."
45975. 
45976. Before the officer had finished speaking the orderly made the same
45977. request on behalf of his master.
45978. 
45979. "Oh, yes, yes, yes!" said the count hastily. "I shall be very pleased,
45980. very pleased. Vasilich, you'll see to it. Just unload one or two carts.
45981. Well, what of it... do what's necessary..." said the count, muttering
45982. some indefinite order.
45983. 
45984. But at the same moment an expression of warm gratitude on the officer's
45985. face had already sealed the order. The count looked around him. In the
45986. yard, at the gates, at the window of the wings, wounded officers and
45987. their orderlies were to be seen. They were all looking at the count and
45988. moving toward the porch.
45989. 
45990. "Please step into the gallery, your excellency," said the major-domo.
45991. "What are your orders about the pictures?"
45992. 
45993. The count went into the house with him, repeating his order not to
45994. refuse the wounded who asked for a lift.
45995. 
45996. "Well, never mind, some of the things can be unloaded," he added in a
45997. soft, confidential voice, as though afraid of being overheard.
45998. 
45999. At nine o'clock the countess woke up, and Matrena Timofeevna, who had
46000. been her lady's maid before her marriage and now performed a sort of
46001. chief gendarme's duty for her, came to say that Madame Schoss was much
46002. offended and the young ladies' summer dresses could not be left behind.
46003. On inquiry, the countess learned that Madame Schoss was offended because
46004. her trunk had been taken down from its cart, and all the loads were
46005. being uncorded and the luggage taken out of the carts to make room for
46006. wounded men whom the count in the simplicity of his heart had ordered
46007. that they should take with them. The countess sent for her husband.
46008. 
46009. "What is this, my dear? I hear that the luggage is being unloaded."
46010. 
46011. "You know, love, I wanted to tell you... Countess dear... an officer
46012. came to me to ask for a few carts for the wounded. After all, ours are
46013. things that can be bought but think what being left behind means to
46014. them!... Really now, in our own yard--we asked them in ourselves and
46015. there are officers among them.... You know, I think, my dear... let them
46016. be taken... where's the hurry?"
46017. 
46018. The count spoke timidly, as he always did when talking of money matters.
46019. The countess was accustomed to this tone as a precursor of news of
46020. something detrimental to the children's interests, such as the building
46021. of a new gallery or conservatory, the inauguration of a private theater
46022. or an orchestra. She was accustomed always to oppose anything announced
46023. in that timid tone and considered it her duty to do so.
46024. 
46025. She assumed her dolefully submissive manner and said to her husband:
46026. "Listen to me, Count, you have managed matters so that we are getting
46027. nothing for the house, and now you wish to throw away all our--all the
46028. children's property! You said yourself that we have a hundred thousand
46029. rubles' worth of things in the house. I don't consent, my dear, I don't!
46030. Do as you please! It's the government's business to look after the
46031. wounded; they know that. Look at the Lopukhins opposite, they cleared
46032. out everything two days ago. That's what other people do. It's only
46033. we who are such fools. If you have no pity on me, have some for the
46034. children."
46035. 
46036. Flourishing his arms in despair the count left the room without
46037. replying.
46038. 
46039. "Papa, what are you doing that for?" asked Natasha, who had followed him
46040. into her mother's room.
46041. 
46042. "Nothing! What business is it of yours?" muttered the count angrily.
46043. 
46044. "But I heard," said Natasha. "Why does Mamma object?"
46045. 
46046. "What business is it of yours?" cried the count.
46047. 
46048. Natasha stepped up to the window and pondered.
46049. 
46050. "Papa! Here's Berg coming to see us," said she, looking out of the
46051. window.
46052. 
46053. 
46054. 
46055. 
46056. 
46057. CHAPTER XVI
46058. 
46059. 
46060. Berg, the Rostovs' son-in-law, was already a colonel wearing the orders
46061. of Vladimir and Anna, and he still filled the quiet and agreeable post
46062. of assistant to the head of the staff of the assistant commander of the
46063. first division of the Second Army.
46064. 
46065. On the first of September he had come to Moscow from the army.
46066. 
46067. He had nothing to do in Moscow, but he had noticed that everyone in the
46068. army was asking for leave to visit Moscow and had something to do there.
46069. So he considered it necessary to ask for leave of absence for family and
46070. domestic reasons.
46071. 
46072. Berg drove up to his father-in-law's house in his spruce little trap
46073. with a pair of sleek roans, exactly like those of a certain prince. He
46074. looked attentively at the carts in the yard and while going up to the
46075. porch took out a clean pocket handkerchief and tied a knot in it.
46076. 
46077. From the anteroom Berg ran with smooth though impatient steps into the
46078. drawing room, where he embraced the count, kissed the hands of Natasha
46079. and Sonya, and hastened to inquire after "Mamma's" health.
46080. 
46081. "Health, at a time like this?" said the count. "Come, tell us the news!
46082. Is the army retreating or will there be another battle?"
46083. 
46084. "God Almighty alone can decide the fate of our fatherland, Papa," said
46085. Berg. "The army is burning with a spirit of heroism and the leaders, so
46086. to say, have now assembled in council. No one knows what is coming. But
46087. in general I can tell you, Papa, that such a heroic spirit, the truly
46088. antique valor of the Russian army, which they--which it" (he
46089. corrected himself) "has shown or displayed in the battle of the
46090. twenty-sixth--there are no words worthy to do it justice! I tell you,
46091. Papa" (he smote himself on the breast as a general he had heard speaking
46092. had done, but Berg did it a trifle late for he should have struck his
46093. breast at the words "Russian army"), "I tell you frankly that we, the
46094. commanders, far from having to urge the men on or anything of that kind,
46095. could hardly restrain those... those... yes, those exploits of antique
46096. valor," he went on rapidly. "General Barclay de Tolly risked his life
46097. everywhere at the head of the troops, I can assure you. Our corps was
46098. stationed on a hillside. You can imagine!"
46099. 
46100. And Berg related all that he remembered of the various tales he had
46101. heard those days. Natasha watched him with an intent gaze that confused
46102. him, as if she were trying to find in his face the answer to some
46103. question.
46104. 
46105. "Altogether such heroism as was displayed by the Russian warriors
46106. cannot be imagined or adequately praised!" said Berg, glancing round
46107. at Natasha, and as if anxious to conciliate her, replying to her intent
46108. look with a smile. "'Russia is not in Moscow, she lives in the hearts of
46109. her sons!' Isn't it so, Papa?" said he.
46110. 
46111. Just then the countess came in from the sitting room with a weary and
46112. dissatisfied expression. Berg hurriedly jumped up, kissed her hand,
46113. asked about her health, and, swaying his head from side to side to
46114. express sympathy, remained standing beside her.
46115. 
46116. "Yes, Mamma, I tell you sincerely that these are hard and sad times for
46117. every Russian. But why are you so anxious? You have still time to get
46118. away...."
46119. 
46120. "I can't think what the servants are about," said the countess, turning
46121. to her husband. "I have just been told that nothing is ready yet.
46122. Somebody after all must see to things. One misses Mitenka at such times.
46123. There won't be any end to it."
46124. 
46125. The count was about to say something, but evidently restrained himself.
46126. He got up from his chair and went to the door.
46127. 
46128. At that moment Berg drew out his handkerchief as if to blow his nose
46129. and, seeing the knot in it, pondered, shaking his head sadly and
46130. significantly.
46131. 
46132. "And I have a great favor to ask of you, Papa," said he.
46133. 
46134. "Hm..." said the count, and stopped.
46135. 
46136. "I was driving past Yusupov's house just now," said Berg with a laugh,
46137. "when the steward, a man I know, ran out and asked me whether I wouldn't
46138. buy something. I went in out of curiosity, you know, and there is a
46139. small chiffonier and a dressing table. You know how dear Vera wanted a
46140. chiffonier like that and how we had a dispute about it." (At the mention
46141. of the chiffonier and dressing table Berg involuntarily changed his tone
46142. to one of pleasure at his admirable domestic arrangements.) "And it's
46143. such a beauty! It pulls out and has a secret English drawer, you know!
46144. And dear Vera has long wanted one. I wish to give her a surprise, you
46145. see. I saw so many of those peasant carts in your yard. Please let me
46146. have one, I will pay the man well, and..."
46147. 
46148. The count frowned and coughed.
46149. 
46150. "Ask the countess, I don't give orders."
46151. 
46152. "If it's inconvenient, please don't," said Berg. "Only I so wanted it,
46153. for dear Vera's sake."
46154. 
46155. "Oh, go to the devil, all of you! To the devil, the devil, the devil..."
46156. cried the old count. "My head's in a whirl!"
46157. 
46158. And he left the room. The countess began to cry.
46159. 
46160. "Yes, Mamma! Yes, these are very hard times!" said Berg.
46161. 
46162. Natasha left the room with her father and, as if finding it difficult to
46163. reach some decision, first followed him and then ran downstairs.
46164. 
46165. Petya was in the porch, engaged in giving out weapons to the servants
46166. who were to leave Moscow. The loaded carts were still standing in the
46167. yard. Two of them had been uncorded and a wounded officer was climbing
46168. into one of them helped by an orderly.
46169. 
46170. "Do you know what it's about?" Petya asked Natasha.
46171. 
46172. She understood that he meant what were their parents quarreling about.
46173. She did not answer.
46174. 
46175. "It's because Papa wanted to give up all the carts to the wounded," said
46176. Petya. "Vasilich told me. I consider..."
46177. 
46178. "I consider," Natasha suddenly almost shouted, turning her angry face to
46179. Petya, "I consider it so horrid, so abominable, so... I don't know what.
46180. Are we despicable Germans?"
46181. 
46182. Her throat quivered with convulsive sobs and, afraid of weakening and
46183. letting the force of her anger run to waste, she turned and rushed
46184. headlong up the stairs.
46185. 
46186. Berg was sitting beside the countess consoling her with the respectful
46187. attention of a relative. The count, pipe in hand, was pacing up and down
46188. the room, when Natasha, her face distorted by anger, burst in like a
46189. tempest and approached her mother with rapid steps.
46190. 
46191. "It's horrid! It's abominable!" she screamed. "You can't possibly have
46192. ordered it!"
46193. 
46194. Berg and the countess looked at her, perplexed and frightened. The count
46195. stood still at the window and listened.
46196. 
46197. "Mamma, it's impossible: see what is going on in the yard!" she cried.
46198. "They will be left!..."
46199. 
46200. "What's the matter with you? Who are 'they'? What do you want?"
46201. 
46202. "Why, the wounded! It's impossible, Mamma. It's monstrous!... No, Mamma
46203. darling, it's not the thing. Please forgive me, darling.... Mamma, what
46204. does it matter what we take away? Only look what is going on in the
46205. yard... Mamma!... It's impossible!"
46206. 
46207. The count stood by the window and listened without turning round.
46208. Suddenly he sniffed and put his face closer to the window.
46209. 
46210. The countess glanced at her daughter, saw her face full of shame for her
46211. mother, saw her agitation, and understood why her husband did not turn
46212. to look at her now, and she glanced round quite disconcerted.
46213. 
46214. "Oh, do as you like! Am I hindering anyone?" she said, not surrendering
46215. at once.
46216. 
46217. "Mamma, darling, forgive me!"
46218. 
46219. But the countess pushed her daughter away and went up to her husband.
46220. 
46221. "My dear, you order what is right.... You know I don't understand about
46222. it," said she, dropping her eyes shamefacedly.
46223. 
46224. "The eggs... the eggs are teaching the hen," muttered the count through
46225. tears of joy, and he embraced his wife who was glad to hide her look of
46226. shame on his breast.
46227. 
46228. "Papa! Mamma! May I see to it? May I?..." asked Natasha. "We will still
46229. take all the most necessary things."
46230. 
46231. The count nodded affirmatively, and Natasha, at the rapid pace at which
46232. she used to run when playing at tag, ran through the ballroom to the
46233. anteroom and downstairs into the yard.
46234. 
46235. The servants gathered round Natasha, but could not believe the strange
46236. order she brought them until the count himself, in his wife's name,
46237. confirmed the order to give up all the carts to the wounded and take the
46238. trunks to the storerooms. When they understood that order the servants
46239. set to work at this new task with pleasure and zeal. It no longer seemed
46240. strange to them but on the contrary it seemed the only thing that could
46241. be done, just as a quarter of an hour before it had not seemed strange
46242. to anyone that the wounded should be left behind and the goods carted
46243. away but that had seemed the only thing to do.
46244. 
46245. The whole household, as if to atone for not having done it sooner, set
46246. eagerly to work at the new task of placing the wounded in the carts. The
46247. wounded dragged themselves out of their rooms and stood with pale but
46248. happy faces round the carts. The news that carts were to be had spread
46249. to the neighboring houses, from which wounded men began to come into the
46250. Rostovs' yard. Many of the wounded asked them not to unload the carts
46251. but only to let them sit on the top of the things. But the work of
46252. unloading, once started, could not be arrested. It seemed not to matter
46253. whether all or only half the things were left behind. Cases full of
46254. china, bronzes, pictures, and mirrors that had been so carefully
46255. packed the night before now lay about the yard, and still they went on
46256. searching for and finding possibilities of unloading this or that and
46257. letting the wounded have another and yet another cart.
46258. 
46259. "We can take four more men," said the steward. "They can have my trap,
46260. or else what is to become of them?"
46261. 
46262. "Let them have my wardrobe cart," said the countess. "Dunyasha can go
46263. with me in the carriage."
46264. 
46265. They unloaded the wardrobe cart and sent it to take wounded men from a
46266. house two doors off. The whole household, servants included, was bright
46267. and animated. Natasha was in a state of rapturous excitement such as she
46268. had not known for a long time.
46269. 
46270. "What could we fasten this onto?" asked the servants, trying to fix a
46271. trunk on the narrow footboard behind a carriage. "We must keep at least
46272. one cart."
46273. 
46274. "What's in it?" asked Natasha.
46275. 
46276. "The count's books."
46277. 
46278. "Leave it, Vasilich will put it away. It's not wanted."
46279. 
46280. The phaeton was full of people and there was a doubt as to where Count
46281. Peter could sit.
46282. 
46283. "On the box. You'll sit on the box, won't you, Petya?" cried Natasha.
46284. 
46285. Sonya too was busy all this time, but the aim of her efforts was quite
46286. different from Natasha's. She was putting away the things that had to
46287. be left behind and making a list of them as the countess wished, and she
46288. tried to get as much taken away with them as possible.
46289. 
46290. 
46291. 
46292. 
46293. 
46294. CHAPTER XVII
46295. 
46296. 
46297. Before two o'clock in the afternoon the Rostovs' four carriages, packed
46298. full and with the horses harnessed, stood at the front door. One by one
46299. the carts with the wounded had moved out of the yard.
46300. 
46301. The caleche in which Prince Andrew was being taken attracted Sonya's
46302. attention as it passed the front porch. With the help of a maid she was
46303. arranging a seat for the countess in the huge high coach that stood at
46304. the entrance.
46305. 
46306. "Whose caleche is that?" she inquired, leaning out of the carriage
46307. window.
46308. 
46309. "Why, didn't you know, Miss?" replied the maid. "The wounded prince: he
46310. spent the night in our house and is going with us."
46311. 
46312. "But who is it? What's his name?"
46313. 
46314. "It's our intended that was--Prince Bolkonski himself! They say he is
46315. dying," replied the maid with a sigh.
46316. 
46317. Sonya jumped out of the coach and ran to the countess. The countess,
46318. tired out and already dressed in shawl and bonnet for her journey,
46319. was pacing up and down the drawing room, waiting for the household to
46320. assemble for the usual silent prayer with closed doors before starting.
46321. Natasha was not in the room.
46322. 
46323. "Mamma," said Sonya, "Prince Andrew is here, mortally wounded. He is
46324. going with us."
46325. 
46326. The countess opened her eyes in dismay and, seizing Sonya's arm, glanced
46327. around.
46328. 
46329. "Natasha?" she murmured.
46330. 
46331. At that moment this news had only one significance for both of them.
46332. They knew their Natasha, and alarm as to what would happen if she heard
46333. this news stifled all sympathy for the man they both liked.
46334. 
46335. "Natasha does not know yet, but he is going with us," said Sonya.
46336. 
46337. "You say he is dying?"
46338. 
46339. Sonya nodded.
46340. 
46341. The countess put her arms around Sonya and began to cry.
46342. 
46343. "The ways of God are past finding out!" she thought, feeling that the
46344. Almighty Hand, hitherto unseen, was becoming manifest in all that was
46345. now taking place.
46346. 
46347. "Well, Mamma? Everything is ready. What's the matter?" asked Natasha, as
46348. with animated face she ran into the room.
46349. 
46350. "Nothing," answered the countess. "If everything is ready let us start."
46351. 
46352. And the countess bent over her reticule to hide her agitated face. Sonya
46353. embraced Natasha and kissed her.
46354. 
46355. Natasha looked at her inquiringly.
46356. 
46357. "What is it? What has happened?"
46358. 
46359. "Nothing... No..."
46360. 
46361. "Is it something very bad for me? What is it?" persisted Natasha with
46362. her quick intuition.
46363. 
46364. Sonya sighed and made no reply. The count, Petya, Madame Schoss, Mavra
46365. Kuzminichna, and Vasilich came into the drawing room and, having closed
46366. the doors, they all sat down and remained for some moments silently
46367. seated without looking at one another.
46368. 
46369. The count was the first to rise, and with a loud sigh crossed himself
46370. before the icon. All the others did the same. Then the count embraced
46371. Mavra Kuzminichna and Vasilich, who were to remain in Moscow, and while
46372. they caught at his hand and kissed his shoulder he patted their backs
46373. lightly with some vaguely affectionate and comforting words. The
46374. countess went into the oratory and there Sonya found her on her knees
46375. before the icons that had been left here and there hanging on the wall.
46376. (The most precious ones, with which some family tradition was connected,
46377. were being taken with them.)
46378. 
46379. In the porch and in the yard the men whom Petya had armed with swords
46380. and daggers, with trousers tucked inside their high boots and with belts
46381. and girdles tightened, were taking leave of those remaining behind.
46382. 
46383. As is always the case at a departure, much had been forgotten or put in
46384. the wrong place, and for a long time two menservants stood one on
46385. each side of the open door and the carriage steps waiting to help the
46386. countess in, while maids rushed with cushions and bundles from the house
46387. to the carriages, the caleche, the phaeton, and back again.
46388. 
46389. "They always will forget everything!" said the countess. "Don't you know
46390. I can't sit like that?"
46391. 
46392. And Dunyasha, with clenched teeth, without replying but with an
46393. aggrieved look on her face, hastily got into the coach to rearrange the
46394. seat.
46395. 
46396. "Oh, those servants!" said the count, swaying his head.
46397. 
46398. Efim, the old coachman, who was the only one the countess trusted to
46399. drive her, sat perched up high on the box and did not so much as glance
46400. round at what was going on behind him. From thirty years' experience
46401. he knew it would be some time yet before the order, "Be off, in God's
46402. name!" would be given him: and he knew that even when it was said
46403. he would be stopped once or twice more while they sent back to fetch
46404. something that had been forgotten, and even after that he would again
46405. be stopped and the countess herself would lean out of the window and beg
46406. him for the love of heaven to drive carefully down the hill. He knew
46407. all this and therefore waited calmly for what would happen, with more
46408. patience than the horses, especially the near one, the chestnut Falcon,
46409. who was pawing the ground and champing his bit. At last all were
46410. seated, the carriage steps were folded and pulled up, the door was shut,
46411. somebody was sent for a traveling case, and the countess leaned out
46412. and said what she had to say. Then Efim deliberately doffed his hat and
46413. began crossing himself. The postilion and all the other servants did the
46414. same. "Off, in God's name!" said Efim, putting on his hat. "Start!" The
46415. postilion started the horses, the off pole horse tugged at his collar,
46416. the high springs creaked, and the body of the coach swayed. The footman
46417. sprang onto the box of the moving coach which jolted as it passed out
46418. of the yard onto the uneven roadway; the other vehicles jolted in
46419. their turn, and the procession of carriages moved up the street. In the
46420. carriages, the caleche, and the phaeton, all crossed themselves as they
46421. passed the church opposite the house. Those who were to remain in Moscow
46422. walked on either side of the vehicles seeing the travelers off.
46423. 
46424. Rarely had Natasha experienced so joyful a feeling as now, sitting in
46425. the carriage beside the countess and gazing at the slowly receding
46426. walls of forsaken, agitated Moscow. Occasionally she leaned out of the
46427. carriage window and looked back and then forward at the long train of
46428. wounded in front of them. Almost at the head of the line she could see
46429. the raised hood of Prince Andrew's caleche. She did not know who was
46430. in it, but each time she looked at the procession her eyes sought that
46431. caleche. She knew it was right in front.
46432. 
46433. In Kudrino, from the Nikitski, Presnya, and Podnovinsk Streets came
46434. several other trains of vehicles similar to the Rostovs', and as they
46435. passed along the Sadovaya Street the carriages and carts formed two rows
46436. abreast.
46437. 
46438. As they were going round the Sukharev water tower Natasha, who was
46439. inquisitively and alertly scrutinizing the people driving or walking
46440. past, suddenly cried out in joyful surprise:
46441. 
46442. "Dear me! Mamma, Sonya, look, it's he!"
46443. 
46444. "Who? Who?"
46445. 
46446. "Look! Yes, on my word, it's Bezukhov!" said Natasha, putting her head
46447. out of the carriage and staring at a tall, stout man in a coachman's
46448. long coat, who from his manner of walking and moving was evidently
46449. a gentleman in disguise, and who was passing under the arch of the
46450. Sukharev tower accompanied by a small, sallow-faced, beardless old man
46451. in a frieze coat.
46452. 
46453. "Yes, it really is Bezukhov in a coachman's coat, with a queer-looking
46454. old boy. Really," said Natasha, "look, look!"
46455. 
46456. "No, it's not he. How can you talk such nonsense?"
46457. 
46458. "Mamma," screamed Natasha, "I'll stake my head it's he! I assure you!
46459. Stop, stop!" she cried to the coachman.
46460. 
46461. But the coachman could not stop, for from the Meshchanski Street came
46462. more carts and carriages, and the Rostovs were being shouted at to move
46463. on and not block the way.
46464. 
46465. In fact, however, though now much farther off than before, the Rostovs
46466. all saw Pierre--or someone extraordinarily like him--in a coachman's
46467. coat, going down the street with head bent and a serious face beside a
46468. small, beardless old man who looked like a footman. That old man
46469. noticed a face thrust out of the carriage window gazing at them, and
46470. respectfully touching Pierre's elbow said something to him and pointed
46471. to the carriage. Pierre, evidently engrossed in thought, could not at
46472. first understand him. At length when he had understood and looked in the
46473. direction the old man indicated, he recognized Natasha, and following
46474. his first impulse stepped instantly and rapidly toward the coach. But
46475. having taken a dozen steps he seemed to remember something and stopped.
46476. 
46477. Natasha's face, leaning out of the window, beamed with quizzical
46478. kindliness.
46479. 
46480. "Peter Kirilovich, come here! We have recognized you! This is
46481. wonderful!" she cried, holding out her hand to him. "What are you doing?
46482. Why are you like this?"
46483. 
46484. Pierre took her outstretched hand and kissed it awkwardly as he walked
46485. along beside her while the coach still moved on.
46486. 
46487. "What is the matter, Count?" asked the countess in a surprised and
46488. commiserating tone.
46489. 
46490. "What? What? Why? Don't ask me," said Pierre, and looked round at
46491. Natasha whose radiant, happy expression--of which he was conscious
46492. without looking at her--filled him with enchantment.
46493. 
46494. "Are you remaining in Moscow, then?"
46495. 
46496. Pierre hesitated.
46497. 
46498. "In Moscow?" he said in a questioning tone. "Yes, in Moscow. Good-by!"
46499. 
46500. "Ah, if only I were a man? I'd certainly stay with you. How splendid!"
46501. said Natasha. "Mamma, if you'll let me, I'll stay!"
46502. 
46503. Pierre glanced absently at Natasha and was about to say something, but
46504. the countess interrupted him.
46505. 
46506. "You were at the battle, we heard."
46507. 
46508. "Yes, I was," Pierre answered. "There will be another battle
46509. tomorrow..." he began, but Natasha interrupted him.
46510. 
46511. "But what is the matter with you, Count? You are not like yourself...."
46512. 
46513. "Oh, don't ask me, don't ask me! I don't know myself. Tomorrow... But
46514. no! Good-by, good-by!" he muttered. "It's an awful time!" and dropping
46515. behind the carriage he stepped onto the pavement.
46516. 
46517. Natasha continued to lean out of the window for a long time, beaming at
46518. him with her kindly, slightly quizzical, happy smile.
46519. 
46520. 
46521. 
46522. 
46523. 
46524. CHAPTER XVIII
46525. 
46526. 
46527. For the last two days, ever since leaving home, Pierre had been living
46528. in the empty house of his deceased benefactor, Bazdeev. This is how it
46529. happened.
46530. 
46531. When he woke up on the morning after his return to Moscow and his
46532. interview with Count Rostopchin, he could not for some time make out
46533. where he was and what was expected of him. When he was informed that
46534. among others awaiting him in his reception room there was a Frenchman
46535. who had brought a letter from his wife, the Countess Helene, he felt
46536. suddenly overcome by that sense of confusion and hopelessness to which
46537. he was apt to succumb. He felt that everything was now at an end, all
46538. was in confusion and crumbling to pieces, that nobody was right or
46539. wrong, the future held nothing, and there was no escape from this
46540. position. Smiling unnaturally and muttering to himself, he first sat
46541. down on the sofa in an attitude of despair, then rose, went to the door
46542. of the reception room and peeped through the crack, returned flourishing
46543. his arms, and took up a book. His major-domo came in a second time to
46544. say that the Frenchman who had brought the letter from the countess
46545. was very anxious to see him if only for a minute, and that someone from
46546. Bazdeev's widow had called to ask Pierre to take charge of her husband's
46547. books, as she herself was leaving for the country.
46548. 
46549. "Oh, yes, in a minute; wait... or no! No, of course... go and say I will
46550. come directly," Pierre replied to the major-domo.
46551. 
46552. But as soon as the man had left the room Pierre took up his hat which
46553. was lying on the table and went out of his study by the other door.
46554. There was no one in the passage. He went along the whole length of this
46555. passage to the stairs and, frowning and rubbing his forehead with
46556. both hands, went down as far as the first landing. The hall porter was
46557. standing at the front door. From the landing where Pierre stood there
46558. was a second staircase leading to the back entrance. He went down that
46559. staircase and out into the yard. No one had seen him. But there were
46560. some carriages waiting, and as soon as Pierre stepped out of the gate
46561. the coachmen and the yard porter noticed him and raised their caps to
46562. him. When he felt he was being looked at he behaved like an ostrich
46563. which hides its head in a bush in order not to be seen: he hung his head
46564. and quickening his pace went down the street.
46565. 
46566. Of all the affairs awaiting Pierre that day the sorting of Joseph
46567. Bazdeev's books and papers appeared to him the most necessary.
46568. 
46569. He hired the first cab he met and told the driver to go to the
46570. Patriarch's Ponds, where the widow Bazdeev's house was.
46571. 
46572. Continually turning round to look at the rows of loaded carts that were
46573. making their way from all sides out of Moscow, and balancing his bulky
46574. body so as not to slip out of the ramshackle old vehicle, Pierre,
46575. experiencing the joyful feeling of a boy escaping from school, began to
46576. talk to his driver.
46577. 
46578. The man told him that arms were being distributed today at the Kremlin
46579. and that tomorrow everyone would be sent out beyond the Three Hills
46580. gates and a great battle would be fought there.
46581. 
46582. Having reached the Patriarch's Ponds Pierre found the Bazdeevs' house,
46583. where he had not been for a long time past. He went up to the gate.
46584. Gerasim, that sallow beardless old man Pierre had seen at Torzhok five
46585. years before with Joseph Bazdeev, came out in answer to his knock.
46586. 
46587. "At home?" asked Pierre.
46588. 
46589. "Owing to the present state of things Sophia Danilovna has gone to the
46590. Torzhok estate with the children, your excellency."
46591. 
46592. "I will come in all the same, I have to look through the books," said
46593. Pierre.
46594. 
46595. "Be so good as to step in. Makar Alexeevich, the brother of my late
46596. master--may the kingdom of heaven be his--has remained here, but he is
46597. in a weak state as you know," said the old servant.
46598. 
46599. Pierre knew that Makar Alexeevich was Joseph Bazdeev's half-insane
46600. brother and a hard drinker.
46601. 
46602. "Yes, yes, I know. Let us go in..." said Pierre and entered the house.
46603. 
46604. A tall, bald-headed old man with a red nose, wearing a dressing gown and
46605. with galoshes on his bare feet, stood in the anteroom. On seeing Pierre
46606. he muttered something angrily and went away along the passage.
46607. 
46608. "He was a very clever man but has now grown quite feeble, as your honor
46609. sees," said Gerasim. "Will you step into the study?" Pierre nodded. "As
46610. it was sealed up so it has remained, but Sophia Danilovna gave orders
46611. that if anyone should come from you they were to have the books."
46612. 
46613. Pierre went into that gloomy study which he had entered with such
46614. trepidation in his benefactor's lifetime. The room, dusty and untouched
46615. since the death of Joseph Bazdeev was now even gloomier.
46616. 
46617. Gerasim opened one of the shutters and left the room on tiptoe. Pierre
46618. went round the study, approached the cupboard in which the manuscripts
46619. were kept, and took out what had once been one of the most important,
46620. the holy of holies of the order. This was the authentic Scotch Acts
46621. with Bazdeev's notes and explanations. He sat down at the dusty writing
46622. table, and, having laid the manuscripts before him, opened them out,
46623. closed them, finally pushed them away, and resting his head on his hand
46624. sank into meditation.
46625. 
46626. Gerasim looked cautiously into the study several times and saw Pierre
46627. always sitting in the same attitude.
46628. 
46629. More than two hours passed and Gerasim took the liberty of making a
46630. slight noise at the door to attract his attention, but Pierre did not
46631. hear him.
46632. 
46633. "Is the cabman to be discharged, your honor?"
46634. 
46635. "Oh yes!" said Pierre, rousing himself and rising hurriedly. "Look
46636. here," he added, taking Gerasim by a button of his coat and looking down
46637. at the old man with moist, shining, and ecstatic eyes, "I say, do you
46638. know that there is going to be a battle tomorrow?"
46639. 
46640. "We heard so," replied the man.
46641. 
46642. "I beg you not to tell anyone who I am, and to do what I ask you."
46643. 
46644. "Yes, your excellency," replied Gerasim. "Will you have something to
46645. eat?"
46646. 
46647. "No, but I want something else. I want peasant clothes and a pistol,"
46648. said Pierre, unexpectedly blushing.
46649. 
46650. "Yes, your excellency," said Gerasim after thinking for a moment.
46651. 
46652. All the rest of that day Pierre spent alone in his benefactor's study,
46653. and Gerasim heard him pacing restlessly from one corner to another and
46654. talking to himself. And he spent the night on a bed made up for him
46655. there.
46656. 
46657. Gerasim, being a servant who in his time had seen many strange things,
46658. accepted Pierre's taking up his residence in the house without
46659. surprise, and seemed pleased to have someone to wait on. That same
46660. evening--without even asking himself what they were wanted for--he
46661. procured a coachman's coat and cap for Pierre, and promised to get him
46662. the pistol next day. Makar Alexeevich came twice that evening shuffling
46663. along in his galoshes as far as the door and stopped and looked
46664. ingratiatingly at Pierre. But as soon as Pierre turned toward him he
46665. wrapped his dressing gown around him with a shamefaced and angry look
46666. and hurried away. It was when Pierre (wearing the coachman's coat which
46667. Gerasim had procured for him and had disinfected by steam) was on his
46668. way with the old man to buy the pistol at the Sukharev market that he
46669. met the Rostovs.
46670. 
46671. 
46672. 
46673. 
46674. 
46675. CHAPTER XIX
46676. 
46677. 
46678. Kutuzov's order to retreat through Moscow to the Ryazan road was issued
46679. at night on the first of September.
46680. 
46681. The first troops started at once, and during the night they marched
46682. slowly and steadily without hurry. At daybreak, however, those nearing
46683. the town at the Dorogomilov bridge saw ahead of them masses of soldiers
46684. crowding and hurrying across the bridge, ascending on the opposite side
46685. and blocking the streets and alleys, while endless masses of troops were
46686. bearing down on them from behind, and an unreasoning hurry and alarm
46687. overcame them. They all rushed forward to the bridge, onto it, and
46688. to the fords and the boats. Kutuzov himself had driven round by side
46689. streets to the other side of Moscow.
46690. 
46691. By ten o'clock in the morning of the second of September, only the rear
46692. guard remained in the Dorogomilov suburb, where they had ample room. The
46693. main army was on the other side of Moscow or beyond it.
46694. 
46695. At that very time, at ten in the morning of the second of September,
46696. Napoleon was standing among his troops on the Poklonny Hill looking at
46697. the panorama spread out before him. From the twenty-sixth of August
46698. to the second of September, that is from the battle of Borodino to the
46699. entry of the French into Moscow, during the whole of that agitating,
46700. memorable week, there had been the extraordinary autumn weather that
46701. always comes as a surprise, when the sun hangs low and gives more heat
46702. than in spring, when everything shines so brightly in the rare clear
46703. atmosphere that the eyes smart, when the lungs are strengthened and
46704. refreshed by inhaling the aromatic autumn air, when even the nights
46705. are warm, and when in those dark warm nights, golden stars startle and
46706. delight us continually by falling from the sky.
46707. 
46708. At ten in the morning of the second of September this weather still
46709. held.
46710. 
46711. The brightness of the morning was magical. Moscow seen from the Poklonny
46712. Hill lay spaciously spread out with her river, her gardens, and her
46713. churches, and she seemed to be living her usual life, her cupolas
46714. glittering like stars in the sunlight.
46715. 
46716. The view of the strange city with its peculiar architecture, such as
46717. he had never seen before, filled Napoleon with the rather envious and
46718. uneasy curiosity men feel when they see an alien form of life that has
46719. no knowledge of them. This city was evidently living with the full force
46720. of its own life. By the indefinite signs which, even at a distance,
46721. distinguish a living body from a dead one, Napoleon from the Poklonny
46722. Hill perceived the throb of life in the town and felt, as it were, the
46723. breathing of that great and beautiful body.
46724. 
46725. Every Russian looking at Moscow feels her to be a mother; every
46726. foreigner who sees her, even if ignorant of her significance as the
46727. mother city, must feel her feminine character, and Napoleon felt it.
46728. 
46729. "Cette ville asiatique aux innombrables eglises, Moscou la sainte. La
46730. voila done enfin, cette fameuse ville! Il etait temps," * said he, and
46731. dismounting he ordered a plan of Moscow to be spread out before him, and
46732. summoned Lelorgne d'Ideville, the interpreter.
46733. 
46734. 
46735.      * "That Asiatic city of the innumerable churches, holy
46736.      Moscow! Here it is then at last, that famous city. It was
46737.      high time."
46738. 
46739. 
46740. "A town captured by the enemy is like a maid who has lost her honor,"
46741. thought he (he had said so to Tuchkov at Smolensk). From that point of
46742. view he gazed at the Oriental beauty he had not seen before. It seemed
46743. strange to him that his long-felt wish, which had seemed unattainable,
46744. had at last been realized. In the clear morning light he gazed now at
46745. the city and now at the plan, considering its details, and the assurance
46746. of possessing it agitated and awed him.
46747. 
46748. "But could it be otherwise?" he thought. "Here is this capital at my
46749. feet. Where is Alexander now, and of what is he thinking? A strange,
46750. beautiful, and majestic city; and a strange and majestic moment! In what
46751. light must I appear to them!" thought he, thinking of his troops.
46752. "Here she is, the reward for all those fainthearted men," he reflected,
46753. glancing at those near him and at the troops who were approaching and
46754. forming up. "One word from me, one movement of my hand, and that ancient
46755. capital of the Tsars would perish. But my clemency is always ready to
46756. descend upon the vanquished. I must be magnanimous and truly great. But
46757. no, it can't be true that I am in Moscow," he suddenly thought.
46758. "Yet here she is lying at my feet, with her golden domes and crosses
46759. scintillating and twinkling in the sunshine. But I shall spare her. On
46760. the ancient monuments of barbarism and despotism I will inscribe great
46761. words of justice and mercy.... It is just this which Alexander will
46762. feel most painfully, I know him." (It seemed to Napoleon that the chief
46763. import of what was taking place lay in the personal struggle between
46764. himself and Alexander.) "From the height of the Kremlin--yes, there
46765. is the Kremlin, yes--I will give them just laws; I will teach them the
46766. meaning of true civilization, I will make generations of boyars remember
46767. their conqueror with love. I will tell the deputation that I did not,
46768. and do not, desire war, that I have waged war only against the false
46769. policy of their court; that I love and respect Alexander and that in
46770. Moscow I will accept terms of peace worthy of myself and of my people.
46771. I do not wish to utilize the fortunes of war to humiliate an honored
46772. monarch. 'Boyars,' I will say to them, 'I do not desire war, I desire
46773. the peace and welfare of all my subjects.' However, I know their
46774. presence will inspire me, and I shall speak to them as I always do:
46775. clearly, impressively, and majestically. But can it be true that I am in
46776. Moscow? Yes, there she lies."
46777. 
46778. "Qu'on m'amene les boyars," * said he to his suite.
46779. 
46780. 
46781.     * "Bring the boyars to me."
46782. 
46783. 
46784. A general with a brilliant suite galloped off at once to fetch the
46785. boyars.
46786. 
46787. Two hours passed. Napoleon had lunched and was again standing in the
46788. same place on the Poklonny Hill awaiting the deputation. His speech to
46789. the boyars had already taken definite shape in his imagination. That
46790. speech was full of dignity and greatness as Napoleon understood it.
46791. 
46792. He was himself carried away by the tone of magnanimity he intended to
46793. adopt toward Moscow. In his imagination he appointed days for assemblies
46794. at the palace of the Tsars, at which Russian notables and his own would
46795. mingle. He mentally appointed a governor, one who would win the
46796. hearts of the people. Having learned that there were many charitable
46797. institutions in Moscow he mentally decided that he would shower favors
46798. on them all. He thought that, as in Africa he had to put on a burnoose
46799. and sit in a mosque, so in Moscow he must be beneficent like the Tsars.
46800. And in order finally to touch the hearts of the Russians--and being like
46801. all Frenchmen unable to imagine anything sentimental without a reference
46802. to ma chere, ma tendre, ma pauvre mere * --he decided that he would
46803. place an inscription on all these establishments in large letters:
46804. "This establishment is dedicated to my dear mother." Or no, it should
46805. be simply: Maison de ma Mere, *(2) he concluded. "But am I really in
46806. Moscow? Yes, here it lies before me, but why is the deputation from the
46807. city so long in appearing?" he wondered.
46808. 
46809. 
46810.      * "My dear, my tender, my poor mother."
46811. 
46812.      * (2) "House of my Mother."
46813. 
46814. 
46815. Meanwhile an agitated consultation was being carried on in whispers
46816. among his generals and marshals at the rear of his suite. Those sent to
46817. fetch the deputation had returned with the news that Moscow was empty,
46818. that everyone had left it. The faces of those who were not conferring
46819. together were pale and perturbed. They were not alarmed by the fact
46820. that Moscow had been abandoned by its inhabitants (grave as that fact
46821. seemed), but by the question how to tell the Emperor--without putting
46822. him in the terrible position of appearing ridiculous--that he had been
46823. awaiting the boyars so long in vain: that there were drunken mobs left
46824. in Moscow but no one else. Some said that a deputation of some sort must
46825. be scraped together, others disputed that opinion and maintained that
46826. the Emperor should first be carefully and skillfully prepared, and then
46827. told the truth.
46828. 
46829. "He will have to be told, all the same," said some gentlemen of the
46830. suite. "But, gentlemen..."
46831. 
46832. The position was the more awkward because the Emperor, meditating upon
46833. his magnanimous plans, was pacing patiently up and down before the
46834. outspread map, occasionally glancing along the road to Moscow from under
46835. his lifted hand with a bright and proud smile.
46836. 
46837. "But it's impossible..." declared the gentlemen of the suite, shrugging
46838. their shoulders but not venturing to utter the implied word--le
46839. ridicule...
46840. 
46841. At last the Emperor, tired of futile expectation, his actor's instinct
46842. suggesting to him that the sublime moment having been too long drawn out
46843. was beginning to lose its sublimity, gave a sign with his hand. A single
46844. report of a signaling gun followed, and the troops, who were already
46845. spread out on different sides of Moscow, moved into the city through
46846. Tver, Kaluga, and Dorogomilov gates. Faster and faster, vying with
46847. one another, they moved at the double or at a trot, vanishing amid the
46848. clouds of dust they raised and making the air ring with a deafening roar
46849. of mingling shouts.
46850. 
46851. Drawn on by the movement of his troops Napoleon rode with them as far as
46852. the Dorogomilov gate, but there again stopped and, dismounting from his
46853. horse, paced for a long time by the Kammer-Kollezski rampart, awaiting
46854. the deputation.
46855. 
46856. 
46857. 
46858. 
46859. 
46860. CHAPTER XX
46861. 
46862. 
46863. Meanwhile Moscow was empty. There were still people in it, perhaps a
46864. fiftieth part of its former inhabitants had remained, but it was empty.
46865. It was empty in the sense that a dying queenless hive is empty.
46866. 
46867. In a queenless hive no life is left though to a superficial glance it
46868. seems as much alive as other hives.
46869. 
46870. The bees circle round a queenless hive in the hot beams of the midday
46871. sun as gaily as around the living hives; from a distance it smells of
46872. honey like the others, and bees fly in and out in the same way. But one
46873. has only to observe that hive to realize that there is no longer any
46874. life in it. The bees do not fly in the same way, the smell and the sound
46875. that meet the beekeeper are not the same. To the beekeeper's tap on the
46876. wall of the sick hive, instead of the former instant unanimous
46877. humming of tens of thousands of bees with their abdomens threateningly
46878. compressed, and producing by the rapid vibration of their wings an
46879. aerial living sound, the only reply is a disconnected buzzing from
46880. different parts of the deserted hive. From the alighting board, instead
46881. of the former spirituous fragrant smell of honey and venom, and the warm
46882. whiffs of crowded life, comes an odor of emptiness and decay mingling
46883. with the smell of honey. There are no longer sentinels sounding the
46884. alarm with their abdomens raised, and ready to die in defense of the
46885. hive. There is no longer the measured quiet sound of throbbing activity,
46886. like the sound of boiling water, but diverse discordant sounds of
46887. disorder. In and out of the hive long black robber bees smeared with
46888. honey fly timidly and shiftily. They do not sting, but crawl away from
46889. danger. Formerly only bees laden with honey flew into the hive, and they
46890. flew out empty; now they fly out laden. The beekeeper opens the lower
46891. part of the hive and peers in. Instead of black, glossy bees--tamed by
46892. toil, clinging to one another's legs and drawing out the wax, with a
46893. ceaseless hum of labor--that used to hang in long clusters down to
46894. the floor of the hive, drowsy shriveled bees crawl about separately
46895. in various directions on the floor and walls of the hive. Instead of a
46896. neatly glued floor, swept by the bees with the fanning of their wings,
46897. there is a floor littered with bits of wax, excrement, dying bees
46898. scarcely moving their legs, and dead ones that have not been cleared
46899. away.
46900. 
46901. The beekeeper opens the upper part of the hive and examines the super.
46902. Instead of serried rows of bees sealing up every gap in the combs and
46903. keeping the brood warm, he sees the skillful complex structures of the
46904. combs, but no longer in their former state of purity. All is neglected
46905. and foul. Black robber bees are swiftly and stealthily prowling about
46906. the combs, and the short home bees, shriveled and listless as if they
46907. were old, creep slowly about without trying to hinder the robbers,
46908. having lost all motive and all sense of life. Drones, bumblebees, wasps,
46909. and butterflies knock awkwardly against the walls of the hive in their
46910. flight. Here and there among the cells containing dead brood and honey
46911. an angry buzzing can sometimes be heard. Here and there a couple of
46912. bees, by force of habit and custom cleaning out the brood cells, with
46913. efforts beyond their strength laboriously drag away a dead bee or
46914. bumblebee without knowing why they do it. In another corner two old bees
46915. are languidly fighting, or cleaning themselves, or feeding one another,
46916. without themselves knowing whether they do it with friendly or hostile
46917. intent. In a third place a crowd of bees, crushing one another, attack
46918. some victim and fight and smother it, and the victim, enfeebled or
46919. killed, drops from above slowly and lightly as a feather, among the heap
46920. of corpses. The keeper opens the two center partitions to examine
46921. the brood cells. In place of the former close dark circles formed by
46922. thousands of bees sitting back to back and guarding the high mystery
46923. of generation, he sees hundreds of dull, listless, and sleepy shells of
46924. bees. They have almost all died unawares, sitting in the sanctuary they
46925. had guarded and which is now no more. They reek of decay and death. Only
46926. a few of them still move, rise, and feebly fly to settle on the enemy's
46927. hand, lacking the spirit to die stinging him; the rest are dead and fall
46928. as lightly as fish scales. The beekeeper closes the hive, chalks a mark
46929. on it, and when he has time tears out its contents and burns it clean.
46930. 
46931. So in the same way Moscow was empty when Napoleon, weary, uneasy, and
46932. morose, paced up and down in front of the Kammer-Kollezski rampart,
46933. awaiting what to his mind was a necessary, if but formal, observance of
46934. the proprieties--a deputation.
46935. 
46936. In various corners of Moscow there still remained a few people aimlessly
46937. moving about, following their old habits and hardly aware of what they
46938. were doing.
46939. 
46940. When with due circumspection Napoleon was informed that Moscow was
46941. empty, he looked angrily at his informant, turned away, and silently
46942. continued to walk to and fro.
46943. 
46944. "My carriage!" he said.
46945. 
46946. He took his seat beside the aide-de-camp on duty and drove into the
46947. suburb. "Moscow deserted!" he said to himself. "What an incredible
46948. event!"
46949. 
46950. He did not drive into the town, but put up at an inn in the Dorogomilov
46951. suburb.
46952. 
46953. The coup de theatre had not come off.
46954. 
46955. 
46956. 
46957. 
46958. 
46959. CHAPTER XXI
46960. 
46961. 
46962. The Russian troops were passing through Moscow from two o'clock at night
46963. till two in the afternoon and bore away with them the wounded and the
46964. last of the inhabitants who were leaving.
46965. 
46966. The greatest crush during the movement of the troops took place at the
46967. Stone, Moskva, and Yauza bridges.
46968. 
46969. While the troops, dividing into two parts when passing around the
46970. Kremlin, were thronging the Moskva and the Stone bridges, a great many
46971. soldiers, taking advantage of the stoppage and congestion, turned back
46972. from the bridges and slipped stealthily and silently past the church of
46973. Vasili the Beatified and under the Borovitski gate, back up the hill
46974. to the Red Square where some instinct told them they could easily take
46975. things not belonging to them. Crowds of the kind seen at cheap sales
46976. filled all the passages and alleys of the Bazaar. But there were no
46977. dealers with voices of ingratiating affability inviting customers to
46978. enter; there were no hawkers, nor the usual motley crowd of female
46979. purchasers--but only soldiers, in uniforms and overcoats though without
46980. muskets, entering the Bazaar empty-handed and silently making their way
46981. out through its passages with bundles. Tradesmen and their assistants
46982. (of whom there were but few) moved about among the soldiers quite
46983. bewildered. They unlocked their shops and locked them up again, and
46984. themselves carried goods away with the help of their assistants. On the
46985. square in front of the Bazaar were drummers beating the muster call.
46986. But the roll of the drums did not make the looting soldiers run in the
46987. direction of the drum as formerly, but made them, on the contrary, run
46988. farther away. Among the soldiers in the shops and passages some men were
46989. to be seen in gray coats, with closely shaven heads. Two officers, one
46990. with a scarf over his uniform and mounted on a lean, dark-gray horse,
46991. the other in an overcoat and on foot, stood at the corner of Ilyinka
46992. Street, talking. A third officer galloped up to them.
46993. 
46994. "The general orders them all to be driven out at once, without fail.
46995. This is outrageous! Half the men have dispersed."
46996. 
46997. "Where are you off to?... Where?..." he shouted to three infantrymen
46998. without muskets who, holding up the skirts of their overcoats, were
46999. slipping past him into the Bazaar passage. "Stop, you rascals!"
47000. 
47001. "But how are you going to stop them?" replied another officer. "There is
47002. no getting them together. The army should push on before the rest bolt,
47003. that's all!"
47004. 
47005. "How can one push on? They are stuck there, wedged on the bridge, and
47006. don't move. Shouldn't we put a cordon round to prevent the rest from
47007. running away?"
47008. 
47009. "Come, go in there and drive them out!" shouted the senior officer.
47010. 
47011. The officer in the scarf dismounted, called up a drummer, and went with
47012. him into the arcade. Some soldiers started running away in a group. A
47013. shopkeeper with red pimples on his cheeks near the nose, and a calm,
47014. persistent, calculating expression on his plump face, hurriedly and
47015. ostentatiously approached the officer, swinging his arms.
47016. 
47017. "Your honor!" said he. "Be so good as to protect us! We won't grudge
47018. trifles, you are welcome to anything--we shall be delighted! Pray!...
47019. I'll fetch a piece of cloth at once for such an honorable gentleman,
47020. or even two pieces with pleasure. For we feel how it is; but what's all
47021. this--sheer robbery! If you please, could not guards be placed if only
47022. to let us close the shop...."
47023. 
47024. Several shopkeepers crowded round the officer.
47025. 
47026. "Eh, what twaddle!" said one of them, a thin, stern-looking man. "When
47027. one's head is gone one doesn't weep for one's hair! Take what any of you
47028. like!" And flourishing his arm energetically he turned sideways to the
47029. officer.
47030. 
47031. "It's all very well for you, Ivan Sidorych, to talk," said the first
47032. tradesman angrily. "Please step inside, your honor!"
47033. 
47034. "Talk indeed!" cried the thin one. "In my three shops here I have a
47035. hundred thousand rubles' worth of goods. Can they be saved when the army
47036. has gone? Eh, what people! 'Against God's might our hands can't fight.'"
47037. 
47038. "Come inside, your honor!" repeated the tradesman, bowing.
47039. 
47040. The officer stood perplexed and his face showed indecision.
47041. 
47042. "It's not my business!" he exclaimed, and strode on quickly down one of
47043. the passages.
47044. 
47045. From one open shop came the sound of blows and vituperation, and just
47046. as the officer came up to it a man in a gray coat with a shaven head was
47047. flung out violently.
47048. 
47049. This man, bent double, rushed past the tradesman and the officer. The
47050. officer pounced on the soldiers who were in the shops, but at that
47051. moment fearful screams reached them from the huge crowd on the Moskva
47052. bridge and the officer ran out into the square.
47053. 
47054. "What is it? What is it?" he asked, but his comrade was already
47055. galloping off past Vasili the Beatified in the direction from which the
47056. screams came.
47057. 
47058. The officer mounted his horse and rode after him. When he reached the
47059. bridge he saw two unlimbered guns, the infantry crossing the bridge,
47060. several overturned carts, and frightened and laughing faces among the
47061. troops. Beside the cannon a cart was standing to which two horses were
47062. harnessed. Four borzois with collars were pressing close to the wheels.
47063. The cart was loaded high, and at the very top, beside a child's chair
47064. with its legs in the air, sat a peasant woman uttering piercing and
47065. desperate shrieks. He was told by his fellow officers that the screams
47066. of the crowd and the shrieks of the woman were due to the fact that
47067. General Ermolov, coming up to the crowd and learning that soldiers were
47068. dispersing among the shops while crowds of civilians blocked the bridge,
47069. had ordered two guns to be unlimbered and made a show of firing at the
47070. bridge. The crowd, crushing one another, upsetting carts, and shouting
47071. and squeezing desperately, had cleared off the bridge and the troops
47072. were now moving forward.
47073. 
47074. 
47075. 
47076. 
47077. 
47078. CHAPTER XXII
47079. 
47080. 
47081. Meanwhile, the city itself was deserted. There was hardly anyone in the
47082. streets. The gates and shops were all closed, only here and there round
47083. the taverns solitary shouts or drunken songs could be heard. Nobody
47084. drove through the streets and footsteps were rarely heard. The
47085. Povarskaya was quite still and deserted. The huge courtyard of the
47086. Rostovs' house was littered with wisps of hay and with dung from the
47087. horses, and not a soul was to be seen there. In the great drawing
47088. room of the house, which had been left with all it contained, were
47089. two people. They were the yard porter Ignat, and the page boy Mishka,
47090. Vasilich's grandson who had stayed in Moscow with his grandfather.
47091. Mishka had opened the clavichord and was strumming on it with
47092. one finger. The yard porter, his arms akimbo, stood smiling with
47093. satisfaction before the large mirror.
47094. 
47095. "Isn't it fine, eh, Uncle Ignat?" said the boy, suddenly beginning to
47096. strike the keyboard with both hands.
47097. 
47098. "Only fancy!" answered Ignat, surprised at the broadening grin on his
47099. face in the mirror.
47100. 
47101. "Impudence! Impudence!" they heard behind them the voice of Mavra
47102. Kuzminichna who had entered silently. "How he's grinning, the fat mug!
47103. Is that what you're here for? Nothing's cleared away down there and
47104. Vasilich is worn out. Just you wait a bit!"
47105. 
47106. Ignat left off smiling, adjusted his belt, and went out of the room with
47107. meekly downcast eyes.
47108. 
47109. "Aunt, I did it gently," said the boy.
47110. 
47111. "I'll give you something gently, you monkey you!" cried Mavra
47112. Kuzminichna, raising her arm threateningly. "Go and get the samovar to
47113. boil for your grandfather."
47114. 
47115. Mavra Kuzminichna flicked the dust off the clavichord and closed it, and
47116. with a deep sigh left the drawing room and locked its main door.
47117. 
47118. Going out into the yard she paused to consider where she should go
47119. next--to drink tea in the servants' wing with Vasilich, or into the
47120. storeroom to put away what still lay about.
47121. 
47122. She heard the sound of quick footsteps in the quiet street. Someone
47123. stopped at the gate, and the latch rattled as someone tried to open it.
47124. Mavra Kuzminichna went to the gate.
47125. 
47126. "Who do you want?"
47127. 
47128. "The count--Count Ilya Andreevich Rostov."
47129. 
47130. "And who are you?"
47131. 
47132. "An officer, I have to see him," came the reply in a pleasant, well-bred
47133. Russian voice.
47134. 
47135. Mavra Kuzminichna opened the gate and an officer of eighteen, with the
47136. round face of a Rostov, entered the yard.
47137. 
47138. "They have gone away, sir. Went away yesterday at vespertime," said
47139. Mavra Kuzminichna cordially.
47140. 
47141. The young officer standing in the gateway, as if hesitating whether to
47142. enter or not, clicked his tongue.
47143. 
47144. "Ah, how annoying!" he muttered. "I should have come yesterday.... Ah,
47145. what a pity."
47146. 
47147. Meanwhile, Mavra Kuzminichna was attentively and sympathetically
47148. examining the familiar Rostov features of the young man's face, his
47149. tattered coat and trodden-down boots.
47150. 
47151. "What did you want to see the count for?" she asked.
47152. 
47153. "Oh well... it can't be helped!" said he in a tone of vexation and
47154. placed his hand on the gate as if to leave.
47155. 
47156. He again paused in indecision.
47157.
