47158. "You see," he suddenly said, "I am a kinsman of the count's and he has
47159. been very kind to me. As you see" (he glanced with an amused air and
47160. good-natured smile at his coat and boots) "my things are worn out and I
47161. have no money, so I was going to ask the count..."
47162. 
47163. Mavra Kuzminichna did not let him finish.
47164. 
47165. "Just wait a minute, sir. One little moment," said she.
47166. 
47167. And as soon as the officer let go of the gate handle she turned and,
47168. hurrying away on her old legs, went through the back yard to the
47169. servants' quarters.
47170. 
47171. While Mavra Kuzminichna was running to her room the officer walked about
47172. the yard gazing at his worn-out boots with lowered head and a faint
47173. smile on his lips. "What a pity I've missed Uncle! What a nice old
47174. woman! Where has she run off to? And how am I to find the nearest way
47175. to overtake my regiment, which must by now be getting near the Rogozhski
47176. gate?" thought he. Just then Mavra Kuzminichna appeared from behind
47177. the corner of the house with a frightened yet resolute look, carrying a
47178. rolled-up check kerchief in her hand. While still a few steps from
47179. the officer she unfolded the kerchief and took out of it a white
47180. twenty-five-ruble assignat and hastily handed it to him.
47181. 
47182. "If his excellency had been at home, as a kinsman he would of course...
47183. but as it is..."
47184. 
47185. Mavra Kuzminichna grew abashed and confused. The officer did not
47186. decline, but took the note quietly and thanked her.
47187. 
47188. "If the count had been at home..." Mavra Kuzminichna went on
47189. apologetically. "Christ be with you, sir! May God preserve you!" said
47190. she, bowing as she saw him out.
47191. 
47192. Swaying his head and smiling as if amused at himself, the officer ran
47193. almost at a trot through the deserted streets toward the Yauza bridge to
47194. overtake his regiment.
47195. 
47196. But Mavra Kuzminichna stood at the closed gate for some time with moist
47197. eyes, pensively swaying her head and feeling an unexpected flow of
47198. motherly tenderness and pity for the unknown young officer.
47199. 
47200. 
47201. 
47202. 
47203. 
47204. CHAPTER XXIII
47205. 
47206. 
47207. From an unfinished house on the Varvarka, the ground floor of which was
47208. a dramshop, came drunken shouts and songs. On benches round the tables
47209. in a dirty little room sat some ten factory hands. Tipsy and perspiring,
47210. with dim eyes and wide-open mouths, they were all laboriously singing
47211. some song or other. They were singing discordantly, arduously, and with
47212. great effort, evidently not because they wished to sing, but because
47213. they wanted to show they were drunk and on a spree. One, a tall,
47214. fair-haired lad in a clean blue coat, was standing over the others. His
47215. face with its fine straight nose would have been handsome had it not
47216. been for his thin, compressed, twitching lips and dull, gloomy, fixed
47217. eyes. Evidently possessed by some idea, he stood over those who were
47218. singing, and solemnly and jerkily flourished above their heads his white
47219. arm with the sleeve turned up to the elbow, trying unnaturally to spread
47220. out his dirty fingers. The sleeve of his coat kept slipping down and he
47221. always carefully rolled it up again with his left hand, as if it were
47222. most important that the sinewy white arm he was flourishing should be
47223. bare. In the midst of the song cries were heard, and fighting and blows
47224. in the passage and porch. The tall lad waved his arm.
47225. 
47226. "Stop it!" he exclaimed peremptorily. "There's a fight, lads!" And,
47227. still rolling up his sleeve, he went out to the porch.
47228. 
47229. The factory hands followed him. These men, who under the leadership of
47230. the tall lad were drinking in the dramshop that morning, had brought the
47231. publican some skins from the factory and for this had had drink served
47232. them. The blacksmiths from a neighboring smithy, hearing the sounds of
47233. revelry in the tavern and supposing it to have been broken into, wished
47234. to force their way in too and a fight in the porch had resulted.
47235. 
47236. The publican was fighting one of the smiths at the door, and when the
47237. workmen came out the smith, wrenching himself free from the tavern
47238. keeper, fell face downward on the pavement.
47239. 
47240. Another smith tried to enter the doorway, pressing against the publican
47241. with his chest.
47242. 
47243. The lad with the turned-up sleeve gave the smith a blow in the face and
47244. cried wildly: "They're fighting us, lads!"
47245. 
47246. At that moment the first smith got up and, scratching his bruised
47247. face to make it bleed, shouted in a tearful voice: "Police! Murder!...
47248. They've killed a man, lads!"
47249. 
47250. "Oh, gracious me, a man beaten to death--killed!..." screamed a woman
47251. coming out of a gate close by.
47252. 
47253. A crowd gathered round the bloodstained smith.
47254. 
47255. "Haven't you robbed people enough--taking their last shirts?" said a
47256. voice addressing the publican. "What have you killed a man for, you
47257. thief?"
47258. 
47259. The tall lad, standing in the porch, turned his bleared eyes from the
47260. publican to the smith and back again as if considering whom he ought to
47261. fight now.
47262. 
47263. "Murderer!" he shouted suddenly to the publican. "Bind him, lads!"
47264. 
47265. "I daresay you would like to bind me!" shouted the publican, pushing
47266. away the men advancing on him, and snatching his cap from his head he
47267. flung it on the ground.
47268. 
47269. As if this action had some mysterious and menacing significance, the
47270. workmen surrounding the publican paused in indecision.
47271. 
47272. "I know the law very well, mates! I'll take the matter to the captain
47273. of police. You think I won't get to him? Robbery is not permitted to
47274. anybody now a days!" shouted the publican, picking up his cap.
47275. 
47276. "Come along then! Come along then!" the publican and the tall young
47277. fellow repeated one after the other, and they moved up the street
47278. together.
47279. 
47280. The bloodstained smith went beside them. The factory hands and others
47281. followed behind, talking and shouting.
47282. 
47283. At the corner of the Moroseyka, opposite a large house with closed
47284. shutters and bearing a bootmaker's signboard, stood a score of thin,
47285. worn-out, gloomy-faced bootmakers, wearing overalls and long tattered
47286. coats.
47287. 
47288. "He should pay folks off properly," a thin workingman, with frowning
47289. brows and a straggly beard, was saying.
47290. 
47291. "But he's sucked our blood and now he thinks he's quit of us. He's been
47292. misleading us all the week and now that he's brought us to this pass
47293. he's made off."
47294. 
47295. On seeing the crowd and the bloodstained man the workman ceased
47296. speaking, and with eager curiosity all the bootmakers joined the moving
47297. crowd.
47298. 
47299. "Where are all the folks going?"
47300. 
47301. "Why, to the police, of course!"
47302. 
47303. "I say, is it true that we have been beaten?" "And what did you think?
47304. Look what folks are saying."
47305. 
47306. Questions and answers were heard. The publican, taking advantage of the
47307. increased crowd, dropped behind and returned to his tavern.
47308. 
47309. The tall youth, not noticing the disappearance of his foe, waved his
47310. bare arm and went on talking incessantly, attracting general attention
47311. to himself. It was around him that the people chiefly crowded, expecting
47312. answers from him to the questions that occupied all their minds.
47313. 
47314. "He must keep order, keep the law, that's what the government is there
47315. for. Am I not right, good Christians?" said the tall youth, with a
47316. scarcely perceptible smile. "He thinks there's no government! How can
47317. one do without government? Or else there would be plenty who'd rob us."
47318. 
47319. "Why talk nonsense?" rejoined voices in the crowd. "Will they give
47320. up Moscow like this? They told you that for fun, and you believed it!
47321. Aren't there plenty of troops on the march? Let him in, indeed! That's
47322. what the government is for. You'd better listen to what people are
47323. saying," said some of the mob pointing to the tall youth.
47324. 
47325. By the wall of China-Town a smaller group of people were gathered round
47326. a man in a frieze coat who held a paper in his hand.
47327. 
47328. "An ukase, they are reading an ukase! Reading an ukase!" cried voices in
47329. the crowd, and the people rushed toward the reader.
47330. 
47331. The man in the frieze coat was reading the broadsheet of August 31 When
47332. the crowd collected round him he seemed confused, but at the demand
47333. of the tall lad who had pushed his way up to him, he began in a rather
47334. tremulous voice to read the sheet from the beginning.
47335. 
47336. "Early tomorrow I shall go to his Serene Highness," he read ("Sirin
47337. Highness," said the tall fellow with a triumphant smile on his lips and
47338. a frown on his brow), "to consult with him to act, and to aid the army
47339. to exterminate these scoundrels. We too will take part..." the reader
47340. went on, and then paused ("Do you see," shouted the youth victoriously,
47341. "he's going to clear up the whole affair for you...."), "in destroying
47342. them, and will send these visitors to the devil. I will come back to
47343. dinner, and we'll set to work. We will do, completely do, and undo these
47344. scoundrels."
47345. 
47346. The last words were read out in the midst of complete silence. The tall
47347. lad hung his head gloomily. It was evident that no one had understood
47348. the last part. In particular, the words "I will come back to dinner,"
47349. evidently displeased both reader and audience. The people's minds
47350. were tuned to a high pitch and this was too simple and needlessly
47351. comprehensible--it was what any one of them might have said and
47352. therefore was what an ukase emanating from the highest authority should
47353. not say.
47354. 
47355. They all stood despondent and silent. The tall youth moved his lips and
47356. swayed from side to side.
47357. 
47358. "We should ask him... that's he himself?"... "Yes, ask him indeed!...
47359. Why not? He'll explain"... voices in the rear of the crowd were
47360. suddenly heard saying, and the general attention turned to the police
47361. superintendent's trap which drove into the square attended by two
47362. mounted dragoons.
47363. 
47364. The superintendent of police, who had gone that morning by Count
47365. Rostopchin's orders to burn the barges and had in connection with that
47366. matter acquired a large sum of money which was at that moment in his
47367. pocket, on seeing a crowd bearing down upon him told his coachman to
47368. stop.
47369. 
47370. "What people are these?" he shouted to the men, who were moving singly
47371. and timidly in the direction of his trap.
47372. 
47373. "What people are these?" he shouted again, receiving no answer.
47374. 
47375. "Your honor..." replied the shopman in the frieze coat, "your honor, in
47376. accord with the proclamation of his highest excellency the count, they
47377. desire to serve, not sparing their lives, and it is not any kind of
47378. riot, but as his highest excellence said..."
47379. 
47380. "The count has not left, he is here, and an order will be issued
47381. concerning you," said the superintendent of police. "Go on!" he ordered
47382. his coachman.
47383. 
47384. The crowd halted, pressing around those who had heard what the
47385. superintendent had said, and looking at the departing trap.
47386. 
47387. The superintendent of police turned round at that moment with a scared
47388. look, said something to his coachman, and his horses increased their
47389. speed.
47390. 
47391. "It's a fraud, lads! Lead the way to him, himself!" shouted the tall
47392. youth. "Don't let him go, lads! Let him answer us! Keep him!" shouted
47393. different people and the people dashed in pursuit of the trap.
47394. 
47395. Following the superintendent of police and talking loudly the crowd went
47396. in the direction of the Lubyanka Street.
47397. 
47398. "There now, the gentry and merchants have gone away and left us to
47399. perish. Do they think we're dogs?" voices in the crowd were heard saying
47400. more and more frequently.
47401. 
47402. 
47403. 
47404. 
47405. 
47406. CHAPTER XXIV
47407. 
47408. 
47409. On the evening of the first of September, after his interview with
47410. Kutuzov, Count Rostopchin had returned to Moscow mortified and offended
47411. because he had not been invited to attend the council of war, and
47412. because Kutuzov had paid no attention to his offer to take part in the
47413. defense of the city; amazed also at the novel outlook revealed to him
47414. at the camp, which treated the tranquillity of the capital and its
47415. patriotic fervor as not merely secondary but quite irrelevant and
47416. unimportant matters. Distressed, offended, and surprised by all this,
47417. Rostopchin had returned to Moscow. After supper he lay down on a sofa
47418. without undressing, and was awakened soon after midnight by a courier
47419. bringing him a letter from Kutuzov. This letter requested the count to
47420. send police officers to guide the troops through the town, as the army
47421. was retreating to the Ryazan road beyond Moscow. This was not news to
47422. Rostopchin. He had known that Moscow would be abandoned not merely since
47423. his interview the previous day with Kutuzov on the Poklonny Hill but
47424. ever since the battle of Borodino, for all the generals who came to
47425. Moscow after that battle had said unanimously that it was impossible to
47426. fight another battle, and since then the government property had been
47427. removed every night, and half the inhabitants had left the city
47428. with Rostopchin's own permission. Yet all the same this information
47429. astonished and irritated the count, coming as it did in the form of a
47430. simple note with an order from Kutuzov, and received at night, breaking
47431. in on his beauty sleep.
47432. 
47433. When later on in his memoirs Count Rostopchin explained his actions at
47434. this time, he repeatedly says that he was then actuated by two important
47435. considerations: to maintain tranquillity in Moscow and expedite the
47436. departure of the inhabitants. If one accepts this twofold aim all
47437. Rostopchin's actions appear irreproachable. "Why were the holy relics,
47438. the arms, ammunition, gunpowder, and stores of corn not removed? Why
47439. were thousands of inhabitants deceived into believing that Moscow would
47440. not be given up--and thereby ruined?" "To preserve the tranquillity
47441. of the city," explains Count Rostopchin. "Why were bundles of useless
47442. papers from the government offices, and Leppich's balloon and other
47443. articles removed?" "To leave the town empty," explains Count Rostopchin.
47444. One need only admit that public tranquillity is in danger and any action
47445. finds a justification.
47446. 
47447. All the horrors of the reign of terror were based only on solicitude for
47448. public tranquillity.
47449. 
47450. On what, then, was Count Rostopchin's fear for the tranquillity of
47451. Moscow based in 1812? What reason was there for assuming any probability
47452. of an uprising in the city? The inhabitants were leaving it and the
47453. retreating troops were filling it. Why should that cause the masses to
47454. riot?
47455. 
47456. Neither in Moscow nor anywhere in Russia did anything resembling an
47457. insurrection ever occur when the enemy entered a town. More than
47458. ten thousand people were still in Moscow on the first and second of
47459. September, and except for a mob in the governor's courtyard, assembled
47460. there at his bidding, nothing happened. It is obvious that there would
47461. have been even less reason to expect a disturbance among the people
47462. if after the battle of Borodino, when the surrender of Moscow became
47463. certain or at least probable, Rostopchin instead of exciting the people
47464. by distributing arms and broadsheets had taken steps to remove all
47465. the holy relics, the gunpowder, munitions, and money, and had told the
47466. population plainly that the town would be abandoned.
47467. 
47468. Rostopchin, though he had patriotic sentiments, was a sanguine and
47469. impulsive man who had always moved in the highest administrative circles
47470. and had no understanding at all of the people he supposed himself to
47471. be guiding. Ever since the enemy's entry into Smolensk he had in
47472. imagination been playing the role of director of the popular feeling
47473. of "the heart of Russia." Not only did it seem to him (as to all
47474. administrators) that he controlled the external actions of Moscow's
47475. inhabitants, but he also thought he controlled their mental attitude by
47476. means of his broadsheets and posters, written in a coarse tone which the
47477. people despise in their own class and do not understand from those in
47478. authority. Rostopchin was so pleased with the fine role of leader of
47479. popular feeling, and had grown so used to it, that the necessity of
47480. relinquishing that role and abandoning Moscow without any heroic display
47481. took him unawares and he suddenly felt the ground slip away from under
47482. his feet, so that he positively did not know what to do. Though he knew
47483. it was coming, he did not till the last moment wholeheartedly believe
47484. that Moscow would be abandoned, and did not prepare for it. The
47485. inhabitants left against his wishes. If the government offices were
47486. removed, this was only done on the demand of officials to whom the count
47487. yielded reluctantly. He was absorbed in the role he had created
47488. for himself. As is often the case with those gifted with an ardent
47489. imagination, though he had long known that Moscow would be abandoned he
47490. knew it only with his intellect, he did not believe it in his heart and
47491. did not adapt himself mentally to this new position of affairs.
47492. 
47493. All his painstaking and energetic activity (in how far it was useful
47494. and had any effect on the people is another question) had been simply
47495. directed toward arousing in the masses his own feeling of patriotic
47496. hatred of the French.
47497. 
47498. But when events assumed their true historical character, when expressing
47499. hatred for the French in words proved insufficient, when it was not
47500. even possible to express that hatred by fighting a battle, when
47501. self-confidence was of no avail in relation to the one question before
47502. Moscow, when the whole population streamed out of Moscow as one man,
47503. abandoning their belongings and proving by that negative action all
47504. the depth of their national feeling, then the role chosen by Rostopchin
47505. suddenly appeared senseless. He unexpectedly felt himself ridiculous,
47506. weak, and alone, with no ground to stand on.
47507. 
47508. When, awakened from his sleep, he received that cold, peremptory note
47509. from Kutuzov, he felt the more irritated the more he felt himself
47510. to blame. All that he had been specially put in charge of, the state
47511. property which he should have removed, was still in Moscow and it was no
47512. longer possible to take the whole of it away.
47513. 
47514. "Who is to blame for it? Who has let things come to such a pass?" he
47515. ruminated. "Not I, of course. I had everything ready. I had Moscow
47516. firmly in hand. And this is what they have let it come to! Villains!
47517. Traitors!" he thought, without clearly defining who the villains and
47518. traitors were, but feeling it necessary to hate those traitors whoever
47519. they might be who were to blame for the false and ridiculous position in
47520. which he found himself.
47521. 
47522. All that night Count Rostopchin issued orders, for which people came to
47523. him from all parts of Moscow. Those about him had never seen the count
47524. so morose and irritable.
47525. 
47526. "Your excellency, the Director of the Registrar's Department has sent
47527. for instructions... From the Consistory, from the Senate, from the
47528. University, from the Foundling Hospital, the Suffragan has sent...
47529. asking for information.... What are your orders about the Fire Brigade?
47530. From the governor of the prison... from the superintendent of the
47531. lunatic asylum..." All night long such announcements were continually
47532. being received by the count.
47533. 
47534. To all these inquiries he gave brief and angry replies indicating that
47535. orders from him were not now needed, that the whole affair, carefully
47536. prepared by him, had now been ruined by somebody, and that that somebody
47537. would have to bear the whole responsibility for all that might happen.
47538. 
47539. "Oh, tell that blockhead," he said in reply to the question from the
47540. Registrar's Department, "that he should remain to guard his documents.
47541. Now why are you asking silly questions about the Fire Brigade? They have
47542. horses, let them be off to Vladimir, and not leave them to the French."
47543. 
47544. "Your excellency, the superintendent of the lunatic asylum has come:
47545. what are your commands?"
47546. 
47547. "My commands? Let them go away, that's all.... And let the lunatics
47548. out into the town. When lunatics command our armies God evidently means
47549. these other madmen to be free."
47550. 
47551. In reply to an inquiry about the convicts in the prison, Count
47552. Rostopchin shouted angrily at the governor:
47553. 
47554. "Do you expect me to give you two battalions--which we have not got--for
47555. a convoy? Release them, that's all about it!"
47556. 
47557. "Your excellency, there are some political prisoners, Meshkov,
47558. Vereshchagin..."
47559. 
47560. "Vereshchagin! Hasn't he been hanged yet?" shouted Rostopchin. "Bring
47561. him to me!"
47562. 
47563. 
47564. 
47565. 
47566. 
47567. CHAPTER XXV
47568. 
47569. 
47570. Toward nine o'clock in the morning, when the troops were already moving
47571. through Moscow, nobody came to the count any more for instructions.
47572. Those who were able to get away were going of their own accord, those
47573. who remained behind decided for themselves what they must do.
47574. 
47575. The count ordered his carriage that he might drive to Sokolniki, and sat
47576. in his study with folded hands, morose, sallow, and taciturn.
47577. 
47578. In quiet and untroubled times it seems to every administrator that it
47579. is only by his efforts that the whole population under his rule is
47580. kept going, and in this consciousness of being indispensable every
47581. administrator finds the chief reward of his labor and efforts. While the
47582. sea of history remains calm the ruler-administrator in his frail bark,
47583. holding on with a boat hook to the ship of the people and himself
47584. moving, naturally imagines that his efforts move the ship he is holding
47585. on to. But as soon as a storm arises and the sea begins to heave and
47586. the ship to move, such a delusion is no longer possible. The ship moves
47587. independently with its own enormous motion, the boat hook no longer
47588. reaches the moving vessel, and suddenly the administrator, instead
47589. of appearing a ruler and a source of power, becomes an insignificant,
47590. useless, feeble man.
47591. 
47592. Rostopchin felt this, and it was this which exasperated him.
47593. 
47594. The superintendent of police, whom the crowd had stopped, went in to
47595. see him at the same time as an adjutant who informed the count that the
47596. horses were harnessed. They were both pale, and the superintendent of
47597. police, after reporting that he had executed the instructions he had
47598. received, informed the count that an immense crowd had collected in the
47599. courtyard and wished to see him.
47600. 
47601. Without saying a word Rostopchin rose and walked hastily to his light,
47602. luxurious drawing room, went to the balcony door, took hold of the
47603. handle, let it go again, and went to the window from which he had a
47604. better view of the whole crowd. The tall lad was standing in front,
47605. flourishing his arm and saying something with a stern look. The blood
47606. stained smith stood beside him with a gloomy face. A drone of voices was
47607. audible through the closed window.
47608. 
47609. "Is my carriage ready?" asked Rostopchin, stepping back from the window.
47610. 
47611. "It is, your excellency," replied the adjutant.
47612. 
47613. Rostopchin went again to the balcony door.
47614. 
47615. "But what do they want?" he asked the superintendent of police.
47616. 
47617. "Your excellency, they say they have got ready, according to your
47618. orders, to go against the French, and they shouted something about
47619. treachery. But it is a turbulent crowd, your excellency--I hardly
47620. managed to get away from it. Your excellency, I venture to suggest..."
47621. 
47622. "You may go. I don't need you to tell me what to do!" exclaimed
47623. Rostopchin angrily.
47624. 
47625. He stood by the balcony door looking at the crowd.
47626. 
47627. "This is what they have done with Russia! This is what they have done
47628. with me!" thought he, full of an irrepressible fury that welled up
47629. within him against the someone to whom what was happening might be
47630. attributed. As often happens with passionate people, he was mastered by
47631. anger but was still seeking an object on which to vent it. "Here is
47632. that mob, the dregs of the people," he thought as he gazed at the crowd:
47633. "this rabble they have roused by their folly! They want a victim,"
47634. he thought as he looked at the tall lad flourishing his arm. And this
47635. thought occurred to him just because he himself desired a victim,
47636. something on which to vent his rage.
47637. 
47638. "Is the carriage ready?" he asked again.
47639. 
47640. "Yes, your excellency. What are your orders about Vereshchagin? He is
47641. waiting at the porch," said the adjutant.
47642. 
47643. "Ah!" exclaimed Rostopchin, as if struck by an unexpected recollection.
47644. 
47645. And rapidly opening the door he went resolutely out onto the balcony.
47646. The talking instantly ceased, hats and caps were doffed, and all eyes
47647. were raised to the count.
47648. 
47649. "Good morning, lads!" said the count briskly and loudly. "Thank you for
47650. coming. I'll come out to you in a moment, but we must first settle
47651. with the villain. We must punish the villain who has caused the ruin of
47652. Moscow. Wait for me!"
47653. 
47654. And the count stepped as briskly back into the room and slammed the door
47655. behind him.
47656. 
47657. A murmur of approbation and satisfaction ran through the crowd. "He'll
47658. settle with all the villains, you'll see! And you said the French...
47659. He'll show you what law is!" the mob were saying as if reproving one
47660. another for their lack of confidence.
47661. 
47662. A few minutes later an officer came hurriedly out of the front door,
47663. gave an order, and the dragoons formed up in line. The crowd moved
47664. eagerly from the balcony toward the porch. Rostopchin, coming out there
47665. with quick angry steps, looked hastily around as if seeking someone.
47666. 
47667. "Where is he?" he inquired. And as he spoke he saw a young man coming
47668. round the corner of the house between two dragoons. He had a long thin
47669. neck, and his head, that had been half shaved, was again covered by
47670. short hair. This young man was dressed in a threadbare blue cloth coat
47671. lined with fox fur, that had once been smart, and dirty hempen convict
47672. trousers, over which were pulled his thin, dirty, trodden-down boots.
47673. On his thin, weak legs were heavy chains which hampered his irresolute
47674. movements.
47675. 
47676. "Ah!" said Rostopchin, hurriedly turning away his eyes from the young
47677. man in the fur-lined coat and pointing to the bottom step of the porch.
47678. "Put him there."
47679. 
47680. The young man in his clattering chains stepped clumsily to the spot
47681. indicated, holding away with one finger the coat collar which chafed
47682. his neck, turned his long neck twice this way and that, sighed, and
47683. submissively folded before him his thin hands, unused to work.
47684. 
47685. For several seconds while the young man was taking his place on the step
47686. the silence continued. Only among the back rows of the people, who were
47687. all pressing toward the one spot, could sighs, groans, and the shuffling
47688. of feet be heard.
47689. 
47690. While waiting for the young man to take his place on the step Rostopchin
47691. stood frowning and rubbing his face with his hand.
47692. 
47693. "Lads!" said he, with a metallic ring in his voice. "This man,
47694. Vereshchagin, is the scoundrel by whose doing Moscow is perishing."
47695. 
47696. The young man in the fur-lined coat, stooping a little, stood in a
47697. submissive attitude, his fingers clasped before him. His emaciated young
47698. face, disfigured by the half-shaven head, hung down hopelessly. At
47699. the count's first words he raised it slowly and looked up at him as if
47700. wishing to say something or at least to meet his eye. But Rostopchin did
47701. not look at him. A vein in the young man's long thin neck swelled like a
47702. cord and went blue behind the ear, and suddenly his face flushed.
47703. 
47704. All eyes were fixed on him. He looked at the crowd, and rendered more
47705. hopeful by the expression he read on the faces there, he smiled sadly
47706. and timidly, and lowering his head shifted his feet on the step.
47707. 
47708. "He has betrayed his Tsar and his country, he has gone over to
47709. Bonaparte. He alone of all the Russians has disgraced the Russian name,
47710. he has caused Moscow to perish," said Rostopchin in a sharp, even voice,
47711. but suddenly he glanced down at Vereshchagin who continued to stand in
47712. the same submissive attitude. As if inflamed by the sight, he raised his
47713. arm and addressed the people, almost shouting:
47714. 
47715. "Deal with him as you think fit! I hand him over to you."
47716. 
47717. The crowd remained silent and only pressed closer and closer to
47718. one another. To keep one another back, to breathe in that stifling
47719. atmosphere, to be unable to stir, and to await something unknown,
47720. uncomprehended, and terrible, was becoming unbearable. Those standing
47721. in front, who had seen and heard what had taken place before them, all
47722. stood with wide open eyes and mouths, straining with all their strength,
47723. and held back the crowd that was pushing behind them.
47724. 
47725. "Beat him!... Let the traitor perish and not disgrace the Russian name!"
47726. shouted Rostopchin. "Cut him down. I command it."
47727. 
47728. Hearing not so much the words as the angry tone of Rostopchin's voice,
47729. the crowd moaned and heaved forward, but again paused.
47730. 
47731. "Count!" exclaimed the timid yet theatrical voice of Vereshchagin in the
47732. midst of the momentary silence that ensued, "Count! One God is above us
47733. both...." He lifted his head and again the thick vein in his thin neck
47734. filled with blood and the color rapidly came and went in his face.
47735. 
47736. He did not finish what he wished to say.
47737. 
47738. "Cut him down! I command it..." shouted Rostopchin, suddenly growing
47739. pale like Vereshchagin.
47740. 
47741. "Draw sabers!" cried the dragoon officer, drawing his own.
47742. 
47743. Another still stronger wave flowed through the crowd and reaching the
47744. front ranks carried it swaying to the very steps of the porch. The tall
47745. youth, with a stony look on his face, and rigid and uplifted arm, stood
47746. beside Vereshchagin.
47747. 
47748. "Saber him!" the dragoon officer almost whispered.
47749. 
47750. And one of the soldiers, his face all at once distorted with fury,
47751. struck Vereshchagin on the head with the blunt side of his saber.
47752. 
47753. "Ah!" cried Vereshchagin in meek surprise, looking round with a
47754. frightened glance as if not understanding why this was done to him. A
47755. similar moan of surprise and horror ran through the crowd. "O Lord!"
47756. exclaimed a sorrowful voice.
47757. 
47758. But after the exclamation of surprise that had escaped from Vereshchagin
47759. he uttered a plaintive cry of pain, and that cry was fatal. The barrier
47760. of human feeling, strained to the utmost, that had held the crowd in
47761. check suddenly broke. The crime had begun and must now be completed. The
47762. plaintive moan of reproach was drowned by the threatening and angry roar
47763. of the crowd. Like the seventh and last wave that shatters a ship, that
47764. last irresistible wave burst from the rear and reached the front ranks,
47765. carrying them off their feet and engulfing them all. The dragoon was
47766. about to repeat his blow. Vereshchagin with a cry of horror, covering
47767. his head with his hands, rushed toward the crowd. The tall youth,
47768. against whom he stumbled, seized his thin neck with his hands and,
47769. yelling wildly, fell with him under the feet of the pressing, struggling
47770. crowd.
47771. 
47772. Some beat and tore at Vereshchagin, others at the tall youth. And the
47773. screams of those that were being trampled on and of those who tried to
47774. rescue the tall lad only increased the fury of the crowd. It was a long
47775. time before the dragoons could extricate the bleeding youth, beaten
47776. almost to death. And for a long time, despite the feverish haste with
47777. which the mob tried to end the work that had been begun, those who were
47778. hitting, throttling, and tearing at Vereshchagin were unable to kill
47779. him, for the crowd pressed from all sides, swaying as one mass with them
47780. in the center and rendering it impossible for them either to kill him or
47781. let him go.
47782. 
47783. "Hit him with an ax, eh!... Crushed?... Traitor, he sold Christ....
47784. Still alive... tenacious... serves him right! Torture serves a thief
47785. right. Use the hatchet!... What--still alive?"
47786. 
47787. Only when the victim ceased to struggle and his cries changed to a
47788. long-drawn, measured death rattle did the crowd around his prostrate,
47789. bleeding corpse begin rapidly to change places. Each one came
47790. up, glanced at what had been done, and with horror, reproach, and
47791. astonishment pushed back again.
47792. 
47793. "O Lord! The people are like wild beasts! How could he be alive?" voices
47794. in the crowd could be heard saying. "Quite a young fellow too... must
47795. have been a merchant's son. What men!... and they say he's not the right
47796. one.... How not the right one?... O Lord! And there's another has been
47797. beaten too--they say he's nearly done for.... Oh, the people... Aren't
47798. they afraid of sinning?..." said the same mob now, looking with pained
47799. distress at the dead body with its long, thin, half-severed neck and its
47800. livid face stained with blood and dust.
47801. 
47802. A painstaking police officer, considering the presence of a corpse in
47803. his excellency's courtyard unseemly, told the dragoons to take it away.
47804. Two dragoons took it by its distorted legs and dragged it along the
47805. ground. The gory, dust-stained, half-shaven head with its long neck
47806. trailed twisting along the ground. The crowd shrank back from it.
47807. 
47808. At the moment when Vereshchagin fell and the crowd closed in with savage
47809. yells and swayed about him, Rostopchin suddenly turned pale and, instead
47810. of going to the back entrance where his carriage awaited him, went
47811. with hurried steps and bent head, not knowing where and why, along the
47812. passage leading to the rooms on the ground floor. The count's face was
47813. white and he could not control the feverish twitching of his lower jaw.
47814. 
47815. "This way, your excellency... Where are you going?... This way,
47816. please..." said a trembling, frightened voice behind him.
47817. 
47818. Count Rostopchin was unable to reply and, turning obediently, went in
47819. the direction indicated. At the back entrance stood his caleche. The
47820. distant roar of the yelling crowd was audible even there. He hastily
47821. took his seat and told the coachman to drive him to his country house in
47822. Sokolniki.
47823. 
47824. When they reached the Myasnitski Street and could no longer hear
47825. the shouts of the mob, the count began to repent. He remembered with
47826. dissatisfaction the agitation and fear he had betrayed before his
47827. subordinates. "The mob is terrible--disgusting," he said to himself
47828. in French. "They are like wolves whom nothing but flesh can appease."
47829. "Count! One God is above us both!"--Vereshchagin's words suddenly
47830. recurred to him, and a disagreeable shiver ran down his back. But this
47831. was only a momentary feeling and Count Rostopchin smiled disdainfully
47832. at himself. "I had other duties," thought he. "The people had to be
47833. appeased. Many other victims have perished and are perishing for the
47834. public good"--and he began thinking of his social duties to his family
47835. and to the city entrusted to him, and of himself--not himself as
47836. Theodore Vasilyevich Rostopchin (he fancied that Theodore Vasilyevich
47837. Rostopchin was sacrificing himself for the public good) but himself as
47838. governor, the representative of authority and of the Tsar. "Had I been
47839. simply Theodore Vasilyevich my course of action would have been quite
47840. different, but it was my duty to safeguard my life and dignity as
47841. commander in chief."
47842. 
47843. Lightly swaying on the flexible springs of his carriage and no longer
47844. hearing the terrible sounds of the crowd, Rostopchin grew physically
47845. calm and, as always happens, as soon as he became physically tranquil
47846. his mind devised reasons why he should be mentally tranquil too. The
47847. thought which tranquillized Rostopchin was not a new one. Since the
47848. world began and men have killed one another no one has ever committed
47849. such a crime against his fellow man without comforting himself with
47850. this same idea. This idea is le bien public, the hypothetical welfare of
47851. other people.
47852. 
47853. To a man not swayed by passion that welfare is never certain, but he
47854. who commits such a crime always knows just where that welfare lies. And
47855. Rostopchin now knew it.
47856. 
47857. Not only did his reason not reproach him for what he had done, but
47858. he even found cause for self-satisfaction in having so successfully
47859. contrived to avail himself of a convenient opportunity to punish a
47860. criminal and at the same time pacify the mob.
47861. 
47862. "Vereshchagin was tried and condemned to death," thought Rostopchin
47863. (though the Senate had only condemned Vereshchagin to hard labor), "he
47864. was a traitor and a spy. I could not let him go unpunished and so I have
47865. killed two birds with one stone: to appease the mob I gave them a victim
47866. and at the same time punished a miscreant."
47867. 
47868. Having reached his country house and begun to give orders about domestic
47869. arrangements, the count grew quite tranquil.
47870. 
47871. Half an hour later he was driving with his fast horses across the
47872. Sokolniki field, no longer thinking of what had occurred but considering
47873. what was to come. He was driving to the Yauza bridge where he had heard
47874. that Kutuzov was. Count Rostopchin was mentally preparing the angry and
47875. stinging reproaches he meant to address to Kutuzov for his deception. He
47876. would make that foxy old courtier feel that the responsibility for all
47877. the calamities that would follow the abandonment of the city and the
47878. ruin of Russia (as Rostopchin regarded it) would fall upon his doting
47879. old head. Planning beforehand what he would say to Kutuzov, Rostopchin
47880. turned angrily in his caleche and gazed sternly from side to side.
47881. 
47882. The Sokolniki field was deserted. Only at the end of it, in front of the
47883. almshouse and the lunatic asylum, could be seen some people in white
47884. and others like them walking singly across the field shouting and
47885. gesticulating.
47886. 
47887. One of these was running to cross the path of Count Rostopchin's
47888. carriage, and the count himself, his coachman, and his dragoons
47889. looked with vague horror and curiosity at these released lunatics and
47890. especially at the one running toward them.
47891. 
47892. Swaying from side to side on his long, thin legs in his fluttering
47893. dressing gown, this lunatic was running impetuously, his gaze fixed on
47894. Rostopchin, shouting something in a hoarse voice and making signs to him
47895. to stop. The lunatic's solemn, gloomy face was thin and yellow, with
47896. its beard growing in uneven tufts. His black, agate pupils with
47897. saffron-yellow whites moved restlessly near the lower eyelids.
47898. 
47899. "Stop! Pull up, I tell you!" he cried in a piercing voice, and again
47900. shouted something breathlessly with emphatic intonations and gestures.
47901. 
47902. Coming abreast of the caleche he ran beside it.
47903. 
47904. "Thrice have they slain me, thrice have I risen from the dead. They
47905. stoned me, crucified me... I shall rise... shall rise... shall rise.
47906. They have torn my body. The kingdom of God will be overthrown... Thrice
47907. will I overthrow it and thrice re-establish it!" he cried, raising his
47908. voice higher and higher.
47909. 
47910. Count Rostopchin suddenly grew pale as he had done when the crowd closed
47911. in on Vereshchagin. He turned away. "Go fas... faster!" he cried in a
47912. trembling voice to his coachman. The caleche flew over the ground as
47913. fast as the horses could draw it, but for a long time Count Rostopchin
47914. still heard the insane despairing screams growing fainter in the
47915. distance, while his eyes saw nothing but the astonished, frightened,
47916. bloodstained face of "the traitor" in the fur-lined coat.
47917. 
47918. Recent as that mental picture was, Rostopchin already felt that it had
47919. cut deep into his heart and drawn blood. Even now he felt clearly that
47920. the gory trace of that recollection would not pass with time, but that
47921. the terrible memory would, on the contrary, dwell in his heart ever more
47922. cruelly and painfully to the end of his life. He seemed still to hear
47923. the sound of his own words: "Cut him down! I command it...."
47924. 
47925. "Why did I utter those words? It was by some accident I said them....
47926. I need not have said them," he thought. "And then nothing would have
47927. happened." He saw the frightened and then infuriated face of the dragoon
47928. who dealt the blow, the look of silent, timid reproach that boy in the
47929. fur-lined coat had turned upon him. "But I did not do it for my own
47930. sake. I was bound to act that way.... The mob, the traitor... the public
47931. welfare," thought he.
47932. 
47933. Troops were still crowding at the Yauza bridge. It was hot. Kutuzov,
47934. dejected and frowning, sat on a bench by the bridge toying with his
47935. whip in the sand when a caleche dashed up noisily. A man in a general's
47936. uniform with plumes in his hat went up to Kutuzov and said something
47937. in French. It was Count Rostopchin. He told Kutuzov that he had come
47938. because Moscow, the capital, was no more and only the army remained.
47939. 
47940. "Things would have been different if your Serene Highness had not told
47941. me that you would not abandon Moscow without another battle; all this
47942. would not have happened," he said.
47943. 
47944. Kutuzov looked at Rostopchin as if, not grasping what was said to him,
47945. he was trying to read something peculiar written at that moment on the
47946. face of the man addressing him. Rostopchin grew confused and became
47947. silent. Kutuzov slightly shook his head and not taking his penetrating
47948. gaze from Rostopchin's face muttered softly:
47949. 
47950. "No! I shall not give up Moscow without a battle!"
47951. 
47952. Whether Kutuzov was thinking of something entirely different when
47953. he spoke those words, or uttered them purposely, knowing them to be
47954. meaningless, at any rate Rostopchin made no reply and hastily left him.
47955. And strange to say, the Governor of Moscow, the proud Count Rostopchin,
47956. took up a Cossack whip and went to the bridge where he began with shouts
47957. to drive on the carts that blocked the way.
47958. 
47959. 
47960. 
47961. 
47962. 
47963. CHAPTER XXVI
47964. 
47965. 
47966. Toward four o'clock in the afternoon Murat's troops were entering
47967. Moscow. In front rode a detachment of Wurttemberg hussars and behind
47968. them rode the King of Naples himself accompanied by a numerous suite.
47969. 
47970. About the middle of the Arbat Street, near the Church of the Miraculous
47971. Icon of St. Nicholas, Murat halted to await news from the advanced
47972. detachment as to the condition in which they had found the citadel, le
47973. Kremlin.
47974. 
47975. Around Murat gathered a group of those who had remained in Moscow. They
47976. all stared in timid bewilderment at the strange, long-haired commander
47977. dressed up in feathers and gold.
47978. 
47979. "Is that their Tsar himself? He's not bad!" low voices could be heard
47980. saying.
47981. 
47982. An interpreter rode up to the group.
47983. 
47984. "Take off your cap... your caps!" These words went from one to another
47985. in the crowd. The interpreter addressed an old porter and asked if
47986. it was far to the Kremlin. The porter, listening in perplexity to the
47987. unfamiliar Polish accent and not realizing that the interpreter was
47988. speaking Russian, did not understand what was being said to him and
47989. slipped behind the others.
47990. 
47991. Murat approached the interpreter and told him to ask where the Russian
47992. army was. One of the Russians understood what was asked and several
47993. voices at once began answering the interpreter. A French officer,
47994. returning from the advanced detachment, rode up to Murat and reported
47995. that the gates of the citadel had been barricaded and that there was
47996. probably an ambuscade there.
47997. 
47998. "Good!" said Murat and, turning to one of the gentlemen in his suite,
47999. ordered four light guns to be moved forward to fire at the gates.
48000. 
48001. The guns emerged at a trot from the column following Murat and advanced
48002. up the Arbat. When they reached the end of the Vozdvizhenka Street they
48003. halted and drew in the Square. Several French officers superintended the
48004. placing of the guns and looked at the Kremlin through field glasses.
48005. 
48006. The bells in the Kremlin were ringing for vespers, and this sound
48007. troubled the French. They imagined it to be a call to arms. A few
48008. infantrymen ran to the Kutafyev Gate. Beams and wooden screens had been
48009. put there, and two musket shots rang out from under the gate as soon as
48010. an officer and men began to run toward it. A general who was standing
48011. by the guns shouted some words of command to the officer, and the latter
48012. ran back again with his men.
48013. 
48014. The sound of three more shots came from the gate.
48015. 
48016. One shot struck a French soldier's foot, and from behind the screens
48017. came the strange sound of a few voices shouting. Instantly as at a
48018. word of command the expression of cheerful serenity on the faces of
48019. the French general, officers, and men changed to one of determined
48020. concentrated readiness for strife and suffering. To all of them from
48021. the marshal to the least soldier, that place was not the Vozdvizhenka,
48022. Mokhavaya, or Kutafyev Street, nor the Troitsa Gate (places familiar in
48023. Moscow), but a new battlefield which would probably prove sanguinary.
48024. And all made ready for that battle. The cries from the gates ceased. The
48025. guns were advanced, the artillerymen blew the ash off their linstocks,
48026. and an officer gave the word "Fire!" This was followed by two whistling
48027. sounds of canister shot, one after another. The shot rattled against
48028. the stone of the gate and upon the wooden beams and screens, and two
48029. wavering clouds of smoke rose over the Square.
48030. 
48031. A few instants after the echo of the reports resounding over the
48032. stone-built Kremlin had died away the French heard a strange sound above
48033. their head. Thousands of crows rose above the walls and circled in the
48034. air, cawing and noisily flapping their wings. Together with that sound
48035. came a solitary human cry from the gateway and amid the smoke appeared
48036. the figure of a bareheaded man in a peasant's coat. He grasped a musket
48037. and took aim at the French. "Fire!" repeated the officer once more,
48038. and the reports of a musket and of two cannon shots were heard
48039. simultaneously. The gate was again hidden by smoke.
48040. 
48041. Nothing more stirred behind the screens and the French infantry soldiers
48042. and officers advanced to the gate. In the gateway lay three wounded and
48043. four dead. Two men in peasant coats ran away at the foot of the wall,
48044. toward the Znamenka.
48045. 
48046. "Clear that away!" said the officer, pointing to the beams and the
48047. corpses, and the French soldiers, after dispatching the wounded, threw
48048. the corpses over the parapet.
48049. 
48050. Who these men were nobody knew. "Clear that away!" was all that was said
48051. of them, and they were thrown over the parapet and removed later on that
48052. they might not stink. Thiers alone dedicates a few eloquent lines to
48053. their memory: "These wretches had occupied the sacred citadel, having
48054. supplied themselves with guns from the arsenal, and fired" (the
48055. wretches) "at the French. Some of them were sabered and the Kremlin was
48056. purged of their presence."
48057. 
48058. Murat was informed that the way had been cleared. The French entered
48059. the gates and began pitching their camp in the Senate Square. Out of the
48060. windows of the Senate House the soldiers threw chairs into the Square
48061. for fuel and kindled fires there.
48062. 
48063. Other detachments passed through the Kremlin and encamped along
48064. the Moroseyka, the Lubyanka, and Pokrovka Streets. Others quartered
48065. themselves along the Vozdvizhenka, the Nikolski, and the Tverskoy
48066. Streets. No masters of the houses being found anywhere, the French were
48067. not billeted on the inhabitants as is usual in towns but lived in it as
48068. in a camp.
48069. 
48070. Though tattered, hungry, worn out, and reduced to a third of their
48071. original number, the French entered Moscow in good marching order. It
48072. was a weary and famished, but still a fighting and menacing army. But
48073. it remained an army only until its soldiers had dispersed into their
48074. different lodgings. As soon as the men of the various regiments began
48075. to disperse among the wealthy and deserted houses, the army was lost
48076. forever and there came into being something nondescript, neither
48077. citizens nor soldiers but what are known as marauders. When five weeks
48078. later these same men left Moscow, they no longer formed an army. They
48079. were a mob of marauders, each carrying a quantity of articles which
48080. seemed to him valuable or useful. The aim of each man when he left
48081. Moscow was no longer, as it had been, to conquer, but merely to keep
48082. what he had acquired. Like a monkey which puts its paw into the narrow
48083. neck of a jug, and having seized a handful of nuts will not open its
48084. fist for fear of losing what it holds, and therefore perishes, the
48085. French when they left Moscow had inevitably to perish because they
48086. carried their loot with them, yet to abandon what they had stolen was as
48087. impossible for them as it is for the monkey to open its paw and let
48088. go of its nuts. Ten minutes after each regiment had entered a Moscow
48089. district, not a soldier or officer was left. Men in military uniforms
48090. and Hessian boots could be seen through the windows, laughing and
48091. walking through the rooms. In cellars and storerooms similar men were
48092. busy among the provisions, and in the yards unlocking or breaking open
48093. coach house and stable doors, lighting fires in kitchens and kneading
48094. and baking bread with rolled-up sleeves, and cooking; or frightening,
48095. amusing, or caressing women and children. There were many such men both
48096. in the shops and houses--but there was no army.
48097. 
48098. Order after order was issued by the French commanders that day
48099. forbidding the men to disperse about the town, sternly forbidding any
48100. violence to the inhabitants or any looting, and announcing a roll call
48101. for that very evening. But despite all these measures the men, who had
48102. till then constituted an army, flowed all over the wealthy, deserted
48103. city with its comforts and plentiful supplies. As a hungry herd of
48104. cattle keeps well together when crossing a barren field, but gets out
48105. of hand and at once disperses uncontrollably as soon as it reaches rich
48106. pastures, so did the army disperse all over the wealthy city.
48107. 
48108. No residents were left in Moscow, and the soldiers--like water
48109. percolating through sand--spread irresistibly through the city in all
48110. directions from the Kremlin into which they had first marched. The
48111. cavalry, on entering a merchant's house that had been abandoned and
48112. finding there stabling more than sufficient for their horses, went on,
48113. all the same, to the next house which seemed to them better. Many of
48114. them appropriated several houses, chalked their names on them, and
48115. quarreled and even fought with other companies for them. Before they had
48116. had time to secure quarters the soldiers ran out into the streets to
48117. see the city and, hearing that everything had been abandoned, rushed
48118. to places where valuables were to be had for the taking. The officers
48119. followed to check the soldiers and were involuntarily drawn into doing
48120. the same. In Carriage Row carriages had been left in the shops, and
48121. generals flocked there to select caleches and coaches for themselves.
48122. The few inhabitants who had remained invited commanding officers to
48123. their houses, hoping thereby to secure themselves from being plundered.
48124. There were masses of wealth and there seemed no end to it. All around
48125. the quarters occupied by the French were other regions still unexplored
48126. and unoccupied where, they thought, yet greater riches might be found.
48127. And Moscow engulfed the army ever deeper and deeper. When water is
48128. spilled on dry ground both the dry ground and the water disappear and
48129. mud results; and in the same way the entry of the famished army into the
48130. rich and deserted city resulted in fires and looting and the destruction
48131. of both the army and the wealthy city.
48132. 
48133. 
48134. The French attributed the Fire of Moscow au patriotisme feroce de
48135. Rostopchine, * the Russians to the barbarity of the French. In reality,
48136. however, it was not, and could not be, possible to explain the burning
48137. of Moscow by making any individual, or any group of people, responsible
48138. for it. Moscow was burned because it found itself in a position in which
48139. any town built of wood was bound to burn, quite apart from whether it
48140. had, or had not, a hundred and thirty inferior fire engines. Deserted
48141. Moscow had to burn as inevitably as a heap of shavings has to burn on
48142. which sparks continually fall for several days. A town built of wood,
48143. where scarcely a day passes without conflagrations when the house owners
48144. are in residence and a police force is present, cannot help burning when
48145. its inhabitants have left it and it is occupied by soldiers who smoke
48146. pipes, make campfires of the Senate chairs in the Senate Square, and
48147. cook themselves meals twice a day. In peacetime it is only necessary to
48148. billet troops in the villages of any district and the number of fires in
48149. that district immediately increases. How much then must the probability
48150. of fire be increased in an abandoned, wooden town where foreign troops
48151. are quartered. "Le patriotisme feroce de Rostopchine" and the barbarity
48152. of the French were not to blame in the matter. Moscow was set on fire by
48153. the soldiers' pipes, kitchens, and campfires, and by the carelessness of
48154. enemy soldiers occupying houses they did not own. Even if there was any
48155. arson (which is very doubtful, for no one had any reason to burn the
48156. houses--in any case a troublesome and dangerous thing to do), arson
48157. cannot be regarded as the cause, for the same thing would have happened
48158. without any incendiarism.
48159. 
48160. 
48161.     * To Rostopchin's ferocious patriotism.
48162. 
48163. 
48164. However tempting it might be for the French to blame Rostopchin's
48165. ferocity and for Russians to blame the scoundrel Bonaparte, or later
48166. on to place an heroic torch in the hands of their own people, it is
48167. impossible not to see that there could be no such direct cause of the
48168. fire, for Moscow had to burn as every village, factory, or house must
48169. burn which is left by its owners and in which strangers are allowed to
48170. live and cook their porridge. Moscow was burned by its inhabitants, it
48171. is true, but by those who had abandoned it and not by those who remained
48172. in it. Moscow when occupied by the enemy did not remain intact like
48173. Berlin, Vienna, and other towns, simply because its inhabitants
48174. abandoned it and did not welcome the French with bread and salt, nor
48175. bring them the keys of the city.
48176. 
48177. 
48178. 
48179. 
48180. 
48181. CHAPTER XXVII
48182. 
48183. 
48184. The absorption of the French by Moscow, radiating starwise as it did,
48185. only reached the quarter where Pierre was staying by the evening of the
48186. second of September.
48187. 
48188. After the last two days spent in solitude and unusual circumstances,
48189. Pierre was in a state bordering on insanity. He was completely obsessed
48190. by one persistent thought. He did not know how or when this thought had
48191. taken such possession of him, but he remembered nothing of the past,
48192. understood nothing of the present, and all he saw and heard appeared to
48193. him like a dream.
48194. 
48195. He had left home only to escape the intricate tangle of life's demands
48196. that enmeshed him, and which in his present condition he was unable
48197. to unravel. He had gone to Joseph Alexeevich's house, on the plea of
48198. sorting the deceased's books and papers, only in search of rest from
48199. life's turmoil, for in his mind the memory of Joseph Alexeevich was
48200. connected with a world of eternal, solemn, and calm thoughts, quite
48201. contrary to the restless confusion into which he felt himself being
48202. drawn. He sought a quiet refuge, and in Joseph Alexeevich's study he
48203. really found it. When he sat with his elbows on the dusty writing table
48204. in the deathlike stillness of the study, calm and significant memories
48205. of the last few days rose one after another in his imagination,
48206. particularly of the battle of Borodino and of that vague sense of his
48207. own insignificance and insincerity compared with the truth, simplicity,
48208. and strength of the class of men he mentally classed as they. When
48209. Gerasim roused him from his reverie the idea occurred to him of taking
48210. part in the popular defense of Moscow which he knew was projected. And
48211. with that object he had asked Gerasim to get him a peasant's coat and
48212. a pistol, confiding to him his intentions of remaining in Joseph
48213. Alexeevich's house and keeping his name secret. Then during the first
48214. day spent in inaction and solitude (he tried several times to fix his
48215. attention on the Masonic manuscripts, but was unable to do so) the idea
48216. that had previously occurred to him of the cabalistic significance of
48217. his name in connection with Bonaparte's more than once vaguely presented
48218. itself. But the idea that he, L'russe Besuhof, was destined to set a
48219. limit to the power of the Beast was as yet only one of the fancies that
48220. often passed through his mind and left no trace behind.
48221. 
48222. When, having bought the coat merely with the object of taking part among
48223. the people in the defense of Moscow, Pierre had met the Rostovs and
48224. Natasha had said to him: "Are you remaining in Moscow?... How splendid!"
48225. the thought flashed into his mind that it really would be a good thing,
48226. even if Moscow were taken, for him to remain there and do what he was
48227. predestined to do.
48228. 
48229. Next day, with the sole idea of not sparing himself and not lagging in
48230. any way behind them, Pierre went to the Three Hills gate. But when he
48231. returned to the house convinced that Moscow would not be defended, he
48232. suddenly felt that what before had seemed to him merely a possibility
48233. had now become absolutely necessary and inevitable. He must remain in
48234. Moscow, concealing his name, and must meet Napoleon and kill him, and
48235. either perish or put an end to the misery of all Europe--which it seemed
48236. to him was solely due to Napoleon.
48237. 
48238. Pierre knew all the details of the attempt on Bonaparte's life in 1809
48239. by a German student in Vienna, and knew that the student had been shot.
48240. And the risk to which he would expose his life by carrying out his
48241. design excited him still more.
48242. 
48243. Two equally strong feelings drew Pierre irresistibly to this purpose.
48244. The first was a feeling of the necessity of sacrifice and suffering in
48245. view of the common calamity, the same feeling that had caused him to go
48246. to Mozhaysk on the twenty-fifth and to make his way to the very thick
48247. of the battle and had now caused him to run away from his home and, in
48248. place of the luxury and comfort to which he was accustomed, to sleep
48249. on a hard sofa without undressing and eat the same food as Gerasim.
48250. The other was that vague and quite Russian feeling of contempt for
48251. everything conventional, artificial, and human--for everything the
48252. majority of men regard as the greatest good in the world. Pierre had
48253. first experienced this strange and fascinating feeling at the Sloboda
48254. Palace, when he had suddenly felt that wealth, power, and life--all that
48255. men so painstakingly acquire and guard--if it has any worth has so only
48256. by reason of the joy with which it can all be renounced.
48257. 
48258. It was the feeling that induces a volunteer recruit to spend his last
48259. penny on drink, and a drunken man to smash mirrors or glasses for no
48260. apparent reason and knowing that it will cost him all the money he
48261. possesses: the feeling which causes a man to perform actions which from
48262. an ordinary point of view are insane, to test, as it were, his personal
48263. power and strength, affirming the existence of a higher, nonhuman
48264. criterion of life.
48265. 
48266. From the very day Pierre had experienced this feeling for the first time
48267. at the Sloboda Palace he had been continuously under its influence, but
48268. only now found full satisfaction for it. Moreover, at this moment Pierre
48269. was supported in his design and prevented from renouncing it by what he
48270. had already done in that direction. If he were now to leave Moscow like
48271. everyone else, his flight from home, the peasant coat, the pistol, and
48272. his announcement to the Rostovs that he would remain in Moscow would all
48273. become not merely meaningless but contemptible and ridiculous, and to
48274. this Pierre was very sensitive.
48275. 
48276. Pierre's physical condition, as is always the case, corresponded to his
48277. mental state. The unaccustomed coarse food, the vodka he drank during
48278. those days, the absence of wine and cigars, his dirty unchanged linen,
48279. two almost sleepless nights passed on a short sofa without bedding--all
48280. this kept him in a state of excitement bordering on insanity.
48281. 
48282. It was two o'clock in the afternoon. The French had already entered
48283. Moscow. Pierre knew this, but instead of acting he only thought about
48284. his undertaking, going over its minutest details in his mind. In his
48285. fancy he did not clearly picture to himself either the striking of the
48286. blow or the death of Napoleon, but with extraordinary vividness and
48287. melancholy enjoyment imagined his own destruction and heroic endurance.
48288. 
48289. "Yes, alone, for the sake of all, I must do it or perish!" he thought.
48290. "Yes, I will approach... and then suddenly... with pistol or dagger?
48291. But that is all the same! 'It is not I but the hand of Providence that
48292. punishes thee,' I shall say," thought he, imagining what he would say
48293. when killing Napoleon. "Well then, take me and execute me!" he went on,
48294. speaking to himself and bowing his head with a sad but firm expression.
48295. 
48296. While Pierre, standing in the middle of the room, was talking to himself
48297. in this way, the study door opened and on the threshold appeared
48298. the figure of Makar Alexeevich, always so timid before but now quite
48299. transformed.
48300. 
48301. His dressing gown was unfastened, his face red and distorted. He
48302. was obviously drunk. On seeing Pierre he grew confused at first, but
48303. noticing embarrassment on Pierre's face immediately grew bold and,
48304. staggering on his thin legs, advanced into the middle of the room.
48305. 
48306. "They're frightened," he said confidentially in a hoarse voice. "I say I
48307. won't surrender, I say... Am I not right, sir?"
48308. 
48309. He paused and then suddenly seeing the pistol on the table seized it
48310. with unexpected rapidity and ran out into the corridor.
48311. 
48312. Gerasim and the porter, who had followed Makar Alexeevich, stopped him
48313. in the vestibule and tried to take the pistol from him. Pierre, coming
48314. out into the corridor, looked with pity and repulsion at the half-crazy
48315. old man. Makar Alexeevich, frowning with exertion, held on to the pistol
48316. and screamed hoarsely, evidently with some heroic fancy in his head.
48317. 
48318. "To arms! Board them! No, you shan't get it," he yelled.
48319. 
48320. "That will do, please, that will do. Have the goodness--please, sir, to
48321. let go! Please, sir..." pleaded Gerasim, trying carefully to steer Makar
48322. Alexeevich by the elbows back to the door.
48323. 
48324. "Who are you? Bonaparte!..." shouted Makar Alexeevich.
48325. 
48326. "That's not right, sir. Come to your room, please, and rest. Allow me to
48327. have the pistol."
48328. 
48329. "Be off, thou base slave! Touch me not! See this?" shouted Makar
48330. Alexeevich, brandishing the pistol. "Board them!"
48331. 
48332. "Catch hold!" whispered Gerasim to the porter.
48333. 
48334. They seized Makar Alexeevich by the arms and dragged him to the door.
48335. 
48336. The vestibule was filled with the discordant sounds of a struggle and of
48337. a tipsy, hoarse voice.
48338. 
48339. Suddenly a fresh sound, a piercing feminine scream, reverberated from
48340. the porch and the cook came running into the vestibule.
48341. 
48342. "It's them! Gracious heavens! O Lord, four of them, horsemen!" she
48343. cried.
48344. 
48345. Gerasim and the porter let Makar Alexeevich go, and in the now silent
48346. corridor the sound of several hands knocking at the front door could be
48347. heard.
48348. 
48349. 
48350. 
48351. 
48352. 
48353. CHAPTER XXVIII
48354. 
48355. 
48356. Pierre, having decided that until he had carried out his design he would
48357. disclose neither his identity nor his knowledge of French, stood at the
48358. half-open door of the corridor, intending to conceal himself as soon
48359. as the French entered. But the French entered and still Pierre did not
48360. retire--an irresistible curiosity kept him there.
48361. 
48362. There were two of them. One was an officer--a tall, soldierly, handsome
48363. man--the other evidently a private or an orderly, sunburned, short, and
48364. thin, with sunken cheeks and a dull expression. The officer walked in
48365. front, leaning on a stick and slightly limping. When he had advanced
48366. a few steps he stopped, having apparently decided that these were good
48367. quarters, turned round to the soldiers standing at the entrance, and in
48368. a loud voice of command ordered them to put up the horses. Having done
48369. that, the officer, lifting his elbow with a smart gesture, stroked his
48370. mustache and lightly touched his hat.
48371. 
48372. "Bonjour, la compagnie!" * said he gaily, smiling and looking about him.
48373. 
48374. 
48375.     * "Good day, everybody!"
48376. 
48377. 
48378. No one gave any reply.
48379. 
48380. "Vous etes le bourgeois?" * the officer asked Gerasim.
48381. 
48382. 
48383.     * "Are you the master here?"
48384. 
48385. 
48386. Gerasim gazed at the officer with an alarmed and inquiring look.
48387. 
48388. "Quartier, quartier, logement!" said the officer, looking down at the
48389. little man with a condescending and good-natured smile. "Les francais
48390. sont de bons enfants. Que diable! Voyons! Ne nous fachons pas, mon
48391. vieux!" * added he, clapping the scared and silent Gerasim on the
48392. shoulder. "Well, does no one speak French in this establishment?" he
48393. asked again in French, looking around and meeting Pierre's eyes. Pierre
48394. moved away from the door.
48395. 
48396. 
48397.      * "Quarters, quarters, lodgings! The French are good
48398.      fellows. What the devil! There, don't let us be cross, old
48399.      fellow!"
48400. 
48401. 
48402. Again the officer turned to Gerasim and asked him to show him the rooms
48403. in the house.
48404. 
48405. "Master, not here--don't understand... me, you..." said Gerasim, trying
48406. to render his words more comprehensible by contorting them.
48407. 
48408. Still smiling, the French officer spread out his hands before Gerasim's
48409. nose, intimating that he did not understand him either, and moved,
48410. limping, to the door at which Pierre was standing. Pierre wished to go
48411. away and conceal himself, but at that moment he saw Makar Alexeevich
48412. appearing at the open kitchen door with the pistol in his hand. With
48413. a madman's cunning, Makar Alexeevich eyed the Frenchman, raised his
48414. pistol, and took aim.
48415. 
48416. "Board them!" yelled the tipsy man, trying to press the trigger. Hearing
48417. the yell the officer turned round, and at the same moment Pierre threw
48418. himself on the drunkard. Just when Pierre snatched at and struck up the
48419. pistol Makar Alexeevich at last got his fingers on the trigger, there
48420. was a deafening report, and all were enveloped in a cloud of smoke. The
48421. Frenchman turned pale and rushed to the door.
48422. 
48423. Forgetting his intention of concealing his knowledge of French, Pierre,
48424. snatching away the pistol and throwing it down, ran up to the officer
48425. and addressed him in French.
48426. 
48427. "You are not wounded?" he asked.
48428. 
48429. "I think not," answered the Frenchman, feeling himself over. "But I have
48430. had a lucky escape this time," he added, pointing to the damaged plaster
48431. of the wall. "Who is that man?" said he, looking sternly at Pierre.
48432. 
48433. "Oh, I am really in despair at what has occurred," said Pierre rapidly,
48434. quite forgetting the part he had intended to play. "He is an unfortunate
48435. madman who did not know what he was doing."
48436. 
48437. The officer went up to Makar Alexeevich and took him by the collar.
48438. 
48439. Makar Alexeevich was standing with parted lips, swaying, as if about to
48440. fall asleep, as he leaned against the wall.
48441. 
48442. "Brigand! You shall pay for this," said the Frenchman, letting go
48443. of him. "We French are merciful after victory, but we do not pardon
48444. traitors," he added, with a look of gloomy dignity and a fine energetic
48445. gesture.
48446. 
48447. Pierre continued, in French, to persuade the officer not to hold that
48448. drunken imbecile to account. The Frenchman listened in silence with the
48449. same gloomy expression, but suddenly turned to Pierre with a smile. For
48450. a few seconds he looked at him in silence. His handsome face assumed a
48451. melodramatically gentle expression and he held out his hand.
48452. 
48453. "You have saved my life. You are French," said he.
48454. 
48455. For a Frenchman that deduction was indubitable. Only a Frenchman could
48456. perform a great deed, and to save his life--the life of M. Ramballe,
48457. captain of the 13th Light Regiment--was undoubtedly a very great deed.
48458. 
48459. But however indubitable that conclusion and the officer's conviction
48460. based upon it, Pierre felt it necessary to disillusion him.
48461. 
48462. "I am Russian," he said quickly.
48463. 
48464. "Tut, tut, tut! Tell that to others," said the officer, waving his
48465. finger before his nose and smiling. "You shall tell me all about that
48466. presently. I am delighted to meet a compatriot. Well, and what are we
48467. to do with this man?" he added, addressing himself to Pierre as to a
48468. brother.
48469. 
48470. Even if Pierre were not a Frenchman, having once received that loftiest
48471. of human appellations he could not renounce it, said the officer's look
48472. and tone. In reply to his last question Pierre again explained who Makar
48473. Alexeevich was and how just before their arrival that drunken imbecile
48474. had seized the loaded pistol which they had not had time to recover from
48475. him, and begged the officer to let the deed go unpunished.
48476. 
48477. The Frenchman expanded his chest and made a majestic gesture with his
48478. arm.
48479. 
48480. "You have saved my life! You are French. You ask his pardon? I grant it
48481. you. Lead that man away!" said he quickly and energetically, and taking
48482. the arm of Pierre whom he had promoted to be a Frenchman for saving his
48483. life, he went with him into the room.
48484. 
48485. The soldiers in the yard, hearing the shot, came into the passage asking
48486. what had happened, and expressed their readiness to punish the culprits,
48487. but the officer sternly checked them.
48488. 
48489. "You will be called in when you are wanted," he said.
48490. 
48491. The soldiers went out again, and the orderly, who had meanwhile had time
48492. to visit the kitchen, came up to his officer.
48493. 
48494. "Captain, there is soup and a leg of mutton in the kitchen," said he.
48495. "Shall I serve them up?"
48496. 
48497. "Yes, and some wine," answered the captain.
48498. 
48499. 
48500. 
48501. 
48502. 
48503. CHAPTER XXIX
48504. 
48505. 
48506. When the French officer went into the room with Pierre the latter again
48507. thought it his duty to assure him that he was not French and wished to
48508. go away, but the officer would not hear of it. He was so very polite,
48509. amiable, good-natured, and genuinely grateful to Pierre for saving his
48510. life that Pierre had not the heart to refuse, and sat down with him in
48511. the parlor--the first room they entered. To Pierre's assurances that he
48512. was not a Frenchman, the captain, evidently not understanding how anyone
48513. could decline so flattering an appellation, shrugged his shoulders and
48514. said that if Pierre absolutely insisted on passing for a Russian let it
48515. be so, but for all that he would be forever bound to Pierre by gratitude
48516. for saving his life.
48517. 
48518. Had this man been endowed with the slightest capacity for perceiving the
48519. feelings of others, and had he at all understood what Pierre's feelings
48520. were, the latter would probably have left him, but the man's animated
48521. obtuseness to everything other than himself disarmed Pierre.
48522. 
48523. "A Frenchman or a Russian prince incognito," said the officer, looking
48524. at Pierre's fine though dirty linen and at the ring on his finger.
48525. "I owe my life to you and offer you my friendship. A Frenchman never
48526. forgets either an insult or a service. I offer you my friendship. That
48527. is all I can say."
48528. 
48529. There was so much good nature and nobility (in the French sense of the
48530. word) in the officer's voice, in the expression of his face and in
48531. his gestures, that Pierre, unconsciously smiling in response to the
48532. Frenchman's smile, pressed the hand held out to him.
48533. 
48534. "Captain Ramballe, of the 13th Light Regiment, Chevalier of the Legion
48535. of Honor for the affair on the seventh of September," he introduced
48536. himself, a self-satisfied irrepressible smile puckering his lips under
48537. his mustache. "Will you now be so good as to tell me with whom I have
48538. the honor of conversing so pleasantly, instead of being in the ambulance
48539. with that maniac's bullet in my body?"
48540. 
48541. Pierre replied that he could not tell him his name and, blushing,
48542. began to try to invent a name and to say something about his reason for
48543. concealing it, but the Frenchman hastily interrupted him.
48544. 
48545. "Oh, please!" said he. "I understand your reasons. You are an officer...
48546. a superior officer perhaps. You have borne arms against us. That's not
48547. my business. I owe you my life. That is enough for me. I am quite at
48548. your service. You belong to the gentry?" he concluded with a shade of
48549. inquiry in his tone. Pierre bent his head. "Your baptismal name, if you
48550. please. That is all I ask. Monsieur Pierre, you say.... That's all I
48551. want to know."
48552. 
48553. When the mutton and an omelet had been served and a samovar and vodka
48554. brought, with some wine which the French had taken from a Russian cellar
48555. and brought with them, Ramballe invited Pierre to share his dinner, and
48556. himself began to eat greedily and quickly like a healthy and hungry man,
48557. munching his food rapidly with his strong teeth, continually smacking
