48558. his lips, and repeating--"Excellent! Delicious!" His face grew red and
48559. was covered with perspiration. Pierre was hungry and shared the dinner
48560. with pleasure. Morel, the orderly, brought some hot water in a saucepan
48561. and placed a bottle of claret in it. He also brought a bottle of kvass,
48562. taken from the kitchen for them to try. That beverage was already known
48563. to the French and had been given a special name. They called it limonade
48564. de cochon (pig's lemonade), and Morel spoke well of the limonade de
48565. cochon he had found in the kitchen. But as the captain had the wine they
48566. had taken while passing through Moscow, he left the kvass to Morel and
48567. applied himself to the bottle of Bordeaux. He wrapped the bottle up
48568. to its neck in a table napkin and poured out wine for himself and for
48569. Pierre. The satisfaction of his hunger and the wine rendered the captain
48570. still more lively and he chatted incessantly all through dinner.
48571. 
48572. "Yes, my dear Monsieur Pierre, I owe you a fine votive candle for
48573. saving me from that maniac.... You see, I have bullets enough in my
48574. body already. Here is one I got at Wagram" (he touched his side) "and a
48575. second at Smolensk"--he showed a scar on his cheek--"and this leg which
48576. as you see does not want to march, I got that on the seventh at the
48577. great battle of la Moskowa. Sacre Dieu! It was splendid! That deluge of
48578. fire was worth seeing. It was a tough job you set us there, my word!
48579. You may be proud of it! And on my honor, in spite of the cough I caught
48580. there, I should be ready to begin again. I pity those who did not see
48581. it."
48582. 
48583. "I was there," said Pierre.
48584. 
48585. "Bah, really? So much the better! You are certainly brave foes. The
48586. great redoubt held out well, by my pipe!" continued the Frenchman. "And
48587. you made us pay dear for it. I was at it three times--sure as I sit
48588. here. Three times we reached the guns and three times we were thrown
48589. back like cardboard figures. Oh, it was beautiful, Monsieur Pierre! Your
48590. grenadiers were splendid, by heaven! I saw them close up their ranks six
48591. times in succession and march as if on parade. Fine fellows! Our King of
48592. Naples, who knows what's what, cried 'Bravo!' Ha, ha! So you are one of
48593. us soldiers!" he added, smiling, after a momentary pause. "So much
48594. the better, so much the better, Monsieur Pierre! Terrible in battle...
48595. gallant... with the fair" (he winked and smiled), "that's what the
48596. French are, Monsieur Pierre, aren't they?"
48597. 
48598. The captain was so naively and good-humoredly gay, so real, and so
48599. pleased with himself that Pierre almost winked back as he looked merrily
48600. at him. Probably the word "gallant" turned the captain's thoughts to the
48601. state of Moscow.
48602. 
48603. "Apropos, tell me please, is it true that the women have all left
48604. Moscow? What a queer idea! What had they to be afraid of?"
48605. 
48606. "Would not the French ladies leave Paris if the Russians entered it?"
48607. asked Pierre.
48608. 
48609. "Ha, ha, ha!" The Frenchman emitted a merry, sanguine chuckle, patting
48610. Pierre on the shoulder. "What a thing to say!" he exclaimed. "Paris?...
48611. But Paris, Paris..."
48612. 
48613. "Paris--the capital of the world," Pierre finished his remark for him.
48614. 
48615. The captain looked at Pierre. He had a habit of stopping short in the
48616. middle of his talk and gazing intently with his laughing, kindly eyes.
48617. 
48618. "Well, if you hadn't told me you were Russian, I should have wagered
48619. that you were Parisian! You have that... I don't know what, that..." and
48620. having uttered this compliment, he again gazed at him in silence.
48621. 
48622. "I have been in Paris. I spent years there," said Pierre.
48623. 
48624. "Oh yes, one sees that plainly. Paris!... A man who doesn't know Paris
48625. is a savage. You can tell a Parisian two leagues off. Paris is Talma, la
48626. Duchenois, Potier, the Sorbonne, the boulevards," and noticing that
48627. his conclusion was weaker than what had gone before, he added quickly:
48628. "There is only one Paris in the world. You have been to Paris and have
48629. remained Russian. Well, I don't esteem you the less for it."
48630. 
48631. Under the influence of the wine he had drunk, and after the days he had
48632. spent alone with his depressing thoughts, Pierre involuntarily enjoyed
48633. talking with this cheerful and good-natured man.
48634. 
48635. "To return to your ladies--I hear they are lovely. What a wretched idea
48636. to go and bury themselves in the steppes when the French army is
48637. in Moscow. What a chance those girls have missed! Your peasants,
48638. now--that's another thing; but you civilized people, you ought to know
48639. us better than that. We took Vienna, Berlin, Madrid, Naples, Rome,
48640. Warsaw, all the world's capitals.... We are feared, but we are loved.
48641. We are nice to know. And then the Emperor..." he began, but Pierre
48642. interrupted him.
48643. 
48644. "The Emperor," Pierre repeated, and his face suddenly became sad and
48645. embarrassed, "is the Emperor...?"
48646. 
48647. "The Emperor? He is generosity, mercy, justice, order, genius--that's
48648. what the Emperor is! It is I, Ramballe, who tell you so.... I assure you
48649. I was his enemy eight years ago. My father was an emigrant count.... But
48650. that man has vanquished me. He has taken hold of me. I could not resist
48651. the sight of the grandeur and glory with which he has covered France.
48652. When I understood what he wanted--when I saw that he was preparing a bed
48653. of laurels for us, you know, I said to myself: 'That is a monarch,' and
48654. I devoted myself to him! So there! Oh yes, mon cher, he is the greatest
48655. man of the ages past or future."
48656. 
48657. "Is he in Moscow?" Pierre stammered with a guilty look.
48658. 
48659. The Frenchman looked at his guilty face and smiled.
48660. 
48661. "No, he will make his entry tomorrow," he replied, and continued his
48662. talk.
48663. 
48664. Their conversation was interrupted by the cries of several voices at
48665. the gate and by Morel, who came to say that some Wurttemberg hussars had
48666. come and wanted to put up their horses in the yard where the captain's
48667. horses were. This difficulty had arisen chiefly because the hussars did
48668. not understand what was said to them in French.
48669. 
48670. The captain had their senior sergeant called in, and in a stern voice
48671. asked him to what regiment he belonged, who was his commanding officer,
48672. and by what right he allowed himself to claim quarters that were already
48673. occupied. The German who knew little French, answered the two first
48674. questions by giving the names of his regiment and of his commanding
48675. officer, but in reply to the third question which he did not understand
48676. said, introducing broken French into his own German, that he was the
48677. quartermaster of the regiment and his commander had ordered him to
48678. occupy all the houses one after another. Pierre, who knew German,
48679. translated what the German said to the captain and gave the captain's
48680. reply to the Wurttemberg hussar in German. When he had understood what
48681. was said to him, the German submitted and took his men elsewhere. The
48682. captain went out into the porch and gave some orders in a loud voice.
48683. 
48684. When he returned to the room Pierre was sitting in the same place as
48685. before, with his head in his hands. His face expressed suffering. He
48686. really was suffering at that moment. When the captain went out and he
48687. was left alone, suddenly he came to himself and realized the position
48688. he was in. It was not that Moscow had been taken or that the happy
48689. conquerors were masters in it and were patronizing him. Painful as
48690. that was it was not that which tormented Pierre at the moment. He was
48691. tormented by the consciousness of his own weakness. The few glasses of
48692. wine he had drunk and the conversation with this good-natured man had
48693. destroyed the mood of concentrated gloom in which he had spent the last
48694. few days and which was essential for the execution of his design. The
48695. pistol, dagger, and peasant coat were ready. Napoleon was to enter the
48696. town next day. Pierre still considered that it would be a useful and
48697. worthy action to slay the evildoer, but now he felt that he would not
48698. do it. He did not know why, but he felt a foreboding that he would not
48699. carry out his intention. He struggled against the confession of his
48700. weakness but dimly felt that he could not overcome it and that his
48701. former gloomy frame of mind, concerning vengeance, killing, and
48702. self-sacrifice, had been dispersed like dust by contact with the first
48703. man he met.
48704. 
48705. The captain returned to the room, limping slightly and whistling a tune.
48706. 
48707. The Frenchman's chatter which had previously amused Pierre now repelled
48708. him. The tune he was whistling, his gait, and the gesture with which
48709. he twirled his mustache, all now seemed offensive. "I will go away
48710. immediately. I won't say another word to him," thought Pierre. He
48711. thought this, but still sat in the same place. A strange feeling of
48712. weakness tied him to the spot; he wished to get up and go away, but
48713. could not do so.
48714. 
48715. The captain, on the other hand, seemed very cheerful. He paced up and
48716. down the room twice. His eyes shone and his mustache twitched as if he
48717. were smiling to himself at some amusing thought.
48718. 
48719. "The colonel of those Wurttembergers is delightful," he suddenly said.
48720. "He's a German, but a nice fellow all the same.... But he's a German."
48721. He sat down facing Pierre. "By the way, you know German, then?"
48722. 
48723. Pierre looked at him in silence.
48724. 
48725. "What is the German for 'shelter'?"
48726. 
48727. "Shelter?" Pierre repeated. "The German for shelter is Unterkunft."
48728. 
48729. "How do you say it?" the captain asked quickly and doubtfully.
48730. 
48731. "Unterkunft," Pierre repeated.
48732. 
48733. "Onterkoff," said the captain and looked at Pierre for some seconds with
48734. laughing eyes. "These Germans are first-rate fools, don't you think so,
48735. Monsieur Pierre?" he concluded.
48736. 
48737. "Well, let's have another bottle of this Moscow Bordeaux, shall we?
48738. Morel will warm us up another little bottle. Morel!" he called out
48739. gaily.
48740. 
48741. Morel brought candles and a bottle of wine. The captain looked at Pierre
48742. by the candlelight and was evidently struck by the troubled expression
48743. on his companion's face. Ramballe, with genuine distress and sympathy in
48744. his face, went up to Pierre and bent over him.
48745. 
48746. "There now, we're sad," said he, touching Pierre's hand. "Have I
48747. upset you? No, really, have you anything against me?" he asked Pierre.
48748. "Perhaps it's the state of affairs?"
48749. 
48750. Pierre did not answer, but looked cordially into the Frenchman's eyes
48751. whose expression of sympathy was pleasing to him.
48752. 
48753. "Honestly, without speaking of what I owe you, I feel friendship for
48754. you. Can I do anything for you? Dispose of me. It is for life and death.
48755. I say it with my hand on my heart!" said he, striking his chest.
48756. 
48757. "Thank you," said Pierre.
48758. 
48759. The captain gazed intently at him as he had done when he learned that
48760. "shelter" was Unterkunft in German, and his face suddenly brightened.
48761. 
48762. "Well, in that case, I drink to our friendship!" he cried gaily, filling
48763. two glasses with wine.
48764. 
48765. Pierre took one of the glasses and emptied it. Ramballe emptied his too,
48766. again pressed Pierre's hand, and leaned his elbows on the table in a
48767. pensive attitude.
48768. 
48769. "Yes, my dear friend," he began, "such is fortune's caprice. Who would
48770. have said that I should be a soldier and a captain of dragoons in the
48771. service of Bonaparte, as we used to call him? Yet here I am in Moscow
48772. with him. I must tell you, mon cher," he continued in the sad and
48773. measured tones of a man who intends to tell a long story, "that our name
48774. is one of the most ancient in France."
48775. 
48776. And with a Frenchman's easy and naive frankness the captain told Pierre
48777. the story of his ancestors, his childhood, youth, and manhood, and all
48778. about his relations and his financial and family affairs, "ma pauvre
48779. mere" playing of course an important part in the story.
48780. 
48781. "But all that is only life's setting, the real thing is love--love! Am I
48782. not right, Monsieur Pierre?" said he, growing animated. "Another glass?"
48783. 
48784. Pierre again emptied his glass and poured himself out a third.
48785. 
48786. "Oh, women, women!" and the captain, looking with glistening eyes at
48787. Pierre, began talking of love and of his love affairs.
48788. 
48789. There were very many of these, as one could easily believe, looking
48790. at the officer's handsome, self-satisfied face, and noting the eager
48791. enthusiasm with which he spoke of women. Though all Ramballe's love
48792. stories had the sensual character which Frenchmen regard as the special
48793. charm and poetry of love, yet he told his story with such sincere
48794. conviction that he alone had experienced and known all the charm of love
48795. and he described women so alluringly that Pierre listened to him with
48796. curiosity.
48797. 
48798. It was plain that l'amour which the Frenchman was so fond of was not
48799. that low and simple kind that Pierre had once felt for his wife, nor
48800. was it the romantic love stimulated by himself that he experienced for
48801. Natasha. (Ramballe despised both these kinds of love equally: the one
48802. he considered the "love of clodhoppers" and the other the "love
48803. of simpletons.") L'amour which the Frenchman worshiped consisted
48804. principally in the unnaturalness of his relation to the woman and in a
48805. combination of incongruities giving the chief charm to the feeling.
48806. 
48807. Thus the captain touchingly recounted the story of his love for a
48808. fascinating marquise of thirty-five and at the same time for a charming,
48809. innocent child of seventeen, daughter of the bewitching marquise. The
48810. conflict of magnanimity between the mother and the daughter, ending in
48811. the mother's sacrificing herself and offering her daughter in marriage
48812. to her lover, even now agitated the captain, though it was the memory of
48813. a distant past. Then he recounted an episode in which the husband
48814. played the part of the lover, and he--the lover--assumed the role of the
48815. husband, as well as several droll incidents from his recollections of
48816. Germany, where "shelter" is called Unterkunft and where the husbands eat
48817. sauerkraut and the young girls are "too blonde."
48818. 
48819. Finally, the latest episode in Poland still fresh in the captain's
48820. memory, and which he narrated with rapid gestures and glowing face, was
48821. of how he had saved the life of a Pole (in general, the saving of
48822. life continually occurred in the captain's stories) and the Pole had
48823. entrusted to him his enchanting wife (parisienne de coeur) while himself
48824. entering the French service. The captain was happy, the enchanting
48825. Polish lady wished to elope with him, but, prompted by magnanimity, the
48826. captain restored the wife to the husband, saying as he did so: "I have
48827. saved your life, and I save your honor!" Having repeated these words the
48828. captain wiped his eyes and gave himself a shake, as if driving away the
48829. weakness which assailed him at this touching recollection.
48830. 
48831. Listening to the captain's tales, Pierre--as often happens late in the
48832. evening and under the influence of wine--followed all that was told him,
48833. understood it all, and at the same time followed a train of personal
48834. memories which, he knew not why, suddenly arose in his mind. While
48835. listening to these love stories his own love for Natasha unexpectedly
48836. rose to his mind, and going over the pictures of that love in his
48837. imagination he mentally compared them with Ramballe's tales. Listening
48838. to the story of the struggle between love and duty, Pierre saw before
48839. his eyes every minutest detail of his last meeting with the object of
48840. his love at the Sukharev water tower. At the time of that meeting it had
48841. not produced an effect upon him--he had not even once recalled it. But
48842. now it seemed to him that that meeting had had in it something very
48843. important and poetic.
48844. 
48845. "Peter Kirilovich, come here! We have recognized you," he now seemed
48846. to hear the words she had uttered and to see before him her eyes, her
48847. smile, her traveling hood, and a stray lock of her hair... and there
48848. seemed to him something pathetic and touching in all this.
48849. 
48850. Having finished his tale about the enchanting Polish lady, the captain
48851. asked Pierre if he had ever experienced a similar impulse to sacrifice
48852. himself for love and a feeling of envy of the legitimate husband.
48853. 
48854. Challenged by this question Pierre raised his head and felt a need to
48855. express the thoughts that filled his mind. He began to explain that he
48856. understood love for a women somewhat differently. He said that in all
48857. his life he had loved and still loved only one woman, and that she could
48858. never be his.
48859. 
48860. "Tiens!" said the captain.
48861. 
48862. Pierre then explained that he had loved this woman from his earliest
48863. years, but that he had not dared to think of her because she was too
48864. young, and because he had been an illegitimate son without a name.
48865. Afterwards when he had received a name and wealth he dared not think of
48866. her because he loved her too well, placing her far above everything in
48867. the world, and especially therefore above himself.
48868. 
48869. When he had reached this point, Pierre asked the captain whether he
48870. understood that.
48871. 
48872. The captain made a gesture signifying that even if he did not understand
48873. it he begged Pierre to continue.
48874. 
48875. "Platonic love, clouds..." he muttered.
48876. 
48877. Whether it was the wine he had drunk, or an impulse of frankness, or the
48878. thought that this man did not, and never would, know any of those who
48879. played a part in his story, or whether it was all these things together,
48880. something loosened Pierre's tongue. Speaking thickly and with a faraway
48881. look in his shining eyes, he told the whole story of his life: his
48882. marriage, Natasha's love for his best friend, her betrayal of him, and
48883. all his own simple relations with her. Urged on by Ramballe's questions
48884. he also told what he had at first concealed--his own position and even
48885. his name.
48886. 
48887. More than anything else in Pierre's story the captain was impressed by
48888. the fact that Pierre was very rich, had two mansions in Moscow, and that
48889. he had abandoned everything and not left the city, but remained there
48890. concealing his name and station.
48891. 
48892. When it was late at night they went out together into the street. The
48893. night was warm and light. To the left of the house on the Pokrovka a
48894. fire glowed--the first of those that were beginning in Moscow. To the
48895. right and high up in the sky was the sickle of the waning moon and
48896. opposite to it hung that bright comet which was connected in Pierre's
48897. heart with his love. At the gate stood Gerasim, the cook, and two
48898. Frenchmen. Their laughter and their mutually incomprehensible remarks in
48899. two languages could be heard. They were looking at the glow seen in the
48900. town.
48901. 
48902. There was nothing terrible in the one small, distant fire in the immense
48903. city.
48904. 
48905. Gazing at the high starry sky, at the moon, at the comet, and at the
48906. glow from the fire, Pierre experienced a joyful emotion. "There now,
48907. how good it is, what more does one need?" thought he. And suddenly
48908. remembering his intention he grew dizzy and felt so faint that he leaned
48909. against the fence to save himself from falling.
48910. 
48911. Without taking leave of his new friend, Pierre left the gate with
48912. unsteady steps and returning to his room lay down on the sofa and
48913. immediately fell asleep.
48914. 
48915. 
48916. 
48917. 
48918. 
48919. CHAPTER XXX
48920. 
48921. 
48922. The glow of the first fire that began on the second of September was
48923. watched from the various roads by the fugitive Muscovites and by the
48924. retreating troops, with many different feelings.
48925. 
48926. The Rostov party spent the night at Mytishchi, fourteen miles from
48927. Moscow. They had started so late on the first of September, the road
48928. had been so blocked by vehicles and troops, so many things had been
48929. forgotten for which servants were sent back, that they had decided to
48930. spend that night at a place three miles out of Moscow. The next morning
48931. they woke late and were again delayed so often that they only got as far
48932. as Great Mytishchi. At ten o'clock that evening the Rostov family and
48933. the wounded traveling with them were all distributed in the yards and
48934. huts of that large village. The Rostovs' servants and coachmen and the
48935. orderlies of the wounded officers, after attending to their masters, had
48936. supper, fed the horses, and came out into the porches.
48937. 
48938. In a neighboring hut lay Raevski's adjutant with a fractured wrist. The
48939. awful pain he suffered made him moan incessantly and piteously, and his
48940. moaning sounded terrible in the darkness of the autumn night. He had
48941. spent the first night in the same yard as the Rostovs. The countess said
48942. she had been unable to close her eyes on account of his moaning, and at
48943. Mytishchi she moved into a worse hut simply to be farther away from the
48944. wounded man.
48945. 
48946. In the darkness of the night one of the servants noticed, above the high
48947. body of a coach standing before the porch, the small glow of another
48948. fire. One glow had long been visible and everybody knew that it was
48949. Little Mytishchi burning--set on fire by Mamonov's Cossacks.
48950. 
48951. "But look here, brothers, there's another fire!" remarked an orderly.
48952. 
48953. All turned their attention to the glow.
48954. 
48955. "But they told us Little Mytishchi had been set on fire by Mamonov's
48956. Cossacks."
48957. 
48958. "But that's not Mytishchi, it's farther away."
48959. 
48960. "Look, it must be in Moscow!"
48961. 
48962. Two of the gazers went round to the other side of the coach and sat down
48963. on its steps.
48964. 
48965. "It's more to the left, why, Little Mytishchi is over there, and this is
48966. right on the other side."
48967. 
48968. Several men joined the first two.
48969. 
48970. "See how it's flaring," said one. "That's a fire in Moscow: either in
48971. the Sushchevski or the Rogozhski quarter."
48972. 
48973. No one replied to this remark and for some time they all gazed silently
48974. at the spreading flames of the second fire in the distance.
48975. 
48976. Old Daniel Terentich, the count's valet (as he was called), came up to
48977. the group and shouted at Mishka.
48978. 
48979. "What are you staring at, you good-for-nothing?... The count will be
48980. calling and there's nobody there; go and gather the clothes together."
48981. 
48982. "I only ran out to get some water," said Mishka.
48983. 
48984. "But what do you think, Daniel Terentich? Doesn't it look as if that
48985. glow were in Moscow?" remarked one of the footmen.
48986. 
48987. Daniel Terentich made no reply, and again for a long time they were all
48988. silent. The glow spread, rising and falling, farther and farther still.
48989. 
48990. "God have mercy.... It's windy and dry..." said another voice.
48991. 
48992. "Just look! See what it's doing now. O Lord! You can even see the crows
48993. flying. Lord have mercy on us sinners!"
48994. 
48995. "They'll put it out, no fear!"
48996. 
48997. "Who's to put it out?" Daniel Terentich, who had hitherto been silent,
48998. was heard to say. His voice was calm and deliberate. "Moscow it is,
48999. brothers," said he. "Mother Moscow, the white..." his voice faltered,
49000. and he gave way to an old man's sob.
49001. 
49002. And it was as if they had all only waited for this to realize the
49003. significance for them of the glow they were watching. Sighs were heard,
49004. words of prayer, and the sobbing of the count's old valet.
49005. 
49006. 
49007. 
49008. 
49009. 
49010. CHAPTER XXXI
49011. 
49012. 
49013. The valet, returning to the cottage, informed the count that Moscow was
49014. burning. The count donned his dressing gown and went out to look. Sonya
49015. and Madame Schoss, who had not yet undressed, went out with him. Only
49016. Natasha and the countess remained in the room. Petya was no longer
49017. with the family, he had gone on with his regiment which was making for
49018. Troitsa.
49019. 
49020. The countess, on hearing that Moscow was on fire, began to cry. Natasha,
49021. pale, with a fixed look, was sitting on the bench under the icons just
49022. where she had sat down on arriving and paid no attention to her father's
49023. words. She was listening to the ceaseless moaning of the adjutant, three
49024. houses off.
49025. 
49026. "Oh, how terrible," said Sonya returning from the yard chilled and
49027. frightened. "I believe the whole of Moscow will burn, there's an awful
49028. glow! Natasha, do look! You can see it from the window," she said to her
49029. cousin, evidently wishing to distract her mind.
49030. 
49031. But Natasha looked at her as if not understanding what was said to her
49032. and again fixed her eyes on the corner of the stove. She had been in
49033. this condition of stupor since the morning, when Sonya, to the surprise
49034. and annoyance of the countess, had for some unaccountable reason found
49035. it necessary to tell Natasha of Prince Andrew's wound and of his being
49036. with their party. The countess had seldom been so angry with anyone as
49037. she was with Sonya. Sonya had cried and begged to be forgiven and now,
49038. as if trying to atone for her fault, paid unceasing attention to her
49039. cousin.
49040. 
49041. "Look, Natasha, how dreadfully it is burning!" said she.
49042. 
49043. "What's burning?" asked Natasha. "Oh, yes, Moscow."
49044. 
49045. And as if in order not to offend Sonya and to get rid of her, she turned
49046. her face to the window, looked out in such a way that it was evident
49047. that she could not see anything, and again settled down in her former
49048. attitude.
49049. 
49050. "But you didn't see it!"
49051. 
49052. "Yes, really I did," Natasha replied in a voice that pleaded to be left
49053. in peace.
49054. 
49055. Both the countess and Sonya understood that, naturally, neither Moscow
49056. nor the burning of Moscow nor anything else could seem of importance to
49057. Natasha.
49058. 
49059. The count returned and lay down behind the partition. The countess went
49060. up to her daughter and touched her head with the back of her hand as she
49061. was wont to do when Natasha was ill, then touched her forehead with her
49062. lips as if to feel whether she was feverish, and finally kissed her.
49063. 
49064. "You are cold. You are trembling all over. You'd better lie down," said
49065. the countess.
49066. 
49067. "Lie down? All right, I will. I'll lie down at once," said Natasha.
49068. 
49069. When Natasha had been told that morning that Prince Andrew was seriously
49070. wounded and was traveling with their party, she had at first asked many
49071. questions: Where was he going? How was he wounded? Was it serious? And
49072. could she see him? But after she had been told that she could not see
49073. him, that he was seriously wounded but that his life was not in danger,
49074. she ceased to ask questions or to speak at all, evidently disbelieving
49075. what they told her, and convinced that say what she might she would
49076. still be told the same. All the way she had sat motionless in a corner
49077. of the coach with wide open eyes, and the expression in them which the
49078. countess knew so well and feared so much, and now she sat in the same
49079. way on the bench where she had seated herself on arriving. She was
49080. planning something and either deciding or had already decided something
49081. in her mind. The countess knew this, but what it might be she did not
49082. know, and this alarmed and tormented her.
49083. 
49084. "Natasha, undress, darling; lie down on my bed."
49085. 
49086. A bed had been made on a bedstead for the countess only. Madame Schoss
49087. and the two girls were to sleep on some hay on the floor.
49088. 
49089. "No, Mamma, I will lie down here on the floor," Natasha replied
49090. irritably and she went to the window and opened it. Through the open
49091. window the moans of the adjutant could be heard more distinctly. She put
49092. her head out into the damp night air, and the countess saw her slim neck
49093. shaking with sobs and throbbing against the window frame. Natasha knew
49094. it was not Prince Andrew who was moaning. She knew Prince Andrew was in
49095. the same yard as themselves and in a part of the hut across the passage;
49096. but this dreadful incessant moaning made her sob. The countess exchanged
49097. a look with Sonya.
49098. 
49099. "Lie down, darling; lie down, my pet," said the countess, softly
49100. touching Natasha's shoulders. "Come, lie down."
49101. 
49102. "Oh, yes... I'll lie down at once," said Natasha, and began hurriedly
49103. undressing, tugging at the tapes of her petticoat.
49104. 
49105. When she had thrown off her dress and put on a dressing jacket, she sat
49106. down with her foot under her on the bed that had been made up on the
49107. floor, jerked her thin and rather short plait of hair to the front,
49108. and began replaiting it. Her long, thin, practiced fingers rapidly
49109. unplaited, replaited, and tied up her plait. Her head moved from side
49110. to side from habit, but her eyes, feverishly wide, looked fixedly before
49111. her. When her toilet for the night was finished she sank gently onto the
49112. sheet spread over the hay on the side nearest the door.
49113. 
49114. "Natasha, you'd better lie in the middle," said Sonya.
49115. 
49116. "I'll stay here," muttered Natasha. "Do lie down," she added crossly,
49117. and buried her face in the pillow.
49118. 
49119. The countess, Madame Schoss, and Sonya undressed hastily and lay down.
49120. The small lamp in front of the icons was the only light left in
49121. the room. But in the yard there was a light from the fire at Little
49122. Mytishchi a mile and a half away, and through the night came the noise
49123. of people shouting at a tavern Mamonov's Cossacks had set up across the
49124. street, and the adjutant's unceasing moans could still be heard.
49125. 
49126. For a long time Natasha listened attentively to the sounds that reached
49127. her from inside and outside the room and did not move. First she heard
49128. her mother praying and sighing and the creaking of her bed under
49129. her, then Madame Schoss' familiar whistling snore and Sonya's gentle
49130. breathing. Then the countess called to Natasha. Natasha did not answer.
49131. 
49132. "I think she's asleep, Mamma," said Sonya softly.
49133. 
49134. After a short silence the countess spoke again but this time no one
49135. replied.
49136. 
49137. Soon after that Natasha heard her mother's even breathing. Natasha did
49138. not move, though her little bare foot, thrust out from under the quilt,
49139. was growing cold on the bare floor.
49140. 
49141. As if to celebrate a victory over everybody, a cricket chirped in a
49142. crack in the wall. A cock crowed far off and another replied near
49143. by. The shouting in the tavern had died down; only the moaning of the
49144. adjutant was heard. Natasha sat up.
49145. 
49146. "Sonya, are you asleep? Mamma?" she whispered.
49147. 
49148. No one replied. Natasha rose slowly and carefully, crossed herself, and
49149. stepped cautiously on the cold and dirty floor with her slim, supple,
49150. bare feet. The boards of the floor creaked. Stepping cautiously from one
49151. foot to the other she ran like a kitten the few steps to the door and
49152. grasped the cold door handle.
49153. 
49154. It seemed to her that something heavy was beating rhythmically against
49155. all the walls of the room: it was her own heart, sinking with alarm and
49156. terror and overflowing with love.
49157. 
49158. She opened the door and stepped across the threshold and onto the cold,
49159. damp earthen floor of the passage. The cold she felt refreshed her. With
49160. her bare feet she touched a sleeping man, stepped over him, and opened
49161. the door into the part of the hut where Prince Andrew lay. It was dark
49162. in there. In the farthest corner, on a bench beside a bed on which
49163. something was lying, stood a tallow candle with a long, thick, and
49164. smoldering wick.
49165. 
49166. From the moment she had been told that morning of Prince Andrew's wound
49167. and his presence there, Natasha had resolved to see him. She did not
49168. know why she had to, she knew the meeting would be painful, but felt the
49169. more convinced that it was necessary.
49170. 
49171. All day she had lived only in hope of seeing him that night. But now
49172. that the moment had come she was filled with dread of what she might
49173. see. How was he maimed? What was left of him? Was he like that incessant
49174. moaning of the adjutant's? Yes, he was altogether like that. In her
49175. imagination he was that terrible moaning personified. When she saw an
49176. indistinct shape in the corner, and mistook his knees raised under the
49177. quilt for his shoulders, she imagined a horrible body there, and stood
49178. still in terror. But an irresistible impulse drew her forward. She
49179. cautiously took one step and then another, and found herself in the
49180. middle of a small room containing baggage. Another man--Timokhin--was
49181. lying in a corner on the benches beneath the icons, and two others--the
49182. doctor and a valet--lay on the floor.
49183. 
49184. The valet sat up and whispered something. Timokhin, kept awake by the
49185. pain in his wounded leg, gazed with wide-open eyes at this strange
49186. apparition of a girl in a white chemise, dressing jacket, and nightcap.
49187. The valet's sleepy, frightened exclamation, "What do you want? What's
49188. the matter?" made Natasha approach more swiftly to what was lying in the
49189. corner. Horribly unlike a man as that body looked, she must see him.
49190. She passed the valet, the snuff fell from the candle wick, and she saw
49191. Prince Andrew clearly with his arms outside the quilt, and such as she
49192. had always seen him.
49193. 
49194. He was the same as ever, but the feverish color of his face, his
49195. glittering eyes rapturously turned toward her, and especially his neck,
49196. delicate as a child's, revealed by the turn-down collar of his shirt,
49197. gave him a peculiarly innocent, childlike look, such as she had never
49198. seen on him before. She went up to him and with a swift, flexible,
49199. youthful movement dropped on her knees.
49200. 
49201. He smiled and held out his hand to her.
49202. 
49203. 
49204. 
49205. 
49206. 
49207. CHAPTER XXXII
49208. 
49209. 
49210. Seven days had passed since Prince Andrew found himself in the
49211. ambulance station on the field of Borodino. His feverish state and the
49212. inflammation of his bowels, which were injured, were in the doctor's
49213. opinion sure to carry him off. But on the seventh day he ate with
49214. pleasure a piece of bread with some tea, and the doctor noticed that his
49215. temperature was lower. He had regained consciousness that morning.
49216. The first night after they left Moscow had been fairly warm and he had
49217. remained in the caleche, but at Mytishchi the wounded man himself asked
49218. to be taken out and given some tea. The pain caused by his removal into
49219. the hut had made him groan aloud and again lose consciousness. When he
49220. had been placed on his camp bed he lay for a long time motionless with
49221. closed eyes. Then he opened them and whispered softly: "And the tea?"
49222. His remembering such a small detail of everyday life astonished
49223. the doctor. He felt Prince Andrew's pulse, and to his surprise and
49224. dissatisfaction found it had improved. He was dissatisfied because he
49225. knew by experience that if his patient did not die now, he would do so
49226. a little later with greater suffering. Timokhin, the red-nosed major of
49227. Prince Andrew's regiment, had joined him in Moscow and was being
49228. taken along with him, having been wounded in the leg at the battle of
49229. Borodino. They were accompanied by a doctor, Prince Andrew's valet, his
49230. coachman, and two orderlies.
49231. 
49232. They gave Prince Andrew some tea. He drank it eagerly, looking with
49233. feverish eyes at the door in front of him as if trying to understand and
49234. remember something.
49235. 
49236. "I don't want any more. Is Timokhin here?" he asked.
49237. 
49238. Timokhin crept along the bench to him.
49239. 
49240. "I am here, your excellency."
49241. 
49242. "How's your wound?"
49243. 
49244. "Mine, sir? All right. But how about you?"
49245. 
49246. Prince Andrew again pondered as if trying to remember something.
49247. 
49248. "Couldn't one get a book?" he asked.
49249. 
49250. "What book?"
49251. 
49252. "The Gospels. I haven't one."
49253. 
49254. The doctor promised to procure it for him and began to ask how he
49255. was feeling. Prince Andrew answered all his questions reluctantly but
49256. reasonably, and then said he wanted a bolster placed under him as he was
49257. uncomfortable and in great pain. The doctor and valet lifted the cloak
49258. with which he was covered and, making wry faces at the noisome smell of
49259. mortifying flesh that came from the wound, began examining that dreadful
49260. place. The doctor was very much displeased about something and made a
49261. change in the dressings, turning the wounded man over so that he groaned
49262. again and grew unconscious and delirious from the agony. He kept asking
49263. them to get him the book and put it under him.
49264. 
49265. "What trouble would it be to you?" he said. "I have not got one. Please
49266. get it for me and put it under for a moment," he pleaded in a piteous
49267. voice.
49268. 
49269. The doctor went into the passage to wash his hands.
49270. 
49271. "You fellows have no conscience," said he to the valet who was pouring
49272. water over his hands. "For just one moment I didn't look after you...
49273. It's such pain, you know, that I wonder how he can bear it."
49274. 
49275. "By the Lord Jesus Christ, I thought we had put something under him!"
49276. said the valet.
49277. 
49278. The first time Prince Andrew understood where he was and what was the
49279. matter with him and remembered being wounded and how was when he asked
49280. to be carried into the hut after his caleche had stopped at Mytishchi.
49281. After growing confused from pain while being carried into the hut he
49282. again regained consciousness, and while drinking tea once more recalled
49283. all that had happened to him, and above all vividly remembered the
49284. moment at the ambulance station when, at the sight of the sufferings of
49285. a man he disliked, those new thoughts had come to him which promised him
49286. happiness. And those thoughts, though now vague and indefinite, again
49287. possessed his soul. He remembered that he had now a new source of
49288. happiness and that this happiness had something to do with the Gospels.
49289. That was why he asked for a copy of them. The uncomfortable position in
49290. which they had put him and turned him over again confused his thoughts,
49291. and when he came to himself a third time it was in the complete
49292. stillness of the night. Everybody near him was sleeping. A cricket
49293. chirped from across the passage; someone was shouting and singing in
49294. the street; cockroaches rustled on the table, on the icons, and on
49295. the walls, and a big fly flopped at the head of the bed and around the
49296. candle beside him, the wick of which was charred and had shaped itself
49297. like a mushroom.
49298. 
49299. His mind was not in a normal state. A healthy man usually thinks of,
49300. feels, and remembers innumerable things simultaneously, but has the
49301. power and will to select one sequence of thoughts or events on which to
49302. fix his whole attention. A healthy man can tear himself away from the
49303. deepest reflections to say a civil word to someone who comes in and can
49304. then return again to his own thoughts. But Prince Andrew's mind was not
49305. in a normal state in that respect. All the powers of his mind were more
49306. active and clearer than ever, but they acted apart from his will. Most
49307. diverse thoughts and images occupied him simultaneously. At times his
49308. brain suddenly began to work with a vigor, clearness, and depth it had
49309. never reached when he was in health, but suddenly in the midst of its
49310. work it would turn to some unexpected idea and he had not the strength
49311. to turn it back again.
49312. 
49313. "Yes, a new happiness was revealed to me of which man cannot be
49314. deprived," he thought as he lay in the semidarkness of the quiet hut,
49315. gazing fixedly before him with feverish wide open eyes. "A happiness
49316. lying beyond material forces, outside the material influences that act
49317. on man--a happiness of the soul alone, the happiness of loving. Every
49318. man can understand it, but to conceive it and enjoin it was possible
49319. only for God. But how did God enjoin that law? And why was the Son...?"
49320. 
49321. And suddenly the sequence of these thoughts broke off, and Prince Andrew
49322. heard (without knowing whether it was a delusion or reality) a
49323. soft whispering voice incessantly and rhythmically repeating
49324. "piti-piti-piti," and then "titi," and then again "piti-piti-piti," and
49325. "ti-ti" once more. At the same time he felt that above his face, above
49326. the very middle of it, some strange airy structure was being erected out
49327. of slender needles or splinters, to the sound of this whispered music.
49328. He felt that he had to balance carefully (though it was difficult) so
49329. that this airy structure should not collapse; but nevertheless it kept
49330. collapsing and again slowly rising to the sound of whispered rhythmic
49331. music--"it stretches, stretches, spreading out and stretching," said
49332. Prince Andrew to himself. While listening to this whispering and feeling
49333. the sensation of this drawing out and the construction of this edifice
49334. of needles, he also saw by glimpses a red halo round the candle, and
49335. heard the rustle of the cockroaches and the buzzing of the fly that
49336. flopped against his pillow and his face. Each time the fly touched his
49337. face it gave him a burning sensation and yet to his surprise it did not
49338. destroy the structure, though it knocked against the very region of his
49339. face where it was rising. But besides this there was something else of
49340. importance. It was something white by the door--the statue of a sphinx,
49341. which also oppressed him.
49342. 
49343. "But perhaps that's my shirt on the table," he thought, "and that's my
49344. legs, and that is the door, but why is it always stretching and drawing
49345. itself out, and 'piti-piti-piti' and 'ti-ti' and 'piti-piti-piti'...?
49346. That's enough, please leave off!" Prince Andrew painfully entreated
49347. someone. And suddenly thoughts and feelings again swam to the surface of
49348. his mind with peculiar clearness and force.
49349. 
49350. "Yes--love," he thought again quite clearly. "But not love which loves
49351. for something, for some quality, for some purpose, or for some reason,
49352. but the love which I--while dying--first experienced when I saw my enemy
49353. and yet loved him. I experienced that feeling of love which is the very
49354. essence of the soul and does not require an object. Now again I feel
49355. that bliss. To love one's neighbors, to love one's enemies, to love
49356. everything, to love God in all His manifestations. It is possible to
49357. love someone dear to you with human love, but an enemy can only be loved
49358. by divine love. That is why I experienced such joy when I felt that I
49359. loved that man. What has become of him? Is he alive?...
49360. 
49361. "When loving with human love one may pass from love to hatred, but
49362. divine love cannot change. No, neither death nor anything else can
49363. destroy it. It is the very essence of the soul. Yet how many people have
49364. I hated in my life? And of them all, I loved and hated none as I did
49365. her." And he vividly pictured to himself Natasha, not as he had done in
49366. the past with nothing but her charms which gave him delight, but for
49367. the first time picturing to himself her soul. And he understood her
49368. feelings, her sufferings, shame, and remorse. He now understood for the
49369. first time all the cruelty of his rejection of her, the cruelty of his
49370. rupture with her. "If only it were possible for me to see her once more!
49371. Just once, looking into those eyes to say..."
49372. 
49373. 
49374. "Piti-piti-piti and ti-ti and piti-piti-piti boom!" flopped the fly...
49375. And his attention was suddenly carried into another world, a world of
49376. reality and delirium in which something particular was happening. In
49377. that world some structure was still being erected and did not fall,
49378. something was still stretching out, and the candle with its red halo
49379. was still burning, and the same shirtlike sphinx lay near the door; but
49380. besides all this something creaked, there was a whiff of fresh air, and
49381. a new white sphinx appeared, standing at the door. And that sphinx had
49382. the pale face and shining eyes of the very Natasha of whom he had just
49383. been thinking.
49384. 
49385. "Oh, how oppressive this continual delirium is," thought Prince Andrew,
49386. trying to drive that face from his imagination. But the face remained
49387. before him with the force of reality and drew nearer. Prince Andrew
49388. wished to return to that former world of pure thought, but he could not,
49389. and delirium drew him back into its domain. The soft whispering voice
49390. continued its rhythmic murmur, something oppressed him and stretched
49391. out, and the strange face was before him. Prince Andrew collected all
49392. his strength in an effort to recover his senses, he moved a little, and
49393. suddenly there was a ringing in his ears, a dimness in his eyes, and
49394. like a man plunged into water he lost consciousness. When he came to
49395. himself, Natasha, that same living Natasha whom of all people he most
49396. longed to love with this new pure divine love that had been revealed to
49397. him, was kneeling before him. He realized that it was the real living
49398. Natasha, and he was not surprised but quietly happy. Natasha, motionless
49399. on her knees (she was unable to stir), with frightened eyes riveted on
49400. him, was restraining her sobs. Her face was pale and rigid. Only in the
49401. lower part of it something quivered.
49402. 
49403. Prince Andrew sighed with relief, smiled, and held out his hand.
49404. 
49405. "You?" he said. "How fortunate!"
49406. 
49407. With a rapid but careful movement Natasha drew nearer to him on her
49408. knees and, taking his hand carefully, bent her face over it and began
49409. kissing it, just touching it lightly with her lips.
49410. 
49411. "Forgive me!" she whispered, raising her head and glancing at him.
49412. "Forgive me!"
49413. 
49414. "I love you," said Prince Andrew.
49415. 
49416. "Forgive...!"
49417. 
49418. "Forgive what?" he asked.
49419. 
49420. "Forgive me for what I ha-ve do-ne!" faltered Natasha in a scarcely
49421. audible, broken whisper, and began kissing his hand more rapidly, just
49422. touching it with her lips.
49423. 
49424. "I love you more, better than before," said Prince Andrew, lifting her
49425. face with his hand so as to look into her eyes.
49426. 
49427. Those eyes, filled with happy tears, gazed at him timidly,
49428. compassionately, and with joyous love. Natasha's thin pale face, with
49429. its swollen lips, was more than plain--it was dreadful. But Prince
49430. Andrew did not see that, he saw her shining eyes which were beautiful.
49431. They heard the sound of voices behind them.
49432. 
49433. Peter the valet, who was now wide awake, had roused the doctor.
49434. Timokhin, who had not slept at all because of the pain in his leg, had
49435. long been watching all that was going on, carefully covering his bare
49436. body with the sheet as he huddled up on his bench.
49437. 
49438. "What's this?" said the doctor, rising from his bed. "Please go away,
49439. madam!"
49440. 
49441. At that moment a maid sent by the countess, who had noticed her
49442. daughter's absence, knocked at the door.
49443. 
49444. Like a somnambulist aroused from her sleep Natasha went out of the room
49445. and, returning to her hut, fell sobbing on her bed.
49446. 
49447. 
49448. From that time, during all the rest of the Rostovs' journey, at every
49449. halting place and wherever they spent a night, Natasha never left the
49450. wounded Bolkonski, and the doctor had to admit that he had not expected
49451. from a young girl either such firmness or such skill in nursing a
49452. wounded man.
49453. 
49454. Dreadful as the countess imagined it would be should Prince Andrew
49455. die in her daughter's arms during the journey--as, judging by what
49456. the doctor said, it seemed might easily happen--she could not oppose
49457. Natasha. Though with the intimacy now established between the wounded
49458. man and Natasha the thought occurred that should he recover their former
49459. engagement would be renewed, no one--least of all Natasha and Prince
49460. Andrew--spoke of this: the unsettled question of life and death, which
49461. hung not only over Bolkonski but over all Russia, shut out all other
49462. considerations.
49463. 
49464. 
49465. 
49466. 
49467. 
49468. CHAPTER XXXIII
49469. 
49470. 
49471. On the third of September Pierre awoke late. His head was aching, the
49472. clothes in which he had slept without undressing felt uncomfortable on
49473. his body, and his mind had a dim consciousness of something shameful
49474. he had done the day before. That something shameful was his yesterday's
49475. conversation with Captain Ramballe.
49476. 
49477. It was eleven by the clock, but it seemed peculiarly dark out of doors.
49478. Pierre rose, rubbed his eyes, and seeing the pistol with an engraved
49479. stock which Gerasim had replaced on the writing table, he remembered
49480. where he was and what lay before him that very day.
49481. 
49482. "Am I not too late?" he thought. "No, probably he won't make his entry
49483. into Moscow before noon."
49484. 
49485. Pierre did not allow himself to reflect on what lay before him, but
49486. hastened to act.
49487. 
49488. After arranging his clothes, he took the pistol and was about to go out.
49489. But it then occurred to him for the first time that he certainly could
49490. not carry the weapon in his hand through the streets. It was difficult
49491. to hide such a big pistol even under his wide coat. He could not
49492. carry it unnoticed in his belt or under his arm. Besides, it had been
49493. discharged, and he had not had time to reload it. "No matter, dagger
49494. will do," he said to himself, though when planning his design he had
49495. more than once come to the conclusion that the chief mistake made by the
49496. student in 1809 had been to try to kill Napoleon with a dagger. But as
49497. his chief aim consisted not in carrying out his design, but in proving
49498. to himself that he would not abandon his intention and was doing all he
49499. could to achieve it, Pierre hastily took the blunt jagged dagger in a
49500. green sheath which he had bought at the Sukharev market with the pistol,
49501. and hid it under his waistcoat.
49502. 
49503. Having tied a girdle over his coat and pulled his cap low on his head,
49504. Pierre went down the corridor, trying to avoid making a noise or meeting
49505. the captain, and passed out into the street.
49506. 
49507. The conflagration, at which he had looked with so much indifference the
49508. evening before, had greatly increased during the night. Moscow was on
49509. fire in several places. The buildings in Carriage Row, across the river,
49510. in the Bazaar and the Povarskoy, as well as the barges on the Moskva
49511. River and the timber yards by the Dorogomilov Bridge, were all ablaze.
49512. 
49513. Pierre's way led through side streets to the Povarskoy and from there
49514. to the church of St. Nicholas on the Arbat, where he had long before
49515. decided that the deed should be done. The gates of most of the houses
49516. were locked and the shutters up. The streets and lanes were deserted.
49517. The air was full of smoke and the smell of burning. Now and then he met
49518. Russians with anxious and timid faces, and Frenchmen with an air not of
49519. the city but of the camp, walking in the middle of the streets. Both
49520. the Russians and the French looked at Pierre with surprise. Besides his
49521. height and stoutness, and the strange morose look of suffering in his
49522. face and whole figure, the Russians stared at Pierre because they could
49523. not make out to what class he could belong. The French followed him with
49524. astonishment in their eyes chiefly because Pierre, unlike all the
49525. other Russians who gazed at the French with fear and curiosity, paid no
49526. attention to them. At the gate of one house three Frenchmen, who were
49527. explaining something to some Russians who did not understand them,
49528. stopped Pierre asking if he did not know French.
49529. 
49530. Pierre shook his head and went on. In another side street a sentinel
49531. standing beside a green caisson shouted at him, but only when the shout
49532. was threateningly repeated and he heard the click of the man's musket as
49533. he raised it did Pierre understand that he had to pass on the other side
49534. of the street. He heard nothing and saw nothing of what went on around
49535. him. He carried his resolution within himself in terror and haste, like
49536. something dreadful and alien to him, for, after the previous night's
49537. experience, he was afraid of losing it. But he was not destined to bring
49538. his mood safely to his destination. And even had he not been hindered by
49539. anything on the way, his intention could not now have been carried out,
49540. for Napoleon had passed the Arbat more than four hours previously on his
49541. way from the Dorogomilov suburb to the Kremlin, and was now sitting in
49542. a very gloomy frame of mind in a royal study in the Kremlin, giving
49543. detailed and exact orders as to measures to be taken immediately
49544. to extinguish the fire, to prevent looting, and to reassure the
49545. inhabitants. But Pierre did not know this; he was entirely absorbed
49546. in what lay before him, and was tortured--as those are who obstinately
49547. undertake a task that is impossible for them not because of its
49548. difficulty but because of its incompatibility with their natures--by the
49549. fear of weakening at the decisive moment and so losing his self-esteem.
49550. 
49551. Though he heard and saw nothing around him he found his way by instinct
49552. and did not go wrong in the side streets that led to the Povarskoy.
49553. 
49554. As Pierre approached that street the smoke became denser and denser--he
49555. even felt the heat of the fire. Occasionally curly tongues of flame rose
49556. from under the roofs of the houses. He met more people in the streets
49557. and they were more excited. But Pierre, though he felt that something
49558. unusual was happening around him, did not realize that he was
49559. approaching the fire. As he was going along a foot path across a
49560. wide-open space adjoining the Povarskoy on one side and the gardens
49561. of Prince Gruzinski's house on the other, Pierre suddenly heard the
49562. desperate weeping of a woman close to him. He stopped as if awakening
49563. from a dream and lifted his head.
49564. 
49565. By the side of the path, on the dusty dry grass, all sorts of household
49566. goods lay in a heap: featherbeds, a samovar, icons, and trunks. On the
49567. ground, beside the trunks, sat a thin woman no longer young, with long,
49568. prominent upper teeth, and wearing a black cloak and cap. This woman,
49569. swaying to and fro and muttering something, was choking with sobs. Two
49570. girls of about ten and twelve, dressed in dirty short frocks and cloaks,
49571. were staring at their mother with a look of stupefaction on their pale
49572. frightened faces. The youngest child, a boy of about seven, who wore an
49573. overcoat and an immense cap evidently not his own, was crying in his
49574. old nurse's arms. A dirty, barefooted maid was sitting on a trunk,
49575. and, having undone her pale-colored plait, was pulling it straight
49576. and sniffing at her singed hair. The woman's husband, a short,
49577. round-shouldered man in the undress uniform of a civilian official, with
49578. sausage-shaped whiskers and showing under his square-set cap the hair
49579. smoothly brushed forward over his temples, with expressionless face was
49580. moving the trunks, which were placed one on another, and was dragging
49581. some garments from under them.
49582. 
49583. As soon as she saw Pierre, the woman almost threw herself at his feet.
49584. 
49585. "Dear people, good Christians, save me, help me, dear friends... help
49586. us, somebody," she muttered between her sobs. "My girl... My daughter!
49587. My youngest daughter is left behind. She's burned! Ooh! Was it for this
49588. I nursed you.... Ooh!"
49589. 
49590. "Don't, Mary Nikolievna!" said her husband to her in a low voice,
49591. evidently only to justify himself before the stranger. "Sister must have
49592. taken her, or else where can she be?" he added.
49593. 
49594. "Monster! Villain!" shouted the woman angrily, suddenly ceasing to weep.
49595. "You have no heart, you don't feel for your own child! Another man would
49596. have rescued her from the fire. But this is a monster and neither a
49597. man nor a father! You, honored sir, are a noble man," she went on,
49598. addressing Pierre rapidly between her sobs. "The fire broke out
49599. alongside, and blew our way, the maid called out 'Fire!' and we rushed
49600. to collect our things. We ran out just as we were.... This is what we
49601. have brought away.... The icons, and my dowry bed, all the rest is lost.
49602. We seized the children. But not Katie! Ooh! O Lord!..." and again she
49603. began to sob. "My child, my dear one! Burned, burned!"
49604. 
49605. "But where was she left?" asked Pierre.
49606. 
49607. From the expression of his animated face the woman saw that this man
49608. might help her.
49609. 
49610. "Oh, dear sir!" she cried, seizing him by the legs. "My benefactor, set
49611. my heart at ease.... Aniska, go, you horrid girl, show him the way!" she
49612. cried to the maid, angrily opening her mouth and still farther exposing
49613. her long teeth.
49614. 
49615. "Show me the way, show me, I... I'll do it," gasped Pierre rapidly.
49616. 
49617. The dirty maidservant stepped from behind the trunk, put up her plait,
49618. sighed, and went on her short, bare feet along the path. Pierre felt
49619. as if he had come back to life after a heavy swoon. He held his head
49620. higher, his eyes shone with the light of life, and with swift steps
49621. he followed the maid, overtook her, and came out on the Povarskoy. The
49622. whole street was full of clouds of black smoke. Tongues of flame here
49623. and there broke through that cloud. A great number of people crowded in
49624. front of the conflagration. In the middle of the street stood a French
49625. general saying something to those around him. Pierre, accompanied by the
49626. maid, was advancing to the spot where the general stood, but the French
49627. soldiers stopped him.
49628. 
49629. "On ne passe pas!" * cried a voice.
49630. 
49631. 
49632.     * "You can't pass!"
49633. 
49634. 
49635. "This way, uncle," cried the girl. "We'll pass through the side street,
49636. by the Nikulins'!"
49637. 
49638. Pierre turned back, giving a spring now and then to keep up with her.
49639. She ran across the street, turned down a side street to the left, and,
49640. passing three houses, turned into a yard on the right.
49641. 
49642. "It's here, close by," said she and, running across the yard, opened a
49643. gate in a wooden fence and, stopping, pointed out to him a small wooden
49644. wing of the house, which was burning brightly and fiercely. One of its
49645. sides had fallen in, another was on fire, and bright flames issued from
49646. the openings of the windows and from under the roof.
49647. 
49648. As Pierre passed through the fence gate, he was enveloped by hot air and
49649. involuntarily stopped.
49650. 
49651. "Which is it? Which is your house?" he asked.
49652. 
49653. "Ooh!" wailed the girl, pointing to the wing. "That's it, that was our
49654. lodging. You've burned to death, our treasure, Katie, my precious little
49655. missy! Ooh!" lamented Aniska, who at the sight of the fire felt that she
49656. too must give expression to her feelings.
49657. 
49658. Pierre rushed to the wing, but the heat was so great that he
49659. involuntarily passed round in a curve and came upon the large house
49660. that was as yet burning only at one end, just below the roof, and around
49661. which swarmed a crowd of Frenchmen. At first Pierre did not realize
49662. what these men, who were dragging something out, were about; but seeing
49663. before him a Frenchman hitting a peasant with a blunt saber and trying
49664. to take from him a fox-fur coat, he vaguely understood that looting was
49665. going on there, but he had no time to dwell on that idea.
49666. 
49667. The sounds of crackling and the din of falling walls and ceilings, the
49668. whistle and hiss of the flames, the excited shouts of the people, and
49669. the sight of the swaying smoke, now gathering into thick black clouds
49670. and now soaring up with glittering sparks, with here and there dense
49671. sheaves of flame (now red and now like golden fish scales creeping along
49672. the walls), and the heat and smoke and rapidity of motion, produced
49673. on Pierre the usual animating effects of a conflagration. It had a
49674. peculiarly strong effect on him because at the sight of the fire he felt
49675. himself suddenly freed from the ideas that had weighed him down. He felt
49676. young, bright, adroit, and resolute. He ran round to the other side of
49677. the lodge and was about to dash into that part of it which was still
49678. standing, when just above his head he heard several voices shouting
49679. and then a cracking sound and the ring of something heavy falling close
49680. beside him.
49681. 
49682. Pierre looked up and saw at a window of the large house some Frenchmen
49683. who had just thrown out the drawer of a chest, filled with metal
49684. articles. Other French soldiers standing below went up to the drawer.
49685. 
49686. "What does this fellow want?" shouted one of them referring to Pierre.
49687. 
49688. "There's a child in that house. Haven't you seen a child?" cried Pierre.
49689. 
49690. "What's he talking about? Get along!" said several voices, and one of
49691. the soldiers, evidently afraid that Pierre might want to take from
49692. them some of the plate and bronzes that were in the drawer, moved
49693. threateningly toward him.
49694. 
49695. "A child?" shouted a Frenchman from above. "I did hear something
49696. squealing in the garden. Perhaps it's his brat that the fellow is
49697. looking for. After all, one must be human, you know...."
49698. 
49699. "Where is it? Where?" said Pierre.
49700. 
49701. "There! There!" shouted the Frenchman at the window, pointing to the
49702. garden at the back of the house. "Wait a bit--I'm coming down."
49703. 
49704. And a minute or two later the Frenchman, a black-eyed fellow with a spot
49705. on his cheek, in shirt sleeves, really did jump out of a window on the
49706. ground floor, and clapping Pierre on the shoulder ran with him into the
49707. garden.
49708. 
49709. "Hurry up, you others!" he called out to his comrades. "It's getting
49710. hot."
49711. 
49712. When they reached a gravel path behind the house the Frenchman pulled
49713. Pierre by the arm and pointed to a round, graveled space where a
49714. three-year-old girl in a pink dress was lying under a seat.
49715. 
49716. "There is your child! Oh, a girl, so much the better!" said the
49717. Frenchman. "Good-by, Fatty. We must be human, we are all mortal you
49718. know!" and the Frenchman with the spot on his cheek ran back to his
49719. comrades.
49720. 
49721. Breathless with joy, Pierre ran to the little girl and was going to take
49722. her in his arms. But seeing a stranger the sickly, scrofulous-looking
49723. child, unattractively like her mother, began to yell and run away.
49724. Pierre, however, seized her and lifted her in his arms. She screamed
49725. desperately and angrily and tried with her little hands to pull Pierre's
49726. hands away and to bite them with her slobbering mouth. Pierre was seized
49727. by a sense of horror and repulsion such as he had experienced when
49728. touching some nasty little animal. But he made an effort not to throw
49729. the child down and ran with her to the large house. It was now, however,
49730. impossible to get back the way he had come; the maid, Aniska, was no
49731. longer there, and Pierre with a feeling of pity and disgust pressed the
49732. wet, painfully sobbing child to himself as tenderly as he could and ran
49733. with her through the garden seeking another way out.
49734. 
49735. 
49736. 
49737. 
49738. 
49739. CHAPTER XXXIV
49740. 
49741. 
49742. Having run through different yards and side streets, Pierre got back
49743. with his little burden to the Gruzinski garden at the corner of the
49744. Povarskoy. He did not at first recognize the place from which he had set
49745. out to look for the child, so crowded was it now with people and goods
49746. that had been dragged out of the houses. Besides Russian families who
49747. had taken refuge here from the fire with their belongings, there were
49748. several French soldiers in a variety of clothing. Pierre took no notice
49749. of them. He hurried to find the family of that civil servant in order to
49750. restore the daughter to her mother and go to save someone else. Pierre
49751. felt that he had still much to do and to do quickly. Glowing with the
49752. heat and from running, he felt at that moment more strongly than ever
49753. the sense of youth, animation, and determination that had come on him
49754. when he ran to save the child. She had now become quiet and, clinging
49755. with her little hands to Pierre's coat, sat on his arm gazing about
49756. her like some little wild animal. He glanced at her occasionally with a
49757. slight smile. He fancied he saw something pathetically innocent in that
49758. frightened, sickly little face.
49759. 
49760. He did not find the civil servant or his wife where he had left them. He
49761. walked among the crowd with rapid steps, scanning the various faces he
49762. met. Involuntarily he noticed a Georgian or Armenian family
49763. consisting of a very handsome old man of Oriental type, wearing a new,
49764. cloth-covered, sheepskin coat and new boots, an old woman of similar
49765. type, and a young woman. That very young woman seemed to Pierre the
49766. perfection of Oriental beauty, with her sharply outlined, arched,
49767. black eyebrows and the extraordinarily soft, bright color of her long,
49768. beautiful, expressionless face. Amid the scattered property and the
49769. crowd on the open space, she, in her rich satin cloak with a bright
49770. lilac shawl on her head, suggested a delicate exotic plant thrown out
49771. onto the snow. She was sitting on some bundles a little behind the old
49772. woman, and looked from under her long lashes with motionless, large,
49773. almond-shaped eyes at the ground before her. Evidently she was aware
49774. of her beauty and fearful because of it. Her face struck Pierre and,
49775. hurrying along by the fence, he turned several times to look at her.
49776. When he had reached the fence, still without finding those he sought, he
49777. stopped and looked about him.
49778. 
49779. With the child in his arms his figure was now more conspicuous than
49780. before, and a group of Russians, both men and women, gathered about him.
49781. 
49782. "Have you lost anyone, my dear fellow? You're of the gentry yourself,
49783. aren't you? Whose child is it?" they asked him.
49784. 
49785. Pierre replied that the child belonged to a woman in a black coat who
49786. had been sitting there with her other children, and he asked whether
49787. anyone knew where she had gone.
49788. 
49789. "Why, that must be the Anferovs," said an old deacon, addressing a
49790. pockmarked peasant woman. "Lord have mercy, Lord have mercy!" he added
49791. in his customary bass.
49792. 
49793. "The Anferovs? No," said the woman. "They left in the morning. That must
49794. be either Mary Nikolievna's or the Ivanovs'!"
49795. 
49796. "He says 'a woman,' and Mary Nikolievna is a lady," remarked a house
49797. serf.
49798. 
49799. "Do you know her? She's thin, with long teeth," said Pierre.
49800. 
49801. "That's Mary Nikolievna! They went inside the garden when these wolves
49802. swooped down," said the woman, pointing to the French soldiers.
49803. 
49804. "O Lord, have mercy!" added the deacon.
49805. 
49806. "Go over that way, they're there. It's she! She kept on lamenting and
49807. crying," continued the woman. "It's she. Here, this way!"
49808. 
49809. But Pierre was not listening to the woman. He had for some seconds been
49810. intently watching what was going on a few steps away. He was looking at
49811. the Armenian family and at two French soldiers who had gone up to them.
49812. One of these, a nimble little man, was wearing a blue coat tied round
49813. the waist with a rope. He had a nightcap on his head and his feet were
49814. bare. The other, whose appearance particularly struck Pierre, was a
49815. long, lank, round-shouldered, fair-haired man, slow in his movements
49816. and with an idiotic expression of face. He wore a woman's loose gown
49817. of frieze, blue trousers, and large torn Hessian boots. The little
49818. barefooted Frenchman in the blue coat went up to the Armenians and,
49819. saying something, immediately seized the old man by his legs and the old
49820. man at once began pulling off his boots. The other in the frieze gown
49821. stopped in front of the beautiful Armenian girl and with his hands in
49822. his pockets stood staring at her, motionless and silent.
49823. 
49824. "Here, take the child!" said Pierre peremptorily and hurriedly to the
49825. woman, handing the little girl to her. "Give her back to them, give her
49826. back!" he almost shouted, putting the child, who began screaming, on the
49827. ground, and again looking at the Frenchman and the Armenian family.
49828. 
49829. The old man was already sitting barefoot. The little Frenchman had
49830. secured his second boot and was slapping one boot against the other.
49831. The old man was saying something in a voice broken by sobs, but Pierre
49832. caught but a glimpse of this, his whole attention was directed to the
49833. Frenchman in the frieze gown who meanwhile, swaying slowly from side to
49834. side, had drawn nearer to the young woman and taking his hands from his
49835. pockets had seized her by the neck.
49836. 
49837. The beautiful Armenian still sat motionless and in the same attitude,
49838. with her long lashes drooping as if she did not see or feel what the
49839. soldier was doing to her.
49840. 
49841. While Pierre was running the few steps that separated him from the
49842. Frenchman, the tall marauder in the frieze gown was already tearing
49843. from her neck the necklace the young Armenian was wearing, and the young
49844. woman, clutching at her neck, screamed piercingly.
49845. 
49846. "Let that woman alone!" exclaimed Pierre hoarsely in a furious voice,
49847. seizing the soldier by his round shoulders and throwing him aside.
49848. 
49849. The soldier fell, got up, and ran away. But his comrade, throwing down
49850. the boots and drawing his sword, moved threateningly toward Pierre.
49851. 
49852. "Voyons, Pas de betises!" * he cried.
49853. 
49854. 
49855.     * "Look here, no nonsense!"
49856. 
49857. 
49858. Pierre was in such a transport of rage that he remembered nothing and
49859. his strength increased tenfold. He rushed at the barefooted Frenchman
49860. and, before the latter had time to draw his sword, knocked him off his
49861. feet and hammered him with his fists. Shouts of approval were heard
49862. from the crowd around, and at the same moment a mounted patrol of French
49863. Uhlans appeared from round the corner. The Uhlans came up at a trot to
49864. Pierre and the Frenchman and surrounded them. Pierre remembered nothing
49865. of what happened after that. He only remembered beating someone and
49866. being beaten and finally feeling that his hands were bound and that a
49867. crowd of French soldiers stood around him and were searching him.
49868. 
49869. "Lieutenant, he has a dagger," were the first words Pierre understood.
49870. 
49871. "Ah, a weapon?" said the officer and turned to the barefooted soldier
49872. who had been arrested with Pierre. "All right, you can tell all about it
49873. at the court-martial." Then he turned to Pierre. "Do you speak French?"
49874. 
49875. Pierre looked around him with bloodshot eyes and did not reply. His
49876. face probably looked very terrible, for the officer said something in
49877. a whisper and four more Uhlans left the ranks and placed themselves on
49878. both sides of Pierre.
49879. 
49880. "Do you speak French?" the officer asked again, keeping at a distance
49881. from Pierre. "Call the interpreter."
49882. 
49883. A little man in Russian civilian clothes rode out from the ranks, and
49884. by his clothes and manner of speaking Pierre at once knew him to be a
49885. French salesman from one of the Moscow shops.
49886. 
49887. "He does not look like a common man," said the interpreter, after a
49888. searching look at Pierre.
49889. 
49890. "Ah, he looks very much like an incendiary," remarked the officer. "And
49891. ask him who he is," he added.
49892. 
49893. "Who are you?" asked the interpreter in poor Russian. "You must answer
49894. the chief."
49895. 
49896. "I will not tell you who I am. I am your prisoner--take me!" Pierre
49897. suddenly replied in French.
49898. 
49899. "Ah, ah!" muttered the officer with a frown. "Well then, march!"
49900. 
49901. A crowd had collected round the Uhlans. Nearest to Pierre stood the
49902. pockmarked peasant woman with the little girl, and when the patrol
49903. started she moved forward.
49904. 
49905. "Where are they taking you to, you poor dear?" said she. "And the little
49906. girl, the little girl, what am I to do with her if she's not theirs?"
49907. said the woman.
49908. 
49909. "What does that woman want?" asked the officer.
49910. 
49911. Pierre was as if intoxicated. His elation increased at the sight of the
49912. little girl he had saved.
49913. 
49914. "What does she want?" he murmured. "She is bringing me my daughter whom
49915. I have just saved from the flames," said he. "Good-by!" And without
49916. knowing how this aimless lie had escaped him, he went along with
49917. resolute and triumphant steps between the French soldiers.
49918. 
49919. The French patrol was one of those sent out through the various
49920. streets of Moscow by Durosnel's order to put a stop to the pillage,
49921. and especially to catch the incendiaries who, according to the general
49922. opinion which had that day originated among the higher French officers,
49923. were the cause of the conflagrations. After marching through a number
49924. of streets the patrol arrested five more Russian suspects: a small
49925. shopkeeper, two seminary students, a peasant, and a house serf, besides
49926. several looters. But of all these various suspected characters, Pierre
49927. was considered to be the most suspicious of all. When they had all been
49928. brought for the night to a large house on the Zubov Rampart that was
49929. being used as a guardhouse, Pierre was placed apart under strict guard.
49930. 
49931. 
49932. 
49933.
