49941. CHAPTER I
49942. 
49943. 
49944. In Petersburg at that time a complicated struggle was being carried on
49945. with greater heat than ever in the highest circles, between the parties
49946. of Rumyantsev, the French, Marya Fedorovna, the Tsarevich, and others,
49947. drowned as usual by the buzzing of the court drones. But the calm,
49948. luxurious life of Petersburg, concerned only about phantoms and
49949. reflections of real life, went on in its old way and made it hard,
49950. except by a great effort, to realize the danger and the difficult
49951. position of the Russian people. There were the same receptions and
49952. balls, the same French theater, the same court interests and service
49953. interests and intrigues as usual. Only in the very highest circles were
49954. attempts made to keep in mind the difficulties of the actual position.
49955. Stories were whispered of how differently the two Empresses behaved
49956. in these difficult circumstances. The Empress Marya, concerned for
49957. the welfare of the charitable and educational institutions under her
49958. patronage, had given directions that they should all be removed to
49959. Kazan, and the things belonging to these institutions had already been
49960. packed up. The Empress Elisabeth, however, when asked what instructions
49961. she would be pleased to give--with her characteristic Russian patriotism
49962. had replied that she could give no directions about state institutions
49963. for that was the affair of the sovereign, but as far as she personally
49964. was concerned she would be the last to quit Petersburg.
49965. 
49966. At Anna Pavlovna's on the twenty-sixth of August, the very day of the
49967. battle of Borodino, there was a soiree, the chief feature of which was
49968. to be the reading of a letter from His Lordship the Bishop when sending
49969. the Emperor an icon of the Venerable Sergius. It was regarded as a model
49970. of ecclesiastical, patriotic eloquence. Prince Vasili himself, famed for
49971. his elocution, was to read it. (He used to read at the Empress'.) The
49972. art of his reading was supposed to lie in rolling out the words, quite
49973. independently of their meaning, in a loud and singsong voice alternating
49974. between a despairing wail and a tender murmur, so that the wail fell
49975. quite at random on one word and the murmur on another. This reading,
49976. as was always the case at Anna Pavlovna's soirees, had a political
49977. significance. That evening she expected several important personages who
49978. had to be made ashamed of their visits to the French theater and aroused
49979. to a patriotic temper. A good many people had already arrived, but Anna
49980. Pavlovna, not yet seeing all those whom she wanted in her drawing room,
49981. did not let the reading begin but wound up the springs of a general
49982. conversation.
49983. 
49984. The news of the day in Petersburg was the illness of Countess Bezukhova.
49985. She had fallen ill unexpectedly a few days previously, had missed
49986. several gatherings of which she was usually ornament, and was said to be
49987. receiving no one, and instead of the celebrated Petersburg doctors who
49988. usually attended her had entrusted herself to some Italian doctor who
49989. was treating her in some new and unusual way.
49990. 
49991. They all knew very well that the enchanting countess' illness arose from
49992. an inconvenience resulting from marrying two husbands at the same time,
49993. and that the Italian's cure consisted in removing such inconvenience;
49994. but in Anna Pavlovna's presence no one dared to think of this or even
49995. appear to know it.
49996. 
49997. "They say the poor countess is very ill. The doctor says it is angina
49998. pectoris."
49999. 
50000. "Angina? Oh, that's a terrible illness!"
50001. 
50002. "They say that the rivals are reconciled, thanks to the angina..." and
50003. the word angina was repeated with great satisfaction.
50004. 
50005. "The count is pathetic, they say. He cried like a child when the doctor
50006. told him the case was dangerous."
50007. 
50008. "Oh, it would be a terrible loss, she is an enchanting woman."
50009. 
50010. "You are speaking of the poor countess?" said Anna Pavlovna, coming
50011. up just then. "I sent to ask for news, and hear that she is a little
50012. better. Oh, she is certainly the most charming woman in the world," she
50013. went on, with a smile at her own enthusiasm. "We belong to different
50014. camps, but that does not prevent my esteeming her as she deserves. She
50015. is very unfortunate!" added Anna Pavlovna.
50016. 
50017. Supposing that by these words Anna Pavlovna was somewhat lifting the
50018. veil from the secret of the countess' malady, an unwary young man
50019. ventured to express surprise that well known doctors had not been called
50020. in and that the countess was being attended by a charlatan who might
50021. employ dangerous remedies.
50022. 
50023. "Your information maybe better than mine," Anna Pavlovna suddenly and
50024. venomously retorted on the inexperienced young man, "but I know on good
50025. authority that this doctor is a very learned and able man. He is private
50026. physician to the Queen of Spain."
50027. 
50028. And having thus demolished the young man, Anna Pavlovna turned to
50029. another group where Bilibin was talking about the Austrians: having
50030. wrinkled up his face he was evidently preparing to smooth it out again
50031. and utter one of his mots.
50032. 
50033. "I think it is delightful," he said, referring to a diplomatic note that
50034. had been sent to Vienna with some Austrian banners captured from the
50035. French by Wittgenstein, "the hero of Petropol" as he was then called in
50036. Petersburg.
50037. 
50038. "What? What's that?" asked Anna Pavlovna, securing silence for the mot,
50039. which she had heard before.
50040. 
50041. And Bilibin repeated the actual words of the diplomatic dispatch, which
50042. he had himself composed.
50043. 
50044. "The Emperor returns these Austrian banners," said Bilibin, "friendly
50045. banners gone astray and found on a wrong path," and his brow became
50046. smooth again.
50047. 
50048. "Charming, charming!" observed Prince Vasili.
50049. 
50050. "The path to Warsaw, perhaps," Prince Hippolyte remarked loudly and
50051. unexpectedly. Everybody looked at him, understanding what he meant.
50052. Prince Hippolyte himself glanced around with amused surprise. He knew no
50053. more than the others what his words meant. During his diplomatic career
50054. he had more than once noticed that such utterances were received as very
50055. witty, and at every opportunity he uttered in that way the first words
50056. that entered his head. "It may turn out very well," he thought, "but
50057. if not, they'll know how to arrange matters." And really, during the
50058. awkward silence that ensued, that insufficiently patriotic person

50062. begged him to begin. Everyone became silent.
50063. 
50064. 
50065. "Most Gracious Sovereign and Emperor!" Prince Vasili sternly declaimed,
50066. looking round at his audience as if to inquire whether anyone had
50067. anything to say to the contrary. But no one said anything. "Moscow, our
50068. ancient capital, the New Jerusalem, receives her Christ"--he placed a
50069. sudden emphasis on the word her--"as a mother receives her zealous sons
50070. into her arms, and through the gathering mists, foreseeing the brilliant
50071. glory of thy rule, sings in exultation, 'Hosanna, blessed is he that
50072. cometh!'"
50073. 
50074. 
50075. Prince Vasili pronounced these last words in a tearful voice.
50076. 
50077. Bilibin attentively examined his nails, and many of those present
50078. appeared intimidated, as if asking in what they were to blame. Anna
50079. Pavlovna whispered the next words in advance, like an old woman

50081. Goliath..." she whispered.
50082. 
50083. Prince Vasili continued.
50084. 
50085.

50087. the realms of Russia with death-bearing terrors; humble Faith, the sling
50088. of the Russian David, shall suddenly smite his head in his bloodthirsty
50089. pride. This icon of the Venerable Sergius, the servant of God and
50090. zealous champion of old of our country's weal, is offered to Your
50091. Imperial Majesty. I grieve that my waning strength prevents rejoicing
50092. in the sight of your most gracious presence. I raise fervent prayers to
50093. Heaven that the Almighty may exalt the race of the just, and mercifully
50094. fulfill the desires of Your Majesty."
50095. 
50096. 
50097. "What force! What a style!" was uttered in approval both of reader and
50098. of author.
50099. 
50100. Animated by that address Anna Pavlovna's guests talked for a long time
50101. of the state of the fatherland and offered various conjectures as to the
50102. result of the battle to be fought in a few days.
50103. 
50104. "You will see," said Anna Pavlovna, "that tomorrow, on the Emperor's
50105. birthday, we shall receive news. I have a favorable presentiment!"
50106. 
50107. 
50108. 
50109. 
50110. 
50111. CHAPTER II
50112. 
50113. 
50114. Anna Pavlovna's presentiment was in fact fulfilled. Next day during the
50115. service at the palace church in honor of the Emperor's birthday, Prince
50116. Volkonski was called out of the church and received a dispatch from
50117. Prince Kutuzov. It was Kutuzov's report, written from Tatarinova on the
50118. day of the battle. Kutuzov wrote that the Russians had not retreated a
50119. step, that the French losses were much heavier than ours, and that he
50120. was writing in haste from the field of battle before collecting full
50121. information. It followed that there must have been a victory. And at
50122. once, without leaving the church, thanks were rendered to the Creator
50123. for His help and for the victory.
50124. 
50125. Anna Pavlovna's presentiment was justified, and all that morning a
50126. joyously festive mood reigned in the city. Everyone believed the victory
50127. to have been complete, and some even spoke of Napoleon's having been
50128. captured, of his deposition, and of the choice of a new ruler for
50129. France.
50130. 
50131. It is very difficult for events to be reflected in their real strength
50132. and completeness amid the conditions of court life and far from the
50133. scene of action. General events involuntarily group themselves around
50134. some particular incident. So now the courtiers' pleasure was based as
50135. much on the fact that the news had arrived on the Emperor's birthday as
50136. on the fact of the victory itself. It was like a successfully arranged
50137. surprise. Mention was made in Kutuzov's report of the Russian losses,
50138. among which figured the names of Tuchkov, Bagration, and Kutaysov. In
50139. the Petersburg world this sad side of the affair again involuntarily
50140. centered round a single incident: Kutaysov's death. Everybody knew
50141. him, the Emperor liked him, and he was young and interesting. That day
50142. everyone met with the words:
50143. 
50144. "What a wonderful coincidence! Just during the service. But what a loss
50145. Kutaysov is! How sorry I am!"
50146. 
50147. "What did I tell about Kutuzov?" Prince Vasili now said with a
50148. prophet's pride. "I always said he was the only man capable of defeating
50149. Napoleon."
50150. 
50151. But next day no news arrived from the army and the public mood grew
50152. anxious. The courtiers suffered because of the suffering the suspense
50153. occasioned the Emperor.
50154. 
50155. "Fancy the Emperor's position!" said they, and instead of extolling
50156. Kutuzov as they had done the day before, they condemned him as the cause
50157. of the Emperor's anxiety. That day Prince Vasili no longer boasted of
50158. his protege Kutuzov, but remained silent when the commander in chief was
50159. mentioned. Moreover, toward evening, as if everything conspired to make
50160. Petersburg society anxious and uneasy, a terrible piece of news was
50161. added. Countess Helene Bezukhova had suddenly died of that terrible
50162. malady it had been so agreeable to mention. Officially, at large
50163. gatherings, everyone said that Countess Bezukhova had died of a
50164. terrible attack of angina pectoris, but in intimate circles details
50165. were mentioned of how the private physician of the Queen of Spain had
50166. prescribed small doses of a certain drug to produce a certain effect;
50167. but Helene, tortured by the fact that the old count suspected her and
50168. that her husband to whom she had written (that wretched, profligate
50169. Pierre) had not replied, had suddenly taken a very large dose of the
50170. drug, and had died in agony before assistance could be rendered her.
50171. It was said that Prince Vasili and the old count had turned upon the
50172. Italian, but the latter had produced such letters from the unfortunate
50173. deceased that they had immediately let the matter drop.
50174. 
50175. Talk in general centered round three melancholy facts: the Emperor's
50176. lack of news, the loss of Kutuzov, and the death of Helene.
50177. 
50178. On the third day after Kutuzov's report a country gentleman arrived from
50179. Moscow, and news of the surrender of Moscow to the French spread through
50180. the whole town. This was terrible! What a position for the Emperor to
50181. be in! Kutuzov was a traitor, and Prince Vasili during the visits of
50182. condolence paid to him on the occasion of his daughter's death said of
50183. Kutuzov, whom he had formerly praised (it was excusable for him in his
50184. grief to forget what he had said), that it was impossible to expect
50185. anything else from a blind and depraved old man.
50186. 
50187. "I only wonder that the fate of Russia could have been entrusted to such
50188. a man."
50189. 
50190. As long as this news remained unofficial it was possible to doubt it,
50191. but the next day the following communication was received from Count
50192. Rostopchin:
50193. 
50194. 
50195. Prince Kutuzov's adjutant has brought me a letter in which he demands
50196. police officers to guide the army to the Ryazan road. He writes that
50197. he is regretfully abandoning Moscow. Sire! Kutuzov's action decides the
50198. fate of the capital and of your empire! Russia will shudder to learn of
50199. the abandonment of the city in which her greatness is centered and in
50200. which lie the ashes of your ancestors! I shall follow the army. I have
50201. had everything removed, and it only remains for me to weep over the fate
50202. of my fatherland.
50203. 
50204. 
50205. On receiving this dispatch the Emperor sent Prince Volkonski to Kutuzov
50206. with the following rescript:
50207. 
50208. 
50209. Prince Michael Ilarionovich! Since the twenty-ninth of August I have
50210. received no communication from you, yet on the first of September I
50211. received from the commander in chief of Moscow, via Yaroslavl, the sad
50212. news that you, with the army, have decided to abandon Moscow. You can
50213. yourself imagine the effect this news has had on me, and your silence
50214. increases my astonishment. I am sending this by Adjutant-General Prince
50215. Volkonski, to hear from you the situation of the army and the reasons
50216. that have induced you to take this melancholy decision.
50217.

50222. CHAPTER III
50223. 
50224. 
50225. Nine days after the abandonment of Moscow, a messenger from Kutuzov
50226. reached Petersburg with the official announcement of that event. This
50227. messenger was Michaud, a Frenchman who did not know Russian, but who was
50228. quoique etranger, russe de coeur et d'ame, * as he said of himself.
50229. 
50230. 
50231.     * Though a foreigner, Russian in heart and soul.
50232. 
50233. 
50234. The Emperor at once received this messenger in his study at the palace
50235. on Stone Island. Michaud, who had never seen Moscow before the campaign
50236. and who did not know Russian, yet felt deeply moved (as he wrote) when
50237. he appeared before notre tres gracieux souverain * with the news of the
50238. burning of Moscow, dont les flammes eclairaient sa route. *(2)
50239. 
50240. 
50241.      * Our most gracious sovereign.
50242. 
50243.      * (2) Whose flames illumined his route.
50244. 
50245. 
50246. Though the source of M. Michaud's chagrin must have been different from
50247. that which caused Russians to grieve, he had such a sad face when shown
50248. into the Emperor's study that the latter at once asked:
50249. 
50250. "Have you brought me sad news, Colonel?"
50251. 
50252. "Very sad, sire," replied Michaud, lowering his eyes with a sigh. "The
50253. abandonment of Moscow."
50254. 
50255. "Have they surrendered my ancient capital without a battle?" asked the
50256. Emperor quickly, his face suddenly flushing.
50257. 
50258. Michaud respectfully delivered the message Kutuzov had entrusted to him,
50259. which was that it had been impossible to fight before Moscow, and that
50260. as the only remaining choice was between losing the army as well as
50261. Moscow, or losing Moscow alone, the field marshal had to choose the
50262. latter.
50263. 
50264. The Emperor listened in silence, not looking at Michaud.
50265. 
50266. "Has the enemy entered the city?" he asked.
50267. 
50268. "Yes, sire, and Moscow is now in ashes. I left it all in flames,"
50269. replied Michaud in a decided tone, but glancing at the Emperor he was
50270. frightened by what he had done.
50271. 
50272. The Emperor began to breathe heavily and rapidly, his lower lip
50273. trembled, and tears instantly appeared in his fine blue eyes.
50274. 
50275. But this lasted only a moment. He suddenly frowned, as if blaming
50276. himself for his weakness, and raising his head addressed Michaud in a
50277. firm voice:
50278. 
50279. "I see, Colonel, from all that is happening, that Providence requires
50280. great sacrifices of us... I am ready to submit myself in all things to
50281. His will; but tell me, Michaud, how did you leave the army when it
50282. saw my ancient capital abandoned without a battle? Did you not notice
50283. discouragement?..."
50284. 
50285. Seeing that his most gracious ruler was calm once more, Michaud also
50286. grew calm, but was not immediately ready to reply to the Emperor's
50287. direct and relevant question which required a direct answer.
50288. 
50289. "Sire, will you allow me to speak frankly as befits a loyal soldier?" he
50290. asked to gain time.
50291. 
50292. "Colonel, I always require it," replied the Emperor. "Conceal nothing
50293. from me, I wish to know absolutely how things are."
50294. 
50295. "Sire!" said Michaud with a subtle, scarcely perceptible smile on his
50296. lips, having now prepared a well-phrased reply, "sire, I left the
50297. whole army, from its chiefs to the lowest soldier, without exception in
50298. desperate and agonized terror..."
50299. 
50300. "How is that?" the Emperor interrupted him, frowning sternly. "Would
50301. misfortune make my Russians lose heart?... Never!"
50302. 
50303. Michaud had only waited for this to bring out the phrase he had
50304. prepared.
50305. 
50306. "Sire," he said, with respectful playfulness, "they are only afraid lest
50307. Your Majesty, in the goodness of your heart, should allow yourself to be
50308. persuaded to make peace. They are burning for the combat," declared this
50309. representative of the Russian nation, "and to prove to Your Majesty by
50310. the sacrifice of their lives how devoted they are...."
50311. 
50312. "Ah!" said the Emperor reassured, and with a kindly gleam in his eyes,
50313. he patted Michaud on the shoulder. "You set me at ease, Colonel."
50314. 
50315. He bent his head and was silent for some time.
50316. 
50317. "Well, then, go back to the army," he said, drawing himself up to his
50318. full height and addressing Michaud with a gracious and majestic gesture,
50319. "and tell our brave men and all my good subjects wherever you go that
50320. when I have not a soldier left I shall put myself at the head of my
50321. beloved nobility and my good peasants and so use the last resources of
50322. my empire. It still offers me more than my enemies suppose," said the
50323. Emperor growing more and more animated; "but should it ever be ordained
50324. by Divine Providence," he continued, raising to heaven his fine eyes
50325. shining with emotion, "that my dynasty should cease to reign on the
50326. throne of my ancestors, then after exhausting all the means at my
50327. command, I shall let my beard grow to here" (he pointed halfway down his
50328. chest) "and go and eat potatoes with the meanest of my peasants, rather
50329. than sign the disgrace of my country and of my beloved people whose
50330. sacrifices I know how to appreciate."
50331. 
50332. Having uttered these words in an agitated voice the Emperor suddenly
50333. turned away as if to hide from Michaud the tears that rose to his eyes,
50334. and went to the further end of his study. Having stood there a few
50335. moments, he strode back to Michaud and pressed his arm below the elbow
50336. with a vigorous movement. The Emperor's mild and handsome face was
50337. flushed and his eyes gleamed with resolution and anger.
50338. 
50339. "Colonel Michaud, do not forget what I say to you here, perhaps we may
50340. recall it with pleasure someday... Napoleon or I," said the Emperor,
50341. touching his breast. "We can no longer both reign together. I have
50342. learned to know him, and he will not deceive me any more...."
50343. 
50344. And the Emperor paused, with a frown.
50345. 
50346. When he heard these words and saw the expression of firm resolution
50347. in the Emperor's eyes, Michaud--quoique etranger, russe de coeur et
50348. d'ame--at that solemn moment felt himself enraptured by all that he had
50349. heard (as he used afterwards to say), and gave expression to his
50350. own feelings and those of the Russian people whose representative he
50351. considered himself to be, in the following words:
50352. 
50353. "Sire!" said he, "Your Majesty is at this moment signing the glory of
50354. the nation and the salvation of Europe!"
50355. 
50356. With an inclination of the head the Emperor dismissed him.
50357. 
50358. 
50359. 
50360. 
50361. 
50362. CHAPTER IV
50363. 
50364. 
50365. It is natural for us who were not living in those days to imagine that
50366. when half Russia had been conquered and the inhabitants were fleeing to
50367. distant provinces, and one levy after another was being raised for the
50368. defense of the fatherland, all Russians from the greatest to the least
50369. were solely engaged in sacrificing themselves, saving their fatherland,
50370. or weeping over its downfall. The tales and descriptions of that time
50371. without exception speak only of the self-sacrifice, patriotic devotion,
50372. despair, grief, and the heroism of the Russians. But it was not really
50373. so. It appears so to us because we see only the general historic
50374. interest of that time and do not see all the personal human interests
50375. that people had. Yet in reality those personal interests of the moment
50376. so much transcend the general interests that they always prevent the
50377. public interest from being felt or even noticed. Most of the people at
50378. that time paid no attention to the general progress of events but were
50379. guided only by their private interests, and they were the very people
50380. whose activities at that period were most useful.
50381. 
50382. Those who tried to understand the general course of events and to take
50383. part in it by self-sacrifice and heroism were the most useless members
50384. of society, they saw everything upside down, and all they did for the
50385. common good turned out to be useless and foolish--like Pierre's and
50386. Mamonov's regiments which looted Russian villages, and the lint the
50387. young ladies prepared and that never reached the wounded, and so on.
50388. Even those, fond of intellectual talk and of expressing their feelings,
50389. who discussed Russia's position at the time involuntarily introduced
50390. into their conversation either a shade of pretense and falsehood or
50391. useless condemnation and anger directed against people accused of
50392. actions no one could possibly be guilty of. In historic events the rule
50393. forbidding us to eat of the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge is specially
50394. applicable. Only unconscious action bears fruit, and he who plays a part
50395. in an historic event never understands its significance. If he tries to
50396. realize it his efforts are fruitless.
50397. 
50398. The more closely a man was engaged in the events then taking place in
50399. Russia the less did he realize their significance. In Petersburg and
50400. in the provinces at a distance from Moscow, ladies, and gentlemen in
50401. militia uniforms, wept for Russia and its ancient capital and talked of
50402. self-sacrifice and so on; but in the army which retired beyond Moscow
50403. there was little talk or thought of Moscow, and when they caught sight
50404. of its burned ruins no one swore to be avenged on the French, but they
50405. thought about their next pay, their next quarters, of Matreshka the
50406. vivandiere, and like matters.
50407. 
50408. As the war had caught him in the service, Nicholas Rostov took a close
50409. and prolonged part in the defense of his country, but did so casually,
50410. without any aim at self-sacrifice, and he therefore looked at what was
50411. going on in Russia without despair and without dismally racking his
50412. brains over it. Had he been asked what he thought of the state of
50413. Russia, he would have said that it was not his business to think about
50414. it, that Kutuzov and others were there for that purpose, but that he had
50415. heard that the regiments were to be made up to their full strength, that
50416. fighting would probably go on for a long time yet, and that things being
50417. so it was quite likely he might be in command of a regiment in a couple
50418. of years' time.
50419. 
50420. As he looked at the matter in this way, he learned that he was being
50421. sent to Voronezh to buy remounts for his division, not only without
50422. regret at being prevented from taking part in the coming battle, but
50423. with the greatest pleasure--which he did not conceal and which his
50424. comrades fully understood.
50425. 
50426. A few days before the battle of Borodino, Nicholas received the
50427. necessary money and warrants, and having sent some hussars on in
50428. advance, he set out with post horses for Voronezh.
50429. 
50430. Only a man who has experienced it--that is, has passed some months
50431. continuously in an atmosphere of campaigning and war--can understand
50432. the delight Nicholas felt when he escaped from the region covered by the
50433. army's foraging operations, provision trains, and hospitals. When--free
50434. from soldiers, wagons, and the filthy traces of a camp--he saw villages
50435. with peasants and peasant women, gentlemen's country houses, fields
50436. where cattle were grazing, posthouses with stationmasters asleep in
50437. them, he rejoiced as though seeing all this for the first time. What for
50438. a long while specially surprised and delighted him were the women, young
50439. and healthy, without a dozen officers making up to each of them; women,
50440. too, who were pleased and flattered that a passing officer should joke
50441. with them.
50442. 
50443. In the highest spirits Nicholas arrived at night at a hotel in Voronezh,
50444. ordered things he had long been deprived of in camp, and next day, very
50445. clean-shaven and in a full-dress uniform he had not worn for a long
50446. time, went to present himself to the authorities.
50447. 
50448. The commander of the militia was a civilian general, an old man who was
50449. evidently pleased with his military designation and rank. He received
50450. Nicholas brusquely (imagining this to be characteristically military)
50451. and questioned him with an important air, as if considering the general
50452. progress of affairs and approving and disapproving with full right to do
50453. so. Nicholas was in such good spirits that this merely amused him.
50454. 
50455. From the commander of the militia he drove to the governor. The governor
50456. was a brisk little man, very simple and affable. He indicated the stud
50457. farms at which Nicholas might procure horses, recommended to him a horse
50458. dealer in the town and a landowner fourteen miles out of town who had
50459. the best horses, and promised to assist him in every way.
50460. 
50461. "You are Count Ilya Rostov's son? My wife was a great friend of your
50462. mother's. We are at home on Thursdays--today is Thursday, so please come
50463. and see us quite informally," said the governor, taking leave of him.
50464. 
50465. Immediately on leaving the governor's, Nicholas hired post horses and,
50466. taking his squadron quartermaster with him, drove at a gallop to the
50467. landowner, fourteen miles away, who had the stud. Everything seemed to
50468. him pleasant and easy during that first part of his stay in Voronezh
50469. and, as usually happens when a man is in a pleasant state of mind,
50470. everything went well and easily.
50471. 
50472. The landowner to whom Nicholas went was a bachelor, an old cavalryman, a
50473. horse fancier, a sportsman, the possessor of some century-old brandy
50474. and some old Hungarian wine, who had a snuggery where he smoked, and who
50475. owned some splendid horses.
50476. 
50477. In very few words Nicholas bought seventeen picked stallions for six
50478. thousand rubles--to serve, as he said, as samples of his remounts.
50479. After dining and taking rather too much of the Hungarian wine,
50480. Nicholas--having exchanged kisses with the landowner, with whom he was
50481. already on the friendliest terms--galloped back over abominable roads,
50482. in the brightest frame of mind, continually urging on the driver so as
50483. to be in time for the governor's party.
50484. 
50485. When he had changed, poured water over his head, and scented himself,
50486. Nicholas arrived at the governor's rather late, but with the phrase
50487. "better late than never" on his lips.
50488. 
50489. It was not a ball, nor had dancing been announced, but everyone knew
50490. that Catherine Petrovna would play valses and the ecossaise on the
50491. clavichord and that there would be dancing, and so everyone had come as
50492. to a ball.
50493. 
50494. Provincial life in 1812 went on very much as usual, but with this
50495. difference, that it was livelier in the towns in consequence of the
50496. arrival of many wealthy families from Moscow, and as in everything that
50497. went on in Russia at that time a special recklessness was noticeable, an
50498. "in for a penny, in for a pound--who cares?" spirit, and the inevitable
50499. small talk, instead of turning on the weather and mutual acquaintances,
50500. now turned on Moscow, the army, and Napoleon.
50501. 
50502. The society gathered together at the governor's was the best in
50503. Voronezh.
50504. 
50505. There were a great many ladies and some of Nicholas' Moscow
50506. acquaintances, but there were no men who could at all vie with the
50507. cavalier of St. George, the hussar remount officer, the good-natured
50508. and well-bred Count Rostov. Among the men was an Italian prisoner, an
50509. officer of the French army; and Nicholas felt that the presence of that
50510. prisoner enhanced his own importance as a Russian hero. The Italian
50511. was, as it were, a war trophy. Nicholas felt this, it seemed to him
50512. that everyone regarded the Italian in the same light, and he treated him
50513. cordially though with dignity and restraint.
50514. 
50515. As soon as Nicholas entered in his hussar uniform, diffusing around him
50516. a fragrance of perfume and wine, and had uttered the words "better late
50517. than never" and heard them repeated several times by others, people
50518. clustered around him; all eyes turned on him, and he felt at once that
50519. he had entered into his proper position in the province--that of a
50520. universal favorite: a very pleasant position, and intoxicatingly so
50521. after his long privations. At posting stations, at inns, and in the
50522. landowner's snuggery, maidservants had been flattered by his notice, and
50523. here too at the governor's party there were (as it seemed to Nicholas)
50524. an inexhaustible number of pretty young women, married and unmarried,
50525. impatiently awaiting his notice. The women and girls flirted with him
50526. and, from the first day, the people concerned themselves to get this
50527. fine young daredevil of an hussar married and settled down. Among these
50528. was the governor's wife herself, who welcomed Rostov as a near relative
50529. and called him "Nicholas."
50530. 
50531. Catherine Petrovna did actually play valses and the ecossaise, and
50532. dancing began in which Nicholas still further captivated the provincial
50533. society by his agility. His particularly free manner of dancing even
50534. surprised them all. Nicholas was himself rather surprised at the way he
50535. danced that evening. He had never danced like that in Moscow and would
50536. even have considered such a very free and easy manner improper and in
50537. bad form, but here he felt it incumbent on him to astonish them all by
50538. something unusual, something they would have to accept as the regular
50539. thing in the capital though new to them in the provinces.
50540. 
50541. All the evening Nicholas paid attention to a blue-eyed, plump and
50542. pleasing little blonde, the wife of one of the provincial officials.
50543. With the naive conviction of young men in a merry mood that other men's
50544. wives were created for them, Rostov did not leave the lady's side and
50545. treated her husband in a friendly and conspiratorial style, as if,
50546. without speaking of it, they knew how capitally Nicholas and the lady
50547. would get on together. The husband, however, did not seem to share that
50548. conviction and tried to behave morosely with Rostov. But the
50549. latter's good-natured naivete was so boundless that sometimes even he
50550. involuntarily yielded to Nicholas' good humor. Toward the end of the
50551. evening, however, as the wife's face grew more flushed and animated, the
50552. husband's became more and more melancholy and solemn, as though there
50553. were but a given amount of animation between them and as the wife's
50554. share increased the husband's diminished.
50555. 
50556. 
50557. 
50558. 
50559. 
50560. CHAPTER V
50561. 
50562. 
50563. Nicholas sat leaning slightly forward in an armchair, bending closely
50564. over the blonde lady and paying her mythological compliments with a
50565. smile that never left his face. Jauntily shifting the position of his
50566. legs in their tight riding breeches, diffusing an odor of perfume, and
50567. admiring his partner, himself, and the fine outlines of his legs in
50568. their well-fitting Hessian boots, Nicholas told the blonde lady that he
50569. wished to run away with a certain lady here in Voronezh.
50570. 
50571. "Which lady?"
50572. 
50573. "A charming lady, a divine one. Her eyes" (Nicholas looked at his
50574. partner) "are blue, her mouth coral and ivory; her figure" (he glanced
50575. at her shoulders) "like Diana's...."
50576. 
50577. The husband came up and sullenly asked his wife what she was talking
50578. about.
50579. 
50580. "Ah, Nikita Ivanych!" cried Nicholas, rising politely, and as if wishing
50581. Nikita Ivanych to share his joke, he began to tell him of his intention
50582. to elope with a blonde lady.
50583. 
50584. The husband smiled gloomily, the wife gaily. The governor's good-natured
50585. wife came up with a look of disapproval.
50586. 
50587. "Anna Ignatyevna wants to see you, Nicholas," said she, pronouncing the
50588. name so that Nicholas at once understood that Anna Ignatyevna was a very
50589. important person. "Come, Nicholas! You know you let me call you so?"
50590. 
50591. "Oh, yes, Aunt. Who is she?"
50592. 
50593. "Anna Ignatyevna Malvintseva. She has heard from her niece how you
50594. rescued her... Can you guess?"
50595. 
50596. "I rescued such a lot of them!" said Nicholas.
50597. 
50598. "Her niece, Princess Bolkonskaya. She is here in Voronezh with her aunt.
50599. Oho! How you blush. Why, are...?"
50600. 
50601. "Not a bit! Please don't, Aunt!"
50602. 
50603. "Very well, very well!... Oh, what a fellow you are!"
50604. 
50605. The governor's wife led him up to a tall and very stout old lady with
50606. a blue headdress, who had just finished her game of cards with the most
50607. important personages of the town. This was Malvintseva, Princess Mary's
50608. aunt on her mother's side, a rich, childless widow who always lived in
50609. Voronezh. When Rostov approached her she was standing settling up for
50610. the game. She looked at him and, screwing up her eyes sternly, continued
50611. to upbraid the general who had won from her.
50612. 
50613. "Very pleased, mon cher," she then said, holding out her hand to
50614. Nicholas. "Pray come and see me."
50615. 
50616. After a few words about Princess Mary and her late father, whom
50617. Malvintseva had evidently not liked, and having asked what Nicholas
50618. knew of Prince Andrew, who also was evidently no favorite of hers, the
50619. important old lady dismissed Nicholas after repeating her invitation to
50620. come to see her.
50621. 
50622. Nicholas promised to come and blushed again as he bowed. At the mention
50623. of Princess Mary he experienced a feeling of shyness and even of fear,
50624. which he himself did not understand.
50625. 
50626. When he had parted from Malvintseva Nicholas wished to return to the
50627. dancing, but the governor's little wife placed her plump hand on his
50628. sleeve and, saying that she wanted to have a talk with him, led him to
50629. her sitting room, from which those who were there immediately withdrew
50630. so as not to be in her way.
50631. 
50632. "Do you know, dear boy," began the governor's wife with a serious
50633. expression on her kind little face, "that really would be the match for
50634. you: would you like me to arrange it?"
50635. 
50636. "Whom do you mean, Aunt?" asked Nicholas.
50637. 
50638. "I will make a match for you with the princess. Catherine Petrovna
50639. speaks of Lily, but I say, no--the princess! Do you want me to do it? I
50640. am sure your mother will be grateful to me. What a charming girl she is,
50641. really! And she is not at all so plain, either."
50642. 
50643. "Not at all," replied Nicholas as if offended at the idea. "As befits
50644. a soldier, Aunt, I don't force myself on anyone or refuse anything," he
50645. said before he had time to consider what he was saying.
50646. 
50647. "Well then, remember, this is not a joke!"
50648. 
50649. "Of course not!"
50650. 
50651. "Yes, yes," the governor's wife said as if talking to herself. "But,
50652. my dear boy, among other things you are too attentive to the other, the
50653. blonde. One is sorry for the husband, really...."
50654. 
50655. "Oh no, we are good friends with him," said Nicholas in the simplicity
50656. of his heart; it did not enter his head that a pastime so pleasant to
50657. himself might not be pleasant to someone else.
50658. 
50659. "But what nonsense I have been saying to the governor's wife!" thought
50660. Nicholas suddenly at supper. "She will really begin to arrange a
50661. match... and Sonya...?" And on taking leave of the governor's wife,
50662. when she again smilingly said to him, "Well then, remember!" he drew her
50663. aside.
50664. 
50665. "But see here, to tell the truth, Aunt..."
50666. 
50667. "What is it, my dear? Come, let's sit down here," said she.
50668. 
50669. Nicholas suddenly felt a desire and need to tell his most intimate
50670. thoughts (which he would not have told to his mother, his sister, or
50671. his friend) to this woman who was almost a stranger. When he afterwards
50672. recalled that impulse to unsolicited and inexplicable frankness which
50673. had very important results for him, it seemed to him--as it seems to
50674. everyone in such cases--that it was merely some silly whim that seized
50675. him: yet that burst of frankness, together with other trifling events,
50676. had immense consequences for him and for all his family.
50677. 
50678. "You see, Aunt, Mamma has long wanted me to marry an heiress, but the
50679. very idea of marrying for money is repugnant to me."
50680. 
50681. "Oh yes, I understand," said the governor's wife.
50682. 
50683. "But Princess Bolkonskaya--that's another matter. I will tell you the
50684. truth. In the first place I like her very much, I feel drawn to her; and
50685. then, after I met her under such circumstances--so strangely, the idea
50686. often occurred to me: 'This is fate.' Especially if you remember that
50687. Mamma had long been thinking of it; but I had never happened to meet her
50688. before, somehow it had always happened that we did not meet. And as long
50689. as my sister Natasha was engaged to her brother it was of course out of
50690. the question for me to think of marrying her. And it must needs happen
50691. that I should meet her just when Natasha's engagement had been broken
50692. off... and then everything... So you see... I never told this to anyone
50693. and never will, only to you."
50694. 
50695. The governor's wife pressed his elbow gratefully.
50696. 
50697. "You know Sonya, my cousin? I love her, and promised to marry her, and
50698. will do so.... So you see there can be no question about-" said Nicholas
50699. incoherently and blushing.
50700. 
50701. "My dear boy, what a way to look at it! You know Sonya has nothing and
50702. you yourself say your Papa's affairs are in a very bad way. And what
50703. about your mother? It would kill her, that's one thing. And what sort of
50704. life would it be for Sonya--if she's a girl with a heart? Your mother
50705. in despair, and you all ruined.... No, my dear, you and Sonya ought to
50706. understand that."
50707. 
50708. Nicholas remained silent. It comforted him to hear these arguments.
50709. 
50710. "All the same, Aunt, it is impossible," he rejoined with a sigh, after
50711. a short pause. "Besides, would the princess have me? And besides, she is
50712. now in mourning. How can one think of it!"
50713. 
50714. "But you don't suppose I'm going to get you married at once? There is
50715. always a right way of doing things," replied the governor's wife.
50716. 
50717. "What a matchmaker you are, Aunt..." said Nicholas, kissing her plump
50718. little hand.
50719. 
50720. 
50721. 
50722. 
50723. 
50724. CHAPTER VI
50725. 
50726. 
50727. On reaching Moscow after her meeting with Rostov, Princess Mary had
50728. found her nephew there with his tutor, and a letter from Prince Andrew
50729. giving her instructions how to get to her Aunt Malvintseva at Voronezh.
50730. That feeling akin to temptation which had tormented her during her
50731. father's illness, since his death, and especially since her meeting with
50732. Rostov was smothered by arrangements for the journey, anxiety about her
50733. brother, settling in a new house, meeting new people, and attending to
50734. her nephew's education. She was sad. Now, after a month passed in quiet
50735. surroundings, she felt more and more deeply the loss of her father which
50736. was associated in her mind with the ruin of Russia. She was agitated and
50737. incessantly tortured by the thought of the dangers to which her brother,
50738. the only intimate person now remaining to her, was exposed. She was
50739. worried too about her nephew's education for which she had always felt
50740. herself incompetent, but in the depths of her soul she felt at peace--a
50741. peace arising from consciousness of having stifled those personal dreams
50742. and hopes that had been on the point of awakening within her and were
50743. related to her meeting with Rostov.
50744. 
50745. The day after her party the governor's wife came to see Malvintseva
50746. and, after discussing her plan with the aunt, remarked that though
50747. under present circumstances a formal betrothal was, of course, not to be
50748. thought of, all the same the young people might be brought together and
50749. could get to know one another. Malvintseva expressed approval, and the
50750. governor's wife began to speak of Rostov in Mary's presence, praising
50751. him and telling how he had blushed when Princess Mary's name was
50752. mentioned. But Princess Mary experienced a painful rather than a joyful
50753. feeling--her mental tranquillity was destroyed, and desires, doubts,
50754. self-reproach, and hopes reawoke.
50755. 
50756. During the two days that elapsed before Rostov called, Princess Mary
50757. continually thought of how she ought to behave to him. First she decided
50758. not to come to the drawing room when he called to see her aunt--that it
50759. would not be proper for her, in her deep mourning, to receive visitors;
50760. then she thought this would be rude after what he had done for her; then
50761. it occurred to her that her aunt and the governor's wife had intentions
50762. concerning herself and Rostov--their looks and words at times seemed to
50763. confirm this supposition--then she told herself that only she, with
50764. her sinful nature, could think this of them: they could not forget that
50765. situated as she was, while still wearing deep mourning, such matchmaking
50766. would be an insult to her and to her father's memory. Assuming that she
50767. did go down to see him, Princess Mary imagined the words he would say
50768. to her and what she would say to him, and these words sometimes seemed
50769. undeservedly cold and then to mean too much. More than anything she
50770. feared lest the confusion she felt might overwhelm her and betray her as
50771. soon as she saw him.
50772. 
50773. But when on Sunday after church the footman announced in the drawing
50774. room that Count Rostov had called, the princess showed no confusion,
50775. only a slight blush suffused her cheeks and her eyes lit up with a new
50776. and radiant light.
50777. 
50778. "You have met him, Aunt?" said she in a calm voice, unable herself to
50779. understand that she could be outwardly so calm and natural.
50780. 
50781. When Rostov entered the room, the princess dropped her eyes for an
50782. instant, as if to give the visitor time to greet her aunt, and then
50783. just as Nicholas turned to her she raised her head and met his look with
50784. shining eyes. With a movement full of dignity and grace she half rose
50785. with a smile of pleasure, held out her slender, delicate hand to him,
50786. and began to speak in a voice in which for the first time new deep
50787. womanly notes vibrated. Mademoiselle Bourienne, who was in the drawing
50788. room, looked at Princess Mary in bewildered surprise. Herself a
50789. consummate coquette, she could not have maneuvered better on meeting a
50790. man she wished to attract.
50791. 
50792. "Either black is particularly becoming to her or she really has greatly
50793. improved without my having noticed it. And above all, what tact and
50794. grace!" thought Mademoiselle Bourienne.
50795. 
50796. Had Princess Mary been capable of reflection at that moment, she would
50797. have been more surprised than Mademoiselle Bourienne at the change that
50798. had taken place in herself. From the moment she recognized that dear,
50799. loved face, a new life force took possession of her and compelled her to
50800. speak and act apart from her own will. From the time Rostov entered, her
50801. face became suddenly transformed. It was as if a light had been kindled
50802. in a carved and painted lantern and the intricate, skillful, artistic
50803. work on its sides, that previously seemed dark, coarse, and meaningless,
50804. was suddenly shown up in unexpected and striking beauty. For the first
50805. time all that pure, spiritual, inward travail through which she had
50806. lived appeared on the surface. All her inward labor, her dissatisfaction
50807. with herself, her sufferings, her strivings after goodness, her
50808. meekness, love, and self-sacrifice--all this now shone in those radiant
50809. eyes, in her delicate smile, and in every trait of her gentle face.
50810. 
50811. Rostov saw all this as clearly as if he had known her whole life. He
50812. felt that the being before him was quite different from, and better
50813. than, anyone he had met before, and above all better than himself.
50814. 
50815. Their conversation was very simple and unimportant. They spoke of the
50816. war, and like everyone else unconsciously exaggerated their sorrow about
50817. it; they spoke of their last meeting--Nicholas trying to change
50818. the subject--they talked of the governor's kind wife, of Nicholas'
50819. relations, and of Princess Mary's.
50820. 
50821. She did not talk about her brother, diverting the conversation as soon
50822. as her aunt mentioned Andrew. Evidently she could speak of Russia's
50823. misfortunes with a certain artificiality, but her brother was too near
50824. her heart and she neither could nor would speak lightly of him. Nicholas
50825. noticed this, as he noticed every shade of Princess Mary's character
50826. with an observation unusual to him, and everything confirmed his
50827. conviction that she was a quite unusual and extraordinary being.
50828. Nicholas blushed and was confused when people spoke to him about the
50829. princess (as she did when he was mentioned) and even when he thought of
50830. her, but in her presence he felt quite at ease, and said not at all what
50831. he had prepared, but what, quite appropriately, occurred to him at the
50832. moment.
50833. 
50834. When a pause occurred during his short visit, Nicholas, as is usual when
50835. there are children, turned to Prince Andrew's little son, caressing him
50836. and asking whether he would like to be an hussar. He took the boy on
50837. his knee, played with him, and looked round at Princess Mary. With a
50838. softened, happy, timid look she watched the boy she loved in the arms
50839. of the man she loved. Nicholas also noticed that look and, as if
50840. understanding it, flushed with pleasure and began to kiss the boy with
50841. good natured playfulness.
50842. 
50843. As she was in mourning Princess Mary did not go out into society, and
50844. Nicholas did not think it the proper thing to visit her again; but all
50845. the same the governor's wife went on with her matchmaking, passing on to
50846. Nicholas the flattering things Princess Mary said of him and vice
50847. versa, and insisting on his declaring himself to Princess Mary. For this
50848. purpose she arranged a meeting between the young people at the bishop's
50849. house before Mass.
50850. 
50851. Though Rostov told the governor's wife that he would not make any
50852. declaration to Princess Mary, he promised to go.
50853. 
50854. As at Tilsit Rostov had not allowed himself to doubt that what everybody
50855. considered right was right, so now, after a short but sincere struggle
50856. between his effort to arrange his life by his own sense of justice, and
50857. in obedient submission to circumstances, he chose the latter and yielded
50858. to the power he felt irresistibly carrying him he knew not where. He
50859. knew that after his promise to Sonya it would be what he deemed base to
50860. declare his feelings to Princess Mary. And he knew that he would never
50861. act basely. But he also knew (or rather felt at the bottom of his heart)
50862. that by resigning himself now to the force of circumstances and to those
50863. who were guiding him, he was not only doing nothing wrong, but was doing
50864. something very important--more important than anything he had ever done
50865. in his life.
50866. 
50867. After meeting Princess Mary, though the course of his life went on
50868. externally as before, all his former amusements lost their charm for him
50869. and he often thought about her. But he never thought about her as he
50870. had thought of all the young ladies without exception whom he had met
50871. in society, nor as he had for a long time, and at one time rapturously,
50872. thought about Sonya. He had pictured each of those young ladies as
50873. almost all honest-hearted young men do, that is, as a possible wife,
50874. adapting her in his imagination to all the conditions of married life:
50875. a white dressing gown, his wife at the tea table, his wife's carriage,
50876. little ones, Mamma and Papa, their relations to her, and so on--and
50877. these pictures of the future had given him pleasure. But with Princess
50878. Mary, to whom they were trying to get him engaged, he could never
50879. picture anything of future married life. If he tried, his pictures
50880. seemed incongruous and false. It made him afraid.
50881. 
50882. 
50883. 
50884. 
50885. 
50886. CHAPTER VII
50887. 
50888. 
50889. The dreadful news of the battle of Borodino, of our losses in killed and
50890. wounded, and the still more terrible news of the loss of Moscow reached
50891. Voronezh in the middle of September. Princess Mary, having learned of
50892. her brother's wound only from the Gazette and having no definite news of
50893. him, prepared (so Nicholas heard, he had not seen her again himself) to
50894. set off in search of Prince Andrew.
50895. 
50896. When he received the news of the battle of Borodino and the abandonment
50897. of Moscow, Rostov was not seized with despair, anger, the desire for
50898. vengeance, or any feeling of that kind, but everything in Voronezh
50899. suddenly seemed to him dull and tiresome, and he experienced an
50900. indefinite feeling of shame and awkwardness. The conversations he heard
50901. seemed to him insincere; he did not know how to judge all these affairs
50902. and felt that only in the regiment would everything again become clear
50903. to him. He made haste to finish buying the horses, and often became
50904. unreasonably angry with his servant and squadron quartermaster.
50905. 
50906. A few days before his departure a special thanksgiving, at which
50907. Nicholas was present, was held in the cathedral for the Russian victory.
50908. He stood a little behind the governor and held himself with military
50909. decorum through the service, meditating on a great variety of subjects.
50910. When the service was over the governor's wife beckoned him to her.
50911. 
50912. "Have you seen the princess?" she asked, indicating with a movement of
50913. her head a lady standing on the opposite side, beyond the choir.
50914. 
50915. Nicholas immediately recognized Princess Mary not so much by the profile
50916. he saw under her bonnet as by the feeling of solicitude, timidity, and
50917. pity that immediately overcame him. Princess Mary, evidently engrossed
50918. by her thoughts, was crossing herself for the last time before leaving
50919. the church.
50920. 
50921. Nicholas looked at her face with surprise. It was the same face he had
50922. seen before, there was the same general expression of refined, inner,
50923. spiritual labor, but now it was quite differently lit up. There was a
50924. pathetic expression of sorrow, prayer, and hope in it. As had occurred
50925. before when she was present, Nicholas went up to her without waiting to
50926. be prompted by the governor's wife and not asking himself whether or not
50927. it was right and proper to address her here in church, and told her he
50928. had heard of her trouble and sympathized with his whole soul. As soon as
50929. she heard his voice a vivid glow kindled in her face, lighting up both
50930. her sorrow and her joy.
50931. 
50932. "There is one thing I wanted to tell you, Princess," said Rostov. "It
50933. is that if your brother, Prince Andrew Nikolievich, were not living, it
50934. would have been at once announced in the Gazette, as he is a colonel."
50935. 
50936. The princess looked at him, not grasping what he was saying, but cheered
50937. by the expression of regretful sympathy on his face.
50938. 
50939. "And I have known so many cases of a splinter wound" (the Gazette said
50940. it was a shell) "either proving fatal at once or being very slight,"
50941. continued Nicholas. "We must hope for the best, and I am sure..."
50942. 
50943. Princess Mary interrupted him.
50944. 
50945. "Oh, that would be so dread..." she began and, prevented by agitation
50946. from finishing, she bent her head with a movement as graceful as
50947. everything she did in his presence and, looking up at him gratefully,
50948. went out, following her aunt.
50949. 
50950. That evening Nicholas did not go out, but stayed at home to settle some
50951. accounts with the horse dealers. When he had finished that business it
50952. was already too late to go anywhere but still too early to go to bed,
50953. and for a long time he paced up and down the room, reflecting on his
50954. life, a thing he rarely did.
50955. 
50956. Princess Mary had made an agreeable impression on him when he had met
50957. her in Smolensk province. His having encountered her in such exceptional
50958. circumstances, and his mother having at one time mentioned her to him as
50959. a good match, had drawn his particular attention to her. When he met her
50960. again in Voronezh the impression she made on him was not merely pleasing
50961. but powerful. Nicholas had been struck by the peculiar moral beauty he
50962. observed in her at this time. He was, however, preparing to go away and
50963. it had not entered his head to regret that he was thus depriving himself
50964. of chances of meeting her. But that day's encounter in church had, he
50965. felt, sunk deeper than was desirable for his peace of mind. That pale,
50966. sad, refined face, that radiant look, those gentle graceful gestures,
50967. and especially the deep and tender sorrow expressed in all her features
50968. agitated him and evoked his sympathy. In men Rostov could not bear to
50969. see the expression of a higher spiritual life (that was why he did not
50970. like Prince Andrew) and he referred to it contemptuously as philosophy
50971. and dreaminess, but in Princess Mary that very sorrow which revealed
50972. the depth of a whole spiritual world foreign to him was an irresistible
50973. attraction.
50974. 
50975. "She must be a wonderful woman. A real angel!" he said to himself.
50976. "Why am I not free? Why was I in such a hurry with Sonya?" And he
50977. involuntarily compared the two: the lack of spirituality in the one and
50978. the abundance of it in the other--a spirituality he himself lacked and
50979. therefore valued most highly. He tried to picture what would happen were
50980. he free. How he would propose to her and how she would become his wife.
50981. But no, he could not imagine that. He felt awed, and no clear picture
50982. presented itself to his mind. He had long ago pictured to himself a
50983. future with Sonya, and that was all clear and simple just because it
50984. had all been thought out and he knew all there was in Sonya, but it was
50985. impossible to picture a future with Princess Mary, because he did not
50986. understand her but simply loved her.
50987. 
50988. Reveries about Sonya had had something merry and playful in them, but to
50989. dream of Princess Mary was always difficult and a little frightening.
50990. 
50991. "How she prayed!" he thought. "It was plain that her whole soul was in
50992. her prayer. Yes, that was the prayer that moves mountains, and I am
50993. sure her prayer will be answered. Why don't I pray for what I want?" he
50994. suddenly thought. "What do I want? To be free, released from Sonya...
50995. She was right," he thought, remembering what the governor's wife had
50996. said: "Nothing but misfortune can come of marrying Sonya. Muddles,
50997. grief for Mamma... business difficulties... muddles, terrible muddles!
50998. Besides, I don't love her--not as I should. O, God! release me from
50999. this dreadful, inextricable position!" he suddenly began to pray. "Yes,
51000. prayer can move mountains, but one must have faith and not pray as
51001. Natasha and I used to as children, that the snow might turn into
51002. sugar--and then run out into the yard to see whether it had done so.
51003. No, but I am not praying for trifles now," he thought as he put his pipe
51004. down in a corner, and folding his hands placed himself before the icon.
51005. Softened by memories of Princess Mary he began to pray as he had not
51006. done for a long time. Tears were in his eyes and in his throat when the
51007. door opened and Lavrushka came in with some papers.
51008. 
51009. "Blockhead! Why do you come in without being called?" cried Nicholas,
51010. quickly changing his attitude.
51011. 
51012. "From the governor," said Lavrushka in a sleepy voice. "A courier has
51013. arrived and there's a letter for you."
51014. 
51015. "Well, all right, thanks. You can go!"
51016. 
51017. Nicholas took the two letters, one of which was from his mother and
51018. the other from Sonya. He recognized them by the handwriting and opened
51019. Sonya's first. He had read only a few lines when he turned pale and his
51020. eyes opened wide with fear and joy.
51021. 
51022. "No, it's not possible!" he cried aloud.
51023. 
51024. Unable to sit still he paced up and down the room holding the letter and
51025. reading it. He glanced through it, then read it again, and then again,
51026. and standing still in the middle of the room he raised his shoulders,
51027. stretching out his hands, with his mouth wide open and his eyes fixed.
51028. What he had just been praying for with confidence that God would hear
51029. him had come to pass; but Nicholas was as much astonished as if it were
51030. something extraordinary and unexpected, and as if the very fact that it
51031. had happened so quickly proved that it had not come from God to whom he
51032. had prayed, but by some ordinary coincidence.
51033. 
51034. This unexpected and, as it seemed to Nicholas, quite voluntary letter
51035. from Sonya freed him from the knot that fettered him and from which
51036. there had seemed no escape. She wrote that the last unfortunate
51037. events--the loss of almost the whole of the Rostovs' Moscow
51038. property--and the countess' repeatedly expressed wish that Nicholas
51039. should marry Princess Bolkonskaya, together with his silence and
51040. coldness of late, had all combined to make her decide to release him
51041. from his promise and set him completely free.
51042. 
51043. 
51044. It would be too painful to me to think that I might be a cause of sorrow
51045. or discord in the family that has been so good to me (she wrote), and my
51046. love has no aim but the happiness of those I love; so, Nicholas, I
51047. beg you to consider yourself free, and to be assured that, in spite of
51048. everything, no one can love you more than does
51049. 
51050. Your Sonya
51051. 
51052. 
51053. Both letters were written from Troitsa. The other, from the countess,
51054. described their last days in Moscow, their departure, the fire, and
51055. the destruction of all their property. In this letter the countess also
51056. mentioned that Prince Andrew was among the wounded traveling with them;
51057. his state was very critical, but the doctor said there was now more
51058. hope. Sonya and Natasha were nursing him.
51059. 
51060. Next day Nicholas took his mother's letter and went to see Princess
51061. Mary. Neither he nor she said a word about what "Natasha nursing him"
51062. might mean, but thanks to this letter Nicholas suddenly became almost as
51063. intimate with the princess as if they were relations.
51064. 
51065. The following day he saw Princess Mary off on her journey to Yaroslavl,
51066. and a few days later left to rejoin his regiment.
51067. 
51068. 
51069. 
51070. 
51071. 
51072. CHAPTER VIII
51073. 
51074. 
51075. Sonya's letter written from Troitsa, which had come as an answer to
51076. Nicholas' prayer, was prompted by this: the thought of getting Nicholas
51077. married to an heiress occupied the old countess' mind more and more. She
51078. knew that Sonya was the chief obstacle to this happening, and Sonya's
51079. life in the countess' house had grown harder and harder, especially
51080. after they had received a letter from Nicholas telling of his meeting
51081. with Princess Mary in Bogucharovo. The countess let no occasion slip of
51082. making humiliating or cruel allusions to Sonya.
51083. 
51084. But a few days before they left Moscow, moved and excited by all that
51085. was going on, she called Sonya to her and, instead of reproaching and
51086. making demands on her, tearfully implored her to sacrifice herself
51087. and repay all that the family had done for her by breaking off her
51088. engagement with Nicholas.
51089. 
51090. "I shall not be at peace till you promise me this."
51091. 
51092. Sonya burst into hysterical tears and replied through her sobs that
51093. she would do anything and was prepared for anything, but gave no actual
51094. promise and could not bring herself to decide to do what was demanded
51095. of her. She must sacrifice herself for the family that had reared and
51096. brought her up. To sacrifice herself for others was Sonya's habit. Her
51097. position in the house was such that only by sacrifice could she show her
51098. worth, and she was accustomed to this and loved doing it. But in all her
51099. former acts of self-sacrifice she had been happily conscious that they
51100. raised her in her own esteem and in that of others, and so made her more
51101. worthy of Nicholas whom she loved more than anything in the world. But
51102. now they wanted her to sacrifice the very thing that constituted the
51103. whole reward for her self-sacrifice and the whole meaning of her life.
51104. And for the first time she felt bitterness against those who had been
51105. her benefactors only to torture her the more painfully; she felt jealous
51106. of Natasha who had never experienced anything of this sort, had never
51107. needed to sacrifice herself, but made others sacrifice themselves for
51108. her and yet was beloved by everybody. And for the first time Sonya felt
51109. that out of her pure, quiet love for Nicholas a passionate feeling
51110. was beginning to grow up which was stronger than principle, virtue,
51111. or religion. Under the influence of this feeling Sonya, whose life of
51112. dependence had taught her involuntarily to be secretive, having answered
51113. the countess in vague general terms, avoided talking with her and
51114. resolved to wait till she should see Nicholas, not in order to set him
51115. free but on the contrary at that meeting to bind him to her forever.
51116. 
51117. The bustle and terror of the Rostovs' last days in Moscow stifled the
51118. gloomy thoughts that oppressed Sonya. She was glad to find escape
51119. from them in practical activity. But when she heard of Prince Andrew's
51120. presence in their house, despite her sincere pity for him and for
51121. Natasha, she was seized by a joyful and superstitious feeling that God
51122. did not intend her to be separated from Nicholas. She knew that Natasha
51123. loved no one but Prince Andrew and had never ceased to love him. She
51124. knew that being thrown together again under such terrible circumstances
51125. they would again fall in love with one another, and that Nicholas would
51126. then not be able to marry Princess Mary as they would be within the
51127. prohibited degrees of affinity. Despite all the terror of what had
51128. happened during those last days and during the first days of their
51129. journey, this feeling that Providence was intervening in her personal
51130. affairs cheered Sonya.
51131. 
51132. At the Troitsa monastery the Rostovs first broke their journey for a
51133. whole day.
51134. 
51135. Three large rooms were assigned to them in the monastery hostelry, one
51136. of which was occupied by Prince Andrew. The wounded man was much better
51137. that day and Natasha was sitting with him. In the next room sat the
51138. count and countess respectfully conversing with the prior, who was
51139. calling on them as old acquaintances and benefactors of the monastery.
51140. Sonya was there too, tormented by curiosity as to what Prince Andrew and
51141. Natasha were talking about. She heard the sound of their voices through
51142. the door. That door opened and Natasha came out, looking excited. Not
51143. noticing the monk, who had risen to greet her and was drawing back the
51144. wide sleeve on his right arm, she went up to Sonya and took her hand.
51145. 
51146. "Natasha, what are you about? Come here!" said the countess.
51147. 
51148. Natasha went up to the monk for his blessing, and he advised her to pray
51149. for aid to God and His saint.
51150. 
51151. As soon as the prior withdrew, Natasha took her friend by the hand and
51152. went with her into the unoccupied room.
51153. 
51154. "Sonya, will he live?" she asked. "Sonya, how happy I am, and how
51155. unhappy!... Sonya, dovey, everything is as it used to be. If only he
51156. lives! He cannot... because... because... of" and Natasha burst into
51157. tears.
51158. 
51159. "Yes! I knew it! Thank God!" murmured Sonya. "He will live."
51160. 
51161. Sonya was not less agitated than her friend by the latter's fear and
51162. grief and by her own personal feelings which she shared with no one.
51163. Sobbing, she kissed and comforted Natasha. "If only he lives!" she
51164. thought. Having wept, talked, and wiped away their tears, the two
51165. friends went together to Prince Andrew's door. Natasha opened it
51166. cautiously and glanced into the room, Sonya standing beside her at the
51167. half-open door.
51168. 
51169. Prince Andrew was lying raised high on three pillows. His pale face was
51170. calm, his eyes closed, and they could see his regular breathing.
51171. 
51172. "O, Natasha!" Sonya suddenly almost screamed, catching her companion's
51173. arm and stepping back from the door.
51174. 
51175. "What? What is it?" asked Natasha.
51176. 
51177. "It's that, that..." said Sonya, with a white face and trembling lips.
51178. 
51179. Natasha softly closed the door and went with Sonya to the window, not
51180. yet understanding what the latter was telling her.
51181. 
51182. "You remember," said Sonya with a solemn and frightened expression.
51183. "You remember when I looked in the mirror for you... at Otradnoe at
51184. Christmas? Do you remember what I saw?"
51185. 
51186. "Yes, yes!" cried Natasha opening her eyes wide, and vaguely recalling
51187. that Sonya had told her something about Prince Andrew whom she had seen
51188. lying down.
51189. 
51190. "You remember?" Sonya went on. "I saw it then and told everybody, you
51191. and Dunyasha. I saw him lying on a bed," said she, making a gesture with
51192. her hand and a lifted finger at each detail, "and that he had his eyes
51193. closed and was covered just with a pink quilt, and that his hands were
51194. folded," she concluded, convincing herself that the details she had just
51195. seen were exactly what she had seen in the mirror.
51196. 
51197. She had in fact seen nothing then but had mentioned the first thing that
51198. came into her head, but what she had invented then seemed to her now
51199. as real as any other recollection. She not only remembered what she had
51200. then said--that he turned to look at her and smiled and was covered with
51201. something red--but was firmly convinced that she had then seen and said
51202. that he was covered with a pink quilt and that his eyes were closed.
51203. 
51204. "Yes, yes, it really was pink!" cried Natasha, who now thought she
51205. too remembered the word pink being used, and saw in this the most
51206. extraordinary and mysterious part of the prediction.
51207. 
51208. "But what does it mean?" she added meditatively.
51209. 
51210. "Oh, I don't know, it is all so strange," replied Sonya, clutching at
51211. her head.
51212. 
51213. A few minutes later Prince Andrew rang and Natasha went to him, but
51214. Sonya, feeling unusually excited and touched, remained at the window
51215. thinking about the strangeness of what had occurred.
51216. 
51217. 
51218. They had an opportunity that day to send letters to the army, and the
51219. countess was writing to her son.
51220. 
51221. "Sonya!" said the countess, raising her eyes from her letter as her
51222. niece passed, "Sonya, won't you write to Nicholas?" She spoke in a soft,
51223. tremulous voice, and in the weary eyes that looked over her spectacles
51224. Sonya read all that the countess meant to convey with these words. Those
51225. eyes expressed entreaty, shame at having to ask, fear of a refusal, and
51226. readiness for relentless hatred in case of such refusal.
51227. 
51228. Sonya went up to the countess and, kneeling down, kissed her hand.
51229. 
51230. "Yes, Mamma, I will write," said she.
51231. 
51232. Sonya was softened, excited, and touched by all that had occurred that
51233. day, especially by the mysterious fulfillment she had just seen of her
51234. vision. Now that she knew that the renewal of Natasha's relations with
51235. Prince Andrew would prevent Nicholas from marrying Princess Mary, she
51236. was joyfully conscious of a return of that self-sacrificing spirit in
51237. which she was accustomed to live and loved to live. So with a joyful
51238. consciousness of performing a magnanimous deed--interrupted several
51239. times by the tears that dimmed her velvety black eyes--she wrote that
51240. touching letter the arrival of which had so amazed Nicholas.
51241. 
51242. 
51243. 
51244. 
51245. 
51246. CHAPTER IX
51247. 
51248. 
51249. The officer and soldiers who had arrested Pierre treated him with
51250. hostility but yet with respect, in the guardhouse to which he was taken.
51251. In their attitude toward him could still be felt both uncertainty as
51252. to who he might be--perhaps a very important person--and hostility as a
51253. result of their recent personal conflict with him.
51254. 
51255. But when the guard was relieved next morning, Pierre felt that for the
51256. new guard--both officers and men--he was not as interesting as he had
51257. been to his captors; and in fact the guard of the second day did not
51258. recognize in this big, stout man in a peasant coat the vigorous person
51259. who had fought so desperately with the marauder and the convoy and had
51260. uttered those solemn words about saving a child; they saw in him only
51261. No. 17 of the captured Russians, arrested and detained for some reason
51262. by order of the Higher Command. If they noticed anything remarkable
51263. about Pierre, it was only his unabashed, meditative concentration
51264. and thoughtfulness, and the way he spoke French, which struck them as
51265. surprisingly good. In spite of this he was placed that day with the
51266. other arrested suspects, as the separate room he had occupied was
51267. required by an officer.
51268. 
51269. All the Russians confined with Pierre were men of the lowest class and,
51270. recognizing him as a gentleman, they all avoided him, more especially as
51271. he spoke French. Pierre felt sad at hearing them making fun of him.
51272. 
51273. That evening he learned that all these prisoners (he, probably, among
51274. them) were to be tried for incendiarism. On the third day he was taken
51275. with the others to a house where a French general with a white mustache
51276. sat with two colonels and other Frenchmen with scarves on their arms.
51277. With the precision and definiteness customary in addressing prisoners,
51278. and which is supposed to preclude human frailty, Pierre like the others
51279. was questioned as to who he was, where he had been, with what object,
51280. and so on.
51281. 
51282. These questions, like questions put at trials generally, left the
51283. essence of the matter aside, shut out the possibility of that essence's
51284. being revealed, and were designed only to form a channel through which
51285. the judges wished the answers of the accused to flow so as to lead to
51286. the desired result, namely a conviction. As soon as Pierre began to say
51287. anything that did not fit in with that aim, the channel was removed and
51288. the water could flow to waste. Pierre felt, moreover, what the accused
51289. always feel at their trial, perplexity as to why these questions were
51290. put to him. He had a feeling that it was only out of condescension or a
51291. kind of civility that this device of placing a channel was employed. He
51292. knew he was in these men's power, that only by force had they brought
51293. him there, that force alone gave them the right to demand answers
51294. to their questions, and that the sole object of that assembly was to
51295. inculpate him. And so, as they had the power and wish to inculpate
51296. him, this expedient of an inquiry and trial seemed unnecessary. It was
51297. evident that any answer would lead to conviction. When asked what he
51298. was doing when he was arrested, Pierre replied in a rather tragic manner
51299. that he was restoring to its parents a child he had saved from the
51300. flames. Why had he fought the marauder? Pierre answered that he "was
51301. protecting a woman," and that "to protect a woman who was being insulted
51302. was the duty of every man; that..." They interrupted him, for this
51303. was not to the point. Why was he in the yard of a burning house where
51304. witnesses had seen him? He replied that he had gone out to see what
51305. was happening in Moscow. Again they interrupted him: they had not asked
51306. where he was going, but why he was found near the fire? Who was he? they
51307. asked, repeating their first question, which he had declined to answer.
51308. Again he replied that he could not answer it.
51309. 
51310. "Put that down, that's bad... very bad," sternly remarked the general
51311. with the white mustache and red flushed face.
51312. 
51313. 
51314. On the fourth day fires broke out on the Zubovski rampart.
51315. 
51316. Pierre and thirteen others were moved to the coach house of a merchant's
51317. house near the Crimean bridge. On his way through the streets Pierre
51318. felt stifled by the smoke which seemed to hang over the whole
51319. city. Fires were visible on all sides. He did not then realize the
51320. significance of the burning of Moscow, and looked at the fires with
51321. horror.
51322. 
51323. He passed four days in the coach house near the Crimean bridge and
51324. during that time learned, from the talk of the French soldiers, that all
51325. those confined there were awaiting a decision which might come any day
51326. from the marshal. What marshal this was, Pierre could not learn from the
51327. soldiers. Evidently for them "the marshal" represented a very high and
51328. rather mysterious power.
51329. 
51330. These first days, before the eighth of September when the prisoners were
51331. had up for a second examination, were the hardest of all for Pierre.
51332.
