51333. 
51334. 
51335. 
51336. 
51337. CHAPTER X
51338. 
51339. 
51340. On the eighth of September an officer--a very important one judging by
51341. the respect the guards showed him--entered the coach house where the
51342. prisoners were. This officer, probably someone on the staff, was holding
51343. a paper in his hand, and called over all the Russians there, naming
51344. Pierre as "the man who does not give his name." Glancing indolently and
51345. indifferently at all the prisoners, he ordered the officer in charge
51346. to have them decently dressed and tidied up before taking them to the
51347. marshal. An hour later a squad of soldiers arrived and Pierre with
51348. thirteen others was led to the Virgin's Field. It was a fine day, sunny
51349. after rain, and the air was unusually pure. The smoke did not hang low
51350. as on the day when Pierre had been taken from the guardhouse on the
51351. Zubovski rampart, but rose through the pure air in columns. No flames
51352. were seen, but columns of smoke rose on all sides, and all Moscow as far
51353. as Pierre could see was one vast charred ruin. On all sides there were
51354. waste spaces with only stoves and chimney stacks still standing, and
51355. here and there the blackened walls of some brick houses. Pierre gazed
51356. at the ruins and did not recognize districts he had known well. Here and
51357. there he could see churches that had not been burned. The Kremlin, which
51358. was not destroyed, gleamed white in the distance with its towers and
51359. the belfry of Ivan the Great. The domes of the New Convent of the Virgin
51360. glittered brightly and its bells were ringing particularly clearly.
51361. These bells reminded Pierre that it was Sunday and the feast of the
51362. Nativity of the Virgin. But there seemed to be no one to celebrate this
51363. holiday: everywhere were blackened ruins, and the few Russians to be
51364. seen were tattered and frightened people who tried to hide when they saw
51365. the French.
51366. 
51367. It was plain that the Russian nest was ruined and destroyed, but in
51368. place of the Russian order of life that had been destroyed, Pierre
51369. unconsciously felt that a quite different, firm, French order had been
51370. established over this ruined nest. He felt this in the looks of
51371. the soldiers who, marching in regular ranks briskly and gaily, were
51372. escorting him and the other criminals; he felt it in the looks of an
51373. important French official in a carriage and pair driven by a soldier,
51374. whom they met on the way. He felt it in the merry sounds of regimental
51375. music he heard from the left side of the field, and felt and realized
51376. it especially from the list of prisoners the French officer had read out
51377. when he came that morning. Pierre had been taken by one set of soldiers
51378. and led first to one and then to another place with dozens of other men,
51379. and it seemed that they might have forgotten him, or confused him with
51380. the others. But no: the answers he had given when questioned had come
51381. back to him in his designation as "the man who does not give his name,"
51382. and under that appellation, which to Pierre seemed terrible, they were
51383. now leading him somewhere with unhesitating assurance on their faces
51384. that he and all the other prisoners were exactly the ones they wanted
51385. and that they were being taken to the proper place. Pierre felt himself
51386. to be an insignificant chip fallen among the wheels of a machine whose
51387. action he did not understand but which was working well.
51388. 
51389. He and the other prisoners were taken to the right side of the Virgin's
51390. Field, to a large white house with an immense garden not far from the
51391. convent. This was Prince Shcherbitov's house, where Pierre had often
51392. been in other days, and which, as he learned from the talk of the
51393. soldiers, was now occupied by the marshal, the Duke of Eckmuhl (Davout).
51394. 
51395. They were taken to the entrance and led into the house one by one.
51396. Pierre was the sixth to enter. He was conducted through a glass gallery,
51397. an anteroom, and a hall, which were familiar to him, into a long low
51398. study at the door of which stood an adjutant.
51399. 
51400. Davout, spectacles on nose, sat bent over a table at the further end of
51401. the room. Pierre went close up to him, but Davout, evidently consulting
51402. a paper that lay before him, did not look up. Without raising his eyes,
51403. he said in a low voice:
51404. 
51405. "Who are you?"
51406. 
51407. Pierre was silent because he was incapable of uttering a word. To him
51408. Davout was not merely a French general, but a man notorious for his
51409. cruelty. Looking at his cold face, as he sat like a stern schoolmaster
51410. who was prepared to wait awhile for an answer, Pierre felt that every
51411. instant of delay might cost him his life; but he did not know what
51412. to say. He did not venture to repeat what he had said at his first
51413. examination, yet to disclose his rank and position was dangerous and
51414. embarrassing. So he was silent. But before he had decided what to do,
51415. Davout raised his head, pushed his spectacles back on his forehead,
51416. screwed up his eyes, and looked intently at him.
51417. 
51418. "I know that man," he said in a cold, measured tone, evidently
51419. calculated to frighten Pierre.
51420. 
51421. The chill that had been running down Pierre's back now seized his head
51422. as in a vise.
51423. 
51424. "You cannot know me, General, I have never seen you..."
51425. 
51426. "He is a Russian spy," Davout interrupted, addressing another general
51427. who was present, but whom Pierre had not noticed.
51428. 
51429. Davout turned away. With an unexpected reverberation in his voice Pierre
51430. rapidly began:
51431. 
51432. "No, monseigneur," he said, suddenly remembering that Davout was a duke.
51433. "No, monseigneur, you cannot have known me. I am a militia officer and
51434. have not quitted Moscow."
51435. 
51436. "Your name?" asked Davout.
51437. 
51438. "Bezukhov."
51439. 
51440. "What proof have I that you are not lying?"
51441. 
51442. "Monseigneur!" exclaimed Pierre, not in an offended but in a pleading
51443. voice.
51444. 
51445. Davout looked up and gazed intently at him. For some seconds they looked
51446. at one another, and that look saved Pierre. Apart from conditions of war
51447. and law, that look established human relations between the two men. At
51448. that moment an immense number of things passed dimly through both their
51449. minds, and they realized that they were both children of humanity and
51450. were brothers.
51451. 
51452. At the first glance, when Davout had only raised his head from the
51453. papers where human affairs and lives were indicated by numbers, Pierre
51454. was merely a circumstance, and Davout could have shot him without
51455. burdening his conscience with an evil deed, but now he saw in him a
51456. human being. He reflected for a moment.
51457. 
51458. "How can you show me that you are telling the truth?" said Davout
51459. coldly.
51460. 
51461. Pierre remembered Ramballe, and named him and his regiment and the
51462. street where the house was.
51463. 
51464. "You are not what you say," returned Davout.
51465. 
51466. In a trembling, faltering voice Pierre began adducing proofs of the
51467. truth of his statements.
51468. 
51469. But at that moment an adjutant entered and reported something to Davout.
51470. 
51471. Davout brightened up at the news the adjutant brought, and began
51472. buttoning up his uniform. It seemed that he had quite forgotten Pierre.
51473. 
51474. When the adjutant reminded him of the prisoner, he jerked his head in
51475. Pierre's direction with a frown and ordered him to be led away. But
51476. where they were to take him Pierre did not know: back to the coach house
51477. or to the place of execution his companions had pointed out to him as
51478. they crossed the Virgin's Field.
51479. 
51480. He turned his head and saw that the adjutant was putting another
51481. question to Davout.
51482. 
51483. "Yes, of course!" replied Davout, but what this "yes" meant, Pierre did
51484. not know.
51485. 
51486. Pierre could not afterwards remember how he went, whether it was far, or
51487. in which direction. His faculties were quite numbed, he was stupefied,
51488. and noticing nothing around him went on moving his legs as the others
51489. did till they all stopped and he stopped too. The only thought in his
51490. mind at that time was: who was it that had really sentenced him to
51491. death? Not the men on the commission that had first examined him--not
51492. one of them wished to or, evidently, could have done it. It was not
51493. Davout, who had looked at him in so human a way. In another moment
51494. Davout would have realized that he was doing wrong, but just then
51495. the adjutant had come in and interrupted him. The adjutant, also, had
51496. evidently had no evil intent though he might have refrained from coming
51497. in. Then who was executing him, killing him, depriving him of life--him,
51498. Pierre, with all his memories, aspirations, hopes, and thoughts? Who was
51499. doing this? And Pierre felt that it was no one.
51500. 
51501. It was a system--a concurrence of circumstances.
51502. 
51503. A system of some sort was killing him--Pierre--depriving him of life, of
51504. everything, annihilating him.
51505. 
51506. 
51507. 
51508. 
51509. 
51510. CHAPTER XI
51511. 
51512. 
51513. From Prince Shcherbatov's house the prisoners were led straight down the
51514. Virgin's Field, to the left of the nunnery, as far as a kitchen garden
51515. in which a post had been set up. Beyond that post a fresh pit had been
51516. dug in the ground, and near the post and the pit a large crowd stood
51517. in a semicircle. The crowd consisted of a few Russians and many of
51518. Napoleon's soldiers who were not on duty--Germans, Italians, and
51519. Frenchmen, in a variety of uniforms. To the right and left of the post
51520. stood rows of French troops in blue uniforms with red epaulets and high
51521. boots and shakos.
51522. 
51523. The prisoners were placed in a certain order, according to the list
51524. (Pierre was sixth), and were led to the post. Several drums suddenly
51525. began to beat on both sides of them, and at that sound Pierre felt as
51526. if part of his soul had been torn away. He lost the power of thinking
51527. or understanding. He could only hear and see. And he had only one
51528. wish--that the frightful thing that had to happen should happen quickly.
51529. Pierre looked round at his fellow prisoners and scrutinized them.
51530. 
51531. The two first were convicts with shaven heads. One was tall and thin,
51532. the other dark, shaggy, and sinewy, with a flat nose. The third was
51533. a domestic serf, about forty-five years old, with grizzled hair and a
51534. plump, well-nourished body. The fourth was a peasant, a very handsome
51535. man with a broad, light-brown beard and black eyes. The fifth was a
51536. factory hand, a thin, sallow-faced lad of eighteen in a loose coat.
51537. 
51538. Pierre heard the French consulting whether to shoot them separately or
51539. two at a time. "In couples," replied the officer in command in a calm
51540. voice. There was a stir in the ranks of the soldiers and it was evident
51541. that they were all hurrying--not as men hurry to do something they
51542. understand, but as people hurry to finish a necessary but unpleasant and
51543. incomprehensible task.
51544. 
51545. A French official wearing a scarf came up to the right of the row of
51546. prisoners and read out the sentence in Russian and in French.
51547. 
51548. Then two pairs of Frenchmen approached the criminals and at the
51549. officer's command took the two convicts who stood first in the row. The
51550. convicts stopped when they reached the post and, while sacks were being
51551. brought, looked dumbly around as a wounded beast looks at an approaching
51552. huntsman. One crossed himself continually, the other scratched his back
51553. and made a movement of the lips resembling a smile. With hurried hands
51554. the soldiers blindfolded them, drawing the sacks over their heads, and
51555. bound them to the post.
51556. 
51557. Twelve sharpshooters with muskets stepped out of the ranks with a firm
51558. regular tread and halted eight paces from the post. Pierre turned away
51559. to avoid seeing what was going to happen. Suddenly a crackling, rolling
51560. noise was heard which seemed to him louder than the most terrific
51561. thunder, and he looked round. There was some smoke, and the Frenchmen
51562. were doing something near the pit, with pale faces and trembling hands.
51563. Two more prisoners were led up. In the same way and with similar looks,
51564. these two glanced vainly at the onlookers with only a silent appeal for
51565. protection in their eyes, evidently unable to understand or believe
51566. what was going to happen to them. They could not believe it because they
51567. alone knew what their life meant to them, and so they neither understood
51568. nor believed that it could be taken from them.
51569. 
51570. Again Pierre did not wish to look and again turned away; but again the
51571. sound as of a frightful explosion struck his ear, and at the same moment
51572. he saw smoke, blood, and the pale, scared faces of the Frenchmen who
51573. were again doing something by the post, their trembling hands impeding
51574. one another. Pierre, breathing heavily, looked around as if asking what
51575. it meant. The same question was expressed in all the looks that met his.
51576. 
51577. On the faces of all the Russians and of the French soldiers and officers
51578. without exception, he read the same dismay, horror, and conflict that
51579. were in his own heart. "But who, after all, is doing this? They are all
51580. suffering as I am. Who then is it? Who?" flashed for an instant through
51581. his mind.
51582. 
51583. "Sharpshooters of the 86th, forward!" shouted someone. The fifth
51584. prisoner, the one next to Pierre, was led away--alone. Pierre did not
51585. understand that he was saved, that he and the rest had been brought
51586. there only to witness the execution. With ever-growing horror, and no
51587. sense of joy or relief, he gazed at what was taking place. The fifth man
51588. was the factory lad in the loose cloak. The moment they laid hands on
51589. him he sprang aside in terror and clutched at Pierre. (Pierre shuddered
51590. and shook himself free.) The lad was unable to walk. They dragged him
51591. along, holding him up under the arms, and he screamed. When they got
51592. him to the post he grew quiet, as if he suddenly understood something.
51593. Whether he understood that screaming was useless or whether he thought
51594. it incredible that men should kill him, at any rate he took his stand at
51595. the post, waiting to be blindfolded like the others, and like a wounded
51596. animal looked around him with glittering eyes.
51597. 
51598. Pierre was no longer able to turn away and close his eyes. His curiosity
51599. and agitation, like that of the whole crowd, reached the highest pitch
51600. at this fifth murder. Like the others this fifth man seemed calm; he
51601. wrapped his loose cloak closer and rubbed one bare foot with the other.
51602. 
51603. When they began to blindfold him he himself adjusted the knot which
51604. hurt the back of his head; then when they propped him against the
51605. bloodstained post, he leaned back and, not being comfortable in that
51606. position, straightened himself, adjusted his feet, and leaned back again
51607. more comfortably. Pierre did not take his eyes from him and did not miss
51608. his slightest movement.
51609. 
51610. Probably a word of command was given and was followed by the reports of
51611. eight muskets; but try as he would Pierre could not afterwards remember
51612. having heard the slightest sound of the shots. He only saw how the
51613. workman suddenly sank down on the cords that held him, how blood showed
51614. itself in two places, how the ropes slackened under the weight of the
51615. hanging body, and how the workman sat down, his head hanging unnaturally
51616. and one leg bent under him. Pierre ran up to the post. No one hindered
51617. him. Pale, frightened people were doing something around the workman.
51618. The lower jaw of an old Frenchman with a thick mustache trembled as he
51619. untied the ropes. The body collapsed. The soldiers dragged it awkwardly
51620. from the post and began pushing it into the pit.
51621. 
51622. They all plainly and certainly knew that they were criminals who must
51623. hide the traces of their guilt as quickly as possible.
51624. 
51625. Pierre glanced into the pit and saw that the factory lad was lying with
51626. his knees close up to his head and one shoulder higher than the other.
51627. That shoulder rose and fell rhythmically and convulsively, but spadefuls
51628. of earth were already being thrown over the whole body. One of the
51629. soldiers, evidently suffering, shouted gruffly and angrily at Pierre to
51630. go back. But Pierre did not understand him and remained near the post,
51631. and no one drove him away.
51632. 
51633. When the pit had been filled up a command was given. Pierre was taken
51634. back to his place, and the rows of troops on both sides of the post
51635. made a half turn and went past it at a measured pace. The twenty-four
51636. sharpshooters with discharged muskets, standing in the center of the
51637. circle, ran back to their places as the companies passed by.
51638. 
51639. Pierre gazed now with dazed eyes at these sharpshooters who ran in
51640. couples out of the circle. All but one rejoined their companies. This
51641. one, a young soldier, his face deadly pale, his shako pushed back, and
51642. his musket resting on the ground, still stood near the pit at the spot
51643. from which he had fired. He swayed like a drunken man, taking some steps
51644. forward and back to save himself from falling. An old, noncommissioned
51645. officer ran out of the ranks and taking him by the elbow dragged him to
51646. his company. The crowd of Russians and Frenchmen began to disperse. They
51647. all went away silently and with drooping heads.
51648. 
51649. "That will teach them to start fires," said one of the Frenchmen.
51650. 
51651. Pierre glanced round at the speaker and saw that it was a soldier who
51652. was trying to find some relief after what had been done, but was not
51653. able to do so. Without finishing what he had begun to say he made a
51654. hopeless movement with his arm and went away.
51655. 
51656. 
51657. 
51658. 
51659. 
51660. CHAPTER XII
51661. 
51662. 
51663. After the execution Pierre was separated from the rest of the prisoners
51664. and placed alone in a small, ruined, and befouled church.
51665. 
51666. Toward evening a noncommissioned officer entered with two soldiers and
51667. told him that he had been pardoned and would now go to the barracks for
51668. the prisoners of war. Without understanding what was said to him, Pierre
51669. got up and went with the soldiers. They took him to the upper end of the
51670. field, where there were some sheds built of charred planks, beams,
51671. and battens, and led him into one of them. In the darkness some twenty
51672. different men surrounded Pierre. He looked at them without understanding
51673. who they were, why they were there, or what they wanted of him. He heard
51674. what they said, but did not understand the meaning of the words and
51675. made no kind of deduction from or application of them. He replied to
51676. questions they put to him, but did not consider who was listening to his
51677. replies, nor how they would understand them. He looked at their faces
51678. and figures, but they all seemed to him equally meaningless.
51679. 
51680. From the moment Pierre had witnessed those terrible murders committed by
51681. men who did not wish to commit them, it was as if the mainspring of
51682. his life, on which everything depended and which made everything appear
51683. alive, had suddenly been wrenched out and everything had collapsed
51684. into a heap of meaningless rubbish. Though he did not acknowledge it to
51685. himself, his faith in the right ordering of the universe, in humanity,
51686. in his own soul, and in God, had been destroyed. He had experienced this
51687. before, but never so strongly as now. When similar doubts had assailed
51688. him before, they had been the result of his own wrongdoing, and at the
51689. bottom of his heart he had felt that relief from his despair and from
51690. those doubts was to be found within himself. But now he felt that
51691. the universe had crumbled before his eyes and only meaningless ruins
51692. remained, and this not by any fault of his own. He felt that it was not
51693. in his power to regain faith in the meaning of life.
51694. 
51695. Around him in the darkness men were standing and evidently something
51696. about him interested them greatly. They were telling him something and
51697. asking him something. Then they led him away somewhere, and at last he
51698. found himself in a corner of the shed among men who were laughing and
51699. talking on all sides.
51700. 
51701. "Well, then, mates... that very prince who..." some voice at the other
51702. end of the shed was saying, with a strong emphasis on the word who.
51703. 
51704. Sitting silent and motionless on a heap of straw against the wall,
51705. Pierre sometimes opened and sometimes closed his eyes. But as soon as
51706. he closed them he saw before him the dreadful face of the factory
51707. lad--especially dreadful because of its simplicity--and the faces of the
51708. murderers, even more dreadful because of their disquiet. And he opened
51709. his eyes again and stared vacantly into the darkness around him.
51710. 
51711. Beside him in a stooping position sat a small man of whose presence he
51712. was first made aware by a strong smell of perspiration which came from
51713. him every time he moved. This man was doing something to his legs in the
51714. darkness, and though Pierre could not see his face he felt that the man
51715. continually glanced at him. On growing used to the darkness Pierre saw
51716. that the man was taking off his leg bands, and the way he did it aroused
51717. Pierre's interest.
51718. 
51719. Having unwound the string that tied the band on one leg, he carefully
51720. coiled it up and immediately set to work on the other leg, glancing up
51721. at Pierre. While one hand hung up the first string the other was already
51722. unwinding the band on the second leg. In this way, having carefully
51723. removed the leg bands by deft circular motions of his arm following
51724. one another uninterruptedly, the man hung the leg bands up on some pegs
51725. fixed above his head. Then he took out a knife, cut something, closed
51726. the knife, placed it under the head of his bed, and, seating himself
51727. comfortably, clasped his arms round his lifted knees and fixed his eyes
51728. on Pierre. The latter was conscious of something pleasant, comforting,
51729. and well rounded in these deft movements, in the man's well-ordered
51730. arrangements in his corner, and even in his very smell, and he looked at
51731. the man without taking his eyes from him.
51732. 
51733. "You've seen a lot of trouble, sir, eh?" the little man suddenly said.
51734. 
51735. And there was so much kindliness and simplicity in his singsong voice
51736. that Pierre tried to reply, but his jaw trembled and he felt tears
51737. rising to his eyes. The little fellow, giving Pierre no time to betray
51738. his confusion, instantly continued in the same pleasant tones:
51739. 
51740. "Eh, lad, don't fret!" said he, in the tender singsong caressing voice
51741. old Russian peasant women employ. "Don't fret, friend--'suffer an hour,
51742. live for an age!' that's how it is, my dear fellow. And here we live,
51743. thank heaven, without offense. Among these folk, too, there are good
51744. men as well as bad," said he, and still speaking, he turned on his knees
51745. with a supple movement, got up, coughed, and went off to another part of
51746. the shed.
51747. 
51748. "Eh, you rascal!" Pierre heard the same kind voice saying at the other
51749. end of the shed. "So you've come, you rascal? She remembers... Now, now,
51750. that'll do!"
51751. 
51752. And the soldier, pushing away a little dog that was jumping up at
51753. him, returned to his place and sat down. In his hands he had something
51754. wrapped in a rag.
51755. 
51756. "Here, eat a bit, sir," said he, resuming his former respectful tone as
51757. he unwrapped and offered Pierre some baked potatoes. "We had soup for
51758. dinner and the potatoes are grand!"
51759. 
51760. Pierre had not eaten all day and the smell of the potatoes seemed
51761. extremely pleasant to him. He thanked the soldier and began to eat.
51762. 
51763. "Well, are they all right?" said the soldier with a smile. "You should
51764. do like this."
51765. 
51766. He took a potato, drew out his clasp knife, cut the potato into two
51767. equal halves on the palm of his hand, sprinkled some salt on it from the
51768. rag, and handed it to Pierre.
51769. 
51770. "The potatoes are grand!" he said once more. "Eat some like that!"
51771. 
51772. Pierre thought he had never eaten anything that tasted better.
51773. 
51774. "Oh, I'm all right," said he, "but why did they shoot those poor
51775. fellows? The last one was hardly twenty."
51776. 
51777. "Tss, tt...!" said the little man. "Ah, what a sin... what a sin!" he
51778. added quickly, and as if his words were always waiting ready in his
51779. mouth and flew out involuntarily he went on: "How was it, sir, that you
51780. stayed in Moscow?"
51781. 
51782. "I didn't think they would come so soon. I stayed accidentally," replied
51783. Pierre.
51784. 
51785. "And how did they arrest you, dear lad? At your house?"
51786. 
51787. "No, I went to look at the fire, and they arrested me there, and tried
51788. me as an incendiary."
51789. 
51790. "Where there's law there's injustice," put in the little man.
51791. 
51792. "And have you been here long?" Pierre asked as he munched the last of
51793. the potato.
51794. 
51795. "I? It was last Sunday they took me, out of a hospital in Moscow."
51796. 
51797. "Why, are you a soldier then?"
51798. 
51799. "Yes, we are soldiers of the Apsheron regiment. I was dying of fever. We
51800. weren't told anything. There were some twenty of us lying there. We had
51801. no idea, never guessed at all."
51802. 
51803. "And do you feel sad here?" Pierre inquired.
51804. 
51805. "How can one help it, lad? My name is Platon, and the surname is
51806. Karataev," he added, evidently wishing to make it easier for Pierre to
51807. address him. "They call me 'little falcon' in the regiment. How is one
51808. to help feeling sad? Moscow--she's the mother of cities. How can one see
51809. all this and not feel sad? But 'the maggot gnaws the cabbage, yet dies
51810. first'; that's what the old folks used to tell us," he added rapidly.
51811. 
51812. "What? What did you say?" asked Pierre.
51813. 
51814. "Who? I?" said Karataev. "I say things happen not as we plan but as God
51815. judges," he replied, thinking that he was repeating what he had said
51816. before, and immediately continued:
51817. 
51818. "Well, and you, have you a family estate, sir? And a house? So you have
51819. abundance, then? And a housewife? And your old parents, are they still
51820. living?" he asked.
51821. 
51822. And though it was too dark for Pierre to see, he felt that a suppressed
51823. smile of kindliness puckered the soldier's lips as he put these
51824. questions. He seemed grieved that Pierre had no parents, especially that
51825. he had no mother.
51826. 
51827. "A wife for counsel, a mother-in-law for welcome, but there's none as
51828. dear as one's own mother!" said he. "Well, and have you little ones?" he
51829. went on asking.
51830. 
51831. Again Pierre's negative answer seemed to distress him, and he hastened
51832. to add:
51833. 
51834. "Never mind! You're young folks yet, and please God may still have some.
51835. The great thing is to live in harmony...."
51836. 
51837. "But it's all the same now," Pierre could not help saying.
51838. 
51839. "Ah, my dear fellow!" rejoined Karataev, "never decline a prison or a
51840. beggar's sack!"
51841. 
51842. He seated himself more comfortably and coughed, evidently preparing to
51843. tell a long story.
51844. 
51845. "Well, my dear fellow, I was still living at home," he began. "We had
51846. a well-to-do homestead, plenty of land, we peasants lived well and our
51847. house was one to thank God for. When Father and we went out mowing
51848. there were seven of us. We lived well. We were real peasants. It so
51849. happened..."
51850. 
51851. And Platon Karataev told a long story of how he had gone into someone's
51852. copse to take wood, how he had been caught by the keeper, had been
51853. tried, flogged, and sent to serve as a soldier.
51854. 
51855. "Well, lad," and a smile changed the tone of his voice "we thought it
51856. was a misfortune but it turned out a blessing! If it had not been for
51857. my sin, my brother would have had to go as a soldier. But he, my younger
51858. brother, had five little ones, while I, you see, only left a wife
51859. behind. We had a little girl, but God took her before I went as a
51860. soldier. I come home on leave and I'll tell you how it was, I look and
51861. see that they are living better than before. The yard full of cattle,
51862. the women at home, two brothers away earning wages, and only Michael the
51863. youngest, at home. Father, he says, 'All my children are the same to
51864. me: it hurts the same whichever finger gets bitten. But if Platon hadn't
51865. been shaved for a soldier, Michael would have had to go.' called us
51866. all to him and, will you believe it, placed us in front of the icons.
51867. 'Michael,' he says, 'come here and bow down to his feet; and you, young
51868. woman, you bow down too; and you, grandchildren, also bow down before
51869. him! Do you understand?' he says. That's how it is, dear fellow. Fate
51870. looks for a head. But we are always judging, 'that's not well--that's
51871. not right!' Our luck is like water in a dragnet: you pull at it and it
51872. bulges, but when you've drawn it out it's empty! That's how it is."
51873. 
51874. And Platon shifted his seat on the straw.
51875. 
51876. After a short silence he rose.
51877. 
51878. "Well, I think you must be sleepy," said he, and began rapidly crossing
51879. himself and repeating:
51880. 
51881. "Lord Jesus Christ, holy Saint Nicholas, Frola and Lavra! Lord Jesus
51882. Christ, holy Saint Nicholas, Frola and Lavra! Lord Jesus Christ, have
51883. mercy on us and save us!" he concluded, then bowed to the ground, got
51884. up, sighed, and sat down again on his heap of straw. "That's the way.
51885. Lay me down like a stone, O God, and raise me up like a loaf," he
51886. muttered as he lay down, pulling his coat over him.
51887. 
51888. "What prayer was that you were saying?" asked Pierre.
51889. 
51890. "Eh?" murmured Platon, who had almost fallen asleep. "What was I saying?
51891. I was praying. Don't you pray?"
51892. 
51893. "Yes, I do," said Pierre. "But what was that you said: Frola and Lavra?"
51894. 
51895. "Well, of course," replied Platon quickly, "the horses' saints. One must
51896. pity the animals too. Eh, the rascal! Now you've curled up and got warm,
51897. you daughter of a bitch!" said Karataev, touching the dog that lay at
51898. his feet, and again turning over he fell asleep immediately.
51899. 
51900. Sounds of crying and screaming came from somewhere in the distance
51901. outside, and flames were visible through the cracks of the shed, but
51902. inside it was quiet and dark. For a long time Pierre did not sleep, but
51903. lay with eyes open in the darkness, listening to the regular snoring
51904. of Platon who lay beside him, and he felt that the world that had been
51905. shattered was once more stirring in his soul with a new beauty and on
51906. new and unshakable foundations.
51907. 
51908. 
51909. 
51910. 
51911. 
51912. CHAPTER XIII
51913. 
51914. 
51915. Twenty-three soldiers, three officers, and two officials were confined
51916. in the shed in which Pierre had been placed and where he remained for
51917. four weeks.
51918. 
51919. When Pierre remembered them afterwards they all seemed misty figures to
51920. him except Platon Karataev, who always remained in his mind a most
51921. vivid and precious memory and the personification of everything Russian,
51922. kindly, and round. When Pierre saw his neighbor next morning at dawn
51923. the first impression of him, as of something round, was fully confirmed:
51924. Platon's whole figure--in a French overcoat girdled with a cord, a
51925. soldier's cap, and bast shoes--was round. His head was quite round,
51926. his back, chest, shoulders, and even his arms, which he held as if ever
51927. ready to embrace something, were rounded, his pleasant smile and his
51928. large, gentle brown eyes were also round.
51929. 
51930. Platon Karataev must have been fifty, judging by his stories of
51931. campaigns he had been in, told as by an old soldier. He did not himself
51932. know his age and was quite unable to determine it. But his brilliantly
51933. white, strong teeth which showed in two unbroken semicircles when he
51934. laughed--as he often did--were all sound and good, there was not a gray
51935. hair in his beard or on his head, and his whole body gave an impression
51936. of suppleness and especially of firmness and endurance.
51937. 
51938. His face, despite its fine, rounded wrinkles, had an expression of
51939. innocence and youth, his voice was pleasant and musical. But the chief
51940. peculiarity of his speech was its directness and appositeness. It was
51941. evident that he never considered what he had said or was going to say,
51942. and consequently the rapidity and justice of his intonation had an
51943. irresistible persuasiveness.
51944. 
51945. His physical strength and agility during the first days of his
51946. imprisonment were such that he seemed not to know what fatigue and
51947. sickness meant. Every night before lying down, he said: "Lord, lay me
51948. down as a stone and raise me up as a loaf!" and every morning on getting
51949. up, he said: "I lay down and curled up, I get up and shake myself." And
51950. indeed he only had to lie down, to fall asleep like a stone, and he
51951. only had to shake himself, to be ready without a moment's delay for some
51952. work, just as children are ready to play directly they awake. He could
51953. do everything, not very well but not badly. He baked, cooked, sewed,
51954. planed, and mended boots. He was always busy, and only at night allowed
51955. himself conversation--of which he was fond--and songs. He did not sing
51956. like a trained singer who knows he is listened to, but like the birds,
51957. evidently giving vent to the sounds in the same way that one stretches
51958. oneself or walks about to get rid of stiffness, and the sounds were
51959. always high-pitched, mournful, delicate, and almost feminine, and his
51960. face at such times was very serious.
51961. 
51962. Having been taken prisoner and allowed his beard to grow, he seemed to
51963. have thrown off all that had been forced upon him--everything military
51964. and alien to himself--and had returned to his former peasant habits.
51965. 
51966. "A soldier on leave--a shirt outside breeches," he would say.
51967. 
51968. He did not like talking about his life as a soldier, though he did not
51969. complain, and often mentioned that he had not been flogged once during
51970. the whole of his army service. When he related anything it was generally
51971. some old and evidently precious memory of his "Christian" life, as he
51972. called his peasant existence. The proverbs, of which his talk was full,
51973. were for the most part not the coarse and indecent saws soldiers
51974. employ, but those folk sayings which taken without a context seem so
51975. insignificant, but when used appositely suddenly acquire a significance
51976. of profound wisdom.
51977. 
51978. He would often say the exact opposite of what he had said on a previous
51979. occasion, yet both would be right. He liked to talk and he talked well,
51980. adorning his speech with terms of endearment and with folk sayings which
51981. Pierre thought he invented himself, but the chief charm of his talk lay
51982. in the fact that the commonest events--sometimes just such as Pierre
51983. had witnessed without taking notice of them--assumed in Karataev's a
51984. character of solemn fitness. He liked to hear the folk tales one of the
51985. soldiers used to tell of an evening (they were always the same), but
51986. most of all he liked to hear stories of real life. He would smile
51987. joyfully when listening to such stories, now and then putting in a word
51988. or asking a question to make the moral beauty of what he was told clear
51989. to himself. Karataev had no attachments, friendships, or love, as Pierre
51990. understood them, but loved and lived affectionately with everything life
51991. brought him in contact with, particularly with man--not any particular
51992. man, but those with whom he happened to be. He loved his dog, his
51993. comrades, the French, and Pierre who was his neighbor, but Pierre felt
51994. that in spite of Karataev's affectionate tenderness for him (by which
51995. he unconsciously gave Pierre's spiritual life its due) he would not have
51996. grieved for a moment at parting from him. And Pierre began to feel in
51997. the same way toward Karataev.
51998. 
51999. To all the other prisoners Platon Karataev seemed a most ordinary
52000. soldier. They called him "little falcon" or "Platosha," chaffed him
52001. good-naturedly, and sent him on errands. But to Pierre he always
52002. remained what he had seemed that first night: an unfathomable, rounded,
52003. eternal personification of the spirit of simplicity and truth.
52004. 
52005. Platon Karataev knew nothing by heart except his prayers. When he began
52006. to speak he seemed not to know how he would conclude.
52007. 
52008. Sometimes Pierre, struck by the meaning of his words, would ask him to
52009. repeat them, but Platon could never recall what he had said a moment
52010. before, just as he never could repeat to Pierre the words of his
52011. favorite song: native and birch tree and my heart is sick occurred in
52012. it, but when spoken and not sung, no meaning could be got out of it. He
52013. did not, and could not, understand the meaning of words apart from
52014. their context. Every word and action of his was the manifestation of
52015. an activity unknown to him, which was his life. But his life, as he
52016. regarded it, had no meaning as a separate thing. It had meaning only as
52017. part of a whole of which he was always conscious. His words and actions
52018. flowed from him as evenly, inevitably, and spontaneously as fragrance
52019. exhales from a flower. He could not understand the value or significance
52020. of any word or deed taken separately.
52021. 
52022. 
52023. 
52024. 
52025. 
52026. CHAPTER XIV
52027. 
52028. 
52029. When Princess Mary heard from Nicholas that her brother was with the
52030. Rostovs at Yaroslavl she at once prepared to go there, in spite of her
52031. aunt's efforts to dissuade her--and not merely to go herself but to
52032. take her nephew with her. Whether it were difficult or easy, possible
52033. or impossible, she did not ask and did not want to know: it was her duty
52034. not only herself to be near her brother who was perhaps dying, but to do
52035. everything possible to take his son to him, and so she prepared to set
52036. off. That she had not heard from Prince Andrew himself, Princess Mary
52037. attributed to his being too weak to write or to his considering the long
52038. journey too hard and too dangerous for her and his son.
52039. 
52040. In a few days Princess Mary was ready to start. Her equipages were the
52041. huge family coach in which she had traveled to Voronezh, a semiopen
52042. trap, and a baggage cart. With her traveled Mademoiselle Bourienne,
52043. little Nicholas and his tutor, her old nurse, three maids, Tikhon, and a
52044. young footman and courier her aunt had sent to accompany her.
52045. 
52046. The usual route through Moscow could not be thought of, and the
52047. roundabout way Princess Mary was obliged to take through Lipetsk,
52048. Ryazan, Vladimir, and Shuya was very long and, as post horses were not
52049. everywhere obtainable, very difficult, and near Ryazan where the French
52050. were said to have shown themselves was even dangerous.
52051. 
52052. During this difficult journey Mademoiselle Bourienne, Dessalles, and
52053. Princess Mary's servants were astonished at her energy and firmness of
52054. spirit. She went to bed later and rose earlier than any of them, and
52055. no difficulties daunted her. Thanks to her activity and energy, which
52056. infected her fellow travelers, they approached Yaroslavl by the end of
52057. the second week.
52058. 
52059. The last days of her stay in Voronezh had been the happiest of her life.
52060. Her love for Rostov no longer tormented or agitated her. It filled her
52061. whole soul, had become an integral part of herself, and she no longer
52062. struggled against it. Latterly she had become convinced that she loved
52063. and was beloved, though she never said this definitely to herself
52064. in words. She had become convinced of it at her last interview with
52065. Nicholas, when he had come to tell her that her brother was with the
52066. Rostovs. Not by a single word had Nicholas alluded to the fact that
52067. Prince Andrew's relations with Natasha might, if he recovered, be
52068. renewed, but Princess Mary saw by his face that he knew and thought of
52069. this.
52070. 
52071. Yet in spite of that, his relation to her--considerate, delicate, and
52072. loving--not only remained unchanged, but it sometimes seemed to Princess
52073. Mary that he was even glad that the family connection between them
52074. allowed him to express his friendship more freely. She knew that she
52075. loved for the first and only time in her life and felt that she was
52076. beloved, and was happy in regard to it.
52077. 
52078. But this happiness on one side of her spiritual nature did not prevent
52079. her feeling grief for her brother with full force; on the contrary, that
52080. spiritual tranquility on the one side made it the more possible for her
52081. to give full play to her feeling for her brother. That feeling was so
52082. strong at the moment of leaving Voronezh that those who saw her off, as
52083. they looked at her careworn, despairing face, felt sure she would fall
52084. ill on the journey. But the very difficulties and preoccupations of the
52085. journey, which she took so actively in hand, saved her for a while from
52086. her grief and gave her strength.
52087. 
52088. As always happens when traveling, Princess Mary thought only of the
52089. journey itself, forgetting its object. But as she approached Yaroslavl
52090. the thought of what might await her there--not after many days, but that
52091. very evening--again presented itself to her and her agitation increased
52092. to its utmost limit.
52093. 
52094. The courier who had been sent on in advance to find out where the
52095. Rostovs were staying in Yaroslavl, and in what condition Prince Andrew
52096. was, when he met the big coach just entering the town gates was appalled
52097. by the terrible pallor of the princess' face that looked out at him from
52098. the window.
52099. 
52100. "I have found out everything, your excellency: the Rostovs are staying
52101. at the merchant Bronnikov's house, in the Square not far from here,
52102. right above the Volga," said the courier.
52103. 
52104. Princess Mary looked at him with frightened inquiry, not understanding
52105. why he did not reply to what she chiefly wanted to know: how was her
52106. brother? Mademoiselle Bourienne put that question for her.
52107. 
52108. "How is the prince?" she asked.
52109. 
52110. "His excellency is staying in the same house with them."
52111. 
52112. "Then he is alive," thought Princess Mary, and asked in a low voice:
52113. "How is he?"
52114. 
52115. "The servants say he is still the same."
52116. 
52117. What "still the same" might mean Princess Mary did not ask, but with an
52118. unnoticed glance at little seven-year-old Nicholas, who was sitting in
52119. front of her looking with pleasure at the town, she bowed her head
52120. and did not raise it again till the heavy coach, rumbling, shaking and
52121. swaying, came to a stop. The carriage steps clattered as they were let
52122. down.
52123. 
52124. The carriage door was opened. On the left there was water--a great
52125. river--and on the right a porch. There were people at the entrance:
52126. servants, and a rosy girl with a large plait of black hair, smiling as
52127. it seemed to Princess Mary in an unpleasantly affected way. (This was
52128. Sonya.) Princess Mary ran up the steps. "This way, this way!" said the
52129. girl, with the same artificial smile, and the princess found herself in
52130. the hall facing an elderly woman of Oriental type, who came rapidly to
52131. meet her with a look of emotion. This was the countess. She embraced
52132. Princess Mary and kissed her.
52133. 
52134. "Mon enfant!" she muttered, "je vous aime et vous connais depuis
52135. longtemps." *
52136. 
52137. 
52138.     * "My child! I love you and have known you a long time."
52139. 
52140. 
52141.  Despite her excitement, Princess Mary realized that this was the
52142. countess and that it was necessary to say something to her. Hardly
52143. knowing how she did it, she contrived to utter a few polite phrases in
52144. French in the same tone as those that had been addressed to her, and
52145. asked: "How is he?"
52146. 
52147. "The doctor says that he is not in danger," said the countess, but as
52148. she spoke she raised her eyes with a sigh, and her gesture conveyed a
52149. contradiction of her words.
52150. 
52151. "Where is he? Can I see him--can I?" asked the princess.
52152. 
52153. "One moment, Princess, one moment, my dear! Is this his son?" said the
52154. countess, turning to little Nicholas who was coming in with Dessalles.
52155. "There will be room for everybody, this is a big house. Oh, what a
52156. lovely boy!"
52157. 
52158. The countess took Princess Mary into the drawing room, where Sonya was
52159. talking to Mademoiselle Bourienne. The countess caressed the boy, and
52160. the old count came in and welcomed the princess. He had changed very
52161. much since Princess Mary had last seen him. Then he had been a brisk,
52162. cheerful, self-assured old man; now he seemed a pitiful, bewildered
52163. person. While talking to Princess Mary he continually looked round as
52164. if asking everyone whether he was doing the right thing. After the
52165. destruction of Moscow and of his property, thrown out of his accustomed
52166. groove he seemed to have lost the sense of his own significance and to
52167. feel that there was no longer a place for him in life.
52168. 
52169. In spite of her one desire to see her brother as soon as possible, and
52170. her vexation that at the moment when all she wanted was to see him they
52171. should be trying to entertain her and pretending to admire her nephew,
52172. the princess noticed all that was going on around her and felt the
52173. necessity of submitting, for a time, to this new order of things which
52174. she had entered. She knew it to be necessary, and though it was hard for
52175. her she was not vexed with these people.
52176. 
52177. "This is my niece," said the count, introducing Sonya--"You don't know
52178. her, Princess?"
52179. 
52180. Princess Mary turned to Sonya and, trying to stifle the hostile
52181. feeling that arose in her toward the girl, she kissed her. But she felt
52182. oppressed by the fact that the mood of everyone around her was so far
52183. from what was in her own heart.
52184. 
52185. "Where is he?" she asked again, addressing them all.
52186. 
52187. "He is downstairs. Natasha is with him," answered Sonya, flushing. "We
52188. have sent to ask. I think you must be tired, Princess."
52189. 
52190. Tears of vexation showed themselves in Princess Mary's eyes. She turned
52191. away and was about to ask the countess again how to go to him, when
52192. light, impetuous, and seemingly buoyant steps were heard at the
52193. door. The princess looked round and saw Natasha coming in, almost
52194. running--that Natasha whom she had liked so little at their meeting in
52195. Moscow long since.
52196. 
52197. But hardly had the princess looked at Natasha's face before she realized
52198. that here was a real comrade in her grief, and consequently a friend.
52199. She ran to meet her, embraced her, and began to cry on her shoulder.
52200. 
52201. As soon as Natasha, sitting at the head of Prince Andrew's bed, heard
52202. of Princess Mary's arrival, she softly left his room and hastened to her
52203. with those swift steps that had sounded buoyant to Princess Mary.
52204. 
52205. There was only one expression on her agitated face when she ran into the
52206. drawing room--that of love--boundless love for him, for her, and for all
52207. that was near to the man she loved; and of pity, suffering for others,
52208. and passionate desire to give herself entirely to helping them. It was
52209. plain that at that moment there was in Natasha's heart no thought of
52210. herself or of her own relations with Prince Andrew.
52211. 
52212. Princess Mary, with her acute sensibility, understood all this at the
52213. first glance at Natasha's face, and wept on her shoulder with sorrowful
52214. pleasure.
52215. 
52216. "Come, come to him, Mary," said Natasha, leading her into the other
52217. room.
52218. 
52219. Princess Mary raised her head, dried her eyes, and turned to Natasha.
52220. She felt that from her she would be able to understand and learn
52221. everything.
52222. 
52223. "How..." she began her question but stopped short.
52224. 
52225. She felt that it was impossible to ask, or to answer, in words.
52226. Natasha's face and eyes would have to tell her all more clearly and
52227. profoundly.
52228. 
52229. Natasha was gazing at her, but seemed afraid and in doubt whether to say
52230. all she knew or not; she seemed to feel that before those luminous eyes
52231. which penetrated into the very depths of her heart, it was impossible
52232. not to tell the whole truth which she saw. And suddenly, Natasha's lips
52233. twitched, ugly wrinkles gathered round her mouth, and covering her face
52234. with her hands she burst into sobs.
52235. 
52236. Princess Mary understood.
52237. 
52238. But she still hoped, and asked, in words she herself did not trust:
52239. 
52240. "But how is his wound? What is his general condition?"
52241. 
52242. "You, you... will see," was all Natasha could say.
52243. 
52244. They sat a little while downstairs near his room till they had left off
52245. crying and were able to go to him with calm faces.
52246. 
52247. "How has his whole illness gone? Is it long since he grew worse? When
52248. did this happen?" Princess Mary inquired.
52249. 
52250. Natasha told her that at first there had been danger from his feverish
52251. condition and the pain he suffered, but at Troitsa that had passed
52252. and the doctor had only been afraid of gangrene. That danger had also
52253. passed. When they reached Yaroslavl the wound had begun to fester
52254. (Natasha knew all about such things as festering) and the doctor had
52255. said that the festering might take a normal course. Then fever set in,
52256. but the doctor had said the fever was not very serious.
52257. 
52258. "But two days ago this suddenly happened," said Natasha, struggling with
52259. her sobs. "I don't know why, but you will see what he is like."
52260. 
52261. "Is he weaker? Thinner?" asked the princess.
52262. 
52263. "No, it's not that, but worse. You will see. O, Mary, he is too good, he
52264. cannot, cannot live, because..."
52265. 
52266. 
52267. 
52268. 
52269. 
52270. CHAPTER XV
52271. 
52272. 
52273. When Natasha opened Prince Andrew's door with a familiar movement and
52274. let Princess Mary pass into the room before her, the princess felt the
52275. sobs in her throat. Hard as she had tried to prepare herself, and now
52276. tried to remain tranquil, she knew that she would be unable to look at
52277. him without tears.
52278. 
52279. The princess understood what Natasha had meant by the words: "two days
52280. ago this suddenly happened." She understood those words to mean that he
52281. had suddenly softened and that this softening and gentleness were signs
52282. of approaching death. As she stepped to the door she already saw in
52283. imagination Andrew's face as she remembered it in childhood, a gentle,
52284. mild, sympathetic face which he had rarely shown, and which therefore
52285. affected her very strongly. She was sure he would speak soft, tender
52286. words to her such as her father had uttered before his death, and
52287. that she would not be able to bear it and would burst into sobs in his
52288. presence. Yet sooner or later it had to be, and she went in. The sobs
52289. rose higher and higher in her throat as she more and more clearly
52290. distinguished his form and her shortsighted eyes tried to make out his
52291. features, and then she saw his face and met his gaze.
52292. 
52293. He was lying in a squirrel-fur dressing gown on a divan, surrounded by
52294. pillows. He was thin and pale. In one thin, translucently white hand
52295. he held a handkerchief, while with the other he stroked the delicate
52296. mustache he had grown, moving his fingers slowly. His eyes gazed at them
52297. as they entered.
52298. 
52299. On seeing his face and meeting his eyes Princess Mary's pace suddenly
52300. slackened, she felt her tears dry up and her sobs ceased. She suddenly
52301. felt guilty and grew timid on catching the expression of his face and
52302. eyes.
52303. 
52304. "But in what am I to blame?" she asked herself. And his cold, stern look
52305. replied: "Because you are alive and thinking of the living, while I..."
52306. 
52307. In the deep gaze that seemed to look not outwards but inwards there
52308. was an almost hostile expression as he slowly regarded his sister and
52309. Natasha.
52310. 
52311. He kissed his sister, holding her hand in his as was their wont.
52312. 
52313. "How are you, Mary? How did you manage to get here?" said he in a voice
52314. as calm and aloof as his look.
52315. 
52316. Had he screamed in agony, that scream would not have struck such horror
52317. into Princess Mary's heart as the tone of his voice.
52318. 
52319. "And have you brought little Nicholas?" he asked in the same slow, quiet
52320. manner and with an obvious effort to remember.
52321. 
52322. "How are you now?" said Princess Mary, herself surprised at what she was
52323. saying.
52324. 
52325. "That, my dear, you must ask the doctor," he replied, and again making
52326. an evident effort to be affectionate, he said with his lips only (his
52327. words clearly did not correspond to his thoughts):
52328. 
52329. "Merci, chere amie, d'etre venue." *
52330. 
52331. 
52332.     * "Thank you for coming, my dear."
52333. 
52334. 
52335. Princess Mary pressed his hand. The pressure made him wince just
52336. perceptibly. He was silent, and she did not know what to say. She now
52337. understood what had happened to him two days before. In his words, his
52338. tone, and especially in that calm, almost antagonistic look could be
52339. felt an estrangement from everything belonging to this world, terrible
52340. in one who is alive. Evidently only with an effort did he understand
52341. anything living; but it was obvious that he failed to understand, not
52342. because he lacked the power to do so but because he understood something
52343. else--something the living did not and could not understand--and which
52344. wholly occupied his mind.
52345. 
52346. "There, you see how strangely fate has brought us together," said he,
52347. breaking the silence and pointing to Natasha. "She looks after me all
52348. the time."
52349. 
52350. Princess Mary heard him and did not understand how he could say such a
52351. thing. He, the sensitive, tender Prince Andrew, how could he say that,
52352. before her whom he loved and who loved him? Had he expected to live he
52353. could not have said those words in that offensively cold tone. If he had
52354. not known that he was dying, how could he have failed to pity her and
52355. how could he speak like that in her presence? The only explanation was
52356. that he was indifferent, because something else, much more important,
52357. had been revealed to him.
52358. 
52359. The conversation was cold and disconnected and continually broke off.
52360. 
52361. "Mary came by way of Ryazan," said Natasha.
52362. 
52363. Prince Andrew did not notice that she called his sister Mary, and only
52364. after calling her so in his presence did Natasha notice it herself.
52365. 
52366. "Really?" he asked.
52367. 
52368. "They told her that all Moscow has been burned down, and that..."
52369. 
52370. Natasha stopped. It was impossible to talk. It was plain that he was
52371. making an effort to listen, but could not do so.
52372. 
52373. "Yes, they say it's burned," he said. "It's a great pity," and he gazed
52374. straight before him, absently stroking his mustache with his fingers.
52375. 
52376. "And so you have met Count Nicholas, Mary?" Prince Andrew suddenly said,
52377. evidently wishing to speak pleasantly to them. "He wrote here that he
52378. took a great liking to you," he went on simply and calmly, evidently
52379. unable to understand all the complex significance his words had for
52380. living people. "If you liked him too, it would be a good thing for you
52381. to get married," he added rather more quickly, as if pleased at having
52382. found words he had long been seeking.
52383. 
52384. Princess Mary heard his words but they had no meaning for her, except as
52385. a proof of how far away he now was from everything living.
52386. 
52387. "Why talk of me?" she said quietly and glanced at Natasha.
52388. 
52389. Natasha, who felt her glance, did not look at her. All three were again
52390. silent.
52391. 
52392. "Andrew, would you like..." Princess Mary suddenly said in a trembling
52393. voice, "would you like to see little Nicholas? He is always talking
52394. about you!"
52395. 
52396. Prince Andrew smiled just perceptibly and for the first time, but
52397. Princess Mary, who knew his face so well, saw with horror that he did
52398. not smile with pleasure or affection for his son, but with quiet, gentle
52399. irony because he thought she was trying what she believed to be the last
52400. means of arousing him.
52401. 
52402. "Yes, I shall be very glad to see him. Is he quite well?"
52403. 
52404. When little Nicholas was brought into Prince Andrew's room he looked at
52405. his father with frightened eyes, but did not cry, because no one else
52406. was crying. Prince Andrew kissed him and evidently did not know what to
52407. say to him.
52408. 
52409. When Nicholas had been led away, Princess Mary again went up to her
52410. brother, kissed him, and unable to restrain her tears any longer began
52411. to cry.
52412. 
52413. He looked at her attentively.
52414. 
52415. "Is it about Nicholas?" he asked.
52416. 
52417. Princess Mary nodded her head, weeping.
52418. 
52419. "Mary, you know the Gosp..." but he broke off.
52420. 
52421. "What did you say?"
52422. 
52423. "Nothing. You mustn't cry here," he said, looking at her with the same
52424. cold expression.
52425. 
52426. 
52427. When Princess Mary began to cry, he understood that she was crying at
52428. the thought that little Nicholas would be left without a father. With
52429. a great effort he tried to return to life and to see things from their
52430. point of view.
52431. 
52432. "Yes, to them it must seem sad!" he thought. "But how simple it is.
52433. 
52434. "The fowls of the air sow not, neither do they reap, yet your Father
52435. feedeth them," he said to himself and wished to say to Princess Mary;
52436. "but no, they will take it their own way, they won't understand!
52437. They can't understand that all those feelings they prize so--all our
52438. feelings, all those ideas that seem so important to us, are unnecessary.
52439. We cannot understand one another," and he remained silent.
52440. 
52441. 
52442. Prince Andrew's little son was seven. He could scarcely read, and knew
52443. nothing. After that day he lived through many things, gaining knowledge,
52444. observation, and experience, but had he possessed all the faculties he
52445. afterwards acquired, he could not have had a better or more profound
52446. understanding of the meaning of the scene he had witnessed between
52447. his father, Mary, and Natasha, than he had then. He understood it
52448. completely, and, leaving the room without crying, went silently up
52449. to Natasha who had come out with him and looked shyly at her with his
52450. beautiful, thoughtful eyes, then his uplifted, rosy upper lip trembled
52451. and leaning his head against her he began to cry.
52452. 
52453. After that he avoided Dessalles and the countess who caressed him and
52454. either sat alone or came timidly to Princess Mary, or to Natasha of whom
52455. he seemed even fonder than of his aunt, and clung to them quietly and
52456. shyly.
52457. 
52458. When Princess Mary had left Prince Andrew she fully understood what
52459. Natasha's face had told her. She did not speak any more to Natasha of
52460. hopes of saving his life. She took turns with her beside his sofa, and
52461. did not cry any more, but prayed continually, turning in soul to that
52462. Eternal and Unfathomable, whose presence above the dying man was now so
52463. evident.
52464. 
52465. 
52466. 
52467. 
52468. 
52469. CHAPTER XVI
52470. 
52471. 
52472. Not only did Prince Andrew know he would die, but he felt that he was
52473. dying and was already half dead. He was conscious of an aloofness from
52474. everything earthly and a strange and joyous lightness of existence.
52475. Without haste or agitation he awaited what was coming. That inexorable,
52476. eternal, distant, and unknown the presence of which he had felt
52477. continually all his life--was now near to him and, by the strange
52478. lightness he experienced, almost comprehensible and palpable...
52479. 
52480. 
52481. Formerly he had feared the end. He had twice experienced that terribly
52482. tormenting fear of death--the end--but now he no longer understood that
52483. fear.
52484. 
52485.  He had felt it for the first time when the shell spun like a top
52486. before him, and he looked at the fallow field, the bushes, and the sky,
52487. and knew that he was face to face with death. When he came to himself
52488. after being wounded and the flower of eternal, unfettered love had
52489. instantly unfolded itself in his soul as if freed from the bondage of
52490. life that had restrained it, he no longer feared death and ceased to
52491. think about it.
52492. 
52493. During the hours of solitude, suffering, and partial delirium he
52494. spent after he was wounded, the more deeply he penetrated into the new
52495. principle of eternal love revealed to him, the more he unconsciously
52496. detached himself from earthly life. To love everything and everybody and
52497. always to sacrifice oneself for love meant not to love anyone, not
52498. to live this earthly life. And the more imbued he became with that
52499. principle of love, the more he renounced life and the more completely
52500. he destroyed that dreadful barrier which--in the absence of such
52501. love--stands between life and death. When during those first days he
52502. remembered that he would have to die, he said to himself: "Well, what of
52503. it? So much the better!"
52504. 
52505. But after the night in Mytishchi when, half delirious, he had seen her
52506. for whom he longed appear before him and, having pressed her hand to his
52507. lips, had shed gentle, happy tears, love for a particular woman again
52508. crept unobserved into his heart and once more bound him to life. And
52509. joyful and agitating thoughts began to occupy his mind. Recalling the
52510. moment at the ambulance station when he had seen Kuragin, he could not
52511. now regain the feeling he then had, but was tormented by the question
52512. whether Kuragin was alive. And he dared not inquire.
52513. 
52514. His illness pursued its normal physical course, but what Natasha
52515. referred to when she said: "This suddenly happened," had occurred two
52516. days before Princess Mary arrived. It was the last spiritual struggle
52517. between life and death, in which death gained the victory. It was
52518. the unexpected realization of the fact that he still valued life as
52519. presented to him in the form of his love for Natasha, and a last, though
52520. ultimately vanquished, attack of terror before the unknown.
52521. 
52522. It was evening. As usual after dinner he was slightly feverish, and his
52523. thoughts were preternaturally clear. Sonya was sitting by the table. He
52524. began to doze. Suddenly a feeling of happiness seized him.
52525. 
52526. "Ah, she has come!" thought he.
52527. 
52528. And so it was: in Sonya's place sat Natasha who had just come in
52529. noiselessly.
52530. 
52531. Since she had begun looking after him, he had always experienced this
52532. physical consciousness of her nearness. She was sitting in an armchair
52533. placed sideways, screening the light of the candle from him, and was
52534. knitting a stocking. She had learned to knit stockings since Prince
52535. Andrew had casually mentioned that no one nursed the sick so well as old
52536. nurses who knit stockings, and that there is something soothing in
52537. the knitting of stockings. The needles clicked lightly in her slender,
52538. rapidly moving hands, and he could clearly see the thoughtful profile
52539. of her drooping face. She moved, and the ball rolled off her knees. She
52540. started, glanced round at him, and screening the candle with her hand
52541. stooped carefully with a supple and exact movement, picked up the ball,
52542. and regained her former position.
52543. 
52544. He looked at her without moving and saw that she wanted to draw a
52545. deep breath after stooping, but refrained from doing so and breathed
52546. cautiously.
52547. 
52548. At the Troitsa monastery they had spoken of the past, and he had told
52549. her that if he lived he would always thank God for his wound which had
52550. brought them together again, but after that they never spoke of the
52551. future.
52552. 
52553. "Can it or can it not be?" he now thought as he looked at her and
52554. listened to the light click of the steel needles. "Can fate have brought
52555. me to her so strangely only for me to die?... Is it possible that the
52556. truth of life has been revealed to me only to show me that I have spent
52557. my life in falsity? I love her more than anything in the world! But what
52558. am I to do if I love her?" he thought, and he involuntarily groaned,
52559. from a habit acquired during his sufferings.
52560. 
52561. On hearing that sound Natasha put down the stocking, leaned nearer to
52562. him, and suddenly, noticing his shining eyes, stepped lightly up to him
52563. and bent over him.
52564. 
52565. "You are not asleep?"
52566. 
52567. "No, I have been looking at you a long time. I felt you come in. No one
52568. else gives me that sense of soft tranquillity that you do... that light.
52569. I want to weep for joy."
52570. 
52571. Natasha drew closer to him. Her face shone with rapturous joy.
52572. 
52573. "Natasha, I love you too much! More than anything in the world."
52574. 
52575. "And I!"--She turned away for an instant. "Why too much?" she asked.
52576. 
52577. "Why too much?... Well, what do you, what do you feel in your soul, your
52578. whole soul--shall I live? What do you think?"
52579. 
52580. "I am sure of it, sure!" Natasha almost shouted, taking hold of both his
52581. hands with a passionate movement.
52582. 
52583. He remained silent awhile.
52584. 
52585. "How good it would be!" and taking her hand he kissed it.
52586. 
52587. Natasha felt happy and agitated, but at once remembered that this would
52588. not do and that he had to be quiet.
52589. 
52590. "But you have not slept," she said, repressing her joy. "Try to sleep...
52591. please!"
52592. 
52593. He pressed her hand and released it, and she went back to the candle and
52594. sat down again in her former position. Twice she turned and looked at
52595. him, and her eyes met his beaming at her. She set herself a task on her
52596. stocking and resolved not to turn round till it was finished.
52597. 
52598. Soon he really shut his eyes and fell asleep. He did not sleep long and
52599. suddenly awoke with a start and in a cold perspiration.
52600. 
52601. As he fell asleep he had still been thinking of the subject that now
52602. always occupied his mind--about life and death, and chiefly about death.
52603. He felt himself nearer to it.
52604. 
52605. "Love? What is love?" he thought.
52606. 
52607. "Love hinders death. Love is life. All, everything that I understand, I
52608. understand only because I love. Everything is, everything exists, only
52609. because I love. Everything is united by it alone. Love is God, and to
52610. die means that I, a particle of love, shall return to the general and
52611. eternal source." These thoughts seemed to him comforting. But they were
52612. only thoughts. Something was lacking in them, they were not clear, they
52613. were too one-sidedly personal and brain-spun. And there was the former
52614. agitation and obscurity. He fell asleep.
52615. 
52616. He dreamed that he was lying in the room he really was in, but that
52617. he was quite well and unwounded. Many various, indifferent, and
52618. insignificant people appeared before him. He talked to them and
52619. discussed something trivial. They were preparing to go away somewhere.
52620. Prince Andrew dimly realized that all this was trivial and that he had
52621. more important cares, but he continued to speak, surprising them by
52622. empty witticisms. Gradually, unnoticed, all these persons began to
52623. disappear and a single question, that of the closed door, superseded
52624. all else. He rose and went to the door to bolt and lock it. Everything
52625. depended on whether he was, or was not, in time to lock it. He went, and
52626. tried to hurry, but his legs refused to move and he knew he would not be
52627. in time to lock the door though he painfully strained all his powers. He
52628. was seized by an agonizing fear. And that fear was the fear of death. It
52629. stood behind the door. But just when he was clumsily creeping toward
52630. the door, that dreadful something on the other side was already pressing
52631. against it and forcing its way in. Something not human--death--was
52632. breaking in through that door, and had to be kept out. He seized the
52633. door, making a final effort to hold it back--to lock it was no longer
52634. possible--but his efforts were weak and clumsy and the door, pushed from
52635. behind by that terror, opened and closed again.
52636. 
52637. Once again it pushed from outside. His last superhuman efforts were vain
52638. and both halves of the door noiselessly opened. It entered, and it was
52639. death, and Prince Andrew died.
52640. 
52641. But at the instant he died, Prince Andrew remembered that he was asleep,
52642. and at the very instant he died, having made an effort, he awoke.
52643. 
52644. "Yes, it was death! I died--and woke up. Yes, death is an awakening!"
52645. And all at once it grew light in his soul and the veil that had till
52646. then concealed the unknown was lifted from his spiritual vision. He felt
52647. as if powers till then confined within him had been liberated, and that
52648. strange lightness did not again leave him.
52649. 
52650. When, waking in a cold perspiration, he moved on the divan, Natasha went
52651. up and asked him what was the matter. He did not answer and looked at
52652. her strangely, not understanding.
52653. 
52654. That was what had happened to him two days before Princess Mary's
52655. arrival. From that day, as the doctor expressed it, the wasting fever
52656. assumed a malignant character, but what the doctor said did not interest
52657. Natasha, she saw the terrible moral symptoms which to her were more
52658. convincing.
52659. 
52660. From that day an awakening from life came to Prince Andrew together with
52661. his awakening from sleep. And compared to the duration of life it did
52662. not seem to him slower than an awakening from sleep compared to the
52663. duration of a dream.
52664. 
52665. There was nothing terrible or violent in this comparatively slow
52666. awakening.
52667. 
52668. His last days and hours passed in an ordinary and simple way. Both
52669. Princess Mary and Natasha, who did not leave him, felt this. They did
52670. not weep or shudder and during these last days they themselves felt
52671. that they were not attending on him (he was no longer there, he had left
52672. them) but on what reminded them most closely of him--his body. Both felt
52673. this so strongly that the outward and terrible side of death did not
52674. affect them and they did not feel it necessary to foment their grief.
52675. Neither in his presence nor out of it did they weep, nor did they ever
52676. talk to one another about him. They felt that they could not express in
52677. words what they understood.
52678. 
52679. They both saw that he was sinking slowly and quietly, deeper and deeper,
52680. away from them, and they both knew that this had to be so and that it
52681. was right.
52682. 
52683. He confessed, and received communion: everyone came to take leave of
52684. him. When they brought his son to him, he pressed his lips to the boy's
52685. and turned away, not because he felt it hard and sad (Princess Mary and
52686. Natasha understood that) but simply because he thought it was all that
52687. was required of him, but when they told him to bless the boy, he did
52688. what was demanded and looked round as if asking whether there was
52689. anything else he should do.
52690. 
52691. When the last convulsions of the body, which the spirit was leaving,
52692. occurred, Princess Mary and Natasha were present.
52693. 
52694. "Is it over?" said Princess Mary when his body had for a few minutes
52695. lain motionless, growing cold before them. Natasha went up, looked at
52696. the dead eyes, and hastened to close them. She closed them but did not
52697. kiss them, but clung to that which reminded her most nearly of him--his
52698. body.
52699. 
52700. "Where has he gone? Where is he now?..."
52701. 
52702. When the body, washed and dressed, lay in the coffin on a table,
52703. everyone came to take leave of him and they all wept.
52704. 
52705. Little Nicholas cried because his heart was rent by painful perplexity.
52706. The countess and Sonya cried from pity for Natasha and because he was
52707. no more. The old count cried because he felt that before long, he, too,
52708. must take the same terrible step.
52709. 
52710. Natasha and Princess Mary also wept now, but not because of their own
52711. personal grief; they wept with a reverent and softening emotion which
52712. had taken possession of their souls at the consciousness of the
52713. simple and solemn mystery of death that had been accomplished in their
52714. presence.
52715. 
52716. 
52717. 
52718. 
52719. 
52720. BOOK THIRTEEN: 1812
52721. 
52722. 
52723. 
52724. 
52725. 
52726. CHAPTER I
52727. 
52728. 
52729. Man's mind cannot grasp the causes of events in their completeness, but
52730. the desire to find those causes is implanted in man's soul. And without
52731. considering the multiplicity and complexity of the conditions any one
52732. of which taken separately may seem to be the cause, he snatches at the
52733. first approximation to a cause that seems to him intelligible and says:
52734. "This is the cause!" In historical events (where the actions of men are
52735. the subject of observation) the first and most primitive approximation
52736. to present itself was the will of the gods and, after that, the will of
52737. those who stood in the most prominent position--the heroes of history.
52738. But we need only penetrate to the essence of any historic event--which
52739. lies in the activity of the general mass of men who take part in it--to
52740. be convinced that the will of the historic hero does not control the
52741. actions of the mass but is itself continually controlled. It may seem
52742. to be a matter of indifference whether we understand the meaning of
52743. historical events this way or that; yet there is the same difference
52744. between a man who says that the people of the West moved on the East
52745. because Napoleon wished it and a man who says that this happened because
52746. it had to happen, as there is between those who declared that the
52747. earth was stationary and that the planets moved round it and those who
52748. admitted that they did not know what upheld the earth, but knew there
52749. were laws directing its movement and that of the other planets. There
52750. is, and can be, no cause of an historical event except the one cause of
52751. all causes. But there are laws directing events, and some of these laws
52752. are known to us while we are conscious of others we cannot comprehend.
52753. The discovery of these laws is only possible when we have quite
52754. abandoned the attempt to find the cause in the will of some one man,
52755. just as the discovery of the laws of the motion of the planets was
52756. possible only when men abandoned the conception of the fixity of the
52757. earth.
52758. 
52759. The historians consider that, next to the battle of Borodino and the
52760. occupation of Moscow by the enemy and its destruction by fire, the most
52761. important episode of the war of 1812 was the movement of the Russian
52762. army from the Ryazana to the Kaluga road and to the Tarutino camp--the
52763. so-called flank march across the Krasnaya Pakhra River. They ascribe the
52764. glory of that achievement of genius to different men and dispute as to
52765. whom the honor is due. Even foreign historians, including the French,
52766. acknowledge the genius of the Russian commanders when they speak of
52767. that flank march. But it is hard to understand why military writers,
