52768. and following them others, consider this flank march to be the profound
52769. conception of some one man who saved Russia and destroyed Napoleon. In
52770. the first place it is hard to understand where the profundity and genius
52771. of this movement lay, for not much mental effort was needed to see that
52772. the best position for an army when it is not being attacked is where
52773. there are most provisions; and even a dull boy of thirteen could have
52774. guessed that the best position for an army after its retreat from Moscow
52775. in 1812 was on the Kaluga road. So it is impossible to understand by
52776. what reasoning the historians reach the conclusion that this maneuver
52777. was a profound one. And it is even more difficult to understand just why
52778. they think that this maneuver was calculated to save Russia and destroy
52779. the French; for this flank march, had it been preceded, accompanied,
52780. or followed by other circumstances, might have proved ruinous to the
52781. Russians and salutary for the French. If the position of the Russian
52782. army really began to improve from the time of that march, it does not at
52783. all follow that the march was the cause of it.
52784. 
52785. That flank march might not only have failed to give any advantage to
52786. the Russian army, but might in other circumstances have led to its
52787. destruction. What would have happened had Moscow not burned down? If
52788. Murat had not lost sight of the Russians? If Napoleon had not remained
52789. inactive? If the Russian army at Krasnaya Pakhra had given battle as
52790. Bennigsen and Barclay advised? What would have happened had the French
52791. attacked the Russians while they were marching beyond the Pakhra? What
52792. would have happened if on approaching Tarutino, Napoleon had attacked
52793. the Russians with but a tenth of the energy he had shown when he
52794. attacked them at Smolensk? What would have happened had the French moved
52795. on Petersburg?... In any of these eventualities the flank march that
52796. brought salvation might have proved disastrous.
52797. 
52798. The third and most incomprehensible thing is that people studying
52799. history deliberately avoid seeing that this flank march cannot be
52800. attributed to any one man, that no one ever foresaw it, and that in
52801. reality, like the retreat from Fili, it did not suggest itself to anyone
52802. in its entirety, but resulted--moment by moment, step by step, event by
52803. event--from an endless number of most diverse circumstances and was only
52804. seen in its entirety when it had been accomplished and belonged to the
52805. past.
52806. 
52807. At the council at Fili the prevailing thought in the minds of the
52808. Russian commanders was the one naturally suggesting itself, namely, a
52809. direct retreat by the Nizhni road. In proof of this there is the fact
52810. that the majority of the council voted for such a retreat, and above
52811. all there is the well-known conversation after the council, between the
52812. commander in chief and Lanskoy, who was in charge of the commissariat
52813. department. Lanskoy informed the commander in chief that the army
52814. supplies were for the most part stored along the Oka in the Tula and
52815. Ryazan provinces, and that if they retreated on Nizhni the army would
52816. be separated from its supplies by the broad river Oka, which cannot be
52817. crossed early in winter. This was the first indication of the necessity
52818. of deviating from what had previously seemed the most natural course--a
52819. direct retreat on Nizhni-Novgorod. The army turned more to the south,
52820. along the Ryazan road and nearer to its supplies. Subsequently the
52821. inactivity of the French (who even lost sight of the Russian army),
52822. concern for the safety of the arsenal at Tula, and especially the
52823. advantages of drawing nearer to its supplies caused the army to turn
52824. still further south to the Tula road. Having crossed over, by a forced
52825. march, to the Tula road beyond the Pakhra, the Russian commanders
52826. intended to remain at Podolsk and had no thought of the Tarutino
52827. position; but innumerable circumstances and the reappearance of French
52828. troops who had for a time lost touch with the Russians, and projects
52829. of giving battle, and above all the abundance of provisions in Kaluga
52830. province, obliged our army to turn still more to the south and to cross
52831. from the Tula to the Kaluga road and go to Tarutino, which was between
52832. the roads along which those supplies lay. Just as it is impossible to
52833. say when it was decided to abandon Moscow, so it is impossible to say
52834. precisely when, or by whom, it was decided to move to Tarutino. Only
52835. when the army had got there, as the result of innumerable and varying
52836. forces, did people begin to assure themselves that they had desired this
52837. movement and long ago foreseen its result.
52838. 
52839. 
52840. 
52841. 
52842. 
52843. CHAPTER II
52844. 
52845. 
52846. The famous flank movement merely consisted in this: after the advance
52847. of the French had ceased, the Russian army, which had been continually
52848. retreating straight back from the invaders, deviated from that direct
52849. course and, not finding itself pursued, was naturally drawn toward the
52850. district where supplies were abundant.
52851. 
52852. If instead of imagining to ourselves commanders of genius leading the
52853. Russian army, we picture that army without any leaders, it could not
52854. have done anything but make a return movement toward Moscow, describing
52855. an arc in the direction where most provisions were to be found and where
52856. the country was richest.
52857. 
52858. That movement from the Nizhni to the Ryazan, Tula, and Kaluga roads was
52859. so natural that even the Russian marauders moved in that direction, and
52860. demands were sent from Petersburg for Kutuzov to take his army that
52861. way. At Tarutino Kutuzov received what was almost a reprimand from
52862. the Emperor for having moved his army along the Ryazan road, and the
52863. Emperor's letter indicated to him the very position he had already
52864. occupied near Kaluga.
52865. 
52866. Having rolled like a ball in the direction of the impetus given by the
52867. whole campaign and by the battle of Borodino, the Russian army--when
52868. the strength of that impetus was exhausted and no fresh push was
52869. received--assumed the position natural to it.
52870. 
52871. Kutuzov's merit lay, not in any strategic maneuver of genius, as it is
52872. called, but in the fact that he alone understood the significance of
52873. what had happened. He alone then understood the meaning of the French
52874. army's inactivity, he alone continued to assert that the battle of
52875. Borodino had been a victory, he alone--who as commander in chief might
52876. have been expected to be eager to attack--employed his whole strength to
52877. restrain the Russian army from useless engagements.
52878. 
52879. The beast wounded at Borodino was lying where the fleeing hunter had
52880. left him; but whether he was still alive, whether he was strong and
52881. merely lying low, the hunter did not know. Suddenly the beast was heard
52882. to moan.
52883. 
52884. The moan of that wounded beast (the French army) which betrayed its
52885. calamitous condition was the sending of Lauriston to Kutuzov's camp with
52886. overtures for peace.
52887. 
52888. Napoleon, with his usual assurance that whatever entered his head was
52889. right, wrote to Kutuzov the first words that occurred to him, though
52890. they were meaningless.
52891. 
52892. 
52893. MONSIEUR LE PRINCE KOUTOUZOV: I am sending one of my adjutants-general
52894. to discuss several interesting questions with you. I beg your Highness
52895. to credit what he says to you, especially when he expresses the
52896. sentiment of esteem and special regard I have long entertained for your
52897. person. This letter having no other object, I pray God, monsieur le
52898. Prince Koutouzov, to keep you in His holy and gracious protection!
52899. 
52900. NAPOLEON
52901. 
52902. MOSCOW, OCTOBER 30, 1812
52903. 
52904. 
52905. Kutuzov replied: "I should be cursed by posterity were I looked on as
52906. the initiator of a settlement of any sort. Such is the present spirit
52907. of my nation." But he continued to exert all his powers to restrain his
52908. troops from attacking.
52909. 
52910. During the month that the French troops were pillaging in Moscow and
52911. the Russian troops were quietly encamped at Tarutino, a change had taken
52912. place in the relative strength of the two armies--both in spirit and in
52913. number--as a result of which the superiority had passed to the Russian
52914. side. Though the condition and numbers of the French army were unknown
52915. to the Russians, as soon as that change occurred the need of attacking
52916. at once showed itself by countless signs. These signs were: Lauriston's
52917. mission; the abundance of provisions at Tarutino; the reports coming in
52918. from all sides of the inactivity and disorder of the French; the flow of
52919. recruits to our regiments; the fine weather; the long rest the Russian
52920. soldiers had enjoyed, and the impatience to do what they had been
52921. assembled for, which usually shows itself in an army that has been
52922. resting; curiosity as to what the French army, so long lost sight of,
52923. was doing; the boldness with which our outposts now scouted close up to
52924. the French stationed at Tarutino; the news of easy successes gained by
52925. peasants and guerrilla troops over the French, the envy aroused by this;
52926. the desire for revenge that lay in the heart of every Russian as long as
52927. the French were in Moscow, and (above all) a dim consciousness in every
52928. soldier's mind that the relative strength of the armies had changed and
52929. that the advantage was now on our side. There was a substantial change
52930. in the relative strength, and an advance had become inevitable. And at
52931. once, as a clock begins to strike and chime as soon as the minute hand
52932. has completed a full circle, this change was shown by an increased
52933. activity, whirring, and chiming in the higher spheres.
52934. 
52935. 
52936. 
52937. 
52938. 
52939. CHAPTER III
52940. 
52941. 
52942. The Russian army was commanded by Kutuzov and his staff, and also by the
52943. Emperor from Petersburg. Before the news of the abandonment of Moscow
52944. had been received in Petersburg, a detailed plan of the whole campaign
52945. had been drawn up and sent to Kutuzov for his guidance. Though this plan
52946. had been drawn up on the supposition that Moscow was still in our hands,
52947. it was approved by the staff and accepted as a basis for action.
52948. Kutuzov only replied that movements arranged from a distance were always
52949. difficult to execute. So fresh instructions were sent for the solution
52950. of difficulties that might be encountered, as well as fresh people who
52951. were to watch Kutuzov's actions and report upon them.
52952. 
52953. Besides this, the whole staff of the Russian army was now reorganized.
52954. The posts left vacant by Bagration, who had been killed, and by
52955. Barclay, who had gone away in dudgeon, had to be filled. Very serious
52956. consideration was given to the question whether it would be better to
52957. put A in B's place and B in D's, or on the contrary to put D in A's
52958. place, and so on--as if anything more than A's or B's satisfaction
52959. depended on this.
52960. 
52961. As a result of the hostility between Kutuzov and Bennigsen, his Chief of
52962. Staff, the presence of confidential representatives of the Emperor, and
52963. these transfers, a more than usually complicated play of parties
52964. was going on among the staff of the army. A was undermining B, D was
52965. undermining C, and so on in all possible combinations and permutations.
52966. In all these plottings the subject of intrigue was generally the conduct
52967. of the war, which all these men believed they were directing; but this
52968. affair of the war went on independently of them, as it had to go:
52969. that is, never in the way people devised, but flowing always from the
52970. essential attitude of the masses. Only in the highest spheres did
52971. all these schemes, crossings, and interminglings appear to be a true
52972. reflection of what had to happen.
52973. 
52974. 
52975. Prince Michael Ilarionovich! (wrote the Emperor on the second of October
52976. in a letter that reached Kutuzov after the battle at Tarutino) Since
52977. September 2 Moscow has been in the hands of the enemy. Your last reports
52978. were written on the twentieth, and during all this time not only has
52979. no action been taken against the enemy or for the relief of the ancient
52980. capital, but according to your last report you have even retreated
52981. farther. Serpukhov is already occupied by an enemy detachment and Tula
52982. with its famous arsenal so indispensable to the army, is in danger.
52983. From General Wintzingerode's reports, I see that an enemy corps of ten
52984. thousand men is moving on the Petersburg road. Another corps of several
52985. thousand men is moving on Dmitrov. A third has advanced along the
52986. Vladimir road, and a fourth, rather considerable detachment is stationed
52987. between Ruza and Mozhaysk. Napoleon himself was in Moscow as late as
52988. the twenty-fifth. In view of all this information, when the enemy has
52989. scattered his forces in large detachments, and with Napoleon and his
52990. Guards in Moscow, is it possible that the enemy's forces confronting you
52991. are so considerable as not to allow of your taking the offensive? On the
52992. contrary, he is probably pursuing you with detachments, or at most with
52993. an army corps much weaker than the army entrusted to you. It would seem
52994. that, availing yourself of these circumstances, you might advantageously
52995. attack a weaker one and annihilate him, or at least oblige him to
52996. retreat, retaining in our hands an important part of the provinces now
52997. occupied by the enemy, and thereby averting danger from Tula and other
52998. towns in the interior. You will be responsible if the enemy is able to
52999. direct a force of any size against Petersburg to threaten this capital
53000. in which it has not been possible to retain many troops; for with the
53001. army entrusted to you, and acting with resolution and energy, you have
53002. ample means to avert this fresh calamity. Remember that you have still
53003. to answer to our offended country for the loss of Moscow. You have
53004. experienced my readiness to reward you. That readiness will not weaken
53005. in me, but I and Russia have a right to expect from you all the zeal,
53006. firmness, and success which your intellect, military talent, and the
53007. courage of the troops you command justify us in expecting.
53008. 
53009. 
53010. But by the time this letter, which proved that the real relation of
53011. the forces had already made itself felt in Petersburg, was dispatched,
53012. Kutuzov had found himself unable any longer to restrain the army he
53013. commanded from attacking and a battle had taken place.
53014. 
53015. On the second of October a Cossack, Shapovalov, who was out scouting,
53016. killed one hare and wounded another. Following the wounded hare he made
53017. his way far into the forest and came upon the left flank of Murat's
53018. army, encamped there without any precautions. The Cossack laughingly
53019. told his comrades how he had almost fallen into the hands of the French.
53020. A cornet, hearing the story, informed his commander.
53021. 
53022. The Cossack was sent for and questioned. The Cossack officers wished
53023. to take advantage of this chance to capture some horses, but one of
53024. the superior officers, who was acquainted with the higher authorities,
53025. reported the incident to a general on the staff. The state of things on
53026. the staff had of late been exceedingly strained. Ermolov had been to
53027. see Bennigsen a few days previously and had entreated him to use
53028. his influence with the commander in chief to induce him to take the
53029. offensive.
53030. 
53031. "If I did not know you I should think you did not want what you are
53032. asking for. I need only advise anything and his Highness is sure to do
53033. the opposite," replied Bennigsen.
53034. 
53035. The Cossack's report, confirmed by horse patrols who were sent out, was
53036. the final proof that events had matured. The tightly coiled spring was
53037. released, the clock began to whirr and the chimes to play. Despite all
53038. his supposed power, his intellect, his experience, and his knowledge of
53039. men, Kutuzov--having taken into consideration the Cossack's report, a
53040. note from Bennigsen who sent personal reports to the Emperor, the wishes
53041. he supposed the Emperor to hold, and the fact that all the generals
53042. expressed the same wish--could no longer check the inevitable movement,
53043. and gave the order to do what he regarded as useless and harmful--gave
53044. his approval, that is, to the accomplished fact.
53045. 
53046. 
53047. 
53048. 
53049. 
53050. CHAPTER IV
53051. 
53052. 
53053. Bennigsen's note and the Cossack's information that the left flank
53054. of the French was unguarded were merely final indications that it was
53055. necessary to order an attack, and it was fixed for the fifth of October.
53056. 
53057. On the morning of the fourth of October Kutuzov signed the dispositions.
53058. Toll read them to Ermolov, asking him to attend to the further
53059. arrangements.
53060. 
53061. "All right--all right. I haven't time just now," replied Ermolov, and
53062. left the hut.
53063. 
53064. The dispositions drawn up by Toll were very good. As in the Austerlitz
53065. dispositions, it was written--though not in German this time:
53066. 
53067. "The First Column will march here and here," "the Second Column will
53068. march there and there," and so on; and on paper, all these columns
53069. arrived at their places at the appointed time and destroyed the enemy.
53070. Everything had been admirably thought out as is usual in dispositions,
53071. and as is always the case, not a single column reached its place at the
53072. appointed time.
53073. 
53074. When the necessary number of copies of the dispositions had been
53075. prepared, an officer was summoned and sent to deliver them to Ermolov
53076. to deal with. A young officer of the Horse Guards, Kutuzov's orderly,
53077. pleased at the importance of the mission entrusted to him, went to
53078. Ermolov's quarters.
53079. 
53080. "Gone away," said Ermolov's orderly.
53081. 
53082. The officer of the Horse Guards went to a general with whom Ermolov was
53083. often to be found.
53084. 
53085. "No, and the general's out too."
53086. 
53087. The officer, mounting his horse, rode off to someone else.
53088. 
53089. "No, he's gone out."
53090. 
53091. "If only they don't make me responsible for this delay! What a nuisance
53092. it is!" thought the officer, and he rode round the whole camp. One man
53093. said he had seen Ermolov ride past with some other generals, others said
53094. he must have returned home. The officer searched till six o'clock in the
53095. evening without even stopping to eat. Ermolov was nowhere to be found
53096. and no one knew where he was. The officer snatched a little food at
53097. a comrade's, and rode again to the vanguard to find Miloradovich.
53098. Miloradovich too was away, but here he was told that he had gone to a
53099. ball at General Kikin's and that Ermolov was probably there too.
53100. 
53101. "But where is it?"
53102. 
53103. "Why, there, over at Echkino," said a Cossack officer, pointing to a
53104. country house in the far distance.
53105. 
53106. "What, outside our line?"
53107. 
53108. "They've put two regiments as outposts, and they're having such a spree
53109. there, it's awful! Two bands and three sets of singers!"
53110. 
53111. The officer rode out beyond our lines to Echkino. While still at a
53112. distance he heard as he rode the merry sounds of a soldier's dance song
53113. proceeding from the house.
53114. 
53115. "In the meadows... in the meadows!" he heard, accompanied by whistling
53116. and the sound of a torban, drowned every now and then by shouts. These
53117. sounds made his spirits rise, but at the same time he was afraid that
53118. he would be blamed for not having executed sooner the important order
53119. entrusted to him. It was already past eight o'clock. He dismounted
53120. and went up into the porch of a large country house which had remained
53121. intact between the Russian and French forces. In the refreshment room
53122. and the hall, footmen were bustling about with wine and viands. Groups
53123. of singers stood outside the windows. The officer was admitted and
53124. immediately saw all the chief generals of the army together, and among
53125. them Ermolov's big imposing figure. They all had their coats unbuttoned
53126. and were standing in a semicircle with flushed and animated faces,
53127. laughing loudly. In the middle of the room a short handsome general with
53128. a red face was dancing the trepak with much spirit and agility.
53129. 
53130. "Ha, ha, ha! Bravo, Nicholas Ivanych! Ha, ha, ha!"
53131. 
53132. The officer felt that by arriving with important orders at such a moment
53133. he was doubly to blame, and he would have preferred to wait; but one of
53134. the generals espied him and, hearing what he had come about, informed
53135. Ermolov.
53136. 
53137. Ermolov came forward with a frown on his face and, hearing what the
53138. officer had to say, took the papers from him without a word.
53139. 
53140. 
53141. "You think he went off just by chance?" said a comrade, who was on the
53142. staff that evening, to the officer of the Horse Guards, referring to
53143. Ermolov. "It was a trick. It was done on purpose to get Konovnitsyn into
53144. trouble. You'll see what a mess there'll be tomorrow."
53145. 
53146. 
53147. 
53148. 
53149. 
53150. CHAPTER V
53151. 
53152. 
53153. Next day the decrepit Kutuzov, having given orders to be called early,
53154. said his prayers, dressed, and, with an unpleasant consciousness of
53155. having to direct a battle he did not approve of, got into his caleche
53156. and drove from Letashovka (a village three and a half miles from
53157. Tarutino) to the place where the attacking columns were to meet. He sat
53158. in the caleche, dozing and waking up by turns, and listening for any
53159. sound of firing on the right as an indication that the action had begun.
53160. But all was still quiet. A damp dull autumn morning was just dawning. On
53161. approaching Tarutino Kutuzov noticed cavalrymen leading their horses to
53162. water across the road along which he was driving. Kutuzov looked at
53163. them searchingly, stopped his carriage, and inquired what regiment they
53164. belonged to. They belonged to a column that should have been far in
53165. front and in ambush long before then. "It may be a mistake," thought
53166. the old commander in chief. But a little further on he saw infantry
53167. regiments with their arms piled and the soldiers, only partly dressed,
53168. eating their rye porridge and carrying fuel. He sent for an officer. The
53169. officer reported that no order to advance had been received.
53170. 
53171. "How! Not rec..." Kutuzov began, but checked himself immediately and
53172. sent for a senior officer. Getting out of his caleche, he waited with
53173. drooping head and breathing heavily, pacing silently up and down. When
53174. Eykhen, the officer of the general staff whom he had summoned, appeared,
53175. Kutuzov went purple in the face, not because that officer was to blame
53176. for the mistake, but because he was an object of sufficient importance
53177. for him to vent his wrath on. Trembling and panting the old man fell
53178. into that state of fury in which he sometimes used to roll on the
53179. ground, and he fell upon Eykhen, threatening him with his hands,
53180. shouting and loading him with gross abuse. Another man, Captain Brozin,
53181. who happened to turn up and who was not at all to blame, suffered the
53182. same fate.
53183. 
53184. "What sort of another blackguard are you? I'll have you shot!
53185. Scoundrels!" yelled Kutuzov in a hoarse voice, waving his arms and
53186. reeling.
53187. 
53188. He was suffering physically. He, the commander in chief, a Serene
53189. Highness who everybody said possessed powers such as no man had ever had
53190. in Russia, to be placed in this position--made the laughingstock of the
53191. whole army! "I needn't have been in such a hurry to pray about today,
53192. or have kept awake thinking everything over all night," thought he to
53193. himself. "When I was a chit of an officer no one would have dared to
53194. mock me so... and now!" He was in a state of physical suffering as if
53195. from corporal punishment, and could not avoid expressing it by cries of
53196. anger and distress. But his strength soon began to fail him, and looking
53197. about him, conscious of having said much that was amiss, he again got
53198. into his caleche and drove back in silence.
53199. 
53200. His wrath, once expended, did not return, and blinking feebly he
53201. listened to excuses and self-justifications (Ermolov did not come to see
53202. him till the next day) and to the insistence of Bennigsen, Konovnitsyn,
53203. and Toll that the movement that had miscarried should be executed next
53204. day. And once more Kutuzov had to consent.
53205. 
53206. 
53207. 
53208. 
53209. 
53210. CHAPTER VI
53211. 
53212. 
53213. Next day the troops assembled in their appointed places in the evening
53214. and advanced during the night. It was an autumn night with dark purple
53215. clouds, but no rain. The ground was damp but not muddy, and the troops
53216. advanced noiselessly, only occasionally a jingling of the artillery
53217. could be faintly heard. The men were forbidden to talk out loud, to
53218. smoke their pipes, or to strike a light, and they tried to prevent their
53219. horses neighing. The secrecy of the undertaking heightened its charm
53220. and they marched gaily. Some columns, supposing they had reached their
53221. destination, halted, piled arms, and settled down on the cold ground,
53222. but the majority marched all night and arrived at places where they
53223. evidently should not have been.
53224. 
53225. Only Count Orlov-Denisov with his Cossacks (the least important
53226. detachment of all) got to his appointed place at the right time. This
53227. detachment halted at the outskirts of a forest, on the path leading from
53228. the village of Stromilova to Dmitrovsk.
53229. 
53230. Toward dawn, Count Orlov-Denisov, who had dozed off, was awakened by a
53231. deserter from the French army being brought to him. This was a Polish
53232. sergeant of Poniatowski's corps, who explained in Polish that he had
53233. come over because he had been slighted in the service: that he ought
53234. long ago to have been made an officer, that he was braver than any of
53235. them, and so he had left them and wished to pay them out. He said that
53236. Murat was spending the night less than a mile from where they were,
53237. and that if they would let him have a convoy of a hundred men he would
53238. capture him alive. Count Orlov-Denisov consulted his fellow officers.
53239. 
53240. The offer was too tempting to be refused. Everyone volunteered to go and
53241. everybody advised making the attempt. After much disputing and arguing,
53242. Major-General Grekov with two Cossack regiments decided to go with the
53243. Polish sergeant.
53244. 
53245. "Now, remember," said Count Orlov-Denisov to the sergeant at parting,
53246. "if you have been lying I'll have you hanged like a dog; but if it's
53247. true you shall have a hundred gold pieces!"
53248. 
53249. Without replying, the sergeant, with a resolute air, mounted and rode
53250. away with Grekov whose men had quickly assembled. They disappeared into
53251. the forest, and Count Orlov-Denisov, having seen Grekov off, returned,
53252. shivering from the freshness of the early dawn and excited by what he
53253. had undertaken on his own responsibility, and began looking at the enemy
53254. camp, now just visible in the deceptive light of dawn and the dying
53255. campfires. Our columns ought to have begun to appear on an open
53256. declivity to his right. He looked in that direction, but though the
53257. columns would have been visible quite far off, they were not to be seen.
53258. It seemed to the count that things were beginning to stir in the French
53259. camp, and his keen-sighted adjutant confirmed this.
53260. 
53261. "Oh, it is really too late," said Count Orlov, looking at the camp.
53262. 
53263. As often happens when someone we have trusted is no longer before
53264. our eyes, it suddenly seemed quite clear and obvious to him that the
53265. sergeant was an impostor, that he had lied, and that the whole Russian
53266. attack would be ruined by the absence of those two regiments, which
53267. he would lead away heaven only knew where. How could one capture a
53268. commander in chief from among such a mass of troops!
53269. 
53270. "I am sure that rascal was lying," said the count.
53271. 
53272. "They can still be called back," said one of his suite, who like Count
53273. Orlov felt distrustful of the adventure when he looked at the enemy's
53274. camp.
53275. 
53276. "Eh? Really... what do you think? Should we let them go on or not?"
53277. 
53278. "Will you have them fetched back?"
53279. 
53280. "Fetch them back, fetch them back!" said Count Orlov with sudden
53281. determination, looking at his watch. "It will be too late. It is quite
53282. light."
53283. 
53284. And the adjutant galloped through the forest after Grekov. When Grekov
53285. returned, Count Orlov-Denisov, excited both by the abandoned attempt and
53286. by vainly awaiting the infantry columns that still did not appear, as
53287. well as by the proximity of the enemy, resolved to advance. All his men
53288. felt the same excitement.
53289. 
53290. "Mount!" he commanded in a whisper. The men took their places and
53291. crossed themselves.... "Forward, with God's aid!"
53292. 
53293. "Hurrah-ah-ah!" reverberated in the forest, and the Cossack companies,
53294. trailing their lances and advancing one after another as if poured out
53295. of a sack, dashed gaily across the brook toward the camp.
53296. 
53297. One desperate, frightened yell from the first French soldier who saw the
53298. Cossacks, and all who were in the camp, undressed and only just waking
53299. up, ran off in all directions, abandoning cannons, muskets, and horses.
53300. 
53301. Had the Cossacks pursued the French, without heeding what was behind and
53302. around them, they would have captured Murat and everything there.
53303. That was what the officers desired. But it was impossible to make the
53304. Cossacks budge when once they had got booty and prisoners. None of them
53305. listened to orders. Fifteen hundred prisoners and thirty-eight guns were
53306. taken on the spot, besides standards and (what seemed most important to
53307. the Cossacks) horses, saddles, horsecloths, and the like. All this had
53308. to be dealt with, the prisoners and guns secured, the booty divided--not
53309. without some shouting and even a little fighting among themselves--and
53310. it was on this that the Cossacks all busied themselves.
53311. 
53312. The French, not being farther pursued, began to recover themselves: they
53313. formed into detachments and began firing. Orlov-Denisov, still waiting
53314. for the other columns to arrive, advanced no further.
53315. 
53316. Meantime, according to the dispositions which said that "the First
53317. Column will march" and so on, the infantry of the belated columns,
53318. commanded by Bennigsen and directed by Toll, had started in due order
53319. and, as always happens, had got somewhere, but not to their appointed
53320. places. As always happens the men, starting cheerfully, began to halt;
53321. murmurs were heard, there was a sense of confusion, and finally a
53322. backward movement. Adjutants and generals galloped about, shouted, grew
53323. angry, quarreled, said they had come quite wrong and were late, gave
53324. vent to a little abuse, and at last gave it all up and went forward,
53325. simply to get somewhere. "We shall get somewhere or other!" And they did
53326. indeed get somewhere, though not to their right places; a few eventually
53327. even got to their right place, but too late to be of any use and only
53328. in time to be fired at. Toll, who in this battle played the part of
53329. Weyrother at Austerlitz, galloped assiduously from place to place,
53330. finding everything upside down everywhere. Thus he stumbled on Bagovut's
53331. corps in a wood when it was already broad daylight, though the corps
53332. should long before have joined Orlov-Denisov. Excited and vexed by the
53333. failure and supposing that someone must be responsible for it, Toll
53334. galloped up to the commander of the corps and began upbraiding him
53335. severely, saying that he ought to be shot. General Bagovut, a fighting
53336. old soldier of placid temperament, being also upset by all the delay,
53337. confusion, and cross-purposes, fell into a rage to everybody's surprise
53338. and quite contrary to his usual character and said disagreeable things
53339. to Toll.
53340. 
53341. "I prefer not to take lessons from anyone, but I can die with my men as
53342. well as anybody," he said, and advanced with a single division.
53343. 
53344. Coming out onto a field under the enemy's fire, this brave general went
53345. straight ahead, leading his men under fire, without considering in his
53346. agitation whether going into action now, with a single division, would
53347. be of any use or no. Danger, cannon balls, and bullets were just what he
53348. needed in his angry mood. One of the first bullets killed him, and other
53349. bullets killed many of his men. And his division remained under fire for
53350. some time quite uselessly.
53351. 
53352. 
53353. 
53354. 
53355. 
53356. CHAPTER VII
53357. 
53358. 
53359. Meanwhile another column was to have attacked the French from the front,
53360. but Kutuzov accompanied that column. He well knew that nothing but
53361. confusion would come of this battle undertaken against his will, and as
53362. far as was in his power held the troops back. He did not advance.
53363. 
53364. He rode silently on his small gray horse, indolently answering
53365. suggestions that they should attack.
53366. 
53367. "The word attack is always on your tongue, but you don't see that we are
53368. unable to execute complicated maneuvers," said he to Miloradovich who
53369. asked permission to advance.
53370. 
53371. "We couldn't take Murat prisoner this morning or get to the place in
53372. time, and nothing can be done now!" he replied to someone else.
53373. 
53374. When Kutuzov was informed that at the French rear--where according to
53375. the reports of the Cossacks there had previously been nobody--there were
53376. now two battalions of Poles, he gave a sidelong glance at Ermolov who
53377. was behind him and to whom he had not spoken since the previous day.
53378. 
53379. "You see! They are asking to attack and making plans of all kinds,
53380. but as soon as one gets to business nothing is ready, and the enemy,
53381. forewarned, takes measures accordingly."
53382. 
53383. Ermolov screwed up his eyes and smiled faintly on hearing these words.
53384. He understood that for him the storm had blown over, and that Kutuzov
53385. would content himself with that hint.
53386. 
53387. "He's having a little fun at my expense," said Ermolov softly, nudging
53388. with his knee Raevski who was at his side.
53389. 
53390. Soon after this, Ermolov moved up to Kutuzov and respectfully remarked:
53391. 
53392. "It is not too late yet, your Highness--the enemy has not gone away--if
53393. you were to order an attack! If not, the Guards will not so much as see
53394. a little smoke."
53395. 
53396. Kutuzov did not reply, but when they reported to him that Murat's troops
53397. were in retreat he ordered an advance, though at every hundred paces he
53398. halted for three quarters of an hour.
53399. 
53400. The whole battle consisted in what Orlov-Denisov's Cossacks had done:
53401. the rest of the army merely lost some hundreds of men uselessly.
53402. 
53403. In consequence of this battle Kutuzov received a diamond decoration,
53404. and Bennigsen some diamonds and a hundred thousand rubles, others also
53405. received pleasant recognitions corresponding to their various grades,
53406. and following the battle fresh changes were made in the staff.
53407. 
53408. "That's how everything is done with us, all topsy-turvy!" said the
53409. Russian officers and generals after the Tarutino battle, letting it be
53410. understood that some fool there is doing things all wrong but that
53411. we ourselves should not have done so, just as people speak today. But
53412. people who talk like that either do not know what they are talking about
53413. or deliberately deceive themselves. No battle--Tarutino, Borodino, or
53414. Austerlitz--takes place as those who planned it anticipated. That is an
53415. essential condition.
53416. 
53417. A countless number of free forces (for nowhere is man freer than during
53418. a battle, where it is a question of life and death) influence the course
53419. taken by the fight, and that course never can be known in advance and
53420. never coincides with the direction of any one force.
53421. 
53422. If many simultaneously and variously directed forces act on a given
53423. body, the direction of its motion cannot coincide with any one of those
53424. forces, but will always be a mean--what in mechanics is represented by
53425. the diagonal of a parallelogram of forces.
53426. 
53427. If in the descriptions given by historians, especially French ones, we
53428. find their wars and battles carried out in accordance with previously
53429. formed plans, the only conclusion to be drawn is that those descriptions
53430. are false.
53431. 
53432. The battle of Tarutino obviously did not attain the aim Toll had in
53433. view--to lead the troops into action in the order prescribed by the
53434. dispositions; nor that which Count Orlov-Denisov may have had in
53435. view--to take Murat prisoner; nor the result of immediately destroying
53436. the whole corps, which Bennigsen and others may have had in view; nor
53437. the aim of the officer who wished to go into action to distinguish
53438. himself; nor that of the Cossack who wanted more booty than he got, and
53439. so on. But if the aim of the battle was what actually resulted and what
53440. all the Russians of that day desired--to drive the French out of Russia
53441. and destroy their army--it is quite clear that the battle of Tarutino,
53442. just because of its incongruities, was exactly what was wanted at that
53443. stage of the campaign. It would be difficult and even impossible to
53444. imagine any result more opportune than the actual outcome of this
53445. battle. With a minimum of effort and insignificant losses, despite the
53446. greatest confusion, the most important results of the whole campaign
53447. were attained: the transition from retreat to advance, an exposure of
53448. the weakness of the French, and the administration of that shock which
53449. Napoleon's army had only awaited to begin its flight.
53450. 
53451. 
53452. 
53453. 
53454. 
53455. CHAPTER VIII
53456. 
53457. 
53458. Napoleon enters Moscow after the brilliant victory de la Moskowa; there
53459. can be no doubt about the victory for the battlefield remains in the
53460. hands of the French. The Russians retreat and abandon their ancient
53461. capital. Moscow, abounding in provisions, arms, munitions, and
53462. incalculable wealth, is in Napoleon's hands. The Russian army, only half
53463. the strength of the French, does not make a single attempt to attack for
53464. a whole month. Napoleon's position is most brilliant. He can either fall
53465. on the Russian army with double its strength and destroy it; negotiate
53466. an advantageous peace, or in case of a refusal make a menacing move on
53467. Petersburg, or even, in the case of a reverse, return to Smolensk or
53468. Vilna; or remain in Moscow; in short, no special genius would seem to be
53469. required to retain the brilliant position the French held at that time.
53470. For that, only very simple and easy steps were necessary: not to allow
53471. the troops to loot, to prepare winter clothing--of which there was
53472. sufficient in Moscow for the whole army--and methodically to collect
53473. the provisions, of which (according to the French historians) there were
53474. enough in Moscow to supply the whole army for six months. Yet Napoleon,
53475. that greatest of all geniuses, who the historians declare had control of
53476. the army, took none of these steps.
53477. 
53478. He not merely did nothing of the kind, but on the contrary he used his
53479. power to select the most foolish and ruinous of all the courses open
53480. to him. Of all that Napoleon might have done: wintering in Moscow,
53481. advancing on Petersburg or on Nizhni-Novgorod, or retiring by a more
53482. northerly or more southerly route (say by the road Kutuzov afterwards
53483. took), nothing more stupid or disastrous can be imagined than what he
53484. actually did. He remained in Moscow till October, letting the troops
53485. plunder the city; then, hesitating whether to leave a garrison behind
53486. him, he quitted Moscow, approached Kutuzov without joining battle,
53487. turned to the right and reached Malo-Yaroslavets, again without
53488. attempting to break through and take the road Kutuzov took, but retiring
53489. instead to Mozhaysk along the devastated Smolensk road. Nothing more
53490. stupid than that could have been devised, or more disastrous for the
53491. army, as the sequel showed. Had Napoleon's aim been to destroy his army,
53492. the most skillful strategist could hardly have devised any series
53493. of actions that would so completely have accomplished that purpose,
53494. independently of anything the Russian army might do.
53495. 
53496. Napoleon, the man of genius, did this! But to say that he destroyed his
53497. army because he wished to, or because he was very stupid, would be as
53498. unjust as to say that he had brought his troops to Moscow because he
53499. wished to and because he was very clever and a genius.
53500. 
53501. In both cases his personal activity, having no more force than the
53502. personal activity of any soldier, merely coincided with the laws that
53503. guided the event.
53504. 
53505. The historians quite falsely represent Napoleon's faculties as having
53506. weakened in Moscow, and do so only because the results did not justify
53507. his actions. He employed all his ability and strength to do the best he
53508. could for himself and his army, as he had done previously and as he did
53509. subsequently in 1813. His activity at that time was no less astounding
53510. than it was in Egypt, in Italy, in Austria, and in Prussia. We do not
53511. know for certain in how far his genius was genuine in Egypt--where forty
53512. centuries looked down upon his grandeur--for his great exploits there
53513. are all told us by Frenchmen. We cannot accurately estimate his genius
53514. in Austria or Prussia, for we have to draw our information from French
53515. or German sources, and the incomprehensible surrender of whole corps
53516. without fighting and of fortresses without a siege must incline Germans
53517. to recognize his genius as the only explanation of the war carried on
53518. in Germany. But we, thank God, have no need to recognize his genius
53519. in order to hide our shame. We have paid for the right to look at the
53520. matter plainly and simply, and we will not abandon that right.
53521. 
53522. His activity in Moscow was as amazing and as full of genius as
53523. elsewhere. Order after order and plan after plan were issued by him
53524. from the time he entered Moscow till the time he left it. The absence
53525. of citizens and of a deputation, and even the burning of Moscow, did not
53526. disconcert him. He did not lose sight either of the welfare of his
53527. army or of the doings of the enemy, or of the welfare of the people
53528. of Russia, or of the direction of affairs in Paris, or of diplomatic
53529. considerations concerning the terms of the anticipated peace.
53530. 
53531. 
53532. 
53533. 
53534. 
53535. CHAPTER IX
53536. 
53537. 
53538. With regard to military matters, Napoleon immediately on his entry into
53539. Moscow gave General Sabastiani strict orders to observe the movements
53540. of the Russian army, sent army corps out along the different roads, and
53541. charged Murat to find Kutuzov. Then he gave careful directions about the
53542. fortification of the Kremlin, and drew up a brilliant plan for a future
53543. campaign over the whole map of Russia.
53544. 
53545. With regard to diplomatic questions, Napoleon summoned Captain Yakovlev,
53546. who had been robbed and was in rags and did not know how to get out of
53547. Moscow, minutely explained to him his whole policy and his magnanimity,
53548. and having written a letter to the Emperor Alexander in which he
53549. considered it his duty to inform his Friend and Brother that Rostopchin
53550. had managed affairs badly in Moscow, he dispatched Yakovlev to
53551. Petersburg.
53552. 
53553. Having similarly explained his views and his magnanimity to Tutolmin, he
53554. dispatched that old man also to Petersburg to negotiate.
53555. 
53556. With regard to legal matters, immediately after the fires he gave orders
53557. to find and execute the incendiaries. And the scoundrel Rostopchin was
53558. punished by an order to burn down his houses.
53559. 
53560. With regard to administrative matters, Moscow was granted a
53561. constitution. A municipality was established and the following
53562. announcement issued:
53563. 
53564. 
53565. INHABITANTS OF MOSCOW!
53566. 
53567. Your misfortunes are cruel, but His Majesty the Emperor and King
53568. desires to arrest their course. Terrible examples have taught you how he
53569. punishes disobedience and crime. Strict measures have been taken to
53570. put an end to disorder and to re-establish public security. A
53571. paternal administration, chosen from among yourselves, will form your
53572. municipality or city government. It will take care of you, of your
53573. needs, and of your welfare. Its members will be distinguished by a red
53574. ribbon worn across the shoulder, and the mayor of the city will wear
53575. a white belt as well. But when not on duty they will only wear a red
53576. ribbon round the left arm.
53577. 
53578. The city police is established on its former footing, and better order
53579. already prevails in consequence of its activity. The government has
53580. appointed two commissaries general, or chiefs of police, and twenty
53581. commissaries or captains of wards have been appointed to the different
53582. wards of the city. You will recognize them by the white ribbon they will
53583. wear on the left arm. Several churches of different denominations are
53584. open, and divine service is performed in them unhindered. Your fellow
53585. citizens are returning every day to their homes and orders have been
53586. given that they should find in them the help and protection due to
53587. their misfortunes. These are the measures the government has adopted to
53588. re-establish order and relieve your condition. But to achieve this
53589. aim it is necessary that you should add your efforts and should, if
53590. possible, forget the misfortunes you have suffered, should entertain
53591. the hope of a less cruel fate, should be certain that inevitable and
53592. ignominious death awaits those who make any attempt on your persons or
53593. on what remains of your property, and finally that you should not doubt
53594. that these will be safeguarded, since such is the will of the greatest
53595. and most just of monarchs. Soldiers and citizens, of whatever nation you
53596. may be, re-establish public confidence, the source of the welfare of
53597. a state, live like brothers, render mutual aid and protection one to
53598. another, unite to defeat the intentions of the evil-minded, obey the
53599. military and civil authorities, and your tears will soon cease to flow!
53600. 
53601. 
53602. With regard to supplies for the army, Napoleon decreed that all the
53603. troops in turn should enter Moscow a la maraude * to obtain provisions
53604. for themselves, so that the army might have its future provided for.
53605. 
53606. 
53607.     * As looters.
53608. 
53609. 
53610. With regard to religion, Napoleon ordered the priests to be brought back
53611. and services to be again performed in the churches.
53612. 
53613. With regard to commerce and to provisioning the army, the following was
53614. placarded everywhere:
53615. 
53616. 
53617. PROCLAMATION!
53618. 
53619. You, peaceful inhabitants of Moscow, artisans and workmen whom
53620. misfortune has driven from the city, and you scattered tillers of
53621. the soil, still kept out in the fields by groundless fear, listen!
53622. Tranquillity is returning to this capital and order is being restored in
53623. it. Your fellow countrymen are emerging boldly from their hiding places
53624. on finding that they are respected. Any violence to them or to their
53625. property is promptly punished. His Majesty the Emperor and King protects
53626. them, and considers no one among you his enemy except those who disobey
53627. his orders. He desires to end your misfortunes and restore you to your
53628. homes and families. Respond, therefore, to his benevolent intentions
53629. and come to us without fear. Inhabitants, return with confidence to your
53630. abodes! You will soon find means of satisfying your needs. Craftsmen
53631. and industrious artisans, return to your work, your houses, your shops,
53632. where the protection of guards awaits you! You shall receive proper pay
53633. for your work. And lastly you too, peasants, come from the forests where
53634. you are hiding in terror, return to your huts without fear, in full
53635. assurance that you will find protection! Markets are established in the
53636. city where peasants can bring their surplus supplies and the products of
53637. the soil. The government has taken the following steps to ensure freedom
53638. of sale for them: (1) From today, peasants, husbandmen, and those
53639. living in the neighborhood of Moscow may without any danger bring their
53640. supplies of all kinds to two appointed markets, of which one is on
53641. the Mokhovaya Street and the other at the Provision Market. (2) Such
53642. supplies will be bought from them at such prices as seller and buyer may
53643. agree on, and if a seller is unable to obtain a fair price he will be
53644. free to take his goods back to his village and no one may hinder him
53645. under any pretense. (3) Sunday and Wednesday of each week are appointed
53646. as the chief market days and to that end a sufficient number of troops
53647. will be stationed along the highroads on Tuesdays and Saturdays at such
53648. distances from the town as to protect the carts. (4) Similar measures
53649. will be taken that peasants with their carts and horses may meet with no
53650. hindrance on their return journey. (5) Steps will immediately be taken
53651. to re-establish ordinary trading.
53652. 
53653. Inhabitants of the city and villages, and you, workingmen and artisans,
53654. to whatever nation you belong, you are called on to carry out the
53655. paternal intentions of His Majesty the Emperor and King and to
53656. co-operate with him for the public welfare! Lay your respect and
53657. confidence at his feet and do not delay to unite with us!
53658. 
53659. 
53660. With the object of raising the spirits of the troops and of the people,
53661. reviews were constantly held and rewards distributed. The Emperor
53662. rode through the streets to comfort the inhabitants, and, despite his
53663. preoccupation with state affairs, himself visited the theaters that were
53664. established by his order.
53665. 
53666. In regard to philanthropy, the greatest virtue of crowned heads,
53667. Napoleon also did all in his power. He caused the words Maison de ma
53668. Mere to be inscribed on the charitable institutions, thereby combining
53669. tender filial affection with the majestic benevolence of a monarch. He
53670. visited the Foundling Hospital and, allowing the orphans saved by him
53671. to kiss his white hands, graciously conversed with Tutolmin. Then, as
53672. Thiers eloquently recounts, he ordered his soldiers to be paid in forged
53673. Russian money which he had prepared: "Raising the use of these means
53674. by an act worthy of himself and of the French army, he let relief
53675. be distributed to those who had been burned out. But as food was too
53676. precious to be given to foreigners, who were for the most part enemies,
53677. Napoleon preferred to supply them with money with which to purchase food
53678. from outside, and had paper rubles distributed to them."
53679. 
53680. With reference to army discipline, orders were continually being issued
53681. to inflict severe punishment for the nonperformance of military duties
53682. and to suppress robbery.
53683. 
53684. 
53685. 
53686. 
53687. 
53688. CHAPTER X
53689. 
53690. 
53691. But strange to say, all these measures, efforts, and plans--which were
53692. not at all worse than others issued in similar circumstances--did not
53693. affect the essence of the matter but, like the hands of a clock detached
53694. from the mechanism, swung about in an arbitrary and aimless way without
53695. engaging the cogwheels.
53696. 
53697. With reference to the military side--the plan of campaign--that work of
53698. genius of which Thiers remarks that, "His genius never devised anything
53699. more profound, more skillful, or more admirable," and enters into a
53700. polemic with M. Fain to prove that this work of genius must be referred
53701. not to the fourth but to the fifteenth of October--that plan never was
53702. or could be executed, for it was quite out of touch with the facts
53703. of the case. The fortifying of the Kremlin, for which la Mosquee (as
53704. Napoleon termed the church of Basil the Beatified) was to have been
53705. razed to the ground, proved quite useless. The mining of the Kremlin
53706. only helped toward fulfilling Napoleon's wish that it should be blown
53707. up when he left Moscow--as a child wants the floor on which he has
53708. hurt himself to be beaten. The pursuit of the Russian army, about which
53709. Napoleon was so concerned, produced an unheard-of result. The French
53710. generals lost touch with the Russian army of sixty thousand men, and
53711. according to Thiers it was only eventually found, like a lost pin, by
53712. the skill--and apparently the genius--of Murat.
53713. 
53714. With reference to diplomacy, all Napoleon's arguments as to his
53715. magnanimity and justice, both to Tutolmin and to Yakovlev (whose chief
53716. concern was to obtain a greatcoat and a conveyance), proved useless;
53717. Alexander did not receive these envoys and did not reply to their
53718. embassage.
53719. 
53720. With regard to legal matters, after the execution of the supposed
53721. incendiaries the rest of Moscow burned down.
53722. 
53723. With regard to administrative matters, the establishment of a
53724. municipality did not stop the robberies and was only of use to certain
53725. people who formed part of that municipality and under pretext of
53726. preserving order looted Moscow or saved their own property from being
53727. looted.
53728. 
53729. With regard to religion, as to which in Egypt matters had so easily been
53730. settled by Napoleon's visit to a mosque, no results were achieved.
53731. Two or three priests who were found in Moscow did try to carry out
53732. Napoleon's wish, but one of them was slapped in the face by a French
53733. soldier while conducting service, and a French official reported of
53734. another that: "The priest whom I found and invited to say Mass cleaned
53735. and locked up the church. That night the doors were again broken
53736. open, the padlocks smashed, the books mutilated, and other disorders
53737. perpetrated."
53738. 
53739. With reference to commerce, the proclamation to industrious workmen and
53740. to peasants evoked no response. There were no industrious workmen, and
53741. the peasants caught the commissaries who ventured too far out of town
53742. with the proclamation and killed them.
53743. 
53744. As to the theaters for the entertainment of the people and the troops,
53745. these did not meet with success either. The theaters set up in the
53746. Kremlin and in Posnyakov's house were closed again at once because the
53747. actors and actresses were robbed.
53748. 
53749. Even philanthropy did not have the desired effect. The genuine as
53750. well as the false paper money which flooded Moscow lost its value. The
53751. French, collecting booty, cared only for gold. Not only was the
53752. paper money valueless which Napoleon so graciously distributed to the
53753. unfortunate, but even silver lost its value in relation to gold.
53754. 
53755. But the most amazing example of the ineffectiveness of the orders given
53756. by the authorities at that time was Napoleon's attempt to stop the
53757. looting and re-establish discipline.
53758. 
53759. This is what the army authorities were reporting:
53760. 
53761. "Looting continues in the city despite the decrees against it. Order
53762. is not yet restored and not a single merchant is carrying on trade in a
53763. lawful manner. The sutlers alone venture to trade, and they sell stolen
53764. goods."
53765. 
53766. "The neighborhood of my ward continues to be pillaged by soldiers of
53767. the 3rd Corps who, not satisfied with taking from the unfortunate
53768. inhabitants hiding in the cellars the little they have left, even have
53769. the ferocity to wound them with their sabers, as I have repeatedly
53770. witnessed."
53771. 
53772. "Nothing new, except that the soldiers are robbing and
53773. pillaging--October 9."
53774. 
53775. "Robbery and pillaging continue. There is a band of thieves in our
53776. district who ought to be arrested by a strong force--October 11."
53777. 
53778. "The Emperor is extremely displeased that despite the strict orders to
53779. stop pillage, parties of marauding Guards are continually seen returning
53780. to the Kremlin. Among the Old Guard disorder and pillage were renewed
53781. more violently than ever yesterday evening, last night, and today. The
53782. Emperor sees with regret that the picked soldiers appointed to guard his
53783. person, who should set an example of discipline, carry disobedience to
53784. such a point that they break into the cellars and stores containing army
53785. supplies. Others have disgraced themselves to the extent of disobeying
53786. sentinels and officers, and have abused and beaten them."
53787. 
53788. "The Grand Marshal of the palace," wrote the governor, "complains
53789. bitterly that in spite of repeated orders, the soldiers continue to
53790. commit nuisances in all the courtyards and even under the very windows
53791. of the Emperor."
53792. 
53793. That army, like a herd of cattle run wild and trampling underfoot the
53794. provender which might have saved it from starvation, disintegrated and
53795. perished with each additional day it remained in Moscow. But it did not
53796. go away.
53797. 
53798. It began to run away only when suddenly seized by a panic caused by the
53799. capture of transport trains on the Smolensk road, and by the battle of
53800. Tarutino. The news of that battle of Tarutino, unexpectedly received
53801. by Napoleon at a review, evoked in him a desire to punish the Russians
53802. (Thiers says), and he issued the order for departure which the whole
53803. army was demanding.
53804. 
53805. Fleeing from Moscow the soldiers took with them everything they had
53806. stolen. Napoleon, too, carried away his own personal tresor, but on
53807. seeing the baggage trains that impeded the army, he was (Thiers says)
53808. horror-struck. And yet with his experience of war he did not order all
53809. the superfluous vehicles to be burned, as he had done with those of a
53810. certain marshal when approaching Moscow. He gazed at the caleches and
53811. carriages in which soldiers were riding and remarked that it was a very
53812. good thing, as those vehicles could be used to carry provisions, the
53813. sick, and the wounded.
53814. 
53815. The plight of the whole army resembled that of a wounded animal which
53816. feels it is perishing and does not know what it is doing. To study the
53817. skillful tactics and aims of Napoleon and his army from the time it
53818. entered Moscow till it was destroyed is like studying the dying leaps
53819. and shudders of a mortally wounded animal. Very often a wounded animal,
53820. hearing a rustle, rushes straight at the hunter's gun, runs forward and
53821. back again, and hastens its own end. Napoleon, under pressure from his
53822. whole army, did the same thing. The rustle of the battle of Tarutino
53823. frightened the beast, and it rushed forward onto the hunter's gun,
53824. reached him, turned back, and finally--like any wild beast--ran back
53825. along the most disadvantageous and dangerous path, where the old scent
53826. was familiar.
53827. 
53828. During the whole of that period Napoleon, who seems to us to have been
53829. the leader of all these movements--as the figurehead of a ship may
53830. seem to a savage to guide the vessel--acted like a child who, holding a
53831. couple of strings inside a carriage, thinks he is driving it.
53832. 
53833. 
53834. 
53835. 
53836. 
53837. CHAPTER XI
53838. 
53839. 
53840. Early in the morning of the sixth of October Pierre went out of the
53841. shed, and on returning stopped by the door to play with a little
53842. blue-gray dog, with a long body and short bandy legs, that jumped about
53843. him. This little dog lived in their shed, sleeping beside Karataev at
53844. night; it sometimes made excursions into the town but always returned
53845. again. Probably it had never had an owner, and it still belonged to
53846. nobody and had no name. The French called it Azor; the soldier who
53847. told stories called it Femgalka; Karataev and others called it Gray, or
53848. sometimes Flabby. Its lack of a master, a name, or even of a breed or
53849. any definite color did not seem to trouble the blue-gray dog in the
53850. least. Its furry tail stood up firm and round as a plume, its bandy legs
53851. served it so well that it would often gracefully lift a hind leg and run
53852. very easily and quickly on three legs, as if disdaining to use all
53853. four. Everything pleased it. Now it would roll on its back, yelping with
53854. delight, now bask in the sun with a thoughtful air of importance, and
53855. now frolic about playing with a chip of wood or a straw.
53856. 
53857. Pierre's attire by now consisted of a dirty torn shirt (the only
53858. remnant of his former clothing), a pair of soldier's trousers which by
53859. Karataev's advice he tied with string round the ankles for warmth, and
53860. a peasant coat and cap. Physically he had changed much during this
53861. time. He no longer seemed stout, though he still had the appearance of
53862. solidity and strength hereditary in his family. A beard and mustache
53863. covered the lower part of his face, and a tangle of hair, infested
53864. with lice, curled round his head like a cap. The look of his eyes
53865. was resolute, calm, and animatedly alert, as never before. The former
53866. slackness which had shown itself even in his eyes was now replaced by an
53867. energetic readiness for action and resistance. His feet were bare.
53868. 
53869. Pierre first looked down the field across which vehicles and horsemen
53870. were passing that morning, then into the distance across the river, then
53871. at the dog who was pretending to be in earnest about biting him,
53872. and then at his bare feet which he placed with pleasure in various
53873. positions, moving his dirty thick big toes. Every time he looked at his
53874. bare feet a smile of animated self-satisfaction flitted across his face.
53875. The sight of them reminded him of all he had experienced and learned
53876. during these weeks and this recollection was pleasant to him.
53877. 
53878. For some days the weather had been calm and clear with slight frosts in
53879. the mornings--what is called an "old wives' summer."
53880. 
53881. In the sunshine the air was warm, and that warmth was particularly
53882. pleasant with the invigorating freshness of the morning frost still in
53883. the air.
53884. 
53885. On everything--far and near--lay the magic crystal glitter seen only
53886. at that time of autumn. The Sparrow Hills were visible in the distance,
53887. with the village, the church, and the large white house. The bare trees,
53888. the sand, the bricks and roofs of the houses, the green church spire,
53889. and the corners of the white house in the distance, all stood out in the
53890. transparent air in most delicate outline and with unnatural clearness.
53891. Near by could be seen the familiar ruins of a half-burned mansion
53892. occupied by the French, with lilac bushes still showing dark green
53893. beside the fence. And even that ruined and befouled house--which in
53894. dull weather was repulsively ugly--seemed quietly beautiful now, in the
53895. clear, motionless brilliance.
53896. 
53897. A French corporal, with coat unbuttoned in a homely way, a skullcap on
53898. his head, and a short pipe in his mouth, came from behind a corner of
53899. the shed and approached Pierre with a friendly wink.
53900. 
53901. "What sunshine, Monsieur Kiril!" (Their name for Pierre.) "Eh? Just like
53902. spring!"
53903. 
53904. And the corporal leaned against the door and offered Pierre his pipe,
53905. though whenever he offered it Pierre always declined it.
53906. 
53907. "To be on the march in such weather..." he began.
53908. 
53909. Pierre inquired what was being said about leaving, and the corporal told
53910. him that nearly all the troops were starting and there ought to be an
53911. order about the prisoners that day. Sokolov, one of the soldiers in the
53912. shed with Pierre, was dying, and Pierre told the corporal that something
53913. should be done about him. The corporal replied that Pierre need not
53914. worry about that as they had an ambulance and a permanent hospital and
53915. arrangements would be made for the sick, and that in general everything
53916. that could happen had been foreseen by the authorities.
53917. 
53918. "Besides, Monsieur Kiril, you have only to say a word to the captain,
53919. you know. He is a man who never forgets anything. Speak to the captain
53920. when he makes his round, he will do anything for you."
53921. 
53922. (The captain of whom the corporal spoke often had long chats with Pierre
53923. and showed him all sorts of favors.)
53924. 
53925. "'You see, St. Thomas,' he said to me the other day. 'Monsieur Kiril is
53926. a man of education, who speaks French. He is a Russian seigneur who has
53927. had misfortunes, but he is a man. He knows what's what.... If he wants
53928. anything and asks me, he won't get a refusal. When one has studied, you
53929. see, one likes education and well-bred people.' It is for your sake I
53930. mention it, Monsieur Kiril. The other day if it had not been for you
53931. that affair would have ended ill."
53932. 
53933. And after chatting a while longer, the corporal went away. (The affair
53934. he had alluded to had happened a few days before--a fight between the
53935. prisoners and the French soldiers, in which Pierre had succeeded in
53936. pacifying his comrades.) Some of the prisoners who had heard Pierre
53937. talking to the corporal immediately asked what the Frenchman had said.
53938. While Pierre was repeating what he had been told about the army leaving
53939. Moscow, a thin, sallow, tattered French soldier came up to the door of
53940. the shed. Rapidly and timidly raising his fingers to his forehead by way
53941. of greeting, he asked Pierre whether the soldier Platoche to whom he had
53942. given a shirt to sew was in that shed.
53943. 
53944. A week before the French had had boot leather and linen issued to them,
53945. which they had given out to the prisoners to make up into boots and
53946. shirts for them.
53947. 
53948. "Ready, ready, dear fellow!" said Karataev, coming out with a neatly
53949. folded shirt.
53950. 
53951. Karataev, on account of the warm weather and for convenience at work,
53952. was wearing only trousers and a tattered shirt as black as soot. His
53953. hair was bound round, workman fashion, with a wisp of lime-tree bast,
53954. and his round face seemed rounder and pleasanter than ever.
53955. 
53956. "A promise is own brother to performance! I said Friday and here it is,
53957. ready," said Platon, smiling and unfolding the shirt he had sewn.
53958. 
53959. The Frenchman glanced around uneasily and then, as if overcoming his
53960. hesitation, rapidly threw off his uniform and put on the shirt. He had
53961. a long, greasy, flowered silk waistcoat next to his sallow, thin bare
53962. body, but no shirt. He was evidently afraid the prisoners looking on
53963. would laugh at him, and thrust his head into the shirt hurriedly. None
53964. of the prisoners said a word.
53965. 
53966. "See, it fits well!" Platon kept repeating, pulling the shirt straight.
53967. 
53968. The Frenchman, having pushed his head and hands through, without raising
53969. his eyes, looked down at the shirt and examined the seams.
53970. 
53971. "You see, dear man, this is not a sewing shop, and I had no proper
53972. tools; and, as they say, one needs a tool even to kill a louse," said
53973. Platon with one of his round smiles, obviously pleased with his work.
53974. 
53975. "It's good, quite good, thank you," said the Frenchman, in French, "but
53976. there must be some linen left over.
53977. 
53978. "It will fit better still when it sets to your body," said Karataev,
53979. still admiring his handiwork. "You'll be nice and comfortable...."
53980. 
53981. "Thanks, thanks, old fellow.... But the bits left over?" said the
53982. Frenchman again and smiled. He took out an assignation ruble note and
53983. gave it to Karataev. "But give me the pieces that are over."
53984. 
53985. Pierre saw that Platon did not want to understand what the Frenchman
53986. was saying, and he looked on without interfering. Karataev thanked the
53987. Frenchman for the money and went on admiring his own work. The Frenchman
53988. insisted on having the pieces returned that were left over and asked
53989. Pierre to translate what he said.
53990. 
53991. "What does he want the bits for?" said Karataev. "They'd make fine leg
53992. bands for us. Well, never mind."
53993. 
53994. And Karataev, with a suddenly changed and saddened expression, took
53995. a small bundle of scraps from inside his shirt and gave it to the
53996. Frenchman without looking at him. "Oh dear!" muttered Karataev and went
53997. away. The Frenchman looked at the linen, considered for a moment, then
53998. looked inquiringly at Pierre and, as if Pierre's look had told him
53999. something, suddenly blushed and shouted in a squeaky voice:
54000. 
54001. "Platoche! Eh, Platoche! Keep them yourself!" And handing back the odd
54002. bits he turned and went out.
54003. 
54004. "There, look at that," said Karataev, swaying his head. "People said
54005. they were not Christians, but they too have souls. It's what the old
54006. folk used to say: 'A sweating hand's an open hand, a dry hand's close.'
54007. He's naked, but yet he's given it back."
54008. 
54009. Karataev smiled thoughtfully and was silent awhile looking at the
54010. pieces.
54011. 
54012. "But they'll make grand leg bands, dear friend," he said, and went back
54013. into the shed.
54014. 
54015. 
54016. 
54017. 
54018. 
54019. CHAPTER XII
54020. 
54021. 
54022. Four weeks had passed since Pierre had been taken prisoner and though
54023. the French had offered to move him from the men's to the officers' shed,
54024. he had stayed in the shed where he was first put.
54025. 
54026. In burned and devastated Moscow Pierre experienced almost the extreme
54027. limits of privation a man can endure; but thanks to his physical
54028. strength and health, of which he had till then been unconscious, and
54029. thanks especially to the fact that the privations came so gradually that
54030. it was impossible to say when they began, he endured his position
54031. not only lightly but joyfully. And just at this time he obtained the
54032. tranquillity and ease of mind he had formerly striven in vain to reach.
54033. He had long sought in different ways that tranquillity of mind, that
54034. inner harmony which had so impressed him in the soldiers at the battle
54035. of Borodino. He had sought it in philanthropy, in Freemasonry, in the
54036. dissipations of town life, in wine, in heroic feats of self-sacrifice,
54037. and in romantic love for Natasha; he had sought it by reasoning--and all
54038. these quests and experiments had failed him. And now without thinking
54039. about it he had found that peace and inner harmony only through the
54040. horror of death, through privation, and through what he recognized in
54041. Karataev.
54042. 
54043. Those dreadful moments he had lived through at the executions had as it
54044. were forever washed away from his imagination and memory the agitating
54045. thoughts and feelings that had formerly seemed so important. It did
54046. not now occur to him to think of Russia, or the war, or politics, or
54047. Napoleon. It was plain to him that all these things were no business
54048. of his, and that he was not called on to judge concerning them and
54049. therefore could not do so. "Russia and summer weather are not bound
54050. together," he thought, repeating words of Karataev's which he found
54051. strangely consoling. His intention of killing Napoleon and his
54052. calculations of the cabalistic number of the beast of the Apocalypse now
54053. seemed to him meaningless and even ridiculous. His anger with his wife
54054. and anxiety that his name should not be smirched now seemed not merely
54055. trivial but even amusing. What concern was it of his that somewhere or
54056. other that woman was leading the life she preferred? What did it matter
54057. to anybody, and especially to him, whether or not they found out that
54058. their prisoner's name was Count Bezukhov?
54059. 
54060. He now often remembered his conversation with Prince Andrew and quite
54061. agreed with him, though he understood Prince Andrew's thoughts somewhat
54062. differently. Prince Andrew had thought and said that happiness could
54063. only be negative, but had said it with a shade of bitterness and irony
54064. as though he was really saying that all desire for positive happiness is
54065. implanted in us merely to torment us and never be satisfied. But Pierre
54066. believed it without any mental reservation. The absence of suffering,
54067. the satisfaction of one's needs and consequent freedom in the choice of
54068. one's occupation, that is, of one's way of life, now seemed to Pierre to
54069. be indubitably man's highest happiness. Here and now for the first time
54070. he fully appreciated the enjoyment of eating when he wanted to eat,
54071. drinking when he wanted to drink, sleeping when he wanted to sleep, of
54072. warmth when he was cold, of talking to a fellow man when he wished to
54073. talk and to hear a human voice. The satisfaction of one's needs--good
54074. food, cleanliness, and freedom--now that he was deprived of all this,
54075. seemed to Pierre to constitute perfect happiness; and the choice
54076. of occupation, that is, of his way of life--now that that was so
54077. restricted--seemed to him such an easy matter that he forgot that a
54078. superfluity of the comforts of life destroys all joy in satisfying one's
54079. needs, while great freedom in the choice of occupation--such freedom as
54080. his wealth, his education, and his social position had given him in
54081. his own life--is just what makes the choice of occupation insolubly
54082. difficult and destroys the desire and possibility of having an
54083. occupation.
54084. 
54085. All Pierre's daydreams now turned on the time when he would be free. Yet
54086. subsequently, and for the rest of his life, he thought and spoke with
54087. enthusiasm of that month of captivity, of those irrecoverable, strong,
54088. joyful sensations, and chiefly of the complete peace of mind and inner
54089. freedom which he experienced only during those weeks.
54090. 
54091. When on the first day he got up early, went out of the shed at dawn, and
54092. saw the cupolas and crosses of the New Convent of the Virgin still dark
54093. at first, the hoarfrost on the dusty grass, the Sparrow Hills, and the
54094. wooded banks above the winding river vanishing in the purple distance,
54095. when he felt the contact of the fresh air and heard the noise of the
54096. crows flying from Moscow across the field, and when afterwards light
54097. gleamed from the east and the sun's rim appeared solemnly from behind a
54098. cloud, and the cupolas and crosses, the hoarfrost, the distance and the
54099. river, all began to sparkle in the glad light--Pierre felt a new joy and
54100. strength in life such as he had never before known. And this not only
54101. stayed with him during the whole of his imprisonment, but even grew in
54102. strength as the hardships of his position increased.
54103. 
54104. That feeling of alertness and of readiness for anything was still
54105. further strengthened in him by the high opinion his fellow prisoners
54106. formed of him soon after his arrival at the shed. With his knowledge
54107. of languages, the respect shown him by the French, his simplicity, his
54108. readiness to give anything asked of him (he received the allowance
54109. of three rubles a week made to officers); with his strength, which he
54110. showed to the soldiers by pressing nails into the walls of the hut; his
54111. gentleness to his companions, and his capacity for sitting still and
54112. thinking without doing anything (which seemed to them incomprehensible),
54113. he appeared to them a rather mysterious and superior being. The very
