54114. qualities that had been a hindrance, if not actually harmful, to him in
54115. the world he had lived in--his strength, his disdain for the comforts of
54116. life, his absent-mindedness and simplicity--here among these people
54117. gave him almost the status of a hero. And Pierre felt that their opinion
54118. placed responsibilities upon him.
54119. 
54120. 
54121. 
54122. 
54123. 
54124. CHAPTER XIII
54125. 
54126. 
54127. The French evacuation began on the night between the sixth and seventh
54128. of October: kitchens and sheds were dismantled, carts loaded, and troops
54129. and baggage trains started.
54130. 
54131. At seven in the morning a French convoy in marching trim, wearing shakos
54132. and carrying muskets, knapsacks, and enormous sacks, stood in front
54133. of the sheds, and animated French talk mingled with curses sounded all
54134. along the lines.
54135. 
54136. In the shed everyone was ready, dressed, belted, shod, and only awaited
54137. the order to start. The sick soldier, Sokolov, pale and thin with dark
54138. shadows round his eyes, alone sat in his place barefoot and not dressed.
54139. His eyes, prominent from the emaciation of his face, gazed inquiringly
54140. at his comrades who were paying no attention to him, and he moaned
54141. regularly and quietly. It was evidently not so much his sufferings that
54142. caused him to moan (he had dysentery) as his fear and grief at being
54143. left alone.
54144. 
54145. Pierre, girt with a rope round his waist and wearing shoes Karataev had
54146. made for him from some leather a French soldier had torn off a tea chest
54147. and brought to have his boots mended with, went up to the sick man and
54148. squatted down beside him.
54149. 
54150. "You know, Sokolov, they are not all going away! They have a hospital
54151. here. You may be better off than we others," said Pierre.
54152. 
54153. "O Lord! Oh, it will be the death of me! O Lord!" moaned the man in a
54154. louder voice.
54155. 
54156. "I'll go and ask them again directly," said Pierre, rising and going to
54157. the door of the shed.
54158. 
54159. Just as Pierre reached the door, the corporal who had offered him a
54160. pipe the day before came up to it with two soldiers. The corporal and
54161. soldiers were in marching kit with knapsacks and shakos that had metal
54162. straps, and these changed their familiar faces.
54163. 
54164. The corporal came, according to orders, to shut the door. The prisoners
54165. had to be counted before being let out.
54166. 
54167. "Corporal, what will they do with the sick man?..." Pierre began.
54168. 
54169. But even as he spoke he began to doubt whether this was the corporal
54170. he knew or a stranger, so unlike himself did the corporal seem at that
54171. moment. Moreover, just as Pierre was speaking a sharp rattle of drums
54172. was suddenly heard from both sides. The corporal frowned at Pierre's
54173. words and, uttering some meaningless oaths, slammed the door. The shed
54174. became semidark, and the sharp rattle of the drums on two sides drowned
54175. the sick man's groans.
54176. 
54177. "There it is!... It again!..." said Pierre to himself, and an
54178. involuntary shudder ran down his spine. In the corporal's changed face,
54179. in the sound of his voice, in the stirring and deafening noise of the
54180. drums, he recognized that mysterious, callous force which compelled
54181. people against their will to kill their fellow men--that force the
54182. effect of which he had witnessed during the executions. To fear or to
54183. try to escape that force, to address entreaties or exhortations to those
54184. who served as its tools, was useless. Pierre knew this now. One had to
54185. wait and endure. He did not again go to the sick man, nor turn to look
54186. at him, but stood frowning by the door of the hut.
54187. 
54188. When that door was opened and the prisoners, crowding against one
54189. another like a flock of sheep, squeezed into the exit, Pierre pushed
54190. his way forward and approached that very captain who as the corporal had
54191. assured him was ready to do anything for him. The captain was also in
54192. marching kit, and on his cold face appeared that same it which Pierre
54193. had recognized in the corporal's words and in the roll of the drums.
54194. 
54195. "Pass on, pass on!" the captain reiterated, frowning sternly, and
54196. looking at the prisoners who thronged past him.
54197. 
54198. Pierre went up to him, though he knew his attempt would be vain.
54199. 
54200. "What now?" the officer asked with a cold look as if not recognizing
54201. Pierre.
54202. 
54203. Pierre told him about the sick man.
54204. 
54205. "He'll manage to walk, devil take him!" said the captain. "Pass on, pass
54206. on!" he continued without looking at Pierre.
54207. 
54208. "But he is dying," Pierre again began.
54209. 
54210. "Be so good..." shouted the captain, frowning angrily.
54211. 
54212. "Dram-da-da-dam, dam-dam..." rattled the drums, and Pierre understood
54213. that this mysterious force completely controlled these men and that it
54214. was now useless to say any more.
54215. 
54216. The officer prisoners were separated from the soldiers and told to march
54217. in front. There were about thirty officers, with Pierre among them, and
54218. about three hundred men.
54219. 
54220. The officers, who had come from the other sheds, were all strangers to
54221. Pierre and much better dressed than he. They looked at him and at his
54222. shoes mistrustfully, as at an alien. Not far from him walked a fat major
54223. with a sallow, bloated, angry face, who was wearing a Kazan dressing
54224. gown tied round with a towel, and who evidently enjoyed the respect of
54225. his fellow prisoners. He kept one hand, in which he clasped his tobacco
54226. pouch, inside the bosom of his dressing gown and held the stem of his
54227. pipe firmly with the other. Panting and puffing, the major grumbled and
54228. growled at everybody because he thought he was being pushed and that
54229. they were all hurrying when they had nowhere to hurry to and were
54230. all surprised at something when there was nothing to be surprised at.
54231. Another, a thin little officer, was speaking to everyone, conjecturing
54232. where they were now being taken and how far they would get that day. An
54233. official in felt boots and wearing a commissariat uniform ran round from
54234. side to side and gazed at the ruins of Moscow, loudly announcing his
54235. observations as to what had been burned down and what this or that part
54236. of the city was that they could see. A third officer, who by his accent
54237. was a Pole, disputed with the commissariat officer, arguing that he was
54238. mistaken in his identification of the different wards of Moscow.
54239. 
54240. "What are you disputing about?" said the major angrily. "What does it
54241. matter whether it is St. Nicholas or St. Blasius? You see it's burned
54242. down, and there's an end of it.... What are you pushing for? Isn't the
54243. road wide enough?" said he, turning to a man behind him who was not
54244. pushing him at all.
54245. 
54246. "Oh, oh, oh! What have they done?" the prisoners on one side and another
54247. were heard saying as they gazed on the charred ruins. "All beyond the
54248. river, and Zubova, and in the Kremlin.... Just look! There's not half of
54249. it left. Yes, I told you--the whole quarter beyond the river, and so it
54250. is."
54251. 
54252. "Well, you know it's burned, so what's the use of talking?" said the
54253. major.
54254. 
54255. As they passed near a church in the Khamovniki (one of the few unburned
54256. quarters of Moscow) the whole mass of prisoners suddenly started to one
54257. side and exclamations of horror and disgust were heard.
54258. 
54259. "Ah, the villains! What heathens! Yes; dead, dead, so he is... And
54260. smeared with something!"
54261. 
54262. Pierre too drew near the church where the thing was that evoked these
54263. exclamations, and dimly made out something leaning against the palings
54264. surrounding the church. From the words of his comrades who saw better
54265. than he did, he found that this was the body of a man, set upright
54266. against the palings with its face smeared with soot.
54267. 
54268. "Go on! What the devil... Go on! Thirty thousand devils!..." the convoy
54269. guards began cursing and the French soldiers, with fresh virulence,
54270. drove away with their swords the crowd of prisoners who were gazing at
54271. the dead man.
54272. 
54273. 
54274. 
54275. 
54276. 
54277. CHAPTER XIV
54278. 
54279. 
54280. Through the cross streets of the Khamovniki quarter the prisoners
54281. marched, followed only by their escort and the vehicles and wagons
54282. belonging to that escort, but when they reached the supply stores they
54283. came among a huge and closely packed train of artillery mingled with
54284. private vehicles.
54285. 
54286. At the bridge they all halted, waiting for those in front to get across.
54287. From the bridge they had a view of endless lines of moving baggage
54288. trains before and behind them. To the right, where the Kaluga road turns
54289. near Neskuchny, endless rows of troops and carts stretched away into
54290. the distance. These were troops of Beauharnais' corps which had started
54291. before any of the others. Behind, along the riverside and across the
54292. Stone Bridge, were Ney's troops and transport.
54293. 
54294. Davout's troops, in whose charge were the prisoners, were crossing the
54295. Crimean bridge and some were already debouching into the Kaluga road.
54296. But the baggage trains stretched out so that the last of Beauharnais'
54297. train had not yet got out of Moscow and reached the Kaluga road when
54298. the vanguard of Ney's army was already emerging from the Great Ordynka
54299. Street.
54300. 
54301. When they had crossed the Crimean bridge the prisoners moved a few steps
54302. forward, halted, and again moved on, and from all sides vehicles and men
54303. crowded closer and closer together. They advanced the few hundred paces
54304. that separated the bridge from the Kaluga road, taking more than an
54305. hour to do so, and came out upon the square where the streets of the
54306. Transmoskva ward and the Kaluga road converge, and the prisoners jammed
54307. close together had to stand for some hours at that crossway. From all
54308. sides, like the roar of the sea, were heard the rattle of wheels, the
54309. tramp of feet, and incessant shouts of anger and abuse. Pierre stood
54310. pressed against the wall of a charred house, listening to that noise
54311. which mingled in his imagination with the roll of the drums.
54312. 
54313. To get a better view, several officer prisoners climbed onto the wall of
54314. the half-burned house against which Pierre was leaning.
54315. 
54316. "What crowds! Just look at the crowds!... They've loaded goods even on
54317. the cannon! Look there, those are furs!" they exclaimed. "Just see what
54318. the blackguards have looted.... There! See what that one has behind
54319. in the cart.... Why, those are settings taken from some icons, by
54320. heaven!... Oh, the rascals!... See how that fellow has loaded
54321. himself up, he can hardly walk! Good lord, they've even grabbed those
54322. chaises!... See that fellow there sitting on the trunks.... Heavens!
54323. They're fighting."
54324. 
54325. "That's right, hit him on the snout--on his snout! Like this, we
54326. shan't get away before evening. Look, look there.... Why, that must be
54327. Napoleon's own. See what horses! And the monograms with a crown! It's
54328. like a portable house.... That fellow's dropped his sack and doesn't see
54329. it. Fighting again... A woman with a baby, and not bad-looking either!
54330. Yes, I dare say, that's the way they'll let you pass... Just look,
54331. there's no end to it. Russian wenches, by heaven, so they are! In
54332. carriages--see how comfortably they've settled themselves!"
54333. 
54334. Again, as at the church in Khamovniki, a wave of general curiosity
54335. bore all the prisoners forward onto the road, and Pierre, thanks to
54336. his stature, saw over the heads of the others what so attracted their
54337. curiosity. In three carriages involved among the munition carts, closely
54338. squeezed together, sat women with rouged faces, dressed in glaring
54339. colors, who were shouting something in shrill voices.
54340. 
54341. From the moment Pierre had recognized the appearance of the mysterious
54342. force nothing had seemed to him strange or dreadful: neither the corpse
54343. smeared with soot for fun nor these women hurrying away nor the burned
54344. ruins of Moscow. All that he now witnessed scarcely made an impression
54345. on him--as if his soul, making ready for a hard struggle, refused to
54346. receive impressions that might weaken it.
54347. 
54348. The women's vehicles drove by. Behind them came more carts, soldiers,
54349. wagons, soldiers, gun carriages, carriages, soldiers, ammunition carts,
54350. more soldiers, and now and then women.
54351. 
54352. Pierre did not see the people as individuals but saw their movement.
54353. 
54354. All these people and horses seemed driven forward by some invisible
54355. power. During the hour Pierre watched them they all came flowing from
54356. the different streets with one and the same desire to get on quickly;
54357. they all jostled one another, began to grow angry and to fight, white
54358. teeth gleamed, brows frowned, ever the same words of abuse flew from
54359. side to side, and all the faces bore the same swaggeringly resolute
54360. and coldly cruel expression that had struck Pierre that morning on the
54361. corporal's face when the drums were beating.
54362. 
54363. It was not till nearly evening that the officer commanding the escort
54364. collected his men and with shouts and quarrels forced his way in among
54365. the baggage trains, and the prisoners, hemmed in on all sides, emerged
54366. onto the Kaluga road.
54367. 
54368. They marched very quickly, without resting, and halted only when the sun
54369. began to set. The baggage carts drew up close together and the men
54370. began to prepare for their night's rest. They all appeared angry and
54371. dissatisfied. For a long time, oaths, angry shouts, and fighting could
54372. be heard from all sides. A carriage that followed the escort ran
54373. into one of the carts and knocked a hole in it with its pole. Several
54374. soldiers ran toward the cart from different sides: some beat the
54375. carriage horses on their heads, turning them aside, others fought among
54376. themselves, and Pierre saw that one German was badly wounded on the head
54377. by a sword.
54378. 
54379. It seemed that all these men, now that they had stopped amid fields
54380. in the chill dusk of the autumn evening, experienced one and the same
54381. feeling of unpleasant awakening from the hurry and eagerness to push on
54382. that had seized them at the start. Once at a standstill they all seemed
54383. to understand that they did not yet know where they were going, and that
54384. much that was painful and difficult awaited them on this journey.
54385. 
54386. During this halt the escort treated the prisoners even worse than they
54387. had done at the start. It was here that the prisoners for the first time
54388. received horseflesh for their meat ration.
54389. 
54390. From the officer down to the lowest soldier they showed what seemed like
54391. personal spite against each of the prisoners, in unexpected contrast to
54392. their former friendly relations.
54393. 
54394. This spite increased still more when, on calling over the roll of
54395. prisoners, it was found that in the bustle of leaving Moscow one Russian
54396. soldier, who had pretended to suffer from colic, had escaped. Pierre saw
54397. a Frenchman beat a Russian soldier cruelly for straying too far from
54398. the road, and heard his friend the captain reprimand and threaten to
54399. court-martial a noncommissioned officer on account of the escape of the
54400. Russian. To the noncommissioned officer's excuse that the prisoner was
54401. ill and could not walk, the officer replied that the order was to shoot
54402. those who lagged behind. Pierre felt that that fatal force which had
54403. crushed him during the executions, but which he had not felt during his
54404. imprisonment, now again controlled his existence. It was terrible, but
54405. he felt that in proportion to the efforts of that fatal force to crush
54406. him, there grew and strengthened in his soul a power of life independent
54407. of it.
54408. 
54409. He ate his supper of buckwheat soup with horseflesh and chatted with his
54410. comrades.
54411. 
54412. Neither Pierre nor any of the others spoke of what they had seen in
54413. Moscow, or of the roughness of their treatment by the French, or of the
54414. order to shoot them which had been announced to them. As if in reaction
54415. against the worsening of their position they were all particularly
54416. animated and gay. They spoke of personal reminiscences, of amusing
54417. scenes they had witnessed during the campaign, and avoided all talk of
54418. their present situation.
54419. 
54420. The sun had set long since. Bright stars shone out here and there in the
54421. sky. A red glow as of a conflagration spread above the horizon from the
54422. rising full moon, and that vast red ball swayed strangely in the gray
54423. haze. It grew light. The evening was ending, but the night had not yet
54424. come. Pierre got up and left his new companions, crossing between the
54425. campfires to the other side of the road where he had been told the
54426. common soldier prisoners were stationed. He wanted to talk to them. On
54427. the road he was stopped by a French sentinel who ordered him back.
54428. 
54429. Pierre turned back, not to his companions by the campfire, but to an
54430. unharnessed cart where there was nobody. Tucking his legs under him and
54431. dropping his head he sat down on the cold ground by the wheel of the
54432. cart and remained motionless a long while sunk in thought. Suddenly he
54433. burst out into a fit of his broad, good-natured laughter, so loud that
54434. men from various sides turned with surprise to see what this strange and
54435. evidently solitary laughter could mean.
54436. 
54437. "Ha-ha-ha!" laughed Pierre. And he said aloud to himself: "The soldier
54438. did not let me pass. They took me and shut me up. They hold me captive.
54439. What, me? Me? My immortal soul? Ha-ha-ha! Ha-ha-ha!..." and he laughed
54440. till tears started to his eyes.
54441. 
54442. A man got up and came to see what this queer big fellow was laughing at
54443. all by himself. Pierre stopped laughing, got up, went farther away from
54444. the inquisitive man, and looked around him.
54445. 
54446. The huge, endless bivouac that had previously resounded with the
54447. crackling of campfires and the voices of many men had grown quiet, the
54448. red campfires were growing paler and dying down. High up in the light
54449. sky hung the full moon. Forests and fields beyond the camp, unseen
54450. before, were now visible in the distance. And farther still, beyond
54451. those forests and fields, the bright, oscillating, limitless distance
54452. lured one to itself. Pierre glanced up at the sky and the twinkling
54453. stars in its faraway depths. "And all that is me, all that is within me,
54454. and it is all I!" thought Pierre. "And they caught all that and put it
54455. into a shed boarded up with planks!" He smiled, and went and lay down to
54456. sleep beside his companions.
54457. 
54458. 
54459. 
54460. 
54461. 
54462. CHAPTER XV
54463. 
54464. 
54465. In the early days of October another envoy came to Kutuzov with a letter
54466. from Napoleon proposing peace and falsely dated from Moscow, though
54467. Napoleon was already not far from Kutuzov on the old Kaluga road.
54468. Kutuzov replied to this letter as he had done to the one formerly
54469. brought by Lauriston, saying that there could be no question of peace.
54470. 
54471. Soon after that a report was received from Dorokhov's guerrilla
54472. detachment operating to the left of Tarutino that troops of Broussier's
54473. division had been seen at Forminsk and that being separated from the
54474. rest of the French army they might easily be destroyed. The soldiers and
54475. officers again demanded action. Generals on the staff, excited by the
54476. memory of the easy victory at Tarutino, urged Kutuzov to carry out
54477. Dorokhov's suggestion. Kutuzov did not consider any offensive necessary.
54478. The result was a compromise which was inevitable: a small detachment was
54479. sent to Forminsk to attack Broussier.
54480. 
54481. By a strange coincidence, this task, which turned out to be a most
54482. difficult and important one, was entrusted to Dokhturov--that same
54483. modest little Dokhturov whom no one had described to us as drawing up
54484. plans of battles, dashing about in front of regiments, showering crosses
54485. on batteries, and so on, and who was thought to be and was spoken of
54486. as undecided and undiscerning--but whom we find commanding wherever
54487. the position was most difficult all through the Russo-French wars from
54488. Austerlitz to the year 1813. At Austerlitz he remained last at the
54489. Augezd dam, rallying the regiments, saving what was possible when all
54490. were flying and perishing and not a single general was left in the rear
54491. guard. Ill with fever he went to Smolensk with twenty thousand men
54492. to defend the town against Napoleon's whole army. In Smolensk, at the
54493. Malakhov Gate, he had hardly dozed off in a paroxysm of fever before he
54494. was awakened by the bombardment of the town--and Smolensk held out all
54495. day long. At the battle of Borodino, when Bagration was killed and nine
54496. tenths of the men of our left flank had fallen and the full force of the
54497. French artillery fire was directed against it, the man sent there was
54498. this same irresolute and undiscerning Dokhturov--Kutuzov hastening to
54499. rectify a mistake he had made by sending someone else there first.
54500. And the quiet little Dokhturov rode thither, and Borodino became the
54501. greatest glory of the Russian army. Many heroes have been described to
54502. us in verse and prose, but of Dokhturov scarcely a word has been said.
54503. 
54504. It was Dokhturov again whom they sent to Forminsk and from there to
54505. Malo-Yaroslavets, the place where the last battle with the French was
54506. fought and where the obvious disintegration of the French army began;
54507. and we are told of many geniuses and heroes of that period of the
54508. campaign, but of Dokhturov nothing or very little is said and that
54509. dubiously. And this silence about Dokhturov is the clearest testimony to
54510. his merit.
54511. 
54512. It is natural for a man who does not understand the workings of a
54513. machine to imagine that a shaving that has fallen into it by chance
54514. and is interfering with its action and tossing about in it is its most
54515. important part. The man who does not understand the construction of
54516. the machine cannot conceive that the small connecting cogwheel which
54517. revolves quietly is one of the most essential parts of the machine, and
54518. not the shaving which merely harms and hinders the working.
54519. 
54520. On the tenth of October when Dokhturov had gone halfway to Forminsk and
54521. stopped at the village of Aristovo, preparing faithfully to execute the
54522. orders he had received, the whole French army having, in its convulsive
54523. movement, reached Murat's position apparently in order to give
54524. battle--suddenly without any reason turned off to the left onto the new
54525. Kaluga road and began to enter Forminsk, where only Broussier had
54526. been till then. At that time Dokhturov had under his command, besides
54527. Dorokhov's detachment, the two small guerrilla detachments of Figner and
54528. Seslavin.
54529. 
54530. On the evening of October 11 Seslavin came to the Aristovo headquarters
54531. with a French guardsman he had captured. The prisoner said that the
54532. troops that had entered Forminsk that day were the vanguard of the whole
54533. army, that Napoleon was there and the whole army had left Moscow four
54534. days previously. That same evening a house serf who had come from
54535. Borovsk said he had seen an immense army entering the town. Some
54536. Cossacks of Dokhturov's detachment reported having sighted the French
54537. Guards marching along the road to Borovsk. From all these reports it was
54538. evident that where they had expected to meet a single division there
54539. was now the whole French army marching from Moscow in an unexpected
54540. direction--along the Kaluga road. Dokhturov was unwilling to undertake
54541. any action, as it was not clear to him now what he ought to do. He had
54542. been ordered to attack Forminsk. But only Broussier had been there at
54543. that time and now the whole French army was there. Ermolov wished to act
54544. on his own judgment, but Dokhturov insisted that he must have Kutuzov's
54545. instructions. So it was decided to send a dispatch to the staff.
54546. 
54547. For this purpose a capable officer, Bolkhovitinov, was chosen, who
54548. was to explain the whole affair by word of mouth, besides delivering
54549. a written report. Toward midnight Bolkhovitinov, having received the
54550. dispatch and verbal instructions, galloped off to the General Staff
54551. accompanied by a Cossack with spare horses.
54552. 
54553. 
54554. 
54555. 
54556. 
54557. CHAPTER XVI
54558. 
54559. 
54560. It was a warm, dark, autumn night. It had been raining for four days.
54561. Having changed horses twice and galloped twenty miles in an hour and a
54562. half over a sticky, muddy road, Bolkhovitinov reached Litashevka after
54563. one o'clock at night. Dismounting at a cottage on whose wattle fence
54564. hung a signboard, GENERAL STAFF, and throwing down his reins, he entered
54565. a dark passage.
54566. 
54567. "The general on duty, quick! It's very important!" said he to someone
54568. who had risen and was sniffing in the dark passage.
54569. 
54570. "He has been very unwell since the evening and this is the third night
54571. he has not slept," said the orderly pleadingly in a whisper. "You should
54572. wake the captain first."
54573. 
54574. "But this is very important, from General Dokhturov," said
54575. Bolkhovitinov, entering the open door which he had found by feeling in
54576. the dark.
54577. 
54578. The orderly had gone in before him and began waking somebody.
54579. 
54580. "Your honor, your honor! A courier."
54581. 
54582. "What? What's that? From whom?" came a sleepy voice.
54583. 
54584. "From Dokhturov and from Alexey Petrovich. Napoleon is at Forminsk,"
54585. said Bolkhovitinov, unable to see in the dark who was speaking but
54586. guessing by the voice that it was not Konovnitsyn.
54587. 
54588. The man who had wakened yawned and stretched himself.
54589. 
54590. "I don't like waking him," he said, fumbling for something. "He is very
54591. ill. Perhaps this is only a rumor."
54592. 
54593. "Here is the dispatch," said Bolkhovitinov. "My orders are to give it at
54594. once to the general on duty."
54595. 
54596. "Wait a moment, I'll light a candle. You damned rascal, where do you
54597. always hide it?" said the voice of the man who was stretching himself,
54598. to the orderly. (This was Shcherbinin, Konovnitsyn's adjutant.) "I've
54599. found it, I've found it!" he added.
54600. 
54601. The orderly was striking a light and Shcherbinin was fumbling for
54602. something on the candlestick.
54603. 
54604. "Oh, the nasty beasts!" said he with disgust.
54605. 
54606. By the light of the sparks Bolkhovitinov saw Shcherbinin's youthful face
54607. as he held the candle, and the face of another man who was still asleep.
54608. This was Konovnitsyn.
54609. 
54610. When the flame of the sulphur splinters kindled by the tinder burned
54611. up, first blue and then red, Shcherbinin lit the tallow candle, from
54612. the candlestick of which the cockroaches that had been gnawing it were
54613. running away, and looked at the messenger. Bolkhovitinov was bespattered
54614. all over with mud and had smeared his face by wiping it with his sleeve.
54615. 
54616. "Who gave the report?" inquired Shcherbinin, taking the envelope.
54617. 
54618. "The news is reliable," said Bolkhovitinov. "Prisoners, Cossacks, and
54619. the scouts all say the same thing."
54620. 
54621. "There's nothing to be done, we'll have to wake him," said Shcherbinin,
54622. rising and going up to the man in the nightcap who lay covered by a
54623. greatcoat. "Peter Petrovich!" said he. (Konovnitsyn did not stir.) "To
54624. the General Staff!" he said with a smile, knowing that those words would
54625. be sure to arouse him.
54626. 
54627. And in fact the head in the nightcap was lifted at once. On
54628. Konovnitsyn's handsome, resolute face with cheeks flushed by fever,
54629. there still remained for an instant a faraway dreamy expression remote
54630. from present affairs, but then he suddenly started and his face assumed
54631. its habitual calm and firm appearance.
54632. 
54633. "Well, what is it? From whom?" he asked immediately but without hurry,
54634. blinking at the light.
54635. 
54636. While listening to the officer's report Konovnitsyn broke the seal and
54637. read the dispatch. Hardly had he done so before he lowered his legs in
54638. their woolen stockings to the earthen floor and began putting on his
54639. boots. Then he took off his nightcap, combed his hair over his temples,
54640. and donned his cap.
54641. 
54642. "Did you get here quickly? Let us go to his Highness."
54643. 
54644. Konovnitsyn had understood at once that the news brought was of great
54645. importance and that no time must be lost. He did not consider or ask
54646. himself whether the news was good or bad. That did not interest him. He
54647. regarded the whole business of the war not with his intelligence or his
54648. reason but by something else. There was within him a deep unexpressed
54649. conviction that all would be well, but that one must not trust to this
54650. and still less speak about it, but must only attend to one's own work.
54651. And he did his work, giving his whole strength to the task.
54652. 
54653. Peter Petrovich Konovnitsyn, like Dokhturov, seems to have been included
54654. merely for propriety's sake in the list of the so-called heroes of
54655. 1812--the Barclays, Raevskis, Ermolovs, Platovs, and Miloradoviches.
54656. Like Dokhturov he had the reputation of being a man of very limited
54657. capacity and information, and like Dokhturov he never made plans of
54658. battle but was always found where the situation was most difficult.
54659. Since his appointment as general on duty he had always slept with his
54660. door open, giving orders that every messenger should be allowed to wake
54661. him up. In battle he was always under fire, so that Kutuzov reproved him
54662. for it and feared to send him to the front, and like Dokhturov he
54663. was one of those unnoticed cogwheels that, without clatter or noise,
54664. constitute the most essential part of the machine.
54665. 
54666. Coming out of the hut into the damp, dark night Konovnitsyn
54667. frowned--partly from an increased pain in his head and partly at
54668. the unpleasant thought that occurred to him, of how all that nest
54669. of influential men on the staff would be stirred up by this news,
54670. especially Bennigsen, who ever since Tarutino had been at daggers
54671. drawn with Kutuzov; and how they would make suggestions, quarrel, issue
54672. orders, and rescind them. And this premonition was disagreeable to him
54673. though he knew it could not be helped.
54674. 
54675. And in fact Toll, to whom he went to communicate the news, immediately
54676. began to expound his plans to a general sharing his quarters, until
54677. Konovnitsyn, who listened in weary silence, reminded him that they must
54678. go to see his Highness.
54679. 
54680. 
54681. 
54682. 
54683. 
54684. CHAPTER XVII
54685. 
54686. 
54687. Kutuzov like all old people did not sleep much at night. He often fell
54688. asleep unexpectedly in the daytime, but at night, lying on his bed
54689. without undressing, he generally remained awake thinking.
54690. 
54691. So he lay now on his bed, supporting his large, heavy, scarred head on
54692. his plump hand, with his one eye open, meditating and peering into the
54693. darkness.
54694. 
54695. Since Bennigsen, who corresponded with the Emperor and had more
54696. influence than anyone else on the staff, had begun to avoid him, Kutuzov
54697. was more at ease as to the possibility of himself and his troops being
54698. obliged to take part in useless aggressive movements. The lesson of the
54699. Tarutino battle and of the day before it, which Kutuzov remembered with
54700. pain, must, he thought, have some effect on others too.
54701. 
54702. "They must understand that we can only lose by taking the offensive.
54703. Patience and time are my warriors, my champions," thought Kutuzov. He
54704. knew that an apple should not be plucked while it is green. It will fall
54705. of itself when ripe, but if picked unripe the apple is spoiled, the tree
54706. is harmed, and your teeth are set on edge. Like an experienced sportsman
54707. he knew that the beast was wounded, and wounded as only the whole
54708. strength of Russia could have wounded it, but whether it was mortally
54709. wounded or not was still an undecided question. Now by the fact of
54710. Lauriston and Barthelemi having been sent, and by the reports of the
54711. guerrillas, Kutuzov was almost sure that the wound was mortal. But he
54712. needed further proofs and it was necessary to wait.
54713. 
54714. "They want to run to see how they have wounded it. Wait and we shall
54715. see! Continual maneuvers, continual advances!" thought he. "What for?
54716. Only to distinguish themselves! As if fighting were fun. They are
54717. like children from whom one can't get any sensible account of what has
54718. happened because they all want to show how well they can fight. But
54719. that's not what is needed now.
54720. 
54721. "And what ingenious maneuvers they all propose to me! It seems to
54722. them that when they have thought of two or three contingencies" (he
54723. remembered the general plan sent him from Petersburg) "they have
54724. foreseen everything. But the contingencies are endless."
54725. 
54726. The undecided question as to whether the wound inflicted at Borodino was
54727. mortal or not had hung over Kutuzov's head for a whole month. On the one
54728. hand the French had occupied Moscow. On the other Kutuzov felt assured
54729. with all his being that the terrible blow into which he and all the
54730. Russians had put their whole strength must have been mortal. But in any
54731. case proofs were needed; he had waited a whole month for them and grew
54732. more impatient the longer he waited. Lying on his bed during those
54733. sleepless nights he did just what he reproached those younger generals
54734. for doing. He imagined all sorts of possible contingencies, just like
54735. the younger men, but with this difference, that he saw thousands of
54736. contingencies instead of two or three and based nothing on them. The
54737. longer he thought the more contingencies presented themselves. He
54738. imagined all sorts of movements of the Napoleonic army as a whole or
54739. in sections--against Petersburg, or against him, or to outflank him.
54740. He thought too of the possibility (which he feared most of all) that
54741. Napoleon might fight him with his own weapon and remain in Moscow
54742. awaiting him. Kutuzov even imagined that Napoleon's army might turn back
54743. through Medyn and Yukhnov, but the one thing he could not foresee was
54744. what happened--the insane, convulsive stampede of Napoleon's army
54745. during its first eleven days after leaving Moscow: a stampede which made
54746. possible what Kutuzov had not yet even dared to think of--the complete
54747. extermination of the French. Dorokhov's report about Broussier's
54748. division, the guerrillas' reports of distress in Napoleon's army, rumors
54749. of preparations for leaving Moscow, all confirmed the supposition that
54750. the French army was beaten and preparing for flight. But these were
54751. only suppositions, which seemed important to the younger men but not to
54752. Kutuzov. With his sixty years' experience he knew what value to attach
54753. to rumors, knew how apt people who desire anything are to group all news
54754. so that it appears to confirm what they desire, and he knew how readily
54755. in such cases they omit all that makes for the contrary. And the more
54756. he desired it the less he allowed himself to believe it. This question
54757. absorbed all his mental powers. All else was to him only life's
54758. customary routine. To such customary routine belonged his conversations
54759. with the staff, the letters he wrote from Tarutino to Madame de Stael,
54760. the reading of novels, the distribution of awards, his correspondence
54761. with Petersburg, and so on. But the destruction of the French, which he
54762. alone foresaw, was his heart's one desire.
54763. 
54764. On the night of the eleventh of October he lay leaning on his arm and
54765. thinking of that.
54766. 
54767. There was a stir in the next room and he heard the steps of Toll,
54768. Konovnitsyn, and Bolkhovitinov.
54769. 
54770. "Eh, who's there? Come in, come in! What news?" the field marshal called
54771. out to them.
54772. 
54773. While a footman was lighting a candle, Toll communicated the substance
54774. of the news.
54775. 
54776. "Who brought it?" asked Kutuzov with a look which, when the candle was
54777. lit, struck Toll by its cold severity.
54778. 
54779. "There can be no doubt about it, your Highness."
54780. 
54781. "Call him in, call him here."
54782. 
54783. Kutuzov sat up with one leg hanging down from the bed and his big paunch
54784. resting against the other which was doubled under him. He screwed up his
54785. seeing eye to scrutinize the messenger more carefully, as if wishing to
54786. read in his face what preoccupied his own mind.
54787. 
54788. "Tell me, tell me, friend," said he to Bolkhovitinov in his low, aged
54789. voice, as he pulled together the shirt which gaped open on his chest,
54790. "come nearer--nearer. What news have you brought me? Eh? That Napoleon
54791. has left Moscow? Are you sure? Eh?"
54792. 
54793. Bolkhovitinov gave a detailed account from the beginning of all he had
54794. been told to report.
54795. 
54796. "Speak quicker, quicker! Don't torture me!" Kutuzov interrupted him.
54797. 
54798. Bolkhovitinov told him everything and was then silent, awaiting
54799. instructions. Toll was beginning to say something but Kutuzov checked
54800. him. He tried to say something, but his face suddenly puckered and
54801. wrinkled; he waved his arm at Toll and turned to the opposite side of
54802. the room, to the corner darkened by the icons that hung there.
54803. 
54804. "O Lord, my Creator, Thou has heard our prayer..." said he in a
54805. tremulous voice with folded hands. "Russia is saved. I thank Thee, O
54806. Lord!" and he wept.
54807. 
54808. 
54809. 
54810. 
54811. 
54812. CHAPTER XVIII
54813. 
54814. 
54815. From the time he received this news to the end of the campaign all
54816. Kutuzov's activity was directed toward restraining his troops, by
54817. authority, by guile, and by entreaty, from useless attacks,
54818. maneuvers, or encounters with the perishing enemy. Dokhturov went to
54819. Malo-Yaroslavets, but Kutuzov lingered with the main army and gave
54820. orders for the evacuation of Kaluga--a retreat beyond which town seemed
54821. to him quite possible.
54822. 
54823. Everywhere Kutuzov retreated, but the enemy without waiting for his
54824. retreat fled in the opposite direction.
54825. 
54826. Napoleon's historians describe to us his skilled maneuvers at Tarutino
54827. and Malo-Yaroslavets, and make conjectures as to what would have
54828. happened had Napoleon been in time to penetrate into the rich southern
54829. provinces.
54830. 
54831. But not to speak of the fact that nothing prevented him from advancing
54832. into those southern provinces (for the Russian army did not bar his
54833. way), the historians forget that nothing could have saved his army, for
54834. then already it bore within itself the germs of inevitable ruin. How
54835. could that army--which had found abundant supplies in Moscow and had
54836. trampled them underfoot instead of keeping them, and on arriving at
54837. Smolensk had looted provisions instead of storing them--how could that
54838. army recuperate in Kaluga province, which was inhabited by Russians such
54839. as those who lived in Moscow, and where fire had the same property of
54840. consuming what was set ablaze?
54841. 
54842. That army could not recover anywhere. Since the battle of Borodino
54843. and the pillage of Moscow it had borne within itself, as it were, the
54844. chemical elements of dissolution.
54845. 
54846. The members of what had once been an army--Napoleon himself and all his
54847. soldiers fled--without knowing whither, each concerned only to make his
54848. escape as quickly as possible from this position, of the hopelessness of
54849. which they were all more or less vaguely conscious.
54850. 
54851. So it came about that at the council at Malo-Yaroslavets, when the
54852. generals pretending to confer together expressed various opinions, all
54853. mouths were closed by the opinion uttered by the simple-minded soldier
54854. Mouton who, speaking last, said what they all felt: that the one thing
54855. needful was to get away as quickly as possible; and no one, not
54856. even Napoleon, could say anything against that truth which they all
54857. recognized.
54858. 
54859. But though they all realized that it was necessary to get away, there
54860. still remained a feeling of shame at admitting that they must flee. An
54861. external shock was needed to overcome that shame, and this shock came in
54862. due time. It was what the French called "le hourra de l'Empereur."
54863. 
54864. The day after the council at Malo-Yaroslavets Napoleon rode out early in
54865. the morning amid the lines of his army with his suite of marshals and
54866. an escort, on the pretext of inspecting the army and the scene of the
54867. previous and of the impending battle. Some Cossacks on the prowl for
54868. booty fell in with the Emperor and very nearly captured him. If the
54869. Cossacks did not capture Napoleon then, what saved him was the very
54870. thing that was destroying the French army, the booty on which the
54871. Cossacks fell. Here as at Tarutino they went after plunder, leaving the
54872. men. Disregarding Napoleon they rushed after the plunder and Napoleon
54873. managed to escape.
54874. 
54875. When les enfants du Don might so easily have taken the Emperor himself
54876. in the midst of his army, it was clear that there was nothing for it but
54877. to fly as fast as possible along the nearest, familiar road. Napoleon
54878. with his forty-year-old stomach understood that hint, not feeling his
54879. former agility and boldness, and under the influence of the fright
54880. the Cossacks had given him he at once agreed with Mouton and issued
54881. orders--as the historians tell us--to retreat by the Smolensk road.
54882. 
54883. That Napoleon agreed with Mouton, and that the army retreated, does
54884. not prove that Napoleon caused it to retreat, but that the forces which
54885. influenced the whole army and directed it along the Mozhaysk (that is,
54886. the Smolensk) road acted simultaneously on him also.
54887. 
54888. 
54889. 
54890. 
54891. 
54892. CHAPTER XIX
54893. 
54894. 
54895. A man in motion always devises an aim for that motion. To be able to go
54896. a thousand miles he must imagine that something good awaits him at the
54897. end of those thousand miles. One must have the prospect of a promised
54898. land to have the strength to move.
54899. 
54900. The promised land for the French during their advance had been Moscow,
54901. during their retreat it was their native land. But that native land
54902. was too far off, and for a man going a thousand miles it is absolutely
54903. necessary to set aside his final goal and to say to himself: "Today I
54904. shall get to a place twenty-five miles off where I shall rest and
54905. spend the night," and during the first day's journey that resting place
54906. eclipses his ultimate goal and attracts all his hopes and desires. And
54907. the impulses felt by a single person are always magnified in a crowd.
54908. 
54909. For the French retreating along the old Smolensk road, the final
54910. goal--their native land--was too remote, and their immediate goal
54911. was Smolensk, toward which all their desires and hopes, enormously
54912. intensified in the mass, urged them on. It was not that they knew that
54913. much food and fresh troops awaited them in Smolensk, nor that they were
54914. told so (on the contrary their superior officers, and Napoleon himself,
54915. knew that provisions were scarce there), but because this alone could
54916. give them strength to move on and endure their present privations. So
54917. both those who knew and those who did not know deceived themselves, and
54918. pushed on to Smolensk as to a promised land.
54919. 
54920. Coming out onto the highroad the French fled with surprising energy
54921. and unheard-of rapidity toward the goal they had fixed on. Besides the
54922. common impulse which bound the whole crowd of French into one mass and
54923. supplied them with a certain energy, there was another cause binding
54924. them together--their great numbers. As with the physical law of gravity,
54925. their enormous mass drew the individual human atoms to itself. In their
54926. hundreds of thousands they moved like a whole nation.
54927. 
54928. Each of them desired nothing more than to give himself up as a prisoner
54929. to escape from all this horror and misery; but on the one hand the force
54930. of this common attraction to Smolensk, their goal, drew each of them in
54931. the same direction; on the other hand an army corps could not surrender
54932. to a company, and though the French availed themselves of every
54933. convenient opportunity to detach themselves and to surrender on the
54934. slightest decent pretext, such pretexts did not always occur. Their
54935. very numbers and their crowded and swift movement deprived them of that
54936. possibility and rendered it not only difficult but impossible for the
54937. Russians to stop this movement, to which the French were directing all
54938. their energies. Beyond a certain limit no mechanical disruption of the
54939. body could hasten the process of decomposition.
54940. 
54941. A lump of snow cannot be melted instantaneously. There is a certain
54942. limit of time in less than which no amount of heat can melt the snow. On
54943. the contrary the greater the heat the more solidified the remaining snow
54944. becomes.
54945. 
54946. Of the Russian commanders Kutuzov alone understood this. When the flight
54947. of the French army along the Smolensk road became well defined, what
54948. Konovnitsyn had foreseen on the night of the eleventh of October began
54949. to occur. The superior officers all wanted to distinguish themselves,
54950. to cut off, to seize, to capture, and to overthrow the French, and all
54951. clamored for action.
54952. 
54953. Kutuzov alone used all his power (and such power is very limited in the
54954. case of any commander in chief) to prevent an attack.
54955. 
54956. He could not tell them what we say now: "Why fight, why block the road,
54957. losing our own men and inhumanly slaughtering unfortunate wretches? What
54958. is the use of that, when a third of their army has melted away on the
54959. road from Moscow to Vyazma without any battle?" But drawing from his
54960. aged wisdom what they could understand, he told them of the golden
54961. bridge, and they laughed at and slandered him, flinging themselves on,
54962. rending and exulting over the dying beast.
54963. 
54964. Ermolov, Miloradovich, Platov, and others in proximity to the French
54965. near Vyazma could not resist their desire to cut off and break up two
54966. French corps, and by way of reporting their intention to Kutuzov they
54967. sent him a blank sheet of paper in an envelope.
54968. 
54969. And try as Kutuzov might to restrain the troops, our men attacked,
54970. trying to bar the road. Infantry regiments, we are told, advanced to the
54971. attack with music and with drums beating, and killed and lost thousands
54972. of men.
54973. 
54974. But they did not cut off or overthrow anybody and the French army,
54975. closing up more firmly at the danger, continued, while steadily melting
54976. away, to pursue its fatal path to Smolensk.
54977. 
54978. 
54979. 
54980. 
54981. 
54982. BOOK FOURTEEN: 1812
54983. 
54984. 
54985. 
54986. 
54987. 
54988. CHAPTER I
54989. 
54990. 
54991. The Battle of Borodino, with the occupation of Moscow that followed it
54992. and the flight of the French without further conflicts, is one of the
54993. most instructive phenomena in history.
54994. 
54995. All historians agree that the external activity of states and nations
54996. in their conflicts with one another is expressed in wars, and that as a
54997. direct result of greater or less success in war the political strength
54998. of states and nations increases or decreases.
54999. 
55000. Strange as may be the historical account of how some king or emperor,
55001. having quarreled with another, collects an army, fights his enemy's
55002. army, gains a victory by killing three, five, or ten thousand men, and
55003. subjugates a kingdom and an entire nation of several millions, all
55004. the facts of history (as far as we know it) confirm the truth of the
55005. statement that the greater or lesser success of one army against another
55006. is the cause, or at least an essential indication, of an increase or
55007. decrease in the strength of the nation--even though it is unintelligible
55008. why the defeat of an army--a hundredth part of a nation--should oblige
55009. that whole nation to submit. An army gains a victory, and at once the
55010. rights of the conquering nation have increased to the detriment of the
55011. defeated. An army has suffered defeat, and at once a people loses its
55012. rights in proportion to the severity of the reverse, and if its army
55013. suffers a complete defeat the nation is quite subjugated.
55014. 
55015. So according to history it has been found from the most ancient times,
55016. and so it is to our own day. All Napoleon's wars serve to confirm this
55017. rule. In proportion to the defeat of the Austrian army Austria loses
55018. its rights, and the rights and the strength of France increase. The
55019. victories of the French at Jena and Auerstadt destroy the independent
55020. existence of Prussia.
55021. 
55022. But then, in 1812, the French gain a victory near Moscow. Moscow is
55023. taken and after that, with no further battles, it is not Russia that
55024. ceases to exist, but the French army of six hundred thousand, and
55025. then Napoleonic France itself. To strain the facts to fit the rules of
55026. history: to say that the field of battle at Borodino remained in the
55027. hands of the Russians, or that after Moscow there were other battles
55028. that destroyed Napoleon's army, is impossible.
55029. 
55030. After the French victory at Borodino there was no general engagement nor
55031. any that were at all serious, yet the French army ceased to exist. What
55032. does this mean? If it were an example taken from the history of China,
55033. we might say that it was not an historic phenomenon (which is the
55034. historians' usual expedient when anything does not fit their standards);
55035. if the matter concerned some brief conflict in which only a small number
55036. of troops took part, we might treat it as an exception; but this event
55037. occurred before our fathers' eyes, and for them it was a question of the
55038. life or death of their fatherland, and it happened in the greatest of
55039. all known wars.
55040. 
55041. The period of the campaign of 1812 from the battle of Borodino to the
55042. expulsion of the French proved that the winning of a battle does not
55043. produce a conquest and is not even an invariable indication of conquest;
55044. it proved that the force which decides the fate of peoples lies not in
55045. the conquerors, nor even in armies and battles, but in something else.
55046. 
55047. The French historians, describing the condition of the French army
55048. before it left Moscow, affirm that all was in order in the Grand Army,
55049. except the cavalry, the artillery, and the transport--there was no
55050. forage for the horses or the cattle. That was a misfortune no one could
55051. remedy, for the peasants of the district burned their hay rather than
55052. let the French have it.
55053. 
55054. The victory gained did not bring the usual results because the peasants
55055. Karp and Vlas (who after the French had evacuated Moscow drove in their
55056. carts to pillage the town, and in general personally failed to manifest
55057. any heroic feelings), and the whole innumerable multitude of such
55058. peasants, did not bring their hay to Moscow for the high price offered
55059. them, but burned it instead.
55060. 
55061. Let us imagine two men who have come out to fight a duel with rapiers
55062. according to all the rules of the art of fencing. The fencing has
55063. gone on for some time; suddenly one of the combatants, feeling himself
55064. wounded and understanding that the matter is no joke but concerns his
55065. life, throws down his rapier, and seizing the first cudgel that comes to
55066. hand begins to brandish it. Then let us imagine that the combatant who
55067. so sensibly employed the best and simplest means to attain his end was
55068. at the same time influenced by traditions of chivalry and, desiring to
55069. conceal the facts of the case, insisted that he had gained his victory
55070. with the rapier according to all the rules of art. One can imagine what
55071. confusion and obscurity would result from such an account of the duel.
55072. 
55073. The fencer who demanded a contest according to the rules of fencing was
55074. the French army; his opponent who threw away the rapier and snatched up
55075. the cudgel was the Russian people; those who try to explain the matter
55076. according to the rules of fencing are the historians who have described
55077. the event.
55078. 
55079. After the burning of Smolensk a war began which did not follow any
55080. previous traditions of war. The burning of towns and villages, the
55081. retreats after battles, the blow dealt at Borodino and the renewed
55082. retreat, the burning of Moscow, the capture of marauders, the seizure of
55083. transports, and the guerrilla war were all departures from the rules.
55084. 
55085. Napoleon felt this, and from the time he took up the correct fencing
55086. attitude in Moscow and instead of his opponent's rapier saw a cudgel
55087. raised above his head, he did not cease to complain to Kutuzov and to
55088. the Emperor Alexander that the war was being carried on contrary to all
55089. the rules--as if there were any rules for killing people. In spite of
55090. the complaints of the French as to the nonobservance of the rules, in
55091. spite of the fact that to some highly placed Russians it seemed rather
55092. disgraceful to fight with a cudgel and they wanted to assume a pose en
55093. quarte or en tierce according to all the rules, and to make an adroit
55094. thrust en prime, and so on--the cudgel of the people's war was lifted
55095. with all its menacing and majestic strength, and without consulting
55096. anyone's tastes or rules and regardless of anything else, it rose and
55097. fell with stupid simplicity, but consistently, and belabored the French
55098. till the whole invasion had perished.
55099. 
55100. And it is well for a people who do not--as the French did in
55101. 1813--salute according to all the rules of art, and, presenting the hilt
55102. of their rapier gracefully and politely, hand it to their magnanimous
55103. conqueror, but at the moment of trial, without asking what rules others
55104. have adopted in similar cases, simply and easily pick up the first
55105. cudgel that comes to hand and strike with it till the feeling of
55106. resentment and revenge in their soul yields to a feeling of contempt and
55107. compassion.
55108. 
55109. 
55110. 
55111. 
55112. 
55113. CHAPTER II
55114. 
55115. 
55116. One of the most obvious and advantageous departures from the so-called
55117. laws of war is the action of scattered groups against men pressed
55118. together in a mass. Such action always occurs in wars that take on a
55119. national character. In such actions, instead of two crowds opposing
55120. each other, the men disperse, attack singly, run away when attacked by
55121. stronger forces, but again attack when opportunity offers. This was done
55122. by the guerrillas in Spain, by the mountain tribes in the Caucasus, and
55123. by the Russians in 1812.
55124. 
55125. People have called this kind of war "guerrilla warfare" and assume that
55126. by so calling it they have explained its meaning. But such a war does
55127. not fit in under any rule and is directly opposed to a well-known rule
55128. of tactics which is accepted as infallible. That rule says that an
55129. attacker should concentrate his forces in order to be stronger than his
55130. opponent at the moment of conflict.
55131. 
55132. Guerrilla war (always successful, as history shows) directly infringes
55133. that rule.
55134. 
55135. This contradiction arises from the fact that military science assumes
55136. the strength of an army to be identical with its numbers. Military
55137. science says that the more troops the greater the strength. Les gros
55138. bataillons ont toujours raison. *
55139. 
55140. 
55141.     * Large battalions are always victorious.
55142. 
55143. 
55144. For military science to say this is like defining momentum in mechanics
55145. by reference to the mass only: stating that momenta are equal or unequal
55146. to each other simply because the masses involved are equal or unequal.
55147. 
55148. Momentum (quantity of motion) is the product of mass and velocity.
55149. 
55150. In military affairs the strength of an army is the product of its mass
55151. and some unknown x.
55152. 
55153. Military science, seeing in history innumerable instances of the fact
55154. that the size of any army does not coincide with its strength and that
55155. small detachments defeat larger ones, obscurely admits the existence
55156. of this unknown factor and tries to discover it--now in a geometric
55157. formation, now in the equipment employed, now, and most usually, in the
55158. genius of the commanders. But the assignment of these various meanings
55159. to the factor does not yield results which accord with the historic
55160. facts.
55161. 
55162. Yet it is only necessary to abandon the false view (adopted to gratify
55163. the "heroes") of the efficacy of the directions issued in wartime by
55164. commanders, in order to find this unknown quantity.
55165. 
55166. That unknown quantity is the spirit of the army, that is to say, the
55167. greater or lesser readiness to fight and face danger felt by all the men
55168. composing an army, quite independently of whether they are, or are not,
55169. fighting under the command of a genius, in two--or three-line formation,
55170. with cudgels or with rifles that repeat thirty times a minute. Men
55171. who want to fight will always put themselves in the most advantageous
55172. conditions for fighting.
55173. 
55174. The spirit of an army is the factor which multiplied by the mass gives
55175. the resulting force. To define and express the significance of this
55176. unknown factor--the spirit of an army--is a problem for science.
55177. 
55178. This problem is only solvable if we cease arbitrarily to substitute
55179. for the unknown x itself the conditions under which that force becomes
55180. apparent--such as the commands of the general, the equipment employed,
55181. and so on--mistaking these for the real significance of the factor,
55182. and if we recognize this unknown quantity in its entirety as being
55183. the greater or lesser desire to fight and to face danger. Only then,
55184. expressing known historic facts by equations and comparing the relative
55185. significance of this factor, can we hope to define the unknown.
55186. 
55187. Ten men, battalions, or divisions, fighting fifteen men, battalions, or
55188. divisions, conquer--that is, kill or take captive--all the others, while
55189. themselves losing four, so that on the one side four and on the other
55190. fifteen were lost. Consequently the four were equal to the fifteen, and
55191. therefore 4x = 15y. Consequently x/y = 15/4. This equation does not
55192. give us the value of the unknown factor but gives us a ratio between two
55193. unknowns. And by bringing variously selected historic units (battles,
55194. campaigns, periods of war) into such equations, a series of numbers
55195. could be obtained in which certain laws should exist and might be
55196. discovered.
55197. 
55198. The tactical rule that an army should act in masses when attacking, and
55199. in smaller groups in retreat, unconsciously confirms the truth that the
55200. strength of an army depends on its spirit. To lead men forward under
55201. fire more discipline (obtainable only by movement in masses) is needed
55202. than is needed to resist attacks. But this rule which leaves out of
55203. account the spirit of the army continually proves incorrect and is in
55204. particularly striking contrast to the facts when some strong rise or
55205. fall in the spirit of the troops occurs, as in all national wars.
55206. 
55207. The French, retreating in 1812--though according to tactics they should
55208. have separated into detachments to defend themselves--congregated into
55209. a mass because the spirit of the army had so fallen that only the mass
55210. held the army together. The Russians, on the contrary, ought according
55211. to tactics to have attacked in mass, but in fact they split up
55212. into small units, because their spirit had so risen that separate
55213. individuals, without orders, dealt blows at the French without needing
55214. any compulsion to induce them to expose themselves to hardships and
55215. dangers.
55216. 
55217. 
55218. 
55219. 
55220. 
55221. CHAPTER III
55222. 
55223. 
55224. The so-called partisan war began with the entry of the French into
55225. Smolensk.
55226. 
55227. Before partisan warfare had been officially recognized by the
55228. government, thousands of enemy stragglers, marauders, and foragers had
55229. been destroyed by the Cossacks and the peasants, who killed them off
55230. as instinctively as dogs worry a stray mad dog to death. Denis Davydov,
55231. with his Russian instinct, was the first to recognize the value of
55232. this terrible cudgel which regardless of the rules of military science
55233. destroyed the French, and to him belongs the credit for taking the first
55234. step toward regularizing this method of warfare.
55235. 
55236. On August 24 Davydov's first partisan detachment was formed and then
55237. others were recognized. The further the campaign progressed the more
55238. numerous these detachments became.
55239. 
55240. The irregulars destroyed the great army piecemeal. They gathered the
55241. fallen leaves that dropped of themselves from that withered tree--the
55242. French army--and sometimes shook that tree itself. By October, when
55243. the French were fleeing toward Smolensk, there were hundreds of such
55244. companies, of various sizes and characters. There were some that adopted
55245. all the army methods and had infantry, artillery, staffs, and the
55246. comforts of life. Others consisted solely of Cossack cavalry. There were
55247. also small scratch groups of foot and horse, and groups of peasants and
55248. landowners that remained unknown. A sacristan commanded one party which
55249. captured several hundred prisoners in the course of a month; and there
55250. was Vasilisa, the wife of a village elder, who slew hundreds of the
55251. French.
55252. 
55253. The partisan warfare flamed up most fiercely in the latter days of
55254. October. Its first period had passed: when the partisans themselves,
55255. amazed at their own boldness, feared every minute to be surrounded
55256. and captured by the French, and hid in the forests without unsaddling,
55257. hardly daring to dismount and always expecting to be pursued. By the end
55258. of October this kind of warfare had taken definite shape: it had become
55259. clear to all what could be ventured against the French and what could
55260. not. Now only the commanders of detachments with staffs, and moving
55261. according to rules at a distance from the French, still regarded many
55262. things as impossible. The small bands that had started their activities
55263. long before and had already observed the French closely considered
55264. things possible which the commanders of the big detachments did not dare
55265. to contemplate. The Cossacks and peasants who crept in among the French
55266. now considered everything possible.
55267. 
55268. On October 22, Denisov (who was one of the irregulars) was with his
55269. group at the height of the guerrilla enthusiasm. Since early morning he
55270. and his party had been on the move. All day long he had been watching
55271. from the forest that skirted the highroad a large French convoy of
55272. cavalry baggage and Russian prisoners separated from the rest of the
55273. army, which--as was learned from spies and prisoners--was moving under a
55274. strong escort to Smolensk. Besides Denisov and Dolokhov (who also led
55275. a small party and moved in Denisov's vicinity), the commanders of some
55276. large divisions with staffs also knew of this convoy and, as Denisov
55277. expressed it, were sharpening their teeth for it. Two of the commanders
55278. of large parties--one a Pole and the other a German--sent invitations
55279. to Denisov almost simultaneously, requesting him to join up with their
55280. divisions to attack the convoy.
55281. 
55282. "No, bwother, I have gwown mustaches myself," said Denisov on reading
55283. these documents, and he wrote to the German that, despite his heartfelt
55284. desire to serve under so valiant and renowned a general, he had to forgo
55285. that pleasure because he was already under the command of the Polish
55286. general. To the Polish general he replied to the same effect, informing
55287. him that he was already under the command of the German.
55288. 
55289. Having arranged matters thus, Denisov and Dolokhov intended, without
55290. reporting matters to the higher command, to attack and seize that
55291. convoy with their own small forces. On October 22 it was moving from
55292. the village of Mikulino to that of Shamshevo. To the left of the road
55293. between Mikulino and Shamshevo there were large forests, extending in
55294. some places up to the road itself though in others a mile or more back
55295. from it. Through these forests Denisov and his party rode all day,
55296. sometimes keeping well back in them and sometimes coming to the very
55297. edge, but never losing sight of the moving French. That morning,
55298. Cossacks of Denisov's party had seized and carried off into the forest
55299. two wagons loaded with cavalry saddles, which had stuck in the mud not
55300. far from Mikulino where the forest ran close to the road. Since then,
55301. and until evening, the party had watched the movements of the French
55302. without attacking. It was necessary to let the French reach Shamshevo
55303. quietly without alarming them and then, after joining Dolokhov who was
55304. to come that evening to a consultation at a watchman's hut in the forest
55305. less than a mile from Shamshevo, to surprise the French at dawn, falling
55306. like an avalanche on their heads from two sides, and rout and capture
55307. them all at one blow.
55308. 
55309. In their rear, more than a mile from Mikulino where the forest came
55310. right up to the road, six Cossacks were posted to report if any fresh
55311. columns of French should show themselves.
55312. 
55313. Beyond Shamshevo, Dolokhov was to observe the road in the same way, to
55314. find out at what distance there were other French troops. They reckoned
55315. that the convoy had fifteen hundred men. Denisov had two hundred, and
55316. Dolokhov might have as many more, but the disparity of numbers did not
55317. deter Denisov. All that he now wanted to know was what troops these were
55318. and to learn that he had to capture a "tongue"--that is, a man from
55319. the enemy column. That morning's attack on the wagons had been made so
55320. hastily that the Frenchmen with the wagons had all been killed; only a
55321. little drummer boy had been taken alive, and as he was a straggler he
55322. could tell them nothing definite about the troops in that column.
55323. 
55324. Denisov considered it dangerous to make a second attack for fear of
55325. putting the whole column on the alert, so he sent Tikhon Shcherbaty, a
55326. peasant of his party, to Shamshevo to try and seize at least one of the
55327. French quartermasters who had been sent on in advance.
55328. 
55329. 
55330. 
55331. 
55332. 
55333. CHAPTER IV
55334. 
55335. 
55336. It was a warm rainy autumn day. The sky and the horizon were both
55337. the color of muddy water. At times a sort of mist descended, and then
55338. suddenly heavy slanting rain came down.
55339. 
55340. Denisov in a felt cloak and a sheepskin cap from which the rain ran down
55341. was riding a thin thoroughbred horse with sunken sides. Like his horse,
55342. which turned its head and laid its ears back, he shrank from the driving
55343. rain and gazed anxiously before him. His thin face with its short, thick
55344. black beard looked angry.
55345. 
55346. Beside Denisov rode an esaul, * Denisov's fellow worker, also in felt
55347. cloak and sheepskin cap, and riding a large sleek Don horse.
55348. 
55349. 
55350.     * A captain of Cossacks.
55351. 
55352. 
55353. Esaul Lovayski the Third was a tall man as straight as an arrow,
55354. pale-faced, fair-haired, with narrow light eyes and with calm
55355. self-satisfaction in his face and bearing. Though it was impossible to
55356. say in what the peculiarity of the horse and rider lay, yet at first
55357. glance at the esaul and Denisov one saw that the latter was wet and
55358. uncomfortable and was a man mounted on a horse, while looking at the
55359. esaul one saw that he was as comfortable and as much at ease as always
55360. and that he was not a man who had mounted a horse, but a man who was one
55361. with his horse, a being consequently possessed of twofold strength.
55362. 
55363. A little ahead of them walked a peasant guide, wet to the skin and
55364. wearing a gray peasant coat and a white knitted cap.
55365. 
55366. A little behind, on a poor, small, lean Kirghiz mount with an enormous
55367. tail and mane and a bleeding mouth, rode a young officer in a blue
55368. French overcoat.
55369. 
55370. Beside him rode an hussar, with a boy in a tattered French uniform and
55371. blue cap behind him on the crupper of his horse. The boy held on to the
55372. hussar with cold, red hands, and raising his eyebrows gazed about him
55373. with surprise. This was the French drummer boy captured that morning.
55374. 
55375. Behind them along the narrow, sodden, cutup forest road came hussars in
55376. threes and fours, and then Cossacks: some in felt cloaks, some in French
55377. greatcoats, and some with horsecloths over their heads. The horses,
55378. being drenched by the rain, all looked black whether chestnut or bay.
55379. Their necks, with their wet, close-clinging manes, looked strangely
55380. thin. Steam rose from them. Clothes, saddles, reins, were all wet,
55381. slippery, and sodden, like the ground and the fallen leaves that strewed
55382. the road. The men sat huddled up trying not to stir, so as to warm the
55383. water that had trickled to their bodies and not admit the fresh cold
55384. water that was leaking in under their seats, their knees, and at the
55385. back of their necks. In the midst of the outspread line of Cossacks two
55386. wagons, drawn by French horses and by saddled Cossack horses that had
55387. been hitched on in front, rumbled over the tree stumps and branches and
55388. splashed through the water that lay in the ruts.
55389. 
55390. Denisov's horse swerved aside to avoid a pool in the track and bumped
55391. his rider's knee against a tree.
55392. 
55393. "Oh, the devil!" exclaimed Denisov angrily, and showing his teeth he
55394. struck his horse three times with his whip, splashing himself and his
55395. comrades with mud.
55396. 
55397. Denisov was out of sorts both because of the rain and also from hunger
55398. (none of them had eaten anything since morning), and yet more because he
55399. still had no news from Dolokhov and the man sent to capture a "tongue"
55400. had not returned.
55401. 
55402. "There'll hardly be another such chance to fall on a transport as today.
55403. It's too risky to attack them by oneself, and if we put it off till
55404. another day one of the big guerrilla detachments will snatch the prey
55405. from under our noses," thought Denisov, continually peering forward,
55406. hoping to see a messenger from Dolokhov.
55407. 
55408. On coming to a path in the forest along which he could see far to the
55409. right, Denisov stopped.
55410. 
55411. "There's someone coming," said he.
55412. 
55413. The esaul looked in the direction Denisov indicated.
55414. 
55415. "There are two, an officer and a Cossack. But it is not presupposable
55416. that it is the lieutenant colonel himself," said the esaul, who was fond
55417. of using words the Cossacks did not know.
55418. 
55419. The approaching riders having descended a decline were no longer
55420. visible, but they reappeared a few minutes later. In front, at a weary
55421. gallop and using his leather whip, rode an officer, disheveled and
55422. drenched, whose trousers had worked up to above his knees. Behind him,
55423. standing in the stirrups, trotted a Cossack. The officer, a very young
55424. lad with a broad rosy face and keen merry eyes, galloped up to Denisov
55425. and handed him a sodden envelope.
55426. 
55427. "From the general," said the officer. "Please excuse its not being quite
55428. dry."
55429. 
55430. Denisov, frowning, took the envelope and opened it.
55431. 
55432. "There, they kept telling us: 'It's dangerous, it's dangerous,'"
55433. said the officer, addressing the esaul while Denisov was reading
55434. the dispatch. "But Komarov and I"--he pointed to the Cossack--"were
55435. prepared. We have each of us two pistols.... But what's this?" he asked,
55436. noticing the French drummer boy. "A prisoner? You've already been in
55437. action? May I speak to him?"
55438. 
55439. "Wostov! Petya!" exclaimed Denisov, having run through the dispatch.
55440. "Why didn't you say who you were?" and turning with a smile he held out
55441. his hand to the lad.
55442. 
55443. The officer was Petya Rostov.
55444. 
55445. All the way Petya had been preparing himself to behave with Denisov as
55446. befitted a grownup man and an officer--without hinting at their previous
55447. acquaintance. But as soon as Denisov smiled at him Petya brightened
55448. up, blushed with pleasure, forgot the official manner he had been
55449. rehearsing, and began telling him how he had already been in a battle
55450. near Vyazma and how a certain hussar had distinguished himself there.
55451. 
55452. "Well, I am glad to see you," Denisov interrupted him, and his face
55453. again assumed its anxious expression.
55454. 
55455. "Michael Feoklitych," said he to the esaul, "this is again fwom that
55456. German, you know. He"--he indicated Petya--"is serving under him."
55457. 
55458. And Denisov told the esaul that the dispatch just delivered was a
55459. repetition of the German general's demand that he should join forces
55460. with him for an attack on the transport.
55461. 
55462. "If we don't take it tomowwow, he'll snatch it fwom under our noses," he
55463. added.
55464. 
55465. While Denisov was talking to the esaul, Petya--abashed by Denisov's
55466. cold tone and supposing that it was due to the condition of his
55467. trousers--furtively tried to pull them down under his greatcoat so
55468. that no one should notice it, while maintaining as martial an air as
55469. possible.
55470. 
55471. "Will there be any orders, your honor?" he asked Denisov, holding his
55472. hand at the salute and resuming the game of adjutant and general for
55473. which he had prepared himself, "or shall I remain with your honor?"
55474. 
55475. "Orders?" Denisov repeated thoughtfully. "But can you stay till
55476. tomowwow?"
55477. 
55478. "Oh, please... May I stay with you?" cried Petya.
55479. 
55480. "But, just what did the genewal tell you? To weturn at once?" asked
55481. Denisov.
55482. 
55483. Petya blushed.
55484. 
55485. "He gave me no instructions. I think I could?" he returned, inquiringly.
55486. 
55487. "Well, all wight," said Denisov.
55488. 
55489. And turning to his men he directed a party to go on to the halting place
55490. arranged near the watchman's hut in the forest, and told the officer on
55491. the Kirghiz horse (who performed the duties of an adjutant) to go and
55492. find out where Dolokhov was and whether he would come that evening.
55493. Denisov himself intended going with the esaul and Petya to the edge of
55494. the forest where it reached out to Shamshevo, to have a look at the part
55495. of the French bivouac they were to attack next day.
55496. 
55497. "Well, old fellow," said he to the peasant guide, "lead us to
55498. Shamshevo."
55499. 
55500. Denisov, Petya, and the esaul, accompanied by some Cossacks and the
55501. hussar who had the prisoner, rode to the left across a ravine to the
55502. edge of the forest.
55503. 
55504. 
55505. 
55506. 
55507. 
55508. CHAPTER V
55509. 
55510. 
55511. The rain had stopped, and only the mist was falling and drops from
55512. the trees. Denisov, the esaul, and Petya rode silently, following the
55513. peasant in the knitted cap who, stepping lightly with outturned toes
55514. and moving noiselessly in his bast shoes over the roots and wet leaves,
55515. silently led them to the edge of the forest.
55516.
