55517. He ascended an incline, stopped, looked about him, and advanced to where
55518. the screen of trees was less dense. On reaching a large oak tree that
55519. had not yet shed its leaves, he stopped and beckoned mysteriously to
55520. them with his hand.
55521. 
55522. Denisov and Petya rode up to him. From the spot where the peasant was
55523. standing they could see the French. Immediately beyond the forest, on a
55524. downward slope, lay a field of spring rye. To the right, beyond a steep
55525. ravine, was a small village and a landowner's house with a broken roof.
55526. In the village, in the house, in the garden, by the well, by the pond,
55527. over all the rising ground, and all along the road uphill from the
55528. bridge leading to the village, not more than five hundred yards
55529. away, crowds of men could be seen through the shimmering mist. Their
55530. un-Russian shouting at their horses which were straining uphill with the
55531. carts, and their calls to one another, could be clearly heard.
55532. 
55533. "Bwing the prisoner here," said Denisov in a low voice, not taking his
55534. eyes off the French.
55535. 
55536. A Cossack dismounted, lifted the boy down, and took him to Denisov.
55537. Pointing to the French troops, Denisov asked him what these and those
55538. of them were. The boy, thrusting his cold hands into his pockets and
55539. lifting his eyebrows, looked at Denisov in affright, but in spite of
55540. an evident desire to say all he knew gave confused answers, merely
55541. assenting to everything Denisov asked him. Denisov turned away from him
55542. frowning and addressed the esaul, conveying his own conjectures to him.
55543. 
55544. Petya, rapidly turning his head, looked now at the drummer boy, now
55545. at Denisov, now at the esaul, and now at the French in the village and
55546. along the road, trying not to miss anything of importance.
55547. 
55548. "Whether Dolokhov comes or not, we must seize it, eh?" said Denisov with
55549. a merry sparkle in his eyes.
55550. 
55551. "It is a very suitable spot," said the esaul.
55552. 
55553. "We'll send the infantwy down by the swamps," Denisov continued.
55554. "They'll cweep up to the garden; you'll wide up fwom there with the
55555. Cossacks"--he pointed to a spot in the forest beyond the village--"and I
55556. with my hussars fwom here. And at the signal shot..."
55557. 
55558. "The hollow is impassable--there's a swamp there," said the esaul. "The
55559. horses would sink. We must ride round more to the left...."
55560. 
55561. While they were talking in undertones the crack of a shot sounded
55562. from the low ground by the pond, a puff of white smoke appeared, then
55563. another, and the sound of hundreds of seemingly merry French voices
55564. shouting together came up from the slope. For a moment Denisov and the
55565. esaul drew back. They were so near that they thought they were the cause
55566. of the firing and shouting. But the firing and shouting did not relate
55567. to them. Down below, a man wearing something red was running through the
55568. marsh. The French were evidently firing and shouting at him.
55569. 
55570. "Why, that's our Tikhon," said the esaul.
55571. 
55572. "So it is! It is!"
55573. 
55574. "The wascal!" said Denisov.
55575. 
55576. "He'll get away!" said the esaul, screwing up his eyes.
55577. 
55578. The man whom they called Tikhon, having run to the stream, plunged in
55579. so that the water splashed in the air, and, having disappeared for an
55580. instant, scrambled out on all fours, all black with the wet, and ran on.
55581. The French who had been pursuing him stopped.
55582. 
55583. "Smart, that!" said the esaul.
55584. 
55585. "What a beast!" said Denisov with his former look of vexation. "What has
55586. he been doing all this time?"
55587. 
55588. "Who is he?" asked Petya.
55589. 
55590. "He's our plastun. I sent him to capture a 'tongue.'"
55591. 
55592. "Oh, yes," said Petya, nodding at the first words Denisov uttered as if
55593. he understood it all, though he really did not understand anything of
55594. it.
55595. 
55596. Tikhon Shcherbaty was one of the most indispensable men in their band.
55597. He was a peasant from Pokrovsk, near the river Gzhat. When Denisov had
55598. come to Pokrovsk at the beginning of his operations and had as usual
55599. summoned the village elder and asked him what he knew about the French,
55600. the elder, as though shielding himself, had replied, as all village
55601. elders did, that he had neither seen nor heard anything of them. But
55602. when Denisov explained that his purpose was to kill the French, and
55603. asked if no French had strayed that way, the elder replied that some
55604. "more-orderers" had really been at their village, but that Tikhon
55605. Shcherbaty was the only man who dealt with such matters. Denisov had
55606. Tikhon called and, having praised him for his activity, said a few words
55607. in the elder's presence about loyalty to the Tsar and the country and
55608. the hatred of the French that all sons of the fatherland should cherish.
55609. 
55610. "We don't do the French any harm," said Tikhon, evidently frightened by
55611. Denisov's words. "We only fooled about with the lads for fun, you know!
55612. We killed a score or so of 'more-orderers,' but we did no harm else..."
55613. 
55614. Next day when Denisov had left Pokrovsk, having quite forgotten about
55615. this peasant, it was reported to him that Tikhon had attached himself
55616. to their party and asked to be allowed to remain with it. Denisov gave
55617. orders to let him do so.
55618. 
55619. Tikhon, who at first did rough work, laying campfires, fetching water,
55620. flaying dead horses, and so on, soon showed a great liking and aptitude
55621. for partisan warfare. At night he would go out for booty and always
55622. brought back French clothing and weapons, and when told to would bring
55623. in French captives also. Denisov then relieved him from drudgery and
55624. began taking him with him when he went out on expeditions and had him
55625. enrolled among the Cossacks.
55626. 
55627. Tikhon did not like riding, and always went on foot, never lagging
55628. behind the cavalry. He was armed with a musketoon (which he carried
55629. rather as a joke), a pike and an ax, which latter he used as a wolf uses
55630. its teeth, with equal case picking fleas out of its fur or crunching
55631. thick bones. Tikhon with equal accuracy would split logs with blows at
55632. arm's length, or holding the head of the ax would cut thin little pegs
55633. or carve spoons. In Denisov's party he held a peculiar and exceptional
55634. position. When anything particularly difficult or nasty had to be
55635. done--to push a cart out of the mud with one's shoulders, pull a horse
55636. out of a swamp by its tail, skin it, slink in among the French, or walk
55637. more than thirty miles in a day--everybody pointed laughingly at Tikhon.
55638. 
55639. "It won't hurt that devil--he's as strong as a horse!" they said of him.
55640. 
55641. Once a Frenchman Tikhon was trying to capture fired a pistol at him
55642. and shot him in the fleshy part of the back. That wound (which Tikhon
55643. treated only with internal and external applications of vodka) was the
55644. subject of the liveliest jokes by the whole detachment--jokes in which
55645. Tikhon readily joined.
55646. 
55647. "Hallo, mate! Never again? Gave you a twist?" the Cossacks would banter
55648. him. And Tikhon, purposely writhing and making faces, pretended to be
55649. angry and swore at the French with the funniest curses. The only effect
55650. of this incident on Tikhon was that after being wounded he seldom
55651. brought in prisoners.
55652. 
55653. He was the bravest and most useful man in the party. No one found more
55654. opportunities for attacking, no one captured or killed more Frenchmen,
55655. and consequently he was made the buffoon of all the Cossacks and hussars
55656. and willingly accepted that role. Now he had been sent by Denisov
55657. overnight to Shamshevo to capture a "tongue." But whether because he
55658. had not been content to take only one Frenchman or because he had slept
55659. through the night, he had crept by day into some bushes right among the
55660. French and, as Denisov had witnessed from above, had been detected by
55661. them.
55662. 
55663. 
55664. 
55665. 
55666. 
55667. CHAPTER VI
55668. 
55669. 
55670. After talking for some time with the esaul about next day's attack,
55671. which now, seeing how near they were to the French, he seemed to have
55672. definitely decided on, Denisov turned his horse and rode back.
55673. 
55674. "Now, my lad, we'll go and get dwy," he said to Petya.
55675. 
55676. As they approached the watchhouse Denisov stopped, peering into the
55677. forest. Among the trees a man with long legs and long, swinging arms,
55678. wearing a short jacket, bast shoes, and a Kazan hat, was approaching
55679. with long, light steps. He had a musketoon over his shoulder and an ax
55680. stuck in his girdle. When he espied Denisov he hastily threw something
55681. into the bushes, removed his sodden hat by its floppy brim, and
55682. approached his commander. It was Tikhon. His wrinkled and pockmarked
55683. face and narrow little eyes beamed with self-satisfied merriment. He
55684. lifted his head high and gazed at Denisov as if repressing a laugh.
55685. 
55686. "Well, where did you disappear to?" inquired Denisov.
55687. 
55688. "Where did I disappear to? I went to get Frenchmen," answered Tikhon
55689. boldly and hurriedly, in a husky but melodious bass voice.
55690. 
55691. "Why did you push yourself in there by daylight? You ass! Well, why
55692. haven't you taken one?"
55693. 
55694. "Oh, I took one all right," said Tikhon.
55695. 
55696. "Where is he?"
55697. 
55698. "You see, I took him first thing at dawn," Tikhon continued, spreading
55699. out his flat feet with outturned toes in their bast shoes. "I took him
55700. into the forest. Then I see he's no good and think I'll go and fetch a
55701. likelier one."
55702. 
55703. "You see?... What a wogue--it's just as I thought," said Denisov to the
55704. esaul. "Why didn't you bwing that one?"
55705. 
55706. "What was the good of bringing him?" Tikhon interrupted hastily and
55707. angrily--"that one wouldn't have done for you. As if I don't know what
55708. sort you want!"
55709. 
55710. "What a bwute you are!... Well?"
55711. 
55712. "I went for another one," Tikhon continued, "and I crept like this
55713. through the wood and lay down." (He suddenly lay down on his stomach
55714. with a supple movement to show how he had done it.) "One turned up and
55715. I grabbed him, like this." (He jumped up quickly and lightly.) "'Come
55716. along to the colonel,' I said. He starts yelling, and suddenly there
55717. were four of them. They rushed at me with their little swords. So I went
55718. for them with my ax, this way: 'What are you up to?' says I. 'Christ
55719. be with you!'" shouted Tikhon, waving his arms with an angry scowl and
55720. throwing out his chest.
55721. 
55722. "Yes, we saw from the hill how you took to your heels through the
55723. puddles!" said the esaul, screwing up his glittering eyes.
55724. 
55725. Petya badly wanted to laugh, but noticed that they all refrained from
55726. laughing. He turned his eyes rapidly from Tikhon's face to the esaul's
55727. and Denisov's, unable to make out what it all meant.
55728. 
55729. "Don't play the fool!" said Denisov, coughing angrily. "Why didn't you
55730. bwing the first one?"
55731. 
55732. Tikhon scratched his back with one hand and his head with the other,
55733. then suddenly his whole face expanded into a beaming, foolish grin,
55734. disclosing a gap where he had lost a tooth (that was why he was called
55735. Shcherbaty--the gap-toothed). Denisov smiled, and Petya burst into a
55736. peal of merry laughter in which Tikhon himself joined.
55737. 
55738. "Oh, but he was a regular good-for-nothing," said Tikhon. "The clothes
55739. on him--poor stuff! How could I bring him? And so rude, your honor! Why,
55740. he says: 'I'm a general's son myself, I won't go!' he says."
55741. 
55742. "You are a bwute!" said Denisov. "I wanted to question..."
55743. 
55744. "But I questioned him," said Tikhon. "He said he didn't know much.
55745. 'There are a lot of us,' he says, 'but all poor stuff--only soldiers
55746. in name,' he says. 'Shout loud at them,' he says, 'and you'll take
55747. them all,'" Tikhon concluded, looking cheerfully and resolutely into
55748. Denisov's eyes.
55749. 
55750. "I'll give you a hundwed sharp lashes--that'll teach you to play the
55751. fool!" said Denisov severely.
55752. 
55753. "But why are you angry?" remonstrated Tikhon, "just as if I'd never seen
55754. your Frenchmen! Only wait till it gets dark and I'll fetch you any of
55755. them you want--three if you like."
55756. 
55757. "Well, let's go," said Denisov, and rode all the way to the watchhouse
55758. in silence and frowning angrily.
55759. 
55760. Tikhon followed behind and Petya heard the Cossacks laughing with him
55761. and at him, about some pair of boots he had thrown into the bushes.
55762. 
55763. When the fit of laughter that had seized him at Tikhon's words and smile
55764. had passed and Petya realized for a moment that this Tikhon had killed a
55765. man, he felt uneasy. He looked round at the captive drummer boy and felt
55766. a pang in his heart. But this uneasiness lasted only a moment. He felt
55767. it necessary to hold his head higher, to brace himself, and to question
55768. the esaul with an air of importance about tomorrow's undertaking, that
55769. he might not be unworthy of the company in which he found himself.
55770. 
55771. The officer who had been sent to inquire met Denisov on the way with the
55772. news that Dolokhov was soon coming and that all was well with him.
55773. 
55774. Denisov at once cheered up and, calling Petya to him, said: "Well, tell
55775. me about yourself."
55776. 
55777. 
55778. 
55779. 
55780. 
55781. CHAPTER VII
55782. 
55783. 
55784. Petya, having left his people after their departure from Moscow, joined
55785. his regiment and was soon taken as orderly by a general commanding a
55786. large guerrilla detachment. From the time he received his commission,
55787. and especially since he had joined the active army and taken part in
55788. the battle of Vyazma, Petya had been in a constant state of blissful
55789. excitement at being grown-up and in a perpetual ecstatic hurry not to
55790. miss any chance to do something really heroic. He was highly delighted
55791. with what he saw and experienced in the army, but at the same time
55792. it always seemed to him that the really heroic exploits were being
55793. performed just where he did not happen to be. And he was always in a
55794. hurry to get where he was not.
55795. 
55796. When on the twenty-first of October his general expressed a wish to send
55797. somebody to Denisov's detachment, Petya begged so piteously to be sent
55798. that the general could not refuse. But when dispatching him he recalled
55799. Petya's mad action at the battle of Vyazma, where instead of riding by
55800. the road to the place to which he had been sent, he had galloped to the
55801. advanced line under the fire of the French and had there twice fired
55802. his pistol. So now the general explicitly forbade his taking part in any
55803. action whatever of Denisov's. That was why Petya had blushed and grown
55804. confused when Denisov asked him whether he could stay. Before they had
55805. ridden to the outskirts of the forest Petya had considered he must carry
55806. out his instructions strictly and return at once. But when he saw the
55807. French and saw Tikhon and learned that there would certainly be an
55808. attack that night, he decided, with the rapidity with which young people
55809. change their views, that the general, whom he had greatly respected till
55810. then, was a rubbishy German, that Denisov was a hero, the esaul a hero,
55811. and Tikhon a hero too, and that it would be shameful for him to leave
55812. them at a moment of difficulty.
55813. 
55814. It was already growing dusk when Denisov, Petya, and the esaul rode up
55815. to the watchhouse. In the twilight saddled horses could be seen, and
55816. Cossacks and hussars who had rigged up rough shelters in the glade and
55817. were kindling glowing fires in a hollow of the forest where the French
55818. could not see the smoke. In the passage of the small watchhouse a
55819. Cossack with sleeves rolled up was chopping some mutton. In the room
55820. three officers of Denisov's band were converting a door into a tabletop.
55821. Petya took off his wet clothes, gave them to be dried, and at once began
55822. helping the officers to fix up the dinner table.
55823. 
55824. In ten minutes the table was ready and a napkin spread on it. On the
55825. table were vodka, a flask of rum, white bread, roast mutton, and salt.
55826. 
55827. Sitting at table with the officers and tearing the fat savory mutton
55828. with his hands, down which the grease trickled, Petya was in an ecstatic
55829. childish state of love for all men, and consequently of confidence that
55830. others loved him in the same way.
55831. 
55832. "So then what do you think, Vasili Dmitrich?" said he to Denisov. "It's
55833. all right my staying a day with you?" And not waiting for a reply he
55834. answered his own question: "You see I was told to find out--well, I
55835. am finding out.... Only do let me into the very... into the chief... I
55836. don't want a reward... But I want..."
55837. 
55838. Petya clenched his teeth and looked around, throwing back his head and
55839. flourishing his arms.
55840. 
55841. "Into the vewy chief..." Denisov repeated with a smile.
55842. 
55843. "Only, please let me command something, so that I may really command..."
55844. Petya went on. "What would it be to you?... Oh, you want a knife?" he
55845. said, turning to an officer who wished to cut himself a piece of mutton.
55846. 
55847. And he handed him his clasp knife. The officer admired it.
55848. 
55849. "Please keep it. I have several like it," said Petya, blushing.
55850. "Heavens! I was quite forgetting!" he suddenly cried. "I have some
55851. raisins, fine ones; you know, seedless ones. We have a new sutler and
55852. he has such capital things. I bought ten pounds. I am used to something
55853. sweet. Would you like some?..." and Petya ran out into the passage to
55854. his Cossack and brought back some bags which contained about five pounds
55855. of raisins. "Have some, gentlemen, have some!"
55856. 
55857. "You want a coffeepot, don't you?" he asked the esaul. "I bought a
55858. capital one from our sutler! He has splendid things. And he's very
55859. honest, that's the chief thing. I'll be sure to send it to you. Or
55860. perhaps your flints are giving out, or are worn out--that happens
55861. sometimes, you know. I have brought some with me, here they are"--and he
55862. showed a bag--"a hundred flints. I bought them very cheap. Please take
55863. as many as you want, or all if you like...."
55864. 
55865. Then suddenly, dismayed lest he had said too much, Petya stopped and
55866. blushed.
55867. 
55868. He tried to remember whether he had not done anything else that was
55869. foolish. And running over the events of the day he remembered the French
55870. drummer boy. "It's capital for us here, but what of him? Where have they
55871. put him? Have they fed him? Haven't they hurt his feelings?" he thought.
55872. But having caught himself saying too much about the flints, he was now
55873. afraid to speak out.
55874. 
55875. "I might ask," he thought, "but they'll say: 'He's a boy himself and so
55876. he pities the boy.' I'll show them tomorrow whether I'm a boy. Will it
55877. seem odd if I ask?" Petya thought. "Well, never mind!" and immediately,
55878. blushing and looking anxiously at the officers to see if they appeared
55879. ironical, he said:
55880. 
55881. "May I call in that boy who was taken prisoner and give him something to
55882. eat?... Perhaps..."
55883. 
55884. "Yes, he's a poor little fellow," said Denisov, who evidently saw
55885. nothing shameful in this reminder. "Call him in. His name is Vincent
55886. Bosse. Have him fetched."
55887. 
55888. "I'll call him," said Petya.
55889. 
55890. "Yes, yes, call him. A poor little fellow," Denisov repeated.
55891. 
55892. Petya was standing at the door when Denisov said this. He slipped in
55893. between the officers, came close to Denisov, and said:
55894. 
55895. "Let me kiss you, dear old fellow! Oh, how fine, how splendid!"
55896. 
55897. And having kissed Denisov he ran out of the hut.
55898. 
55899. "Bosse! Vincent!" Petya cried, stopping outside the door.
55900. 
55901. "Who do you want, sir?" asked a voice in the darkness.
55902. 
55903. Petya replied that he wanted the French lad who had been captured that
55904. day.
55905. 
55906. "Ah, Vesenny?" said a Cossack.
55907. 
55908. Vincent, the boy's name, had already been changed by the Cossacks into
55909. Vesenny (vernal) and into Vesenya by the peasants and soldiers. In both
55910. these adaptations the reference to spring (vesna) matched the impression
55911. made by the young lad.
55912. 
55913. "He is warming himself there by the bonfire. Ho, Vesenya!
55914. Vesenya!--Vesenny!" laughing voices were heard calling to one another in
55915. the darkness.
55916. 
55917. "He's a smart lad," said an hussar standing near Petya. "We gave him
55918. something to eat a while ago. He was awfully hungry!"
55919. 
55920. The sound of bare feet splashing through the mud was heard in the
55921. darkness, and the drummer boy came to the door.
55922. 
55923. "Ah, c'est vous!" said Petya. "Voulez-vous manger? N'ayez pas peur, on
55924. ne vous fera pas de mal," * he added shyly and affectionately, touching
55925. the boy's hand. "Entrez, entrez." *(2)
55926. 
55927. 
55928.      * "Ah, it's you! Do you want something to eat? Don't be
55929.      afraid, they won't hurt you."
55930. 
55931.      * (2) "Come in, come in."
55932. 
55933. 
55934. "Merci, monsieur," * said the drummer boy in a trembling almost childish
55935. voice, and he began scraping his dirty feet on the threshold.
55936. 
55937. 
55938.     * "Thank you, sir."
55939. 
55940. 
55941. There were many things Petya wanted to say to the drummer boy, but did
55942. not dare to. He stood irresolutely beside him in the passage. Then in
55943. the darkness he took the boy's hand and pressed it.
55944. 
55945. "Come in, come in!" he repeated in a gentle whisper. "Oh, what can I do
55946. for him?" he thought, and opening the door he let the boy pass in first.
55947. 
55948. When the boy had entered the hut, Petya sat down at a distance from
55949. him, considering it beneath his dignity to pay attention to him. But
55950. he fingered the money in his pocket and wondered whether it would seem
55951. ridiculous to give some to the drummer boy.
55952. 
55953. 
55954. 
55955. 
55956. 
55957. CHAPTER VIII
55958. 
55959. 
55960. The arrival of Dolokhov diverted Petya's attention from the drummer boy,
55961. to whom Denisov had had some mutton and vodka given, and whom he had had
55962. dressed in a Russian coat so that he might be kept with their band and
55963. not sent away with the other prisoners. Petya had heard in the army many
55964. stories of Dolokhov's extraordinary bravery and of his cruelty to the
55965. French, so from the moment he entered the hut Petya did not take his
55966. eyes from him, but braced himself up more and more and held his head
55967. high, that he might not be unworthy even of such company.
55968. 
55969. Dolokhov's appearance amazed Petya by its simplicity.
55970. 
55971. Denisov wore a Cossack coat, had a beard, had an icon of Nicholas the
55972. Wonder-Worker on his breast, and his way of speaking and everything he
55973. did indicated his unusual position. But Dolokhov, who in Moscow had worn
55974. a Persian costume, had now the appearance of a most correct officer of
55975. the Guards. He was clean-shaven and wore a Guardsman's padded coat with
55976. an Order of St. George at his buttonhole and a plain forage cap set
55977. straight on his head. He took off his wet felt cloak in a corner of
55978. the room, and without greeting anyone went up to Denisov and began
55979. questioning him about the matter in hand. Denisov told him of the
55980. designs the large detachments had on the transport, of the message Petya
55981. had brought, and his own replies to both generals. Then he told him all
55982. he knew of the French detachment.
55983. 
55984. "That's so. But we must know what troops they are and their numbers,"
55985. said Dolokhov. "It will be necessary to go there. We can't start the
55986. affair without knowing for certain how many there are. I like to work
55987. accurately. Here now--wouldn't one of these gentlemen like to ride over
55988. to the French camp with me? I have brought a spare uniform."
55989. 
55990. "I, I... I'll go with you!" cried Petya.
55991. 
55992. "There's no need for you to go at all," said Denisov, addressing
55993. Dolokhov, "and as for him, I won't let him go on any account."
55994. 
55995. "I like that!" exclaimed Petya. "Why shouldn't I go?"
55996. 
55997. "Because it's useless."
55998. 
55999. "Well, you must excuse me, because... because... I shall go, and that's
56000. all. You'll take me, won't you?" he said, turning to Dolokhov.
56001. 
56002. "Why not?" Dolokhov answered absently, scrutinizing the face of the
56003. French drummer boy. "Have you had that youngster with you long?" he
56004. asked Denisov.
56005. 
56006. "He was taken today but he knows nothing. I'm keeping him with me."
56007. 
56008. "Yes, and where do you put the others?" inquired Dolokhov.
56009. 
56010. "Where? I send them away and take a weceipt for them," shouted Denisov,
56011. suddenly flushing. "And I say boldly that I have not a single man's life
56012. on my conscience. Would it be difficult for you to send thirty or
56013. thwee hundwed men to town under escort, instead of staining--I speak
56014. bluntly--staining the honor of a soldier?"
56015. 
56016. "That kind of amiable talk would be suitable from this young count of
56017. sixteen," said Dolokhov with cold irony, "but it's time for you to drop
56018. it."
56019. 
56020. "Why, I've not said anything! I only say that I'll certainly go with
56021. you," said Petya shyly.
56022. 
56023. "But for you and me, old fellow, it's time to drop these amenities,"
56024. continued Dolokhov, as if he found particular pleasure in speaking of
56025. this subject which irritated Denisov. "Now, why have you kept this lad?"
56026. he went on, swaying his head. "Because you are sorry for him! Don't we
56027. know those 'receipts' of yours? You send a hundred men away, and thirty
56028. get there. The rest either starve or get killed. So isn't it all the
56029. same not to send them?"
56030. 
56031. The esaul, screwing up his light-colored eyes, nodded approvingly.
56032. 
56033. "That's not the point. I'm not going to discuss the matter. I do not
56034. wish to take it on my conscience. You say they'll die. All wight. Only
56035. not by my fault!"
56036. 
56037. Dolokhov began laughing.
56038. 
56039. "Who has told them not to capture me these twenty times over? But if
56040. they did catch me they'd string me up to an aspen tree, and with all
56041. your chivalry just the same." He paused. "However, we must get to work.
56042. Tell the Cossack to fetch my kit. I have two French uniforms in it.
56043. Well, are you coming with me?" he asked Petya.
56044. 
56045. "I? Yes, yes, certainly!" cried Petya, blushing almost to tears and
56046. glancing at Denisov.
56047. 
56048. While Dolokhov had been disputing with Denisov what should be done with
56049. prisoners, Petya had once more felt awkward and restless; but again he
56050. had no time to grasp fully what they were talking about. "If grown-up,
56051. distinguished men think so, it must be necessary and right," thought he.
56052. "But above all Denisov must not dare to imagine that I'll obey him and
56053. that he can order me about. I will certainly go to the French camp with
56054. Dolokhov. If he can, so can I!"
56055. 
56056. And to all Denisov's persuasions, Petya replied that he too was
56057. accustomed to do everything accurately and not just anyhow, and that he
56058. never considered personal danger.
56059. 
56060. "For you'll admit that if we don't know for sure how many of them there
56061. are... hundreds of lives may depend on it, while there are only two
56062. of us. Besides, I want to go very much and certainly will go, so don't
56063. hinder me," said he. "It will only make things worse..."
56064. 
56065. 
56066. 
56067. 
56068. 
56069. CHAPTER IX
56070. 
56071. 
56072. Having put on French greatcoats and shakos, Petya and Dolokhov rode to
56073. the clearing from which Denisov had reconnoitered the French camp,
56074. and emerging from the forest in pitch darkness they descended into the
56075. hollow. On reaching the bottom, Dolokhov told the Cossacks accompanying
56076. him to await him there and rode on at a quick trot along the road to the
56077. bridge. Petya, his heart in his mouth with excitement, rode by his side.
56078. 
56079. "If we're caught, I won't be taken alive! I have a pistol," whispered
56080. he.
56081. 
56082. "Don't talk Russian," said Dolokhov in a hurried whisper, and at that
56083. very moment they heard through the darkness the challenge: "Qui vive?" *
56084. and the click of a musket.
56085. 
56086. 
56087.     * "Who goes there?"
56088. 
56089. 
56090. The blood rushed to Petya's face and he grasped his pistol.
56091. 
56092. "Lanciers du 6-me," * replied Dolokhov, neither hastening nor slackening
56093. his horse's pace.
56094. 
56095. 
56096.     * "Lancers of the 6th Regiment."
56097. 
56098. 
56099. The black figure of a sentinel stood on the bridge.
56100. 
56101. "Mot d'ordre." *
56102. 
56103. 
56104.     * "Password."
56105. 
56106. 
56107. Dolokhov reined in his horse and advanced at a walk.
56108. 
56109. "Dites donc, le colonel Gerard est ici?" * he asked.
56110. 
56111. 
56112.     * "Tell me, is Colonel Gerard here?"
56113. 
56114. 
56115. "Mot d'ordre," repeated the sentinel, barring the way and not replying.
56116. 
56117. "Quand un officier fait sa ronde, les sentinelles ne demandent pas le
56118. mot d'ordre..." cried Dolokhov suddenly flaring up and riding straight
56119. at the sentinel. "Je vous demande si le colonel est ici." *
56120. 
56121. 
56122.      * "When an officer is making his round, sentinels don't ask
56123.      him for the password.... I am asking you if the colonel is
56124.      here."
56125. 
56126. 
56127. And without waiting for an answer from the sentinel, who had stepped
56128. aside, Dolokhov rode up the incline at a walk.
56129. 
56130. Noticing the black outline of a man crossing the road, Dolokhov stopped
56131. him and inquired where the commander and officers were. The man,
56132. a soldier with a sack over his shoulder, stopped, came close up to
56133. Dolokhov's horse, touched it with his hand, and explained simply and in
56134. a friendly way that the commander and the officers were higher up
56135. the hill to the right in the courtyard of the farm, as he called the
56136. landowner's house.
56137. 
56138. Having ridden up the road, on both sides of which French talk could be
56139. heard around the campfires, Dolokhov turned into the courtyard of the
56140. landowner's house. Having ridden in, he dismounted and approached a
56141. big blazing campfire, around which sat several men talking noisily.
56142. Something was boiling in a small cauldron at the edge of the fire and
56143. a soldier in a peaked cap and blue overcoat, lit up by the fire, was
56144. kneeling beside it stirring its contents with a ramrod.
56145. 
56146. "Oh, he's a hard nut to crack," said one of the officers who was sitting
56147. in the shadow at the other side of the fire.
56148. 
56149. "He'll make them get a move on, those fellows!" said another, laughing.
56150. 
56151. Both fell silent, peering out through the darkness at the sound of
56152. Dolokhov's and Petya's steps as they advanced to the fire leading their
56153. horses.
56154. 
56155. "Bonjour, messieurs!" * said Dolokhov loudly and clearly.
56156. 
56157. 
56158.     * "Good day, gentlemen."
56159. 
56160. 
56161. There was a stir among the officers in the shadow beyond the fire,
56162. and one tall, long-necked officer, walking round the fire, came up to
56163. Dolokhov.
56164. 
56165. "Is that you, Clement?" he asked. "Where the devil...?" But, noticing
56166. his mistake, he broke off short and, with a frown, greeted Dolokhov as a
56167. stranger, asking what he could do for him.
56168. 
56169. Dolokhov said that he and his companion were trying to overtake their
56170. regiment, and addressing the company in general asked whether they knew
56171. anything of the 6th Regiment. None of them knew anything, and Petya
56172. thought the officers were beginning to look at him and Dolokhov with
56173. hostility and suspicion. For some seconds all were silent.
56174. 
56175. "If you were counting on the evening soup, you have come too late," said
56176. a voice from behind the fire with a repressed laugh.
56177. 
56178. Dolokhov replied that they were not hungry and must push on farther that
56179. night.
56180. 
56181. He handed the horses over to the soldier who was stirring the pot and
56182. squatted down on his heels by the fire beside the officer with the long
56183. neck. That officer did not take his eyes from Dolokhov and again asked
56184. to what regiment he belonged. Dolokhov, as if he had not heard the
56185. question, did not reply, but lighting a short French pipe which he took
56186. from his pocket began asking the officer in how far the road before them
56187. was safe from Cossacks.
56188. 
56189. "Those brigands are everywhere," replied an officer from behind the
56190. fire.
56191. 
56192. Dolokhov remarked that the Cossacks were a danger only to stragglers
56193. such as his companion and himself, "but probably they would not dare to
56194. attack large detachments?" he added inquiringly. No one replied.
56195. 
56196. "Well, now he'll come away," Petya thought every moment as he stood by
56197. the campfire listening to the talk.
56198. 
56199. But Dolokhov restarted the conversation which had dropped and began
56200. putting direct questions as to how many men there were in the battalion,
56201. how many battalions, and how many prisoners. Asking about the Russian
56202. prisoners with that detachment, Dolokhov said:
56203. 
56204. "A horrid business dragging these corpses about with one! It would be
56205. better to shoot such rabble," and burst into loud laughter, so strange
56206. that Petya thought the French would immediately detect their disguise,
56207. and involuntarily took a step back from the campfire.
56208. 
56209. No one replied a word to Dolokhov's laughter, and a French officer whom
56210. they could not see (he lay wrapped in a greatcoat) rose and whispered
56211. something to a companion. Dolokhov got up and called to the soldier who
56212. was holding their horses.
56213. 
56214. "Will they bring our horses or not?" thought Petya, instinctively
56215. drawing nearer to Dolokhov.
56216. 
56217. The horses were brought.
56218. 
56219. "Good evening, gentlemen," said Dolokhov.
56220. 
56221. Petya wished to say "Good night" but could not utter a word. The
56222. officers were whispering together. Dolokhov was a long time mounting
56223. his horse which would not stand still, then he rode out of the yard at a
56224. footpace. Petya rode beside him, longing to look round to see whether or
56225. not the French were running after them, but not daring to.
56226. 
56227. Coming out onto the road Dolokhov did not ride back across the open
56228. country, but through the village. At one spot he stopped and listened.
56229. "Do you hear?" he asked. Petya recognized the sound of Russian voices
56230. and saw the dark figures of Russian prisoners round their campfires.
56231. When they had descended to the bridge Petya and Dolokhov rode past the
56232. sentinel, who without saying a word paced morosely up and down it, then
56233. they descended into the hollow where the Cossacks awaited them.
56234. 
56235. "Well now, good-by. Tell Denisov, 'at the first shot at daybreak,'" said
56236. Dolokhov and was about to ride away, but Petya seized hold of him.
56237. 
56238. "Really!" he cried, "you are such a hero! Oh, how fine, how splendid!
56239. How I love you!"
56240. 
56241. "All right, all right!" said Dolokhov. But Petya did not let go of him
56242. and Dolokhov saw through the gloom that Petya was bending toward him and
56243. wanted to kiss him. Dolokhov kissed him, laughed, turned his horse, and
56244. vanished into the darkness.
56245. 
56246. 
56247. 
56248. 
56249. 
56250. CHAPTER X
56251. 
56252. 
56253. Having returned to the watchman's hut, Petya found Denisov in the
56254. passage. He was awaiting Petya's return in a state of agitation,
56255. anxiety, and self-reproach for having let him go.
56256. 
56257. "Thank God!" he exclaimed. "Yes, thank God!" he repeated, listening to
56258. Petya's rapturous account. "But, devil take you, I haven't slept because
56259. of you! Well, thank God. Now lie down. We can still get a nap before
56260. morning."
56261. 
56262. "But... no," said Petya, "I don't want to sleep yet. Besides I know
56263. myself, if I fall asleep it's finished. And then I am used to not
56264. sleeping before a battle."
56265. 
56266. He sat awhile in the hut joyfully recalling the details of his
56267. expedition and vividly picturing to himself what would happen next day.
56268. 
56269. Then, noticing that Denisov was asleep, he rose and went out of doors.
56270. 
56271. It was still quite dark outside. The rain was over, but drops were still
56272. falling from the trees. Near the watchman's hut the black shapes of the
56273. Cossacks' shanties and of horses tethered together could be seen. Behind
56274. the hut the dark shapes of the two wagons with their horses beside them
56275. were discernible, and in the hollow the dying campfire gleamed red.
56276. Not all the Cossacks and hussars were asleep; here and there, amid the
56277. sounds of falling drops and the munching of the horses near by, could be
56278. heard low voices which seemed to be whispering.
56279. 
56280. Petya came out, peered into the darkness, and went up to the wagons.
56281. Someone was snoring under them, and around them stood saddled horses
56282. munching their oats. In the dark Petya recognized his own horse, which
56283. he called "Karabakh" though it was of Ukranian breed, and went up to it.
56284. 
56285. "Well, Karabakh! We'll do some service tomorrow," said he, sniffing its
56286. nostrils and kissing it.
56287. 
56288. "Why aren't you asleep, sir?" said a Cossack who was sitting under a
56289. wagon.
56290. 
56291. "No, ah... Likhachev--isn't that your name? Do you know I have only just
56292. come back! We've been into the French camp."
56293. 
56294. And Petya gave the Cossack a detailed account not only of his ride but
56295. also of his object, and why he considered it better to risk his life
56296. than to act "just anyhow."
56297. 
56298. "Well, you should get some sleep now," said the Cossack.
56299. 
56300. "No, I am used to this," said Petya. "I say, aren't the flints in your
56301. pistols worn out? I brought some with me. Don't you want any? You can
56302. have some."
56303. 
56304. The Cossack bent forward from under the wagon to get a closer look at
56305. Petya.
56306. 
56307. "Because I am accustomed to doing everything accurately," said Petya.
56308. "Some fellows do things just anyhow, without preparation, and then
56309. they're sorry for it afterwards. I don't like that."
56310. 
56311. "Just so," said the Cossack.
56312. 
56313. "Oh yes, another thing! Please, my dear fellow, will you sharpen my
56314. saber for me? It's got bl..." (Petya feared to tell a lie, and the saber
56315. never had been sharpened.) "Can you do it?"
56316. 
56317. "Of course I can."
56318. 
56319. Likhachev got up, rummaged in his pack, and soon Petya heard the warlike
56320. sound of steel on whetstone. He climbed onto the wagon and sat on its
56321. edge. The Cossack was sharpening the saber under the wagon.
56322. 
56323. "I say! Are the lads asleep?" asked Petya.
56324. 
56325. "Some are, and some aren't--like us."
56326. 
56327. "Well, and that boy?"
56328. 
56329. "Vesenny? Oh, he's thrown himself down there in the passage. Fast asleep
56330. after his fright. He was that glad!"
56331. 
56332. After that Petya remained silent for a long time, listening to the
56333. sounds. He heard footsteps in the darkness and a black figure appeared.
56334. 
56335. "What are you sharpening?" asked a man coming up to the wagon.
56336. 
56337. "Why, this gentleman's saber."
56338. 
56339. "That's right," said the man, whom Petya took to be an hussar. "Was the
56340. cup left here?"
56341. 
56342. "There, by the wheel!"
56343. 
56344. The hussar took the cup.
56345. 
56346. "It must be daylight soon," said he, yawning, and went away.
56347. 
56348. Petya ought to have known that he was in a forest with Denisov's
56349. guerrilla band, less than a mile from the road, sitting on a wagon
56350. captured from the French beside which horses were tethered, that under
56351. it Likhachev was sitting sharpening a saber for him, that the big dark
56352. blotch to the right was the watchman's hut, and the red blotch below to
56353. the left was the dying embers of a campfire, that the man who had come
56354. for the cup was an hussar who wanted a drink; but he neither knew nor
56355. waited to know anything of all this. He was in a fairy kingdom where
56356. nothing resembled reality. The big dark blotch might really be the
56357. watchman's hut or it might be a cavern leading to the very depths of
56358. the earth. Perhaps the red spot was a fire, or it might be the eye of an
56359. enormous monster. Perhaps he was really sitting on a wagon, but it might
56360. very well be that he was not sitting on a wagon but on a terribly high
56361. tower from which, if he fell, he would have to fall for a whole day or a
56362. whole month, or go on falling and never reach the bottom. Perhaps it
56363. was just the Cossack, Likhachev, who was sitting under the wagon, but it
56364. might be the kindest, bravest, most wonderful, most splendid man in the
56365. world, whom no one knew of. It might really have been that the hussar
56366. came for water and went back into the hollow, but perhaps he had simply
56367. vanished--disappeared altogether and dissolved into nothingness.
56368. 
56369. Nothing Petya could have seen now would have surprised him. He was in a
56370. fairy kingdom where everything was possible.
56371. 
56372. He looked up at the sky. And the sky was a fairy realm like the earth.
56373. It was clearing, and over the tops of the trees clouds were swiftly
56374. sailing as if unveiling the stars. Sometimes it looked as if the clouds
56375. were passing, and a clear black sky appeared. Sometimes it seemed as
56376. if the black spaces were clouds. Sometimes the sky seemed to be rising
56377. high, high overhead, and then it seemed to sink so low that one could
56378. touch it with one's hand.
56379. 
56380. Petya's eyes began to close and he swayed a little.
56381. 
56382. The trees were dripping. Quiet talking was heard. The horses neighed and
56383. jostled one another. Someone snored.
56384. 
56385. "Ozheg-zheg, Ozheg-zheg..." hissed the saber against the whetstone,
56386. and suddenly Petya heard an harmonious orchestra playing some unknown,
56387. sweetly solemn hymn. Petya was as musical as Natasha and more so than
56388. Nicholas, but had never learned music or thought about it, and so the
56389. melody that unexpectedly came to his mind seemed to him particularly
56390. fresh and attractive. The music became more and more audible. The melody
56391. grew and passed from one instrument to another. And what was played was
56392. a fugue--though Petya had not the least conception of what a fugue is.
56393. Each instrument--now resembling a violin and now a horn, but better
56394. and clearer than violin or horn--played its own part, and before it had
56395. finished the melody merged with another instrument that began almost the
56396. same air, and then with a third and a fourth; and they all blended into
56397. one and again became separate and again blended, now into solemn church
56398. music, now into something dazzlingly brilliant and triumphant.
56399. 
56400. "Oh--why, that was in a dream!" Petya said to himself, as he lurched
56401. forward. "It's in my ears. But perhaps it's music of my own. Well, go
56402. on, my music! Now!..."
56403. 
56404. He closed his eyes, and, from all sides as if from a distance, sounds
56405. fluttered, grew into harmonies, separated, blended, and again all
56406. mingled into the same sweet and solemn hymn. "Oh, this is delightful!
56407. As much as I like and as I like!" said Petya to himself. He tried to
56408. conduct that enormous orchestra.
56409. 
56410. "Now softly, softly die away!" and the sounds obeyed him. "Now fuller,
56411. more joyful. Still more and more joyful!" And from an unknown depth rose
56412. increasingly triumphant sounds. "Now voices join in!" ordered Petya. And
56413. at first from afar he heard men's voices and then women's. The voices
56414. grew in harmonious triumphant strength, and Petya listened to their
56415. surpassing beauty in awe and joy.
56416. 
56417. With a solemn triumphal march there mingled a song, the drip from the
56418. trees, and the hissing of the saber, "Ozheg-zheg-zheg..." and again the
56419. horses jostled one another and neighed, not disturbing the choir but
56420. joining in it.
56421. 
56422. Petya did not know how long this lasted: he enjoyed himself all the
56423. time, wondered at his enjoyment and regretted that there was no one to
56424. share it. He was awakened by Likhachev's kindly voice.
56425. 
56426. "It's ready, your honor; you can split a Frenchman in half with it!"
56427. 
56428. Petya woke up.
56429. 
56430. "It's getting light, it's really getting light!" he exclaimed.
56431. 
56432. The horses that had previously been invisible could now be seen to their
56433. very tails, and a watery light showed itself through the bare branches.
56434. Petya shook himself, jumped up, took a ruble from his pocket and gave it
56435. to Likhachev; then he flourished the saber, tested it, and sheathed
56436. it. The Cossacks were untying their horses and tightening their saddle
56437. girths.
56438. 
56439. "And here's the commander," said Likhachev.
56440. 
56441. Denisov came out of the watchman's hut and, having called Petya, gave
56442. orders to get ready.
56443. 
56444. 
56445. 
56446. 
56447. 
56448. CHAPTER XI
56449. 
56450. 
56451. The men rapidly picked out their horses in the semidarkness, tightened
56452. their saddle girths, and formed companies. Denisov stood by the
56453. watchman's hut giving final orders. The infantry of the detachment
56454. passed along the road and quickly disappeared amid the trees in the mist
56455. of early dawn, hundreds of feet splashing through the mud. The esaul
56456. gave some orders to his men. Petya held his horse by the bridle,
56457. impatiently awaiting the order to mount. His face, having been bathed
56458. in cold water, was all aglow, and his eyes were particularly brilliant.
56459. Cold shivers ran down his spine and his whole body pulsed rhythmically.
56460. 
56461. "Well, is ev'wything weady?" asked Denisov. "Bwing the horses."
56462. 
56463. The horses were brought. Denisov was angry with the Cossack because the
56464. saddle girths were too slack, reproved him, and mounted. Petya put his
56465. foot in the stirrup. His horse by habit made as if to nip his leg, but
56466. Petya leaped quickly into the saddle unconscious of his own weight and,
56467. turning to look at the hussars starting in the darkness behind him, rode
56468. up to Denisov.
56469. 
56470. "Vasili Dmitrich, entrust me with some commission! Please... for God's
56471. sake...!" said he.
56472. 
56473. Denisov seemed to have forgotten Petya's very existence. He turned to
56474. glance at him.
56475. 
56476. "I ask one thing of you," he said sternly, "to obey me and not shove
56477. yourself forward anywhere."
56478. 
56479. He did not say another word to Petya but rode in silence all the way.
56480. When they had come to the edge of the forest it was noticeably growing
56481. light over the field. Denisov talked in whispers with the esaul and
56482. the Cossacks rode past Petya and Denisov. When they had all ridden by,
56483. Denisov touched his horse and rode down the hill. Slipping onto their
56484. haunches and sliding, the horses descended with their riders into the
56485. ravine. Petya rode beside Denisov, the pulsation of his body constantly
56486. increasing. It was getting lighter and lighter, but the mist still hid
56487. distant objects. Having reached the valley, Denisov looked back and
56488. nodded to a Cossack beside him.
56489. 
56490. "The signal!" said he.
56491. 
56492. The Cossack raised his arm and a shot rang out. In an instant the tramp
56493. of horses galloping forward was heard, shouts came from various sides,
56494. and then more shots.
56495. 
56496. At the first sound of trampling hoofs and shouting, Petya lashed his
56497. horse and loosening his rein galloped forward, not heeding Denisov who
56498. shouted at him. It seemed to Petya that at the moment the shot was
56499. fired it suddenly became as bright as noon. He galloped to the bridge.
56500. Cossacks were galloping along the road in front of him. On the bridge
56501. he collided with a Cossack who had fallen behind, but he galloped on.
56502. In front of him soldiers, probably Frenchmen, were running from right
56503. to left across the road. One of them fell in the mud under his horse's
56504. feet.
56505. 
56506. Cossacks were crowding about a hut, busy with something. From the midst
56507. of that crowd terrible screams arose. Petya galloped up, and the
56508. first thing he saw was the pale face and trembling jaw of a Frenchman,
56509. clutching the handle of a lance that had been aimed at him.
56510. 
56511. "Hurrah!... Lads!... ours!" shouted Petya, and giving rein to his
56512. excited horse he galloped forward along the village street.
56513. 
56514. He could hear shooting ahead of him. Cossacks, hussars, and ragged
56515. Russian prisoners, who had come running from both sides of the road,
56516. were shouting something loudly and incoherently. A gallant-looking
56517. Frenchman, in a blue overcoat, capless, and with a frowning red face,
56518. had been defending himself against the hussars. When Petya galloped
56519. up the Frenchman had already fallen. "Too late again!" flashed through
56520. Petya's mind and he galloped on to the place from which the rapid firing
56521. could be heard. The shots came from the yard of the landowner's house
56522. he had visited the night before with Dolokhov. The French were making
56523. a stand there behind a wattle fence in a garden thickly overgrown with
56524. bushes and were firing at the Cossacks who crowded at the gateway.
56525. Through the smoke, as he approached the gate, Petya saw Dolokhov, whose
56526. face was of a pale-greenish tint, shouting to his men. "Go round! Wait
56527. for the infantry!" he exclaimed as Petya rode up to him.
56528. 
56529. "Wait?... Hurrah-ah-ah!" shouted Petya, and without pausing a moment
56530. galloped to the place whence came the sounds of firing and where the
56531. smoke was thickest.
56532. 
56533. A volley was heard, and some bullets whistled past, while others plashed
56534. against something. The Cossacks and Dolokhov galloped after Petya into
56535. the gateway of the courtyard. In the dense wavering smoke some of the
56536. French threw down their arms and ran out of the bushes to meet the
56537. Cossacks, while others ran down the hill toward the pond. Petya was
56538. galloping along the courtyard, but instead of holding the reins he waved
56539. both his arms about rapidly and strangely, slipping farther and farther
56540. to one side in his saddle. His horse, having galloped up to a campfire
56541. that was smoldering in the morning light, stopped suddenly, and Petya
56542. fell heavily on to the wet ground. The Cossacks saw that his arms and
56543. legs jerked rapidly though his head was quite motionless. A bullet had
56544. pierced his skull.
56545. 
56546. After speaking to the senior French officer, who came out of the house
56547. with a white handkerchief tied to his sword and announced that
56548. they surrendered, Dolokhov dismounted and went up to Petya, who lay
56549. motionless with outstretched arms.
56550. 
56551. "Done for!" he said with a frown, and went to the gate to meet Denisov
56552. who was riding toward him.
56553. 
56554. "Killed?" cried Denisov, recognizing from a distance the unmistakably
56555. lifeless attitude--very familiar to him--in which Petya's body was
56556. lying.
56557. 
56558. "Done for!" repeated Dolokhov as if the utterance of these words
56559. afforded him pleasure, and he went quickly up to the prisoners, who
56560. were surrounded by Cossacks who had hurried up. "We won't take them!" he
56561. called out to Denisov.
56562. 
56563. Denisov did not reply; he rode up to Petya, dismounted, and with
56564. trembling hands turned toward himself the bloodstained, mud-bespattered
56565. face which had already gone white.
56566. 
56567. "I am used to something sweet. Raisins, fine ones... take them all!" he
56568. recalled Petya's words. And the Cossacks looked round in surprise at the
56569. sound, like the yelp of a dog, with which Denisov turned away, walked to
56570. the wattle fence, and seized hold of it.
56571. 
56572. Among the Russian prisoners rescued by Denisov and Dolokhov was Pierre
56573. Bezukhov.
56574. 
56575. 
56576. 
56577. 
56578. 
56579. CHAPTER XII
56580. 
56581. 
56582. During the whole of their march from Moscow no fresh orders had been
56583. issued by the French authorities concerning the party of prisoners
56584. among whom was Pierre. On the twenty-second of October that party was
56585. no longer with the same troops and baggage trains with which it had left
56586. Moscow. Half the wagons laden with hardtack that had traveled the first
56587. stages with them had been captured by Cossacks, the other half had gone
56588. on ahead. Not one of those dismounted cavalrymen who had marched in
56589. front of the prisoners was left; they had all disappeared. The artillery
56590. the prisoners had seen in front of them during the first days was
56591. now replaced by Marshal Junot's enormous baggage train, convoyed by
56592. Westphalians. Behind the prisoners came a cavalry baggage train.
56593. 
56594. From Vyazma onwards the French army, which had till then moved in three
56595. columns, went on as a single group. The symptoms of disorder that Pierre
56596. had noticed at their first halting place after leaving Moscow had now
56597. reached the utmost limit.
56598. 
56599. The road along which they moved was bordered on both sides by dead
56600. horses; ragged men who had fallen behind from various regiments
56601. continually changed about, now joining the moving column, now again
56602. lagging behind it.
56603. 
56604. Several times during the march false alarms had been given and the
56605. soldiers of the escort had raised their muskets, fired, and run
56606. headlong, crushing one another, but had afterwards reassembled and
56607. abused each other for their causeless panic.
56608. 
56609. These three groups traveling together--the cavalry stores, the convoy of
56610. prisoners, and Junot's baggage train--still constituted a separate and
56611. united whole, though each of the groups was rapidly melting away.
56612. 
56613. Of the artillery baggage train which had consisted of a hundred and
56614. twenty wagons, not more than sixty now remained; the rest had been
56615. captured or left behind. Some of Junot's wagons also had been captured
56616. or abandoned. Three wagons had been raided and robbed by stragglers
56617. from Davout's corps. From the talk of the Germans Pierre learned that
56618. a larger guard had been allotted to that baggage train than to the
56619. prisoners, and that one of their comrades, a German soldier, had been
56620. shot by the marshal's own order because a silver spoon belonging to the
56621. marshal had been found in his possession.
56622. 
56623. The group of prisoners had melted away most of all. Of the three hundred
56624. and thirty men who had set out from Moscow fewer than a hundred now
56625. remained. The prisoners were more burdensome to the escort than even the
56626. cavalry saddles or Junot's baggage. They understood that the saddles and
56627. Junot's spoon might be of some use, but that cold and hungry soldiers
56628. should have to stand and guard equally cold and hungry Russians who
56629. froze and lagged behind on the road (in which case the order was to
56630. shoot them) was not merely incomprehensible but revolting. And the
56631. escort, as if afraid, in the grievous condition they themselves were in,
56632. of giving way to the pity they felt for the prisoners and so rendering
56633. their own plight still worse, treated them with particular moroseness
56634. and severity.
56635. 
56636. At Dorogobuzh while the soldiers of the convoy, after locking the
56637. prisoners in a stable, had gone off to pillage their own stores, several
56638. of the soldier prisoners tunneled under the wall and ran away, but were
56639. recaptured by the French and shot.
56640. 
56641. The arrangement adopted when they started, that the officer prisoners
56642. should be kept separate from the rest, had long since been abandoned.
56643. All who could walk went together, and after the third stage Pierre had
56644. rejoined Karataev and the gray-blue bandy-legged dog that had chosen
56645. Karataev for its master.
56646. 
56647. On the third day after leaving Moscow Karataev again fell ill with the
56648. fever he had suffered from in the hospital in Moscow, and as he grew
56649. gradually weaker Pierre kept away from him. Pierre did not know why, but
56650. since Karataev had begun to grow weaker it had cost him an effort to
56651. go near him. When he did so and heard the subdued moaning with which
56652. Karataev generally lay down at the halting places, and when he smelled
56653. the odor emanating from him which was now stronger than before, Pierre
56654. moved farther away and did not think about him.
56655. 
56656. While imprisoned in the shed Pierre had learned not with his intellect
56657. but with his whole being, by life itself, that man is created for
56658. happiness, that happiness is within him, in the satisfaction of simple
56659. human needs, and that all unhappiness arises not from privation but from
56660. superfluity. And now during these last three weeks of the march he had
56661. learned still another new, consolatory truth--that nothing in this world
56662. is terrible. He had learned that as there is no condition in which man
56663. can be happy and entirely free, so there is no condition in which he
56664. need be unhappy and lack freedom. He learned that suffering and freedom
56665. have their limits and that those limits are very near together; that the
56666. person in a bed of roses with one crumpled petal suffered as keenly as
56667. he now, sleeping on the bare damp earth with one side growing chilled
56668. while the other was warming; and that when he had put on tight dancing
56669. shoes he had suffered just as he did now when he walked with bare feet
56670. that were covered with sores--his footgear having long since fallen to
56671. pieces. He discovered that when he had married his wife--of his own free
56672. will as it had seemed to him--he had been no more free than now
56673. when they locked him up at night in a stable. Of all that he himself
56674. subsequently termed his sufferings, but which at the time he scarcely
56675. felt, the worst was the state of his bare, raw, and scab-covered feet.
56676. (The horseflesh was appetizing and nourishing, the saltpeter flavor of
56677. the gunpowder they used instead of salt was even pleasant; there was
56678. no great cold, it was always warm walking in the daytime, and at night
56679. there were the campfires; the lice that devoured him warmed his body.)
56680. The one thing that was at first hard to bear was his feet.
56681. 
56682. After the second day's march Pierre, having examined his feet by the
56683. campfire, thought it would be impossible to walk on them; but when
56684. everybody got up he went along, limping, and, when he had warmed up,
56685. walked without feeling the pain, though at night his feet were more
56686. terrible to look at than before. However, he did not look at them now,
56687. but thought of other things.
56688. 
56689. Only now did Pierre realize the full strength of life in man and the
56690. saving power he has of transferring his attention from one thing
56691. to another, which is like the safety valve of a boiler that allows
56692. superfluous steam to blow off when the pressure exceeds a certain limit.
56693. 
56694. He did not see and did not hear how they shot the prisoners who lagged
56695. behind, though more than a hundred perished in that way. He did not
56696. think of Karataev who grew weaker every day and evidently would soon
56697. have to share that fate. Still less did Pierre think about himself. The
56698. harder his position became and the more terrible the future, the more
56699. independent of that position in which he found himself were the joyful
56700. and comforting thoughts, memories, and imaginings that came to him.
56701. 
56702. 
56703. 
56704. 
56705. 
56706. CHAPTER XIII
56707. 
56708. 
56709. At midday on the twenty-second of October Pierre was going uphill along
56710. the muddy, slippery road, looking at his feet and at the roughness of
56711. the way. Occasionally he glanced at the familiar crowd around him and
56712. then again at his feet. The former and the latter were alike familiar
56713. and his own. The blue-gray bandy legged dog ran merrily along the side
56714. of the road, sometimes in proof of its agility and self-satisfaction
56715. lifting one hind leg and hopping along on three, and then again going on
56716. all four and rushing to bark at the crows that sat on the carrion. The
56717. dog was merrier and sleeker than it had been in Moscow. All around lay
56718. the flesh of different animals--from men to horses--in various stages
56719. of decomposition; and as the wolves were kept off by the passing men the
56720. dog could eat all it wanted.
56721. 
56722. It had been raining since morning and had seemed as if at any moment it
56723. might cease and the sky clear, but after a short break it began raining
56724. harder than before. The saturated road no longer absorbed the water,
56725. which ran along the ruts in streams.
56726. 
56727. Pierre walked along, looking from side to side, counting his steps in
56728. threes, and reckoning them off on his fingers. Mentally addressing the
56729. rain, he repeated: "Now then, now then, go on! Pelt harder!"
56730. 
56731. It seemed to him that he was thinking of nothing, but far down and
56732. deep within him his soul was occupied with something important and
56733. comforting. This something was a most subtle spiritual deduction from a
56734. conversation with Karataev the day before.
56735. 
56736. At their yesterday's halting place, feeling chilly by a dying campfire,
56737. Pierre had got up and gone to the next one, which was burning better.
56738. There Platon Karataev was sitting covered up--head and all--with
56739. his greatcoat as if it were a vestment, telling the soldiers in his
56740. effective and pleasant though now feeble voice a story Pierre knew. It
56741. was already past midnight, the hour when Karataev was usually free of
56742. his fever and particularly lively. When Pierre reached the fire and
56743. heard Platon's voice enfeebled by illness, and saw his pathetic face
56744. brightly lit up by the blaze, he felt a painful prick at his heart. His
56745. feeling of pity for this man frightened him and he wished to go away,
56746. but there was no other fire, and Pierre sat down, trying not to look at
56747. Platon.
56748. 
56749. "Well, how are you?" he asked.
56750. 
56751. "How am I? If we grumble at sickness, God won't grant us death," replied
56752. Platon, and at once resumed the story he had begun.
56753. 
56754. "And so, brother," he continued, with a smile on his pale emaciated face
56755. and a particularly happy light in his eyes, "you see, brother..."
56756. 
56757. Pierre had long been familiar with that story. Karataev had told it
56758. to him alone some half-dozen times and always with a specially joyful
56759. emotion. But well as he knew it, Pierre now listened to that tale as to
56760. something new, and the quiet rapture Karataev evidently felt as he told
56761. it communicated itself also to Pierre. The story was of an old merchant
56762. who lived a good and God-fearing life with his family, and who went once
56763. to the Nizhni fair with a companion--a rich merchant.
56764. 
56765. Having put up at an inn they both went to sleep, and next morning his
56766. companion was found robbed and with his throat cut. A bloodstained knife
56767. was found under the old merchant's pillow. He was tried, knouted, and
56768. his nostrils having been torn off, "all in due form" as Karataev put it,
56769. he was sent to hard labor in Siberia.
56770. 
56771. "And so, brother" (it was at this point that Pierre came up), "ten years
56772. or more passed by. The old man was living as a convict, submitting as
56773. he should and doing no wrong. Only he prayed to God for death. Well, one
56774. night the convicts were gathered just as we are, with the old man among
56775. them. And they began telling what each was suffering for, and how they
56776. had sinned against God. One told how he had taken a life, another had
56777. taken two, a third had set a house on fire, while another had simply
56778. been a vagrant and had done nothing. So they asked the old man: 'What
56779. are you being punished for, Daddy?'--'I, my dear brothers,' said he, 'am
56780. being punished for my own and other men's sins. But I have not killed
56781. anyone or taken anything that was not mine, but have only helped my
56782. poorer brothers. I was a merchant, my dear brothers, and had much
56783. property. 'And he went on to tell them all about it in due order. 'I
56784. don't grieve for myself,' he says, 'God, it seems, has chastened me.
56785. Only I am sorry for my old wife and the children,' and the old man began
56786. to weep. Now it happened that in the group was the very man who had
56787. killed the other merchant. 'Where did it happen, Daddy?' he said. 'When,
56788. and in what month?' He asked all about it and his heart began to ache.
56789. So he comes up to the old man like this, and falls down at his feet!
56790. 'You are perishing because of me, Daddy,' he says. 'It's quite true,
56791. lads, that this man,' he says, 'is being tortured innocently and for
56792. nothing! I,' he says, 'did that deed, and I put the knife under your
56793. head while you were asleep. Forgive me, Daddy,' he says, 'for Christ's
56794. sake!'"
56795. 
56796. Karataev paused, smiling joyously as he gazed into the fire, and he drew
56797. the logs together.
56798. 
56799. "And the old man said, 'God will forgive you, we are all sinners in His
56800. sight. I suffer for my own sins,' and he wept bitter tears. Well,
56801. and what do you think, dear friends?" Karataev continued, his face
56802. brightening more and more with a rapturous smile as if what he now had
56803. to tell contained the chief charm and the whole meaning of his story:
56804. "What do you think, dear fellows? That murderer confessed to the
56805. authorities. 'I have taken six lives,' he says (he was a great sinner),
56806. 'but what I am most sorry for is this old man. Don't let him suffer
56807. because of me.' So he confessed and it was all written down and the
56808. papers sent off in due form. The place was a long way off, and while
56809. they were judging, what with one thing and another, filling in the
56810. papers all in due form--the authorities I mean--time passed. The affair
56811. reached the Tsar. After a while the Tsar's decree came: to set the
56812. merchant free and give him a compensation that had been awarded. The
56813. paper arrived and they began to look for the old man. 'Where is the old
56814. man who has been suffering innocently and in vain? A paper has come from
56815. the Tsar!' so they began looking for him," here Karataev's lower jaw
56816. trembled, "but God had already forgiven him--he was dead! That's how it
56817. was, dear fellows!" Karataev concluded and sat for a long time silent,
56818. gazing before him with a smile.
56819. 
56820. And Pierre's soul was dimly but joyfully filled not by the story itself
56821. but by its mysterious significance: by the rapturous joy that lit up
56822. Karataev's face as he told it, and the mystic significance of that joy.
56823. 
56824. 
56825. 
56826. 
56827. 
56828. CHAPTER XIV
56829. 
56830. 
56831. "A vos places!" * suddenly cried a voice.
56832. 
56833. 
56834.     * "To your places."
56835. 
56836. 
56837. A pleasant feeling of excitement and an expectation of something
56838. joyful and solemn was aroused among the soldiers of the convoy and the
56839. prisoners. From all sides came shouts of command, and from the left came
56840. smartly dressed cavalrymen on good horses, passing the prisoners at a
56841. trot. The expression on all faces showed the tension people feel at the
56842. approach of those in authority. The prisoners thronged together and were
56843. pushed off the road. The convoy formed up.
56844. 
56845. "The Emperor! The Emperor! The Marshal! The Duke!" and hardly had the
56846. sleek cavalry passed, before a carriage drawn by six gray horses rattled
56847. by. Pierre caught a glimpse of a man in a three-cornered hat with a
56848. tranquil look on his handsome, plump, white face. It was one of the
56849. marshals. His eye fell on Pierre's large and striking figure, and in
56850. the expression with which he frowned and looked away Pierre thought he
56851. detected sympathy and a desire to conceal that sympathy.
56852. 
56853. The general in charge of the stores galloped after the carriage with a
56854. red and frightened face, whipping up his skinny horse. Several officers
56855. formed a group and some soldiers crowded round them. Their faces all
56856. looked excited and worried.
56857. 
56858. "What did he say? What did he say?" Pierre heard them ask.
56859. 
56860. While the marshal was passing, the prisoners had huddled together in a
56861. crowd, and Pierre saw Karataev whom he had not yet seen that morning.
56862. He sat in his short overcoat leaning against a birch tree. On his face,
56863. besides the look of joyful emotion it had worn yesterday while telling
56864. the tale of the merchant who suffered innocently, there was now an
56865. expression of quiet solemnity.
56866. 
56867. Karataev looked at Pierre with his kindly round eyes now filled with
56868. tears, evidently wishing him to come near that he might say something to
56869. him. But Pierre was not sufficiently sure of himself. He made as if he
56870. did not notice that look and moved hastily away.
56871. 
56872. When the prisoners again went forward Pierre looked round. Karataev
56873. was still sitting at the side of the road under the birch tree and two
56874. Frenchmen were talking over his head. Pierre did not look round again
56875. but went limping up the hill.
56876. 
56877. From behind, where Karataev had been sitting, came the sound of a shot.
56878. Pierre heard it plainly, but at that moment he remembered that he
56879. had not yet finished reckoning up how many stages still remained to
56880. Smolensk--a calculation he had begun before the marshal went by. And
56881. he again started reckoning. Two French soldiers ran past Pierre, one of
56882. whom carried a lowered and smoking gun. They both looked pale, and
56883. in the expression on their faces--one of them glanced timidly at
56884. Pierre--there was something resembling what he had seen on the face of
56885. the young soldier at the execution. Pierre looked at the soldier and
56886. remembered that, two days before, that man had burned his shirt while
56887. drying it at the fire and how they had laughed at him.
56888. 
56889. Behind him, where Karataev had been sitting, the dog began to howl.
56890. "What a stupid beast! Why is it howling?" thought Pierre.
56891. 
56892. His comrades, the prisoner soldiers walking beside him, avoided looking
56893. back at the place where the shot had been fired and the dog was howling,
56894. just as Pierre did, but there was a set look on all their faces.
56895. 
56896. 
56897. 
56898. 
56899. 
56900. CHAPTER XV
56901. 
56902. 
56903. The stores, the prisoners, and the marshal's baggage train stopped at
56904. the village of Shamshevo. The men crowded together round the campfires.
56905. Pierre went up to the fire, ate some roast horseflesh, lay down with his
56906. back to the fire, and immediately fell asleep. He again slept as he had
56907. done at Mozhaysk after the battle of Borodino.
56908. 
56909. Again real events mingled with dreams and again someone, he or another,
56910. gave expression to his thoughts, and even to the same thoughts that had
56911. been expressed in his dream at Mozhaysk.
56912. 
56913. "Life is everything. Life is God. Everything changes and moves and that
56914. movement is God. And while there is life there is joy in consciousness
56915. of the divine. To love life is to love God. Harder and more blessed
56916. than all else is to love this life in one's sufferings, in innocent
56917. sufferings."
56918. 
56919. "Karataev!" came to Pierre's mind.
56920. 
56921. And suddenly he saw vividly before him a long-forgotten, kindly old man
56922. who had given him geography lessons in Switzerland. "Wait a bit,"
56923. said the old man, and showed Pierre a globe. This globe was alive--a
56924. vibrating ball without fixed dimensions. Its whole surface consisted of
56925. drops closely pressed together, and all these drops moved and changed
56926. places, sometimes several of them merging into one, sometimes one
56927. dividing into many. Each drop tried to spread out and occupy as much
56928. space as possible, but others striving to do the same compressed it,
56929. sometimes destroyed it, and sometimes merged with it.
56930. 
56931. "That is life," said the old teacher.
56932. 
56933. "How simple and clear it is," thought Pierre. "How is it I did not know
56934. it before?"
56935. 
56936. "God is in the midst, and each drop tries to expand so as to reflect
56937. Him to the greatest extent. And it grows, merges, disappears from the
56938. surface, sinks to the depths, and again emerges. There now, Karataev
56939. has spread out and disappeared. Do you understand, my child?" said the
56940. teacher.
56941. 
56942. "Do you understand, damn you?" shouted a voice, and Pierre woke up.
56943. 
56944. He lifted himself and sat up. A Frenchman who had just pushed a Russian
56945. soldier away was squatting by the fire, engaged in roasting a piece
56946. of meat stuck on a ramrod. His sleeves were rolled up and his sinewy,
56947. hairy, red hands with their short fingers deftly turned the ramrod. His
56948. brown morose face with frowning brows was clearly visible by the glow of
56949. the charcoal.
56950. 
56951. "It's all the same to him," he muttered, turning quickly to a soldier
56952. who stood behind him. "Brigand! Get away!"
56953. 
56954. And twisting the ramrod he looked gloomily at Pierre, who turned
56955. away and gazed into the darkness. A prisoner, the Russian soldier the
56956. Frenchman had pushed away, was sitting near the fire patting something
56957. with his hand. Looking more closely Pierre recognized the blue-gray dog,
56958. sitting beside the soldier, wagging its tail.
56959. 
56960. "Ah, he's come?" said Pierre. "And Plat-" he began, but did not finish.
56961. 
56962. Suddenly and simultaneously a crowd of memories awoke in his fancy--of
56963. the look Platon had given him as he sat under the tree, of the shot
56964. heard from that spot, of the dog's howl, of the guilty faces of the two
56965. Frenchmen as they ran past him, of the lowered and smoking gun, and of
56966. Karataev's absence at this halt--and he was on the point of realizing
56967. that Karataev had been killed, but just at that instant, he knew not
56968. why, the recollection came to his mind of a summer evening he had spent
56969. with a beautiful Polish lady on the veranda of his house in Kiev. And
56970. without linking up the events of the day or drawing a conclusion
56971. from them, Pierre closed his eyes, seeing a vision of the country in
56972. summertime mingled with memories of bathing and of the liquid, vibrating
56973. globe, and he sank into water so that it closed over his head.
56974. 
56975. Before sunrise he was awakened by shouts and loud and rapid firing.
56976. French soldiers were running past him.
56977. 
56978. "The Cossacks!" one of them shouted, and a moment later a crowd of
56979. Russians surrounded Pierre.
56980. 
56981. For a long time he could not understand what was happening to him. All
56982. around he heard his comrades sobbing with joy.
56983. 
56984. "Brothers! Dear fellows! Darlings!" old soldiers exclaimed, weeping, as
56985. they embraced Cossacks and hussars.
56986. 
56987. The hussars and Cossacks crowded round the prisoners; one offered them
56988. clothes, another boots, and a third bread. Pierre sobbed as he sat
56989. among them and could not utter a word. He hugged the first soldier who
56990. approached him, and kissed him, weeping.
56991. 
56992. Dolokhov stood at the gate of the ruined house, letting a crowd
56993. of disarmed Frenchmen pass by. The French, excited by all that had
56994. happened, were talking loudly among themselves, but as they passed
56995. Dolokhov who gently switched his boots with his whip and watched them
56996. with cold glassy eyes that boded no good, they became silent. On the
56997. opposite side stood Dolokhov's Cossack, counting the prisoners and
56998. marking off each hundred with a chalk line on the gate.
56999. 
57000. "How many?" Dolokhov asked the Cossack.
57001. 
57002. "The second hundred," replied the Cossack.
57003. 
57004. "Filez, filez!" * Dolokhov kept saying, having adopted this expression
57005. from the French, and when his eyes met those of the prisoners they
57006. flashed with a cruel light.
57007. 
57008. 
57009.     * "Get along, get along!"
57010. 
57011. 
57012. Denisov, bareheaded and with a gloomy face, walked behind some Cossacks
