57013. who were carrying the body of Petya Rostov to a hole that had been dug
57014. in the garden.
57015. 
57016. 
57017. 
57018. 
57019. 
57020. CHAPTER XVI
57021. 
57022. 
57023. After the twenty-eighth of October when the frosts began, the flight of
57024. the French assumed a still more tragic character, with men freezing,
57025. or roasting themselves to death at the campfires, while carriages
57026. with people dressed in furs continued to drive past, carrying away the
57027. property that had been stolen by the Emperor, kings, and dukes; but
57028. the process of the flight and disintegration of the French army went on
57029. essentially as before.
57030. 
57031. From Moscow to Vyazma the French army of seventy-three thousand men not
57032. reckoning the Guards (who did nothing during the whole war but pillage)
57033. was reduced to thirty-six thousand, though not more than five thousand
57034. had fallen in battle. From this beginning the succeeding terms of the
57035. progression could be determined mathematically. The French army melted
57036. away and perished at the same rate from Moscow to Vyazma, from Vyazma
57037. to Smolensk, from Smolensk to the Berezina, and from the Berezina to
57038. Vilna--independently of the greater or lesser intensity of the cold,
57039. the pursuit, the barring of the way, or any other particular conditions.
57040. Beyond Vyazma the French army instead of moving in three columns huddled
57041. together into one mass, and so went on to the end. Berthier wrote to his
57042. Emperor (we know how far commanding officers allow themselves to diverge
57043. from the truth in describing the condition of an army) and this is what
57044. he said:
57045. 
57046. 
57047. I deem it my duty to report to Your Majesty the condition of the various
57048. corps I have had occasion to observe during different stages of the last
57049. two or three days' march. They are almost disbanded. Scarcely a quarter
57050. of the soldiers remain with the standards of their regiments, the others
57051. go off by themselves in different directions hoping to find food and
57052. escape discipline. In general they regard Smolensk as the place where
57053. they hope to recover. During the last few days many of the men have been
57054. seen to throw away their cartridges and their arms. In such a state
57055. of affairs, whatever your ultimate plans may be, the interest of Your
57056. Majesty's service demands that the army should be rallied at Smolensk
57057. and should first of all be freed from ineffectives, such as dismounted
57058. cavalry, unnecessary baggage, and artillery material that is no longer
57059. in proportion to the present forces. The soldiers, who are worn out with
57060. hunger and fatigue, need these supplies as well as a few days' rest.
57061. Many have died these last days on the road or at the bivouacs. This
57062. state of things is continually becoming worse and makes one fear that
57063. unless a prompt remedy is applied the troops will no longer be under
57064. control in case of an engagement.
57065. 
57066. November 9: twenty miles from Smolensk.
57067. 
57068. 
57069. After staggering into Smolensk which seemed to them a promised land, the
57070. French, searching for food, killed one another, sacked their own stores,
57071. and when everything had been plundered fled farther.
57072. 
57073. They all went without knowing whither or why they were going. Still less
57074. did that genius, Napoleon, know it, for no one issued any orders to
57075. him. But still he and those about him retained their old habits: wrote
57076. commands, letters, reports, and orders of the day; called one another
57077. sire, mon cousin, prince d'Eckmuhl, roi de Naples, and so on. But these
57078. orders and reports were only on paper, nothing in them was acted upon
57079. for they could not be carried out, and though they entitled one
57080. another Majesties, Highnesses, or Cousins, they all felt that they were
57081. miserable wretches who had done much evil for which they had now to
57082. pay. And though they pretended to be concerned about the army, each
57083. was thinking only of himself and of how to get away quickly and save
57084. himself.
57085. 
57086. 
57087. 
57088. 
57089. 
57090. CHAPTER XVII
57091. 
57092. 
57093. The movements of the Russian and French armies during the campaign
57094. from Moscow back to the Niemen were like those in a game of Russian
57095. blindman's bluff, in which two players are blindfolded and one of
57096. them occasionally rings a little bell to inform the catcher of his
57097. whereabouts. First he rings his bell fearlessly, but when he gets into
57098. a tight place he runs away as quietly as he can, and often thinking to
57099. escape runs straight into his opponent's arms.
57100. 
57101. At first while they were still moving along the Kaluga road, Napoleon's
57102. armies made their presence known, but later when they reached the
57103. Smolensk road they ran holding the clapper of their bell tight--and
57104. often thinking they were escaping ran right into the Russians.
57105. 
57106. Owing to the rapidity of the French flight and the Russian pursuit
57107. and the consequent exhaustion of the horses, the chief means
57108. of approximately ascertaining the enemy's position--by cavalry
57109. scouting--was not available. Besides, as a result of the frequent
57110. and rapid change of position by each army, even what information was
57111. obtained could not be delivered in time. If news was received one day
57112. that the enemy had been in a certain position the day before, by the
57113. third day when something could have been done, that army was already two
57114. days' march farther on and in quite another position.
57115. 
57116. One army fled and the other pursued. Beyond Smolensk there were several
57117. different roads available for the French, and one would have thought
57118. that during their stay of four days they might have learned where
57119. the enemy was, might have arranged some more advantageous plan and
57120. undertaken something new. But after a four days' halt the mob, with no
57121. maneuvers or plans, again began running along the beaten track, neither
57122. to the right nor to the left but along the old--the worst--road, through
57123. Krasnoe and Orsha.
57124. 
57125. Expecting the enemy from behind and not in front, the French separated
57126. in their flight and spread out over a distance of twenty-four hours. In
57127. front of them all fled the Emperor, then the kings, then the dukes. The
57128. Russian army, expecting Napoleon to take the road to the right
57129. beyond the Dnieper--which was the only reasonable thing for him to
57130. do--themselves turned to the right and came out onto the highroad at
57131. Krasnoe. And here as in a game of blindman's buff the French ran into
57132. our vanguard. Seeing their enemy unexpectedly the French fell into
57133. confusion and stopped short from the sudden fright, but then they
57134. resumed their flight, abandoning their comrades who were farther behind.
57135. Then for three days separate portions of the French army--first Murat's
57136. (the vice-king's), then Davout's, and then Ney's--ran, as it were, the
57137. gauntlet of the Russian army. They abandoned one another, abandoned
57138. all their heavy baggage, their artillery, and half their men, and fled,
57139. getting past the Russians by night by making semicircles to the right.
57140. 
57141. Ney, who came last, had been busying himself blowing up the walls of
57142. Smolensk which were in nobody's way, because despite the unfortunate
57143. plight of the French or because of it, they wished to punish the floor
57144. against which they had hurt themselves. Ney, who had had a corps of ten
57145. thousand men, reached Napoleon at Orsha with only one thousand men left,
57146. having abandoned all the rest and all his cannon, and having crossed the
57147. Dnieper at night by stealth at a wooded spot.
57148. 
57149. From Orsha they fled farther along the road to Vilna, still playing
57150. at blindman's buff with the pursuing army. At the Berezina they again
57151. became disorganized, many were drowned and many surrendered, but those
57152. who got across the river fled farther. Their supreme chief donned a
57153. fur coat and, having seated himself in a sleigh, galloped on alone,
57154. abandoning his companions. The others who could do so drove away too,
57155. leaving those who could not to surrender or die.
57156. 
57157. 
57158. 
57159. 
57160. 
57161. CHAPTER XVIII
57162. 
57163. 
57164. This campaign consisted in a flight of the French during which they did
57165. all they could to destroy themselves. From the time they turned onto
57166. the Kaluga road to the day their leader fled from the army, none of the
57167. movements of the crowd had any sense. So one might have thought that
57168. regarding this period of the campaign the historians, who attributed
57169. the actions of the mass to the will of one man, would have found it
57170. impossible to make the story of the retreat fit their theory. But
57171. no! Mountains of books have been written by the historians about this
57172. campaign, and everywhere are described Napoleon's arrangements, the
57173. maneuvers, and his profound plans which guided the army, as well as the
57174. military genius shown by his marshals.
57175. 
57176. The retreat from Malo-Yaroslavets when he had a free road into a
57177. well-supplied district and the parallel road was open to him along
57178. which Kutuzov afterwards pursued him--this unnecessary retreat along
57179. a devastated road--is explained to us as being due to profound
57180. considerations. Similarly profound considerations are given for
57181. his retreat from Smolensk to Orsha. Then his heroism at Krasnoe is
57182. described, where he is reported to have been prepared to accept battle
57183. and take personal command, and to have walked about with a birch stick
57184. and said:
57185. 
57186. "J'ai assez fait l'empereur; il est temps de faire le general," * but
57187. nevertheless immediately ran away again, abandoning to its fate the
57188. scattered fragments of the army he left behind.
57189. 
57190. 
57191.      * "I have acted the Emperor long enough; it is time to act
57192.      the general."
57193. 
57194. 
57195. Then we are told of the greatness of soul of the marshals, especially
57196. of Ney--a greatness of soul consisting in this: that he made his way by
57197. night around through the forest and across the Dnieper and escaped to
57198. Orsha, abandoning standards, artillery, and nine tenths of his men.
57199. 
57200. And lastly, the final departure of the great Emperor from his heroic
57201. army is presented to us by the historians as something great and
57202. characteristic of genius. Even that final running away, described in
57203. ordinary language as the lowest depth of baseness which every child
57204. is taught to be ashamed of--even that act finds justification in the
57205. historians' language.
57206. 
57207. When it is impossible to stretch the very elastic threads of historical
57208. ratiocination any farther, when actions are clearly contrary to all
57209. that humanity calls right or even just, the historians produce a saving
57210. conception of "greatness." "Greatness," it seems, excludes the standards
57211. of right and wrong. For the "great" man nothing is wrong, there is no
57212. atrocity for which a "great" man can be blamed.
57213. 
57214. "C'est grand!" * say the historians, and there no longer exists either
57215. good or evil but only "grand" and "not grand." Grand is good, not
57216. grand is bad. Grand is the characteristic, in their conception, of some
57217. special animals called "heroes." And Napoleon, escaping home in a warm
57218. fur coat and leaving to perish those who were not merely his comrades
57219. but were (in his opinion) men he had brought there, feels que c'est
57220. grand, *(2) and his soul is tranquil.
57221. 
57222. 
57223.      * "It is great."
57224. 
57225.      * (2) That it is great.
57226. 
57227. 
57228. "Du sublime (he saw something sublime in himself) au ridicule il n'y
57229. a qu'un pas," * said he. And the whole world for fifty years has been
57230. repeating: "Sublime! Grand! Napoleon le Grand!" Du sublime au ridicule
57231. il n'y a qu'un pas.
57232. 
57233. 
57234.     * "From the sublime to the ridiculous is but a step."
57235. 
57236. 
57237. And it occurs to no one that to admit a greatness not commensurable with
57238. the standard of right and wrong is merely to admit one's own nothingness
57239. and immeasurable meanness.
57240. 
57241. For us with the standard of good and evil given us by Christ, no human
57242. actions are incommensurable. And there is no greatness where simplicity,
57243. goodness, and truth are absent.
57244. 
57245. 
57246. 
57247. 
57248. 
57249. CHAPTER XIX
57250. 
57251. 
57252. What Russian, reading the account of the last part of the campaign
57253. of 1812, has not experienced an uncomfortable feeling of regret,
57254. dissatisfaction, and perplexity? Who has not asked himself how it is
57255. that the French were not all captured or destroyed when our three armies
57256. surrounded them in superior numbers, when the disordered French, hungry
57257. and freezing, surrendered in crowds, and when (as the historians relate)
57258. the aim of the Russians was to stop the French, to cut them off, and
57259. capture them all?
57260. 
57261. How was it that the Russian army, which when numerically weaker than the
57262. French had given battle at Borodino, did not achieve its purpose when it
57263. had surrounded the French on three sides and when its aim was to capture
57264. them? Can the French be so enormously superior to us that when we had
57265. surrounded them with superior forces we could not beat them? How could
57266. that happen?
57267. 
57268. History (or what is called by that name) replying to these questions
57269. says that this occurred because Kutuzov and Tormasov and Chichagov, and
57270. this man and that man, did not execute such and such maneuvers...
57271. 
57272. But why did they not execute those maneuvers? And why if they were
57273. guilty of not carrying out a prearranged plan were they not tried and
57274. punished? But even if we admitted that Kutuzov, Chichagov, and others
57275. were the cause of the Russian failures, it is still incomprehensible
57276. why, the position of the Russian army being what it was at Krasnoe and
57277. at the Berezina (in both cases we had superior forces), the French army
57278. with its marshals, kings, and Emperor was not captured, if that was what
57279. the Russians aimed at.
57280. 
57281. The explanation of this strange fact given by Russian military
57282. historians (to the effect that Kutuzov hindered an attack) is unfounded,
57283. for we know that he could not restrain the troops from attacking at
57284. Vyazma and Tarutino.
57285. 
57286. Why was the Russian army--which with inferior forces had withstood the
57287. enemy in full strength at Borodino--defeated at Krasnoe and the Berezina
57288. by the disorganized crowds of the French when it was numerically
57289. superior?
57290. 
57291. If the aim of the Russians consisted in cutting off and capturing
57292. Napoleon and his marshals--and that aim was not merely frustrated but
57293. all attempts to attain it were most shamefully baffled--then this last
57294. period of the campaign is quite rightly considered by the French to be a
57295. series of victories, and quite wrongly considered victorious by Russian
57296. historians.
57297. 
57298. The Russian military historians in so far as they submit to claims
57299. of logic must admit that conclusion, and in spite of their lyrical
57300. rhapsodies about valor, devotion, and so forth, must reluctantly admit
57301. that the French retreat from Moscow was a series of victories for
57302. Napoleon and defeats for Kutuzov.
57303. 
57304. But putting national vanity entirely aside one feels that such a
57305. conclusion involves a contradiction, since the series of French
57306. victories brought the French complete destruction, while the series
57307. of Russian defeats led to the total destruction of their enemy and the
57308. liberation of their country.
57309. 
57310. The source of this contradiction lies in the fact that the historians
57311. studying the events from the letters of the sovereigns and the generals,
57312. from memoirs, reports, projects, and so forth, have attributed to this
57313. last period of the war of 1812 an aim that never existed, namely that of
57314. cutting off and capturing Napoleon with his marshals and his army.
57315. 
57316. There never was or could have been such an aim, for it would have been
57317. senseless and its attainment quite impossible.
57318. 
57319. It would have been senseless, first because Napoleon's disorganized
57320. army was flying from Russia with all possible speed, that is to say, was
57321. doing just what every Russian desired. So what was the use of performing
57322. various operations on the French who were running away as fast as they
57323. possibly could?
57324. 
57325. Secondly, it would have been senseless to block the passage of men whose
57326. whole energy was directed to flight.
57327. 
57328. Thirdly, it would have been senseless to sacrifice one's own troops in
57329. order to destroy the French army, which without external interference
57330. was destroying itself at such a rate that, though its path was not
57331. blocked, it could not carry across the frontier more than it actually
57332. did in December, namely a hundredth part of the original army.
57333. 
57334. Fourthly, it would have been senseless to wish to take captive the
57335. Emperor, kings, and dukes--whose capture would have been in the highest
57336. degree embarrassing for the Russians, as the most adroit diplomatists of
57337. the time (Joseph de Maistre and others) recognized. Still more senseless
57338. would have been the wish to capture army corps of the French, when our
57339. own army had melted away to half before reaching Krasnoe and a whole
57340. division would have been needed to convoy the corps of prisoners, and
57341. when our men were not always getting full rations and the prisoners
57342. already taken were perishing of hunger.
57343. 
57344. All the profound plans about cutting off and capturing Napoleon and his
57345. army were like the plan of a market gardener who, when driving out of
57346. his garden a cow that had trampled down the beds he had planted, should
57347. run to the gate and hit the cow on the head. The only thing to be said
57348. in excuse of that gardener would be that he was very angry. But not even
57349. that could be said for those who drew up this project, for it was not
57350. they who had suffered from the trampled beds.
57351. 
57352. But besides the fact that cutting off Napoleon with his army would have
57353. been senseless, it was impossible.
57354. 
57355. It was impossible first because--as experience shows that a three-mile
57356. movement of columns on a battlefield never coincides with the plans--the
57357. probability of Chichagov, Kutuzov, and Wittgenstein effecting a junction
57358. on time at an appointed place was so remote as to be tantamount to
57359. impossibility, as in fact thought Kutuzov, who when he received the plan
57360. remarked that diversions planned over great distances do not yield the
57361. desired results.
57362. 
57363. Secondly it was impossible, because to paralyze the momentum with which
57364. Napoleon's army was retiring, incomparably greater forces than the
57365. Russians possessed would have been required.
57366. 
57367. Thirdly it was impossible, because the military term "to cut off" has no
57368. meaning. One can cut off a slice of bread, but not an army. To cut
57369. off an army--to bar its road--is quite impossible, for there is always
57370. plenty of room to avoid capture and there is the night when nothing can
57371. be seen, as the military scientists might convince themselves by the
57372. example of Krasnoe and of the Berezina. It is only possible to capture
57373. prisoners if they agree to be captured, just as it is only possible
57374. to catch a swallow if it settles on one's hand. Men can only be taken
57375. prisoners if they surrender according to the rules of strategy and
57376. tactics, as the Germans did. But the French troops quite rightly did not
57377. consider that this suited them, since death by hunger and cold awaited
57378. them in flight or captivity alike.
57379. 
57380. Fourthly and chiefly it was impossible, because never since the world
57381. began has a war been fought under such conditions as those that obtained
57382. in 1812, and the Russian army in its pursuit of the French strained its
57383. strength to the utmost and could not have done more without destroying
57384. itself.
57385. 
57386. During the movement of the Russian army from Tarutino to Krasnoe it
57387. lost fifty thousand sick or stragglers, that is a number equal to the
57388. population of a large provincial town. Half the men fell out of the army
57389. without a battle.
57390. 
57391. And it is of this period of the campaign--when the army lacked boots
57392. and sheepskin coats, was short of provisions and without vodka, and
57393. was camping out at night for months in the snow with fifteen degrees
57394. of frost, when there were only seven or eight hours of daylight and
57395. the rest was night in which the influence of discipline cannot be
57396. maintained, when men were taken into that region of death where
57397. discipline fails, not for a few hours only as in a battle, but for
57398. months, where they were every moment fighting death from hunger and
57399. cold, when half the army perished in a single month--it is of this
57400. period of the campaign that the historians tell us how Miloradovich
57401. should have made a flank march to such and such a place, Tormasov to
57402. another place, and Chichagov should have crossed (more than knee-deep
57403. in snow) to somewhere else, and how so-and-so "routed" and "cut off" the
57404. French and so on and so on.
57405. 
57406. The Russians, half of whom died, did all that could and should have been
57407. done to attain an end worthy of the nation, and they are not to blame
57408. because other Russians, sitting in warm rooms, proposed that they should
57409. do what was impossible.
57410. 
57411. All that strange contradiction now difficult to understand between the
57412. facts and the historical accounts only arises because the historians
57413. dealing with the matter have written the history of the beautiful words
57414. and sentiments of various generals, and not the history of the events.
57415. 
57416. To them the words of Miloradovich seem very interesting, and so do their
57417. surmises and the rewards this or that general received; but the question
57418. of those fifty thousand men who were left in hospitals and in graves
57419. does not even interest them, for it does not come within the range of
57420. their investigation.
57421. 
57422. Yet one need only discard the study of the reports and general plans and
57423. consider the movement of those hundreds of thousands of men who took a
57424. direct part in the events, and all the questions that seemed insoluble
57425. easily and simply receive an immediate and certain solution.
57426. 
57427. The aim of cutting off Napoleon and his army never existed except in
57428. the imaginations of a dozen people. It could not exist because it was
57429. senseless and unattainable.
57430. 
57431. The people had a single aim: to free their land from invasion. That aim
57432. was attained in the first place of itself, as the French ran away,
57433. and so it was only necessary not to stop their flight. Secondly it was
57434. attained by the guerrilla warfare which was destroying the French, and
57435. thirdly by the fact that a large Russian army was following the French,
57436. ready to use its strength in case their movement stopped.
57437. 
57438. The Russian army had to act like a whip to a running animal. And the
57439. experienced driver knew it was better to hold the whip raised as a
57440. menace than to strike the running animal on the head.
57441. 
57442. 
57443. 
57444. 
57445. 
57446. BOOK FIFTEEN: 1812 - 13
57447. 
57448. 
57449. 
57450. 
57451. 
57452. CHAPTER I
57453. 
57454. 
57455. When seeing a dying animal a man feels a sense of horror: substance
57456. similar to his own is perishing before his eyes. But when it is a
57457. beloved and intimate human being that is dying, besides this horror at
57458. the extinction of life there is a severance, a spiritual wound, which
57459. like a physical wound is sometimes fatal and sometimes heals, but always
57460. aches and shrinks at any external irritating touch.
57461. 
57462. After Prince Andrew's death Natasha and Princess Mary alike felt this.
57463. Drooping in spirit and closing their eyes before the menacing cloud of
57464. death that overhung them, they dared not look life in the face. They
57465. carefully guarded their open wounds from any rough and painful contact.
57466. Everything: a carriage passing rapidly in the street, a summons to
57467. dinner, the maid's inquiry what dress to prepare, or worse still any
57468. word of insincere or feeble sympathy, seemed an insult, painfully
57469. irritated the wound, interrupting that necessary quiet in which
57470. they both tried to listen to the stern and dreadful choir that still
57471. resounded in their imagination, and hindered their gazing into those
57472. mysterious limitless vistas that for an instant had opened out before
57473. them.
57474. 
57475. Only when alone together were they free from such outrage and pain.
57476. They spoke little even to one another, and when they did it was of very
57477. unimportant matters.
57478. 
57479. Both avoided any allusion to the future. To admit the possibility of
57480. a future seemed to them to insult his memory. Still more carefully did
57481. they avoid anything relating to him who was dead. It seemed to them that
57482. what they had lived through and experienced could not be expressed in
57483. words, and that any reference to the details of his life infringed the
57484. majesty and sacredness of the mystery that had been accomplished before
57485. their eyes.
57486. 
57487. Continued abstention from speech, and constant avoidance of everything
57488. that might lead up to the subject--this halting on all sides at the
57489. boundary of what they might not mention--brought before their minds with
57490. still greater purity and clearness what they were both feeling.
57491. 
57492. But pure and complete sorrow is as impossible as pure and complete joy.
57493. Princess Mary, in her position as absolute and independent arbiter of
57494. her own fate and guardian and instructor of her nephew, was the first to
57495. be called back to life from that realm of sorrow in which she had dwelt
57496. for the first fortnight. She received letters from her relations to
57497. which she had to reply; the room in which little Nicholas had been put
57498. was damp and he began to cough; Alpatych came to Yaroslavl with reports
57499. on the state of their affairs and with advice and suggestions that they
57500. should return to Moscow to the house on the Vozdvizhenka Street, which
57501. had remained uninjured and needed only slight repairs. Life did not
57502. stand still and it was necessary to live. Hard as it was for Princess
57503. Mary to emerge from the realm of secluded contemplation in which she
57504. had lived till then, and sorry and almost ashamed as she felt to leave
57505. Natasha alone, yet the cares of life demanded her attention and she
57506. involuntarily yielded to them. She went through the accounts with
57507. Alpatych, conferred with Dessalles about her nephew, and gave orders and
57508. made preparations for the journey to Moscow.
57509. 
57510. Natasha remained alone and, from the time Princess Mary began making
57511. preparations for departure, held aloof from her too.
57512. 
57513. Princess Mary asked the countess to let Natasha go with her to Moscow,
57514. and both parents gladly accepted this offer, for they saw their daughter
57515. losing strength every day and thought that a change of scene and the
57516. advice of Moscow doctors would be good for her.
57517. 
57518. "I am not going anywhere," Natasha replied when this was proposed to
57519. her. "Do please just leave me alone!" And she ran out of the room, with
57520. difficulty refraining from tears of vexation and irritation rather than
57521. of sorrow.
57522. 
57523. After she felt herself deserted by Princes Mary and alone in her grief,
57524. Natasha spent most of the time in her room by herself, sitting huddled
57525. up feet and all in the corner of the sofa, tearing and twisting
57526. something with her slender nervous fingers and gazing intently and
57527. fixedly at whatever her eyes chanced to fall on. This solitude exhausted
57528. and tormented her but she was in absolute need of it. As soon as anyone
57529. entered she got up quickly, changed her position and expression, and
57530. picked up a book or some sewing, evidently waiting impatiently for the
57531. intruder to go.
57532. 
57533. She felt all the time as if she might at any moment penetrate that
57534. on which--with a terrible questioning too great for her strength--her
57535. spiritual gaze was fixed.
57536. 
57537. One day toward the end of December Natasha, pale and thin, dressed in a
57538. black woolen gown, her plaited hair negligently twisted into a knot, was
57539. crouched feet and all in the corner of her sofa, nervously crumpling and
57540. smoothing out the end of her sash while she looked at a corner of the
57541. door.
57542. 
57543. She was gazing in the direction in which he had gone--to the other side
57544. of life. And that other side of life, of which she had never before
57545. thought and which had formerly seemed to her so far away and improbable,
57546. was now nearer and more akin and more comprehensible than this side of
57547. life, where everything was either emptiness and desolation or suffering
57548. and indignity.
57549. 
57550. She was gazing where she knew him to be; but she could not imagine him
57551. otherwise than as he had been here. She now saw him again as he had been
57552. at Mytishchi, at Troitsa, and at Yaroslavl.
57553. 
57554. She saw his face, heard his voice, repeated his words and her own, and
57555. sometimes devised other words they might have spoken.
57556. 
57557. There he is lying back in an armchair in his velvet cloak, leaning
57558. his head on his thin pale hand. His chest is dreadfully hollow and his
57559. shoulders raised. His lips are firmly closed, his eyes glitter, and a
57560. wrinkle comes and goes on his pale forehead. One of his legs twitches
57561. just perceptibly, but rapidly. Natasha knows that he is struggling with
57562. terrible pain. "What is that pain like? Why does he have that pain? What
57563. does he feel? How does it hurt him?" thought Natasha. He noticed her
57564. watching him, raised his eyes, and began to speak seriously:
57565. 
57566. "One thing would be terrible," said he: "to bind oneself forever to a
57567. suffering man. It would be continual torture." And he looked searchingly
57568. at her. Natasha as usual answered before she had time to think what
57569. she would say. She said: "This can't go on--it won't. You will get
57570. well--quite well."
57571. 
57572. She now saw him from the commencement of that scene and relived what she
57573. had then felt. She recalled his long sad and severe look at those words
57574. and understood the meaning of the rebuke and despair in that protracted
57575. gaze.
57576. 
57577. "I agreed," Natasha now said to herself, "that it would be dreadful if
57578. he always continued to suffer. I said it then only because it would have
57579. been dreadful for him, but he understood it differently. He thought it
57580. would be dreadful for me. He then still wished to live and feared death.
57581. And I said it so awkwardly and stupidly! I did not say what I meant.
57582. I thought quite differently. Had I said what I thought, I should have
57583. said: even if he had to go on dying, to die continually before my eyes,
57584. I should have been happy compared with what I am now. Now there is
57585. nothing... nobody. Did he know that? No, he did not and never will know
57586. it. And now it will never, never be possible to put it right." And
57587. now he again seemed to be saying the same words to her, only in her
57588. imagination Natasha this time gave him a different answer. She stopped
57589. him and said: "Terrible for you, but not for me! You know that for me
57590. there is nothing in life but you, and to suffer with you is the greatest
57591. happiness for me," and he took her hand and pressed it as he had
57592. pressed it that terrible evening four days before his death. And in her
57593. imagination she said other tender and loving words which she might have
57594. said then but only spoke now: "I love thee!... thee! I love, love..."
57595. she said, convulsively pressing her hands and setting her teeth with a
57596. desperate effort...
57597. 
57598. She was overcome by sweet sorrow and tears were already rising in her
57599. eyes; then she suddenly asked herself to whom she was saying this.
57600. Again everything was shrouded in hard, dry perplexity, and again with a
57601. strained frown she peered toward the world where he was. And now, now
57602. it seemed to her she was penetrating the mystery.... But at the instant
57603. when it seemed that the incomprehensible was revealing itself to her a
57604. loud rattle of the door handle struck painfully on her ears. Dunyasha,
57605. her maid, entered the room quickly and abruptly with a frightened look
57606. on her face and showing no concern for her mistress.
57607. 
57608. "Come to your Papa at once, please!" said she with a strange, excited
57609. look. "A misfortune... about Peter Ilynich... a letter," she finished
57610. with a sob.
57611. 
57612. 
57613. 
57614. 
57615. 
57616. CHAPTER II
57617. 
57618. 
57619. Besides a feeling of aloofness from everybody Natasha was feeling
57620. a special estrangement from the members of her own family. All of
57621. them--her father, mother, and Sonya--were so near to her, so familiar,
57622. so commonplace, that all their words and feelings seemed an insult to
57623. the world in which she had been living of late, and she felt not
57624. merely indifferent to them but regarded them with hostility. She heard
57625. Dunyasha's words about Peter Ilynich and a misfortune, but did not grasp
57626. them.
57627. 
57628. "What misfortune? What misfortune can happen to them? They just live
57629. their own old, quiet, and commonplace life," thought Natasha.
57630. 
57631. As she entered the ballroom her father was hurriedly coming out of
57632. her mother's room. His face was puckered up and wet with tears. He
57633. had evidently run out of that room to give vent to the sobs that were
57634. choking him. When he saw Natasha he waved his arms despairingly and
57635. burst into convulsively painful sobs that distorted his soft round face.
57636. 
57637. "Pe... Petya... Go, go, she... is calling..." and weeping like a child
57638. and quickly shuffling on his feeble legs to a chair, he almost fell into
57639. it, covering his face with his hands.
57640. 
57641. Suddenly an electric shock seemed to run through Natasha's whole being.
57642. Terrible anguish struck her heart, she felt a dreadful ache as if
57643. something was being torn inside her and she were dying. But the pain
57644. was immediately followed by a feeling of release from the oppressive
57645. constraint that had prevented her taking part in life. The sight of her
57646. father, the terribly wild cries of her mother that she heard through the
57647. door, made her immediately forget herself and her own grief.
57648. 
57649. She ran to her father, but he feebly waved his arm, pointing to her
57650. mother's door. Princess Mary, pale and with quivering chin, came out
57651. from that room and taking Natasha by the arm said something to her.
57652. Natasha neither saw nor heard her. She went in with rapid steps, pausing
57653. at the door for an instant as if struggling with herself, and then ran
57654. to her mother.
57655. 
57656. The countess was lying in an armchair in a strange and awkward position,
57657. stretching out and beating her head against the wall. Sonya and the
57658. maids were holding her arms.
57659. 
57660. "Natasha! Natasha!..." cried the countess. "It's not true... it's not
57661. true... He's lying... Natasha!" she shrieked, pushing those around her
57662. away. "Go away, all of you; it's not true! Killed!... ha, ha, ha!...
57663. It's not true!"
57664. 
57665. Natasha put one knee on the armchair, stooped over her mother, embraced
57666. her, and with unexpected strength raised her, turned her face toward
57667. herself, and clung to her.
57668. 
57669. "Mummy!... darling!... I am here, my dearest Mummy," she kept on
57670. whispering, not pausing an instant.
57671. 
57672. She did not let go of her mother but struggled tenderly with her,
57673. demanded a pillow and hot water, and unfastened and tore open her
57674. mother's dress.
57675. 
57676. "My dearest darling... Mummy, my precious!..." she whispered
57677. incessantly, kissing her head, her hands, her face, and feeling her own
57678. irrepressible and streaming tears tickling her nose and cheeks.
57679. 
57680. The countess pressed her daughter's hand, closed her eyes, and became
57681. quiet for a moment. Suddenly she sat up with unaccustomed swiftness,
57682. glanced vacantly around her, and seeing Natasha began to press her
57683. daughter's head with all her strength. Then she turned toward her
57684. daughter's face which was wincing with pain and gazed long at it.
57685. 
57686. "Natasha, you love me?" she said in a soft trustful whisper. "Natasha,
57687. you would not deceive me? You'll tell me the whole truth?"
57688. 
57689. Natasha looked at her with eyes full of tears and in her look there was
57690. nothing but love and an entreaty for forgiveness.
57691. 
57692. "My darling Mummy!" she repeated, straining all the power of her love to
57693. find some way of taking on herself the excess of grief that crushed her
57694. mother.
57695. 
57696. And again in a futile struggle with reality her mother, refusing to
57697. believe that she could live when her beloved boy was killed in the bloom
57698. of life, escaped from reality into a world of delirium.
57699. 
57700. Natasha did not remember how that day passed nor that night, nor the
57701. next day and night. She did not sleep and did not leave her mother. Her
57702. persevering and patient love seemed completely to surround the countess
57703. every moment, not explaining or consoling, but recalling her to life.
57704. 
57705. During the third night the countess kept very quiet for a few minutes,
57706. and Natasha rested her head on the arm of her chair and closed her eyes,
57707. but opened them again on hearing the bedstead creak. The countess was
57708. sitting up in bed and speaking softly.
57709. 
57710. "How glad I am you have come. You are tired. Won't you have some tea?"
57711. Natasha went up to her. "You have improved in looks and grown more
57712. manly," continued the countess, taking her daughter's hand.
57713. 
57714. "Mamma! What are you saying..."
57715. 
57716. "Natasha, he is no more, no more!"
57717. 
57718. And embracing her daughter, the countess began to weep for the first
57719. time.
57720. 
57721. 
57722. 
57723. 
57724. 
57725. CHAPTER III
57726. 
57727. 
57728. Princess Mary postponed her departure. Sonya and the count tried to
57729. replace Natasha but could not. They saw that she alone was able to
57730. restrain her mother from unreasoning despair. For three weeks Natasha
57731. remained constantly at her mother's side, sleeping on a lounge chair
57732. in her room, making her eat and drink, and talking to her incessantly
57733. because the mere sound of her tender, caressing tones soothed her
57734. mother.
57735. 
57736. The mother's wounded spirit could not heal. Petya's death had torn from
57737. her half her life. When the news of Petya's death had come she had been
57738. a fresh and vigorous woman of fifty, but a month later she left her room
57739. a listless old woman taking no interest in life. But the same blow that
57740. almost killed the countess, this second blow, restored Natasha to life.
57741. 
57742. A spiritual wound produced by a rending of the spiritual body is like
57743. a physical wound and, strange as it may seem, just as a deep wound may
57744. heal and its edges join, physical and spiritual wounds alike can yet
57745. heal completely only as the result of a vital force from within.
57746. 
57747. Natasha's wound healed in that way. She thought her life was ended,
57748. but her love for her mother unexpectedly showed her that the essence of
57749. life--love--was still active within her. Love awoke and so did life.
57750. 
57751. Prince Andrew's last days had bound Princess Mary and Natasha together;
57752. this new sorrow brought them still closer to one another. Princess Mary
57753. put off her departure, and for three weeks looked after Natasha as if
57754. she had been a sick child. The last weeks passed in her mother's bedroom
57755. had strained Natasha's physical strength.
57756. 
57757. One afternoon noticing Natasha shivering with fever, Princess Mary took
57758. her to her own room and made her lie down on the bed. Natasha lay down,
57759. but when Princess Mary had drawn the blinds and was going away she
57760. called her back.
57761. 
57762. "I don't want to sleep, Mary, sit by me a little."
57763. 
57764. "You are tired--try to sleep."
57765. 
57766. "No, no. Why did you bring me away? She will be asking for me."
57767. 
57768. "She is much better. She spoke so well today," said Princess Mary.
57769. 
57770. Natasha lay on the bed and in the semidarkness of the room scanned
57771. Princess Mary's face.
57772. 
57773. "Is she like him?" thought Natasha. "Yes, like and yet not like. But she
57774. is quite original, strange, new, and unknown. And she loves me. What
57775. is in her heart? All that is good. But how? What is her mind like? What
57776. does she think about me? Yes, she is splendid!"
57777. 
57778. "Mary," she said timidly, drawing Princess Mary's hand to herself,
57779. "Mary, you mustn't think me wicked. No? Mary darling, how I love you!
57780. Let us be quite, quite friends."
57781. 
57782. And Natasha, embracing her, began kissing her face and hands, making
57783. Princess Mary feel shy but happy by this demonstration of her feelings.
57784. 
57785. From that day a tender and passionate friendship such as exists only
57786. between women was established between Princess Mary and Natasha. They
57787. were continually kissing and saying tender things to one another and
57788. spent most of their time together. When one went out the other became
57789. restless and hastened to rejoin her. Together they felt more in harmony
57790. with one another than either of them felt with herself when alone. A
57791. feeling stronger than friendship sprang up between them; an exclusive
57792. feeling of life being possible only in each other's presence.
57793. 
57794. Sometimes they were silent for hours; sometimes after they were already
57795. in bed they would begin talking and go on till morning. They spoke most
57796. of what was long past. Princess Mary spoke of her childhood, of her
57797. mother, her father, and her daydreams; and Natasha, who with a passive
57798. lack of understanding had formerly turned away from that life of
57799. devotion, submission, and the poetry of Christian self-sacrifice, now
57800. feeling herself bound to Princess Mary by affection, learned to love her
57801. past too and to understand a side of life previously incomprehensible to
57802. her. She did not think of applying submission and self-abnegation to her
57803. own life, for she was accustomed to seek other joys, but she understood
57804. and loved in another those previously incomprehensible virtues. For
57805. Princess Mary, listening to Natasha's tales of childhood and early
57806. youth, there also opened out a new and hitherto uncomprehended side of
57807. life: belief in life and its enjoyment.
57808. 
57809. Just as before, they never mentioned him so as not to lower (as they
57810. thought) their exalted feelings by words; but this silence about him had
57811. the effect of making them gradually begin to forget him without being
57812. conscious of it.
57813. 
57814. Natasha had grown thin and pale and physically so weak that they all
57815. talked about her health, and this pleased her. But sometimes she was
57816. suddenly overcome by fear not only of death but of sickness, weakness,
57817. and loss of good looks, and involuntarily she examined her bare arm
57818. carefully, surprised at its thinness, and in the morning noticed her
57819. drawn and, as it seemed to her, piteous face in her glass. It seemed to
57820. her that things must be so, and yet it was dreadfully sad.
57821. 
57822. One day she went quickly upstairs and found herself out of breath.
57823. Unconsciously she immediately invented a reason for going down, and
57824. then, testing her strength, ran upstairs again, observing the result.
57825. 
57826. Another time when she called Dunyasha her voice trembled, so she called
57827. again--though she could hear Dunyasha coming--called her in the deep
57828. chest tones in which she had been wont to sing, and listened attentively
57829. to herself.
57830. 
57831. She did not know and would not have believed it, but beneath the layer
57832. of slime that covered her soul and seemed to her impenetrable, delicate
57833. young shoots of grass were already sprouting, which taking root would so
57834. cover with their living verdure the grief that weighed her down that
57835. it would soon no longer be seen or noticed. The wound had begun to heal
57836. from within.
57837. 
57838. At the end of January Princess Mary left for Moscow, and the count
57839. insisted on Natasha's going with her to consult the doctors.
57840. 
57841. 
57842. 
57843. 
57844. 
57845. CHAPTER IV
57846. 
57847. 
57848. After the encounter at Vyazma, where Kutuzov had been unable to hold
57849. back his troops in their anxiety to overwhelm and cut off the enemy and
57850. so on, the farther movement of the fleeing French, and of the Russians
57851. who pursued them, continued as far as Krasnoe without a battle. The
57852. flight was so rapid that the Russian army pursuing the French could
57853. not keep up with them; cavalry and artillery horses broke down, and the
57854. information received of the movements of the French was never reliable.
57855. 
57856. The men in the Russian army were so worn out by this continuous marching
57857. at the rate of twenty-seven miles a day that they could not go any
57858. faster.
57859. 
57860. To realize the degree of exhaustion of the Russian army it is only
57861. necessary to grasp clearly the meaning of the fact that, while not
57862. losing more than five thousand killed and wounded after Tarutino and
57863. less than a hundred prisoners, the Russian army which left that place a
57864. hundred thousand strong reached Krasnoe with only fifty thousand.
57865. 
57866. The rapidity of the Russian pursuit was just as destructive to our army
57867. as the flight of the French was to theirs. The only difference was that
57868. the Russian army moved voluntarily, with no such threat of destruction
57869. as hung over the French, and that the sick Frenchmen were left behind
57870. in enemy hands while the sick Russians left behind were among their
57871. own people. The chief cause of the wastage of Napoleon's army was
57872. the rapidity of its movement, and a convincing proof of this is the
57873. corresponding decrease of the Russian army.
57874. 
57875. Kutuzov as far as was in his power, instead of trying to check the
57876. movement of the French as was desired in Petersburg and by the Russian
57877. army generals, directed his whole activity here, as he had done at
57878. Tarutino and Vyazma, to hastening it on while easing the movement of our
57879. army.
57880. 
57881. But besides this, since the exhaustion and enormous diminution of the
57882. army caused by the rapidity of the advance had become evident, another
57883. reason for slackening the pace and delaying presented itself to Kutuzov.
57884. The aim of the Russian army was to pursue the French. The road the
57885. French would take was unknown, and so the closer our troops trod on
57886. their heels the greater distance they had to cover. Only by following
57887. at some distance could one cut across the zigzag path of the French. All
57888. the artful maneuvers suggested by our generals meant fresh movements of
57889. the army and a lengthening of its marches, whereas the only reasonable
57890. aim was to shorten those marches. To that end Kutuzov's activity was
57891. directed during the whole campaign from Moscow to Vilna--not casually or
57892. intermittently but so consistently that he never once deviated from it.
57893. 
57894. Kutuzov felt and knew--not by reasoning or science but with the whole of
57895. his Russian being--what every Russian soldier felt: that the French were
57896. beaten, that the enemy was flying and must be driven out; but at the
57897. same time he like the soldiers realized all the hardship of this march,
57898. the rapidity of which was unparalleled for such a time of the year.
57899. 
57900. But to the generals, especially the foreign ones in the Russian army,
57901. who wished to distinguish themselves, to astonish somebody, and for some
57902. reason to capture a king or a duke--it seemed that now--when any battle
57903. must be horrible and senseless--was the very time to fight and conquer
57904. somebody. Kutuzov merely shrugged his shoulders when one after
57905. another they presented projects of maneuvers to be made with those
57906. soldiers--ill-shod, insufficiently clad, and half starved--who within a
57907. month and without fighting a battle had dwindled to half their number,
57908. and who at the best if the flight continued would have to go a greater
57909. distance than they had already traversed, before they reached the
57910. frontier.
57911. 
57912. This longing to distinguish themselves, to maneuver, to overthrow, and
57913. to cut off showed itself particularly whenever the Russians stumbled on
57914. the French army.
57915. 
57916. So it was at Krasnoe, where they expected to find one of the three
57917. French columns and stumbled instead on Napoleon himself with sixteen
57918. thousand men. Despite all Kutuzov's efforts to avoid that ruinous
57919. encounter and to preserve his troops, the massacre of the broken mob
57920. of French soldiers by worn-out Russians continued at Krasnoe for three
57921. days.
57922. 
57923. Toll wrote a disposition: "The first column will march to so and so,"
57924. etc. And as usual nothing happened in accord with the disposition.
57925. Prince Eugene of Wurttemberg fired from a hill over the French crowds
57926. that were running past, and demanded reinforcements which did not
57927. arrive. The French, avoiding the Russians, dispersed and hid themselves
57928. in the forest by night, making their way round as best they could, and
57929. continued their flight.
57930. 
57931. Miloradovich, who said he did not want to know anything about the
57932. commissariat affairs of his detachment, and could never be found when
57933. he was wanted--that chevalier sans peur et sans reproche * as he styled
57934. himself--who was fond of parleys with the French, sent envoys demanding
57935. their surrender, wasted time, and did not do what he was ordered to do.
57936. 
57937. 
57938.     * Knight without fear and without reproach.
57939. 
57940. 
57941. "I give you that column, lads," he said, riding up to the troops and
57942. pointing out the French to the cavalry.
57943. 
57944. And the cavalry, with spurs and sabers urging on horses that could
57945. scarcely move, trotted with much effort to the column presented
57946. to them--that is to say, to a crowd of Frenchmen stark with cold,
57947. frost-bitten, and starving--and the column that had been presented to
57948. them threw down its arms and surrendered as it had long been anxious to
57949. do.
57950. 
57951. At Krasnoe they took twenty-six thousand prisoners, several hundred
57952. cannon, and a stick called a "marshal's staff," and disputed as to
57953. who had distinguished himself and were pleased with their
57954. achievement--though they much regretted not having taken Napoleon, or at
57955. least a marshal or a hero of some sort, and reproached one another and
57956. especially Kutuzov for having failed to do so.
57957. 
57958. These men, carried away by their passions, were but blind tools of the
57959. most melancholy law of necessity, but considered themselves heroes and
57960. imagined that they were accomplishing a most noble and honorable
57961. deed. They blamed Kutuzov and said that from the very beginning of the
57962. campaign he had prevented their vanquishing Napoleon, that he thought of
57963. nothing but satisfying his passions and would not advance from the Linen
57964. Factories because he was comfortable there, that at Krasnoe he checked
57965. the advance because on learning that Napoleon was there he had quite
57966. lost his head, and that it was probable that he had an understanding
57967. with Napoleon and had been bribed by him, and so on, and so on.
57968. 
57969. Not only did his contemporaries, carried away by their passions, talk
57970. in this way, but posterity and history have acclaimed Napoleon as grand,
57971. while Kutuzov is described by foreigners as a crafty, dissolute, weak
57972. old courtier, and by Russians as something indefinite--a sort of puppet
57973. useful only because he had a Russian name.
57974. 
57975. 
57976. 
57977. 
57978. 
57979. CHAPTER V
57980. 
57981. 
57982. In 1812 and 1813 Kutuzov was openly accused of blundering. The Emperor
57983. was dissatisfied with him. And in a history recently written by order
57984. of the Highest Authorities it is said that Kutuzov was a cunning court
57985. liar, frightened of the name of Napoleon, and that by his blunders at
57986. Krasnoe and the Berezina he deprived the Russian army of the glory of
57987. complete victory over the French. *
57988. 
57989. 
57990.      * History of the year 1812. The character of Kutuzov and
57991.      reflections on the unsatisfactory results of the battles at
57992.      Krasnoe, by Bogdanovich.
57993. 
57994. 
57995. Such is the fate not of great men (grands hommes) whom the Russian mind
57996. does not acknowledge, but of those rare and always solitary individuals
57997. who, discerning the will of Providence, submit their personal will to
57998. it. The hatred and contempt of the crowd punish such men for discerning
57999. the higher laws.
58000. 
58001. For Russian historians, strange and terrible to say, Napoleon--that most
58002. insignificant tool of history who never anywhere, even in exile, showed
58003. human dignity--Napoleon is the object of adulation and enthusiasm; he
58004. is grand. But Kutuzov--the man who from the beginning to the end of his
58005. activity in 1812, never once swerving by word or deed from Borodino to
58006. Vilna, presented an example exceptional in history of self-sacrifice
58007. and a present consciousness of the future importance of what was
58008. happening--Kutuzov seems to them something indefinite and pitiful, and
58009. when speaking of him and of the year 1812 they always seem a little
58010. ashamed.
58011. 
58012. And yet it is difficult to imagine an historical character whose
58013. activity was so unswervingly directed to a single aim; and it would be
58014. difficult to imagine any aim more worthy or more consonant with the
58015. will of the whole people. Still more difficult would it be to find
58016. an instance in history of the aim of an historical personage being so
58017. completely accomplished as that to which all Kutuzov's efforts were
58018. directed in 1812.
58019. 
58020. Kutuzov never talked of "forty centuries looking down from the
58021. Pyramids," of the sacrifices he offered for the fatherland, or of
58022. what he intended to accomplish or had accomplished; in general he said
58023. nothing about himself, adopted no prose, always appeared to be the
58024. simplest and most ordinary of men, and said the simplest and most
58025. ordinary things. He wrote letters to his daughters and to Madame de
58026. Stael, read novels, liked the society of pretty women, jested with
58027. generals, officers, and soldiers, and never contradicted those who tried
58028. to prove anything to him. When Count Rostopchin at the Yauza bridge
58029. galloped up to Kutuzov with personal reproaches for having caused the
58030. destruction of Moscow, and said: "How was it you promised not to abandon
58031. Moscow without a battle?" Kutuzov replied: "And I shall not abandon
58032. Moscow without a battle," though Moscow was then already abandoned. When
58033. Arakcheev, coming to him from the Emperor, said that Ermolov ought to
58034. be appointed chief of the artillery, Kutuzov replied: "Yes, I was
58035. just saying so myself," though a moment before he had said quite the
58036. contrary. What did it matter to him--who then alone amid a senseless
58037. crowd understood the whole tremendous significance of what was
58038. happening--what did it matter to him whether Rostopchin attributed the
58039. calamities of Moscow to him or to himself? Still less could it matter to
58040. him who was appointed chief of the artillery.
58041. 
58042. Not merely in these cases but continually did that old man--who by
58043. experience of life had reached the conviction that thoughts and the
58044. words serving as their expression are not what move people--use quite
58045. meaningless words that happened to enter his head.
58046. 
58047. But that man, so heedless of his words, did not once during the whole
58048. time of his activity utter one word inconsistent with the single aim
58049. toward which he moved throughout the whole war. Obviously in spite of
58050. himself, in very diverse circumstances, he repeatedly expressed his real
58051. thoughts with the bitter conviction that he would not be understood.
58052. Beginning with the battle of Borodino, from which time his disagreement
58053. with those about him began, he alone said that the battle of Borodino
58054. was a victory, and repeated this both verbally and in his dispatches
58055. and reports up to the time of his death. He alone said that the loss of
58056. Moscow is not the loss of Russia. In reply to Lauriston's proposal of
58057. peace, he said: There can be no peace, for such is the people's will. He
58058. alone during the retreat of the French said that all our maneuvers are
58059. useless, everything is being accomplished of itself better than we could
58060. desire; that the enemy must be offered "a golden bridge"; that neither
58061. the Tarutino, the Vyazma, nor the Krasnoe battles were necessary; that
58062. we must keep some force to reach the frontier with, and that he would
58063. not sacrifice a single Russian for ten Frenchmen.
58064. 
58065. And this courtier, as he is described to us, who lies to Arakcheev
58066. to please the Emperor, he alone--incurring thereby the Emperor's
58067. displeasure--said in Vilna that to carry the war beyond the frontier is
58068. useless and harmful.
58069. 
58070. Nor do words alone prove that only he understood the meaning of the
58071. events. His actions--without the smallest deviation--were all directed
58072. to one and the same threefold end: (1) to brace all his strength for
58073. conflict with the French, (2) to defeat them, and (3) to drive them out
58074. of Russia, minimizing as far as possible the sufferings of our people
58075. and of our army.
58076. 
58077. This procrastinator Kutuzov, whose motto was "Patience and Time,"
58078. this enemy of decisive action, gave battle at Borodino, investing the
58079. preparations for it with unparalleled solemnity. This Kutuzov who before
58080. the battle of Austerlitz began said that it would be lost, he alone, in
58081. contradiction to everyone else, declared till his death that Borodino
58082. was a victory, despite the assurance of generals that the battle was
58083. lost and despite the fact that for an army to have to retire after
58084. winning a battle was unprecedented. He alone during the whole retreat
58085. insisted that battles, which were useless then, should not be fought,
58086. and that a new war should not be begun nor the frontiers of Russia
58087. crossed.
58088. 
58089. It is easy now to understand the significance of these events--if
58090. only we abstain from attributing to the activity of the mass aims that
58091. existed only in the heads of a dozen individuals--for the events and
58092. results now lie before us.
58093. 
58094. But how did that old man, alone, in opposition to the general opinion,
58095. so truly discern the importance of the people's view of the events that
58096. in all his activity he was never once untrue to it?
58097. 
58098. The source of that extraordinary power of penetrating the meaning of the
58099. events then occuring lay in the national feeling which he possessed in
58100. full purity and strength.
58101. 
58102. Only the recognition of the fact that he possessed this feeling caused
58103. the people in so strange a manner, contrary to the Tsar's wish, to
58104. select him--an old man in disfavor--to be their representative in the
58105. national war. And only that feeling placed him on that highest human
58106. pedestal from which he, the commander in chief, devoted all his powers
58107. not to slaying and destroying men but to saving and showing pity on
58108. them.
58109. 
58110. That simple, modest, and therefore truly great, figure could not be cast
58111. in the false mold of a European hero--the supposed ruler of men--that
58112. history has invented.
58113. 
58114. To a lackey no man can be great, for a lackey has his own conception of
58115. greatness.
58116. 
58117. 
58118. 
58119. 
58120. 
58121. CHAPTER VI
58122. 
58123. 
58124. The fifth of November was the first day of what is called the battle of
58125. Krasnoe. Toward evening--after much disputing and many mistakes made by
58126. generals who did not go to their proper places, and after adjutants had
58127. been sent about with counterorders--when it had become plain that the
58128. enemy was everywhere in flight and that there could and would be no
58129. battle, Kutuzov left Krasnoe and went to Dobroe whither his headquarters
58130. had that day been transferred.
58131. 
58132. The day was clear and frosty. Kutuzov rode to Dobroe on his plump little
58133. white horse, followed by an enormous suite of discontented generals who
58134. whispered among themselves behind his back. All along the road groups of
58135. French prisoners captured that day (there were seven thousand of them)
58136. were crowding to warm themselves at campfires. Near Dobroe an immense
58137. crowd of tattered prisoners, buzzing with talk and wrapped and bandaged
58138. in anything they had been able to get hold of, were standing in the road
58139. beside a long row of unharnessed French guns. At the approach of the
58140. commander in chief the buzz of talk ceased and all eyes were fixed on
58141. Kutuzov who, wearing a white cap with a red band and a padded overcoat
58142. that bulged on his round shoulders, moved slowly along the road on his
58143. white horse. One of the generals was reporting to him where the guns and
58144. prisoners had been captured.
58145. 
58146. Kutuzov seemed preoccupied and did not listen to what the general was
58147. saying. He screwed up his eyes with a dissatisfied look as he gazed
58148. attentively and fixedly at these prisoners, who presented a specially
58149. wretched appearance. Most of them were disfigured by frost-bitten noses
58150. and cheeks, and nearly all had red, swollen and festering eyes.
58151. 
58152. One group of the French stood close to the road, and two of them, one of
58153. whom had his face covered with sores, were tearing a piece of raw
58154. flesh with their hands. There was something horrible and bestial in
58155. the fleeting glance they threw at the riders and in the malevolent
58156. expression with which, after a glance at Kutuzov, the soldier with the
58157. sores immediately turned away and went on with what he was doing.
58158. 
58159. Kutuzov looked long and intently at these two soldiers. He puckered his
58160. face, screwed up his eyes, and pensively swayed his head. At another
58161. spot he noticed a Russian soldier laughingly patting a Frenchman on the
58162. shoulder, saying something to him in a friendly manner, and Kutuzov with
58163. the same expression on his face again swayed his head.
58164. 
58165. "What were you saying?" he asked the general, who continuing his report
58166. directed the commander in chief's attention to some standards captured
58167. from the French and standing in front of the Preobrazhensk regiment.
58168. 
58169. "Ah, the standards!" said Kutuzov, evidently detaching himself with
58170. difficulty from the thoughts that preoccupied him.
58171. 
58172. He looked about him absently. Thousands of eyes were looking at him from
58173. all sides awaiting a word from him.
58174. 
58175. He stopped in front of the Preobrazhensk regiment, sighed deeply, and
58176. closed his eyes. One of his suite beckoned to the soldiers carrying
58177. the standards to advance and surround the commander in chief with them.
58178. Kutuzov was silent for a few seconds and then, submitting with evident
58179. reluctance to the duty imposed by his position, raised his head
58180. and began to speak. A throng of officers surrounded him. He looked
58181. attentively around at the circle of officers, recognizing several of
58182. them.
58183. 
58184. "I thank you all!" he said, addressing the soldiers and then again the
58185. officers. In the stillness around him his slowly uttered words were
58186. distinctly heard. "I thank you all for your hard and faithful service.
58187. The victory is complete and Russia will not forget you! Honor to you
58188. forever."
58189. 
58190. He paused and looked around.
58191. 
58192. "Lower its head, lower it!" he said to a soldier who had accidentally
58193. lowered the French eagle he was holding before the Preobrazhensk
58194. standards. "Lower, lower, that's it. Hurrah lads!" he added, addressing
58195. the men with a rapid movement of his chin.
58196. 
58197. "Hur-r-rah!" roared thousands of voices.
58198. 
58199. While the soldiers were shouting Kutuzov leaned forward in his saddle
58200. and bowed his head, and his eye lit up with a mild and apparently ironic
58201. gleam.
58202. 
58203. "You see, brothers..." said he when the shouts had ceased... and all at
58204. once his voice and the expression of his face changed. It was no longer
58205. the commander in chief speaking but an ordinary old man who wanted to
58206. tell his comrades something very important.
58207. 
58208. There was a stir among the throng of officers and in the ranks of the
58209. soldiers, who moved that they might hear better what he was going to
58210. say.
58211. 
58212. "You see, brothers, I know it's hard for you, but it can't be helped!
58213. Bear up; it won't be for long now! We'll see our visitors off and then
58214. we'll rest. The Tsar won't forget your service. It is hard for you, but
58215. still you are at home while they--you see what they have come to," said
58216. he, pointing to the prisoners. "Worse off than our poorest beggars.
58217. While they were strong we didn't spare ourselves, but now we may even
58218. pity them. They are human beings too. Isn't it so, lads?"
58219. 
58220. He looked around, and in the direct, respectful, wondering gaze fixed
58221. upon him he read sympathy with what he had said. His face grew brighter
58222. and brighter with an old man's mild smile, which drew the corners of his
58223. lips and eyes into a cluster of wrinkles. He ceased speaking and bowed
58224. his head as if in perplexity.
58225. 
58226. "But after all who asked them here? Serves them right, the bloody
58227. bastards!" he cried, suddenly lifting his head.
58228. 
58229. And flourishing his whip he rode off at a gallop for the first time
58230. during the whole campaign, and left the broken ranks of the soldiers
58231. laughing joyfully and shouting "Hurrah!"
58232. 
58233. Kutuzov's words were hardly understood by the troops. No one could have
58234. repeated the field marshal's address, begun solemnly and then changing
58235. into an old man's simplehearted talk; but the hearty sincerity of that
58236. speech, the feeling of majestic triumph combined with pity for the foe
58237. and consciousness of the justice of our cause, exactly expressed by that
58238. old man's good-natured expletives, was not merely understood but lay
58239. in the soul of every soldier and found expression in their joyous and
58240. long-sustained shouts. Afterwards when one of the generals addressed
58241. Kutuzov asking whether he wished his caleche to be sent for, Kutuzov in
58242. answering unexpectedly gave a sob, being evidently greatly moved.
58243. 
58244. 
58245. 
58246. 
58247. 
58248. CHAPTER VII
58249. 
58250. 
58251. When the troops reached their night's halting place on the eighth of
58252. November, the last day of the Krasnoe battles, it was already growing
58253. dusk. All day it had been calm and frosty with occasional lightly
58254. falling snow and toward evening it began to clear. Through the falling
58255. snow a purple-black and starry sky showed itself and the frost grew
58256. keener.
58257. 
58258. An infantry regiment which had left Tarutino three thousand strong but
58259. now numbered only nine hundred was one of the first to arrive that night
58260. at its halting place--a village on the highroad. The quartermasters who
58261. met the regiment announced that all the huts were full of sick and dead
58262. Frenchmen, cavalrymen, and members of the staff. There was only one hut
58263. available for the regimental commander.
58264. 
58265. The commander rode up to his hut. The regiment passed through the
58266. village and stacked its arms in front of the last huts.
58267. 
58268. Like some huge many-limbed animal, the regiment began to prepare its
58269. lair and its food. One part of it dispersed and waded knee-deep
58270. through the snow into a birch forest to the right of the village, and
58271. immediately the sound of axes and swords, the crashing of branches,
58272. and merry voices could be heard from there. Another section amid the
58273. regimental wagons and horses which were standing in a group was busy
58274. getting out caldrons and rye biscuit, and feeding the horses. A third
58275. section scattered through the village arranging quarters for the staff
58276. officers, carrying out the French corpses that were in the huts, and
58277. dragging away boards, dry wood, and thatch from the roofs, for the
58278. campfires, or wattle fences to serve for shelter.
58279. 
58280. Some fifteen men with merry shouts were shaking down the high wattle
58281. wall of a shed, the roof of which had already been removed.
58282. 
58283. "Now then, all together--shove!" cried the voices, and the huge surface
58284. of the wall, sprinkled with snow and creaking with frost, was seen
58285. swaying in the gloom of the night. The lower stakes cracked more and
58286. more and at last the wall fell, and with it the men who had been pushing
58287. it. Loud, coarse laughter and joyous shouts ensued.
58288. 
58289. "Now then, catch hold in twos! Hand up the lever! That's it... Where are
58290. you shoving to?"
58291. 
58292. "Now, all together! But wait a moment, boys... With a song!"
58293. 
58294. All stood silent, and a soft, pleasant velvety voice began to sing. At
58295. the end of the third verse as the last note died away, twenty voices
58296. roared out at once: "Oo-oo-oo-oo! That's it. All together! Heave away,
58297. boys!..." but despite their united efforts the wattle hardly moved, and
58298. in the silence that followed the heavy breathing of the men was audible.
58299. 
58300. "Here, you of the Sixth Company! Devils that you are! Lend a hand...
58301. will you? You may want us one of these days."
58302. 
58303. Some twenty men of the Sixth Company who were on their way into the
58304. village joined the haulers, and the wattle wall, which was about
58305. thirty-five feet long and seven feet high, moved forward along the
58306. village street, swaying, pressing upon and cutting the shoulders of the
58307. gasping men.
58308. 
58309. "Get along... Falling? What are you stopping for? There now..."
58310. 
58311. Merry senseless words of abuse flowed freely.
58312. 
58313. "What are you up to?" suddenly came the authoritative voice of a
58314. sergeant major who came upon the men who were hauling their burden.
58315. "There are gentry here; the general himself is in that hut, and you
58316. foul-mouthed devils, you brutes, I'll give it to you!" shouted he,
58317. hitting the first man who came in his way a swinging blow on the back.
58318. "Can't you make less noise?"
58319. 
58320. The men became silent. The soldier who had been struck groaned and wiped
58321. his face, which had been scratched till it bled by his falling against
58322. the wattle.
58323. 
58324. "There, how that devil hits out! He's made my face all bloody," said he
58325. in a frightened whisper when the sergeant major had passed on.
58326. 
58327. "Don't you like it?" said a laughing voice, and moderating their tones
58328. the men moved forward.
58329. 
58330. When they were out of the village they began talking again as loud as
58331. before, interlarding their talk with the same aimless expletives.
58332. 
58333. In the hut which the men had passed, the chief officers had gathered and
58334. were in animated talk over their tea about the events of the day and the
58335. maneuvers suggested for tomorrow. It was proposed to make a flank march
58336. to the left, cut off the Vice-King (Murat) and capture him.
58337. 
58338. By the time the soldiers had dragged the wattle fence to its place
58339. the campfires were blazing on all sides ready for cooking, the wood
58340. crackled, the snow was melting, and black shadows of soldiers flitted
58341. to and fro all over the occupied space where the snow had been trodden
58342. down.
58343. 
58344. Axes and choppers were plied all around. Everything was done without any
58345. orders being given. Stores of wood were brought for the night, shelters
58346. were rigged up for the officers, caldrons were being boiled, and muskets
58347. and accouterments put in order.
58348. 
58349. The wattle wall the men had brought was set up in a semicircle by the
58350. Eighth Company as a shelter from the north, propped up by musket rests,
58351. and a campfire was built before it. They beat the tattoo, called the
58352. roll, had supper, and settled down round the fires for the night--some
58353. repairing their footgear, some smoking pipes, and some stripping
58354. themselves naked to steam the lice out of their shirts.
58355. 
58356. 
58357. 
58358. 
58359. 
58360. CHAPTER VIII
58361. 
58362. 
58363. One would have thought that under the almost incredibly wretched
58364. conditions the Russian soldiers were in at that time--lacking warm boots
58365. and sheepskin coats, without a roof over their heads, in the snow
58366. with eighteen degrees of frost, and without even full rations (the
58367. commissariat did not always keep up with the troops)--they would have
58368. presented a very sad and depressing spectacle.
58369. 
58370. On the contrary, the army had never under the best material conditions
58371. presented a more cheerful and animated aspect. This was because all who
58372. began to grow depressed or who lost strength were sifted out of the army
58373. day by day. All the physically or morally weak had long since been
58374. left behind and only the flower of the army--physically and
58375. mentally--remained.
58376. 
58377. More men collected behind the wattle fence of the Eighth Company than
58378. anywhere else. Two sergeants major were sitting with them and their
58379. campfire blazed brighter than others. For leave to sit by their wattle
58380. they demanded contributions of fuel.
58381. 
58382. "Eh, Makeev! What has become of you, you son of a bitch? Are you lost or
58383. have the wolves eaten you? Fetch some more wood!" shouted a red-haired
58384. and red-faced man, screwing up his eyes and blinking because of the
58385. smoke but not moving back from the fire. "And you, Jackdaw, go and fetch
58386. some wood!" said he to another soldier.
58387. 
58388. This red-haired man was neither a sergeant nor a corporal, but being
58389. robust he ordered about those weaker than himself. The soldier
58390. they called "Jackdaw," a thin little fellow with a sharp nose, rose
58391. obediently and was about to go but at that instant there came into
58392. the light of the fire the slender, handsome figure of a young soldier
58393. carrying a load of wood.
58394. 
58395. "Bring it here--that's fine!"
58396. 
58397. They split up the wood, pressed it down on the fire, blew at it with
58398. their mouths, and fanned it with the skirts of their greatcoats, making
58399. the flames hiss and crackle. The men drew nearer and lit their pipes.
58400. The handsome young soldier who had brought the wood, setting his arms
58401. akimbo, began stamping his cold feet rapidly and deftly on the spot
58402. where he stood.
58403. 
58404. "Mother! The dew is cold but clear.... It's well that I'm a
58405. musketeer..." he sang, pretending to hiccough after each syllable.
58406. 
58407. "Look out, your soles will fly off!" shouted the red-haired man,
58408. noticing that the sole of the dancer's boot was hanging loose. "What a
58409. fellow you are for dancing!"
58410. 
58411. The dancer stopped, pulled off the loose piece of leather, and threw it
58412. on the fire.
58413. 
58414. "Right enough, friend," said he, and, having sat down, took out of his
58415. knapsack a scrap of blue French cloth, and wrapped it round his foot.
58416. "It's the steam that spoils them," he added, stretching out his feet
58417. toward the fire.
58418. 
58419. "They'll soon be issuing us new ones. They say that when we've finished
58420. hammering them, we're to receive double kits!"
58421. 
58422. "And that son of a bitch Petrov has lagged behind after all, it seems,"
58423. said one sergeant major.
58424. 
58425. "I've had an eye on him this long while," said the other.
58426. 
58427. "Well, he's a poor sort of soldier..."
58428.
