58429. "But in the Third Company they say nine men were missing yesterday."
58430. 
58431. "Yes, it's all very well, but when a man's feet are frozen how can he
58432. walk?"
58433. 
58434. "Eh? Don't talk nonsense!" said a sergeant major.
58435. 
58436. "Do you want to be doing the same?" said an old soldier, turning
58437. reproachfully to the man who had spoken of frozen feet.
58438. 
58439. "Well, you know," said the sharp-nosed man they called Jackdaw in a
58440. squeaky and unsteady voice, raising himself at the other side of the
58441. fire, "a plump man gets thin, but for a thin one it's death. Take
58442. me, now! I've got no strength left," he added, with sudden resolution
58443. turning to the sergeant major. "Tell them to send me to hospital; I'm
58444. aching all over; anyway I shan't be able to keep up."
58445. 
58446. "That'll do, that'll do!" replied the sergeant major quietly.
58447. 
58448. The soldier said no more and the talk went on.
58449. 
58450. "What a lot of those Frenchies were taken today, and the fact is that
58451. not one of them had what you might call real boots on," said a soldier,
58452. starting a new theme. "They were no more than make-believes."
58453. 
58454. "The Cossacks have taken their boots. They were clearing the hut for the
58455. colonel and carried them out. It was pitiful to see them, boys," put in
58456. the dancer. "As they turned them over one seemed still alive and, would
58457. you believe it, he jabbered something in their lingo."
58458. 
58459. "But they're a clean folk, lads," the first man went on; "he was
58460. white--as white as birchbark--and some of them are such fine fellows,
58461. you might think they were nobles."
58462. 
58463. "Well, what do you think? They make soldiers of all classes there."
58464. 
58465. "But they don't understand our talk at all," said the dancer with a
58466. puzzled smile. "I asked him whose subject he was, and he jabbered in his
58467. own way. A queer lot!"
58468. 
58469. "But it's strange, friends," continued the man who had wondered at their
58470. whiteness, "the peasants at Mozhaysk were saying that when they began
58471. burying the dead--where the battle was you know--well, those dead had
58472. been lying there for nearly a month, and says the peasant, 'they lie
58473. as white as paper, clean, and not as much smell as a puff of powder
58474. smoke.'"
58475. 
58476. "Was it from the cold?" asked someone.
58477. 
58478. "You're a clever fellow! From the cold indeed! Why, it was hot. If it
58479. had been from the cold, ours would not have rotted either. 'But,' he
58480. says, 'go up to ours and they are all rotten and maggoty. So,' he says,
58481. 'we tie our faces up with kerchiefs and turn our heads away as we drag
58482. them off: we can hardly do it. But theirs,' he says, 'are white as paper
58483. and not so much smell as a whiff of gunpowder.'"
58484. 
58485. All were silent.
58486. 
58487. "It must be from their food," said the sergeant major. "They used to
58488. gobble the same food as the gentry."
58489. 
58490. No one contradicted him.
58491. 
58492. "That peasant near Mozhaysk where the battle was said the men were all
58493. called up from ten villages around and they carted for twenty days and
58494. still didn't finish carting the dead away. And as for the wolves, he
58495. says..."
58496. 
58497. "That was a real battle," said an old soldier. "It's the only one worth
58498. remembering; but since that... it's only been tormenting folk."
58499. 
58500. "And do you know, Daddy, the day before yesterday we ran at them and,
58501. my word, they didn't let us get near before they just threw down their
58502. muskets and went on their knees. 'Pardon!' they say. That's only one
58503. case. They say Platov took 'Poleon himself twice. But he didn't know the
58504. right charm. He catches him and catches him--no good! He turns into
58505. a bird in his hands and flies away. And there's no way of killing him
58506. either."
58507. 
58508. "You're a first-class liar, Kiselev, when I come to look at you!"
58509. 
58510. "Liar, indeed! It's the real truth."
58511. 
58512. "If he fell into my hands, when I'd caught him I'd bury him in the
58513. ground with an aspen stake to fix him down. What a lot of men he's
58514. ruined!"
58515. 
58516. "Well, anyhow we're going to end it. He won't come here again," remarked
58517. the old soldier, yawning.
58518. 
58519. The conversation flagged, and the soldiers began settling down to sleep.
58520. 
58521. "Look at the stars. It's wonderful how they shine! You would think the
58522. women had spread out their linen," said one of the men, gazing with
58523. admiration at the Milky Way.
58524. 
58525. "That's a sign of a good harvest next year."
58526. 
58527. "We shall want some more wood."
58528. 
58529. "You warm your back and your belly gets frozen. That's queer."
58530. 
58531. "O Lord!"
58532. 
58533. "What are you pushing for? Is the fire only for you? Look how he's
58534. sprawling!"
58535. 
58536. In the silence that ensued, the snoring of those who had fallen asleep
58537. could be heard. Others turned over and warmed themselves, now and again
58538. exchanging a few words. From a campfire a hundred paces off came a sound
58539. of general, merry laughter.
58540. 
58541. "Hark at them roaring there in the Fifth Company!" said one of the
58542. soldiers, "and what a lot of them there are!"
58543. 
58544. One of the men got up and went over to the Fifth Company.
58545. 
58546. "They're having such fun," said he, coming back. "Two Frenchies have
58547. turned up. One's quite frozen and the other's an awful swaggerer. He's
58548. singing songs...."
58549. 
58550. "Oh, I'll go across and have a look...."
58551. 
58552. And several of the men went over to the Fifth Company.
58553. 
58554. 
58555. 
58556. 
58557. 
58558. CHAPTER IX
58559. 
58560. 
58561. The fifth company was bivouacking at the very edge of the forest. A huge
58562. campfire was blazing brightly in the midst of the snow, lighting up the
58563. branches of trees heavy with hoarfrost.
58564. 
58565. About midnight they heard the sound of steps in the snow of the forest,
58566. and the crackling of dry branches.
58567. 
58568. "A bear, lads," said one of the men.
58569. 
58570. They all raised their heads to listen, and out of the forest into the
58571. bright firelight stepped two strangely clad human figures clinging to
58572. one another.
58573. 
58574. These were two Frenchmen who had been hiding in the forest. They came up
58575. to the fire, hoarsely uttering something in a language our soldiers did
58576. not understand. One was taller than the other; he wore an officer's hat
58577. and seemed quite exhausted. On approaching the fire he had been going to
58578. sit down, but fell. The other, a short sturdy soldier with a shawl
58579. tied round his head, was stronger. He raised his companion and said
58580. something, pointing to his mouth. The soldiers surrounded the Frenchmen,
58581. spread a greatcoat on the ground for the sick man, and brought some
58582. buckwheat porridge and vodka for both of them.
58583. 
58584. The exhausted French officer was Ramballe and the man with his head
58585. wrapped in the shawl was Morel, his orderly.
58586. 
58587. When Morel had drunk some vodka and finished his bowl of porridge he
58588. suddenly became unnaturally merry and chattered incessantly to the
58589. soldiers, who could not understand him. Ramballe refused food and
58590. resting his head on his elbow lay silent beside the campfire, looking at
58591. the Russian soldiers with red and vacant eyes. Occasionally he emitted
58592. a long-drawn groan and then again became silent. Morel, pointing to his
58593. shoulders, tried to impress on the soldiers the fact that Ramballe was
58594. an officer and ought to be warmed. A Russian officer who had come up
58595. to the fire sent to ask his colonel whether he would not take a French
58596. officer into his hut to warm him, and when the messenger returned and
58597. said that the colonel wished the officer to be brought to him, Ramballe
58598. was told to go. He rose and tried to walk, but staggered and would have
58599. fallen had not a soldier standing by held him up.
58600. 
58601. "You won't do it again, eh?" said one of the soldiers, winking and
58602. turning mockingly to Ramballe.
58603. 
58604. "Oh, you fool! Why talk rubbish, lout that you are--a real peasant!"
58605. came rebukes from all sides addressed to the jesting soldier.
58606. 
58607. They surrounded Ramballe, lifted him on the crossed arms of two
58608. soldiers, and carried him to the hut. Ramballe put his arms around their
58609. necks while they carried him and began wailing plaintively:
58610. 
58611. "Oh, you fine fellows, my kind, kind friends! These are men! Oh, my
58612. brave, kind friends," and he leaned his head against the shoulder of one
58613. of the men like a child.
58614. 
58615. Meanwhile Morel was sitting in the best place by the fire, surrounded by
58616. the soldiers.
58617. 
58618. Morel, a short sturdy Frenchman with inflamed and streaming eyes, was
58619. wearing a woman's cloak and had a shawl tied woman fashion round his
58620. head over his cap. He was evidently tipsy, and was singing a French song
58621. in a hoarse broken voice, with an arm thrown round the nearest soldier.
58622. The soldiers simply held their sides as they watched him.
58623. 
58624. "Now then, now then, teach us how it goes! I'll soon pick it up. How is
58625. it?" said the man--a singer and a wag--whom Morel was embracing.
58626. 
58627. "Vive Henri Quatre! Vive ce roi valiant!" sang Morel, winking. "Ce
58628. diable a quatre..." *
58629. 
58630. 
58631.      * "Long live Henry the Fourth, that valiant king! That rowdy
58632.      devil."
58633. 
58634. 
58635. "Vivarika! Vif-seruvaru! Sedyablyaka!" repeated the soldier, flourishing
58636. his arm and really catching the tune.
58637. 
58638. "Bravo! Ha, ha, ha!" rose their rough, joyous laughter from all sides.
58639. 
58640. Morel, wrinkling up his face, laughed too.
58641. 
58642. "Well, go on, go on!"
58643. 
58644.     "Qui eut le triple talent,
58645.     De boire, de battre,
58646.     Et d'etre un vert galant." *
58647. 
58648. 
58649.       * Who had a triple talent
58650.       For drinking, for fighting,
58651.       And for being a gallant old boy...
58652. 
58653. 
58654. "It goes smoothly, too. Well, now, Zaletaev!"
58655. 
58656. "Ke..." Zaletaev, brought out with effort: "ke-e-e-e," he drawled,
58657. laboriously pursing his lips, "le-trip-ta-la-de-bu-de-ba, e
58658. de-tra-va-ga-la" he sang.
58659. 
58660. "Fine! Just like the Frenchie! Oh, ho ho! Do you want some more to eat?"
58661. 
58662. "Give him some porridge: it takes a long time to get filled up after
58663. starving."
58664. 
58665. They gave him some more porridge and Morel with a laugh set to work on
58666. his third bowl. All the young soldiers smiled gaily as they watched him.
58667. The older men, who thought it undignified to amuse themselves with such
58668. nonsense, continued to lie at the opposite side of the fire, but one
58669. would occasionally raise himself on an elbow and glance at Morel with a
58670. smile.
58671. 
58672. "They are men too," said one of them as he wrapped himself up in his
58673. coat. "Even wormwood grows on its own root."
58674. 
58675. "O Lord, O Lord! How starry it is! Tremendous! That means a hard
58676. frost...."
58677. 
58678. They all grew silent. The stars, as if knowing that no one was looking
58679. at them, began to disport themselves in the dark sky: now flaring
58680. up, now vanishing, now trembling, they were busy whispering something
58681. gladsome and mysterious to one another.
58682. 
58683. 
58684. 
58685. 
58686. 
58687. CHAPTER X
58688. 
58689. 
58690. The French army melted away at the uniform rate of a mathematical
58691. progression; and that crossing of the Berezina about which so much has
58692. been written was only one intermediate stage in its destruction, and
58693. not at all the decisive episode of the campaign. If so much has been
58694. and still is written about the Berezina, on the French side this is only
58695. because at the broken bridge across that river the calamities their army
58696. had been previously enduring were suddenly concentrated at one moment
58697. into a tragic spectacle that remained in every memory, and on the
58698. Russian side merely because in Petersburg--far from the seat of war--a
58699. plan (again one of Pfuel's) had been devised to catch Napoleon in a
58700. strategic trap at the Berezina River. Everyone assured himself that all
58701. would happen according to plan, and therefore insisted that it was just
58702. the crossing of the Berezina that destroyed the French army. In reality
58703. the results of the crossing were much less disastrous to the French--in
58704. guns and men lost--than Krasnoe had been, as the figures show.
58705. 
58706. The sole importance of the crossing of the Berezina lies in the fact
58707. that it plainly and indubitably proved the fallacy of all the plans for
58708. cutting off the enemy's retreat and the soundness of the only possible
58709. line of action--the one Kutuzov and the general mass of the army
58710. demanded--namely, simply to follow the enemy up. The French crowd fled
58711. at a continually increasing speed and all its energy was directed to
58712. reaching its goal. It fled like a wounded animal and it was impossible
58713. to block its path. This was shown not so much by the arrangements it
58714. made for crossing as by what took place at the bridges. When the bridges
58715. broke down, unarmed soldiers, people from Moscow and women with
58716. children who were with the French transport, all--carried on by vis
58717. inertiae--pressed forward into boats and into the ice-covered water and
58718. did not, surrender.
58719. 
58720. That impulse was reasonable. The condition of fugitives and of pursuers
58721. was equally bad. As long as they remained with their own people each
58722. might hope for help from his fellows and the definite place he held
58723. among them. But those who surrendered, while remaining in the same
58724. pitiful plight, would be on a lower level to claim a share in the
58725. necessities of life. The French did not need to be informed of the fact
58726. that half the prisoners--with whom the Russians did not know what to
58727. do--perished of cold and hunger despite their captors' desire to save
58728. them; they felt that it could not be otherwise. The most compassionate
58729. Russian commanders, those favorable to the French--and even the
58730. Frenchmen in the Russian service--could do nothing for the prisoners.
58731. The French perished from the conditions to which the Russian army was
58732. itself exposed. It was impossible to take bread and clothes from our
58733. hungry and indispensable soldiers to give to the French who, though not
58734. harmful, or hated, or guilty, were simply unnecessary. Some Russians
58735. even did that, but they were exceptions.
58736. 
58737. Certain destruction lay behind the French but in front there was hope.
58738. Their ships had been burned, there was no salvation save in collective
58739. flight, and on that the whole strength of the French was concentrated.
58740. 
58741. The farther they fled the more wretched became the plight of the
58742. remnant, especially after the Berezina, on which (in consequence of the
58743. Petersburg plan) special hopes had been placed by the Russians, and
58744. the keener grew the passions of the Russian commanders, who blamed one
58745. another and Kutuzov most of all. Anticipation that the failure of
58746. the Petersburg Berezina plan would be attributed to Kutuzov led
58747. to dissatisfaction, contempt, and ridicule, more and more strongly
58748. expressed. The ridicule and contempt were of course expressed in a
58749. respectful form, making it impossible for him to ask wherein he was
58750. to blame. They did not talk seriously to him; when reporting to him or
58751. asking for his sanction they appeared to be fulfilling a regrettable
58752. formality, but they winked behind his back and tried to mislead him at
58753. every turn.
58754. 
58755. Because they could not understand him all these people assumed that
58756. it was useless to talk to the old man; that he would never grasp the
58757. profundity of their plans, that he would answer with his phrases (which
58758. they thought were mere phrases) about a "golden bridge," about the
58759. impossibility of crossing the frontier with a crowd of tatterdemalions,
58760. and so forth. They had heard all that before. And all he said--that it
58761. was necessary to await provisions, or that the men had no boots--was so
58762. simple, while what they proposed was so complicated and clever, that
58763. it was evident that he was old and stupid and that they, though not in
58764. power, were commanders of genius.
58765. 
58766. After the junction with the army of the brilliant admiral and Petersburg
58767. hero Wittgenstein, this mood and the gossip of the staff reached their
58768. maximum. Kutuzov saw this and merely sighed and shrugged his shoulders.
58769. Only once, after the affair of the Berezina, did he get angry and write
58770. to Bennigsen (who reported separately to the Emperor) the following
58771. letter:
58772. 
58773. "On account of your spells of ill health, will your excellency please
58774. be so good as to set off for Kaluga on receipt of this, and there await
58775. further commands and appointments from His Imperial Majesty."
58776. 
58777. But after Bennigsen's departure, the Grand Duke Tsarevich Constantine
58778. Pavlovich joined the army. He had taken part in the beginning of the
58779. campaign but had subsequently been removed from the army by Kutuzov.
58780. Now having come to the army, he informed Kutuzov of the Emperor's
58781. displeasure at the poor success of our forces and the slowness of their
58782. advance. The Emperor intended to join the army personally in a few days'
58783. time.
58784. 
58785. The old man, experienced in court as well as in military affairs--this
58786. same Kutuzov who in August had been chosen commander in chief
58787. against the sovereign's wishes and who had removed the Grand Duke and
58788. heir--apparent from the army--who on his own authority and contrary
58789. to the Emperor's will had decided on the abandonment of Moscow, now
58790. realized at once that his day was over, that his part was played,
58791. and that the power he was supposed to hold was no longer his. And he
58792. understood this not merely from the attitude of the court. He saw on the
58793. one hand that the military business in which he had played his part was
58794. ended and felt that his mission was accomplished; and at the same time
58795. he began to be conscious of the physical weariness of his aged body and
58796. of the necessity of physical rest.
58797. 
58798. On the twenty-ninth of November Kutuzov entered Vilna--his "dear Vilna"
58799. as he called it. Twice during his career Kutuzov had been governor of
58800. Vilna. In that wealthy town, which had not been injured, he found old
58801. friends and associations, besides the comforts of life of which he had
58802. so long been deprived. And he suddenly turned from the cares of army
58803. and state and, as far as the passions that seethed around him allowed,
58804. immersed himself in the quiet life to which he had formerly been
58805. accustomed, as if all that was taking place and all that had still to be
58806. done in the realm of history did not concern him at all.
58807. 
58808. Chichagov, one of the most zealous "cutters-off" and "breakers-up," who
58809. had first wanted to effect a diversion in Greece and then in Warsaw but
58810. never wished to go where he was sent: Chichagov, noted for the boldness
58811. with which he spoke to the Emperor, and who considered Kutuzov to be
58812. under an obligation to him because when he was sent to make peace
58813. with Turkey in 1811 independently of Kutuzov, and found that peace had
58814. already been concluded, he admitted to the Emperor that the merit of
58815. securing that peace was really Kutuzov's; this Chichagov was the first
58816. to meet Kutuzov at the castle where the latter was to stay. In undress
58817. naval uniform, with a dirk, and holding his cap under his arm, he handed
58818. Kutuzov a garrison report and the keys of the town. The contemptuously
58819. respectful attitude of the younger men to the old man in his dotage was
58820. expressed in the highest degree by the behavior of Chichagov, who knew
58821. of the accusations that were being directed against Kutuzov.
58822. 
58823. When speaking to Chichagov, Kutuzov incidentally mentioned that the
58824. vehicles packed with china that had been captured from him at Borisov
58825. had been recovered and would be restored to him.
58826. 
58827. "You mean to imply that I have nothing to eat out of.... On the
58828. contrary, I can supply you with everything even if you want to give
58829. dinner parties," warmly replied Chichagov, who tried by every word he
58830. spoke to prove his own rectitude and therefore imagined Kutuzov to be
58831. animated by the same desire.
58832. 
58833. Kutuzov, shrugging his shoulders, replied with his subtle penetrating
58834. smile: "I meant merely to say what I said."
58835. 
58836. Contrary to the Emperor's wish Kutuzov detained the greater part of the
58837. army at Vilna. Those about him said that he became extraordinarily slack
58838. and physically feeble during his stay in that town. He attended to army
58839. affairs reluctantly, left everything to his generals, and while awaiting
58840. the Emperor's arrival led a dissipated life.
58841. 
58842. Having left Petersburg on the seventh of December with his suite--Count
58843. Tolstoy, Prince Volkonski, Arakcheev, and others--the Emperor reached
58844. Vilna on the eleventh, and in his traveling sleigh drove straight to
58845. the castle. In spite of the severe frost some hundred generals and staff
58846. officers in full parade uniform stood in front of the castle, as well as
58847. a guard of honor of the Semenov regiment.
58848. 
58849. A courier who galloped to the castle in advance, in a troyka with three
58850. foam-flecked horses, shouted "Coming!" and Konovnitsyn rushed into the
58851. vestibule to inform Kutuzov, who was waiting in the hall porter's little
58852. lodge.
58853. 
58854. A minute later the old man's large stout figure in full-dress uniform,
58855. his chest covered with orders and a scarf drawn round his stomach,
58856. waddled out into the porch. He put on his hat with its peaks to the
58857. sides and, holding his gloves in his hand and walking with an effort
58858. sideways down the steps to the level of the street, took in his hand the
58859. report he had prepared for the Emperor.
58860. 
58861. There was running to and fro and whispering; another troyka flew
58862. furiously up, and then all eyes were turned on an approaching sleigh
58863. in which the figures of the Emperor and Volkonski could already be
58864. descried.
58865. 
58866. From the habit of fifty years all this had a physically agitating effect
58867. on the old general. He carefully and hastily felt himself all over,
58868. readjusted his hat, and pulling himself together drew himself up and,
58869. at the very moment when the Emperor, having alighted from the sleigh,
58870. lifted his eyes to him, handed him the report and began speaking in his
58871. smooth, ingratiating voice.
58872. 
58873. The Emperor with a rapid glance scanned Kutuzov from head to foot,
58874. frowned for an instant, but immediately mastering himself went up to the
58875. old man, extended his arms and embraced him. And this embrace too, owing
58876. to a long-standing impression related to his innermost feelings, had its
58877. usual effect on Kutuzov and he gave a sob.
58878. 
58879. The Emperor greeted the officers and the Semenov guard, and again
58880. pressing the old man's hand went with him into the castle.
58881. 
58882. When alone with the field marshal the Emperor expressed his
58883. dissatisfaction at the slowness of the pursuit and at the mistakes made
58884. at Krasnoe and the Berezina, and informed him of his intentions for a
58885. future campaign abroad. Kutuzov made no rejoinder or remark. The same
58886. submissive, expressionless look with which he had listened to the
58887. Emperor's commands on the field of Austerlitz seven years before settled
58888. on his face now.
58889. 
58890. When Kutuzov came out of the study and with lowered head was crossing
58891. the ballroom with his heavy waddling gait, he was arrested by someone's
58892. voice saying:
58893. 
58894. "Your Serene Highness!"
58895. 
58896. Kutuzov raised his head and looked for a long while into the eyes of
58897. Count Tolstoy, who stood before him holding a silver salver on which lay
58898. a small object. Kutuzov seemed not to understand what was expected of
58899. him.
58900. 
58901. Suddenly he seemed to remember; a scarcely perceptible smile flashed
58902. across his puffy face, and bowing low and respectfully he took the
58903. object that lay on the salver. It was the Order of St. George of the
58904. First Class.
58905. 
58906. 
58907. 
58908. 
58909. 
58910. CHAPTER XI
58911. 
58912. 
58913. Next day the field marshal gave a dinner and ball which the Emperor
58914. honored by his presence. Kutuzov had received the Order of St. George
58915. of the First Class and the Emperor showed him the highest honors, but
58916. everyone knew of the imperial dissatisfaction with him. The proprieties
58917. were observed and the Emperor was the first to set that example,
58918. but everybody understood that the old man was blameworthy and
58919. good-for-nothing. When Kutuzov, conforming to a custom of Catherine's
58920. day, ordered the standards that had been captured to be lowered at the
58921. Emperor's feet on his entering the ballroom, the Emperor made a wry face
58922. and muttered something in which some people caught the words, "the old
58923. comedian."
58924. 
58925. The Emperor's displeasure with Kutuzov was specially increased at Vilna
58926. by the fact that Kutuzov evidently could not or would not understand the
58927. importance of the coming campaign.
58928. 
58929. When on the following morning the Emperor said to the officers assembled
58930. about him: "You have not only saved Russia, you have saved Europe!" they
58931. all understood that the war was not ended.
58932. 
58933. Kutuzov alone would not see this and openly expressed his opinion that
58934. no fresh war could improve the position or add to the glory of Russia,
58935. but could only spoil and lower the glorious position that Russia had
58936. gained. He tried to prove to the Emperor the impossibility of levying
58937. fresh troops, spoke of the hardships already endured by the people, of
58938. the possibility of failure and so forth.
58939. 
58940. This being the field marshal's frame of mind he was naturally regarded
58941. as merely a hindrance and obstacle to the impending war.
58942. 
58943. To avoid unpleasant encounters with the old man, the natural method was
58944. to do what had been done with him at Austerlitz and with Barclay at
58945. the beginning of the Russian campaign--to transfer the authority to the
58946. Emperor himself, thus cutting the ground from under the commander in
58947. chief's feet without upsetting the old man by informing him of the
58948. change.
58949. 
58950. With this object his staff was gradually reconstructed and its real
58951. strength removed and transferred to the Emperor. Toll, Konovnitsyn, and
58952. Ermolov received fresh appointments. Everyone spoke loudly of the field
58953. marshal's great weakness and failing health.
58954. 
58955. His health had to be bad for his place to be taken away and given to
58956. another. And in fact his health was poor.
58957. 
58958. So naturally, simply, and gradually--just as he had come from Turkey to
58959. the Treasury in Petersburg to recruit the militia, and then to the army
58960. when he was needed there--now when his part was played out, Kutuzov's
58961. place was taken by a new and necessary performer.
58962. 
58963. The war of 1812, besides its national significance dear to every Russian
58964. heart, was now to assume another, a European, significance.
58965. 
58966. The movement of peoples from west to east was to be succeeded by a
58967. movement of peoples from east to west, and for this fresh war another
58968. leader was necessary, having qualities and views differing from
58969. Kutuzov's and animated by different motives.
58970. 
58971. Alexander I was as necessary for the movement of the peoples from east
58972. to west and for the refixing of national frontiers as Kutuzov had been
58973. for the salvation and glory of Russia.
58974. 
58975. Kutuzov did not understand what Europe, the balance of power, or
58976. Napoleon meant. He could not understand it. For the representative of
58977. the Russian people, after the enemy had been destroyed and Russia had
58978. been liberated and raised to the summit of her glory, there was nothing
58979. left to do as a Russian. Nothing remained for the representative of the
58980. national war but to die, and Kutuzov died.
58981. 
58982. 
58983. 
58984. 
58985. 
58986. CHAPTER XII
58987. 
58988. 
58989. As generally happens, Pierre did not feel the full effects of the
58990. physical privation and strain he had suffered as prisoner until after
58991. they were over. After his liberation he reached Orel, and on the third
58992. day there, when preparing to go to Kiev, he fell ill and was laid up
58993. for three months. He had what the doctors termed "bilious fever." But
58994. despite the fact that the doctors treated him, bled him, and gave him
58995. medicines to drink, he recovered.
58996. 
58997. Scarcely any impression was left on Pierre's mind by all that happened
58998. to him from the time of his rescue till his illness. He remembered
58999. only the dull gray weather now rainy and now snowy, internal physical
59000. distress, and pains in his feet and side. He remembered a general
59001. impression of the misfortunes and sufferings of people and of being
59002. worried by the curiosity of officers and generals who questioned him, he
59003. also remembered his difficulty in procuring a conveyance and horses, and
59004. above all he remembered his incapacity to think and feel all that time.
59005. On the day of his rescue he had seen the body of Petya Rostov. That same
59006. day he had learned that Prince Andrew, after surviving the battle of
59007. Borodino for more than a month had recently died in the Rostovs' house
59008. at Yaroslavl, and Denisov who told him this news also mentioned Helene's
59009. death, supposing that Pierre had heard of it long before. All this at
59010. the time seemed merely strange to Pierre: he felt he could not grasp its
59011. significance. Just then he was only anxious to get away as quickly as
59012. possible from places where people were killing one another, to some
59013. peaceful refuge where he could recover himself, rest, and think over
59014. all the strange new facts he had learned; but on reaching Orel he
59015. immediately fell ill. When he came to himself after his illness he saw
59016. in attendance on him two of his servants, Terenty and Vaska, who had
59017. come from Moscow; and also his cousin the eldest princess, who had been
59018. living on his estate at Elets and hearing of his rescue and illness had
59019. come to look after him.
59020. 
59021. It was only gradually during his convalescence that Pierre lost the
59022. impressions he had become accustomed to during the last few months
59023. and got used to the idea that no one would oblige him to go anywhere
59024. tomorrow, that no one would deprive him of his warm bed, and that he
59025. would be sure to get his dinner, tea, and supper. But for a long time in
59026. his dreams he still saw himself in the conditions of captivity. In the
59027. same way little by little he came to understand the news he had been
59028. told after his rescue, about the death of Prince Andrew, the death of
59029. his wife, and the destruction of the French.
59030. 
59031. A joyous feeling of freedom--that complete inalienable freedom natural
59032. to man which he had first experienced at the first halt outside
59033. Moscow--filled Pierre's soul during his convalescence. He was surprised
59034. to find that this inner freedom, which was independent of external
59035. conditions, now had as it were an additional setting of external
59036. liberty. He was alone in a strange town, without acquaintances. No one
59037. demanded anything of him or sent him anywhere. He had all he wanted:
59038. the thought of his wife which had been a continual torment to him was no
59039. longer there, since she was no more.
59040. 
59041. "Oh, how good! How splendid!" said he to himself when a cleanly laid
59042. table was moved up to him with savory beef tea, or when he lay down for
59043. the night on a soft clean bed, or when he remembered that the French had
59044. gone and that his wife was no more. "Oh, how good, how splendid!"
59045. 
59046. And by old habit he asked himself the question: "Well, and what then?
59047. What am I going to do?" And he immediately gave himself the answer:
59048. "Well, I shall live. Ah, how splendid!"
59049. 
59050. The very question that had formerly tormented him, the thing he had
59051. continually sought to find--the aim of life--no longer existed for
59052. him now. That search for the aim of life had not merely disappeared
59053. temporarily--he felt that it no longer existed for him and could not
59054. present itself again. And this very absence of an aim gave him the
59055. complete, joyous sense of freedom which constituted his happiness at
59056. this time.
59057. 
59058. He could not see an aim, for he now had faith--not faith in any kind
59059. of rule, or words, or ideas, but faith in an ever-living, ever-manifest
59060. God. Formerly he had sought Him in aims he set himself. That search for
59061. an aim had been simply a search for God, and suddenly in his captivity
59062. he had learned not by words or reasoning but by direct feeling what his
59063. nurse had told him long ago: that God is here and everywhere. In his
59064. captivity he had learned that in Karataev God was greater, more infinite
59065. and unfathomable than in the Architect of the Universe recognized by the
59066. Freemasons. He felt like a man who after straining his eyes to see into
59067. the far distance finds what he sought at his very feet. All his life
59068. he had looked over the heads of the men around him, when he should have
59069. merely looked in front of him without straining his eyes.
59070. 
59071. In the past he had never been able to find that great inscrutable
59072. infinite something. He had only felt that it must exist somewhere and
59073. had looked for it. In everything near and comprehensible he had only
59074. what was limited, petty, commonplace, and senseless. He had equipped
59075. himself with a mental telescope and looked into remote space, where
59076. petty worldliness hiding itself in misty distance had seemed to him
59077. great and infinite merely because it was not clearly seen. And such
59078. had European life, politics, Freemasonry, philosophy, and philanthropy
59079. seemed to him. But even then, at moments of weakness as he had accounted
59080. them, his mind had penetrated to those distances and he had there seen
59081. the same pettiness, worldliness, and senselessness. Now, however, he
59082. had learned to see the great, eternal, and infinite in everything, and
59083. therefore--to see it and enjoy its contemplation--he naturally threw
59084. away the telescope through which he had till now gazed over men's heads,
59085. and gladly regarded the ever-changing, eternally great, unfathomable,
59086. and infinite life around him. And the closer he looked the more tranquil
59087. and happy he became. That dreadful question, "What for?" which had
59088. formerly destroyed all his mental edifices, no longer existed for him.
59089. To that question, "What for?" a simple answer was now always ready in
59090. his soul: "Because there is a God, that God without whose will not one
59091. hair falls from a man's head."
59092. 
59093. 
59094. 
59095. 
59096. 
59097. CHAPTER XIII
59098. 
59099. 
59100. In external ways Pierre had hardly changed at all. In appearance he
59101. was just what he used to be. As before he was absent-minded and seemed
59102. occupied not with what was before his eyes but with something special
59103. of his own. The difference between his former and present self was that
59104. formerly when he did not grasp what lay before him or was said to
59105. him, he had puckered his forehead painfully as if vainly seeking to
59106. distinguish something at a distance. At present he still forgot what was
59107. said to him and still did not see what was before his eyes, but he now
59108. looked with a scarcely perceptible and seemingly ironic smile at what
59109. was before him and listened to what was said, though evidently seeing
59110. and hearing something quite different. Formerly he had appeared to be
59111. a kindhearted but unhappy man, and so people had been inclined to avoid
59112. him. Now a smile at the joy of life always played round his lips, and
59113. sympathy for others, shone in his eyes with a questioning look as to
59114. whether they were as contented as he was, and people felt pleased by his
59115. presence.
59116. 
59117. Previously he had talked a great deal, grew excited when he talked, and
59118. seldom listened; now he was seldom carried away in conversation and
59119. knew how to listen so that people readily told him their most intimate
59120. secrets.
59121. 
59122. The princess, who had never liked Pierre and had been particularly
59123. hostile to him since she had felt herself under obligations to him after
59124. the old count's death, now after staying a short time in Orel--where she
59125. had come intending to show Pierre that in spite of his ingratitude she
59126. considered it her duty to nurse him--felt to her surprise and vexation
59127. that she had become fond of him. Pierre did not in any way seek her
59128. approval, he merely studied her with interest. Formerly she had felt
59129. that he regarded her with indifference and irony, and so had shrunk into
59130. herself as she did with others and had shown him only the combative side
59131. of her nature; but now he seemed to be trying to understand the most
59132. intimate places of her heart, and, mistrustfully at first but afterwards
59133. gratefully, she let him see the hidden, kindly sides of her character.
59134. 
59135. The most cunning man could not have crept into her confidence more
59136. successfully, evoking memories of the best times of her youth and
59137. showing sympathy with them. Yet Pierre's cunning consisted simply in
59138. finding pleasure in drawing out the human qualities of the embittered,
59139. hard, and (in her own way) proud princess.
59140. 
59141. "Yes, he is a very, very kind man when he is not under the influence of
59142. bad people but of people such as myself," thought she.
59143. 
59144. His servants too--Terenty and Vaska--in their own way noticed the change
59145. that had taken place in Pierre. They considered that he had become much
59146. "simpler." Terenty, when he had helped him undress and wished him good
59147. night, often lingered with his master's boots in his hands and clothes
59148. over his arm, to see whether he would not start a talk. And Pierre,
59149. noticing that Terenty wanted a chat, generally kept him there.
59150. 
59151. "Well, tell me... now, how did you get food?" he would ask.
59152. 
59153. And Terenty would begin talking of the destruction of Moscow, and of
59154. the old count, and would stand for a long time holding the clothes and
59155. talking, or sometimes listening to Pierre's stories, and then would go
59156. out into the hall with a pleasant sense of intimacy with his master and
59157. affection for him.
59158. 
59159. The doctor who attended Pierre and visited him every day, though he
59160. considered it his duty as a doctor to pose as a man whose every moment
59161. was of value to suffering humanity, would sit for hours with Pierre
59162. telling him his favorite anecdotes and his observations on the
59163. characters of his patients in general, and especially of the ladies.
59164. 
59165. "It's a pleasure to talk to a man like that; he is not like our
59166. provincials," he would say.
59167. 
59168. There were several prisoners from the French army in Orel, and the
59169. doctor brought one of them, a young Italian, to see Pierre.
59170. 
59171. This officer began visiting Pierre, and the princess used to make fun of
59172. the tenderness the Italian expressed for him.
59173. 
59174. The Italian seemed happy only when he could come to see Pierre, talk
59175. with him, tell him about his past, his life at home, and his love,
59176. and pour out to him his indignation against the French and especially
59177. against Napoleon.
59178. 
59179. "If all Russians are in the least like you, it is sacrilege to fight
59180. such a nation," he said to Pierre. "You, who have suffered so from the
59181. French, do not even feel animosity toward them."
59182. 
59183. Pierre had evoked the passionate affection of the Italian merely by
59184. evoking the best side of his nature and taking a pleasure in so doing.
59185. 
59186. During the last days of Pierre's stay in Orel his old Masonic
59187. acquaintance Count Willarski, who had introduced him to the lodge in
59188. 1807, came to see him. Willarski was married to a Russian heiress who
59189. had a large estate in Orel province, and he occupied a temporary post in
59190. the commissariat department in that town.
59191. 
59192. Hearing that Bezukhov was in Orel, Willarski, though they had never been
59193. intimate, came to him with the professions of friendship and intimacy
59194. that people who meet in a desert generally express for one another.
59195. Willarski felt dull in Orel and was pleased to meet a man of his own
59196. circle and, as he supposed, of similar interests.
59197. 
59198. But to his surprise Willarski soon noticed that Pierre had lagged much
59199. behind the times, and had sunk, as he expressed it to himself, into
59200. apathy and egotism.
59201. 
59202. "You are letting yourself go, my dear fellow," he said.
59203. 
59204. But for all that Willarski found it pleasanter now than it had been
59205. formerly to be with Pierre, and came to see him every day. To Pierre as
59206. he looked at and listened to Willarski, it seemed strange to think that
59207. he had been like that himself but a short time before.
59208. 
59209. Willarski was a married man with a family, busy with his family affairs,
59210. his wife's affairs, and his official duties. He regarded all these
59211. occupations as hindrances to life, and considered that they were all
59212. contemptible because their aim was the welfare of himself and his
59213. family. Military, administrative, political, and Masonic interests
59214. continually absorbed his attention. And Pierre, without trying to
59215. change the other's views and without condemning him, but with the quiet,
59216. joyful, and amused smile now habitual to him, was interested in this
59217. strange though very familiar phenomenon.
59218. 
59219. There was a new feature in Pierre's relations with Willarski, with the
59220. princess, with the doctor, and with all the people he now met, which
59221. gained for him the general good will. This was his acknowledgment of
59222. the impossibility of changing a man's convictions by words, and his
59223. recognition of the possibility of everyone thinking, feeling, and seeing
59224. things each from his own point of view. This legitimate peculiarity of
59225. each individual which used to excite and irritate Pierre now became a
59226. basis of the sympathy he felt for, and the interest he took in, other
59227. people. The difference, and sometimes complete contradiction, between
59228. men's opinions and their lives, and between one man and another, pleased
59229. him and drew from him an amused and gentle smile.
59230. 
59231. In practical matters Pierre unexpectedly felt within himself a center
59232. of gravity he had previously lacked. Formerly all pecuniary questions,
59233. especially requests for money to which, as an extremely wealthy man,
59234. he was very exposed, produced in him a state of hopeless agitation and
59235. perplexity. "To give or not to give?" he had asked himself. "I have
59236. it and he needs it. But someone else needs it still more. Who needs it
59237. most? And perhaps they are both impostors?" In the old days he had been
59238. unable to find a way out of all these surmises and had given to all
59239. who asked as long as he had anything to give. Formerly he had been in a
59240. similar state of perplexity with regard to every question concerning his
59241. property, when one person advised one thing and another something else.
59242. 
59243. Now to his surprise he found that he no longer felt either doubt or
59244. perplexity about these questions. There was now within him a judge who
59245. by some rule unknown to him decided what should or should not be done.
59246. 
59247. He was as indifferent as heretofore to money matters, but now he felt
59248. certain of what ought and what ought not to be done. The first time he
59249. had recourse to his new judge was when a French prisoner, a colonel,
59250. came to him and, after talking a great deal about his exploits,
59251. concluded by making what amounted to a demand that Pierre should give
59252. him four thousand francs to send to his wife and children. Pierre
59253. refused without the least difficulty or effort, and was afterwards
59254. surprised how simple and easy had been what used to appear so
59255. insurmountably difficult. At the same time that he refused the colonel's
59256. demand he made up his mind that he must have recourse to artifice when
59257. leaving Orel, to induce the Italian officer to accept some money of
59258. which he was evidently in need. A further proof to Pierre of his own
59259. more settled outlook on practical matters was furnished by his decision
59260. with regard to his wife's debts and to the rebuilding of his houses in
59261. and near Moscow.
59262. 
59263. His head steward came to him at Orel and Pierre reckoned up with him his
59264. diminished income. The burning of Moscow had cost him, according to the
59265. head steward's calculation, about two million rubles.
59266. 
59267. To console Pierre for these losses the head steward gave him an estimate
59268. showing that despite these losses his income would not be diminished but
59269. would even be increased if he refused to pay his wife's debts which he
59270. was under no obligation to meet, and did not rebuild his Moscow house
59271. and the country house on his Moscow estate, which had cost him eighty
59272. thousand rubles a year and brought in nothing.
59273. 
59274. "Yes, of course that's true," said Pierre with a cheerful smile. "I
59275. don't need all that at all. By being ruined I have become much richer."
59276. 
59277. But in January Savelich came from Moscow and gave him an account of the
59278. state of things there, and spoke of the estimate an architect had made
59279. of the cost of rebuilding the town and country houses, speaking of this
59280. as of a settled matter. About the same time he received letters from
59281. Prince Vasili and other Petersburg acquaintances speaking of his wife's
59282. debts. And Pierre decided that the steward's proposals which had so
59283. pleased him were wrong and that he must go to Petersburg and settle his
59284. wife's affairs and must rebuild in Moscow. Why this was necessary he
59285. did not know, but he knew for certain that it was necessary. His income
59286. would be reduced by three fourths, but he felt it must be done.
59287. 
59288. Willarski was going to Moscow and they agreed to travel together.
59289. 
59290. During the whole time of his convalescence in Orel Pierre had
59291. experienced a feeling of joy, freedom, and life; but when during his
59292. journey he found himself in the open world and saw hundreds of new
59293. faces, that feeling was intensified. Throughout his journey he felt like
59294. a schoolboy on holiday. Everyone--the stagecoach driver, the post-house
59295. overseers, the peasants on the roads and in the villages--had a
59296. new significance for him. The presence and remarks of Willarski who
59297. continually deplored the ignorance and poverty of Russia and its
59298. backwardness compared with Europe only heightened Pierre's pleasure.
59299. Where Willarski saw deadness Pierre saw an extraordinary strength
59300. and vitality--the strength which in that vast space amid the snows
59301. maintained the life of this original, peculiar, and unique people.
59302. He did not contradict Willarski and even seemed to agree with him--an
59303. apparent agreement being the simplest way to avoid discussions that
59304. could lead to nothing--and he smiled joyfully as he listened to him.
59305. 
59306. 
59307. 
59308. 
59309. 
59310. CHAPTER XIV
59311. 
59312. 
59313. It would be difficult to explain why and whither ants whose heap
59314. has been destroyed are hurrying: some from the heap dragging bits of
59315. rubbish, larvae, and corpses, others back to the heap, or why they
59316. jostle, overtake one another, and fight, and it would be equally
59317. difficult to explain what caused the Russians after the departure of the
59318. French to throng to the place that had formerly been Moscow. But when
59319. we watch the ants round their ruined heap, the tenacity, energy, and
59320. immense number of the delving insects prove that despite the destruction
59321. of the heap, something indestructible, which though intangible is the
59322. real strength of the colony, still exists; and similarly, though in
59323. Moscow in the month of October there was no government and no churches,
59324. shrines, riches, or houses--it was still the Moscow it had been in
59325. August. All was destroyed, except something intangible yet powerful and
59326. indestructible.
59327. 
59328. The motives of those who thronged from all sides to Moscow after it had
59329. been cleared of the enemy were most diverse and personal, and at first
59330. for the most part savage and brutal. One motive only they all had in
59331. common: a desire to get to the place that had been called Moscow, to
59332. apply their activities there.
59333. 
59334. Within a week Moscow already had fifteen thousand inhabitants, in a
59335. fortnight twenty-five thousand, and so on. By the autumn of 1813 the
59336. number, ever increasing and increasing, exceeded what it had been in
59337. 1812.
59338. 
59339. The first Russians to enter Moscow were the Cossacks of Wintzingerode's
59340. detachment, peasants from the adjacent villages, and residents who had
59341. fled from Moscow and had been hiding in its vicinity. The Russians who
59342. entered Moscow, finding it plundered, plundered it in their turn. They
59343. continued what the French had begun. Trains of peasant carts came to
59344. Moscow to carry off to the villages what had been abandoned in the
59345. ruined houses and the streets. The Cossacks carried off what they could
59346. to their camps, and the householders seized all they could find in other
59347. houses and moved it to their own, pretending that it was their property.
59348. 
59349. But the first plunderers were followed by a second and a third
59350. contingent, and with increasing numbers plundering became more and more
59351. difficult and assumed more definite forms.
59352. 
59353. The French found Moscow abandoned but with all the organizations of
59354. regular life, with diverse branches of commerce and craftsmanship, with
59355. luxury, and governmental and religious institutions. These forms were
59356. lifeless but still existed. There were bazaars, shops, warehouses,
59357. market stalls, granaries--for the most part still stocked with
59358. goods--and there were factories and workshops, palaces and wealthy
59359. houses filled with luxuries, hospitals, prisons, government offices,
59360. churches, and cathedrals. The longer the French remained the more these
59361. forms of town life perished, until finally all was merged into one
59362. confused, lifeless scene of plunder.
59363. 
59364. The more the plundering by the French continued, the more both the
59365. wealth of Moscow and the strength of its plunderers was destroyed. But
59366. plundering by the Russians, with which the reoccupation of the city
59367. began, had an opposite effect: the longer it continued and the greater
59368. the number of people taking part in it the more rapidly was the wealth
59369. of the city and its regular life restored.
59370. 
59371. Besides the plunderers, very various people, some drawn by curiosity,
59372. some by official duties, some by self-interest--house owners, clergy,
59373. officials of all kinds, tradesmen, artisans, and peasants--streamed into
59374. Moscow as blood flows to the heart.
59375. 
59376. Within a week the peasants who came with empty carts to carry off
59377. plunder were stopped by the authorities and made to cart the corpses
59378. out of the town. Other peasants, having heard of their comrades'
59379. discomfiture, came to town bringing rye, oats, and hay, and beat down
59380. one another's prices to below what they had been in former days. Gangs
59381. of carpenters hoping for high pay arrived in Moscow every day, and on
59382. all sides logs were being hewn, new houses built, and old, charred ones
59383. repaired. Tradesmen began trading in booths. Cookshops and taverns were
59384. opened in partially burned houses. The clergy resumed the services
59385. in many churches that had not been burned. Donors contributed
59386. Church property that had been stolen. Government clerks set up their
59387. baize-covered tables and their pigeonholes of documents in small rooms.
59388. The higher authorities and the police organized the distribution of
59389. goods left behind by the French. The owners of houses in which much
59390. property had been left, brought there from other houses, complained of
59391. the injustice of taking everything to the Faceted Palace in the Kremlin;
59392. others insisted that as the French had gathered things from different
59393. houses into this or that house, it would be unfair to allow its owner to
59394. keep all that was found there. They abused the police and bribed them,
59395. made out estimates at ten times their value for government stores that
59396. had perished in the fire, and demanded relief. And Count Rostopchin
59397. wrote proclamations.
59398. 
59399. 
59400. 
59401. 
59402. 
59403. CHAPTER XV
59404. 
59405. 
59406. At the end of January Pierre went to Moscow and stayed in an annex of
59407. his house which had not been burned. He called on Count Rostopchin and
59408. on some acquaintances who were back in Moscow, and he intended to leave
59409. for Petersburg two days later. Everybody was celebrating the victory,
59410. everything was bubbling with life in the ruined but reviving city.
59411. Everyone was pleased to see Pierre, everyone wished to meet him, and
59412. everyone questioned him about what he had seen. Pierre felt particularly
59413. well disposed toward them all, but was now instinctively on his
59414. guard for fear of binding himself in any way. To all questions put to
59415. him--whether important or quite trifling--such as: Where would he live?
59416. Was he going to rebuild? When was he going to Petersburg and would he
59417. mind taking a parcel for someone?--he replied: "Yes, perhaps," or, "I
59418. think so," and so on.
59419. 
59420. He had heard that the Rostovs were at Kostroma but the thought of
59421. Natasha seldom occurred to him. If it did it was only as a pleasant
59422. memory of the distant past. He felt himself not only free from social
59423. obligations but also from that feeling which, it seemed to him, he had
59424. aroused in himself.
59425. 
59426. On the third day after his arrival he heard from the Drubetskoys that
59427. Princess Mary was in Moscow. The death, sufferings, and last days of
59428. Prince Andrew had often occupied Pierre's thoughts and now recurred to
59429. him with fresh vividness. Having heard at dinner that Princess Mary
59430. was in Moscow and living in her house--which had not been burned--in
59431. Vozdvizhenka Street, he drove that same evening to see her.
59432. 
59433. On his way to the house Pierre kept thinking of Prince Andrew, of their
59434. friendship, of his various meetings with him, and especially of the last
59435. one at Borodino.
59436. 
59437. "Is it possible that he died in the bitter frame of mind he was then in?
59438. Is it possible that the meaning of life was not disclosed to him
59439. before he died?" thought Pierre. He recalled Karataev and his death and
59440. involuntarily began to compare these two men, so different, and yet so
59441. similar in that they had both lived and both died and in the love he
59442. felt for both of them.
59443. 
59444. Pierre drove up to the house of the old prince in a most serious mood.
59445. The house had escaped the fire; it showed signs of damage but its
59446. general aspect was unchanged. The old footman, who met Pierre with a
59447. stern face as if wishing to make the visitor feel that the absence
59448. of the old prince had not disturbed the order of things in the house,
59449. informed him that the princess had gone to her own apartments, and that
59450. she received on Sundays.
59451. 
59452. "Announce me. Perhaps she will see me," said Pierre.
59453. 
59454. "Yes, sir," said the man. "Please step into the portrait gallery."
59455. 
59456. A few minutes later the footman returned with Dessalles, who brought
59457. word from the princess that she would be very glad to see Pierre if he
59458. would excuse her want of ceremony and come upstairs to her apartment.
59459. 
59460. In a rather low room lit by one candle sat the princess and with her
59461. another person dressed in black. Pierre remembered that the princess
59462. always had lady companions, but who they were and what they were like
59463. he never knew or remembered. "This must be one of her companions," he
59464. thought, glancing at the lady in the black dress.
59465. 
59466. The princess rose quickly to meet him and held out her hand.
59467. 
59468. "Yes," she said, looking at his altered face after he had kissed her
59469. hand, "so this is how we meet again. He spoke of you even at the very
59470. last," she went on, turning her eyes from Pierre to her companion with a
59471. shyness that surprised him for an instant.
59472. 
59473. "I was so glad to hear of your safety. It was the first piece of good
59474. news we had received for a long time."
59475. 
59476. Again the princess glanced round at her companion with even more
59477. uneasiness in her manner and was about to add something, but Pierre
59478. interrupted her.
59479. 
59480. "Just imagine--I knew nothing about him!" said he. "I thought he had
59481. been killed. All I know I heard at second hand from others. I only know
59482. that he fell in with the Rostovs.... What a strange coincidence!"
59483. 
59484. Pierre spoke rapidly and with animation. He glanced once at the
59485. companion's face, saw her attentive and kindly gaze fixed on him, and,
59486. as often happens when one is talking, felt somehow that this companion
59487. in the black dress was a good, kind, excellent creature who would not
59488. hinder his conversing freely with Princess Mary.
59489. 
59490. But when he mentioned the Rostovs, Princess Mary's face expressed still
59491. greater embarrassment. She again glanced rapidly from Pierre's face to
59492. that of the lady in the black dress and said:
59493. 
59494. "Do you really not recognize her?"
59495. 
59496. Pierre looked again at the companion's pale, delicate face with its
59497. black eyes and peculiar mouth, and something near to him, long forgotten
59498. and more than sweet, looked at him from those attentive eyes.
59499. 
59500. "But no, it can't be!" he thought. "This stern, thin, pale face that
59501. looks so much older! It cannot be she. It merely reminds me of her."
59502. But at that moment Princess Mary said, "Natasha!" And with difficulty,
59503. effort, and stress, like the opening of a door grown rusty on its
59504. hinges, a smile appeared on the face with the attentive eyes, and from
59505. that opening door came a breath of fragrance which suffused Pierre with
59506. a happiness he had long forgotten and of which he had not even been
59507. thinking--especially at that moment. It suffused him, seized him, and
59508. enveloped him completely. When she smiled doubt was no longer possible,
59509. it was Natasha and he loved her.
59510. 
59511. At that moment Pierre involuntarily betrayed to her, to Princess Mary,
59512. and above all to himself, a secret of which he himself had been unaware.
59513. He flushed joyfully yet with painful distress. He tried to hide his
59514. agitation. But the more he tried to hide it the more clearly--clearer
59515. than any words could have done--did he betray to himself, to her, and to
59516. Princess Mary that he loved her.
59517. 
59518. "No, it's only the unexpectedness of it," thought Pierre. But as soon as
59519. he tried to continue the conversation he had begun with Princess Mary he
59520. again glanced at Natasha, and a still-deeper flush suffused his face and
59521. a still-stronger agitation of mingled joy and fear seized his soul. He
59522. became confused in his speech and stopped in the middle of what he was
59523. saying.
59524. 
59525. Pierre had failed to notice Natasha because he did not at all expect to
59526. see her there, but he had failed to recognize her because the change in
59527. her since he last saw her was immense. She had grown thin and pale, but
59528. that was not what made her unrecognizable; she was unrecognizable at the
59529. moment he entered because on that face whose eyes had always shone with
59530. a suppressed smile of the joy of life, now when he first entered and
59531. glanced at her there was not the least shadow of a smile: only her eyes
59532. were kindly attentive and sadly interrogative.
59533. 
59534. Pierre's confusion was not reflected by any confusion on Natasha's part,
59535. but only by the pleasure that just perceptibly lit up her whole face.
59536. 
59537. 
59538. 
59539. 
59540. 
59541. CHAPTER XVI
59542. 
59543. 
59544. "She has come to stay with me," said Princess Mary. "The count and
59545. countess will be here in a few days. The countess is in a dreadful
59546. state; but it was necessary for Natasha herself to see a doctor. They
59547. insisted on her coming with me."
59548. 
59549. "Yes, is there a family free from sorrow now?" said Pierre, addressing
59550. Natasha. "You know it happened the very day we were rescued. I saw him.
59551. What a delightful boy he was!"
59552. 
59553. Natasha looked at him, and by way of answer to his words her eyes
59554. widened and lit up.
59555. 
59556. "What can one say or think of as a consolation?" said Pierre. "Nothing!
59557. Why had such a splendid boy, so full of life, to die?"
59558. 
59559. "Yes, in these days it would be hard to live without faith..." remarked
59560. Princess Mary.
59561. 
59562. "Yes, yes, that is really true," Pierre hastily interrupted her.
59563. 
59564. "Why is it true?" Natasha asked, looking attentively into Pierre's eyes.
59565. 
59566. "How can you ask why?" said Princess Mary. "The thought alone of what
59567. awaits..."
59568. 
59569. Natasha without waiting for Princess Mary to finish again looked
59570. inquiringly at Pierre.
59571. 
59572. "And because," Pierre continued, "only one who believes that there is a
59573. God ruling us can bear a loss such as hers and... yours."
59574. 
59575. Natasha had already opened her mouth to speak but suddenly stopped.
59576. Pierre hurriedly turned away from her and again addressed Princess Mary,
59577. asking about his friend's last days.
59578. 
59579. Pierre's confusion had now almost vanished, but at the same time he felt
59580. that his freedom had also completely gone. He felt that there was now a
59581. judge of his every word and action whose judgment mattered more to
59582. him than that of all the rest of the world. As he spoke now he was
59583. considering what impression his words would make on Natasha. He did
59584. not purposely say things to please her, but whatever he was saying he
59585. regarded from her standpoint.
59586. 
59587. Princess Mary--reluctantly as is usual in such cases--began telling of
59588. the condition in which she had found Prince Andrew. But Pierre's face
59589. quivering with emotion, his questions and his eager restless expression,
59590. gradually compelled her to go into details which she feared to recall
59591. for her own sake.
59592. 
59593. "Yes, yes, and so...?" Pierre kept saying as he leaned toward her with
59594. his whole body and eagerly listened to her story. "Yes, yes... so he
59595. grew tranquil and softened? With all his soul he had always sought one
59596. thing--to be perfectly good--so he could not be afraid of death.
59597. The faults he had--if he had any--were not of his making. So he did
59598. soften?... What a happy thing that he saw you again," he added, suddenly
59599. turning to Natasha and looking at her with eyes full of tears.
59600. 
59601. Natasha's face twitched. She frowned and lowered her eyes for a moment.
59602. She hesitated for an instant whether to speak or not.
59603. 
59604. "Yes, that was happiness," she then said in her quiet voice with its
59605. deep chest notes. "For me it certainly was happiness." She paused. "And
59606. he... he... he said he was wishing for it at the very moment I entered
59607. the room...."
59608. 
59609. Natasha's voice broke. She blushed, pressed her clasped hands on her
59610. knees, and then controlling herself with an evident effort lifted her
59611. head and began to speak rapidly.
59612. 
59613. "We knew nothing of it when we started from Moscow. I did not dare to
59614. ask about him. Then suddenly Sonya told me he was traveling with us. I
59615. had no idea and could not imagine what state he was in, all I wanted was
59616. to see him and be with him," she said, trembling, and breathing quickly.
59617. 
59618. And not letting them interrupt her she went on to tell what she had
59619. never yet mentioned to anyone--all she had lived through during those
59620. three weeks of their journey and life at Yaroslavl.
59621. 
59622. Pierre listened to her with lips parted and eyes fixed upon her full of
59623. tears. As he listened he did not think of Prince Andrew, nor of death,
59624. nor of what she was telling. He listened to her and felt only pity for
59625. her, for what she was suffering now while she was speaking.
59626. 
59627. Princess Mary, frowning in her effort to hold back her tears, sat beside
59628. Natasha, and heard for the first time the story of those last days of
59629. her brother's and Natasha's love.
59630. 
59631. Evidently Natasha needed to tell that painful yet joyful tale.
59632. 
59633. She spoke, mingling most trifling details with the intimate secrets of
59634. her soul, and it seemed as if she could never finish. Several times she
59635. repeated the same thing twice.
59636. 
59637. Dessalles' voice was heard outside the door asking whether little
59638. Nicholas might come in to say good night.
59639. 
59640. "Well, that's all--everything," said Natasha.
59641. 
59642. She got up quickly just as Nicholas entered, almost ran to the door
59643. which was hidden by curtains, struck her head against it, and rushed
59644. from the room with a moan either of pain or sorrow.
59645. 
59646. Pierre gazed at the door through which she had disappeared and did not
59647. understand why he suddenly felt all alone in the world.
59648. 
59649. Princess Mary roused him from his abstraction by drawing his attention
59650. to her nephew who had entered the room.
59651. 
59652. At that moment of emotional tenderness young Nicholas' face, which
59653. resembled his father's, affected Pierre so much that when he had kissed
59654. the boy he got up quickly, took out his handkerchief, and went to the
59655. window. He wished to take leave of Princess Mary, but she would not let
59656. him go.
59657. 
59658. "No, Natasha and I sometimes don't go to sleep till after two, so please
59659. don't go. I will order supper. Go downstairs, we will come immediately."
59660. 
59661. Before Pierre left the room Princess Mary told him: "This is the first
59662. time she has talked of him like that."
59663. 
59664. 
59665. 
59666. 
59667. 
59668. CHAPTER XVII
59669. 
59670. 
59671. Pierre was shown into the large, brightly lit dining room; a few minutes
59672. later he heard footsteps and Princess Mary entered with Natasha. Natasha
59673. was calm, though a severe and grave expression had again settled on her
59674. face. They all three of them now experienced that feeling of awkwardness
59675. which usually follows after a serious and heartfelt talk. It is
59676. impossible to go back to the same conversation, to talk of trifles is
59677. awkward, and yet the desire to speak is there and silence seems like
59678. affectation. They went silently to table. The footmen drew back the
59679. chairs and pushed them up again. Pierre unfolded his cold table napkin
59680. and, resolving to break the silence, looked at Natasha and at Princess
59681. Mary. They had evidently both formed the same resolution; the eyes of
59682. both shone with satisfaction and a confession that besides sorrow life
59683. also has joy.
59684. 
59685. "Do you take vodka, Count?" asked Princess Mary, and those words
59686. suddenly banished the shadows of the past. "Now tell us about yourself,"
59687. said she. "One hears such improbable wonders about you."
59688. 
59689. "Yes," replied Pierre with the smile of mild irony now habitual to him.
59690. "They even tell me wonders I myself never dreamed of! Mary Abramovna
59691. invited me to her house and kept telling me what had happened, or ought
59692. to have happened, to me. Stepan Stepanych also instructed me how I ought
59693. to tell of my experiences. In general I have noticed that it is very
59694. easy to be an interesting man (I am an interesting man now); people
59695. invite me out and tell me all about myself."
59696. 
59697. Natasha smiled and was on the point of speaking.
59698. 
59699. "We have been told," Princess Mary interrupted her, "that you lost two
59700. millions in Moscow. Is that true?"
59701. 
59702. "But I am three times as rich as before," returned Pierre.
59703. 
59704. Though the position was now altered by his decision to pay his wife's
59705. debts and to rebuild his houses, Pierre still maintained that he had
59706. become three times as rich as before.
59707. 
59708. "What I have certainly gained is freedom," he began seriously, but did
59709. not continue, noticing that this theme was too egotistic.
59710. 
59711. "And are you building?"
59712. 
59713. "Yes. Savelich says I must!"
59714. 
59715. "Tell me, you did not know of the countess' death when you decided to
59716. remain in Moscow?" asked Princess Mary and immediately blushed, noticing
59717. that her question, following his mention of freedom, ascribed to his
59718. words a meaning he had perhaps not intended.
59719. 
59720. "No," answered Pierre, evidently not considering awkward the meaning
59721. Princess Mary had given to his words. "I heard of it in Orel and you
59722. cannot imagine how it shocked me. We were not an exemplary couple," he
59723. added quickly, glancing at Natasha and noticing on her face curiosity as
59724. to how he would speak of his wife, "but her death shocked me terribly.
59725. When two people quarrel they are always both in fault, and one's own
59726. guilt suddenly becomes terribly serious when the other is no longer
59727. alive. And then such a death... without friends and without consolation!
59728. I am very, very sorry for her," he concluded, and was pleased to notice
59729. a look of glad approval on Natasha's face.
59730. 
59731. "Yes, and so you are once more an eligible bachelor," said Princess
59732. Mary.
59733. 
59734. Pierre suddenly flushed crimson and for a long time tried not to look
59735. at Natasha. When he ventured to glance her way again her face was cold,
59736. stern, and he fancied even contemptuous.
59737. 
59738. "And did you really see and speak to Napoleon, as we have been told?"
59739. said Princess Mary.
59740. 
59741. Pierre laughed.
59742. 
59743. "No, not once! Everybody seems to imagine that being taken prisoner
59744. means being Napoleon's guest. Not only did I never see him but I heard
59745. nothing about him--I was in much lower company!"
59746. 
59747. Supper was over, and Pierre who at first declined to speak about his
59748. captivity was gradually led on to do so.
59749. 
59750. "But it's true that you remained in Moscow to kill Napoleon?" Natasha
59751. asked with a slight smile. "I guessed it then when we met at the
59752. Sukharev tower, do you remember?"
59753. 
59754. Pierre admitted that it was true, and from that was gradually led by
59755. Princess Mary's questions and especially by Natasha's into giving a
59756. detailed account of his adventures.
59757. 
59758. At first he spoke with the amused and mild irony now customary with
59759. him toward everybody and especially toward himself, but when he came
59760. to describe the horrors and sufferings he had witnessed he was
59761. unconsciously carried away and began speaking with the suppressed
59762. emotion of a man re-experiencing in recollection strong impressions he
59763. has lived through.
59764. 
59765. Princess Mary with a gentle smile looked now at Pierre and now at
59766. Natasha. In the whole narrative she saw only Pierre and his goodness.
59767. Natasha, leaning on her elbow, the expression of her face constantly
59768. changing with the narrative, watched Pierre with an attention that never
59769. wandered--evidently herself experiencing all that he described. Not only
59770. her look, but her exclamations and the brief questions she put, showed
59771. Pierre that she understood just what he wished to convey. It was clear
59772. that she understood not only what he said but also what he wished to,
59773. but could not, express in words. The account Pierre gave of the incident
59774. with the child and the woman for protecting whom he was arrested was
59775. this: "It was an awful sight--children abandoned, some in the flames...
59776. One was snatched out before my eyes... and there were women who had
59777. their things snatched off and their earrings torn out..." he flushed
59778. and grew confused. "Then a patrol arrived and all the men--all those who
59779. were not looting, that is--were arrested, and I among them."
59780. 
59781. "I am sure you're not telling us everything; I am sure you did
59782. something..." said Natasha and pausing added, "something fine?"
59783. 
59784. Pierre continued. When he spoke of the execution he wanted to pass
59785. over the horrible details, but Natasha insisted that he should not omit
59786. anything.
59787. 
59788. Pierre began to tell about Karataev, but paused. By this time he had
59789. risen from the table and was pacing the room, Natasha following him with
59790. her eyes. Then he added:
59791. 
59792. "No, you can't understand what I learned from that illiterate man--that
59793. simple fellow."
59794. 
59795. "Yes, yes, go on!" said Natasha. "Where is he?"
59796. 
59797. "They killed him almost before my eyes."
59798. 
59799. And Pierre, his voice trembling continually, went on to tell of the last
59800. days of their retreat, of Karataev's illness and his death.
59801. 
59802. He told of his adventures as he had never yet recalled them. He now, as
59803. it were, saw a new meaning in all he had gone through. Now that he was
59804. telling it all to Natasha he experienced that pleasure which a man has
59805. when women listen to him--not clever women who when listening either try
59806. to remember what they hear to enrich their minds and when opportunity
59807. offers to retell it, or who wish to adopt it to some thought of their
59808. own and promptly contribute their own clever comments prepared in their
59809. little mental workshop--but the pleasure given by real women gifted with
59810. a capacity to select and absorb the very best a man shows of himself.
59811. Natasha without knowing it was all attention: she did not lose a word,
59812. no single quiver in Pierre's voice, no look, no twitch of a muscle in
59813. his face, nor a single gesture. She caught the unfinished word in its
59814. flight and took it straight into her open heart, divining the secret
59815. meaning of all Pierre's mental travail.
59816. 
59817. Princess Mary understood his story and sympathized with him, but she
59818. now saw something else that absorbed all her attention. She saw the
59819. possibility of love and happiness between Natasha and Pierre, and the
59820. first thought of this filled her heart with gladness.
59821. 
59822. It was three o'clock in the morning. The footmen came in with sad and
59823. stern faces to change the candles, but no one noticed them.
59824. 
59825. Pierre finished his story. Natasha continued to look at him intently
59826. with bright, attentive, and animated eyes, as if trying to understand
59827. something more which he had perhaps left untold. Pierre in shamefaced
59828. and happy confusion glanced occasionally at her, and tried to think what
59829. to say next to introduce a fresh subject. Princess Mary was silent. It
59830. occurred to none of them that it was three o'clock and time to go to
59831. bed.
59832. 
59833. "People speak of misfortunes and sufferings," remarked Pierre, "but if
59834. at this moment I were asked: 'Would you rather be what you were before
59835. you were taken prisoner, or go through all this again?' then for
59836. heaven's sake let me again have captivity and horseflesh! We imagine
59837. that when we are thrown out of our usual ruts all is lost, but it is
59838. only then that what is new and good begins. While there is life there is
59839. happiness. There is much, much before us. I say this to you," he added,
59840. turning to Natasha.
59841. 
59842. "Yes, yes," she said, answering something quite different. "I too should
59843. wish nothing but to relive it all from the beginning."
59844. 
59845. Pierre looked intently at her.
59846. 
59847. "Yes, and nothing more," said Natasha.
59848. 
59849. "It's not true, not true!" cried Pierre. "I am not to blame for being
59850. alive and wishing to live--nor you either."
59851. 
59852. Suddenly Natasha bent her head, covered her face with her hands, and
