59853. began to cry.
59854. 
59855. "What is it, Natasha?" said Princess Mary.
59856. 
59857. "Nothing, nothing." She smiled at Pierre through her tears. "Good night!
59858. It is time for bed."
59859. 
59860. Pierre rose and took his leave.
59861. 
59862. 
59863. Princess Mary and Natasha met as usual in the bedroom. They talked of
59864. what Pierre had told them. Princess Mary did not express her opinion of
59865. Pierre nor did Natasha speak of him.
59866. 
59867. "Well, good night, Mary!" said Natasha. "Do you know, I am often afraid
59868. that by not speaking of him" (she meant Prince Andrew) "for fear of not
59869. doing justice to our feelings, we forget him."
59870. 
59871. Princess Mary sighed deeply and thereby acknowledged the justice of
59872. Natasha's remark, but she did not express agreement in words.
59873. 
59874. "Is it possible to forget?" said she.
59875. 
59876. "It did me so much good to tell all about it today. It was hard and
59877. painful, but good, very good!" said Natasha. "I am sure he really loved
59878. him. That is why I told him... Was it all right?" she added, suddenly
59879. blushing.
59880. 
59881. "To tell Pierre? Oh, yes. What a splendid man he is!" said Princess
59882. Mary.
59883. 
59884. "Do you know, Mary..." Natasha suddenly said with a mischievous smile
59885. such as Princess Mary had not seen on her face for a long time, "he has
59886. somehow grown so clean, smooth, and fresh--as if he had just come out of
59887. a Russian bath; do you understand? Out of a moral bath. Isn't it true?"
59888. 
59889. "Yes," replied Princess Mary. "He has greatly improved."
59890. 
59891. "With a short coat and his hair cropped; just as if, well, just as if he
59892. had come straight from the bath... Papa used to..."
59893. 
59894. "I understand why he" (Prince Andrew) "liked no one so much as him,"
59895. said Princess Mary.
59896. 
59897. "Yes, and yet he is quite different. They say men are friends when
59898. they are quite different. That must be true. Really he is quite unlike
59899. him--in everything."
59900. 
59901. "Yes, but he's wonderful."
59902. 
59903. "Well, good night," said Natasha.
59904. 
59905. And the same mischievous smile lingered for a long time on her face as
59906. if it had been forgotten there.
59907. 
59908. 
59909. 
59910. 
59911. 
59912. CHAPTER XVIII
59913. 
59914. 
59915. It was a long time before Pierre could fall asleep that night. He paced
59916. up and down his room, now turning his thoughts on a difficult problem
59917. and frowning, now suddenly shrugging his shoulders and wincing, and now
59918. smiling happily.
59919. 
59920. He was thinking of Prince Andrew, of Natasha, and of their love, at one
59921. moment jealous of her past, then reproaching himself for that feeling.
59922. It was already six in the morning and he still paced up and down the
59923. room.
59924. 
59925. "Well, what's to be done if it cannot be avoided? What's to be done?
59926. Evidently it has to be so," said he to himself, and hastily undressing
59927. he got into bed, happy and agitated but free from hesitation or
59928. indecision.
59929. 
59930. "Strange and impossible as such happiness seems, I must do everything
59931. that she and I may be man and wife," he told himself.
59932. 
59933. A few days previously Pierre had decided to go to Petersburg on the
59934. Friday. When he awoke on the Thursday, Savelich came to ask him about
59935. packing for the journey.
59936. 
59937. "What, to Petersburg? What is Petersburg? Who is there in Petersburg?"
59938. he asked involuntarily, though only to himself. "Oh, yes, long ago
59939. before this happened I did for some reason mean to go to Petersburg,"
59940. he reflected. "Why? But perhaps I shall go. What a good fellow he is and
59941. how attentive, and how he remembers everything," he thought, looking at
59942. Savelich's old face, "and what a pleasant smile he has!"
59943. 
59944. "Well, Savelich, do you still not wish to accept your freedom?" Pierre
59945. asked him.
59946. 
59947. "What's the good of freedom to me, your excellency? We lived under the
59948. late count--the kingdom of heaven be his!--and we have lived under you
59949. too, without ever being wronged."
59950. 
59951. "And your children?"
59952. 
59953. "The children will live just the same. With such masters one can live."
59954. 
59955. "But what about my heirs?" said Pierre. "Supposing I suddenly marry...
59956. it might happen," he added with an involuntary smile.
59957. 
59958. "If I may take the liberty, your excellency, it would be a good thing."
59959. 
59960. "How easy he thinks it," thought Pierre. "He doesn't know how terrible
59961. it is and how dangerous. Too soon or too late... it is terrible!"
59962. 
59963. "So what are your orders? Are you starting tomorrow?" asked Savelich.
59964. 
59965. "No, I'll put it off for a bit. I'll tell you later. You must forgive
59966. the trouble I have put you to," said Pierre, and seeing Savelich smile,
59967. he thought: "But how strange it is that he should not know that now
59968. there is no Petersburg for me, and that that must be settled first of
59969. all! But probably he knows it well enough and is only pretending. Shall
59970. I have a talk with him and see what he thinks?" Pierre reflected. "No,
59971. another time."
59972. 
59973. At breakfast Pierre told the princess, his cousin, that he had been to
59974. see Princess Mary the day before and had there met--"Whom do you think?
59975. Natasha Rostova!"
59976. 
59977. The princess seemed to see nothing more extraordinary in that than if he
59978. had seen Anna Semenovna.
59979. 
59980. "Do you know her?" asked Pierre.
59981. 
59982. "I have seen the princess," she replied. "I heard that they were
59983. arranging a match for her with young Rostov. It would be a very good
59984. thing for the Rostovs, they are said to be utterly ruined."
59985. 
59986. "No; I mean do you know Natasha Rostova?"
59987. 
59988. "I heard about that affair of hers at the time. It was a great pity."
59989. 
59990. "No, she either doesn't understand or is pretending," thought Pierre.
59991. "Better not say anything to her either."
59992. 
59993. The princess too had prepared provisions for Pierre's journey.
59994. 
59995. "How kind they all are," thought Pierre. "What is surprising is that
59996. they should trouble about these things now when it can no longer be of
59997. interest to them. And all for me!"
59998. 
59999. On the same day the Chief of Police came to Pierre, inviting him to send
60000. a representative to the Faceted Palace to recover things that were to be
60001. returned to their owners that day.
60002. 
60003. "And this man too," thought Pierre, looking into the face of the Chief
60004. of Police. "What a fine, good-looking officer and how kind. Fancy
60005. bothering about such trifles now! And they actually say he is not honest
60006. and takes bribes. What nonsense! Besides, why shouldn't he take bribes?
60007. That's the way he was brought up, and everybody does it. But what a
60008. kind, pleasant face and how he smiles as he looks at me."
60009. 
60010. Pierre went to Princess Mary's to dinner.
60011. 
60012. As he drove through the streets past the houses that had been burned
60013. down, he was surprised by the beauty of those ruins. The picturesqueness
60014. of the chimney stacks and tumble-down walls of the burned-out quarters
60015. of the town, stretching out and concealing one another, reminded him of
60016. the Rhine and the Colosseum. The cabmen he met and their passengers,
60017. the carpenters cutting the timber for new houses with axes, the women
60018. hawkers, and the shopkeepers, all looked at him with cheerful beaming
60019. eyes that seemed to say: "Ah, there he is! Let's see what will come of
60020. it!"
60021. 
60022. At the entrance to Princess Mary's house Pierre felt doubtful whether
60023. he had really been there the night before and really seen Natasha and
60024. talked to her. "Perhaps I imagined it; perhaps I shall go in and find
60025. no one there." But he had hardly entered the room before he felt her
60026. presence with his whole being by the loss of his sense of freedom. She
60027. was in the same black dress with soft folds and her hair was done the
60028. same way as the day before, yet she was quite different. Had she been
60029. like this when he entered the day before he could not for a moment have
60030. failed to recognize her.
60031. 
60032. She was as he had known her almost as a child and later on as Prince
60033. Andrew's fiancee. A bright questioning light shone in her eyes, and on
60034. her face was a friendly and strangely roguish expression.
60035. 
60036. Pierre dined with them and would have spent the whole evening there, but
60037. Princess Mary was going to vespers and Pierre left the house with her.
60038. 
60039. Next day he came early, dined, and stayed the whole evening. Though
60040. Princess Mary and Natasha were evidently glad to see their visitor and
60041. though all Pierre's interest was now centered in that house, by the
60042. evening they had talked over everything and the conversation passed from
60043. one trivial topic to another and repeatedly broke off. He stayed so long
60044. that Princess Mary and Natasha exchanged glances, evidently wondering
60045. when he would go. Pierre noticed this but could not go. He felt uneasy
60046. and embarrassed, but sat on because he simply could not get up and take
60047. his leave.
60048. 
60049. Princess Mary, foreseeing no end to this, rose first, and complaining of
60050. a headache began to say good night.
60051. 
60052. "So you are going to Petersburg tomorrow?" she asked.
60053. 
60054. "No, I am not going," Pierre replied hastily, in a surprised tone and as
60055. though offended. "Yes... no... to Petersburg? Tomorrow--but I won't say
60056. good-by yet. I will call round in case you have any commissions for me,"
60057. said he, standing before Princess Mary and turning red, but not taking
60058. his departure.
60059. 
60060. Natasha gave him her hand and went out. Princess Mary on the other hand
60061. instead of going away sank into an armchair, and looked sternly and
60062. intently at him with her deep, radiant eyes. The weariness she
60063. had plainly shown before had now quite passed off. With a deep and
60064. long-drawn sigh she seemed to be prepared for a lengthy talk.
60065. 
60066. When Natasha left the room Pierre's confusion and awkwardness
60067. immediately vanished and were replaced by eager excitement. He quickly
60068. moved an armchair toward Princess Mary.
60069. 
60070. "Yes, I wanted to tell you," said he, answering her look as if she had
60071. spoken. "Princess, help me! What am I to do? Can I hope? Princess, my
60072. dear friend, listen! I know it all. I know I am not worthy of her, I
60073. know it's impossible to speak of it now. But I want to be a brother to
60074. her. No, not that, I don't, I can't..."
60075. 
60076. He paused and rubbed his face and eyes with his hands.
60077. 
60078. "Well," he went on with an evident effort at self-control and coherence.
60079. "I don't know when I began to love her, but I have loved her and her
60080. alone all my life, and I love her so that I cannot imagine life without
60081. her. I cannot propose to her at present, but the thought that
60082. perhaps she might someday be my wife and that I may be missing that
60083. possibility... that possibility... is terrible. Tell me, can I hope?
60084. Tell me what I am to do, dear princess!" he added after a pause, and
60085. touched her hand as she did not reply.
60086. 
60087. "I am thinking of what you have told me," answered Princess Mary.
60088. "This is what I will say. You are right that to speak to her of love at
60089. present..."
60090. 
60091. Princess Mary stopped. She was going to say that to speak of love was
60092. impossible, but she stopped because she had seen by the sudden change
60093. in Natasha two days before that she would not only not be hurt if Pierre
60094. spoke of his love, but that it was the very thing she wished for.
60095. 
60096. "To speak to her now wouldn't do," said the princess all the same.
60097. 
60098. "But what am I to do?"
60099. 
60100. "Leave it to me," said Princess Mary. "I know..."
60101. 
60102. Pierre was looking into Princess Mary's eyes.
60103. 
60104. "Well?... Well?..." he said.
60105. 
60106. "I know that she loves... will love you," Princess Mary corrected
60107. herself.
60108. 
60109. Before her words were out, Pierre had sprung up and with a frightened
60110. expression seized Princess Mary's hand.
60111. 
60112. "What makes you think so? You think I may hope? You think...?"
60113. 
60114. "Yes, I think so," said Princess Mary with a smile. "Write to her
60115. parents, and leave it to me. I will tell her when I can. I wish it to
60116. happen and my heart tells me it will."
60117. 
60118. "No, it cannot be! How happy I am! But it can't be.... How happy I am!
60119. No, it can't be!" Pierre kept saying as he kissed Princess Mary's hands.
60120. 
60121. "Go to Petersburg, that will be best. And I will write to you," she
60122. said.
60123. 
60124. "To Petersburg? Go there? Very well, I'll go. But I may come again
60125. tomorrow?"
60126. 
60127. Next day Pierre came to say good-by. Natasha was less animated than
60128. she had been the day before; but that day as he looked at her Pierre
60129. sometimes felt as if he was vanishing and that neither he nor she
60130. existed any longer, that nothing existed but happiness. "Is it possible?
60131. No, it can't be," he told himself at every look, gesture, and word that
60132. filled his soul with joy.
60133. 
60134. When on saying good-by he took her thin, slender hand, he could not help
60135. holding it a little longer in his own.
60136. 
60137. "Is it possible that this hand, that face, those eyes, all this treasure
60138. of feminine charm so strange to me now, is it possible that it will one
60139. day be mine forever, as familiar to me as I am to myself?... No, that's
60140. impossible!..."
60141. 
60142. "Good-by, Count," she said aloud. "I shall look forward very much to
60143. your return," she added in a whisper.
60144. 
60145. And these simple words, her look, and the expression on her face which
60146. accompanied them, formed for two months the subject of inexhaustible
60147. memories, interpretations, and happy meditations for Pierre. "'I shall
60148. look forward very much to your return....' Yes, yes, how did she say it?
60149. Yes, 'I shall look forward very much to your return.' Oh, how happy I
60150. am! What is happening to me? How happy I am!" said Pierre to himself.
60151. 
60152. 
60153. 
60154. 
60155. 
60156. CHAPTER XIX
60157. 
60158. 
60159. There was nothing in Pierre's soul now at all like what had troubled it
60160. during his courtship of Helene.
60161. 
60162. He did not repeat to himself with a sickening feeling of shame the words
60163. he had spoken, or say: "Oh, why did I not say that?" and, "Whatever made
60164. me say 'Je vous aime'?" On the contrary, he now repeated in imagination
60165. every word that he or Natasha had spoken and pictured every detail of
60166. her face and smile, and did not wish to diminish or add anything, but
60167. only to repeat it again and again. There was now not a shadow of doubt
60168. in his mind as to whether what he had undertaken was right or wrong.
60169. Only one terrible doubt sometimes crossed his mind: "Wasn't it all
60170. a dream? Isn't Princess Mary mistaken? Am I not too conceited and
60171. self-confident? I believe all this--and suddenly Princess Mary will tell
60172. her, and she will be sure to smile and say: 'How strange! He must be
60173. deluding himself. Doesn't he know that he is a man, just a man, while
60174. I...? I am something altogether different and higher.'"
60175. 
60176. That was the only doubt often troubling Pierre. He did not now make any
60177. plans. The happiness before him appeared so inconceivable that if only
60178. he could attain it, it would be the end of all things. Everything ended
60179. with that.
60180. 
60181. A joyful, unexpected frenzy, of which he had thought himself incapable,
60182. possessed him. The whole meaning of life--not for him alone but for the
60183. whole world--seemed to him centered in his love and the possibility of
60184. being loved by her. At times everybody seemed to him to be occupied with
60185. one thing only--his future happiness. Sometimes it seemed to him that
60186. other people were all as pleased as he was himself and merely tried to
60187. hide that pleasure by pretending to be busy with other interests. In
60188. every word and gesture he saw allusions to his happiness. He often
60189. surprised those he met by his significantly happy looks and smiles which
60190. seemed to express a secret understanding between him and them. And when
60191. he realized that people might not be aware of his happiness, he pitied
60192. them with his whole heart and felt a desire somehow to explain to them
60193. that all that occupied them was a mere frivolous trifle unworthy of
60194. attention.
60195. 
60196. When it was suggested to him that he should enter the civil service,
60197. or when the war or any general political affairs were discussed on the
60198. assumption that everybody's welfare depended on this or that issue
60199. of events, he would listen with a mild and pitying smile and surprise
60200. people by his strange comments. But at this time he saw everybody--both
60201. those who, as he imagined, understood the real meaning of life (that
60202. is, what he was feeling) and those unfortunates who evidently did not
60203. understand it--in the bright light of the emotion that shone within
60204. himself, and at once without any effort saw in everyone he met
60205. everything that was good and worthy of being loved.
60206. 
60207. When dealing with the affairs and papers of his dead wife, her memory
60208. aroused in him no feeling but pity that she had not known the bliss he
60209. now knew. Prince Vasili, who having obtained a new post and some
60210. fresh decorations was particularly proud at this time, seemed to him a
60211. pathetic, kindly old man much to be pitied.
60212. 
60213. Often in afterlife Pierre recalled this period of blissful insanity. All
60214. the views he formed of men and circumstances at this time remained true
60215. for him always. He not only did not renounce them subsequently, but when
60216. he was in doubt or inwardly at variance, he referred to the views he had
60217. held at this time of his madness and they always proved correct.
60218. 
60219. "I may have appeared strange and queer then," he thought, "but I was
60220. not so mad as I seemed. On the contrary I was then wiser and had
60221. more insight than at any other time, and understood all that is worth
60222. understanding in life, because... because I was happy."
60223. 
60224. Pierre's insanity consisted in not waiting, as he used to do, to
60225. discover personal attributes which he termed "good qualities" in people
60226. before loving them; his heart was now overflowing with love, and by
60227. loving people without cause he discovered indubitable causes for loving
60228. them.
60229. 
60230. 
60231. 
60232. 
60233. 
60234. CHAPTER XX
60235. 
60236. 
60237. After Pierre's departure that first evening, when Natasha had said to
60238. Princess Mary with a gaily mocking smile: "He looks just, yes, just as
60239. if he had come out of a Russian bath--in a short coat and with his hair
60240. cropped," something hidden and unknown to herself, but irrepressible,
60241. awoke in Natasha's soul.
60242. 
60243. Everything: her face, walk, look, and voice, was suddenly altered.
60244. To her own surprise a power of life and hope of happiness rose to the
60245. surface and demanded satisfaction. From that evening she seemed to have
60246. forgotten all that had happened to her. She no longer complained of her
60247. position, did not say a word about the past, and no longer feared to
60248. make happy plans for the future. She spoke little of Pierre, but when
60249. Princess Mary mentioned him a long-extinguished light once more kindled
60250. in her eyes and her lips curved with a strange smile.
60251. 
60252. The change that took place in Natasha at first surprised Princess Mary;
60253. but when she understood its meaning it grieved her. "Can she have loved
60254. my brother so little as to be able to forget him so soon?" she thought
60255. when she reflected on the change. But when she was with Natasha she was
60256. not vexed with her and did not reproach her. The reawakened power
60257. of life that had seized Natasha was so evidently irrepressible and
60258. unexpected by her that in her presence Princess Mary felt that she had
60259. no right to reproach her even in her heart.
60260. 
60261.  Natasha gave herself up so fully and frankly to this new feeling
60262. that she did not try to hide the fact that she was no longer sad, but
60263. bright and cheerful.
60264. 
60265. When Princess Mary returned to her room after her nocturnal talk with
60266. Pierre, Natasha met her on the threshold.
60267. 
60268. "He has spoken? Yes? He has spoken?" she repeated.
60269. 
60270. And a joyful yet pathetic expression which seemed to beg forgiveness for
60271. her joy settled on Natasha's face.
60272. 
60273. "I wanted to listen at the door, but I knew you would tell me."
60274. 
60275. Understandable and touching as the look with which Natasha gazed at
60276. her seemed to Princess Mary, and sorry as she was to see her agitation,
60277. these words pained her for a moment. She remembered her brother and his
60278. love.
60279. 
60280. "But what's to be done? She can't help it," thought the princess.
60281. 
60282. And with a sad and rather stern look she told Natasha all that Pierre
60283. had said. On hearing that he was going to Petersburg Natasha was
60284. astounded.
60285. 
60286. "To Petersburg!" she repeated as if unable to understand.
60287. 
60288. But noticing the grieved expression on Princess Mary's face she guessed
60289. the reason of that sadness and suddenly began to cry.
60290. 
60291. "Mary," said she, "tell me what I should do! I am afraid of being bad.
60292. Whatever you tell me, I will do. Tell me...."
60293. 
60294. "You love him?"
60295. 
60296. "Yes," whispered Natasha.
60297. 
60298. "Then why are you crying? I am happy for your sake," said Princess Mary,
60299. who because of those tears quite forgave Natasha's joy.
60300. 
60301. "It won't be just yet--someday. Think what fun it will be when I am his
60302. wife and you marry Nicholas!"
60303. 
60304. "Natasha, I have asked you not to speak of that. Let us talk about you."
60305. 
60306. They were silent awhile.
60307. 
60308. "But why go to Petersburg?" Natasha suddenly asked, and hastily replied
60309. to her own question. "But no, no, he must... Yes, Mary, He must...."
60310. 
60311. 
60312. 
60313. 
60314. 
60315. FIRST EPILOGUE: 1813 - 20
60316. 
60317. 
60318. 
60319. 
60320. 
60321. CHAPTER I
60322. 
60323. 
60324. Seven years had passed. The storm-tossed sea of European history had
60325. subsided within its shores and seemed to have become calm. But the
60326. mysterious forces that move humanity (mysterious because the laws of
60327. their motion are unknown to us) continued to operate.
60328. 
60329. Though the surface of the sea of history seemed motionless, the movement
60330. of humanity went on as unceasingly as the flow of time. Various groups
60331. of people formed and dissolved, the coming formation and dissolution of
60332. kingdoms and displacement of peoples was in course of preparation.
60333. 
60334. The sea of history was not driven spasmodically from shore to shore as
60335. previously. It was seething in its depths. Historic figures were not
60336. borne by the waves from one shore to another as before. They now seemed
60337. to rotate on one spot. The historical figures at the head of armies,
60338. who formerly reflected the movement of the masses by ordering wars,
60339. campaigns, and battles, now reflected the restless movement by political
60340. and diplomatic combinations, laws, and treaties.
60341. 
60342. The historians call this activity of the historical figures "the
60343. reaction."
60344. 
60345. In dealing with this period they sternly condemn the historical
60346. personages who, in their opinion, caused what they describe as the
60347. reaction. All the well-known people of that period, from Alexander and
60348. Napoleon to Madame de Stael, Photius, Schelling, Fichte, Chateaubriand,
60349. and the rest, pass before their stern judgment seat and are acquitted or
60350. condemned according to whether they conduced to progress or to reaction.
60351. 
60352. According to their accounts a reaction took place at that time in Russia
60353. also, and the chief culprit was Alexander I, the same man who according
60354. to them was the chief cause of the liberal movement at the commencement
60355. of his reign, being the savior of Russia.
60356. 
60357. There is no one in Russian literature now, from schoolboy essayist to
60358. learned historian, who does not throw his little stone at Alexander for
60359. things he did wrong at this period of his reign.
60360. 
60361. "He ought to have acted in this way and in that way. In this case he did
60362. well and in that case badly. He behaved admirably at the beginning of
60363. his reign and during 1812, but acted badly by giving a constitution
60364. to Poland, forming the Holy Alliance, entrusting power to Arakcheev,
60365. favoring Golitsyn and mysticism, and afterwards Shishkov and Photius.
60366. He also acted badly by concerning himself with the active army and
60367. disbanding the Semenov regiment."
60368. 
60369. It would take a dozen pages to enumerate all the reproaches the
60370. historians address to him, based on their knowledge of what is good for
60371. humanity.
60372. 
60373. What do these reproaches mean?
60374. 
60375. Do not the very actions for which the historians praise Alexander I
60376. (the liberal attempts at the beginning of his reign, his struggle with
60377. Napoleon, the firmness he displayed in 1812 and the campaign of 1813)
60378. flow from the same sources--the circumstances of his birth, education,
60379. and life--that made his personality what it was and from which the
60380. actions for which they blame him (the Holy Alliance, the restoration of
60381. Poland, and the reaction of 1820 and later) also flowed?
60382. 
60383. In what does the substance of those reproaches lie?
60384. 
60385. It lies in the fact that an historic character like Alexander I,
60386. standing on the highest possible pinnacle of human power with the
60387. blinding light of history focused upon him; a character exposed to those
60388. strongest of all influences: the intrigues, flattery, and self-deception
60389. inseparable from power; a character who at every moment of his life
60390. felt a responsibility for all that was happening in Europe; and not
60391. a fictitious but a live character who like every man had his personal
60392. habits, passions, and impulses toward goodness, beauty, and truth--that
60393. this character--though not lacking in virtue (the historians do not
60394. accuse him of that)--had not the same conception of the welfare of
60395. humanity fifty years ago as a present-day professor who from his
60396. youth upwards has been occupied with learning: that is, with books and
60397. lectures and with taking notes from them.
60398. 
60399. But even if we assume that fifty years ago Alexander I was mistaken in
60400. his view of what was good for the people, we must inevitably assume that
60401. the historian who judges Alexander will also after the lapse of some
60402. time turn out to be mistaken in his view of what is good for humanity.
60403. This assumption is all the more natural and inevitable because, watching
60404. the movement of history, we see that every year and with each new
60405. writer, opinion as to what is good for mankind changes; so that what
60406. once seemed good, ten years later seems bad, and vice versa. And what is
60407. more, we find at one and the same time quite contradictory views as to
60408. what is bad and what is good in history: some people regard giving a
60409. constitution to Poland and forming the Holy Alliance as praiseworthy in
60410. Alexander, while others regard it as blameworthy.
60411. 
60412. The activity of Alexander or of Napoleon cannot be called useful or
60413. harmful, for it is impossible to say for what it was useful or harmful.
60414. If that activity displeases somebody, this is only because it does
60415. not agree with his limited understanding of what is good. Whether the
60416. preservation of my father's house in Moscow, or the glory of the Russian
60417. arms, or the prosperity of the Petersburg and other universities, or the
60418. freedom of Poland or the greatness of Russia, or the balance of power in
60419. Europe, or a certain kind of European culture called "progress" appear
60420. to me to be good or bad, I must admit that besides these things the
60421. action of every historic character has other more general purposes
60422. inaccessible to me.
60423. 
60424. But let us assume that what is called science can harmonize all
60425. contradictions and possesses an unchanging standard of good and bad by
60426. which to try historic characters and events; let us say that Alexander
60427. could have done everything differently; let us say that with guidance
60428. from those who blame him and who profess to know the ultimate aim of the
60429. movement of humanity, he might have arranged matters according to the
60430. program his present accusers would have given him--of nationality,
60431. freedom, equality, and progress (these, I think, cover the ground). Let
60432. us assume that this program was possible and had then been formulated,
60433. and that Alexander had acted on it. What would then have become of the
60434. activity of all those who opposed the tendency that then prevailed in
60435. the government--an activity that in the opinion of the historians was
60436. good and beneficent? Their activity would not have existed: there would
60437. have been no life, there would have been nothing.
60438. 
60439. If we admit that human life can be ruled by reason, the possibility of
60440. life is destroyed.
60441. 
60442. 
60443. 
60444. 
60445. 
60446. CHAPTER II
60447. 
60448. 
60449. If we assume as the historians do that great men lead humanity to the
60450. attainment of certain ends--the greatness of Russia or of France,
60451. the balance of power in Europe, the diffusion of the ideas of the
60452. Revolution, general progress, or anything else--then it is impossible
60453. to explain the facts of history without introducing the conceptions of
60454. chance and genius.
60455. 
60456. If the aim of the European wars at the beginning of the nineteenth
60457. century had been the aggrandizement of Russia, that aim might have been
60458. accomplished without all the preceding wars and without the invasion. If
60459. the aim was the aggrandizement of France, that might have been attained
60460. without the Revolution and without the Empire. If the aim was the
60461. dissemination of ideas, the printing press could have accomplished that
60462. much better than warfare. If the aim was the progress of civilization,
60463. it is easy to see that there are other ways of diffusing civilization
60464. more expedient than by the destruction of wealth and of human lives.
60465. 
60466. Why did it happen in this and not in some other way?
60467. 
60468. Because it happened so! "Chance created the situation; genius utilized
60469. it," says history.
60470. 
60471. But what is chance? What is genius?
60472. 
60473. The words chance and genius do not denote any really existing thing and
60474. therefore cannot be defined. Those words only denote a certain stage of
60475. understanding of phenomena. I do not know why a certain event occurs; I
60476. think that I cannot know it; so I do not try to know it and I talk about
60477. chance. I see a force producing effects beyond the scope of ordinary
60478. human agencies; I do not understand why this occurs and I talk of
60479. genius.
60480. 
60481. To a herd of rams, the ram the herdsman drives each evening into a
60482. special enclosure to feed and that becomes twice as fat as the others
60483. must seem to be a genius. And it must appear an astonishing conjunction
60484. of genius with a whole series of extraordinary chances that this ram,
60485. who instead of getting into the general fold every evening goes into
60486. a special enclosure where there are oats--that this very ram, swelling
60487. with fat, is killed for meat.
60488. 
60489. But the rams need only cease to suppose that all that happens to them
60490. happens solely for the attainment of their sheepish aims; they need only
60491. admit that what happens to them may also have purposes beyond their ken,
60492. and they will at once perceive a unity and coherence in what happened
60493. to the ram that was fattened. Even if they do not know for what purpose
60494. they are fattened, they will at least know that all that happened to the
60495. ram did not happen accidentally, and will no longer need the conceptions
60496. of chance or genius.
60497. 
60498. Only by renouncing our claim to discern a purpose immediately
60499. intelligible to us, and admitting the ultimate purpose to be beyond our
60500. ken, may we discern the sequence of experiences in the lives of
60501. historic characters and perceive the cause of the effect they produce
60502. (incommensurable with ordinary human capabilities), and then the words
60503. chance and genius become superfluous.
60504. 
60505. We need only confess that we do not know the purpose of the European
60506. convulsions and that we know only the facts--that is, the murders, first
60507. in France, then in Italy, in Africa, in Prussia, in Austria, in Spain,
60508. and in Russia--and that the movements from the west to the east and from
60509. the east to the west form the essence and purpose of these events, and
60510. not only shall we have no need to see exceptional ability and genius in
60511. Napoleon and Alexander, but we shall be unable to consider them to
60512. be anything but like other men, and we shall not be obliged to have
60513. recourse to chance for an explanation of those small events which made
60514. these people what they were, but it will be clear that all those small
60515. events were inevitable.
60516. 
60517. By discarding a claim to knowledge of the ultimate purpose, we shall
60518. clearly perceive that just as one cannot imagine a blossom or seed for
60519. any single plant better suited to it than those it produces, so it is
60520. impossible to imagine any two people more completely adapted down to the
60521. smallest detail for the purpose they had to fulfill, than Napoleon and
60522. Alexander with all their antecedents.
60523. 
60524. 
60525. 
60526. 
60527. 
60528. CHAPTER III
60529. 
60530. 
60531. The fundamental and essential significance of the European events of the
60532. beginning of the nineteenth century lies in the movement of the mass of
60533. the European peoples from west to east and afterwards from east to west.
60534. The commencement of that movement was the movement from west to east.
60535. For the peoples of the west to be able to make their warlike movement
60536. to Moscow it was necessary: (1) that they should form themselves into
60537. a military group of a size able to endure a collision with the warlike
60538. military group of the east, (2) that they should abandon all established
60539. traditions and customs, and (3) that during their military movement they
60540. should have at their head a man who could justify to himself and to them
60541. the deceptions, robberies, and murders which would have to be committed
60542. during that movement.
60543. 
60544. And beginning with the French Revolution the old inadequately large
60545. group was destroyed, as well as the old habits and traditions, and step
60546. by step a group was formed of larger dimensions with new customs and
60547. traditions, and a man was produced who would stand at the head of the
60548. coming movement and bear the responsibility for all that had to be done.
60549. 
60550. A man without convictions, without habits, without traditions, without
60551. a name, and not even a Frenchman, emerges--by what seem the strangest
60552. chances--from among all the seething French parties, and without joining
60553. any one of them is borne forward to a prominent position.
60554. 
60555. The ignorance of his colleagues, the weakness and insignificance of
60556. his opponents, the frankness of his falsehoods, and the dazzling and
60557. self-confident limitations of this man raise him to the head of the
60558. army. The brilliant qualities of the soldiers of the army sent to Italy,
60559. his opponents' reluctance to fight, and his own childish audacity and
60560. self-confidence secure him military fame. Innumerable so called chances
60561. accompany him everywhere. The disfavor into which he falls with the
60562. rulers of France turns to his advantage. His attempts to avoid his
60563. predestined path are unsuccessful: he is not received into the Russian
60564. service, and the appointment he seeks in Turkey comes to nothing. During
60565. the war in Italy he is several times on the verge of destruction and
60566. each time is saved in an unexpected manner. Owing to various diplomatic
60567. considerations the Russian armies--just those which might have destroyed
60568. his prestige--do not appear upon the scene till he is no longer there.
60569. 
60570. On his return from Italy he finds the government in Paris in a process
60571. of dissolution in which all those who are in it are inevitably wiped
60572. out and destroyed. And by chance an escape from this dangerous position
60573. presents itself in the form of an aimless and senseless expedition
60574. to Africa. Again so-called chance accompanies him. Impregnable Malta
60575. surrenders without a shot; his most reckless schemes are crowned with
60576. success. The enemy's fleet, which subsequently did not let a single boat
60577. pass, allows his entire army to elude it. In Africa a whole series of
60578. outrages are committed against the almost unarmed inhabitants. And the
60579. men who commit these crimes, especially their leader, assure themselves
60580. that this is admirable, this is glory--it resembles Caesar and Alexander
60581. the Great and is therefore good.
60582. 
60583. This ideal of glory and grandeur--which consists not merely in
60584. considering nothing wrong that one does but in priding oneself on every
60585. crime one commits, ascribing to it an incomprehensible supernatural
60586. significance--that ideal, destined to guide this man and his associates,
60587. had scope for its development in Africa. Whatever he does succeeds. The
60588. plague does not touch him. The cruelty of murdering prisoners is not
60589. imputed to him as a fault. His childishly rash, uncalled-for, and
60590. ignoble departure from Africa, leaving his comrades in distress, is
60591. set down to his credit, and again the enemy's fleet twice lets him slip
60592. past. When, intoxicated by the crimes he has committed so successfully,
60593. he reaches Paris, the dissolution of the republican government, which a
60594. year earlier might have ruined him, has reached its extreme limit, and
60595. his presence there now as a newcomer free from party entanglements can
60596. only serve to exalt him--and though he himself has no plan, he is quite
60597. ready for his new role.
60598. 
60599. He had no plan, he was afraid of everything, but the parties snatched at
60600. him and demanded his participation.
60601. 
60602. He alone--with his ideal of glory and grandeur developed in Italy and
60603. Egypt, his insane self-adulation, his boldness in crime and frankness in
60604. lying--he alone could justify what had to be done.
60605. 
60606. He is needed for the place that awaits him, and so almost apart from
60607. his will and despite his indecision, his lack of a plan, and all his
60608. mistakes, he is drawn into a conspiracy that aims at seizing power and
60609. the conspiracy is crowned with success.
60610. 
60611. He is pushed into a meeting of the legislature. In alarm he wishes to
60612. flee, considering himself lost. He pretends to fall into a swoon and
60613. says senseless things that should have ruined him. But the once proud
60614. and shrewd rulers of France, feeling that their part is played out, are
60615. even more bewildered than he, and do not say the words they should have
60616. said to destroy him and retain their power.
60617. 
60618. Chance, millions of chances, give him power, and all men as if by
60619. agreement co-operate to confirm that power. Chance forms the characters
60620. of the rulers of France, who submit to him; chance forms the character
60621. of Paul I of Russia who recognizes his government; chance contrives
60622. a plot against him which not only fails to harm him but confirms his
60623. power. Chance puts the Duc d'Enghien in his hands and unexpectedly
60624. causes him to kill him--thereby convincing the mob more forcibly than
60625. in any other way that he had the right, since he had the might.
60626. Chance contrives that though he directs all his efforts to prepare an
60627. expedition against England (which would inevitably have ruined him) he
60628. never carries out that intention, but unexpectedly falls upon Mack and
60629. the Austrians, who surrender without a battle. Chance and genius give
60630. him the victory at Austerlitz; and by chance all men, not only the
60631. French but all Europe--except England which does not take part in the
60632. events about to happen--despite their former horror and detestation of
60633. his crimes, now recognize his authority, the title he has given
60634. himself, and his ideal of grandeur and glory, which seems excellent and
60635. reasonable to them all.
60636. 
60637. As if measuring themselves and preparing for the coming movement, the
60638. western forces push toward the east several times in 1805, 1806, 1807,
60639. and 1809, gaining strength and growing. In 1811 the group of people that
60640. had formed in France unites into one group with the peoples of Central
60641. Europe. The strength of the justification of the man who stands at the
60642. head of the movement grows with the increased size of the group. During
60643. the ten-year preparatory period this man had formed relations with all
60644. the crowned heads of Europe. The discredited rulers of the world can
60645. oppose no reasonable ideal to the insensate Napoleonic ideal of
60646. glory and grandeur. One after another they hasten to display their
60647. insignificance before him. The King of Prussia sends his wife to seek
60648. the great man's mercy; the Emperor of Austria considers it a favor that
60649. this man receives a daughter of the Caesars into his bed; the Pope, the
60650. guardian of all that the nations hold sacred, utilizes religion for the
60651. aggrandizement of the great man. It is not Napoleon who prepares himself
60652. for the accomplishment of his role, so much as all those round him who
60653. prepare him to take on himself the whole responsibility for what is
60654. happening and has to happen. There is no step, no crime or petty fraud
60655. he commits, which in the mouths of those around him is not at once
60656. represented as a great deed. The most suitable fete the Germans can
60657. devise for him is a celebration of Jena and Auerstadt. Not only is he
60658. great, but so are his ancestors, his brothers, his stepsons, and his
60659. brothers-in-law. Everything is done to deprive him of the remains of his
60660. reason and to prepare him for his terrible part. And when he is ready so
60661. too are the forces.
60662. 
60663. The invasion pushes eastward and reaches its final goal--Moscow. That
60664. city is taken; the Russian army suffers heavier losses than the opposing
60665. armies had suffered in the former war from Austerlitz to Wagram. But
60666. suddenly instead of those chances and that genius which hitherto had
60667. so consistently led him by an uninterrupted series of successes to the
60668. predestined goal, an innumerable sequence of inverse chances occur--from
60669. the cold in his head at Borodino to the sparks which set Moscow on
60670. fire, and the frosts--and instead of genius, stupidity and immeasurable
60671. baseness become evident.
60672. 
60673. The invaders flee, turn back, flee again, and all the chances are now
60674. not for Napoleon but always against him.
60675. 
60676. A countermovement is then accomplished from east to west with a
60677. remarkable resemblance to the preceding movement from west to east.
60678. Attempted drives from east to west--similar to the contrary movements of
60679. 1805, 1807, and 1809--precede the great westward movement; there is the
60680. same coalescence into a group of enormous dimensions; the same adhesion
60681. of the people of Central Europe to the movement; the same hesitation
60682. midway, and the same increasing rapidity as the goal is approached.
60683. 
60684. Paris, the ultimate goal, is reached. The Napoleonic government and army
60685. are destroyed. Napoleon himself is no longer of any account; all his
60686. actions are evidently pitiful and mean, but again an inexplicable chance
60687. occurs. The allies detest Napoleon whom they regard as the cause of
60688. their sufferings. Deprived of power and authority, his crimes and his
60689. craft exposed, he should have appeared to them what he appeared ten
60690. years previously and one year later--an outlawed brigand. But by some
60691. strange chance no one perceives this. His part is not yet ended. The man
60692. who ten years before and a year later was considered an outlawed brigand
60693. is sent to an island two days' sail from France, which for some reason
60694. is presented to him as his dominion, and guards are given to him and
60695. millions of money are paid him.
60696. 
60697. 
60698. 
60699. 
60700. 
60701. CHAPTER IV
60702. 
60703. 
60704. The flood of nations begins to subside into its normal channels. The
60705. waves of the great movement abate, and on the calm surface eddies are
60706. formed in which float the diplomatists, who imagine that they have
60707. caused the floods to abate.
60708. 
60709. But the smooth sea again suddenly becomes disturbed. The diplomatists
60710. think that their disagreements are the cause of this fresh pressure
60711. of natural forces; they anticipate war between their sovereigns; the
60712. position seems to them insoluble. But the wave they feel to be rising
60713. does not come from the quarter they expect. It rises again from the same
60714. point as before--Paris. The last backwash of the movement from the west
60715. occurs: a backwash which serves to solve the apparently insuperable
60716. diplomatic difficulties and ends the military movement of that period of
60717. history.
60718. 
60719. The man who had devastated France returns to France alone, without any
60720. conspiracy and without soldiers. Any guard might arrest him, but by
60721. strange chance no one does so and all rapturously greet the man they
60722. cursed the day before and will curse again a month later.
60723. 
60724. This man is still needed to justify the final collective act.
60725. 
60726. That act is performed.
60727. 
60728. The last role is played. The actor is bidden to disrobe and wash off his
60729. powder and paint: he will not be wanted any more.
60730. 
60731. And some years pass during which he plays a pitiful comedy to himself
60732. in solitude on his island, justifying his actions by intrigues and lies
60733. when the justification is no longer needed, and displaying to the whole
60734. world what it was that people had mistaken for strength as long as an
60735. unseen hand directed his actions.
60736. 
60737. The manager having brought the drama to a close and stripped the actor
60738. shows him to us.
60739. 
60740. "See what you believed in! This is he! Do you now see that it was not he
60741. but I who moved you?"
60742. 
60743. But dazed by the force of the movement, it was long before people
60744. understood this.
60745. 
60746. Still greater coherence and inevitability is seen in the life of
60747. Alexander I, the man who stood at the head of the countermovement from
60748. east to west.
60749. 
60750. What was needed for him who, overshadowing others, stood at the head of
60751. that movement from east to west?
60752. 
60753. What was needed was a sense of justice and a sympathy with European
60754. affairs, but a remote sympathy not dulled by petty interests; a moral
60755. superiority over those sovereigns of the day who co-operated with him;
60756. a mild and attractive personality; and a personal grievance against
60757. Napoleon. And all this was found in Alexander I; all this had been
60758. prepared by innumerable so-called chances in his life: his education,
60759. his early liberalism, the advisers who surrounded him, and by
60760. Austerlitz, and Tilsit, and Erfurt.
60761. 
60762. During the national war he was inactive because he was not needed. But
60763. as soon as the necessity for a general European war presented itself he
60764. appeared in his place at the given moment and, uniting the nations of
60765. Europe, led them to the goal.
60766. 
60767. The goal is reached. After the final war of 1815 Alexander possesses all
60768. possible power. How does he use it?
60769. 
60770. Alexander I--the pacifier of Europe, the man who from his early years
60771. had striven only for his people's welfare, the originator of the liberal
60772. innovations in his fatherland--now that he seemed to possess the utmost
60773. power and therefore to have the possibility of bringing about the
60774. welfare of his peoples--at the time when Napoleon in exile was drawing
60775. up childish and mendacious plans of how he would have made mankind happy
60776. had he retained power--Alexander I, having fulfilled his mission and
60777. feeling the hand of God upon him, suddenly recognizes the insignificance
60778. of that supposed power, turns away from it, and gives it into the hands
60779. of contemptible men whom he despises, saying only:
60780. 
60781. "Not unto us, not unto us, but unto Thy Name!... I too am a man like the
60782. rest of you. Let me live like a man and think of my soul and of God."
60783. 
60784. As the sun and each atom of ether is a sphere complete in itself, and
60785. yet at the same time only a part of a whole too immense for man to
60786. comprehend, so each individual has within himself his own aims and yet
60787. has them to serve a general purpose incomprehensible to man.
60788. 
60789. A bee settling on a flower has stung a child. And the child is afraid
60790. of bees and declares that bees exist to sting people. A poet admires the
60791. bee sucking from the chalice of a flower and says it exists to suck the
60792. fragrance of flowers. A beekeeper, seeing the bee collect pollen from
60793. flowers and carry it to the hive, says that it exists to gather honey.
60794. Another beekeeper who has studied the life of the hive more closely
60795. says that the bee gathers pollen dust to feed the young bees and rear
60796. a queen, and that it exists to perpetuate its race. A botanist notices
60797. that the bee flying with the pollen of a male flower to a pistil
60798. fertilizes the latter, and sees in this the purpose of the bee's
60799. existence. Another, observing the migration of plants, notices that the
60800. bee helps in this work, and may say that in this lies the purpose of the
60801. bee. But the ultimate purpose of the bee is not exhausted by the first,
60802. the second, or any of the processes the human mind can discern. The
60803. higher the human intellect rises in the discovery of these purposes,
60804. the more obvious it becomes, that the ultimate purpose is beyond our
60805. comprehension.
60806. 
60807. All that is accessible to man is the relation of the life of the bee to
60808. other manifestations of life. And so it is with the purpose of historic
60809. characters and nations.
60810. 
60811. 
60812. 
60813. 
60814. 
60815. CHAPTER V
60816. 
60817. 
60818. Natasha's wedding to Bezukhov, which took place in 1813, was the last
60819. happy event in the family of the old Rostovs. Count Ilya Rostov died
60820. that same year and, as always happens, after the father's death the
60821. family group broke up.
60822. 
60823. The events of the previous year: the burning of Moscow and the flight
60824. from it, the death of Prince Andrew, Natasha's despair, Petya's death,
60825. and the old countess' grief fell blow after blow on the old count's
60826. head. He seemed to be unable to understand the meaning of all these
60827. events, and bowed his old head in a spiritual sense as if expecting and
60828. inviting further blows which would finish him. He seemed now frightened
60829. and distraught and now unnaturally animated and enterprising.
60830. 
60831. The arrangements for Natasha's marriage occupied him for a while. He
60832. ordered dinners and suppers and obviously tried to appear cheerful, but
60833. his cheerfulness was not infectious as it used to be: on the contrary it
60834. evoked the compassion of those who knew and liked him.
60835. 
60836. When Pierre and his wife had left, he grew very quiet and began to
60837. complain of depression. A few days later he fell ill and took to his
60838. bed. He realized from the first that he would not get up again, despite
60839. the doctor's encouragement. The countess passed a fortnight in an
60840. armchair by his pillow without undressing. Every time she gave him
60841. his medicine he sobbed and silently kissed her hand. On his last day,
60842. sobbing, he asked her and his absent son to forgive him for having
60843. dissipated their property--that being the chief fault of which he was
60844. conscious. After receiving communion and unction he quietly died; and
60845. next day a throng of acquaintances who came to pay their last respects
60846. to the deceased filled the house rented by the Rostovs. All these
60847. acquaintances, who had so often dined and danced at his house and had so
60848. often laughed at him, now said, with a common feeling of self-reproach
60849. and emotion, as if justifying themselves: "Well, whatever he may have
60850. been he was a most worthy man. You don't meet such men nowadays.... And
60851. which of us has not weaknesses of his own?"
60852. 
60853. It was just when the count's affairs had become so involved that it was
60854. impossible to say what would happen if he lived another year that he
60855. unexpectedly died.
60856. 
60857. Nicholas was with the Russian army in Paris when the news of his
60858. father's death reached him. He at once resigned his commission, and
60859. without waiting for it to be accepted took leave of absence and went to
60860. Moscow. The state of the count's affairs became quite obvious a month
60861. after his death, surprising everyone by the immense total of small
60862. debts the existence of which no one had suspected. The debts amounted to
60863. double the value of the property.
60864. 
60865. Friends and relations advised Nicholas to decline the inheritance. But
60866. he regarded such a refusal as a slur on his father's memory, which he
60867. held sacred, and therefore would not hear of refusing and accepted the
60868. inheritance together with the obligation to pay the debts.
60869. 
60870. The creditors who had so long been silent, restrained by a vague
60871. but powerful influence exerted on them while he lived by the count's
60872. careless good nature, all proceeded to enforce their claims at once. As
60873. always happens in such cases rivalry sprang up as to which should get
60874. paid first, and those who like Mitenka held promissory notes given them
60875. as presents now became the most exacting of the creditors. Nicholas was
60876. allowed no respite and no peace, and those who had seemed to pity
60877. the old man--the cause of their losses (if they were losses)--now
60878. remorselessly pursued the young heir who had voluntarily undertaken the
60879. debts and was obviously not guilty of contracting them.
60880. 
60881. Not one of the plans Nicholas tried succeeded; the estate was sold by
60882. auction for half its value, and half the debts still remained
60883. unpaid. Nicholas accepted thirty thousand rubles offered him by his
60884. brother-in-law Bezukhov to pay off debts he regarded as genuinely due
60885. for value received. And to avoid being imprisoned for the remainder, as
60886. the creditors threatened, he re-entered the government service.
60887. 
60888. He could not rejoin the army where he would have been made colonel at
60889. the next vacancy, for his mother now clung to him as her one hold on
60890. life; and so despite his reluctance to remain in Moscow among people who
60891. had known him before, and despite his abhorrence of the civil service,
60892. he accepted a post in Moscow in that service, doffed the uniform of
60893. which he was so fond, and moved with his mother and Sonya to a small
60894. house on the Sivtsev Vrazhek.
60895. 
60896. Natasha and Pierre were living in Petersburg at the time and had no
60897. clear idea of Nicholas' circumstances. Having borrowed money from his
60898. brother-in-law, Nicholas tried to hide his wretched condition from him.
60899. His position was the more difficult because with his salary of twelve
60900. hundred rubles he had not only to keep himself, his mother, and Sonya,
60901. but had to shield his mother from knowledge of their poverty. The
60902. countess could not conceive of life without the luxurious conditions she
60903. had been used to from childhood and, unable to realize how hard it was
60904. for her son, kept demanding now a carriage (which they did not keep) to
60905. send for a friend, now some expensive article of food for herself, or
60906. wine for her son, or money to buy a present as a surprise for Natasha or
60907. Sonya, or for Nicholas himself.
60908. 
60909. Sonya kept house, attended on her aunt, read to her, put up with her
60910. whims and secret ill-will, and helped Nicholas to conceal their poverty
60911. from the old countess. Nicholas felt himself irredeemably indebted
60912. to Sonya for all she was doing for his mother and greatly admired her
60913. patience and devotion, but tried to keep aloof from her.
60914. 
60915. He seemed in his heart to reproach her for being too perfect, and
60916. because there was nothing to reproach her with. She had all that people
60917. are valued for, but little that could have made him love her. He felt
60918. that the more he valued her the less he loved her. He had taken her at
60919. her word when she wrote giving him his freedom and now behaved as if all
60920. that had passed between them had been long forgotten and could never in
60921. any case be renewed.
60922. 
60923. Nicholas' position became worse and worse. The idea of putting something
60924. aside out of his salary proved a dream. Not only did he not save
60925. anything, but to comply with his mother's demands he even incurred some
60926. small debts. He could see no way out of this situation. The idea of
60927. marrying some rich woman, which was suggested to him by his female
60928. relations, was repugnant to him. The other way out--his mother's
60929. death--never entered his head. He wished for nothing and hoped
60930. for nothing, and deep in his heart experienced a gloomy and stern
60931. satisfaction in an uncomplaining endurance of his position. He tried
60932. to avoid his old acquaintances with their commiseration and offensive
60933. offers of assistance; he avoided all distraction and recreation, and
60934. even at home did nothing but play cards with his mother, pace silently
60935. up and down the room, and smoke one pipe after another. He seemed
60936. carefully to cherish within himself the gloomy mood which alone enabled
60937. him to endure his position.
60938. 
60939. 
60940. 
60941. 
60942. 
60943. CHAPTER VI
60944. 
60945. 
60946. At the beginning of winter Princess Mary came to Moscow. From reports
60947. current in town she learned how the Rostovs were situated, and how "the
60948. son has sacrificed himself for his mother," as people were saying.
60949. 
60950. "I never expected anything else of him," said Princess Mary to herself,
60951. feeling a joyous sense of her love for him. Remembering her friendly
60952. relations with all the Rostovs which had made her almost a member of the
60953. family, she thought it her duty to go to see them. But remembering her
60954. relations with Nicholas in Voronezh she was shy about doing so. Making
60955. a great effort she did however go to call on them a few weeks after her
60956. arrival in Moscow.
60957. 
60958. Nicholas was the first to meet her, as the countess' room could only be
60959. reached through his. But instead of being greeted with pleasure as she
60960. had expected, at his first glance at her his face assumed a cold, stiff,
60961. proud expression she had not seen on it before. He inquired about her
60962. health, led the way to his mother, and having sat there for five minutes
60963. left the room.
60964. 
60965. When the princess came out of the countess' room Nicholas met her again,
60966. and with marked solemnity and stiffness accompanied her to the anteroom.
60967. To her remarks about his mother's health he made no reply. "What's that
60968. to you? Leave me in peace," his looks seemed to say.
60969. 
60970. "Why does she come prowling here? What does she want? I can't bear these
60971. ladies and all these civilities!" said he aloud in Sonya's presence,
60972. evidently unable to repress his vexation, after the princess' carriage
60973. had disappeared.
60974. 
60975. "Oh, Nicholas, how can you talk like that?" cried Sonya, hardly able to
60976. conceal her delight. "She is so kind and Mamma is so fond of her!"
60977. 
60978. Nicholas did not reply and tried to avoid speaking of the princess any
60979. more. But after her visit the old countess spoke of her several times a
60980. day.
60981. 
60982. She sang her praises, insisted that her son must call on her, expressed
60983. a wish to see her often, but yet always became ill-humored when she
60984. began to talk about her.
60985. 
60986. Nicholas tried to keep silence when his mother spoke of the princess,
60987. but his silence irritated her.
60988. 
60989. "She is a very admirable and excellent young woman," said she, "and you
60990. must go and call on her. You would at least be seeing somebody, and I
60991. think it must be dull for you only seeing us."
60992. 
60993. "But I don't in the least want to, Mamma."
60994. 
60995. "You used to want to, and now you don't. Really I don't understand you,
60996. my dear. One day you are dull, and the next you refuse to see anyone."
60997. 
60998. "But I never said I was dull."
60999. 
61000. "Why, you said yourself you don't want even to see her. She is a very
61001. admirable young woman and you always liked her, but now suddenly you
61002. have got some notion or other in your head. You hide everything from
61003. me."
61004. 
61005. "Not at all, Mamma."
61006. 
61007. "If I were asking you to do something disagreeable now--but I only ask
61008. you to return a call. One would think mere politeness required it....
61009. Well, I have asked you, and now I won't interfere any more since you
61010. have secrets from your mother."
61011. 
61012. "Well, then, I'll go if you wish it."
61013. 
61014. "It doesn't matter to me. I only wish it for your sake."
61015. 
61016. Nicholas sighed, bit his mustache, and laid out the cards for a
61017. patience, trying to divert his mother's attention to another topic.
61018. 
61019. The same conversation was repeated next day and the day after, and the
61020. day after that.
61021. 
61022. After her visit to the Rostovs and her unexpectedly chilly reception by
61023. Nicholas, Princess Mary confessed to herself that she had been right in
61024. not wishing to be the first to call.
61025. 
61026. "I expected nothing else," she told herself, calling her pride to her
61027. aid. "I have nothing to do with him and I only wanted to see the
61028. old lady, who was always kind to me and to whom I am under many
61029. obligations."
61030. 
61031. But she could not pacify herself with these reflections; a feeling akin
61032. to remorse troubled her when she thought of her visit. Though she had
61033. firmly resolved not to call on the Rostovs again and to forget the whole
61034. matter, she felt herself all the time in an awkward position. And when
61035. she asked herself what distressed her, she had to admit that it was her
61036. relation to Rostov. His cold, polite manner did not express his feeling
61037. for her (she knew that) but it concealed something, and until she could
61038. discover what that something was, she felt that she could not be at
61039. ease.
61040. 
61041. One day in midwinter when sitting in the schoolroom attending to her
61042. nephew's lessons, she was informed that Rostov had called. With a firm
61043. resolution not to betray herself and not show her agitation, she sent
61044. for Mademoiselle Bourienne and went with her to the drawing room.
61045. 
61046. Her first glance at Nicholas' face told her that he had only come to
61047. fulfill the demands of politeness, and she firmly resolved to maintain
61048. the tone in which he addressed her.
61049. 
61050. They spoke of the countess' health, of their mutual friends, of the
61051. latest war news, and when the ten minutes required by propriety had
61052. elapsed after which a visitor may rise, Nicholas got up to say good-by.
61053. 
61054. With Mademoiselle Bourienne's help the princess had maintained the
61055. conversation very well, but at the very last moment, just when he rose,
61056. she was so tired of talking of what did not interest her, and her
61057. mind was so full of the question why she alone was granted so little
61058. happiness in life, that in a fit of absent-mindedness she sat still, her
61059. luminous eyes gazing fixedly before her, not noticing that he had risen.
61060. 
61061. Nicholas glanced at her and, wishing to appear not to notice her
61062. abstraction, made some remark to Mademoiselle Bourienne and then
61063. again looked at the princess. She still sat motionless with a look of
61064. suffering on her gentle face. He suddenly felt sorry for her and was
61065. vaguely conscious that he might be the cause of the sadness her face
61066. expressed. He wished to help her and say something pleasant, but could
61067. think of nothing to say.
61068. 
61069. "Good-by, Princess!" said he.
61070. 
61071. She started, flushed, and sighed deeply.
61072. 
61073. "Oh, I beg your pardon," she said as if waking up. "Are you going
61074. already, Count? Well then, good-by! Oh, but the cushion for the
61075. countess!"
61076. 
61077. "Wait a moment, I'll fetch it," said Mademoiselle Bourienne, and she
61078. left the room.
61079. 
61080. They both sat silent, with an occasional glance at one another.
61081. 
61082. "Yes, Princess," said Nicholas at last with a sad smile, "it doesn't
61083. seem long ago since we first met at Bogucharovo, but how much water
61084. has flowed since then! In what distress we all seemed to be then, yet
61085. I would give much to bring back that time... but there's no bringing it
61086. back."
61087. 
61088. Princess Mary gazed intently into his eyes with her own luminous ones
61089. as he said this. She seemed to be trying to fathom the hidden meaning of
61090. his words which would explain his feeling for her.
61091. 
61092. "Yes, yes," said she, "but you have no reason to regret the past, Count.
61093. As I understand your present life, I think you will always recall it
61094. with satisfaction, because the self-sacrifice that fills it now..."
61095. 
61096. "I cannot accept your praise," he interrupted her hurriedly. "On the
61097. contrary I continually reproach myself.... But this is not at all an
61098. interesting or cheerful subject."
61099. 
61100. His face again resumed its former stiff and cold expression. But the
61101. princess had caught a glimpse of the man she had known and loved, and it
61102. was to him that she now spoke.
61103. 
61104. "I thought you would allow me to tell you this," she said. "I had come
61105. so near to you... and to all your family that I thought you would not
61106. consider my sympathy misplaced, but I was mistaken," and suddenly her
61107. voice trembled. "I don't know why," she continued, recovering herself,
61108. "but you used to be different, and..."
61109. 
61110. "There are a thousand reasons why," laying special emphasis on the why.
61111. "Thank you, Princess," he added softly. "Sometimes it is hard."
61112. 
61113. "So that's why! That's why!" a voice whispered in Princess Mary's soul.
61114. "No, it was not only that gay, kind, and frank look, not only that
61115. handsome exterior, that I loved in him. I divined his noble, resolute,
61116. self-sacrificing spirit too," she said to herself. "Yes, he is poor now
61117. and I am rich.... Yes, that's the only reason.... Yes, were it not for
61118. that..." And remembering his former tenderness, and looking now at his
61119. kind, sorrowful face, she suddenly understood the cause of his coldness.
61120. 
61121. "But why, Count, why?" she almost cried, unconsciously moving closer to
61122. him. "Why? Tell me. You must tell me!"
61123. 
61124. He was silent.
61125. 
61126. "I don't understand your why, Count," she continued, "but it's hard for
61127. me... I confess it. For some reason you wish to deprive me of our former
61128. friendship. And that hurts me." There were tears in her eyes and in her
61129. voice. "I have had so little happiness in life that every loss is hard
61130. for me to bear.... Excuse me, good-by!" and suddenly she began to cry
61131. and was hurrying from the room.
61132. 
61133. "Princess, for God's sake!" he exclaimed, trying to stop her.
61134. "Princess!"
61135. 
61136. She turned round. For a few seconds they gazed silently into one
61137. another's eyes--and what had seemed impossible and remote suddenly
61138. became possible, inevitable, and very near.
61139. 
61140. 
61141. 
61142. 
61143. 
61144. CHAPTER VII
61145. 
61146. 
61147. In the winter of 1813 Nicholas married Princess Mary and moved to Bald
61148. Hills with his wife, his mother, and Sonya.
61149. 
61150. Within four years he had paid off all his remaining debts without
61151. selling any of his wife's property, and having received a small
61152. inheritance on the death of a cousin he paid his debt to Pierre as well.
61153. 
61154. In another three years, by 1820, he had so managed his affairs that he
61155. was able to buy a small estate adjoining Bald Hills and was negotiating
61156. to buy back Otradnoe--that being his pet dream.
61157. 
61158. Having started farming from necessity, he soon grew so devoted to it
61159. that it became his favorite and almost his sole occupation. Nicholas was
61160. a plain farmer: he did not like innovations, especially the English ones
61161. then coming into vogue. He laughed at theoretical treatises on estate
61162. management, disliked factories, the raising of expensive products,
61163. and the buying of expensive seed corn, and did not make a hobby of any
61164. particular part of the work on his estate. He always had before his
61165. mind's eye the estate as a whole and not any particular part of it. The
61166. chief thing in his eyes was not the nitrogen in the soil, nor the oxygen
61167. in the air, nor manures, nor special plows, but that most important
61168. agent by which nitrogen, oxygen, manure, and plow were made
61169. effective--the peasant laborer. When Nicholas first began farming
61170. and began to understand its different branches, it was the serf who
61171. especially attracted his attention. The peasant seemed to him not merely
61172. a tool, but also a judge of farming and an end in himself. At first
61173. he watched the serfs, trying to understand their aims and what they
61174. considered good and bad, and only pretended to direct them and give
61175. orders while in reality learning from them their methods, their manner
61176. of speech, and their judgment of what was good and bad. Only when he
61177. had understood the peasants' tastes and aspirations, had learned to talk
61178. their language, to grasp the hidden meaning of their words, and felt
61179. akin to them did he begin boldly to manage his serfs, that is, to
61180. perform toward them the duties demanded of him. And Nicholas' management
61181. produced very brilliant results.
61182. 
61183. Guided by some gift of insight, on taking up the management of the
61184. estates he at once unerringly appointed as bailiff, village elder, and
61185. delegate, the very men the serfs would themselves have chosen had they
61186. had the right to choose, and these posts never changed hands. Before
61187. analyzing the properties of manure, before entering into the debit and
61188. credit (as he ironically called it), he found out how many cattle the
61189. peasants had and increased the number by all possible means. He kept the
61190. peasant families together in the largest groups possible, not allowing
61191. the family groups to divide into separate households. He was hard alike
61192. on the lazy, the depraved, and the weak, and tried to get them expelled
61193. from the commune.
61194. 
61195. He was as careful of the sowing and reaping of the peasants' hay
61196. and corn as of his own, and few landowners had their crops sown
61197. and harvested so early and so well, or got so good a return, as did
61198. Nicholas.
61199. 
61200. He disliked having anything to do with the domestic serfs--the "drones"
61201. as he called them--and everyone said he spoiled them by his laxity. When
61202. a decision had to be taken regarding a domestic serf, especially if one
61203. had to be punished, he always felt undecided and consulted everybody in
61204. the house; but when it was possible to have a domestic serf conscripted
61205. instead of a land worker he did so without the least hesitation. He
61206. never felt any hesitation in dealing with the peasants. He knew that his
61207. every decision would be approved by them all with very few exceptions.
61208. 
61209. He did not allow himself either to be hard on or punish a man, or to
61210. make things easy for or reward anyone, merely because he felt inclined
61211. to do so. He could not have said by what standard he judged what he
61212. should or should not do, but the standard was quite firm and definite in
61213. his own mind.
61214. 
61215. Often, speaking with vexation of some failure or irregularity, he would
61216. say: "What can one do with our Russian peasants?" and imagined that he
61217. could not bear them.
61218. 
61219. Yet he loved "our Russian peasants" and their way of life with his whole
61220. soul, and for that very reason had understood and assimilated the one
61221. way and manner of farming which produced good results.
61222. 
61223. Countess Mary was jealous of this passion of her husband's and regretted
61224. that she could not share it; but she could not understand the joys and
61225. vexations he derived from that world, to her so remote and alien. She
61226. could not understand why he was so particularly animated and happy
61227. when, after getting up at daybreak and spending the whole morning in the
61228. fields or on the threshing floor, he returned from the sowing or mowing
61229. or reaping to have tea with her. She did not understand why he spoke
61230. with such admiration and delight of the farming of the thrifty and
61231. well-to-do peasant Matthew Ermishin, who with his family had carted
61232. corn all night; or of the fact that his (Nicholas') sheaves were already
61233. stacked before anyone else had his harvest in. She did not understand
61234. why he stepped out from the window to the veranda and smiled under his
61235. mustache and winked so joyfully, when warm steady rain began to fall
61236. on the dry and thirsty shoots of the young oats, or why when the wind
61237. carried away a threatening cloud during the hay harvest he would return
61238. from the barn, flushed, sunburned, and perspiring, with a smell of
61239. wormwood and gentian in his hair and, gleefully rubbing his hands, would
61240. say: "Well, one more day and my grain and the peasants' will all be
61241. under cover."
61242. 
61243. Still less did she understand why he, kindhearted and always ready to
61244. anticipate her wishes, should become almost desperate when she brought
61245. him a petition from some peasant men or women who had appealed to her
61246. to be excused some work; why he, that kind Nicholas, should obstinately
61247. refuse her, angrily asking her not to interfere in what was not her
61248. business. She felt he had a world apart, which he loved passionately and
61249. which had laws she had not fathomed.
61250. 
61251. Sometimes when, trying to understand him, she spoke of the good work he
61252. was doing for his serfs, he would be vexed and reply: "Not in the least;
61253. it never entered my head and I wouldn't do that for their good! That's
61254. all poetry and old wives' talk--all that doing good to one's neighbor!
61255. What I want is that our children should not have to go begging. I must
61256. put our affairs in order while I am alive, that's all. And to do that,
61257. order and strictness are essential.... That's all about it!" said he,
61258. clenching his vigorous fist. "And fairness, of course," he added, "for
61259. if the peasant is naked and hungry and has only one miserable horse, he
61260. can do no good either for himself or for me."
61261. 
61262. And all Nicholas did was fruitful--probably just because he refused to
61263. allow himself to think that he was doing good to others for virtue's
61264. sake. His means increased rapidly; serfs from neighboring estates came
61265. to beg him to buy them, and long after his death the memory of his
61266. administration was devoutly preserved among the serfs. "He was a
61267. master... the peasants' affairs first and then his own. Of course he was
61268. not to be trifled with either--in a word, he was a real master!"
61269. 
61270. 
61271. 
61272. 
61273. 
61274. CHAPTER VIII
61275. 
61276. 
61277. One matter connected with his management sometimes worried Nicholas, and
61278. that was his quick temper together with his old hussar habit of making
61279. free use of his fists. At first he saw nothing reprehensible in
61280. this, but in the second year of his marriage his view of that form of
61281. punishment suddenly changed.
61282. 
61283. Once in summer he had sent for the village elder from Bogucharovo, a
61284. man who had succeeded to the post when Dron died and who was accused of
