61285. dishonesty and various irregularities. Nicholas went out into the porch
61286. to question him, and immediately after the elder had given a few replies
61287. the sound of cries and blows were heard. On returning to lunch Nicholas
61288. went up to his wife, who sat with her head bent low over her embroidery
61289. frame, and as usual began to tell her what he had been doing that
61290. morning. Among other things he spoke of the Bogucharovo elder. Countess
61291. Mary turned red and then pale, but continued to sit with head bowed and
61292. lips compressed and gave her husband no reply.
61293. 
61294. "Such an insolent scoundrel!" he cried, growing hot again at the mere
61295. recollection of him. "If he had told me he was drunk and did not see...
61296. But what is the matter with you, Mary?" he suddenly asked.
61297. 
61298. Countess Mary raised her head and tried to speak, but hastily looked
61299. down again and her lips puckered.
61300. 
61301. "Why, whatever is the matter, my dearest?"
61302. 
61303. The looks of the plain Countess Mary always improved when she was in
61304. tears. She never cried from pain or vexation, but always from sorrow or
61305. pity, and when she wept her radiant eyes acquired an irresistible charm.
61306. 
61307. The moment Nicholas took her hand she could no longer restrain herself
61308. and began to cry.
61309. 
61310. "Nicholas, I saw it... he was to blame, but why do you... Nicholas!" and
61311. she covered her face with her hands.
61312. 
61313. Nicholas said nothing. He flushed crimson, left her side, and paced up
61314. and down the room. He understood what she was weeping about, but could
61315. not in his heart at once agree with her that what he had regarded
61316. from childhood as quite an everyday event was wrong. "Is it just
61317. sentimentality, old wives' tales, or is she right?" he asked himself.
61318. Before he had solved that point he glanced again at her face filled with
61319. love and pain, and he suddenly realized that she was right and that he
61320. had long been sinning against himself.
61321. 
61322. "Mary," he said softly, going up to her, "it will never happen again;
61323. I give you my word. Never," he repeated in a trembling voice like a boy
61324. asking for forgiveness.
61325. 
61326. The tears flowed faster still from the countess' eyes. She took his hand
61327. and kissed it.
61328. 
61329. "Nicholas, when did you break your cameo?" she asked to change the
61330. subject, looking at his finger on which he wore a ring with a cameo of
61331. Laocoon's head.
61332. 
61333. "Today--it was the same affair. Oh, Mary, don't remind me of it!" and
61334. again he flushed. "I give you my word of honor it shan't occur again,
61335. and let this always be a reminder to me," and he pointed to the broken
61336. ring.
61337. 
61338. After that, when in discussions with his village elders or stewards the
61339. blood rushed to his face and his fists began to clench, Nicholas would
61340. turn the broken ring on his finger and would drop his eyes before the
61341. man who was making him angry. But he did forget himself once or twice
61342. within a twelvemonth, and then he would go and confess to his wife, and
61343. would again promise that this should really be the very last time.
61344. 
61345. "Mary, you must despise me!" he would say. "I deserve it."
61346. 
61347. "You should go, go away at once, if you don't feel strong enough to
61348. control yourself," she would reply sadly, trying to comfort her husband.
61349. 
61350. Among the gentry of the province Nicholas was respected but not liked.
61351. He did not concern himself with the interests of his own class, and
61352. consequently some thought him proud and others thought him stupid. The
61353. whole summer, from spring sowing to harvest, he was busy with the work
61354. on his farm. In autumn he gave himself up to hunting with the same
61355. business like seriousness--leaving home for a month, or even two, with
61356. his hunt. In winter he visited his other villages or spent his time
61357. reading. The books he read were chiefly historical, and on these he
61358. spent a certain sum every year. He was collecting, as he said, a serious
61359. library, and he made it a rule to read through all the books he bought.
61360. He would sit in his study with a grave air, reading--a task he first
61361. imposed upon himself as a duty, but which afterwards became a habit
61362. affording him a special kind of pleasure and a consciousness of
61363. being occupied with serious matters. In winter, except for business
61364. excursions, he spent most of his time at home making himself one with
61365. his family and entering into all the details of his children's relations
61366. with their mother. The harmony between him and his wife grew closer and
61367. closer and he daily discovered fresh spiritual treasures in her.
61368. 
61369. From the time of his marriage Sonya had lived in his house. Before
61370. that, Nicholas had told his wife all that had passed between himself and
61371. Sonya, blaming himself and commending her. He had asked Princess Mary to
61372. be gentle and kind to his cousin. She thoroughly realized the wrong he
61373. had done Sonya, felt herself to blame toward her, and imagined that her
61374. wealth had influenced Nicholas' choice. She could not find fault with
61375. Sonya in any way and tried to be fond of her, but often felt ill-will
61376. toward her which she could not overcome.
61377. 
61378. Once she had a talk with her friend Natasha about Sonya and about her
61379. own injustice toward her.
61380. 
61381. "You know," said Natasha, "you have read the Gospels a great deal--there
61382. is a passage in them that just fits Sonya."
61383. 
61384. "What?" asked Countess Mary, surprised.
61385. 
61386. "'To him that hath shall be given, and from him that hath not shall be
61387. taken away.' You remember? She is one that hath not; why, I don't know.
61388. Perhaps she lacks egotism, I don't know, but from her is taken away, and
61389. everything has been taken away. Sometimes I am dreadfully sorry for her.
61390. Formerly I very much wanted Nicholas to marry her, but I always had
61391. a sort of presentiment that it would not come off. She is a sterile
61392. flower, you know--like some strawberry blossoms. Sometimes I am sorry
61393. for her, and sometimes I think she doesn't feel it as you or I would."
61394. 
61395. Though Countess Mary told Natasha that those words in the Gospel must be
61396. understood differently, yet looking at Sonya she agreed with Natasha's
61397. explanation. It really seemed that Sonya did not feel her position
61398. trying, and had grown quite reconciled to her lot as a sterile flower.
61399. She seemed to be fond not so much of individuals as of the family as a
61400. whole. Like a cat, she had attached herself not to the people but to the
61401. home. She waited on the old countess, petted and spoiled the children,
61402. was always ready to render the small services for which she had a gift,
61403. and all this was unconsciously accepted from her with insufficient
61404. gratitude.
61405. 
61406. The country seat at Bald Hills had been rebuilt, though not on the same
61407. scale as under the old prince.
61408. 
61409. The buildings, begun under straitened circumstances, were more than
61410. simple. The immense house on the old stone foundations was of wood,
61411. plastered only inside. It had bare deal floors and was furnished with
61412. very simple hard sofas, armchairs, tables, and chairs made by their own
61413. serf carpenters out of their own birchwood. The house was spacious
61414. and had rooms for the house serfs and apartments for visitors. Whole
61415. families of the Rostovs' and Bolkonskis' relations sometimes came to
61416. Bald Hills with sixteen horses and dozens of servants and stayed for
61417. months. Besides that, four times a year, on the name days and birthdays
61418. of the hosts, as many as a hundred visitors would gather there for a day
61419. or two. The rest of the year life pursued its unbroken routine with its
61420. ordinary occupations, and its breakfasts, lunches, dinners, and suppers,
61421. provided out of the produce of the estate.
61422. 
61423. 
61424. 
61425. 
61426. 
61427. CHAPTER IX
61428. 
61429. 
61430. It was the eve of St. Nicholas, the fifth of December, 1820. Natasha had
61431. been staying at her brother's with her husband and children since early
61432. autumn. Pierre had gone to Petersburg on business of his own for three
61433. weeks as he said, but had remained there nearly seven weeks and was
61434. expected back every minute.
61435. 
61436. Besides the Bezukhov family, Nicholas' old friend the retired General
61437. Vasili Dmitrich Denisov was staying with the Rostovs this fifth of
61438. December.
61439. 
61440. On the sixth, which was his name day when the house would be full of
61441. visitors, Nicholas knew he would have to exchange his Tartar tunic for
61442. a tail coat, and put on narrow boots with pointed toes, and drive to
61443. the new church he had built, and then receive visitors who would come to
61444. congratulate him, offer them refreshments, and talk about the elections
61445. of the nobility; but he considered himself entitled to spend the eve
61446. of that day in his usual way. He examined the bailiff's accounts of
61447. the village in Ryazan which belonged to his wife's nephew, wrote two
61448. business letters, and walked over to the granaries, cattle yards and
61449. stables before dinner. Having taken precautions against the general
61450. drunkenness to be expected on the morrow because it was a great saint's
61451. day, he returned to dinner, and without having time for a private talk
61452. with his wife sat down at the long table laid for twenty persons, at
61453. which the whole household had assembled. At that table were his mother,
61454. his mother's old lady companion Belova, his wife, their three children
61455. with their governess and tutor, his wife's nephew with his tutor, Sonya,
61456. Denisov, Natasha, her three children, their governess, and old Michael
61457. Ivanovich, the late prince's architect, who was living on in retirement
61458. at Bald Hills.
61459. 
61460. Countess Mary sat at the other end of the table. When her husband took
61461. his place she concluded, from the rapid manner in which after taking
61462. up his table napkin he pushed back the tumbler and wineglass standing
61463. before him, that he was out of humor, as was sometimes the case when he
61464. came in to dinner straight from the farm--especially before the soup.
61465. Countess Mary well knew that mood of his, and when she herself was in
61466. a good frame of mind quietly waited till he had had his soup and then
61467. began to talk to him and make him admit that there was no cause for his
61468. ill-humor. But today she quite forgot that and was hurt that he should
61469. be angry with her without any reason, and she felt unhappy. She asked
61470. him where he had been. He replied. She again inquired whether
61471. everything was going well on the farm. Her unnatural tone made him wince
61472. unpleasantly and he replied hastily.
61473. 
61474. "Then I'm not mistaken," thought Countess Mary. "Why is he cross with
61475. me?" She concluded from his tone that he was vexed with her and wished
61476. to end the conversation. She knew her remarks sounded unnatural, but
61477. could not refrain from asking some more questions.
61478. 
61479. Thanks to Denisov the conversation at table soon became general and
61480. lively, and she did not talk to her husband. When they left the table
61481. and went as usual to thank the old countess, Countess Mary held out her
61482. hand and kissed her husband, and asked him why he was angry with her.
61483. 
61484. "You always have such strange fancies! I didn't even think of being
61485. angry," he replied.
61486. 
61487. But the word always seemed to her to imply: "Yes, I am angry but I won't
61488. tell you why."
61489. 
61490. Nicholas and his wife lived together so happily that even Sonya and the
61491. old countess, who felt jealous and would have liked them to disagree,
61492. could find nothing to reproach them with; but even they had their
61493. moments of antagonism. Occasionally, and it was always just after they
61494. had been happiest together, they suddenly had a feeling of estrangement
61495. and hostility, which occurred most frequently during Countess Mary's
61496. pregnancies, and this was such a time.
61497. 
61498. "Well, messieurs et mesdames," said Nicholas loudly and with apparent
61499. cheerfulness (it seemed to Countess Mary that he did it on purpose to
61500. vex her), "I have been on my feet since six this morning. Tomorrow I
61501. shall have to suffer, so today I'll go and rest."
61502. 
61503. And without a word to his wife he went to the little sitting room and
61504. lay down on the sofa.
61505. 
61506. "That's always the way," thought Countess Mary. "He talks to everyone
61507. except me. I see... I see that I am repulsive to him, especially when I
61508. am in this condition." She looked down at her expanded figure and in the
61509. glass at her pale, sallow, emaciated face in which her eyes now looked
61510. larger than ever.
61511. 
61512. And everything annoyed her--Denisov's shouting and laughter, Natasha's
61513. talk, and especially a quick glance Sonya gave her.
61514. 
61515. Sonya was always the first excuse Countess Mary found for feeling
61516. irritated.
61517. 
61518. Having sat awhile with her visitors without understanding anything of
61519. what they were saying, she softly left the room and went to the nursery.
61520. 
61521. The children were playing at "going to Moscow" in a carriage made of
61522. chairs and invited her to go with them. She sat down and played with
61523. them a little, but the thought of her husband and his unreasonable
61524. crossness worried her. She got up and, walking on tiptoe with
61525. difficulty, went to the small sitting room.
61526. 
61527. "Perhaps he is not asleep; I'll have an explanation with him," she
61528. said to herself. Little Andrew, her eldest boy, imitating his mother,
61529. followed her on tiptoe. She did not notice him.
61530. 
61531. "Mary, dear, I think he is asleep--he was so tired," said Sonya, meeting
61532. her in the large sitting room (it seemed to Countess Mary that she
61533. crossed her path everywhere). "Andrew may wake him."
61534. 
61535. Countess Mary looked round, saw little Andrew following her, felt that
61536. Sonya was right, and for that very reason flushed and with evident
61537. difficulty refrained from saying something harsh. She made no reply, but
61538. to avoid obeying Sonya beckoned to Andrew to follow her quietly and went
61539. to the door. Sonya went away by another door. From the room in which
61540. Nicholas was sleeping came the sound of his even breathing, every
61541. slightest tone of which was familiar to his wife. As she listened to it
61542. she saw before her his smooth handsome forehead, his mustache, and his
61543. whole face, as she had so often seen it in the stillness of the night
61544. when he slept. Nicholas suddenly moved and cleared his throat. And at
61545. that moment little Andrew shouted from outside the door: "Papa! Mamma's
61546. standing here!" Countess Mary turned pale with fright and made signs
61547. to the boy. He grew silent, and quiet ensued for a moment, terrible to
61548. Countess Mary. She knew how Nicholas disliked being waked. Then through
61549. the door she heard Nicholas clearing his throat again and stirring, and
61550. his voice said crossly:
61551. 
61552. "I can't get a moment's peace.... Mary, is that you? Why did you bring
61553. him here?"
61554. 
61555. "I only came in to look and did not notice... forgive me..."
61556. 
61557. Nicholas coughed and said no more. Countess Mary moved away from the
61558. door and took the boy back to the nursery. Five minutes later little
61559. black-eyed three-year-old Natasha, her father's pet, having learned from
61560. her brother that Papa was asleep and Mamma was in the sitting room, ran
61561. to her father unobserved by her mother. The dark-eyed little girl boldly
61562. opened the creaking door, went up to the sofa with energetic steps of
61563. her sturdy little legs, and having examined the position of her father,
61564. who was asleep with his back to her, rose on tiptoe and kissed the hand
61565. which lay under his head. Nicholas turned with a tender smile on his
61566. face.
61567. 
61568. "Natasha, Natasha!" came Countess Mary's frightened whisper from the
61569. door. "Papa wants to sleep."
61570. 
61571. "No, Mamma, he doesn't want to sleep," said little Natasha with
61572. conviction. "He's laughing."
61573. 
61574. Nicholas lowered his legs, rose, and took his daughter in his arms.
61575. 
61576. "Come in, Mary," he said to his wife.
61577. 
61578. She went in and sat down by her husband.
61579. 
61580. "I did not notice him following me," she said timidly. "I just looked
61581. in."
61582. 
61583. Holding his little girl with one arm, Nicholas glanced at his wife and,
61584. seeing her guilty expression, put his other arm around her and kissed
61585. her hair.
61586. 
61587. "May I kiss Mamma?" he asked Natasha.
61588. 
61589. Natasha smiled bashfully.
61590. 
61591. "Again!" she commanded, pointing with a peremptory gesture to the spot
61592. where Nicholas had placed the kiss.
61593. 
61594. "I don't know why you think I am cross," said Nicholas, replying to the
61595. question he knew was in his wife's mind.
61596. 
61597. "You have no idea how unhappy, how lonely, I feel when you are like
61598. that. It always seems to me..."
61599. 
61600. "Mary, don't talk nonsense. You ought to be ashamed of yourself!" he
61601. said gaily.
61602. 
61603. "It seems to be that you can't love me, that I am so plain... always...
61604. and now... in this cond..."
61605. 
61606. "Oh, how absurd you are! It is not beauty that endears, it's love that
61607. makes us see beauty. It is only Malvinas and women of that kind who are
61608. loved for their beauty. But do I love my wife? I don't love her, but...
61609. I don't know how to put it. Without you, or when something comes between
61610. us like this, I seem lost and can't do anything. Now do I love my
61611. finger? I don't love it, but just try to cut it off!"
61612. 
61613. "I'm not like that myself, but I understand. So you're not angry with
61614. me?"
61615. 
61616. "Awfully angry!" he said, smiling and getting up. And smoothing his hair
61617. he began to pace the room.
61618. 
61619. "Do you know, Mary, what I've been thinking?" he began, immediately
61620. thinking aloud in his wife's presence now that they had made it up.
61621. 
61622. He did not ask if she was ready to listen to him. He did not care. A
61623. thought had occurred to him and so it belonged to her also. And he told
61624. her of his intention to persuade Pierre to stay with them till spring.
61625. 
61626. Countess Mary listened till he had finished, made some remark, and in
61627. her turn began thinking aloud. Her thoughts were about the children.
61628. 
61629. "You can see the woman in her already," she said in French, pointing to
61630. little Natasha. "You reproach us women with being illogical. Here is our
61631. logic. I say: 'Papa wants to sleep!' but she says, 'No, he's laughing.'
61632. And she was right," said Countess Mary with a happy smile.
61633. 
61634. "Yes, yes." And Nicholas, taking his little daughter in his strong hand,
61635. lifted her high, placed her on his shoulder, held her by the legs, and
61636. paced the room with her. There was an expression of carefree happiness
61637. on the faces of both father and daughter.
61638. 
61639. "But you know you may be unfair. You are too fond of this one," his wife
61640. whispered in French.
61641. 
61642. "Yes, but what am I to do?... I try not to show..."
61643. 
61644. At that moment they heard the sound of the door pulley and footsteps in
61645. the hall and anteroom, as if someone had arrived.
61646. 
61647. "Somebody has come."
61648. 
61649. "I am sure it is Pierre. I will go and see," said Countess Mary and left
61650. the room.
61651. 
61652. In her absence Nicholas allowed himself to give his little daughter a
61653. gallop round the room. Out of breath, he took the laughing child quickly
61654. from his shoulder and pressed her to his heart. His capers reminded
61655. him of dancing, and looking at the child's round happy little face he
61656. thought of what she would be like when he was an old man, taking her
61657. into society and dancing the mazurka with her as his old father had
61658. danced Daniel Cooper with his daughter.
61659. 
61660. "It is he, it is he, Nicholas!" said Countess Mary, re-entering the room
61661. a few minutes later. "Now our Natasha has come to life. You should have
61662. seen her ecstasy, and how he caught it for having stayed away so long.
61663. Well, come along now, quick, quick! It's time you two were parted," she
61664. added, looking smilingly at the little girl who clung to her father.
61665. 
61666. Nicholas went out holding the child by the hand.
61667. 
61668. Countess Mary remained in the sitting room.
61669. 
61670. "I should never, never have believed that one could be so happy," she
61671. whispered to herself. A smile lit up her face but at the same time she
61672. sighed, and her deep eyes expressed a quiet sadness as though she
61673. felt, through her happiness, that there is another sort of happiness
61674. unattainable in this life and of which she involuntarily thought at that
61675. instant.
61676. 
61677. 
61678. 
61679. 
61680. 
61681. CHAPTER X
61682. 
61683. 
61684. Natasha had married in the early spring of 1813, and in 1820 already had
61685. three daughters besides a son for whom she had longed and whom she was
61686. now nursing. She had grown stouter and broader, so that it was difficult
61687. to recognize in this robust, motherly woman the slim, lively Natasha of
61688. former days. Her features were more defined and had a calm, soft,
61689. and serene expression. In her face there was none of the ever-glowing
61690. animation that had formerly burned there and constituted its charm.
61691. Now her face and body were often all that one saw, and her soul was
61692. not visible at all. All that struck the eye was a strong, handsome, and
61693. fertile woman. The old fire very rarely kindled in her face now. That
61694. happened only when, as was the case that day, her husband returned home,
61695. or a sick child was convalescent, or when she and Countess Mary spoke of
61696. Prince Andrew (she never mentioned him to her husband, who she imagined
61697. was jealous of Prince Andrew's memory), or on the rare occasions when
61698. something happened to induce her to sing, a practice she had quite
61699. abandoned since her marriage. At the rare moments when the old fire
61700. did kindle in her handsome, fully developed body she was even more
61701. attractive than in former days.
61702. 
61703. Since their marriage Natasha and her husband had lived in Moscow, in
61704. Petersburg, on their estate near Moscow, or with her mother, that is to
61705. say, in Nicholas' house. The young Countess Bezukhova was not often seen
61706. in society, and those who met her there were not pleased with her
61707. and found her neither attractive nor amiable. Not that Natasha liked
61708. solitude--she did not know whether she liked it or not, she even thought
61709. that she did not--but with her pregnancies, her confinements, the
61710. nursing of her children, and sharing every moment of her husband's life,
61711. she had demands on her time which could be satisfied only by renouncing
61712. society. All who had known Natasha before her marriage wondered at the
61713. change in her as at something extraordinary. Only the old countess with
61714. her maternal instinct had realized that all Natasha's outbursts had
61715. been due to her need of children and a husband--as she herself had once
61716. exclaimed at Otradnoe not so much in fun as in earnest--and her mother
61717. was now surprised at the surprise expressed by those who had never
61718. understood Natasha, and she kept saying that she had always known that
61719. Natasha would make an exemplary wife and mother.
61720. 
61721. "Only she lets her love of her husband and children overflow all
61722. bounds," said the countess, "so that it even becomes absurd."
61723. 
61724. Natasha did not follow the golden rule advocated by clever folk,
61725. especially by the French, which says that a girl should not let herself
61726. go when she marries, should not neglect her accomplishments, should be
61727. even more careful of her appearance than when she was unmarried, and
61728. should fascinate her husband as much as she did before he became her
61729. husband. Natasha on the contrary had at once abandoned all her witchery,
61730. of which her singing had been an unusually powerful part. She gave it up
61731. just because it was so powerfully seductive. She took no pains with
61732. her manners or with delicacy of speech, or with her toilet, or to show
61733. herself to her husband in her most becoming attitudes, or to avoid
61734. inconveniencing him by being too exacting. She acted in contradiction
61735. to all those rules. She felt that the allurements instinct had formerly
61736. taught her to use would now be merely ridiculous in the eyes of
61737. her husband, to whom she had from the first moment given herself up
61738. entirely--that is, with her whole soul, leaving no corner of it hidden
61739. from him. She felt that her unity with her husband was not maintained
61740. by the poetic feelings that had attracted him to her, but by something
61741. else--indefinite but firm as the bond between her own body and soul.
61742. 
61743. To fluff out her curls, put on fashionable dresses, and sing romantic
61744. songs to fascinate her husband would have seemed as strange as to adorn
61745. herself to attract herself. To adorn herself for others might perhaps
61746. have been agreeable--she did not know--but she had no time at all for
61747. it. The chief reason for devoting no time either to singing, to dress,
61748. or to choosing her words was that she really had no time to spare for
61749. these things.
61750. 
61751. We know that man has the faculty of becoming completely absorbed in
61752. a subject however trivial it may be, and that there is no subject so
61753. trivial that it will not grow to infinite proportions if one's entire
61754. attention is devoted to it.
61755. 
61756. The subject which wholly engrossed Natasha's attention was her family:
61757. that is, her husband whom she had to keep so that he should belong
61758. entirely to her and to the home, and the children whom she had to bear,
61759. bring into the world, nurse, and bring up.
61760. 
61761. And the deeper she penetrated, not with her mind only but with her whole
61762. soul, her whole being, into the subject that absorbed her, the larger
61763. did that subject grow and the weaker and more inadequate did her powers
61764. appear, so that she concentrated them wholly on that one thing and yet
61765. was unable to accomplish all that she considered necessary.
61766. 
61767. There were then as now conversations and discussions about women's
61768. rights, the relations of husband and wife and their freedom and rights,
61769. though these themes were not yet termed questions as they are now; but
61770. these topics were not merely uninteresting to Natasha, she positively
61771. did not understand them.
61772. 
61773. These questions, then as now, existed only for those who see nothing in
61774. marriage but the pleasure married people get from one another, that is,
61775. only the beginnings of marriage and not its whole significance, which
61776. lies in the family.
61777. 
61778. Discussions and questions of that kind, which are like the question of
61779. how to get the greatest gratification from one's dinner, did not then
61780. and do not now exist for those for whom the purpose of a dinner is the
61781. nourishment it affords; and the purpose of marriage is the family.
61782. 
61783. If the purpose of dinner is to nourish the body, a man who eats two
61784. dinners at once may perhaps get more enjoyment but will not attain his
61785. purpose, for his stomach will not digest the two dinners.
61786. 
61787. If the purpose of marriage is the family, the person who wishes to have
61788. many wives or husbands may perhaps obtain much pleasure, but in that
61789. case will not have a family.
61790. 
61791. If the purpose of food is nourishment and the purpose of marriage is the
61792. family, the whole question resolves itself into not eating more than one
61793. can digest, and not having more wives or husbands than are needed for
61794. the family--that is, one wife or one husband. Natasha needed a husband.
61795. A husband was given her and he gave her a family. And she not only saw
61796. no need of any other or better husband, but as all the powers of her
61797. soul were intent on serving that husband and family, she could not
61798. imagine and saw no interest in imagining how it would be if things were
61799. different.
61800. 
61801. Natasha did not care for society in general, but prized the more the
61802. society of her relatives--Countess Mary, and her brother, her mother,
61803. and Sonya. She valued the company of those to whom she could come
61804. striding disheveled from the nursery in her dressing gown, and with
61805. joyful face show a yellow instead of a green stain on baby's napkin, and
61806. from whom she could hear reassuring words to the effect that baby was
61807. much better.
61808. 
61809. To such an extent had Natasha let herself go that the way she dressed
61810. and did her hair, her ill-chosen words, and her jealousy--she was
61811. jealous of Sonya, of the governess, and of every woman, pretty or
61812. plain--were habitual subjects of jest to those about her. The general
61813. opinion was that Pierre was under his wife's thumb, which was really
61814. true. From the very first days of their married life Natasha had
61815. announced her demands. Pierre was greatly surprised by his wife's view,
61816. to him a perfectly novel one, that every moment of his life belonged to
61817. her and to the family. His wife's demands astonished him, but they also
61818. flattered him, and he submitted to them.
61819. 
61820. Pierre's subjection consisted in the fact that he not only dared not
61821. flirt with, but dared not even speak smilingly to, any other woman; did
61822. not dare dine at the Club as a pastime, did not dare spend money on a
61823. whim, and did not dare absent himself for any length of time, except on
61824. business--in which his wife included his intellectual pursuits, which
61825. she did not in the least understand but to which she attributed great
61826. importance. To make up for this, at home Pierre had the right to
61827. regulate his life and that of the whole family exactly as he chose. At
61828. home Natasha placed herself in the position of a slave to her husband,
61829. and the whole household went on tiptoe when he was occupied--that is,
61830. was reading or writing in his study. Pierre had but to show a partiality
61831. for anything to get just what he liked done always. He had only to
61832. express a wish and Natasha would jump up and run to fulfill it.
61833. 
61834. The entire household was governed according to Pierre's supposed orders,
61835. that is, by his wishes which Natasha tried to guess. Their way of
61836. life and place of residence, their acquaintances and ties, Natasha's
61837. occupations, the children's upbringing, were all selected not merely
61838. with regard to Pierre's expressed wishes, but to what Natasha from the
61839. thoughts he expressed in conversation supposed his wishes to be. And she
61840. deduced the essentials of his wishes quite correctly, and having once
61841. arrived at them clung to them tenaciously. When Pierre himself wanted to
61842. change his mind she would fight him with his own weapons.
61843. 
61844. Thus in a time of trouble ever memorable to him after the birth of their
61845. first child who was delicate, when they had to change the wet nurse
61846. three times and Natasha fell ill from despair, Pierre one day told her
61847. of Rousseau's view, with which he quite agreed, that to have a wet
61848. nurse is unnatural and harmful. When her next baby was born, despite
61849. the opposition of her mother, the doctors, and even of her husband
61850. himself--who were all vigorously opposed to her nursing her baby
61851. herself, a thing then unheard of and considered injurious--she insisted
61852. on having her own way, and after that nursed all her babies herself.
61853. 
61854. It very often happened that in a moment of irritation husband and wife
61855. would have a dispute, but long afterwards Pierre to his surprise and
61856. delight would find in his wife's ideas and actions the very thought
61857. against which she had argued, but divested of everything superfluous
61858. that in the excitement of the dispute he had added when expressing his
61859. opinion.
61860. 
61861. After seven years of marriage Pierre had the joyous and firm
61862. consciousness that he was not a bad man, and he felt this because he saw
61863. himself reflected in his wife. He felt the good and bad within himself
61864. inextricably mingled and overlapping. But only what was really good in
61865. him was reflected in his wife, all that was not quite good was rejected.
61866. And this was not the result of logical reasoning but was a direct and
61867. mysterious reflection.
61868. 
61869. 
61870. 
61871. 
61872. 
61873. CHAPTER XI
61874. 
61875. 
61876. Two months previously when Pierre was already staying with the Rostovs
61877. he had received a letter from Prince Theodore, asking him to come
61878. to Petersburg to confer on some important questions that were being
61879. discussed there by a society of which Pierre was one of the principal
61880. founders.
61881. 
61882. On reading that letter (she always read her husband's letters) Natasha
61883. herself suggested that he should go to Petersburg, though she would feel
61884. his absence very acutely. She attributed immense importance to all
61885. her husband's intellectual and abstract interests though she did not
61886. understand them, and she always dreaded being a hindrance to him in such
61887. matters. To Pierre's timid look of inquiry after reading the letter she
61888. replied by asking him to go, but to fix a definite date for his return.
61889. He was given four weeks' leave of absence.
61890. 
61891. Ever since that leave of absence had expired, more than a fortnight
61892. before, Natasha had been in a constant state of alarm, depression, and
61893. irritability.
61894. 
61895. Denisov, now a general on the retired list and much dissatisfied with
61896. the present state of affairs, had arrived during that fortnight. He
61897. looked at Natasha with sorrow and surprise as at a bad likeness of a
61898. person once dear. A dull, dejected look, random replies, and talk about
61899. the nursery was all he saw and heard from his former enchantress.
61900. 
61901. Natasha was sad and irritable all that time, especially when her mother,
61902. her brother, Sonya, or Countess Mary in their efforts to console her
61903. tried to excuse Pierre and suggested reasons for his delay in returning.
61904. 
61905. "It's all nonsense, all rubbish--those discussions which lead to nothing
61906. and all those idiotic societies!" Natasha declared of the very affairs
61907. in the immense importance of which she firmly believed.
61908. 
61909. And she would go to the nursery to nurse Petya, her only boy. No one
61910. else could tell her anything so comforting or so reasonable as this
61911. little three-month-old creature when he lay at her breast and she was
61912. conscious of the movement of his lips and the snuffling of his little
61913. nose. That creature said: "You are angry, you are jealous, you would
61914. like to pay him out, you are afraid--but here am I! And I am he..." and
61915. that was unanswerable. It was more than true.
61916. 
61917. During that fortnight of anxiety Natasha resorted to the baby for
61918. comfort so often, and fussed over him so much, that she overfed him and
61919. he fell ill. She was terrified by his illness, and yet that was just
61920. what she needed. While attending to him she bore the anxiety about her
61921. husband more easily.
61922. 
61923. She was nursing her boy when the sound of Pierre's sleigh was heard
61924. at the front door, and the old nurse--knowing how to please her
61925. mistress--entered the room inaudibly but hurriedly and with a beaming
61926. face.
61927. 
61928. "Has he come?" Natasha asked quickly in a whisper, afraid to move lest
61929. she should rouse the dozing baby.
61930. 
61931. "He's come, ma'am," whispered the nurse.
61932. 
61933. The blood rushed to Natasha's face and her feet involuntarily moved, but
61934. she could not jump up and run out. The baby again opened his eyes and
61935. looked at her. "You're here?" he seemed to be saying, and again lazily
61936. smacked his lips.
61937. 
61938. Cautiously withdrawing her breast, Natasha rocked him a little, handed
61939. him to the nurse, and went with rapid steps toward the door. But at the
61940. door she stopped as if her conscience reproached her for having in
61941. her joy left the child too soon, and she glanced round. The nurse with
61942. raised elbows was lifting the infant over the rail of his cot.
61943. 
61944. "Go, ma'am! Don't worry, go!" she whispered, smiling, with the kind of
61945. familiarity that grows up between a nurse and her mistress.
61946. 
61947. Natasha ran with light footsteps to the anteroom.
61948. 
61949. Denisov, who had come out of the study into the dancing room with his
61950. pipe, now for the first time recognized the old Natasha. A flood of
61951. brilliant, joyful light poured from her transfigured face.
61952. 
61953. "He's come!" she exclaimed as she ran past, and Denisov felt that he too
61954. was delighted that Pierre, whom he did not much care for, had returned.
61955. 
61956. On reaching the vestibule Natasha saw a tall figure in a fur coat
61957. unwinding his scarf. "It's he! It's really he! He has come!" she said
61958. to herself, and rushing at him embraced him, pressed his head to her
61959. breast, and then pushed him back and gazed at his ruddy, happy face,
61960. covered with hoarfrost. "Yes, it is he, happy and contented..."
61961. 
61962. Then all at once she remembered the tortures of suspense she had
61963. experienced for the last fortnight, and the joy that had lit up her
61964. face vanished; she frowned and overwhelmed Pierre with a torrent of
61965. reproaches and angry words.
61966. 
61967. "Yes, it's all very well for you. You are pleased, you've had a good
61968. time.... But what about me? You might at least have shown consideration
61969. for the children. I am nursing and my milk was spoiled.... Petya was at
61970. death's door. But you were enjoying yourself. Yes, enjoying..."
61971. 
61972. Pierre knew he was not to blame, for he could not have come sooner; he
61973. knew this outburst was unseemly and would blow over in a minute or two;
61974. above all he knew that he himself was bright and happy. He wanted
61975. to smile but dared not even think of doing so. He made a piteous,
61976. frightened face and bent down.
61977. 
61978. "I could not, on my honor. But how is Petya?"
61979. 
61980. "All right now. Come along! I wonder you're not ashamed! If only you
61981. could see what I was like without you, how I suffered!"
61982. 
61983. "You are well?"
61984. 
61985. "Come, come!" she said, not letting go of his arm. And they went to
61986. their rooms.
61987. 
61988. When Nicholas and his wife came to look for Pierre he was in the nursery
61989. holding his baby son, who was again awake, on his huge right palm and
61990. dandling him. A blissful bright smile was fixed on the baby's broad face
61991. with its toothless open mouth. The storm was long since over and there
61992. was bright, joyous sunshine on Natasha's face as she gazed tenderly at
61993. her husband and child.
61994. 
61995. "And have you talked everything well over with Prince Theodore?" she
61996. asked.
61997. 
61998. "Yes, capitally."
61999. 
62000. "You see, he holds it up." (She meant the baby's head.) "But how he did
62001. frighten me... You've seen the princess? Is it true she's in love with
62002. that..."
62003. 
62004. "Yes, just fancy..."
62005. 
62006. At that moment Nicholas and Countess Mary came in. Pierre with the baby
62007. on his hand stooped, kissed them, and replied to their inquiries. But
62008. in spite of much that was interesting and had to be discussed, the baby
62009. with the little cap on its unsteady head evidently absorbed all his
62010. attention.
62011. 
62012. "How sweet!" said Countess Mary, looking at and playing with the baby.
62013. "Now, Nicholas," she added, turning to her husband, "I can't understand
62014. how it is you don't see the charm of these delicious marvels."
62015. 
62016. "I don't and can't," replied Nicholas, looking coldly at the baby. "A
62017. lump of flesh. Come along, Pierre!"
62018. 
62019. "And yet he's such an affectionate father," said Countess Mary,
62020. vindicating her husband, "but only after they are a year old or so..."
62021. 
62022. "Now, Pierre nurses them splendidly," said Natasha. "He says his hand is
62023. just made for a baby's seat. Just look!"
62024. 
62025. "Only not for this..." Pierre suddenly exclaimed with a laugh, and
62026. shifting the baby he gave him to the nurse.
62027. 
62028. 
62029. 
62030. 
62031. 
62032. CHAPTER XII
62033. 
62034. 
62035. As in every large household, there were at Bald Hills several perfectly
62036. distinct worlds which merged into one harmonious whole, though each
62037. retained its own peculiarities and made concessions to the others. Every
62038. event, joyful or sad, that took place in that house was important to all
62039. these worlds, but each had its own special reasons to rejoice or grieve
62040. over that occurrence independently of the others.
62041. 
62042. For instance, Pierre's return was a joyful and important event and they
62043. all felt it to be so.
62044. 
62045. The servants--the most reliable judges of their masters because they
62046. judge not by their conversation or expressions of feeling but by their
62047. acts and way of life--were glad of Pierre's return because they knew
62048. that when he was there Count Nicholas would cease going every day to
62049. attend to the estate, and would be in better spirits and temper, and
62050. also because they would all receive handsome presents for the holidays.
62051. 
62052. The children and their governesses were glad of Pierre's return because
62053. no one else drew them into the social life of the household as he did.
62054. He alone could play on the clavichord that ecossaise (his only piece)
62055. to which, as he said, all possible dances could be danced, and they felt
62056. sure he had brought presents for them all.
62057. 
62058. Young Nicholas, now a slim lad of fifteen, delicate and intelligent,
62059. with curly light-brown hair and beautiful eyes, was delighted because
62060. Uncle Pierre as he called him was the object of his rapturous and
62061. passionate affection. No one had instilled into him this love for Pierre
62062. whom he saw only occasionally. Countess Mary who had brought him up
62063. had done her utmost to make him love her husband as she loved him, and
62064. little Nicholas did love his uncle, but loved him with just a shade of
62065. contempt. Pierre, however, he adored. He did not want to be an hussar or
62066. a Knight of St. George like his uncle Nicholas; he wanted to be learned,
62067. wise, and kind like Pierre. In Pierre's presence his face always shone
62068. with pleasure and he flushed and was breathless when Pierre spoke to
62069. him. He did not miss a single word he uttered, and would afterwards,
62070. with Dessalles or by himself, recall and reconsider the meaning of
62071. everything Pierre had said. Pierre's past life and his unhappiness prior
62072. to 1812 (of which young Nicholas had formed a vague poetic picture from
62073. some words he had overheard), his adventures in Moscow, his captivity,
62074. Platon Karataev (of whom he had heard from Pierre), his love for Natasha
62075. (of whom the lad was also particularly fond), and especially Pierre's
62076. friendship with the father whom Nicholas could not remember--all this
62077. made Pierre in his eyes a hero and a saint.
62078. 
62079. From broken remarks about Natasha and his father, from the emotion with
62080. which Pierre spoke of that dead father, and from the careful, reverent
62081. tenderness with which Natasha spoke of him, the boy, who was only just
62082. beginning to guess what love is, derived the notion that his father had
62083. loved Natasha and when dying had left her to his friend. But the father
62084. whom the boy did not remember appeared to him a divinity who could not
62085. be pictured, and of whom he never thought without a swelling heart and
62086. tears of sadness and rapture. So the boy also was happy that Pierre had
62087. arrived.
62088. 
62089. The guests welcomed Pierre because he always helped to enliven and unite
62090. any company he was in.
62091. 
62092. The grown-up members of the family, not to mention his wife, were
62093. pleased to have back a friend whose presence made life run more smoothly
62094. and peacefully.
62095. 
62096. The old ladies were pleased with the presents he brought them, and
62097. especially that Natasha would now be herself again.
62098. 
62099. Pierre felt the different outlooks of these various worlds and made
62100. haste to satisfy all their expectations.
62101. 
62102. Though the most absent-minded and forgetful of men, Pierre, with the aid
62103. of a list his wife drew up, had now bought everything, not forgetting
62104. his mother--and brother-in-law's commissions, nor the dress material for
62105. a present to Belova, nor toys for his wife's nephews. In the early days
62106. of his marriage it had seemed strange to him that his wife should expect
62107. him not to forget to procure all the things he undertook to buy, and he
62108. had been taken aback by her serious annoyance when on his first trip he
62109. forgot everything. But in time he grew used to this demand. Knowing that
62110. Natasha asked nothing for herself, and gave him commissions for others
62111. only when he himself had offered to undertake them, he now found an
62112. unexpected and childlike pleasure in this purchase of presents for
62113. everyone in the house, and never forgot anything. If he now incurred
62114. Natasha's censure it was only for buying too many and too expensive
62115. things. To her other defects (as most people thought them, but which
62116. to Pierre were qualities) of untidiness and neglect of herself, she now
62117. added stinginess.
62118. 
62119. From the time that Pierre began life as a family man on a footing
62120. entailing heavy expenditure, he had noticed to his surprise that he
62121. spent only half as much as before, and that his affairs--which had been
62122. in disorder of late, chiefly because of his first wife's debts--had
62123. begun to improve.
62124. 
62125. Life was cheaper because it was circumscribed: that most expensive
62126. luxury, the kind of life that can be changed at any moment, was no
62127. longer his nor did he wish for it. He felt that his way of life had now
62128. been settled once for all till death and that to change it was not in
62129. his power, and so that way of life proved economical.
62130. 
62131. With a merry, smiling face Pierre was sorting his purchases.
62132. 
62133. "What do you think of this?" said he, unrolling a piece of stuff like a
62134. shopman.
62135. 
62136. Natasha, who was sitting opposite to him with her eldest daughter on her
62137. lap, turned her sparkling eyes swiftly from her husband to the things he
62138. showed her.
62139. 
62140. "That's for Belova? Excellent!" She felt the quality of the material.
62141. "It was a ruble an arshin, I suppose?"
62142. 
62143. Pierre told her the price.
62144. 
62145. "Too dear!" Natasha remarked. "How pleased the children will be and
62146. Mamma too! Only you need not have bought me this," she added, unable to
62147. suppress a smile as she gazed admiringly at a gold comb set with pearls,
62148. of a kind then just coming into fashion.
62149. 
62150. "Adele tempted me: she kept on telling me to buy it," returned Pierre.
62151. 
62152. "When am I to wear it?" and Natasha stuck it in her coil of hair. "When
62153. I take little Masha into society? Perhaps they will be fashionable again
62154. by then. Well, let's go now."
62155. 
62156. And collecting the presents they went first to the nursery and then to
62157. the old countess' rooms.
62158. 
62159. The countess was sitting with her companion Belova, playing
62160. grand-patience as usual, when Pierre and Natasha came into the drawing
62161. room with parcels under their arms.
62162. 
62163. The countess was now over sixty, was quite gray, and wore a cap with a
62164. frill that surrounded her face. Her face had shriveled, her upper lip
62165. had sunk in, and her eyes were dim.
62166. 
62167. After the deaths of her son and husband in such rapid succession, she
62168. felt herself a being accidentally forgotten in this world and left
62169. without aim or object for her existence. She ate, drank, slept, or kept
62170. awake, but did not live. Life gave her no new impressions. She wanted
62171. nothing from life but tranquillity, and that tranquillity only death
62172. could give her. But until death came she had to go on living, that is,
62173. to use her vital forces. A peculiarity one sees in very young children
62174. and very old people was particularly evident in her. Her life had
62175. no external aims--only a need to exercise her various functions and
62176. inclinations was apparent. She had to eat, sleep, think, speak, weep,
62177. work, give vent to her anger, and so on, merely because she had a
62178. stomach, a brain, muscles, nerves, and a liver. She did these things not
62179. under any external impulse as people in the full vigor of life do,
62180. when behind the purpose for which they strive that of exercising their
62181. functions remains unnoticed. She talked only because she physically
62182. needed to exercise her tongue and lungs. She cried as a child does,
62183. because her nose had to be cleared, and so on. What for people in their
62184. full vigor is an aim was for her evidently merely a pretext.
62185. 
62186. Thus in the morning--especially if she had eaten anything rich the day
62187. before--she felt a need of being angry and would choose as the handiest
62188. pretext Belova's deafness.
62189. 
62190. She would begin to say something to her in a low tone from the other end
62191. of the room.
62192. 
62193. "It seems a little warmer today, my dear," she would murmur.
62194. 
62195. And when Belova replied: "Oh yes, they've come," she would mutter
62196. angrily: "O Lord! How stupid and deaf she is!"
62197. 
62198. Another pretext would be her snuff, which would seem too dry or too damp
62199. or not rubbed fine enough. After these fits of irritability her face
62200. would grow yellow, and her maids knew by infallible symptoms when Belova
62201. would again be deaf, the snuff damp, and the countess' face yellow. Just
62202. as she needed to work off her spleen so she had sometimes to exercise
62203. her still-existing faculty of thinking--and the pretext for that was a
62204. game of patience. When she needed to cry, the deceased count would be
62205. the pretext. When she wanted to be agitated, Nicholas and his health
62206. would be the pretext, and when she felt a need to speak spitefully, the
62207. pretext would be Countess Mary. When her vocal organs needed exercise,
62208. which was usually toward seven o'clock when she had had an after-dinner
62209. rest in a darkened room, the pretext would be the retelling of the same
62210. stories over and over again to the same audience.
62211. 
62212. The old lady's condition was understood by the whole household though no
62213. one ever spoke of it, and they all made every possible effort to satisfy
62214. her needs. Only by a rare glance exchanged with a sad smile
62215. between Nicholas, Pierre, Natasha, and Countess Mary was the common
62216. understanding of her condition expressed.
62217. 
62218. But those glances expressed something more: they said that she had
62219. played her part in life, that what they now saw was not her whole self,
62220. that we must all become like her, and that they were glad to yield to
62221. her, to restrain themselves for this once precious being formerly as
62222. full of life as themselves, but now so much to be pitied. "Memento
62223. mori," said these glances.
62224. 
62225. Only the really heartless, the stupid ones of that household, and the
62226. little children failed to understand this and avoided her.
62227. 
62228. 
62229. 
62230. 
62231. 
62232. CHAPTER XIII
62233. 
62234. 
62235. When Pierre and his wife entered the drawing room the countess was in
62236. one of her customary states in which she needed the mental exertion of
62237. playing patience, and so--though by force of habit she greeted him
62238. with the words she always used when Pierre or her son returned after an
62239. absence: "High time, my dear, high time! We were all weary of waiting
62240. for you. Well, thank God!" and received her presents with another
62241. customary remark: "It's not the gift that's precious, my dear, but that
62242. you give it to me, an old woman..."--yet it was evident that she was
62243. not pleased by Pierre's arrival at that moment when it diverted her
62244. attention from the unfinished game.
62245. 
62246. She finished her game of patience and only then examined the presents.
62247. They consisted of a box for cards, of splendid workmanship, a
62248. bright-blue Sevres tea cup with shepherdesses depicted on it and with
62249. a lid, and a gold snuffbox with the count's portrait on the lid which
62250. Pierre had had done by a miniaturist in Petersburg. The countess had
62251. long wished for such a box, but as she did not want to cry just then she
62252. glanced indifferently at the portrait and gave her attention chiefly to
62253. the box for cards.
62254. 
62255. "Thank you, my dear, you have cheered me up," said she as she always
62256. did. "But best of all you have brought yourself back--for I never saw
62257. anything like it, you ought to give your wife a scolding! What are we
62258. to do with her? She is like a mad woman when you are away. Doesn't see
62259. anything, doesn't remember anything," she went on, repeating her usual
62260. phrases. "Look, Anna Timofeevna," she added to her companion, "see what
62261. a box for cards my son has brought us!"
62262. 
62263. Belova admired the presents and was delighted with her dress material.
62264. 
62265. Though Pierre, Natasha, Nicholas, Countess Mary, and Denisov had much to
62266. talk about that they could not discuss before the old countess--not
62267. that anything was hidden from her, but because she had dropped so
62268. far behindhand in many things that had they begun to converse in her
62269. presence they would have had to answer inopportune questions and to
62270. repeat what they had already told her many times: that so-and-so was
62271. dead and so-and-so was married, which she would again be unable to
62272. remember--yet they sat at tea round the samovar in the drawing room from
62273. habit, and Pierre answered the countess' questions as to whether Prince
62274. Vasili had aged and whether Countess Mary Alexeevna had sent greetings
62275. and still thought of them, and other matters that interested no one and
62276. to which she herself was indifferent.
62277. 
62278. Conversation of this kind, interesting to no one yet unavoidable,
62279. continued all through teatime. All the grown-up members of the family
62280. were assembled near the round tea table at which Sonya presided beside
62281. the samovar. The children with their tutors and governesses had had
62282. tea and their voices were audible from the next room. At tea all sat
62283. in their accustomed places: Nicholas beside the stove at a small table
62284. where his tea was handed to him; Milka, the old gray borzoi bitch
62285. (daughter of the first Milka), with a quite gray face and large black
62286. eyes that seemed more prominent than ever, lay on the armchair beside
62287. him; Denisov, whose curly hair, mustache, and whiskers had turned half
62288. gray, sat beside countess Mary with his general's tunic unbuttoned;
62289. Pierre sat between his wife and the old countess. He spoke of what he
62290. knew might interest the old lady and that she could understand. He
62291. told her of external social events and of the people who had formed
62292. the circle of her contemporaries and had once been a real, living, and
62293. distinct group, but who were now for the most part scattered about the
62294. world and like herself were garnering the last ears of the harvests they
62295. had sown in earlier years. But to the old countess those contemporaries
62296. of hers seemed to be the only serious and real society. Natasha saw by
62297. Pierre's animation that his visit had been interesting and that he had
62298. much to tell them but dare not say it before the old countess. Denisov,
62299. not being a member of the family, did not understand Pierre's caution
62300. and being, as a malcontent, much interested in what was occurring in
62301. Petersburg, kept urging Pierre to tell them about what had happened in
62302. the Semenovsk regiment, then about Arakcheev, and then about the Bible
62303. Society. Once or twice Pierre was carried away and began to speak of
62304. these things, but Nicholas and Natasha always brought him back to the
62305. health of Prince Ivan and Countess Mary Alexeevna.
62306. 
62307. "Well, and all this idiocy--Gossner and Tatawinova?" Denisov asked. "Is
62308. that weally still going on?"
62309. 
62310. "Going on?" Pierre exclaimed. "Why more than ever! The Bible Society is
62311. the whole government now!"
62312. 
62313.  "What is that, mon cher ami?" asked the countess, who had
62314. finished her tea and evidently needed a pretext for being angry
62315. after her meal. "What are you saying about the government? I don't
62316. understand."
62317. 
62318. "Well, you know, Maman," Nicholas interposed, knowing how to translate
62319. things into his mother's language, "Prince Alexander Golitsyn has
62320. founded a society and in consequence has great influence, they say."
62321. 
62322. "Arakcheev and Golitsyn," incautiously remarked Pierre, "are now the
62323. whole government! And what a government! They see treason everywhere and
62324. are afraid of everything."
62325. 
62326. "Well, and how is Prince Alexander to blame? He is a most estimable
62327. man. I used to meet him at Mary Antonovna's," said the countess in an
62328. offended tone; and still more offended that they all remained silent,
62329. she went on: "Nowadays everyone finds fault. A Gospel Society! Well, and
62330. what harm is there in that?" and she rose (everybody else got up too)
62331. and with a severe expression sailed back to her table in the sitting
62332. room.
62333. 
62334. The melancholy silence that followed was broken by the sounds of the
62335. children's voices and laughter from the next room. Evidently some jolly
62336. excitement was going on there.
62337. 
62338. "Finished, finished!" little Natasha's gleeful yell rose above them all.
62339. 
62340. Pierre exchanged glances with Countess Mary and Nicholas (Natasha he
62341. never lost sight of) and smiled happily.
62342. 
62343. "That's delightful music!" said he.
62344. 
62345. "It means that Anna Makarovna has finished her stocking," said Countess
62346. Mary.
62347. 
62348. "Oh, I'll go and see," said Pierre, jumping up. "You know," he added,
62349. stopping at the door, "why I'm especially fond of that music? It is
62350. always the first thing that tells me all is well. When I was driving
62351. here today, the nearer I got to the house the more anxious I grew. As I
62352. entered the anteroom I heard Andrusha's peals of laughter and that meant
62353. that all was well."
62354. 
62355. "I know! I know that feeling," said Nicholas. "But I mustn't go
62356. there--those stockings are to be a surprise for me."
62357. 
62358. Pierre went to the children, and the shouting and laughter grew still
62359. louder.
62360. 
62361. "Come, Anna Makarovna," Pierre's voice was heard saying, "come here into
62362. the middle of the room and at the word of command, 'One, two,' and when
62363. I say 'three'... You stand here, and you in my arms--well now! One,
62364. two!..." said Pierre, and a silence followed: "three!" and a rapturously
62365. breathless cry of children's voices filled the room. "Two, two!" they
62366. shouted.
62367. 
62368. This meant two stockings, which by a secret process known only to
62369. herself Anna Makarovna used to knit at the same time on the same
62370. needles, and which, when they were ready, she always triumphantly drew,
62371. one out of the other, in the children's presence.
62372. 
62373. 
62374. 
62375. 
62376. 
62377. CHAPTER XIV
62378. 
62379. 
62380. Soon after this the children came in to say good night. They kissed
62381. everyone, the tutors and governesses made their bows, and they went out.
62382. Only young Nicholas and his tutor remained. Dessalles whispered to the
62383. boy to come downstairs.
62384. 
62385. "No, Monsieur Dessalles, I will ask my aunt to let me stay," replied
62386. Nicholas Bolkonski also in a whisper.
62387. 
62388. "Ma tante, please let me stay," said he, going up to his aunt.
62389. 
62390. His face expressed entreaty, agitation, and ecstasy. Countess Mary
62391. glanced at him and turned to Pierre.
62392. 
62393. "When you are here he can't tear himself away," she said.
62394. 
62395. "I will bring him to you directly, Monsieur Dessalles. Good night!"
62396. said Pierre, giving his hand to the Swiss tutor, and he turned to young
62397. Nicholas with a smile. "You and I haven't seen anything of one another
62398. yet... How like he is growing, Mary!" he added, addressing Countess
62399. Mary.
62400. 
62401. "Like my father?" asked the boy, flushing crimson and looking up at
62402. Pierre with bright, ecstatic eyes.
62403. 
62404. Pierre nodded, and went on with what he had been saying when the
62405. children had interrupted. Countess Mary sat down doing woolwork; Natasha
62406. did not take her eyes off her husband. Nicholas and Denisov rose, asked
62407. for their pipes, smoked, went to fetch more tea from Sonya--who
62408. sat weary but resolute at the samovar--and questioned Pierre. The
62409. curly-headed, delicate boy sat with shining eyes unnoticed in a corner,
62410. starting every now and then and muttering something to himself, and
62411. evidently experiencing a new and powerful emotion as he turned his curly
62412. head, with his thin neck exposed by his turn-down collar, toward the
62413. place where Pierre sat.
62414. 
62415. The conversation turned on the contemporary gossip about those in power,
62416. in which most people see the chief interest of home politics. Denisov,
62417. dissatisfied with the government on account of his own disappointments
62418. in the service, heard with pleasure of the things done in Petersburg
62419. which seemed to him stupid, and made forcible and sharp comments on what
62420. Pierre told them.
62421. 
62422. "One used to have to be a German--now one must dance with Tatawinova
62423. and Madame Kwudener, and wead Ecka'tshausen and the bwethwen. Oh, they
62424. should let that fine fellow Bonaparte lose--he'd knock all this nonsense
62425. out of them! Fancy giving the command of the Semenov wegiment to a
62426. fellow like that Schwa'tz!" he cried.
62427. 
62428. Nicholas, though free from Denisov's readiness to find fault with
62429. everything, also thought that discussion of the government was a very
62430. serious and weighty matter, and the fact that A had been appointed
62431. Minister of This and B Governor General of That, and that the Emperor
62432. had said so-and-so and this minister so-and-so, seemed to him very
62433. important. And so he thought it necessary to take an interest in these
62434. things and to question Pierre. The questions put by these two kept the
62435. conversation from changing its ordinary character of gossip about the
62436. higher government circles.
62437. 
62438. But Natasha, knowing all her husband's ways and ideas, saw that he had
62439. long been wishing but had been unable to divert the conversation to
62440. another channel and express his own deeply felt idea for the sake of
62441. which he had gone to Petersburg to consult with his new friend Prince
62442. Theodore, and she helped him by asking how his affairs with Prince
62443. Theodore had gone.
62444. 
62445. "What was it about?" asked Nicholas.
62446. 
62447. "Always the same thing," said Pierre, looking round at his listeners.
62448. "Everybody sees that things are going so badly that they cannot be
62449. allowed to go on so and that it is the duty of all decent men to
62450. counteract it as far as they can."
62451. 
62452. "What can decent men do?" Nicholas inquired, frowning slightly. "What
62453. can be done?"
62454. 
62455. "Why, this..."
62456. 
62457. "Come into my study," said Nicholas.
62458. 
62459. Natasha, who had long expected to be fetched to nurse her baby, now
62460. heard the nurse calling her and went to the nursery. Countess Mary
62461. followed her. The men went into the study and little Nicholas Bolkonski
62462. followed them unnoticed by his uncle and sat down at the writing table
62463. in a shady corner by the window.
62464. 
62465. "Well, what would you do?" asked Denisov.
62466. 
62467. "Always some fantastic schemes," said Nicholas.
62468. 
62469. "Why this," began Pierre, not sitting down but pacing the room,
62470. sometimes stopping short, gesticulating, and lisping: "the position
62471. in Petersburg is this: the Emperor does not look into anything. He
62472. has abandoned himself altogether to this mysticism" (Pierre could not
62473. tolerate mysticism in anyone now). "He seeks only for peace, and only
62474. these people sans foi ni loi * can give it him--people who recklessly
62475. hack at and strangle everything--Magnitski, Arakcheev, and tutti
62476. quanti.... You will agree that if you did not look after your estates
62477. yourself but only wanted a quiet life, the harsher your steward was the
62478. more readily your object might be attained," he said to Nicholas.
62479. 
62480. 
62481.     * Without faith or law.
62482. 
62483. 
62484. "Well, what does that lead up to?" said Nicholas.
62485. 
62486. "Well, everything is going to ruin! Robbery in the law courts, in the
62487. army nothing but flogging, drilling, and Military Settlements; the
62488. people are tortured, enlightenment is suppressed. All that is young and
62489. honest is crushed! Everyone sees that this cannot go on. Everything is
62490. strained to such a degree that it will certainly break," said Pierre (as
62491. those who examine the actions of any government have always said since
62492. governments began). "I told them just one thing in Petersburg."
62493. 
62494. "Told whom?"
62495. 
62496. "Well, you know whom," said Pierre, with a meaning glance from under
62497. his brows. "Prince Theodore and all those. To encourage culture and
62498. philanthropy is all very well of course. The aim is excellent but in the
62499. present circumstances something else is needed."
62500. 
62501. At that moment Nicholas noticed the presence of his nephew. His face
62502. darkened and he went up to the boy.
62503. 
62504. "Why are you here?"
62505. 
62506. "Why? Let him be," said Pierre, taking Nicholas by the arm and
62507. continuing. "That is not enough, I told them. Something else is needed.
62508. When you stand expecting the overstrained string to snap at any moment,
62509. when everyone is expecting the inevitable catastrophe, as many as
62510. possible must join hands as closely as they can to withstand the general
62511. calamity. Everything that is young and strong is being enticed away and
62512. depraved. One is lured by women, another by honors, a third by ambition
62513. or money, and they go over to that camp. No independent men, such as you
62514. or I, are left. What I say is widen the scope of our society, let the
62515. mot d'ordre be not virtue alone but independence and action as well!"
62516. 
62517. Nicholas, who had left his nephew, irritably pushed up an armchair, sat
62518. down in it, and listened to Pierre, coughing discontentedly and frowning
62519. more and more.
62520. 
62521. "But action with what aim?" he cried. "And what position will you adopt
62522. toward the government?"
62523. 
62524. "Why, the position of assistants. The society need not be secret if the
62525. government allows it. Not merely is it not hostile to government, but it
62526. is a society of true conservatives--a society of gentlemen in the full
62527. meaning of that word. It is only to prevent some Pugachev or other from
62528. killing my children and yours, and Arakcheev from sending me off to some
62529. Military Settlement. We join hands only for the public welfare and the
62530. general safety."
62531. 
62532. "Yes, but it's a secret society and therefore a hostile and harmful one
62533. which can only cause harm."
62534. 
62535. "Why? Did the Tugendbund which saved Europe" (they did not then venture
62536. to suggest that Russia had saved Europe) "do any harm? The Tugendbund
62537. is an alliance of virtue: it is love, mutual help... it is what Christ
62538. preached on the Cross."
62539. 
62540. Natasha, who had come in during the conversation, looked joyfully at her
62541. husband. It was not what he was saying that pleased her--that did not
62542. even interest her, for it seemed to her that was all extremely simple
62543. and that she had known it a long time (it seemed so to her because she
62544. knew that it sprang from Pierre's whole soul), but it was his animated
62545. and enthusiastic appearance that made her glad.
62546. 
62547. The boy with the thin neck stretching out from the turn-down
62548. collar--whom everyone had forgotten--gazed at Pierre with even greater
62549. and more rapturous joy. Every word of Pierre's burned into his heart,
62550. and with a nervous movement of his fingers he unconsciously broke the
62551. sealing wax and quill pens his hands came upon on his uncle's table.
62552. 
62553. "It is not at all what you suppose; but that is what the German
62554. Tugendbund was, and what I am proposing."
62555. 
62556. "No, my fwiend! The Tugendbund is all vewy well for the sausage eaters,
62557. but I don't understand it and can't even pwonounce it," interposed
62558. Denisov in a loud and resolute voice. "I agwee that evewything here is
62559. wotten and howwible, but the Tugendbund I don't understand. If we're
62560. not satisfied, let us have a bunt of our own. That's all wight. Je suis
62561. vot'e homme!" *
62562. 
62563. 
62564.     * "I'm your man."
62565. 
62566. 
62567. Pierre smiled, Natasha began to laugh, but Nicholas knitted his brows
62568. still more and began proving to Pierre that there was no prospect of
62569. any great change and that all the danger he spoke of existed only in his
62570. imagination. Pierre maintained the contrary, and as his mental faculties
62571. were greater and more resourceful, Nicholas felt himself cornered. This
62572. made him still angrier, for he was fully convinced, not by reasoning
62573. but by something within him stronger than reason, of the justice of his
62574. opinion.
62575. 
62576. "I will tell you this," he said, rising and trying with nervously
62577. twitching fingers to prop up his pipe in a corner, but finally
62578. abandoning the attempt. "I can't prove it to you. You say that
62579. everything here is rotten and that an overthrow is coming: I don't
62580. see it. But you also say that our oath of allegiance is a conditional
62581. matter, and to that I reply: 'You are my best friend, as you know,
62582. but if you formed a secret society and began working against the
62583. government--be it what it may--I know it is my duty to obey the
62584. government. And if Arakcheev ordered me to lead a squadron against you
62585. and cut you down, I should not hesitate an instant, but should do it.'
62586. And you may argue about that as you like!"
62587. 
62588. An awkward silence followed these words. Natasha was the first to speak,
62589. defending her husband and attacking her brother. Her defense was weak
62590. and inapt but she attained her object. The conversation was resumed, and
62591. no longer in the unpleasantly hostile tone of Nicholas' last remark.
62592. 
62593. When they all got up to go in to supper, little Nicholas Bolkonski went
62594. up to Pierre, pale and with shining, radiant eyes.
62595. 
62596. "Uncle Pierre, you... no... If Papa were alive... would he agree with
62597. you?" he asked.
62598. 
62599. And Pierre suddenly realized what a special, independent, complex, and
62600. powerful process of thought and feeling must have been going on in
62601. this boy during that conversation, and remembering all he had said he
62602. regretted that the lad should have heard him. He had, however, to give
62603. him an answer.
62604. 
62605. "Yes, I think so," he said reluctantly, and left the study.
62606. 
62607. The lad looked down and seemed now for the first time to notice what he
62608. had done to the things on the table. He flushed and went up to Nicholas.
62609. 
62610. "Uncle, forgive me, I did that... unintentionally," he said, pointing to
62611. the broken sealing wax and pens.
62612. 
62613. Nicholas started angrily.
62614. 
62615. "All right, all right," he said, throwing the bits under the table.
62616. 
62617. And evidently suppressing his vexation with difficulty, he turned away
62618. from the boy.
62619. 
62620. "You ought not to have been here at all," he said.
62621. 
62622. 
62623. 
62624. 
62625. 
62626. CHAPTER XV
62627. 
62628. 
62629. The conversation at supper was not about politics or societies, but
62630. turned on the subject Nicholas liked best--recollections of 1812.
62631. Denisov started these and Pierre was particularly agreeable and amusing
62632. about them. The family separated on the most friendly terms.
62633. 
62634. After supper Nicholas, having undressed in his study and given
62635. instructions to the steward who had been waiting for him, went to the
62636. bedroom in his dressing gown, where he found his wife still at her
62637. table, writing.
62638. 
62639. "What are you writing, Mary?" Nicholas asked.
62640. 
62641. Countess Mary blushed. She was afraid that what she was writing would
62642. not be understood or approved by her husband.
62643. 
62644. She had wanted to conceal what she was writing from him, but at the same
62645. time was glad he had surprised her at it and that she would now have to
62646. tell him.
62647. 
62648. "A diary, Nicholas," she replied, handing him a blue exercise book
62649. filled with her firm, bold writing.
62650. 
62651. "A diary?" Nicholas repeated with a shade of irony, and he took up the
62652. book.
62653. 
62654. It was in French.
62655. 
62656. 
62657. December 4. Today when Andrusha (her eldest boy) woke up he did not
62658. wish to dress and Mademoiselle Louise sent for me. He was naughty and
62659. obstinate. I tried threats, but he only grew angrier. Then I took the
62660. matter in hand: I left him alone and began with nurse's help to get the
62661. other children up, telling him that I did not love him. For a long time
62662. he was silent, as if astonished, then he jumped out of bed, ran to me in
62663. his shirt, and sobbed so that I could not calm him for a long time.
62664. It was plain that what troubled him most was that he had grieved me.
62665. Afterwards in the evening when I gave him his ticket, he again began
62666. crying piteously and kissing me. One can do anything with him by
62667. tenderness.
62668. 
62669. 
62670. "What is a 'ticket'?" Nicholas inquired.
62671. 
62672. "I have begun giving the elder ones marks every evening, showing how
62673. they have behaved."
62674. 
62675. Nicholas looked into the radiant eyes that were gazing at him, and
62676. continued to turn over the pages and read. In the diary was set down
62677. everything in the children's lives that seemed noteworthy to their
62678. mother as showing their characters or suggesting general reflections
62679. on educational methods. They were for the most part quite insignificant
62680. trifles, but did not seem so to the mother or to the father either, now
62681. that he read this diary about his children for the first time.
62682. 
62683. Under the date "5" was entered:
62684. 
62685. 
62686. Mitya was naughty at table. Papa said he was to have no pudding. He had
62687. none, but looked so unhappily and greedily at the others while they were
62688. eating! I think that punishment by depriving children of sweets only
62689. develops their greediness. Must tell Nicholas this.
62690. 
62691. 
62692. Nicholas put down the book and looked at his wife. The radiant eyes
62693. gazed at him questioningly: would he approve or disapprove of her
62694. diary? There could be no doubt not only of his approval but also of his
62695. admiration for his wife.
62696. 
62697. Perhaps it need not be done so pedantically, thought Nicholas, or even
62698. done at all, but this untiring, continual spiritual effort of which the
62699. sole aim was the children's moral welfare delighted him. Had Nicholas
62700. been able to analyze his feelings he would have found that his steady,
62701. tender, and proud love of his wife rested on his feeling of wonder at
62702. her spirituality and at the lofty moral world, almost beyond his reach,
62703. in which she had her being.
62704. 
62705. He was proud of her intelligence and goodness, recognized his own
62706. insignificance beside her in the spiritual world, and rejoiced all the
62707. more that she with such a soul not only belonged to him but was part of
62708. himself.
62709. 
62710. "I quite, quite approve, my dearest!" said he with a significant look,
62711. and after a short pause he added: "And I behaved badly today. You
62712. weren't in the study. We began disputing--Pierre and I--and I lost my
62713. temper. But he is impossible: such a child! I don't know what would
62714. become of him if Natasha didn't keep him in hand.... Have you any idea
62715. why he went to Petersburg? They have formed..."
62716. 
62717. "Yes, I know," said Countess Mary. "Natasha told me."
62718.
