62719. "Well, then, you know," Nicholas went on, growing hot at the mere
62720. recollection of their discussion, "he wanted to convince me that it is
62721. every honest man's duty to go against the government, and that the oath
62722. of allegiance and duty... I am sorry you weren't there. They all fell
62723. on me--Denisov and Natasha... Natasha is absurd. How she rules over him!
62724. And yet there need only be a discussion and she has no words of her
62725. own but only repeats his sayings..." added Nicholas, yielding to that
62726. irresistible inclination which tempts us to judge those nearest and
62727. dearest to us. He forgot that what he was saying about Natasha could
62728. have been applied word for word to himself in relation to his wife.
62729. 
62730. "Yes, I have noticed that," said Countess Mary.
62731. 
62732. "When I told him that duty and the oath were above everything, he
62733. started proving goodness knows what! A pity you were not there--what
62734. would you have said?"
62735. 
62736. "As I see it you were quite right, and I told Natasha so. Pierre says
62737. everybody is suffering, tortured, and being corrupted, and that it
62738. is our duty to help our neighbor. Of course he is right there," said
62739. Countess Mary, "but he forgets that we have other duties nearer to us,
62740. duties indicated to us by God Himself, and that though we might expose
62741. ourselves to risks we must not risk our children."
62742. 
62743. "Yes, that's it! That's just what I said to him," put in Nicholas, who
62744. fancied he really had said it. "But they insisted on their own view:
62745. love of one's neighbor and Christianity--and all this in the presence of
62746. young Nicholas, who had gone into my study and broke all my things."
62747. 
62748. "Ah, Nicholas, do you know I am often troubled about little Nicholas,"
62749. said Countess Mary. "He is such an exceptional boy. I am afraid I
62750. neglect him in favor of my own: we all have children and relations while
62751. he has no one. He is constantly alone with his thoughts."
62752. 
62753. "Well, I don't think you need reproach yourself on his account. All that
62754. the fondest mother could do for her son you have done and are doing for
62755. him, and of course I am glad of it. He is a fine lad, a fine lad! This
62756. evening he listened to Pierre in a sort of trance, and fancy--as we were
62757. going in to supper I looked and he had broken everything on my table to
62758. bits, and he told me of it himself at once! I never knew him to tell an
62759. untruth. A fine lad, a fine lad!" repeated Nicholas, who at heart was
62760. not fond of Nicholas Bolkonski but was always anxious to recognize that
62761. he was a fine lad.
62762. 
62763. "Still, I am not the same as his own mother," said Countess Mary. "I
62764. feel I am not the same and it troubles me. A wonderful boy, but I am
62765. dreadfully afraid for him. It would be good for him to have companions."
62766. 
62767. "Well it won't be for long. Next summer I'll take him to Petersburg,"
62768. said Nicholas. "Yes, Pierre always was a dreamer and always will be,"
62769. he continued, returning to the talk in the study which had evidently
62770. disturbed him. "Well, what business is it of mine what goes on
62771. there--whether Arakcheev is bad, and all that? What business was it of
62772. mine when I married and was so deep in debt that I was threatened with
62773. prison, and had a mother who could not see or understand it? And
62774. then there are you and the children and our affairs. Is it for my own
62775. pleasure that I am at the farm or in the office from morning to night?
62776. No, but I know I must work to comfort my mother, to repay you, and not
62777. to leave the children such beggars as I was."
62778. 
62779. Countess Mary wanted to tell him that man does not live by bread alone
62780. and that he attached too much importance to these matters. But she knew
62781. she must not say this and that it would be useless to do so. She only
62782. took his hand and kissed it. He took this as a sign of approval and
62783. a confirmation of his thoughts, and after a few minutes' reflection
62784. continued to think aloud.
62785. 
62786. "You know, Mary, today Elias Mitrofanych" (this was his overseer) "came
62787. back from the Tambov estate and told me they are already offering eighty
62788. thousand rubles for the forest."
62789. 
62790. And with an eager face Nicholas began to speak of the possibility of
62791. repurchasing Otradnoe before long, and added: "Another ten years of life
62792. and I shall leave the children... in an excellent position."
62793. 
62794. Countess Mary listened to her husband and understood all that he told
62795. her. She knew that when he thought aloud in this way he would sometimes
62796. ask her what he had been saying, and be vexed if he noticed that she
62797. had been thinking about something else. But she had to force herself to
62798. attend, for what he was saying did not interest her at all. She looked
62799. at him and did not think, but felt, about something different. She felt
62800. a submissive tender love for this man who would never understand all
62801. that she understood, and this seemed to make her love for him still
62802. stronger and added a touch of passionate tenderness. Besides this
62803. feeling which absorbed her altogether and hindered her from following
62804. the details of her husband's plans, thoughts that had no connection with
62805. what he was saying flitted through her mind. She thought of her nephew.
62806. Her husband's account of the boy's agitation while Pierre was speaking
62807. struck her forcibly, and various traits of his gentle, sensitive
62808. character recurred to her mind; and while thinking of her nephew she
62809. thought also of her own children. She did not compare them with him, but
62810. compared her feeling for them with her feeling for him, and felt
62811. with regret that there was something lacking in her feeling for young
62812. Nicholas.
62813. 
62814. Sometimes it seemed to her that this difference arose from the
62815. difference in their ages, but she felt herself to blame toward him and
62816. promised in her heart to do better and to accomplish the impossible--in
62817. this life to love her husband, her children, little Nicholas, and all
62818. her neighbors, as Christ loved mankind. Countess Mary's soul always
62819. strove toward the infinite, the eternal, and the absolute, and could
62820. therefore never be at peace. A stern expression of the lofty, secret
62821. suffering of a soul burdened by the body appeared on her face. Nicholas
62822. gazed at her. "O God! What will become of us if she dies, as I always
62823. fear when her face is like that?" thought he, and placing himself before
62824. the icon he began to say his evening prayers.
62825. 
62826. 
62827. 
62828. 
62829. 
62830. CHAPTER XVI
62831. 
62832. 
62833. Natasha and Pierre, left alone, also began to talk as only a husband
62834. and wife can talk, that is, with extraordinary clearness and rapidity,
62835. understanding and expressing each other's thoughts in ways contrary to
62836. all rules of logic, without premises, deductions, or conclusions, and in
62837. a quite peculiar way. Natasha was so used to this kind of talk with her
62838. husband that for her it was the surest sign of something being wrong
62839. between them if Pierre followed a line of logical reasoning. When he
62840. began proving anything, or talking argumentatively and calmly and she,
62841. led on by his example, began to do the same, she knew that they were on
62842. the verge of a quarrel.
62843. 
62844. From the moment they were alone and Natasha came up to him with
62845. wide-open happy eyes, and quickly seizing his head pressed it to her
62846. bosom, saying: "Now you are all mine, mine! You won't escape!"--from
62847. that moment this conversation began, contrary to all the laws of logic
62848. and contrary to them because quite different subjects were talked about
62849. at one and the same time. This simultaneous discussion of many topics
62850. did not prevent a clear understanding but on the contrary was the surest
62851. sign that they fully understood one another.
62852. 
62853. Just as in a dream when all is uncertain, unreasoning, and
62854. contradictory, except the feeling that guides the dream, so in this
62855. intercourse contrary to all laws of reason, the words themselves were
62856. not consecutive and clear but only the feeling that prompted them.
62857. 
62858. Natasha spoke to Pierre about her brother's life and doings, of how she
62859. had suffered and lacked life during his own absence, and of how she
62860. was fonder than ever of Mary, and how Mary was in every way better than
62861. herself. In saying this Natasha was sincere in acknowledging Mary's
62862. superiority, but at the same time by saying it she made a demand on
62863. Pierre that he should, all the same, prefer her to Mary and to all
62864. other women, and that now, especially after having seen many women in
62865. Petersburg, he should tell her so afresh.
62866. 
62867. Pierre, answering Natasha's words, told her how intolerable it had been
62868. for him to meet ladies at dinners and balls in Petersburg.
62869. 
62870. "I have quite lost the knack of talking to ladies," he said. "It was
62871. simply dull. Besides, I was very busy."
62872. 
62873. Natasha looked intently at him and went on:
62874. 
62875. "Mary is so splendid," she said. "How she understands children! It is as
62876. if she saw straight into their souls. Yesterday, for instance, Mitya was
62877. naughty..."
62878. 
62879. "How like his father he is," Pierre interjected.
62880. 
62881. Natasha knew why he mentioned Mitya's likeness to Nicholas: the
62882. recollection of his dispute with his brother-in-law was unpleasant and
62883. he wanted to know what Natasha thought of it.
62884. 
62885. "Nicholas has the weakness of never agreeing with anything not generally
62886. accepted. But I understand that you value what opens up a fresh line,"
62887. said she, repeating words Pierre had once uttered.
62888. 
62889. "No, the chief point is that to Nicholas ideas and discussions are
62890. an amusement--almost a pastime," said Pierre. "For instance, he is
62891. collecting a library and has made it a rule not to buy a new book
62892. till he has read what he had already bought--Sismondi and Rousseau and
62893. Montesquieu," he added with a smile. "You know how much I..." he began
62894. to soften down what he had said; but Natasha interrupted him to show
62895. that this was unnecessary.
62896. 
62897. "So you say ideas are an amusement to him...."
62898. 
62899. "Yes, and for me nothing else is serious. All the time in Petersburg I
62900. saw everyone as in a dream. When I am taken up by a thought, all else is
62901. mere amusement."
62902. 
62903. "Ah, I'm so sorry I wasn't there when you met the children," said
62904. Natasha. "Which was most delighted? Lisa, I'm sure."
62905. 
62906. "Yes," Pierre replied, and went on with what was in his mind. "Nicholas
62907. says we ought not to think. But I can't help it. Besides, when I was in
62908. Petersburg I felt (I can say this to you) that the whole affair would go
62909. to pieces without me--everyone was pulling his own way. But I succeeded
62910. in uniting them all; and then my idea is so clear and simple. You see,
62911. I don't say that we ought to oppose this and that. We may be mistaken.
62912. What I say is: 'Join hands, you who love the right, and let there be but
62913. one banner--that of active virtue.' Prince Sergey is a fine fellow and
62914. clever."
62915. 
62916. Natasha would have had no doubt as to the greatness of Pierre's idea,
62917. but one thing disconcerted her. "Can a man so important and necessary to
62918. society be also my husband? How did this happen?" She wished to express
62919. this doubt to him. "Now who could decide whether he is really cleverer
62920. than all the others?" she asked herself, and passed in review all those
62921. whom Pierre most respected. Judging by what he had said there was no one
62922. he had respected so highly as Platon Karataev.
62923. 
62924. "Do you know what I am thinking about?" she asked. "About Platon
62925. Karataev. Would he have approved of you now, do you think?"
62926. 
62927. Pierre was not at all surprised at this question. He understood his
62928. wife's line of thought.
62929. 
62930. "Platon Karataev?" he repeated, and pondered, evidently sincerely
62931. trying to imagine Karataev's opinion on the subject. "He would not have
62932. understood... yet perhaps he would."
62933. 
62934. "I love you awfully!" Natasha suddenly said. "Awfully, awfully!"
62935. 
62936. "No, he would not have approved," said Pierre, after reflection. "What
62937. he would have approved of is our family life. He was always so anxious
62938. to find seemliness, happiness, and peace in everything, and I should
62939. have been proud to let him see us. There now--you talk of my absence,
62940. but you wouldn't believe what a special feeling I have for you after a
62941. separation...."
62942. 
62943. "Yes, I should think..." Natasha began.
62944. 
62945. "No, it's not that. I never leave off loving you. And one couldn't love
62946. more, but this is something special.... Yes, of course-" he did not
62947. finish because their eyes meeting said the rest.
62948. 
62949. "What nonsense it is," Natasha suddenly exclaimed, "about honeymoons,
62950. and that the greatest happiness is at first! On the contrary, now is
62951. the best of all. If only you did not go away! Do you remember how
62952. we quarreled? And it was always my fault. Always mine. And what we
62953. quarreled about--I don't even remember!"
62954. 
62955. "Always about the same thing," said Pierre with a smile. "Jealo..."
62956. 
62957. "Don't say it! I can't bear it!" Natasha cried, and her eyes glittered
62958. coldly and vindictively. "Did you see her?" she added, after a pause.
62959. 
62960. "No, and if I had I shouldn't have recognized her."
62961. 
62962. They were silent for a while.
62963. 
62964. "Oh, do you know? While you were talking in the study I was looking at
62965. you," Natasha began, evidently anxious to disperse the cloud that had
62966. come over them. "You are as like him as two peas--like the boy." (She
62967. meant her little son.) "Oh, it's time to go to him.... The milk's
62968. come.... But I'm sorry to leave you."
62969. 
62970. They were silent for a few seconds. Then suddenly turning to one
62971. another at the same time they both began to speak. Pierre began with
62972. self-satisfaction and enthusiasm, Natasha with a quiet, happy smile.
62973. Having interrupted one another they both stopped to let the other
62974. continue.
62975. 
62976. "No. What did you say? Go on, go on."
62977. 
62978. "No, you go on, I was talking nonsense," said Natasha.
62979. 
62980. Pierre finished what he had begun. It was the sequel to his complacent
62981. reflections on his success in Petersburg. At that moment it seemed to
62982. him that he was chosen to give a new direction to the whole of Russian
62983. society and to the whole world.
62984. 
62985. "I only wished to say that ideas that have great results are always
62986. simple ones. My whole idea is that if vicious people are united and
62987. constitute a power, then honest folk must do the same. Now that's simple
62988. enough."
62989. 
62990. "Yes."
62991. 
62992. "And what were you going to say?"
62993. 
62994. "I? Only nonsense."
62995. 
62996. "But all the same?"
62997. 
62998. "Oh nothing, only a trifle," said Natasha, smilingly still more
62999. brightly. "I only wanted to tell you about Petya: today nurse was coming
63000. to take him from me, and he laughed, shut his eyes, and clung to me. I'm
63001. sure he thought he was hiding. Awfully sweet! There, now he's crying.
63002. Well, good-by!" and she left the room.
63003. 
63004. 
63005. Meanwhile downstairs in young Nicholas Bolkonski's bedroom a little lamp
63006. was burning as usual. (The boy was afraid of the dark and they could
63007. not cure him of it.) Dessalles slept propped up on four pillows and his
63008. Roman nose emitted sounds of rhythmic snoring. Little Nicholas, who had
63009. just waked up in a cold perspiration, sat up in bed and gazed before him
63010. with wide-open eyes. He had awaked from a terrible dream. He had dreamed
63011. that he and Uncle Pierre, wearing helmets such as were depicted in
63012. his Plutarch, were leading a huge army. The army was made up of white
63013. slanting lines that filled the air like the cobwebs that float about in
63014. autumn and which Dessalles called les fils de la Vierge. In front was
63015. Glory, which was similar to those threads but rather thicker. He and
63016. Pierre were borne along lightly and joyously, nearer and nearer to their
63017. goal. Suddenly the threads that moved them began to slacken and become
63018. entangled and it grew difficult to move. And Uncle Nicholas stood before
63019. them in a stern and threatening attitude.
63020. 
63021. "Have you done this?" he said, pointing to some broken sealing wax and
63022. pens. "I loved you, but I have orders from Arakcheev and will kill
63023. the first of you who moves forward." Little Nicholas turned to look
63024. at Pierre but Pierre was no longer there. In his place was his
63025. father--Prince Andrew--and his father had neither shape nor form, but he
63026. existed, and when little Nicholas perceived him he grew faint with love:
63027. he felt himself powerless, limp, and formless. His father caressed and
63028. pitied him. But Uncle Nicholas came nearer and nearer to them. Terror
63029. seized young Nicholas and he awoke.
63030. 
63031. "My father!" he thought. (Though there were two good portraits of Prince
63032. Andrew in the house, Nicholas never imagined him in human form.) "My
63033. father has been with me and caressed me. He approved of me and of Uncle
63034. Pierre. Whatever he may tell me, I will do it. Mucius Scaevola burned
63035. his hand. Why should not the same sort of thing happen to me? I know
63036. they want me to learn. And I will learn. But someday I shall have
63037. finished learning, and then I will do something. I only pray God that
63038. something may happen to me such as happened to Plutarch's men, and I
63039. will act as they did. I will do better. Everyone shall know me, love me,
63040. and be delighted with me!" And suddenly his bosom heaved with sobs and
63041. he began to cry.
63042. 
63043. "Are you ill?" he heard Dessalles' voice asking.
63044. 
63045. "No," answered Nicholas, and lay back on his pillow.
63046. 
63047. "He is good and kind and I am fond of him!" he thought of Dessalles.
63048. "But Uncle Pierre! Oh, what a wonderful man he is! And my father? Oh,
63049. Father, Father! Yes, I will do something with which even he would be
63050. satisfied...."
63051. 
63052. 
63053. 
63054. 
63055. 
63056. SECOND EPILOGUE
63057. 
63058. 
63059. 
63060. 
63061. 
63062. CHAPTER I
63063. 
63064. 
63065. History is the life of nations and of humanity. To seize and put into
63066. words, to describe directly the life of humanity or even of a single
63067. nation, appears impossible.
63068. 
63069. The ancient historians all employed one and the same method to describe
63070. and seize the apparently elusive--the life of a people. They described
63071. the activity of individuals who ruled the people, and regarded the
63072. activity of those men as representing the activity of the whole nation.
63073. 
63074. The question: how did individuals make nations act as they wished and by
63075. what was the will of these individuals themselves guided? the ancients
63076. met by recognizing a divinity which subjected the nations to the will of
63077. a chosen man, and guided the will of that chosen man so as to accomplish
63078. ends that were predestined.
63079. 
63080. For the ancients these questions were solved by a belief in the direct
63081. participation of the Deity in human affairs.
63082. 
63083. Modern history, in theory, rejects both these principles.
63084. 
63085. It would seem that having rejected the belief of the ancients in man's
63086. subjection to the Deity and in a predetermined aim toward which nations
63087. are led, modern history should study not the manifestations of power but
63088. the causes that produce it. But modern history has not done this. Having
63089. in theory rejected the view held by the ancients, it still follows them
63090. in practice.
63091. 
63092. Instead of men endowed with divine authority and directly guided by
63093. the will of God, modern history has given us either heroes endowed with
63094. extraordinary, superhuman capacities, or simply men of very various
63095. kinds, from monarchs to journalists, who lead the masses. Instead of the
63096. former divinely appointed aims of the Jewish, Greek, or Roman nations,
63097. which ancient historians regarded as representing the progress of
63098. humanity, modern history has postulated its own aims--the welfare of the
63099. French, German, or English people, or, in its highest abstraction, the
63100. welfare and civilization of humanity in general, by which is usually
63101. meant that of the peoples occupying a small northwesterly portion of a
63102. large continent.
63103. 
63104. Modern history has rejected the beliefs of the ancients without
63105. replacing them by a new conception, and the logic of the situation has
63106. obliged the historians, after they had apparently rejected the divine
63107. authority of the kings and the "fate" of the ancients, to reach the same
63108. conclusion by another road, that is, to recognize (1) nations guided
63109. by individual men, and (2) the existence of a known aim to which these
63110. nations and humanity at large are tending.
63111. 
63112. At the basis of the works of all the modern historians from Gibbon to
63113. Buckle, despite their seeming disagreements and the apparent novelty of
63114. their outlooks, lie those two old, unavoidable assumptions.
63115. 
63116. In the first place the historian describes the activity of individuals
63117. who in his opinion have directed humanity (one historian considers
63118. only monarchs, generals, and ministers as being such men, while another
63119. includes also orators, learned men, reformers, philosophers, and poets).
63120. Secondly, it is assumed that the goal toward which humanity is being led
63121. is known to the historians: to one of them this goal is the greatness of
63122. the Roman, Spanish, or French realm; to another it is liberty, equality,
63123. and a certain kind of civilization of a small corner of the world called
63124. Europe.
63125. 
63126. In 1789 a ferment arises in Paris; it grows, spreads, and is expressed
63127. by a movement of peoples from west to east. Several times it moves
63128. eastward and collides with a countermovement from the east westward.
63129. In 1812 it reaches its extreme limit, Moscow, and then, with remarkable
63130. symmetry, a countermovement occurs from east to west, attracting to
63131. it, as the first movement had done, the nations of middle Europe. The
63132. counter movement reaches the starting point of the first movement in the
63133. west--Paris--and subsides.
63134. 
63135. During that twenty-year period an immense number of fields were left
63136. untilled, houses were burned, trade changed its direction, millions
63137. of men migrated, were impoverished, or were enriched, and millions
63138. of Christian men professing the law of love of their fellows slew one
63139. another.
63140. 
63141. What does all this mean? Why did it happen? What made those people burn
63142. houses and slay their fellow men? What were the causes of these events?
63143. What force made men act so? These are the instinctive, plain, and
63144. most legitimate questions humanity asks itself when it encounters the
63145. monuments and tradition of that period.
63146. 
63147. For a reply to these questions the common sense of mankind turns to the
63148. science of history, whose aim is to enable nations and humanity to know
63149. themselves.
63150. 
63151. If history had retained the conception of the ancients it would have
63152. said that God, to reward or punish his people, gave Napoleon power and
63153. directed his will to the fulfillment of the divine ends, and that reply,
63154. would have been clear and complete. One might believe or disbelieve
63155. in the divine significance of Napoleon, but for anyone believing in
63156. it there would have been nothing unintelligible in the history of that
63157. period, nor would there have been any contradictions.
63158. 
63159. But modern history cannot give that reply. Science does not admit the
63160. conception of the ancients as to the direct participation of the Deity
63161. in human affairs, and therefore history ought to give other answers.
63162. 
63163. Modern history replying to these questions says: you want to know what
63164. this movement means, what caused it, and what force produced these
63165. events? Then listen:
63166. 
63167. "Louis XIV was a very proud and self-confident man; he had such and such
63168. mistresses and such and such ministers and he ruled France badly. His
63169. descendants were weak men and they too ruled France badly. And they had
63170. such and such favorites and such and such mistresses. Moreover, certain
63171. men wrote some books at that time. At the end of the eighteenth century
63172. there were a couple of dozen men in Paris who began to talk about all
63173. men being free and equal. This caused people all over France to begin
63174. to slash at and drown one another. They killed the king and many other
63175. people. At that time there was in France a man of genius--Napoleon. He
63176. conquered everybody everywhere--that is, he killed many people because
63177. he was a great genius. And for some reason he went to kill Africans, and
63178. killed them so well and was so cunning and wise that when he returned to
63179. France he ordered everybody to obey him, and they all obeyed him. Having
63180. become an Emperor he again went out to kill people in Italy, Austria,
63181. and Prussia. And there too he killed a great many. In Russia there
63182. was an Emperor, Alexander, who decided to restore order in Europe and
63183. therefore fought against Napoleon. In 1807 he suddenly made friends
63184. with him, but in 1811 they again quarreled and again began killing many
63185. people. Napoleon led six hundred thousand men into Russia and captured
63186. Moscow; then he suddenly ran away from Moscow, and the Emperor
63187. Alexander, helped by the advice of Stein and others, united Europe to
63188. arm against the disturber of its peace. All Napoleon's allies suddenly
63189. became his enemies and their forces advanced against the fresh forces he
63190. raised. The Allies defeated Napoleon, entered Paris, forced Napoleon to
63191. abdicate, and sent him to the island of Elba, not depriving him of the
63192. title of Emperor and showing him every respect, though five years before
63193. and one year later they all regarded him as an outlaw and a brigand.
63194. Then Louis XVIII, who till then had been the laughingstock both of the
63195. French and the Allies, began to reign. And Napoleon, shedding tears
63196. before his Old Guards, renounced the throne and went into exile. Then
63197. the skillful statesmen and diplomatists (especially Talleyrand, who
63198. managed to sit down in a particular chair before anyone else and
63199. thereby extended the frontiers of France) talked in Vienna and by
63200. these conversations made the nations happy or unhappy. Suddenly the
63201. diplomatists and monarchs nearly quarreled and were on the point of
63202. again ordering their armies to kill one another, but just then Napoleon
63203. arrived in France with a battalion, and the French, who had been hating
63204. him, immediately all submitted to him. But the Allied monarchs were
63205. angry at this and went to fight the French once more. And they defeated
63206. the genius Napoleon and, suddenly recognizing him as a brigand, sent him
63207. to the island of St. Helena. And the exile, separated from the beloved
63208. France so dear to his heart, died a lingering death on that rock and
63209. bequeathed his great deeds to posterity. But in Europe a reaction
63210. occurred and the sovereigns once again all began to oppress their
63211. subjects."
63212. 
63213. It would be a mistake to think that this is ironic--a caricature of the
63214. historical accounts. On the contrary it is a very mild expression of
63215. the contradictory replies, not meeting the questions, which all the
63216. historians give, from the compilers of memoirs and the histories
63217. of separate states to the writers of general histories and the new
63218. histories of the culture of that period.
63219. 
63220. The strangeness and absurdity of these replies arise from the fact that
63221. modern history, like a deaf man, answers questions no one has asked.
63222. 
63223. If the purpose of history be to give a description of the movement of
63224. humanity and of the peoples, the first question--in the absence of a
63225. reply to which all the rest will be incomprehensible--is: what is the
63226. power that moves peoples? To this, modern history laboriously replies
63227. either that Napoleon was a great genius, or that Louis XIV was very
63228. proud, or that certain writers wrote certain books.
63229. 
63230. All that may be so and mankind is ready to agree with it, but it is not
63231. what was asked. All that would be interesting if we recognized a divine
63232. power based on itself and always consistently directing its nations
63233. through Napoleons, Louis-es, and writers; but we do not acknowledge such
63234. a power, and therefore before speaking about Napoleons, Louis-es, and
63235. authors, we ought to be shown the connection existing between these men
63236. and the movement of the nations.
63237. 
63238. If instead of a divine power some other force has appeared, it should
63239. be explained in what this new force consists, for the whole interest of
63240. history lies precisely in that force.
63241. 
63242. History seems to assume that this force is self-evident and known to
63243. everyone. But in spite of every desire to regard it as known, anyone
63244. reading many historical works cannot help doubting whether this new
63245. force, so variously understood by the historians themselves, is really
63246. quite well known to everybody.
63247. 
63248. 
63249. 
63250. 
63251. 
63252. CHAPTER II
63253. 
63254. 
63255. What force moves the nations?
63256. 
63257. Biographical historians and historians of separate nations understand
63258. this force as a power inherent in heroes and rulers. In their narration
63259. events occur solely by the will of a Napoleon, and Alexander, or in
63260. general of the persons they describe. The answers given by this kind
63261. of historian to the question of what force causes events to happen are
63262. satisfactory only as long as there is but one historian to each event.
63263. As soon as historians of different nationalities and tendencies begin
63264. to describe the same event, the replies they give immediately lose all
63265. meaning, for this force is understood by them all not only differently
63266. but often in quite contradictory ways. One historian says that an
63267. event was produced by Napoleon's power, another that it was produced by
63268. Alexander's, a third that it was due to the power of some other person.
63269. Besides this, historians of that kind contradict each other even
63270. in their statement as to the force on which the authority of some
63271. particular person was based. Thiers, a Bonapartist, says that Napoleon's
63272. power was based on his virtue and genius. Lanfrey, a Republican, says it
63273. was based on his trickery and deception of the people. So the historians
63274. of this class, by mutually destroying one another's positions, destroy
63275. the understanding of the force which produces events, and furnish no
63276. reply to history's essential question.
63277. 
63278. Writers of universal history who deal with all the nations seem to
63279. recognize how erroneous is the specialist historians' view of the force
63280. which produces events. They do not recognize it as a power inherent in
63281. heroes and rulers, but as the resultant of a multiplicity of variously
63282. directed forces. In describing a war or the subjugation of a people, a
63283. general historian looks for the cause of the event not in the power
63284. of one man, but in the interaction of many persons connected with the
63285. event.
63286. 
63287. According to this view the power of historical personages, represented
63288. as the product of many forces, can no longer, it would seem, be regarded
63289. as a force that itself produces events. Yet in most cases universal
63290. historians still employ the conception of power as a force that itself
63291. produces events, and treat it as their cause. In their exposition, an
63292. historic character is first the product of his time, and his power only
63293. the resultant of various forces, and then his power is itself a force
63294. producing events. Gervinus, Schlosser, and others, for instance, at one
63295. time prove Napoleon to be a product of the Revolution, of the ideas of
63296. 1789 and so forth, and at another plainly say that the campaign of 1812
63297. and other things they do not like were simply the product of Napoleon's
63298. misdirected will, and that the very ideas of 1789 were arrested in their
63299. development by Napoleon's caprice. The ideas of the Revolution and the
63300. general temper of the age produced Napoleon's power. But Napoleon's
63301. power suppressed the ideas of the Revolution and the general temper of
63302. the age.
63303. 
63304. This curious contradiction is not accidental. Not only does it occur at
63305. every step, but the universal historians' accounts are all made up of
63306. a chain of such contradictions. This contradiction occurs because after
63307. entering the field of analysis the universal historians stop halfway.
63308. 
63309. To find component forces equal to the composite or resultant force, the
63310. sum of the components must equal the resultant. This condition is never
63311. observed by the universal historians, and so to explain the resultant
63312. forces they are obliged to admit, in addition to the insufficient
63313. components, another unexplained force affecting the resultant action.
63314. 
63315. Specialist historians describing the campaign of 1813 or the restoration
63316. of the Bourbons plainly assert that these events were produced by the
63317. will of Alexander. But the universal historian Gervinus, refuting this
63318. opinion of the specialist historian, tries to prove that the campaign of
63319. 1813 and the restoration of the Bourbons were due to other things beside
63320. Alexander's will--such as the activity of Stein, Metternich, Madame
63321. de Stael, Talleyrand, Fichte Chateaubriand, and others. The historian
63322. evidently decomposes Alexander's power into the components: Talleyrand,
63323. Chateaubriand, and the rest--but the sum of the components, that is,
63324. the interactions of Chateaubriand, Talleyrand, Madame de Stael, and the
63325. others, evidently does not equal the resultant, namely the phenomenon
63326. of millions of Frenchmen submitting to the Bourbons. That Chateaubriand,
63327. Madame de Stael, and others spoke certain words to one another only
63328. affected their mutual relations but does not account for the submission
63329. of millions. And therefore to explain how from these relations of theirs
63330. the submission of millions of people resulted--that is, how component
63331. forces equal to one A gave a resultant equal to a thousand times A--the
63332. historian is again obliged to fall back on power--the force he had
63333. denied--and to recognize it as the resultant of the forces, that is, he
63334. has to admit an unexplained force acting on the resultant. And that is
63335. just what the universal historians do, and consequently they not only
63336. contradict the specialist historians but contradict themselves.
63337. 
63338. Peasants having no clear idea of the cause of rain, say, according to
63339. whether they want rain or fine weather: "The wind has blown the clouds
63340. away," or, "The wind has brought up the clouds." And in the same way the
63341. universal historians sometimes, when it pleases them and fits in with
63342. their theory, say that power is the result of events, and sometimes,
63343. when they want to prove something else, say that power produces events.
63344. 
63345. A third class of historians--the so-called historians of
63346. culture--following the path laid down by the universal historians who
63347. sometimes accept writers and ladies as forces producing events--again
63348. take that force to be something quite different. They see it in what is
63349. called culture--in mental activity.
63350. 
63351. The historians of culture are quite consistent in regard to their
63352. progenitors, the writers of universal histories, for if historical
63353. events may be explained by the fact that certain persons treated one
63354. another in such and such ways, why not explain them by the fact that
63355. such and such people wrote such and such books? Of the immense number of
63356. indications accompanying every vital phenomenon, these historians select
63357. the indication of intellectual activity and say that this indication is
63358. the cause. But despite their endeavors to prove that the cause of events
63359. lies in intellectual activity, only by a great stretch can one admit
63360. that there is any connection between intellectual activity and the
63361. movement of peoples, and in no case can one admit that intellectual
63362. activity controls people's actions, for that view is not confirmed by
63363. such facts as the very cruel murders of the French Revolution resulting
63364. from the doctrine of the equality of man, or the very cruel wars and
63365. executions resulting from the preaching of love.
63366. 
63367. But even admitting as correct all the cunningly devised arguments with
63368. which these histories are filled--admitting that nations are governed by
63369. some undefined force called an idea--history's essential question still
63370. remains unanswered, and to the former power of monarchs and to the
63371. influence of advisers and other people introduced by the universal
63372. historians, another, newer force--the idea--is added, the connection of
63373. which with the masses needs explanation. It is possible to understand
63374. that Napoleon had power and so events occurred; with some effort one may
63375. even conceive that Napoleon together with other influences was the cause
63376. of an event; but how a book, Le Contrat social, had the effect of making
63377. Frenchmen begin to drown one another cannot be understood without an
63378. explanation of the causal nexus of this new force with the event.
63379. 
63380. Undoubtedly some relation exists between all who live contemporaneously,
63381. and so it is possible to find some connection between the intellectual
63382. activity of men and their historical movements, just as such a
63383. connection may be found between the movements of humanity and commerce,
63384. handicraft, gardening, or anything else you please. But why intellectual
63385. activity is considered by the historians of culture to be the cause or
63386. expression of the whole historical movement is hard to understand.
63387. Only the following considerations can have led the historians to such
63388. a conclusion: (1) that history is written by learned men, and so it is
63389. natural and agreeable for them to think that the activity of their class
63390. supplies the basis of the movement of all humanity, just as a similar
63391. belief is natural and agreeable to traders, agriculturists, and soldiers
63392. (if they do not express it, that is merely because traders and soldiers
63393. do not write history), and (2) that spiritual activity, enlightenment,
63394. civilization, culture, ideas, are all indistinct, indefinite conceptions
63395. under whose banner it is very easy to use words having a still less
63396. definite meaning, and which can therefore be readily introduced into any
63397. theory.
63398. 
63399. But not to speak of the intrinsic quality of histories of this kind
63400. (which may possibly even be of use to someone for something) the
63401. histories of culture, to which all general histories tend more and more
63402. to approximate, are significant from the fact that after seriously
63403. and minutely examining various religious, philosophic, and political
63404. doctrines as causes of events, as soon as they have to describe an
63405. actual historic event such as the campaign of 1812 for instance, they
63406. involuntarily describe it as resulting from an exercise of power--and
63407. say plainly that that was the result of Napoleon's will. Speaking so,
63408. the historians of culture involuntarily contradict themselves, and show
63409. that the new force they have devised does not account for what happens
63410. in history, and that history can only be explained by introducing a
63411. power which they apparently do not recognize.
63412. 
63413. 
63414. 
63415. 
63416. 
63417. CHAPTER III
63418. 
63419. 
63420. A locomotive is moving. Someone asks: "What moves it?" A peasant says
63421. the devil moves it. Another man says the locomotive moves because its
63422. wheels go round. A third asserts that the cause of its movement lies in
63423. the smoke which the wind carries away.
63424. 
63425. The peasant is irrefutable. He has devised a complete explanation. To
63426. refute him someone would have to prove to him that there is no devil,
63427. or another peasant would have to explain to him that it is not the devil
63428. but a German, who moves the locomotive. Only then, as a result of the
63429. contradiction, will they see that they are both wrong. But the man who
63430. says that the movement of the wheels is the cause refutes himself, for
63431. having once begun to analyze he ought to go on and explain further why
63432. the wheels go round; and till he has reached the ultimate cause of the
63433. movement of the locomotive in the pressure of steam in the boiler, he
63434. has no right to stop in his search for the cause. The man who explains
63435. the movement of the locomotive by the smoke that is carried back has
63436. noticed that the wheels do not supply an explanation and has taken the
63437. first sign that occurs to him and in his turn has offered that as an
63438. explanation.
63439. 
63440. The only conception that can explain the movement of the locomotive is
63441. that of a force commensurate with the movement observed.
63442. 
63443. The only conception that can explain the movement of the peoples is that
63444. of some force commensurate with the whole movement of the peoples.
63445. 
63446. Yet to supply this conception various historians take forces of
63447. different kinds, all of which are incommensurate with the movement
63448. observed. Some see it as a force directly inherent in heroes, as the
63449. peasant sees the devil in the locomotive; others as a force resulting
63450. from several other forces, like the movement of the wheels; others again
63451. as an intellectual influence, like the smoke that is blown away.
63452. 
63453. So long as histories are written of separate individuals, whether
63454. Caesars, Alexanders, Luthers, or Voltaires, and not the histories
63455. of all, absolutely all those who take part in an event, it is quite
63456. impossible to describe the movement of humanity without the conception
63457. of a force compelling men to direct their activity toward a certain end.
63458. And the only such conception known to historians is that of power.
63459. 
63460. This conception is the one handle by means of which the material of
63461. history, as at present expounded, can be dealt with, and anyone who
63462. breaks that handle off, as Buckle did, without finding some other method
63463. of treating historical material, merely deprives himself of the one
63464. possible way of dealing with it. The necessity of the conception of
63465. power as an explanation of historical events is best demonstrated by
63466. the universal historians and historians of culture themselves, for they
63467. professedly reject that conception but inevitably have recourse to it at
63468. every step.
63469. 
63470. In dealing with humanity's inquiry, the science of history up to now
63471. is like money in circulation--paper money and coin. The biographies and
63472. special national histories are like paper money. They can be used and
63473. can circulate and fulfill their purpose without harm to anyone and even
63474. advantageously, as long as no one asks what is the security behind them.
63475. You need only forget to ask how the will of heroes produces events, and
63476. such histories as Thiers' will be interesting and instructive and may
63477. perhaps even possess a tinge of poetry. But just as doubts of the real
63478. value of paper money arise either because, being easy to make, too much
63479. of it gets made or because people try to exchange it for gold, so also
63480. doubts concerning the real value of such histories arise either because
63481. too many of them are written or because in his simplicity of heart
63482. someone inquires: by what force did Napoleon do this?--that is, wants
63483. to exchange the current paper money for the real gold of actual
63484. comprehension.
63485. 
63486. The writers of universal histories and of the history of culture are
63487. like people who, recognizing the defects of paper money, decide to
63488. substitute for it money made of metal that has not the specific gravity
63489. of gold. It may indeed make jingling coin, but will do no more than
63490. that. Paper money may deceive the ignorant, but nobody is deceived by
63491. tokens of base metal that have no value but merely jingle. As gold is
63492. gold only if it is serviceable not merely for exchange but also for use,
63493. so universal historians will be valuable only when they can reply to
63494. history's essential question: what is power? The universal historians
63495. give contradictory replies to that question, while the historians of
63496. culture evade it and answer something quite different. And as counters
63497. of imitation gold can be used only among a group of people who agree to
63498. accept them as gold, or among those who do not know the nature of
63499. gold, so universal historians and historians of culture, not answering
63500. humanity's essential question, serve as currency for some purposes of
63501. their own, only in universities and among the mass of readers who have a
63502. taste for what they call "serious reading."
63503. 
63504. 
63505. 
63506. 
63507. 
63508. CHAPTER IV
63509. 
63510. 
63511. Having abandoned the conception of the ancients as to the divine
63512. subjection of the will of a nation to some chosen man and the subjection
63513. of that man's will to the Deity, history cannot without contradictions
63514. take a single step till it has chosen one of two things: either a return
63515. to the former belief in the direct intervention of the Deity in human
63516. affairs or a definite explanation of the meaning of the force producing
63517. historical events and termed "power."
63518. 
63519. A return to the first is impossible, the belief has been destroyed; and
63520. so it is essential to explain what is meant by power.
63521. 
63522. Napoleon ordered an army to be raised and go to war. We are so
63523. accustomed to that idea and have become so used to it that the question:
63524. why did six hundred thousand men go to fight when Napoleon uttered
63525. certain words, seems to us senseless. He had the power and so what he
63526. ordered was done.
63527. 
63528. This reply is quite satisfactory if we believe that the power was given
63529. him by God. But as soon as we do not admit that, it becomes essential to
63530. determine what is this power of one man over others.
63531. 
63532. It cannot be the direct physical power of a strong man over a weak
63533. one--a domination based on the application or threat of physical force,
63534. like the power of Hercules; nor can it be based on the effect of moral
63535. force, as in their simplicity some historians think who say that the
63536. leading figures in history are heroes, that is, men gifted with a
63537. special strength of soul and mind called genius. This power cannot be
63538. based on the predominance of moral strength, for, not to mention heroes
63539. such as Napoleon about whose moral qualities opinions differ widely,
63540. history shows us that neither a Louis XI nor a Metternich, who ruled
63541. over millions of people, had any particular moral qualities, but on the
63542. contrary were generally morally weaker than any of the millions they
63543. ruled over.
63544. 
63545. If the source of power lies neither in the physical nor in the moral
63546. qualities of him who possesses it, it must evidently be looked for
63547. elsewhere--in the relation to the people of the man who wields the
63548. power.
63549. 
63550. And that is how power is understood by the science of jurisprudence,
63551. that exchange bank of history which offers to exchange history's
63552. understanding of power for true gold.
63553. 
63554. Power is the collective will of the people transferred, by expressed or
63555. tacit consent, to their chosen rulers.
63556. 
63557. In the domain of jurisprudence, which consists of discussions of how a
63558. state and power might be arranged were it possible for all that to
63559. be arranged, it is all very clear; but when applied to history that
63560. definition of power needs explanation.
63561. 
63562. The science of jurisprudence regards the state and power as the ancients
63563. regarded fire--namely, as something existing absolutely. But for
63564. history, the state and power are merely phenomena, just as for modern
63565. physics fire is not an element but a phenomenon.
63566. 
63567. From this fundamental difference between the view held by history and
63568. that held by jurisprudence, it follows that jurisprudence can tell
63569. minutely how in its opinion power should be constituted and what
63570. power--existing immutably outside time--is, but to history's questions
63571. about the meaning of the mutations of power in time it can answer
63572. nothing.
63573. 
63574. If power be the collective will of the people transferred to their
63575. ruler, was Pugachev a representative of the will of the people? If not,
63576. then why was Napoleon I? Why was Napoleon III a criminal when he was
63577. taken prisoner at Boulogne, and why, later on, were those criminals whom
63578. he arrested?
63579. 
63580. Do palace revolutions--in which sometimes only two or three people take
63581. part--transfer the will of the people to a new ruler? In international
63582. relations, is the will of the people also transferred to their
63583. conqueror? Was the will of the Confederation of the Rhine transferred
63584. to Napoleon in 1806? Was the will of the Russian people transferred
63585. to Napoleon in 1809, when our army in alliance with the French went to
63586. fight the Austrians?
63587. 
63588. To these questions three answers are possible:
63589. 
63590. Either to assume (1) that the will of the people is always
63591. unconditionally transferred to the ruler or rulers they have chosen, and
63592. that therefore every emergence of a new power, every struggle
63593. against the power once appointed, should be absolutely regarded as an
63594. infringement of the real power; or (2) that the will of the people
63595. is transferred to the rulers conditionally, under definite and known
63596. conditions, and to show that all limitations, conflicts, and even
63597. destructions of power result from a nonobservance by the rulers of the
63598. conditions under which their power was entrusted to them; or (3) that
63599. the will of the people is delegated to the rulers conditionally, but
63600. that the conditions are unknown and indefinite, and that the appearance
63601. of several authorities, their struggles and their falls, result solely
63602. from the greater or lesser fulfillment by the rulers of these unknown
63603. conditions on which the will of the people is transferred from some
63604. people to others.
63605. 
63606. And these are the three ways in which the historians do explain the
63607. relation of the people to their rulers.
63608. 
63609. Some historians--those biographical and specialist historians already
63610. referred to--in their simplicity failing to understand the question of
63611. the meaning of power, seem to consider that the collective will of
63612. the people is unconditionally transferred to historical persons, and
63613. therefore when describing some single state they assume that particular
63614. power to be the one absolute and real power, and that any other force
63615. opposing this is not a power but a violation of power--mere violence.
63616. 
63617. Their theory, suitable for primitive and peaceful periods of history,
63618. has the inconvenience--in application to complex and stormy periods in
63619. the life of nations during which various powers arise simultaneously and
63620. struggle with one another--that a Legitimist historian will prove
63621. that the National Convention, the Directory, and Bonaparte were mere
63622. infringers of the true power, while a Republican and a Bonapartist will
63623. prove: the one that the Convention and the other that the Empire was the
63624. real power, and that all the others were violations of power.
63625. Evidently the explanations furnished by these historians being mutually
63626. contradictory can only satisfy young children.
63627. 
63628. Recognizing the falsity of this view of history, another set of
63629. historians say that power rests on a conditional delegation of the will
63630. of the people to their rulers, and that historical leaders have power
63631. only conditionally on carrying out the program that the will of the
63632. people has by tacit agreement prescribed to them. But what this program
63633. consists in these historians do not say, or if they do they continually
63634. contradict one another.
63635. 
63636. Each historian, according to his view of what constitutes a nation's
63637. progress, looks for these conditions in the greatness, wealth, freedom,
63638. or enlightenment of citizens of France or some other country. But not
63639. to mention the historians' contradictions as to the nature of this
63640. program--or even admitting that some one general program of these
63641. conditions exists--the facts of history almost always contradict that
63642. theory. If the conditions under which power is entrusted consist in the
63643. wealth, freedom, and enlightenment of the people, how is it that Louis
63644. XIV and Ivan the Terrible end their reigns tranquilly, while Louis XVI
63645. and Charles I are executed by their people? To this question historians
63646. reply that Louis XIV's activity, contrary to the program, reacted on
63647. Louis XVI. But why did it not react on Louis XIV or on Louis XV--why
63648. should it react just on Louis XVI? And what is the time limit for such
63649. reactions? To these questions there are and can be no answers. Equally
63650. little does this view explain why for several centuries the collective
63651. will is not withdrawn from certain rulers and their heirs, and
63652. then suddenly during a period of fifty years is transferred to the
63653. Convention, to the Directory, to Napoleon, to Alexander, to Louis XVIII,
63654. to Napoleon again, to Charles X, to Louis Philippe, to a Republican
63655. government, and to Napoleon III. When explaining these rapid transfers
63656. of the people's will from one individual to another, especially in view
63657. of international relations, conquests, and alliances, the historians are
63658. obliged to admit that some of these transfers are not normal delegations
63659. of the people's will but are accidents dependent on cunning, on
63660. mistakes, on craft, or on the weakness of a diplomatist, a ruler, or a
63661. party leader. So that the greater part of the events of history--civil
63662. wars, revolutions, and conquests--are presented by these historians
63663. not as the results of free transferences of the people's will, but as
63664. results of the ill-directed will of one or more individuals, that is,
63665. once again, as usurpations of power. And so these historians also see
63666. and admit historical events which are exceptions to the theory.
63667. 
63668. These historians resemble a botanist who, having noticed that some
63669. plants grow from seeds producing two cotyledons, should insist that all
63670. that grows does so by sprouting into two leaves, and that the palm, the
63671. mushroom, and even the oak, which blossom into full growth and no longer
63672. resemble two leaves, are deviations from the theory.
63673. 
63674. Historians of the third class assume that the will of the people
63675. is transferred to historic personages conditionally, but that the
63676. conditions are unknown to us. They say that historical personages have
63677. power only because they fulfill the will of the people which has been
63678. delegated to them.
63679. 
63680. But in that case, if the force that moves nations lies not in the
63681. historic leaders but in the nations themselves, what significance have
63682. those leaders?
63683. 
63684. The leaders, these historians tell us, express the will of the people:
63685. the activity of the leaders represents the activity of the people.
63686. 
63687. But in that case the question arises whether all the activity of the
63688. leaders serves as an expression of the people's will or only some part
63689. of it. If the whole activity of the leaders serves as the expression of
63690. the people's will, as some historians suppose, then all the details
63691. of the court scandals contained in the biographies of a Napoleon or
63692. a Catherine serve to express the life of the nation, which is evident
63693. nonsense; but if it is only some particular side of the activity of an
63694. historical leader which serves to express the people's life, as other
63695. so-called "philosophical" historians believe, then to determine which
63696. side of the activity of a leader expresses the nation's life, we have
63697. first of all to know in what the nation's life consists.
63698. 
63699. Met by this difficulty historians of that class devise some most
63700. obscure, impalpable, and general abstraction which can cover all
63701. conceivable occurrences, and declare this abstraction to be the aim of
63702. humanity's movement. The most usual generalizations adopted by almost
63703. all the historians are: freedom, equality, enlightenment, progress,
63704. civilization, and culture. Postulating some generalization as the goal
63705. of the movement of humanity, the historians study the men of whom the
63706. greatest number of monuments have remained: kings, ministers, generals,
63707. authors, reformers, popes, and journalists, to the extent to which in
63708. their opinion these persons have promoted or hindered that abstraction.
63709. But as it is in no way proved that the aim of humanity does consist in
63710. freedom, equality, enlightenment, or civilization, and as the connection
63711. of the people with the rulers and enlighteners of humanity is only based
63712. on the arbitrary assumption that the collective will of the people is
63713. always transferred to the men whom we have noticed, it happens that the
63714. activity of the millions who migrate, burn houses, abandon agriculture,
63715. and destroy one another never is expressed in the account of the
63716. activity of some dozen people who did not burn houses, practice
63717. agriculture, or slay their fellow creatures.
63718. 
63719. History proves this at every turn. Is the ferment of the peoples of
63720. the west at the end of the eighteenth century and their drive eastward
63721. explained by the activity of Louis XIV, XV, and XVI, their mistresses
63722. and ministers, and by the lives of Napoleon, Rousseau, Diderot,
63723. Beaumarchais, and others?
63724. 
63725. Is the movement of the Russian people eastward to Kazan and Siberia
63726. expressed by details of the morbid character of Ivan the Terrible and by
63727. his correspondence with Kurbski?
63728. 
63729. Is the movement of the peoples at the time of the Crusades explained by
63730. the life and activity of the Godfreys and the Louis-es and their ladies?
63731. For us that movement of the peoples from west to east, without
63732. leaders, with a crowd of vagrants, and with Peter the Hermit, remains
63733. incomprehensible. And yet more incomprehensible is the cessation of that
63734. movement when a rational and sacred aim for the Crusade--the deliverance
63735. of Jerusalem--had been clearly defined by historic leaders. Popes,
63736. kings, and knights incited the peoples to free the Holy Land; but the
63737. people did not go, for the unknown cause which had previously impelled
63738. them to go no longer existed. The history of the Godfreys and the
63739. Minnesingers can evidently not cover the life of the peoples. And the
63740. history of the Godfreys and the Minnesingers has remained the history
63741. of Godfreys and Minnesingers, but the history of the life of the peoples
63742. and their impulses has remained unknown.
63743. 
63744. Still less does the history of authors and reformers explain to us the
63745. life of the peoples.
63746. 
63747. The history of culture explains to us the impulses and conditions of
63748. life and thought of a writer or a reformer. We learn that Luther had
63749. a hot temper and said such and such things; we learn that Rousseau was
63750. suspicious and wrote such and such books; but we do not learn why after
63751. the Reformation the peoples massacred one another, nor why during the
63752. French Revolution they guillotined one another.
63753. 
63754. If we unite both these kinds of history, as is done by the newest
63755. historians, we shall have the history of monarchs and writers, but not
63756. the history of the life of the peoples.
63757. 
63758. 
63759. 
63760. 
63761. 
63762. CHAPTER V
63763. 
63764. 
63765. The life of the nations is not contained in the lives of a few men, for
63766. the connection between those men and the nations has not been found.
63767. The theory that this connection is based on the transference of the
63768. collective will of a people to certain historical personages is an
63769. hypothesis unconfirmed by the experience of history.
63770. 
63771. The theory of the transference of the collective will of the people to
63772. historic persons may perhaps explain much in the domain of jurisprudence
63773. and be essential for its purposes, but in its application to history, as
63774. soon as revolutions, conquests, or civil wars occur--that is, as soon as
63775. history begins--that theory explains nothing.
63776. 
63777. The theory seems irrefutable just because the act of transference of the
63778. people's will cannot be verified, for it never occurred.
63779. 
63780. Whatever happens and whoever may stand at the head of affairs, the
63781. theory can always say that such and such a person took the lead because
63782. the collective will was transferred to him.
63783. 
63784. The replies this theory gives to historical questions are like the
63785. replies of a man who, watching the movements of a herd of cattle and
63786. paying no attention to the varying quality of the pasturage in different
63787. parts of the field, or to the driving of the herdsman, should attribute
63788. the direction the herd takes to what animal happens to be at its head.
63789. 
63790. "The herd goes in that direction because the animal in front leads
63791. it and the collective will of all the other animals is vested in that
63792. leader." This is what historians of the first class say--those who
63793. assume the unconditional transference of the people's will.
63794. 
63795. "If the animals leading the herd change, this happens because the
63796. collective will of all the animals is transferred from one leader to
63797. another, according to whether the animal is or is not leading them in
63798. the direction selected by the whole herd." Such is the reply historians
63799. who assume that the collective will of the people is delegated to
63800. rulers under conditions which they regard as known. (With this method
63801. of observation it often happens that the observer, influenced by the
63802. direction he himself prefers, regards those as leaders who, owing to the
63803. people's change of direction, are no longer in front, but on one side,
63804. or even in the rear.)
63805. 
63806. "If the animals in front are continually changing and the direction of
63807. the whole herd is constantly altered, this is because in order to follow
63808. a given direction the animals transfer their will to the animals that
63809. have attracted our attention, and to study the movements of the herd
63810. we must watch the movements of all the prominent animals moving on all
63811. sides of the herd." So say the third class of historians who regard all
63812. historical persons, from monarchs to journalists, as the expression of
63813. their age.
63814. 
63815. The theory of the transference of the will of the people to historic
63816. persons is merely a paraphrase--a restatement of the question in other
63817. words.
63818. 
63819. What causes historical events? Power. What is power? Power is the
63820. collective will of the people transferred to one person. Under what
63821. condition is the will of the people delegated to one person? On
63822. condition that that person expresses the will of the whole people. That
63823. is, power is power: in other words, power is a word the meaning of which
63824. we do not understand.
63825. 
63826. 
63827. If the realm of human knowledge were confined to abstract reasoning,
63828. then having subjected to criticism the explanation of "power" that
63829. juridical science gives us, humanity would conclude that power is merely
63830. a word and has no real existence. But to understand phenomena man
63831. has, besides abstract reasoning, experience by which he verifies his
63832. reflections. And experience tells us that power is not merely a word but
63833. an actually existing phenomenon.
63834. 
63835. Not to speak of the fact that no description of the collective activity
63836. of men can do without the conception of power, the existence of power is
63837. proved both by history and by observing contemporary events.
63838. 
63839. Whenever an event occurs a man appears or men appear, by whose will the
63840. event seems to have taken place. Napoleon III issues a decree and the
63841. French go to Mexico. The King of Prussia and Bismarck issue decrees and
63842. an army enters Bohemia. Napoleon I issues a decree and an army enters
63843. Russia. Alexander I gives a command and the French submit to the
63844. Bourbons. Experience shows us that whatever event occurs it is always
63845. related to the will of one or of several men who have decreed it.
63846. 
63847. The historians, in accord with the old habit of acknowledging divine
63848. intervention in human affairs, want to see the cause of events in
63849. the expression of the will of someone endowed with power, but that
63850. supposition is not confirmed either by reason or by experience.
63851. 
63852. On the one side reflection shows that the expression of a man's
63853. will--his words--are only part of the general activity expressed in an
63854. event, as for instance in a war or a revolution, and so without assuming
63855. an incomprehensible, supernatural force--a miracle--one cannot admit
63856. that words can be the immediate cause of the movements of millions of
63857. men. On the other hand, even if we admitted that words could be the
63858. cause of events, history shows that the expression of the will of
63859. historical personages does not in most cases produce any effect, that
63860. is to say, their commands are often not executed, and sometimes the very
63861. opposite of what they order occurs.
63862. 
63863. Without admitting divine intervention in the affairs of humanity we
63864. cannot regard "power" as the cause of events.
63865. 
63866. Power, from the standpoint of experience, is merely the relation that
63867. exists between the expression of someone's will and the execution of
63868. that will by others.
63869. 
63870. To explain the conditions of that relationship we must first establish a
63871. conception of the expression of will, referring it to man and not to the
63872. Deity.
63873. 
63874. If the Deity issues a command, expresses His will, as ancient history
63875. tells us, the expression of that will is independent of time and is not
63876. caused by anything, for the Divinity is not controlled by an event. But
63877. speaking of commands that are the expression of the will of men acting
63878. in time and in relation to one another, to explain the connection of
63879. commands with events we must restore: (1) the condition of all that
63880. takes place: the continuity of movement in time both of the events and
63881. of the person who commands, and (2) the inevitability of the connection
63882. between the person commanding and those who execute his command.
63883. 
63884. 
63885. 
63886. 
63887. 
63888. CHAPTER VI
63889. 
63890. 
63891. Only the expression of the will of the Deity, not dependent on time, can
63892. relate to a whole series of events occurring over a period of years or
63893. centuries, and only the Deity, independent of everything, can by His
63894. sole will determine the direction of humanity's movement; but man acts
63895. in time and himself takes part in what occurs.
63896. 
63897. Reinstating the first condition omitted, that of time, we see that no
63898. command can be executed without some preceding order having been given
63899. rendering the execution of the last command possible.
63900. 
63901. No command ever appears spontaneously, or itself covers a whole series
63902. of occurrences; but each command follows from another, and never refers
63903. to a whole series of events but always to one moment only of an event.
63904. 
63905. When, for instance, we say that Napoleon ordered armies to go to war,
63906. we combine in one simultaneous expression a whole series of consecutive
63907. commands dependent one on another. Napoleon could not have commanded
63908. an invasion of Russia and never did so. Today he ordered such and such
63909. papers to be written to Vienna, to Berlin, and to Petersburg;
63910. tomorrow such and such decrees and orders to the army, the fleet, the
63911. commissariat, and so on and so on--millions of commands, which formed
63912. a whole series corresponding to a series of events which brought the
63913. French armies into Russia.
63914. 
63915. If throughout his reign Napoleon gave commands concerning an invasion
63916. of England and expended on no other undertaking so much time and effort,
63917. and yet during his whole reign never once attempted to execute that
63918. design but undertook an expedition into Russia, with which country he
63919. considered it desirable to be in alliance (a conviction he repeatedly
63920. expressed)--this came about because his commands did not correspond to
63921. the course of events in the first case, but did so correspond in the
63922. latter.
63923. 
63924. For an order to be certainly executed, it is necessary that a man should
63925. order what can be executed. But to know what can and what cannot be
63926. executed is impossible, not only in the case of Napoleon's invasion of
63927. Russia in which millions participated, but even in the simplest event,
63928. for in either case millions of obstacles may arise to prevent its
63929. execution. Every order executed is always one of an immense number
63930. unexecuted. All the impossible orders inconsistent with the course of
63931. events remain unexecuted. Only the possible ones get linked up with a
63932. consecutive series of commands corresponding to a series of events, and
63933. are executed.
63934. 
63935. Our false conception that an event is caused by a command which precedes
63936. it is due to the fact that when the event has taken place and out of
63937. thousands of others those few commands which were consistent with that
63938. event have been executed, we forget about the others that were not
63939. executed because they could not be. Apart from that, the chief source
63940. of our error in this matter is due to the fact that in the historical
63941. accounts a whole series of innumerable, diverse, and petty events, such
63942. for instance as all those which led the French armies to Russia, is
63943. generalized into one event in accord with the result produced by that
63944. series of events, and corresponding with this generalization the whole
63945. series of commands is also generalized into a single expression of will.
63946. 
63947. We say that Napoleon wished to invade Russia and invaded it. In
63948. reality in all Napoleon's activity we never find anything resembling an
63949. expression of that wish, but find a series of orders, or expressions of
63950. his will, very variously and indefinitely directed. Amid a long series
63951. of unexecuted orders of Napoleon's one series, for the campaign of 1812,
63952. was carried out--not because those orders differed in any way from the
63953. other, unexecuted orders but because they coincided with the course of
63954. events that led the French army into Russia; just as in stencil work
63955. this or that figure comes out not because the color was laid on from
63956. this side or in that way, but because it was laid on from all sides over
63957. the figure cut in the stencil.
63958. 
63959. So that examining the relation in time of the commands to the events,
63960. we find that a command can never be the cause of the event, but that a
63961. certain definite dependence exists between the two.
63962. 
63963. To understand in what this dependence consists it is necessary to
63964. reinstate another omitted condition of every command proceeding not from
63965. the Deity but from a man, which is, that the man who gives the command
63966. himself takes part in the event.
63967. 
63968. This relation of the commander to those he commands is just what is
63969. called power. This relation consists in the following:
63970. 
63971. For common action people always unite in certain combinations, in which
63972. regardless of the difference of the aims set for the common action, the
63973. relation between those taking part in it is always the same.
63974. 
63975. Men uniting in these combinations always assume such relations toward
63976. one another that the larger number take a more direct share, and the
63977. smaller number a less direct share, in the collective action for which
63978. they have combined.
63979. 
63980. Of all the combinations in which men unite for collective action one of
63981. the most striking and definite examples is an army.
63982. 
63983. Every army is composed of lower grades of the service--the rank and
63984. file--of whom there are always the greatest number; of the next higher
63985. military rank--corporals and noncommissioned officers of whom there are
63986. fewer, and of still-higher officers of whom there are still fewer,
63987. and so on to the highest military command which is concentrated in one
63988. person.
63989. 
63990. A military organization may be quite correctly compared to a cone, of
63991. which the base with the largest diameter consists of the rank and file;
63992. the next higher and smaller section of the cone consists of the next
63993. higher grades of the army, and so on to the apex, the point of which
63994. will represent the commander in chief.
63995. 
63996. The soldiers, of whom there are the most, form the lower section of
63997. the cone and its base. The soldier himself does the stabbing, hacking,
63998. burning, and pillaging, and always receives orders for these actions
63999. from men above him; he himself never gives an order. The noncommissioned
64000. officers (of whom there are fewer) perform the action itself less
64001. frequently than the soldiers, but they already give commands. An
64002. officer still less often acts directly himself, but commands still more
64003. frequently. A general does nothing but command the troops, indicates the
64004. objective, and hardly ever uses a weapon himself. The commander in chief
64005. never takes direct part in the action itself, but only gives general
64006. orders concerning the movement of the mass of the troops. A similar
64007. relation of people to one another is seen in every combination of men
64008. for common activity--in agriculture, trade, and every administration.
64009. 
64010. And so without particularly analyzing all the contiguous sections of
64011. a cone and of the ranks of an army, or the ranks and positions in
64012. any administrative or public business whatever from the lowest to the
64013. highest, we see a law by which men, to take associated action, combine
64014. in such relations that the more directly they participate in performing
64015. the action the less they can command and the more numerous they are,
64016. while the less their direct participation in the action itself, the more
64017. they command and the fewer of them there are; rising in this way from
64018. the lowest ranks to the man at the top, who takes the least direct share
64019. in the action and directs his activity chiefly to commanding.
64020. 
64021. This relation of the men who command to those they command is what
64022. constitutes the essence of the conception called power.
64023. 
64024. Having restored the condition of time under which all events occur,
64025. we find that a command is executed only when it is related to a
64026. corresponding series of events. Restoring the essential condition of
64027. relation between those who command and those who execute, we find that
64028. by the very nature of the case those who command take the smallest part
64029. in the action itself and that their activity is exclusively directed to
64030. commanding.
64031. 
64032. 
64033. 
64034. 
64035. 
64036. CHAPTER VII
64037. 
64038. 
64039. When an event is taking place people express their opinions and wishes
64040. about it, and as the event results from the collective activity of
64041. many people, some one of the opinions or wishes expressed is sure to be
