64042. fulfilled if but approximately. When one of the opinions expressed
64043. is fulfilled, that opinion gets connected with the event as a command
64044. preceding it.
64045. 
64046. Men are hauling a log. Each of them expresses his opinion as to how and
64047. where to haul it. They haul the log away, and it happens that this is
64048. done as one of them said. He ordered it. There we have command and power
64049. in their primary form. The man who worked most with his hands could not
64050. think so much about what he was doing, or reflect on or command what
64051. would result from the common activity; while the man who commanded
64052. more would evidently work less with his hands on account of his greater
64053. verbal activity.
64054. 
64055. When some larger concourse of men direct their activity to a common aim
64056. there is a yet sharper division of those who, because their activity is
64057. given to directing and commanding, take less part in the direct work.
64058. 
64059. When a man works alone he always has a certain set of reflections which
64060. as it seems to him directed his past activity, justify his present
64061. activity, and guide him in planning his future actions. Just the same is
64062. done by a concourse of people, allowing those who do not take a direct
64063. part in the activity to devise considerations, justifications, and
64064. surmises concerning their collective activity.
64065. 
64066. For reasons known or unknown to us the French began to drown and kill
64067. one another. And corresponding to the event its justification appears in
64068. people's belief that this was necessary for the welfare of France, for
64069. liberty, and for equality. People ceased to kill one another, and
64070. this event was accompanied by its justification in the necessity for a
64071. centralization of power, resistance to Europe, and so on. Men went
64072. from the west to the east killing their fellow men, and the event
64073. was accompanied by phrases about the glory of France, the baseness of
64074. England, and so on. History shows us that these justifications of the
64075. events have no common sense and are all contradictory, as in the case of
64076. killing a man as the result of recognizing his rights, and the killing
64077. of millions in Russia for the humiliation of England. But these
64078. justifications have a very necessary significance in their own day.
64079. 
64080. These justifications release those who produce the events from moral
64081. responsibility. These temporary aims are like the broom fixed in front
64082. of a locomotive to clear the snow from the rails in front: they clear
64083. men's moral responsibilities from their path.
64084. 
64085. Without such justification there would be no reply to the simplest
64086. question that presents itself when examining each historical event. How
64087. is it that millions of men commit collective crimes--make war, commit
64088. murder, and so on?
64089. 
64090. With the present complex forms of political and social life in Europe
64091. can any event that is not prescribed, decreed, or ordered by monarchs,
64092. ministers, parliaments, or newspapers be imagined? Is there any
64093. collective action which cannot find its justification in political
64094. unity, in patriotism, in the balance of power, or in civilization? So
64095. that every event that occurs inevitably coincides with some expressed
64096. wish and, receiving a justification, presents itself as the result of
64097. the will of one man or of several men.
64098. 
64099. In whatever direction a ship moves, the flow of the waves it cuts
64100. will always be noticeable ahead of it. To those on board the ship the
64101. movement of those waves will be the only perceptible motion.
64102. 
64103. Only by watching closely moment by moment the movement of that flow and
64104. comparing it with the movement of the ship do we convince ourselves that
64105. every bit of it is occasioned by the forward movement of the ship,
64106. and that we were led into error by the fact that we ourselves were
64107. imperceptibly moving.
64108. 
64109. We see the same if we watch moment by moment the movement of historical
64110. characters (that is, re-establish the inevitable condition of all that
64111. occurs--the continuity of movement in time) and do not lose sight of the
64112. essential connection of historical persons with the masses.
64113. 
64114. When the ship moves in one direction there is one and the same wave
64115. ahead of it, when it turns frequently the wave ahead of it also turns
64116. frequently. But wherever it may turn there always will be the wave
64117. anticipating its movement.
64118. 
64119. Whatever happens it always appears that just that event was foreseen
64120. and decreed. Wherever the ship may go, the rush of water which neither
64121. directs nor increases its movement foams ahead of it, and at a distance
64122. seems to us not merely to move of itself but to govern the ship's
64123. movement also.
64124. 
64125. 
64126. Examining only those expressions of the will of historical persons
64127. which, as commands, were related to events, historians have assumed
64128. that the events depended on those commands. But examining the events
64129. themselves and the connection in which the historical persons stood to
64130. the people, we have found that they and their orders were dependent on
64131. events. The incontestable proof of this deduction is that, however many
64132. commands were issued, the event does not take place unless there are
64133. other causes for it, but as soon as an event occurs--be it what it
64134. may--then out of all the continually expressed wishes of different
64135. people some will always be found which by their meaning and their time
64136. of utterance are related as commands to the events.
64137. 
64138. Arriving at this conclusion we can reply directly and positively to
64139. these two essential questions of history:
64140. 
64141. (1) What is power?
64142. 
64143. (2) What force produces the movement of the nations?
64144. 
64145. (1) Power is the relation of a given person to other individuals,
64146. in which the more this person expresses opinions, predictions, and
64147. justifications of the collective action that is performed, the less is
64148. his participation in that action.
64149. 
64150. (2) The movement of nations is caused not by power, nor by intellectual
64151. activity, nor even by a combination of the two as historians have
64152. supposed, but by the activity of all the people who participate in
64153. the events, and who always combine in such a way that those taking
64154. the largest direct share in the event take on themselves the least
64155. responsibility and vice versa.
64156. 
64157. Morally the wielder of power appears to cause the event; physically
64158. it is those who submit to the power. But as the moral activity is
64159. inconceivable without the physical, the cause of the event is neither in
64160. the one nor in the other but in the union of the two.
64161. 
64162. Or in other words, the conception of a cause is inapplicable to the
64163. phenomena we are examining.
64164. 
64165. In the last analysis we reach the circle of infinity--that final limit
64166. to which in every domain of thought man's reason arrives if it is not
64167. playing with the subject. Electricity produces heat, heat produces
64168. electricity. Atoms attract each other and atoms repel one another.
64169. 
64170. Speaking of the interaction of heat and electricity and of atoms, we
64171. cannot say why this occurs, and we say that it is so because it is
64172. inconceivable otherwise, because it must be so and that it is a law. The
64173. same applies to historical events. Why war and revolution occur we do
64174. not know. We only know that to produce the one or the other action,
64175. people combine in a certain formation in which they all take part, and
64176. we say that this is so because it is unthinkable otherwise, or in other
64177. words that it is a law.
64178. 
64179. 
64180. 
64181. 
64182. 
64183. CHAPTER VIII
64184. 
64185. 
64186. If history dealt only with external phenomena, the establishment of this
64187. simple and obvious law would suffice and we should have finished our
64188. argument. But the law of history relates to man. A particle of matter
64189. cannot tell us that it does not feel the law of attraction or repulsion
64190. and that that law is untrue, but man, who is the subject of history,
64191. says plainly: I am free and am therefore not subject to the law.
64192. 
64193. The presence of the problem of man's free will, though unexpressed, is
64194. felt at every step of history.
64195. 
64196. All seriously thinking historians have involuntarily encountered this
64197. question. All the contradictions and obscurities of history and the
64198. false path historical science has followed are due solely to the lack of
64199. a solution of that question.
64200. 
64201. If the will of every man were free, that is, if each man could act as he
64202. pleased, all history would be a series of disconnected incidents.
64203. 
64204. If in a thousand years even one man in a million could act freely, that
64205. is, as he chose, it is evident that one single free act of that man's
64206. in violation of the laws governing human action would destroy the
64207. possibility of the existence of any laws for the whole of humanity.
64208. 
64209. If there be a single law governing the actions of men, free will cannot
64210. exist, for then man's will is subject to that law.
64211. 
64212. In this contradiction lies the problem of free will, which from most
64213. ancient times has occupied the best human minds and from most ancient
64214. times has been presented in its whole tremendous significance.
64215. 
64216. The problem is that regarding man as a subject of observation
64217. from whatever point of view--theological, historical, ethical, or
64218. philosophic--we find a general law of necessity to which he (like all
64219. that exists) is subject. But regarding him from within ourselves as what
64220. we are conscious of, we feel ourselves to be free.
64221. 
64222. This consciousness is a source of self-cognition quite apart from and
64223. independent of reason. Through his reason man observes himself, but only
64224. through consciousness does he know himself.
64225. 
64226. Apart from consciousness of self no observation or application of reason
64227. is conceivable.
64228. 
64229. To understand, observe, and draw conclusions, man must first of all be
64230. conscious of himself as living. A man is only conscious of himself as
64231. a living being by the fact that he wills, that is, is conscious of
64232. his volition. But his will--which forms the essence of his life--man
64233. recognizes (and can but recognize) as free.
64234. 
64235. If, observing himself, man sees that his will is always directed by
64236. one and the same law (whether he observes the necessity of taking
64237. food, using his brain, or anything else) he cannot recognize this
64238. never-varying direction of his will otherwise than as a limitation of
64239. it. Were it not free it could not be limited. A man's will seems to him
64240. to be limited just because he is not conscious of it except as free.
64241. 
64242. You say: I am not free. But I have lifted my hand and let it fall.
64243. Everyone understands that this illogical reply is an irrefutable
64244. demonstration of freedom.
64245. 
64246. That reply is the expression of a consciousness that is not subject to
64247. reason.
64248. 
64249. If the consciousness of freedom were not a separate and independent
64250. source of self-consciousness it would be subject to reasoning and
64251. to experience, but in fact such subjection does not exist and is
64252. inconceivable.
64253. 
64254. A series of experiments and arguments proves to every man that he, as
64255. an object of observation, is subject to certain laws, and man submits to
64256. them and never resists the laws of gravity or impermeability once he
64257. has become acquainted with them. But the same series of experiments
64258. and arguments proves to him that the complete freedom of which he is
64259. conscious in himself is impossible, and that his every action depends
64260. on his organization, his character, and the motives acting upon him; yet
64261. man never submits to the deductions of these experiments and arguments.
64262. Having learned from experiment and argument that a stone falls
64263. downwards, a man indubitably believes this and always expects the law
64264. that he has learned to be fulfilled.
64265. 
64266. But learning just as certainly that his will is subject to laws, he does
64267. not and cannot believe this.
64268. 
64269. However often experiment and reasoning may show a man that under the
64270. same conditions and with the same character he will do the same thing as
64271. before, yet when under the same conditions and with the same character
64272. he approaches for the thousandth time the action that always ends in the
64273. same way, he feels as certainly convinced as before the experiment
64274. that he can act as he pleases. Every man, savage or sage, however
64275. incontestably reason and experiment may prove to him that it is
64276. impossible to imagine two different courses of action in precisely the
64277. same conditions, feels that without this irrational conception (which
64278. constitutes the essence of freedom) he cannot imagine life. He feels
64279. that however impossible it may be, it is so, for without this conception
64280. of freedom not only would he be unable to understand life, but he would
64281. be unable to live for a single moment.
64282. 
64283. He could not live, because all man's efforts, all his impulses to life,
64284. are only efforts to increase freedom. Wealth and poverty, fame and
64285. obscurity, power and subordination, strength and weakness, health and
64286. disease, culture and ignorance, work and leisure, repletion and hunger,
64287. virtue and vice, are only greater or lesser degrees of freedom.
64288. 
64289. A man having no freedom cannot be conceived of except as deprived of
64290. life.
64291. 
64292. If the conception of freedom appears to reason to be a senseless
64293. contradiction like the possibility of performing two actions at one and
64294. the same instant of time, or of an effect without a cause, that only
64295. proves that consciousness is not subject to reason.
64296. 
64297. This unshakable, irrefutable consciousness of freedom, uncontrolled by
64298. experiment or argument, recognized by all thinkers and felt by everyone
64299. without exception, this consciousness without which no conception of man
64300. is possible constitutes the other side of the question.
64301. 
64302. Man is the creation of an all-powerful, all-good, and all-seeing God.
64303. What is sin, the conception of which arises from the consciousness of
64304. man's freedom? That is a question for theology.
64305. 
64306. The actions of men are subject to general immutable laws expressed in
64307. statistics. What is man's responsibility to society, the conception of
64308. which results from the conception of freedom? That is a question for
64309. jurisprudence.
64310. 
64311. Man's actions proceed from his innate character and the motives acting
64312. upon him. What is conscience and the perception of right and wrong
64313. in actions that follows from the consciousness of freedom? That is a
64314. question for ethics.
64315. 
64316. Man in connection with the general life of humanity appears subject
64317. to laws which determine that life. But the same man apart from that
64318. connection appears to be free. How should the past life of nations and
64319. of humanity be regarded--as the result of the free, or as the result of
64320. the constrained, activity of man? That is a question for history.
64321. 
64322. Only in our self-confident day of the popularization of
64323. knowledge--thanks to that most powerful engine of ignorance, the
64324. diffusion of printed matter--has the question of the freedom of will
64325. been put on a level on which the question itself cannot exist. In our
64326. time the majority of so-called advanced people--that is, the crowd of
64327. ignoramuses--have taken the work of the naturalists who deal with one
64328. side of the question for a solution of the whole problem.
64329. 
64330. They say and write and print that the soul and freedom do not exist,
64331. for the life of man is expressed by muscular movements and muscular
64332. movements are conditioned by the activity of the nerves; the soul and
64333. free will do not exist because at an unknown period of time we sprang
64334. from the apes. They say this, not at all suspecting that thousands of
64335. years ago that same law of necessity which with such ardor they are now
64336. trying to prove by physiology and comparative zoology was not merely
64337. acknowledged by all the religions and all the thinkers, but has never
64338. been denied. They do not see that the role of the natural sciences in
64339. this matter is merely to serve as an instrument for the illumination
64340. of one side of it. For the fact that, from the point of view of
64341. observation, reason and the will are merely secretions of the brain, and
64342. that man following the general law may have developed from lower animals
64343. at some unknown period of time, only explains from a fresh side
64344. the truth admitted thousands of years ago by all the religious and
64345. philosophic theories--that from the point of view of reason man is
64346. subject to the law of necessity; but it does not advance by a hair's
64347. breadth the solution of the question, which has another, opposite, side,
64348. based on the consciousness of freedom.
64349. 
64350. If men descended from the apes at an unknown period of time, that is
64351. as comprehensible as that they were made from a handful of earth at a
64352. certain period of time (in the first case the unknown quantity is the
64353. time, in the second case it is the origin); and the question of how
64354. man's consciousness of freedom is to be reconciled with the law of
64355. necessity to which he is subject cannot be solved by comparative
64356. physiology and zoology, for in a frog, a rabbit, or an ape, we can
64357. observe only the muscular nervous activity, but in man we observe
64358. consciousness as well as the muscular and nervous activity.
64359. 
64360. The naturalists and their followers, thinking they can solve this
64361. question, are like plasterers set to plaster one side of the walls of
64362. a church who, availing themselves of the absence of the chief
64363. superintendent of the work, should in an access of zeal plaster over the
64364. windows, icons, woodwork, and still unbuttressed walls, and should be
64365. delighted that from their point of view as plasterers, everything is now
64366. so smooth and regular.
64367. 
64368. 
64369. 
64370. 
64371. 
64372. CHAPTER IX
64373. 
64374. 
64375. For the solution of the question of free will or inevitability, history
64376. has this advantage over other branches of knowledge in which the
64377. question is dealt with, that for history this question does not refer
64378. to the essence of man's free will but its manifestation in the past and
64379. under certain conditions.
64380. 
64381. In regard to this question, history stands to the other sciences as
64382. experimental science stands to abstract science.
64383. 
64384. The subject for history is not man's will itself but our presentation of
64385. it.
64386. 
64387. And so for history, the insoluble mystery presented by the
64388. incompatibility of free will and inevitability does not exist as it does
64389. for theology, ethics, and philosophy. History surveys a presentation of
64390. man's life in which the union of these two contradictions has already
64391. taken place.
64392. 
64393. In actual life each historic event, each human action, is very clearly
64394. and definitely understood without any sense of contradiction, although
64395. each event presents itself as partly free and partly compulsory.
64396. 
64397. To solve the question of how freedom and necessity are combined and
64398. what constitutes the essence of these two conceptions, the philosophy
64399. of history can and should follow a path contrary to that taken by other
64400. sciences. Instead of first defining the conceptions of freedom and
64401. inevitability in themselves, and then ranging the phenomena of life
64402. under those definitions, history should deduce a definition of the
64403. conception of freedom and inevitability themselves from the immense
64404. quantity of phenomena of which it is cognizant and that always appear
64405. dependent on these two elements.
64406. 
64407. Whatever presentation of the activity of many men or of an individual
64408. we may consider, we always regard it as the result partly of man's free
64409. will and partly of the law of inevitability.
64410. 
64411. Whether we speak of the migration of the peoples and the incursions
64412. of the barbarians, or of the decrees of Napoleon III, or of someone's
64413. action an hour ago in choosing one direction out of several for his
64414. walk, we are unconscious of any contradiction. The degree of freedom and
64415. inevitability governing the actions of these people is clearly defined
64416. for us.
64417. 
64418. Our conception of the degree of freedom often varies according to
64419. differences in the point of view from which we regard the event, but
64420. every human action appears to us as a certain combination of freedom and
64421. inevitability. In every action we examine we see a certain measure of
64422. freedom and a certain measure of inevitability. And always the more
64423. freedom we see in any action the less inevitability do we perceive, and
64424. the more inevitability the less freedom.
64425. 
64426. The proportion of freedom to inevitability decreases and increases
64427. according to the point of view from which the action is regarded, but
64428. their relation is always one of inverse proportion.
64429. 
64430. A sinking man who clutches at another and drowns him; or a hungry mother
64431. exhausted by feeding her baby, who steals some food; or a man trained
64432. to discipline who on duty at the word of command kills a defenseless
64433. man--seem less guilty, that is, less free and more subject to the law of
64434. necessity, to one who knows the circumstances in which these people were
64435. placed, and more free to one who does not know that the man was himself
64436. drowning, that the mother was hungry, that the soldier was in the ranks,
64437. and so on. Similarly a man who committed a murder twenty years ago and
64438. has since lived peaceably and harmlessly in society seems less guilty
64439. and his action more due to the law of inevitability, to someone who
64440. considers his action after twenty years have elapsed than to one who
64441. examined it the day after it was committed. And in the same way every
64442. action of an insane, intoxicated, or highly excited man appears less
64443. free and more inevitable to one who knows the mental condition of him
64444. who committed the action, and seems more free and less inevitable to one
64445. who does not know it. In all these cases the conception of freedom
64446. is increased or diminished and the conception of compulsion is
64447. correspondingly decreased or increased, according to the point of view
64448. from which the action is regarded. So that the greater the conception of
64449. necessity the smaller the conception of freedom and vice versa.
64450. 
64451. Religion, the common sense of mankind, the science of jurisprudence,
64452. and history itself understand alike this relation between necessity and
64453. freedom.
64454. 
64455. All cases without exception in which our conception of freedom and
64456. necessity is increased and diminished depend on three considerations:
64457. 
64458. (1) The relation to the external world of the man who commits the deeds.
64459. 
64460. (2) His relation to time.
64461. 
64462. (3) His relation to the causes leading to the action.
64463. 
64464. The first consideration is the clearness of our perception of the man's
64465. relation to the external world and the greater or lesser clearness
64466. of our understanding of the definite position occupied by the man
64467. in relation to everything coexisting with him. This is what makes it
64468. evident that a drowning man is less free and more subject to necessity
64469. than one standing on dry ground, and that makes the actions of a man
64470. closely connected with others in a thickly populated district, or of one
64471. bound by family, official, or business duties, seem certainly less free
64472. and more subject to necessity than those of a man living in solitude and
64473. seclusion.
64474. 
64475. If we consider a man alone, apart from his relation to everything around
64476. him, each action of his seems to us free. But if we see his relation
64477. to anything around him, if we see his connection with anything
64478. whatever--with a man who speaks to him, a book he reads, the work on
64479. which he is engaged, even with the air he breathes or the light that
64480. falls on the things about him--we see that each of these circumstances
64481. has an influence on him and controls at least some side of his activity.
64482. And the more we perceive of these influences the more our conception of
64483. his freedom diminishes and the more our conception of the necessity that
64484. weighs on him increases.
64485. 
64486. The second consideration is the more or less evident time relation of
64487. the man to the world and the clearness of our perception of the place
64488. the man's action occupies in time. That is the ground which makes the
64489. fall of the first man, resulting in the production of the human race,
64490. appear evidently less free than a man's entry into marriage today. It is
64491. the reason why the life and activity of people who lived centuries ago
64492. and are connected with me in time cannot seem to me as free as the life
64493. of a contemporary, the consequences of which are still unknown to me.
64494. 
64495. The degree of our conception of freedom or inevitability depends in this
64496. respect on the greater or lesser lapse of time between the performance
64497. of the action and our judgment of it.
64498. 
64499. If I examine an act I performed a moment ago in approximately the same
64500. circumstances as those I am in now, my action appears to me undoubtedly
64501. free. But if I examine an act performed a month ago, then being in
64502. different circumstances, I cannot help recognizing that if that act had
64503. not been committed much that resulted from it--good, agreeable, and even
64504. essential--would not have taken place. If I reflect on an action still
64505. more remote, ten years ago or more, then the consequences of my action
64506. are still plainer to me and I find it hard to imagine what would have
64507. happened had that action not been performed. The farther I go back
64508. in memory, or what is the same thing the farther I go forward in my
64509. judgment, the more doubtful becomes my belief in the freedom of my
64510. action.
64511. 
64512. In history we find a very similar progress of conviction concerning
64513. the part played by free will in the general affairs of humanity. A
64514. contemporary event seems to us to be indubitably the doing of all the
64515. known participants, but with a more remote event we already see its
64516. inevitable results which prevent our considering anything else possible.
64517. And the farther we go back in examining events the less arbitrary do
64518. they appear.
64519. 
64520. The Austro-Prussian war appears to us undoubtedly the result of the
64521. crafty conduct of Bismarck, and so on. The Napoleonic wars still seem
64522. to us, though already questionably, to be the outcome of their heroes'
64523. will. But in the Crusades we already see an event occupying its definite
64524. place in history and without which we cannot imagine the modern history
64525. of Europe, though to the chroniclers of the Crusades that event appeared
64526. as merely due to the will of certain people. In regard to the migration
64527. of the peoples it does not enter anyone's head today to suppose that
64528. the renovation of the European world depended on Attila's caprice. The
64529. farther back in history the object of our observation lies, the more
64530. doubtful does the free will of those concerned in the event become and
64531. the more manifest the law of inevitability.
64532. 
64533. The third consideration is the degree to which we apprehend that
64534. endless chain of causation inevitably demanded by reason, in which each
64535. phenomenon comprehended, and therefore man's every action, must have
64536. its definite place as a result of what has gone before and as a cause of
64537. what will follow.
64538. 
64539. The better we are acquainted with the physiological, psychological, and
64540. historical laws deduced by observation and by which man is controlled,
64541. and the more correctly we perceive the physiological, psychological,
64542. and historical causes of the action, and the simpler the action we are
64543. observing and the less complex the character and mind of the man in
64544. question, the more subject to inevitability and the less free do our
64545. actions and those of others appear.
64546. 
64547. When we do not at all understand the cause of an action, whether a
64548. crime, a good action, or even one that is simply nonmoral, we ascribe a
64549. greater amount of freedom to it. In the case of a crime we most urgently
64550. demand the punishment for such an act; in the case of a virtuous act we
64551. rate its merit most highly. In an indifferent case we recognize in it
64552. more individuality, originality, and independence. But if even one of
64553. the innumerable causes of the act is known to us we recognize a certain
64554. element of necessity and are less insistent on punishment for the crime,
64555. or the acknowledgment of the merit of the virtuous act, or the freedom
64556. of the apparently original action. That a criminal was reared among male
64557. factors mitigates his fault in our eyes. The self-sacrifice of a father
64558. or mother, or self-sacrifice with the possibility of a reward, is more
64559. comprehensible than gratuitous self-sacrifice, and therefore seems less
64560. deserving of sympathy and less the result of free will. The founder of a
64561. sect or party, or an inventor, impresses us less when we know how or by
64562. what the way was prepared for his activity. If we have a large range
64563. of examples, if our observation is constantly directed to seeking the
64564. correlation of cause and effect in people's actions, their actions
64565. appear to us more under compulsion and less free the more correctly we
64566. connect the effects with the causes. If we examined simple actions and
64567. had a vast number of such actions under observation, our conception of
64568. their inevitability would be still greater. The dishonest conduct of the
64569. son of a dishonest father, the misconduct of a woman who had fallen
64570. into bad company, a drunkard's relapse into drunkenness, and so on are
64571. actions that seem to us less free the better we understand their cause.
64572. If the man whose actions we are considering is on a very low stage
64573. of mental development, like a child, a madman, or a simpleton--then,
64574. knowing the causes of the act and the simplicity of the character and
64575. intelligence in question, we see so large an element of necessity and so
64576. little free will that as soon as we know the cause prompting the action
64577. we can foretell the result.
64578. 
64579. On these three considerations alone is based the conception of
64580. irresponsibility for crimes and the extenuating circumstances admitted
64581. by all legislative codes. The responsibility appears greater or less
64582. according to our greater or lesser knowledge of the circumstances in
64583. which the man was placed whose action is being judged, and according
64584. to the greater or lesser interval of time between the commission of the
64585. action and its investigation, and according to the greater or lesser
64586. understanding of the causes that led to the action.
64587. 
64588. 
64589. 
64590. 
64591. 
64592. CHAPTER X
64593. 
64594. 
64595. Thus our conception of free will and inevitability gradually diminishes
64596. or increases according to the greater or lesser connection with the
64597. external world, the greater or lesser remoteness of time, and the
64598. greater or lesser dependence on the causes in relation to which we
64599. contemplate a man's life.
64600. 
64601. So that if we examine the case of a man whose connection with the
64602. external world is well known, where the time between the action and
64603. its examination is great, and where the causes of the action are most
64604. accessible, we get the conception of a maximum of inevitability and a
64605. minimum of free will. If we examine a man little dependent on external
64606. conditions, whose action was performed very recently, and the causes of
64607. whose action are beyond our ken, we get the conception of a minimum of
64608. inevitability and a maximum of freedom.
64609. 
64610. In neither case--however we may change our point of view, however plain
64611. we may make to ourselves the connection between the man and the external
64612. world, however inaccessible it may be to us, however long or short the
64613. period of time, however intelligible or incomprehensible the causes
64614. of the action may be--can we ever conceive either complete freedom or
64615. complete necessity.
64616. 
64617. (1) To whatever degree we may imagine a man to be exempt from the
64618. influence of the external world, we never get a conception of freedom
64619. in space. Every human action is inevitably conditioned by what surrounds
64620. him and by his own body. I lift my arm and let it fall. My action seems
64621. to me free; but asking myself whether I could raise my arm in every
64622. direction, I see that I raised it in the direction in which there was
64623. least obstruction to that action either from things around me or from
64624. the construction of my own body. I chose one out of all the possible
64625. directions because in it there were fewest obstacles. For my action
64626. to be free it was necessary that it should encounter no obstacles. To
64627. conceive of a man being free we must imagine him outside space, which is
64628. evidently impossible.
64629. 
64630. (2) However much we approximate the time of judgment to the time of the
64631. deed, we never get a conception of freedom in time. For if I examine
64632. an action committed a second ago I must still recognize it as not
64633. being free, for it is irrevocably linked to the moment at which it was
64634. committed. Can I lift my arm? I lift it, but ask myself: could I have
64635. abstained from lifting my arm at the moment that has already passed? To
64636. convince myself of this I do not lift it the next moment. But I am
64637. not now abstaining from doing so at the first moment when I asked the
64638. question. Time has gone by which I could not detain, the arm I then
64639. lifted is no longer the same as the arm I now refrain from lifting,
64640. nor is the air in which I lifted it the same that now surrounds me. The
64641. moment in which the first movement was made is irrevocable, and at that
64642. moment I could make only one movement, and whatever movement I made
64643. would be the only one. That I did not lift my arm a moment later does
64644. not prove that I could have abstained from lifting it then. And since I
64645. could make only one movement at that single moment of time, it could not
64646. have been any other. To imagine it as free, it is necessary to imagine
64647. it in the present, on the boundary between the past and the future--that
64648. is, outside time, which is impossible.
64649. 
64650. (3) However much the difficulty of understanding the causes may be
64651. increased, we never reach a conception of complete freedom, that is,
64652. an absence of cause. However inaccessible to us may be the cause of the
64653. expression of will in any action, our own or another's, the first demand
64654. of reason is the assumption of and search for a cause, for without a
64655. cause no phenomenon is conceivable. I raise my arm to perform an action
64656. independently of any cause, but my wish to perform an action without a
64657. cause is the cause of my action.
64658. 
64659. But even if--imagining a man quite exempt from all influences, examining
64660. only his momentary action in the present, unevoked by any cause--we were
64661. to admit so infinitely small a remainder of inevitability as equaled
64662. zero, we should even then not have arrived at the conception of complete
64663. freedom in man, for a being uninfluenced by the external world, standing
64664. outside of time and independent of cause, is no longer a man.
64665. 
64666. In the same way we can never imagine the action of a man quite devoid of
64667. freedom and entirely subject to the law of inevitability.
64668. 
64669. (1) However we may increase our knowledge of the conditions of space
64670. in which man is situated, that knowledge can never be complete, for the
64671. number of those conditions is as infinite as the infinity of space. And
64672. therefore so long as not all the conditions influencing men are defined,
64673. there is no complete inevitability but a certain measure of freedom
64674. remains.
64675. 
64676. (2) However we may prolong the period of time between the action we are
64677. examining and the judgment upon it, that period will be finite, while
64678. time is infinite, and so in this respect too there can never be absolute
64679. inevitability.
64680. 
64681. (3) However accessible may be the chain of causation of any action, we
64682. shall never know the whole chain since it is endless, and so again we
64683. never reach absolute inevitability.
64684. 
64685. But besides this, even if, admitting the remaining minimum of freedom to
64686. equal zero, we assumed in some given case--as for instance in that of a
64687. dying man, an unborn babe, or an idiot--complete absence of freedom, by
64688. so doing we should destroy the very conception of man in the case we are
64689. examining, for as soon as there is no freedom there is also no man. And
64690. so the conception of the action of a man subject solely to the law of
64691. inevitability without any element of freedom is just as impossible as
64692. the conception of a man's completely free action.
64693. 
64694. And so to imagine the action of a man entirely subject to the law of
64695. inevitability without any freedom, we must assume the knowledge of an
64696. infinite number of space relations, an infinitely long period of time,
64697. and an infinite series of causes.
64698. 
64699. To imagine a man perfectly free and not subject to the law of
64700. inevitability, we must imagine him all alone, beyond space, beyond time,
64701. and free from dependence on cause.
64702. 
64703. In the first case, if inevitability were possible without freedom
64704. we should have reached a definition of inevitability by the laws of
64705. inevitability itself, that is, a mere form without content.
64706. 
64707. In the second case, if freedom were possible without inevitability we
64708. should have arrived at unconditioned freedom beyond space, time, and
64709. cause, which by the fact of its being unconditioned and unlimited would
64710. be nothing, or mere content without form.
64711. 
64712. We should in fact have reached those two fundamentals of which man's
64713. whole outlook on the universe is constructed--the incomprehensible
64714. essence of life, and the laws defining that essence.
64715. 
64716. Reason says: (1) space with all the forms of matter that give it
64717. visibility is infinite, and cannot be imagined otherwise. (2) Time is
64718. infinite motion without a moment of rest and is unthinkable otherwise.
64719. (3) The connection between cause and effect has no beginning and can
64720. have no end.
64721. 
64722. Consciousness says: (1) I alone am, and all that exists is but me,
64723. consequently I include space. (2) I measure flowing time by the fixed
64724. moment of the present in which alone I am conscious of myself as living,
64725. consequently I am outside time. (3) I am beyond cause, for I feel myself
64726. to be the cause of every manifestation of my life.
64727. 
64728. Reason gives expression to the laws of inevitability. Consciousness
64729. gives expression to the essence of freedom.
64730. 
64731. Freedom not limited by anything is the essence of life, in man's
64732. consciousness. Inevitability without content is man's reason in its
64733. three forms.
64734. 
64735. Freedom is the thing examined. Inevitability is what examines. Freedom
64736. is the content. Inevitability is the form.
64737. 
64738. Only by separating the two sources of cognition, related to one another
64739. as form to content, do we get the mutually exclusive and separately
64740. incomprehensible conceptions of freedom and inevitability.
64741. 
64742. Only by uniting them do we get a clear conception of man's life.
64743. 
64744. Apart from these two concepts which in their union mutually define one
64745. another as form and content, no conception of life is possible.
64746. 
64747. All that we know of the life of man is merely a certain relation of free
64748. will to inevitability, that is, of consciousness to the laws of reason.
64749. 
64750. All that we know of the external world of nature is only a certain
64751. relation of the forces of nature to inevitability, or of the essence of
64752. life to the laws of reason.
64753. 
64754. The great natural forces lie outside us and we are not conscious of
64755. them; we call those forces gravitation, inertia, electricity, animal
64756. force, and so on, but we are conscious of the force of life in man and
64757. we call that freedom.
64758. 
64759. But just as the force of gravitation, incomprehensible in itself but
64760. felt by every man, is understood by us only to the extent to which we
64761. know the laws of inevitability to which it is subject (from the first
64762. knowledge that all bodies have weight, up to Newton's law), so too the
64763. force of free will, incomprehensible in itself but of which everyone is
64764. conscious, is intelligible to us only in as far as we know the laws of
64765. inevitability to which it is subject (from the fact that every man dies,
64766. up to the knowledge of the most complex economic and historic laws).
64767. 
64768. All knowledge is merely a bringing of this essence of life under the
64769. laws of reason.
64770. 
64771. Man's free will differs from every other force in that man is directly
64772. conscious of it, but in the eyes of reason it in no way differs from
64773. any other force. The forces of gravitation, electricity, or chemical
64774. affinity are only distinguished from one another in that they are
64775. differently defined by reason. Just so the force of man's free will
64776. is distinguished by reason from the other forces of nature only by the
64777. definition reason gives it. Freedom, apart from necessity, that is,
64778. apart from the laws of reason that define it, differs in no way from
64779. gravitation, or heat, or the force that makes things grow; for reason,
64780. it is only a momentary undefinable sensation of life.
64781. 
64782. And as the undefinable essence of the force moving the heavenly bodies,
64783. the undefinable essence of the forces of heat and electricity, or
64784. of chemical affinity, or of the vital force, forms the content of
64785. astronomy, physics, chemistry, botany, zoology, and so on, just in the
64786. same way does the force of free will form the content of history.
64787. But just as the subject of every science is the manifestation of this
64788. unknown essence of life while that essence itself can only be the
64789. subject of metaphysics, even the manifestation of the force of free will
64790. in human beings in space, in time, and in dependence on cause forms
64791. the subject of history, while free will itself is the subject of
64792. metaphysics.
64793. 
64794. In the experimental sciences what we know we call the laws of
64795. inevitability, what is unknown to us we call vital force. Vital force is
64796. only an expression for the unknown remainder over and above what we know
64797. of the essence of life.
64798. 
64799. So also in history what is known to us we call laws of inevitability,
64800. what is unknown we call free will. Free will is for history only an
64801. expression for the unknown remainder of what we know about the laws of
64802. human life.
64803. 
64804. 
64805. 
64806. 
64807. 
64808. CHAPTER XI
64809. 
64810. 
64811. History examines the manifestations of man's free will in connection
64812. with the external world in time and in dependence on cause, that is, it
64813. defines this freedom by the laws of reason, and so history is a science
64814. only in so far as this free will is defined by those laws.
64815. 
64816. The recognition of man's free will as something capable of influencing
64817. historical events, that is, as not subject to laws, is the same for
64818. history as the recognition of a free force moving the heavenly bodies
64819. would be for astronomy.
64820. 
64821. That assumption would destroy the possibility of the existence of laws,
64822. that is, of any science whatever. If there is even a single body
64823. moving freely, then the laws of Kepler and Newton are negatived and no
64824. conception of the movement of the heavenly bodies any longer exists. If
64825. any single action is due to free will, then not a single historical law
64826. can exist, nor any conception of historical events.
64827. 
64828. For history, lines exist of the movement of human wills, one end
64829. of which is hidden in the unknown but at the other end of which a
64830. consciousness of man's will in the present moves in space, time, and
64831. dependence on cause.
64832. 
64833. The more this field of motion spreads out before our eyes, the more
64834. evident are the laws of that movement. To discover and define those laws
64835. is the problem of history.
64836. 
64837. From the standpoint from which the science of history now regards its
64838. subject on the path it now follows, seeking the causes of events in
64839. man's freewill, a scientific enunciation of those laws is impossible,
64840. for however man's free will may be restricted, as soon as we recognize
64841. it as a force not subject to law, the existence of law becomes
64842. impossible.
64843. 
64844. Only by reducing this element of free will to the infinitesimal, that
64845. is, by regarding it as an infinitely small quantity, can we convince
64846. ourselves of the absolute inaccessibility of the causes, and then
64847. instead of seeking causes, history will take the discovery of laws as
64848. its problem.
64849. 
64850. The search for these laws has long been begun and the new methods of
64851. thought which history must adopt are being worked out simultaneously
64852. with the self-destruction toward which--ever dissecting and dissecting
64853. the causes of phenomena--the old method of history is moving.
64854. 
64855. All human sciences have traveled along that path. Arriving at
64856. infinitesimals, mathematics, the most exact of sciences, abandons the
64857. process of analysis and enters on the new process of the integration
64858. of unknown, infinitely small, quantities. Abandoning the conception
64859. of cause, mathematics seeks law, that is, the property common to all
64860. unknown, infinitely small, elements.
64861. 
64862. In another form but along the same path of reflection the other sciences
64863. have proceeded. When Newton enunciated the law of gravity he did not say
64864. that the sun or the earth had a property of attraction; he said that all
64865. bodies from the largest to the smallest have the property of attracting
64866. one another, that is, leaving aside the question of the cause of the
64867. movement of the bodies, he expressed the property common to all bodies
64868. from the infinitely large to the infinitely small. The same is done by
64869. the natural sciences: leaving aside the question of cause, they seek for
64870. laws. History stands on the same path. And if history has for its object
64871. the study of the movement of the nations and of humanity and not the
64872. narration of episodes in the lives of individuals, it too, setting
64873. aside the conception of cause, should seek the laws common to all the
64874. inseparably interconnected infinitesimal elements of free will.
64875. 
64876. 
64877. 
64878. 
64879. 
64880. CHAPTER XII
64881. 
64882. 
64883. From the time the law of Copernicus was discovered and proved, the mere
64884. recognition of the fact that it was not the sun but the earth that moves
64885. sufficed to destroy the whole cosmography of the ancients. By disproving
64886. that law it might have been possible to retain the old conception of
64887. the movements of the bodies, but without disproving it, it would seem
64888. impossible to continue studying the Ptolemaic worlds. But even after
64889. the discovery of the law of Copernicus the Ptolemaic worlds were still
64890. studied for a long time.
64891. 
64892. From the time the first person said and proved that the number of births
64893. or of crimes is subject to mathematical laws, and that this or that
64894. mode of government is determined by certain geographical and economic
64895. conditions, and that certain relations of population to soil produce
64896. migrations of peoples, the foundations on which history had been built
64897. were destroyed in their essence.
64898. 
64899. By refuting these new laws the former view of history might have been
64900. retained; but without refuting them it would seem impossible to continue
64901. studying historic events as the results of man's free will. For if a
64902. certain mode of government was established or certain migrations
64903. of peoples took place in consequence of such and such geographic,
64904. ethnographic, or economic conditions, then the free will of those
64905. individuals who appear to us to have established that mode of government
64906. or occasioned the migrations can no longer be regarded as the cause.
64907. 
64908. And yet the former history continues to be studied side by side with the
64909. laws of statistics, geography, political economy, comparative philology,
64910. and geology, which directly contradict its assumptions.
64911. 
64912. The struggle between the old views and the new was long and stubbornly
64913. fought out in physical philosophy. Theology stood on guard for the
64914. old views and accused the new of violating revelation. But when truth
64915. conquered, theology established itself just as firmly on the new
64916. foundation.
64917. 
64918. Just as prolonged and stubborn is the struggle now proceeding between
64919. the old and the new conception of history, and theology in the same way
64920. stands on guard for the old view, and accuses the new view of subverting
64921. revelation.
64922. 
64923. In the one case as in the other, on both sides the struggle provokes
64924. passion and stifles truth. On the one hand there is fear and regret for
64925. the loss of the whole edifice constructed through the ages, on the other
64926. is the passion for destruction.
64927. 
64928. To the men who fought against the rising truths of physical philosophy,
64929. it seemed that if they admitted that truth it would destroy faith in
64930. God, in the creation of the firmament, and in the miracle of Joshua the
64931. son of Nun. To the defenders of the laws of Copernicus and Newton, to
64932. Voltaire for example, it seemed that the laws of astronomy destroyed
64933. religion, and he utilized the law of gravitation as a weapon against
64934. religion.
64935. 
64936. Just so it now seems as if we have only to admit the law of
64937. inevitability, to destroy the conception of the soul, of good and evil,
64938. and all the institutions of state and church that have been built up on
64939. those conceptions.
64940. 
64941. So too, like Voltaire in his time, uninvited defenders of the law of
64942. inevitability today use that law as a weapon against religion, though
64943. the law of inevitability in history, like the law of Copernicus in
64944. astronomy, far from destroying, even strengthens the foundation on which
64945. the institutions of state and church are erected.
64946. 
64947. As in the question of astronomy then, so in the question of history
64948. now, the whole difference of opinion is based on the recognition or
64949. nonrecognition of something absolute, serving as the measure of visible
64950. phenomena. In astronomy it was the immovability of the earth, in history
64951. it is the independence of personality--free will.
64952. 
64953. As with astronomy the difficulty of recognizing the motion of the earth
64954. lay in abandoning the immediate sensation of the earth's fixity and of
64955. the motion of the planets, so in history the difficulty of recognizing
64956. the subjection of personality to the laws of space, time, and cause
64957. lies in renouncing the direct feeling of the independence of one's own
64958. personality. But as in astronomy the new view said: "It is true that we
64959. do not feel the movement of the earth, but by admitting its immobility
64960. we arrive at absurdity, while by admitting its motion (which we do not
64961. feel) we arrive at laws," so also in history the new view says: "It is
64962. true that we are not conscious of our dependence, but by admitting our
64963. free will we arrive at absurdity, while by admitting our dependence on
64964. the external world, on time, and on cause, we arrive at laws."
64965. 
64966. In the first case it was necessary to renounce the consciousness of an
64967. unreal immobility in space and to recognize a motion we did not feel;
64968. in the present case it is similarly necessary to renounce a freedom
64969. that does not exist, and to recognize a dependence of which we are not
64970. conscious.
64971. 
64972. 
64973. 
64974.
